More recently his government was found to have spied on journalists and human rights defenders and done little to investigate the surveillance abuses when exposed.\n\nThe front-runner in polls to succeed him is Andr\u00e9s Manuel L\u00f3pez Obrador, a nationalist whose anti-corruption rhetoric and pledge to govern austerely has struck a chord with voters.\n\nIn Colombia, scandals within one of its newest political groups have been creating election waves.\n\nOn Monday, Mr. Santos announced the arrest of Mr. Hern\u00e1ndez, the blind former rebel who was one of the top leaders in the Common Alternative Revolutionary Party, which was formed by guerrilla fighters after they signed a peace deal in 2016.\n\nThe authorities said Mr. Hern\u00e1ndez, whose group has renounced decades of violence and drug running, was in the process of trafficking 11 tons of cocaine to the United States \u2014 even as he prepared to take one of the party\u2019s first congressional seats. The trafficking accusations immediately turned into a political football in the May election, where the front-runners harbor deep criticisms of the peace deal.\n\nSome point out that bright spots exist in the region as well.\n\nIn Guatemala, high-level investigations of corruption have been outsourced to an independent body of international prosecutors backed by the United Nations. Working with the attorney general, they gathered evidence against Otto P\u00e9rez, who resigned as president in 2015 and is awaiting trial on corruption charges.\n\nTwo countries in the south, Uruguay and Chile, both scored well on Transparency International\u2019s Corruption Perception Index in 2017, holding the 23rd and 26th places out of 180 countries. (The region\u2019s largest countries sit in the middle, around the 100th slot.)\n\nMr. Schneider, the former State Department official, said Chile in particular had much to teach other countries when it came to fighting corruption.", "title": "For Americas Summit, a Peruvian Seaside Locale, and Plenty of Trouble", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-27 00:00:00", "text": "WASHINGTON \u2014 On March 29, Georgetown University Hospital opened a proton-therapy cancer unit that is expected to treat about 300 patients a year at premium prices using what its proponents promote as the most advanced radiology for attacking certain tumors.\n\nAt the facility\u2019s heart is a 15-ton particle accelerator that bombards malignancies with beams of magnet-controlled protons designed to stop at tumors rather than shoot through them like standard X-ray waves, mostly sparing healthy tissue.\n\nWith the addition, Georgetown joined a medical arms race in which hospitals and private investors, sometimes as partners, are pumping vast sums of money into technology whose effectiveness, in many cases, has not yet been shown to justify its cost.\n\nAlthough most of the proton centers in the United States are profitable, the industry is littered with financial failure: Nearly a third of the existing centers lose money, have defaulted on debt or have had to overhaul their finances.", "title": "For Cancer Centers, Proton Therapy\u2019s Promise Is Undercut by Lagging Demand", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-26 00:00:00", "text": "Since medieval times Catalans have celebrated the feast of their patron, Sant Jordi, or Saint George, on April 23, which happens to coincide with the deaths of both William Shakespeare and Miguel de Cervantes.\n\nAlmost a century ago, business-savvy publishers turned it into a book-selling event. Men traditionally offer women roses, and women buy them books in return \u2014 though these days women also receive books to ensure gender equality. All through Barcelona and other Catalan cities, bookstands are erected side-by-side with flower stalls.\n\nBut this year, after months of secessionist turmoil, not even a festive day of books and roses was immune to the political divides of Catalan society. The question was, perhaps inevitably, to be, or not to be, independent.\n\nAda Colau, Barcelona\u2019s far-left mayor, wore a yellow rose as a lapel pin, a nod to the yellow ribbon that has become the symbol of Catalans demanding the release of jailed Catalan politicians awaiting trial for rebellion, after briefly declaring independence from Spain last October.", "title": "For Catalans, a Day of Books, Roses and, of Course, Politics", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-27 00:00:00", "text": "And that helped you tap into Marlo\u2019s emotional state.\n\nWell, I thought I was just going to start with the physical transformation, and then I would get to her inner workings. And what ended up happening was very much like this character, and I think a lot of women. It really affects your mood and your brain when you\u2019re eating that much processed food and sugar, and for the first time in my life I went into a really, really deep depression.\n\nYou co-parent with your mother, Gerda.\n\nYeah, she lives right up the road from us and is very, very involved in my kids\u2019 lives. And it\u2019s a relationship that\u2019s very different from the relationship that I have with my kids. It\u2019s one that I don\u2019t think we talk enough about or value enough. We get so restricted in our thoughts of a mother and a father and what a family should look like, and we neglect other relationships like that of a parent, a grandparent and a child, a grandchild. And aside what it gives me, I just think my kids are going to be cool little dudes.\n\nShifting gears, any thoughts about #MeToo and your own experiences with sexual harassment?\n\nI have definitely felt powerless in situations because of the power that some men in my career have placed in the space that I had to work in. Or even prior to working \u2014 just trying to get a job or going out for an audition and having that feeling of: \u201cOh, O.K., I get it. You\u2019re letting me know that you\u2019re the boss in the room, and my dignity is maybe not so important in this moment.\u201d\n\nI feel in my core that there\u2019s something about this movement that\u2019s going to stick, and we\u2019re just not going to go backward. I wish it was there 20 years ago when I started. I wish there was a way to speak about this stuff and not be judged or be shamed, or even just believed.\n\nYou demanded \u2014 and received \u2014 equal pay to Chris Hemsworth in \u201cThe Huntsman: Winter\u2019s War.\u201d\n\nI\u2019ve had to put my foot down and say, \u201cLook, if we\u2019re going to make another movie, then we have to do it fair.\u201d The problem is that I know that I am not representative in my industry, and what I can do is not necessarily what every other woman out there can do. They might have families that they have to feed, and the fear of being replaced makes it not a choice. It\u2019s those women that I want to help. And that\u2019s where we have to change things.", "title": "For Charlize Theron, Motherhood Is Messy Business", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-17 00:00:00", "text": "You\u2019re on the advisory board of the Association of Women in the Arts. What does the group do?\n\nYou have to be working for at least five years in order to become a member. It\u2019s a forum where you can give career advice and really engage in very interesting conversations. The first discussion that I led was, \u201cIf you could look back today, what were the three things that you would change?\u201d That brought out a very good conversation, and the next one was on mentoring. I\u2019m very happy to be part of it.\n\nSo what would you do differently?\n\nThe very first thing that I said was, \u201cYou have to remember, when I started in the art world it was 1990.\u201d Things have changed. I might have been working in what was called a contemporary field, but I was really only working with artists that were already very established. Every work of art had to be at least 10 years old before we sold it, and I don\u2019t think I got out enough. It took me a few more years, courtesy of Charles Saatchi and the like, to pick up on the truly contemporary scene. So my advice to myself would be: I should have been more grass-roots right at the beginning.\n\nYou\u2019re up against a famous duopoly in Christie\u2019s and Sotheby\u2019s. How does that change your thinking?\n\nI love that question. I genuinely think that we have a chance to make a big dent in the duopoly. We can give collectors a third option that they like. I think the time is right. We really want to be the premier auction house in all areas that have to do with the 20th and 21st century. And, when you look at certain market segments, we are world leaders. We\u2019ve got the top worldwide market share in watches. We are also leaders in photography. The biggest financial piece is, of course, the 20th-century market, and that\u2019s where we are putting a lot of efforts. And since 2014 our sales are up 80 percent across the company.\n\nWhat makes you want to collect art?\n\nHow can you be in this market, and live in this world, and not want to buy things? I\u2019ve had a chance to work closely with some artists, like Damien Hirst. He and I did an amazing charity sale with Bono for (RED), and of course, the \u201cBeautiful Inside My Head Forever\u201d auction, that brought 220 works of art directly from the studio to market. And so, of course I\u2019ve also collected Damien over the years.\n\nThat\u2019s no small buy-in. How many Hirsts do you own?\n\nIf we\u2019re counting prints, I have more than five. Less than 10.\n\nWho else?\n\nI really, really do love Gerhard Richter. Obviously, you know, he is very expensive, but wherever I saw an opportunity, whether it\u2019s an edition or whether it\u2019s an overpainted postcard, I take it. I\u2019ve got one of his wonderful 1989 souvenirs. I don\u2019t own, and probably won\u2019t own, a large painting. But it\u2019s not about scale.\n\nDo you think living with art as a collector gives you a useful perspective in terms of your job?\n\nYes. And I\u2019m lucky that in my office I can hang works of art that are coming up for sale \u2014 I spend time with the art. I\u2019m lucky to have something amazing with me for six or eight weeks. You get a very different sense of the work.", "title": "For Cheyenne Westphal, an Education Fostered by Collecting", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-27 00:00:00", "text": "As it turns out, Mr. de Blasio has a #MeToo problem much closer to home.\n\nData released by his administration last week shows that New York City doesn\u2019t consistently track sexual harassment complaints across its 361,000-person work force. It has little or no information about how often those complaints lead to any discipline, or how long it takes the city to address the complaints. And until this month, it didn\u2019t require city agencies to report sexual harassment complaints to City Hall in a uniform way.\n\nOver the past four years, city employees filed 1,312 complaints, 221 of which were substantiated. The data suggests widespread variation in the way complaints are handled and tracked across agencies.\n\nThe New York City Housing Authority uses federal reporting rules to handle its sexual harassment complaints, for example, while many other agencies use city guidelines. Some agencies reported complaints by calendar year, while others did so by the city\u2019s fiscal year, which ends in June, making it difficult to spot trends.\n\nAnd some agencies seem to warrant closer scrutiny.\n\nAt the Department of Education, 570 complaints (a number city officials originally gave as 471) were filed over the past four years, but only seven were substantiated. At the Police Department, 94 sexual harassment complaints were made over roughly the same period, while 10 were substantiated.\n\nIt is not clear exactly what has happened to many of the complaints that have not been substantiated.", "title": "Opinion | For City Hall, #MeToo Becomes #YouToo", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-16 00:00:00", "text": "Late last summer, the Brooklyn Kitchen expanded from its main location in Williamsburg with a more intimate space for hands-on classes in the Industry City complex in Sunset Park. On the schedule at Industry City are a series of \u201cdate night\u201d classes covering seasonal spring menus, typically a braised chicken dish with cherry tomatoes, goat cheese polenta and roasted asparagus with a dessert of strawberry-lemon spelt torte. All date-night classes cost $100 per person and must be bought in pairs. They last up to two hours and include a meal with wine: Date Night Spring Seasonal, May 18 and 26, the Brooklyn Kitchen, 220 36th Street (Third Avenue), 718-389-2982, thebrooklynkitchen.com.\n\nFollow NYT Food on Facebook, Instagram, Twitter and Pinterest. Get regular updates from NYT Cooking, with recipe suggestions, cooking tips and shopping advice.", "title": "For Couples Who Really Cook Together", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-19 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cFreedom of speech and the right to exercise oversight are fundamental rights granted to citizens by the Constitution,\u201d said an article on Thursday in Guangming Daily, a party-run newspaper. When it comes to food and medicine concerns, it added, \u201cfreedom of speech must receive particular protection.\u201d\n\nChinese news outlets and law experts have said that the Hongmao company and its official backers should explain who authorized his arrest and gave the police the power to spirit Dr. Tan 1,700 miles from his home in Guangzhou, a city in China\u2019s far south, to a squalid cell in Liangcheng County.\n\n\u201cThis is a fairly typical instance of the public security authorities intervening in a civil dispute; it\u2019s an overreach of power,\u201d Wang Yong, a professor of commercial law at the China University of Political Science and Law in Beijing, said in an interview.\n\nThe number of cases of Chinese companies mobilizing the police against critics or commercial rivals has shrunk in recent years, he said.\n\n\u201cBut in this Hongmao Medical Tonic case, the role of the public security authorities in local protectionism has again come to the fore,\u201d Professor Wang said. \u201cThe fundamental problem is that for a long time in Chinese law, the boundary between civil and criminal cases has been blurred.\u201d\n\nDr. Tan never expected such a ruckus after he published his essay criticizing Hongmao in December. He initially shared his views on a blog, which he said only a few fellow doctors read. He then spread it on WeChat, a popular Chinese social media service, where it was viewed more than 2,000 times, according to the police.\n\nBut the title of Dr. Tan\u2019s article was eye-catching: \u201cChina\u2019s miracle liquor, \u2018Hongmao Medical Tonic,\u2019 a poison from heaven.\u201d Dr. Tan argued that the supposed curative effects of the 67 ingredients said to be used in the alcohol-based elixir were unclear at best, and could be dangerous for people with high blood pressure or diabetes.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nHongmao had brushed aside these medical concerns, and its plethora of ads on Chinese television have exaggerated its powers, Dr. Tan wrote. Citing traditional Chinese medical theories, it claimed to relieve ailments like painful joints, frail kidneys, and weakness and anemia in women by combining 67 ingredients from plants and animals.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHis essay had little initial impact. But in January, when Dr. Tan entered an elevator to his apartment, two men jumped in and showed police badges. They revealed that they were officers, sent from Inner Mongolia to detain and question him. Later, they took Dr. Tan to Liangcheng County by train and a long car ride.\n\nThere he lingered in jail for three months, arrested under Article 221 of the Chinese criminal code, a little-used provision that makes it an offense to fabricate and spread claims that seriously damage a business\u2019s reputation.\n\n\u201cHonestly, that time was not for humans,\u201d Dr. Tan said after his release. \u201cEvery day I slept beside the toilet, every day I ate two and a half pieces of steamed bread. There was no freedom.\u201d\n\nDr. Tan said thoughts of suicide crossed his mind before he steadied himself and began to accept that he could be convicted and imprisoned for a year or two. But then this week, a news report mentioned his detention and his case became a national controversy.\n\nAfter the initial reports, the police in Liangcheng County at first insisted that they had plenty of evidence to support their charge.\n\nBut they wilted under the pressure and criticism of the state-run news media, as well as the Chinese Medical Doctor Association. The Supreme People\u2019s Procuratorate, the top national prosecution office, ordered the police to release him for lack of evidence.\n\nDr. Tan was freed on a kind of bail. But the investigation has not officially ended, and his lawyer, Hu Dingfeng, said he could still be rearrested. But if the police entirely abandon their case, Dr. Tan may seek compensation from the government, Mr. Hu said in a phone interview.\n\n\u201cI\u2019m quite optimistic about how this case will go,\u201d Mr. Hu said. \u201cThe case should be withdrawn, but it\u2019s too early to say.\u201d\n\nMeanwhile, the Hongmao Pharmaceutical Company\u2019s attempt to silence one critic has ignited a firestorm of criticism and inquiries into its extravagant advertising. Health Times, a Chinese newspaper, estimated that Hongmao had violated rules against misleading advertising more than 2,600 times.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cAfter we heard the news this week, we took the tonic off our shelves,\u201d Han Li, a drugstore manager in Beijing, said in an interview. \u201cThere was not notification from above; we just worried that there\u2019d be a problem.\u201d", "title": "For Faulting a Chinese Tonic, He Got 3 Months in Jail. Then Cheers.", "authors": ["Chris Buckley", "Karoline Kan"]} {"date": "2018-04-29 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Gerim, well within range, and resting between slinging stones, shouts back: \u201cWe want to return!\u201d\n\nSay what you will about root causes and immediate ones \u2014 about incitement and militancy, about siege and control, about who did what first to whom \u2014 one thing is clear. More than a decade of deprivation and desperation, with little hope of relief, has led thousands of young Gazans to throw themselves into a protest that few, if any, think can actually achieve its stated goal: a return to the homes in what is now Israel that their forebears left behind in 1948.\n\nIn five weeks of protests, 46 people have been killed, and hundreds more have been badly wounded, according to the Gaza health ministry.\n\nWith its 64 percent unemployment rate among the young, Gaza, under a blockade maintained by Israel and Egypt for years, presents countless men like Mr. Gerim with the grimmest of options.\n\nThey can seek an education in preparation for lives and careers that now seem out of reach, and hope for a chance to eventually emigrate. They can join groups like Hamas or Islamic Jihad, devoting themselves to armed conflict with Israel in return for a livelihood and a sense of purpose and belonging. Or they can stay home, staving off boredom by smoking shisha, a tobacco-molasses mix, or stronger stuff, and wait for things to change.\n\nMr. Gerim considers himself neither a terrorist nor a freedom fighter. He is not much for prayer or for politics; he says he does not belong to Hamas or Fatah or any other faction. He is a young man with nothing to do, for whom the protests have offered a chance to barbecue with friends late into the night, sleep late most mornings, make himself useful while singing songs of love or martyrdom or an end to suffering, and lash out at a hated enemy all afternoon.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cIt doesn\u2019t matter to me if they shoot me or not,\u201d he said in a quiet moment inside his family\u2019s tent. \u201cDeath or life \u2014 it\u2019s the same thing.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe protests, with an outdoor festival\u2019s schedule of fun and games, performances and creative programming \u2014 and carnage every Friday \u2014 is meant to build to a climax on May 15, the day Palestinians mark the Nakba, or catastrophe, of their flight and expulsion when Israel was established 70 years ago.\n\nThe protest, which grew out of a young activist\u2019s Facebook page and was a grass-roots initiative before being embraced, organized and publicized by Hamas, the militant Islamist group that rules Gaza, has hardly scared the Israelis into altering their basic policy. Israel continues to treat the tiny coastal enclave like a deadly virus to be quarantined and, other than that, more or less tunes it out.\n\nBut it has been a success in one important respect: It has cast a light onto the unsolved problem that is Gaza, and reminded a world that had seemed to move on to more urgent crises that its two million people, deprived of clean water, freedom of movement and a steady supply of electricity, are sliding steadily into despair.\n\nMr. Gerim is typical in another way: He does not think of Gaza as his home, but he has no idea what home is.\n\nHis grandmother, Haniya al-Kurdi, 80, was a little girl when her family left what is now Ashdod, Israel, in 1948. She has never been back, but has heard that there is a coffee shop next to where her home was. The closest anyone else in the family has gotten was in 2013, when Mr. Gerim\u2019s sister, Sabreen, now 26, contracted cancer and was allowed to spend a year in Tel Aviv getting treatment. On the way there, her mother, Iktimal al-Gerim, asked their driver to point out Ashdod to them from the highway.\n\nFor Mr. Gerim, the family\u2019s old property is an idea more than a place he can actually picture.\n\nIsraelis themselves he has had more experience with. When he was about 10, before the Israelis evacuated their Gaza settlements in 2005, Mr. Gerim climbed a tree outside his grandfather\u2019s house to get a better look at the soldiers a few hundred yards away. Then he fell to the ground and broke his right hand.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nHe has been as enterprising, and as ill-starred, ever since.\n\nHe used to raise pigeons and chickens on his family\u2019s roof, for fun and for food \u2014 until an Israeli airstrike hit a neighbor\u2019s house and it collapsed on the coop, killing all of his birds.\n\nHe sometimes dreams of working in an automobile-manufacturing plant, of traveling overseas to learn how to build cars, then coming back to Gaza to make them. But the closest he has ever gotten is loading tuk-tuks \u2014 motorcycles with cargo beds \u2014 or handling a pushcart to distribute sacks of donated flour, sugar and other staples to his fellow refugees.\n\nIn the autumn, Mr. Gerim sometimes harvests olives. When there is construction work, he looks for chances to lay bricks or pour concrete. He has never had a regular job.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHe is stoic for a 22-year-old, though this may be an acquired response to adversity: His father is mentally ill, Mr. Gerim says, given to flying into destructive rages over the slightest disappointments. His family \u2014 two younger brothers, their sister and their parents \u2014 all share a single room with a tile floor and blankets but no beds. The kitchen floor is sand. The family\u2019s debts are choking them, he says.\n\nMr. Gerim\u2019s industriousness shows at the protests, as does his stoicism.\n\nOn Thursday, he arrived early at his family\u2019s tent, a roomy contraption that was provided to them by the protest\u2019s organizers, and set about sweeping the tarpaulin floor for the first of several times, before building a fire and cooking eggplants and tomatoes that city workers were distributing to the needy.\n\nPhoto\n\nAt lunch, a charity handed out meals of chicken and rice, and then Mr. Gerim swept the floor of crumbs and bones, singing a love song as he did.\n\nHe has no girlfriend, and no hopes of marrying. \u201cThere is no money, no work,\u201d he explained. \u201cMarriage is not free.\u201d\n\nAfter lunch, he walked up to the fence for a quick look across at the Israeli soldiers, then foraged for firewood. He dragged a six-foot log more than a quarter-mile back to the tent, and broke it apart with his hands and feet.\n\nLater, he assembled kites from sticks, clear plastic and paper \u2014 and talked about attaching soda cans to them stuffed with gasoline-soaked rags, to sail over the fence and maybe set something or someone on fire.\n\nAt 10 p.m., he and his friends began barbecuing a feast for 12. It didn\u2019t end until 2:30 a.m. It takes a long time to cook 22 pounds of chicken wings on a grill about 18 inches across.\n\nSitting around the fire, a friend named Abu Moaz, 25, said he wanted to use a kite to drop leaflets in Hebrew and Arabic warning Israeli soldiers to \u201cevacuate your houses and return to the countries from which you came.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nEveryone liked the sound of that.\n\nMr. Gerim went home to sleep, but was back at the tent at 8 a.m. on Friday, sweeping again, building the wood fire, drinking tea with his neighbors.\n\nHe went to Friday Prayer, then ate a falafel sandwich.\n\nAt 2:30, he was crouching behind the barbed-wire barrier, whirling his slingshot like a helicopter rotor, aiming in vain at Israeli soldiers again and again.\n\nAround 5 p.m., he saw a group of men a few hundred yards to the south, and ran to see what they were doing. They had breached the barbed wire, and were trying to get to the main fence marking Israeli territory. Mr. Gerim hung back, and did not try to join them.\n\nNear him, a man fell, hit in the stomach by what seemed like a grenade fragment, Mr. Gerim said.\n\nHe was not shocked by this, he said afterward.\n\n\u201cI could be shot or killed anytime,\u201d he said. \u201cIt doesn\u2019t matter.\u201d\n\nNight had fallen now; the protesters were headed home. And soon Mr. Gerim was singing again \u2014 this time a Lebanese tune of weariness with conflict.\n\n\u201cEnough is enough,\u201d he crooned softly in Arabic. \u201cEnough for miseries, promises and words. School students, church bells, a soldier, a knight and the calls of prayer \u2014 all pray for prevailing peace.\u201d", "title": "For Gaza Protester, Living or Dying Is the \u2018Same Thing\u2019", "authors": ["Iyad Abuheweila", "David M. Halbfinger"]} {"date": "2018-04-11 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cWe were both old enough to know what was important,\u201d Mr. Nelson said.\n\nMarriage never seemed necessary to the couple over their first 18 years together. They toyed with the idea off and on, but neither bit.\n\n\u201cWe always said, \u2018If you want to, I\u2019d be happy to,\u2019\u201d Mr. Nelson said. \u201cJudy said to me, \u2018I\u2019d follow you anywhere.\u2019 That\u2019s pretty amazing.\u201d\n\nThat was enough of a commitment until Mr. Nelson had a serious complication from a burst appendix. Because they were not married, Ms. Collins was locked out of medical decisions.\n\n\u201cI\u2019m a hippie, I don\u2019t get it,\u201d Ms. Collins recalled. \u201cAnd then I thought, wait a minute, what am I supposed to do? I went into his hospital room with a big frown on my face and said, \u2018I think we should get married.\u2019 In my fog, I\u2019m thinking if you\u2019re married, all of those things are simple.\u201d\n\nThey were married on April 16, 1996, at St. John the Divine in New York in front of 280 guests, 18 years to the day after they met. Guests included Peter Yarrow, Gloria Steinem, Bill Moyers, Susan Cheever and Donna E. Shalala.\n\nPondering their four decades together, Ms. Collins said: \u201cYou share the good things, share the tragedies, share the traumas.\u201d\n\n\u201cWe shared the worst thing that could possibly ever happen,\u201d Mr. Nelson said.\n\nThat was the death of Ms. Collins\u2019s son, Clark C. Taylor (his father was Ms. Collins\u2019s first husband), who committed suicide in 1992.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cAnd we got through that,\u201d Ms. Collins said. \u201cI understand that a lot of people who come up against a tragedy like that don\u2019t necessarily make it through, they don\u2019t necessarily survive it.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nThey have survived bouts of jealousy too. Fifty years ago, Ms. Collins and Stephen Stills of Buffalo Springfield and Crosby, Stills, Nash & Young became romantically involved while making an album together. Their time together inspired Mr. Stills\u2019s hit song \u201cSuite: Judy Blue Eyes.\u201d The two remained friends and even toured together in 2017; they\u2019re hitting the road again on May 1.\n\nMs. Collins has no problem being on tour with a former lover. But in the words of her husband, \u201cit\u2019s a rub.\u201d\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s annoying,\u201d Mr. Nelson said. \u201cBut the thing is, I can say that.\u201d\n\nHe came to a second conclusion too: \u201cI guess I won.\u201d\n\nLeading separate professional lives has also, they believe, helped their longevity. Ms. Collins and Mr. Nelson do not collaborate \u2014 they even keep their bank accounts separate \u2014 but they do lean on each other for input. He comes to her shows and provides feedback, and she reads his writing projects. (He is probably best known for designing the Korean War Veterans Memorial mural in Washington.)\n\n\u201cIt means we help each other but we\u2019re very clear about what we\u2019re responsible for,\u201d Mr. Nelson said.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Of the Moment The lifestyle newsletter from the Styles, Travel and Food sections, offering the latest trends to news you can use. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThey are also not shy about asking for help. Once, Ms. Collins suggested they split up. Mr. Nelson said, \u201cAbsolutely not, let\u2019s go see somebody.\u201d\n\n\u201cIf you have an issue, get someone to help you deal with it,\u201d Ms. Collins said. \u201cDon\u2019t be afraid to talk about it with the person. We both have good relationships with friends that we can run things by. I think that\u2019s also important, that you have an integrated life but you\u2019re not completely, emotionally dependent on one person to be solving everything you have.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSo after 18 years together, was being married any different?\n\n\u201cAfter we were married, I never had this feeling before, but all of the sudden I didn\u2019t feel alone anymore,\u201d Mr. Nelson said.\n\n\u201cThings go on in your psyche that have to do with the nature of living on the planet and having certain things that are reliable and certain things that aren\u2019t,\u201d Ms. Collins said. \u201cI didn\u2019t have the same kind of feeling during my first marriage when I was young, at all. It was very sustaining and very palpable. But it does make a difference, and it\u2019s a different feeling.\u201d\n\nMr. Nelson turned slightly to face Ms. Collins, his face relaxed and wide.\n\n\u201cI don\u2019t think you ever told me that,\u201d Mr. Nelson said. \u201cBut I agree with you, it is different.\u201d", "title": "For Judy Collins, Marriage Is a Song of Many Verses", "authors": ["Remy Tumin"]} {"date": "2018-04-20 00:00:00", "text": "Landis failed a drug test and was stripped of the Tour de France title in 2006, the year after Armstrong\u2019s reign ended. Landis traveled around the United States professing his innocence, wrote a book on the subject and persuaded people to donate to his effort to regain his title and cycling eligibility. More than 1,700 contributed nearly $500,000 to the \u201cFloyd Fairness Fund.\u201d\n\nBut Landis lost his legal fight and ended up ostracized from cycling. The whistle-blowing began. He confessed and agreed in court to repay his Fairness Fund donors. It\u2019s entirely possible that he will keep very little of his $1.1 million from Thursday\u2019s settlement, after taxes, a cut for his lawyers and any remaining compensation for the deceived supporters.\n\nArmstrong would surely find little solace in that. Still, aside from paying Landis for his betrayal, Armstrong can write off the settlement as an act of prudence.\n\nThe case was scheduled to go to trial on May 7. It would have been great theater \u2014 the first time Armstrong\u2019s ugly history had been explored in front of a jury. A cast of memorable characters, many with doping pasts who have been caught in grand lies, would have had the room rapt.\n\nCycling\u2019s longstanding code of silence would have sustained yet another smarting blow.\n\nI would have paid good money to see Betsy Andreu go toe to toe with Armstrong\u2019s lawyers. The wife of Frankie Andreu, another former Armstrong teammate, Betsy became one of the first people to speak out against Armstrong\u2019s doping \u2014 years before Landis did. Armstrong repeatedly tried bullying her, to no avail. Facing Andreu\u2019s sharp tongue and backbone of steel, Armstrong\u2019s legal team would have earned every dime of its fees.\n\nArmstrong smartly pre-empted that show.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s a sad day for justice,\u201d Andreu said Thursday after she heard the news of the settlement. \u201cHonestly, it feels like he just got away with it. This will just empower him to be as ruthless and as vengeful as ever. I\u2019m disappointed because I was looking forward to telling the truth.\u201d\n\nI\u2019m not sure Andreu, who has been proven right many times against steep odds, was correct on this point \u2014 that a trial would have brought more justice than the deal cut by federal prosecutors.", "title": "For Lance Armstrong, Backing Down Might Have Hurt More Than Paying $5 Million", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-08 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Di Maio\u2019s anti-establishment Five Star Movement won about a third of the vote, by far the most for any single party. But the right-wing and populist League, led by the equally ambitious Matteo Salvini, 45, emerged as the leader of a coalition of parties that won even more votes, but still not enough to form a government on its own.\n\nAs a result, both men have strong claims to lead the next government. Neither seems particularly eager to let the opportunity of a lifetime slip away.\n\n\u201cAccording to the rules of our democracy, it is necessary that there be some accords between different political forces to form a coalition,\u201d Italy\u2019s president, Sergio Mattarella, who has the job of cobbling together a sustainable government from the fractured parties, said on Thursday at the presidential palace. \u201cThis condition has not yet emerged.\u201d\n\nFor now \u2014 a key phrase when discussing fluid Italian politics \u2014 it seems doubtful such conditions will soon present themselves.\n\nFor now, Mr. Di Maio says he is seeking support in Parliament from the center-left Democratic Party, which suffered a crushing defeat and was incessantly demonized by Five Star\u2019s vast and often virulent social media network. (In an interview published in Saturday\u2019s La Repubblica newspaper, Mr. Di Maio said it was time to \u201cbury the hatchet.\u201d)\n\nFor now, the Democratic Party has resisted Five Star\u2019s entreaties and retreated to the opposition.\n\nFor now, Mr. Di Maio has said he refuses to join any government involving Silvio Berlusconi, the octogenarian whom Five Star leaders called a mafioso and a psychotic dwarf.\n\nPhoto\n\nFor now, Mr. Salvini won\u2019t abandon Mr. Berlusconi, whose comeback plans suffered a humiliating setback when Mr. Salvini outperformed him.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nFor now, Mr. Di Maio and Mr. Salvini, who have expressed a similarly jaundiced outlook toward Europe, migrants and changes to the pensions system, are maintaining their opposing positions, despite Roman graffiti depicting the two in a lusty embrace.\n\nAnd for now, Mr. Di Maio says he is honoring the term-limit rule, of which he has said he is \u201cproud.\u201d\n\nSpeaking on March 13 at Rome\u2019s Foreign Press Club, Mr. Di Maio fielded a question about whether the term limit would still be valid if the president had to call new elections. The results of the vote would technically create a new legislature and a third term for Mr. Di Maio.\n\nIn response, Mr. Di Maio called the two-term limit \u201cfundamental for us.\u201d\n\n\u201cAs I have always said,\u201d he added, \u201cthe rule of the two mandates is sacrosanct.\u201d\n\nRocco Casalino, a spokesman for the party, said it was a \u201cpossibility\u201d that in the case of a new election, Mr. Di Maio and all the other newly elected Five Star members of Parliament, including those currently in their second terms, would automatically receive nominations to their current seats. But he insisted such a maneuver had \u201cnever been discussed.\u201d\n\nThe party has loosened apparently hard-and-fast rules in the past.\n\nIt scratched its early ban on members appearing on television, hired a media consultant and flooded the airwaves with telegenic candidates.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nIt softened its originally draconian rules against members facing legal travails.\n\nIt also pledged never to enter a coalition, a promise challenged by the current negotiations over forming a government.\n\nBut the two-mandates commandment, central to the party\u2019s anti-establishment character, has held.\n\nSoon before her election as mayor of Rome in the summer of 2016, Virginia Raggi, a member of the Five Star Movement, balked at the question of whether she would ever want to be prime minister.\n\nWhile her rocky tenure has made such a proposition unlikely, she explained in an interview at the time that since she had served in the City Council, she would be barred by the party\u2019s rules from ever serving again.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cAt the moment it\u2019s not thinkable,\u201d she said, adding that she would be free to help out a successor in a free or paid capacity: \u201cI don\u2019t know. Maybe a consultancy, one can hypothesize.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nPressed as to whether great statesmen such as Franklin D. Roosevelt would have ever had the chance to hold higher office with such a rule, she said, \u201cNo, I don\u2019t think so.\u201d\n\n\u201cLet\u2019s put it this way,\u201d she added. \u201cIn Italy, professional politicians have ruined politics.\u201d\n\nBut some former Five Star members say the rule has ruined promising politicians.\n\nFabio Fucci, 38, who served an abbreviated term as councilman of the Five Star Movement, was elected as mayor of Pomezia in 2013. Mr. Di Maio and others hailed him as a model of good governance, but when he announced his desire to run for re-election, he found himself on the outs with the party\u2019s power-brokers.\n\nMr. Fucci argued in an interview that while the rule perhaps made sense 10 years ago when the party was a fringe protest movement, it was now \u201cillogical.\u201d\n\nNow that Five Star had become the leading political force in the country, the term limits prevented the formation of a management class with the necessary expertise at the local, regional and national levels, he said.\n\nTo make his case, Mr. Fucci and others traveled up to Milan in the Spring of 2017 to Casaleggio Associates, the internet consulting firm run by Davide Casaleggio, the son of the party\u2019s co-founder and the keeper of the web platform upon which Five Star elections are held.\n\nMr. Fucci said Mr. Casaleggio, who is unelected and unchecked by term limits, has a \u201chuge role\u201d in political decisions.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cHe was inflexible,\u201d Mr. Fucci said, recalling Mr. Casaleggio as saying, \u201cThe rule doesn\u2019t change and you can forget it.\u201d\n\nBut that was for Mr. Fucci. Now it is the career of Mr. Di Maio, the mainstream face of the party, that is at stake.\n\nIf the legislature were to be cut short for new elections, \u201cnot only Di Maio but dozens of newly elected members of Parliament\u201d would be barred from running again. \u201cThis will weaken greatly the Five Star Movement,\u201d he said.\n\nBeyond automatically reinstating nominations, the Italian press has reported that the party has considered redefining two mandates as 10 years in office.\n\nMr. Fucci said he considered some such maneuver \u201cvery probable.\u201d\n\n\u201cUnfortunately, and I say this with disappointment and bitterness,\u201d he said, \u201cthey change the rules because it\u2019s convenient. In this case to save Di Maio and the other parliamentarians.\u201d", "title": "For Luigi Di Maio, It\u2019s Now or Never to Lead Italy. Unless It\u2019s Later.", "authors": ["Jason Horowitz"]} {"date": "2018-04-26 00:00:00", "text": "Still, former advisers like Michael T. Flynn, Paul Manafort and Rick Gates have all been charged with or pleaded guilty to crimes and are looking at prison time.\n\nOthers worry they may face the same fate. Scott Pruitt, the head of the Environmental Protection Agency whose spending and security practices were spotlighted Thursday at a contentious House hearing, may yet lose his job.\n\nOther presidents have seen associates get caught up in investigations or scandals that were highlighted or magnified because of their closeness. Plenty of advisers, aides and friends of Ronald Reagan and Bill Clinton met untimely ends to their political careers or even went to prison, and critics of both presidents often said they did not seem to care about the consequences to those around them.\n\nThe closer someone gets to a president, the harsher the spotlight can be. Many who seek the power and stature of the White House somehow convince themselves that their own foibles or misdeeds will not be exposed, only to learn otherwise, or become intoxicated by their new positions of influence and exercise poor judgment. And Washington can be especially unforgiving. \u201cHere, ruining people is considered sport,\u201d Vincent W. Foster Jr., a longtime Clinton friend and aide, wrote before killing himself in 1993.\n\nSeveral people who have been close to Mr. Trump over the years say that he is exceptionally good at rationalizing his own behavior to himself, and compartmentalizing the types of personal catastrophes that would leave other people emotionally ravaged.\n\n\u201cI think that loyalty has always been a one-way street with Trump, and he doesn\u2019t really care about the wreckages he engenders as long as he comes out where he wants to be,\u201d said Tim O\u2019Brien, a biographer who was sued by Mr. Trump over a book reporting that Mr. Trump had inflated his net worth.\n\n\u201cRonny Jackson\u2019s reputation would never have been in play had the president not put him up for this job,\u201d Mr. O\u2019Brien said, adding that in Mr. Trump\u2019s mind, the issue is, \u201cRonny was great, but Washington is a snake pit.\u201d", "title": "For Many, Life in Trump\u2019s Orbit Ends in a Crash Landing", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-06 00:00:00", "text": "While General McMaster said the United States had liberated nearly all the territory held by the Islamic State, also known as ISIS, he said the American military would continue to carry out operations in Syria \u201cuntil ISIS is completely defeated, population centers are stabilized and refugees can safely return home.\u201d\n\nThat prospect seemed in doubt last week after Mr. Trump declared, \u201cWe\u2019ll be coming out of Syria, like, very soon.\u201d At a meeting of the National Security Council on Tuesday, which General McMaster did not attend, Mr. Trump pressed his military advisers to wrap up the campaign immediately.\n\nThe advisers, Defense Secretary Jim Mattis and the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, Gen. Joseph F. Dunford Jr., demurred, according to a person in the room. Instead, they sold the president on an alternative plan, in which troops would stay in Syria for months \u2014 though not years \u2014 to stabilize territories liberated from the Islamic State and to train local forces.\n\nGeneral McMaster, people who know him said, favored a deeper commitment to Syria than even Mr. Mattis or General Dunford. His colleagues said he skipped the N.S.C. meeting to attend a military awards ceremony. But his presence would likely not have helped. By that time, Mr. Trump was long past listening to his national security adviser.\n\nThe two men had a stilted relationship, even before the president decided to replace him with Mr. Bolton. They got off on the wrong foot during the debate over Afghanistan, these officials said, because General McMaster was so fervent about sending additional troops.\n\nMr. Trump acquiesced, but unhappily \u2014 a frustration that may have colored his views on Syria, they said. The president also bridled at General McMaster\u2019s military-style briefings, viewing him as pedantic and condescending.\n\nIf the president\u2019s treatment stung General McMaster, however, he did not show it. Unlike Rex W. Tillerson, who lamented the inability of people to treat one another with respect after Mr. Trump fired him as secretary of state on Twitter, General McMaster has not taken swipes at the president, either publicly or in remarks to staff members.", "title": "For McMaster, Pomp Under Bittersweet Circumstances", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-26 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cI guess I\u2019ve always been my own person,\u201d Mr. Graves said, sitting in baggy sweatpants and a flannel jacket by a bank of six computer monitors. \u201cI didn\u2019t have no teacher, and that was great, because I was allowed to figure it out without anybody telling me to do it this way or that way. That came later, when I said, Oh, that\u2019s the conventional way.\u201d\n\nHe grew up playing timbales in Latin jazz and mambo bands, where the rhythmic complexity is greater and more gravity-defying than in standard jazz drumming. Mr. Graves decided to move to the kit after hearing Elvin Jones with John Coltrane at a club \u2014 not to imitate what he\u2019d heard, but to transcend it, add more range. \u201cI said, \u2018He\u2019s cool, but I hear something else, man,\u2019\u201d Mr. Graves said. \u201cI heard what he wasn\u2019t doing.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Louder Newsletter Every week, stay on top of the latest in pop and jazz with reviews, interviews, podcasts and more from The New York Times music critics. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nOn the drum kit, he met the new challenge of incorporating foot pedals. Playing Latin percussion, he recalled, \u201cwe\u2019d be doing dance movements while we were playing. So I said: \u2018That\u2019s all I\u2019ll do. I\u2019m going to start dancing down below.\u2019 I started dancing on the high-hat.\u201d\n\nHe fell in with the improvising avant-garde around 1963, recording first with the New York Art Quartet, a group that\u2019s now iconic. He had begun to develop a polyrhythmic style of free playing, shapely and articulate and unabating. Delivering most strokes at about 60 to 80 percent force, Mr. Graves sometimes holds multiple sticks in one hand, each tapping a different drum with a different rhythm. He maintains a low and certain flow, even as patterns tilt and tempos shift.\n\nSoon he had radically remodeled his drum kit, ditching the snare drum and taking the bottom skins off his toms, getting a soupier resonance. He said the snare\u2019s stiff-toned sound fit its European military origins better than it did his music. \u201cThe potential of how you can manipulate a vibrating drum membrane is much greater,\u201d Mr. Graves said. He suggested that jazz drummers who use the snare might simply be \u201cfollowing orders without questioning those orders\u201d \u2014 his idea of a grave sin.\n\nPhoto\n\nIn 1973, he began teaching at Bennington College in Vermont, where he stayed on as a professor until 2012, holding forth on topics well beyond any single subject, despite having no more than a high school diploma. But he spent most of each week back in Queens, teaching percussion and yara, a hybrid martial art of his own creation, to interested artists and neighborhood residents.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn \u201cFull Mantis,\u201d Mr. Graves is the only speaker, which makes for both a captivating sound poem (philosophical speech interleaved with performances) and a risk: It positions him as a solitary figure, too far ahead to relate to, whereas, in fact, he\u2019s always been a convener and a sharer. For many years, he has hosted informal Sunday get-togethers in his basement, assembling different groups of guests, teaching and opening up broad discussions.\n\n\u201cAt the house, you meet people from all over,\u201d said Mr. Meginsky, who served as Mr. Graves\u2019s personal assistant for over a decade before making \u201cFull Mantis\u201d out of a combination of his own recordings and Mr. Graves\u2019s old videos. \u201cYou\u2019re meeting classical musicians there, you\u2019re meeting consecrated priests in Santeria and If\u00e1 and voodoo, you\u2019re meeting doctors, you\u2019re meeting guys who run the health food store in South Jamaica, drummers, gardeners.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nThe pianist Jason Moran, who sought out Mr. Graves for a duet at Big Ears, said in an interview that he\u2019s long been impressed by the way Mr. Graves \u201cturns the way that knowledge functions around, into the personal, away from the textbook.\u201d\n\nHe added: \u201cHe follows through on all those intuitions where I think most of us sometimes don\u2019t, really spending his time.\u201d\n\nOnstage at the Bijou Theater in Knoxville, the two musicians let their instincts multiply, Mr. Moran moving from chunky chords to rippling repetitions of a single high note. Even when the pianist swept down to the lowest reaches of his instrument, Mr. Graves seemed to stay underneath him, a ballast in constant flux, offering only the guarantee that he would listen, and change.", "title": "For Milford Graves, Jazz Innovation Is Only Part of the Alchemy", "authors": ["Giovanni Russonello"]} {"date": "2018-04-20 00:00:00", "text": "During her husband\u2019s eight years as vice president, she traveled 1,629 days, visited 50 states and 65 foreign countries and covered 1.3 million miles, which is 54 times around the world. She mothered her kids in every kind of living quarter imaginable \u2014 cheap inns, well-heeled mansions, hotel rooms, apartments and the back of a station wagon that she drove from Maine to Texas every year. She hosted 1,192 events at her house and 1,232 events in Washington. Yet she still answered her own front door. Her smile was genuine, her delight infectious. Mrs. Bush liked to laugh, and she could converse as easily with a Mexican mother of seven as she could with a head of state. It made no difference. She was a true Christian. My mother admired her.\n\nShe was not without fault. Her public statements sometimes caused controversy. She recalled wearing sneakers to meet the prime minister of Greece. When she was a young bride-to-be and was called upon to cook for Mr. Bush\u2019s younger brothers, her future mother-in-law bragged to Mrs. Bush\u2019s mother that Barbara was a wonderful cook. Her mother, shocked, responded, \u201cOh?\u201d Peanut butter and jelly was the actual menu. It didn\u2019t matter. The menu was love, something Mrs. Bush learned from her own mother, whom she would lose in an auto accident after she married, unable to attend the funeral because she was living in California and very pregnant with her second child and, ironically, her own duties as a wife and mother prevented it. There was nothing to do. Family comes first.\n\nAnd what a family she raised. In the tight-knuckled, bare-fisted world of Washington politics, the Bushes proved over the years that they could hit as hard as anyone. Some did not like it. Still, you will not find a more loyal family. Republican, Democratic, black, white, Latino, North, South, Dixie, New England \u2014 you won\u2019t have to look far down the Bush family line to find some of this, or that, or the other. They\u2019re a real American family, flawed as all families are, shaped by a matriarch who understood, even as a young woman, that in all the ways of life, the importance of a mother\u2019s love is paramount. It is the last line of reason and discourse in a planet gone seemingly mad. It is our last breath and greatest hope. Motherhood defines a society.\n\nBarbara Pierce Bush defined every single bit of it. In the last years of her life, she dragged her octogenarian body onto planes and buses and into cars from one end of the country to the other, raising money for her literacy foundation. She despised ignorance. She despised it because she knew it was wrong.\n\nAnd if you loved her and what she represented, you\u2019ll go out and get a book. And you will read it. You will turn off that TV and pay attention. And cut the tweeting. And cut the Facebook chatter and all the other nonsense. And you will get busy doing what Barbara Bush spent a majority of her life doing. You will fight ignorance. You will learn to love. And in doing so, you will do what she did.\n\nYou will change the world.", "title": "Opinion | For Mrs. Bush", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-05 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Mueller\u2019s original assignment from Mr. Rosenstein was to look into Russian meddling in the 2016 election and any links to Trump campaign officials, with the ambiguous addition of \u201cany matters that arose or may arise directly from the investigation.\u201d\n\nIn a response this week, Mr. Mueller\u2019s team insisted that Mr. Manafort\u2019s Ukraine dealings, in light of his campaign role, were relevant to investigating links between Russia and the Trump campaign. The team also argued that Mr. Manafort had no right to challenge Mr. Mueller\u2019s jurisdiction. (It did not, however, invoke the widespread belief that Mr. Mueller is using the Ukraine charges to pressure Mr. Manafort to divulge what he knows about 2016 events as part of a plea bargain.)\n\nBut members of Mr. Mueller\u2019s team also backed up those arguments with a striking move: They emphatically pointed to their subordination to Mr. Rosenstein \u2014 the acting attorney general for the Russia investigation because Attorney General Jeff Sessions is recused from it.\n\nWhile Mr. Rosenstein has testified that he knows about and approves of what Mr. Mueller is doing, the filing went into significant new detail, including disclosing that Mr. Rosenstein wrote a memo on Aug. 2 blessing the idea that Mr. Mueller\u2019s jurisdiction extends to Mr. Manafort\u2019s Ukraine-linked dealings.\n\n\u201cThe acting attorney general appointed the special counsel, defined his jurisdiction, understands the scope of his investigation and has specifically confirmed that the allegations that form the basis\u201d of Mr. Manafort\u2019s prosecution are within Mr. Mueller\u2019s purview, the filing said. \u201cIn these circumstances, no serious question of political accountability can be raised.\u201d\n\nMr. Mueller\u2019s assertive use of a Trump appointee\u2019s control over his investigation as a shield against Mr. Manafort\u2019s attack was a remarkable moment in the history of recurring tensions over the independence of investigations touching on high-level executive branch officials.\n\nPhoto\n\nAfter the Watergate scandal, in which President Richard M. Nixon forced the Justice Department to fire the prosecutor investigating him, Congress enacted a law permitting the appointment of an \u201cindependent\u201d counsel who would report to a panel of judges rather than to a presidential appointee.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAlthough the Supreme Court upheld Congress\u2019s constitutional power to make that arrangement in a 1988 case, both political parties came to see it as a bad idea. In 1999, when the independent counsel statute expired, lawmakers did not renew it.\n\nAs a replacement, the Justice Department created a regulation to permit the appointment, from outside the government, of a special counsel who would exercise day-to-day independence but remain subject to control by the attorney general, who could veto decisions like whether to file charges or expand jurisdiction. At the same time, it limited the attorney general\u2019s power to fire a special counsel to cases of misconduct.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nBut that regulation has rarely been used. The most high-profile case arising during George W. Bush\u2019s administration \u2014 the appointment in 2003 of Patrick J. Fitzgerald to investigate who leaked the identity of Valerie Plame Wilson, a C.I.A. official \u2014 bypassed its envisioned arrangement.\n\nMr. Fitzgerald, then a United States attorney in Chicago, was appointed as a special counsel by James B. Comey, then the deputy attorney general, after Attorney General John Ashcroft recused himself from the investigation. Mr. Comey also delegated his supervisory powers as the acting attorney general to Mr. Fitzgerald, permitting the prosecutor to take major investigative steps \u201cindependent of the supervision or control of any officer of the department.\u201d\n\nBy contrast, after Mr. Trump fired Mr. Comey in May from his subsequent job as F.B.I. director and Mr. Rosenstein appointed Mr. Mueller as special counsel, Mr. Rosenstein invoked the regulation \u2014 meaning he retained supervisory control.\n\nAt the time, some Democrats greeted that arrangement with suspicion. They worried that Mr. Rosenstein \u2014 a Trump appointee who had helped with Mr. Trump\u2019s firing of Mr. Comey by writing a memo criticizing Mr. Comey\u2019s handling of the Hillary Clinton email investigation \u2014 would keep Mr. Mueller on a short leash.\n\nDuring a June hearing, for example, Senator Kamala Harris, Democrat of California, pressed Mr. Rosenstein to instead create a more independent special counsel who could oversee himself, like Mr. Fitzgerald.\n\n\u201cAre you willing to do as has been done before?\u201d she demanded.\n\nMr. Rosenstein demurred. While noting that Mr. Bush could have fired Mr. Fitzgerald for any reason \u2014 so working under the regulation gave Mr. Mueller greater protection \u2014 he also said there were other complicated legal issues that led him to his decision. (One of the complexities may have been that Mr. Mueller was not a current Justice Department employee at the time of his appointment, unlike Mr. Fitzgerald in 2003, so Mr. Mueller most likely could not have been delegated attorney general supervisory powers, Mr. Katyal said.)\n\nThe anxieties of that period make it all the more striking that, 10 months later, Mr. Mueller\u2019s team is stressing his subordination to Mr. Rosenstein to repel Mr. Manafort\u2019s attack.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nStill, several specialists cautioned that Mr. Mueller\u2019s subordination could revert to a weakness if Mr. Trump were to fire Mr. Sessions or Mr. Rosenstein, putting someone else in charge of the special counsel.\n\nAgainst that backdrop, Julie O\u2019Sullivan, a Georgetown University law professor and a former federal prosecutor, worried about the lengths the filing went to in detailing Mr. Rosenstein\u2019s approval for Mr. Mueller\u2019s actions.\n\n\u201cMueller\u2019s lack of independence was viewed as a real problem, but now it\u2019s a response to any attack on the indictment,\u201d she said. \u201cI do wonder, though, if he hasn\u2019t put Rosenstein in additional jeopardy.\u201d", "title": "For Mueller, a Feared Weakness Becomes a Strength", "authors": ["Charlie Savage"]} {"date": "2018-04-13 00:00:00", "text": "About two and a half hours. I start in the special-effects makeup trailer and do all the prosthetics. I have a big forehead piece that covers my eyebrows and a nose that goes on, and then they paint it to match my skin tone, airbrush the whole thing with wrinkles and spots and hand-paint bags under the eyes and capillaries. After that I get a three-piece unibrow, two muttonchops, a goatee and a two-piece wig. And then I get dressed, and I\u2019m ready to go.\n\nWhew.\n\nAs much time as I spend in the process of looking like Olaf, it pales in comparison to the workload that Louis and Malina have. They\u2019re on set doing their scene, blocking and learning lines, and then they\u2019re rushed to school to think only about honors biology. Then there\u2019s a knock at the door, and they stop where they are and go recite dialogue and act stressed and emotional. Rinse and repeat all day long until they\u2019re pumpkined, which is the term for when they\u2019re wrapped.\n\nYou recently rented out a theater in your hometown, Albuquerque, N.M., so that locals could see \u201cLove, Simon\u201d free of charge.\n\nIt was a movie that I think is profound, about a gay high school student who is afraid to come out and falls in love, and I was really moved by just how pure it was. But that purity doesn\u2019t have to be pretentious. It\u2019s not \u201cBrokeback Mountain\u201d; it\u2019s more \u201cSixteen Candles,\u201d handled in such a confident, casual, easy way. So I got 111 people to see it, and hopefully they were moved by it and will tell their friends and pay it forward.\n\nTalking about smart kids, you also host NBC\u2019s \u201cGenius Junior.\u201d What\u2019s the appeal?\n\nIt\u2019s these remarkable kids that do the most amazing feats, who can spell \u201comnidirectional\u201d backward as fast as you can say it and remember a shuffled deck of cards and know the Greyhound bus map. These are achievable goals that kids can accomplish. If it can be aspirational and inspirational and still watchable, then I\u2019m happy to be the ringmaster of that circus.\n\nDoes it make you want to go home and quiz Harper and Gideon?\n\nI\u2019m having to shift into that parent. Not, certainly, spelling backward. But to get them to recognize that homework, that reading, that writing, isn\u2019t something that they do for an hour until they can play \u2014 and so they\u2019re excited to know that it doesn\u2019t stop until you\u2019re 80 and you have cataracts. So I\u2019m on them to make sure they\u2019re using sentence structure well, that they\u2019re spelling things right, that their E\u2019s look uniform. It\u2019s time.", "title": "For Neil Patrick Harris, It Takes an Adult to Make a Kids\u2019 Show", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-23 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cThe interesting thing about an impeachment \u2014 and people always need to keep this in mind \u2014 is it\u2019s inherently a political exercise, and not a legal exercise,\u201d said David Ellis, who prosecuted Gov. Rod Blagojevich of Illinois during his Senate trial in 2009 when Mr. Blagojevich was convicted and removed from office. \u201cIt\u2019s governed by the legislature, not the courts. Courts have all sorts of procedural protections built in \u2014 due process rights, impartial juries \u2014 but you cannot perfectly analogize that to the legislative realm.\u201d\n\nWith impeachments still relatively rare, even as some Democrats talk of removing President Trump from office, lawyers working recent cases in state capitals like Montgomery, Ala., have found little precedent to guide them. Instead they often find that the processes long codified in constitutions can, in modern practice, be murky to the point of inviting chaos.\n\nThat lack of clarity invites clashes about privileges and subpoena power, legislative authority and access to evidence. Arcane-seeming subjects may be able to reshape a state\u2019s approach to executive power. And a particular brand of politics \u2014 fueled by self-flagellation, piety, pride and legal jeopardy \u2014 seems to thread through every threatened impeachment.\n\n\u201cThere\u2019s a common structure, but as far as how you\u2019re supposed to do it on the ground, substantively or procedurally or in terms of burden of proof, there\u2019s a lot of debate on that, and not a lot of consensus,\u201d said Jackson R. Sharman III, who was special counsel to the Alabama legislative committee that investigated Gov. Robert Bentley before his resignation last year.\n\nThe absence of norms lends extraordinary influence to the lawyers who are often tasked with speedily setting up something resembling, but not always behaving like, a traditional investigation and trial.\n\nMr. Ellis was counsel to the state\u2019s House speaker when legislative leaders urged him to take the case, a role he said he accepted only after \u201ca pregnant pause.\u201d He had about two weeks to prepare for trial.\n\nMr. Garber, a white-collar criminal defense lawyer who once edited his high school newspaper, more or less fell into impeachments as a legal niche. After Mr. Garber\u2019s bid for Connecticut state treasurer faltered \u2014 he was \u201cthe silver medalist,\u201d he noted wryly \u2014 Gov. John G. Rowland\u2019s office sought the lawyer\u2019s help for a federal corruption investigation. Mr. Rowland had lawyers on his staff, but, like those in all governor\u2019s offices, they were far more familiar with legislative haggling than with inquiries that could lead to prison terms.\n\nPhoto\n\nMr. Rowland resigned before lawmakers could decide whether to impeach him. But Mr. Garber, who describes his work as safeguarding the institutional traditions and privileges of the governor\u2019s offices he represents, had stumbled into a legal arena in which few others were experts.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHe was later asked to advise Gov. Mark Sanford of South Carolina, whom lawmakers eventually declined to impeach over accusations connected to his whereabouts while he visited his mistress in Argentina.\n\nAnd then last year, Mr. Garber, whose usual work includes handling regulatory investigations and international trade issues, was on Mr. Bentley\u2019s team after the Alabama governor was enmeshed in a sex scandal. He said his name comes up so often because there are so few in the field.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cBecause so much of what happens isn\u2019t reported or recorded or even known, one of the things I bring to the process is the sense of having done them and spent a lot of time studying them,\u201d Mr. Garber said.\n\nAt the federal level, the United States Senate has conducted just 19 impeachment trials in its history; nearly all have been of federal judges, including the most recent, in 2010. State legislatures have impeached a host of lower-ranking officials, from a university regent in Nebraska to a Kentucky agriculture commissioner, but only 16 governors have ever been impeached, and almost all were before the Great Depression.\n\nAlthough some governors, like Mr. Sanford, withstand the pressure, modern governors tend to succumb to political or legal realities and leave office before an impeachment can happen.\n\nNeither Mr. Bentley, who now practices dermatology in an Alabama college town, nor Mr. Sanford, a member of Congress, responded to messages. Mr. Blagojevich and Mr. Rowland, who were convicted of corruption charges after leaving office, are in federal custody.\n\nFor Mr. Garber, whose bills are often paid with tax dollars because he is not representing a governor\u2019s personal interests, part of his job is ensuring that politics alone do not settle impeachments and undermine the authority of governors for generations to come.\n\nHis goal, he said, is to argue \u201cthat our constitutional system is set up so that elections don\u2019t get overthrown because of political whims, that elections have consequences and we don\u2019t throw those out absent very, very serious acts that affect the public official\u2019s office, that are proven with a high degree of certainty after a fair process.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMissouri lawmakers are still grappling over how they will reckon with Mr. Greitens, who has been criminally charged with two felonies: invasion of privacy, for photographing a nude or partially nude person without the person\u2019s knowledge or consent, and for tampering with computer data for allegedly obtaining a charity\u2019s donor list and using it for political fund-raising.\n\nThe governor has denied criminal wrongdoing and rebuffed demands for his resignation, calling the efforts against him \u201ca witch hunt.\u201d A legislative committee will decide in the coming weeks whether to pursue the impeachment process that is broadly outlined in the Missouri Constitution.\n\nMr. Garber, who teaches about political investigations and impeachments at Tulane University\u2019s law school and largely splits his time between Washington, Hartford and New Orleans, declined to detail any of his plans for the Missouri case. His record, though, suggests that he will argue, in public and in private, that lawmakers should not hastily negate the voters\u2019 choice for governor and should save impeachment for a most exceptional case.\n\nLike just about every impeachment lawyer these days, he is likely to look to history, where the proceedings against President Richard M. Nixon remain especially important for lawyers working in state capitols. More than 40 years later, it remains a lesson in the strategies and risks that come with representing the most powerful figures in government.\n\n\u201cInstitutions, even something so sophisticated as the White House,\u201d Mr. Garber observed, \u201caren\u2019t set up to deal with these kinds of crises.\u201d", "title": "For Politicians Scraping Bottom, a Scarce Resource: Impeachment Lawyers", "authors": ["Alan Blinder"]} {"date": "2018-04-24 00:00:00", "text": "Once a book has been selected, the next task is finding a reviewer \u2014 and the editors of the Review take very seriously the mandate not to assign a review to anyone who has any personal affiliation with a book\u2019s author. \u201cYou can disagree with a reviewer\u2019s assessment, but you shouldn\u2019t distrust it,\u201d Ms. Paul said. \u201cSo, for that reason, conflict of interest and fact-checking are two of the most important things that we worry about here.\u201d\n\nIf a book was written by a Times employee, that means The Times\u2019s daily critics \u2014 Dwight Garner, Parul Sehgal and Jennifer Szalai, all of whom are full-time employees at the paper \u2014 cannot review it; nor can anyone from a directly competing news organization. Beyond that, Ms. Paul said, the editors apply the same standards they would to any other book. A reviewer cannot review a book by anyone with whom he or she shares an agent, publisher or editor; anyone the reviewer has blurbed, or been blurbed by; anyone, even, with whom the reviewer has shared a contentious moment on a panel or at a conference. Friends are out, as are enemies.\n\nThe ubiquity of social media has complicated these assessments. \u201cIf you\u2019re following someone on Twitter or if you\u2019re \u2018Facebook friends,\u2019 I think that we have all been disabused of the notion that that actually constitutes a friendship,\u201d Ms. Paul said. Those relationships aren\u2019t necessarily seen as a conflict of interest that would preclude a review.\n\nOf course, the literary world is a small one \u2014 as are the fields represented by many of the books the Review covers. \u201cIn certain areas, everyone knows everyone,\u201d Ms. Paul said, citing politics, science and even British literature. (\u201cIt\u2019s an island nation,\u201d she added.)\n\nIt can be difficult to find a reviewer who has never been in the same room as a book\u2019s author; and on a case-by-case basis, some passing familiarity can be acceptable. A handshake at a party is fine; a sexual relationship \u2014 even years ago, as at least one prospective reviewer has tried to emphasize \u2014 is not.\n\nIn the case of \u201cChasing Hillary,\u201d Ms. Chozick, the author, had never met Ms. Alter, the reviewer, who is a radio host and a national correspondent at Time magazine. In choosing her, Ms. Paul sought a reviewer who could \u201cunderstand the political landscape but who would also be able to assess the book as a memoir,\u201d she said.\n\nWithout exception, the reviewer must be able to answer \u201cyes\u201d to the question: \u201cIf need be, would you feel free to criticize the book?\u201d\n\nAnd criticize they do. Though it wasn\u2019t the case this time, Times employees have received plenty of negative reviews in the past. The Books desk doesn\u2019t edit opinions, nor does it kill and reassign a review if it comes back negative.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cThere have been instances where writers, both in the newsroom and on the opinion side, have had very negative assessments in the Book Review,\u201d Ms. Paul said. \u201cYou just hope that you don\u2019t run into that person in the elevator.\u201d", "title": "For Reviews of Times Employees\u2019 Books, the Only Guarantee Is Integrity", "authors": ["Alexandria Symonds"]} {"date": "2018-04-03 00:00:00", "text": "Last week, in a sentencing memorandum for the lawyer Alex Van Der Zwaan, the special counsel\u2019s office noted that Rick Gates and \u201cPerson A\u201d \u2014 an unnamed figure who has ties to a \u201cRussian intelligence service and had such ties in 2016\u201d \u2014 \u201cwere directly communicating in September and October 2016.\u201d\n\nWhat coverage there was of this staggering claim \u2014 evidence of a direct link between a member of Donald Trump\u2019s campaign and Russian intelligence \u2014 and the Van Der Zwaan filing was quickly overtaken by controversy over the president\u2019s relationship with an adult film star.\n\nIt\u2019s been a year since I testified to the Senate Select Intelligence Committee on Russian interference in the presidential election of 2016. On Tuesday, he formally announced his most sweeping regulatory rollback to date: a plan to weaken President Barack Obama\u2019s stringent rules on planet-warming tailpipe emissions.\n\nMr. Pruitt\u2019s proposal is designed to unravel a signature piece of Mr. Obama\u2019s environmental legacy, hand a victory to the American automakers and please his boss, President Trump. But instead of basking in glory, Mr. Pruitt is caught up in a swirl of allegations of impropriety \u2014 most recently centered on the fact that last year he rented a room in Washington from the wife of a prominent lobbyist.\n\nMr. Pruitt unveiled his rollback in a hastily announced presentation at E.P.A. headquarters after canceling a plan to speak at a suburban Virginia auto dealership, a more public setting that might have exposed him to questions about the lease arrangement, or about his first-class air travel at taxpayer expense over the past year, for which he has also faced criticism. Mr. Pruitt declined to field questions at the event.\n\nLate Monday, Mr. Trump phoned Mr. Pruitt to reassure him that his job was safe. \u201cKeep your head up, keep fighting, we got your back,\u201d Mr. Trump told Mr. Pruitt, according to an administration official.
