Rollbacks", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-30 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nFor the second time in a week, President Trump on Monday urged other countries to support the North American bid to host the 2026 World Cup and again implied there might be consequences for those who did not. The comments, made during a news conference in the Rose Garden, raised new questions about whether Mr. Trump\u2019s input constitutes political interference in the bidding process, which could jeopardize the joint bid by the United States, Mexico and Canada.\n\nIn remarks about international trade while meeting with the Nigerian president, Muhammadu Buhari, at the White House, Mr. Trump said, \u201cI hope, all African countries and countries throughout the world, that we also will be supporting you and that they will likewise support us in our bid along with Canada and Mexico for the 2026 World Cup.\u201d\n\nHe added: \u201cWe will be watching very closely, and any help that they could give us in that bid, we would appreciate.\u201d\n\nLast Thursday, Mr. Trump praised the bid on Twitter, adding remarks that some observers construed as a veiled threat: \u201cThe U.S. has put together a STRONG bid w/ Canada and Mexico for the 2026 World Cup. It would be a shame if countries that we always support were to lobby against the U.S. bid. Why should we be supporting these countries when they don\u2019t support us (including at the United Nations)?\u201d\n\nFIFA, global soccer\u2019s governing body, declined to comment on the Twitter post. A FIFA spokesman, however, did point to its pre-existing rules of conduct, which warn governments of bidding nations not to participate in activities that \u201cmay adversely affect the integrity of the bidding process and create an undue influence on the bidding process.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe host of the 2026 World Cup will be named June 13, a day before the opening match of the 2018 World Cup in Russia. Even before Mr. Trump\u2019s remarks, the North American bid was not considered a lock against its only rival, the North African nation of Morocco, even though the United States has an abundance of large stadiums and, in 1994, sold more tickets than any World Cup before or since.", "title": "For Second Time in a Week, Trump Weighs In on World Cup Bidding", "authors": ["Jer\u00e9 Longman"]} {"date": "2018-04-16 00:00:00", "text": "A former fine arts student, Mr. Etaki, 28, struggles to support his extended family with freelance media and design work.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cI lost my job,\u201d he joked, referring to his activism in Aleppo. \u201cFor people who were relying on me for information, I am no longer useful.\u201d\n\nBut he continues to blog and post on social media about the war in Syria and to help those still resisting inside.\n\n\u201cI am just talking to friends in Ghouta and giving advice how to survive because I have some experience,\u201d he said. \u201cI am telling them to save their equipment and not be worried, be calm, that everything will be solved in the end.\u201d\n\nFearful for his family \u2014 his son was born on July 10, 2016, just before the siege of Aleppo began \u2014 he said he lost control at times toward the end.\n\n\u201cOnce I cried,\u201d he recalled. \u201cOnce I burned my car. I forgot to take my things.\u201d\n\nMany of the opposition members set fire to their cars and belongings to prevent them falling into the hands of the pro-government militias that were encroaching into the rebel neighborhoods. In the end, the last to leave were allowed to drive their cars out since there was a lack of buses and in the snow and freezing night, the soldiers stopped checking all those evacuating.\n\nMr. Etaki even left the gas on in his home, hoping to destroy it so the pro-government militias could not use it.\n\n\u201cI was thinking it would burn, but then we did not evacuate that day and I had to go back,\u201d he laughed. There was still just enough gas in the bottle to keep warm that night, he said.\n\nWhen he did leave, he said Russian soldiers stole his computers, and his cameras and other equipment were taken as well.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nDr. Hamza al-Khatib, who became known for his work running the last functioning medical center in Aleppo, Al Quds hospital, warned a friend in Ghouta how the siege would play out.", "title": "For Survivors of Aleppo Siege, the News From Syria Is Especially Painful", "authors": ["Carlotta Gall"]} {"date": "2018-04-03 00:00:00", "text": "Tesla began producing electric cars at its plant in Fremont, Calif., six years ago, starting with small quantities and ramping up to about 100,000 vehicles last year. Now, as it tries to double or triple that number, the company and its chief executive, Elon Musk, are getting a lesson in how hard it is to mass-produce automobiles.\n\nOn Tuesday, Tesla reported that it had managed to increase production of a crucial new model in the first quarter of 2018, although it remained well short of the company\u2019s already lowered target. At the same time, it encountered a new hitch \u2014 a drop in sales of its two established products, the Model S sedan and Model X sport-utility vehicle.\n\nThe company is counting on the success of the new offering, the Model 3, to increase revenue and help pare its losses as Tesla invests heavily in the vehicles it hopes to offer in the future.\n\nBut a series of setbacks have left Tesla far behind schedule in turning out the Model 3 \u2014 for which nearly 400,000 prospective buyers have already put down $1,000 deposits \u2014 and it is taking some extraordinary measures to turn things around. Mr. Musk said on Twitter this week that he had been sleeping at the plant, and the company said some workers who normally assemble the Model S and Model X were shifted to Model 3 production.", "title": "For Tesla, \u2018Production Hell\u2019 Looks Like the Reality of the Car Business", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-18 00:00:00", "text": "THE LIFE TO COME\n\nBy Michelle de Kretser\n\n344 pp. Catapult. $26.\n\nThe Australian novelist Michelle de Kretser has made a habit of disputing the notion that travel necessarily broadens the mind. Her fourth novel, \u201cQuestions of Travel,\u201d which won Australia\u2019s most prestigious literary award, the Miles Franklin, contrasted the journeys of an asylum-seeker from the subcontinent with those of a backpacking travel-guide writer from Sydney. The characters in \u201cThe Life to Come,\u201d de Kretser\u2019s fifth novel, are similarly peripatetic. While they all eventually enjoy a comfortable life in suburban Sydney, some are dogged by memories of past lives in violent places. The memory of a stretch of wall split by the sun transports an elderly woman back to her childhood in Sri Lanka: \u201cPictures like that were always there, running invisibly under her Australian life, appearing now and again like snatches of an old videotape that a later recording has overlaid without entirely erasing.\u201d\n\nThe \u00e9migr\u00e9 is one kind of traveler, portrayed here with sympathy and lyricism. But de Kretser, who was born in Sri Lanka and came to Australia at 14, saves her startling satirical firepower for another \u2014 the expats of the global West, or those who can travel on a whim. In a novel that restlessly spans decades and continents, a woman named Pippa is as close as de Kretser gets to a protagonist. It is Pippa\u2019s friends, colleagues and acquaintances whose stories we learn via impressionistic flashbacks. In the late 1990s, when we meet her, she is an idealistic undergraduate in Sydney who announces \u201cI love India\u201d after watching a documentary on TV. Over time, she becomes a more interesting character, a full-fledged writer who seeks experiences in the world with which to animate her fiction. Yet Pippa remains na\u00efve. She preaches empathy for refugees on Facebook, but is careless of the inner lives of others.\n\nImage\n\nIn 2010, Pippa goes to Paris on a writing fellowship. (The ensuing novel, \u201cFrench Lessons,\u201d is a flop.) Her approach to other cultures is uncomplicated. Europe, she thinks, is \u201cmomentous and world-historical\u201d; Australia, \u201ceventless.\u201d Plus, there\u2019s all that foreign food, which can be recreated at Instagram-worthy dinner parties back home. Many scenes revolve around Pippa in the kitchen, whipping up something ostentatiously multicultural: a lamb tagine with saffron, carrots and fennel for a sick neighbor; a salad of pork and ginger during a Thai phase; local prawns for her literary agent served with lemon juice, brown bread and butter. Meals like these are as familiar in Brooklyn or Portland as they are in inner-city Sydney. Call it the cult of Ottolenghi \u2014 that trendy Israeli-British chef is name-checked on more than one occasion.\n\nIn one scene, the function of food as a status symbol for globe-trotting cosmopolites becomes clear. During her time in Paris, Pippa befriends C\u00e9leste, an older woman who lives alone. C\u00e9leste\u2019s father died in the aftermath of the massacre of Algerians in the French capital in 1961; her mother remarried an Australian man she met on the M\u00e9tro. The family emigrated to Western Australia, but in adulthood C\u00e9leste found her way back to Paris as a translator. (This is the kind of fractured life, filled with loss and hard-won visa stamps, that de Kretser protects from ridicule.) Relatives visiting from Perth come over to C\u00e9leste\u2019s small apartment for lunch, and she prepares gratin dauphinois, chicken in a wine sauce and asparagus from the market.", "title": "For These Characters, Foreign Cultures Are Just Another Consumer Good", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-25 00:00:00", "text": "For many of the young undocumented immigrants whose futures have seemed to be hitched to a roller-coaster in recent months, Wednesday was a day of unusual hopefulness: The night before, a federal judge had signaled his readiness to open applications once again for a program that protects some young undocumented immigrants, known as Dreamers, from deportation and allows them to work.\n\n\u201cFirst thing this morning, I opened up my email to find inquiries from potential applicants. We\u2019re telling them to get all their paperwork together, let\u2019s get ready,\u201d said Fernanda Durand, communications manager at Casa, an immigrant advocacy organization. \u201cThis is the first ray of hope that these Dreamers have had in a very long time.\u201d\n\nNot so fast, she had to tell her clients. Judge John D. Bates of the Federal District Court in Washington wasn\u2019t going to make his order effective for 90 days. Much could change in the meantime. It might not happen at all.\n\nSince the early days of the 2016 presidential campaign, young people who benefited from the Obama-era program, Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals, or DACA, have seen their hopes alternately elevated and dashed, sometimes in the space of a single week. President Trump canceled the program, some judges revived it, politicians negotiated deals to save it \u2014 but none of them closed.", "title": "For Thousands of \u2018Dreamers,\u2019 It Has Been a Wild Ride. And It\u2019s Not Over Yet.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-20 00:00:00", "text": "A new breed of state-based savings accounts can help workers prepare for retirement, in part by allowing them to push back the time when they file for Social Security payments, a new analysis suggests.\n\nHalf of all states have considered plans to offer automatic individual retirement accounts, and at least five (California, Connecticut, Illinois, Maryland and Oregon) have begun offering them or have taken steps toward doing so. The plans vary in their details but, in general, are for workers at private-sector employers that don\u2019t offer retirement plans. Those workers are automatically enrolled in the state I.R.A. program and have contributions withdrawn from their paychecks, although they can choose to opt out or change their contribution.\n\nMany people think they must start receiving Social Security as soon as they retire, but the two steps don\u2019t have to be done simultaneously. People can start claiming their federal benefits at age 62, but waiting at least a year or two to collect means their monthly payments will be larger because of the way the federal program is structured.\n\nThose enrolled in the new state-sponsored accounts could, instead, use that money to temporarily cover their expenses after they retire, allowing them to delay claiming their Social Security benefits for a year or more, the report from the Pew Charitable Trusts said.", "title": "For Workers Without Retirement Savings, State-Run I.R.A.s Can Pay Off", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-19 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cNow he has 20,\u201d Demid said, referring to Federer\u2019s Australian Open victory in January, \u201cso I have to get another photo.\u201d\n\nFor other players, family life and tennis do not always jibe so smoothly. Azarenka has been involved in a custody dispute over her 1-year-old son, Leo, and when she and the boy\u2019s father were temporarily barred from leaving California with the child, Azarenka declined to travel to several tournaments.\n\nYet even in cases without conflict, Mirnyi said, \u201cit\u2019s tougher for the mothers.\u201d\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s important to have a good support team with you,\u201d he added. \u201cWe know that there are some difficulties with men and women and husbands and wives getting in the situation that Vika is in right now. The board imposed a $500 fine for anyone caught doing this, but without cameras, catching the culprits is nearly impossible. I received a notice that if the situation isn\u2019t rectified, all the tenants on the floor will be fined $50 each. Can the board really fine an entire group because one person is a slob? What recourse do I have?\n\nA: When I was in fifth grade, my teacher used to take away recess from the entire class because one child habitually had a messy desk. The collective punishment certainly made everyone unhappy, but it did little to get the disorganized student\u2019s papers in order. I\u2019m not sure what your board expects to achieve with this strategy, other than enrage those who have done nothing wrong, and reduce the penalty for the few people who deserve discipline.\n\nDoes your board even have the right to do such a thing? Probably not. Generally, a co-op board can impose only fines authorized by the proprietary lease, which governs the co-op. It is very unlikely that your lease authorizes a group fine, according to Peter R. Massa, a real estate lawyer and partner in the Manhattan law firm Gallet Dreyer & Berkey. Review the lease to confirm this.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Real Estate Newsletter Every week, get updates on residential real estate news, covering the five boroughs and beyond. Or you could not pay it, and if the co-op sues you for eviction for nonpayment of rent, you could argue your case in court, Mr. Massa said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut before you end up in court over $50, write a letter to the co-op board and the managing agent insisting that the building address this issue fairly and appropriately. They claimed a stake in our local community. From there, the Knights went on to win their first seven games. By February, they broke the N.H.L.\u2019s record of wins by an expansion team.\n\nThe city of Las Vegas extends far beyond the two-mile corporate glitz where T-Mobile Arena is, yet our identity is so often contained to the Strip. Getting the nation to acknowledge us as anything other than America\u2019s favorite place to party has been an endless challenge. The Route 91 massacre seemed to awaken the country to the community of Las Vegas, a collection of diverse people with shared victories and disappointments.\n\nBut the Golden Knights recognized this truth almost immediately. As the season progressed and the city moved forward, the team certainly catered to our big personality, but it also continued to acknowledge our often overlooked heart.\n\nProfessional sports franchises helping their cities cope with tragedy is nothing new. After Sept. 11, the New York Yankees made it to the World Series.\n\nHad the Golden Knights never been displaced to the desert, Las Vegas\u2019s grief and recovery still would have occurred, but on a much quieter, lonely scale. We would have pressed on, because surprisingly, Las Vegans are not strangers to loneliness or displacement: Three out of every four residents were not born here. Similarly, despite the team\u2019s slogan, \u201cVegas Born,\u201d the players for the Golden Knights were plucked from all around the country.\n\nThe Golden Knights have offered residents a way to be rooted to one of the most transient cities in the world. For the small contingent that truly is \u201cVegas Born,\u201d they have affirmed that being so is something to be proud of.\n\nBut our new, shiny armor is certainly not indestructible. Explosions of fandom are always tied to success. Hard times will certainly come to the Golden Knights, whether it\u2019s in the next round of the Stanley Cup playoffs or next season.\n\nBut in our quintessentially Las Vegas style, we never ease into anything. We started our show with the entire bejeweled and bedazzled bandwagon. Who knows how long the ride will go? Ford expects the measures to enable it to achieve a global profit margin of 8 percent by 2020, two years earlier than it previously forecast, he said.", "title": "Ford Will Drop Focus and Fusion Sedans in North America", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-06 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Weizman has an especially long history of run-ins there. Born in Haifa, educated at the Architectural Association in London, he was just starting out as an architect in Tel Aviv when he began to study the legacy of town planning in the occupied territories. What he saw suggested to him architecture\u2019s complicity in human rights violations. In 2002, with a colleague, Rafi Segal, he was hired to organize a show of new Israeli architecture. Mr. Weizman and Mr. Segal presented settlements in the occupied territories. Appalled, the Israel Association of United Architects canceled the exhibition and withdrew the catalog. The incident brought Mr. Weizman attention.\n\nAnd it made him think.\n\nHis timing could hardly seem better, with technology rapidly democratizing the instruments of forensic research and the purview of young architects widening. He begins his recent book, \u201cForensic Architecture,\u201d recalling the libel trial in London of the Holocaust denier and historian David Irving, nearly two decades ago. Mr. Irving\u2019s shameful case relied on a tidbit of architectural evidence: he made much of fuzzy satellite imagery showing a demolished crematory at Auschwitz. Survivors had said they recalled poison cyanide gas canisters dropped through a hole in the crematory\u2019s roof, but Mr. Irving said there was no hole in the satellite photos. \u201cNo hole, no Holocaust,\u201d became the deniers\u2019 catchphrase.\n\nMr. Irving lost his trial. But Mr. Weizman cites the case as a cautionary tale. The tools of forensic analysis can easily be perverted. Wielded especially by governments and other powers in defense of violence and crime, they need to be challenged by equally sophisticated means. Architecture and forensics may be disparate disciplines but brought together they could produce a new, \u201cdifferent mode of practice,\u201d Mr. Weizman realized. They could help reverse \u201cthe forensic gaze\u201d back onto state agencies \u201cthat usually monopolize it.\u201d\n\nAdopting a phrase coined by the photographer Allan Sekula, Mr. Weizman terms the practice \u201ccounter forensics.\u201d", "title": "Forensics Helps Widen Architecture\u2019s Mission", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-10 00:00:00", "text": "MEDELL\u00cdN, Colombia \u2014 A former guerrilla peace negotiator has been arrested on drug trafficking charges in Colombia, after government officials said he and associates had returned to the drug trade his group had vowed to give up.\n\nThe arrest of Seusis Hern\u00e1ndez Solarte was a surprise turn of events for the FARC, the former rebel organization that has refashioned itself as a political party called the Common Alternative Revolutionary Force.\n\nIn signing a peace deal in 2016, its leaders \u2014 all wanted as drug traffickers in the United States \u2014 were promised immunity for past crimes and, in return, they renounced future ones.\n\nBut on Monday, the Colombian government said that Mr. Hern\u00e1ndez, whose nom de guerre was Jes\u00fas Santrich, had quickly returned to the drug business. Wright of the United States District Court for the District of Minnesota will decide his sentence.\n\nIn his plea, Mr. Albury acknowledged that the facts outlined by the government were accurate and that he had acted with the knowledge that he was breaking the law. His lawyers, JaneAnne Murray and Joshua Dratel, said in a statement that he viewed his disclosures as \u201can act of conscience\u201d in the face of racism at the F.B.I.\n\n\u201cIt has long been a critique of the F.B.I. that it consists of and reflects a predominantly white male culture, which, as a result, has often treated minority communities with suspicion and disrespect,\u201d the statement said. Agent Admits He Shared Classified Documents", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-13 00:00:00", "text": "WASHINGTON \u2014 The Justice Department inspector general delivered to Congress on Friday a scathing report that accused Andrew G. McCabe, the former F.B.I. deputy director, of violating the federal law enforcement agency\u2019s media policy and then repeatedly misleading investigators about his actions.\n\nThe inspector general found that Mr. McCabe, 50, had lacked candor on four occasions when questioned by investigators and faulted his decision to authorize the disclosure of information to a reporter with The Wall Street Journal in October 2016 as self-serving.\n\nIn a point-by-point rebuttal of the report, Mr. McCabe said that he had full authorization to share this information with the news media as deputy director and that he did not intentionally mislead investigators. Deputy Director Is Faulted in Scathing Inspector General Report", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-26 00:00:00", "text": "She added, \u201cIf at any point it turns out that the special master review process is going too slowly, I\u2019ll revisit the question of the scope of the special master\u2019s role.\u201d\n\nAt the hearing, prosecutors said that they had already started handing over portions of the seized materials to Mr. Cohen\u2019s lawyers, a process that could take weeks to finish. Under a system laid out by Judge Wood, Mr. Cohen\u2019s lawyers will now begin to screen them for attorney-client privilege and will pass on those records that pertain to Mr. Trump to his own lawyers, who will do the same.\n\nAt the same time, Ms. Jones will begin a simultaneous review, setting aside records that she herself concludes may be privileged. Each of the parties, Judge Wood said, will have the right to challenge decisions made by the others.\n\nWhile highly technical, the findings about which records are privileged could shape the contours of the government\u2019s investigation into Mr. Cohen. That inquiry is seeking to determine whether he broke the law by attempting to tamp down negative news coverage of the president in the run-up to the 2016 election.\n\nJudge Wood made it clear that Ms. Jones was well positioned to serve as an arbiter. For 17 years, she served on the bench in the same courthouse where the Cohen case is now being heard. Before that, she worked as a prosecutor in the United States attorney\u2019s office for the Southern District of New York. Ms. Jones was also once a senior aide to Robert M. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nAs a private lawyer, Ms. Jones has worked as a monitor or a \u201cneutral party\u201d in disputes. In 2014, she was picked to hear the appeal by Ray Rice, a former Baltimore Ravens player, of the National Football League\u2019s decision to suspend him over a domestic-abuse case.\n\nIn the past week or so, Mr. Cohen has been shedding legal exposure in separate but related court cases. On Wednesday, he filed papers in California saying he planned to invoke his Fifth Amendment right against self-incrimination in a lawsuit filed last month against President Trump by Stephanie Clifford, a former pornographic film star better known as Stormy Daniels, who claims she had an affair with the president.\n\nMr. Cohen has admitted to paying Ms. Clifford $130,000 in exchange for signing a nondisclosure agreement in October 2016, a month before the election. Ms. Clifford\u2019s suit seeks to invalidate the agreement, alleging it was void because Mr. Trump never put his name to it.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Cohen also dropped two defamation lawsuits last week against the political research firm Fusion GPS and the website BuzzFeed related to their publication of the so-called Steele dossier, an intelligence report alleging ties between the Trump campaign and Russia. In the suits, Mr. Cohen had accused both companies of disseminating the dossier even though both knew that it contained what he described as lies.\n\nAll three moves may help Mr. Cohen avoid releasing documents or providing answers to probing questions that could have been used against him in the criminal investigation. That inquiry is said to be focusing not only on hush-money payments that Mr. Cohen made to Ms. Clifford, but also on his role in keeping quiet another woman who claims she had an affair with Mr. Trump, Karen McDougal, a former Playboy model.\n\nOn Thursday, Ms. Clifford\u2019s lawyer, Michael Avenatti, filed a motion on her behalf to formally intervene in Mr. Cohen\u2019s case in New York.\n\nIn the motion, Mr. Avenatti said that Ms. Clifford\u2019s former lawyer, Keith Davidson, had communicated with Mr. Cohen about hush-money payments he had made to her, and that records of those dealings were now in the hands of prosecutors. Mr. Davidson confirmed last week that he was contacted by federal authorities after the raids on Mr. Cohen, and that he had shared some of his records with the government.\n\nJudge Wood declined to rule from the bench on Ms. Clifford\u2019s motion to intervene. And when asked in court what he and Ms. Clifford wanted, Mr. Avenatti admitted that it wasn\u2019t much.\n\n\u201cA seat at the table,\u201d he said.", "title": "Former Judge Chosen to Review Materials Seized From Michael Cohen", "authors": ["Benjamin Weiser", "Alan Feuer"]} {"date": "2018-04-21 00:00:00", "text": "The Beverly Hills lawyer who represented two women who were paid in 2016 to keep quiet about their alleged affairs with Donald J. Trump has been drawn into the federal investigation focused on Michael D. Cohen, Mr. Trump\u2019s longtime lawyer and fixer.\n\nThat lawyer, Keith M. Davidson \u2014 who finalized another legal agreement with Mr. Cohen in recent months \u2014 was contacted by federal authorities in the wake of this month\u2019s raid on Mr. Cohen\u2019s Manhattan office and has shared records with investigators, a spokesman said.\n\n\u201cMr. Davidson has been contacted by the federal authorities regarding the Michael Cohen probe in the Southern District of New York,\u201d the spokesman, Dave Wedge, said on Friday. \u201cMr. Davidson was asked to provide certain limited electronic information. He has done so and will continue to cooperate to the fullest extent possible under the law.\u201d\n\nMr. Davidson has reached multiple agreements with Mr. Cohen \u2014 one of them negotiated in late 2017, when the men brokered the silence of a Playboy model who had had an affair with a major Republican donor and Trump ally. Our office will work with our clubs in sharing best practices and employment-related processes that will support club cheerleading squads within an appropriate and supportive workplace.\u201d\n\nMs. Blackwell\u2019s letter to the league cited that statement and said: \u201cIf the NFL is serious about this statement, then this should be an acceptable settlement demand. It is one that is virtually free for the NFL and for the NFL teams and it will ensure the positive and respectful environment the NFL states is the right of the NFL cheerleaders.\u201d\n\nOne of the cheerleaders present would be Ms. Davis, who was fired from the Saintsations, the cheerleading and dance squad of the New Orleans Saints, after posting a photograph of herself on Instagram. She filed a complaint with the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission, accusing the Saints of having different standards for women and men.\n\nAnother cheerleader who would meet with the N.F.L. would be Ms. Ware, who worked three seasons with the Miami Dolphins. Earlier this month, she filed a complaint with the Florida Commission on Human Relations alleging that she was discriminated against because of her gender and religion.\n\nMs. Blackwell said the other two cheerleaders who would attend the meeting have not been determined, but they would have no association with Ms. Blackwell and would come from other teams. The four cheerleaders would discuss both the \u201cunlawful\u201d and the \u201clawful, but egregious\u201d employment practices pervasive in professional cheerleading, according to the letter.\n\n\u201cWe want change,\u201d Ms. Blackwell said. \u201cWe want the opportunity for change.\u201d\n\nIf the N.F.L. rejects the proposal, the complaints made by Davis and Ware would continue through due process. If the N.F.L. accepts it, there is still no guarantee that the meeting would be fruitful, or that it would greatly improve conditions for cheerleaders.\n\n\u201cI understand that they could meet with us, patronize us and do nothing in the end,\u201d Ms. Blackwell said. \u201cI understand that risk. Mukasey.\n\nMr. Flotron\u2019s acquittal could spell trouble for similar cases brought by the United States government. In January, federal prosecutors filed criminal charges against seven other people for spoofing, among the first criminal charges brought for suspected financial crimes during the Trump administration. The Commodity Futures Trading Commission simultaneously brought civil cases against a number of the former traders, including Mr. Flotron. The traders\u2019 behavior, a Justice Department official said at the time, reflected \u201ca systemic problem.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe Connecticut jury decided otherwise.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s a huge setback for the government,\u201d Mr. Mukasey said. \u201cWe basically smacked them in the face.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. From Nantucket and Cape Cod in Massachusetts to Newport , R.I., substantial savings are available alongside cooler temperatures and peaceful beaches.\n\nSpa Treatments, Fondue and Fire Pits in Nantucket\n\nAt the Nantucket Hotel and Resort, rooms are available in April and May starting at $195 per night, compared to $625 per night during the high season. If the weather isn\u2019t cooperating outdoors, there are several indoor activities including yoga classes, massages and board games. Fondue served by outdoor fire pits and an outdoor hot tub are a nice match for cool spring evenings.\n\nA Pair of Great Deals Near the Heart of Newport\n\nA three-tiered deck with several fire pits overlooks the Newport harbor at Gurney\u2019s Newport Resort and Marina. During the shoulder season, rooms start at $189 per night, compared to $329 per night during the high season. A complimentary water taxi connects guests to the heart of Newport for strolling along the Cliff Walk or touring the town\u2019s historic mansions.\n\nSome of Newport\u2019s mansions are also hotels, including the 33-room Grace Vanderbilt, built in 1909. Before Memorial Day weekend, rates start at $390 per night compared to $600 per night during high season. This boutique hotel has a spa with an indoor pool and a blooming garden terrace where cocktails and boozy Popsicles are served.", "title": "Four Affordable, Springtime New England Getaways", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-20 00:00:00", "text": "EXTREME CITIES\n\nThe Peril and Promise of Urban Life in the Age of Climate Change\n\nBy Ashley Dawson\n\n384 pp. Verso. $29.95.\n\nImage\n\n\u201cExtreme Cities\u201d examines the intersection of climate change and urbanization, and some of the challenges and contradictions involved. Dawson seems to be inspired by quasi-anarchist movements like Occupy Sandy. Yet to carry out the kinds of transformations he envisions, like the expropriation of fossil fuel assets, would require a very powerful government, even though he himself argues that moneyed interests have captured the state.\n\nOf particular value is Dawson\u2019s discussion of the way climate change adaptation has been sabotaged, even hijacked, by real estate interests. Cities like Miami and New York continue to build luxury buildings on waterfront land that rising sea levels are expected to overrun. Even in developing world cities like Jakarta, projects billed as climate change mitigation, like constructing artificial barrier islands, are really gussied up luxury real estate boondoggles.\n\nDawson can\u2019t identify a clear path to the kinds of extreme reforms he advocates, but at least he puts subjects on the table that many want to avoid facing up to. For instance, rising sea levels are almost guaranteed to require painful retreats from coastal settlement. But it\u2019s much sexier to talk about building green skyscrapers than it is to envision abandoning Miami Beach. The problem for writers like Dawson is that the future they foresee is so gloomy it promotes a fatalism that justifies inaction.", "title": "Four Books Explore Various Aspects of Cities Past and Present", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-19 00:00:00", "text": "Alvin Ailey, Choreographer, 1931-1989\n\nImagined at age 87\n\nThe head of his school, Denise Jefferson, would ask up-and-coming young choreographers like me to come and work with his students. And when I was at UCLA, in the early \u201980s, he invited me to see him at the Del Capri hotel, which was straight out of the \u201950s: kidney-shaped pools, bungalows where his dancers stayed. But while everyone was out by the pool, he was alone in a big suite, and I came to understand his loneliness: He did not have a partner.\n\nHe wanted to share a new piece about Jim Morrison which he said had \u201ca little Bill T. Jones in there,\u201d but I could not for the life of me tell which part reminded him of my style. Yet, in that moment, I realized how caring he was: He saw me as part of his lineage, and I think he was breathing a sigh of relief, that there was someone coming along who was not trying to be Mr. Ailey. \u2014 Bill T. Jones, choreographer\n\nThe first time I laid eyes on him was when the company performed in Philadelphia: Can you imagine him dancing in \u201cWade in the Water\u201d [Ailey\u2019s legendary 1960 piece]? And then, you saw them afterwards, loading their costumes into wicker baskets to move to the next city. It was so difficult at the beginning. They did everything themselves. Everyone talks about diversity now; he cared about inclusion while keeping the company predominantly African-American. To him, this was entwined with the Civil Rights movement. But as long as you could really dance \u2014 as long as you were truly special \u2014 he didn\u2019t care what color you were.\n\nThe happiest I ever saw him, I mean, just truly happy, was when 10 of us went to the World Festival of Negro Arts in Dakar in 1966. Duke Ellington was there, and so were Katherine Dunham and Langston Hughes. It was intense \u2014 when you do something like that in Senegal, it isn\u2019t going to be like a gala in New York \u2014 but it was magical. At the very end, when we were boarding the plane on its outside steps, he turned back and chuckled. There has never been a smile like that. \u2014 Judith Jamison, artistic director emerita of Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater\n\nImage A behind-the-scenes photo from T\u2019s shoot, with our interpretation of how Tina Chow might look if she were still alive today. Credit Photograph by Anthony Goicolea. Styled by Haidee Findlay-Levin. Hair and makeup direction by Regina Harris\n\nBehind the Story\n\nI wanted the photographer Anthony Goicolea to shoot this story, so I met with him to discuss an idea by Hanya Yanagihara, T\u2019s editor in chief, to depict Keith Haring, Alvin Ailey, Perry Ellis and Tina Chow as if they were still alive: Above all, this project was meant to celebrate these creative legends and address the cultural void their deaths \u2014 and those of so many others with AIDS-related illnesses \u2014 left. Anthony, who is 46, told me that when he was a younger artist in New York he felt that he was \u201cmissing this whole group of people who, if they hadn\u2019t died, would have been mentors.\u201d He still feels this today.\n\nThen I started talking to Regina Harris, who had done hair and makeup for three of Matthew Barney\u2019s \u201cCremaster\u201d films. She found three of the models (a casting agent scouted the fourth), people she encountered in daily life who had the right face shape and looked the appropriate age. Our stylist, Haidee Findlay-Levin, brought some scarves that were similar to ones worn by Ailey and went to visit Patricia Von Musulin, whose jewelry Tina Chow had often worn.", "title": "Four Geniuses, Gone to AIDS, as They Might Be Today", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-20 00:00:00", "text": "Israel has drawn international censure for using live fire against the mostly unarmed protesters who did not appear to present any immediately life-threatening danger to the soldiers.\n\nOn Friday, Nickolay E. Mladenov, the United Nations special coordinator for the long-stalled Israeli-Palestinian peace process, denounced the shooting of the 15-year-old as \u201coutrageous,\u201d writing on Twitter: \u201cHow does the killing of a child in #Gaza today help #peace? It doesn\u2019t! It fuels anger and breeds more killing.\u201d He called for an investigation into the killing.\n\nEven as the numbers of protesters waned, the international campaign supporting the Palestinians received a boost this week when Natalie Portman, the Oscar-winning actress, backed out of a major award ceremony meant to honor her in Jerusalem. Representatives initially cited her distress over \u201crecent events\u201d in Israel. On Friday, Ms. Portman issued a statement explaining her absence, saying, \u201cI did not want to appear as endorsing Benjamin Netanyahu.\u201d\n\nIsrael\u2019s military says it is acting to prevent any mass crossing of the fence and to prevent attacks against Israeli soldiers and nearby communities. The military said it was looking into the reports of the fatalities.\n\nOn Friday, the Israeli military said in a statement that people participating in what it described as riots were \u201cattempting to approach the security infrastructures,\u201d burning tires and trying to fly kites over the border with burning items attached to them. Several crossed into Israel, the statement said, and \u201cwere extinguished when required.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nThe military added that it would \u201cnot allow any harm to security infrastructure that protects Israeli civilians, and will act against the violent rioters and terrorists who threaten either.\u201d The troops responded with tear gas and live fire.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAs in previous weeks, no injuries were reported on the Israeli side.\n\nThe protests began as a grass-roots campaign but were quickly adopted by Hamas, the Islamist militant group that controls Gaza. They are meant to draw international attention to the 11-year blockade imposed by Israel and Egypt on the isolated, impoverished coastal territory. The protests also are meant to punctuate Palestinian demands for the return to lands in what is now Israel.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe organizers of the protests, named the Great Return March, originally said the idea had been for a peaceful, family-style six-week sit-in at tent encampments erected about 700 yards from the fence, with weekly marches building up to a peak on May 15. That is when Palestinians mark the Nakba, or the catastrophe, of the foundation of Israel and the war surrounding its creation in 1948, during which hundreds of thousands of Palestinians fled or were expelled from their homes in what is now Israel. Many of the refugees ended up in Gaza.\n\nIsrael says the campaign has been taken over by Hamas, which Israel, like much of the Western world, classifies as a terrorist organization.\n\nIn leaflets dropped from the air on Friday the military warned protesters, in Arabic, to stay away from the fence, and told them to ignore instructions from Hamas, which Israel says is exploiting the protesters for its own political interests. While a few confronted the troops, most of the protesters stood by, watching.\n\nOne protester, Abdallah Daoud, 16, explained why he was participating. With his face black with soot from the burning tires and slingshot in hand, he said: \u201cThere is no money, there is nothing. I want to be a martyr because of the siege,\u201d a reference to the blockade. \u201cI cannot get out of Gaza. There is no income.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nIn a new tactic, protesters including whole families in the Shejaiya area of eastern Gaza moved tents forward to about 300 yards from the fence, considered the edge of the danger zone.\n\nSome Shejaiya protesters built a cage, like a mock prison cell, containing effigies of two Israeli soldiers whose bodies are being held by Hamas in Gaza, and two Israeli citizens also believed held by Hamas there. The entrance to the Shejaiya protest site included a large poster with pictures and names of those killed during the first three Fridays.\n\nDuring a visit to the protest area, Ismail Haniya, the political leader of the Hamas organization, said: \u201cBe ready and prepared for the human flood on all the borders of Palestine inside and outside the occupied lands on the anniversary of the Nakba.\u201d\n\nIslamic Jihad, an extremist group that often rivals Hamas in Gaza, went further, releasing a video on Thursday showing Israeli officers, including a senior general, in its sights as they toured the Israeli side of the fence.\n\nAvigdor Lieberman, Israel\u2019s hard-line defense minister, visited the Gaza border area on Friday. \u201cWhat we have seen in these four weeks is that every week there are less and less people on the one hand,\u201d he said, \u201cand on the other hand, there is much more terror activity.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHe warned, \u201cWhoever makes threats will lose in the end.\u201d", "title": "Four Killed in Gaza, as Weekly Protests Shrink", "authors": ["Isabel Kershner", "Iyad Abuheweila"]} {"date": "2018-04-19 00:00:00", "text": "\u2022 A set of 14 gold belt plaques.\n\n\u2022 A Jizhou stoneware vase.\n\nThe police have not put a price on the haul, saying that the items vary in monetary value but that their \u201ccultural significance is priceless.\u201d\n\nImage A carving of jade mandarin ducks with lotus flowers was among the items stolen. Credit Museum of East Asian Art\n\nThe police said the thieves fled in a dark sport utility vehicle. Officers have seized a white Ford van that was stolen and left at the scene. The police have appealed to the public for information to solve the crime, and are scouring CCTV footage for clues.\n\nDetective Sgt. Matthew Reed said in a statement, \u201cDue to the items stolen and the speed of the burglary, we suspect this to be a targeted attack with the artifacts possibly stolen to order.\u201d\n\nNicole Chiang, the museum\u2019s curator, said in a statement: \u201cWe are deeply shocked and saddened by the burglary as we are preparing for our 25th anniversary celebrations. Not only do the stolen objects have significant historical and cultural value, they also hold irreplaceable emotional value for our founder.\u201d\n\nThe museum was founded by Brian McElney, a former lawyer who lived in Hong Kong for many years, and whose own collection of East Asian art formed the initial basis of its holdings.\n\nThe museum \u2014 which boasts a collection representing more than 7,000 years \u2014 will remain closed for the next few weeks while employees take an inventory. Save To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nSeason 3 of \u201cUnReal\u201d couldn\u2019t quite recapture the magic of Season 1, but to its credit it avoided many of the mistakes of Season 2. This two-part season finale brings in the \u201csuitress\u201d \u2014 bachelorette \u2014 story for a solid landing. Our antiheroine Rachel (Shiri Appleby) remains up there with Sally Draper on the list of TV\u2019s most damaged characters, so much of this season\u2019s fun has come from the zesty manipulator Quinn (Constance Zimmer) and from the not-as-dopey-as-she-seems Madison (Genevieve Buechner), both of whom get satisfying arcs.\n\n\u201cUnReal\u201d has already been renewed for a fourth season, and perhaps a \u201cBachelor in Paradise\u201d-style bacchanalia could give the show some of its audaciousness back, maybe free it from its more plodding miseries.\n\nI Want Something Sporty With an Edge\n\nHank Azaria, left, and Tyrel Jackson Williams in \u201cBrockmire.\u201d Alfonso Bresciani/IFC\n\n\u2018Brockmire\u2019\n\nWhen to watch: Wednesday at 10 p.m., on IFC.\n\nWednesday at 10 p.m., on IFC. Save To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\n\u201cBrockmire\u201d remains one of the filthiest shows on television \u2014 but in a gleeful, sincere way, not in a mopey or morose way. Hank Azaria stars as a debauched baseball broadcaster, now demoted to calling games in the minors. Season 1, available on Hulu, is a booze-fueled rom-com between Azaria and Amanda Peet, who plays a small-time team owner; Season 2, which begins on IFC this week, focuses much more on just Azaria, and Peet barely appears in the eight episodes. She\u2019s terrific on the show, so this is a shame, but Season 2 is still raunchy and funny and fun, even in her absence.\n\nI Want a Celebratory Series\n\nA scene from \u201cMy House.\u201d Viceland\n\n\u2018My House\u2019\n\nWhen to watch: Wednesday at 10:30 p.m., on Viceland.\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nIf you\u2019ve never seen \u201cParis Is Burning,\u201d start with \u201cParis Is Burning.\u201d But if you\u2019re curious what the modern incarnation of the queer ballroom scene in New York City is, this new series will vogue its way into your heart. Even though \u201cMy House\u201d uses a lot of direct-to-the-camera monologues, this is much more documentary than canned reality show.\n\n0\n\nI Want to Crawl Into a Hole\n\nA scene from \u201cThe Handmaid\u2019s Tale.\u201d George Kraychyk/Hulu\n\n\u2018The Handmaid\u2019s Tale\u2019\n\nWhen to watch: Season 2 starts Wednesday, on\n\nSeason 2 starts Wednesday, on Hulu Save To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nTorture, suffering, violence, grief \u2014 you name it, \u201cThe Handmaid\u2019s Tale\u201d will find a way to bring it to you in its most misogynistic, nightmarish form. Sure, it\u2019s gross to lose a fingernail, but what if you lost it because of environmental toxins in the work camp where you\u2019re enslaved because you\u2019re a lesbian? Yep, that\u2019s a worse way! Congratulations, \u201cThe Handmaid\u2019s Tale,\u201d you\u2019ve done it again.\n\nSeason 2 of the show picks up with Offred (Elisabeth Moss), formerly known as June, as she tries to escape Gilead, the oppressive religious society America has turned into in the show\u2019s hellish near-future. Season 1 hewed closely to the source novel by Margaret Atwood early on, and then expanded as the season progressed. This season moves past the events in the book, and is poorer for it: June\u2019s inner monologue is less compelling, even though her character is becoming more extraordinary within her world.\n\nThe show relies too heavily on Moss\u2019s panicked stares and ominous panting, and some of these episodes can feel like one agonizing tension montage. But in the six episodes made available to critics, the season is clearly building to something, and it can still be utterly engrossing. (Hulu is making the first two episodes of Season 2 available Wednesday, adding a new episode each Wednesday after that.)", "title": "Four Shows to Watch This Week", "authors": ["Margaret Lyons"]} {"date": "2018-04-30 00:00:00", "text": "Watching is The New York Times\u2019s TV and film recommendation website. Sign up for our thrice-weekly newsletter here.\n\nI crave superb stand-up\n\n\u2018John Mulaney: Kid Gorgeous at Radio City\u2019\n\nWhen to watch: Starting Tuesday, on\n\nStarting Tuesday, on Netflix Save To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nJohn Mulaney is one of the best, most consistent stand-up comics working today, and his new special, \u201cKid Gorgeous,\u201d is practically perfect. It\u2019s quintessential Mulaney, going in on the peculiarities of childhood \u2014 here, stranger-danger assemblies \u2014 and the baffling illogic of adulthood. He\u2019s incensed by his college\u2019s fund-raising requests, given that he already paid, by his estimation, $120,000 in tuition. \u201cI gave you more money than the Civil War cost, and you [ahem] spent it already?\u201d Yes, as in his previous work, there is also a section about the mundanities of attending Catholic church. (\u201cThe homily is when the priest does a book report that\u2019s also stand-up comedy.\u201d)\n\nA lot of stand-up comedy is angry, or it can involve a certain amount of rage. The best part of Mulaney\u2019s comedy is that even as he\u2019s shouting in frustration, there\u2019s no gloom or nastiness in the delivery \u2014 he\u2019s practically radiant as he paces the stage.\n\n(If you saw his recent \u201cS.N.L.\u201d monologue, those jokes were pulled from this larger work.)\n\nI want a zingy comedy I\u2019ve completely missed\n\nFrom left, Kim Matula, Nathan Lee Graham and Ed Weeks in \u201cLA TO VEGAS.\u201d Fox\n\n\u2018L.A. to Vegas\u2019\n\nWhen to watch: Now on\n\nNow on Hulu , and also Tuesday at 9 p.m., on Fox. Save To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nWhen \u201cHappy Endings\u201d was canceled a few years ago, a full half of the internet became \u201cHappy Endings\u201d tribute posts. But now there is a show that shares that show\u2019s breakneck one-liners, pop references and wild-eyed energy \u2014 heck, Zachary Knighton is on this \u2014 and I cannot even convince my own sister to try it. If you like quippy, unsentimental comedies, and if the idea of a Bible-themed costume party called \u201cFashion of the Christ\u201d appeals, try this.\n\nSo far, 14 episodes of \u201cL.A. to Vegas\u201d have aired, all of which are on Hulu; I like it from the get-go, but it picks up a bit with Episode 5, and you can just start there. This week\u2019s broadcast episode is the season finale, and the show has not yet been renewed for a second season.\n\n0\n\nActually, a different zingy comedy I\u2019ve completely missed\n\nFrom left, Andy Favreau, J.J. Totah and Anders Holm in \u201cChampions.\u201d Evans Vestal Ward/NBC\n\n\u2018Champions\u2019\n\nWhen to watch: Now on\n\nNow on Hulu , and Thursday at 9:30 p.m. on NBC. Save To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nSpeaking of shows airing season finales this week that have not yet been renewed for a second season, behold \u201cChampions,\u201d created in part by Mindy Kaling and with a similar tone, pace and cast as \u201cThe Mindy Project.\u201d (Don\u2019t be confused: Ed Weeks, who played Jeremy on \u201cThe Mindy Project,\u201d is actually on \u201cL.A. to Vegas,\u201d not this.)\n\n\u201cChampions\u201d centers on Michael (J.J. Totah), a 13-year-old boy who was raised in Ohio by his single mom (Kaling, who appears occasionally) and has now been sent to live with his dad (Anders Holm) and uncle (Andy Favreau) in New York so he can attend the performing arts high school of his dreams.\n\nThe show has a few too many supporting characters \u2014 something \u201cThe Mindy Project\u201d struggled with, too \u2014 but there are plenty of jokes to go around, so it\u2019s hard to be too down on any one of them. The conflict is low-stakes, and usually boils down to characters not knowing the best way to express affection; even the occasional snipe does more to illuminate the character delivering it than the character being insulted. Think \u201cBrooklyn Nine-Nine.\u201d \u201cChampions\u201d isn\u2019t a \u201cfeel-good\u201d show in that it\u2019s unbearably corny or upbeat, but it is a show that feels good to watch. If you\u2019re maxed out on murder shows, try this.\n\nI\u2019m experiencing the mental equivalent of having my jaw wired shut; I need a show I can drink through a straw\n\nOlympic figure skater Adam Rippon will compete on the new season of \u201cDancing with the Stars: Athletes.\u201d Craig Sjodin/ABC\n\n\u2018Dancing With the Stars\u2019\n\nWhen to watch: Monday at 8 p.m., on ABC.\n\nI\u2019m not historically a big \u201cDancing With the Stars\u201d person, but my interest is piqued ever so slightly because this is an all-athlete season. Kareem Abdul-Jabbar, Jamie Anderson, Jennie Finch Daigle, Johnny Damon, Tonya Harding, Chris Mazdzer, Mirai Nagasu, Josh Norman, Arike Ogunbowale and Adam Rippon are all going to dance for us, the thirsty and decrepit public.", "title": "Four Shows to Watch This Week", "authors": ["Margaret Lyons"]} {"date": "2018-04-16 00:00:00", "text": "Watching is The New York Times\u2019s TV and film recommendation website. Sign up for our thrice-weekly newsletter here.\n\nI Want a British Cop Show With an Edge\n\nElaine Cassidy in \u201cNo Offence.\u201d Ryan McNamara/Acorn TV\n\n\u2018No Offence\u2019\n\nWhen to watch: Now, on\n\nNow, on Acorn TV Save To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\n\u201cNo Offence\u201d hails from Paul Abbott, the creator of the original British \u201cShameless,\u201d and it shares that show\u2019s shaggy irreverence and scrappiness. Joanna Scanlan (\u201cGetting On,\u201d \u201cPuppy Love\u201d) stars as Detective Inspector Vivienne Deering, an often raunchy boss whose precinct is investigating several serious crimes, including tracking a serial killer who appears to be targeting women with Down syndrome. As is often the case on police shows, the detectives get a little too personally involved, especially Detective Constable Dinah Kowalska (Elaine Cassidy) \u2014 she invites a young woman who escaped the murderer\u2019s clutches to come live with her.\n\nThe show\u2019s dark humor does not cover up the fact that it\u2019s a straight-up dark drama, where violence and depravity abound. But at just eight episodes, it\u2019s a beautiful balance of seriousness and bingeability. Oddly, the score sounds an awful lot like the score from \u201cJustified,\u201d adding a surprising clash of context for fans of clever cop shows.\n\nI Want Something Ridiculous but Good\n\nA contestant on \u201cForged in Fire: Knife or Death.\u201d History\n\n\u2018Forged in Fire: Knife or Death\u2019\n\nWhen to watch: Tuesday at 10 p.m., on History.\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nThis spinoff of the popular blade-making series \u201cForged in Fire\u201d is the best kind of good-bad there is, self-serious about something completely goofy. It\u2019s an obstacle course show, in which contestants bring their own knives \u2014 \u201cblades,\u201d excuse me \u2014 and then race to slice their ways through ice blocks, buckets of sand, a dead fish and other blade-worthy objects. It\u2019s pretty dumb! I loved it.\n\nIf you like \u201cForged in Fire,\u201d \u201cSteve Austin\u2019s Broken Skull Challenge,\u201d \u201cAmerican Ninja Warrior\u201d or the marksmanship series \u201cTop Shot,\u201d or if you remember fondly the primal thrill of being handed a cardboard wrapping-paper tube as a small child and being set loose to \u201craaaah\u201d your way down a hallway, this is for you.\n\n0\n\nI Want Something Serious but Not Depressing\n\nA scene from \u201cCivilizations.\u201d Nutopia\n\n\u2018Civilizations\u2019\n\nWhen to watch: Tuesday at 8 p.m., on PBS (check local listings).\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nPeople make stuff. They make paintings and pottery and music, and this nine-part show argues convincingly that these acts of creativity are what define us as a species. This is the quintessence of a PBS mini-series, engaging and nutritious.\n\nI Want Whatever the Youths Are Having\n\nFrom left, foreground, KJ Apa, Lili Reinhart, Camila Mendes and Jordan Calloway in \u201cRiverdale.\u201d Katie Yu/CW\n\n\u2018Riverdale\u2019\n\nWhen to watch: Wednesday at 8 p.m., on the CW.\n\nWednesday at 8 p.m., on the CW. Save To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nA musical episode is now a rite of passage for teen shows, and the dark and referential collage-come-to-life \u201cRiverdale\u201d has its song-and-dance installment this week. The kids of Murdertown, U.S.A., are putting on \u201cCarrie: The Musical\u201d (I can\u2019t lie; I was hoping for \u201cBe More Chill\u201d) and things get bloody! As you might imagine!\n\n\u201cRiverdale\u201d lends itself to goofy excess, thanks to its smoky aesthetic and soap-inflected dialogue, so if you\u2019ve been looking for an excuse to jump in on this \u201cTwin Peaks Jr.\u201d kind of show, this is a good episode to sample. The singing is actually fine, but \u201cRiverdale\u201d seems populated with movers, not dancers.", "title": "Four Shows to Watch This Week", "authors": ["Margaret Lyons"]} {"date": "2018-04-11 00:00:00", "text": "Fran Bera\u2019s fascination with flight began when she took an airplane-themed carnival ride as a young girl in Michigan in the 1930s.\n\nAs a teenager she hitchhiked more than 30 miles to an airfield, where she worked odd jobs and saved for flight lessons. She earned her pilot\u2019s license at 16, and by 24, the youngest allowable age, she became a designated examiner, allowed to certify new pilots.\n\nMs. Bera went on to win more than a dozen air races. She set an unbroken National Aeronautic Association record for highest altitude attained in a twin-engine Piper Aztec, pushing that plane to an altitude better suited for a jet. And, she said, she once flew a small plane from California to Siberia on a whim.\n\nMs. Bera also oversaw more than 3,000 check rides, or licensing examinations, for new pilots, and in the 1980s stopped counting her flight hours after she had accumulated 25,000.", "title": "Fran Bera, Competitive, Record-Breaking Aviator, Is Dead at 93", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-25 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Macron\u2019s criticism of his host\u2019s policies contrasted sharply with \u201cle bromance\u201d with President Trump, which continued at the Trumps\u2019 first state dinner. He oversees about 375,000 military and civilian personnel.\n\n_____\n\nPhoto\n\n\u2022 In the Philippines, a cleanup or an invasion?\n\nTourists will be barred from the central Philippine island of Boracay for six months, starting today, as President Rodrigo Duterte vows to clean up what he calls an environmental \u201ccesspool.\u201d\n\nMr. Duterte ordered Boracay to be closed this month, saying that the water \u201csmells\u201d and that it poses a danger to people\u2019s health. But residents fear that the island will be militarized and that its tourism industry, which brought in more than $1 billion last year, may never recover.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n_____\n\nPhoto\n\n\u2022 Bangladesh struggles to move on from the Rana Plaza disaster.\n\nThis week was the fifth anniversary of the deadliest garment industry accident in modern history: More than 1,100 people were killed in a horrific building collapse and more than 2,500 were injured.\n\nAt the time, hundreds of factories were shuttered, and today the land where Rana Plaza once stood is overgrown with weeds. But as the garment industry returns to business as usual, critics say that the jailing of labor leaders and the expiration of safeguards show that little has been learned.\n\nBusiness\n\nPhoto\n\n\u2022 Chinese tech companies are hiring female \u201cmotivators\u201d to help overworked male coders relieve stress through conversation, activities \u2014 and massages.\n\n\u2022 Takeda, a Japanese drugmaker, reached a tentative agreement to buy Ireland-based Shire for $64 billion, in one of the biggest pharma deals to date.\n\n\u2022 Kobe Steel\u2019s shares fell sharply as the Japanese authorities investigate the company\u2019s data falsification scandal.\n\n\u2022 Foreign auto executives at China\u2019s annual auto show this week said Beijing\u2019s plan to open its car market will change little, and is unlikely to avert a trade war with Washington.\n\n\u2022 U.S. stocks were mixed. As the series moves past Margaret Atwood\u2019s novel, it feels, as it should, like the end of the world, our chief TV critic writes.\n\nBack Story\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s a dictatorship at the door and a democracy on the dance floor.\u201d\n\nThat\u2019s what Andy Warhol said was the key to success for Studio 54, the famously wild New York City nightclub that opened its doors on April 26, 1977.\n\nDonald and Ivana Trump were among the first guests \u2014 but they arrived early in the night. It would be hours before it turned into a hedonistic dance party of epic proportions.\n\n\u201cAll of us knew that night that we weren\u2019t at the opening of a discoth\u00e8que but the opening of something historical,\u201d said Robin Leach, who went on to host \u201cLifestyles of the Rich and Famous.\u201d\n\nHis comments were included in the book \u201cThe Last Party: Studio 54, Disco, and the Culture of the Night,\u201d by Anthony Haden-Guest.\n\nThe owners of Studio 54, Steve Rubell and Ian Schrager, came to be known as the \u201cfirst pashas of disco.\u201d Above, Mr. Rubell, Liza Minnelli, Bianca Jagger and Mr. Warhol at the first anniversary party.\n\nBut just two years after opening, the owners were charged with tax evasion for skimming from club receipts. After serving time in prison, they went on to open hotels and clubs.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Rubell died in 1989, and Mr. Schrager was pardoned by President Barack Obama just before he left office.\n\nKaren Zraick wrote today\u2019s Back Story.\n\n_____\n\nYour Morning Briefing is published weekday mornings and updated online.
