Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nHave a good weekend,\n\nJessica\n\n______\n\nIn the News\n\nPhoto\n\n\u2022 Cliff Huxtable was Cosby\u2019s sickest joke: Wesley Morris, culture critic at The Times, wrote in the wake of Thursday\u2019s verdict on the complicated mental math required to process what \u201cAmerica\u2019s Dad\u201d did for many young black men like him: inspire. \u201cIn the 1980s he made the black American family seem \u2018just like us,\u2019\u201d he writes.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u2022 Who gets a shot at redemption? Murmurs of a possible comeback for figures felled in recent months by accusatons of sexual misconduct, including the comedian Louis C.K. and the chef Mario Batali has raised the question: What does this mean for #MeToo? You can read about it in Vox, Jezebel, and The Ringer. Also in The Times, what #MeToo means to middle schoolers and teens.\n\n\u2022 What is an \u2018incel\u2019? The term used by the man accused of killing 10 people when he plowed his van into them on a Toronto street stands for \u201cinvoluntary celibate.\u201d People who identify themselves as such blame women for denying them their right to sex. Read more on the phenomenon in The Times, The Guardian, and Elle, as well as a great Twitter thread here. Jessica Valenti, the founder of Feministing, expounds on the theme in her New York Times Op-Ed, When Misogynists Become Terrorists.\n\n\u2022 Corner office parity? A new study finds that there may be no pay gap between male and female CEOs of publicly traded companies. Which seems like great news, until you remember that there are more men named \u201cJames\u201d than there are women overall among Fortune 500 executives (more on this below). .\n\n\u2022 Census DTR. For the first time ever, the 2020 U.S. Census will ask about same-sex relationships. According to Pew, the responses for \u201chusband or wife\u201d and \u201cunmarried partner\u201d will be broken out into \u201copposite-sex\u201d and \u201csame-sex\u201d options.\n\n\u2022 Cryptocurrency isn\u2019t just for tech bros. Meet nine women who are changing the blockchain game, courtesy of Glamour.\n\n\u2022 N.F.L. cheerleader truce? They\u2019ve offered to settle for $1 and a \u201cgood faith\u201d meeting with N.F.L. Commissioner Roger Goodell.\n\n\u2022 The only woman who has \u201cit all.\u201d Yes, she exists! \u201cI have two kids and the unspoken pressure to act like they don\u2019t exist when I\u2019m on a conference call. I have a professional mandate to know what\u2019s happening in pop culture and an 11-year-old who tells me to \u2018stop trying to act so cool.\u2019\u201d ICYMI, this is a lovely little LOL from The New Yorker\u2019s Shouts & Murmers.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n______\n\nBy The Numbers (Well, Actually, Names)\n\nPhoto\n\nJAMES\n\nFewer Fortune 500 executives are women than men with this name.\n\nJOHN\n\nFewer Republican senators (as well as Democratic governors) are women than men with this name.\n\nMICHAEL\n\nFewer top-grossing film directors are women than men with this name (along with the name James).\n\n\n\nRead the article in The Upshot.\n\n\n\n____\n\nOverlooked But Not Forgotten\n\nSince 1851, the vast majority of obituaries in The New York Times have been about men. Last month, we began a series called Overlooked in which we are writing the obituaries for important and interesting women who never got them. This week, we remember Maria Bochkareva, a Russian army officer who led an all-female unit into battle during World War I.\n\n______\n\nFrom the Archives\n\nPhoto\n\nSay, hypothetically, Billie Jean King and Bobby Riggs were lunching at a restaurant. To whom would you present the check? What if a doctor and her husband were invited to a holiday party. Should they be addressed as Dr. and Mrs.?\n\nThese are the questions the witty Lois Guild presented in this 1973 article, about manners for \u201cliberated persons\u201d (that\u2019s you, right?), which we dug out of The New York Times archives. The author noted that in the personal manners category, she would indeed give up her seat on the subway to a man with a baby \u2014 unless he called her an \u201cauthoress.\u201d\n\n______\n\nLike this article? Sign up here to get Gender Letter delivered to your in-box. Want us in your Instagram? We gotchu. Tell us what you think here.", "title": "Gender Letter: The Culture Is Changing. Cosby is Proof.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-23 00:00:00", "text": "[For more coverage of women and gender issues, subscribe to Gender Letter, a new newsletter.]\n\nThe new study, however, appears to be exhaustive.\n\n\u201cWe controlled for several possible confounding factors,\u201d the authors wrote in a post on the website of Harvard Law School\u2019s Forum on Corporate Governance and Financial Regulation. Those factors included the chief executives\u2019 tenure, characteristics of the firms (size, performance and risk), and the size and independence of the boards.\n\nThe authors added that their model accounted for the fact that compensation for chief executives and the number of women in the role had increased over time. \u201cOur results reveal that there is no significant difference between male and female C.E.O. compensation,\u201d they said.\n\nThe study also \u201ccasts doubt on the veracity\u201d of the previous studies showing that female chief executives were paid more. \u201cThe truth seems to be that, once relevant confounding factors are accounted for, male and female C.E.O.s earn similar compensation, which is what standard economic theory would suggest and most people would like to see happen in society,\u201d they said.\n\nOne of the most interesting theories about why women may have bridged the pay divide at the highest levels has been offered by previous studies and experts: that a premium has been applied because there is such a limited supply of women in the chief executive role. Some readers may find that an offensive idea on its face \u2014 that women in effect are being overpaid because of their scarcity \u2014 but it\u2019s one that has gained currency among some academics.\n\nIn an interview, Professor Mortal said she was surprised by the results of her own study. \u201cI would have expected that women were paid less,\u201d she said.\n\n\u201cThere is still is discrimination against women in getting to the top,\u201d she added, but said she welcomed the news that women were well paid \u201conce they actually are there.\u201d", "title": "Gender Pay Gap? Maybe Not in the Corner Office, a Study Shows", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-04 00:00:00", "text": "Want the Australia Letter by email? Sign up and forward to your friends for heaps of global coverage and provocative Australia insight.\n\n______\n\nWhen Francesca Donner, director of The New York Times Gender Initiative, arrived in Australia a few weeks ago, she was almost immediately swept up in the wave of #MeToo and news media activities.\n\nIn addition to public panels on the #MeToo movement, there were conferences, university discussions and a dinner with young female New York Times readers to talk about our coverage.\n\nEveryone, it seemed, had something to say about #MeToo.\n\nOn her way back to New York, Francesca jotted down a few impressions about Australia\u2019s gender movement and how it compares with what\u2019s happening in the United States.", "title": "Gender Progress in Macho Australia?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-11 00:00:00", "text": "With that in mind, please bring your friends and loved ones into that conversation. Forward this newsletter, share the sign-up page and tell people why you think it\u2019s worth joining our little email community.\n\nThe more this Letter grows, the more the conversation will deepen.\n\nNow for your answers to our questions about #MeToo in Australia, gender and where it\u2019s heading next, followed by stories of the week, and a call from our food critic for restaurant recommendations in Perth.\n\nWe Need More Female Leaders\n\nI think the #MeToo movement in Australia \u2014 which has gone after a couple of high-profile media personalities \u2014 has not been as visible or vocal as in the U.S.\n\nYou mention the defamation laws, which is one reason why, but I also believe it\u2019s because we don\u2019t have a strong female leader advocating for women\u2019s rights. Don\u2019t get me wrong, there are some excellent investigative journalists exposing serious issues (Tracey Spicer, Kate McClymont etc.), but we don\u2019t have a Rose McGowan or Ashley Judd \u2014 someone who is willing to speak out not just about their own experience but about the broader discrimination and harassment issues facing women. As a result the #MeToo movement relies on investigative media stories for attention and when the news moves on, #MeToo gets left behind. I think the other constraining factor is a cultural one. Many Australians like to say \u2018we\u2019re nothing like the U.S.\u2019 For example we\u2019re not (or at least we think we aren\u2019t) as litigious, we don\u2019t love guns and our politics isn\u2019t as brash or cultlike (I\u2019m thinking of all the clapping when a politician gives a speech). This gives Australians an excuse to say #MeToo is really an issue for Americans, not us. I don\u2019t believe this, but it\u2019s a belief that sits below the surface for many. A local leader of the movement could address this. Gender progress here is the same as everywhere else. The #MeToo movement has brought to light the unacceptable and appalling behavior of many men. However, this reflects only what\u2019s above the surface. It\u2019s what\u2019s below the surface that needs to be addressed if we want real, long-lasting change. And what sits below the surface is the gendered way we treat girls (and boys) from the day they are born. We accept and excuse certain behaviors for boys (I\u2019m thinking of boisterous loud and aggressive behaviors). If as a society we can look at a behavior and say it is acceptable or not, and take the gendered bias away, then we would have a fairer world. Girls and boys will grow up expecting the same behavior from each other, and call each other out when they don\u2019t. Alas, I have grown up in a world that hasn\u2019t done this, and I see my 6-year-old daughter facing the same bias.\n\n\u2014 Pip Nagy\n\nRipples Not Tidal Waves\n\nIf the world thinks of us as a particularly macho country, it\u2019s the inertia of our popular cultural image. It\u2019s a \u2018Crocodile Dundee\u2019 vision of Australia as rough-speaking, rugged, rural and masculine. But Australia is changed and changing, shedding its caricatures. Today, more than a third of Australians were born overseas. Two-thirds of us live in capital cities and women outnumber men in all but one of them. Not to mention Paul Hogan hasn\u2019t lived in Australia since last century. There will always be Australians who maintain and proclaim our so-called macho image. However for many, and for the majority of younger people, this image is an anachronism. Gender progress reflects this change, demonstrated in the #MeToo and Time\u2019s Up conversations flourishing in Twitter feeds and public spaces. The global wave of accountability has had an impact beyond public panels and television specials. #MeToo has played first fiddle to several falls from grace in Australia, among them an iconic entertainer and a high-profile politician. It has infiltrated debates about national and institutional policy and civil and criminal law. If the ripples in Australia have not matched the tidal wave seen in the States, it may only be a matter of time until a critical mass of Australian voices joins the global conversation. For the moment, whether our hopes are too high or expectations too low depends on who is being asked the question.\n\n\u2014 Jill Masters\n\n#MeToo and Regional Australia\n\nWhat Francesca observed is the two Australias. Australia is a largely progressive, politically engaged, compassionate nation \u2014 #auspol is one of the most active Twitter discussions in the world. The community is highly reactive to issues of the day, cares a lot about public perception and the \u2018pub test,\u2019 and egalitarianism / equality (to the point of suffocating ambition and achievement, cf. \u2018Tall Poppy Syndrome\u2019) is one of Australia\u2019s strongest national values. We got right on board with #MeToo. We were primed to do so by a strong debate around domestic violence that had been riding high since Rosie Batty was Australian of the Year. In a way, our shift in psyche was not as severe as it was in other countries. Tracey Spicer trying to claim credit or ownership of it, and last week implying that it was a thing that happened in America to differentiate it from her Now campaign, has actually been quite infuriating and insulting to the many hundreds of thousands of Australian women who said #MeToo, including myself. But there are other parts of our culture, particularly in rural areas, that mitigate that liberation, and the fight against sexual and domestic violence. The tolerance of such violence parlays into the tolerance of Barnaby Joyce. I come from New England \u2014 it\u2019s my home electorate \u2014 and I know every square inch of it well. The University of New England has the highest rate of sexual harassment and assault of any university campus in the country. Smaller towns in the area like Inverell have domestic violence and sexual/indecent assault rates as much as two and half times the state average. There are few local supports for domestic violence and sexual assault victims. The communities are so small and social pressure so high that most crimes of this nature remain unreported. In the city, and even larger coastal towns, there is a refusal to accept such behavior; support services are provided; and #MeToo resonated strongly. #MeToo was heard in places like New England, but they didn\u2019t join in \u2014 to do so would have meant social death. With such small populations, spread out over such vast land spaces, you need your neighbors, you tolerate abuse, and you don\u2019t speak out about such troubles. You keep the peace so you can stay living in your town \u2014 the next town might be two or three hours\u2019 drive away, not 10 minutes, and there\u2019s certainly little to no public transport to get you out of town if you needed it. Given that, you won\u2019t be surprised to learn that more young women than young men leave their rural communities and do not return.\n\n\u2014 Raphaella Kathryn Crosby\n\nThe Perils of Feminism?\n\nThe change in the role of women due to second-wave feminism in the 1960s is the key cause of Australia\u2019s negative birthrate and the aging of the population. On this basis feminism is biologically dysfunctional whilst patriarchality is biologically functional. Therefore the promotion of feminist sexual equality in politics, business and society in Australia is not the way for the greatest number of young women to find happiness in marriage and children or in the best interests of Australia. So how do we change our currently biologically dysfunctional culture to one in which the maximum number of young women can find happiness in marriage and children and restore a positive birthrate? I don\u2019t know the answer, but if there is one, I suspect it will come from women, not men \u2014 and from women born in the 21st century. In the interim, helping Australians understand the negative impacts of feminism and not supporting or promoting it further would seem a prudent course. When a society uses its young women for wealth creation, rather than procreation, it eats the seed corn of its future. As a result of feminism women are no longer pregnant and barefoot in the kitchen but now are increasingly well heeled and childless in the boardroom.\n\n\u2014 Paul McFadyen\n\nGendered Everything\n\nI am a junior in college in the U.S. and am currently studying in Australia for the semester, in Brisbane. Before I left, I was under the impression that the cultural norms of gender would be similar to what I had experienced in the U.S. \u2014 not perfect but actively seeking ways to improve itself for the most part, or at least in my opinion. News such as the legalization of gay marriage and the extent of the #MeToo movement here along with other stories you had mentioned convinced me of this. But the first thing I noticed when I got here was how gendered everything was. The floors of my dorm were gendered, my orientation week consistently paired people only in opposite genders, the police officer who came in to talk about sexual assault proposed that the girls play up their feminine stereotypes to trick the assumed sex-obsessed males in order to prevent rape. In my residential college of over three hundred people, I can only name one person who is openly gay. During dinner, one of the freshmen asked me if it was true \u201cif the United States really had people who didn\u2019t believe in male or female, and called themselves they instead\u201d as the rest of the table snickered. In general, I find that the men are overwhelmingly masculine and the women are overwhelmingly feminine in a polarizing sort of way. This is all while I take classes at the university in anthropology in which we talk openly about the same topics in gender and sexuality as I did in those classes back home. To summarize, I have found through living here that the external culture and internal culture of gender and sexuality have not quite aligned in the way I had assumed. This might just be the demographic I am most exposed to, or the city I am living in, but it truly has been quite surprising.\n\n\u2014 Ann Bisognano\n\n______", "title": "Gender and #MeToo in Australia: Where Do We Begin?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-23 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nPresident George Bush was hospitalized in Houston on Sunday after contracting an infection that spread to his blood, his office said on Monday.\n\nMr. Bush, 93, was \u201cresponding to treatments and appears to be recovering,\u201d said Jim McGrath, his spokesman.\n\nHis hospitalization at Houston Methodist Hospital came one day after the funeral for his wife, Barbara Bush, who died on Tuesday in her bedroom with the former president at her side. He was photographed at the funeral in a wheelchair with his son George W. and Laura Bush; Bill and Hillary Clinton; Barack and Michelle Obama; and Melania Trump.\n\nOn Friday, George Bush and his daughter, Dorothy Bush Koch, greeted mourners who came to St. Martin\u2019s Episcopal Church to pay their respects to the former first lady.\n\nMrs. Bush was 92, and the couple had been married for 73 years.\n\nMr. Bush, who served as president from 1989 to 1993, has had a series of health problems in the last few years, and was hospitalized twice after contracting pneumonia last year.", "title": "George Bush Is Hospitalized One Day After Wife\u2019s Funeral", "authors": ["Daniel Victor"]} {"date": "2018-04-07 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cI think the game has been cleaned up quite considerably, but there are still dangers out there,\u201d he said. \u201cWe\u2019re trying to figure out what those are and how to deal with them.\u201d\n\nThe deputy commissioner Bill Daly said Parros was a very good fit for this role.\n\n\u201cI know that many people think that, because of the role he played during his N.H.L. career, he must not \u2018think the game,\u2019\u201d Daly said. \u201cJust the opposite is true.\u201d\n\nParros spends much of his time talking to team officials and players about ways to make the game safer. Although a player who tests the limits of the rules might not warrant a suspension or a fine, Parros often lets him know the league is watching.\n\n\u201cThe game has changed dramatically,\u201d Parros said. \u201cIt\u2019s tremendously faster than when I played. Some of the things we deal with now deal with the speed of that game. There are a lot more accidental collisions. There\u2019s a lot more things that happen with less intention than when I played. There was a lot more head-hunting going on, head shots, perhaps more reckless behavior. Guys looking to hurt or injure, in some manner.\u201d\n\nParros\u2019s department has four advisers: Stephane Quintal, Parros\u2019s predecessor; Damian Echevarrieta, the group vice president, who has an encyclopedic memory of past infractions; Patrick Burke, the senior director; and Ray Whitney, the director. Quintal and Whitney are also former N.H.L. players.\n\nThe department\u2019s nerve center is a windowless room down the hall from Parros\u2019s office. Each N.H.L. game is monitored in real time by a staff member on two screens, often one with the home team\u2019s television feed, the other with the visiting team\u2019s feed. National network feeds are also used.\n\n\u201cIn today\u2019s game,\u201d Parros said, \u201cyou can see everything.\u201d\n\nIf an incident merits closer examination, the monitors alert Parros and his advisers by phone, including details like the infraction, the player\u2019s suspension and fine history, the opponent, and, perhaps most important, the player\u2019s next game. Video of the incident is available.", "title": "George Parros Used to be an N.H.L. Enforcer. Now He\u2019s in Charge of Player Safety.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-01 00:00:00", "text": "In speeches, both took delight in belittling people. Mr. Wallace made rhetorical pin cushions of \u201cpointy-head college professors who can\u2019t even park a bicycle straight.\u201d At one of his rallies, he called out to a longhaired male protester, \u201cOh, I thought you were a she.\u201d Mr. Trump has yet to meet a demeaning adjective he doesn\u2019t like, with his \u201cCrooked Hillary,\u201d \u201cLyin\u2019 Ted,\u201d \u201cLiddle Bob Corker\u201d and other insults.\n\nBoth exhorted audiences to get physically rough with hecklers. Both called for certain malefactors to be put to death. \u201cBam, shoot \u2019em dead on the spot!\u201d Mr. Wallace said in 1968, referring to those rioting in America\u2019s cities. Last month, Mr. Trump said drug dealers should be executed. The two men even had similar speech mannerisms, often saying the exact same sentence twice in rapid succession.\n\nFor a time, a George Wallace presidency was not an outlandish notion. He ran well on the American Independent Party ticket in 1968, capturing 13.5 percent of the popular vote and the 45 electoral votes of five southern states \u2014 Alabama, Arkansas, Georgia, Louisiana and Mississippi \u2014 plus a \u201cfaithless elector\u201d in North Carolina, a state won by Richard M. Nixon.\n\nIn 1972, Mr. Wallace seemed to have the wind at his back in pursuing the Democratic presidential nomination, until he was gravely wounded by a would-be assassin\u2019s bullets at a campaign stop in Maryland. From then on, his was a life in a wheelchair and in constant pain. (The gunman, Arthur Bremer, now 67, served 35 years of a 53-year prison sentence and was paroled in 2007.)\n\nMr. Wallace had one more presidential race in him, in 1976, but he quickly faded. Six years later, he was elected Alabama governor for a fourth time. But long before then, he cast himself as a changed, even chastened, man on race relations.\n\nIn 1973, he crowned the University of Alabama\u2019s first black homecoming queen, Terry Points. More substantively, he began speaking remorsefully about his race-baiting past \u2014 how wrong it was and how sorry he was. In 1979, he went to a church in Montgomery, Ala., where the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. had once been pastor. There, he spoke of having learned the meaning of suffering. \u201cI think I can understand something of the pain that black people have come to endure,\u201d he said. \u201cI know I contributed to that pain, and I can only ask your forgiveness.\u201d\n\nAfrican-Americans in Alabama granted him redemption. They voted for him in large numbers in his final runs for governor. After he died in 1998 at age 79, Representative John Lewis, an icon of the civil rights era, wrote in The Times that \u201cGeorge Wallace should be remembered for his capacity to change.\u201d", "title": "George Wallace Tapped Into Racial Fear. Decades Later, Its Force Remains Potent.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-19 00:00:00", "text": "MONROVIA, Liberia \u2014 I grew up in the Gibraltar area of Clara Town, a slum in Monrovia, the capital of Liberia. Sport was my passport out of poverty. A combination of luck and hard work enabled me to make my improbable journey from the dusty football fields of Clara Town to glamorous stadiums in Europe. I played professional football for the biggest clubs in the world and was honored to be the first African named FIFA World Player of the Year.\n\nOn Jan. 22, I returned to the Samuel Doe football stadium in Monrovia \u2014 a beloved venue where I had played numerous games \u2014 to take the oath of office as the president of Liberia. It was the nation\u2019s first peaceful, democratic transfer of power in almost 75 years. I stood in the stadium proud and aware of the great responsibility of leading Team Liberia.\n\nGrowing up as a poor child, I intimately saw and experienced the hardships an ordinary Liberian faced. I know the difficulties and horrors our people suffered before and during the crippling conflicts that tore Liberia apart from 1989 to 2003. In the mid- and the late \u201990s, I often returned home as a good-will ambassador for the United Nations Children\u2019s Fund to help draw attention to my people\u2019s plight and to work to disarm child soldiers.\n\nI moved back to Liberia in 2003. The arrival of peacekeepers the same year, first from our West African neighbors and then from the United Nations, helped end 14 years of successive, brutal civil wars, which killed around 250,000 people and displaced around two million.", "title": "Opinion | George Weah: Don\u2019t Forget About Liberia", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-13 00:00:00", "text": "Traditionally, the anchor of German conservatism in the Bundestag has been the Christian Social Union, the Bavarian sister party of Ms. Merkel\u2019s Christian Democrats. In the run-up to this year\u2019s state elections in Bavaria, it too has been hardening its position on immigration and integration, explicitly to block the far-right Alternative for Germany party, known by its German abbreviation AfD.\n\n\u201cIf we talk and act in a manner that broad groups have painfully missed recently, we can render the AfD obsolete,\u201d said Alexander Dobrindt, who heads the Christian Social Union\u2019s caucus at the Bundestag.\n\nIn January, Mr. Dobrindt published his own conservative manifesto in the German newspaper Die Welt. The majority in Germany, he writes, thinks and feels \u201cb\u00fcrgerlich\u201d \u2014 a term often rendered in English as \u201ccivic,\u201d but in German, it also encompasses a sense of tradition, orderliness and normality. According to Mr. Dobrindt, the \u201ccivic\u201d majority is underrepresented in the public debate, which, he claims, is dominated by left-leaning opinion leaders. It is time, he writes, for a \u201cconservative revolution.\u201d\n\nBut what would be gained if the AfD vanishes yet populist thought seeps into mainstream politics?\n\nOn the one hand, the \u201cnew conservatives\u201d share some of the tangible policy positions held by the AfD \u2014 a reduction in immigration, repatriation of migrants, stronger domestic security policies. These are not new conservative policies per se, and they are a part of mainstream politics. But with the traditional right embracing them so loudly in the context of a resurgent far right, there\u2019s no question that the far right itself is gaining ground as an ideology. There\u2019s a new radicalism in the new conservatism.\n\nLike the AfD, the new conservatives see immigration not just as a practical problem that poses difficulties for the welfare system, integration, housing and security. Many frame it as an existential threat to Germany\u2019s national identity, and to \u201cthe Occident\u201d more broadly. \u201cExistential\u201d threats can legitimize extraordinary measures.\n\nMany new conservatives like to think of themselves as rebels against the Merkelian status quo. They often call themselves the \u201csilent majority,\u201d large in number but underrepresented in the country\u2019s news media and political institutions. It\u2019s an old trope, and not unique to Germany, but again, context matters \u2014 and in today\u2019s climate, it reinforces the idea that there is something fundamentally wrong with our democratic system.\n\nThe implication is that the system does not recognize the true interests of society. It also suggests that the system can no longer be changed by democratic deliberation, but that a more fundamental opposition may be needed, and a deposing of the elites allegedly manipulating the system in their favor. In brief, the new conservatism is populist.", "title": "Opinion | German Conservatism Is Making a Comeback", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-04 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nBERLIN \u2014 A German food bank is to begin considering non-German applicants again next week, after setting off a national debate on refugees and poverty by deciding to bar any more foreigners from signing up for its service.\n\nThe food bank, in the western city of Essen, found itself at the center of a storm that brought it international media attention, vociferous support from some Germans \u2014 reflected in increased donations \u2014 and a public rebuke from Chancellor Angela Merkel.\n\nIts case became a talking point in the continued conversation over the country\u2019s decision, three years ago, to welcome more than a million refugees. J\u00f6rg Sartor, volunteer director of the food bank, the Essener Tafel, said he had made the initial policy change in part because the proportion of foreigners among the organization\u2019s users had risen over those years to three-quarters of its clients from one-third.\n\nBut on Wednesday, Jochen Br\u00fchl, the chairman of the national Tafel organization, which oversees a network of 934 food banks, appeared keen to play down both the initial decision and the reversal.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cWith all the media attention, Mr. Br\u00fchl said, \u201cone should not forget that this decision was temporary from the beginning.\u201d", "title": "German Food Bank Reopens Doors to New Foreign Applicants", "authors": ["Christopher F. Schuetze"]} {"date": "2018-04-30 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Leiber, known as Gus, was noted for energetic, lyrical and colorful paintings, which he continued to create into his 90s.\n\n\u201cHe was a true modernist, experimenting with form and technique and exploring Abstract Expressionism alongside the artists who would go on to define the movement, like de Kooning and Pollock,\u201d said Jess Frost, associate curator of Guild Hall, the entertainment, arts and education center in East Hampton, N.Y.\n\nPhoto\n\nMs. Frost, who had cataloged the Leibers\u2019 work at their museum, added, in a telephone interview, \u201cHe shifted easily between styles and was fearlessly committed to a new body of work that at times was altogether different from what he had been doing a year earlier.\u201d\n\nMr. Leiber\u2019s paintings ranged from abstract landscapes to representational, if stylized, fashion figures \u2014 some of which Ms. Leiber used for her handbag designs. He also made prints and sculptures.\n\nIn 2014, Mr. Leiber showed some of his later paintings in an exhibition at the Carter Burden Gallery on West 28th Street in Manhattan.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s very rare to paint for 70 years, every day, which is what he did,\u201d Marlena Vaccaro, the gallery\u2019s director, said in a telephone interview. \u201cHis skill level, his commitment to the process of painting, was an inspiration. He kept his creative flow going and did not repeat the past. His paintings had a vital and beautiful quality to them.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nMr. Leiber called the paintings in the show \u201cthe summation of a long search for clarity, honesty and beauty.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHis works are in the collections of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, the National Gallery of Art in Washington and the Whitney Museum of American Art, among other museums.\n\nMr. Leiber was born in Brooklyn on Nov. 12, 1921. His family \u2014 including his mother, Rebecca, and his father, William, a junk dealer \u2014 moved to Titusville, in northwest Pennsylvania, when he was a boy.\n\nWhile in school he developed an interest in art, but his hopes of becoming an artist were limited by his family\u2019s poverty; to help make ends meet he worked as a soda jerk and newspaper delivery boy. After working as a printer at the local newspaper, he entered the Army and was assigned to its Signal Corps.\n\nPhoto\n\nSergeant Leiber was stationed in North Africa and Italy before he was sent to Budapest as World War II was ending. There, in 1945, he met Judith Peto, who had begun selling her unusual handbags and purses to American soldiers.\n\nIn their first encounter, on a street in Budapest, he invited her to attended the opera. She later told him that her family had a room to rent to a military officer.\n\n\u201cShe knew nothing about how the U.S. military made housing decisions,\u201d Mr. Leiber told The New York Times last year. \u201cShe did, however, speak excellent English. I couldn\u2019t find her a tenant, but I did fall in love.\u201d\n\nRecalling their courtship, he told The New York Post last year that he brought the Peto family \u201ca few gifts of large cans of chicken from the mess hall.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nJudith Peto encouraged him to attend art school, where his talent thrived. They married in early 1946 and immigrated soon after to the United States.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWhen the couple visited his family in Titusville \u2014 home to a 19th-century oil boom \u2014 Mr. Leiber asked his mother where she had put the drawings of nude models he had sent her from Budapest. She had burned them all, she replied, because \u201cthey were immoral.\u201d\n\nThe Leibers soon headed to New York, where he enrolled in the Art Students League, coming under the influence of the painter Will Barnet. He also studied engraving at the Brooklyn Museum Art School. Ms. Leiber designed handbags to support him while he was in school, and years later he urged her to open her own company.\n\n\u201cIt sounds romantic,\u201d Ms. Frost said, \u201cbut they shared a mind.\u201d\n\nMr. Leiber \u2014 who is survived by a brother, Dr. Joseph Leiber, and two sisters, Martha Dermer and Sarah Stachel \u2014 had said that he and his wife were fulfilled without having children. Their children \u201chang on walls and from arms and shoulders,\u201d he told The Times in 1970, adding, \u201cAs a couple we felt complete and still do.\u201d", "title": "Gerson Leiber, 96, Dies; Artist Created Museum With Designer Wife", "authors": ["Richard Sandomir"]} {"date": "2018-04-26 00:00:00", "text": "She was later reprimanded by an inspector, but she drove off with her very first customer.\n\nMs. Jeannette, who was also one of the first women to get a motorcycle license in New York, and who later overcame a speech impediment to become a Broadway, film and television actor as well as a playwright, producer and director, died on April 4 at her home in Harlem. She was 103.\n\nHer niece Angela Hadley Brown confirmed the death.\n\nMs. Jeannette got her hack license in 1942. She had responded to an ad in a newspaper looking for women to replace the male cabdrivers who had been drafted into World War II.\n\n\u201cWomen were going into plants and everything else, taking over jobs,\u201d she recalled in a 2005 interview. \u201cI said, well, I know one thing \u2014 I can drive a car.\u201d\n\n\u201cThirty-two of us took the test and only two of us passed,\u201d said Ms. Jeannette, who learned how to drive a Chrysler truck at the age of 13 in Arkansas. \u201cBut the other girl didn\u2019t get her license because she had citations on her driver\u2019s license. And so I, I was the first.\u201d\n\n(Ms. Jeannette is widely thought to be the first woman to get a taxi license in New York City, said Allan Fromberg, the deputy commissioner for public affairs at the Taxi and Limousine Commission, but records from that period have been lost or destroyed. The first unlicensed female cabdriver in New York City was Wilma K. Russey in 1915.)\n\nPhoto\n\nMs. Jeannette never wanted to act, she said, but was pushed into the theater.\n\nWith the money she earned driving, she had set out to correct her childhood stammer by enrolling in the one speech class she could find, at the American Negro Theater, housed in the basement of what is today the Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture in Harlem.\n\nActing instruction was part of the curriculum, and she studied alongside Sidney Poitier, Ruby Dee and Ossie Davis. She was quickly singled out for her stage presence and cast in her first Broadway production, \u201cLost in the Stars,\u201d which had its premiere at the Music Box Theater in 1949.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nShe would go on to land roles in Broadway productions like \u201cThe Long Dream\u201d (1960), \u201cNobody Loves an Albatross\u201d (1963), \u201cThe Amen Corner\u201d (1965), \u201cThe Skin of Our Teeth\u201d (1975) and \u201cVieux Carr\u00e9\u201d (1977), written by Tennessee Williams, with whom she became friends. Her film credits include \u201cCotton Comes to Harlem\u201d (1970), \u201cShaft\u201d (1971) and \u201cBlack Girl\u201d (1972).\n\nMs. Jeannette began writing plays in 1950 in response to what she saw as an absence of authentic black characters on the stage.\n\n\u201cI saw parts that I knew I wouldn\u2019t play,\u201d she said in an interview in 1995. \u201cAnd so I started writing about women, and strong women, that I knew that no one would be ashamed to play.\u201d\n\nGertrude Hadley was born on Nov. 28, 1914, in Urbana, Ark., about 15 miles from the Louisiana border. Her father, Willis Lawrence Hadley, taught at a mission on a Native American reservation near Spiro, Okla. Her mother, Salley Gertrude Crawford Hadley, was a homemaker.\n\nGertrude grew up on a farm with five brothers and one sister, climbing walnut trees, playing stickball and fishing for trout. During the Depression, she moved with her family to Little Rock, Ark., and enrolled at Dunbar High School, a segregated one-room schoolhouse, where she recalled beginning each day singing \u201cLift Every Voice and Sing.\u201d\n\nOn her prom night, she met her future husband, Joe Jeannette, a heavyweight prizefighter 35 years her senior, who was in town from New York. The pair danced the Lindy Hop, a popular dance in Harlem, and by the end of the song he had asked her to marry him.\n\n\u201cJust because I\u2019m a small-town girl, I\u2019m not a fool,\u201d she recalled telling him, in 2005. \u201cAnd I walked off the floor.\u201d\n\nHe persisted, and they eloped to New York in 1933.\n\nMr. Jeannette was the president of the Harlem Dusters, a motorcycle club, and he taught his wife how to ride a motorcycle under the elevated train tracks (now demolished) on what is now Frederick Douglass Boulevard in Harlem.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cThe \u2018el\u2019 train, they had these big pillars,\u201d she recalled. \u201cAnd he would push me with no motor running, take the motorcycle and push me around, and have me to guide in and out those \u2018el\u2019 posts to get the swing of the motorcycle.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Race/Related Newsletter Join a deep and provocative exploration of race with a diverse group of New York Times journalists. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nShe got her motorcycle license in 1935, the same year she had her only son, Robert. He died at age 5.\n\nHer husband worked as a bodyguard of sorts for Paul Robeson, the baritone singer, actor and political activist. In 1949, the Harlem Dusters, including Gertrude, traveled to what was to be an open-air concert in Peekskill, N.Y.\n\n\u201cThat\u2019s the first time I saw the Ku Klux Klan,\u201d Ms. Jeannette recalled in 2015. \u201cThey came out to lynch Paul Robeson.\u201d\n\nKlansmen set fire to crosses on the field, and American Legion members, protesting what they saw as Mr. Robeson\u2019s affinity for the Soviet Union and communism, clashed with concertgoers. The melee became known as the Peekskill Riots.\n\nWhen the American Negro Theater closed in 1949, many of the company\u2019s black actors moved to California or elsewhere. Some, including Ms. Jeannette, were barred from working during the Red Scare of the 1950s; she was singled out, she said, because of her association with Mr. Robeson.\n\nSo Ms. Jeannette \u2014 \u201cMother Gertrude\u201d or \u201cMs. J,\u201d as she was known in Harlem \u2014 set up a succession of theater companies in the neighborhood, including the H.A.D.L.E.Y. players (the letters stand for Harlem Artist\u2019s Development League Especially for You) in 1979.\n\n\u201cShe had many opportunities to go to Hollywood, but she always stayed in Harlem,\u201d said Ward Nixon, who was the company\u2019s artistic director. \u201cShe stayed in Harlem to make sure the community had top-notch theater.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nA demanding director, Ms. Jeannette mentored a generation of young black actors in New York. She wrote five plays, which grappled with racism, politics, family ties and the importance of education.\n\nHer first, and her favorite, was \u201cThe Way Forward\u201d (1950), which drew upon her childhood in Arkansas. In \u201cA Bolt From the Blue,\u201d she explored the so-called Bronx Slave Market \u2014 groups of black women who huddled outside department stores searching for jobs as day laborers or domestic workers in the 1930s and \u203240s.\n\n\u201cThey were wonderfully dramatic pieces, punctuated by lighter moments throughout,\u201d Mr. Nixon said of her work. \u201cYou always walked out of one of her plays feeling uplifted and encouraged.\u201d\n\nShe continued to act into her 80s and retired from directing at 98. Her husband died in 1956. She is survived by 10 nephews and 6 nieces.\n\n\u201cMs. Jeannette left on this earth the feeling of hope,\u201d Mr. Nixon said. \u201cThat wherever you are in life, and whatever you want to do, you can always rise up.\u201d", "title": "Gertrude Jeannette, Actor, Director and Cabdriver, Dies at 103", "authors": ["Jonathan Wolfe"]} {"date": "2018-04-18 00:00:00", "text": "But in Germany, such an action is controversial, whatever the intended goal.\n\n\u201cShall I wear a Jewish star like my parents were forced to? For me it isn\u2019t a disguise,\u201d Ruth Frenk, the head of the local chapter of the German-Israeli Society, said in an interview.\n\nIn an open letter, Ms. Frenk and the head of a local group promoting interfaith dialogue criticized the theater, its decision to open the play on the anniversary of Hitler\u2019s birth and the opening-night deal for free tickets.\n\n\u201cThe bizarre marketing ploy by the City Theater of Konstanz is not acceptable,\u201d they wrote.\n\nAndreas Mathy of the public prosecutor\u2019s office confirmed in a statement that it had received \u201cseveral\u201d complaints, but said it declined to investigate because the symbols were clearly covered by laws ensuring freedom of artistic expression.\n\nThe theater has given an assurance that the symbols are crucial to the performance and that spectators will have to return the items before they leave.\n\nThe play itself, \u201cMein Kampf\u201d by George Tabori, which producers describe as a loud and colorful caricature, tells the story of a Hitler as young man trying to get established in the Vienna art scene, where he is befriended by an older Jewish man who takes pity on him. It was first performed in Vienna in 1987 and was made into a film in Germany in 2009.", "title": "Get In Free if You\u2019ll Wear a Swastika: A German Theater\u2019s Provocation", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-09 00:00:00", "text": "Harold Levy. If you didn\u2019t yet read the Sunday Review piece by Harold Levy, with help from Peg Tyre, I hope you\u2019ll do so. I\u2019ve known Levy for years as a passionate, thoughtful advocate for economic opportunity. He is now dying of A.L.S., far too young, which has added obvious urgency to his thoughts.\n\nThe foundation he runs \u2014 the Jack Kent Cooke Foundation \u2014 has been a particularly strong voice on behalf of community-college students. You can read about some of them here. Levy has always glowed when he\u2019s talked to me about the students that he\u2019s worked with.\n\nRelated: The Times ran a collection of letters yesterday about closing the college-graduation gap between rich and poor.\n\nL\u2019Affaire Williamson, continued. She writes: \u201cHe was fired for being unable to have a reasoned, civil debate about abortion that doesn\u2019t involve fantasizing not just about the government killing women who get abortions, but about how they kill them.\u201d", "title": "Opinion | Get Ready for James Comey", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-16 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nCast-iron cookware is in the spotlight. Having started with skillets, producers are now introducing Dutch ovens. Despite already owning pots from Staub and Le Creuset, I could not resist the new Dutch oven by Finex Cast Iron Cookware, an American company that makes distinctive octagonal pieces with a dark bronze finish. The brass knob on the lid bears my initials (they happen to coincide with the company logo). It was fine for a test-drive pot roast, snugly holding a four-pound piece of chuck. The angled shape, meant to facilitate pouring, proved effective, and clean-up, thanks to its pre-seasoned organic flaxseed oil coating, was a breeze. You just need a few sessions at the gym to lift its nearly 12 pounds (empty): Finex 5-Quart Dutch Oven With Cover, $300, finexusa.com.\n\nFollow NYT Food on Facebook, Instagram, Twitter and Pinterest. Get regular updates from NYT Cooking, with recipe suggestions, cooking tips and shopping advice.", "title": "Get a Workout With a New Dutch Oven", "authors": ["Florence Fabricant", "Front Burner"]} {"date": "2018-04-27 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nA state judge has ordered a new parole hearing for Judith Clark, a former left-wing militant who took part in a 1981 armored car robbery that left three dead, saying the State Board of Parole\u2019s decision last year to deny her parole was arbitrary and capricious.\n\nThe judge, John J. Kelley of State Supreme Court in Manhattan, said the three-member board had focused too heavily on the severity of the crime and had given too little weight to Ms. Clark\u2019s long record of good works in prison as well as to Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo\u2019s decision in December 2016 to reduce her sentence. The judge ordered that a new parole hearing be held within 60 days.\n\n\u201cMs. Clark has undergone a remarkable transformation over the three decades during which she has been incarcerated,\u201d Justice Kelley wrote in a decision made public on Friday. \u201cMs. Clark has taken responsibility for her actions, expressed remorse and tried to improve the lives of her fellow prisoners, as well as many others.\u201d\n\nMs. Clark, 68, drove a getaway car during the attempted robbery of a Brink\u2019s armored car in Rockland County in 1981. The heist was part of a scheme by the May 19th Communist movement and a revolutionary black group to steal $1.6 million for financing a guerrilla uprising. Two police officers and a security guard were shot and killed during the robbery.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMs. Clark represented herself at trial, expressing no remorse and telling the jury that revolutionary violence was a \u201cliberating force.\u201d The sentencing judge said she was beyond rehabilitation and sentenced her to 75 years to life.", "title": "Getaway Driver in Brink\u2019s Heist Merits New Parole Hearing, Judge Rules", "authors": ["James C. Mckinley Jr."]} {"date": "2018-04-27 00:00:00", "text": "This is where Nathan Dungan, a wealth educator and founder of Share Save Spend, a financial consulting firm in Minneapolis, is trying to take a smarter approach to any conversation around prenuptial agreements. He wants to require both partners to attend what could be called Prenup 101.\n\nIt is far from something couples can take casually. Mr. Dungan has developed work sheets and quizzes to complement extensive counseling that lasts at least six months, though ideally closer to a year. He calls the whole process \u201conboarding\u201d \u2014 a far more welcoming description than \u201cdivorce planning.\u201d\n\n\u201cYou want to say, \u2018We\u2019re in this together,\u2019 but then there\u2019s this big wrench that gets put in place,\u201d he said. \u201cWhat if we looked at it as an opportunity and not this huge problem?\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nTo this end, the work sheets ask open-ended questions about how people feel about money: \u201cWhat is money to me?\u201d \u201cWhat things matter most to me in life?\u201d \u201cWhy is it important to understand how each person is wired with respect to money?\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cThey have homework assignments they need to do,\u201d Mr. Dungan said. \u201cSome are together, some are separate.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut emphasis is put on the discussion, he said.\n\n\u201cPart of this is to recognize that this is not a romantic conversation,\u201d Mr. Dungan said. \u201cWe get that, but it\u2019s an opportunity for them to step into this and talk about their own family of origin and their own money story.\u201d\n\nMr. Dungan said his goal is to take the prenuptial agreement out of the conversation and present the couple with an opportunity to have an honest conversation about money. He wants them to learn if they are spenders, savers or sharers when it comes to money in their lives.\n\nAndrew, who comes from a prominent Midwestern family and asked that his last name not be used, said his family had been a client of Mr. Dungan\u2019s since he was a teenager. He\u2019s in his late 20s now and has been married for four years.\n\nHis wife became part of the family\u2019s financial discussions while they were dating. Still, when they got engaged and the process ramped up, the conversations were not easy.\n\n\u201cThere were things that got brought up that my wife and I never knew were bothering us,\u201d Andrew said. Mr. Dungan helped them ask about their attitudes toward money. \u201cIt allowed my wife and me to learn why this is important and to understand this isn\u2019t a \u2018me vs. you\u2019 thing,\u201d he said.\n\nThe process took about six months until a prenuptial agreement was signed.\n\n\u201cIt can feel like you\u2019re against each other from the start,\u201d Andrew said. But in the end, he was glad they were both on the same page. \u201cIt lets you start your marriage on the right foot,\u201d he said.\n\nMr. Dungan\u2019s method appeals to people who are confident and open enough to at least discuss money within their own families. That\u2019s usually how they know about him in the first place: as clients of his getting advice on wealth and inheritance.\n\nBut many prenuptial financial conversations are not well planned. More often, couples wait until weeks or even days before their wedding before talking about a prenuptial agreement \u2014 a hasty decision signed in what the industry calls \u201cthe shadow of the altar.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nCasting that kind of uncertainty on a wedding can dim the sunny days most couples expect. But such an approach can also have unintended ramifications.\n\nThe person who is being presented with the prenuptial agreement can feel unprepared or, worse, ambushed. As for the agreement itself, that kind of rush also increases the likelihood that whatever is signed will not hold up in court.\n\nPart of what makes a prenuptial agreement enforceable is a full disclosure of existing assets. To do this, there needs to be time for both parties to understand what is involved.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s difficult to challenge a prenup in New York,\u201d said Jacqueline Newman, managing partner at the New York law firm Berkman Bottger Newman & Rodd. \u201cBut if it\u2019s literally thrown to the person in the shadow of the altar, courts consider all of that. It\u2019s not smart on the part of the person who wants a prenup to give it to someone last minute.\u201d\n\nInherited assets and family gifts are generally protected in divorce proceedings. But if, say, income from a trust was used to pay for the family\u2019s lifestyle, it could be subject to division in a divorce, said Silvana D. Raso, managing partner at Schepisi & McLaughlin, a law firm based in New Jersey.\n\nThe same, she said, holds true for a family business, even if a new spouse is only partly involved in managing it and receiving income from it. Both concerns can be handled in a properly drafted agreement, but doing so takes time and discussions.\n\nMs. Newman, however, noted that for the so-called non-monied spouse, a prenuptial agreement can offer access to funds supporting the couple\u2019s married lifestyle that would not be available in a divorce, such as otherwise untouchable inheritance funds.\n\nThere is consensus on what makes a good prenuptial agreement: time to discuss all the issues and draft a document that is fair to both sides and perhaps even has provisions to change over time.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut getting to that document can cause lasting problems in a family if the process is not handled with care. Mr. Dungan\u2019s classes attempt to fend off emotional distress, much of which can revolve around how families talk \u2014 or don\u2019t talk \u2014 about money.\n\nAlison Comstock Moss, chairman and chief executive of Paul Comstock Partners, which advises clients on a total of $2.2 billion in assets, recalled a client who told his future son-in-law that he would not get a dime from the family if the marriage ended. The son-in-law, who was himself financially successful, had not planned to ask for anything from his wife\u2019s family in the prenuptial agreement.\n\nYears later, the marriage is happy, but the two men still do not get along. \u201cKnowing all the parties involved, I don\u2019t think the intent was to be nasty,\u201d Ms. Moss said. \u201cI think they got bad advice and the way they communicated with each other was really hurtful.\u201d\n\nA better way to have handled the situation, she said, would have been to ask a simple question about expectations, which would have allowed the son-in-law to speak his mind.\n\nBut an approach like that requires planning, education and openness about financial expectations, which may not be possible if the focus is on the agreement itself.\n\nMr. Dungan said that his process still led to the same end \u2014 a prenuptial agreement \u2014 but that it got there in a way that required more thought.\n\n\u201cWe\u2019re not robotically moving through this process,\u201d he said. \u201cWe\u2019re creating a dynamic that allows them to have the best outcome.\u201d", "title": "Getting Married? Forget Sweet Nothings; Let\u2019s Talk About Money", "authors": ["Paul Sullivan", "Wealth Matters"]} {"date": "2018-04-20 00:00:00", "text": "For resizing and moving, you can expand a window by clicking the square Maximize icon on the far-right side of a window\u2019s title bar. When you right-click a Windows title bar, or press the Alt key and the space bar, you also get Move and Size options in the menu.\n\nWhen you select Move and then slide the cursor to the center of the screen, you can use the arrow keys on the keyboard to nudge the window over; press the Enter key when you have it where you want it. Selecting the Size option lets you use the keyboard arrow keys to resize the window.\n\nOn a Mac, you have a few ways to reel in wandering windows. If you are not sure what you have open, go to the Mac\u2019s Mission Control view to see miniature versions of all the open windows at once \u2014 and select the one you need. Just press the Mission Control key (often F3 on an Apple keyboard) or the Control and up-arrow keys; you can also get into Mission Control by clicking its icon in the desktop dock, using the Control Strip on compatible MacBooks or swiping up with three fingers on a trackpad.\n\nTo move and resize windows even if the desktop Dock is in the way, hold down the Option key and click the green dot in the window\u2019s upper-left corner to resize the window to fit the screen. Clicking the green dot by itself expands the window to the full-screen size.\n\nYou can drag any of the four sides of a window to change the size, and holding down the Shift and Option keys while you drag an edge resizes the whole window proportionally. If you can click on part of a visible window, you can also go to the Window menu in the Mac\u2019s tool bar and choose Zoom to resize the window to fit the screen.", "title": "Getting Your Desktop Windows in Order", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-14 00:00:00", "text": "Last month, the president of Ghana, Nana Akufo-Addo, unveiled the design for a national cathedral that the government will build in Accra. This is a huge deal. It signals that the country is poised to consolidate the gains of decades of democracy. And the new interdenominational Christian cathedral will inspire ambitious civic architecture projects across the continent that harness the talents of Africa\u2019s emerging artists.\n\nNot everyone is cheering, though. Some West Africans have complained that the mixing of church and state is ill advised. They argue that it\u2019s a worrisome case of official partisanship in a part of the world rived by religious conflicts. Others say the money for the project should have instead been invested in schools, hospitals and infrastructure \u2014 stuff that, according to them, Africa really needs. They are right to point to these endemic problems; but they are wrong to connect them with the cathedral.\n\nThe cathedral is the first major project in Africa by the Ghanaian-British architect David Adjaye, who was knighted last year for his services to his field. He is perhaps the most exciting architect in the world. His reputation is built on his stunning designs for Rivington Place in London, the Moscow School of Management Skolkovo, and, most spectacularly, the Smithsonian National Museum of African American History and Culture in Washington.\n\nThis Accra commission is not just a recognition by his homeland of Mr. Adjaye\u2019s acclaim. It also signifies that Africa can build a major work by a leading architect at the top of his game. This is a remarkable thing: Ghana will get to brag about a globally recognized architectural landmark.", "title": "Opinion | Ghana Deserves This Cathedral. Don\u2019t Fight It.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-15 00:00:00", "text": "Stanton vaguely alluded to these issues in Boston last Tuesday, when he was asked if he had been trying to do too much at the plate during the Yankees\u2019 homestand.\n\n\u201cNo,\u201d he said. \u201cI just felt there was a lot going on. Focusing on maybe too many things. But not trying too hard, I don\u2019t think.\u201d\n\nAsked to elaborate, Stanton smiled and said, \u201cNot to worry about.\u201d\n\nStanton later declined to comment when he was asked if setting up his place had been a distraction.\n\n\u201cI\u2019m not going to make excuses,\u201d he said.\n\nSince the start of the Yankees\u2019 series in Boston last week, Stanton has begun to more closely resemble the hitter who belted 59 home runs last year and won the National League Most Valuable Player Award. He is 6 for 17 with a double, triple, three runs batted in and five strikeouts in four games.\n\nStanton and Manager Aaron Boone had the same answer when asked to describe how Stanton was swinging the bat this weekend compared to a week ago: \u201cMuch better.\u201d\n\n\u201cMy balance points are better,\u201d Stanton added. \u201cI\u2019m picking the ball up better. So, I\u2019ve just got to continue.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nThat rounding into form comes at a propitious time: the Yankees, who were rained out in Detroit on Saturday and Sunday, return home Monday for a two-game series against Stanton\u2019s former team, the Miami Marlins.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nStanton is looking forward to seeing his old manager, Don Mattingly, and some of his friends who were not traded away in the Marlins\u2019 winter sell-off. One person he will not see is the Marlins chief executive, Derek Jeter, who will travel with the team but not attend the games, saying it would be awkward for him to return to Yankee Stadium.\n\nStanton said he holds no enmity toward Jeter, who tried to strong-arm him into accepting a trade to St. Louis or San Francisco, threatening to hold onto him through a lengthy rebuild of the Marlins. Stanton, with the leverage of a no-trade clause, pushed back, and eventually a trade with the Yankees was worked out.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Since their series under a dome in Toronto, the opening-pitch temperature for nine of the Yankees\u2019 10 games has been under 54 degrees. They have had three games postponed by rain or snow, all of which has limited their time outdoors for batting and fielding practice.\n\nIf that deprived Stanton of getting used to his new surroundings at Yankee Stadium, his acclimation to New York has also taken place on the fly.\n\nWhen the Yankees left spring training in Tampa, they flew to Atlanta for an exhibition the next night, March 28, and went directly to Toronto for the season opener. It was only after that series when Stanton arrived to New York.\n\n\u201cIt was a load, getting oriented to New York and trying to get his condo set up,\u201d Stanton\u2019s father, Mike, said in a telephone interview. \u201cI think it\u2019s your natural instinct when you move in somewhere to try to get it set up as quickly possible. But in retrospect, he didn\u2019t have a lot of down time.\u201d\n\nBoone said the logistics of setting down roots in a new city are part of a ballplayer\u2019s life, even if it is something that Stanton is doing for the first time since his rookie season in Miami. Soon, he said, Stanton would be settled into a new routine and there will be comfort in that.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s part of the gig, part of the way we\u2019ve lived our whole life,\u201d said Boone, who switched teams five times in his final nine seasons in the majors. \u201cLook, I want to get into the flow of the season as I know the players do \u2014 the routine of it \u2014 as much we can. A lot of times getting moved in, especially with a new club, learning people in the organization, playing in crappy conditions \u2014 it\u2019s all part of it.\u201d\n\nThe Yankees, after returning to New York on Sunday night, will be anchored there for nearly two weeks, giving Stanton another chance \u2014 and not just at Yankee Stadium \u2014 to feel at home.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nINSIDE PITCH\n\nThe Yankees games that were rained out over the weekend will be made up as part of a day-night doubleheader on June 4 in Detroit.", "title": "Giancarlo Stanton Bothered by Pressure? It would be hard to declare the move a dramatic success, with Stanton going 1 for 3 with an infield single and a walk, but no matter how the sausage was made, the team walked away with a 4-3 win.\n\nBoone played down the lineup change, saying it was partially inspired by Toronto\u2019s starter, Aaron Sanchez, being tough against right-handed batters. Even the result \u2014 an 11-4 Yankees win \u2014 did little to quell the fans\u2019 disappointment with Stanton\u2019s debut.\n\n\u201cYou put up a performance like that, you should get booed,\u201d Stanton said after the home opener.\n\nThe sense of discontent clearly lingered overnight; more than a few boos were heard as Stanton headed to the plate in the first inning against Rays\u2019 starter Blake Snell on Wednesday. Stanton has now struck out in eight of his first nine Yankee Stadium at-bats.\n\nBut as Manager Aaron Boone pointed out, the benefits that come from players like Stanton, Judge and, to a lesser extent, Sanchez are often accompanied by strikeouts. Cron that sailed over Stanton\u2019s glove in left, limiting the Rays to just two more singles before leaving with one out in the eighth inning.\n\n\u201cWe lean on those guys a lot,\u201d Boone said, referring to Stanton, Judge and Sanchez. \u201cThose three guys are going to make you pay when you make a mistake. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nWith Barkley, listed at 6 feet and 233 pounds, Manning will be handing off to a back who can run as well as he can catch and return kicks. Last season with the Nittany Lions, he accounted for 1,903 yards from scrimmage and 21 touchdowns, and averaged 28.4 yards per kickoff return with two touchdowns.\n\nBefore moving outside Allentown, Pa., Barkley grew up in the Bronx, where he cheered for the Jets, whose logo is tattooed in red on his father\u2019s forearm and who might have been his ideal destination.\n\nIn a different year, perhaps. But not this one, not with the Jets (again) committed to drafting a quarterback. Aside from the Jets, only three other teams have failed to make the playoffs in the last seven seasons: Chicago, Tampa Bay and Cleveland. The Bears and the Buccaneers identified their franchise quarterbacks in recent drafts, and the Browns, after years of dysfunction, believed they found theirs on Thursday, when they took Mayfield.\n\nThe Jets, after a failed free-agent pursuit of Kirk Cousins, had been on the clock at No. 3 for nearly six weeks. Though they knew they would be drafting a quarterback, they did not know which one. They gained that position with a gambit as aggressive as it was desperate, surrendering picks No. 6, 37 and 49, plus a second-rounder next year, to Indianapolis for the right to move up three spots.\n\nPreparing to take his third quarterback in four drafts with the Jets, Maccagnan could not afford to sit at No. 6 and risk other needy teams, like Buffalo or Arizona, maneuvering ahead of him (the Bills and the Cardinals moved up Thursday night to take quarterbacks, with Josh Allen going to Buffalo at No. 7 and Josh Rosen to Arizona at No. 10). Maccagnan needed to be comfortable with, at worst, his third-rated quarterback.\n\n\u201cWe felt very good about the players that would be there,\u201d Maccagnan said.\n\nDarnold joins the Jets at a pivotal time in the A.F.C. East, with Buffalo and Miami no closer to overtaking New England than the Jets are, and with the Patriots nearer to the end of the Tom Brady era than the beginning. The Jets\u2019 chances of disrupting New England\u2019s divisional supremacy, of contending season after season, depend on Darnold\u2019s progress and aptitude for maximizing the talent around him.\n\nDarnold will get an opportunity to ascend the depth chart at once, competing with last year\u2019s starter, 38-year-old Josh McCown, and Teddy Bridgewater, whom the Jets signed in free agency after he missed most of the past two seasons because of a knee injury.\n\n\u201cWe\u2019re not going to throw him in there,\u201d Coach Todd Bowles said. \u201cBut at the same time, we\u2019re not going to hold him back, either.\u201d", "title": "Giants Select Saquon Barkley; Jets Choose Sam Darnold", "authors": ["Ben Shpigel"]} {"date": "2018-04-15 00:00:00", "text": "Gillian Ayres, a leading British abstract painter whose pursuit of beauty led her to use evocative colors, texture her works with thick layers of oils and occasionally to hurl paint at her canvasses, died on Wednesday in North Devon, England. She was 88.\n\nHer son Sam Mundy said the cause was heart and kidney failure.\n\n\u201cPainting is a visual, silent medium, but I love it and I am obsessed by it,\u201d Ms. Ayres told The Guardian in 2001.\n\nShe was besotted by paint \u2014 what it felt like physically and what she could do with it. She used her hands, brushes, parts of cardboard boxes and brooms to arrange the vivid images that distinguished her work for more than 60 years. She often spent more time staring at a work-in-progress to determine how to organize shapes and space than she did painting it.", "title": "Gillian Ayres, Abstract Artist Besotted by Paint, Dies at 88", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-28 00:00:00", "text": "As Rudolph Giuliani joins President Trump\u2019s legal defense team, here are biographies on three men (including Giuliani) that illuminate the world of New York City politics.\n\nImage\n\nBOSS TWEED\n\nThe Rise and Fall of the Corrupt Pol Who Conceived the Soul of Modern New York\n\nBy Kenneth D. Ackerman.\n\n437 pp. Carroll & Graf Publishers. (2005)\n\nWilliam Magear Tweed, or Boss Tweed as he was called, was first elected to public office in 1852. According to this biography, he perfected a system of corruption that helped him control \u201cthe courts, the legislature, the treasury and the ballot box.\u201d He laundered at least the equivalent of $1 billion today, much of which went into his or his associates\u2019 pockets. Tweed was a complex figure, because despite his criminality, he improved the lives of the poor in New York City; he funded schools and hospitals and helped the disadvantaged navigate President Abraham Lincoln\u2019s draft law, which allowed the rich to buy their way out of service. Our reviewer called Ackerman\u2019s book an \u201cexcellent\u201d biography: The story of Tweed\u2019s rise and fall is told in a crisp, clear way.\u201d\n\nImage\n\nCITY FOR SALE\n\nEd Koch and the Betrayal of New York\n\nBy Jack Newfield and Wayne Barrett\n\n466 pp. Harper & Row. (1989)", "title": "Giuliani Is Back! Three Books on Larger-Than-Life New York Politicians", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-19 00:00:00", "text": "At the same time, though, they have determined that for Mr. Mueller to complete his inquiry in a timely manner, Mr. Trump will need to sit down for questioning. Mr. Giuliani plans to try to work with Mr. Mueller to come up with a way to question Mr. Trump that both sides are comfortable with.\n\nThe addition of Mr. Giuliani comes at a particularly tumultuous time for the president. Last month the president\u2019s lead lawyer, John Dowd, quit the team after he determined the president was not following his advice. For much of the past month, the team has been led by Mr. Sekulow, who has had to assemble a new group of lawyers to deal with the issues in New York and another team to confront Mr. Mueller.\n\nAt the same time, Mr. Mueller has been pressuring Mr. Trump to sit down for an interview. The president, who initially said he was eager to answer Mr. Mueller\u2019s questions under oath, is said to be more skeptical of an interview in the wake of the raid on Mr. Cohen\u2019s office.\n\nAfter Mr. Dowd quit, many well-known lawyers turned down the opportunity to join the president\u2019s legal team. Some said that they did not believe Mr. Trump would listen to them and that their firms did not want to be associated with the president. But after the raid on Mr. Cohen, many more lawyers have become interested in working for Mr. Trump, according to people briefed on the matter. The lawyers believe the government overstepped its bounds by executing a warrant at a lawyer\u2019s office and have contended the government violated the attorney-client privilege between Mr. Cohen and his clients.\n\nMr. Trump negotiated the discussions to have Mr. Giuliani join his team with Mr. Giuliani directly, a person close to the process said. Mr. Trump had repeatedly offered Mr. Giuliani the job of attorney general during the transition, but Mr. Giuliani turned it down because he wanted to be secretary of state.\n\nMr. Trump turned to Senator Jeff Sessions, Republican of Alabama, to be attorney general, but has publicly criticized Mr. Sessions for recusing himself from the Russia inquiry. Mr. Trump has said that Mr. Sessions should be protecting him from the inquiry.\n\nSome close to the president believe he could try to replace Mr. Sessions with Mr. Giuliani in the coming months, although Mr. Giuliani would face an extremely difficult confirmation hearing in the Senate. But the three people briefed on the sit-down \u2014 the first since the former New York City mayor joined the legal team last week \u2014 described it as a productive effort to reopen negotiations over a possible interview that the special counsel, Robert S. Mueller III, is seeking with the president.\n\nNews of the meeting was first reported by The Washington Post.\n\nIn an interview, Mr. Giuliani said that his goal in the coming days was to find out where Mr. Mueller stands, particularly as it relates to the credibility of James B. Comey, the F.B.I. director whom the president fired in April 2017. Mr. Comey has been interviewed by Mr. Mueller, and he has been deeply, personally critical of the president in his media tour promoting his new memoir.\n\n\u201cAt this stage of an investigation, it\u2019d be highly unusual to let an ordinary client testify,\u201d Mr. Giuliani said.
