This is the president of the United States.\u201d", "title": "Giuliani, in Meeting With Mueller\u2019s Office, Is Said to Be Negotiating Trump Interview", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-12 00:00:00", "text": "Antipoverty advocates have embraced the idea for years. So have we. But Mr. de Blasio is dragging his feet, saying that the idea is a \u201cnoble\u201d one, but that the city cannot afford it.\n\nGiven the mayor\u2019s free-spending ways, we\u2019re somewhat perplexed by his hesitation. The city\u2019s budget has increased every year since Mr. de Blasio took office, to $87.4 billion this year from about $70 billion in 2014 fiscal year, the last budget negotiated under Mayor Michael Bloomberg. The city should continue to add to its reserves and increase spending only with caution. It should keep an especially careful watch on the city\u2019s swelling payroll, which has added billions of dollars in recurring costs under Mr. de Blasio.\n\nBut the MetroCard program is a responsible addition. Seniors, people with disabilities and some students already receive reduced fares. The city can afford to extend that benefit to the poorest New Yorkers. The mayor has said that he supports it in theory, and that it should be paid for by a millionaire\u2019s tax. Yet the elusive millionaire\u2019s tax requires Albany\u2019s approval, and isn\u2019t likely to happen.\n\nThankfully, Mr. Johnson has given the idea new life, joining forces with antipoverty activists who have long fought for the measure to put pressure on the mayor.\n\nStanding with them this week at a rally outside City Hall to support the half-price MetroCard were the Manhattan district attorney, Cyrus Vance Jr.; the Brooklyn district attorney, Eric Gonzalez; and the Bronx district attorney, Darcel Clark, who view the proposal as another tool to chip away at the poverty that can lead to crime. Mr. Vance said earlier this year that he would no longer prosecute people based solely on fare-beating, a sordid use of the courts that costs taxpayers about $50 million every year. In Manhattan alone, about 8,000 people were prosecuted for fare-beating in 2017, according to Mr. Vance\u2019s office.", "title": "Opinion | Give Poor New Yorkers a Break on Subway and Bus Fares", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-08 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nMONDAY PUZZLE \u2014 Not all Monday puzzle themes are completely straightforward.\n\nSure, you\u2019ve got your simple letter or sound addition or subtraction themes, or your vowel progressions. Other themes, even if they\u2019re easy, will insist that you train your brain to think somewhat outside the box, and I\u2019ve heard from people who say that they just can\u2019t put the theme together in their minds, even on a Monday. That has to be discouraging.\n\nThere is good news, though: If you are asked to solve a tougher-than-usual theme, the surrounding entries and the clues will be gentle. You\u2019ll find extra toeholds sprinkled throughout the grid so that you can fill in enough to enable you to take that educated guess at solving the theme.\n\nSo hang in there if you are just getting started. There\u2019s a way to do this.\n\nErik Agard \u2014 who just broke records at the American Crossword Puzzle Tournament by not only solving faster than the seven-time champion, Dan Feyer, but by solving faster than anyone has ever solved an A Division final puzzle before \u2014 returns with a shiny, Monday puzzle.\n\nToday\u2019s Theme\n\nThis is the kind of theme that might not make much sense until you get to the revealer at 52A, but that\u2019s O.K. There\u2019s something to be said for a Monday puzzle that holds its secrets until the end. I think it makes the solve more exciting, and there\u2019s no letdown from having guessed the theme right out of the gate.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nYou might have noticed that the three starred clues all have answers that have two things in common. First, the three theme entries are all actors. Second, their initials are A. G.", "title": "Given Their Initials", "authors": ["Deb Amlen"]} {"date": "2018-04-02 00:00:00", "text": "Babies given antibiotics or antacids in infancy may be at increased risk for allergies in childhood.\n\nResearchers retrospectively studied 792,130 infants covered by a health insurance program. Of these, 131,708 received antibiotics, 60,209 got histamine-2 receptor antagonists and 13,687 were given proton pump inhibitors. Both H2 blockers and P.P.I.s are prescribed for gastroesophageal reflex, or GERD.\n\nThe study, in JAMA Pediatrics, followed the children for an average of four and a half years. It found that infants given H2 blockers or P.P.I.s were more than twice as likely to have a food allergy as those who were not; the risk was especially high for allergy to cow\u2019s milk. Those given antibiotics were at a 14 percent increased risk for food allergy, a 51 percent increased risk for anaphylaxis (a potentially fatal type of allergic reaction), and more than double the risk for asthma.\n\nThe authors suggest that both antacids and antibiotics disrupt the normal intestinal bacteria and that this may explain the association.", "title": "Giving Babies Antibiotics or Antacids May Increase Allergy Risk", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-22 00:00:00", "text": "Those players came to the Yankees on free-agent deals worth a combined $300 million. Torres arrived in a much different way than almost any other Yankee: as another team\u2019s sapling, not a redwood. Torres had never played above Class A when the Chicago Cubs traded him and three others to the Yankees for Aroldis Chapman in July 2016.\n\n\u201cWe were all extremely excited about it,\u201d said the injured outfielder Billy McKinney, who was also part of the deal. \u201cI thought it was really cool, because it was, I guess, a little bit different from the Yankees\u2019 culture.\u201d\n\nInstead of pushing for a long-shot berth in the 2016 World Series, General Manager Brian Cashman played matchmaker for the Cubs and the Cleveland Indians, who got reliever Andrew Miller for outfielder Clint Frazier. Torres said he did not watch that Cubs/Indians World Series, because he was playing in the Arizona Fall League. He had moved on.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cI think everybody wants to play with the Yankees,\u201d Torres said. \u201cI got the opportunity, and I\u2019m excited for that.\u201d\n\nThe Yankees could have given second base to Torres and third base to Miguel Andujar \u2014 who was 4 for 4 on Sunday \u2014 out of spring training. Instead, after camp began, they traded for Brandon Drury and signed Neil Walker. That was the Yankees at their best, protecting themselves with affordable veteran placeholders until the kids push their way up.\n\n\u201cThey\u2019re earning their time,\u201d Manager Aaron Boone said. \u201cMaybe a little bit different \u2014 this early \u2014 than maybe we thought, but hats off to them for putting us in that position right now.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThink of Robinson Cano tearing through the minors in early 2005, bumping Tony Womack off second base in the first week of May. That could be Torres now. He had a forgettable debut on Sunday, with a strikeout, a ground-ball double play, a foul out and a fly out to right. But Cano went 2 for 23 in his first week, and turned out just fine.\n\nGiancarlo Stanton compared Torres\u2019s swing to that of another second baseman, Javier Baez, one of the infielders who had blocked Torres\u2019 path in Chicago. Baez hit .273 with 23 homers last season and, like Torres, was a consensus top-10 prospect before his promotion.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cThere\u2019s a lot going on, but it\u2019s very precise,\u201d Stanton said of Torres\u2019 swing. \u201cHe\u2019s got some cool action in there and some pop at the end.\u201d\n\nTorres has played only 14 games at second base in the minors, and 23 at third. His main position, shortstop, belongs to Didi Gregorius in the Bronx. But McKinney called Torres an electrifying defender \u2014 \u201cHe can make fireworks happen, I like to say,\u201d McKinney said \u2014 and Boone praised his overall acumen, without citing a standout tool.\n\n\u201cI don\u2019t necessarily think there\u2019s anything that\u2019s \u2018wow,\u2019\u201d Boone said. \u201cHe\u2019s not going to go out in B.P. and hit the ball, like some of our guys, a mile. He\u2019s not going to wow you with his speed. But he does everything really well on the baseball field.\n\n\u201cHe can hit, he uses the entire field, his strike-zone recognition \u2014 I think he\u2019s going to be a guy that walks, over time. He\u2019s a really good defender at all three spots and can legitimately play short, that\u2019s the kind of defender he is. That baseball I.Q., baseball clock \u2014 he just seems to have all those things.\u201d\n\nTorres sped up his career clock, and now he has arrived. The hard part awaits.\n\n\u201cLike I tell all the guys, making it to the big leagues, it\u2019s like nothing,\u201d Gregorius said. \u201cStaying in the big leagues for a long time, that shows your worth.\u201d", "title": "Gleyber Torres Arrives as Part of a Pinstriped Youth Movement", "authors": ["Tyler Kepner", "On Baseball"]} {"date": "2018-04-21 00:00:00", "text": "Gleyber Torres cannot help an erratic staff of starting pitchers. Nor can he help shake Giancarlo Stanton from his April funk. But the Yankees hope that calling up Torres from Class AAA on Saturday will provide a jolt before they fall much farther behind the Boston Red Sox in the American League East.\n\nTorres, the Yankees\u2019 much-ballyhooed top prospect, will be in uniform \u2014 and quite likely in the lineup at second or third base \u2014 on Sunday at Yankee Stadium against the Toronto Blue Jays.\n\nTorres, who was acquired nearly two years ago from the Chicago Cubs, was pulled from Scranton/Wilkes-Barre\u2019s game in the seventh inning on Saturday so he could head to New York, according to a baseball official who was speaking on the condition of anonymity. The New York Post first reported the move.\n\nTorres, who was hitting .370 with a .415 on-base percentage and a .543 slugging percentage in Class AAA, will be joining a team in need of a boost. The Yankees beat the Blue Jays on Saturday to improve to 10-9 and pull within six and one-half games of the Red Sox, who were beaten in a no-hitter in Oakland Saturday night. The Blue Jays are in second place, four games behind the Red Sox.", "title": "Gleyber Torres Is Joining the Yankees", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-30 00:00:00", "text": "Dear Diary:\n\nSo long ago the plans were flimsy,\n\nBut thanks now Bloomie, Blazie, Lindsay,\n\nDinkins, Koch \u2014 for wheels and whimsy.\n\nGod Save the Q.\n\nFew lines elicit more affection,\n\nUptown, downtown, each direction\n\nGo wherever, your selection.\n\nGod Save the Q.\n\nTwisting, turning, westly, eastly,\n\nOther routes are brutish, beastly,\n\nBut this one\u2019s regal, pure and priestly.\n\nGod Save the Q.\n\nThose moving stairs \u2014 the escalation,\n\nThe artwork too earns adulation.\n\nClean and bright, what transportation!\n\nGod Save the Q.\n\nAnd if the N or R get grumpy,\n\nCompared to the Q they\u2019re drab and dumpy.\n\nEasy guys, the ride\u2019s still bumpy \u2014\n\nGod Save the Q\n\nOn Second Avenue.", "title": "God Save the Q", "authors": ["Lou Craft", "Metropolitan Diary"]} {"date": "2018-04-05 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nRe \u201cMy Journey Into a Cashless Future,\u201d by David Gelles (Sunday Business, April 1):\n\nGoing cashless seems like a good idea, but it isn\u2019t. Many have \u201cgo bags,\u201d filled with essentials so that they can get out of town in case of a disaster. But if there is such an event, credit cards won\u2019t help.\n\nDrive away and try to check into a motel, and the credit card network may be down. In addition to a go bag, it helps to have some ready cash on hand, mostly in fives, tens and twenties. That will get you what you need when your credit card won\u2019t.\n\nRICHARD WATT, NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y.", "title": "Opinion | Going Cashless Is Risky", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-16 00:00:00", "text": "Thanks to the early riser in the motel room next door, I made it into the sanctuary. While we waited for President Carter to arrive, I chatted with a Baptist minister sitting in the pew behind me about a recent interview with Stephen Colbert, in which Mr. Carter hinted that he considers the sitting president of the United States a liar. Asked what it takes to be president, he told Mr. Colbert, \u201cI used to think it was to tell the truth. But I\u2019ve changed my mind lately.\u201d\n\nThere were flashes of the same impish wit on display at the church in Plains. \u201cDo we have any visitors this morning?\u201d he joked to the crowd. He asked where we were all from, and voices sang out from places like Cameroon, Israel, Uzbekistan.\n\nWhen it was time for the lesson itself, President Carter stood smiling and spoke without referring to notes, moving to the lectern only to read from the scripture. The text was from the Acts of the Apostles, passages concerning the priorities of the early church. \u201cThey worshiped together. They had fellowship together. And a third thing: They took care of each other\u2019s needs, even in a sacrificial way,\u201d he said. He spoke particularly about the generosity of Barnabas, who sold his own field and gave the money to Jesus\u2019 apostles to distribute to the needy.\n\nPresident Carter is not a pacing, gesturing, booming-voiced orator, but he is a brilliant teacher \u2014 moving nimbly between his memories, his concerns for the world and what the Acts have to say about the right relationship of human beings to one another. He asks questions, nods encouragement when an answer is close but keeps nudging until someone hits on the point he\u2019s trying to make.\n\n\u201cWe have lost faith in a lot of things that have always nurtured us,\u201d he said. \u201cMany people in the world have lost faith in democracy. We\u2019ve lost faith in the sanctity of telling the truth and the value of education. We\u2019ve lost faith in the equality of people. In our country\u2019s history, some of our greatest struggles have been over the issue of equality.\u201d\n\nThen he asked the congregation what year women in the United States gained the right to vote.\n\nSeveral called out \u201c1920!\u201d But it was a trick question. \u201cThat was white women,\u201d he reminded us. \u201cA lot of white people don\u2019t remember that distinction.\u201d\n\nHe spoke movingly about his first security briefing as president-elect, about the solemn responsibility of the country\u2019s commander in chief to safeguard nuclear weapons. \u201cIf we don\u2019t figure out as collective human beings how to get along with each other, even the people we don\u2019t like and with whom we don\u2019t agree \u2014 say the Americans and the Russians, the Americans and the Chinese, the Americans and anybody else \u2014 if we don\u2019t figure out collectively how to get along with each other and take care of each other, that might be the end of humanity.\u201d", "title": "Opinion | Going to Church With Jimmy Carter", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-26 00:00:00", "text": "Over the last several years, Ms. Domingo has immersed herself in the world of armchair detectives and online sleuths. She has spent hours on social media trying to be a \u201csqueaky wheel\u201d \u2014 putting together clues that might identify the killer. A handful of other victims joined together to do same, talking almost daily. They formed a kind of sorority based on shared pain and relentless focus. The process, Ms. Domingo said, was \u201ctherapeutic.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Race/Related Newsletter Join a deep and provocative exploration of race with a diverse group of New York Times journalists. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cWe just did not give up hope,\u201d she said. \u201cTo see that the DNA matches came through, that he\u2019s alive and that they have him in custody \u2014 that\u2019s what we were all praying for.\u201d\n\nClose to Home\n\nThe Golden State Killer had terrorized one of his victims in the very town where Mr. DeAngelo was arrested Tuesday.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nLinda O\u2019Dell and her husband were sleeping in her Citrus Heights home in 1977 when she awoke to find a strange man in their bedroom, who told her not to move.\n\nShe thought she might be having a nightmare as the man tied them both up, so tight that her husband soon could not feel his hands. He untied her ankles and took her to the living room, where he held a knife to her throat and raped her. He stayed in the house, drinking beer, for several hours; before he left, he demanded her wedding band and engagement ring, warning her he would cut her fingers off if she couldn\u2019t remove them. He also took her state photo identification, which would haunt her for years to come.\n\n\u201cI couldn\u2019t identify him because he had a ski mask on the whole time,\u201d Ms. O\u2019Dell, 63, said. \u201cBut he had my photograph and my driver\u2019s license, so I always had this fear that he could be standing next to me at the grocery story and I\u2019d have no idea. That was always a fear.\u201d\n\nShe could hardly believe that he had been living in Citrus Heights, so close to where he had attacked her. For a long time, she could not talk about what happened. Ms. O\u2019Dell said her sister had provided comfort, moving in for a year after the attack because Ms. O\u2019Dell was afraid to be alone while her husband was at work. She said she shared her story freely now because she felt more empowered.\n\n\u201cI was 22 years old and there was a lot of shame and there wasn\u2019t empathy for victims. And I felt embarrassed. I felt judged. I didn\u2019t feel like a victim back then. I didn\u2019t want people to know it about me,\u201d she said. \u201cBut I\u2019m part of the Me Too movement now, and I feel like I\u2019m strong and healthy. There\u2019s power in being this way.\u201d\n\n\u2018I Was the Victor\u2019\n\nPhoto\n\nBy the fall of 1977, the man who was then known as the East Area Rapist had been terrorizing women in the suburbs of Sacramento for more than a year. Margaret Wardlow, then 13, had been captivated by the case, reading about the methodical ways he had sought and attacked his victims.\n\nHer mother, who was then 55, tried to assure her that they were too old and too young to make for appealing targets. But one night in November, Ms. Wardlow awoke to a man holding a flashlight in her face, whispering angrily. Initially, she thought it was a neighbor playing a joke to get her out of bed before school. Then, she saw a clock showing it was 2:30 a.m.\n\n\u201cThen I knew clearly: This is the East Area Rapist,\u201d she said. \u201cI knew he got off by frightening people and I thought the less enjoyable time he has here the better.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nKnowing that he had yet to kill anyone, Ms. Wardlow said she had focused on getting the rape over with. As he tied her up and blindfolded her, he asked if she wanted him to kill her mother or her. She recalled responding coolly, \u201cI don\u2019t care.\u201d\n\nWhile the attack was over within minutes, he stayed in her home for more than an hour. He had placed plates on her mother\u2019s back, warning her he would kill her if he heard the plates rattling \u2014 just as he had warned the husbands of other women he raped.\n\nHe had entered through the sliding glass door upstairs and left through the front door, Ms. Wardlow said, turning on the kitchen sink and stove fan for ambient noise. She recalled hearing her mother screaming for help. Soon after, a neighbor arrived with a shotgun. Investigators later confirmed Ms. Wardlow\u2019s hunch that she had been attacked by the serial rapist, who used the same method over and over again.\n\nA couple of years after the attack, Ms. Wardlow and her mother moved to Orange County, Calif., where murders that the authorities believed to be linked to the same suspect had occurred. Her mother urged her to go to therapy, but she refused. Ms. Wardlow said that to this day she has not spoken of her attack to a professional.\n\nIt was only a year and a half ago, after Ms. Wardlow had searched \u201cEast Area Rapist\u201d on the internet, that she realized the serial rapist who had attacked her had become a serial killer and was never caught.\n\n\u201cI always felt like I triumphed,\u201d she said. \u201cI felt like I controlled what happened as much as I could, I had influence over that night. I felt like I was the victor and I\u2019ve always gone with that.\u201d\n\n\u2018He Deserves Terror\u2019\n\nPhoto\n\nJennifer Carole had just turned 18 when her father and stepmother, Lyman and Charlene Smith, were murdered in their Ventura home in March of 1980. Her younger brother, then 12, found their bodies in their bedroom when he went to mow the lawn and heard their alarm clock going off. At first he thought nothing of it, but he grew concerned when it continued to ring.\n\nThe killer had sexually assaulted Ms. Smith and bludgeoned both husband and wife to death with a log from the fireplace. Their killing sparked enormous fear and unrest in the small town. Even with her own loss, Ms. Carole expressed sympathy for the surviving rape victims, who have had to carry their trauma with them for so many years.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cI don\u2019t know what you do after you\u2019ve been raped and terrorized,\u201d she said. \u201cThe people who are alive, they are the ones that really suffered.\u201d\n\nMs. Carole, now 56, said that after the murders she, as the oldest sibling, took methodical steps to manage the logistics involved, which she said helped give her a sense of order. It wasn\u2019t until a year later, while at college, that she began experiencing panic attacks and difficulty focusing. Now living in Santa Cruz, she said she has seen a counselor about the trauma and that she and her brothers are living full, productive lives.\n\nStill, she expressed immense relief that the killer was finally caught.\n\n\u201cHe\u2019s a narcissist and a psychopath. There isn\u2019t a word we can say that will mean a thing to him,\u201d she said. \u201cI don\u2019t want him on death row. He does not deserve a private room or notoriety. He deserves terror, just like what he did to us. He needs to be living in fear. That would be so highly satisfying for me.\u201d", "title": "Golden State Killer\u2019s Victims: The Families Who Never Gave Up Hope", "authors": ["Jennifer Medina", "Jose A. Del Real"]} {"date": "2018-04-17 00:00:00", "text": "Goldman Sachs has gotten its groove back \u2014 for the first three months of 2018, at least.\n\nAfter a year of uncharacteristic struggles, the bank benefited from wild swings in prices for stocks and other assets to rake in cash in the first quarter, according to an earnings report released on Tuesday.\n\nAccustomed to dominating its rivals in the trading business, Goldman spent the past year trying to figure out how to rev up an operation feeling the pressure of new regulations and facing competition from non-bank trading platforms. As a result, it lagged its closest competitors last year.\n\nNo longer. Goldman booked $10 billion in revenue for the quarter, its highest total in three years and a 25 percent increase over the same period in 2017. It reported profits of $2.8 billion, compared with $2.3 billion a year earlier.\n\nInvestors were unimpressed. After rallying in early trading on Tuesday, Goldman shares fell more than 1 percent. Its competitors\u2019 shares had followed a similar trajectory, falling or barely moving after they reported quarterly earnings on Friday and Monday.", "title": "Goldman Sachs May Be Getting Its Groove Back", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-17 00:00:00", "text": "And it\u2019s important to remember that other major businesses at Goldman are also volatile. Investing and lending, which mostly involves making longer-term investments in companies, and whose revenue can be unpredictable, made up 21 percent of total revenue in the first quarter, the second largest contribution.\n\nDespite the bumper results in trading along with investing and lending, Goldman\u2019s shares slid slightly on Tuesday, suggesting investors are waiting on longer-term trends than one quarter\u2019s results.\n\nBut the volatility of revenue is not the only reason investors are often skeptical about Wall Street firms. The huge amounts that they pay out in compensation is also a concern. When revenue rises, so does pay. As a result, money that could have fallen to the bottom line at other types of companies instead gets paid out to traders and bankers. Compensation at Goldman Sachs made up 45 percent of non-interest revenue in the first quarter, up from 44 percent the first quarter of 2017.\n\n\u2014 Peter Eavis\n\nGoldman\u2019s profit jumps\n\nTaxes and market volatility lifted Goldman Sachs\u2019 bottom line during the first quarter.\n\nHere are the numbers:\n\n\u2014 Goldman reported earnings of $2.83 billion, up 26 percent from a year ago.\n\n\u2014 Earnings per share came in at $6.95. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expected $5.58 a share.\n\n\u2014 Revenue increased to $10.04 billion from $8.03 billion a year ago. Analysts had expected revenue of $8.74 billion.\n\n\u2014 Overall trading revenue rose 31 percent from a year ago.\n\n\u2014 Revenue from stock trading climbed 38 percent.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u2014 Fixed-income trading revenue increased 23 percent.\n\n\u2014 Fees from investment-banking revenue rose 5 percent to $1.79 billion, driven by an increase in underwriting revenue.\n\nPhoto\n\nStarbucks will shut 8,000 U.S. stores for racial-bias training.\n\nStarbucks said it would close more than 8,000 of its stores in the United States on May 29 to conduct racial-bias training for nearly 175,000 employees.\n\nThe move comes amid an outcry prompted by the arrests of two African-American men at a Starbucks location in Philadelphia last week.\n\nThe two men were arrested after asking to use the restroom in the shop. An employee refused their request, because the men had not bought anything, according to officials. The men sat down and were asked to leave, and an employee eventually called the police. The prosecutor\u2019s office in Philadelphia reviewed the case and declined to pursue charges against the men because of \u201ca lack of evidence that a crime was committed,\u201d according to a spokesman.\n\nTom Buerkle of Breakingviews writes that Starbucks is setting an example for corporate America: \u201cFacing a backlash over the arrest of two black men at a Philadelphia shop, the chain will shut all of its company-owned U.S. outlets for an afternoon of racial-bias education. The swift response backs up Starbucks\u2019 social goals and offers a lesson to others.\u201d\n\nIt\u2019s happy hour in America\n\nSome may be optimistic that the $1.5 trillion tax cut will extend the business cycle.\n\nThe strategists at Morgan Stanley are not among them.\n\n\u201cWhile there\u2019s a fair amount of debate about how much this fiscal expansion extended the economic cycle, for markets our analysis suggests we\u2019re closer to the end of the day than the beginning. Hence, there\u2019s less reason to behave like it\u2019s \u2018morning in America\u2019 than \u2018happy hour in America.\u2019\u201d\n\nKey points\n\n\u2022 Morgan Stanley argues that while the tax cuts will help lift growth in the near term, its benefits are already priced into the markets.\n\n\u2022 The new tax law creates economic cliffs, as many key provisions in the law are not permanent and end in just a few years.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u2022 The tax cuts may make it more difficult for the government to turn to fiscal stimulus to fight the next downturn.\n\nIn conclusion\n\n\u201cWhile this policy supports growth in the near term, it may worsen the next downturn while limiting the fiscal reaction to it. Even if those concerns are unfounded, we think much of fiscal stimulus\u2019 \u2018good news\u2019 is already in the price of key markets.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nHas Netflix reached escape velocity?\n\nIt was another blockbuster quarter for Netflix.\n\nThe streaming video company added 7.41 million subscribers during the first quarter. Its profit jumped 62 percent, and sales grew 40 percent.\n\nNetflix also said it plans to spend $10 billion on content and marketing this year.\n\nShares are up 8.6 percent Tuesday and 75 percent this year. That easily beats the S.&P. 500, which has gained just 0.2 percent this year. It also tops the performance of its fellow FANG stocks. Facebook is off 4.5 percent this year, Google-parent Alphabet is up about 3 percent, and Amazon has risen 28 percent.\n\nStephen Ju, an analyst over at Credit Suisse, writes in a note titled \u201cGetting Closer and Closer to Achieving Escape Velocity\u201d:\n\n\u201cNetflix continues to reap the benefits of its programming win streak, as it wields its large content acquisition budget as a weapon to put greater distance between itself and its competitors (especially as Disney prepares to exit the platform). And we find it hard to argue with the accelerated pace of subscriber additions as the conceptual proof of its capital allocation decision, and we also expect the Street to continue to underwrite the investments.\u201d\n\nAs good a day as Netflix is having...\n\nTwitter is having an even better day.\n\nIts shares are up 12 percent after a Morgan Stanley analyst upgraded the stock to equal-weight and raised its price target to $29. It is the eighth upgrade since it reported third-quarter earnings in October, according to Bloomberg.\n\nThe stock is up 87 percent over that period.\n\nPhoto\n\nA \u2018Geneva Convention\u2019 for cyberwar?\n\nIn pledging not to help any government \u2014 including the U.S. \u2014 with cyberattacks against \u201cinnocent civilians and enterprises,\u201d Microsoft, Facebook and 29 other tech companies are trying to distance themselves from the messy business of national cyberwarfare.\n\nThat may reassure some tech workers. (Earlier this month, Google employees protested their company\u2019s work on a Pentagon project, saying the tech giant \u201cshould not be in the business of war.\u201d)\n\nThe NYT\u2019s David Sanger says the impetus came largely from Microsoft\u2019s president, Brad Smith, \u201cwho has been arguing for several years that the world needs a \u2018digital Geneva Convention\u2019 that sets norms of behavior for cyberspace just as the Geneva Conventions set rules for the conduct of war in the physical world.\u201d\n\nAlso striking: Who hasn\u2019t yet signed, including Google, Apple and Amazon.\n\nThe context: The U.S. and Britain just yesterday warned about sweeping Russian cyberattacks on governments, businesses and private individuals.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nElsewhere in tech: Tesla halted production of its Model 3 to work out kinks. Netflix reported its strongest subscriber growth since going public. Investors are considering dropping Facebook from their FAANG bets, while a federal judge gave a photo-scanning lawsuit against the company class-action status. Amazon Business is reportedly holding off on selling drugs to hospitals. Coinbase is buying the paid inbox service Earn.com. And TaskRabbit has gone offline to investigate a possible hack.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe U.S.-China fight has pushed deeper into tech\n\nTrump administration officials said that moving to block China\u2019s ZTE from using U.S. components wasn\u2019t a trade-related decision. But it\u2019s hard not to see as the latest salvo in Washington\u2019s fight with Beijing, particularly over technology. (Another Chinese tech giant, Huawei, is scaling back its U.S. presence.)\n\nChina\u2019s trade deficit with the U.S. is widening. But China offered an olive branch today by loosening regulations for foreign makers of electric vehicles.\n\nOn currency concerns: The Treasury Department chose not to label China as a currency manipulator. President Trump disagreed: \u201cRussia and China are playing the Currency Devaluation game.\u201d The truth is more complicated.\n\nPhoto\n\nWhat was Michael Cohen doing for Sean Hannity?\n\nNow that Mr. Hannity has been revealed as a legal client of Mr. Cohen\u2019s, the media world has wondered what Fox News star wanted from the lawyer used by President Trump and the disgraced Republican donor Elliott Broidy.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story The All-New DealBook Newsletter Our columnist Andrew Ross Sorkin and his Times colleagues help you make sense of major business and policy headlines \u2014 and the power-brokers who shape them. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMr. Hannity has denied paying Mr. Cohen legal fees and asserted that none of their talks involved a matter involving him and a third-party \u2014 i.e., a settlement. (The talks, he said, were brief and about real estate.)\n\nMore eye-catching is the Fox News host\u2019s contention that he might have slipped Mr. Cohen a few bucks for attorney-client privilege, which appears to be right out of \u201cBreaking Bad.\u201d (And legally erroneous.)\n\nThe political flyaround\n\n\u2022 President Trump has nominated Richard Clarida, an economist specializing in monetary policy, as the Fed\u2019s vice chairman. (NYT)\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u2022 Republicans want to run on tax cuts, but most Americans \u2014 including President Trump \u2014 seem uninterested. We hear about how many global languages are in sharp decline; I guess I had assumed that Esperanto was one of them, especially since the goals of a universal language, like simpler communication and world peace, seem less attainable than ever. There are actually people using it in many countries \u2014 you can even learn it on Duolingo and go on an Esperanto world tour with free home stays.\n\n20A: In the department of \u201cyou either know it or you don\u2019t,\u201d I call this one a double. First of all, you have to think of the name of this powdery concoction, and then you have to spell it. I vaguely knew of \u201cpixie sticks\u201d \u2014 paper straws with sort of puckery sugar in them like you find on sour gummy candy \u2014 but they actually go by PIXY STIX.\n\n29A: Like other epics, \u201cAladdin\u201d has a sprawling and contested history; apparently it was not one of Scheherezade\u2019s original tales at all, nor did it necessarily take place in the Middle East, and the protagonist might have originally been a Chinese peasant. The 1992 Disney version, though, was definitely set in a city named Agrabah, which drew influence from AGRA and its amazing palace, the Taj Mahal. To be frank with you, researching this topic was surprisingly confusing, but I must refer to this 2015 poll, in light of 1A. Apparently, at one time, there were plenty of people in the actual United States perfectly willing and eager to drop bombs on Agrabah, that fictional city.\n\n32A: Believe it or not, today ABUJA debuts in the puzzle as \u201cNigeria\u2019s capital,\u201d even though it replaced Lagos (which has been an entry dozens of times) in 1991.\n\n55A: Phrase clues like this are always tricky: \u201cThis looks like the end for me!\u201d can be interpreted as bleak or (bear with me) sunny, as in \u201cI am there!\u201d which is what I thought at first. IM A GONER is the bleak version that fits. Now, his whimsical psychedelia will appear in New York in the forms of Charlie Brown, Snoopy and the rest of the Peanuts gang, as part of a new public art project bringing Charles M. Schulz\u2019s characters to cities around the world.\n\nThe project was commissioned by Peanuts Worldwide, which oversees all representations of Schulz\u2019s indelible comics. Seven artists were chosen to form the Peanuts Global Artist Collective and interpret the characters. Nina Chanel Abney, for example, has created a digitalized, geometric rendering of Snoopy and Woodstock riding skateboards. The provocateur Rob Pruitt, known for startling juxtapositions, has placed Snoopy next to a panda bear, while the graffiti artist Andr\u00e9 Saraiva has Snoopy interacting with Mr. Saraiva\u2019s signature stick-figure doodle. The other artists are Tomokazu Matsuyama, the duo FriendsWithYou (Samuel Borkson and Arturo Sandoval III) and the collective AVAF, founded by Eli Sudbrack.\n\n\u201cI think I taught myself how to draw by copying Peanuts characters and strips over and over, especially the details \u2014 the grass, the snow, the wobbly lines,\u201d Mr. Pruitt said in a statement.\n\nThe murals, approximately 15 feet wide by 10 feet tall, will go up on office buildings in Hudson Square on April 16. (A map of their specific locations will be put up at the Children\u2019s Museum of the Arts the day of.) They will remain up for three months, with similar projects going up in Paris; Seoul, South Korea; Berlin; San Francisco; Tokyo and Mexico City.", "title": "Good Grief, Charlie Brown! You\u2019re Graffiti", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-11 00:00:00", "text": "For seven years, the leadership raised countless millions of dollars and won first the House, then the Senate, and finally the presidency, in part by promising to repeal Obamacare. Nothing was more central to Republican identity between 2010 and the rise of President Trump. But when given the chance, Mr. Ryan couldn\u2019t get the House to pass repeal. The bill the House finally sent to the Senate wasn\u2019t a repeal but a dilution. It never became law, either.\n\nLikewise, Mr. Ryan, a longtime budget hawk, was incapable of returning the House budget process to regular order. And rather than reducing spending and the deficit, he increased both. Worse, Mr. Ryan is at odds with the president and a majority in his party on immigration and border control. The bill for those contradictions and failures has finally come due.\n\nIn order to inspire the necessary loyalty and camaraderie to pass legislation effectively, House Republicans need to know that the speaker has their back. But Mr. Ryan didn\u2019t. When Representative Adam Schiff, Democrat of California, made a spurious allegation against Representative Devin Nunes, Republican of California, Mr. Ryan backed Mr. Schiff and sidelined Mr. Nunes for months. Mr. Nunes was subsequently cleared. It\u2019s no wonder that Mr. Ryan couldn\u2019t hold the conference together on big votes. Republicans want and deserve a speaker with the courage and tenacity of Mr. Nunes \u2014 one who supports his troops when they\u2019re under fire.\n\nIntellectually and politically, Mr. Ryan is part of the Reagan Revolution\u2019s third generation. And as it is with many entrepreneurial families, it is the third generation that squanders the family fortune. They don\u2019t know how it was created, and in their own lives they have known nothing but wealth. Reaganism remains a rich legacy, but Republicans can\u2019t live off the interest.\n\nThe predictable response from Democrats will be that Mr. Ryan couldn\u2019t square his principles with the reality of Mr. Trump\u2019s presidency. That might score a quick rhetorical win, but it misses the bigger political picture. America is in the midst of a major political realignment that is redefining both the left and the right. Mr. Trump\u2019s sudden ascendance to power is a symptom of the larger trend and also a catalyst for the intellectual and political reformation that is currently underway on the right, which has led to the announced departures of standard bearers of the ancien r\u00e9gime like Senator Jeff Flake, Senator Bob Corker and now Mr. Ryan.", "title": "Opinion | Good Riddance, Mr. Speaker", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-13 00:00:00", "text": "In those years, other nearby villas were sold and demolished, and the cityscape around us drastically changed. High-rises replaced gardens, two or three to a single plot of land. Our house was sought after \u2014 not for its architectural value, but because developers saw it as sitting on prime land along the Nile. Second to buying it out ourselves, which we couldn\u2019t afford, placing it in the hands of a buyer who would preserve it was the best we could do, and that task became a mission for my mother, pitting her against her family in a standoff that lasted 30 years.\n\nIn my early 20s, as the country was beginning to reform economically and I was starting to write, I moved downstairs, inhabiting my grandmother\u2019s floor, and my brother and I took on the cause of protecting the house ourselves. We searched widely for possible patrons who might make our home their own or turn it into a cultural center, a library or a museum. The interest that came, when it did, was always from abroad. Egyptian businessmen and patrons of culture seemed intent on investing in new developments, suburbs and multimillion-dollar modern homes, but not the center of the historic city, not the heritage already there.\n\nFor 30 years the garden bell rang with real estate agents promising \u201crespectable\u201d buyers. Every deal fell through, and it seemed like the house might stay in this limbo forever. I wrote the house into my novel in 2014: It was the only true-to-life character in the book, and the only thing in my life, and the neighborhood, that seemed unchanged through the revolution of 2011, as our hopes for real change after Mubarak\u2019s fall first rose only soon to be shattered. Ours was the last of family homes still inhabited by its original owners, and everyone remarked how it was the one thing that they could depend on always being there.\n\nAnd yet, when I wrote it into fiction, I conjured the moment where we might, indeed, pack it up.\n\nOn April 1, the day that President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi\u2019s re-election was confirmed, we handed the house to its new owners, who had circled it for two years, admiring it. My mother had at last found her buyer, a woman whom she felt would be the next best custodian to the house and its legacy. We walked through its every room together on that last day, and once the handover papers were signed in the garden, I returned inside alone to close all the doors, windows and shutters. I then led myself out of the main door, locking it behind me.\n\nThose final moments walking out, as well as the months that preceded \u2014 as we sifted through nearly 80 years of a family history, packing and throwing out and giving things away \u2014 felt like a closing, the end of an era, both for my family and for modern Egypt, independent since 1922. The house now has foreign owners, and the country \u2014 perhaps at its most conservative and repressive \u2014 is a far cry from what I ever expected it to become. The latest elections came and went, for me, unacknowledged, too farcical to consider. What might have been a turning point, a political opening, became an end.\n\nMy mother\u2019s new apartment overlooks her old garden; from her balcony, I see what used to be mine. The new owners haven\u2019t moved in yet, but their groundsman and his family occupy the basement of our old house, and spend their days sitting on the plastic garden chairs we left behind. When the sun is setting, shutters left open offer a glimpse into my brother\u2019s childhood bedroom; I forgot to roll them down, and the room\u2019s white muslin curtains still hang. I feel shut out of our home, my lifelong prism into the city, and out of the future of this country.", "title": "Opinion | Goodbye to the House My Grandmother Built", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-05 00:00:00", "text": "Most people know Goodwill Industries International primarily through the stores that sell donated goods. But it is a $5 billion nonprofit that provides employment, education and job training for those who have difficulty finding jobs, including older people and people with criminal backgrounds and disabilities. Goodwill has 162 branches in the United States and Canada, which operate largely independently.\n\nAccording to Goodwill\u2019s website, more than $4 billion of its income derives from sales at its retail stores. The remainder comes from other sources, including corporate, foundation and government grants.\n\nDropouts Statistics\n\nOver the most recent five-year period, from 2010 to 2015, the high school dropout rate fell to 5.9 percent from 7.4 percent, according to the National Center for Education Statistics. But that still means millions of Americans are without diplomas. In 2015, about 2.4 million young adults from the ages of 16 to 24 were not in school and did not have a high school degree or equivalency.", "title": "Goodwill Working to Help Dropouts", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-23 00:00:00", "text": "That focus on variety comes as the data-collection practices that underpin the entire digital advertising industry are under intense scrutiny after the personal information of up to 87 million Facebook users ended up in the hands of the political research firm Cambridge Analytica. Google\u2019s advertising business is more than twice the size of Facebook\u2019s, and the company\u2019s portfolio of data about its users is as expansive \u2014 if not more so \u2014 than that of the social network.\n\nStill, the search giant\u2019s core business showed no sign of slowing in the first quarter. Revenue from Google\u2019s advertising business, which includes ads shown on Google search and commercials running before YouTube videos, increased 24 percent during the quarter.\n\nHowever, Google\u2019s advertising profits were weighed down by an increase in traffic acquisition costs \u2014 the fees that it pays companies like Apple to make sure that its search engine is the default option when people open a browser on the iPhone.\n\nAlso among the company\u2019s expenditures in the quarter: $2.4 billion to buy the Chelsea Market building in Manhattan, where the company had set up some of its New York offices.\n\nOn a conference call with investment analysts, Sundar Pichai, Google\u2019s chief executive, avoided answering questions about the potential effects of new regulations concerning data privacy in Europe. The new law, which goes into effect on May 25, will restrict how companies like Google can collect, store and use personal data from users across Europe.\n\nMr. Pichai said the company has been preparing for the law for more than 18 months, but didn\u2019t discuss how the new regulations may affect the company\u2019s bottom line.", "title": "Google\u2019s Parent Company Spends Like It\u2019s Thinking of a Future Beyond Ads", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-17 00:00:00", "text": "The Rockefeller grouping forms a kind of Monet variety pack, spanning 1868 to 1917 and offering an overview of his career.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s very rare that you have five masterpieces by one artist in a single collection,\u201d said Adrien Meyer, a co-chairman of the Impressionist and Modern department at Christie\u2019s. \u201cThey cover all of Monet\u2019s facets.\u201d\n\nThe works include one urban scene, \u201cExt\u00e9rieur de la Gare Saint-Lazare, Effet de Soleil\u201d (1877), and three water scenes: \u201cBord de Mer \u00e0 Sainte-Adresse\u201d (1868), \u201cCamille Assise sur la Plage \u00e0 Trouville\u201d (1870-71) and \u201cLa Seine \u00e0 Lavacourt\u201d (1879).\n\nThe most valuable piece is from Monet\u2019s popular Water Lilies series, \u201cNymph\u00e9as en Fleur\u201d (1914-17). That\u2019s the one the auction house expects to bring the most money: from $50 million to $70 million, Mr. Meyer said, given the track record of similar pictures.\n\nThe Rockefellers doted on this picture in particular. \u201cAs you were coming down the staircase in the country, there was the Monet Water Lilies,\u201d said Jessica Fertig, a senior Impressionist specialist at Christie\u2019s, referring to the family estate in Pocantico Hills in Westchester County. \u201cIt was such a part of their life.\u201d\n\nThe art historian Paul Hayes Tucker, a scholar of Impressionism who has written five books on Monet, said that the lineup spoke well of the Rockefellers\u2019 taste.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s elastic, catholic and embracing of all the periods, the real hallmark of enlightened collecting,\u201d he said.\n\nPhoto\n\nMr. Tucker said he discovered Monet as a student at Williams College in Massachusetts, where he later taught. Since then, he said the painter \u201chas been my companion, my guide, my soothsayer.\u201d\n\nBut only from a distance: He has never owned one of Monet\u2019s works. That privilege is reserved for a lucky few like the Rockefellers and Scott M. Black, the Boston-based founder of the investment firm Delphi Management.\n\nMr. Black\u2019s collection of more than 50 works includes three Monets, which he has lived with on and off over the years, when they are not on loan to museum exhibitions.\n\nMr. Black made a fortune picking winners in stocks, which is why his clients include business titans like Michael R. Bloomberg, the former mayor of New York City. And in his estimation, Monet is a consistent performer.\n\n\u201cHe didn\u2019t have too many off days,\u201d Mr. Black said. \u201cHe\u2019s my favorite single painter of the 19th century.\u201d And he knows the comparables, as they say in the investment game: He owns works by Degas, Renoir, Cassatt and Pissarro.\n\n\u201cThere\u2019s such an exuberance on the canvas,\u201d he said. \u201cIt\u2019s such a pleasing aesthetic experience.\u201d\n\nMr. Black bought his first Monet for around $1 million in 1986 \u2014 what he now considers a bargain. \u201cIt\u2019s worth a lot more now,\u201d he said.", "title": "Got a Few Million? Christie\u2019s May Have a Monet for You. Or Five.", "authors": ["Ted Loos"]} {"date": "2018-04-01 00:00:00", "text": "When Southwest Airlines revamped its brand in 2014, it overhauled its font and logo as part of the upgrade. It wanted to create the image of an airline that cared about customer loyalty \u2014 one that had heart.\n\nSo, Southwest changed its all-caps Helvetica font to a thicker, custom-made Southwest Sans font that included lowercase letters \u2014 changes meant to convey a softer, friendlier tone. It also added a tricolor heart to the logo, along with the tagline \u201cwithout a heart, it\u2019s just a machine.\u201d\n\n\u201cNow we have a unique font that really embodies our personality as a brand,\u201d said Helen Limpitlaw, director of brand communications at Southwest Airlines. \u201cWe\u2019re in a very competitive category and we\u2019re trying to avoid that sameness.\u201d\n\nThe new typeface now appears on Southwest\u2019s planes, ads, airport signage, uniforms, website and in-flight items.\n\nBefore, the colors and fonts used by the airline varied from platform to platform. \u201cThe voice felt very fractured, it was a disconnected experience,\u201d said Rodney Abbot, senior partner at Lippincott, a brand strategy and design firm that worked with Southwest.\n\nA survey of Southwest customers showed that 95 percent found the new identity appealing, according to the National Brand Monitor in 2014. \u201cWe\u2019ve definitely seen an increase in revenue, an increase in bookings and brand momentum,\u201d Ms. Limpitlaw said.\n\nFont style, size, shape, thickness, color, and depth all tell a story.\n\n\u201cThe typeface is an expression of the tone of voice,\u201d Mr. Abbot said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nExperts say the right fonts can help brands stand out in a competitive market. But they need to know who they\u2019re targeting and what they want to say.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cSpeaking to a mom is different from speaking to a teenager or a 65-year-old retiree,\u201d said Frank Liu, chief creative officer at Siegelvision, a branding and communications firm.\n\nMonster Beverage is a good example of a company knowing who it wanted to speak to. In 2002, it rolled out its Monster Energy drink logo, which featured three neon-green claw-marks in the shape of an \u201cM\u201d on a black background, with \u201cMonster\u201d in white Gothic-like lettering under it. The eye-catching logo and colors exuded energy and youth and connected with fans of sports like snowboarding and Formula One racing, who were its target customers.\n\n\u201cThe graphics absolutely nailed it for that demographic,\u201d said Paul Friederichsen, a partner at the Blake Project, a brand marketing and consulting firm. Now, 16 years later, Monster\u2019s logo remains valuable and recognizable.\n\nLegacy companies are sometimes nervous about making changes, but they risk stagnating if they don\u2019t.\n\n\u201cPeople are afraid to rebrand these days because of the haters out there on the internet who can tear things apart,\u201d Mr. Matteson said.\n\nWhen the retailer Gap changed its iconic Spire-like font to Helvetica as part of a 2010 rebrand, customers pushed back hard. \u201cThe new logo lost all the personality the original mark had acquired over the years and was rolled out without explanation or rationale,\u201d said Matt See, senior art director at Siegelvision. \u201cIt felt like no thought was put into it.\u201d The company ultimately switched back to its original logo.\n\nExperts recommended that companies retain font experts and conduct plenty of surveys before making a change.\n\nWhen the real estate giant Remax decided to overhaul and update its logo and font for the first time in 44 years, the company spent two years and surveyed 20,000 people in the United States and Canada before pushing ahead with the changes.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cAt the end of the day, all of these images were going to be on yard signs throughout the world, so we wanted to be sure that it resonated with the consumer,\u201d said Abby Lee, vice president of marketing and media strategies at Remax. \u201cTrying to change a brand after 45 years with 115,000-plus agents out there is quite a task.\u201d\n\nThe company needed the font upgrade because its typefaces didn\u2019t translate well in the digital world: The firm\u2019s recognizable hot-air balloon logo and aging fonts became blurred on mobile devices. This posed a significant problem because 34 percent of current home buyers are millennials \u2014 a group that relies heavily on digital devices.\n\nDone right, fonts allow brands to showcase their human side and personality, which can then connect with consumers emotionally.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s about understanding the power of typography,\u201d said Mr. Frankfurt. \u201cThere are so many different ways that type communicates to us and acts in a voice and takes on a personality and it\u2019s more prevalent than ever.\u201d", "title": "Gothic or Helvetica? For Brands, Fonts Help Tell a Story", "authors": ["Janet Morrissey"]} {"date": "2018-04-08 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nGrace Hollingsworth Chapin and Jason Elliott James were married April 7 at Bond Chapel at the University of Chicago. Jonathan D. Williams, who was ordained by the Church of Spiritual Humanism, officiated, with Brian Droste leading the ceremony.\n\nMrs. James, 29, is a deputy director of undergraduate admissions at the University of Chicago. She graduated with general honors from the University of Chicago, and received a master's degree in higher education administration from Harvard.\n\nShe is a daughter of Susan Svacek Chapin and Paul H. Chapin of Spokane, Wash. Her father recently retired as the senior vice president of People to People Student Travel Programs in Spokane. Her mother, a registered nurse, is an infection prevention specialist at Providence Sacred Heart Medical Center, also in Spokane. She is the president of the board of directors of Spokane Public Schools.\n\nMr. James, 34, works in Chicago as an attorney-adviser for the Illinois Pollution Control Board, which adopts environmental regulations and adjudicates contested pollution-related cases for the state. He graduated from Notre Dame and received a law degree from the University of Virginia. He also earned a master's degree in public policy studies from the University of Chicago.\n\nHe is a son of Jeanne M. James and William C. James of Vienna, Va. The groom\u2019s mother is a preschool teacher at Wesley Preschool in Vienna. His father is the deputy assistant secretary in the office of information and technology at the Department of Veterans Affairs in Washington.\n\nThe couple were introduced through OkCupid during the summer of 2013 while Ms. Chapin was in China for work for several weeks. They had their first conversation via Skype, and made up for lost time three weeks later with an all-day date in the Logan Square area of Chicago.", "title": "Grace Chapin, Jason James", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-05 00:00:00", "text": "You\u2019re used to being on camera, but was it different to have documentarians follow you for years?\n\nOnce I decided I trusted Sophie, I just pretended she wasn\u2019t there. When you grow up in the modeling world, you get to a point where you are all the time having your guard up about how you look. There was maybe one time, I thought, oh, Sophie dear, I look a little bit fat there \u2014 [laughs] not like in my pictures. And I just say to myself, what am I doing? This is not about that. It\u2019s O.K. to be myself.\n\nYour stage presence is so fierce, what did it feel like to show yourself in more vulnerable, intimate moments, like meeting your newborn granddaughter?\n\nNormally I don\u2019t like people to see that vulnerable side of me, it\u2019s not a side that I normally would share with the world. But when I decided to do the film, I felt strong enough, actually, to show the vulnerable side. A lot of my stage performance [persona], I found out later, was actually coming from Mas P, who was my bully, who was an abuser. And I always thought maybe that is why that stronger side was there, to protect the little girl in me. I like to call the little girl Bev [her middle name, which she went by as a child, is Beverly], and Grace is the protector. [Laughs] I\u2019m starting to sound like Sybil.\n\nIn the film, we see how often you still have to keep people in line about how to respect your vision.\n\nThere\u2019s a lot of fantasy connected to me, I know that. I had to be very strict on managers, because sometimes they do have other agendas. I literally managed myself for 15 years. I learned a lot from working with Chris Blackwell [the Island Records founder, who released her debut studio album, \u201cPortfolio,\u201d in 1977]. I still call him one of my mentors. I believe he tested me on some things \u2014 when we were recording sometimes, and he wouldn\u2019t show up, just to see if I was going to handle everything right. And when things would go wrong, I would walk out of the studio. I\u2019ve done a lot worse than what you\u2019ve seen in the film. If I don\u2019t want something, people will tell you, there\u2019s nothing you can do \u2014 you couldn\u2019t pay me enough, you can\u2019t buy me to do something I don\u2019t like, and that\u2019s just how I am. I don\u2019t know if it\u2019s from growing up in a very, very strict family. It could be that \u2014 after I got out of there, and I had my own say, that I\u2019m going to stick with how I am feeling.", "title": "Grace Jones on a Lifetime of Doing Whatever She Pleases", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-22 00:00:00", "text": "It may seem unfair to single out South Africa for its corruption. It\u2019s not the worst offender in sub-Saharan Africa, and far from the worst in the world \u2014 India, China and Russia rank far worse on the Transparency International list, and South Africa has functioning democratic institutions and a lively press. But countries should be measured less against the rest of the world than against their own potential and promise, and on that score, the same African National Congress that Nelson Mandela led to a triumphant victory over apartheid a quarter century ago has become gorged on corruption.\n\nWhat is particularly galling, as Norimitsu Onishi and Selam Gebrekidan reported in The Times, is that so many of the millions filched from state coffers were earmarked to lift up the poor left behind by apartheid. While politically connected companies and individuals have grown wealthy, the gap between them and the poor, most of them blacks, has only grown. A recent report by the World Bank and the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development found that despite some progress since the end of apartheid, South Africa remains \u201cone of the most unequal countries in the world.\u201d\n\nThe potential for change was evident when the A.N.C. finally forced President Jacob Zuma out of office in February. Mr. Zuma\u2019s nine years in office were a byword for obscene corruption, and he now faces corruption, racketeering, fraud and money laundering charges. His successor, Cyril Ramaphosa, promised in his first state-of-the-nation address that \u201cthis is the year in which we will turn the tide of corruption in our public institutions.\u201d Yet President Ramaphosa is himself a veteran A.N.C. member and made a fortune largely through his ties to the party, and his cabinet includes officials who stand accused of corruption.\n\nMr. Mandela may have been partly responsible for the state of affairs when he struck a grand bargain with the white minority that finally gave the black majority control over politics but left many economic resources in the hands of whites. That, according to current perceptions cited in The Times article, created incentives to give and receive bribes.", "title": "Opinion | Graft in South Africa: The People Deserve Better", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-12 00:00:00", "text": "But now eastern Ghouta\u2019s beautiful agricultural landscape has again become a theater of extreme violence and inhumanity, recently described as \u201chell on earth\u201d by the United Nations. Back in August 2013, the area was subjected to a chemical attack that left some 1,400 dead.\n\nAlthough my grandma is old, she follows the ebb and flow of developments on the battlefield that she still considers her neighborhood \u2014 a region where she spent more than 70 years. Dreading the probable impact of the terrible news, her children have not yet told her that her house has been destroyed and looted. So she continues to want to return as soon as possible, and her family continues to put her off.\n\nThe spacious two-floored, three-bedroom house in eastern Ghouta has always been precious to Grandma. It was a gift from her father upon his death. Back in the 1940s, for a Syrian woman to have a whole house in her own right was a mark of advanced empowerment. She treasured the gift, lived in it for decades, and has always taken pride in her ownership. Indeed, every time I visited Grandma on weekends before the civil war broke out, she would tell us stories about her house and how she spent much of her lifetime\u2019s savings to renovate and maintain it.\n\nIn the Syrian culture, a house is worth more than its economic value. It is the source of emotional and physical well-being and security. Family ties are strong, and the idea of placing your mother in a home for the elderly is not socially acceptable; it would bring disgrace to the whole family.\n\nLosing a house is particularly devastating for the elderly. Before Grandma was forced to leave, she would rarely spend a night outside her house. Now she has been displaced for some five years, staying at her children\u2019s homes in Damascus, and changing beds every couple of months. Being displaced is difficult for her. But losing all hope of returning home would feel like losing a beloved child forever.", "title": "Opinion | Grandma Wants to Return Home. I Can\u2019t Tell Her Home Is Gone.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-14 00:00:00", "text": "HELENA, Mont. \u2014 The battle to save the so-called gray ghosts \u2014 the only herd of caribou in the lower 48 states \u2014 has been lost.\n\nA recent aerial survey shows that this international herd of southern mountain caribou, which spends part of its year in the Selkirk Mountains of northern Idaho and Washington near the Canadian border, has dwindled to just three animals and should be considered \u201cfunctionally extinct,\u201d experts say.\n\nThe Selkirk herd had been disappearing for the last several years.\n\nIn 2009, the herd, the southernmost in North America, had about 50 animals and was declining. Wildlife officials in Canada began a last-ditch effort to protect them by killing wolves, which occasionally preyed on the few caribou that remained.\n\nBut the root cause of the extirpation of this herd and the decline of others in Canada is extensive industrial development in British Columbia, experts say.", "title": "Gray Ghosts, the Last Caribou in the Lower 48 States, Are \u2018Functionally Extinct\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-19 00:00:00", "text": "But he added that the decision was unlikely to \u201ctopple\u201d the deal between Turkey and the European Union. The decision on Wednesday, which is not retroactive, will not apply to the more than 15,000 refugees already being held in detention centers for months or even years while their asylum applications are reviewed.\n\nGreece and Turkey have a long history of tensions over territory and sovereignty, which could aggravate the situation. \u201cThe tension does not help the management of the refugee and migration issue,\u201d the migration minister, Dimitris Vitsas, said on Tuesday. \u201cOn the contrary, it creates problems, so it is in our interest and that of Turkey to reduce the tension and the rhetoric.\u201d\n\nWith spring weather improving in Europe, the number of refugees trying to reach European shores has begun to rise again, and dozens arrive each day. That is significantly less, however, than the thousands who crossed the Aegean each day at the peak of the refugee crisis in early 2016.\n\nThe 28 countries in the European Union granted asylum to 538,000 people in 2017, almost 25 percent less than in 2016, according to Eurostat, the statistics arm of the organization. Syrians, Afghans and Iraqis made up 64 percent of those granted protection.\n\nMore than 60 percent of those granted asylum had applied in Germany, with the next largest numbers of successful applications in France, Italy and Austria. Does your spouse have a tattoo? What movies did you watch when you started dating? (One tip: Don\u2019t say \u201cGreen Card.\u201d) Couples must prove that their relationships are real by providing proof they live together or photographs of their time together.\n\nStill, officials and immigration lawyers caution that answering all of the questions correctly doesn\u2019t necessarily result in a green card. And lately, the bar has been a lot higher for immigrants in the country illegally.\n\nHere is a sampling of questions gathered from immigration lawyers that you can test with your partner. (In the real world, officers can separate applicants to make sure they\u2019re not gaming the system.) The questions will get more difficult as we go on.\n\nHow did you meet?\n\nHow soon after you met did you start dating?\n\nWhen did you meet each other\u2019s families?\n\nHow did you decide on getting married?\n\nWhere did you buy the ring?\n\nWhat was the wedding like and who attended?\n\nWhat did you do afterward?\n\nWhere did you eat?\n\nThe goal is to tell the immigration officer your love story.", "title": "Green Card Marriage Interview: Can You Pass It?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-19 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nGregg Popovich did not coach Game 3 of the Spurs-Warriors N.B.A. playoff series on Thursday night after his wife\u2019s death.\n\nErin Popovich died at 67, the Spurs announced on Wednesday. She had been married to Gregg for 40 years, and they had two children and four grandchildren. A cause of death was not reported, but she had been ill for some time. The Popoviches met when Gregg was an assistant coach at Air Force and Erin was the daughter of a team trainer.\n\nFollowing a 110-97 loss to the defending champion Golden State Warriors, the Spurs are down three games to none and are one loss away from being eliminated from the playoffs. Grenfell Tower residents had complained about fire safety for several years and accused the authorities of ignoring those complaints.\n\nResidents also allege that regulators put cost before safety, saying that cheap, combustible materials used on the exterior of the building in a major refurbishment in 2014 might have helped spread the flames.\n\nThe police have said that there are reasonable grounds to suspect that the local council and the organization that managed the tower block had committed corporate manslaughter.\n\nThe council and the management organization have refused to comment on the allegations while a criminal investigation into the causes of the fire\u2019s rapid spread is still in progress.\n\nGrenfell United, an organization for the survivors of the fire, said that the council\u2019s recovery efforts lacked a \u201chumanitarian aspect.\u201d\n\nShahin Sadafi, a spokesman for Grenfell United, questioned why the local council started to buy properties before asking survivors what kind of housing they needed. Local politicians say the $30 million spent on hotels would have been enough to rebuild the original tower at least three times over.\n\nAn independent task force that has been assessing the recovery for Grenfell residents said the local council had made a \u201chuge effort\u201d at rehousing. He told Parliament that only 62 of 202 displaced households had been resettled into permanent housing.\n\nAlan Carter, a member of Justice4Grenfell, a community-led organization, said that while many survivors had found it difficult to make snap decisions about their futures, the council had not been prepared to give them the guidance and options necessary to meet their needs quickly.\n\n\u201cThe waiting has been agonizing for some of the bereaved families,\u201d Mr. Carter said.\n\n\u201cThe council keeps talking about progress,\u201d he added. \u201cBut the fact that we have dozens of people in hotels nine months after such a terrible tragedy is really shameful and unacceptable.\u201d", "title": "Grenfell Tower Survivors Still Displaced 10 Months After Blaze", "authors": ["Ceylan Yeginsu"]} {"date": "2018-04-30 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nCoffee may not be rocket science, but despite the title, even a quick spin through this highly detailed volume suggests it might come close. Consider more than 30 pages just about espresso, best served in a china cup at least a quarter-inch thick. For most filter methods, a kettle with a gooseneck spout is essential. A coffee lover is sure to find plenty that\u2019s useful in this illustrated book, which is mostly about making the beverage properly. Coffee around the world, a coffee lexicon, production, equipment, grinding, storing, proportions and temperatures are all in there: \u201cCoffee Isn\u2019t Rocket Science: A Quick & Easy Guide to Buying, Brewing, Serving, Roasting & Tasting Coffee\u201d by S\u00e9bastien Racineux and Chung-Leng Tran (Black Dog & Leventhal, $24.99).\n\nFollow NYT Food on Facebook, Instagram, Twitter and Pinterest. The Grindr controversy also highlights the widening regulatory gap between the United States, which lacks a comprehensive federal consumer privacy law, and Europe, where privacy is viewed as a fundamental human right, with laws to back it up.\n\nGrindr, which is owned by the Kunlun Group, a company based in Hong Kong, has more than 3.6 million active users. The Norwegian Consumer Council, a nonprofit group in Oslo that first raised concerns about the company\u2019s practices, said the dating app had shared users\u2019 H.I.V. status with two software companies, Apptimize and Localytics. Although the app encrypted the H.I.V. status data, the analysis found that Grindr had shared other highly sensitive details \u2014 including users\u2019 romantic aims and self-identified tribes like \u201cleather\u201d or \u201cbear\u201d \u2014 with an ad-targeting company without encryption.\n\nIn a complaint to the Norwegian data protection agency, the group said Grindr had violated a European data protection law that requires special protections for processing sensitive data including details about health and sex. The group said Grindr had also violated a provision in the law that requires companies to obtain informed consent before using people\u2019s data for new purposes.\n\nIn its statement, Grindr said that it worked with software vendors to improve its platform and that, in doing so, it may share details about users\u2019 H.I.V. status or location. The company reminded users that \u201cGrindr is a public forum\u201d and that they should know that data they included in their profiles, including their H.I.V. status, would become public.", "title": "Grindr Sets Off Privacy Firestorm After Sharing Users\u2019 H.I.V.-Status Data", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-05 00:00:00", "text": "They also said there was no system at all, only a group of organizations and volunteers doing their best to keep up with a torrent of vitriol.\n\n\u201cIn your interview, you refer to your detection \u2018systems.\u2019 We believe your system, in this case, was us \u2014 and we were far from systematic,\u201d the letter says. \u201cFrom where we stand, this case exemplifies the very opposite of effective moderation: It reveals an overreliance on third parties, a lack of a proper mechanism for emergency escalation, a reticence to engage local stakeholders around systemic solutions and a lack of transparency.\u201d\n\nFacebook responded to the criticism in a satement on Friday. \u201cWe are sorry that Mark did not make clearer that it was the civil society groups in Myanmar who first reported these messages,\u201d it said. \u201cWe took their reports very seriously and immediately investigated ways to help prevent the spread of this content. We should have been faster, and are working hard to improve our technology and tools to detect and prevent abusive, hateful or false content.\u201d\n\nMyanmar highlights existential questions about Facebook\u2019s mission and responsibilities. The site has closely connected people in the country \u2014 in many cases, Facebook is the only online service they use. It has also become a major channel for the spread of hate speech and propaganda that has encouraged and obfuscated ethnic cleansing of the country\u2019s Muslim Rohingya, according to human rights groups.\n\nAlmost 700,000 Rohingya have fled to neighboring Bangladesh since last summer, when the military started a crackdown in the country\u2019s western Rakhine State. Last month, United Nations investigators said Facebook played a role in spreading hate speech that incited violence against the Rohingya.\n\nFor Mr. Zuckerberg, the timing of the letter is bad. Both he and his top deputy, Sheryl Sandberg, are making multiple media appearances this week to address questions about how the company handles users\u2019 personal data. The company has faced harsh criticism for reports on how information about millions of users may have been improperly leaked to a political consulting firm connected to President Trump\u2019s 2016 campaign.\n\nThe criticism has sent the company\u2019s stock tumbling. Next week, Mr. Zuckerberg is expected to appear at multiple congressional hearings.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAmong the half-dozen signatories of the letter posted on Thursday in Myanmar are Phandeeyar, a leading technology hub in the country that helped Facebook draft its Burmese-language community standards; Myanmar ICT for Development Organization, which monitors online hate speech; and the Center for Social Integrity.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Interested in All Things Tech?
