After interviewing each family member, they found that Jennifer \u2014 the more domineering of the couple \u2014 would travel with the children to music festivals several weeks a year, that Sarah was a retail manager at a Kohl\u2019s and that the family received about $2,000 a month in adoption assistance.\n\nInvestigators also interviewed at least two women who knew the family, and they painted a disturbing portrait of the Harts\u2019 home life. They told investigators that the children had to raise their hands before speaking, got in trouble for laughing at the dinner table and in one instance were prohibited from telling one of the children, Markis, \u201cHappy Birthday\u201d on his birthday.\n\nIn another episode, one of the women told investigators, Jennifer stayed with the children at her home. They ordered pizza, but Jennifer would allow her children to have only a small piece. The next morning, though, the pizza was gone \u2014 and Jennifer was irate, according to the documents. She told the woman that none of the children would be eating breakfast because none of them had admitted to having eaten the pizza. The woman said Jennifer then forced all the children to lie on their bed for about five hours as punishment.\n\nStill, officials with child protective services ultimately said that they were \u201cunable to determine\u201d if the women were guilty of neglect, according to the documents. They also said they could not identify a \u201csafety threat.\u201d", "title": "Hart Family, Before Driving Off Cliff, Hid Dark Home Life From View", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-12 00:00:00", "text": "In Brazil, where independent judges have exercised a direct impact on the electoral process, have they not opened the way to extremist rabble-rousers like the conservative candidate Jair Bolsonaro, while simultaneously making the country ungovernable?\n\nAnd are the calls for an internationally supported truth commission on corruption and human rights violations in Mexico a symptom of civil society being fed up with interminable scandals, or a menace to the country\u2019s eternally weak justice system?\n\nThere are no simple answers to these questions. Any flat-out judgment, in either direction, is bound to be schematic and skewed. The facts on the ground are that with two or three exceptions \u2014 Uruguay, Chile and perhaps Costa Rica \u2014 no country in Latin America has ever been spared massive doses of corruption. Standing institutions alone have never functioned effectively either in wiping it out, diminishing it noticeably or taking action against impunity for corruption or human rights violations. Regarding the latter plague, for which the region has a dismal reputation even today, international cooperation of one sort or another has proved indispensable for bringing criminals to justice or at least naming and shaming them for generations to come. The best example lies probably in Guatemala, but also in Argentina, where former presidents of the Junta were indicted and jailed for human rights violations.\n\nThere appears to be no choice but to place any attempt to deal legally, democratically and effectively with the lack of punishment above other considerations: institution-building, national sovereignty, political stability, short-term economic performance. Developments over the past few years in all the region\u2019s countries are positive, hopeful ones. In the end, they will strengthen civil society, representative democracy, the rule of law and economic progress. They do not weaken institutions; they help to transform them and make them function.\n\nSimilarly, taking corruption to a supranational level that must be addressed through international cooperation is not an abdication of sovereignty; it is a desirable change.\n\nIn fact, this is perhaps the most imaginative and productive route for the fight against corruption. It is, by definition, a transnational phenomenon: People who steal money hide it far from where they stole it.\n\nThe Odebrecht scandal, the Panama Papers, the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act in the United States and the European Union\u2019s equivalent legislation are all indicators of the need and the tradition of taking on corruption beyond strictly national borders. The inclusion of an anti-corruption chapter in the new Nafta currently being negotiated by Mexico, the United States and Canada is a step in the right direction. But much more has to be done with regard to this supranational approach.", "title": "Opinion | Has Latin America\u2019s Crusade Against Corruption Gone Too Far?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-06 00:00:00", "text": "#Speakingindance\n\nHaunted by the Familiar\n\nThe choreographer and dancer Jack Ferver made this duet, part of his new show \u201cEverything Is Imaginable,\u201d for himself and his old friend Reid Bartelme.", "title": "Haunted by the Familiar", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-23 00:00:00", "text": "One of those fans is Vince Vernon, who sells commercial insurance and served his mission in Hawaii from 2000 to 2002. Mo\u2019 Bettahs, he said, \u201ctook the environment in Hawaii \u2014 where everyone is happy to see you, where people are constantly feeding you, where there\u2019s so much food that you cannot see the bottom of the table \u2014 and they brought that here.\u201d\n\nAt one point, Mr. Vernon said, he visited the restaurant every day for six weeks because it reminded him so strongly of his mission experience. \u201cAnd it\u2019s the best food I have ever had in my life,\u201d he said. \u201cI can\u2019t even begin to describe the endorphin release from that chicken katsu.\u201d\n\nTodd Bangerter, a plumber, served his mission in Kaneohe from 2002 to 2004. \u201cI am a redneck hunting guy from Utah, and by the time I left Hawaii, I felt so much like part of the culture,\u201d Mr. Bangerter said. \u201cI really grew up there.\u201d\n\nTo have a place as true to his memories as Mo\u2019 Bettahs, he said, \u201call the way in Utah, where the biggest body of water close to the ocean is the Great Salt Lake \u2014 it\u2019s amazing.\u201d From his first taste of the macaroni salad, he said, it was like he was back in Hawaii.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe Macks quickly became celebrities in local Mormon circles. \u201cIt got to the point that when I changed congregations, I walked in and everyone knew who I was,\u201d Kimo said. \u201cThey were like, \u2018You\u2019re the Mo\u2019 Bettahs guy!\u2019\u201d\n\nThere is one subset of the local Mormon population that the brothers acknowledge they have not been as successful in wooing: people of Polynesian descent.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nOn a recent afternoon at the original restaurant, a table of teenage Samoan-American girls agreed that the food didn\u2019t have the depth of seasoning they were used to.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s good for Utah, but I\u2019ve had Hawaiian barbecue with a lot more flavor,\u201d said one, Charlotte McFarland. \u201cA lot of the cooks here are white, so they don\u2019t know how to season because they didn\u2019t grow up cooking this food. This chicken katsu just tastes fried.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nA local Lyft driver from the Philippines who has spent much of his life in Hawaii said the food at Mo\u2019 Bettahs was \u201cnot sweet enough\u201d for his tastes.\n\nThis response doesn\u2019t surprise the Macks. Polynesia has people of so many backgrounds that \u201ceveryone makes their food a little differently,\u201d Kalani said. \u201cThat\u2019s why we don\u2019t want to rely on that Polynesian audience, because I think so few of them actually eat with us, and those that do are our harshest critics.\u201d\n\nStill, business continues to look up. Mo\u2019 Bettahs has opened five more locations in Utah, and the brothers say they are one opening away from making $1 million in sales each month. \u201cI\u2019m an island boy who didn\u2019t go to school, so that\u2019s like, whoa!\u201d Kimo said.\n\nIn 2017, the Macks entered into a partnership with the Utah restaurant development company Four Foods Group to standardize their business operations and grow the brand nationally. (Four Foods says it holds a 50.1 percent stake in the chain.)\n\nPhoto\n\nAndrew and Shauna Smith, the group\u2019s founders, said they were impressed by the economics of the restaurant. \u201cYou get so much food for your money, but the food cost is lower than average in the industry,\u201d Mr. Smith said. There are also not many Hawaiian restaurants in Utah to compete with Mo\u2019 Bettahs.\n\nThe plan is to open six more Utah locations starting this summer, with a branch in Idaho \u2014 which also has a large Mormon population \u2014 to follow next year. After that, Mo\u2019 Bettahs plans to expand to states like Nevada and Missouri, in cities where housing costs are low and incomes are high.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nFour Foods has gotten Mo\u2019 Bettahs onto Instagram and Twitter, and expanded its presence on Facebook, which the Mack brothers had all but stopped using once they realized their fellow Mormons provided a much more powerful social platform.\n\n\u201cWe\u2019ve got this network of people from all over the world just because of the connectivity of the church,\u201d Kimo said. \u201cThey have become our customers, our business partners, our insurance guys, our graphic design team.\u201d\n\nIt helps that the teriyaki steak inspires devotion, too.\n\n\u201cThis food is the next big thing,\u201d said Mr. Vernon. \u201cIt\u2019s going to be better than Chipotle and Panda Express.\u201d\n\nFollow NYT Food on Facebook, Instagram, Twitter and Pinterest. Get regular updates from NYT Cooking, with recipe suggestions, cooking tips and shopping advice.", "title": "Hawaiian Food Is Flourishing \u2026 in Utah?", "authors": ["Priya Krishna"]} {"date": "2018-04-09 00:00:00", "text": "Scans of his head and neck showed the kind of constriction in some arteries that can cause intense headaches, doctors reported on Monday in BMJ Case Reports. The scientific term for this temporary narrowing of arteries is reversible cerebral vasoconstriction syndrome.\n\nDr. Kulothungan Gunasekaran, one of the report\u2019s authors, now at the Henry Ford Hospital in Detroit, said that for some reason the man must have been particularly sensitive to capsaicin. The Carolina Reaper is a popular pepper, and many people eat them and experience nothing worse than the desire to cut out their own tongues.\n\n\u201cI was discussing the case with a nurse who had eaten three Carolina Reapers,\u201d Dr. Gunasekaran recalled.\n\nThe Reaper has been measured at more than two million Scoville heat units, the accepted scale for how hot peppers are. Measurements vary, but a really hot habanero might come in at 500,000 Scoville units.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Science Times Newsletter Every week, we\u2019ll bring you stories that capture the wonders of the human body, nature and the cosmos. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe patient was fine, with no lingering damage, but thunderclap headaches are not to be dismissed. For one thing, there\u2019s the pain, which seems to surpass even the normal effect of the peppers.\n\nDr. Lawrence C. Newman, a neurologist and director of the headache division at NYU Langone Health, said, \u201cOn a one to ten scale, it\u2019s off the charts.\u201d And it can indicate the kind of stroke that results from bleeding in the brain.\n\nIt happens instantaneously. If that kind of headache hits you, it makes sense to seek medical attention \u201cwhether you\u2019ve bitten into a pepper or not,\u201d Dr. Newman said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe new study does suggest that capsaicin, being investigated for its role in alleviating pain and lowering blood pressure, can have unexpected effects on certain people.\n\nCayenne pepper pills and a capsaicin patch, sold in China and Turkey, have been blamed in medical reports for two nonfatal heart attacks in young men, the result of spasms in arteries.\n\nBut \u201cwe are not advising anything against the Carolina Reaper,\u201d Dr. Gunasekaran said.\n\nThe Reaper was bred to reach record levels of heat. Reached by phone at the PuckerButt Pepper Company in Fort Mill, S.C., the Reaper\u2019s creator, Ed Currie, offered mixed advice on pepper consumption.\n\nOn the one hand, he said, \u201cPeople who eat whole Reapers are just being stupid.\u201d But Smokin\u2019 Ed, as he calls himself, also gave the impression that wasn\u2019t such a bad thing. \u201cWe eat them all the time,\u201d he said, with no ill consequences beyond pain.\n\nMr. Currie indulges in other competitions of suffering. For instance, he said, he had recently taken the Death Nut Challenge, which involves eating insanely hot peanuts. He has a partnership with a company that produces them.\n\n\u201cI knew beforehand I shouldn\u2019t do it,\u201d Mr. Currie said. \u201cI was in pain for two hours.\u201d\n\nFor the average person interested in spice, not suffering, he advised using small amounts of any really hot pepper in food preparation, as they were intended.\n\nSo if you happen to go beyond your limits \u2014 having, say, entered a hot-pepper-eating competition?\n\n\u201cCitric acid seems to work the best to alleviate the pain,\u201d he said. \u201cDon\u2019t chug milk because you\u2019ll just throw it up.\u201d", "title": "He Ate the World\u2019s Hottest Pepper, Then Landed in the Hospital With \u2018Thunderclap\u2019 Headaches", "authors": ["James Gorman"]} {"date": "2018-04-15 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cHe touched a lot of people,\u201d Mr. Morales said. \u201cWe didn\u2019t come from privilege, we came from the projects. He was a light in a lot of our lives.\u201d\n\nThe act of self-immolation was so shocking, the loss so sudden, that friends and family of Mr. Buckel struggled on Sunday to make sense of his legacy, if not his death.\n\n\u201cHe was very much someone who felt like he always wanted to make sure that while he was alive that he was doing more to make the world a better place,\u201d his partner of nearly 34 years, Terry Kaelber, said. \u201cAnd he wanted to give more than he was taking from it.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nSuicide is, ultimately, ineffable, and experts caution that there is a rarely a single reason people take their own lives; they say there are often underlying issues, such as mental illness.\n\nHis family and friends acknowledged that Mr. Buckel had become distraught recently over the national politics of climate change \u2014 \u201call that\u2019s going on with the Trump administration and the rollback by Pruitt at the Environmental Protection Agency,\u201d Mr. Kaelber said, referring to agency\u2019s embattled administrator, Scott Pruitt.\n\nIn retrospect, Mr. Morales said he knew Mr. Buckel had been upset as recently as February when he began discussing articles about the environment, for instance one about how 96 percent of human beings breathe polluted air and another about the Arctic Circle experiencing record breaking temperatures.\n\nMr. Morales said two weeks ago Mr. Buckel sent him an email with all his contacts for the compost site, showing him how to complete paperwork, annual reports and other documents that would need to be turned over to city agencies.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWith a back injury that limited his work, Mr. Buckel was struggling over what he could do next. Mr. Kaelber said he interpreted this \u201cdramatic act\u201d as \u201cwhat can a person at age 60 do that people would pay attention to.\u201d\n\nMr. Buckel started his career as a Legal Aid lawyer, and gained national prominence by arguing cases with Lambda Legal, an organization that fights for the civil rights of lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender people.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMr. Buckel was the lead lawyer in the case in which a Nebraska sheriff was found liable for failing to protect a transgender man who was murdered in Falls City, and was the strategist behind same-sex marriage cases in New Jersey and Iowa.\n\nHe retired from Lambda Legal in November 2008, and was a grant writer before starting at the composting site at the farm, across from an Ikea store. He felt composting was something that community members could do together to bring about a more sustainable world.\n\nMr. Buckel lived his message. He took showers with a minimum use of water, and walked one hour to work and back from his home at the edge of Prospect Park, rather than use fossil fuels. He refused even to use machines at the composting site, evidence of a passion that friends say was his true fuel.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cI think he had a purity of spirit that was not a possibility in this world and that pained him very much,\u201d said Marisa DeDominicis, the executive director of Earth Matter, which composts on Governors Island.\n\nErik Martig went to YouTube to remember his mentor, who had made a series of instructional videos for the tight-knit community of urban composters. In his typical calm and methodical manner, Mr. Buckel explained how to make neat, rat-proof compost piles with pitchforks, shovels and teamwork.\n\n\u201cThis is the David Buckel that I knew,\u201d said Mr. Martig, 34, who worked with Mr. Buckel at the farm.\n\n\u201cI struggle to believe that this is a protest suicide. I think that, underneath, he\u2019s got to be in a very dark place, it\u2019s not characteristic of David,\u201d he added.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nOn a grim Sunday, neighbors gathered at Mr. Buckel\u2019s home.\n\nGeorge Bachman, a retired firefighter, would greet him tending his garden on a quiet stretch south of Prospect Park. His 16-year-old daughter knew Mr. Buckel\u2019s college-age daughter, Hannah.\n\nHe knew the history of Mr. Buckel\u2019s kind of suicide, but was perplexed. \u201cI\u2019m a Vietnam veteran so I\u2019m well aware,\u201d Mr. Bachman said. \u201cBuddhist monks used to light themselves up in protest of the war.\u201d\n\nMr. Buckel alluded in his letter to the self-immolation of Tibetans as protest against China\u2019s government.\n\nTom and Isa Cucinotta of Lefferts Gardens spent a few minutes in silence at the site in Prospect Park where Mr. Buckel died. They did not know him, but they felt a kinship with him and his despair with the current state of the world.\n\n\u201cIt feels important because he was one of the people able to do something about these injustices. He was successful, whereas we can only do little things,\u201d Ms. Cucinotta said. \u201cIt feels like he has given up. What does that mean for the rest of us?\u201d", "title": "He Called Out Sick, Then Apologized for Leaving This World", "authors": ["Liz Robbins", "Jan Ransom"]} {"date": "2018-04-13 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. David praised Ms. Schmitt, 44, and Ms. Stuart, 52, both psychologists in the Raleigh-Durham area of North Carolina. \u201cThey provided the best quality of life he could\u2019ve hoped for under the circumstances,\u201d he said.\n\nAcknowledging the 21-year gap between the abuse and Mr. Stuart\u2019s death, Mr. David said it was still legally possible to bring homicide charges because North Carolina has no statute of limitations on felonies. He added that it was not uncommon for a murder prosecution to follow an assault prosecution when victims die.\n\nThe North Carolina Office of the Chief Medical Examiner did not immediately respond to a request for information about the cause of Mr. Stuart\u2019s death.\n\nIn North Carolina, a first-degree murder conviction can result in a death sentence or life in prison without parole. Mr. Tripp\u2019s lawyer, W. James Payne, said his client \u201cintends to maintain his innocence and defend himself before the court.\u201d A lawyers for Ms. Noffsinger did not respond to requests for comment.\n\nThe district attorney\u2019s office said Ms. Noffsinger and Mr. Tripp were being held at the Brunswick County Jail on $1 million bail and are scheduled to appear in Brunswick County Superior Court on June 6.\n\nMs. Schmitt said that as she adjusted to life without Mr. Stuart, she wanted to focus on \u201cthe good memories, not just the abuse.\u201d\n\n\u201cIt was a lot of work,\u201d she said of raising him. \u201cBut I would do it all over again.\u201d", "title": "He Died 21 Years After Being Abused. Prosecutors Are Calling it Murder.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-29 00:00:00", "text": "The era of driverless cars is coming down the road.\n\nBut not quickly enough for one British man, who ran afoul of the law when he was caught in the front passenger seat of a Tesla set to Autopilot, cruising at about 40 miles per hour with his hands behind his head.\n\nNo one was in the driver\u2019s seat.\n\nWitnesses told the police that \u201ctraffic was heavy\u201d last May when they saw the nondriver, Bhavesh Patel, 39, of Nottingham, England, in his white Tesla S60 on the M1 motorway near Hemel Hempstead.\n\nThe police said in a statement that Mr. Patel, who had owned the car for about five months before the stunt, admitted that what he had done was \u201csilly\u201d but said that the car was capable of something \u201camazing\u201d and that he was just the \u201cunlucky one who got caught.\u201d\n\nOn April 20, Mr. Patel pleaded guilty to dangerous driving, and a court barred him from driving for 18 months.", "title": "He Drove a Tesla on Autopilot From the Passenger Seat. The Court Was Not Amused.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-24 00:00:00", "text": "For years now you\u2019ve been seen as an opponent of the Church, especially in Chile, where you and your friends accused the bishops of a cover-up. But didn\u2019t you join Father Karadima\u2019s Catholic community in Santiago because you wanted to be a priest?\n\nWhen I joined I was 15, 16. My dad had just died. I was so vulnerable. And I was such a good kid. I wanted to change the world. Since I was a kid I wanted to be a priest. I wanted to die a martyr in Africa if that meant I was going to bring people to God. I had all these dreams.\n\nWhy did you give that up?\n\nThere was massive abuse. This man, Father Karadima, was abusing kids and young people from 1958 through 2010 or 11. I was there eight years, in this setting, under his spell.\n\nHis spell! I know he was pretty powerful in the Chilean church and some of his disciples were made bishops. But you make it sound like he was more than just a regular priest.\n\nThey called him \u201cSantito,\u201d the saint. Probably he would have been made a saint if people didn\u2019t speak up about the abuse. People saved things that he would give them, because we all expected he was going to be made a saint. If he gave you a book and he signed it, you kept it as a relic.\n\nYou have insisted that Bishop Juan Barros Madrid and other bishops in Chile who were mentored by Father Karadima were aware of the sexual abuse. But how do you know that they knew?\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThey would witness when Karadima was kissing someone on the lips, or sticking his tongue in someone\u2019s mouth. Or when we were in Karadima\u2019s room, and he would say, now everybody out. Everybody knew what happened after that. But nobody ever spoke about it.\n\nHow hard was it for you and Jimmy and Jose Andres to decide to sue and take the case public?\n\nI remember the first time we met the lawyer, Juan Pablo Hermosilla \u2014 I only knew he was a famous attorney who had fought Pinochet, the dictator. He said to me, \u201cI want you to be very sure of what you\u2019re doing, because you\u2019re gay and they\u2019re going to descend on you like you cannot imagine.\u201d And that\u2019s exactly what happened. It got to the point where [Chilean Cardinal] Err\u00e1zuriz once said I might have liked being molested, so he wasn\u2019t sure I was a victim. It turned out that being gay was the least of my sufferings, because the way they treated all of us was just horrific.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAnd Cardinal Err\u00e1zuriz \u2014 he\u2019s one of the nine cardinals that Pope Francis chose to be on his council of nine advisers?\n\nRight. That\u2019s what I want to ask the pope: How could you have George Pell [the Australian cardinal charged with sexual assault] and Francisco Err\u00e1zuriz on your council? I\u2019m sure there are other cardinals out there who are good people. You have 120 or something to choose from.\n\nIt sounds like you\u2019re angry at the pope. Are you?\n\nThere\u2019s been moments that I was. I don\u2019t want to be angry at him and I understand that people make mistakes. But this is the most informed man in the world. That is a question mark for me. Why he didn\u2019t act on it faster or understand the situation faster, and had to put everybody through such pain?\n\nIs it true that Pope Francis invited the three of you to stay with him in Casa Santa Marta?\n\nI\u2019m going to be there a week. Probably sleeping three doors down from him. He wants to meet individually with each one of us, and he cleared his agenda Sunday to meet with me. But this encounter, as much as I am so honored, it won\u2019t end up in anything if it doesn\u2019t result in concrete actions. And firing a few bishops won\u2019t do the trick.\n\n\n\nIt sounds like you are expecting Pope Francis to fire Bishop Barros for failing to report Father Karadima\u2019s abuse.\n\nWell, I\u2019m assuming.\n\nWhat if he doesn\u2019t?\n\nIt will be a really bad thing. It will be really disappointing, and I mean the biggest disappointment I\u2019ve ever had.\n\nDo you think you\u2019re also looking to the pope to be a pastor to you? The pastor that Father Karadima failed to be?\n\nProbably. Because I have an image of the pope that no matter how shattered my image of him is, he\u2019s the pope. I hope we all get some kind of healing out of this, for ourselves.", "title": "He Forced the Vatican to Investigate Sex Abuse. Now He\u2019s Meeting With Pope Francis.", "authors": ["Laurie Goodstein"]} {"date": "2018-04-18 00:00:00", "text": "The improvised explosive device that Petty Officer Third Class Jeremiah Foxwell approached in September 2006 resembled hundreds of others he had destroyed in and around Baghdad. On the ground was a damaged artillery shell that had been ejected by a roadside blast. Brown crystals around its nose looked like a homemade explosive that local insurgents often used.\n\nFoxwell\u2019s orders were to remove old shells from the battlefield. He prepared to lift the munition and carry it to his truck. \u201cI stood it upright and basically got a face full of fumes,\u201d he said.\n\nIn that moment, Foxwell unwittingly became the Navy\u2019s first known chemical-warfare casualty in Iraq after the 2003 invasion. The weapon in his hands was an aging mustard shell.\n\nWithin hours of exposure, Foxwell sought treatment for dry eyes, dried blood in his nose and chest tightness. He was admitted to the base\u2019s clinic for 24-hour observation. Symptoms of mustard-agent exposure can take a day or more to fully appear. Two days after the incident, Foxwell went back to the clinic with chest pain, difficulty breathing and \u201craw openings of skin\u201d inside his nose. Despite his symptoms, he was returned to duty within days.", "title": "He Inhaled Mustard Agent in Iraq, but the Navy Denied Him a Purple Heart", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-07 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cThe relationship Lorena had with children was magic,\u201d her colleagues wrote in a tribute later. \u201cWhenever Lorena was around, the environment was radiant.\u201d\n\nMr. Nasim\u2019s attack put at risk a treasured institution run by the Red Cross for nearly three decades, serving thousands of the war wounded in northern Afghanistan. Not only was the orthopedic center closed for two months after the killing, but the agency is now looking to transfer it to another group if it can find one willing to take it over.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Nasim struggled to explain what he had done and why. First, he described it as an impulsive act. But he had brought the gun to Mazar-i-Sharif from his home in Baghlan Province two days before the shooting, which would have required smuggling it past numerous checkpoints along the way.\n\nThen he claimed the Taliban had forced him to do it, threatening to kill his family if he did not. The Taliban vehemently denied that, praising the work the Red Cross does. In a separate interview, Mr. Nasim\u2019s own father, Amin Jan, scoffed at his son\u2019s claim and disowned him.\n\n\u201cI don\u2019t know what made me do this,\u201d Mr. Nasim said.\n\nHe is far from the only Afghan to have killed a foreigner with no apparent provocation. In 2014, a police officer killed an Associated Press photographer. Another killed three Americans at a hospital. Both told investigators they did not know why they had done it.\n\nNeither had any known Taliban or insurgent connections; nor did Mr. Nasim.\n\nWhile his motivations are murky, Mr. Nasim makes no effort to deny his guilt.\n\nUZBEK. TAJIKISTAN TURKMENISTAN Mazar-i- Sharif BAGHLAN Kabul AFGHANISTAN Khost PAKISTAN 100 miles\n\n\u201cI will go to hell for what I did,\u201d he said. \u201cI should just be killed.\u201d\n\nMr. Nasim has yet to be tried on the murder and terrorism charges he faces. Afghanistan has the death penalty and often uses it.\n\nHe has already paid a price. Mr. Nasim shares a cell in the Mazar-i-Sharif prison with 40 others. One of his orthotic braces fell off during his arrest and was left behind, as was his wheelchair. In prison, his other brace broke.\n\n\u201cNow I am not able to walk any more,\u201d he said. \u201cI just go around on my hands.\u201d\n\nHe said he would not ask the Red Cross to fix his braces or return his wheelchair.\n\n\u201cI am too ashamed,\u201d he said. Another prisoner had to carry him on his back a short distance from his cell to the prison\u2019s telephone office for the interview.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Nasim said he was less worried about his own condition than about the Red Cross center\u2019s future.\n\n\u201cI would be ready to die to keep that center open now,\u201d he said. \u201cNo one knows more than me how much we are helpless without them.\u201d", "title": "He Killed a Red Cross Worker: \u2018I Will Go to Hell for What I Did\u2019", "authors": ["Rod Nordland"]} {"date": "2018-04-22 00:00:00", "text": "It has also been widely covered in Israel and has created some unease among the public, which has widely supported the military\u2019s actions on the border.\n\nCriticizing the military for not expressing regret about the killing, the military affairs correspondent of the Maariv newspaper, Tal Lev Ram, wrote in a commentary on Sunday: \u201cThe death of a Palestinian teenager, hostile as he may be, must not find us indifferent and unresponsive. Indifference in this case is first and foremost our own loss.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nIsolated and impoverished, plagued by chronic electricity shortages and hardships exacerbated by Palestinian infighting, Gaza has bred a young generation that lives without hope. Critics have long accused Hamas of cultivating a death cult, and say it is now trying to deflect the Gaza residents\u2019 growing anger away from itself and toward Israel.\n\n\u201cBut Hamas cannot drag young people out of bed at gunpoint and shuttle them to the borders to dance to its tune,\u201d Muhammad Shehada, a writer and civil society activist from the Gaza Strip, wrote of the protests in the Haaretz newspaper this month. \u201cWas it not for the misery inflicted by Gaza\u2019s status quo, no one would show up for that date with death.\u201d\n\nMuhammad\u2019s father, Ibrahim Ayoub, 40, said on Saturday that his son was innocent. He spoke from the mourning tent outside the family\u2019s single-story home with a corrugated metal roof in the hardscrabble Jabaliya refugee camp in northern Gaza. \u201cEven if he touched the fence, he was peaceful,\u201d he said, adding that his son had not been throwing stones or holding a weapon.\n\nBasel Ayoub, 18, the cousin who was with Muhammad at the cemetery and recounted the scene there, saw him again at the protest site around the time he was killed. Both Basel and another cousin who was there, Muhammad Hamouda Ayoub, 29, said Muhammad had been sitting on the ground with other boys, then got up and ran to escape clouds of tear gas, when he was shot.\n\nOver the past four Fridays, at least three dozen Palestinians have been killed by Israeli fire along the Gaza frontier while protesting, sometimes violently, the 11-year blockade of the territory. The protesters are also pressing for Palestinians\u2019 return to lands in what is now Israel.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe Gaza Health Ministry has recorded three other minors among the dead. One was 17, another 15 and a third a few days short of his 14th birthday. Hundreds of other people have been injured.\n\nIsrael says it is acting to secure its border against any mass breach of the fence and to prevent terrorist attacks under the cover of the protests against its soldiers and nearby Israeli communities. The military has warned protesters to stay away from the fence, saying it will not allow them to endanger its soldiers or damage security infrastructure by hurling rocks, burning tires, throwing firebombs or cutting the wire.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe military said on Saturday that it was examining all of the reported deaths. It accused Hamas, which has thrown its weight behind the protests, of placing women and children on the front line and \u201cusing them as a \u2018human shield\u2019 for the realization of its goals.\u201d\n\nOver the weekend, the military revised its initial estimate of the number of participants in Friday\u2019s protest, raising it from 3,000 to about 10,000 by the day\u2019s end. That is still a significantly lower turnout than the 30,000 to 40,000 who came to the five protest sites on March 30, when the campaign began.\n\nComing as Israel celebrates its 70th anniversary, the protest campaign has touched one of the country\u2019s most sensitive nerves. Dubbed the \u201cGreat Return March,\u201d the campaign is expected to peak on May 15 when Palestinians mark what they call the Nakba, or the catastrophe, of Israel\u2019s foundation and the 1948 war over its creation, during which hundreds of thousands of Palestinians fled or were expelled from their homes.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nOne of six siblings ranging in age from 3 to 17, Muhammad grew up in the alleyways of the Jabaliya refugee camp with refugees and their descendants from al-Faluja, a former Palestinian village less than 20 miles northeast of Gaza.\n\nHe had already lived through three wars.\n\nMuhammad\u2019s father worked for the Western-backed Palestinian Authority security forces before Hamas routed them during factional fighting more than a decade ago. Hamas officials came to pay condolences after Muhammad\u2019s death, but left after a few minutes amid an altercation with supporters of Fatah, the rival Palestinian group, whose flags adorned the family\u2019s mourning tent.\n\nHis mother, Raida Ayoub, 39, said her husband had taken Muhammad and his two brothers to the protest on the first two Fridays. They skipped the third, scared off by the Israeli warnings. This Friday, too, she told him not to go, fearing for his safety, and took him to his grandfather\u2019s house instead.\n\nBut after playing outside there, he met an aunt and told her to tell his mother he was going to the protest \u201cjust for one hour.\u201d\n\nIn the video of his killing, panicked voices can be heard shouting that he has been shot in the head. At the time, they were both working full-time jobs, she in New York and he in Washington, and would meet at school every other week when attending classes.\n\n\u201cShe was amazing and beautiful,\u201d he said, \u201cand as soon as I heard her speak I knew that she was much smarter than me, and that was the number one thing that attracted me to her.\u201d\n\nMr. Gryskiewicz had rotated into Ms. Woods\u2019s section of the core curriculum shortly after their first year at Wharton.\n\n\u201cI remember thinking \u2018where did this handsome guy come from?\u2019\u201d Ms. Woods said.\n\nAs it turned out, they had a number of mutual friends, which made it easier to begin talking to each other, first during online group chats, and then one on one.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cHe left a lot of voice mail messages,\u201d Ms. Wood said. \u201cSome funny, some sweet \u2014 all romantic.\u201d\n\nIn March 2014, Ms. Wood awoke in her home on the morning after having Lasik eye surgery and discovered a text message from Mr. Gryskiewicz. She opened it to find a photo of Mr. Gryskiewicz holding up two fingers. Below the photo he wrote: \u201cHow many fingers am I holding up?\u201d\n\nMr. Gryskiewicz\u2019s text became a seminal moment in their budding relationship, as she began to see quite clearly that he was an \u201cextremely thoughtful and selfless man.\u201d\n\n\u201cIt was very sweet,\u201d she said of the text. \u201cA couple of my girlfriends had sent flowers, but I wasn\u2019t expecting anything like that from Kent, it was really cute.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThey grew closer in the ensuing weeks, and in May, they went on a first date in Manhattan, where they had dinner and went to see the Broadway show \u201cOf Mice and Men.\u201d\n\n\u201cOne of the first things I noticed at dinner was how much of a gentlemen he was,\u201d Ms. Wood said.\n\nMr. Gryskiewicz did his fair share of noticing as well. \u201cNot only was she gorgeous, but she just had this comfortable way of talking to me that made it seem as if we were old friends.\u201d\n\nThey began dating long distance, and in January 2015, Mr. Gryskiewicz got his current job in New York so that he could be closer to Ms. Wood.\n\n\u201cKate made me realize that life is meant to go through with someone,\u201d Mr. Gryskiewicz said, \u201cand I knew in my heart that she was that someone.\u201d", "title": "He Saw a Future Right Away. She Did, Too (Post Lasik Surgery).", "authors": ["Vincent M. Mallozzi"]} {"date": "2018-04-06 00:00:00", "text": "And last week, Mr. Mueller turned over a card in the investigation into the Trump campaign\u2019s possible collusion with Russia by asserting in a court document that this person \u201chas ties to a Russian intelligence service\u201d and was in contact with a senior member of the campaign, Rick Gates, during the 2016 election.\n\n\u201cThe Federal Bureau of Investigation special agents assisting the Special Counsel\u2019s Office assess that Person A has ties to a Russian intelligence service and had such ties in 2016,\u201d the filing said.\n\nAs Person A, Mr. Kilimnik, a 47-year-old former Russian military interpreter, has appeared now in multiple court filings by the special prosecutor, which suggests that he could become a pivotal figure in the investigation. For about a decade, he worked as an office manager in Kiev for the political consulting business of Paul Manafort, acting as a go-between and fixer for the American and the Russian-leaning politicians who were its clients.\n\nThe Russian government has denied meddling in the 2016 election and President Trump has denied collusion by members of his campaign staff. But during the years that Mr. Manafort worked in Ukraine, the country was deeply penetrated by Russian intelligence agents. While Mr. Kilimnik continues to deny that he was a Russian agent, it would have been perfectly normal for Moscow to plant someone in the Manafort operation.\n\nKonstantin Viktorovich Kilimnik was born in eastern Ukraine in the Soviet period. He studied at the Military Institute of the Ministry of Defense in Moscow, and after the Soviet breakup took Russian citizenship, he said in the interview. The institute trains interpreters for the Russian military intelligence agency, formerly known as the G.R.U. and now called the Main Directorate.", "title": "He Says He\u2019s an Innocent Victim. Robert Mueller Says He\u2019s a Spy.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-27 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cI wanted to get out of childhood as soon as possible and escape it, and now that I\u2019m making movies, I\u2019m chasing it,\u201d he said during an eight-hour interview that had all the intensity of a Dolan film, accented by allusions to Proust and a heavy snowfall outside. It began at Montreal\u2019s opulent St. James Hotel before migrating to his handsome Edwardian house, which, he notes, channels the red chinoiserie of Diana Vreeland\u2019s lush New York apartment.\n\n\u201cWhat I have been feasting on all these years is nostalgia \u2014 a nostalgia for the childhood that I didn\u2019t end up having,\u201d he added.\n\nWaiflike and compact, wearing a hoodie and with a tattoo of Dumbledore (of \u201cHarry Potter\u201d fame) on his left arm, Mr. Dolan peppers his sentences in English with words like \u201cprolix\u201d and \u201cepistolary,\u201d and only occasionally switches into French to emphasize a point. He used part of his earnings as a child star to take Berlitz classes in English. Even early on, he said, he realized that if he was going to conquer Hollywood, he would need to speak fluent English.\n\nIn person, Mr. Dolan is at once intense and cerebral, funny and self-deprecating.\n\nHe has sometimes been pilloried as impish and arrogant, and he bristles at being labeled an \u201cenfant terrible,\u201d as he often is. It is perhaps an occupational hazard for a director who has been variously compared to Alfred Hitchcock, Woody Allen and the poet Arthur Rimbaud.\n\nHe made his first film, \u201cI Killed My Mother,\u201d a Freudian-tinged, semi-autobiographical film about a gay teenager who clashes with his mother, after he dropped out of college at 17. As one producer after the other rejected it, he scraped together money from his child-acting gigs to make the film himself, at age 20, eventually winning international acclaim. When he later noted wryly that Orson Welles, who made \u201cCitizen Kane\u201d at 25, was a \u201clate bloomer,\u201d the critics pounced, and he turned to Twitter to explain that he had been joking.", "title": "He Wanted to Escape His Childhood. Now, It Fuels His Art.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-19 00:00:00", "text": "The film, \u201cNigerian Prince,\u201d follows a Nigerian-American high schooler, Eze (Antonio J. Bell), whose mother sends him to live with his aunt (played by the Nigerian actress Tina Mba) in Lagos. There, Eze befriends his cousin, Pius (Chinaza Uche), a professional scammer who sends phishing emails, among other deceitful business pursuits.\n\nMr. Okoro wrote the story with Andrew Long, a fellow Howard University alumnus. As they developed the script, they were guided by the director Spike Lee, who mentored Mr. Okoro at N.Y.U. (Mr. Lee is also an executive producer of the film.)\n\nThe project was long-gestating. \u201cThis is classic Faraday,\u201d Sheldon Chau, the film\u2019s cinematographer, said in a phone interview. \u201cHe comes up to me and he asks me, \u2018Sheldon, what are you doing summer 2017?\u2019 This is in 2014. And I was like, \u2018I think I\u2019m free.\u2019 And he was like, \u2018Well, that\u2019s when I want to do my feature.\u2019\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nThe plot is based in part on Mr. Okoro\u2019s own life. A Nigerian-American raised in Maryland, Mr. Okoro was sent to live with his extended family in Lagos for his first two years of high school, in the early 2000s.\n\nLike his character, Eze, he reluctantly left his friends and home. \u201cI definitely resented it,\u201d he said.\n\nHe eventually learned to appreciate the new culture; one of his hopes is that the film will resonate with other young Nigerian-Americans who have felt disconnected from their roots.\n\nBut shooting a movie in the West African city brought a host of unforeseen challenges.\n\n\u201cWe shot during the end of the rainy season,\u201d said Mr. Okoro, who was familiar with the region\u2019s climate but hadn\u2019t bargained for all the difficulty it would present in filming. \u201cThere were some days where we\u2019d go to set at 6 a.m., and it\u2019d rain at 6:30 and flood.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe week before filming began, the crew arrived to a space meant to double as a police station onscreen, but it, too, was flooded. They didn\u2019t end up using that location, though not because of the flooding; as at several other sites, the owner decided at the last minute that despite a signed contract, filming would no longer be allowed there. With little leverage and less time, Mr. Okoro and his team went searching for an alternative.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nIn addition to the frequent rains and notoriously unreliable power, they ran up against in the city\u2019s heavy traffic, which the director described as \u201clike L.A. times five or 10.\u201d\n\n\n\nMr. Okoro and his team did have assistance. Several of his collaborators were peers from N.Y.U. To help them navigate, they hired artists from the prosperous Nigerian film industry, known as Nollywood. Most of the crew members were Nigerian, and the American heads of creative departments were paired with Nigerian artists.\n\n\u201cIt just became apparent that all the departments needed a partner to show us the proper way to do things,\u201d Ari Fulton, the costume designer who met Mr. Okoro at N.Y.U., said in a phone interview.\n\nPhoto\n\nFor Ms. Fulton, the assistance came from Olaogun Opeyemi, a Nigerian costume designer and the film\u2019s costume supervisor, who helped make nuanced choices. One example is a red hat worn by Pius, the cousin, that\u2019s an adaptation of an Igbo cap. Ms. Opeyemi helped fill out the history of the cap, which younger Nigerians have adapted for more casual use.\n\nAnother learning experience was realizing that despite the size of the budget, financial decisions still had to be carefully considered.\n\n\u201cThe million dollars just flies,\u201d said Mr. Chau, the cinematographer. He described the days after winning the grant, when he and Mr. Okoro would fantasize about using elaborate film gear. But they quickly realized that they were being unrealistic; after all, their budget, while several times higher than the $150,000 or $200,000 they\u2019d initially hoped to shoot the movie for, was still modest for a feature film.\n\n\u201cWe went back to pretty much our initial approach,\u201d Mr. Chau said. \u201cIt was a humbling experience.\u201d\n\nStill, Mr. Chau also noted that while Mr. Okoro was the ostensible winner, the money had a trickle-down effect, bolstering the professional portfolios of his young collaborators.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cThe profiles of all of us came up,\u201d Mr. Chau said.\n\nThe pressure trickled down, too.\n\n\u201cIf someone hands you a million dollars, they expect you to turn out an amazing product,\u201d Ms. Fulton observed. \u201cIt\u2019s a huge thing to carry on your shoulders.\u201d\n\nMr. Okoro has carried it for a year.\n\nThe morning after the film was finished \u2014 the sound mixed, the color corrected \u2014 less than two weeks before the film\u2019s April 24 premiere, the director was standing in a Tribeca restaurant where this year\u2019s award finalists were scheduled to pitch their films.\n\nAfter exchanging greetings with two of the new judges, the actor Griffin Dunne and the comedian Ilana Glazer, Mr. Okoro took a seat, waiting for the new finalists to appear.\n\nOn the floor at his feet sat a hard plastic carrying case he\u2019d brought with him. Inside it was a computer drive with the copy of \u201cNigerian Prince\u201d that will be used for the Tribeca screenings. The film was finally ready, and Mr. Okoro would not let it out of his sight.", "title": "He Won $1 Million to Make a Movie. Then the Problems Set in.", "authors": ["Gabe Cohn"]} {"date": "2018-04-18 00:00:00", "text": "In 2010, Judge Wood presided over the guilty pleas of 10 Russian spies who had worked as long-term sleeper agents \u2014 a case that inspired the TV show \u201cThe Americans.\u201d Six years later, when she sentenced Dean G. Skelos, the former Republican leader of New York\u2019s State Senate, to five years in prison on corruption charges, she admonished him for ignoring his \u201cmoral compass.\u201d\n\nImage Judge Wood Credit Amy Sussman/Getty Images\n\n\u201cThrough your crimes,\u201d she said, \u201cyou have caused immeasurable damage to New Yorkers\u2019 confidence in the integrity of their government.\u201d\n\n(Mr. Skelos\u2019s conviction was later overturned on appeal after the Supreme Court narrowed the legal definition of corruption. He is scheduled to be retried in June, again before Judge Wood.)\n\nThe case of Mr. Cohen more or less landed in her lap. In a bit of legal happenstance, Judge Wood was the emergency duty judge last week when Mr. Cohen\u2019s lawyers filed a motion challenging the search warrants that federal agents used to seize his cellphones, papers and computers in a series of extraordinary raids this month. It remains unclear if Judge Wood will continue to preside as the matter moves forward. If criminal charges are ultimately brought, the case would be randomly reassigned.\n\nBut at least so far, Judge Wood has shown herself to be a firm jurist in the proceeding. On Monday, she compelled Mr. Cohen\u2019s lawyers to reveal that Mr. Hannity had once been one of Mr. Cohen\u2019s clients. Engaging her in a game of cat-and-mouse, the lawyers had at first described Mr. Hannity merely as a \u201cprominent individual\u201d who was embarrassed to be connected to the Cohen investigation.\n\nBut after another lawyer \u2014 representing news media outlets \u2014 stepped in to argue that embarrassment was not sufficient grounds to keep the name a secret, Judge Wood decided she agreed. When Mr. Cohen\u2019s lawyers pushed back, Judge Wood was blunt.\n\n\u201cI\u2019m directing you to disclose the name now,\u201d she said.\n\nAnd so the lawyer did.\n\nAlthough the moment passed with a burst of audible gasps, Judge Wood\u2019s measured approach \u2014 not raising her voice, but not backing down \u2014 showed a side of her that lawyers in her court know well.\n\n\u201cWhat\u2019s relevant to this case is that she\u2019s so calm and levelheaded,\u201d said Robert B. Fiske, Jr., a former United States attorney in Manhattan who has known Judge Wood since the 1980s. \u201cBoth sides, I think, would be very happy to have her as the judge. She has the ability to come into a high-pressure situation and deal with it intelligently and fairly.\u201d", "title": "Hearing the Cohen Case: A Soft-Spoken Judge Who \u2018Carries a Big Stick\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-08 00:00:00", "text": "Heather Anne Chronis and Michael Vincent Danek were married April 6. The Rev. Brian Bennett, a Lutheran minister, performed the ceremony at the Heinz Memorial Chapel on the campus of the University of Pittsburgh.\n\nMrs. Danek, 49, is a development officer and director of patient relations for the Eye & Ear Foundation at the University of Pittsburgh, from which she graduated.\n\nShe is the daughter of the late Perry A. Chronis and the late Nicholas A Chronis of Sparta, Tenn. The bride\u2019s father retired as a chief master sergeant in the Air Force and worked for the United States Civil Service Commission in Washington.The bride\u2019s mother was a mental health counselor at Plateau Mental Health Center in Cookeville, Tenn.\n\nMr. Danek, 47, is a clinical staff pharmacist at the Veterans Affairs Pittsburgh Healthcare System. He also graduated from the University of Pittsburgh, from which he also received a law degree.\n\nHe is a son of Regina A. Danek and the late Stanley E. Danek of Charleroi, Pa. The groom\u2019s mother retired as an elementary school art teacher with the Ringgold School District in Donora, Pa. She was 90.\n\nHer family said the cause was Alzheimer\u2019s disease.\n\nMs. Harrison and her husband, Newton Harrison, were both well into careers as educators when, in the late 1960s, they began shifting their focus to making art, vowing that anything they created would involve ecosystems and environmental awareness.\n\nTheir artworks were unconventional, to say the least, pushing the very boundaries of what constitutes art. They made topsoil and grew crops in it. They consulted on urban planning projects in Baltimore, Europe and elsewhere. Well before global warming was in the public consciousness, they considered its likely effects through maps and other means.\n\nAnd then there was \u201cHog Pasture,\u201d one of their earliest works, created for a 1971 exhibition at the Boston Museum of Fine Arts called \u201cEarth, Air, Fire, Water: Elements of Art.\u201d They made an actual pasture indoors, with hopes of having a real hog root around in it. The museum, they recalled years later, was fine with the pasture but not with the pig.", "title": "Helen Mayer Harrison, Leader in Eco-Art Movement, Dies at 90", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-23 00:00:00", "text": "And often, the kids are really trying, Dr. Carlson said. \u201cThe kids get up in the morning and they say, I\u2019m going to do it today, I\u2019m going to really work on this today, and then they can\u2019t do it, their brains won\u2019t let them do it.\u201d\n\nSo the kids need help, and successfully treating A.D.H.D. has multiple components. There is that essential education \u2014 for the child and the family \u2014 about what A.D.H.D. means. There\u2019s educational testing, supports and accommodations in school, behavior techniques and routines at home, especially around schoolwork as kids get older. \u201cYou have lists, and you have incentives, and the star charts,\u201d Dr. Carlson said.\n\nFor parents, this means trying to provide structure, to give positive feedback and set consistent limits, all worthy goals for any child. But frustratingly, Dr. Bertin said, A.D.H.D. itself makes all those interventions much more stressful for everyone, and \u201cwhen parents are feeling swamped and overwhelmed it\u2019s really hard to do a lot of things that are recommended in taking care of A.D.H.D.\u201d\n\nAnd of course, there\u2019s medication. The medication helps many struggling children, but \u201cit doesn\u2019t organize you,\u201d Dr. Carlson said. On the other hand, \u201cit focuses you, it decreases your impulsivity, it helps your mood regulation so you\u2019re less volatile,\u201d and all of that may help with the struggles and frustrations of academic work and family life.\n\n\u201cAt the end of the day, you\u2019re talking to a child psychiatrist who believes in treatment,\u201d Dr. Carlson said. She tells parents that she likens refusing medication to refusing to wear glasses. \u201cI can say, I refuse to wear glasses, I am pathologically opposed to glasses, so I\u2019m going to have to get an aide, I\u2019m going to have to have someone read to me and I can make people make the print large and I\u2019m going to need a chauffeur,\u201d she said. \u201cIf all you have to do is put the glasses on and that takes care of a lot of the problem, then for God\u2019s sake put on the glasses!\u201d\n\nFamilies should not expect simple answers, or short-term solutions. Parents have to take care of themselves, and pay attention to the family dynamic, looking for ways to help everyone thrive. Look for areas of life where the child is successful and for ways to spend positive time together, Dr. Bertin suggested. Make sure the child is getting all the appropriate interventions at school, and look for resources to help with the home side of academics.\n\nAnd watch for sibling issues. It may not be healthy for a child who does not have A.D.H.D. to be cast in the role of the \u201cgood child,\u201d he said. Parents should make sure all children get their share of positive parental attention.", "title": "Helping Kids With A.D.H.D., and Their Families, Thrive", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-20 00:00:00", "text": "Caroline MacDonald, 54, is Rosewood Hotel Group\u2019s vice president of sales and marketing for the Americas and Europe.\n\nDid you have your current job in mind from the start?\n\nNot at all. I wanted to be a vet, because I had a soft spot for animals. My first job at the age of 15 was working for my mother, who owned a small answering service in Los Angeles back when people called in for messages delivered by actual people in real time. Graduating from high school, I did not have a specific path or interest. So I enlisted in the Air Force in 1984.\n\nWhy the Air Force?\n\nFor one thing, they would subsidize my further education and train me in a field. Also, I wanted to travel. I describe my interview at the recruitment center as my \u201cPrivate Benjamin moment.\u201d I said I want to travel to exotic places, to experience different cultures and to go to college while working abroad.\n\nHow did that work out for you?\n\nThey found I had a high administrative and leadership aptitude. So I was sent to Germany, where I held an administrative role during peacetime and later was trained to plot nuclear, biological and chemical fallout as my wartime function. I attained the position of staff sergeant.", "title": "Her Start in the Air Force Led to a Surprising Place", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-04 00:00:00", "text": "The Depression years were difficult for the family, and Timothy Kaiser said that being on the receiving end of public charity left his father with a sense of obligation that he carried his entire life. After graduating from high school, Herbert worked briefly at the Brooklyn Navy Yard and then, in 1942, joined the Navy, serving on the submarine Dragonet, which was stationed off Japan in August 1945 when the atomic bombs were dropped on that country.\n\nHe attended Swarthmore on the G.I. Bill, graduating in 1949, the same year he married Joy Dana Sundgaard, a fellow student. He took a job with the State Department and was posted to Glasgow in 1950. Later in that decade he developed an expertise in Eastern European affairs, and his career included postings to Yugoslavia, Austria, Poland and Romania. He retired in 1983.\n\nMr. Kaiser was fluent in a number of languages, which enabled him to understand the nuances at play in the politically and socially divided areas where he worked. He needed those skills when he and Joy set up their nonprofit.\n\nBesides the tensions and factions within South Africa, the Kaisers had to deal with the international pressure that was causing many prominent people and companies to withdraw investments from that country. Raising money for their fledgling organization was difficult. But eventually a number of companies, including Johnson & Johnson, Kellogg\u2019s and Pfizer International, signed on, and community leaders in South Africa got behind the effort.\n\nScholarship money alone, though, wasn\u2019t the answer. The organization found that it also needed to provide other kinds of support for students, both during apartheid and after.\n\n\u201cSouth African blacks have had to cope with decades of poor primary and secondary education, as well as social neglect,\u201d Saul Levin, Mesab\u2019s chief executive, said in 2005. \u201cStudents who come into universities from rural areas are shellshocked. I have had students who tell me they\u2019ve never had a bank account or ridden in an elevator.\u201d\n\nThus, accommodations were made for the program\u2019s students, like allowing them to repeat failed courses or to cut back on their course load if they were having academic trouble. A mentoring program was established.\n\nAnd Mesab responded to the AIDS crisis with a palliative care program that financed the training of professionals and community caregivers in treating those with the disease.", "title": "Herbert Kaiser, 94, Health Care Champion in South Africa, Dies", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-27 00:00:00", "text": "The Senate Judiciary Committee advanced bipartisan legislation on Thursday that would protect special counsels, like Robert S.
