At one point, we had to step over a steel beam, and then do the limbo under a duct vent \u2014 all while trying our best to remain silent.\n\nMr. Francesconi pointed out the graffiti on many of the beams and poles; scrawling your name up here is a longtime tradition of the hall\u2019s stagehands.\n\nHe then flipped a light switch, illuminating a vaulted ceiling \u2014 hidden to patrons below by the auditorium\u2019s plaster ceiling \u2014 of Guastavino tile, similar to the \u201cWhisper Gallery\u201d at Grand Central Terminal and the abandoned City Hall subway station. From here, we could see the metal structures that supported the two circles of lights below us, the bulbs\u2019 cords dangling at regular intervals, near pathways deviating from the catwalk. Stagehands simply pull the lights up by these cords and change the bulbs.\n\nBefore we turned around, Mr. Francesconi called my attention to a small opening in the floor, through which I could see the orchestra, directly below. The players and their instruments appeared in miniature, but thanks to the hall\u2019s acoustic design, their sound was as crisp from this unusual vantage as from any seat down below.", "title": "How Do You Change the Light Bulbs in Carnegie Hall?", "authors": ["Keith Williams"]} {"date": "2018-04-05 00:00:00", "text": "But cameras made for daylight can miss animals or poachers moving through vegetation, and the devices don\u2019t work at night. Infrared cameras can help: Dr. Wich had been using them for decades to study orangutans.\n\nThese cameras yield large amounts of footage that can\u2019t be analyzed fast enough. So what do animals and stars have in common? They both emit heat. And much like stars, every species has a recognizable thermal footprint.\n\n\u201cThey look like really bright, shining objects in the infrared footage,\u201d said Dr. Burke. So the software used to find stars and galaxies in space can be used to seek out thermal footprints and the animals that produce them.\n\nTo build up a reference library of different animals in various environments, the team is working with a safari park and zoo to film and photograph animals. With these thermal images \u2014 and they\u2019ll need thousands \u2014 they\u2019ll be able to better calibrate algorithms to identify target species in ecosystems around the world.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe experts started with cows and humans in England. On a sunny, summer day in 2015, the team flew their drones over a farm to see if their machine-learning algorithms could locate the animals in infrared footage.\n\nFor the most part, they could.\n\nBut accuracy was compromised when drones flew too high, cows huddled together, or roads and rocks heated up in the sun. In a later test, the machines occasionally mistook hot rocks for students pretending to be poachers hiding in the bush.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nLast September, the scientists honed their tools in the first field test in South Africa. There, they found five Riverine rabbits in a relatively small area. These shy creatures are among the world\u2019s most endangered mammals. Only a thousand have ever been spotted by people.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe tests helped the scientists calculate an optimal height to fly the drones. The team also learned that animals change shape in real time (rocks don\u2019t) as drones fly over. And the researchers found that rain, humidity and other environmental, atmospheric and weather conditions can interfere with proper imaging.\n\nThe scientists are refining their system to account for these issues. And in two years, Dr. Burke said, they plan to have a fully automatic prototype ready for testing. Within five years, she hopes to sell systems at cost \u2014 today, just around $15,000.\n\nIn the meantime, these astro-ecologists are also working with search and rescue groups to help find people lost at sea or in fog. And starting in May, they will collaborate with conservation groups and other universities to look for orangutans and spider monkeys in the dense forests of Malaysia and Mexico, as well as for river dolphins in Brazil\u2019s murky Amazon River.", "title": "How Do You Count Endangered Species? Look to the Stars", "authors": ["Joanna Klein"]} {"date": "2018-04-23 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\n\u201cSmile! It\u2019s not that bad.\u201d\n\n\u201cYou forgot your smile.\u201d\n\nChances are, you\u2019ve heard comments like this at one time or another. What do you think about it? Is it helpful advice, made with the goal of helping the non-smiler feel better? Or is it designed to make everyone else more comfortable\u2014or neither of these?\n\nIn the Opinion essay \u201cAn American Woman Quits Smiling,\u201d Lisa Ko writes about her \u201csmiling boycott\u201d:\n\nI decided to stop smiling because I was tired. Tired of the \u201cCan I get a smile?\u201d and \u201cSmile, it\u2019s not that bad!\u201d comments that are a too common part of city life. Tired of things like the \u201cSmile! You look tired\u201d demand from the T.S.A. agent who recently inspected my bag at the airport. My smiling boycott felt a little risky. It\u2019s well known that women are often expected to smile to make others feel more comfortable. This expectation also seems like a big part of being American. ... Smiling when you don\u2019t feel like it has been proven to make you feel good by producing actual feelings of happiness. I\u2019ve tried it, and it does work, but I don\u2019t want to be ordered to smile. If a smile is the appearance of happiness, then to be commanded to smile takes away our right to our own feelings. We must appear happy, even if we\u2019re not. A man told my friend to smile, for instance, on the day that she found out her father had died. Or maybe there\u2019s just something about my neutral expression that comes across as seeming worried or displeased. People have asked if there was something wrong when I was feeling just fine. To compensate, I\u2019ve found myself smiling forcefully when socializing with strangers, wanting to assure them that they don\u2019t have to worry. That I\u2019m O.K.\n\nStudents: Read the entire essay, then tell us:\n\n\u2014 What do you think of Ms. Ko\u2019s assertion that the expectation to smile is placed more strongly on women?\n\n\u2014 What about the role being American plays? Do you have any experiences that support or contradict the notion that people in the United States are expected to smile a lot?\n\n\u2014 How do you respond to the findings from studies about why Americans and Canadians may smile more than people in other countries and why people in some other places are suspicious of those who smile a lot?\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u2014 Could being told to smile actually help a person feel better, as Ms. Ko claims a study has determined? What do you think about this version of \u201cfake it until you make it\u201d? Has it ever worked for you?\n\n\u2014 Ms. Ko ends her essay with an anecdote about smiling at her neighbor while the two of them rode the elevator together in what she calls \u201ca moment of sincere connection.\u201d Why do you think she includes this anecdote?", "title": "How Do You Feel About Being Told to Smile?", "authors": ["Shannon Doyne", "Student Opinion"]} {"date": "2018-04-27 00:00:00", "text": "Some other older books to look for: \u201cWhere Do They Go?,\u201d by Julia Alvarez and Sabra Field, is a meditative poem that asks all the hard questions and offers lyrical possibilities filled with life and love. In \u201cThe Tenth Good Thing About Barney,\u201d by Judith Viorst and Erik Blegvad, a child\u2019s mother suggests they come up with 10 good things to say about their dead cat, Barney, but the child can only think of nine. Like all of Viorst\u2019s books, it is direct and honest and funny, and sweetly consoling in the end. \u201cThe Purple Balloon,\u201d by Chris Raschka, written with enormous sensitivity in conjunction with Children\u2019s Hospice International, helps families and children confronting their own mortality. In \u201cThe Heart and the Bottle,\u201d by Oliver Jeffers, a girl suffering the loss of her father locks her heart \u2014 and her grief \u2014 in a bottle, only to realize she has also locked up the possibility of curiosity and joy. \u201cThe Goodbye Book,\u201d by Todd Parr, is for the very young and uses deceptively simple images of a bereft goldfish to show us all the things we might feel when we lose someone we love. \u201cDeath Is Stupid,\u201d by Anastasia Higginbotham, is for slightly older children and reminds us all that everyone\u2019s experience of death and pain is personal. It\u2019s not less than others, it\u2019s not more. It\u2019s not the same. It\u2019s also O.K. to say \u201cstupid\u201d when you\u2019re talking about death.\n\nAnd now three new books tackle the subject, in very different ways. TIM\u2019S GOODBYE (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, 40 pp., $17.99; ages 4 to 8), written and illustrated by Steven Salerno (\u201cWild Child\u201d), has retro, Ludwig Bemelmans-inspired illustrations in black crayon line on a flat, digital, yellow background. The main character, Margot, is sad because \u201cTim is gone.\u201d Salerno rapidly introduces a cast of characters who help Margot give her dead pet turtle, the titular Tim, a send-off. It is a mystery what\u2019s happening for most of the book as the children come and go, one of them floating in on a trio of balloons, until the rock, which has been static on each page, is revealed to be poor Tim. The balloons come into service again to lift the turtle, now in a cardboard box, up to the heavens where he possibly becomes a constellation. This gentle story might be just the introduction some readers seek, but for me, the slow reveal that Tim is a dead pet was so light-handed, it left me feeling detached.\n\nPhoto\n\nA STONE FOR SASCHA (Candlewick, 48 pp., $17.99; ages 4 to 8), written and illustrated by Aaron Becker (the \u201cJourney\u201d trilogy), is the wordless story of a girl trying to process the death of her dog. Initially, at least. Lushly illustrated in digital pastels, it soon expands to take on time and history and cosmology and the interconnectedness of things. On vacation at the beach with her family, seeing another child with a dog, the girl hurls a stone into the sea. On the next page, a golden meteor plummets toward Earth, is lodged deep underground during the Paleozoic era, erupts in a dinosaur-scattering earthquake, and then across various ancient civilizations is alternately worshiped, sculpted, erected, celebrated, crushed, sold, neglected, discovered, plundered and lost to the bottom of the sea. Where, washed by time to a smooth golden stone, it is found by our girl on the beach, who takes it home to place on the dog\u2019s grave. Everyone\u2019s experience of death is personal and the same might be said of books. Some children might consider the leaps in this book too great, others will return to ponder the cinematic images and puzzle out the connections.\n\nPhoto\n\nMatt James\u2019s THE FUNERAL (Groundwood, 40 pp., $18.95; ages 4 to 8) is an oddly exhilarating story of Norma\u2019s first experience of a funeral. In fact, she approaches it more as a \u201cfun-eral,\u201d as the book\u2019s cover makes clear with the bright acrylic and collaged blossom-laden tree, the exuberant children and the separation of \u201cfun\u201d from \u201ceral\u201d in the title typography. Like Viorst, James (\u201cWhen the Moon Comes\u201d) has an ear at child level and beautifully and convincingly shows us children who fidget during the service and consider a mourner\u2019s hairy ear perhaps more than they think about the deceased. But they are not completely irreverent, just children, who are full of life.\n\nFor most books about death are also about life, and we are lucky to have them to help us through both.", "title": "How Do You Talk to Children About Death? These Books Can Help", "authors": ["Sophie Blackall", "Children S Books"]} {"date": "2018-04-24 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nI FEEL YOU\n\nThe Surprising Power of Extreme Empathy\n\nBy Cris Beam\n\n251 pp. Houghton Mifflin Harcourt. $26.\n\nDepending on your point of view, Cris Beam\u2019s \u201cI Feel You: The Surprising Power of Extreme Empathy\u201d might seem either laughably behind the times or na\u00efvely, maybe even willfully, ahead \u2014 so far beyond our collective horizon as to be pretty darned invisible. After all, ours is an age when the president is more concerned with building walls than feeding and educating poor kids, Congress is polarized to the point of paralysis and just about everyone else is seemingly focused on getting theirs first. We\u2019ve become a nation of hard cases, armed to the teeth, with fury battling cynicism for primacy as the default emotion. In this world, a book with a cover featuring one bonsai tree leaning lovingly toward another does not appear likely to find much of a place. And yet here is Beam passionately asserting that \u201cthe pendulum is swinging back toward feeling, back toward love and the communal. Back toward empathy.\u201d\n\nWe can only hope. \u201cI Feel You\u201d is less a prescriptive self-help book than a thoughtful exploration of empathy in all its forms \u2014 physiological, historical, sociological and even personal, as Beam struggles to transcend her own less than empathic episodes and explores her aversion to opening herself to change. \u201cSelf-empathy was code for selfish,\u201d she explains before signing up for a workshop on just that. \u201cOne more link in a long chain of American entitlement.\u201d This is a radical book because it challenges the conventional wisdom that self-defense and punitive systems are the only way to keep ourselves physically and emotionally safe, and, maybe more important, because it asserts that it\u2019s possible to work for the betterment of society without the accompanying side effect of feeling like a chump.\n\n\u201cI Feel You\u201d is best thought of as a travelogue, with Beam an amiable and skeptical tour guide to places where a new understanding of empathy has led to new, successful applications. It\u2019s probably fortunate that she is a believer, but not an easy sell. Beam has done a lot of homework on her subject, and early on provides a lively distinction between genuine attempts at social change and what she calls \u201cempathic design,\u201d corporate attempts to make us feel loved or needy or connected \u2014 with the goal that we buy more. As a Harvard Business Review story explains, \u201cEnlightened companies are increasingly aware that delivering empathy for their customers, employees and the public is a powerful tool for improving products.\u201d Those adorable Facebook emojis are a case in point. Early in the book Beam tackles that default American compulsion to monetize even our deepest emotions, quoting, for instance, the headline of a Forbes article that offers that the best reason to teach empathy is \u201cTo Improve Education (and Test Scores).\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nBut this isn\u2019t where Beam puts her emphasis, even though this section is as entertaining as it is damning of American capitalism. She\u2019s looking instead for deeper cuts \u2014 to understand first whether empathy is inborn or a skill to be learned, and then, either way, to investigate how it can be applied to some of our most intractable problems. She takes the obligatory trip through the history of how empathy has been studied in the past and journeys to the neuroscience lab to see what discoveries are being made about how humans feel.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSome of the solutions she presents for deploying empathy in social situations may be familiar to those working in the fields of education and law. Restorative justice, for instance, \u201ctries to weave a web of understanding and repair. It\u2019s messier than the decontextualized, one-two punch of crime and consequence. It\u2019s a humanized, empathic approach to what is, by design, the passionless metrics of the law.\u201d In practice, this means the student and teacher, or the playground bully and his or her victim, have an opportunity to talk about how they feel, a practice that would probably make the likes of Sean Hannity apoplectic. Special courts for prostitutes and veterans, where their behavior would be placed in context and they would be provided with housing and medical care, would also anger many. To the Fox News crowd, this might be called coddling. But studies of such diversionary programs are showing them to be more effective at preventing and reducing crime than the usual expulsions and prison sentences. And anyway, why not try? Few can claim that our conventional institutions are doing a great job. As Beam suggests, \u201cat a time when the police, the whip-tail of our justice system, are finally being called out for their entrenched and learned brutality, this is the moment for overhaul.\u201d", "title": "How Does Empathy Work? A Writer Explores the Science and Its Applications", "authors": ["Mimi Swartz", "Cris Beam"]} {"date": "2018-04-20 00:00:00", "text": "TEA FOR TWO Usually we stop in a little Chinese place, Sweets Bakery, and have a tea and a sweet. (We put Baby in a doggy carrier.) We get a lot of stuff \u2014 it\u2019s so inexpensive that we just keep ordering: we get the red bean paste buns, and sometimes I\u2019ll get a coconut one. They\u2019re really good. We\u2019ll have our tea and then turn around and go back home.\n\nIN THE KITCHEN In the afternoons I get to cook. I love my Sunday cooking! I like making banana bread, I make kale chips \u2014 I\u2019ll make whatever I feel like making. I have a few recipes from the \u201cBetty Crocker Cookbook\u201d that I really like, and then I just make things up. I follow the recipes only so much. I\u2019m always thinking of healthy ingredients: I like to keep it real and healthy and natural as much as possible. I try to cook for a whole week, although it never lasts that long. My husband will usually come in and help, because he wants to taste it.\n\nINTERNATIONAL DINNER That takes us up to about 5 or 6 o\u2019clock. We\u2019ve sort of noshed all day, so we\u2019ll eat whatever I\u2019ve made. If I don\u2019t cook, we have three things: it\u2019s either food from Gena\u2019s Grill Sabor Latino, a hole-in-the-wall place, which is chicken and rice and beans; Indian from Curry in a Hurry, which we love \u2014 I\u2019ve been going there since before we were married; or our favorite Persian restaurant, Ravagh Persian Grill \u2014 it\u2019s just reliably, consistently good. We eat mostly at the kitchen counter \u2014 we\u2019ll sit there and have dinner, watch \u201c60 Minutes,\u201d and that takes us to just about bedtime.", "title": "How Doris Day, Dermatologist, Spends Her Sundays", "authors": ["Rachel Felder", "Sunday Routine"]} {"date": "2018-04-13 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cThe two greatest forces devaluing the value and power of an individual citizen\u2019s vote in America are gerrymandering and money,\u201d Califano says. In one telling anecdote, he recalls Johnson complaining about how demeaning it was to \u201cbeg for money from folks that all want something.\u201d Califano urged him to propose public financing for presidential and congressional campaigns. \u201cThe House will never go for it,\u201d Johnson said. \u201cThere are about 100 members who run without any serious opposition. If there\u2019s public financing they\u2019ll all face serious opponents in running for re-election. Forget it.\u201d\n\nToday, Califano writes, there are 402 safe House seats, referring to House members who won by 10 points or more in 2016. It\u2019s hard to argue with his analysis, although his book often reads like a laundry list of problems \u2014 from an imperial presidency to a dysfunctional Congress to a polarized public \u2014 without a coherent narrative. What would Johnson think of Donald Trump? Califano doesn\u2019t say, but one can only imagine.\n\nTHE PEOPLE VS. DEMOCRACY\n\nWhy Our Freedom Is in Danger and How to Save It\n\nBy Yascha Mounk\n\n393 pp. Harvard University. $29.95.\n\nImage\n\nFor decades, it was assumed that democracy, with its free and fair elections, and liberalism, with its broad protections for civil liberties and individual rights, went hand in hand. But today \u201cwe are seeing the rise of illiberal democracy, or democracy without rights, and undemocratic liberalism, or rights without democracy,\u201d Mounk writes. This has pitted far-right parties in Europe, which now appeal to a sizable chunk of the electorate while demonizing immigrants and minorities, against technocratic institutions like the European Union, which impinge on individual liberty in the name of collective solutions.\n\nMounk\u2019s material is densely packed and he has a tendency to repeat himself, but his book provides important insights into the present political moment. He cites three reasons for the weakening of liberal democracy: the rise of social media, which is \u201cempowering once-marginal movements and politicians\u201d in ways good but often bad; an increase in economic inequality, which he calls \u201caffluence without growth\u201d; and a nativist backlash against an upsurge of immigration and ethnic diversity, which politicians like Donald Trump, Marine Le Pen in France and Viktor Orban in Hungary have exploited.\n\n\u201cTo save democracy,\u201d Mounk writes, \u201cwe need \u2026 to unite citizens around a common conception of their nation; to give them real hope for their economic future; and to make them more resistant to the lies and the hate they encounter on social media each and every day.\u201d As his book shows, that\u2019s easier said than done.", "title": "How Endangered Is American Democracy?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-19 00:00:00", "text": "President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey has called for snap elections on June 24, almost a year and a half before the scheduled date in November 2019. He is expected to win because he has, once again, managed to stack the odds \u2014 militant nationalism, strong economic growth, a post-coup state of emergency that allows him to deploy security forces to crush his opposition and almost complete control of the Turkish media \u2014 in his favor.\n\nThe Turkish economy grew at 7.4 percent last year. Mr. Erdogan is seizing the moment to take credit for the strong economic performance before the economy shows signs of overheating. And there are worries stirred by a credit boom: The annual inflation rate peaked at 13 percent in November, the highest in 14 years. The current account deficit swelled to 4.7 percent of the gross domestic product in December, and the lira tumbled to a historic low in April.\n\nMr. Erdogan is enjoying popular support because of a surge of Turkish nationalism after his victory in the Afrin area of northern Syria, which the Turkish Army and its affiliates took from the Kurdish People\u2019s Protection Units, or YPG. The YPG is linked to the Kurdistan Workers\u2019 Party (PKK), the terrorist group that Turkey has been fighting for decades.\n\nBut there are concerns about the elections being held while the state of emergency, imposed in the aftermath of the failed 2016 coup, remains in place. The state of emergency gives the police, controlled by the central government, the right to arrest anyone without a court order and gives the government administration the mandate to curb freedoms of expression, assembly and association.", "title": "Opinion | How Erdogan Wins", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-25 00:00:00", "text": "In 2014 and 2015, for instance, critical masses of users on Reddit promoted hate against feminists and against people they deemed overweight. Such ideas can naturally proliferate on social media algorithms, by indulging anger against vulnerable targets and us-versus-them tribalism.\n\nOnce those ideas had popped to the top of the user-driven algorithm a few times, they quickly became perceived as mainstream and were adopted \u2014 and even angrily defended \u2014 by much of the site, which is one of the most widely used on the internet. Many users pushed that extremism into the real world, harassing their targets on and offline.\n\nReddit was able expel those ideas, a study found, only when it went much further than banning a handful of extremists. Instead, it began heavily regulating online discussion \u2014 imposing a degree of social control far beyond what other platforms like Facebook and Twitter have done.\n\nAnyone who regularly uses Twitter will recognize the way that it inadvertently trains users \u2014 by providing bursts of affirmation when a post goes viral \u2014 to win plaudits from fellow travelers by putting down users on the other side of any argument and, if no such argument exists, to start one. It is akin to Facebook\u2019s inadvertent promotion of anger and tribalism with a less active algorithm but on a far larger scale.\n\nOnline outrage can sometimes be a necessary way to channel popular opposition to, say, the injustices of systemic racism or other forms of discrimination. It\u2019s not always bad.\n\nThe problem arises when negative, tribal emotions begin to permeate social media, which increasingly dominates users\u2019 lives and therefore shapes their perceptions of the world offline. Like in Sri Lanka, that can have real-world consequences, albeit more subtle ones, by deepening the social and political polarization that is one of American democracy\u2019s toughest problems at the moment.\n\nAnd by contributing to the sense that every issue is just a way to keep score in a zero-sum game between political tribes, that dynamic can make serious problems more difficult to solve.", "title": "How Everyday Social Media Users Become Real-World Extremists", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-25 00:00:00", "text": "After several messages between The Times and a fake Sheryl Sandberg account on Instagram last week, the impostor offered $950,000 and a new car via the \u201cFacebook splash promotion 2018.\u201d\n\nWhen asked for proof the account was Ms. Sandberg, the scammer sent a Photoshopped identification. \u201cI want you to know that this Promo is 100% Real and Legitimate and the Government are aware of this Promo you don\u2019t have to be skeptical all you just have to do is to follow all instruction giving to you okay,\u201d the account added.\n\nThree days later, the account said it needed a $100 iTunes gift card to process and activate the winning A.T.M. card. (iTunes gift cards can quickly be redeemed and traded on the black market for cash.)\n\nAfter initially resisting, the sham Ms. Sandberg agreed to a phone call, adding \u201cI\u2019m not the one that will be speaking to you O.K.\u201d Seconds later, a call arrived from a number with a 650 area code \u2014 Silicon Valley.\n\n\u201cYou have to be careful, there are lots of scam artists,\u201d a man said in accented English after he was informed that he was speaking with The Times. He added, \u201cAll I\u2019m trying to do is get your winning package.\u201d\n\nThe Times reached out to more than 50 impostor accounts. Most messages went unreturned. None that replied broke character.\n\nThe charade has ensnared people like Donna Keithley, 50, a stay-at-home mom with four children in Martinsburg, Pa. In March 2016, an account with the name Linda Ritchey messaged Ms. Keithley \u201con behalf of the Facebook C.E.O Mark Zuckerberg\u201d to pass on word of her good fortune: $650,000 in lottery winnings. Ms. Keithley wired $350 \u2014 a delivery fee \u2014 the next day.", "title": "How Fake Mark Zuckerbergs Scam Facebook Users Out of Their Cash", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-02 00:00:00", "text": "A week later, outside the Yankees\u2019 spring training clubhouse in Tampa, Fla., Giancarlo Stanton said he had no idea about any of this.\n\n\u201cNuh-uh,\u201d he said, laughing, but also realizing the name Fidel wouldn\u2019t have gone over well with the Cuban exile community in South Florida. The Marlins drafted him in 2007 as a 17-year-old, eventually awarded him a $325 million contract and watched him develop into a National League most valuable player before trading him to the Yankees in December.\n\n\u201cThank you for not naming me that, especially being drafted by Miami,\u201d said Stanton, who will make his home debut for the Yankees on Monday afternoon. \u201cThat would have been not so good.\u201d\n\nWe are all born into names, and, like circumstance, some are more fortunate than others, particularly for athletes. Amid the dysfunction of the Knicks, Carmelo Anthony\u2019s countenance remained Melo. Why wouldn\u2019t Noah Syndergaard, towering with flowing blond hair, embrace his distant heritage and answer to the name fans gave him, Thor? And there would not be an admonition for all to rise for Aaron Judge if his adoptive parents had been named Jones.\n\nPhoto\n\nWhile some athletes are destined to embody their names, Stanton\u2019s name \u2014 polyglot, lyrical and lengthy \u2014 may reveal something about him, too.\n\nIf he had stayed with Mike \u2014 the name he used publicly through high school and during his first two seasons with the Marlins \u2014 he would not even be the first Mike Stanton to play for the Yankees. But there has never been another Giancarlo to play in the major leagues.\n\n\u201cYou\u2019ve got something unique, you don\u2019t run from it, you embrace it,\u201d said Stanton, whose bats and gloves have always been stamped with \u201cGiancarlo.\u201d \u201cI\u2019ve met some cool fans that come up and say, \u2018Hey, we\u2019ve got the same name.\u2019 But, personally, there\u2019s no one in my phone that I say, \u2018Oh, what up, Giancarlo?\u2019 I like the uniqueness of it.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThat is not to say he minds what people call him. His mother calls him Cruz, his father calls him Mike, relatives call him Mikey and his new teammates mostly call him G. His parents gave him so many names, they said, in part so he could choose the one he liked.\n\nMeet the Family\n\nWhen Giancarlo was learning how to write, he made a drawing for his father. He spelled out his first name, all in lowercase, with brightly colored markers. His father took it to work at the post office and hung it in his locker.\n\nIf it was hard then to see his son growing up to be one of baseball\u2019s best players, it was easier in that drawing to see an expression of what he might become \u2014 his attention to detail, his zest for rich experiences and an embrace of his name.\n\nIn that way, along with his uncommon size, 6 feet 6 inches and 245 pounds, Stanton seems to be neatly tailored for New York and all that it has to offer. Until now, his exposure to the city\u2019s culture, clubs and cuisine has come in small bites: a night out here, a weekend there. Home runs, like the two he hit on opening day on Thursday in Toronto, will make it easier for the fans to embrace him. But they will also make it harder for him to blend into the background.\n\nStanton was raised in the melting pot Tujunga area of Los Angeles by a mother and father who were poles apart. His parents were married for 10 years \u2014 splitting up when he was 8 \u2014 and seem to have but one thing in common: They both worked for the Postal Service.\n\nMike has the wit and fashion sense of a suburban dad \u2014 khaki shorts with the shirt tucked in, white socks, a sweatband on his wrist \u2014 and is as deeply abiding as one. He was there for his son growing up \u2014 throwing him batting practice after school before putting in a night shift \u2014 and in his moment of peril, accompanying him to a hospital when he was horrifically hit in the face by a pitch in 2014.\n\nJacinta Garay, whose parents were African-American and Puerto Rican, has piercings on each cheek and musical tastes ranging from Afro-Latin jazz to Lynyrd Skynyrd. She recently got her first cellphone so Giancarlo no longer had to leave a message on the house phone to reach her. But she still rates as a cool enough mom that Stanton invited her to his birthday party at a Hollywood club so she could meet Snoop Dogg.\n\nPhoto\n\nOf her son\u2019s predilection for haute couture (and flashy sneakers, including a pair of gold metallic high tops), his mother said: \u201cHe\u2019s really into coordination and how things look and how to match the colors. The bling tennis shoes \u2014 he gets that from me. And he teases me about the furry boots?\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSaid his father, with resignation: \u201cHe didn\u2019t learn how to dress from me.\u201d\n\nWhen it came to naming her children, Garay\u2019s eclectic tastes mostly reigned. Her older son, Egidio Carlos Moacir Garay, has a first name she found poetic with the Portuguese soft \u201cg\u201d (pronounced e-JID-e-o) \u2014 but off-putting with a hard Spanish \u201cg.\u201d Moacir is a nod to the Brazilian jazz composer Moacir Santos.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nHer daughter, who is two years older than Giancarlo (pronounced zhon-CAR-lo), was supposed to be a boy, so Kyricio became Kyrice (pronounced KIE-reece); her middle name is Valivia, the name of Garay\u2019s grandmother.\n\nWhen her plan to name her younger son Fidel was quashed, she pondered an alternative. An aficionado of foreign and independent films, Garay revered the actors Giancarlo Giannini and Giancarlo Esposito, and she liked the way the name sounded. \u201cI talked to my cousin and she was, \u2018Yeah, let\u2019s do it,\u2019 because we just loved the way that Giancarlo flows,\u201d Garay said, pronouncing it with a flourish.\n\n(Stanton\u2019s second name came because his mother\u2019s favorite singer was Celia Cruz and because an actor who lived in the neighborhood \u2014 A Martinez \u2014 played a character named Cruz on the late-1980s soap opera \u201cSanta Barbara.\u201d)\n\nIf their names caused occasional angst, the children did not stew over it. Egidio went by E. G., Kyrice went by Ky and Giancarlo became Mike.\n\n\u201cWe just chalked it up to, my mom went to too many Parliament concerts in the \u201970s,\u201d said Egidio, 38, who teaches political science at Glendale Community College in California. \u201cIt just kind of was. It wasn\u2019t something we spent a lot of time deconstructing.\u201d\n\nIn retrospect, though, their names may have subtly spurred his worldview.\n\n\u201cGrowing up in more suburban areas where you have that name that stands out, it\u2019s already pointing you out as being a little different,\u201d Egidio said. \u201cBeing a little kid in first grade being picked on for your ethnicity and identity, it compels you to make those broader connections to cultures and have a wider horizon about the world.\u201d\n\nFor Giancarlo, there were other nudges to do that. His father had traveled to China, India and Africa. His uncle Miguele would bring him gifts and regale him with tales about his frequent visits to Colombia, and take him to local Latin festivals. Giancarlo\u2019s eyes were opened further when he took a trip with high school classmates to Cabo San Lucas, Mexico, at the tip of Baja California Sur. He went fishing, rode all-terrain vehicles on the beach, ate Mexican food and listened to mariachi.\n\n\u201cIt was fascinating to me,\u201d said Stanton, who in recent off-seasons began to explore Europe, and then places further afield, cities like Istanbul, Bucharest, Jerusalem and Dubai. Asia and South America are being considered as the next possible destinations. \u201cYou don\u2019t understand until you grow up a little bit how cool places are.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nThe more recent trips have been with two housemates \u2014 the former Marlins pitchers A. J. Ramos and Ricky Nolasco \u2014 and another friend, the Marlins clubhouse attendant Jeremy Ruder.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nGetting Away\n\nStanton\u2019s Instagram feed \u2014 a montage of photos from shirtless workouts, vacation spots, celebrity hobnobbing and other areas of the baseball life \u2014 are often accompanied by pithy captions that show an often self-deprecating wit.\n\n\u201cOn the field it\u2019s hard to joke around \u2014 I\u2019m game time,\u201d Stanton said. \u201cBut off, when I\u2019m not working, I\u2019m a jokester. I don\u2019t want to spend all my energy being mad and focused.\u201d\n\nWhile Stanton\u2019s Yankees teammates have been struck by how fastidiously he adheres to his hitting and workout routines, he is adamant about leaving his work at the office. He has told his father, at times, that he does not want to talk about baseball with him. And Ramos, who has lived with him since 2011, said that in the time they have known each other, they have not had more than 10 conversations about baseball away from the ballpark.\n\nThe travels over the winter also provide a necessary break from baseball.\n\n\u201cWe play seven months, counting spring training, and you\u2019re so regimented that if you don\u2019t get away it makes you crazy,\u201d said Ramos, the Mets reliever who will share an apartment with Stanton in New York this season. \u201cWe actually set a plan for what we want to do, and 100 percent of that time we don\u2019t even stick to that plan. There\u2019s no one holding us to it but us. That\u2019s the balance.\u201d\n\nWhile Ramos has relished experiences like riding to a pyramid in Egypt on camelback \u2014 \u201cIt looks fake, like it\u2019s in a movie,\u201d he said \u2014 their group also returned home with conversations that challenged the way they think. \u201cYou go there and you see what\u2019s true and not true,\u201d he said.\n\nFor Stanton, his first trip to Europe was a transformational one. Though it was regimented \u2014 he did baseball clinics in the Netherlands, Czech Republic and Italy after the 2011 season \u2014 the architecture, the food and the culture were unlike anything he had seen growing up in Los Angeles, bouncing through minor league towns or living in Miami.\n\nHe also noticed how it sounded to hear names like Gianpiero, Gianpaolo, Gianluigi and even Giancarlo.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWhen he returned to Los Angeles, he matter-of-factly mentioned to his parents that the next season he was no longer going to go by Mike.\n\n\u201cI was shocked,\u201d his mother said. \u201cI had my mouth open for a week. He\u2019s going to go by Giancarlo now? Are you serious?\u201d\n\n\u201cYeah,\u201d his father said. \u201cI didn\u2019t see it coming.\u201d\n\nStanton said it was simply a matter of growing up, of coming to a fuller appreciation of what was important to him. And part of that was making sure that people knew him not only by the home runs he hit, but also by his name.", "title": "How Giancarlo Stanton Let Go of \u2018Mike\u2019 and Embraced Who He Is", "authors": ["Billy Witz"]} {"date": "2018-04-18 00:00:00", "text": "While filming it in 2002, Karp, then a pediatrician in Santa Monica with a growing reputation, had asked his patients to call him whenever their child was having a crying fit. He then drove across town to record the encounters \u2014 effectively making house calls for screaming babies. Mont\u00e9e, a documentary filmmaker, worked the camera. The result has a zany, homemade quality. Over and over again, Karp is seen swaddling, handling and shushing babies into submission while talking to the camera in a voice so hypnotic it could be trademarked. One exhausted-looking father praised Karp for turning his crying daughter \u201cto Jell-O.\u201d It wasn\u2019t exactly revolutionary, but his method was built on fast, practical tips that, well, worked. So we clung to them, feeling a little sheepish to be following a parenting expert so literally.\n\nBirndorf told Karp that a pediatrician had recently visited the center and suggested that babies not be put to sleep on nursing pillows or on bouncing chairs \u2014 a reversal of previous pediatric guidelines. The advice of parenting experts \u2014 many but not all of whom are doctors \u2014 kept changing, she complained. The contradictions she recounted, from conveying to women that motherhood is a natural state to instructing them on exactly how and where their babies should sleep, all while nullifying earlier recommendations, seemed to get at an inherent paradox at the heart of a profession whose stated goal is to empower parents. \u201cHighlights from 100 years of expert solicitude confirm the dirty little secret of child rearing: Though parenting gurus preach the supreme importance of consistency, their own shifting wisdom is proof of its impossibility,\u201d Ann Hulbert, the author of \u201cRaising America\u201d (2003), a sweeping history of child-rearing advice, wrote in this magazine.\n\nPhoto\n\nKarp nodded at Birndorf sympathetically. That he is one of those gurus, peddling parenting products, didn\u2019t seem to discomfit him. Whenever someone points out the hypocrisies of today\u2019s parenting industry, which happens often enough, Karp doesn\u2019t try to defend it, or himself. He commiserates, and it sounds genuine \u2014 the ambivalent doctor trying to help parents make sense of a chaotic world. That\u2019s one reason many parents find his approach so reassuring. Unlike other parenting books, Karp\u2019s doesn\u2019t feel preachy or berating. His tips can be applied just as easily by fathers as by mothers, and his pragmatic advice and suggested baby schedules don\u2019t feel like more than what they are: suggestions. But as I trailed him on his rounds, his suggestions invariably seemed to crescendo toward a pitch.\n\n\u201cWell,\u201d he told Birndorf, \u201cthis is where they would use a SNOO.\u201d\n\nWhen explaining his philosophy of parenthood, Karp likes to quote his late mother: \u201cKeep an open mind, but don\u2019t let your brain fall out.\u201d Karp grew up in Queens with two older sisters in a family he describes as Jewish but not Orthodox, Democratic but not political. His father was a building engineer and occasionally a door-to-door salesman; his mother was in charge of the business\u2019s bookkeeping. As a child, Harvey was temperamental. At 12, he smashed a golf club into a painting his sister made. Later, he took up meditation. \u201cIt was right when the Beatles were doing it,\u201d he said. This began for him a lifelong interest in Eastern and alternative practices even as he decided to enroll in medical school.\n\nBy his second year at the Albert Einstein College of Medicine in the Bronx, Karp knew that he wanted to care for children, whom he considered more \u201coptimistic and resilient\u201d than adults. He moved to Los Angeles for a residency at Children\u2019s Hospital, meeting and marrying a woman who was studying to become a family counselor. At night, he pored over his wife\u2019s textbooks about family dynamics. He trained under Barbara Korsch, a pediatrician who was among the first to study the field of doctor-patient communication and to call for \u201creducing the power gap\u201d between physicians and parents. \u201cBeing smart is important, but you can\u2019t get through the door by being an arrogant, smart doctor, unless you want to be a surgeon or a radiologist or something like that,\u201d he said. \u201cBut if you\u2019re dealing with patients, you\u2019re knocking at the door and you\u2019re being invited in. You have to be a good guest.\u201d\n\nIn the early 1980s, he began working at U.C.L.A. hospital\u2019s child-abuse team. He watched as babies were wheeled into the hospital in the middle of the night because their parents didn\u2019t know how to soothe them or had badly shaken them when they screamed uncontrollably. \u201cIt was perplexing to me, because I thought: We could put a man on the moon. We could cure some types of cancer. We could make long-distance phone calls around the world. But we don\u2019t know why babies cry, and we don\u2019t know how to help them sleep.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nThis issue of infant colic \u2014 of otherwise healthy babies who cry for more than three hours a day, at least three days a week, in the first three months of life \u2014 gnawed at him, and he immersed himself in books on evolution and anthropology. He learned about a Pygmy tribe that passes around babies between different community members all day long so that children develop multiple relationships early. He read the fieldwork of the anthropologist Melvin Konner about the infants of the !Kung San people in the Kalahari, who are carried in slings and rarely cry for more than a minute at a time. In the West, about 15 to 20 percent of babies have colic. \u201cSo either the !Kung babies were mutant babies \u2014 different from others \u2014 or those parents knew something.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nOne day, when he was 29, Karp felt a dull pain in his neck as he was heading back to the hospital from lunch. He asked an intern to perform an EKG on him, but the intern didn\u2019t know how to read the results. \u201cSo I\u2019m showing him, \u2018Here \u2014 oh, my God, this is cardiac ischemia.\u2019 \u201d What he was reading was his own heart attack. He was kept in the hospital for a week for observation and advised to eat half a pound of salmon a day to reduce his cholesterol. The incident was mild enough that it didn\u2019t have lasting effects, but it left him with a greater sense of urgency. \u201cIt was a crystalline moment,\u201d he told me, of coming to terms with his own limitations. From then on, whenever he went for a run in Santa Monica and reached an area with outdoor stairs, he forced himself to think, as he descended, that at the very bottom \u201cis the end of my life and to prepare for that.\u201d\n\nBefore the heart attack, he had planned on going into child-development research, but now he thought the demands of academia would be too taxing. Instead, he joined a practice in Los Angeles with two other pediatricians and began to develop a local following. He threw himself into the job. Early in his career, he resolved never to do a checkup for less than half an hour. On some days, he visited six different hospitals to meet his newborn patients. As his work got more demanding, Karp and his wife grew apart and divorced.\n\nKarp was beginning to develop his concept of the \u201cmissing fourth trimester.\u201d Human babies are born about three months prematurely, the theory goes, because their heads, which grow rapidly, need to be able to fit through the birth canal. Some scientists dispute Karp\u2019s notion that human gestation is too short. \u201cSadly, the evidence doesn\u2019t support that,\u201d Daniel Lieberman, an evolutionary biologist at Harvard, told me. But Karp insists that this explains why during the first months of life, babies can be lulled back into a womblike \u201ctrance\u201d through the use of certain cues that Karp calls the 5 S\u2019s: a combination of swaddling, shushing, placing the baby on her side or stomach, swinging her and letting her suck. He noticed that for each baby the \u201csymphony of sensations\u201d was slightly different \u2014 some babies needed extra movement, others a light jiggle \u2014 though all the infants responded well to swaddling, even if they seemed resistant at first.\n\nPhoto\n\nBy the early 1990s, Karp was running his own clinic, with a playground out back, and eventually he hired four pediatricians to work with him. \u201cAt the time, if you could get in to see Dr. Karp, then you\u2019ve got it made,\u201d Elaine Hall, whose son became a patient of Karp\u2019s in 1996, told me. \u201cHe had a kind of hippie vibe to him then. He was gentle and comforting, and he had a long ponytail.\u201d Karp gave her son a diagnosis of severe autism when he was 2. \u201cDr. Karp took me aside, and I\u2019ll never forget \u2014 I get teary \u2014 he said: \u2018You\u2019re going to go on a journey. It\u2019s a different path than you envisioned, but I can promise you you\u2019re going to have lots of experiences that are going to make your life richer than you even imagined.\u201d\n\nKarp became famous for what were then unconventional methods for bonding with infants. Deena Goldstone, the mother of one of Karp\u2019s first patients, remembers Karp suggesting that she swaddle her newborn at night, \u201cwhich I thought made no sense,\u201d she told me. Karp also advised Goldstone\u2019s husband to hold their baby against his bare chest, in what doctors now tout as the importance of skin-to-skin contact. As his reputation grew, Hollywood celebrities took their children to see him; he treated the kids of Madonna, Michelle Pfeiffer and Larry David.\n\nHe also had a new family. He and Mont\u00e9e met at a party in Hollywood in 1991, when he was 40, divorced with no children. She was 11 years younger, with a 7-year-old daughter, Lexi, from a previous marriage. Mont\u00e9e is from Belgrade and has a highly polished complexion and the kind of thick, open-syllabled accent in English that makes \u201cbest\u201d sound like \u201cbast.\u201d (Her uncle is Milan Panic, a pharmaceutical multimillionaire and former prime minister of Yugoslavia.) Karp appeared to her so unassuming that when he told her that he took care of the hosts\u2019 son, \u201cI thought, Oh, he\u2019s their \u2018manny,\u2019 \u201d Mont\u00e9e told me.\n\nIn 2000, a famous actress brought in her young son to see Karp. She was accompanied by her baby nurse, a British woman named Tracy Hogg. Karp demonstrated his methods for soothing babies, including swaddling and his theory about the calming reflex. About six months later, he says, he heard that Hogg was working on a manuscript about how to calm a baby. That book, called \u201cSecrets of the Baby Whisperer,\u201d went on to become a best seller later that year: \u201cYou have to re-create the womb,\u201d it advises, before going on to recommend swaddling infants tightly. \u201cIt had nothing to do with my stuff,\u201d Karp said diplomatically. \u201cBut it got publishers interested.\u201d Hogg, who died in 2004, advocated what she called a \u201cstructured routine\u201d for a newborn \u2014 with precise hours for feeding, \u201cactivity,\u201d sleeping and \u201cyou\u201d time. Karp got to work on his own book, wanting to document his techniques for calming crying while promoting a more lenient approach. He visited his patients at home in order to test out his theories. \u201cI needed to understand, When does it not work?\u201d he said. \u201cI needed to see it in the wild.\u201d He often worked through the night, reciting bullet-pointed thoughts into dictation software because he was frustrated by the pace of his typing, then drove Lexi to school in the mornings wearing the same outfit as the day before.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Magazine Newsletter Get the best of the Magazine delivered to your inbox every week, including exclusive feature stories, photography, columns and more. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nKarp\u2019s agent turned down a $450,000 advance for the manuscript, and Karp grew apprehensive that they wouldn\u2019t get a better offer. That morning, Mont\u00e9e gave her husband a pep talk. \u201cAct like you have a million dollars in your backpack,\u201d she told him, a joke that is now part of the family lore. She turned out to be right: Karp ended up securing a $1.1 million advance for \u201cThe Happiest Baby on the Block,\u201d along with a sequel for toddlers. Karp describes Mont\u00e9e as the one in the household who \u201cseals the deal.\u201d At Happiest Baby Inc., she is in charge of business strategy and creative direction (\u201cAs a co-founder, Ruth, I\u2019m so excited,\u201d she told me more than once, having mastered the marketing technique of first-name repetition).\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nA segment on \u201cGood Morning America\u201d in 2002 helped cement Karp\u2019s success, and Mont\u00e9e had the idea of bringing the book\u2019s testimonial sections to life by recording Karp\u2019s interactions with his patients on DVD. Their timing couldn\u2019t have been better. \u201cThe Happiest Baby on the Block\u201d came out just as parenting literature was undergoing a transition of its own.\n\nFor years, the prevailing philosophy on child rearing had been Dr. Benjamin Spock\u2019s rallying call to parents: \u201cTrust yourself. You know more than you think you do.\u201d Spock\u2019s \u201cThe Common Sense Book of Baby and Child Care,\u201d which was published in 1946 and sold more than 50 million copies worldwide, was so thoroughly embraced that some women kept copies of his paperback all over the house, including in their glove compartments. Detractors later blamed him for the permissiveness that they argued set the stage for the 1960s counterculture \u2014 for children being \u201cSpocked when they should have been spanked.\u201d In the late \u201960s, Spock\u2019s involvement in the anti-Vietnam War movement caused some of his readers to turn on him. His sales figures soon dropped by half, though he remains, to this day, the world\u2019s most famous pediatrician.\n\nAs Spock lost ground, the field of expert advice became more polarized between a \u201chard\u201d camp, which stressed discipline and conformity, and a \u201csoft\u201d camp, which believed in the importance of bonding and individuality. The issue of baby sleep was particularly contentious. In 1985, Dr. Richard Ferber, who founded what is now known as the Sleep Center at Boston Children\u2019s Hospital, published a sleep manual so popular that his name became a verb. To \u201cFerberize\u201d is now synonymous with letting a child cry it out (even though his book doesn\u2019t quite advocate that). Following Ferber\u2019s best seller, child-rearing literature was inundated with sleep guides, each with its own impossibly alluring title \u2014 \u201cTwelve Hours Sleep by Twelve Weeks Old,\u201d \u201cThe No-Cry Sleep Solution.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nThe soaring popularity of sleep guides may have been propelled by an observable, objective deterioration in baby sleep, which can be traced back to a single year, 1992, when the American Academy of Pediatrics, upon reviewing research on sudden infant death syndrome, or SIDS, came out with the recommendation that parents put babies to sleep exclusively on their backs in the first year of life. The number of SIDS cases did in fact fall \u2014 by half, according to the National Center for Health Statistics. But the change came at a price. Babies sleep significantly worse on their backs, a fact that pediatricians openly acknowledge.\n\nCertain parental concerns have vanished with technological advances like infant formula or polio vaccines. Others \u2014 like our anxiety about said technological advances \u2014 are perennial: Speaking to mothers in 1910, the pediatrician L. Emmett Holt worried about sensory overload in \u201cthese days of factory and locomotive whistles, trolley cars and automobiles.\u201d But sleep \u2014 how much our children, and by extension we, get; whether it\u2019s continuous or interrupted, light or deep, crying-induced or self-soothed \u2014 is a particularly of-the-moment obsession, particularly among well-off parents. The intense focus on sleep may have less to do with babies and more to do with parents, especially middle-class mothers, who provide as much as or more child care today than housewives did in the 1960s. Highly educated working mothers, Brigid Schulte, the author of \u201cOverwhelmed: Work Love and Play When No One Has the Time,\u201d told me in an email, have \u201cmade their children such a priority\u201d that they spend \u201cvirtually all of their leisure time with their children.\u201d\n\nAs baby sleep came to be seen as a national problem, the pressure intensified on parents to enforce stricter regimens. Champions of \u201chard\u201d advice became known as parent-centered. Many of these advocates were from the Christian right, including Gary Ezzo, whose \u201cOn Becoming Baby Wise,\u201d published in 1995, promoted rigid feeding schedules, \u201chighchair manners\u201d and physical punishment, or \u201cchastisement\u201d \u2014 preferably with a rubber spatula. (These recommendations have since changed.) Ezzo\u2019s and other parent-centered advice books grew in direct opposition to the \u201cideological humanists\u201d of the child-centered approach, with their insistence on feeding on demand, co-sleeping and a shunning of schedules and training methods.\n\nParent-centered advocates inveighed against the 1993 \u201cBaby Book\u201d \u2014 the bible of child-centered parents, written by William and Martha Sears, a pediatrician-and-nurse couple and parents of eight children. The \u201cBaby Book\u201d begins with an aphorism that puts many women at a disadvantage before they\u2019ve even started mothering: \u201cFeeling good about your baby\u2019s birth carries over into feeling good about your baby.\u201d (Tell that to the woman recovering from an emergency C-section.) They go on to ask, hypothetically, \u201cWon\u2019t holding our baby a lot, responding to cries, breast-feeding on cue and even sleeping with baby create a spoiled and overly dependent child?\u201d To which they provide an emphatic answer: \u201cNo!\u201d (Their son Robert, who is also a pediatrician and a \u201cBaby Book\u201d co-author, has become a vocal critic of vaccination laws, counter to evidence-based medical consensus.) Though they see themselves as Spock\u2019s disciples, experts from the soft camp can seem exceedingly hard on parents, especially mothers, not to mention downright punitive for anyone with a full-time job.\n\nPhoto\n\nKarp\u2019s manual represented a welcome middle ground. \u201cI try to be an omnivore and just reflect on each issue and judge it on its own merit or lack of merit, but I\u2019m much closer to the Dr. Sears approach,\u201d he said. He emphasizes the benefits of breast-feeding but argues that experts have become \u201cdogmatic and inflexible about it to the point where we could be hurting kids and certainly hurting mothers.\u201d He includes sections in his books on weaning \u2014 from swaddling, pacifiers, rocking \u2014 even as he dismisses professionals who warn that children could become addicted to these crutches. (\u201cAre we \u2018addicted\u2019 to sleeping on a bed with a pillow?\u201d he retorts.)\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nKarp \u201ckind of serves the purpose that Grandma would have served in the past,\u201d Alison Gopnik, a professor of psychology at the University of California, Berkeley, and author of the book \u201cThe Philosophical Baby,\u201d told me. \u201cBut what science tells us is that variability is the most distinctive feature in terms of what children are like, what parents are like and what caregiving is like. So it\u2019s unlikely that you\u2019re going to find one piece of advice that\u2019s going to suit all the different varieties of children and cultures.\u201d\n\nKarp\u2019s manner is open, engaging, empathetic, inviting confession; ask him about his work, though, and the layers of humility begin to peel off. \u201cNobody else noticed this stuff in the whole world!\u201d he told me at the end of dinner one evening when we talked about the 5 S\u2019s. \u201cNo one knew about swaddling. Nobody knew about sleep.\u201d As \u201cThe Happiest Baby on the Block\u201d began to take off, Karp left his pediatric practice and with Mont\u00e9e turned the \u201cHappiest Baby\u201d into a franchise that now includes three books, two DVDs, a line of swaddles and white noises for purchase on iTunes, as well as SNOO, which rocks and plays white noise continuously and has sensors that respond to a baby\u2019s cry by changing intensities; it keeps the baby swaddled and fastened inside the crib and can be controlled from afar on a smartphone.\n\nKarp earnestly compares the $1,200 bassinet to the advent of penicillin \u2014 \u201cI\u2019m not here to promote a product, but I am saying if someone developed penicillin, wouldn\u2019t it be important to tell people about it?\u201d \u2014 and insists that it can save lives by stopping babies from rolling into an unsafe position in their sleep. Raising the money for SNOO, Karp drew on his celebrity appeal: Justin Timberlake and Jessica Biel are investors, as are Scarlett Johansson, Gwyneth Paltrow and Zoe Saldana. (Or, as Mont\u00e9e put it, \u201cWe have Justin and Jessica and Gwyneth and Scarlett and Zoe.\u201d)\n\nSo far, 30,000 beds have gone into production, and of those, some were given free or at a steep markdown to social \u201cinfluencers\u201d \u2014 a far cry from Karp\u2019s days of working with abused children. Hulu and Activision have begun offering discounted SNOOs as a benefit to their employees. Karp says he hopes to take SNOO beyond the gated precincts of Los Angeles and Silicon Valley: \u201cOnce we get medical studies, we can get insurance companies and employers to subsidize this. It will be like breast pumps ultimately. That\u2019s the goal.\u201d\n\nOther \u201cHappiest Baby\u201d innovations can be viewed as truly helpful or slightly ominous, depending on your level of credulity. Its engineers are aiming to update the SNOO app to serve as a dutiful personal assistant, providing parents a full report on their child in the morning, like \u201cBaby Sophie\u2019s diaper is full; she had a runny nose; the humidifier is on,\u201d Mont\u00e9e explained one morning when I visited the company\u2019s headquarters in a squat building on a main drag in Santa Monica. She saw my face. \u201cI know,\u201d she said. \u201cAt the beginning I thought, Come on, really? But then I see Lexi\u2019s friends, and they turn to an app just to tell them which breast they fed from last. It\u2019s a different generation.\u201d\n\n\u201cHey, love!\u201d Karp called out to Mont\u00e9e as we walked through their house on a recent weekend afternoon. They live in a converted A-frame chalet nestled deep in the hills of the Pacific Palisades that looks like the ideal location for a dream sequence in a film set in 2030. It has a hydraulic door with a laser-perforated metal screen, smooth white terrazzo floors, white floating stairs and an arresting view of the ocean. There are no visible light switches anywhere (Mont\u00e9e is \u201callergic\u201d) and nothing made of plastic: Karp and Mont\u00e9e are environmental activists, and both serve as directors of the Environmental Working Group, a nonprofit research and advocacy organization. With its glass facades and sharp corners, their house also looks decidedly un-baby-proofed. Perhaps the only indication of Karp\u2019s profession can be found upstairs, in his study, where there is a first-edition Dr. Spock and a cloth baby carrier from the Peruvian Amazon \u2014 a gift from Olivia Newton-John and her husband.\n\nKarp has devoted his entire career to babies, so it came as a surprise to learn that he has never raised one of his own. For two years after he and Mont\u00e9e married, they tried to conceive but couldn\u2019t. Devastated, they considered surrogacy or adoption but in the end decided against it. \u201cWe had Lexi,\u201d Karp explained. He came back to that decision in a later conversation. \u201cI kind of feel like everyone is my child,\u201d he told me, his eyes glistening. \u201cI don\u2019t feel the barriers. There\u2019s this passage in \u2018Siddhartha,\u2019 by Hermann Hesse, where Siddhartha\u2019s friend Govinda looks into his face and sees the flow of thousands of human faces like a procession. It\u2019s our joining of humanity.\u201d Does this mean that he views all the children he has treated over the years as, in some sense, his own? \u201cAnd their parents,\u201d he said keenly.\n\nPart of the appeal of Karp\u2019s methods for calming babies was that they didn\u2019t require anything fancy, not even the pre-made swaddles that are sold today \u2014 any old blanket would do. As he himself noted in his book, \u201cFor thousands of years, the most skilled parents have used the 5 S\u2019s to soothe their babies.\u201d Now he was suggesting that, actually, the best way to improve your baby\u2019s sleep required splurging on a sensory bed. Effective as his invention may be, its forbidding price reflects an old-fashioned idea: that child rearing is inherently tied to social status, that you have to spend in order to care.\n\nAs the sun began to set over the ocean, the light glinting on the water like sequins, Karp and Mont\u00e9e still had a long night of work ahead. \u201cWe can stay up more than any youngsters and do \u2014 how do you say? Overnighters?\u201d Mont\u00e9e said. In the coming months, they would launch SNOO in China, and Karp would go on the Home Shopping Network to advertise it. For him, though, that was just the beginning. He mused about Gutenberg\u2019s invention of movable type and how his contemporaries had been alarmed that people wouldn\u2019t memorize anything anymore because of it. He chuckled. \u201cYou can\u2019t get in the way of progress,\u201d he said. Then, standing by the patio with his hands in his pockets, he put it differently: \u201cThe idea is that I could be in every nursery in America.\u201d", "title": "How Harvey Karp Turned Baby Sleep Into Big Business", "authors": ["Ruth Margalit"]} {"date": "2018-04-16 00:00:00", "text": "ON VALENTINE\u2019S DAY 1981 Deborah Harry was the headlining musical guest on \u201cSaturday Night Live.\u201d A product of the fertile downtown Manhattan musical scene, centered around the CBGB club on the Bowery, she had gone pop with a series of hit singles, including Blondie\u2019s \u201cRapture,\u201d which reached No. 1 in 1981. The track, a tribute to an uptown musical culture that most Americans viewed as a curiosity or fad (if they had any awareness of it at all), name-checked a few seminal New York figures, including Grandmaster Flash, the pioneering D.J. whose group the Furious Five formed in 1976 and broke musical ground at house parties in the South Bronx before cracking into the Top 100 in 1982 with the socially conscious rap anthem \u201cThe Message,\u201d and Fab 5 Freddy, a Brooklyn-based graffiti artist who acted as a liaison between street artists, the commercial art world and downtown clubs. At the urging of Blondie\u2019s Harry and the band\u2019s guitarist Chris Stein, \u201cS.N.L.\u201d booked the Bronx\u2019s Funky 4 + 1 (four male rappers and pioneering female M.C. Sha-Rock) to perform their single \u201cThat\u2019s the Joint\u201d for the show\u2019s final number of the night. Harry\u2019s rapped verse on \u201cRapture\u201d was, for most people, a proxy introduction to hip-hop, but it was the Funky 4 + 1 that gave network television viewers the first true taste of what young New Yorkers had been experiencing in parks, subways and schoolyards for several years already.\n\nThis culture, just starting to be described under the umbrella phrase \u201chip-hop,\u201d would emerge from its Bronx and Harlem origins during 1981 to \u201983, engaging in a dialogue with the city\u2019s other musical cultures that would extend its influence. The Funky 4 + 1\u2019s 1980 \u201cThat\u2019s the Joint\u201d is a great example of how hip-hop\u2019s particular vernacular helped propel the culture forward. The idea that something was \u201cthe joint,\u201d meaning something was exciting or pleasing, had been street slang for several summers before this 12-inch single was released. (Spike Lee still labels his films \u201ca Spike Lee Joint\u201d reflecting his growing up in Brooklyn in the \u201970s.) \u201cThat\u2019s the Joint\u201d is significant in another aspect: It took a New York street slang word and introduced it to the wider world, something that became a signature of rap records. Superlatives like \u201cfresh,\u201d \u201cstoopid,\u201d \u201cdef\u201d and the ever enduring \u201cdope\u201d moved from the streets to recordings to advertising to daily usage. Hip-hop records like \u201cThat\u2019s the Joint\u201d literally remixed the way people talk.", "title": "How Hip-Hop Transformed New York", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-10 00:00:00", "text": "In the Netherlands, where the monarchy is quite popular, there was little public appetite for revisiting the law, and some traditionalist opposition to reducing the penalties.\n\n\u201cWe have a very modern king, who binds the country, who is there when we grieve, and who is there when we celebrate, who stands above politics in our country,\u201d said Chris van Dam, a lawmaker from the Christian Democratic Appeal, a center-right party, who fought hard to retain the current penalties in place.\n\n\u201cEverything that is valuable is also vulnerable, so we think that we must protect him,\u201d Mr. van Dam said.\n\nMr. Verhoeven added amendments to make the bill more palatable. These included making the maximum penalty for insulting the king four months rather than three, so that it would match the penalty for verbally abusing civil servants working in stressful situations, and making it clear that the monarch does not have to personally report violations.\n\nThe line of Orange-Nassau has ruled the Netherlands since 1815, when William I, the current king\u2019s ancestor, declared the country a kingdom (the rulers previously held less ostentatious titles). The so-called l\u00e8se-majest\u00e9 law currently on the books dates from that era, and took its current form in the 1880s.\n\nAccording to public opinion polls, the royals enjoy tremendous approval. Part of their success is keeping a humble and people-friendly image, said Henk te Velde, a history professor at Leiden University, the king\u2019s alma mater. Support for transforming the Netherlands into a republic is minimal.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cThe vast part of Dutch society might think that monarchy is not really modern,\u201d Professor te Velde said. \u201cBut why should we get rid of it? It\u2019s nice folklore.\u201d\n\nDuring the 1960s and 1970s, when Dutch society was rethinking the role of government, there was more criticism of the monarchy and the royalty. But even then, the law about insulting the king was only rarely applied.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHowever, it does periodically get used.\n\nAbulkasim Al-Jaberi, an activist, was charged under the law in 2015 after repeatedly yelling an obscene phrase during a demonstration in Amsterdam. He was initially ordered to pay a fine, but then was threatened with prison when he refused to pay. The prosecutor eventually dismissed the case, saying that he had yelled his comments in the context of a public debate.\n\nFrom 2000 to 2012, the year before Queen Beatrix went into retirement, 16 people were prosecuted under the l\u00e8se-majest\u00e9 law.\n\nIn March, the European Court of Human Rights sided with two Spanish citizens who had burned a picture of the Spanish king and queen during a rally in 2007. The court, based in Strasbourg, France, found that Article 10 of the European Convention on Human Rights, which guarantees freedom of expression, superseded Spanish laws protecting the royal family from insults.\n\nThe new Dutch law also limits the maximum prison sentence for insulting a foreign head of state to four months, down from two years.\n\nIn 2016, a German court was forced to decide whether a German comedian\u2019s satirical poem mocking President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey was a criminal insult, after Mr. Erdogan pursued legal action.\n\nChancellor Angela Merkel of Germany was criticized for initially allowing the prosecution. She later said that her having called the poem \u201cdeliberately offensive\u201d was a mistake, given the importance of free speech.\n\nMr. van Dam, the Dutch lawmaker who had fought the bill approved on Tuesday, said he thought the measure was \u201cmore a statement than a practical thing \u2014 both the old law and the big change.\u201d", "title": "How Is Dutch King Like a Cop? Insulting Them Is to Be Treated Equally", "authors": ["Christopher F. Schuetze"]} {"date": "2018-04-27 00:00:00", "text": "FAMILY MAN: Unless you\u2019ve been living under a rock, it won\u2019t surprise you to learn that James Comey\u2019s memoir, \u201cA Higher Loyalty: Truth, Lies, and Leadership,\u201d debuts at No. 1 on the nonfiction list after selling more than 600,000 copies in its first week. The book, which was announced last August, took the former F.B.I. director about six months to complete: \u201cIt was a continuous process of writing and then getting feedback from my wife and kids, my agents and my editor, and then rewriting,\u201d he explains. \u201cThe final step was a daylong family gathering, where each of my five kids and two sons-in-law was assigned a portion to copy-edit. I offered $20 for each typo and then met in my office individually with each of the seven to review and debate their suggested changes. They made me much better.\u201d\n\nGHOST WRITER: \u201cGhost Boys,\u201d which enters the middle-grade list at No. 6, ties the contemporary story of Jerome, a 12-year-old black youth killed by a white police officer, to that of Emmett Till. Jewell Parker Rhodes says the idea for the book grew out of conversations with her editor. \u201cThe deaths of Trayvon Martin, Tamir Rice and so many other innocents had wounded me intellectually and emotionally,\u201d she says. \u201cI was born a year before Emmett Till was murdered, and his death haunted me as I grew during the civil rights movement and when I became a mother raising a son.\u201d At first, she told the American Booksellers Association, she wasn\u2019t sure she could write the book. \u201cBut I felt this strong calling, and I kept thinking about it, and how I would do it \u2026 It was worth it to give to this generation of kids because they\u2019ve given me so much in life, and I\u2019m waiting for them to grow up and rule the world and make it a better place.\u201d\n\nMAKING BOOK: David Baldacci \u2014 whose latest novel, \u201cThe Fallen,\u201d enters the fiction list at No. 1 \u2014 usually publishes two books a year. He juggles seven different series (six for adults, one for kids) and writes stand-alone novels. \u201cI was one of those kids who constantly told tall tales,\u201d Baldacci said in an interview earlier this year. \u201cMy mom bought me a journal and said, \u2018Why don\u2019t you try writing this stuff down?\u2019 I did and thought, \u2018My God, I can write something that other people can read and enjoy just like I do when I open a book.\u2019\u201d When he thanked his mother years later for the gift, she replied, \u201cI\u2019m so glad it worked so well for you, honey, but frankly, I just wanted to shut you the hell up.\u201d", "title": "How James Comey Found Mistakes in His Manuscript", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-19 00:00:00", "text": "The album earned Mon\u00e1e a Grammy nomination for the song \u201cMany Moons.\u201d She would go on to collect five more nominations across two more albums, both of which starred her alter-ego, Mayweather. For years, Mon\u00e1e remained safely cocooned within the character. \u201cCindi helps me talk more,\u201d she said; through Mayweather, she could address things she didn\u2019t feel comfortable talking about directly. \u201cYou can parallel the other in the android to being a black woman right now, to being a part of the L.G.B.T.Q. community,\u201d she said. \u201cWhat it feels like to be called a nigger by your oppressor.\u201d Mayweather was a proxy for all the things about Mona\u00e9 that made others uncomfortable, like her androgyny, her opaque sexual identity, her gender fluidity \u2014 her defiance of easy categorization.\n\nBut then Mon\u00e1e shifted her attention to acting. She made her film debut as the de facto surrogate mother of a young black boy in \u201cMoonlight,\u201d which won the Oscar for Best Picture last year; she starred, with Octavia Spencer and Taraji P. Henson, in the blockbuster \u201cHidden Figures,\u201d about early black female mathematicians. Fans wondered if she would commit to films, where she could attain a level of fame that can be elusive in music. But part of the reason she was slow to return, she told me, is that her mentor, Prince, died unexpectedly. They were working together closely on what would become \u201cDirty Computer.\u201d \u201cThis was the person that I would literally call and talk to about sounds or: \u2018How should I say this? Is this saying too much?\u2019 I just never could imagine a time where I couldn\u2019t pick up the phone or email him, and he\u2019d contact me right back and we\u2019d talk about all these things that I was unsure of.\u201d\n\nThe music Mon\u00e1e introduced on that dusty afternoon in Los Angeles marked her highly anticipated return. \u201cDirty Computer,\u201d a celebratory ode to femininity and queer people, seems to signal a new era in her career: If in the past she seemed distant, using Mayweather to stand in for the real Mon\u00e1e, she now seems ready to present herself to the public. \u201cRight now I\u2019m escaping the gravity of the labels that people have tried to place on me that have stopped my evolution,\u201d she told me. \u201cYou have to go ahead and soar, and not be afraid to jump \u2014 and I\u2019m jumping right now.\u201d\n\nTwo months later, in February, I was in the back of an Uber, riding southwest toward a subdivision of Atlanta. After a pause at a security gate, the car drove through an upscale, predominantly black community, past typical suburban scenes \u2014 teenagers shooting hoops, people taking out their garbage, men working on their cars. I was heading to Wondaland Arts Society, Mon\u00e1e\u2019s creative headquarters. Its inspiration is Paisley Park, the elaborate compound outside Minneapolis that housed Prince\u2019s rehearsal space, recording rooms, concert venue and countless parties.
