Several years ago, Mon\u00e1e established the Wondaland label \u2014 one of the few black women to have a label of her own \u2014 and signed several acts, including the band St. Beauty (one member, Isis Valentino, was a backup singer for Mon\u00e1e) and the singer and rapper Jidenna. The Wondaland artists often practice together and appear on one another\u2019s albums. And the compound, where the artists often crash, has become a center of black culture in Atlanta. Much of \u201cBlack Panther\u201d was shot in and around the city, and the cast held impromptu gatherings at Wondaland. At one, Chadwick Boseman whaled on the drums and Lupita N\u2019yongo was hailed as the best dancer. They were among the first to hear \u201cDirty Computer,\u201d and their approval gave Mon\u00e1e\u2019s confidence a boost. \u201cI felt understood,\u201d she told me. \u201cI felt like, Man, these are people I admire and I respect, and they love this album. I have to finish it.\u201d\n\nOutside Wondaland, eight cars lined the long driveway, and staccato bursts floated from an open window upstairs. It sounded like band practice, a score being workshopped. I recognized the music from \u201cDirty Computer.\u201d A Wondaland staff member named Kelly greeted me at the door and gave me a quick tour. From the outside, the house looked like any other Southern McMansion, but the entryway immediately suggested something different. Thick, leafy palm trees crowded the foyer so densely that I had to wrestle them to get through. A handwritten note asked guests to slip off their shoes. An archway was decorated with a dozen or so clocks, in different shapes and colors, their hands frozen at various times.\n\nPhoto\n\nBefore I went down to the sprawling lower level where Mon\u00e1e and I would talk, I poked my head into a few of the rooms on the first floor, all filled with recording equipment and more luscious tropical plants. People seemed to be having casual meetings in many of them. There was a large wraparound kitchen, where a woman was chopping army quantities of vegetables. On the dining-room table, there was a chocolate cake surrounded by red and blue balloons, a bottle of sparkling ros\u00e9 and a laserjet printout that read in block caps: \u201cCONGRATULATIONS, YOU DIRTY COMPUTER.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe stairs to the basement were covered with green turf, so that even as my eyes adjusted to the dimming light, my feet were receiving the pleasantly disorienting sensation of outdoors. Downstairs, there were tropical plants everywhere; brilliant orange-and-white fish swam in an expansive tank bathed in purple lights. I counted at least five keyboards, eight guitars, two drum kits, a piano, a cello, a trumpet and a saxophone. A stack of books piled on an end table included \u201cWriting Better Lyrics,\u201d \u201cSapiens,\u201d \u201cZen Guitar\u201d and \u201cBuilt to Last,\u201d a book on business management. There was a desk crowded with sound mixers and synthesizers, and a box set of Jimi Hendrix CDs. A minifridge was stocked with seltzer, wine and water, and a bottle of absinthe stood on the desk.\n\nMon\u00e1e soundlessly padded into the room, clad in a velour caftan, gold earrings and rings to match. She was barefoot, her toes painted metallic silver. She had arrived from Los Angeles that morning, and tried to take a nap, but Jidenna, who was in town, woke her up with his practicing. Though she apologized for being tired, she was buoyant. It had been 24 hours since her first two singles \u2014 \u201cDjango Jane\u201d and \u201cMake Me Feel\u201d \u2014 were released, and both were trending on social media. \u201cI\u2019m still nervous, obviously, but I\u2019ll enjoy this moment,\u201d she told me, as she arranged herself more comfortably on a chair next to the couch where I was sitting. \u201cBut I won\u2019t drive myself nuts trying to preplan what people are going to say, what they\u2019re going to think, even though it terrifies me \u2014 I just have to put my energy into finishing.\u201d\n\nMon\u00e1e, who is 32, told me that she has been circling the themes explored on \u201cDirty Computer\u201d for at least a decade, but that earlier it felt safer to package herself in metaphors. \u201cI knew I needed to make this album, and I put it off and put it off because the subject is Janelle Mon\u00e1e.\u201d She\u2019s still having a conversation with herself, she said, about who she wants to be when she\u2019s in the spotlight. The sanitized android version felt more accepted \u2014 and more acceptable \u2014 than her true self. The public, she explained, doesn\u2019t really \u201cknow Janelle Mon\u00e1e, and I felt like I didn\u2019t really have to be her because they were fine with Cindi.\u201d When Prince died in April 2016, she started to rethink how she would present herself. \u201cI couldn\u2019t fake being vulnerable. In terms of how I will be remembered, I have anxiety around that, like the whole concept about what I\u2019ll be remembered for.\u201d\n\nAt its core, \u201cDirty Computer\u201d is a homage to women and the spectrum of sexual identities. The songs can be grouped into three loose categories: Reckoning, Celebration and Reclamation. \u201cThe first songs deal with realizing that this is how society sees me,\u201d she said. \u201cThis is how I\u2019m viewed. I\u2019m a \u2018dirty computer,\u2019 it\u2019s clear. I\u2019m going to be pushed to the margins, outside margins, of the world.\u201d \u201cD\u2019Jango Jane\u201d is an ode to black power and pride that is also a dirge about the struggles that come with that heritage. The middle half of the album is a raucous party. \u201cIt\u2019s like, O.K., these are the cards I\u2019ve been dealt,\u201d she said. These songs include \u201cMake Me Feel\u201d and \u201cPynk\u201d \u2014 the sizzling, sex-drenched songs that titillated the internet when they were released earlier this year. The album winds down with an anthem about being an American, whose sound evokes Prince\u2019s \u201cLet\u2019s Go Crazy,\u201d with lyrics like \u201clove me for who I am,\u201d and \u201ccross my heart and hope to die, I\u2019m a big old piece of American pie.\u201d\n\nMon\u00e1e will release an extended musical film with the album that illustrates and complements \u201cDirty Computer.\u201d The 50-minute \u201cemotion picture,\u201d as she calls it, follows a young woman, played by Mon\u00e1e, on the run from an authoritarian government that hunts down so-called deviants and \u201ccleans\u201d them by erasing their memories. Those memories serve as the musical interludes (the videos) amid the drama \u2014 \u201cHandmaid\u2019s Tale\u201d meets \u201cSan Junipero,\u201d set in a desiccated \u201cMad Max\u201d landscape. It follows a crew of young kids, mostly black, dancing and dodging capture. Longtime fans will recognize the parallels to Mayweather \u2014 which Mon\u00e1e expects \u2014 but instead of focusing on a fictional male human lover, the object of her affection is the actress Tessa Thompson, with whom Mon\u00e1e is frequently photographed in real life. A beautiful man whom she occasionally hugs and kisses makes appearances, but he feels like an afterthought. Plausible deniability. The star-crossed romance between Thompson and Mon\u00e1e, and whether they will be separated or reunited, is the true narrative of the film.\n\nMost popular music is so determinedly centered on heterosexual dynamics that any hint of same-sex interactions can feel revelatory, even radical, upon the first encounter. That\u2019s the way it felt to me when I first watched Mon\u00e1e\u2019s film. The queer sexual interactions are refreshingly explicit \u2014 miming digital and oral sex \u2014 and images throughout celebrate women. The video for the song \u201cPynk\u201d is an extended appreciation of the female anatomy, with neon signs screaming, \u201c[Expletive] Power,\u201d and pink-frilled jumpsuits that wouldn\u2019t look out of place in a Judy Chicago installation.\n\nAlready much of social media has speculated on the nature of Mon\u00e1e and Thompson\u2019s relationship, and this film \u2014 especially with scenes like Thompson poking her head from between the legs of Mon\u00e1e\u2019s pink vagina pantsuit \u2014 is certain to only inflame those rumors. The first time I saw the video for \u201cMake Me Feel,\u201d months before its YouTube release, I found it so sexually suggestive (Thompson appears throughout the song, fawning over Mon\u00e1e, dancing with her, almost kissing her) that I immediately texted the woman I was dating at the time, \u201comg janelle might really be gay.\u201d It felt as declarative as a coming-out could. And yet in person, Mon\u00e1e would say only that she felt this was her coming-out as an advocate of women and queer issues. \u201cI want it to be very clear that I\u2019m an advocate for women,\u201d she said. \u201cI\u2019m a girl\u2019s girl, meaning I support women no matter what they choose to do. I\u2019m proud when everybody is taking agency over their image and their bodies.\u201d She told me that she wanted the album to be especially relevant to black women and queer women, for them to feel seen and heard in this album. \u201cI felt that way when I listened to Lauryn Hill, as I was trying to find myself as a young woman, I felt that way when I listened to Stevie Wonder when I was trying to understand God more.\u201d\n\nI asked Mon\u00e1e what she thought of the internet\u2019s speculation about her romantic relationship with Thompson. Watching her as she decided on a response was like watching a mathematician working out Fermat\u2019s Last Theorem. Gears were churning; calculations were being made. Finally, she laughed, raised her eyebrows and deflected: \u201cI hope people feel celebrated,\u201d she said. \u201cI hope they feel love. I hope they feel seen.\u201d It was late into the evening, and I was conscious of how long we\u2019d been talking \u2014 at least two hours \u2014 and let it drop. But the issue lingered for me, especially the more times I watched her film.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThese days, the culture seems more accepting and welcoming of queerness: Young actors and pop stars like Amandla Stenberg and Lady Gaga are identifying publicly as bisexual. Lena Waithe and her fianc\u00e9e were recently photographed by Annie Leibovitz for Vanity Fair. And yet, nonheteronormative sexuality remains the last taboo. Mon\u00e1e is media-savvy enough to protect herself from becoming tabloid fodder for publications that want to turn her personal life into spectacle or reduce her art to her sexuality. She told me repeatedly that she worried what her early fans and very religious and very Southern family would think. There\u2019s little precedent for a black female celebrity at her level living openly as a lesbian in a gay relationship.\n\nMon\u00e1e has spent a lifetime perfecting the art of being a pop star who isn\u2019t a sexual object. Discretion is a survival strategy, a coping mechanism especially useful for black women living in the public eye. But she has now made an explicit album about sexual expression and identity that is somehow still shrouded in ambiguity. In 2018, empowerment isn\u2019t a color \u2014 it\u2019s a call to action. It\u2019s Cardi B talking about how much she loves her vagina, not holding a neon sign explaining that she has one. On \u201cDirty Computer,\u201d it still feels as if Mon\u00e1e is deciding which version of herself to show the world \u2014 or that this is the tentative beginning of a larger reveal.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Magazine Newsletter Get the best of the Magazine delivered to your inbox every week, including exclusive feature stories, photography, columns and more. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMon\u00e1e grew up in a large yet tightknit family in Kansas City, Kan., the kind with relatives in the double digits. Money was scarce, but they made do. Her parents worked in the service industry, her mother as a janitor and her stepfather as a postal worker. Her mother was a Baptist but didn\u2019t mind when Mona\u00e9 listened to racy R. & B. songs by groups like Jodeci or rappers like Tupac. Her great-grandmothers played organ in church and taught piano. Her biological father sang. She thinks he could have gotten a record deal if he hadn\u2019t battled an addiction to crack. Her mother left him when Mon\u00e1e was a toddler and remarried. He was in and out of prison Mon\u00e1e\u2019s entire childhood. \u201cHe\u2019s sober now,\u201d she told me, and the author of a memoir in which he writes about Mon\u00e1e: \u201cShe always had this distinctive look in her eye that said: \u2018I\u2019m going to make it! No matter what!\u2019 And I believed that she would.\u201d\n\nAs a teenager, Mon\u00e1e was enrolled in a young playwrights\u2019 program and performed in talent showcases on the weekend, where she sang Lauryn Hill songs a cappella and usually won. She watched movies like \u201cThe Wiz\u201d but struggled with the same question that all black children weaned on American pop culture eventually reckon with: Is this all there is?\n\nAfter high school, she moved to New York to study musical theater at the American Musical and Dramatic Academy. She couldn\u2019t afford to live on campus, so she shared a room at 140th and Amsterdam with an older cousin, who worked nights at the Post Office. They each took a shift sleeping while the other was at work or school and saw each other on the weekends. Her congregation supplied some funds, and Mon\u00e1e did some work as a maid to make ends meet. She spent the rest of her time in libraries, reading plays and practicing monologues. Her best friend was studying in Atlanta and regaled her with tales of wild parties and the camaraderie of black Greek life. \u201cIt was just more exciting than what I was doing,\u201d she said. She liked the rigor and discipline of her school but worried she would lose her edge: \u201cI didn\u2019t want to sound, or look or feel like anybody else.\u201d She made the decision to leave New York after a year and a half.\n\nMon\u00e1e eventually settled in a boardinghouse that was directly across from the university center that contains all four of Atlanta\u2019s historically black colleges: Clark Atlanta University, Spelman College, Morehouse College and the Morehouse School of Medicine. She went to Georgia State University\u2019s Perimeter College to save money and began to write her own music. Atlanta in the early 2000s was a hotbed for musical innovation, with artists like OutKast spinning their eccentricities and distinct Southern identity into record deals and national fame. Mon\u00e1e began experimenting with her own sound, performing around campus \u2014 in dorm rooms, at school events and, once, on the steps of the library. She made a CD called \u201cThe Audition\u201d and sold it out of the trunk of her Mitsubishi Galant. She worked at Office Depot and during slow moments updated her Myspace page with new photos and music.\n\nDuring this period, she met Mikael Moore, her longtime manager, and his classmates Chuck Lightning and Nate Wonder, who would eventually became close collaborators and form the backbone of all her creative efforts \u2014 writing songs with Mon\u00e1e and directing her videos, which they continue to do. At an open-mic night, she met Antwan Patton, otherwise known as Big Boi, from OutKast. He invited her to contribute to \u201cGot Purp? Vol. II,\u201d a 2005 compilation album that featured artists of Dirty South rap like Goodie Mob and Bubba Sparxxx but few other women. She also appeared on the soundtrack for \u201cIdlewild,\u201d the 2006 musical film starring Patton and Andr\u00e9 Benjamin, or Andr\u00e9 3000, Patton\u2019s partner in OutKast.\n\nSean Combs, the producer also known as Puffy at the time, reached out to her after her work with Big Boi put her on his radar. Mon\u00e1e had already taken a few meetings with record executives, and was disillusioned by those early encounters. They criticized her style, which then involved, sartorially, androgynous suits, and musically, operatic odes to her character Cindi Mayweather. During one performance, she noticed midsong, breathless and sweating from the effort of dancing and singing, an executive casually reading a magazine. \u201cI cried,\u201d she said. \u201cI mean, I cried.\u201d She made Puffy a deal: She had just finished \u201cMetropolis.\u201d She\u2019d hear him out if he came to see her perform. \u201cIt was important to know if he was serious, that he was going to appreciate me and not try to change my live show or my music.\u201d Combs halted filming on his reality show, \u201cMaking the Band\u201d and flew down. He loved what he saw. \u201cHe said, let\u2019s meet tomorrow and let\u2019s talk,\u201d Mon\u00e1e recalled.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nCombs told Mon\u00e1e that he wanted to introduce her to a larger audience. \u201cI knew I had to work with her,\u201d he told me via email. \u201cIt was immediate. I just knew she was going to be important to music and culture. It was the same sort of feeling I had when I first heard Biggie or Mary J. Blige, and I wanted to help introduce this artist to the world.\u201d\n\nIn 2008, Combs announced the signing of Mon\u00e1e to his label, Bad Boy Records. They rereleased \u201cMetropolis\u201d and then followed up with \u201cThe ArchAndroid\u201d in 2010 and \u201cThe Electric Lady\u201d in 2013 (as well as \u201cDirty Computer\u201d). Mon\u00e1e went on tour with No Doubt and Bruno Mars and collaborated with Solange Knowles and Erykah Badu. She landed an endorsement with CoverGirl. She was being sent movie scripts. None moved her until she read the one for \u201cMoonlight.\u201d\n\nYesi Ramirez, the casting director on the movie, had flagged Mon\u00e1e for the director Barry Jenkins, and they scheduled a screen test over Skype. When she appeared, her hair filled the frame, even more than her face. He was startled. \u201cI wanted to call her Auntie. I was used to the pompadour, and this larger-than-life entity, the outer-space person that I\u2019d seen live in Oakland with Erykah Badu, and I had to reconcile that person with this person before me,\u201d he said. \u201cWe started talking, and it was very clear that she got it.\u201d\n\nDuring the beginning of production, Mon\u00e1e lost a relative to gun violence. Jenkins felt that the story of Chiron, the boy whose life the movie follows as he matures, spoke to her because she knew young men like him, lost and struggling to make sense of their sexuality \u2014 and understood the way strangers can raise you as much as your biological family can. \u201cShe felt it was important that someone like that be centered in a narrative,\u201d Jenkins told me. \u201cAnd whatever she could do to bring it to larger light, she was down for.\u201d\n\nFor Mon\u00e1e, \u201cMoonlight\u201d and then \u201cHidden Figures\u201d were a way to convey the message she has striven over and over to convey: recognition and validation for people overlooked by society. \u201cI was, like, this is just another way to get out the message I\u2019ve been trying to talk about for so [expletive] long that I feel like I don\u2019t know if anybody is listening,\u201d she told me. \u201cYou can show people better than you can tell them.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nRain is Kryptonite to social outings in L.A., but bad weather could not touch the mood in the room at Catch LA in early March. There were a few men \u2014 Jay Ellis from \u201cInsecure,\u201d as well as Mon\u00e1e\u2019s team of male collaborators \u2014 but women were everywhere: Ava DuVernay, Rosario Dawson, the director Dee Rees accompanied by her partner, Sarah Broom, Debra Lee, the president of the BET network. The actresses Danai Gurira and Lupita Nyong\u2019o arrived together. Geena Davis watched the scene approvingly from a nearby table. The former editor of Teen Vogue, Elaine Welteroth, held court at another. The New York DJ Kitty Cash played songs, mostly by female artists. Tessa Thompson bounced around in a gorgeous yellow-and-pink feathery coat and leather pants, occasionally at Mon\u00e1e\u2019s side. The women had gathered for a brunch that Mon\u00e1e was hosting for her \u201cFem the Future\u201d project to support women in the entertainment industry. Mon\u00e1e had chosen three female filmmakers to make short films funded by Belvedere vodka that answered the question: What does a beautiful future look like? The event was nominally to celebrate them but more largely to gather in one room actors, writers, directors and producers Mon\u00e1e admired.\n\nMon\u00e1e, dressed in a Bella Freud ice-blue velvet suit, matching glitter eyeliner and perfectly matte red lips, walked to the front of the restaurant and picked up a microphone. \u201cThis room looks good,\u201d she said. \u201cYou inspire me and encourage me to be a better woman and artist.\u201d Earlier in her career, she said, she asked some label reps to recommend other female producers and creators she could work with. The list they provided stunned her. \u201cIt was so tiny,\u201d she said. \u201cI was upset.\u201d To channel that anger, she said, she started her initiative to help women \u201ccross-connect and open doors,\u201d as she put it. \u201cIt gives everybody a seat at the table.\u201d\n\nThroughout my conversations with Mon\u00e1e, she talked about her dedication to lifting up women. Some of that didn\u2019t quite square with me \u2014 most of the crew that supports her creatively, spiritually, administratively seem to be men. But Mon\u00e1e\u2019s event felt like a mild insistence that she got it. This brunch seemed like a woman-centric version of a few rounds on the golf course \u2014 a space that emphasized the importance of networking, beyond film sets, parties and premieres as a means to lay the groundwork for future collaborations. Seeing her in that capacity reminded me that she\u2019s still evolving into the woman she wants to be in the world and the role she wants to play.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nA few years ago, the singer and actor Harry Belafonte was asked by a reporter for The Hollywood Reporter to comment on \u201cmembers of minorities in Hollywood today.\u201d Belafonte, a prominent civil rights activist who helped organized the 1963 March on Washington where the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. gave his \u201cI Have a Dream\u201d speech, took the opportunity to express frustration about what he perceived as the political malaise of celebrities. \u201cI think one of the great abuses of this modern time is that we should have had such high-profile artists, powerful celebrities,\u201d he said, \u201cbut they have turned their back on social responsibility.\u201d Until recently, few publicly stepped in to fill the hole he named. In the past, Mon\u00e1e shied away from anything that could potentially derail her career. \u201cI used to be a lot more afraid of going off script,\u201d she told me.\n\nShe emerged as an activist in August 2015, at a demonstration in Philadelphia she led in support of the local Black Lives Matter movement. There\u2019s a photo of Mon\u00e1e surrounded by most of the artists in the Wondaland collective: Jidenna, St. Beauty, Roman GianArthur, Chuck Lightning and the producer Nana Kwabena. Their mouths are open, midchant, and the look on their faces is determined. They are holding drums, signs, one another. For Mon\u00e1e, the times were too urgent to ignore. Freddie Gray and Sandra Bland had recently died following controversial encounters with the police. She realized she had a voice that she could use. That she needed to use. A few days later, Mon\u00e1e released the anthem \u201cHell You Talmbout,\u201d which is less a song than a chant. At nearly seven minutes long, it calls out the names of black men and women who were victims of police brutality, followed by the urging to say their names. It was a significant moment in her career: She would no longer be cautious when it came to social responsibility. The song came out almost a year before Beyonc\u00e9\u2019s breaking-chains \u201cFreedom\u201d or Solange Knowles\u2019s primal scream on \u201cA Seat at the Table.\u201d A few months later, Ava DuVernay and Ryan Coogler gave a benefit concert in Flint, Mich., to raise money for the clean-water-deprived city that was also a boycott of the Oscars. Mon\u00e1e performed alongside Stevie Wonder, Vic Mensa and Hannibal Buress. Mona\u00e9 told me that in the past, she tended to write anthems for other people. \u201cI don\u2019t always live them, I don\u2019t. And I\u2019m learning more and more to live them, to make myself live them.\u201d\n\nHer highest-profile moment came with the 2017 presidential inauguration. Mon\u00e1e was invited to speak \u2014 as well as sing \u2014 at the Women\u2019s March by Ginny Suss, a member of the organizing committee in charge of music. Suss wanted artists whose music reflected their personal politic. \u201cWhen you look at the arc of her career, there has always been a moral core and ethical center to her music, that breaks down constructions of race and gender in our society,\u201d Suss told me. \u201cIt\u2019s a tool to imagine the world we want through the accessibility of pop music. Having her stand up and have that voice at the march was amazing.\u201d\n\nMon\u00e1e had heard that Lucia McBath, the mother of Jordan Davis; Sybrina Fulton, the mother of Trayvon Martin; and Gwen Carr, the mother of Eric Garner, were going to be there, too, and she wanted to offer support. She herself was still reeling from the election, she added. \u201cI just wanted to come and not only uplift, but I wanted to be uplifted, too.\u201d As she made her way backstage, she got a sense of the crowd for the first time. \u201cI saw, like, tens of thousands \u2014 hundreds of thousands of women and men and people from all around the world, babies and Muslims and trans and L.G.B.T. folks,\u201d she recalled. \u201cI was like, Oh, my God.\u201d She hadn\u2019t expected such a tremendous turnout, for so many people to care about what happens to women. The importance of the task hit her. But there was no privacy backstage, no place to prepare or gather her thoughts \u2014 just a communal room where the speakers were chatting and taking photographs. Mon\u00e1e had no choice but to wing it. \u201cThat was just one of those moments where I was just, like, It might not come out right, but as long as your intentions are pure, as long as you\u2019re honest,\u201d she told me. She drew from the mixture of emotions stirred up by her recent role in \u201cHidden Figures,\u201d about female African-American mathematicians suffering from discrimination even as they performed pivotal jobs for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration during the American space race of the 1960s. \u201cEverything that was going on in January felt like that era, when we\u2019re talking about a blatant war on women\u2019s rights.\u201d\n\nShe appeared calm as she addressed the enormous crowd. \u201cWomen will be hidden no more,\u201d she said. \u201cWe have names. We are complete human beings.\u201d For many people, the speech cast Mon\u00e1e in a new light: she became more than a psychedelic Tim Burton character. The response galvanized her. \u201cI just had to speak from my heart,\u201d she said. \u201cNot a lot of artists do it.\u201d\n\nThis January, she took the stage at the Grammys, where she delivered a short speech to introduce the singer Kesha, who\u2019d had a legal battle with her former producer Dr. Luke. A member of TimesUp, a Hollywood initiative to fight sexual harassment, Mon\u00e1e wore its pin proudly on her black suit as she called out the music industry for its epidemic patterns of sexual harassment and assault. \u201cWe come in peace, but we mean business,\u201d she said to the crowd. \u201cJust as we have the power to shape culture, we also have the power to undo the culture that does not serve us well.\u201d\n\nIn Atlanta, after our conversation at Wondaland, Mon\u00e1e seemed to get a second wind. The band upstairs had resumed practicing for her forthcoming tour, and she wanted to check in on their progress. She invited me to join her. If the basement was where ideas began to gestate, then the room she led me to was where they were polished before leaving the house. It had a ballet barre and floor-to-ceiling mirrors. She disappeared for a few minutes before returning in black leggings and the same cropped moto jacket from the presentation in Los Angeles.\n\nMon\u00e1e greeted everyone in her band \u2014 the drummer, keyboard player, guitarist and two backup singers \u2014 hugging them and taking a few moments to inquire about their health, their families, their side projects, before taking her position in front of them. She patted her pockets, searching for a missing item, which she spied on a speaker: mirrored sunglasses. She put them on and nodded to the band. They launched into \u201cMake Me Feel\u201d and then \u201cI Got the Juice,\u201d and she ran through them a few times, losing herself a little more in the music during each performance.\n\nDespite the accolades and Grammy nominations, Mon\u00e1e has yet to achieve significant commercial success. If there\u2019s a moment that her entire discography has been building toward, it is right now, with this release. Her desire for a win shone nakedly. She sneaked coy peeks at me to see if I was paying attention. It was impossible to tear my eyes away, not to want for her what she so clearly wants for herself. At the completion of each song, Mon\u00e1e would grin, breathless. \u201cThat\u2019s going to sound so good live,\u201d she said, happily. But then the perfectionist came out again. She asked the band what else they had prepared. The sheepish answer came: Nothing. She paused, letting her displeasure seep out for few moments, just enough for them to know that they\u2019d need to step it up. \u201cWell, all right, then,\u201d she replied. \u201cLet\u2019s go through them again.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn all our encounters, Mon\u00e1e seemed as if she was bracing herself for anything, including the worst \u2014 harsh reviews, irrelevancy, dismissals. But all that carefully maintained composure fell away as she twirled and dropped to her knees. Earlier, I asked her what she ultimately wanted: awards? Album sales? Money? She referred to Prince again: He was in that \u201cfree [expletive] category,\u201d she said. \u201cThat\u2019s where I want to be. That\u2019s where I want to ultimately be.\u201d", "title": "How Janelle Mon\u00e1e Found Her Voice", "authors": ["Jenna Wortham"]} {"date": "2018-04-27 00:00:00", "text": "SLEEP SCHEDULES Our kids wake up well before 7, and Jamie and I take turns when it comes to who wakes up with them. When it\u2019s my chance to sleep in, I stay in bed until 9 or later. Often, I\u2019ll have played a gig on Saturday night. I don\u2019t get to bed until 4 sometimes. My sleep is precious.\n\nPhoto\n\nTHREE CUPS, BLACK I can\u2019t my start my day without strong, black coffee. I usually have three cups spread out over the morning. While I\u2019m drinking, I give the kids breakfast. Or I should say their first breakfast, because they eat again with Jamie and me later. This time around, they\u2019ll have cold cereal, usually Cheerios.\n\nPhoto\n\nMIX AND CHOP We love having friends over for Sunday breakfast so after we\u2019re dressed for the day, Jamie and I cook up the meal. It\u2019s always waffles or pancakes. We may cut up a fruit salad, and we sometimes have bacon. On the odd occasion, we\u2019ll make mimosas.", "title": "How Jonathan Goldman, Professor and Musician, Spends His Sundays", "authors": ["Shivani Vora", "Sunday Routine"]} {"date": "2018-04-05 00:00:00", "text": "The winner of last year\u2019s green jacket, Sergio Garcia, quickly ended any thoughts of a repeat performance. On the par-5 15th, Garcia continually attempted to spin the ball toward a front hole location, and five shots wound up falling into the water. Garcia finished with a 13 on the hole, tied for the most in Masters history.\n\nSpieth, on the other hand, was dialed in. After birdieing two of his first three holes, he bogeyed Nos. 5 and 7 to drop back to even. But an eagle on No. 8 got him going. And at Amen Corner, where he lost the Masters in 2016, he started a remarkable run. It was the first time he birdied five holes in a row at Augusta.\n\nHe zipped past Tony Finau, who, playing in first Masters, suffered a high-ankle sprain on Wednesday while celebrating a hole-in-one at the Par-3 Tournament. Finau was cleared to play Thursday, and though he was walking somewhat gingerly, his game somehow did not show any ill effects. He had the outright lead for a bit before Spieth overran him.\n\nConditions were perfect by the afternoon, which played into Spieth\u2019s favor, as one of the last groups to finish. And for the ninth time in just 17 career rounds at Augusta, he holds the lead.\n\nHere\u2019s how the first round of the Masters played out:\n\nSpieth\u2019s Amazing Round Ends With a Bogey\n\nWell, Jordan Spieth\u2019s birdie streak ended. He made somewhat of a mess of things on the 18th (he\u2019s not the first), hitting a tee shot into the woods, then wedge out, then a 3-wood into the gallery. But he still always has the capacity for something brilliant, and he delivered again, deftly sticking his wedge within three feet to tap in for bogey. So Spieth is in with a 66, the ninth time he has led or shared a lead in 17 career rounds at Augusta.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSpieth Makes It Look Easy at Augusta\n\nFive. Five birdies in a row for Jordan Spieth. The 2015 Masters winner has never done that before at Augusta. But even when things aren\u2019t looking so great \u2014 like his tee shot on 17, which hit some tree limbs \u2014 the ball still bounced into favorable position in the fairway and he took advantage. Tremendous performance. Now 7-under par.\n\nSpieth Continues Birdie Run to Build 2-Stroke Lead\n\nMake it four straight birdies for Jordan Spieth. He\u2019s so confident with his swing that he didn\u2019t even need to look where his tee shot on the 172-yard par-3 16th wound up. He knew it was good when he hit it and just walked straight over to his caddie, Michael Greller, to grab his putter. He would like what he saw: a tap-in to take a two-stroke lead. The cup must look the size of Grand Canyon right now for Spieth.\n\nJordan Spieth Makes Three Straight Birdies for the Lead\n\nConditions at Augusta National have been almost idyllic, and Jordan Spieth is taking advantage. After an errant tee shot left on the par-5 15th, he had to lay up in front of the water. But he stuck his 90-yard approach within just a few feet and made the putt to grab sole possession of the lead at five-under par. Spieth has now birdied three in a row. The eagle on eight really jump-started his round after two bogeys.\n\nTony Finau Finishes With a Share of Lead\n\nAfter a beautiful drive on the last hole, Tony Finau made one of his only mistakes on the day, missing left with his approach and then leaving himself with a long putt. But if we\u2019ve learned anything today, it\u2019s that the 28-year-old Tongan-American is pretty resilient. He made the delicate 13-foot putt to record a 68, currently tied for the lead with Jordan Spieth. The 18th had been a great equalizer on Thursday. Four players came to the 18th with at least a share of the lead, and all four had bogeyed before Finau.\n\nRory McIlroy in the Mix at 1-Under\n\nRory McIlroy is plodding along steadily at 1-under. His tee shot on the par-3 12th sailed right over the pin and off the green, but he was able to putt it back on to save par. He\u2019s been great off the tee but a three-putt on No. 7 is his only blemish on the round as he heads to the 13th hole.\n\nTony Finau Leads, Sprained Ankle and All\n\nHe suffered a high-ankle sprain, yesterday, while celebrating a hole-in-one in the par-3 tournament. But that hasn\u2019t slowed down Tony Finau in his first Masters appearance. He\u2019s been walking gingerly but is somehow now tied for the lead at four-under through 12.\n\nHenrik Stenson Fall Out of Lead on No. 18\n\nTrouble on the 18th hole cost Henrik Stenson a stroke as he finishes at three-under par, one stroke behind Charley Hoffman and Adam Hadwin for the lead. Stenson has never finished in the top 10 at the Masters, so he changed his strategy by dropping his trusty 3-wood in favor of his driver on most holes. He hit 10 of 14 fairways, so that wasn\u2019t bad. But on 18, he hit a poor chip that left him with a long putt that he missed to bogey.\n\nJordan Spieth Runs Into \u2014 and Out of \u2014 Trouble\n\nAfter birdieing two of the first three holes, Jordan Spieth bogeyed Nos. 5 and 7 to drop back to even par. But he just eagled the par-5 8th for a big rebound as he starts to make the turn.\n\nPhoto\n\nSergio Garcia Takes a 13(!) on the 15th Hole\n\nThe defending champion has made his mark at the Masters again. Unfortunately, it\u2019s the wrong kind of mark.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSergio Garcia hit five straight balls into the water on the par-5 15th hole and tied a tournament record with a 13 on the hole. That\u2019s an octuple bogey for those scoring at home. He\u2019s now 9-over par.\n\n\u201cI don\u2019t know what to tell you,\u201d Garc\u00eda said after finishing with an 81. \u201cIt\u2019s one of those things. I feel like it\u2019s the first time in my career where I made a 13 without missing a shot. Simple as that.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nNo. 18: Tiger Finishes at +1, but Ends on Positive Note\n\nThat\u2019s a wrap for Tiger Woods. He ended on another good drive on the 18th. Then from 171 yards was yelling for it to bite but it didn\u2019t listen and went just a bit long. He missed the putt coming back and finished with a par to close at one-over. Currently five strokes off the lead, but it could have gone much, much worse after a difficult stroll through Amen Corner. He kept his composure, rediscovered his swing, and finished two-under on the final six holes.\n\n\u201cSeventy three is fine,\u201d Woods told reporters after the round. \u201cBy the end of the week there will be a bunch of guys with a chance to win this tournament.\u201d\n\nBill Pennington: Two takeaways from Woods\u2019s round: Pretty good job of keeping it together today considering he didn\u2019t make a birdie on a par 5; no one can mount a charge at the Masters without making birdies on the par 5s.\n\nNo. 17: Tiger\u2019s Confidence Is Coming Back\n\nWoods absolutely bombed a perfect drive down the middle (finally) on 17, leaving him with a wedge in. Looked like a good swing with the approach, which went a little long, but still left him with a relatively straightforward downhill birdie opportunity. Unfortunately he left his putt out to the right. But still, he looked much more confident and in control with his swing, and that\u2019s a nice rebound from just a few holes earlier.\n\nNo. 16: Tiger Has Reason to Smile\n\nFinally, a smile from Tiger. A great tee shot on the par-3 16th hit the slope and rolled back to give him an uphill look for birdie from about 20 feet. And he gave it a confident roll and buried it. Big bounceback for Woods, who\u2019s back to 1-over with two holes to play.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nNo. 15: Tiger Still Struggling Off the Tee\n\nA critical hole for Woods, the par-5 15th, and he lost it way right off the tee with driver again. He was forced to lob it up over some pine trees to get back toward the fairway. He made a strong recovery to give himself a look for birdie from around 25 feet, but he left it short and had to tap in for par. He\u2019s been grinding, that\u2019s for sure.\n\nBut a birdie on 15 would have brought him back to 1-over, while Leishman, the co-leader, finished with a double bogey on the hole. Woods just has not taken advantage of the back-nine par-5s, though, mostly because he is nowhere near as sharp off the tee as he looked earlier in the week.\n\nPhoto\n\nJordan Spieth Off to a Promising Start\n\nIt\u2019s still early, but back-to-back birdies on Nos. 2 and 3 have to make Jordan Spieth feel good about this weekend at Augusta. Spieth won the Masters in 2015 and tied Lee Westwood for second place in 2016.\n\nNo. 14: Another Birdie for Tiger, Finally\n\nWoods rebounds with a great birdie on 14. He finally looked sharp with a 3-wood off the tee and then knocked his second shot within a couple of yards. Then he made the putt to move back to 2-over. He needed that.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nNo. 13: Who is This Tiger?\n\nThe wheels are starting to come off for Tiger. A 3-wood off the tee at 13 also hung out too far to the right and left Woods among some trees on the pinestraw. He then whacked into some patrons on the right side of the fairway. After a decent pitch onto the green, he missed the 12-foot comebacker for birdie. He\u2019s now even-par on the par-5s, which is very un-Tiger-like.\n\nNo. 12: Into the Water, Amen\n\nWoods is not enjoying himself at the Amen Corner. His tee shot on the par-3 155-yard 12th went short and trickled into the water. Then he took a while to decide where to drop, looking pretty uncertain. He\u2019s never played No. 12 well in his career, but he did manage to save a bogey with a clutch putt. Now at 3-over heading to No. 13.\n\nBill Pennington: Tiger\u2019s tee shot on the devilish par-3 12th hole looked fat, with a good chunk of turf exploding beneath and behind the ball. That ill-timed contact likely led to the shot being short \u2014 it robbed his shot of a little momentum.\n\nNo. 12 is another of Tiger\u2019s least favorite holes. He came to the tee there today 8-over par on the hole in his career.\n\nSometimes a converted bogey putt is more important than any holed birdie putt. By avoiding a double bogey at No. 12, Tiger still leaves open the possibility of an even par or 1-over-par finish today. Two reachable par 5s remain on the back 9.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nNo. 11: Let the Crowd Say \u2018Amen\u2019\n\nTrouble for Tiger Woods at Amen Corner. On No. 11, he smacks it into the trees on the right. Curiously, he urges the ball to go \u201cway right,\u201d hoping to get onto the next fairway instead. But no, he\u2019s in the trees. Woods has been playing pretty quickly, but he takes his time over this puzzler, asking that some fans be moved. All he can do is punch it out, and it goes into the crowd again. He still has a way to go to the green.\n\nWoods, now with a direct chance at the green, hits a high lofted chip to within 10 feet. He doesn\u2019t come close on the par saver. The bogey drops him to 2-over. Leishman, who has been nailing his iron shots all day, makes another par and stays ahead of the field.\n\nPhoto\n\nPhil Mickelson Opens with a Birdie\n\nZach Johnson, the 2007 Masters champion, dropped a stroke on No. 11 after missing his second shot right of the green and then missing a Seven-foot putt to save par. That drops him back to even for his round. He\u2019s there with Hideki Matsuyama, considered maybe the best player yet to win a major; he has opened with 12 straight pars.\n\nAnd Phil Mickelson has started off his round on a good note with a birdie on No. 1.\n\nNo. 10: Strong Tee Shot. Still Par.\n\nAnother strong tee shot on the 10th hole by Woods. \u201cNo, no\u201d from Woods on the second shot as his ball heads toward the bunker. But it luckily stays out and lands by the lip. He chips from there to a couple of feet and makes par. He remains at 1-over. Marc Leishman still leads at 3-under.\n\nNo. 9: Another Par for Tiger\n\nOn the par-4 ninth, Woods\u2019s drive lands in the second cut of rough but is decently positioned. He puts his second shot on the green 30 feet away. The first putt doesn\u2019t break as much as he expected; he makes a four-foot par putt. Marc Leishman escapes from the trees to save par, and his 1-stroke lead.\n\nPhoto\n\nNo. 8: Another Great Drive, but Where are the Putts?\n\nThe eighth is a 570-yard par 5. Woods creams his drive down the center. With 265 to the hole, he can\u2019t quite get it on the green though, and his third shot goes well past the stick. His 20-footer for birdie takes a huge break and is close enough for a three-footer for par. Another par for Leishman; he still leads by a stroke at 3-under.\n\nBill Pennington: Another striped drive by Woods, long and bouncing high down the 8th fairway. If Tiger was putting as well as he\u2019s been hitting his driver, he\u2019d be one or two strokes off the lead right now. But the putts haven\u2019t been horrible, just not perfect. In other words, it\u2019s just golf. At the Masters.\n\nNo. 7: Another Close Call for Woods, but Another Par\n\nAt the seventh, Woods has no problem with his 3-wood shot. His approach from 150 yards is on the green but a bit farther than he would have liked, leaving him with a good length putt for birdie. Going downhill again, he just misses it and remains at 1-over. Marc Leishman, playing in Woods\u2019s group, makes a birdie to go to 3-under, still the solo leader, but now by two strokes.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nNo. 6: After Great Tee Shot, Woods Takes Par\n\nThe sixth is another par-3, with the flag 195 yards away in the back corner of the big Augusta green. Tiger Woods\u2019s shot is a beauty, less than 10 feet for the birdie. The putt just inches left though, and another opportunity is missed. Marc Leishman keeps churning out pars and still leads at 2-under.\n\nBill Pennington: Really a shame for Tiger. His tee shot at No. 6 will be one of the day\u2019s best from anyone in the field. His missed birdie putt wasn\u2019t stroked left of the hole as much as it broke left of the hole in the final 16 inches.\n\nNo. 5: Another Bogey for Woods\n\nAt the par-4 fifth, Tiger Woods shouts \u201cdown, down\u201d after launching his drive. That tends to be a bad sign, and sure enough, despite the ample landing area, he\u2019s in a fairway bunker. He\u2019s out safely and just sneaks onto the green, but has a long way to go to the hole. He goes past the hole with the putt and was tested by an 8-foot comebacker. Just missed, and Woods has back-to-back bogeys to move to one over par. No change at the top; Leishman still leads at 2-under.\n\nRelated Reading: Will Sponsors Return to Tiger?\n\nDespite his troubles and controversies, golf fans seem willing \u2014 even eager \u2014 to embrace Tiger Woods\u2019s comeback. Will corporate America feel the same? Read this article from Zach Schonbrun.\n\nNo. 4: Leishman Takes the Lead as Woods Bogeys\n\nThe first par 3 of the day is the tricky fourth. Woods, from 240 yards, puts it in the bunker in front of the green. He extricates himself but has a 15-footer for par. It just misses, and Woods bogeys to drop back to even par. His playing partner Marc Leishman is now the solo leader at 2-under.\n\nBill Pennington: That\u2019s a botched bunker shot for Tiger at No. 4 and it cost him par. But Tiger hates the fourth hole here \u2014 he\u2019s now played it in 16-over par in his career.\n\nPhoto\n\nNo. 3: Woods Drains a 12-Footer for Birdie\n\nOn the 350-yard par-4 third, Tiger Woods goes with a driver and easily clears the fairway bunkers for a good angle to the green. His second shot is merely a pitch, and he lands it for a downhill 12-footer. It\u2019s in! Woods moves to 1-under, joining Justin Thomas and Mark O\u2019Meara a stroke off leaders Vijay Singh and Marc Leishman.\n\nBill Pennington: I would say there is a very good chance that Tiger made that downhill birdie putt on the 3rd because he learned something from the downhill birdie putt miss on No. 2. He read the speed better on No. 3 green, having gauged it from No. 2. That let the ball find the hole.\n\nPhoto\n\nNo. 2: Woods Still Even After Near Miss\n\nOn the par-5 second, both his playing partners find the bunker, but Woods smashes a drive deep into the fairway. His iron shot from a good position 220 yards away finds a greenside trap, and he stomps his foot in frustration. He blasts out and goes past the flag by 10 feet. The downhill birdie putt breaks dramatically and just misses. If Woods is going to win this week, he needs to go low on the par 5s. This was a good birdie opportunity squandered.\n\nPhoto\n\nTiger Woods Saves Par on No. 1; Singh Leads\n\nThe crowd is cleared for Woods\u2019s second shot. He makes it out of the trees and winds up just short of the green. Good shot. His long putt ends up a foot from the hole, and he saves par. Meanwhile, ageless Vijay Singh has three birdies in his first four holes and leads the tournament by three clear strokes.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nTiger\u2019s First Drive? Off the Mark.\n\nHere we go! Tiger Woods is first to tee off and hits it to the left of the fairway behind the ropes and crowd. Not a good start.", "title": "How Jordan Spieth Took Control at the Masters", "authors": ["Zach Schonbrun", "Victor Mather", "Bill Pennington"]} {"date": "2018-04-18 00:00:00", "text": "Mexico City, by contrast, looked to its indigenous past for national icons. A statue of Cuauht\u00e9moc, the last Aztec emperor, stands on a pedestal overseeing the new city that had arisen on the ancient Tenochtitl\u00e1n. Redrawn by the Spanish, it was now a source of republican pride.\n\nWe discover many of these statues in hazy prints of silver and sepia, and indeed this is as much an exhibition of early photography as it is of architecture and urban planning. By 1900, shutterbugs in these Latin American capitals were snapping plush urban parks in Buenos Aires and Mexico City, spaces of leisure for the new bourgeoisie. Both of these cities received radical makeovers at this time, with ostentatious, oversized thoroughfares built on the Parisian model. An unnamed photographer\u2019s family pictures capture Buenos Aires\u2019s lordly Avenida de Mayo, a boulevard built in commemoration of Argentine independence and in palpable imitation of Baron Haussmann\u2019s extended axes.\n\nAnd as for the vintage photographs of Rio, it is hard to look without desperate jealousy. The most beautiful city on the planet appears, by some measure, as the most sophisticated of the capitals examined in this exhibition, though the photographers and mapmakers here had far more interest in Rio\u2019s boulevards and gardens than its favelas, the first of which arose in the 1890s.\n\nIn two exquisite photographic panoramas by the Brazilian photographer Marc Ferrez, dating to around 1895, Sugarloaf Mountain looms gently over Botafogo and Flamengo \u2014 the boulevards and alleys of the capital in seductive harmony with the beach and the hillside. Ferrez also shot Rio\u2019s ritzy cinemas and lush botanical gardens, as well as new infrastructure. A tramway cuts through the underbrush to Corcovado, the verdant peak that would soon be topped by the statue of Christ the Redeemer.\n\nEventually a new generation of Latin American architects and urban designers, less hung up on European models, would transform these capitals once again. There is a hint of what\u2019s to come in a 1927 photograph of Rio\u2019s Pra\u00e7a Marechal Floriano, whose undulating mosaics of white and black would soon be replicated in Roberto Burle Marx\u2019s wavy boardwalk on Copacabana Beach. Burle Marx would go on to landscape a new capital, Bras\u00edlia, that would take national ambition to new extremes. Buenos Aires would invite Le Corbusier, the Swiss apostle of towerblocks and bulldozers, to reimagine the Argentine capital from scratch. Cuba would take a different approach to national reinvention, one that, ironically, has left much of Havana\u2019s earlier architecture deteriorating but in place.\n\nLatin American cities would become spaces of utopian fantasies, frequently followed by political nightmares. But before the new towers arrived \u2014 and before, more recently, Rio\u2019s white-elephant Olympic stadiums and Mexico City\u2019s big-money museums \u2014 they were already cities of dreams.", "title": "How Latin America Was Built, Before Modernism Came Along", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-17 00:00:00", "text": "Liberty has also played a significant role in the rise of Donald Trump. Falwell was an early supporter of the reality-TV-star candidate, staying loyal through the release of the \u201cAccess Hollywood\u201d tape and giving Trump a crucial imprimatur with white evangelical voters, who widely supported him at the polls. \u201cThe evangelicals were so great to me,\u201d Trump said in an interview last year. The first commencement speech he gave as president, last spring, was at Liberty. And in August, Falwell stood by Trump following his much-criticized remarks on the violent rally by white supremacists in Charlottesville, declaring on \u201cFox & Friends\u201d that \u201cPresident Donald Trump does not have a racist bone in his body.\u201d\n\nSuch steadfast allyship has prompted ridicule even from some fellow evangelical Republicans. But it makes more sense in light of an overlooked aspect of Liberty: its extraordinary success as a moneymaking venture. Like Trump, Falwell recognized the money to be made in selling success \u2014 in this case, through the booming and lightly regulated realm of online higher education. Falwell\u2019s university has achieved the scale and stature it has because he identified a market opportunity and exploited it.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe real driver of growth at Liberty, it turns out, is not the students who attend classes in Lynchburg but the far greater number of students who are paying for credentials and classes that are delivered remotely, as many as 95,000 in a given year. By 2015, Liberty had quietly become the second-largest provider of online education in the United States, according to The Chronicle of Higher Education, its student population surpassed only by that of University of Phoenix, as it tapped into the same hunger for self-advancement that Trump had with his own pricey Trump University seminars. Yet there was a crucial distinction: Trump\u2019s university was a for-profit venture. (This month, a judge finalized a $25 million settlement for fraud claims against the defunct operation.) Liberty, in contrast, is classified as a nonprofit, which means it faces less regulatory scrutiny even as it enjoys greater access to various federal handouts.\n\nBy 2017, Liberty students were receiving more than $772 million in total aid from the U.S. Department of Education \u2014 nearly $100 million of it in the form of Pell grants and the rest in federal student loans. Among universities nationwide, it ranked sixth in federal aid. Liberty students also received Department of Veterans Affairs benefits, some $42 million in 2016, the most recent year for which figures are available. Although some of that money went to textbooks and nontuition expenses, a vast majority of Liberty\u2019s total revenue that year, which was just above $1 billion, came from taxpayer-funded sources.\n\nAnd it was no secret which part of the university was generating most of that revenue, said Chris Gaumer, a Liberty graduate and former professor of English there. \u201cWhen I was there, at faculty meetings the commentary was that online was funding the school, while they were trying to just break even on the residential side,\u201d he said. \u201cIt was understood that on the online side, they were making a killing.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nJerry Falwell Sr. was raised in Lynchburg by a Christian mother and a nonbelieving father, whose knack for business gained him a small empire of restaurants, bus lines, nightclubs and gas stations and eventually carried him into bootlegging. Falwell cast this dual inheritance in the terms of a clash between God and the Enemy, but it was hard not to see his career as a successful fusing of his parents\u2019 influences, salesmanship wrapped in Christian cloth.\n\nHe founded Thomas Road Baptist Church in the former offices of a bottling company in 1956 and soon began broadcasting recordings of his sermons on regional radio and television. In 1971, the same year his \u201cOld Time Gospel Hour\u201d went national, he founded Lynchburg Baptist College, subsidizing it with revenues from the show. \u201cI believe there are thousands of young students who will catch the vision and who will carry what God is doing in Lynchburg to cities all over the continent and around the world,\u201d he declared at the time, according to his 1996 autobiography. At first the college was scattered in rented spaces around town \u2014 a vacant high school, a Ramada Inn \u2014 but by 1977 it had been renamed Liberty Baptist College and moved up to an initial 2,000-acre swath of land on the mountain.\n\nBy 1984, nearly 400 local broadcasters around the nation were carrying \u201cThe Old Time Gospel Hour.\u201d The toll-free number flashing on the screen reportedly helped bring in more than $72 million per year in donations. Some $10 million of those funds flowed to the college, which at that point numbered about 4,500 students. Another of Falwell\u2019s enterprises pulled in about $12 million a year \u2014 the Moral Majority, an attempt to build a cross-denominational political coalition against the common foes of abortion rights and, as he later put it, \u201cmoral permissiveness, family breakdown and general capitulation to evil and to foreign policies such as Marxism-Leninism.\u201d\n\nLiberty University, as it has been named since 1985, grew steadily, drawing families attracted by the \u201cLiberty Way,\u201d which forbade premarital sex, drinking, smoking and cussing. In 1987, it secured tax-exempt status, which Falwell described in his autobiography as an existential necessity: \u201cIf a tax exemption could not be granted us,\u201d he wrote, \u201cit would have been impossible to carry out the dream of a 50,000-student Christian university in Lynchburg.\u201d\n\nBut another element of the business model \u2014 evangelical broadcasting\u2019s aura of rectitude \u2014 was about to take a hit. That March, Jim Bakker resigned as head of the televangelist PTL ministry amid revelations of a sexual encounter with a former church secretary, Jessica Hahn, who received a payoff to keep quiet about it; Bakker later served just under five years in prison on a federal fraud conviction related to PTL\u2019s fund-raising. In 1988, the televangelist Jimmy Swaggart declared, \u201cI have sinned,\u201d following reports of his consorting with a prostitute in New Orleans; three years later, the police pulled him over with another prostitute in Southern California.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nNo such scandals attached to Falwell, who succeeded Bakker as host of \u201cThe PTL Club.\u201d But the bubble had burst. Amid what Falwell later referred to as the \u201ccredibility crunch\u201d caused by the televangelist scandals, the college\u2019s finances deteriorated. Within a few years, annual contributions dropped by $25 million; the college\u2019s debt swelled to more than $100 million.\n\nIn 1996, the accrediting body overseeing Liberty presented a list of more than 100 \u201crecommendations\u201d for staying accredited, including a demand that it reduce its debt. Falwell went on a 40-day liquids-only fast, praying for deliverance. \u201cI am certain that we will become a world-class university training champions for Christ in every important field of study,\u201d Falwell vowed in his autobiography. \u201cAnd I am asking God to give me more time to guide and fund that dream.\u201d\n\nOne educational novelty that Falwell dabbled in, starting in the mid-\u201970s, was an early form of distance learning. Liberty would mail lecture videotapes and course packets to paying customers around the country \u2014 at first just certificate courses in Bible studies, and by the mid-\u201980s, accredited courses in other subjects as well. By the time of Liberty\u2019s financial embattlement, other education innovators had taken the idea much further \u2014 none more so than a man named John Sperling.\n\nSperling was an unlikely capitalist entrepreneur. The son of a failed farmer in the Missouri Ozarks, he joined the Merchant Marine, embraced socialism and ended up receiving a Ph.D. in history from the University of Cambridge. He got a job teaching at San Jose State University, where he took over the faculty union and led a big strike in 1968. His humble origins and early socialist leanings had given him a jaundiced view of elite schools, and his experience teaching a course to police officers and teachers as part of a federally funded effort to reduce juvenile delinquency furthered his belief that traditional colleges were leaving out a whole swath of Americans eager for higher education. He decided to start a university of his own \u2014 not a nonprofit but a for-profit, and not in California, where he had clashed with skeptical accreditors, but in the laxer regulatory climate of Arizona.\n\nIn 1976, Sperling rented space in a boilermakers\u2019 union hall in Phoenix and started offering weekly classes there to eight students \u2014 all adults who\u2019d had some college education and were looking to complete their degrees. A decade later, University of Phoenix had 6,000 students. But things really took off three years later, in 1989, when Sperling started offering M.B.A.s online through Prodigy, the early electronic communications service. Sperling took the university\u2019s parent company public in 1994; by 2000, enrollment had reached 100,000.\n\nBy the early 2000s, for-profit colleges were booming: Access to the internet was spreading, and the Bush administration was employing a notably light regulatory touch, even as the programs were devouring an ever-greater share of federal student aid. Among the adopters of Sperling\u2019s model was Falwell, who in 2004 began expanding the family\u2019s primitive distance-learning programs into what would become known as Liberty University Online.\n\nIn his autobiography, Falwell praised Jerry Jr.\u2019s business instincts, crediting him with saving Liberty from ruin through his management of its debt. \u201cGod sent him to me just in time,\u201d he wrote. \u201cHe is more responsible, humanly speaking, for the miraculous financial survival of this ministry than any other single person.\u201d When Falwell died in 2007 at age 73, his younger son, Jonathan, took over the pulpit at Thomas Road Baptist, and Jerry Jr. took over the university \u2014 an indication of where the heart of the ministry now was.\n\nAs the Great Recession hit, laid-off Americans turned to online education to seek a new economic foothold. After years of trying to save Liberty by cutting costs, Falwell Jr. said, he adopted his father\u2019s vision of saving it through increasing revenues. In a recent telephone interview, Falwell described the surge in online enrollment as a kind of revelation. \u201cIt took us about 20 years to perfect\u201d the distance-learning model, he said, \u201cbut when we did, that was about when everyone started getting high-speed internet in their homes, and we were the only nonprofit poised to serve that huge adult market of people who had not finished college or needed a master\u2019s degree to get a promotion.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nLiberty had another advantage over online competitors, he said: its status as a religious-based institution, \u201cthat long history of Liberty being a leader among Christian universities,\u201d the \u201cfaith-based mission\u201d that \u201cmakes us so unique and puts us in a class by ourselves.\u201d\n\nThe River Ridge Mall spreads out on the flat ground below Liberty\u2019s campus, among motels and fast-food restaurants. Like much commercial real estate in Lynchburg, it is majority-owned by Liberty University. In 2013, the mall lost one of its anchor tenants, Sears, which occupied a 112,000-square-foot space behind gray, nearly windowless walls. The retailer was replaced by Liberty University Online. When it first arrived inside the mall, the L.U.O. operation numbered 675 employees; it grew so large that in 2015 L.U.O. began moving its operation into a former Nationwide Insurance building several miles away.\n\nAt the front lines are the \u201cadmissions representatives,\u201d some 300 phone recruiters working two shifts from 8 a.m. to 8 p.m., deploying call lists that Liberty gets from websites where people register and search for information about online higher education, like BestCollegesOnline.com. There is such a race to get to customers before University of Phoenix and other rivals that the prospective students sometimes marvel at how little time has elapsed \u2014 just a handful of minutes \u2014 between their providing their information on a website and the call coming from Liberty. Liberty\u2019s tax filings show that in 2016, the university paid Google $16.8 million for \u201cadmissions leads generation.\u201d In other words, advertising Liberty to those searching online for degree options.\n\nThe recruiters work under intense pressure, according to several former L.U.O. employees I spoke with. They get no more than 45 seconds between calls, and sometimes managers override even that short break. There are no formal quotas \u2014 a federal regulation that went into effect in 2011 forbids them. But as one former employee put it, the \u201chighly motivated goal\u201d is for each recruiter to sign up eight new students a day. Multiplied across 300 cubicles, that is 2,400 per day. Of those, only a small fraction end up paying and starting courses, but that is still an extraordinary haul for any kind of education business.\n\nEvery day, according to the former employee, managers send out a report showing the previous day\u2019s tallies. Recruiters who signed up four or fewer new students get their names in red, visible for all to see, and are sometimes subject to a disciplinary conversation. Monthly tallies are also scored as green, yellow or red. Top performers are in the running for a small raise from the base salary, which is about $30,000. \u201cIt was that carrot and stick,\u201d the former employee told me.\n\nA separate division of about 60 people focuses on courting members of the military, who have access to even greater federal tuition assistance, and then advising them on campus. A former employee in that division said that given the smaller crew, the work there was if anything even more intense than in the main branch: More than 30,000 L.U.O. students are from the military or military families.\n\nPhoto\n\nTwo recruiters told me they were instructed to quote L.U.O.\u2019s cost on a per-credit basis, rather than per-course, which makes it sound more affordable. Undergraduate courses for part-time students are $455 per credit, or $1,365 for a typical course; master\u2019s courses are typically about $600 per credit. They are instructed not to press prospective applicants too hard on their academic qualifications. Applicants have to submit past transcripts, but any grade point average above 0.5 \u2014 equivalent to a D-minus \u2014 would suffice, said the former employee in the nonmilitary division. Recruiters, he told me, \u201cwould say, \u2018Congratulations, you\u2019ve been accepted.\u2019 They\u2019d make it seem competitive.\u201d\n\nThe two recruiters also said they were told not to mention Liberty\u2019s Christian orientation until people agree to apply, when this fact is made clear in the user agreement they sign online. It also becomes clear at the moment that the recruiters sign up students for their first classes, typically an orientation class and three required Bible-studies classes. Students often can\u2019t transfer credits for these courses to other colleges, which deters many from dropping out: Leaving L.U.O. without signing up for more courses would mean wasting the money spent on the first four.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nFalwell and other top Liberty officials pushed back on some of these points in my interview with them, insisting, for instance, that the minimum G.P.A. for applicants is 2.0 and that recruiters are assessed according to \u201cthe same H.R. evaluation form that\u2019s standard across the university.\u201d But Ron Kennedy, the executive vice president for online enrollment management, acknowledged that the recruiters working under pressure to meet their targets might say otherwise. \u201cIt\u2019s a call center,\u201d he said.\n\nIn 2010, undercover investigators from the Government Accountability Office scrutinized 15 for-profit colleges, finding that every one of them had misled applicants and that four had encouraged them to lie on their federal student-aid forms. The Obama administration seized on the findings as it began a yearslong clampdown on for-profit education, which by 2013 was gobbling up a fifth of all federal student aid, more than $25 billion, despite enrolling only 10 percent of students \u2014 and also producing about a third of all federal student-loan defaults.\n\nLiberty, too, was hugely reliant on federal money, in the form of Pell grants, Department of Veterans Affairs benefits and federally subsidized loans. By 2010, it had more than 50,000 students enrolled and was pulling in more than $420 million annually. But because Liberty was technically not for-profit, it was spared many of the administration\u2019s new regulations, including its requirement that a certain threshold of graduates be able to attain \u201cgainful employment,\u201d which was designed to hit for-profit colleges much harder. It was also spared from the pre-existing rule that for-profit colleges could get no more than 90 percent of their revenue from federal sources.\n\nIf anything, Liberty benefited from the crackdown. The Obama administration\u2019s actions helped put out of business large for-profit chains like Corinthian and ITT Technical Institute, clearing formidable competition from the field. Though there were other nonprofit institutions with online offerings \u2014 Arizona State, Southern New Hampshire and Western Governors, as well as premium players like Stanford and Duke \u2014 none were operating at Liberty\u2019s scale. The university now touts itself on its website as \u201cthe largest private nonprofit university in the nation.\u201d In a sense, said Ben Miller, who served as a senior policy adviser in Obama\u2019s Department of Education, the crackdown on for-profits offered Liberty a \u201cmarketing advantage.\u201d\n\nFalwell was candid about the benefits of the nonprofit status. \u201cIt insulated us from the attack on the for-profits,\u201d he told me. And it put him on the same footing with other, more established universities. \u201cThere\u2019s no way that an Obama federal government that probably doesn\u2019t care much for schools like Liberty can treat us different than Harvard or Yale or Indiana Wesleyan or the University of Maryland.\u201d\n\nLiberty\u2019s ability to distance itself from for-profit colleges was especially notable given that, by several key metrics, it resembled them more closely than the private nonprofits it was grouped with. The rate of Liberty graduates who default on their loans within three years of graduating is 9.9 percent, several points higher than the average for nonprofit colleges, though still below that for for-profit colleges. Most striking, though, is how little the university spends on actual instruction. It does not report separate figures for spending on the online school and the traditional college. But according to its most recent figures, from 2016, the university reports spending only $2,609 on instruction per full-time equivalent student across both categories. That is a fraction of what traditional private universities spend (Notre Dame\u2019s equivalent figure is $27,391) but also well behind even University of Phoenix, which spends more than $4,000 per student in many states. It is also behind other hybrid online-traditional nonprofit religious colleges like Ohio Christian University, which spends about $4,500. In 2013, according to an audited financial statement I obtained, Liberty received $749 million in tuition and fees but spent only $260 million on instruction, academic support and student services.\n\nBy 2016, Liberty\u2019s net assets had crossed the $1.6 billion mark, up more than tenfold from a decade earlier. Thanks to its low spending on instruction, its net income was an astonishing $215 million on nearly $1 billion in revenue, according to its tax filing \u2014 making it one of the most lucrative nonprofits in the country, based simply on the difference between its operating revenue and expenses, in a league with some of the largest nonprofit hospital systems.\n\nFalwell, whose Liberty salary is nearly $1 million, does not apologize for those margins. Liberty, he said, is simply being shrewd about keeping costs down, while plowing revenue back into the university. He noted proudly that Liberty\u2019s net assets are now $2.5 billion, up from just $150 million in 2007, when he took over. He said he was surprised more universities weren\u2019t following Liberty\u2019s example of increasing online enrollment by keeping instructional spending and tuition low. And he freely acknowledged that the online revenues were going to buttress the residential campus. From Falwell\u2019s perspective, there was nothing wrong with the university\u2019s benefiting so much from the online program. \u201cAs long as we\u2019re keeping the quality up, we don\u2019t think it\u2019s a disservice to anyone,\u201d he said. \u201cAll that is, is ensuring the future of the university.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nStudents at Liberty often quote a favorite line of Falwell Sr.\u2019s: \u201cIf it\u2019s Christian, it ought to be better.\u201d Even those who have misgivings about the university\u2019s conservative culture are quick to defend the education they\u2019ve received on campus. Yet despite its ambitions to become the \u201cevangelical Notre Dame\u201d that Falwell envisioned, Liberty is still ranked well behind that university and other religious-based institutions like Brigham Young and Pepperdine; U.S. News and World Report clumps Liberty in the lowest quartile of institutions in its \u201cnational universities\u201d category. Some of its programs have strong reputations, among them nursing, engineering and flight school. But the college is limited in its ability to compete for premier faculty, not only because its politics are out of step with the greater academic community, but also because none of its programs, with the exception of its law school, offer tenure.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nIn his autobiography, Falwell made virtually no distinction between these students on the Lynchburg campus and those receiving their instruction remotely. All of them, in his telling, were being prepared for the same goal, to be \u201cChampions for Christ,\u201d as the Liberty motto had it. But many students on campus, at least, are openly dismissive of the online experience. They take some classes online, for the convenience of not having to drag themselves to class \u2014 and, they readily admit, for the ease of not having to study much. \u201cPeople know it\u2019s kind of a joke and don\u2019t learn that much from it,\u201d Dustin Wahl, a senior from South Dakota, told me. \u201cYou use Google when you take your quiz and don\u2019t have to work as hard. It\u2019s pretty obvious.\u201d (Liberty says using Google during quizzes or exams is cheating.)\n\nCampus students are especially scornful of the online discussion boards that are in theory meant to replicate the back and forth of a classroom, but that in reality tend to be a rote exercise, with students making only their requisite one post and two comments per week, generating no substantive discussion. \u201cIt\u2019s very minimal engagement,\u201d said Alexander Forbes, a senior from California. Recently, a satirical campus newspaper, The Flaming Bugle, ran an Onion-style article with the headline \u201cCat Playing on Keyboard Inadvertently Earns \u2018A\u2019 for Discussion Board Post.\u201d\n\nChris Gaumer taught English courses both on campus and online at Liberty after getting his bachelor\u2019s degree on campus in 2006. The difference between the two forms of teaching was startling, he told me. As an online instructor, he said, he was not expected to engage in the delivery of any actual educational content. That was all prepared separately by L.U.O.\u2019s team of course designers and editors, who assemble curriculums and videotaped lectures by other Liberty professors. This leaves little for the instructor to do in the courses, which typically run eight weeks. \u201cAs professor, you show up and your job is to handle emails and grade,\u201d Gaumer said. This helps explain why the instructors \u2014 the roughly 2,400 adjuncts scattered around the country, plus the Liberty professors who agree to teach online courses on the side \u2014 are willing to take on the task for what\u2019s long been the going rate for the job: $2,100 per course. (Falwell Jr. said it will soon go up to $2,700.)\n\nUntil recently, the course designers and editors, a team of about 30 people, worked out of the old Thomas Road Baptist Church \u2014 the congregation moved out of the former bottling plant years earlier \u2014 in a concrete room that got so cold in winter that they sometimes kept scarves and hats on. For editors, starting pay is now around $11 per hour. As L.U.O. boomed in size, they became so overwhelmed by the challenge of shaping hundreds of courses that L.U.O. decided in 2015 to focus designers and editors on the hundred or so highest-enrollment courses per term, leaving the maintenance of the remaining hundreds of courses up to the instructors themselves.
