One former editor recalled having a professor send a syllabus along with, essentially, an apology for throwing something together at the last minute.\n\nGaumer, who now works at Randolph College in Lynchburg, said the steep drop-off in quality from the traditional college to the online courses was both openly acknowledged among Liberty faculty and not fully reckoned with. The reason was plain, he said: Everyone knew that L.U.O. was subsidizing the physical university. \u201cThe motivation behind the growth seems to be almost entirely economic, because it\u2019s not as if the education is getting any better,\u201d he said.\n\nPhoto\n\nFalwell acknowledged that Liberty\u2019s faculty initially resisted the rise of the online program, fearing the degradation of academic standards. \u201cThe big victory was finding a way to tame the faculty,\u201d he said. But he disputed that there was any great difference in quality. For one thing, he said, the university made sure that all of its online instructors \u201cadhere to the fundamentals of the Christian faith, our doctrinal statement.\u201d Physical distance was a challenge, he said, but online instructors overcame it by making an extra effort to reach out. \u201cThey spend a lot more time taking a personal interest in the students,\u201d he said.\n\nOne of the 65,000 students who enrolled with L.U.O. in 2013 was Megan Hart, a woman from New Jersey with unflaggingly high spirits. Hart, who is in her 40s, started her working life at the glass company where her father worked, too, until he was laid off. From there, Hart made her way into education, teaching communications at the local community college and the local prison. Adjunct courses at the college paid just $525 per credit, netting her only about $5,000 per semester, so she got a low-level administrative job there, too.\n\nHer first marriage, to the father of her daughter, ended in divorce. In January 2012, her second husband suddenly vanished. Hart and her daughter, then 9 years old, lost their home shortly afterward, and she filed for bankruptcy. She and her daughter moved into her parents\u2019 basement and got by with donations from her local Assemblies of God church, where she was active. In 2013, she signed up to take three courses at L.U.O. that would provide her with a certificate in communications, allowing her to become a full-time instructor at the community college, which would reimburse her L.U.O. tuition.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHart, who had a master\u2019s in communications and leadership through Pat Robertson\u2019s Regent University, chose L.U.O. because of its affordability and Christian cachet. But in her years of teaching and taking courses, she said, she had never seen anything as flimsy as what L.U.O. passed off in its supposedly graduate-level courses. She had little interaction with the instructor, and the questions for the midterm and final exams were so arbitrary that it seemed to Hart as if they had been randomly generated by a computer program. She spent the open-book exams wildly flipping back and forth through the textbook and course materials trying to find the relevant passages. It was, she wrote to L.U.O. officials later, like \u201clooking for Waldo.\u201d\n\nWhen she wrote the instructor for the second class to ask about the test, he responded: \u201cAs to exam question, I have no clue how the final is run.\u201d He said he\u2019d get back to her. He ended his note, \u201cDo remember that God is in control and he works all things for our good.\u201d\n\nWhen Hart emailed the instructor for her third course, which had a closed-book exam, she confirmed Hart\u2019s suspicions: \u201cThe exam questions are random.\u201d Hart got good grades in the first two courses but was increasingly convinced she was paying for a meaningless experience. She sent an email outlining her concerns to the instructor and an L.U.O. academic mentor, adding that she might quit the third course. \u201cWe will certainly take your input very seriously,\u201d the mentor responded. \u201cMay the Lord bless you richly in your studies and future endeavors.\u201d\n\nFinally, Hart told the officials that she was withdrawing from the third course, even though she had been informed that she would still have to pay 25 percent of the cost. \u201cMy spirit has been so sick over what I have experienced,\u201d she wrote. In late 2013, she filed a complaint with a little-known government agency called the State Council of Higher Education for Virginia, which oversees the state\u2019s colleges.\n\nBetween 2009 and summer 2017, L.U.O. students filed 49 complaints with the council, more than for any other institution in the state. For some, the problem was administrative bungling \u2014 L.U.O. registered them for the wrong class, or required a class it turned out they didn\u2019t need, and so on. For some, it was endless technical or logistical troubles that kept them from being able to submit their assignments or get textbooks. For others, it was disputes about tuition and financial aid that left them feeling as if L.U.O. was demanding more money than was fair, and withholding their transcripts until they paid up.\n\nSeveral complainants said they were particularly taken aback by their L.U.O. experiences because of Liberty\u2019s religious underpinnings. \u201cI just expected that Liberty University being a Christian university,\u201d they\u2019d be more helpful, wrote a complainant who went to prison and then became homeless after a stint enrolled in L.U.O. He had been seeking to have his transcript released despite his still having a balance at L.U.O., so that he could resume his education elsewhere; Liberty responded by recommending homeless shelters. \u201cLiberty\u2019s motto is they are a Christian school that is training champions for Christ and they are the light of the world,\u201d another student wrote six years ago. \u201cThat motto needs to be revised.\u201d\n\nThe anodyne responses the students received from L.U.O. were frequently glossed with Christian bromides. To a student whose financial aid was suspended in 2015 after the student failed a course because the textbook didn\u2019t arrive in time, an instructor sent \u201cquiz tips that may help\u201d that included \u201cEat a healthy meal before taking your quiz\u201d and \u201cPray before beginning each quiz!\u201d Other L.U.O. responses included language errors so extreme that they bordered on confusing: One administrator wrote in 2014 about a complainant\u2019s having submitted work that \u201cappeared to have been copied from an unsighted source,\u201d while a professor responded to a student in 2012 that \u201cno other acceptions will be made.\u201d\n\nOther students were left simply to flounder, contrary to Falwell\u2019s claims of close attention from distant instructors. Lydia Terry-Dominelli, who lives in a suburb of Albany, N.Y., signed up with Liberty in 2013, when it looked as if she and her husband were headed for divorce and she was worrying about how she could support herself and her 9-year-old daughter. She decided to get her teacher\u2019s certification and chose Liberty partly because she was an observant Anglican. \u201cI was ready for something that had some kind of value system,\u201d she told me.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn 2015, Terry-Dominelli failed a graduate-level education course when, she said, one of the assignments she submitted vanished from Blackboard, the online system used by Liberty. After twice failing a writing course and puzzling over what she was doing wrong, she asked the course instructor for an explanation. He wrote back to suggest that she might do better if she found a \u201cnew work space\u201d like the local library. After she assured him that her apartment sufficed and the conversation continued, he wrote: \u201cI wonder if you can\u2019t find a great prayer group through L.U.O.?\u201d\n\nTerry-Dominelli struggled further with confusing assignments in another graduate-level education course. She was starting to feel helpless over the lack of guidance. \u201cI have prayed very hard, and what I keep being told is I am in the wrong place,\u201d she wrote to the education instructor in late October of 2015.\n\n\u201cBless your heart. I am so sorry,\u201d the instructor responded. \u201cI will join you in prayer for you to have wisdom and discernment.\u201d\n\nIn early 2016, Terry-Dominelli was unable to access online the spring-semester courses she had registered for. She took it as a final sign and left Liberty, just a few courses short of the master\u2019s degree she had borrowed more than $20,000 to pay for. In August 2016, having failed to establish a decent income, she moved back in with her husband. Lacking certification, she took a part-time job as an aide at a local elementary school. Unable to afford the loans she\u2019d taken out, she filed for help under the U.S. Department of Education\u2019s Borrower Defense program, which is intended for students who have incurred student debt after being misled by higher-education programs. (Her application is still pending.)\n\nShe also filed a complaint with the Virginia agency: \u201cI feel that I was being pushed out of the program and I need to know why,\u201d she had written to one of her professors. The agency declined to take action, finding no clear violations by Liberty. \u201cWhat\u2019s killing me is that I went into this program to try to change my situation,\u201d she told me, \u201cand I\u2019m worse off than I was at the beginning.\u201d\n\nThe Trump-Falwell bond has if anything grown even stronger in recent months. In October, Falwell Jr. told Breitbart News that Trump could \u201cbe the greatest president since Abraham Lincoln\u201d and urged an evangelical army to rise up against the \u201cfake Republicans\u201d standing in his way. In December, he joined Trump in promoting Roy Moore\u2019s Senate candidacy, quoting the song \u201cSweet Home Alabama\u201d in a tweet on the eve of Election Day: \u201cAL voters are too smart to let the media & Estab Repubs & Dems tell them how to vote. I hope the spirit of Lynyrd Skynyrd is alive/well in AL. \u2018A southern man don\u2019t need them around anyhow & Watergate does not bother me, does your conscience bother you, tell me true?\u2019 \u201d In late February, he joined in on Trump\u2019s mau-mauing of Jeff Sessions, calling the attorney general a \u201ccoward\u201d in a tweet for his handling of the Russia investigation.\n\nBut on campus, Falwell has proved a more divisive leader than his father. In May 2016, conflict over his pro-Trump stance prompted the resignation of the chairman of the university board of trustees\u2019 executive committee, Mark DeMoss, whose father was a major donor to the university. DeMoss previously told The Washington Post that \u201cthe bullying tactics of personal insult have no defense \u2014 and certainly not for anyone who claims to be a follower of Christ.\u201d It also prompted students on campus, including Wahl and Forbes, to gather hundreds of signatures in opposition to Trump following the release of the \u201cAccess Hollywood\u201d tape. After Falwell\u2019s support for Trump following Charlottesville, several Liberty graduates mailed back their degrees in protest. One protester was Laura Honnol, a banking officer in Lubbock, Tex., who attended from 2003 to 2007. \u201cThere\u2019s been a huge climate shift from Falwell Senior to Falwell Junior,\u201d she told me. \u201cYou felt like you disagreed with Senior, but he had good intentions and just didn\u2019t do it right sometimes. But Junior came along, and it\u2019s become more of a profit machine and a numbers machine.\u201d\n\nThe Trump connection is not without risk for Falwell. Some people who worked for L.U.O. in late 2016 and early 2017 blamed it for a dip in applications at the time and said the decline led to an April 2017 leadership overhaul and the departure of many employees. Falwell told me that Liberty has deliberately brought online enrollment down to around 85,000, explaining that \u201cwe wanted to make sure we kept the student quality at a certain standard.\u201d And he said that his alliance with Trump has only helped the university: \u201cFor every student we lost because of political concerns, we picked up two or three inquiries who support us because of that political stand.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nA relationship with Trump could benefit Falwell Jr. and Liberty in other ways too. One of the top orders of business for Trump\u2019s education secretary, Betsy DeVos, has been to roll back Obama-era regulations on online-degree providers. She named a former official from for-profit DeVry University to lead the D.O.E. unit that polices fraud in higher education. Claims for student-debt relief under the Borrower Defense program are being considered at a far slower rate under DeVos, who is delaying by two years an Obama rule that would make it easier to file debt-relief claims. And DeVos is expected shortly to roll back several key regulations geared toward online providers: ones giving states regulatory powers over distance-learning programs, establishing clear standards for a credit-hour and requiring \u201cregular and substantive\u201d interactions between online instructors and students. Falwell told me that Liberty officials have had a major hand in some of DeVos\u2019s actions: \u201cA lot of what we sent them is actually what got implemented,\u201d he said.\n\nPhoto\n\nAfter the convocation on the first weekend in November, I met with Dustin Wahl in Liberty\u2019s student center, overlooking the campus quad. He said that the unbridled success of the online program couldn\u2019t help putting him in mind of the profit-seeking tradition within American Christianity, which is closely aligned with evangelical Christianity\u2019s prosperity gospel \u2014 the notion that financial success, far from distracting us from the higher values, is an affirmation of godliness. Wahl told me he\u2019d frequently heard people justify the school\u2019s new wealth in these terms. \u201cA lot of people just talk about it generally, how God has blessed us,\u201d he said.\n\nFalwell rejects such prosperity-gospel talk. \u201cI\u2019m not going to tell you that we\u2019ve done better because we\u2019re better people,\u201d he told me. \u201cWhat I will say is that we\u2019ve always operated from a business perspective. We\u2019ve treated it like a business.\u201d And that\u2019s what first drew him to Trump, he said: the kinship of one businessman to another. \u201cI thought to myself, if there\u2019s one thing this country needs, it\u2019s exactly the methods we employed at Liberty to save the school and make it prosper, and that\u2019s just basic business principles.\u201d\n\nAs I sat with Wahl, the spoils of that prosperity were visible all around us: not just gleaming new buildings like the $50 million library with its robotic book-retrieval system, but also, up the mountain, a $7 million \u201cSnowflex Centre,\u201d with a polymer surface for year-round skiing \u2014 the only one of its kind at any university in the country. Elsewhere, the university is completing a $3 million shooting range. But, Wahl said, once you knew about the thousands of people far from Lynchburg who funded this splendor, it was hard to take your mind off them, and off the faith with which they signed up for L.U.O. \u201cYou get a phone call,\u201d he said, \u201cand it\u2019s God telling you, \u2018I\u2019ll give you an education.\u2019 \u201d\n\nWhen we spoke before my visit, Wahl raved about the campus: \u201cIt\u2019s beautiful,\u201d he said. Then he added: \u201cAnd it\u2019s funded by the online program that\u2019s sold to people who can\u2019t really afford college.\u201d", "title": "How Liberty University Built a Billion-Dollar Empire Online", "authors": ["Alec Macgillis Propublica"]} {"date": "2018-04-05 00:00:00", "text": "On the plane, Willoughby took the opportunity to ask Murkowski what everyone wanted to know: \u201cHave you decided which way you are going to vote on the health care bill?\u201d Murkowski told Willoughby that the last bill she saw was \u201cunpassable,\u201d adding, \u201cWe have to get this right.\u201d\n\nWilloughby left the flight feeling hopeful that Murkowski would not vote to repeal the Affordable Care Act. Three weeks later, Murkowski did, in fact, cast one of the three decisive votes that killed the bill. One of Willoughby\u2019s fellow ReSisters, Julie Nielsen, a fisheries biologist with a side passion for health care reform, was so happy that she put a bright pink sign in the window of her office overlooking one of the main shopping streets in Juneau. \u201cThank you Lisa!!\u201d read the sign. In the middle of the \u201cO\u201d in \u201cyou,\u201d she had drawn a big heart.\n\nAt a celebration rally in Anchorage a few days later, 200 people, many wearing pussy-hat pink, showed their appreciation. Over and over, the organizer screamed, \u201cThank you!\u201d and the ralliers screamed back, \u201cLisa!\u201d Barely known outside her own state before the Trump era, Murkowski, to moderates and liberals across the country, became an improbable hero, a symbol of resistance and integrity; hundreds of grateful phone calls poured in, as well as calls from the press and from governors wanting to collaborate with her on rethinking health care policy. Murkowski, a Slate headline read, had \u201cstood up for womankind over the threats of men\u201d; Bustle, a website for women, instructed readers on how to write letters to Murkowski that would make sure she knew they cared.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe love-in lasted barely four months. Then came the tax bill. Liberals railed against its breaks for the rich; environmentalists bemoaned a provision allowing for drilling in Alaska. Murkowski stayed silent but ultimately announced a few days before the bill came to the floor that she would support it. The responses to her anodyne Twitter feed, which generally features photos of ribbon-cutting-type ceremonies or Alaska\u2019s many waterways, turned almost entirely venomous (\u201cSell Out!!! Shame on you!!\u201d read a typical one). Murkowski\u2019s vote should hardly have come as a surprise; there is no more core value to Republicans than cutting taxes and no dream more dear to most Alaskans than ever more oil drilling.\n\nNonetheless, it was a blow to those who had recently come to hold her in such high regard. \u201cIt was a tough loss from our end, because we really did think we could get her,\u201d says Angel Padilla, the national policy director for the Indivisible Project, a liberal activist group that had helped coordinate protests against the bill in Murkowski\u2019s offices. Nielsen, the biologist, said this spring that she was disillusioned with Murkowski. The pink sign? \u201cI felt like ripping it up,\u201d she told me.\n\nWhen I met with Murkowski at her Washington office in February, she could evaluate those episodes with some distance. We talked in a small, windowless meeting room inside the Hart Senate Office Building. Murkowski, like the room itself, was notably unadorned (although Murkowski, unlike the room, is photogenic); in Alaska, accessibility trumps formality. \u201cEveryone in Alaska just calls her Lisa,\u201d Jonathan Kreiss-Tomkins, a state legislator, told me. \u201cShe\u2019s a mononym, like Charo.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nLiberals\u2019 disappointment with Murkowski had not escaped her. \u201cYou know,\u201d Murkowski said, \u201cone minute you\u2019re the darling of the world. We\u2019ve come together, and we\u2019ve stood up against the administration. And then when you vote for something the administration supports, everyone says, \u2018What happened?\u2019 It\u2019s like, \u2018Well, what did you expect me to do?\u2019 \u201d Murkowski looked almost baffled. \u201cI\u2019m still a Republican.\u201d\n\nOn Aug. 16, about three weeks after the health care vote, Murkowski, along with a few staff members, sat in a rental car outside a hotel in Bethel, a town in western Alaska. They were waiting for someone named Ephraim, a staff member specializing in fisheries, so they could all head to dinner. \u201cEphraim,\u201d Murkowski said. \u201cHe\u2019s a great guy. From Juneau. He\u2019s my fish guy. Great guy.\u201d She peered out the window. \u201cBut very late.\u201d\n\nWhile we waited, Murkowski talked about her family: The five brothers and sisters, the husband, Verne, who encouraged her to start her career in state politics while he looked after their two sons (now 25 and 26). The arrangement worked well, but lately even her marriage was feeling the strains of her political life. \u201cIt\u2019s gotten harder,\u201d she said, staring straight ahead through the windshield, \u201cwith the strangeness of politics right now. Because he\u2019s got his opinions, too. And I just sometimes \u2014 well, not sometimes, most times \u2014 when I come home, I am just, I don\u2019t really want to talk about politics. I want to talk about the flooring that you laid in the living room today.\u201d\n\nIt had been a grueling eight months for Murkowski, peaking with the Affordable Care Act repeal vote. She was clearly as appalled as anyone by the combative culture of the Trump White House, the peculiar barrage of gratuitously insulting tweets. In June, Trump tweeted that he had seen Mika Brzezinski at Mar-a-Lago and that she was \u201cbleeding from a face-lift.\u201d \u201cStop it!\u201d Murkowski tweeted back. \u201cThe Presidential platform should be used for more than bringing people down.\u201d\n\n\u201cI had my mom voice on that day,\u201d Murkowski would tell me later. \u201cKarina knows.\u201d She looked at Karina Petersen, her communications director. \u201cI wanted it all in caps with three exclamation points.\u201d Petersen laughed. \u201cWe talked her down to one exclamation point,\u201d Petersen said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMurkowski is one of only a handful of Republican senators who have shown some degree of independence from Trump. The Republican dissenters fall into a few categories. There are the critics, the most vociferous of whom are Jeff Flake and Bob Corker, both senators who are not running for re-election. There are the strayers, among them Murkowski and Collins, who have criticized Trump and also voted against him on major legislation. Rand Paul, the staunch libertarian, votes with Trump less often than any other Republican senator, but he has also gone out of his way to defend him. Lindsey Graham votes with the president slightly more often than Murkowski and Collins, but he joins them in yet another category: the pragmatists. Those senators have staked out the now-controversial position that they would rather get something done than nothing, even if it means compromising with Democrats. Murkowski, who has exercised her independence in all three ways, has nonetheless managed to bring back to her state its most long-desired spoils \u2014 more opportunities for drilling and more opportunities for building in previously protected wilderness.\n\nMurkowski landed in the Senate essentially by fiat: In 2002, her father, Frank Murkowski, then a senator, was elected governor of Alaska and had to choose a successor. He publicly considered an up-and-coming mayor from Wasilla, Sarah Palin, then rejected her. Instead, he appointed his daughter Lisa, who had been a state legislator for all of four years. The blatant act of nepotism dogged Frank Murkowski, who went on in 2006 to face Palin in a primary challenge for governor, which she easily won.\n\nThat history still seemed fresh in 2010, when Palin backed another Republican, Joe Miller, a friend of Palin\u2019s husband and a Tea Party favorite, in his challenge to Lisa Murkowski in the Republican Senate primary. \u201cI think she\u2019s out for her own self-interest,\u201d Murkowski said of Palin on the evening of the election. To the surprise of many Alaskans, Miller won. \u201cDo you believe in miracles?\u201d Palin tweeted to her followers.\n\nFrom the moment the result was announced, friends and supporters began texting Murkowski to urge her to run in the general election as a write-in candidate. \u201cLeadership told her not to do it, that she was going to jeopardize the seat and have a Democrat win,\u201d says Andrew Halcro, a former Republican state legislator and a friend who served with Murkowski. \u201cI think at that point, Lisa recognized, \u2018I don\u2019t have any friends.\u2019 \u201d Murkowski decided to mount the write-in campaign.\n\nShe ran as a Republican, but in both Alaska and Washington, the party seemed comfortable moving on without her. The National Republican Senatorial Committee spent more than $1 million funding Miller, with the Tea Party Express adding $600,000. Not long after she started the campaign, Murkowski learned, while she was in Alaska, that Senate Republicans were considering voting the next day to remove her from her position as the ranking member on the Energy and Natural Resources Committee. \u201cI have basically been written off by the senatorial committee,\u201d she said, recalling her state of mind in a memoir by Arlen Specter, the moderate former senator from Pennsylvania, \u201cand I\u2019m not going back begging and pleading. My relationships will either stand on their own or not.\u201d In the end, she held on to her post.\n\nMurkowski, whom Palin had tried to cast as part of the entrenched establishment, suddenly became the underdog, a shift that galvanized her campaign. Her team passed out plastic bracelets that said, \u201cfill it in, write it in,\u201d with the correct spelling of her name. Murkowski defeated Miller, with the help of traditional Democratic constituencies like women and Alaska Natives. \u201cIt was an unusual coalition for a Republican,\u201d said Mark Begich, at the time Alaska\u2019s other senator and a Democrat.\n\nMurkowski quickly established that she had returned to the Senate, as she told a reporter from The Hill, with a \u201cstiffer, straighter\u201d spine. A month after her election, she voted with Democrats to repeal the Pentagon\u2019s \u201cdon\u2019t ask, don\u2019t tell\u201d policy. She publicly criticized remarks that Mitch McConnell, the new Republican Senate majority leader, made about the party\u2019s priorities. The Hill headline called Murkowski \u201cA Thorn in McConnell\u2019s Side.\u201d \u201cI\u2019m sure she would have liked that,\u201d Begich said. \u201cIt was no secret. She was not a happy camper.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nSome of Murkowski\u2019s best friends \u2014 and donors \u2014 are Republicans. But among her closest confidantes are a crew of female extended family members whose politics range from liberal to staunchly conservative, professional women with whom she regularly texts, drinks sauvignon blanc and exchanges family gossip. In the weeks before the vote on the Affordable Care Act repeal, she was on the receiving end of several group texts from those women, many of whom seemed to be encouraging her to vote against the bill.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn mid-July, Murkowski sent the group a text with a photo showing her bare, pedicured feet and a thick pile of paper on her lap. \u201cSunday morning with the health care bill,\u201d she wrote. A cousin wrote back: \u201cPeople I run into are telling me that they are worried about you and the pressure you must feel. Like I tell Jack\u201d \u2014 the cousin\u2019s son \u2014 \u201cgo be a leader today. I\u2019ve got your back.\u201d Another added: \u201cWe are tough, and you will be the voice of reason on this. I can feel it.\u201d\n\nMurkowski went to college on the East Coast at Georgetown and then went to Willamette University College of Law. She has long supported abortion rights and has a strong network of frankly feminist friends, many of whom shared her outrage during the presidential election when the \u201cAccess Hollywood\u201d tape became public. The day after it aired, she told Alaskan reporters that the tape, in which Trump bragged about grabbing women\u2019s vaginas, showed Trump\u2019s \u201ctrue character.\u201d She did not sleep the night the news broke, she said, because she was worrying about what it all meant for the country\u2019s leadership. \u201cI cannot and will not support Donald Trump for President,\u201d she tweeted.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThen he was elected. \u201cThis is good for Alaska,\u201d she assured her constituents in an interview. Trump had made it clear during his campaign that he supported drilling for fossil fuel, and Alaska\u2019s economy is built, to a crippling degree, on oil revenues. Decreasing production and dropping oil prices have created a fiscal crisis in the state, which has only amplified the desire among many Alaskans to drill in long-protected regions, specifically on the coastal plain of the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge, or ANWR, which serves as a home to polar bears, caribou and hundreds of bird species. A Republican president could finally make that possible. But Murkowski also knew that the administration was set on repealing the Affordable Care Act, and many of her constituents had come to depend on it, especially its expansion of Medicaid.\n\nMurkowski made it clear where she stood on certain issues that would come up in the repeal bill. She announced to the State Legislature that she was concerned about possible rollbacks of the Medicaid expansion and said in no uncertain terms that she would not support a repeal bill that defunded Planned Parenthood, which Alaskans also depend on for community health care. And yet, in subsequent months, the bill \u2014 written by 13 male Republicans \u2014 kept turning up, in revision after revision, with significant cuts to the nonprofit organization\u2019s funding.\n\nBy early summer, the young staff members answering the phone in Murkowski\u2019s office were subject to scores of aggressive calls from citizens on both sides of the debate. Within the office, there was tension among high-ranking staff members about what she should do. Throngs of health care reporters chased Murkowski down Senate halls, a stress she did not always handle well. \u201cHey,\u201d Murkowski snapped at CNN\u2019s Manu Raju when he followed her down a Senate hallway to try to get a comment on what she thought of the House health care repeal bill. \u201cWould you please be respectful?\u201d she asked, her own tone harsh.\n\nFinally, in late July, she voted against a procedural motion that would have allowed the repeal bill to come to the Senate floor. Dan Sullivan, Alaska\u2019s other senator and a fellow Republican, told the press that Interior Secretary Ryan Zinke had called with a threatening message. Sullivan was concerned, he said, that some of the administration\u2019s pro-energy policies \u201care going to stop.\u201d It was a brazen threat to a member of another branch of government, as if Trump had shown up on the Senate floor to shake a fist in Murkowski\u2019s face.\n\nIn those tense days leading up to the votes, Patty Murray, a Democratic senator from Washington State, occasionally called Murkowski and Collins, who she knew were under considerable pressure, to offer support \u2014 and see if anything had changed. On the issue of Planned Parenthood, Murray told me, \u201cthis is something they have run on, fought for, worked with all of us on for many years.\u201d\n\nTo the extent that there is any remaining spirit of bipartisanship in the Senate, Murray believes it is fostered at monthly dinners that the female senators try to have together. They are sometimes held in the Capitol\u2019s Strom Thurmond Room (\u201cironically,\u201d says Heidi Heitkamp, a North Dakota Democrat; Murray has said that Thurmond once tried to fondle her in an elevator). \u201cWe play some music; we drink a little wine,\u201d says Kirsten Gillibrand, a Democratic senator from New York. Once, the group went bowling, complete with shirts embroidered with nicknames. Murray believes that the conversation was different among female senators than among male ones. \u201cMen, when you hear Chuck Schumer\u201d \u2014 the Democratic minority leader in the Senate \u2014 \u201cand I don\u2019t want to frame it just about Chuck, they share information so they can get information to get things,\u201d Murray says. \u201cWe listen to each other to see why we believe. You can go to a gym and find out if the Republicans are having a vote at 4 and feel you\u2019ve got some power. We actually want to understand each other.\u201d\n\nThe day of the final vote, Collins joined Murkowski, who was talking to McCain on the Senate floor, to provide moral support and find out if he was with them or not. \u201cYou two are right,\u201d he told them. When Pence turned up to try to persuade McCain to vote for the repeal, Collins left to give them some privacy. Collins walked past Murray\u2019s seat, and the senators exchanged glances.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAt the first Republican caucus lunch held after the health care repeal failed, Senator David Perdue of Georgia lashed out at the dissenting senators; later, in a news release, he called for more accountability for committee leaders who voted against the party, implying that he thought they should lose their senior posts. \u201cSuffice it to say, it was a harsh lunch with some heavy criticism,\u201d Collins told me. \u201cIt was uncomfortable, definitely, but I was more annoyed. And I did not go to lunch the next day. To try to send a little message of my own.\u201d\n\nMurkowski did go; she knew she had already weathered worse from her Republican Senate colleagues. \u201cI would much rather have that airing and be there,\u201d she said, \u201cthan find out later that there was another gathering and that they talked about us.\u201d\n\nIn August, when I flew to Alaska to meet with Murkowski, I shared a taxi from the airport in Bethel with a woman who had flown in from a nearby island village with her toddler son to see a doctor. She gave the driver a voucher instead of money: Medicaid paid for both her flight and her cab ride.\n\nLater that day, I joined 30 or so people in the backyard of a community health center that was hosting a barbecue in Murkowski\u2019s honor. The guests, mostly employees of the center and their families, stood in line for hamburgers and Alaskan ice cream (Crisco, sugar, blueberries) and waited for her to arrive. Once she appeared \u2014 she wore a kuspuk, a longish hooded shirt with a large pocket in front \u2014 she made the rounds, introducing herself, thanking the staff members for the work they did and giving a brief speech, her voice just audible over the crackling sound of a partygoer\u2019s hand riffling through a bag of Fritos. A third grader, perhaps the one soul there struck by Murkowski\u2019s celebrity, buried his head in his mother\u2019s bosom as she handed over a jar of home-preserved salmon.\n\nOne woman at the barbecue \u2014 the only one wearing a suit \u2014 had flown from Washington to present Murkowski with a plaque from the National Association of Community Health Centers. She thanked Murkowski formally; many others expressed their appreciation for her vote against the repeal bill \u2014 and for her resolve. \u201cI just really want to thank you for standing up to him,\u201d said one of the community health center\u2019s social workers, a longtime transplant from New Jersey.\n\nBack in Murkowski\u2019s Washington office, her staff debated how to manage her newly heightened profile. Murkowski had no interest in becoming the face of an anti-Trump movement. For months she wanted to operate discreetly under the radar, as she strategized to find a way to get Congress to agree to open ANWR for drilling. In January, shortly after Trump\u2019s inauguration, she approached McConnell to propose that they attach the ANWR provision to a bill that could not be filibustered, and thus would require only 50 votes to pass. McConnell agreed, and soon after \u201cwas when we really got things going, but we did it quietly,\u201d she told a newsletter that covers the energy industry. She wanted to avoid environmentalists\u2019 typical attempts to \u201cerode and undercut\u201d those efforts, she said.\n\nPhoto\n\nWhen details of the Senate tax bill started to emerge in the fall, it became clear that many Republicans hoped the ultimate bill would contain a provision that opened up a portion of ANWR for drilling, as well as language that would eliminate the individual mandate for health insurance, which most economists argue would gut the Affordable Care Act. Nonprofit organizations like the Center for Popular Democracy tried to rally grass-roots activists in Anchorage and raised money to fly a handful of Alaskans to Washington to show up at Murkowski\u2019s office. \u201cI thought she would realize she could not maintain her political success, and her popularity, if she was to repeal any part of Obamacare,\u201d says Jennifer Flynn Walker, the director of mobilization for the organization.\n\nBut in Alaska, most residents knew that she would vote for the tax bill. \u201cYou have to understand, ANWR is like the holy grail for Alaskan politicians for the past 40 years,\u201d Halcro says. For just as long, environmentalists have fought \u2014 and in the past, recruited Republicans like McCain and Collins to their side \u2014 to protect ANWR. But in the end, every Republican senator present, including Murkowski, voted for the tax bill, and for the opening up of the refuge.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMurkowski\u2019s approval rating in Alaska, which soared among progressives after the health care bill, dropped lower than it had in at least seven years. On MSNBC, Representative Joseph Crowley, a New York Democrat, attacked Murkowski for supporting the tax bill. \u201cShe got what she wants,\u201d he said, \u201cand that was her price \u2014 to sell out the Affordable Care Act and the American people.\u201d\n\nWhatever the polls said, Murkowski clearly considered passing legislation opening ANWR an unmitigated success. At a celebration for the tax bill, Murkowski beamed alongside Trump. \u201cThis is a bright day for America, so we thank you for that!\u201d she told him. In January, she tweeted her support for his State of the Union address. That month, she also posted a photograph of a Washington Post article that the president had sent her about a wilderness region where she hoped to build a road. \u201cLisa \u2014 We will get it done,\u201d Trump had written on the clip.\n\nWhen I went to see her in Washington in February, Murkowski made some of her typically plucky, but not exactly blistering, critiques. Trump, she said, should not be using degrading and foul language. She brought up Trump\u2019s characterization of Democratic senators who did not vigorously applaud his State of the Union address. \u201cIn my view,\u201d she said, \u201cto suggest that a duly elected member of Congress who fails to applaud you is somehow treasonous, these statements are not only unnecessary; they are wrong.\u201d She glared a little. \u201cI continue to believe that some of the statements, some of what the president sets out there is really not helpful to where we are as a country.\u201d\n\nThe day I visited the community health center with Murkowski back in Bethel was the same day Trump tweeted that \u201ctwo sides\u201d shared blame for the violence that occurred at a white-supremacist rally in Charlottesville, Va. Murkowski had not minced words then: \u201cWhat the president said yesterday was wrong,\u201d she tweeted. She could not just stand by and say nothing, she told me, \u201cwhere there is evil, where there is hatred.\u201d That week in August was a strange time of upheaval, with Trump swinging wildly, attacking even his own party members.\n\nI could not help asking in Bethel: Did Murkowski worry, as some psychiatrists were suggesting publicly, that Trump was mentally unfit to be president? She was wearing sunglasses, so I could not read her expression. She paused. \u201cI don\u2019t really know him,\u201d she said. \u201cI don\u2019t know what to make of it.\u201d\n\nIn her office in Washington, Murkowski was again talking about Trump when an aide poked her head in to say that Mitch McConnell was on the line. Murkowski, who was in midthought, did not move but looked at the aide steadily for a moment, as if to say: And? The aide looked nervous \u2014 McConnell had asked to pull her out, she emphasized, at which point Murkowski got up to take the call. When she came back to the office a few moments later, she looked upbeat. They had been discussing something about funding for wildfire relief, and McConnell was apparently taking her opinion under close advisement. \u201cIt\u2019s nice to be loved,\u201d she said. \u201cAgain.\u201d She thought for a moment. \u201cIt\u2019s important to know that people know, Don\u2019t forget to check in with Murkowski.\u201d", "title": "How Lisa Murkowski Mastered Trump\u2019s Washington", "authors": ["Susan Dominus"]} {"date": "2018-04-23 00:00:00", "text": "That Facebook and Google may emerge stronger from all of this can seem like a distant prospect. The Silicon Valley companies have been under scrutiny for months for the way they collect and use people\u2019s data, with Facebook reeling from revelations that the political research firm Cambridge Analytica harvested the personal information of up to 87 million of its users. That led Congress to drag Mark Zuckerberg, Facebook\u2019s chief executive, to Washington this month for a grilling.\n\nPhoto\n\nGoogle, too, has grappled with questions about its online video service YouTube as it tries to duck lawmakers who fear that the search giant\u2019s data-collection machinery is as robust as Facebook\u2019s, if not more so.\n\nAt the same time, countries like Brazil and Argentina are exploring European-style privacy regulations that will further test the companies\u2019 advertising-based business models. United States lawmakers also showed more openness to regulating Silicon Valley during Mr. Zuckerberg\u2019s testimony this month.\n\nYet past attempts at privacy regulation have done little to mitigate the power of tech firms. Consider what happened in Europe after earlier attempts at checking the power of Facebook, Google and others.\n\nIn 2014, Europe\u2019s highest court ruled that people had the \u201cright to be forgotten\u201d online, meaning they could ask Google and other digital companies to delete search results about them. Since then, Google has instead become a chief arbiter of what information is kept online in Europe because the company itself is responsible for determining the fate of each deletion request.\n\nAnother 2011 European law requiring websites to alert visitors to \u201ccookie\u201d trackers that collect data on browsing history has largely turned into a distracting annoyance rather than changing how companies operate. People often accept the tracking to get rid of the pop-up warning without reading details about the tracking.\n\nToday, the uproar over data privacy has also done little to diminish the businesses or usage of Facebook and Google. Mr. Zuckerberg said this month that the Cambridge Analytica scandal had no meaningful effect on Facebook\u2019s business, which is expected to show sales growth when the company reports quarterly earnings this week. Alphabet, Google\u2019s parent company, said on Monday that its revenue rose 26 percent for its most recent quarter as its ad business continued to grow.\n\nPhoto\n\nSpokeswomen for Facebook and Google declined to comment.\n\nIn Europe, the coming data privacy laws are known as the General Data Protection Regulation. These rules will restrict how tech companies collect, store and use personal data from people across the region. The laws, which take effect on May 25, require companies to explain how they plan to use people\u2019s personal information in simple, unambiguous language and detail what other entities will gain access to that data. Companies can no longer hide behind convoluted and often ignored user agreements, but must obtain consent with a full understanding of the user where their data may go.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nLawyers, consultants and businesses preparing for the privacy laws said that reining in the large technology companies was not the primary goal of the European legislation.\n\nSome privacy advocates also bristle at the idea that these new restrictions would help already powerful internet companies, noting that is a well-worn argument employed by tech giants to try to prevent future regulation.\n\nBut Nicolas Colin, a co-founder and director at the Family, a Paris-based start-up accelerator, argued that \u201cpeople tend to give that permission to companies they trust.\u201d He said that \u201cstricter rules strengthen companies because they have that key asset that is trust.\u201d\n\nThe European privacy laws may crimp targeted advertising by limiting the flow of personal data, but firms like Google and Facebook still have an advantage because advertisers are likely to turn to services with reach and enormous audiences \u2014 akin to buying an ad during the Super Bowl. Facebook has more than 2.2 billion monthly users, and Google\u2019s YouTube has 1.5 billion monthly users.\n\nGiovanni Buttarelli, the European data protection supervisor who was involved in the creation of privacy rules, said much of the impact would be determined by regulators who enact the law and who will be up against well-funded teams of lobbyists and lawyers. Google and Facebook will be overseen by the Irish data authority because their European headquarters are in Ireland. Mr. Buttarelli noted that Europe had staff of about 2,500 across all the countries working on the issue.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Interested in All Things Tech? The Bits newsletter will keep you updated on the latest from Silicon Valley and the technology industry. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cThat\u2019s peanuts compared to the lobbyists in Brussels and Strasbourg,\u201d he said, referring to the cities where the European Commission and Parliament operate.\n\nHe said large technology companies had advantages but would also be under a microscope. Enforcement of the law is skewed to companies that handle the most personal data.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cThere are pros and cons to being a tech giant,\u201d he said. \u201cWe want to treat small and medium-sized businesses differently.\u201d\n\nYonatan Zunger, a former Google privacy engineer now working at human resources start-up Humu, said Europe was holding Google and Facebook to \u201ca much higher bar\u201d when it came to gaining consent from users. These companies now cannot make data sharing a condition of using their products because consent needs to be freely given, whereas smaller companies are not held to that same standard, he said.\n\nStill, there are already signs the big companies are adjusting to the new privacy norms.\n\nFacebook last week rolled out a new consent form asking users globally \u2014 not just Europeans \u2014 to accept its targeted advertising and to allow features like face recognition. It has also limited access to data brokers such as Acxiom, in a concession to privacy advocates.\n\nGoogle, which spent years preparing for the new rules, has stopped scanning Gmail messages for keywords used to target advertising. And it recently introduced a new marketing product for publishers that shows ads based on the context of other articles or content on a website, instead of relying on personal information.\n\nIn response, privacy critics have challenged Facebook\u2019s new consent forms, saying they are intended to continue encouraging users to share information widely. And Google came under fire for an updated European user consent policy that has open-ended language, which critics said violated a tenet of European privacy rules that requires companies to ask for user consent in specific and explicit ways.\n\n\u201cI\u2019m worried that a lot of people have invested a lot of hope in G.D.P.R., and I\u2019m not sure it\u2019s going to deliver,\u201d said Ben Scott, a senior adviser to the Open Technology Institute at New America, a think tank based in Washington. \u201cIt will all depend on how it\u2019s going to be enforced.\u201d", "title": "How Looming Privacy Regulations May Strengthen Facebook and Google", "authors": ["Daisuke Wakabayashi", "Adam Satariano"]} {"date": "2018-04-06 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nThe playwright Lynn Nottage\u2019s work takes her far from the brownstone in Boerum Hill, Brooklyn, where she grew up, and to which she returned in 1997. \u201cSweat,\u201d which won a Pulitzer Prize for drama in 2017, involved months of immersion among the embattled factory workers of Reading, Pa. Her new play, \u201cMlima\u2019s Tale,\u201d which will open at the Public Theater on April 15, follows the path of an ivory tusk from the savanna, where the title elephant is killed by poachers, through various traders to a high-end store in China. \u201cThe trail of the tusk is very long and circuitous,\u201d Ms. Nottage, 53, said. She lives with her husband, Tony Gerber, 54, a documentary filmmaker, and their son, Melkamu, who is 9. Ruby Aiyo Gerber, their daughter, is a 20-year-old student at Brown University.\n\nPhoto\n\nRISE AND CHAT I get up around 7:30. Usually my husband is the first person up. And my son is the last. I start the day chatting with my husband. When I get up he\u2019s usually responding to email and launched into what\u2019s happened. We talk about what we want for breakfast, and usually on Sundays he\u2019ll cook pancakes and make eggs. We\u2019ll eat breakfast, and if I\u2019m in rehearsals I\u2019ll rush off.\n\nGIVE, THEN TAKE I have a ritual that I do at the end of the rehearsal process, on the evening of our first preview, which is essentially handing the play over to the actors and excusing myself from the process, and really allowing it to grow with them. And the very last day of the production I come and take it back. It\u2019s very cathartic. It allows me a way to separate and to say, I\u2019ve spent all these years researching and writing and developing this, and I have to let it go and let someone else be the caretaker of my words for a period of time. But I always say, I\u2019m coming back for them when we\u2019re finished.\n\nPhoto\n\nEXILED I\u2019ll go and see the performances when we\u2019re in previews. Once it opens I return to my life. It\u2019s always a little difficult because the rehearsal process is so intense and you\u2019re forging bonds and making new friends and going very deep and intimate very quickly, and then you\u2019re asked to remove yourself, while they continue to have that bond. You feel as though you\u2019ve been exiled to an island.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nR & R Sunday I try to rest. Monday is technically our day off, but it\u2019s not a day off for my life, so it\u2019s filled with all the things that I can\u2019t do when I\u2019m in rehearsal or previews, so it\u2019s almost more busy. If I have more time, I try to catch up on some reading and research for some things I\u2019m working on. And then my son has a full day with play dates and basketball. And then perhaps seeing friends in the evening, or I just go home and be with my family. Because I don\u2019t get to see them when we\u2019re doing the show, so that time becomes more precious.\n\nPhoto\n\nHOME-COOKED MEAL We\u2019ll have dinner together at home. One of us will cook, and my guess is that because I\u2019ve been working all day, my husband will cook it.\n\nFASHION VICTIM After dinner we\u2019ve been watching \u201cPlanet Earth,\u201d so we\u2019ll watch an hour of that, and my son will go to bed. And my husband and I will watch an episode of some television show. We\u2019ve been watching \u201cThe Assassination of Gianni Versace: American Crime Story,\u201d which is incredibly dark and giving us nightmares.", "title": "How Lynn Nottage, Playwright, Spends Her Sundays", "authors": ["John Leland", "Sunday Routine"]} {"date": "2018-04-03 00:00:00", "text": "Today, it\u2019s not clear that any shooting could be awful enough to embolden Congress to thwart the National Rifle Association. But even back then, the N.R.A. throttled much of what Mr. Johnson intended to do.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cThe voices that blocked these safeguards were not the voices of an aroused nation,\u201d an angry president said at the bill signing. \u201cThey were the voices of a powerful lobby, a gun lobby, that has prevailed for the moment in an election year.\u201d\n\nHe called on \u201cthose of us who are really concerned about crime\u201d to fight for stronger laws. \u201cWe have been through a great deal of anguish these last few months and these last few years \u2014 too much anguish to forget so quickly.\u201d\n\nThe new law outlawed gun sales to felons, drug abusers, minors and those with mental illness; banned most out-of-state and mail-order gun sales; and sharply curbed imported weapons, including the cheap, tiny pistols used in many homicides.\n\nIt remains a cornerstone of federal gun law today.\n\nThe King assassination spurred the legislation not just because it horrified the nation, but also because it prompted unrest across the country, including in Washington, where lawmakers watched rioters come within blocks of the White House as thousands of federal troops were mobilized.\n\n\u201cIt was in Congress\u2019s backyard, so they didn\u2019t have to read about it in the newspapers. They could see it,\u201d said Larry Temple, a high-ranking aide and special counsel to Mr. Johnson. \u201cThe death of Dr. King and the resulting riots in Washington had an impact on Congress and what they wound up doing.\u201d\n\nBut it wasn\u2019t until June 5, when Senator Kennedy was assassinated, that the logjam looked like it would break. A day later, a modest gun-control proposal that had languished passed Congress, raising the age to buy handguns to 21.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nStill, Mr. Johnson wanted something far more sweeping. He proposed to treat guns like cars: They would be registered and their owners would be licensed.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Race/Related Newsletter Join a deep and provocative exploration of race with a diverse group of New York Times journalists. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nHad something like this passed, gun-control proponents say, the United States today might look more like Britain or Australia, countries where guns are tracked and gun violence is a fraction of what it is here.\n\n\u201cHe said, \u2018We have about 10 days or two weeks to get it passed,\u2019\u201d recalled Joseph Califano, his chief domestic adviser. \u201c\u2018If we don\u2019t get it out of committee by then, the N.R.A. will kill us.\u2019\u201d\n\nThis time, there has been no similar urgency in Washington, even as hundreds of thousands of protesters in the capital and elsewhere have demanded changes after the killing of 17 students and staff at a high school in Parkland, Fla.\n\nCrime is less a concern, as the murder rate has fallen sharply since the sixties. But mass shootings have become frighteningly common. Anyone \u2014 or anyone\u2019s child \u2014 could be a victim, at a school, a concert, a church, a movie theater or a nightclub.\n\nAnd while a smaller percent of households own guns, the country has more of them, and they are deadlier: Semiautomatic rifles like the AR-15 have become the weapon of choice in the largest recent mass killings, leading to death tolls in the dozens.\n\nMost people today favor tighter gun restrictions, polls indicate, just as they did a half-century ago. But the N.R.A. also wields political power disproportionate to the size of its membership, as it did then.\n\nIn 1968, the organization was not yet as uncompromising as it is today. But it used tactics that would feel familiar now.\n\nPhoto\n\nIt flooded its members with sky-is-falling warnings about the government taking away gun rights, and urged them to hound lawmakers. In a letter to 900,000 N.R.A. members in June 1968, the organization\u2019s president, Harold W. Glassen, said that the \u201cright of sportsmen\u201d to lawfully own and use firearms was \u201cin the greatest jeopardy in the history of our country.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nFrustrated gun-control backers called it \u201ccalculated hysteria and distortion.\u201d But it was profoundly effective.\n\nIn its coverage that month, The New York Times called the gun lobby among the most effective in Washington, citing the association\u2019s ability to get \u201csportsmen, farmers and gun lovers to put pressure on their congressmen.\u201d\n\nSoon, Mr. Johnson\u2019s favored provisions were shorn from the bill by his old cadre of fellow Southern Democrats.\n\n\u201cStrom Thurmond is hostile as hell, and so is Jim,\u201d \u2014 James O. Eastland, Democrat of Mississippi \u2014 \u201cand they\u2019re mutilating the bill as it is,\u201d the leader of the Senate Republicans, Everett Dirksen of Illinois, told Mr. Johnson in a recorded phone call on July 24, 1968 that is in the Mr. Johnson\u2019s presidential library. (Senator Thurmond was by then a Republican.)\n\nThe licensing and registration provisions passed neither chamber, and triumphant pro-gun forces announced it was now legislation they could \u201clive with.\u201d\n\nTo which Representative Charles S. Joelson, Democrat of New Jersey, responded: \u201cI suggest that tens of thousands of Americans can die with it.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nThe Gun Control Act was signed into law that fall.\n\nTwo years later, the N.R.A. helped defeat the re-election bid of a leading Senate proponent of tough gun laws, Joseph D. Tydings, Democrat of Maryland, a man who had won his seat just six years earlier in a landslide.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBy now the N.R.A. has perfected the art of going after lawmakers who defy the organization. That is one reason the demands of mass shooting survivors and their allies, now led most visibly by the Parkland students, remain so far apart from the measures Congress is considering.\n\nIn 1956, after his house was bombed, Dr. King applied to the local sheriff for a permit to carry a concealed handgun. He was denied on the grounds that he was \u201cunsuitable,\u201d according to Adam Winkler, the author of \u201cGunfight: The Battle Over the Right to Bear Arms in America.\u201d\n\nFriends and relatives who feared for his safety urged him to hire a bodyguard and armed watchmen, he wrote in his autobiography. But soon, he and Coretta Scott King, his wife, reconsidered and gave up the one gun they owned. \u201cHow could I serve as one of the leaders of a nonviolent movement and at the same time use weapons of violence for my personal protection?\u201d he wrote.\n\nFifty years ago, the death of great leaders prodded Congress to act on gun control. Now, at a similar juncture, it is the death of schoolchildren that has stirred the makings of a movement. It remains uncertain whether the current movement for gun restrictions will result in meaningful reform.\n\nSo far, the main impetus is in state legislatures. \u201cEven in Republican-controlled states it appears there is at least some openness to doing something, building on the foundation laid over the last five years in less conservative states,\u201d said Adam Skaggs, chief counsel of the Giffords Law Center to Prevent Gun Violence. But he said Congress may not do much unless midterm elections shake things up.\n\nFor Dr. King, who would have turned 89 in January, getting rid of his gun helped him reckon with his mortality and focus on his movement.\n\n\u201cFrom that point on, I no longer needed a gun nor have I been afraid,\u201d he wrote. \u201cHad we become distracted by the question of my safety we would have lost the moral offensive and sunk to the level of our oppressors.\u201d", "title": "How M.L.K.\u2019s Death Helped Lead to Gun Control in the U.S.", "authors": ["Richard A. Oppel Jr."]} {"date": "2018-04-10 00:00:00", "text": "First, while he was inexplicably slow and somewhat disjointed in initially addressing the Cambridge Analytica crisis, he has since developed a comprehensive \u201cnarrative.\u201d It not only addresses the company\u2019s data privacy issues but also Facebook\u2019s troubles with fake news and nefarious election influence.\n\nThat narrative served as the basis of both Mr. Zuckerberg\u2019s media call last week and his formal opening statement submitted Monday afternoon. An abridged summary of that narrative could go something like this:\n\n\u201cFacebook created an entirely new tool for connecting people for the purposes of good. We didn\u2019t anticipate bad people would use it for bad purposes. We are genuinely sorry, and I\u2019m personally accountable. We needed to broaden our sense of responsibility and will continue to keep taking meaningful actions to prevent the abuse of the tools we provide. Our business depends on the trust of our community, and so restoring that trust is our biggest business priority. The bad guys can never be fully subdued, but we will be continually learning and making Facebook safer and better.\u201d\n\nThat explanation will hardly appease Facebook\u2019s most severe critics, who want to see more drastic changes. Instead, Mr. Zuckerberg\u2019s message \u2014 laced with promises of ongoing changes to come \u2014 seems designed primarily to allow Facebook to move beyond crisis.\n\nPhoto\n\nTo avoid making himself a fixed target, Mr. Zuckerberg is wise to not defend Facebook\u2019s most egregious historical practices. During questioning, look for him to be highly open-minded. If threatened with regulatory intervention, assume Mr. Zuckerberg will earnestly repeat his recent assertions that Facebook would welcome reasonable regulation.\n\nThe real test of Mr. Zuckerberg\u2019s new malleability will come if he\u2019s asked if Facebook is considering adding a paid subscription that would allow users to avoid sharing their data with advertisers. That would mark a fundamental change in the company\u2019s business model, a shift that some say would be required to truly solve Facebook\u2019s problems. Thus far, Mr. Zuckerberg has staunchly insisted that Facebook remain free to its users.\n\nSecond, Mr. Zuckerberg should benefit from his growing comfort with talking publicly about Facebook\u2019s issues. After the Cambridge Analytica story broke, Mr. Zuckerberg seemed noticeably anxious in his lone televised interview, clearly aware that the issue was far more serious than Facebook\u2019s prior controversies.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nBut a week later, in his hourlong conference call with media, Mr. Zuckerberg seemed far more sure-footed in taking on fairly sharp questions and sometimes sounding almost eager to reply with detailed answers.\n\nMr. Zuckerberg\u2019s performance may also be enhanced by private meetings he had on Capitol Hill on Monday. Those conversations won\u2019t likely win him more favorable treatment during his testimony, but they likely served as a helpful warm-up before he sits down in front of the full committee and the live cameras.\n\nWhile testifying, Mr. Zuckerberg\u2019s first priority is to avoid generating a new round of negative headlines by tossing off a flippant, misguided remark, or by being goaded into a petulant state. But if he endures his inquisition with humility, respectfulness and sincerity, he could actually emerge much better off.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThese hearings tend to serve as turning points in most major business controversies. Sometimes they add fuel to the fire. Other times, they create a sense that the offending big shot has been sufficiently chastened by a public lashing and the crisis starts to fade.\n\nMr. Zuckerberg will likely be peppered with plenty of barbed questions. But the most important one will be highly personal: \u201cHow can you possibly think that you should not be fired?\u201d\n\nAt that moment, if he can convince lawmakers and Facebook users that he is the most capable and determined person to fix his company\u2019s problems, then Facebook can begin turning the corner on this crisis. And if that happens, then Mr. Zuckerberg can actually say that he walked away with a small but critical \u201cwin.\u201d", "title": "How Mark Zuckerberg Can \u2018Win\u2019 on Capitol Hill", "authors": ["Paul Pendergrass", "Another View"]} {"date": "2018-04-12 00:00:00", "text": "The median home value in the United States rose from $195,400 to $210,200 \u2014 a 7.5 percent increase \u2014 between February 2017 and February 2018.\n\nBut according to a study from Zillow, there is another way to think about it: Over the course of a year, that increase amounts to a little more than $7 an hour, if you imagine your home working a 40-hour week for you.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Real Estate Newsletter Every week, get updates on residential real estate news, covering the five boroughs and beyond. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe amount the median American home \u201cearned\u201d is just shy of the federal minimum wage of $7.25 an hour, but in 24 of the 50 largest cities in the country the median-priced home increased in value by more than the local minimum wage.\n\nAnd some cities saw spectacular gains. In San Jose, Calif., the median-priced home \u201cearned\u201d almost $100 an hour over the course of the year, far surpassing the local minimum wage of $13.50.\n\nWhile homeowners made big gains, however, renters and potential buyers did not: Over the same time period, rents went up about three percent, making it harder to save for a down payment.", "title": "How Much Does Your House Make an Hour?", "authors": ["Michael Kolomatsky"]} {"date": "2018-04-09 00:00:00", "text": "If you were a judge sentencing juveniles who vandalized property with racial epithets or remarks, what punishment do you think you might give them? Why?\n\nIn \u201cTeenage Vandals Were Sentenced to ReadBooks. Here\u2019s What One Learned,\u201d Christine Hauser writes about a sentence a judge gave to teenagers who defaced a historic black schoolhouse with swastikas and the words \u201cwhite power\u201d and \u201cblack power\u201d:\n\nInstead of spending time in community service, Judge Avelina Jacob decided, the youths should read a book. But not just any book. They had to choose from a list of ones covering some of history\u2019s most divisive and tragic periods. The horrors of the Holocaust awaited them in \u201cNight,\u201d by Elie Wiesel. The racism of the Jim Crow South was there in Maya Angelou\u2019s \u201cI Know Why the Caged Bird Sings.\u201d The brutal hysteria of persecution could be explored in \u201cThe Crucible\u201d by Arthur Miller. ... Since the Ashburn case, the reading sentence has been applied to another case, one involving a 14-year-old who threatened a black student with a noose, Ms. Rueda said. She gathered a list of 36 books with input from librarians who emphasized that the most enlightening could be \u201cA Wreath for Emmett Till,\u201d a poetry book about a black youth of the same age who was murdered in Mississippi in 1955. Marilyn Nelson, the author, said she was concerned it might have the opposite effect to what was intended. \u201cI can\u2019t say I\u2019m pleased to know that my work is being inflicted as a punishment,\u201d she said. \u201cWill kids punished by being made to read poetry ever read poetry again?\u201d Other authors expressed hope that the underlying message in their works was not lost. Mr. Boyle, whose \u201cThe Tortilla Curtain\u201d is told from four points of view, said he hoped the teenager \u201cwill be able to live inside the skin of someone unfamiliar to him, whether that be the Mexican immigrant couple or the Anglo couple living in a gated community, and that the experience will enrich his social perspective.\u201d\n\nStudents: Read the entire article, then tell us:\n\n\u2014 What are your thoughts on juvenile offenders being required to read certain books as part of their punishment?\n\n\u2014 How do you respond to the idea that making reading books a punishment may lead to resistance to reading in the future? Why?\n\n\u2014 If you were a judge who heard cases involving juveniles, how would you determine what their punishment should be?", "title": "How Much Power Do Books Have to Teach Young People Tolerance of Others?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-19 00:00:00", "text": "No matter how much free time you have this weekend, we have TV recommendations for you. Come back every Friday for new suggestions from our TV critic on what to watch.\n\nThis Weekend I Have \u2026 an Hour, and Anything Goes\n\n\u2018Live From Lincoln Center: Sutton Foster in Concert\u2019\n\nWhen to watch: Friday, 9 p.m., on PBS. (Check local listings.)\n\n\u201cYounger\u201d doesn\u2019t come back until June, but luckily there\u2019s this terrific special to keep its star, Sutton Foster, in our minds and hearts this spring. In this special, she is by turns perky and salty and wistful. The highlight is the goofy, almost variety-show schtick between Ms. Foster and Jonathan Groff, which eventually leads to a fantastic tap duet to the song \u201cFit as a Fiddle (and Ready for Love).\u201d\n\n\u2026 a Few Hours, and I Like the Human Condition\n\nHelen Rhodes in \u201cObsessed.\u201d A&E\n\n\u2018Obsessed\u2019\n\nWhen to watch: Now, on\n\nNow, on Hulu Save To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nThis two-season series, which began in 2009, is for obsessive-compulsive and anxiety disorders what \u201cIntervention\u201d is for addiction: a frank, intimate, sometimes shocking snapshot of a person in crisis. Here, though, we also stay with the subjects through effective therapy and coaching. Pop culture tends to position O.C.D. as cutesy germaphobia, but \u201cObsessed\u201d makes it clear that the disorder is isolating and debilitating \u2014 and, mercifully, also treatable.\n\n\u2026 4 Hours, and I Like Gentle Comedy\n\nJames Acaster in \u201cRepertoire.\u201d Netflix\n\n\u2018James Acaster: Repertoire\u2019\n\nWhere to watch: Now, on\n\nNow, on Netflix Save To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nThe brainy and self-effacing British comedian James Acaster released four stand-up specials at once: three individual chapters and a fourth that synthesizes material from the previous three. The wrinkled backdrops and Mr. Acaster\u2019s unassuming demeanor give off a laid-back vibe, but the material is precisely written and tightly constructed, with elegant moments of poetry and fantasy. The third hour, \u201cReset,\u201d is the best of the bunch, but the episodes build on one another and should be watched in order.\n\n0", "title": "How Much Watching Time Do You Have This Weekend?", "authors": ["Margaret Lyons"]} {"date": "2018-04-12 00:00:00", "text": "\u2026 a Half-Hour, and I\u2019m a News Fiend\n\nFrom left, Alex Wagner, John Heilemann and Mark McKinnon in \u201cThe Circus: Inside the Wildest Political Show on Earth.\u201d Alison Cohen Rosa/Showtime\n\n\u2018The Circus\u2019\n\nWhen to watch: Sunday, 8 p.m., Showtime\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nThe first two seasons of \u201cThe Circus\u201d are about politics and the news industry \u2014 in the first season, amid the suffocation and frustration of the campaign trail, and in the second, amid the stress and tumult of the Trump administration\u2019s first 100 days. The third season kicks off this weekend with a new co-host, Alex Wagner, who has taken over for the disgraced Mark Halperin. Too bad everything is so chill and peaceful and standardized now, and there\u2019s nothing left for \u201cThe Circus\u201d to cover.\n\n\u2026 an Hour, and I Like Feelings\n\nAndrea Navedo in \u201cJane the Virgin.\u201d Jesse Giddings/CW\n\n\u2018Jane the Virgin\u2019\n\nWhen to watch: Friday, 9 p.m., the CW\n\nFriday, 9 p.m., the CW Save To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nNo other show on TV can cram so many moments of real joy and deep sorrow into one episode, but that\u2019s one of the many things that make \u201cJane\u201d such a special show. (Also on that list: beautiful performances and inventive narrative formats.) In this penultimate episode of the season, Xiomara (Andrea Navedo) is undergoing chemotherapy and enduring excruciating physical pain alongside the fear and helplessness of being sick. But the episode isn\u2019t torturous \u2014 instead, it\u2019s a reminder that love, support, human decency and the occasional pot brownie can make even the hardest times a little easier.\n\n\u2026 Several Hours, and I Like Tension\n\nA scene from \u201cMoney Heist.\u201d via Netflix\n\n\u2018Money Heist\u2019\n\nWhen to watch: Now, on\n\n: Now, on Netflix Save To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nFormerly known as \u201cLa Casa de Papel,\u201d this limited Spanish series (in Spanish with subtitles, or dubbed) has been renamed \u201cMoney Heist\u201d for American audiences, and fair enough: It\u2019s about a heist at the Royal Mint of Spain. A scarily brilliant mastermind who calls himself the Professor assembles a group of highly capable thieves and plans an elaborate siege designed to take place over several days, which includes essential tasks for the dozens of hostages and a vow that no one will be hurt. At 22 episodes across two seasons, it is too drawn out, but even so, it\u2019s often as tense and exciting as early-era \u201cLost.\u201d If you want a thriller with visual panache \u2014 like freaky Dal\u00ed masks \u2014 try this.\n\nWatching is The New York Times\u2019s TV and film recommendation website. Sign up for our thrice-weekly newsletter here.\n\n0", "title": "How Much Watching Time Do You Have This Weekend?", "authors": ["Margaret Lyons"]} {"date": "2018-04-26 00:00:00", "text": "No matter how much free time you have this weekend, we have TV recommendations for you. Come back every Friday for new suggestions from our TV critic on what to watch.\n\nThis Weekend I Have \u2026 an Hour, and I Like Games\n\n\u2018Taskmaster\u2019\n\nWhen to watch: Friday at 11 p.m., on Comedy Central.\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nReggie Watts serves as judge and \u201cTaskmaster\u201d in this new game show, in which five comedians and performers compete in silly physical, mental and artistic challenges over the course of eight episodes. (The show airs in two-episode chunks.) This is the American version of a British show, and much of the original\u2019s devilish glee is intact. The tasks are random and wide-ranging \u2014 get a ball through a basketball hoop without using your hands; \u201cimpress this mayor\u201d \u2014 and generate clever aha moments, as well as the occasional \u201cJackass\u201d-like wipeout.\n\nI became obsessed with the British version a few months ago, and this incarnation absolutely holds up. The contestants here are the actor Freddie Highmore, the D.J. Dillon Francis, and the comedians Kate Berlant, Ron Funches and Lisa Lampanelli \u2014 it\u2019s a well-balanced group, and its members each have distinct skills and approaches, and vastly differing energies. Eight episodes were made available to critics, and I watched all eight in a row.\n\n\u2026 90 Minutes, and I Like Documentaries\n\nMattel, via Hulu\n\n\u2018Tiny Shoulders: Rethinking Barbie\u2019\n\nWhen to watch: Now, on\n\nNow, on Hulu Save To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\n\u201cTiny Shoulders\u201d follows the Barbie creative and communications teams as they work on \u201cProject Dawn,\u201d the revised Barbies \u2014 petite, tall and curvy \u2014 that debuted in 2016. The first half of this documentary is for anyone who has strong feelings about Barbie, pro or con, be they memories of adoring her and her Dream House or complaints about her physique and omnipresence in American femininity. But the second part is for anyone who thinks about mass media: In preparation for the rollout, Team Barbie enlists a crisis public relations team to practice fielding terrible tweets.\n\n\u2026 a Few Hours, and I Like HGTV\n\nA scene from \u201cMedieval Terrace,\u201d s01e14 of \u201cThe Great Interior Design Challenge.\u201d BBC/Netflix\n\n\u2018The Great Interior Design Challenge\u2019\n\nWhen to watch: Now, on\n\nNow, on Netflix Save To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nThis British import pits aspiring interior designers against one another to see whose d\u00e9cor reigns supreme. Unlike most contest shows, not everyone competes head-to-head; instead, the show moves through small batches of contestants every three episodes, eventually leading to a quarterfinal, etc. The judging is patient and humane, and the eliminations are swift and merciful. The actual designs, however, can be quite amateurish and are sometimes downright crummy. (Some are good! But \u2026 not all.) After the impossible fantasies of most decorating and renovation shows, this is honestly a huge relief.\n\n0", "title": "How Much Watching Time Do You Have This Weekend?", "authors": ["Margaret Lyons"]} {"date": "2018-04-05 00:00:00", "text": "No matter how much free time you have this weekend, we have TV recommendations for you.
