Please email thoughts and suggestions to bizday@nytimes.com.", "title": "How Shipping Costs Have Put Amazon in a Bind: DealBook Briefing", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-13 00:00:00", "text": "A series of nasty thoughts that had begun as whispers in the back of my head mounted into angry shouts over time. I had moments of happiness and joy over the eight or nine months those dark thoughts haunted me, but as soon as the positive thoughts faded I reverted back into the darkness that had become my default mental setting.\n\nIt built gradually, but those dark thoughts vanished in an instant somewhere high above the beaches of Dubai. And I haven\u2019t heard so much as a faint whisper from them since the moment I stepped out of the airplane.\n\nWhen I got home I began doing some research, and was surprised to find that I\u2019m far from alone. In fact, researchers around the world are currently studying the effectiveness of adventure sports in combating anxiety, depression, post-traumatic stress disorder \u2014 and for the author and counselor Brandon Stogsdill, as a way to help at-risk youths from underprivileged communities overcome childhood trauma.\n\n\u201cIn behavioral therapy we talk about that thought process you had as an automatic negative dialogue, which pops in without any effort, and your brain will create literal neural pathways to make that stronger and stronger until we do something to take ourselves out of it,\u201d he explained over the phone from his office in Seattle.\n\nAccording to Mr. Stogsdill, depression makes it hard for one to concentrate on the present moment. Instead the depressed brain is constantly dreaming up negative future scenarios or dwelling on traumatic past events. \u201cThe healthy thing is to focus on the moment, because we have more control in the moment, and when you\u2019re sky diving you can only focus on right now,\u201d he said.\n\nThere are a variety of depression types and levels of severity, he added, and while some may need only high-adrenaline activity to jolt their brains back to a non-depressed state, it is by no means a universal cure.\n\nFor sufferers of less extreme depression, however, action sports like sky diving are very effective ways to rewire the brain\u2019s focus back into the present moment. Of course, it\u2019s not the only method. Mr. Stogsdill often counsels underprivileged youth on the ski hill, and found painting an effective tactic for focusing his thoughts on the present moment and combating depression after a BMX accident rendered him temporarily immobile.\n\nWhen I signed the intimidatingly long waiver at the flight school in Dubai, I had no idea that I would land back on earth feeling like a completely new person, or at least back to the person I was before my battle with depression began. While the initial adrenaline rush does provide some immediate relief, the dive had a much longer-lasting impact on my general outlook. It allowed me to think clearly for what felt like the first time in months, and reaffirmed something I had once known about myself, but had forgotten somewhere along the way.", "title": "Opinion | How Sky Diving Cured My Depression", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-13 00:00:00", "text": "Steve Schirripa said that landing the role as Bobby Baccalieri on \u201cThe Sopranos\u201d was like \u201chitting the lottery \u2014 twice.\u201d Over the past few years, the actor, who was born in Brooklyn and grew up on welfare, has gone from wiseguy to good guy as a regular on the popular CBS series \u201cBlue Bloods,\u201d in which he plays an investigator for a district attorney. After graduating from Brooklyn College with a teaching degree, he moved to Las Vegas and worked several jobs in the service industry. He was a bouncer at Paul Anka\u2019s disco, Jubilation (which later became the Shark Club), and a m\u00e2itre d\u2019 at the Riviera hotel before becoming the entertainment director there in 1986. Later, he owned his own talent agency in Las Vegas. Mr. Schirripa, 60, now lives in Manhattan with his wife, Laura, 55. They have two daughters, Bria, 26, and Ciara, 22.\n\nGOOD MORNING, PANDORA I get up late on Sundays, about 9:30 or 10 a.m., and the first thing I do is put on Pandora Radio and listen to some Van Morrison, and then I make some coffee. My wife is usually out running, and since my daughters are often gone \u2014 one has moved out, and the other is away at college \u2014 there\u2019s usually no one home to bug me.", "title": "How Steve Schirripa, Actor, Spends His Sundays", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-25 00:00:00", "text": "With those findings as a backdrop, other scientists began to look at the working of the immune systems of athletes during and after draining events. Their research showed that changes occurred, some of them drastic. During an event such as a marathon, for instance, immune cells would begin to flood the bloodstreams of the athletes, apparently flushed there from other parts of the body as heart rates rose and blood sluiced more forcefully through various tissues.\n\nBy the time the race ended, the runners\u2019 bloodstreams would teem with extra immune cells.\n\nBut within a few hours, the numbers of many such immune cells in the bloodstream would crash, researchers found, typically falling to levels far lower than before the event.\n\nThe scientists interpreted these findings to mean that the runners\u2019 physical exertions had killed large numbers of their immune cells and created what some researchers dubbed an \u201copen window\u201d of immune suppression that could allow opportunistic germs to creep in, unopposed.\n\nThat idea became established doctrine in exercise science and sports.\n\nBut recently, health researchers at the University of Bath in England grew skeptical. From an evolutionary standpoint, they reasoned, immune suppression after strenuous exercise made little sense. Early humans often had to chase prey or flee predators, opening themselves to injury. If they experienced a weakened immune response at the same time, they were in serious jeopardy.\n\nThe researchers also suspected that scientific techniques developed since the 1980s might offer updated insights into what was going on inside the bodies of tired athletes.\n\nSo for the new review, which was published this month in Frontiers in Immunology, they gathered and analyzed a wide variety of recent studies and used those findings to reconsider what exercise does to immunity in the short term.\n\nTheir first conclusion was that athletes are lousy at identifying whether and why they are sniffling. The original 1980s studies had relied on runners\u2019 self-reports of illness. But newer experiments that actually tested saliva showed that less than a third of marathon runners who thought they had caught a cold actually had. Statistically, their odds of becoming sick were about the same as for anyone else in the race\u2019s host city.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe athletes probably had misinterpreted allergies or short-term scratchiness in their airways after the race as a cold, says John Campbell, a professor at the University of Bath who was a co-author of the new review.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMeanwhile, the researchers found, technically sophisticated new studies using animals undercut other aspects of the dogma about exercise and immunity.\n\nIn these studies, mouse immune cells were dyed, allowing scientists to track their location. When the mice subsequently ran, many of the cells moved out of various tissues and into the bloodstream, as happens in people.\n\nBut after exercise, these cells did not die off in massive numbers. Instead, the tracking revealed, they moved elsewhere, migrating to the animals\u2019 guts or lungs, portions of the body that might be expected to need extra immune help after hard exercise. A few immune cells also flowed into the bone marrow, where they were thought to spark specialized stem cells into creating additional immune cells.\n\nIn essence, the rodents\u2019 immune systems had bolstered their defenses in vulnerable areas of the body after exercise by redirecting cells from the blood.\n\nWhether the same migrations take place inside of us is still unknown.\n\n\u201cLive tracking of immune cells after exercise has not been done in people,\u201d says James Turner, the review\u2019s co-author and also a professor at the University of Bath.\n\nBut he and Dr. Campbell suspect that this scenario would explain how immune-cell levels in marathoners\u2019 blood rise back to normal within about 24 hours after a race.\n\n\u201cThe body can\u2019t replace cells that quickly,\u201d Dr. Turner says. So they must be returning to the blood from elsewhere.\n\nHe and Dr. Campbell hope that future experiments will follow human athletes\u2019 peripatetic immune cells after exercise and track how they influence health.\n\nBut for now, the researchers would like their review to help to recalibrate our ideas about strenuous exercise and illness.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cPeople should not be put off exercising for fear of it suppressing their immune system,\u201d Dr. Campbell says. \u201cExercise is good for the immune system.\u201d", "title": "How Strenuous Exercise Affects Our Immune System", "authors": ["Gretchen Reynolds", "Phys Ed"]} {"date": "2018-04-13 00:00:00", "text": "In seven years, the casualties of Syria\u2019s civil war have grown from the first handful of protesters shot by government forces to hundreds of thousands of dead.\n\nBut as the war has dragged on, growing more diffuse and complex, many international monitoring groups have essentially stopped counting.\n\nEven the United Nations, which released regular reports on the death toll during the first years of the war, gave its last estimate in 2016 \u2014 when it relied on 2014 data, in part \u2014 and said that it was virtually impossible to verify how many had died.\n\nAt that time, a United Nations official said 400,000 people had been killed.\n\nBut so many of the biggest moments of the war have happened since then. In the past two years, the government of President Bashar al-Assad, with Russia\u2019s help, laid siege to residential areas of Aleppo, once the country\u2019s second-largest city, and several other areas controlled by opposition groups, leveling entire neighborhoods. Last weekend, dozens of people died in a suspected chemical attack on a Damascus suburb, prompting the United States, Britain and France to launch retaliatory strikes against Syrian targets early Saturday.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn addition, American-led forces have bombed the Islamic State in large patches of eastern Syria, in strikes believed to have left thousands dead. And dozens of armed groups, including fighters backed by Iran, have continued to clash, creating a humanitarian catastrophe that the world is struggling to measure.", "title": "How Syria\u2019s Death Toll Is Lost in the Fog of War", "authors": ["Megan Specia"]} {"date": "2018-04-27 00:00:00", "text": "The dream of the \u201980s (and also the \u201990s) is alive in \u201cReady Player One.\u201d\n\nSteven Spielberg\u2019s gamified look at the future spends a lot of visual moments in the pop culture past. The film, based on Ernest Cline\u2019s novel, is set in a dystopian 2045. Wade Watts (who goes by the avatar Parzival) and his friends pass the time plugged into the Oasis, the virtual reality universe where the Hotel Overlook from \u201cThe Shining\u201d and the Iron Giant exist side by side. Mr. Spielberg relied on a frequent visual effects partner, Industrial Light & Magic, to help bring the Oasis to life.\n\nVideo game references make up a big part of that world, but movie references also give fans plenty to parse, whether it\u2019s the DeLorean from \u201cBack to the Future,\u201d the monster from \u201cAlien\u201d or the evil Chucky doll from \u201cChild\u2019s Play.\u201d\n\n\u201cThe asset list on this film was daunting, insanely long and super complicated,\u201d the visual effects supervisor Grady Cofer said, referring to the list of effects needed. \u201cBut for pop culture fans, it was this dream come true. And from the very beginning, what started happening was, artists would request to work on things. Someone would say, \u2018I would love to model the Iron Giant,\u2019 or \u2018I love \u201cGremlins\u201d\u2019 or whatever.\u201d Mr. Cofer realized the production would be fueled by passion.\n\nHere is a look at some key moments and figures that appear in the film, with Mr. Cofer explaining how ILM made them work.", "title": "How They Made the Movie References Pop in \u2018Ready Player One\u2019", "authors": ["Mekado Murphy"]} {"date": "2018-04-03 00:00:00", "text": "Last fall, Kelly Hepburn, a real estate broker in Denver, thought about traveling to the U.S. Virgin Islands, but then Hurricanes Irma and Maria blew in, devastating the destination. In March, Ms. Hepburn decided to go to St. John solo to volunteer, joining projects cleaning up trails in a national park, painting at a local school and assisting at an animal shelter.\n\n\u201cI\u2019m only one person and I know I\u2019m not a huge impact, but getting the word out is important,\u201d she said. \u201cThough the islands are up and running there are big projects still ahead and a lot of needs.\u201d\n\nAfter the back-to-back Category 5 storms ripped through the region, anyone hoping to help was directed to give financially and leave the hands-on efforts to professionals. Now, six months after the storms, while fund-raising remains active, travelers are increasingly being invited to volunteer while on vacation.\n\n\u201cJust by visiting the injection of foreign exchange in the economy is going to help,\u201d said Hugh Riley, the secretary general of the Caribbean Tourism Organization. \u201cBut some want to come to do something in addition to relaxing on the beach and we are seeing many opportunities for voluntourism.\u201d", "title": "How Travelers Can Help Hurricane-Damaged Islands", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-10 00:00:00", "text": "Here\u2019s how it works: The American dollars we use to buy imports are of little use to foreigners outside our borders. They are, however, of great use to foreigners who want to invest within the United States. And that\u2019s what happens with the dollars that aren\u2019t spent on American exports.\n\nForeign investment is key to our economic growth here at home. In other words, we Americans win when we get to buy the stuff we want from abroad and when those dollars are pumped back into our economy.\n\nThis benefit remains intact despite Beijing\u2019s many violations of our trade rules \u2014 such as its subsidization of Chinese steel makers. It\u2019s true that those subsidies artificially lower the price of steel imported by America and might hurt some American steel mills and workers. But this effect is the same as it would be if Chinese steel makers had a genuine efficiency advantage over our producers. Despite the administration\u2019s constant refrain about the devastating impact of foreign export subsidies on the steel industry, experts know that a vastly greater number of steel jobs were lost to innovation, not trade.\n\nEven in the subsidization scenario, we pay for Chinese steel with dollars, and the Chinese then use some of those dollars to buy our exports and use the rest to invest in our country. In both cases, it creates jobs here. The same relationship holds when the Chinese manipulate their currency to stimulate their exports.\n\nSome worry that the Chinese won\u2019t spend their dollars in the United States, but this concern is misplaced. If there were no foreigners who wanted to spend or invest dollars in America, the Chinese would not have exported steel to the United States to begin with. At the end of the day, dollars have value only because they can ultimately be used to buy American-made outputs or be invested in American assets.\n\nIf the Chinese spend their dollars in Japan, the Japanese will turn around and spend their dollars in America, by investing in such things as a brand-new Toyota plant that will employ United States workers. Dollars will always find their way home.\n\nAnother way these dollars make their way back home is through foreign investors who buy Uncle Sam\u2019s debt. As of January 2018, for instance, China has returned $1.17 trillion this way. Overall, about $6.3 trillion of our $15 trillion in public debt is held by foreigners.", "title": "Opinion | How Trump Misunderstands Trade", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-03 00:00:00", "text": "Last week, the Trump administration decided that the next census would ask every person in the country about their citizenship. An uproar followed. Minority communities will bear the most immediate brunt; indeed, some believe that\u2019s the very reason for the change.\n\n\n\nBut the related assumption \u2014 that the decision benefits Republicans \u2014 may be strikingly myopic.\n\nThe Census Bureau collects a lot of information to inform public and private decision making. The most important is what is called the decennial enumeration: a head count, every 10 years, of each and every individual in the country. An accurate census is the Constitution\u2019s first specific job for the federal government, five sentences into our founding charter. It\u2019s the thing that drives political representation and billions of dollars in funding.\n\nTo ensure the accuracy of the constitutionally required count, the decennial enumeration is designed to be minimally intrusive: 10 questions taking 10 minutes or less. For those who in this climate distrust the federal government, adding a question on citizenship makes the head count toxic.\n\nIts intrusion into the census could well have unanticipated consequences for the long-term distribution of power and money. Census results drive both political representation and funding \u2014 for large groups of people in broad areas. This means the decision to roll loaded dice on enumeration does not merely impact undocumented individuals, or permanent residents or minority citizens. Everyone in an area that loses numbers also loses clout and cash.", "title": "Opinion | How Trump\u2019s Citizenship Question May Hurt the G.O.P.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-27 00:00:00", "text": "And by threatening to blow up any deal that does not meet his sometimes inconsistent demands, he may win some concessions at the expense of undermining America\u2019s traditional role as a mediator and convener of negotiations, which Washington has relied on to promote its interests in international forums.\n\nNew Narrative About America?\n\nMr. Trump\u2019s stances on Iran and North Korea appear, at first, difficult to reconcile.\n\nNorth Korea has barreled ahead with its weapons programs, testing nuclear devices as well as long-range missiles that appear capable of striking major American cities. It has achieved what no country has since China developed its own program a half-century ago: a nuclear deterrent against the United States.\n\nTo stall or reverse those gains, Mr. Trump has issued threats and imposed sanctions on North Korea, but for the most part his responses have not been that different from those of previous administrations. His major break with diplomatic orthodoxy was to agree to a direct meeting with North Korea\u2019s leader, Kim Jong-un. The North has long sought such a meeting as a way to portray itself as a peer of the great powers.\n\nAmong Korea experts, Mr. Trump\u2019s approach has won the greatest support from left-leaning doves.\n\nIran, meanwhile, has kept its nuclear program frozen and continues to accept international inspections, according to the international watchdogs and American intelligence officials who have repeatedly said that the country is complying with its obligations under the nuclear deal signed in 2015.\n\nBut Mr. Trump has repeatedly threatened Iran and pledged to withdraw from the agreement or impose sanctions that would abrogate American commitments. He has won cheers from hawks on Iran who oppose the deal.\n\nHow to square these inconsistencies? Within the United States, the most common explanations draw on Mr. Trump\u2019s personality or on domestic politics. Perhaps he opposes the Iran deal because he was not the one to close it, for instance, but he can support a North Korea deal that would bear his signature.\n\nBut foreign states do not have the luxury of shrugging off the American president\u2019s thinking as an inscrutable mystery. They must stitch together a narrative with which to predict future behavior.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe clearest narrative may be that the Americans cannot necessarily be trusted to uphold their commitments \u2014 Mr. Trump has broken or withdrawn from several other international agreements \u2014 but they can be, as Mr. Kim showed, coerced and deterred.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe nuclear lessons may be starker.\n\nDismantle or freeze your program on assurances from the United States, and those assurances may be broken. Accelerate your program in open defiance of international agreements, and the American president will offer to meet with you.\n\nThe Costs of Unpredictability\n\nMr. Trump said on the campaign trail that his businesses had succeeded in part because, in negotiations, he had relied on bluffing, threats to walk out and ruthless, zero-sum transactionalism.\n\nHe had sometimes refused to fully pay contractors, including those working for his campaign. He sued Deutsche Bank in 2008 to escape $40 million in personal loan guarantees. Confronted with a copy of a tax return suggesting that he had not paid federal income tax in some years, Mr. Trump retorted, \u201cThat makes me smart.\u201d\n\nHe has he said would apply his approach in business to foreign relations, pledging to extract maximum concessions even from allies. Unpredictability and threats would keep other leaders guessing, forcing them to deliver concessions, he said.\n\nMr. Trump would not have to look long for countries that have deployed this strategy: Iran and North Korea have pursued more extreme versions for years.\n\nStill, this approach comes with costs. Defense Secretary Jim Mattis said this week of the nuclear agreement with Iran that \u201cit is written almost with an assumption that Iran would try to cheat.\u201d\n\nThe deal, though signed by several world powers, including China and Russia, hands considerable discretion to Washington over when and how to punish any Iranian cheating. In this way, it highlights the difference between how the world treats countries it considers unreliable, like Iran, versus those seen as steady and transparent.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nShould talks with North Korea lead to a written agreement, no one expects its text to treat the United States with the distrust that the 2015 agreement treated Iran.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut it is difficult to imagine America\u2019s allies once again investing Washington with the authority they handed it over Iran.\n\nMr. Trump is asking Washington\u2019s Asian allies to follow his lead on North Korea just as he is defying European allies who are pushing him to stay in the Iran deal. China, which is also a party to the Iran deal, is likely to play a major role in shaping any agreement with North Korea.\n\nTrump administration statements in support of the president\u2019s stance on the Iran deal risk further undermining American efforts with North Korea.\n\nBrian Hook, the State Department policy planning director, told NPR this week that the 2015 agreement signed by Iran and the world powers is \u201ca political commitment by an administration that\u2019s no longer in office.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nThe notion that American commitments made by one administration do not constrain those that follow it implies that any deal Mr. Trump signs with North Korea is good for only three years if he serves one term, seven years if he wins re-election.\n\nPhysical constraints on Iran\u2019s nuclear program, by contrast, last for a minimum of 15 years, which critics like Mr. Trump had deemed woefully insufficient.\n\nLeader or Spoiler?\n\nThere is a reason that the United States has long sought the role of mediator or overseer whenever there is an international crisis, even under a unilateral-minded president like George W. Bush, who convened six-nation talks over North Korea\u2019s nuclear arms program.\n\nThe idea was that the United States would forge a consensus among allies and great powers, then use that consensus as the starting point of talks with whatever rogue state was troubling it.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThis put the United States at the center of the process, ensuring that it would always have a say. If France or Russia wanted some concession or course correction, it had to go through the Americans to get it.\n\nThis state of affairs has required Washington to make frequent compromises to retain the support of other powers for a system anchored to Washington. The United States had to be the rational referee in negotiations, letting other countries issue demands or threaten to walk out.\n\nIncreasingly, the United States is the one issuing demands and threatening to blow up negotiations if they do not satisfy Mr. Trump\u2019s terms.\n\nThis approach does win concessions. European leaders are offering new constraints on Iran.\n\nBut it also gives allies and adversaries incentives to go around the Americans, rather than put them at the center of everything.\n\nSome analysts expect that if Mr. Trump walks away from the Iran deal, the Europeans and Iranians will find some accommodation that excludes him. Washington would lose its leverage over how Iran is held to account.\n\nThis week\u2019s inter-Korean summit meeting also hints at declining American influence over negotiations.\n\nThe Trump administration has demanded that North Korea \u201cdenuclearize\u201d in the sense that the country would immediately and unilaterally surrender its nuclear program. But this week the two Koreas pledged eventual denuclearization of the entire peninsula. Both North and South Korea seem to have ignored Mr. Trump\u2019s demands.\n\nIn the meantime, Mr. Trump shows signs of enjoying his power as international spoiler.\n\nHours before the inter-Korean agreement was released, Mr. Trump wrote on Twitter that he might withdraw American support from any country that \u201cwere to lobby against\u201d his bid for the 2026 soccer World Cup tournament.\n\n\u201cWhy should we be supporting these countries when they don\u2019t support us,\u201d he asked.", "title": "How Trump\u2019s Mixed Signals Complicate America\u2019s Role in the World", "authors": ["Max Fisher", "The Interpreter"]} {"date": "2018-04-18 00:00:00", "text": "This article is part of the Opinion Today newsletter. You can sign up here to receive the newsletter each weekday.\n\nFirst: \u201cShe knew who she was, and she saw no need to apologize for it,\u201d writes the journalist and biographer Jon Meacham, about Barbara Bush. I particularly enjoyed her line about a potential future First Spouse listening to her graduation speech at Wellesley College.\n\nAlso, Christopher Buckley, one of her husband\u2019s old speechwriters, remembers her as \u201cMrs. No-Nonsense,\u201d and The Times obituary, by Enid Nemy, offers a sense of the sweep of Mrs. Bush\u2019s life.\n\nFor anyone inspired to read more, try Richard Ben Cramer\u2019s classic political book, \u201cWhat It Takes.\u201d\n\nThat was then. \u201cAll the evidence we find is that, as a political issue, it is falling flat, influencing very few votes, if any.\u201d So said NBC\u2019s David Brinkley on the air in 1972, referring to the story known as Watergate.", "title": "Opinion | How Trump\u2019s Scandals Mimic Watergate", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-30 00:00:00", "text": "When T-Mobile and Sprint aggressively competed for budget-conscious customers and began gaining subscribers with lower prices, AT&T and Verizon ended up following suit.\n\nWhat other changes might I see as a wireless subscriber?\n\nBeyond lower prices, T-Mobile has been a driving force behind giving consumers more flexibility. Since 2014, T-Mobile has let consumers forgo long-term contracts and allowed users to bring the devices of their choice to its network. It eliminated roaming charges in Canada and Mexico and promised no surprise fees or taxes in its monthly bills.\n\nPhoto\n\nThose policies were praised by government officials as proof positive that a four-way competition among the big carriers had been the right decision. They called T-Mobile a \u201cmaverick\u201d in the wireless industry. (T-Mobile and Sprint say they would continue to offer similar policies.)\n\nBut the question is whether T-Mobile would still have the incentive to be as scrappy after the merger \u2014 when it would look a lot like the big telecom providers it was forced to contend with as an aggressive upstart.\n\n\u201cThe biggest problem with this merger is that these two companies are each other\u2019s biggest competitors for serving middle-income, budget-constrained wireless customers,\u201d said Gene Kimmelman, a former senior antitrust official at the Justice Department who was at the department when it sued to block AT&T\u2019s proposed merger with T-Mobile in 2011.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nWill the company be more like T-Mobile or Sprint after the merger?\n\nThe combined company would be called T-Mobile, and have T-Mobile\u2019s attention-grabbing chief executive, John Legere, in charge. The main headquarters would be at T-Mobile\u2019s offices in Bellevue, Wash., with a second headquarters at Sprint\u2019s offices in Overland Park, Kan.\n\nBut the new company would be a combination of different cultures. T-Mobile has ranked at the top of recent customer satisfaction surveys, and Sprint has often lagged behind its rivals in customers\u2019 minds. T-Mobile has invested heavily in marketing itself as an industry rebel, with Mr. Legere out in front, insulting Verizon and AT&T on Twitter. Sprint, on the other hand, is much more reserved, and its customers aren\u2019t likely to follow its executives on social media.\n\nHow will the merger affect my service? Will I experience technical problems when the networks are combined?\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nCustomers of the combined company would have greater coverage across the country, especially those in rural areas whose current provider would get a boost from the other company\u2019s towers.\n\nAnd even if regulators scuttle the merger, the companies said they had struck a roaming agreement that will allow customers of either company to use the other company\u2019s network.\n\nThe roaming agreement also helps the companies prepare to merge their infrastructure in the event the deal goes through, although it\u2019s hard to say that customers wouldn\u2019t experience some glitches in service. The companies haven\u2019t revealed any details on what kinds of service plans would be offered and what devices would be permitted. And billing and customer service would also have be consolidated, which could be a tricky transition.", "title": "How Would a T-Mobile-Sprint Merger Affect Your Cellphone Bill?", "authors": ["Cecilia Kang", "Michael J. De La Merced"]} {"date": "2018-04-29 00:00:00", "text": "As with many of our behaviors we can\u2019t see ourselves, knowing that we are vulnerable to this trap is the first step toward overcoming it. But we can also train ourselves to be more attentive to signs that we\u2019re placing trust in someone just because we perceive them to be trustworthy or knowledgeable.\n\nMost important: Learn to catch yourself and take a step back when you notice that you\u2019re going along with people who only feel authoritative \u2014 either because they project confidence or dominate the conversation \u2014 and ask yourself whether they truly are trustworthy. Do they have the credentials to back up their claims? Do they talk their way around specific questions rather than address them head-on? (Khalil calls this strategy \u201cif-then plans\u201d: If you catch yourself gravitating toward someone extroverted and loud, then seek another opinion.)\n\nTwo other sound strategies are ideas we\u2019ve covered before in this newsletter. First, relentlessly seek outside input \u2014 oftentimes that can be as simple as asking a friend, \u201cIs my trust misplaced here?\u201d Second, never stop learning, because the more knowledgeable you are about something, the more likely you are to know when someone\u2019s faking it.\n\nThese biases are just part of life. But being aware of them can mean you\u2019re able to find paths around them.\n\nTrust me.\n\n\u2014 Tim\n\nBest of Smarter Living\n\n5 Cheap(ish) Things You Need for Summer Travel Season Time to hit the road!\n\nLocking Up Your Lock Screen If your Windows 10 lock screen changes daily or slows you down in getting to your desktop, you can change its behavior.\n\nHow to Tell a Story The stories we tell are how we know who we are. Here\u2019s how to do it right.\n\nSmartphone Apps for Spontaneous Travel While travelers have long been able to set up airfare alerts, these apps go a step further in helping flexible travelers plan a last-minute trip.\n\nStanding Up at Your Desk Could Make You Smarter We knew sitting too much was bad for the body. Now we know it\u2019s bad for the brain.", "title": "How Your Brain Can Trick You Into Trusting People", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-24 00:00:00", "text": "The Sienese have fierce loyalty to their neighborhoods, or contrade. Since there was, historically, only one hospital, in one contrada, people from the others would bring some dirt from their own neighborhood into the delivery room for births.\n\nThat\u2019s what led me to think about having the baby born on Texas soil, contrada style. I got dirt from various parts of the state, including my hometown, Galveston. A friend also sent some \u2014 he said he chipped a piece off the Alamo, too, but I don\u2019t believe him. The resulting mixture fit into a baggie.\n\nWhen I asked the doctor about bringing it into the hospital, she was, luckily enough, charmed. She\u2019s Italian. She said it would be fine so long as it was in a sterile container and under the delivery table.\n\nUnfortunately, that baby, Elizabeth, was born without the benefit of the dirt, because she was delivered in an emergency procedure and I was stuck in traffic trying to get to the hospital. The dirt was the least of our worries. (She\u2019s fine. She\u2019s 30 now, with a daughter of her own. Who was born in Texas!)\n\nBeing born over a baggie confers no official status, of course. But I was able to get a friendly member of the Texas State Senate to pass a resolution that mentioned the dirt and declared Elizabeth \u201ca child of the Lone Star State.\u201d (The resolution did not, alas, declare her eligible for in-state tuition.)\n\nI held on to the bag, which was present for the births of our second and third children, born in 1990 and 1996, in New York and Maryland; they got resolutions, too. Resolutions are fairly easy to get when your father is a former member of the State Senate.\n\nThe much-traveled bag of dirt has taken on a life of its own.\n\nMy friends Jay and Alice had their first child at St. Vincent\u2019s in New York City. Jay, born in El Paso, called the night of the delivery and asked if I could bring it to him. I raced downtown. He stepped out of the delivery room to meet me in a hospital hallway. I tossed the bag. He snapped it out of the air and ran back to the delivery room.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nLast October, the Times Metro reporter Emma Fitzsimmons borrowed the bag for the birth of her first child, Hudson. Her dad wrapped the bag in a little Texas flag and, she tells me, \u201ctouched the flag to his cute little baby toes within a few hours of his birth so that he would \u2018step foot on Texas soil before any other.\u2019\u201d\n\nMore recently, the dirt made its way into the hospital room of the Times business reporter Amy Chozick, a San Antonio Rose, to help Texanize the birth of Cormac Aidan Ennis.\n\nThe dirt stands ready to serve any of my other Texpatriates.\n\nAnd I held on to the Texas flag wrapper that Emma\u2019s dad provided, so it looks classier now. After all, there are worse ways to start out in life than with this slightly silly but meaningful ritual.", "title": "How a Bag of Texas Dirt Became a Times Tradition", "authors": ["John Schwartz"]} {"date": "2018-04-03 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nThere are few dull moments during the N.C.A.A. tournament, and therefore few opportunities for a dulled mind. But on a Friday night last month, I chanced a beer at a restaurant in Pittsburgh. I sat at a cafe and did some work. I also kept an eye on the games, which I streamed to my laptop.\n\nVirginia was trailing \u2014 a novel departure from No. 1 seeds\u2019 rote first-round games. Since the tournament expanded in 1985, these top-seeded teams had not lost once. I congratulated myself on having prewritten a column on why the Cavaliers could not make a deep run. We were just waiting for the right moment to publish it.\n\nYou likely know what happened next. Virginia never came back. They were beaten by the Retrievers of the University of Maryland, Baltimore County \u2014 the first No. 16 seed ever to win against a No. 1 seed in 136 tries, an accomplishment similar to breaking the sound barrier. With five minutes to go in the game, late on a Friday night, I was on the phone with my editor, figuring out how to hastily rewrite the prewritten column to explain the upset. And my editor had an imprecation: \u201cGet to Baltimore tomorrow.\u201d\n\nFor few is March as mad as for the sportswriters. I travel to a minimum of three sites, one for each weekend of the tournament. Often I supplement this travel with a conference tournament the week before Selection Sunday (I have been to Nashville and Kansas City, Mo., for these) or to sites in between weekends to report tournament-related stories (like last year, when I sneaked in a trip to Asheville, N.C., before the Final Four to write about North Carolina Coach Roy Williams\u2019s accent). Both last year and this year I left for a site a day early to avoid a blizzard in New York. This has been my fourth men\u2019s N.C.A.A. tournament. As of Tuesday I will have spent 18 of the past 20 nights on the road; in 2015, it was 22 of 25.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nEvery year I go in with a handful of ideas and narratives. Then events blow them up. The Saturday morning after the Virginia loss, for the first time I left a site before its games were all played. I drove in a newly rented car across most of Pennsylvania, arrived at U.M.B.C.\u2019s campus in the midafternoon, and proceeded to report, write and file a story on the campus scene one day later (it was spring break; there may have been more geese than students). The next morning, I flew down to Charlotte, N.C., to catch the Retrievers\u2019 second-round game.", "title": "How a College Basketball Reporter Keeps Up With the Madness", "authors": ["Marc Tracy"]} {"date": "2018-04-17 00:00:00", "text": "It is rare that a new organism is introduced as a model for study in biology, but Dr. Parker thinks rove beetles have the potential to answer questions about evolution that other insects, like the ubiquitous fruit fly, Drosophila melanogaster, do not.\n\n\u201cAs valuable as knowing everything about Drosophila is, it\u2019s not the whole universe,\u201d he said.\n\nExcerpts of a telephone conversation with Dr. Parker are below, edited for clarity and length.\n\n\n\nQ. How old were you when rove beetles became your passion?\n\nA: Seven years old was when I started. All of the rest of the world fell away and it was just me and insects. Growing up in the U.K., we don\u2019t really have big, flashy insects, so you end up collecting what you find around you and that\u2019s often quite small beetles that live in dirt and a lot of those are rove beetles.\n\nOne of the first things you learn about rove beetles is that they have this amazing evolutionary tendency to become symbiotic inside ant colonies. And when they do this, their behavior and their anatomy change, and they become what we call social parasites. These are intruder organisms that are able to bypass or kind of hijack ant nest mate recognition systems and integrate socially into the organization of ant colonies and they do this to termites as well.\n\nQ. So you stuck with the rove beetles?\n\nA. They\u2019re a fascinating group of organisms for studying how interactions between different species can evolve because they\u2019ve been able to do it so many times during their evolutionary history. They\u2019re able to socially interact with ants and they are able to produce chemicals that can manipulate ant behavior, so they can integrate into the fabric of ant society.", "title": "How a Common Beetle May Offer Deep Insights Into Evolution", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-26 00:00:00", "text": "SACRAMENTO \u2014 The Golden State Killer raped and murdered victims across California in an era before Google searches and social media, a time when the police relied on shoe leather, not cellphone records or big data.\n\nBut it was technology that got him. The suspect, Joseph James DeAngelo, 72, was arrested by the police on Tuesday. Investigators accuse him of committing more than 50 rapes and 12 murders over decades.\n\nInvestigators used DNA from crime scenes that had been stored all these years and plugged the genetic profile of the suspected assailant into an online genealogy database. One such service, GEDmatch, said in a statement on Friday that law enforcement officials had used its database to crack the case. Officers found distant relatives of Mr. DeAngelo\u2019s and, despite his years of eluding the authorities, traced their DNA to his front door.\n\n\u201cWe found a person that was the right age and lived in this area \u2014 and that was Mr. DeAngelo,\u201d said Steve Grippi, the assistant chief in the Sacramento district attorney\u2019s office.", "title": "How a Genealogy Site Led to the Front Door of the Golden State Killer Suspect", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-06 00:00:00", "text": "In the early 90s, as prominent dissidents such as Mr. Havel and Lech Walesa in Poland entered office, it was widely assumed that the region would transition naturally into democratic states and market economies. Voters expected that living standards would soon match those in Western Europe \u2014 especially as many former communist countries moved to join the European Union.\n\nPersonal freedoms and wealth did increase, but the chaotic nature of the process, compounded by the global financial crisis in 2008, meant that expectations often outpaced progress. In some countries, the privatization of state assets was perceived as benefiting foreign investors and corrupt politicians more often than it did ordinary citizens.\n\nPhoto\n\nPoliticians sensed the mood, and shifted rightward. The current Czech president, Milos Zeman, was a liberal-minded dissident in the dying years of communism but now courts the far right. His prime minister, Andrej Babis, was never a freedom fighter but was elected last year on a populist platform attacking the perceived failings of the post-1989 political elite.\n\nIn Poland, the leader of the governing party, Jaroslaw Kaczynski, is a conservative who was once ostracized by the early leaders of post-communist Poland. But his nativist, autocratic ideas have gained currency as resentment over aspects of the transition set in when voters\u2019 aspirations exceeded the pace of social and economic change.\n\n\u201cKaczynski is a master of playing on bad emotions,\u201d said Radoslaw Sikorski, who was foreign minister and speaker of the Polish Parliament during the government that preceded Mr. Kaczynski\u2019s.\n\nBut no one exemplifies the angry direction of post-communist Eastern Europe more than Viktor Orban, whose journey from liberal academic to illiberal populist is starker than any of his regional contemporaries. He used the Soros grant to study the history of civil society at Oxford University, fought communism as a dissident from behind the Iron Curtain and then, as a center-right politician, helped to steer Hungary into the European Union and NATO.\n\nNow Mr. Orban is a populist hero to Stephen K. Bannon, President Trump\u2019s former strategist, and the self-declared leader of a \u201ccultural counterrevolution\u201d that is dividing the European bloc he once fought to join.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cThe worst nightmare, in terms of Orban-ism spreading, has come true,\u201d said Gerald Knaus, the director of the European Stability Initiative, a Berlin-based research group.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe young Mr. Orban was a passionate dissident, famous for a 1988 speech in which he demanded that Soviet troops leave Hungarian soil. At another rally, Mr. Orban risked his life to protect another opposition leader, Gaspar Miklos Tamas, taking several blows to his head as he thrust himself between the police and Mr. Tamas.\n\nHe gave little hint of his future trajectory \u2014 save a cameo role in a student production of the German Absurdist drama \u201cHow Mr. Mockinpott Was Cured of His Sufferings\u201d, in which he played a demagogue.\n\n\u201cIt was not his aim to be a politician,\u201d said Gabor Fodor, Mr. Orban\u2019s former roommate and best friend. \u201cHe wanted to be an intellectual and to be a member of Hungarian intellectual circles.\u201d\n\nThat all began to shift in 1990, with the approach of Hungary\u2019s first democratic elections in half a century. Mr. Orban had co-founded a liberal youth group, Fidesz, that was reconstituted as a political party and won 22 seats in the new Parliament.\n\nAppointed as the party\u2019s leader, Mr. Orban spoke out against nationalism, defended civil society and opposed clerical influence in politics. But behind the scenes, his political ideology was beginning to morph \u2014 and he was beginning to exert greater control on the management of Fidesz.\n\nBy 1993, Mr. Orban had assumed overall leadership of Fidesz, redefined it as a more nationalist and centrist party and ruthlessly sidelined its liberal faction, headed by his now former friend, Gabor Fodor.\n\nQuite why Mr. Orban changed is a matter of debate. Some contemporaries believe it was the genuine ideological shift of a young man whose politics were a work in progress. Others argue he grew resentful of cosmopolitan liberals.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nBut most feel that Mr. Orban\u2019s transition was a pragmatic response to the landscape of Hungarian politics. Overshadowed by other left-of-center parties, Fidesz lacked a clear brand. By tacking toward the political center, Mr. Orban reckoned that his party could stand out.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nUnlike most other Hungarian politicians of the time, Mr. Orban \u201cthought about politics in a more professional way,\u201d said Zsuzsanna Szelenyi, one of the Fidesz lawmakers sidelined by Mr. Orban in 1993. \u201cHe realized it was about power.\u201d\n\nDespite Mr. Orban\u2019s machinations, Fidesz did poorly in the 1994 elections. He responded by shifting further to the right, turning Fidesz into a center-right Christian democratic party \u2014 one still open to Western and American ideals.\n\n\u201cThe 1990s were wonderful for American diplomats,\u201d said Donald Blinken, who, as the American ambassador to Hungary from 1994 to 1997, lunched annually with Mr. Orban. \u201cEveryone loved us, the Cold War was won, and we thought it was this great period of peace and prosperity.\u201d\n\nBut Mr. Orban kept growing more nationalistic \u2014 and, apparently, more religious.\n\nMarried in a civil wedding a decade earlier, Mr. Orban and his wife, Aniko Levai, renewed their vows in a religious ceremony in 1996. Gabor Ivanyi, the pastor who performed that second ceremony, has since become skeptical of Mr. Orban\u2019s motivations. \u201cHe had to convince people, to win over the conservative right,\u201d Mr. Ivanyi said. \u201cHe is an unscrupulous person.\u201d\n\nMr. Orban finally assumed power in 1998, becoming prime minister for the first time at the head of a conservative coalition. (Voters were angered by the Socialist-led government\u2019s handling of the struggling economy.)\n\nFor the next four years, Mr. Orban operated as a relatively orthodox center-right politician. His administration was tainted by minor corruption scandals, but his performance was mostly praised.\n\nHe brought Hungary to the brink of European Union membership and shepherded the country into NATO, an event he celebrated with a private dinner in Brussels attended by several of his mentors, including Zbigniew Pelczynski, his politics professor at Oxford.\n\nIt was his defeat in the 2002 elections that accelerated his pivot to the far right.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cThey say that power spoils good politicians,\u201d said Jozsef Debreczeni, an adviser to Mr. Orban after his first rightward turn \u2014 and later his biographer. \u201cWith Orban that wasn\u2019t the case. It was the loss of power that did that.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nDuring an intense one-and-a-half days after the election, Mr. Debreczeni listened as Mr. Orban blamed his political demise on a partisan news media that needed to be reined in.\n\nMr. Debreczeni said that Mr. Orban had drawn one conclusion: \u201cThis democracy thing, where power can slip so quickly from you, was no good.\u201d\n\n\u201cAnd from that point on,\u201d Mr. Debreczeni added, \u201che spent his time preparing so that if he ever won power again, he wouldn\u2019t lose it.\u201d\n\nThe global financial crisis of 2008, coupled with increasing resentment of the Socialist-led government, eventually gave Mr. Orban that chance. The Socialists, who were also in power during the economic turmoil of the 1990s, were accused of squandering the political and economic potential of the transition from communism.\n\nMr. Orban reinvented himself as an outsider who promised to restore Hungarian control to an economy buffeted by external forces \u2014 a popular policy among Hungarians rankled by how privatization efforts after 1989 had allowed foreigners to take over parts of Hungarian industry.\n\n\u201cTo understand the Orban phenomenon, you have to go back to 1989,\u201d said Laszlo Andor, who was once Hungary\u2019s most senior representative at the European Commission, the European Union\u2019s executive arm. \u201cPeople\u2019s ambitions were not fulfilled.\u201d\n\nElected by a landslide in 2010, Mr. Orban has steadily weakened Hungary\u2019s democratic institutions while invoking the self-contradictory concept of \u201cilliberal democracy\u201d and hailing the autocratic governments of Vladimir V. Putin of Russia and Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey.\n\nTo outflank a major far-right opposition party, Jobbik, he tacked further to the right on immigration. By 2015, Mr. Orban had cajoled several Central and East European countries to block the European Union\u2019s efforts to resettle thousands of migrants fleeing violence elsewhere \u2014 and provided a template for a democratic backslide in Poland.\n\nPhoto\n\nHis influence then crept further west. He forged an alliance with Horst Seehofer, the new German interior minister; appeared with Geert Wilders, the Dutch nationalist politician; and became a frequent subject of praise during recent election campaigns in Austria that ended with a far-right party joining a coalition government.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Orban sees all this as nothing less than the march of history.\n\n\u201cWhat we are experiencing now is the end of an era: a conceptual-ideological era,\u201d he said in a major speech in 2015, as he began to expand his international profile. \u201cPutting pretension aside, we can simply call this the era of liberal babble.\u201d", "title": "How a Liberal Dissident Became a Far-Right Hero, in Hungary and Beyond", "authors": ["Patrick Kingsley"]} {"date": "2018-04-25 00:00:00", "text": "What are some of your favorite tech tools in general?\n\nOne is the Apple Watch. While I was initially skeptical, I really like how it allows me to be more present in conversations and look at my phone less during the day. It will alert me when I have a meeting coming up. Texts come right to me, which lessens the odds of missing important messages. I also like how it logs the distance of my runs. It would be great to have it be more independent of the phone, though. I haven\u2019t upgraded to the new one, but I may have to.\n\nBattery life is a constant challenge for me, and I know that the new iPhone would help, but I\u2019ve only had mine for a year and it would feel a bit wasteful ditching it. I\u2019ve also been trying out the Huawei Mate 10 Pro phone, which has a significantly longer battery life with two cameras and a processor that uses artificial intelligence to improve the user experience.\n\nI\u2019ve been trying to talk my husband and kids into getting a digital assistant like Alexa. But they are concerned about privacy, and I don\u2019t want to be in the position of imposing more tech on my kids! I think that people will need more guarantees about privacy before they fully embrace digital assistants.\n\nPhoto\n\nWhat are the most important tech trends to follow in the coming years?\n\nI think that artificial intelligence is going to fundamentally change the way we work and live. It won\u2019t replace humans, but it will change the majority of their jobs by eliminating rote parts of work. How exactly this plays out will have tremendous implications for society.\n\nThe battle between Detroit and Silicon Valley over the future of cars is epic. Billions of dollars will be won or lost, and the outcome will have big implications for work, especially in the Midwestern states where the traditional automakers still have most of their operations. Cars have already essentially become computers on wheels, and that will only continue as more autonomous features are added.\n\nBut I believe that electric cars will become far more widespread before fully autonomous driving. We recently bought a Chevy Volt and have been very impressed with the torque of the electric motor and the battery\u2019s 45-mile range before the gas engine takes over. I used to cover the auto industry in Detroit, and I think it\u2019s important to try out new things.\n\nI\u2019m also a firm believer that the spread of technology \u2014 what some call the fourth industrial revolution \u2014 will give opportunities to millions of people around the globe. We need to stop thinking of Silicon Valley and New York as the centers of the world; there are now many others. China, in particular, has emerged as a hotbed of tech innovation. It has 700 million internet users and 50 times the number of people using mobile payments as the United States.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nYou\u2019ve been building up The Times\u2019s conferences and live events. How important is tech to the success of these events?\n\nPhoto\n\nThe heart of a successful event is the quality of the interviews and the conversation. Live events are a way to bring journalism to life \u2014 I call it live journalism. While many people want to dive into a 4,000-word investigative story, even more could learn about the findings through a video of an interview with the reporter.\n\nWe increasingly tap Facebook Live and other social media to make our events more interactive and to include those not fortunate enough to be in the room.\n\nI\u2019m also struck by how important live events are. We have more information at our fingertips than ever before. Yet more than ever we also need events that help us meet that person we otherwise wouldn\u2019t have. This is a phenomena that has been well explained by my friend Priya Parker in her coming book, \u201cThe Art of Gathering.\u201d\n\nWhat tech products are your children currently obsessed with?\n\nI have three kids, and they teach me an enormous amount about the future of technology.\n\nThe two youngest, ages 14 and 17, are very into Snapchat. I delayed getting my daughter an iPhone for years, but gave in when she turned 13. She and her friends don\u2019t talk on the phone. They Snap.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story How Do You Use Tech? Advice and tips on the technology changing how you live. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box.
