Please email thoughts and suggestions to bizday@nytimes.com.", "title": "How the Sprint Deal is a Feather in T-Mobile C.E.O.\u2019s Cap: DealBook Briefing", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-18 00:00:00", "text": "No one should need an excuse to indulge her David Bowie fashion fantasies, but there has never been a more fitting time to channel the glam-rocker. The \u201cDavid Bowie Is\u201d exhibition at the Brooklyn Museum, which runs through July 15, offers unrivaled access to Bowie\u2019s personal archive, including 60 custom-made performance costumes that are bound to kick up some inspirational sartorial sparks.\n\nThere\u2019s something about the whiff of gender-neutral maximalism now sweeping fashion, from bigwigs like Gucci to upstarts like Area, that makes Bowie\u2019s pioneering style feel newly relevant. So, in honor of the true original, and in celebration of the last stop in the five-year world tour of \u201cDavid Bowie Is,\u201d step into those mega-high platforms and pile on the glitter.", "title": "How to Be a Rebel Rebel", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-11 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\n\u201cYou can be 4 feet 10 inches tall and 110 pounds soaking wet and still pick someone up,\u201d says Sgt. First Class Nathan Lethgo, who oversees daily operations at the Army\u2019s largest combat-medic training center, near San Antonio. During two deployments to Iraq and one to Afghanistan, Lethgo trained local soldiers and police officers in basic first aid, including hoisting the injured and unconscious. \u201cFirst ask, \u2018Does this person really need to be moved?\u2019 \u201d Lethgo says.\n\nTo answer that question, you need what those in the military call \u201csituational awareness,\u201d or a rapid assessment of the scene using all your senses: Where are potential hazards? Is the person bleeding? Breathing? What made him or her unconscious? Are others nearby who could help? \u201cDon\u2019t take forever with it,\u201d Lethgo says, but make sure the person actually needs to be carried. \u201cDragging somebody is not a bad option,\u201d he says, especially if you\u2019re smaller and don\u2019t have far to go. If you\u2019re alone and you must move an inert body more than, say, 200 feet to safety, Lethgo recommends what\u2019s called the pack-strap carry, which looks something like a piggyback ride.\n\nRoll the individual onto his or her back, and push the person into a seated position. \u201cReach around and give them a big old bear hug from behind,\u201d Lethgo says. Grab a wrist. Carefully lift the person to a standing position using your legs, not your back. \u201cLock their knees out,\u201d says Lethgo, which will help keep the person upright as you maneuver to the front side. Put your back against the chest. Holding a wrist in each hand, bend your knees and pull up until the person\u2019s armpits are over your shoulders. Draw the arms down and in close to your body to keep them in place. \u201cLean forward slightly in the direction of travel, and then move,\u201d Lethgo says. Once your load is aloft, don\u2019t stall for even a second; transporting a slack, full-size human will tax every muscle in your body. Have a plan before you even touch the individual, because once he or she is your cargo, you are responsible for that person. \u201cIf you move them,\u201d Lethgo says, \u201cyou own them until you get them the help they need.\u201d", "title": "How to Carry Someone Who Is Unconscious", "authors": ["Malia Wollan"]} {"date": "2018-04-06 00:00:00", "text": "The bottom line is that the decisions made during loan servicing matter enormously to the financial well-being of millions of people. Market pressures alone won\u2019t improve the student loan industry because borrowers are locked to the servicer selected for them by the government and can\u2019t vote with their feet.\n\nThis leaves the government as the only real hope for keeping servicers in line. Yet the Trump administration has scaled back oversight of the loan companies. The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, which acted as a loan watchdog under the Obama administration, has been relatively quiescent the past year. In fact, Mick Mulvaney, its new director, is seeking legislation that would weaken the agency.\n\nIn the absence of federal action, some states have stepped in to protect borrowers. But in response to industry complaints, the secretary of education, Betsy DeVos, has warned state regulators not to supervise loan companies, claiming her department has sole jurisdiction over them. Even if the states continue to persevere, their actions won\u2019t substitute for comprehensive federal oversight.\n\nWhat\u2019s the solution? We could make the loan system less difficult for borrowers to navigate. In particular, borrowers should be enrolled automatically in an income-based program if they fall behind on their payments. The lengthy process for enrolling and staying in these programs should be simplified, with tax records used to automatically determine payments.\n\nEven better would be a system of payroll withholding, like those in England and Australia, where loan payments automatically fluctuate with earnings. Some people oppose this approach, arguing that payroll deduction elevates student loans over food and rent as payment priorities. But this misses the strongest protection of payroll withholding: It automatically cuts payments to zero when earnings drop low enough, putting loans at the bottom of the payment hierarchy.\n\nAs it is, we have a punishing system of garnishment in place for student loans. In 2017, the blandly named Treasury Offset Program seized $2.8 billion from student borrowers who were in default. These funds were taken from federal earned-income tax credit, Black Lung Benefits and Social Security payments that would have gone to retired, disabled or deceased workers and their families.\n\nIt makes little sense to have the federal government seize money from these most vulnerable families while shying away from a sensible system of payroll withholding for active workers.", "title": "How to Clean Up the Student Loan Mess", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-18 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cApply pressure where the blood is coming out,\u201d says Christopher B. Colwell, the chief of emergency medicine at Zuckerberg San Francisco General Hospital and Trauma Center. You may need to remove or rip open some of the victim\u2019s clothing to access the injury. \u201cGrab a shirt, a towel, a fabric bag \u2014 it doesn\u2019t have to be clean,\u201d Colwell says. Put the cloth over the wound, and push down continuously and forcefully on it with both hands until the bleeding stops.\n\nIf you see blood spurting, pooling or rapidly soaking through clothing, consider the situation life-threatening. Uncontrolled bleeding is the primary cause of preventable death from trauma. Of the American military personnel who died on the battlefield between 2001 and 2011, researchers found that nearly a quarter were bleed-out deaths that were \u201cpotentially survivable.\u201d \u201cYou don\u2019t need extensive training to save a life,\u201d Colwell says. Move quickly; a severed main vessel near the heart or in the groin can result in death within minutes, but with arms and leg injuries you\u2019ll often have more time. You may need to put your hands inside the gash. Try to avoid getting blood in your eyes or mouth, but don\u2019t fret about disease as long as you don\u2019t have open wounds on your own hands. \u201cThe risk to you is very low, and the benefit to somebody who\u2019s bleeding rapidly is very high,\u201d Colwell says.\n\nIf you\u2019ve been compressing the wound for 20 or 30 seconds and it\u2019s still bleeding heavily, you need to use a tourniquet. Colwell keeps a first-aid tourniquet in his car and would like to see them placed in schools, stadiums and every large building. Until then, you\u2019ll probably have to improvise. A belt works, as does a tie, shoelaces, even a bra. Place the tourniquet an inch or so higher than the wound and tighten until the bleeding stops. If you\u2019re the injured one, you can compress and tourniquet your own wound.\n\nColwell has seen people bleed to death when they might have been saved. He was the on-scene physician after the shooting at Columbine High School; he worked in an E.R. that received victims of the movie-theater shooting in Aurora, Colo. Anticipate \u2014 and resist \u2014 the woozy fright often triggered by a profusion of blood. \u201cDon\u2019t be afraid to act,\u201d Colwell says.", "title": "How to Control Bleeding", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-17 00:00:00", "text": "In retrospect, 2017 was an extraordinary time for investors. The American stock market rose steadily, and it never declined sharply, not even once. It was easy to make money in stocks, and to do so with relatively little skill or worry.\n\nThat\u2019s not what it has been like so far this year. Stocks have been bouncing up and down, and while they haven\u2019t really fallen that much by historical standards, the nine-year-old bull market stumbled in February and hasn\u2019t entirely recovered. Bonds, which are typically a source of stability when stocks fall, lost ground, too, though not as much as stocks.\n\nStill, even for people with diversified portfolios and a long-term outlook, 2018 has been a trying time. This may be a good moment to get some perspective.\n\nWe\u2019ve chosen nine articles with reporting and analysis on where the markets have been and some clues on where they may be heading. As always in these quarterly reports, the selection provides an introduction to investing. And we hope that at least some of these articles will entertain you as well.", "title": "How to Cope When the Market Turns Nasty", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-04 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\n\u201cIt takes 20 years to get good at it,\u201d says Francesco Therisod, 71, who has been a safecracker in Providence, R.I., for nearly 40 years. To know what you\u2019re up against, research the safe\u2019s manufacturer, make, model and materials. At a minimum, you\u2019ll need a drill; diamond and tungsten carbide drill bits, capable of boring into reinforced metals; an optical device called a borescope; and a stethoscope.\n\nPut your stethoscope over the lock as if it were a heart. As you turn the dial, try to feel and hear the notches lining up on the series of interlocking wheels inside. This is what locksmiths call \u201cmanipulation,\u201d and it\u2019s considered the purest form of safecracking. If that doesn\u2019t work, drill a hole next to the lock, and insert your borescope to line up the notches by sight. If you\u2019re not in a hurry, a robotic dialer can be attached to the safe that automatically tries every possible combination. Use brute force \u2014 cutting through the container with an oxyacetylene torch, say \u2014 as a last resort. That can be dangerous and trigger the anti-theft technology in some safes, like relocking mechanisms or even embedded tear-gas canisters.\n\nAny items inside will tend to be valuable, lethal, unlawful or contested. Therisod, who mostly gets calls to work on mechanical safes with forgotten or long-lost combinations, has been hired by siblings feuding over estates, quarreling couples and federal law-enforcement officials. Sometimes multiple parties watch him work with their respective attorneys in tow. People are not always their best selves around safes. Therisod has seen safes full of guns or brimming with narcotics. If you\u2019re cracking a safe for others, always let them open the door to protect yourself from accusations of theft.\n\nBe forewarned: The vast majority of the time, an abandoned safe is empty. \u201cI tell people, 99 times out of 100 there\u2019s nothing inside,\u201d Therisod says. But humans are curious, covetous and prone to disregard terrible odds. Most opt to open a locked safe anyway, sometimes at significant cost. On a few occasions, Therisod has uncovered valuables, including stacks of cash, jewelry and gems. He has also, when he cracked a bank\u2019s safe deposit box, found a fish decomposing in a plastic bag. \u201cI smelled it before I saw it,\u201d he says.", "title": "How to Crack a Safe", "authors": ["Malia Wollan"]} {"date": "2018-04-27 00:00:00", "text": "Tom Camp, 77, is a U.P.S. delivery driver in Livonia, Michigan.\n\nHow did you become a professional truck driver?\n\nI came out of the service \u2014 the Marine Corps \u2014 in 1961 and needed a job. There was a kind of recession going on. I had no driving experience, but I found work delivering packages during Christmas. After the holidays, I was unemployed again.\n\nI heard about U.P.S. from a friend. I had a driving test on a Friday, and on Tuesday I was driving. I\u2019ve been doing it since 1962.\n\nHas behavior on the roads changed since the early \u201960s?\n\nDriving has gotten worse. The guidelines are basically the same, but there is much more traffic out there. Everyone is in such a hurry. There isn\u2019t courtesy among drivers anymore. It seems to be a lost art. Some drivers are so bad, they don\u2019t even put turn signals on. Where did those people learn how to drive? How did they even get out of driving school?", "title": "How to Deliver Packages Safely, for 55 Years", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-14 00:00:00", "text": "6. Take note of their other worries. All immigrants are afraid of not making it. They\u2019ve washed dishes in restaurants or tended the counter of a gas station. They\u2019ve experienced dislocation, heartsickness and uncertainty. They want to spare you that life. But remember that you can navigate the world in ways unimaginable to them.\n\n7. If, at any moment, you feel yourself expecting understanding from them, stop. Ask yourself: Why do I need it? Accept that you may never get it. Transcendent perfect understanding, as a goal, is out of the question. Maybe you\u2019re thinking, but I know a family like that! They\u2019re the nicest! Consider: Doesn\u2019t the child seem weirdly lacking in edge? A little too well adjusted and cheerful? (Note: These are the perfect people to marry; marry them.) Your parents gave you this edge. Because of your relationship, you know how to fight \u2014 you know how to articulate what you believe and withstand skepticism. You\u2019ll thank them some day.\n\n8. If you hope to deepen your relationship, ask them questions. What did they want to become when they were younger? What was the political situation? Was it a just world? What was hard about coming here? If you don\u2019t know their native tongue, try to speak it, even if that means you have to fumble and be uncomfortable. (Welcome to their lives!) If your parents tell you not to bother learning their language, this should break your heart.\n\n9. Remember that what persuades them is your stability. By definition, that takes years to prove. On some profound level, they know they can\u2019t argue with the fact that you\u2019re happy.\n\n10. But you may not, in fact, find happiness. You may not like the choices you believed they failed to understand \u2014 it may be you who fails. Prepare yourself for what they will say. Thought you could change the world? Thought you could do what you love and still pay rent? We told you so!\n\n11. Let them say it.\n\n12. In theory, parents know you most intimately. In practice, they often have no idea how much they hurt you. They feel, rather, that it is you who have hurt them. And this impasse is painful, because in a battle where both feel betrayed, victory is Pyrrhic.\n\n13. I wish I could say: You can disobey them and win their love. I wish I could promise you that your choices are the right ones, and that you won\u2019t come to doubt them. But winning and certainty are actually not the point. The point is: Do you believe that failure is yours to have, rather than theirs to fear?\n\n14. Have faith. There is a long game. They might never see things the way you do, and that\u2019s O.K. Show them love as best you can. Show up for them, and the things that they care about, in the ways that you are able. After all, when you were a baby, they bathed you, wiped your nose, cut your food into tiny little chunks so that you wouldn\u2019t choke and fed the stuff straight into your mouth. And someday, maybe you\u2019ll get to do that for them.", "title": "Opinion | How to Disobey Your Tiger Parents, in 14 Easy Steps", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-25 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cDon\u2019t jam yourself into the ground like a lawn dart,\u201d says Austin Anderson, a trick rider and horse stuntman from Troup, Tex. You\u2019ll have a few fractions of a second in the air before you land; use them to protect yourself by tucking your chin to your chest and preparing to roll, which will increase your deceleration time and distribute the force of the impact over more of your body.\n\n\u201cYour priority should be protecting your head and neck,\u201d says Anderson, who estimates that he has fallen from horses 150 times since he started performing at age 4. Many training courses on how to fall off a horse encourage riders to be careful about breaking their descent with their arms, but Anderson says that if you\u2019re going down head first, you should use your arms as a bumperlike \u201ccrumple zone\u201d: A broken wrist is better than brain trauma. Researchers have found that helmets reduce the risk of head injuries by as much as half, but fewer than a quarter of riders wear them, including Anderson, who opts for a cowboy hat instead.\n\nIn his stunt work, Anderson is usually being paid to look as though he has been shot off his horse, which means he needs to tumble in an uncontrolled, limbs-akimbo way and often land directly on his back or belly. For this type of fall, wear a protective vest and prepare the ground ahead of time by removing rocks and laying down sand or peat moss to make for a softer landing.\n\nIf you ride horses enough, you will eventually fall off; equestrians are admitted to the hospital at a rate of about once per 2,000 hours of riding, which is more than motorcyclists. Horse riders suffer higher rates of severe brain and body injuries than skiers, automobile racers and rugby and football players combined. Anderson has spent much of his life atop horses; he can ride standing with a foot planted on the back of two steeds galloping side by side. No matter how comfortable you are, though, horses are powerful animals: Some can weigh thousands of pounds; some can run 40 miles per hour. In comparison, you are slow and fragile \u2014 eminently breakable, really. \u201cWhen you\u2019re young, you recover easier,\u201d says Anderson, who is 49. \u201cBut as you get older, you end up paying for those falls.\u201d", "title": "How to Fall Off a Horse", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-13 00:00:00", "text": "Send your workplace conundrums to workologist@nytimes.com, including your name and contact information (even if you want it withheld). The Workologist is a guy with well-intentioned opinions, not a professional career adviser. Letters may be edited.\n\nI recently managed to hire someone for a position that was very hard to fill, because of the type of professional license needed and my organization\u2019s location. Unfortunately this new hire, despite an exceptional amount of support and training for the past two months, is struggling. He has a good grasp of the job\u2019s content, but can\u2019t keep up with its pace, volume or administrative requirements. I talked to my boss about this, and was advised to monitor and manage the new hire\u2019s work even more closely, signing off on everything he does until he\u2019s mastered the basics. After that talk, I met with my new hire for a routine one-on-one. When I asked to review the work he\u2019d done that day, he blew up: raised his voice, glared at me and waved his arms, complaining that he didn\u2019t want to be \u201cdistracted\u201d by my presence and expected to work with \u201cautonomy.\u201d I\u2019m known for my ability to be diplomatic and respectful with employees; this was an absurd overreaction. I think it\u2019s essential that I give him a formal warning. The problem is my boss, who has been known to turn a blind eye to employee misconduct for fear of affecting our bottom line. I know my boss really hopes this hire will work out because we had such a tough time finding qualified candidates. I feel like I\u2019m walking a tightrope. If I don\u2019t write him up, I won\u2019t be able to manage him and my boss will see me as weak. If I do write him up, he may lose motivation to improve and my boss will see me as harsh. MARY\n\nIf your boss is worried about the bottom line, you should be able to use that to your advantage. Allowing a new hire who hasn\u2019t figured out his job to run amok, brush off useful supervision and act like a diva without delivering results is definitely not good for business. You need to send the new colleague a message \u2014 but you\u2019d be wise to recruit your boss into some kind of agreement on that decision first.\n\nStart by giving the boss credit: You agree with the advice to monitor the new guy closely until he gets the hang of things. In fact (you can continue), you believe this person can, over time, work out, if he\u2019ll accept direction and learn on the job. Even if you have doubts about this, channel your inner optimist and come across as being focused on achieving solutions, not pointing out problems.\n\nNow tell the boss that the new guy was resistant to the suggested supervision \u2014 and you need to say that this is not acceptable. That\u2019s the best (and really only) way to make this new colleague work out in the long run, and you want to make sure you have your boss\u2019s support.\n\nHaving buy-in from your boss will make the subsequent conversation with your troublesome newcomer easier. But hang on to that optimism: Tell the new guy that you look forward to granting him the autonomy he seeks \u2014 but that getting there is going to require some management.", "title": "How to Help People Who Need It More Than They Know", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-03 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nAs an Army veteran, I have gone to the V.A. Medical Center in Washington, D.C., for over 16 years. During that time I have had treatment for prostate cancer, a new heart valve, a new hip, eye problems, skin problems and hearing.\n\nI have been treated with respect, expertise, timely care and medical professionalism. Many other veterans would surely agree. I am tired of reading about all the problems with the V.A., often espoused by those who do not want to see government-sponsored medical care succeed, as it has in most industrialized countries.\n\nIt is time for our nation to face up to the challenge of providing accessible and affordable health care for all our citizens, as \u201csingle payer\u201d would do, instead of bashing a great health facility in our country, and its leadership, for the purpose of proving that government-sponsored health care cannot work.\n\nLEN OLIVER, WASHINGTON\n\nTo the Editor:\n\nDavid J. Shulkin wants the world to believe that he was fired because of a grand conspiracy within the Trump administration to privatize veterans\u2019 health care. This is simply not true. There is no serious effort to privatize or dismantle the V.A.\u2019s health care system. Even individuals like me who have been harshly critical of the V.A. at times recognize that its health care system plays an important role in providing care for our nation\u2019s veterans.\n\nBut many inside and outside the department urgently want to reform the V.A. so it effectively meets the needs of all its patients \u2014 a task it is still failing at. Recent inspector general reports showed that our nation\u2019s heroes continue to wait too long for care, even for routine needs, and the department still fails to accurately report wait times.", "title": "Opinion | How to Improve Health Care for Veterans", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-25 00:00:00", "text": "Q. Is there any way to both charge the phone and listen to music at the same time on these new models that don\u2019t have the traditional headphone jack?\n\nA. Apple retired the 3.5-millimeter jack in 2016 with the iPhone 7, and Google omitted the port on its Pixel 2 phones last year \u2014 leaving owners of those models a single Lightning or USB-C connection to use for earbuds and the battery charger. Other phones will likely follow suit if they haven\u2019t already, and a few popular workarounds have emerged for people who like to listen to audio while the phone\u2019s battery is charging.\n\nFor those who prefer the fidelity of wired headphones (and the fact you don\u2019t have to charge those up as well), a port adapter may be your best option, and you can find different products online. Although it has mixed reviews, Belkin\u2019s Lightning Audio + Charge RockStar adapter is one option for the iPhone, and can be found for $40 or less. For Google Pixel 2 owners in a similar situation, Moshi\u2019s USB-C Digital Adapter With Charging dongle is about $45.\n\nIf you do not want to keep track of a port adapter, using a wireless charging mat is another approach. These mats, like those that use the Qi technology, allow you to place the phone on its surface to power up the battery. This leaves the single connection port free for headphones.", "title": "How to Juice and Jam at the Same Time", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-14 00:00:00", "text": "Q: I live on the 15th floor of an Upper East Side co-op with windows facing First Avenue. Pigeons are roosting on my window ledge. The birds\u2019 vocalization is loud enough to wake me up in the morning and they leave behind gray and white stains from their droppings. I shoo the birds away when I\u2019m home, but cannot do this all day. I want to be able to open my window in the spring without worrying that the germs from their droppings will enter my room. What can I place on my window ledge to discourage the pigeons from roosting there? I do not want to use anything that could fall off the ledge, endangering a pedestrian below, or poison the birds. What is a safe remedy?\n\nA: You should be able to open your windows this spring without worrying that a pigeon will fly into your apartment or its droppings will soil your home. While their droppings do not generally pose a serious health risk, they are still unsanitary, and gross. But your building, not you, should get the birds off your ledge. As a shareholder, you are responsible for everything inside the walls of your apartment, and the co-op board is responsible for the building. So the board needs to figure out how to get the birds to find a new home.\n\n\u201cResidents should not attempt a solution on their own,\u201d said Daniel Wollman, the chief executive of Gumley Haft, a Manhattan property manager.", "title": "How to Keep Unwelcome Pigeons at Bay", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-26 00:00:00", "text": "MS-13 members call this cocoon \u201cel barrio.\u201d El barrio is part of a mythic notion that if you commit yourself to something that is bigger than yourself, you will be rewarded with respect, status and comrades who will have your back when someone from outside threatens you.\n\nEl barrio is an ethos that can be evoked for good and for bad, including extreme violence, predatory criminal behavior and brutal forms of social control that have led to thousands of deaths in the United States and across Central America.\n\nBoth the church and the gang are tightly knit social organizations, places where people find an alternative family that require deep emotional and time commitments. Church members address one another as brother and sister, and like gang members, they are expected to look out for one another, providing jobs, shelter and food when needed. Churches are also highly patriarchal.\n\nMany evangelical churches tackle the gang menace not just on a spiritual and an emotional level but also a practical one. They provide jobs and job contacts, informal child-care services, and access to health care. Perhaps most important, they monopolize their members\u2019 time. Church services happen every night or nearly every night, coinciding with the hours when gang members are expected to \u201changear,\u201d as they like to say in Spanglish, with fellow gang members.\n\nThis transition to religion suggests that we should devote an equal amount of resources and rhetoric to creating an alternative to MS-13\u2019s barrio, a space that nurtures youth rather than marginalizes, incarcerates and deports them.\n\nSafe spaces include religious institutions but could also include gang-free schools where at-risk youth get emotional as well as practical and financial support. While law enforcement will remain a necessary component in anti-gang strategy, commitment to these types of prevention and exit strategies is the only way to blunt the gang\u2019s influence over the long term. But these programs receive pennies compared to the recent law enforcement initiatives aimed at the gang.\n\nDramatic as his breakdown in the church was, Mr. Deras\u2019s slide from gang life happened over time, as he worked to integrate himself into his new religious community. It was also a while before Mr. Deras felt that he could tell the gang leaders he was going to church regularly. When he did, they didn\u2019t tell him to stop but rather, the opposite: embrace it, they said.", "title": "Opinion | How to Leave MS-13 Alive", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-07 00:00:00", "text": "Because my body is failing, I have enlisted the aid of a colleague, the education journalist Peg Tyre, who has long shared my views. Together, we will lay out some fundamental steps that people of good conscience might take to make sure higher education is aligned with the democratic values we share.\n\nLet\u2019s start with alumni. It is common to harbor fond feelings toward your alma mater. But to be a responsible, forward-looking member of your college\u2019s extended community, look a little deeper. Make it your business to figure out exactly whom your college serves. What is the economic breakdown of the current student body? Some colleges trumpet data about underrepresented minorities and first-generation students. But many don\u2019t. And either way, there are follow-up questions to ask. How has that mix changed over the past 10 years? What policies are in place to increase those numbers? You may not get a direct answer. No matter. When they call you as part of the annual fund-raising drive, press the issue.\n\nBut you need to go further. Legacy admission must end. By some counts, children of alumni, almost all of them from the top economic quartile, account for 10 percent to 25 percent of the students at the top 100 universities. In 2011, an analysis of 30 elite schools found that legacy candidates saw a 23 percentage point increase in their chances of getting in compared with otherwise similar candidates. Among the Harvard class of 2021, 29 percent had a parent, grandparent or close family relation who attended the school.\n\nColleges say they need legacy admissions to encourage donations. But a 2010 study by Chad Coffman, Tara O\u2019Neil and Brian Starr looked at alumni donations at the top 100 universities and found no discernible impact of legacy admission on giving. Leading universities, including M.I.T., Caltech and Berkeley, don\u2019t allot extra credit to legacies. We need to press all schools to do the same. Your child is likely to have a great life even if he or she never sleeps in the same freshman dorm you did.\n\nNext, let\u2019s shorten the college tour. College admissions officers, who opted for the Common Application to make multiple applications to college easier, subsequently tried to weed out the not-so-serious applicants by making a pre-application college visit and a tour weigh in favor of an applicant. They call it \u201cdemonstrated interest,\u201d but what it mainly signifies is a family\u2019s ability to pay for a trip and not much more. The college tours, which for wealthy families gobble up vacation time for most of their child\u2019s junior year in high school, are another way to signify the means, not the seriousness, of a candidate. Princeton and Emory, to name two, do not factor demonstrated interest into their admissions decisions. The rest should follow.\n\nBroadly speaking, more people are going to college. To help students who come from the middle and working classes, cities and states should adopt models like the City University of New York\u2019s ASAP program, which provides intensive advising, money for textbooks and even MetroCards to smooth a student\u2019s pathway to his or her degree.\n\nMore name-brand colleges could do what Bard College has done: Refine the first two years of their four-year liberal arts education into an accredited Bard associate degree. They work with local partners to offer the degree in \u201cmicrocolleges\u201d within libraries and community centers. Their first four students \u2014 all low-income women with children who never considered applying to elite schools \u2014 are graduating from the pilot microcollege, in poverty-stricken Holyoke, Mass., this spring. One has been admitted as a transfer student to both Smith and Mount Holyoke, an almost unimaginable leap. The others are waiting to hear whether they will get to transfer to other selective colleges in the region with enough financial aid and child care to make it a reality.\n\nAnd please, let\u2019s not act like everyone already has the road map to college plotted. The college application system has become costly and baroque. Middle- and working-class kids rely on high school guidance counselors to help them navigate college admission and financial aid. But according to the latest figures, the average national ratio of high school students to counselors runs as high as 482 to 1. We must make it possible for high schools to hire, train and deploy enough guidance counselors, or we will have proved that we are not taking this issue seriously.", "title": "Opinion | How to Level the College Playing Field", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-10 00:00:00", "text": "Facebook and other major platforms are driven by algorithms designed to increase clicks. If you don\u2019t like President Trump, you will be served more and more anti-Trump articles as the algorithm tries to maximize your engagement, which in turn increases potential ad dollars. Revenue tied to sensational but phony news articles proved good for the bottom line. Until, that is, people started to complain, prompting fact-checking schemes, which in turn generated complaints about the political biases of those fact-checkers. In our ideologically diverse world, it\u2019s impossible for any single news distributor to fact-check and rank the news with complete objectivity.\n\nHistorically, editors and not algorithms made news judgments at TV networks, radio stations, newspapers and magazines. The biases of different editors were balanced by rules that limited the power, reach and ownership of any single outlet, thus ensuring diversity of content.\n\nNow, suppose we looked at the internet not as the private preserve of a few huge corporations, but as a public good to be treated no differently from how we treated the licensing of radio and TV stations. We could create new rules intended to force the major internet companies like Facebook and Google to choose one of two paths. They could be fully responsible for all the content on their networks, subject to libel laws (which they are not now). Or they could operate more like broadband providers that license \u201cchannels\u201d to media companies that are responsible for their own content, in the way that cable TV companies agree to carry selected channels. My guess is that they would choose the latter.\n\nTo stay in news distribution and yet avoid greater liability, they could step back from the editorial ranking business and adopt a system similar to what the government helped create with TV and radio. Following this approach, Facebook and Google, because of their unique market power in social and search, would each create a limited number of promoted but ideologically diverse news channels that could be auctioned off to responsible publishers, who would in turn agree to stringent fact-checking and content-responsibility rules. Violations of the rules would cost them their status as a certified channel.\n\nUsers then would select which channels they wanted in their feeds or allow the internet platforms to pick a selection of those channels on the basis of expressed ideology or interests \u2014 political, sports or celebrity news, liberal versus conservative. Search results from the certified channels would be listed first, and posting of items from these sources would carry special status and priority over nonlicensed sources. The revenue model would also be shifted from individual articles that draw clicks to channels that would have to meet standards and could pay annual licensing fees to the platforms. The channels would make money by selling ads or charging for premium content.", "title": "Opinion | How to Make Facebook More Accountable", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-11 00:00:00", "text": "VIGELAND: Speaking of toys and games, I was just watching the finale of \u201cRuPaul\u2019s Drag Race All Stars,\u201d which was won by TRIXIE MATTEL (12), and Mattel is of course a game manufacturer. I\u2019m not sure yet how we might draw a connection, but there is potential here!\n\nTAUSIG: Agreed \u2014 great lead for a theme. Let\u2019s take a quick aside to talk about mechanics. Note that Finn put the name of the theme-answer-to-be, TRIXIE MATTEL, in all-caps, which is a common convention. He also put the letter count in parentheses. That\u2019s something we\u2019ll want to keep track of while we brainstorm.\n\nVIGELAND: Indeed, we\u2019ll need pairs of equally long theme answers so that we can obey one of the more rigid rules of crosswords: placing your theme answers in symmetrical positions in the grid.\n\nTAUSIG: Whatever the lengths, they have to be paired to meet another rule of crossword constructing: most themed grids are diagonally symmetrical for aesthetic reasons. The only exception is if you have an entry running across the center, which wouldn\u2019t have a symmetrical partner. A theme entry set with two (13)s and one (15) would still have symmetry if the (15) ran in the middle row. We\u2019ll aim for a total theme entry letter count of about 40 letters for an easy theme like the one we\u2019re making today.\n\nBack to the Drawing Board\n\nTAUSIG: TRIXIE MATTEL is a great spark, but I can already see a limitation. Namely, the \u201cgame\u201d aspect of our theme is in the word MATTEL. Themes have to be consistent. To make a consistent theme from this, we would need to find at least three phrases with the name of a game company in them. Can we find phrases with HASBRO or LEGO that have nothing to do with the game companies themselves?\n\nVIGELAND: Good point. Unfortunately, after a quick consultation of the Wikipedia list of game manufacturers, I see that we might be out of luck. Ben made a great point. We want phrases that don\u2019t have to do with the actual toy companies \u2014 we lose the wordplay aspect if LEGOLAND was a theme entry, because LEGO in there already refers to the company. The MATTEL in TRIXIE MATTEL has nothing to do with the company, which would have made her an excellent entry in this theme set. Alas, though, the other entries were going to be weaker.", "title": "How to Make a Crossword Puzzle", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-06 00:00:00", "text": "Send your workplace conundrums to workologist@nytimes.com, including your name and contact information (even if you want it withheld). The Workologist is a guy with well-intentioned opinions, not a professional career adviser. Letters may be edited.\n\nI\u2019m a mid-50s guy who was recently laid off from an executive job at a struggling company. It was a job I had planned to leave \u2014 in fact, I got my notice about two weeks before I was going to quit! My plan was to travel around the world for several months before looking for a new position, and that\u2019s what I\u2019ve been doing for the last three months. What\u2019s the best way to portray this on my r\u00e9sum\u00e9? I want potential employers to know the time was spent in an interesting and constructive way. ATLANTA\n\nIt\u2019s smart to think over the best way to handle this \u2014 but don\u2019t overthink it. Figuring out how to explain a three-year gap would be crucial. In your situation, you can almost consider this an opportunity.\n\nObviously if your travel time included activities that easily translate to the work world, emphasize those \u2014 playing a key role on a volunteer team that solved some problem for a deserving constituency, for example. If not, then give some careful and perhaps creative thought to the high-level connections between your travel adventures and the kind of work you\u2019re seeking. Perhaps, for instance, exposure to other cultures will make you a more empathetic manager. The connections don\u2019t have to be explicit, just defensible. (And you should adjust which ones you emphasize for different potential employers; tweaking a r\u00e9sum\u00e9 for specific jobs is often a good idea.)\n\nBut keep it concise. Your actual work skills and experience are a lot more important than any travel lessons, and you don\u2019t want to leave the impression that this three-month break meant more to you than your entire previous career.\n\nFinally, if your main travel achievement turns out to be increasing your tolerance for margaritas and breaking a personal record for consecutive hours slept, you\u2019ll either need to get extremely creative \u2014 or do some judicious editing. Just share the year of your end date, count on your actual work background to get you in the door, and explain in the interview stage that when your last job ended you needed an energizing break.", "title": "How to Make a Travel Break Sound Like Work Experience", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-10 00:00:00", "text": "We had really nice times, restaurants and I. There were the years when I worked for a food magazine with an expense account, and the years when my wife and I lived free of day care and diaper bills, so there are happy memories: the time I saw her weep, overcome by the flavor of a dish of strawberries; the time we spent an entire meal, rapt, watching servers glide toward tables, their dishes alighting in balletic unison.\n\nBut now we have a 2-year-old. We don\u2019t get to restaurants much anymore. Instead, one recent night I spent dinnertime wincing as my daughter dunked a fistful of tuna into her milk, then smeared her fishy fingers on my shirt. I watched her small hands maul a stump of broccoli, then palm it into her jaws to chew it, open-mouthed. Objectively, it was disgusting. But that sight may have made me the happiest I have ever been at the table. For months, I stood by, biologically useless as my wife gave our daughter milk, so feeding her food I\u2019ve made is the closest I\u2019ve ever felt to being truly important.\n\nMy daughter likes broccoli. And mushrooms. Most any vegetable, well roasted, really, and so I roast all the broccoli, mushrooms and whatever other thing I can get my hands on to feel the high of watching my child eat. But after that, after bath time and bedtime, half-passed-out and kept awake mostly by the hunger in our own bellies, my wife and I turn to those vegetables to sustain ourselves.\n\nI\u2019ve learned that the best way to make dinner on nights like that is to exalt in the glories of simple tastes. Along with those vegetables, I almost always keep in the fridge some eggs and a couple of cups of wheat berries rattling around in a container, cooked on a Sunday night with the TV on and next week\u2019s vegetables in the oven. This way, we\u2019re always just minutes away from grain-bowl time.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThere is no one way to make a grain bowl. There is no one recipe. There are paths, a varying series of little things to do in the kitchen that will add up to a delicious thing of many textures and flavors. But there is a structure; a formula. Grains, of course. I love wheat berries, or farro, or wild or brown rice because I love their nutty, mellow flavor and satisfying chew. Or sometimes I\u2019ll mix one of those with some quinoa or couscous because they\u2019re tender and friable on the tongue, and the two textures bounce off each other. My bowls always have vegetables and probably have those eggs, because even great eggs are cheap protein, and they somehow make any assortment of foods feel like a legitimate meal. And I like to shower the whole thing with a handful of something crispy or crunchy, because eating should be fun.", "title": "How to Make a Weeknight Grain Bowl That Is Actually Delicious", "authors": ["Francis Lam"]} {"date": "2018-04-30 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cAny question is fine,\u201d said Ms. Randolph, a former gallerist. \u201cIt can be really basic: How does this person make this work? What is this made out of? Where is this person from? That sparks more in-depth conversation.\u201d\n\nThis week, the New York Times critic Roberta Smith will assess Frieze for the Weekend section, and Martha Schwendener will weigh in on Tefaf. Robin Pogrebin will interview the artist Adam Pendleton. And Brook S. Mason will offer a roundup of Brooklyn art fairs that highlight young emerging artists, with prices starting at $200.\n\nPhoto\n\nFrieze New York\n\nThis fair, now in its seventh year, is the week\u2019s tentpole event, and the only one that boasts an official Champagne sponsor. More than 190 galleries are taking part, presenting booths loaded with artwork in a bespoke 250,000 square-foot pavilion on Randalls Island.\n\nThe most prominent display will undoubtedly be \u201cBlack Dada Flag (Black Lives Matter),\u201d a monumental flag created by the artist Adam Pendleton. It will fly on the island for six months, making it Frieze\u2019s first lasting public art installation. Mr. Pendleton\u2019s work is part of Live, a new component of the fair comprising performances, installations and interactive works.\n\nOther artists with notable solo presentations at Frieze include Tracey Emin (Xavier Hufkens gallery, Brussels), Theaster Gates (Richard Gray Gallery, New York), David Hockney (two shows with Pace, New York; and one with Offer Waterman, London) and Betye Saar (Roberts Projects, Los Angeles). A group show from Chi-Wen Gallery in Taipei will revolve around a flower installation by Atsunobu Katagiri. One section, Frame, focuses on newer galleries.\n\nThere will be conversations with artists, writers and others as part of Frieze Talks, and a collection of art publications available in the Reading Room, should you need to decompress. Food vendors include Court Street Grocers, Roberta\u2019s and the Fat Radish.\n\nThe layout has been redesigned in an attempt to make all of this easier to navigate, but there\u2019s still so much to see that you should plan to make a day of it. Taking the ferry from Manhattan is part of the fun.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nFriday through Sunday on Randalls Island; frieze.com. Tickets: $48; $27 for students.\n\nPhoto\n\nTefaf New York Spring\n\nIn just its second year, this Upper East Side fair, which sprang from the European fair in Maastricht, the Netherlands, brings together blue-chip galleries this spring that bridge the modern and contemporary. One sure highlight being shown by the Mnuchin Gallery is \u201cAlmost,\u201d a new work by the Ghanaian artist El Anatsui, known for using reclaimed materials to create majestic assemblages. Ninety galleries are taking part, and the offerings also include jewelry, furniture and antiquities.\n\nMarian Goodman will have a solo presentation by the Mexican artist Gabriel Orozco. Di Donna Galleries is pairing Surrealist works with the 19th-century Native American masks that inspired them. And Matthew Marks Gallery will be showing \u201cWhite Yellow,\u201d a 1957 Ellsworth Kelly painting that has not been seen in public since 1959. Panel presentations will include a conversation with museum directors and Daniel Weiss, president of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, about the issue of museum admission fees.\n\nFriday through Tuesday at the Park Avenue Armory, 643 Park Avenue; tefaf.com. Day tickets: $55; students: $25.\n\nPhoto\n\nArt New York\n\nOn the West Side of Manhattan is Art New York, an offshoot of Art Miami, which includes nearly 100 galleries from 30 countries. There will be art for sale by major artists such as David Hockney, Jean-Michel Basquiat and Anish Kapoor. A solo show by the artist Cey Adams, the original creative director of Def Jam Recordings, will benefit the Jon Bon Jovi Soul Foundation. And Jason Newsted, the onetime Metallica bassist, will display his ongoing series of art, \u201cRAWK.\u201d\n\nA shuttle bus will also run to this fair directly from the Frieze ferry landing at East 35th Street.\n\nThursday through Sunday at Pier 94, 711 12th Avenue; artnyfair.com. Day tickets:$25; students and seniors: $15.\n\nPhoto\n\n1-54 Contemporary African Art Fair\n\nThis far more intimate event at the Pioneer Works space in Red Hook, Brooklyn, is focused on the work by African and African diaspora artists. Seven of the 21 galleries included are new participants this year. The South African artist Ralph Ziman will install a Casspir armored vehicle, an outsize symbol of Apartheid\u2019s legacy. Phoebe Boswell\u2019s work \u201cI Need to Believe the World Is Still Beautiful\u201d aims to undermine the dominance of the white male gaze while reclaiming the female nude.\n\nFriday through Sunday at Pioneer Works, 159 Pioneer Street, Brooklyn; 1-54.com. Day tickets: $20; students and seniors, $10.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. The 130 participating artists were chosen by a selection committee. The fair is a partner of Saatchi Art, an online gallery that is not to be confused with London\u2019s Saatchi Gallery.\n\nThursday through Sunday at Brooklyn Expo Center, 72 Noble Street, Brooklyn; nyc.theotherartfair.com. Offerings include work from some three dozen artists and galleries, as well as a David Bowie tribute.\n\nWednesday through Sunday at the Nu Hotel, 85 Smith Street, Brooklyn; fridgeartfair.com. Day tickets: $15.", "title": "How to Make the Most of the Frieze Week Art Fairs", "authors": ["Daniel Mcdermon"]} {"date": "2018-04-11 00:00:00", "text": "The next part is a little tricky: Freedom cards are technically cash back cards that earn points redeemable at a penny each. But those points become much more powerful when you transfer them to a Sapphire or Business Preferred card (which is done easily on the Chase website), as you can then redeem them for a bonus in the travel portal and transfer them to travel partners.\n\nThis quarter (April through June), for example, those categories include grocery stores. That means $100 worth of groceries earns you 500 points, or five percent back on your spending. But those points can be transferred to your Sapphire Reserve and redeemed for travel at a 50 percent bonus, meaning it\u2019s an effective return rate of 7.5 percent. The Freedom Unlimited, which is uncapped and gives you a 1.5 percent return on all categories, can also transfer points to the Sapphire Reserve, earning that 50 percent bonus. This equates to a 2.25 percent return on all spending when you redeem for travel.\n\nCiti ThankYou Rewards\n\nThe Citi Prestige is the centerpiece of the ThankYou Rewards suite of cards, and it has some fantastic perks: It has trip delay insurance benefits that are significantly better than those of its competitors, and offers a unique free fourth night hotel benefit that can pay for the card\u2019s annual fee by itself. That means your fourth night of a consecutive four-night stay is completely free, from fleabag motels to the Four Seasons, provided you book through Citi. That\u2019s the good news.\n\nNow, the not-so-good: Citi isn\u2019t quite on the level of American Express and Chase when it comes to its transfer partners which, as we know, offer the best points redemption value. Whereas Chase has United and Southwest Airlines as points transfer partners, and American Express can claim Delta, Citi doesn\u2019t claim a major American legacy carrier. Partners Avianca (Star Alliance) and Asia Miles (Cathay Pacific) can still offer good redemption values, but cardholders may find less value in partners like Garuda Indonesia and Malaysia Airlines, which don\u2019t fly to North America. Finally, while Chase has four hotel transfer partners, including IHG and Hyatt, Citi has zero.\n\nAs with American Express and Chase, I\u2019d generally recommend forgoing the use of points to pay for purchases, merchandise and gift cards.\n\nAmassing Points\n\nUnless you\u2019re putting tons of spend on your credit cards every month, the most efficient way to get points quickly is through sign-up bonuses \u2014 the Chase Sapphire Reserve, for example, currently offers a 50,000 point bonus (possibly higher if you apply in-branch) when you spend $4,000 in the first three months of having the account open. I monitor forums and travel blogs (Doctor of Credit is good) to see what offers are out there.\n\nA couple of things to keep in mind: Some cards have high annual fees \u2014 Chase Sapphire Reserve is $450, American Express Platinum is $550 \u2014 that only are offset if you manage to collect the bonus. Always make sure you can hit the target spend amount before signing up. Most importantly, I don\u2019t recommend juggling a bunch of new credit cards to anyone who can\u2019t pay their balance in full every month. The point is to make money, not give it back to the banks.\n\nI\u2019m fastidious about avoiding interest and late fees, and don\u2019t feel guilty canceling high annual fee cards once I\u2019ve collected my bonus, thus I rarely hesitate to jump on a good sign-up offer. If the banks want to help pay for my next trip, at little or no cost to me, I\u2019m all for it.", "title": "How to Navigate the Complicated World of Credit Card Points", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-19 00:00:00", "text": "Another problem is the stupefying amount of administration that diplomats overseas have to contend with, instead of practicing diplomacy; many have taken to calling it \u201ce-hell.\u201d It gets in the way of the very reason they live in foreign countries \u2014 to understand and analyze developments in those countries and engage with their societies to better inform United States policies.\n\nWhat about the staffing gaps overseas every summer, when officers start new assignments at embassies and consulates weeks or even months after their predecessors have left? Even in the age of instant communication, this leads to a lack of continuity and a need for almost every new officer to reinvent the wheel.\n\nAs for those outside government, internationally focused think tanks could play a role in producing research on trends and innovation in diplomatic practice. They have largely ignored that, saying their job is to study foreign policy, not what some call \u201cthe machinery\u201d that carries it out. The main reason for that is funding \u2014 it\u2019s much easier to find donors willing to finance policy research, which they hope will influence official government decisions. However, given the damage being done to the machinery, getting the process right will be as important as the policy substance on the other side of the dark age.\n\nAcademia can help as well. The Trump administration\u2019s policies and actions have significantly diminished the attractiveness of diplomacy as a career for young Americans. As a result, the number of those taking the Foreign Service exam has decreased by nearly half since Mr. Trump\u2019s election, and compared with pre-2017 figures, fewer than a third of new officers are being accepted into the Foreign Service.\n\nSo it\u2019s vital to keep alive the young generation\u2019s interest in and pursuit of diplomacy as a career. But it\u2019s difficult to find colleges and universities in the United States (and globally, for that matter) that teach diplomacy. Not international relations, but diplomatic practice. Even schools whose names include the words \u201cdiplomacy\u201d or \u201cforeign service\u201d offer no more than a couple of diplomacy-related courses, one of which is usually in diplomatic history.\n\nTo that end, my school, the Washington International Diplomatic Academy, which trains diplomats and other international affairs professionals from around the world, is holding a practical training program for students this summer for the first time. They will learn what is increasingly becoming a lost art, as well as specific skills, from some of the best diplomats in recent years, including recent State Department refugees. Still, I\u2019d rather see dozens of universities offer multiyear degree programs.\n\nThe longer the United States fails to exercise its diplomatic muscle, the worse its atrophy will get. Future Foreign Service leaders could emerge from its current ranks or among Americans still in college. Naturally, they will aspire to become ambassadors and assistant secretaries. But once at the top, despite the huge political demands of those jobs, they should find time to take care of their colleagues in the service. Dark age or renaissance, no one else will.", "title": "Opinion | How to Prepare a Post-Trump Renaissance in Diplomacy", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-01 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\n\u201cTwo white police officers in Baton Rouge, La., will not be prosecuted in the fatal 2016 shooting of Alton Sterling, a black man.\u201d That was the text in a push notification that arrived on lock screens across the country on Tuesday, sent by The New York Times. Many had been awaiting the decision for years; the alert, one of several hundreds The Times will send this year, took readers straight to the breaking news on nytimes.com.\n\nTens of thousands of people accessed the article through the alert; arresting details and emotional content often draw readers in this way, said Michael Owen, editor of the news desk. Every story that lands on a lock screen is a chance to build a relationship with the reader \u2014 or erode it. \u201cIt has to do one or the other for every alert we send, even if the effect is subtle,\u201d he added. \u201cWe always want it to get better.\u201d\n\nPart of that means cultivating \u201ca more human voice,\u201d according to Eric Bishop, assistant editor for mobile at The Times who leads push notification strategy alongside Mr. Owen. The strategy has shifted from simply alerting headlines, two and a half years ago, to something much more lively and conversational today.\n\nPush alerts at The Times had unexpected beginnings. Two and half years ago, Mr. Bishop, Mr. Owen and a team of editors, developers and designers were faced with the challenge of developing alerts for the nascent Apple Watch app. What they came up with was the \u201cone-line story\u201d: packing articles into bite-size pieces that were chattier and more approachable than traditional headlines.\n\nMr. Owen and Mr. Bishop later found that a similar premise worked on mobile platforms, but with added context. \u201cWhen we included more information in the push, we saw higher engagement,\u201d Mr. Owen said, noting that, as the team progressively answered more fundamental questions \u2014 the whos, whats, whens, wheres and whys \u2014 they found a wider audience with each additional detail.\n\nAlerts usually run under 140 characters, to keep them from getting cut off, but that\u2019s not a hard and fast rule. Each day brings a different number and mix of alerts depending on the gravity of a story and the pace of a news cycle, and each year brings new technology \u2014 the team recently unveiled its first alerts with embedded photo, for example.\n\nThe decision for when to send an alert and how, much of the time, comes down to instinct. These days, the team looks forward to the quirky stories, or \u201csome lyrical or amusing detail,\u201d Mr. Owen said. Recent examples include a notification that described reporters\u2019 frozen eyelashes on the scene of a bomb cyclone in early January. One notification alerting a viewer\u2019s guide to \u201cStar Wars: The Last Jedi\u201d advised readers to read it, \u201cOr don\u2019t. We\u2019re not your father.\u201d\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s a way not only to hook people, but also to delight them, which is something we don\u2019t get a ton of opportunities to do as a news operation,\u201d Mr. Owen said. \u201cWhen we get that opportunity, it\u2019s a good way to break up the drumbeat of more serious stuff that we send.\u201d\n\nIt\u2019s not an exact science: In January, after alerts with mistakes warranted corrections, editors put in place new protocol to vet the alerts for accuracy and work with those who had written the stories in question and knew them best. \u201cAs we sent a greater and greater volume of push notifications, we hadn\u2019t really adjusted how we worked to keep the level of quality consistent,\u201d Mr. Owen noted. The notification\u2019s quality, he said, is by far the priority over its speed.\n\nMr. Owen and Mr. Bishop try to stay mindful today of how intrusive the alerts can feel, especially in an era in which breaking news is relentless. They ask themselves constantly where a reader\u2019s daily and hourly tolerance lies. (The alerts team can see if a reader has turned off notifications within an hour of receiving one \u2014 potentially a sign they\u2019ve annoyed somebody.) \u201cWe try to be empathetic,\u201d Mr. Bishop said.\n\nMr. Bishop wants the arc to bend toward more of a two-way conversation, hopefully implementing a way for readers to give feedback on alerts in real time. Some things, after all, remain out of the scope of analytics: for example, \u201cif someone is delighted by a push but doesn\u2019t open it.\u201d", "title": "How to Push a Story", "authors": ["Melina Delkic"]} {"date": "2018-04-24 00:00:00", "text": "Come to Paris and experience it like a Parisian, not like a tourist: That\u2019s exactly what Paris residents and close friends, Jessie Kanelos Weiner and Sarah Moroz, both 33, hope that all visitors to the city can do. Their new book \u201cParis in Stride\u201d aims to help tourists get this insider\u2019s perspective \u2014 it\u2019s divided into seven walking tours that include popular attractions but focus on lesser-known neighborhoods, along with under-the-radar tourist sites, restaurants and shops; Ms. Moroz did the writing while Ms. Kanelos Weiner did the illustrations.\n\nBoth moved to Paris soon after graduating from college: Ms. Kanelos Weiner worked as an au pair in the city and was drawn to the rich culture, history and fashion scene. \u201cI decided to make it home,\u201d she said. Ms. Moroz, who is half French, came to Paris with the intention of spending a year exploring the city before returning to New York, but she, too, chose to settle there.\n\nThe duo met at a magazine launch party in Paris two years ago and became fast friends.\n\nBelow are excerpts from a recent conversation with them.\n\nHow did you conceive the idea for the book?\n\nMs. Kanelos Weiner: I had already published a book with Rizzoli called \u201cEdible Paradise,\u201d and my publisher there was interested in a book on Paris so I asked Sarah if she would be interested in collaborating with me.", "title": "How to Really Experience Paris", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-10 00:00:00", "text": "To find a group in your neighborhood, just search Facebook for \u201cbuy nothing\u201d and your neighborhood (e.g. \u201cbuy nothing royal oak\u201d rather than \u201cbuy nothing Detroit\u201d). The smaller the group, the easier it is to browse and get stuff. You\u2019ll also find related groups for buying and selling, which can be handy.\n\nE-waste centers\n\nDid you know you\u2019re supposed to recycle old electronics? Most of those old gadgets have valuable materials that can be harvested and many cities have local recycling centers that will take your used electronics off your hands.\n\nHowever, many of those recycling centers will also sell any of the working electronics that are donated to them \u2014 at bargain bin prices. You can find monitors, keyboards, networking gear, cables of all types and even old laptops or game systems for next to nothing. These organizations are tougher to find, but where I live, the University of San Diego has their own e-waste center, and many cities have an organization called Free Geek that offers something similar. Free Geek offers free computer classes, too, from basic PC use to coding. Your local university or state government may also have a surplus store where they sell used computers or even desks.\n\nBaby resale stores\n\nIf you have kids, you know how expensive baby clothes can get \u2014 especially when the little tykes seem to grow out of them every few weeks. That\u2019s why baby resale stores exist: They buy gently used clothes, toys and other items and resell them back to parents on a budget.\n\n\u201cLocal parents bring in clothing, shoes, toys and baby gear (strollers, bassinets, etc.) and we check them out and decide what to buy,\u201d says Paige Rigg, owner of Baby Go Round Resale in San Diego. She notes that they\u2019re very careful about what they sell, too: \u201cItems must be in clean condition; toys and gear must have batteries, all of their pieces, and be off the recall list.\u201d They don\u2019t resell car seats (which can be unsafe if they\u2019ve ever been in an accident, or are past their expiration date), cribs (older models of which often have recalls or safety issues) and other items that might be unsafe or unsanitary for children. If you do choose to shop at a baby resale store, make sure the owners take this kind of safety seriously.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Smarter Living Newsletter A weekly roundup of the best advice from The Times on living a better, smarter, more fulfilling life. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThere are also local and traveling consignment events for children\u2019s items like Just Between Friends that you can visit as they happen.\n\nWorkout groups\n\nSaving money isn\u2019t just about getting stuff for less. Your community can also offer services for cheap or free, if you know where to look. Workouts are a prime example: Why spend money on a gym membership when you can work out with a highly motivated group of people in the park?\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThat\u2019s exactly what November Project aims to do. Originally born in Boston, November Project is completely free, organized by volunteers and takes place in 45 cities around the world. Twice a week, these motivated people get together in the mornings to do workouts that include running, body weight exercises and circuit training. It\u2019s intense and energetic, but the workouts are formulated so that people of varying skill levels can join \u2014 whether you\u2019re an Olympic athlete or an average Joe or Jane looking to get in shape. Best of all, there\u2019s no sign up required: Just show up. And if there isn\u2019t a November Project in your area, you can start one \u2014 or find a similar group that almost certainly already exists.\n\nThe obvious: thrift stores, swap meets and Craigslist\n\nWe\u2019d be remiss not to mention some of the more obvious options you already know about, like local thrift stores, consignment shops and swap meets. These types of organizations have been around forever and they can still be a great way to save money \u2014 though they\u2019re usually better for browsing than trying to find something specific. (Remember that Goodwill isn\u2019t the only thrift store around, either \u2014 there are probably locally owned ones that are less trafficked or specialize in different kinds of items.)\n\nIn addition, apps like Craigslist \u2014 and lesser-known counterparts like LetGo and OfferUp \u2014 are always great ways to find good deals on furniture, electronics or anything else you might be searching for. Cast a wide net and don\u2019t be afraid to negotiate \u2014 any experienced seller will expect it and that\u2019s how you go from a good deal to a great one.\n\nHow to find these organizations in your neighborhood\n\nEvery city and town is different, and finding the local version of the above organizations is the real challenge. If you know where to look, though, you can make things a bit easier on yourself. Be sure to check:\n\n\u2022 Facebook: Facebook isn\u2019t just for following friends and news outlets. The revamped Groups feature is a great way to find local community groups and a lot of the above organizations will have pages on Facebook, if you do a bit of searching.\n\n\u2022 NextDoor: Billed as a social network for your neighborhood, NextDoor\u2019s main feed is mostly full of people selling stuff (which itself can be useful). But you can also use the sidebar to look up events (often hosted by local organizations that you can look into), recommended businesses and people offering up services at a discount to their neighbors.\n\n\u2022 Your city\u2019s subreddit: If you\u2019ve ever browsed Reddit, the internet\u2019s community-for-literally-everything, you should check out the subreddit for your city. Below all the memes and cool photos of the skyline, you\u2019ll find people asking about (or sharing) local business information, cool deals for local attractions and other useful information. You can even create a new thread asking for good places to find what you\u2019re looking for!\n\n\u2022 Yelp: Never discount the obvious: Yelp is still one of the best ways to find well-regarded local businesses. It might be tough if you aren\u2019t sure what you\u2019re even looking for, but when it comes to the more prevalent options like thrift stores and consignment shops, Yelp is a great place to find the best ones.\n\n\u2022 Other organizations: You know the organizations I mentioned above? They partner with other organizations that have similar goals. For example, the University of San Diego\u2019s e-waste center partners with a local church group called Jesus Geeks which provides, among other things, inexpensive \u201ctech support\u201d fund-raising nights, where you can get tech support for much less than what most big box stores charge. If you find an organization you like, poke around their website or related Facebook groups to see what else might interest you.\n\nOnce you get on a roll, you\u2019ll be surprised how many great resources you can find right in your own neighborhood. Remember to pay it forward, too \u2014 if these organizations have helped you out, don\u2019t be afraid to offer your own unwanted stuff for donation, too.", "title": "How to Save Money With the Help of Your Community", "authors": ["Whitson Gordon"]} {"date": "2018-04-02 00:00:00", "text": "As Nero worsened, Seneca attempted to leave. Joining Nero\u2019s administration was easy, but an exit was not. Nero could not afford to lose his most influential adviser, or allow the perception that someone as well known as Seneca was cutting ties with him. Seneca was granted a quiet sabbatical at Nero\u2019s whim \u2014 the modern equivalent of a jointly issued news release.\n\nSeneca had finally come to experience the truth of the words of the Roman poet Horace, whose work had greatly influenced him: \u201cTo have a great man for a friend seems pleasant to those who have never tried it; those who have, fear it.\u201d\n\nIn a larger sense, Seneca\u2019s struggle has echoes into our time, especially in politics. Last year, Senator Marco Rubio, a Republican who has both criticized Donald Trump and supported many of his policies, tweeted a quote from Seneca about tyranny, prompting some to ask if he was subtweeting the president. Ken Kurson, the former editor in chief of The New York Observer and an informal adviser to Mr. Trump and Jared Kushner during the election, told me that the Stoics were an inspiration to him as he dealt with the ethical and personal challenges of his position.\n\nMy own early career involved some questionable service to businesspeople. Employed and paid by them, I planned and carried out controversial publicity stunts, and used dishonest tactics with the public and the media. When I finally left those roles, I found a knowledge of Stoic philosophy integral to my ability to assess my past actions, and set a more honorable course going forward.\n\nIn a remarkable essay titled \u201cOn Leisure,\u201d published after Seneca retired, the philosopher wrote in an oblique way about his own experiences: \u201cThe duty of a man is to be useful to his fellow-men; if possible, to be useful to many of them; failing this, to be useful to a few; failing this, to be useful to his neighbors, and, failing them, to himself: for when he helps others, he advances the general interests of mankind.\u201d\n\nRemoved from the day-to-day of Rome\u2019s geopolitics (helping the many), he seemed to have a newfound appreciation for helping the few. Seneca seemed to realize only belatedly that one can contribute to his fellow citizens in ways other than through the state \u2014 for instance, by writing or simply by being a good man at home. There is some irony in the fact that as an individual, the famous letters and essays Seneca wrote would not only have a bigger impact than his work in politics but also in time would whitewash his contributions to a horrible regime.\n\nIn 65 A.D., Seneca would again find that philosophy did not exist only in the ethereal world. Conspirators began to plot against Nero\u2019s life, and Seneca, finally accepting that the monster he had helped create needed to be stopped, appears to have participated \u2014 or covered for those who did.\n\nThe effort failed but provided Seneca an opportunity: His life up to that point had contradicted many of his own teachings, but now when Nero\u2019s guards came and demanded his life, he would be brave and wise. The man who had written much about learning how to die and facing the end without fear would comfort his friends, finish an essay he was writing and distribute some finished pieces for safekeeping. Then, he slit his veins, took hemlock and succumbed to the suffocating steam of a bath.", "title": "Opinion | How to Serve a Deranged Tyrant, Stoically", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-23 00:00:00", "text": "Sadly, we are all just as bad at assessing our skills and abilities, and like Drew, we don\u2019t even realize it. But there\u2019s a solution, and we\u2019ll get to that.\n\nResearch has shown that we humans are generally pretty awful at assessing our own competence and abilities, which in turn leads us to overestimate them \u2014 a phenomenon called the Dunning-Kruger Effect.\n\nThe effect creates a vicious loop that boils down to this: The less skilled you are at something, the less likely you are to recognize how unskilled you truly are, and thus you overestimate your abilities. Worse still, because you can\u2019t see your errors, you\u2019ll never know you need to correct. (If this all sounds familiar, you\u2019ve probably heard of the classic study in which 80 percent of surveyed drivers ranked their driving skills as \u201cabove average.\u201d Noodle on that one.)\n\nConversely, the better we get at something, the likelier we are to see how much more we can improve, which can sometimes lead us to underestimate ourselves. Similarly, those who are exceptionally skilled at something can sometimes think everyone else is at that level, making them unaware of how exceptional their abilities are. Think: Impostor syndrome.\n\nWe all do this! It\u2019s simply in our nature, so it\u2019s not a behavior meant to deceive others or to unreasonably prop up our own ego. In the influential study that first examined this phenomenon in 1999, researchers found that once people realize how bad they are at something, they\u2019ll readily cop to it and want to improve.", "title": "How to Spot and Overcome Your Hidden Weaknesses", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-11 00:00:00", "text": "I also use Twitter and Reddit for trending stories. And there are certain aggregator sites that people swear by. I\u2019ve been using Hvper recently, thanks to a recommendation from my editor. And I still sometimes web surf like an old, using an RSS reader (Feedly).\n\nWhich one is the most important?\n\nFor breaking news, probably Dataminr. It\u2019s a handy tool. For trending news, what we hope to do is put together patterns that others may not have, or to put a new spin on a story that\u2019s already out there.\n\nPhoto\n\nI also use Twitter to follow the news, which sometimes helps me find patterns. (I can\u2019t use Tweetdeck, and I\u2019m always impressed that people are able to, by the way.)\n\nWe also have a pretty active Slack culture on my team, and we get a lot of ideas (like one by my teammate Maya Salam on showering) just from talking about dumb things with one another, saying whether we prefer rice, bread or potatoes, that kind of thing.\n\nBeyond your job, what tech product do you love using in your daily life?\n\nI listen to music near constantly when not at work, so a lot of the technology I use regularly has to do with that.\n\nI have a couple of Bose Bluetooth speakers. The Bose SoundLink Mini is one of my favorite things. I got mine years ago, and it still works. The sound quality is strong, and it\u2019s easy to connect to and to carry around. If I need to play music a little louder, I have a Bose SoundTouch system that works O.K.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story How Do You Use Tech? Advice and tips on the technology changing how you live. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nI use Sennheiser headphones when I want to listen to music closely, and those little Sony over-ear headphones (the ones that came with Discmen) for listening to music on the go.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThere\u2019s a story with those Sennheiser headphones. They were sent to me in the mail and were in a box on my coffee table for a couple of months. I thought they belonged to my roommate (someone had opened the outer layer of the box), but he told me they weren\u2019t his. So I called my parents and some of my best friends to ask if they had gotten me these kind of expensive headphones.
