No one had.\n\nI couldn\u2019t figure out where they had come from and was a little paranoid that someone was spying on me. A year later, I came home and my downstairs neighbor was taking out his trash and wearing those same Sennheisers. Then I thought for a second.\n\n\u201cHey, Evan,\u201d I said. \u201cDid you actually have to order those twice because one package went missing?\u201d He confirmed \u2014 I had stolen his headphones. He was very nice about it, and because he had gotten them replaced, he has let me keep them so far.\n\nPhoto\n\nI also gave in and started using a Tile, which is a Bluetooth tracker, to find my keys. It has made it so I never lose my keys.\n\nWhat could be better?\n\nThe SoundTouch system can be hard to connect to, and it sometimes shuts off inexplicably. The over-ear headphones get blown out kind of easily, but you can order replacements on Amazon and they are super cheap.\n\nThere is now so much tech out there \u2014 tweets, Facebook posts, phone notifications and more \u2014 to distract us. What\u2019s your advice for readers who struggle to concentrate on their work?\n\nI deleted Facebook from my phone last year, so that\u2019s gone. And I sign up for very few notifications.\n\nI don\u2019t have any magic tricks or anything, though, and I get distracted pretty easily. When I really want to concentrate on something, I try to leave my phone in another room. And when I need to write something on deadline, I minimize Slack and put my stolen headphones on.", "title": "How to Stay on Top of Breaking News", "authors": ["Jonah Engel Bromwich", "Tech We Re Using"]} {"date": "2018-04-27 00:00:00", "text": "Dawn and John Strumsky agree about most things, a tendency that has served them well in 45 years of marriage. But there was one subject where they did not see eye to eye for the longest time: their retirement future.\n\nMs. Strumsky wanted desperately to move into a retirement community, to live as \u201ca princess\u201d unburdened by the cooking, cleaning or yardwork required at their Maryland home. Mr. Strumsky didn\u2019t just resist the idea, he detested it. During one argument with his wife, he shouted, \u201cBy God, I\u2019ll sit in the burned-out, firebombed ruins of this home before anybody pulls me out!\u201d\n\nMr. Strumsky, 78, tells that story with a laugh. Because, as he puts it, \u201cI\u2019ve done a 180 on this.\u201d He finally gave in to his wife\u2019s wishes, and in 2011 they moved to Charlestown, a retirement community outside Baltimore. Today, it might have no bigger fan than John Strumsky. One measure of his devotion: He\u2019s the author of an exhaustive, 364-page history of Charlestown that management hands out to prospective residents.\n\nHis reluctance to move into a retirement community was not unusual. People often vow they\u2019ll never do it, for any number of reasons. They fear giving up their independence. They can\u2019t bear leaving their home. They don\u2019t like confronting their own mortality. This can lead to bitter squabbles with members of their family and other loved ones who want them to move.", "title": "How to Talk About Moving to a Retirement Home: \u2018It\u2019s a Journey\u2019", "authors": ["Peter Finch"]} {"date": "2018-04-27 00:00:00", "text": "It\u2019s even less likely that North Korea will give up its nukes now that it sees Trump poised to tear up the Iran nuclear deal.\n\nKim\u2019s game plan seems to be to sign pledges for denuclearization, leaving details to be worked out in follow-up talks, knowing that the pledges won\u2019t be fully implemented and that there will never be intrusive inspections. This may be disingenuous on the part of North Korea, but that\u2019s not terrible: It provides a face-saving way for both North Korea and the U.S. to back away from the precipice of war.\n\nTrump and Kim both badly want a meeting, so expect North Korea to release its three American detainees in the coming weeks and to make soothing statements. Trump and Kim will present themselves as historic peacemakers as they sign some kind of declaration calling for peace and denuclearization, with some kind of timetable; Trump\u2019s aides will then say that he deserves the Nobel Peace Prize more than Barack Obama did.\n\nI hope Trump will also raise human rights issues. A commission of inquiry suggested that North Korea has committed crimes against humanity \u201con a massive scale\u201d in its labor camps, and we should push for access to these camps by humanitarian organizations.\n\n\u201cOver 100,000 people, a figure that includes countless innocent family members of so-called enemies of the state, are effectively consigned to die in North Korea\u2019s political prisons,\u201d Navi Pillay, a former U.N. high commissioner for human rights, told me. \u201cThe forced abortions, infanticide, persecution of Christians, torture and summary executions that regularly occur in those various facilities are well documented. President Trump can demand that the Red Cross and the international community be given access to North Korea\u2019s prisons and labor camp systems.\u201d\n\nIn the meantime, I\u2019m guessing that the North will halt all nuclear and missile testing (hopefully, including short-range missiles), and will stop production of plutonium at its reactors in Yongbyon (North Korea may also claim to stop enriching uranium, but that\u2019s more difficult to verify). In exchange, China and South Korea will quietly ease sanctions \u2014 and Kim will get what he has always wanted, the legitimacy of being treated as a world leader, as an equal, and as the ruler of a de facto nuclear state.\n\nBoth Kim and Trump benefit politically from that scenario, and for that matter so does the world: Hard-liners will fume that we\u2019re being played and that the North is not verifiably giving up nuclear weapons \u2014 true \u2014 but it\u2019s all preferable to war.", "title": "Opinion | How to Understand What\u2019s Happening in North Korea", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-30 00:00:00", "text": "Tom Ford\u2019s new Extreme line of twinkly shadows ($36) in an intriguing new base formula of gel polymers and oils create a barely there, flexible film. (The texture feels almost creamy.) Glitter, pearl and micronized pigments stay on better, so much so that the shadow can appear 3-D or nearly wet.\n\n\u201cThe formula is best applied dry with fingertips or with a brush,\u201d said the makeup artist Isamaya Ffrench, who worked with Mr. Ford on this collection.\n\nThere is also pigment underneath the glitter that has a slight sparkle. \u201cIt\u2019s so when you blend the pigment out, it doesn\u2019t drag but rather melts into the eyelid,\u201d Ms. Ffrench said.\n\nTom Ford isn\u2019t alone in rethinking glitter. Bodyography\u2019s gluten-free and vegan Glitter Pigments ($23) are based on a similar gel-base concept. The rosy Stratus hue is in tune with the pink eye shadows spotted recently on social media and runways.\n\nIf you\u2019re looking for a mirrored, metallic effect without obvious pieces of glitter, Tarte\u2019s Chrome Paint Shadow ($22) is a winner. Dip your ring finger into the little pot and swipe onto your lids for \u201dSpace Odyssey\u201d-worthy results.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe New Face Powders\n\nInnovation isn\u2019t transforming only eye shadows. Armani Beauty is introducing a new compact called Neo Nude Fusion Powder ($58). The formula, which has the appearance of a powder, is essentially a dehydrated liquid foundation that \u201creactivates\u201d when it comes into contact with your skin\u2019s own moisture. Linda Cantello, the international makeup artist for the Armani Beauty, was jazzed by the radiant, natural-looking finish. (Anyone who wants full coverage will need to layer it with foundation.)\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMs. Cantello advised using a \u201clarge natural-hair brush to apply directly over skin.\u201d Perhaps best of all, the formula won\u2019t cake as the day wears on. Also, the powder works best on skin that is somewhat oily or very moisturized; otherwise, it can take up to 20 to 30 minutes to settle. Once it settles, though, the finish is essentially seamless.\n\nFor a more matte look for spring, Urban Decay offers a novel option: a translucent powder that\u2019s designed to mix with your foundation. Called the Velvetizer ($34), it is especially effective at tempering a dewy-finish foundation. Tweak the amount you add according to the humidity or your skin that day.\n\nPhoto\n\nPowdered Lips\n\nLip powders have become the nouveau finish of choice. That\u2019s partly because of their \u201cversatility,\u201d said the Chanel makeup artist Cyndle K, referring to the company\u2019s Poudre \u00e0 L\u00e8vres Lip Balm and Powder Duos ($37).\n\n\u201cApplied on top of a lipstick, the powder gives unbelievable staying power and helps prevent feathering,\u201d she said. \u201cOr you can create a beautiful bitten-lip look by applying the balm and then using your finger to dab on the color.\u201d\n\nLooking for a range of powdery hues? Nars has teamed with the London fashion designer Erdem Moralioglu on a collection that hit the Nars site in mid-April. Among the limited-edition items is a lip powder palette with a tinted balm ($49).\n\nOr wear your own favorite lip balm with CLE Melting Lip Powder ($19.99). The Korean brand designed its formula to be multifunctional. Add a dab to your cheeks for a pulled-together look.\n\nPhoto\n\nJelly Illuminators\n\nThe new jelly illuminators feel young and playful. Jiggly and bouncy, they\u2019re also fun to capture on camera, as demonstrated by Fars\u00e1li, a social-media-savvy brand whose rose gold Jelly Beam Illuminator ($40) has been quite the hit on Instagram. Another option is the Inc.redible You Glow Girl Iridescent Jelly ($12), though the violet-tinged iridescent sheen isn\u2019t for everyone.\n\nUnlike highlighting powders and liquids, which can wander, the jelly consistency largely stays put. It also offers a pretty, slightly dewy finish without the heaviness of a cream formula. Use as you would any highlighting product: Dab on tops of cheekbones, brow bones and the cupid\u2019s bow with your ring finger.\n\nIf you\u2019re new to highlighting, try an illuminator with slightly less pigment, like the H20+ Probiotic Champagne Illuminator ($22), which will give you a subtle, natural-looking sheen.", "title": "How to Wear Spring\u2019s Most Inventive New Makeup", "authors": ["Bee Shapiro", "Skin Deep"]} {"date": "2018-04-03 00:00:00", "text": "Tragically, predictably, infuriatingly, we\u2019re again mourning a shooting \u2014 this time at YouTube\u2019s headquarters \u2014 even as the drive for gun safety legislation has stalled in Washington. Polls show that nine out of 10 Americans favor basic steps like universal background checks before gun purchases, but the exceptions are the president and a majority in Congress.\n\nUsually pundits toss out their own best arguments while ignoring the other side\u2019s, but today I\u2019m going to try something new and engage directly with the arguments made by gun advocates:\n\nYou liberals are in a panic over guns, but look at the numbers. Any one gun is less likely to kill a person than any one vehicle. But we\u2019re not traumatized by cars, and we don\u2019t try to ban them.\n\nIt\u2019s true that any particular car is more likely to be involved in a fatality than any particular gun. But cars are actually a perfect example of the public health approach that we should apply to guns. We don\u2019t ban cars, but we do work hard to take a dangerous product and regulate it to limit the damage.\n\nWe do that through seatbelts and airbags, through speed limits and highway barriers, through driver\u2019s licenses and insurance requirements, through crackdowns on drunken driving and texting while driving. I once calculated that since 1921, we had reduced the auto fatality rate per 100 million miles driven by 95 percent.", "title": "Opinion | How to Win an Argument About Guns", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-26 00:00:00", "text": "At a time black colleges are seeing jumps in applications and enrollment \u2014 Howard had a 25 percent increase in applicants this year, to almost 21,000 \u2014 the sense of crisis here speaks to a contradiction that is befuddling the leaders of many black colleges: As their institutions grow, they continue to be burdened by financial woes. And few face more scrutiny than Howard.\n\n\u201cEveryone sets their eyes on Howard, especially in the black community,\u201d said Amos Jackson III, a junior at the university and the president-elect of the student government. \u201cWe\u2019re the mecca of African-American learning, of African-American cultural, social interactions. We set the premise for how that looks.\u201d\n\nThe aid scandal came to light when an anonymous post on the website Medium alleged that school workers had misappropriated almost a million dollars of aid money. The president of the university, Dr. Wayne A. I. Frederick, soon acknowledged that over several years, some employees who had received tuition assistance had also been improperly given university grants. Six were fired.\n\nThe revelation was \u201cthe straw that broke the camel\u2019s back,\u201d Mr. Jackson said. Protests \u2014 led by HU Resist, the group behind the list of demands \u2014 broke out on campus.\n\n\u201cThis was the first mass mobilization of students and showing of student power of this generation at an H.B.C.U.,\u201d said Alexis McKenney, a senior at Howard and leader of HU Resist. \u201cThat made a big statement.\u201d\n\nFederal officials also took notice. The week the aid scandal became public, the Education Department informed Dr. Frederick that it would conduct an extensive review of the university\u2019s management of financial aid, according to current and former officials familiar with details of the notification.\n\nA university report on the financial aid controversy described violations over a six-year period, starting before Dr. Frederick became president, that involved $369,000 in misappropriated funds.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe sit-in at the administration building, which for some on campus recalled previous student occupations in 1968 and 1989, ended on April 6, when Howard released a statement of commitments that appeared to address many of the students\u2019 demands.\n\nThe commitments were significant, if indefinite. Mr. Jackson, Ms. McKenney, a university trustee and Dr. Frederick gathered on the steps of the administration building to announce them. They included a recommendation to freeze undergraduate tuition, a deadline extension for housing deposits, more student say in administrative appointments, and the creation of task forces to examine mental health and sexual assault services, among other agreements.\n\n\u201cThis experience,\u201d Ms. McKenney said, \u201creally highlighted a large gap between the student experience and the board of trustees\u2019 perception of that student experience.\u201d\n\nOne student demand was a call for Dr. Frederick\u2019s resignation, which was later rescinded after the organizers of the sit-in concluded that such an effort would be unproductive.\n\nBut soon after, Dr. Frederick received a vote of no confidence from hundreds of Howard faculty members, a public blow just days after he appeared to have mended some of his rifts with student organizers. He had been handed a similar no-confidence measure last year from faculty members, who cited the university\u2019s continuing financial problems and concerns about transparency.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Race/Related Newsletter Join a deep and provocative exploration of race with a diverse group of New York Times journalists. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nDr. Frederick also faced criticism weeks before the sit-in, when a student posted a screenshot of an email she received from him in which he appears to reprimand her after she expressed concerns about student housing and a shortage of rooms. \u201cYour tone and tenor is inappropriate,\u201d he wrote in the email. Dr. Frederick later apologized, the student said.\n\n\u201cOur president is very good on the books: We\u2019ve raised crazy amounts of money, new dorms,\u201d Mr. Jackson said. \u201cAll of these great things on the C.E.O. side. But we have to recognize there\u2019s more to it, where you have to have a relationship with students.\u201d\n\nDr. Frederick, who declined to comment for this article, has sustained support from key campus groups: the trustees, the alumni association and the university\u2019s council of deans, which speaks for the heads of Howard\u2019s schools and colleges. Some instructors, against the prevailing mood of students, have urged patience with the established order.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nProfessor Hogan, who graduated from Howard in 2003, was part of a group of 20 faculty and staff members who signed a letter in support of Dr. Frederick during the sit-in. He has since had to defend himself to students upset about his public backing of the president.\n\n\u201cOn a president\u2019s watch, good things can happen and bad things can happen, and those things can be attributed to the president in ways he or she might not be responsible for,\u201d Professor Hogan said.\n\nOne of the president\u2019s central responsibilities is raising private donations to supplement the money the university receives from the government. The financial aid scandal came as the school was celebrating federal funding increases, including nearly $40 million for a program that supports black colleges, and $10.6 million for Howard\u2019s academic programs, endowment and hospital, which has struggled with lawsuits and layoffs in recent years.\n\nAdministering that hospital, along with a large undergraduate college and several professional and graduate schools, has saddled Howard with heavy financial burdens. That many of Howard\u2019s students come from modest means and rely on financial aid (a majority of students of historically black colleges and universities rely on Pell Grants) only adds to those strains.\n\nThis made the announcement of the financial aid misappropriation even more agonizing to Howard students and staff members, many of whom said the university was often held up as a standard-bearer for black colleges.\n\n\u201cPeople feel like if Howard can experience these problems, what does that mean for other H.B.C.U.s that aren\u2019t as big as Howard, who don\u2019t have the federal appropriations that Howard receives from the government?\u201d said Robert Palmer, an associate professor of education at the university.\n\nSome of those smaller colleges have lost their accreditations. Others have been dogged by declining donations from alumni.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s this cycle that prevents them from donating again, once they see problems,\u201d said Bakari Sibert, a Howard sophomore who transferred from Morehouse College, an H.B.C.U. in Atlanta.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cIf there were some reworking of the system, this stigma about H.B.C.U.s not being efficient would solve itself,\u201d Mr. Sibert added.\n\nMarybeth Gasman, a professor at the University of Pennsylvania who studies historically black colleges, said Howard\u2019s most recent trials are a repeat of a phenomenon she has long observed: that black universities are held publicly accountable for their problems and one another\u2019s in a way larger, mostly white universities are not.\n\n\u201cPart of this,\u201d she said of the conflicts at Howard, \u201cis if you\u2019re at one institution, that\u2019s your experience. You don\u2019t know it\u2019s going on at other institutions.\u201d\n\nOutside observers, Professor Gasman said, \u201ctake one H.B.C.U. college problem and generalize it.\u201d\n\nDespite the recent conflicts, there have been ripples of optimism at Howard. The students\u2019 interactions with administrators \u2014 and the university\u2019s subsequent commitments \u2014 have encouraged faith in the long-term health of the institution.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s always an inside joke in the Howard family: new Howard, old Howard. I think this is the turning point of the new Howard, where we can really start a new tradition of student administration,\u201d Mr. Jackson said. \u201cThat\u2019s what it\u2019s going to take to have us be here for another 150 years.\u201d\n\nEven amid protests this month \u2014 as sit-in participants made sandwiches for the homeless, registered voters and met with trustees \u2014 the rhythms of academic life endured.\n\nNear the end of the occupation early this month, Keneshia N. Grant, an assistant professor of political science at Howard, asked her students if they wanted to discuss the protests occurring just yards away from where they were sitting. They were interested, Professor Grant said, but after 10 minutes they asked to return to a discussion on gentrification. Class was in order.", "title": "Howard University Stares Down Challenges, and Hard Questions on Black Colleges", "authors": ["Noah Weiland"]} {"date": "2018-04-30 00:00:00", "text": "So far, Donald Trump and his allies in Congress have achieved one and only one major legislative victory: passing a large tax cut, mainly aimed at corporations and business owners. The tax cut\u2019s proponents promised that it would lead to a dramatic acceleration of economic growth and produce big gains in wages; they hoped that it would also yield big political dividends for the midterm elections.\n\nSo how\u2019s it going? Politically, the tax cut is a damp squib: Most voters say they haven\u2019t seen any boost to their paychecks, and Republicans are barely talking about the law in their political campaigns. But what about the economics?\n\nYou might be tempted to say that it\u2019s too early to tell. After all, the law has been in effect for only a few months, and we got our first look at post-tax-cut economic growth only last week. But here\u2019s the thing: To deliver on its backers\u2019 promises, the tax cut would have to produce a huge surge in business investment \u2014 not in the long run, not five or 10 years from now, but more or less right away. And there\u2019s no sign that anything like that is happening.\n\nLet\u2019s talk about the economics here.\n\nAnything that increases the budget deficit should, other things being the same, lead to higher overall spending and a short-run bump in the economy (although there\u2019s no indication of such a bump in the first-quarter numbers, which were underwhelming). But if you want to boost overall spending, you don\u2019t have to give huge tax breaks to corporations. You could do lots of other things instead \u2014 say, spend money on fixing America\u2019s crumbling infrastructure, an issue on which Trump keeps promising a plan but never delivers.", "title": "Opinion | How\u2019s That Tax Cut Working Out?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-17 00:00:00", "text": "Major American carriers such as Verizon and AT&T have since shunned Huawei. The Commerce and Treasury Departments have subpoenaed it over possible violations of American sanctions on Iran and North Korea. And bills are before Congress to stop government agencies and contractors from buying Huawei products.\n\nIn January, researchers discovered security flaws in the microprocessors inside nearly all of the world\u2019s computers. A Senate committee wrote to Huawei\u2019s founder to ask what the company knew about the vulnerabilities, and how it had been affected by them. Huawei decided not to respond.\n\nThen, last week, Huawei laid off five American employees, including William B. Plummer, the executive who was the face of its Sisyphean efforts to win over Washington.\n\nThe company has said repeatedly that its products pose no security risk and that it complies with the law everywhere it operates. Still, the layoffs appear to be an acknowledgment by Huawei that it has failed to clear the political cloud around it.\n\n\u201cSome things cannot change their course according to our wishes,\u201d Eric Xu, Huawei\u2019s deputy chairman, said at the company\u2019s annual meeting with analysts on Tuesday in its home city, Shenzhen. \u201cWith some things, when you let them go, you actually feel more at ease.\u201d\n\nMr. Plummer, who was Huawei\u2019s vice president of external affairs, had been with the company for almost eight years. He was the most senior member of Huawei\u2019s American policy team who was not a Chinese citizen.\n\nIt is not clear whether he will be replaced. The company\u2019s policy operations in the United States are led by a relatively recent arrival, Zhang Ruijun, who took the post nine months ago after working for the company in Mexico and Russia.", "title": "Huawei and ZTE Hit Hard as U.S. Moves Against Chinese Tech Firms", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-17 00:00:00", "text": "One recent example of reduced communication with Washington came after the discovery in January of security flaws in the microprocessors inside nearly all of the world\u2019s computers. A Senate committee wrote to Huawei\u2019s founder to ask what the company knew about the vulnerabilities, and how it had been affected by them. Huawei decided not to respond.\n\n\u201cSome things cannot change their course according to our wishes,\u201d Eric Xu, Huawei\u2019s deputy chairman, said at the company\u2019s annual meeting with analysts on Tuesday. \u201cWith some things, when you let them go, you actually feel more at ease.\u201d\n\nHuawei\u2019s main Chinese rival, ZTE, also hit a roadblock in Washington this week. The Commerce Department said it would ban the much smaller company from buying American components after it made false statements to the government as part of an investigation into possible violations of American sanctions.\n\nPhoto\n\nYet Huawei\u2019s experience also illustrates how little Washington can do to curb Chinese influence in cutting-edge industries throughout the rest of the world.\n\nAt Tuesday\u2019s meeting with analysts, executives at the company, which says it is owned by its employees and not by the Chinese state, emphasized growth opportunities in Europe and Asia. They also described ambitions to further diversify Huawei\u2019s business into helping organizations of all kinds \u2014 not merely wireless carriers, but factories, governments and the police \u2014 transform themselves through cloud computing and artificial intelligence.\n\n\u201cFor Huawei, the major challenge is not how we can serve operators better,\u201d said David Wang, a company president. Instead, he said, \u201cwe have to work harder to cope with wider challenges in all industries.\u201d\n\nHuawei\u2019s troubles in the United States have been mounting since 2012, when a congressional report warned that its gear could be used to spy on Americans or to destabilize American telecom networks. The company spent $1.2 million on lobbying that year. Last year, it spent $60,000 on such efforts.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMajor American carriers such as Verizon and AT&T have since shunned Huawei. The Commerce and Treasury Departments have subpoenaed it over possible violations of American sanctions on Iran and North Korea. The company\u2019s ambitions to become a major smartphone brand \u2014 it is already the world\u2019s third largest, after Samsung and Apple \u2014 were curtailed when AT&T abandoned a deal this year to sell its handsets. And a bill is before Congress to stop government agencies and contractors from buying Huawei products.\n\nThe company has said repeatedly that its products pose no security risk and that it complies with the law everywhere it operates. Still, the layoffs last week appear to be an acknowledgment by Huawei that it has failed to clear the political cloud around it.\n\nMr. Plummer, Huawei\u2019s vice president of external affairs, had been with the company for almost eight years. He was the most senior member of Huawei\u2019s American policy team who was not a Chinese citizen.\n\nIt is not clear whether he will be replaced. The company\u2019s policy operations in the United States are led by a relatively recent arrival, Zhang Ruijun, who took the post nine months ago after working for the company in Mexico and Russia.\n\nA Huawei spokesman said in a statement that any layoffs simply reflected an effort to better align resources with \u201cbusiness strategy and objectives.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Interested in All Things Tech? The Bits newsletter will keep you updated on the latest from Silicon Valley and the technology industry. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cAny changes to staffing size or structure are simply a reflection of standard business organization,\u201d he said.\n\nFounded three decades ago, Huawei made $93 billion in revenue last year \u2014 not much less than Google\u2019s parent company, Alphabet, and more than its two main rivals in telecom gear, Nokia of Finland and Ericsson of Sweden, combined.\n\nWhen it comes to the next generation of mobile internet, or 5G, Huawei has invested heavily in technology development.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nChinese carriers are likely to deploy such networks more quickly than their American counterparts are, at least in the beginning. But as 5G comes up in the United States, Japan, South Korea and Europe, Nokia and Ericsson will catch up, said Pierre Ferragu, an analyst in New York with New Street Research.\n\nStill, Huawei\u2019s telecom business could be dampened as other countries, particularly allies of the United States, weigh risks to their national security. The chief executive of a leading wireless provider in South Korea told the newspaper The Korea Herald last month that the company was unsure whether to use Huawei\u2019s 5G equipment.\n\nIn the United States, Huawei customers that would be affected by the F.C.C.\u2019s proposed rule \u2014 small carriers in rural areas \u2014 may soon need to find new equipment suppliers.\n\nThese carriers love Huawei gear, said Carri Bennet, general counsel for the Rural Wireless Association, an industry group for American telecom companies with fewer than 100,000 subscribers.\n\n\u201cThey just love it,\u201d she said. \u201cIt works like a charm, the customer service support is awesome,\u201d and the price is attractive, she added.\n\nThe association\u2019s members have even elected a Huawei executive, William Levy, to their board.\n\nMs. Bennet said that rather than blacklisting specific manufacturers, Washington should be creating a system for testing telecom gear for security vulnerabilities.\n\n\u201cThese companies who are reliant on this support, they don\u2019t have the funds to overhaul their whole network,\u201d she said. \u201cPublic safety, getting 911 services, broadband \u2014 it all just starts falling apart.\u201d", "title": "Huawei, Failing to Crack U.S. Market, Signals a Change in Tactics", "authors": ["Raymond Zhong", "Paul Mozur"]} {"date": "2018-04-20 00:00:00", "text": "The data was prepared by the Office of Refugee Resettlement, a division of the Department of Health and Human Services that takes custody of children who have been removed from migrant parents. Senior officials at the Department of Homeland Security, which processes migrants at the border, initially denied that the numbers were so high. But after they were confirmed to The Times by three federal officials who work closely with these cases, a spokesman for the health and human services department on Friday acknowledged in a statement that there were \u201capproximately 700.\u201d\n\nHomeland security officials said the agency does not separate families at the border for deterrence purposes. \u201cAs required by law, D.H.S. must protect the best interests of minor children crossing our borders, and occasionally this results in separating children from an adult they are traveling with if we cannot ascertain the parental relationship, or if we think the child is otherwise in danger,\u201d a spokesman for the agency said in a statement.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Race/Related Newsletter Join a deep and provocative exploration of race with a diverse group of New York Times journalists. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nBut Trump administration officials have suggested publicly in the past that they were, indeed, considering a deterrence policy. Last year, John F. Kelly, President Trump\u2019s chief of staff, floated the idea while he was serving as homeland security secretary.\n\nIf approved, the plan would have closed detention facilities that are designed to house families and replaced them with separate shelters for adults and children. The White House supported the move and convened a group of officials from several federal agencies to consider its merits. But the Department of Homeland Security has said the policy was never adopted.\n\nChildren removed from their families are taken to shelters run by nongovernmental organizations. There, workers seek to identify a relative or guardian in the United States who can take over the child\u2019s care. But if no such adult is available, the children can languish in custody indefinitely. Operators of these facilities say they are often unable to locate the parents of separated children because the children arrive without proper records.\n\nOnce a child has entered the shelter system, there is no firm process to determine whether they have been separated from someone who was legitimately their parent, or for reuniting parents and children who had been mistakenly separated, said a Border Patrol official, who was not authorized to discuss the agency\u2019s policies publicly.\n\n\u201cThe idea of punishing parents who are trying to save their children\u2019s lives, and punishing children for being brought to safety by their parents by separating them, is fundamentally cruel and un-American,\u201d said Michelle Bran\u00e9, director of the Migrant Rights and Justice program at the Women\u2019s Refugee Commission, an advocacy group that conducts interviews and monitoring at immigration detention centers, including those that house children. \u201cIt really to me is just a horrific \u2018Sophie\u2019s Choice\u2019 for a mom.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMirian has pinballed across Texas, held at various times in three other detention centers. She is part of a lawsuit filed by the American Civil Liberties Union on behalf of many immigrant parents seeking to prohibit family separations at the border.\n\nHer son\u2019s name, along with Mirian\u2019s surname, are being withheld for their safety. But in a declaration she filed in that case, she said she was never told why her son was being taken away from her. Since February, the only word she has received about him has come from a case manager at the facility in San Antonio where he is being held. Her son asked about her and \u201ccried all the time\u201d in the days after he arrived at the facility, the case worker said, adding that the boy had developed an ear infection and a cough.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cI had no idea that I would be separated from my child for seeking help,\u201d Mirian said in her sworn statement. \u201cI am so anxious to be reunited with him.\u201d\n\nProtecting children at the border is complicated because there have, indeed, been instances of fraud. Tens of thousands of migrants arrive there every year, and those with children in tow are often released into the United States more quickly than adults who come alone, because of restrictions on the amount of time that minors can be held in custody. Some migrants have admitted they brought their children not only to remove them from danger in such places as Central America and Africa, but because they believed it would cause the authorities to release them from custody sooner.\n\nOthers have admitted to posing falsely with children who are not their own, and Border Patrol officials say that such instances of fraud are increasing.\n\nAs the debate carries on, pressure from the White House to enact a separation policy has continued. In conversations this month with Kirstjen Nielsen, the homeland security secretary, Mr. Trump has repeatedly expressed frustration that the agency has not been aggressive enough in policing the border, according to a person at the White House who is familiar with the discussions.\n\nOfficials presented Mr. Trump with a list of proposals, including the plan to routinely separate immigrant adults from their children. The president urged Ms. Nielsen to move forward with the policies, the person said.\n\nBut even groups that support stricter immigration policies have stopped short of endorsing a family separation policy. Jessica M. Vaughan, the director of policy studies for the Center for Immigration Studies, one such group, said that family separation should only be used as a \u201clast resort.\u201d\n\nHowever, she said that some migrants were using children as \u201chuman shields\u201d in order to get out of immigration custody faster.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cIt makes no sense at all for the government to just accept these attempts at fraud,\u201d Ms. Vaughan said. \u201cIf it appears that the child is being used in this way, it is in the best interest of the child to be kept separately from the parent, for the parent to be prosecuted, because it\u2019s a crime and it\u2019s one that has to be deterred and prosecuted.\u201d", "title": "Hundreds of Immigrant Children Have Been Taken From Parents at U.S. Border", "authors": ["Caitlin Dickerson"]} {"date": "2018-04-08 00:00:00", "text": "The results were not unexpected, given the divisions of the opposition and the uneven playing field on which they were forced to compete. But they still alarmed Western officials who view Mr. Orban\u2019s style of government as a threat to values such as the rule of law and a free press.\n\nMr. Orban\u2019s victory is likely to embolden other leaders who have used a similar playbook, including those in nearby Poland, where the governing party has openly emulated his tactics.\n\nMr. Orban built his campaign on castigating Western nations as a hostile, multicultural force, where Muslim immigrants ran wild and where traditional family values were under constant assault.\n\nInstead of looking to France or Germany for inspiration, Mr. Orban has talked fondly of the autocratic systems of Turkey and Russia.\n\nStill, Hungary is a member of the European Union and deeply reliant on the funds the bloc provides, especially for projects like building roads, bridges and other critical infrastructure.\n\nAs Mr. Orban systematically co-opted the tools of the state \u2014 from the courts to the schools to the electoral system itself \u2014 Brussels has proved unable to effectively pressure him to change course.\n\nOn Sunday, it was the voters who got their chance to have their say.\n\nUnder a brilliant blue sky on warm spring day, more than 70 percent of voters flocked to polling stations across Budapest, the grand capital city, with its stately boulevards lined with architectural treasures.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAcross the country, it was a similar story, with thousands of voters waiting in line hours after the scheduled 7 p.m. end of polling to cast their two ballots \u2014 one for a national list of candidates and one for a local list.\n\nImmigration was a major focus of the election, and throughout the day, state television replayed some of the most dramatic images from 2015, when the crisis of refugees and immigrants flooding into Europe from the Middle East and Africa was at its peak.\n\nPhoto\n\nFor Attila Boda, 48, an army reservist and dishwasher, the perceived threat to his country was persuasive. He cast his two ballots for Fidesz.\n\n\u201cWe don\u2019t want migrants to come to Hungary,\u201d he said. \u201cThey are unwilling to integrate and they respect only their own laws. They want a war; they are brought to Europe by ISIS.\u201d\n\nOthers expressed concern over the long-term consequences of Sunday\u2019s vote.\n\nIstvan Hegedus, the chairman of the Hungarian Europe Society, a research institute, was an early member of Fidesz, at a time when Mr. Orban was a firebrand champion of democracy after three decades of Communist rule.\n\nBut Mr. Hegedus left the party in 1994 and says he has watched with alarm as Mr. Orban has transformed himself from a centrist friend of the West into the leader of a crusade to create what Mr. Orban himself calls an \u201cilliberal democracy.\u201d\n\n\u201cAt each step on this path, the European politicians have proven ineffective,\u201d Mr. Hegedus said. \u201cI think the mistake they made was they viewed him as an enfant terrible, but someone they could deal with. They convinced themselves that we know this man and that there is really nothing at stake.\u201d\n\nSunday\u2019s election, he said, was the best \u2014 and perhaps, last \u2014 chance for Hungary to change course.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nJozsef Peter Martin, the executive director of Transparency International Hungary, an anticorruption advocacy group, said the election was conducted on an unfair playing field. He compared the vote to playing soccer on a field set at a 45-degree angle.\n\n\u201cThe whole institutional system is swayed to one party,\u201d Mr. Martin said. From the state-controlled news media to the gerrymandering of electoral districts to favor Fidesz, an already fragmented opposition found it hard to compete, he said.\n\nUnder the current system, put in place in 2012, voters cast two ballots. One is for a national list, with parties awarded seats in Parliament based on the percentage of votes. That accounts for 93 of the 199 seats.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe rest are filled by the winners of local elections. This is where Fidesz holds the strongest advantage. In the 2014 election, Fidesz candidates were often able to win with as little as 40 percent of the vote because the opposition was split.\n\nNonetheless, in the closing days of this campaign, a grass-roots effort arose to promote \u201cstrategic voting.\u201d\n\nUsing websites to help voters figure out which candidate had the best chance to defeat Fidesz, voters were encouraged to put their political loyalties aside to defeat the governing party.\n\nGergely Karacsony, the mayor of a district in Budapest and a leading opposition contender for prime minister, was placed at the head of an alliance between two left-wing groups \u2014 the Socialist Party and a Green party \u2014 in a partnership based more on need than political affinity.\n\nMr. Karacsony said that Mr. Orban had already largely \u201cdestroyed the constitutional order\u201d and, in an interview before the election, he said he feared what an Orban victory would mean for the country.\n\nMr. Orban has cast himself as the only person capable of defending Hungary from threats seen and unseen. He has also tapped nationalistic sentiments by portraying officials in Brussels as meddling bureaucrats who are a threat to Hungary\u2019s sovereignty.\n\nPhoto\n\nAs the election neared, his already caustic rhetoric took an even darker turn, vowing revenge on political enemies and demonizing immigrants.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cWe do not want to be a multicolored country,\u201d he said during a speech in February. If his point was not clear enough, he said that he did not want Hungarians to interact with immigrants \u201cin such a way that our color is mixed with others\u2019 colors.\u201d\n\nThe United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights, Zeid Ra\u2019ad al-Hussein, denounced Mr. Orban\u2019s remarks as racist.\n\n\u201cThe security state is back and fundamental freedoms are in retreat in every region of the world,\u201d Mr. Hussein said in a statement. \u201cShame is also in retreat. Xenophobes and racists in Europe are casting off any sense of embarrassment \u2014 like Hungary\u2019s Viktor Orban.\u201d\n\nEdit Zgut, a foreign-policy analyst at Political Capital, a research organization based in Budapest, said Mr. Orban had proved effective at channeling public anger. Among the most frequent targets of Mr. Orban\u2019s scorn has been George Soros, the American billionaire and philanthropist who was born in Hungary.\n\nMs. Zgut said that Mr. Orban\u2019s attacks on Mr. Soros, and on the European Union and the United Nations, served a dual purpose: to channel the frustration of anti-establishment voters toward leaders in Brussels and to drive home his contention that migration is the driving factor behind Western accusations that his government was weakening the rule of law even as corruption spreads.\n\n\u201cIf he portrays Brussels and the E.U. as the enemy of the state, his voters might consider the E.U.\u2019s criticisms of the government as part of a broader conspiracy that questions the sovereign decisions of Hungarians,\u201d she said. \u201cThis is why he keeps repeating that this clash between Brussels and Hungary is all about migration.\u201d\n\nIn the weeks leading up to the election, however, it was not concern about the erosion of the rule of law that most galvanized opposition voters. It was corruption, with several high-profile associates and government officials entangled in a variety of scandals involving the alleged looting of state resources.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn addition to local press reports, the European Union\u2019s anticorruption agency, OLAF, released a report in January alleging that a company controlled by Mr. Orban\u2019s son-in-law regularly received huge sums of EU development funds.\n\nZoltan Kovacs, a government spokesman, dismissed groups like Transparency International as tools of those determined to bring down the government.\n\n\u201cCorruption allegations are the only tool the opposition has,\u201d he said.\n\nHe pointed to the strong economy \u2014 the World Bank has projected a 3.9 percent growth rate for Hungary this year \u2014 as evidence that Mr. Orban\u2019s system was working to the benefit of the people.\n\nThat economic growth, however, did not deter Ilona Kovacs, 73, a retired English teacher, from voting against Mr. Orban.\n\n\u201cI don\u2019t like the local candidate I voted for, but I had to, I had no choice,\u201d she said, noting she cast her ballot for the only candidate with a chance of defeating the local Fidesz politician.\n\n\u201cI want to stop the corruption,\u201d she said, adding that Mr. Orban\u2019s \u201canti-migrant and anti-Soros speech is unbearable.\u201d\n\nAn Orban victory, she feared, would mean that \u201cthey will continue to destroy our democratic institutions, everything will be theirs.\u201d\n\n\u201cI had dreamed, that in my old age, there would be better days ahead,\u201d she said. \u201cBut now I feel like my soul is on fire.\u201d", "title": "Hungary Election Gives Orban Big Majority, and Control of Constitution", "authors": ["Marc Santora"]} {"date": "2018-04-09 00:00:00", "text": "While taking the government to task for the way the campaign was conducted, including not allowing civilian monitors, the O.S.C.E. found no problems with the execution of the election itself, where more than 8.3 million people were registered to vote.\n\nAsked about multiple reports of irregularities in the local news media, Mr. Wake said that his group\u2019s mission was limited to looking at the technical issues that relate to counting votes and tabulating results.\n\nOn the national voting list, Fidesz secured more than 49 percent of the vote, with some 2.6 million voting for the party and its Christian Democratic allies. That was roughly the same as the seven largest opposition parties combined.\n\nFidesz also won convincingly in local elections, securing a two-thirds majority in Parliament, which will give the party a free hand to pursue still deeper legal and constitutional changes that have already given it firm control over courts and other state institutions.\n\nIt remains unclear exactly what other measures Mr. Orban might pursue. But Mr. Orban said in a major speech in March that after the election he would seek \u201cmoral, political and legal amends\u201d against his critics. And he hinted last week that the government might try to amend the Constitution to stop the European Union from imposing migrant quotas.\n\nA first step may be a \u201cstop Soros\u201d law that would allow the government to impose financial and other penalties on nongovernmental organizations that assist asylum seekers and refugees.\n\nAlready, Mr. Orban\u2019s harsh talk about immigrants has been matched by policies to close off the country. Over the last three years Mr. Orban has systematically curtailed the ability of people to seek asylum here.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWhere there was once a wall built by the Communist rulers seeking to keep Hungarians from leaving the country, he has erected a steel-and-wire fence to keep people from entering the country. He created two \u201ctransit zones\u201d at the Serbian border, barred to the news media, where those seeking asylum must pass.\n\nThe country now only allows five asylum seekers to be processed at each location every week, and that is just the start of a cumbersome process meant to make this country as unwelcoming as possible.\n\nThe reaction of human rights advocates and nongovernmental organizations, often the target of government attacks, to Mr. Orban\u2019s victory was swift and defiant.\n\nAmnesty International\u2019s Europe director, Gauri van Gulik, said the group was steadfast in its resolve to work to expose abuses.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cWe will continue to push back against attempts to stoke hostility toward refugees and migrants and will continue to speak up for groups that support and defend them,\u201d she said. \u201cWe will not be cowed by those who attempt to muzzle Hungary\u2019s critical voices and to create an atmosphere of fear.\u201d\n\nThere is little doubt that Mr. Orban\u2019s victory presents an even stiffer test for the European Union, which will now have to deal with a vastly empowered Hungarian leader who has already challenged many of the bloc\u2019s core democratic principles.\n\nThe European Commission president, Jean-Claude Juncker, will write Mr. Orban to congratulate him on his \u201cclear victory,\u201d said the commission\u2019s spokesman, Margaritis Schinas.\n\nBut he added: \u201cThe European Union is a union of democracy and values. President Juncker and the Commission feel that defending these principles and defending these values is the common duty of all member states with no exception.\u201d\n\nHowever, Mr. Orban\u2019s victory was cheered by other world leaders with a similar outlook.\n\nJaroslaw Kaszynski, the leader of Poland\u2019s governing party, visited Mr. Orban in the closing days of the campaign and made his admiration clear.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cYou can\u2019t think about Europe\u2019s future without remembering Viktor Orban, without remembering Hungary, Fidesz,\u201d he said on Friday. \u201cOur current friendship is also a shared road, a shared road toward our nations being independent, capable of deciding about our own future, our own internal affairs.\u201d\n\nMr. Kaszynski said that the two countries were not against Europe, rather they were \u201cpointing Europe in the right direction.\u201d\n\nIn Germany, the parliamentary leader of the far-right AfD Party, Beatrix von Storch, tweeted a picture of herself with Mr. Orban and a simple message: \u201cCongratulations, Viktor Orban! A bad day for the EU, a good one for Europe.\u201d\n\nGeert Wilders, the far-right leader in the Netherlands, congratulated Mr. Orban on Twitter, calling the vote \u201ca well deserved victory!\u201d France\u2019s Marine Le Pen suggested that the Hungarian election could be the start of a nationalist wave across the continent.\n\n\u201cA great and clear victory by Viktor Orban in Hungary: the reversal of values and the mass migration of the E.U. have once again been rebuffed,\u201d Ms. Le Pen tweeted. \u201cNationalists could gain a majority in the next European Parliament elections in 2019.\u201d\n\nHowever, it remains to be seen if Mr. Orban\u2019s success can be replicated elsewhere. As the O.S.C.E. report noted, his campaign was conducted in an environment that gave his party clear advantage.\n\nThe O.S.C.E issued a milder criticism of his campaign four years ago, saying that the governing party had a built-in advantage because of biased media coverage, restrictive campaign regulations, and the blurring of the line between the political party and the state.\n\nSo it was unlikely that the group\u2019s criticism this time would compel the party to make any changes to the way it has used the power of the state for its own purposes.\n\n\u201cA number of the issues are indeed the same,\u201d Mr. Wake said.\n\n\u201cThe response to our previous recommendations was extremely limited,\u201d he acknowledged. \u201cIt was a missed opportunity.\u201d", "title": "Hungary Election Was Free but Not Entirely Fair, Observers Say", "authors": ["Marc Santora", "Helene Bienvenu"]} {"date": "2018-04-19 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cOur position has always been clear,\u201d he said in a statement on Thursday. \u201cIssues that are not in line with my government\u2019s public policy will not be carried out. Period.\u201d\n\nEven before Puerto Rico was raked by Hurricane Maria last September, its finances were in disarray. For many years, it had borrowed money to plug holes in its budget and to repay previous borrowings, building up a debt of more than $70 billion that it could not repay. Today its debt and unfunded pension obligations total more than $120 billion, or twice the size of its economy. And the economy has been shrinking, as residents leave for better prospects on the United States mainland.\n\nHowever, the hurricane has led to a big influx of disaster relief and private insurance payments, a bonanza that led Mr. Rossell\u00f3 to project that the island could end the next five years with a cumulative surplus of $6.3 billion.\n\nBut the oversight board warned that without significant fiscal and economic reforms, Puerto Rico would be left, after the current flurry of storm-related activity, back where it started \u2014 with an unproductive economy and too much debt.\n\nThe board meeting was called to certify Puerto Rico\u2019s new fiscal plan, a document intended to chart the way forward. Six of the seven voting members voted in favor of an amended plan that includes the new austerity measures.\n\nSince 2016 the island has been functioning under a federal law called Promesa, which gives it legal powers that are normally found only in bankruptcy \u2014 in particular, protection from creditors. That means that for the time being, Puerto Rico does not have to make payments on its bond debt, for a savings of about $3 billion to $3.5 billion a year.\n\nIn exchange for those extraordinary powers, Congress required the island to submit to a federal oversight board. The law gives the governor of Puerto Rico the right to develop the all-important fiscal plan, but the board must certify it. If it does not find the governor\u2019s fiscal plan credible, it has the authority to impose its own version.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut Mr. Rossell\u00f3 has clashed repeatedly with the board, saying that as Puerto Rico\u2019s elected leader, he has the final say over economic policy.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cOur position has always been clear,\u201d he said in a statement on Thursday. \u201cIssues that are not in line with my government\u2019s public policy will not be carried out. Period.\u201d\n\nPuerto Rico has already been through the process once, certifying a fiscal plan in March 2017. But it soon became clear that the governor was not carrying out the parts he disagreed with, and the oversight board took him to court. Before the lawsuit could be adjudicated, Hurricanes Irma and Maria struck, leaving all financial planning in a shambles.\n\nThe two biggest flash points over the new plan now under review on Thursday appeared to be labor law reform and the cost of the pensions due to Puerto Rico\u2019s retired government workers. On many other elements of the fiscal plan \u2014 reducing health care spending and subsidies to cities; lowering tax rates while improving collections; and cutting red tape for businesses \u2014 the oversight board and the governor appear to be in agreement.\n\nBut board members said none of that would be enough unless Puerto Rico also softened labor laws that make it harder than anywhere else in the United States to lay off workers, which in turn makes employers on the island reluctant to hire people. Employers are also required to provide extensive paid vacations and annual holiday bonuses.\n\n\u201cObviously this is an extremely difficult issue politically,\u201d said one board member, Andrew Biggs, an economist with the conservative American Enterprise Institute. \u201cBut there\u2019s a risk of doing too little to increase Puerto Rico\u2019s labor force participation rate, which is one of the lowest in the world.\u201d The current rate of people either employed or looking for work in Puerto Rico is 40.6 percent, compared with 62.9 percent for the United States as a whole.\n\nOther board members noted that since the hurricane, young Puerto Ricans have been fleeing the island to look for work in the 50 states, even those with much less protective labor laws.\n\nBut the board does not have direct authority over the island\u2019s labor laws, only its fiscal policies. Amending the labor laws would require an act of the Puerto Rican Legislature, and Mr. Rossell\u00f3 said he would \u201cnot propose any bill that reduces vacation and/or sick leave, nor will we eliminate the Christmas bonus.\u201d\n\nBy contrast, fixing the government\u2019s insolvent pension system is a matter of fiscal policy. Retired government workers are counting on future monthly payments worth more than $50 billion in today\u2019s dollars \u2014 and the pension funds already are essentially penniless. The money appears to have been spent on other things.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nPuerto Rico is planning to revert to a pay-as-you-go pension plan, in which the government will pay retirees their monthly benefits directly from its general fund. That will severely strain the general fund, so the oversight board is calling for 10 percent average cuts in the pensions \u2014 people with the biggest pensions would get the biggest cuts.\n\n\u201cThe board wants to make sure they\u2019ll get their pensions, even though there\u2019s no money,\u201d Natalie Jaresko, executive director of the oversight board, said at Thursday\u2019s meeting. But the pain of bankruptcy, she said, had to be fairly shared with all other government creditors, along with younger residents who rely on government services.\n\nMr. Portela, the chairman of Puerto Rico\u2019s Fiscal Agency and Financial Advisory Authority, disagreed with that, calling governmental retirees \u201cthe most vulnerable of Puerto Rican society.\u201d He reminded the oversight board that teachers in Puerto Rico, like those in many of the 50 states, do not participate in Social Security.\n\nAnd the governor said he had no intention of cutting anybody\u2019s pension.\n\n\u201cOur position regarding pensions has always been crystal clear,\u201d he said. \u201cWe will not allow for a vulnerable sector of our population to be attacked. It is wrong and immoral to reduce the benefits for those that have contributed to the economy.\u201d", "title": "Hurricane Aid Has Eased Puerto Rico\u2019s Finances. It May Not Be Enough.", "authors": ["Mary Williams Walsh"]} {"date": "2018-04-12 00:00:00", "text": "Good riddance, Harvey, Irma, Maria and Nate.\n\nThey were the monsters of the hurricane season from hell. Now, their names \u2014 already cursed, loathed and spray-painted on hastily bought plywood \u2014 have been banished.\n\nAn international committee of meteorologists has officially retired the names of the four 2017 storms from the rotating roster of cyclone names. They do that, the World Meteorological Organization says, when the committee judges that \u201ca storm is so deadly or costly that the future use of its name on a different storm would be inappropriate for reasons of sensitivity.\u201d\n\nFour scratches from a single season is a lot, but it is not really a surprise, considering how nasty the storms were.", "title": "Hurricane Names That \u2018Don\u2019t Bear Repeating\u2019: Harvey, Irma, Maria and Nate", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-14 00:00:00", "text": "I asked some parents in a couple of my Facebook groups for their thoughts about what the social network means to them, particularly with the latest news and the calls to delete it. Here\u2019s some of what I heard:\n\n\u201cThis group makes me feel less alone.\u201d\n\n\u201cI felt rescued by a connection made here.\u201d\n\n\u201cI did delete Facebook and found myself sort of unraveling. I feel so alone without it. I\u2019m actually tearing up as I type this.\u201d\n\nAutism is often misunderstood (and it doesn\u2019t help that a weird puzzle piece has been used to symbolize it). But its prevalence means that most people have heard of it. Facebook might be even more valuable for individuals with very rare conditions and their families.\n\nEmily Wilkinson told me about her 5-year-old daughter, who was the first person given a diagnosis of Xia-Gibbs syndrome, caused by a genetic mutation, when she was 20 months old. Since then, about 70 people, mostly children, have been found to have the condition worldwide, and it is thought to lead to both physical and intellectual disabilities. Ms. Wilkinson says the Facebook group that parents and caregivers formed has been life-changing. Members are far-flung, and some of the parents have met in person. There were times when Ms. Wilkinson wanted to delete Facebook, or take a break, but she couldn\u2019t go through with it partly because of the group.\n\nRivka Einy-Biton has a 3-month-old son who was recently found to have megalencephaly-capillary malformation syndrome, a genetic disorder characterized by tissue overgrowth that affects brain development. There are under 300 reported cases of the condition. Joining a private Facebook group for those affected by the syndrome has helped her gain clarity and strength. Her fellow members share advice, resources and pictures of their own children. \u201cIn certain ways,\u201d she noted, \u201cthis group has been more helpful than many of the specialists we have seen.\u201d\n\nAnother parent, Juliet Ross, has a 7-year-old son with eosinophilic esophagitis, a chronic digestive disorder that requires him to use a feeding tube. She said the members of the Facebook group devoted to the condition refer to each other as \u201cour EoE family.\u201d Halloween is difficult for the children because restricted diets leave most, if not all, candy off limits, so the families join forces and mail each other cards instead.\n\nIt\u2019s useful, too, that they know the details about providing this specific type of medical care at home. \u201cWhen I have a feeding tube question in the middle of the night, it\u2019s really helpful that there might be another mom awake, maybe in Australia, who knows the answer,\u201d she noted. The kids themselves can get lonely as the only person in their circle with a feeding tube. It has become common for parents to reach out on Facebook, asking for pictures, so that their children can see that they are not alone.\n\nOf course, it\u2019s not just special-needs parents who find support on Facebook. There are lots of other important groups connecting there, including adults with disabilities. What should we all do?\n\nIt\u2019s not that I care about my personal privacy. I\u2019m boring. It is about what Facebook is allowing to happen with the data it has on millions of boring people like me.", "title": "Opinion | I Can\u2019t Jump Ship From Facebook Yet", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-10 00:00:00", "text": "But be sure you\u2019re right about what\u2019s in your child\u2019s best interests. You should take a closer look at your local public elementary school, and not content yourself with the general skepticism you express about the \u201cpublic-school landscape\u201d and the effects of \u201cstandardized testing.\u201d If it turns out that the private option isn\u2019t obviously better, you can bring your beliefs as a citizen into a more natural alignment with your duties as a parent.\n\nMy children are currently in private school, although both were in public school for many years, and my younger one may switch back to public school for high school. I\u2019m a big supporter of public education, so I was already feeling guilty about my choice \u2014 and then the federal tax bill passed in December. New tax rules allow pretax 529 savings accounts to be used not just for higher education but also for private precollege education. What should I do, if I want to do all I can to be a public-school ally? It seems there are three options: 1) Not take the tax deduction; 2) Take the deduction and give the money I save to the P.T.A. of a local underresourced public school or an organization working to improve public education; or 3) Take the deduction, figuring that as an N.Y.C. resident it will help offset the huge increase I expect to see in my taxes. Name Withheld\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nUnder the new federal tax act, you can withdraw up to $10,000 a year from a 529 savings account to pay for a student\u2019s private precollege education. Vouchers lite! Previously, these accounts could be used only for higher education. But the way that the relevant \u201cdeduction\u201d works hasn\u2019t changed. When you pay into these accounts in New York State, your state income-tax liability is reduced up to a limit of $5,000 for a single person or $10,000 for a couple. Once in the fund, your money grows federal- and state-tax-deferred; but you don\u2019t have to pay taxes when you take the money out, if it\u2019s for a qualified educational expense. (The details here, as with much tax law, get complicated, but this is the basic picture.) You may well be paying into one of these funds already for your child\u2019s college education and getting the maximum state-tax deduction. If so, this particular change in the tax law should not affect your income taxes very much.\n\nOf course, any money you take out in the next few years won\u2019t be available later for college expenses and won\u2019t have compounded for long. Still, the new federal law does encourage you to save for private school as well as college in one of these funds. If things remain as they are, the federal provision that increases the use of these funds threatens to reduce state income-tax revenue. Then again, a \u201cpreliminary report\u201d from New York\u2019s tax department suggests that K-12 payments may not be considered qualified educational expenses and that the state could recapture any associated tax benefits. And, as you\u2019re aware, this new use for 529 funds may do little to offset the loss to you that comes from no longer being able to deduct more than $10,000 in state property and income taxes from your federally taxable income.\n\nNone of that is ethics, though. My ethical view is you should take all the tax deductions you\u2019re legally entitled to. Many features of our tax system are ridiculous; many are the product of lobbying without much regard for the public good. But you don\u2019t have a duty to pay more than you are required to by law just because you and people like you are benefiting from bad policies, any more than you have the right to pay less than you\u2019re required to when you take a hit from bad policies. The right thing to aim for is tax reform that makes the system fairer. (We will all have our own views about whether the recent tax reforms did that. Count me a skeptic.)\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nYou\u2019re already helping to pay for New York\u2019s public schools through your taxes. Your choice to give your children a private education doesn\u2019t lessen your financial support for public schools. If you want to lend additional assistance to public schools without sending your kids to them, you can, as you say, support the local P.T.A. You can also pay attention when voting for candidates for public office and vote for those who will do their best for those schools. And you could lobby your state to make sure that it excludes deductions related to 529 funds used for K-12 expenses \u2014 deductions that encourage people with your sort of income to leave the public schools. With more people like you as parents, those schools might provide better education for all our children.", "title": "I Disapprove of School Vouchers. Can I Still Apply for Them?", "authors": ["Kwame Anthony Appiah", "The Ethicist"]} {"date": "2018-04-11 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cThey don\u2019t delete anything, and that\u2019s a general policy,\u201d said Gabriel Weinberg, the founder of DuckDuckGo, which offers internet privacy tools. He added that data was kept around to eventually help brands serve targeted ads.\n\nBeth Gautier, a Facebook spokeswoman, put it this way: \u201cWhen you delete something, we remove it so it\u2019s not visible or accessible on Facebook.\u201d She added: \u201cYou can also delete your account whenever you want. It may take up to 90 days to delete all backups of data on our servers.\u201d\n\nDigging through your Facebook files is an exercise I highly recommend if you care about how your personal information is stored and used. Here\u2019s what I learned.\n\nFacebook Retains More Data Than We Think\n\nWhen you download a copy of your Facebook data, you will see a folder containing multiple subfolders and files. The most important one is the \u201cindex\u201d file, which is essentially a raw data set of your Facebook account, where you can click through your profile, friends list, timeline and messages, among other features.\n\nOne surprising part of my index file was a section called Contact Info. This contained the 764 names and phone numbers of everyone in my iPhone\u2019s address book. Upon closer inspection, it turned out that Facebook had stored my entire phone book because I had uploaded it when setting up Facebook\u2019s messaging app, Messenger.\n\nThis was unsettling. I had hoped Messenger would use my contacts list to find others who were also using the app so that I could connect with them easily \u2014 and hold on to the relevant contact information only for the people who were on Messenger. Yet Facebook kept the entire list, including the phone numbers for my car mechanic, my apartment door buzzer and a pizzeria.\n\nThis felt unnecessary, though Facebook holds on to your phone book partly to keep it synchronized with your contacts list on Messenger and to help find people who newly sign up for the messaging service. I opted to turn off synchronizing and deleted all my phone book entries.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMy Facebook data also revealed how little the social network forgets. For instance, in addition to recording the exact date I signed up for Facebook in 2004, there was a record of when I deactivated Facebook in October 2010, only to reactivate it four days later \u2014 something I barely remember doing.\n\nFacebook also kept a history of each time I opened Facebook over the last two years, including which device and web browser I used. On some days, it even logged my locations, like when I was at a hospital two years ago or when I visited Tokyo last year.\n\nFacebook keeps a log of this data as a security measure to flag suspicious logins from unknown devices or locations, similar to how banks send a fraud alert when your credit card number is used in a suspicious location. This practice seemed reasonable, so I didn\u2019t try to purge this information.\n\nBut what bothered me was the data that I had explicitly deleted but that lingered in plain sight. On my friends list, Facebook had a record of \u201cRemoved Friends,\u201d a dossier of the 112 people I had removed along with the date I clicked the \u201cUnfriend\u201d button. Why should Facebook remember the people I\u2019ve cut off from my life?\n\nFacebook\u2019s explanation was dissatisfying. The company said it might use my list of deleted friends so that those people did not appear in my feed with the feature \u201cOn This Day,\u201d which resurfaces memories from years past to help people reminisce. I\u2019d rather have the option to delete the list of deleted friends for good.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe Ad Industry Has Eyes Everywhere\n\nWhat Facebook retained about me isn\u2019t remotely as creepy as the sheer number of advertisers that have my information in their databases. I found this out when I clicked on the Ads section in my Facebook file, which loaded a history of the dozen ads I had clicked on while browsing the social network.\n\nLower down, there was a section titled \u201cAdvertisers with your contact info,\u201d followed by a list of roughly 500 brands, the overwhelming majority of which I had never interacted with. Some brands sounded obscure and sketchy \u2014 one was called \u201cMicrophone Check,\u201d which turned out to be a radio show. Other brands were more familiar, like Victoria\u2019s Secret Pink, Good Eggs or AARP.\n\nFacebook said unfamiliar advertisers might appear on the list because they might have obtained my contact information from elsewhere, compiled it into a list of people they wanted to target and uploaded that list into Facebook. Brands can upload their customer lists into a tool called Custom Audiences, which helps them find those same people\u2019s Facebook profiles to serve them ads.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBrands can obtain your information in many different ways. Those include:\n\n\u25a0 Buying information from a data provider like Acxiom, which has amassed one of the world\u2019s largest commercial databases on consumers. Brands can buy different types of customer data sets from a provider, like contact information for people who belong to a certain demographic, and take that information to Facebook to serve targeted ads, said Michael Priem, chief executive of Modern Impact, an advertising firm in Minneapolis.\n\nLast month, Facebook announced that it was limiting its practice of allowing advertisers to target ads using information from third-party data brokers like Acxiom.\n\n\u25a0 Using tracking technologies like web cookies and invisible pixels that load in your web browser to collect information about your browsing activities. There are many different trackers on the web, and Facebook offers 10 different trackers to help brands harvest your information, according to Ghostery, which offers privacy tools that block ads and trackers. The advertisers can take some pieces of data that they have collected with trackers and upload them into the Custom Audiences tool to serve ads to you on Facebook.\n\n\u25a0 Getting your information in simpler ways, too. Someone you shared information with could share it with another entity. Your credit card loyalty program, for example, could share your information with a hotel chain, and that hotel chain could serve you ads on Facebook.\n\nThe upshot? Even a Facebook lurker, like myself, who has barely clicked on any digital ads can have personal information exposed to an enormous number of advertisers. This was not entirely surprising, but seeing the list of unfamiliar brands with my contact information in my Facebook file was a dose of reality.\n\nI tried to contact some of these advertisers, like Very Important Puppets, a toymaker, to ask them about what they did with my data. They did not respond.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story How Do You Use Tech? Advice and tips on the technology changing how you live. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later.
