View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nWhat About Google?\n\nLet\u2019s be clear: Facebook is just the tip of the iceberg when it comes to what information tech companies have collected on me.\n\nKnowing this, I also downloaded copies of my Google data with a tool called Google Takeout. The data sets were exponentially larger than my Facebook data. For my personal email account alone, Google\u2019s archive of my data measured eight gigabytes, enough to hold about 2,000 hours of music. By comparison, my Facebook data was about 650 megabytes, the equivalent of about 160 hours of music.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHere was the biggest surprise in what Google collected on me: In a folder labeled Ads, Google kept a history of many news articles I had read, like a Newsweek story about Apple employees walking into glass walls and a New York Times story about the editor of our Modern Love column. I didn\u2019t click on ads for either of these stories, but the search giant logged them because the sites had loaded ads served by Google.\n\nIn another folder, labeled Android, Google had a record of apps I had opened on an Android phone since 2015, along with the date and time. This felt like an extraordinary level of detail.\n\nGoogle did not immediately respond to a request for comment.\n\nOn a brighter note, I downloaded an archive of my LinkedIn data. The data set was less than half a megabyte and contained exactly what I had expected: spreadsheets of my LinkedIn contacts and information I had added to my profile.\n\nYet that offered little solace. Be warned: Once you see the vast amount of data that has been collected about you, you won\u2019t be able to unsee it.", "title": "I Downloaded the Information That Facebook Has on Me. Yikes.", "authors": ["Brian X. Chen", "Tech Fix"]} {"date": "2018-04-05 00:00:00", "text": "This video is part of a series on voting in America, which will run until Election Day in November. For more, see:\n\nPart 1: On the importance of voting.\n\nPart 2: On a court case over a Kansas voter registration law.\n\nPart 3: On discriminatory voting laws.", "title": "Opinion | I Hacked an Election. So Can the Russians.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-28 00:00:00", "text": "Typecasting aspirations of wealth has not helped diversify the three-comma club. According to Forbes\u2019s annual tally, less than 12 percent of the world\u2019s billionaires are women, and almost three-quarters of that dismal stat inherited their fortunes.\n\nIf we want to close the wealth gap, we have to come at it from every angle. We have to stop paying women 80 cents to a man\u2019s dollar and women of color substantially less than that. We have to start raising girls the way we raise boys. A T. Rowe Price survey shows that in 2017, parents of only boys still save more and pay more for their sons\u2019 educations than parents who have only girls do.\n\nThis trickles down to the way we socialize kids \u2014 girls are expected to be caretakers, boys the ones who will deliver a return. If you want to create your own wealth, the confidence to take calculated risks is a necessary skill. Placing the needs of others above your own is not.\n\nI have always wrestled with what has been expected of me as a woman versus what I expect of myself. The conflicting messages of millennial womanhood: to be ambitious but never bossy, strong but skinny, honest but polite, supportive of my fellow sisters\u2019 success while the culture gets off on girl fights. Only in fiction have I been able to create women who aggressively seek money and power the way men seek money and power. Women who will kill to protect their measly slice of the pie.\n\nI often commiserate with other female authors about the catch-22 of publicity campaigns. We must talk ourselves up despite knowing that women who do so are disliked. Researchers have found that women are actually punished when they succeed at traditionally masculine endeavors. Meanwhile male authors on our panels monopolize the mic to the great delight of the crowd.\n\nSelf-promotion, for us, is a complicated dance with steps men will never have to learn. Oh, to be Daniel Mallory, who wrote \u201cThe Woman in the Window\u201d under the gender-ambiguous pen name A. J. Finn. Mr. Mallory told a reporter that his foreign sales \u2014 in 37 territories, at the time \u2014 \u201cmight be a record for a debut novel.\u201d It wasn\u2019t a record. I knew it wasn\u2019t because my first book sold to 38.\n\nI used to hope someone else might trumpet my foreign sales for me, thinking only men got to be bumptious and beloved. Then Gillian Flynn baldly declared in Chicago magazine that the first page of her next novel is \u201cthe greatest first page that\u2019s ever been written.\u201d Reese Witherspoon told WSJ Magazine that if acting hadn\u2019t worked out, she\u2019d have become the premier surgeon and pediatric cardiologist at Vanderbilt University. And Ellen Pompeo let it rip in The Hollywood Reporter, swanking about what it took to become the highest-paid actress on a prime-time drama.", "title": "Opinion | I Want to Be Rich and I\u2019m Not Sorry", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-12 00:00:00", "text": "On an otherwise unremarkable Tuesday evening, I found myself facing a stranger, swinging my arms back and forth, and hooting like an owl.\n\n\u201cHOOOOOO!\u201d I yelled, blinking uncomfortably. \u201cWOOOOP!\u201d she yelled back.\n\nI was warming up for an ecstatic dance session at Union Square Ballroom in Manhattan, which I attended with about 250 other people. Ecstatic dances are essentially free-form dance parties, and the directions for the one I attended \u2014 hosted each month by Ecstatic Dance NYC \u2014 were pretty simple: no shoes, no drugs or alcohol, no phones or cameras, and no talking on the dance floor.\n\nThe only directive: Allow your body to move exactly how it wants to move.\n\nThis was no small challenge for me, as my body is much more accustomed to slouching over a laptop, or contorting itself into knots to avoid touching people on the subway. But something about ecstatic dance drew me in.\n\nOn the designated evening, I fought my way through an aggressive crush of commuters in Union Square to get to the location and entered a different world. A gentle horde of 20-to-50-somethings in exercise clothes and loose palazzo pants were affectionately touching each other\u2019s faces and greeting one another with slow embraces.", "title": "I Was Skeptical About Ecstatic Dance", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-12 00:00:00", "text": "Not all people want their lawsuit to play out in court. Sometimes victims of harassment and discrimination want privacy; sometimes corporations want to keep the ugly details of workplace disputes out of the public eye. For these cases, there is another avenue for obtaining justice: private arbitration. When the parties to a lawsuit decide to go to arbitration rather than a court of law, they meet with an arbitrator (usually a retired judge, and someone they both have decided to use), present their cases and then accept the judgment handed down. That is, ideally, how arbitration works.\n\nUnfortunately, the reality of how arbitration is used to settle workplace disputes is far from that ideal. In the tech industry, where I work, and where issues of harassment and discrimination remain rampant, nearly every company requires as a condition of employment that its employees sign away their constitutional right to sue it in a court of law and instead agree to take any claims against the company to private arbitration. They are also typically legally bound to keep silent about the illegal treatment they experienced and the entire arbitration process \u2014 a process that will be handled by an arbitrator who is chosen by the company and has financial incentive to keep the company happy. (Forced arbitration of this sort goes beyond issues of sexual harassment: A recent investigation by ProPublica, for example, showed that I.B.M. employees who experienced age discrimination were bound by forced arbitration and would never be able to sue the company in court.)\n\nForced arbitration has become a standard practice for a variety of reasons. The dominant view is that it helps manage long-term legal risk, ensuring that companies won\u2019t become embroiled in costly, drawn-out lawsuits. The examples of Uber and I.B.M. show that the opposite is true: Forced arbitration leads to long-term operating risk. Forcing legal disputes about discrimination, harassment and retaliation to go through secret arbitration proceedings hides the behavior and allows it to become culturally entrenched.\n\nBefore us lie three possible options for putting an end to this practice. The first is to leave it to individual companies and allow them to choose not to force their employees to sign away their constitutional rights. Microsoft has taken the lead on this and has stopped using arbitration agreements in cases of sexual harassment. As hopeful as this option might sound, leaving it up to individual companies is not likely to change the industry: The good companies will elect to ban arbitration agreements, while the bad companies will continue to use them and continue to mistreat their employees.\n\nThe second is to leave it to the Supreme Court, which will soon hand down a decision in the case of Epic Systems Corp. v. Lewis, a suit filed not over harassment but over unpaid overtime, but that nonetheless has the potential to reshape the way companies can use arbitration agreements, particularly when they are used to ban class-action lawsuits. But it\u2019s not clear how the court will rule \u2014 some analysis has suggested it is likely to rule in favor of employers \u2014 nor is it clear how this decision could shape forced arbitration for individuals.", "title": "Opinion | I Wrote the Uber Memo. This Is How to End Sexual Harassment.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-17 00:00:00", "text": "WASHINGTON \u2014 The global economy is looking stronger than it has in years, but as world leaders gather here this week for the spring meetings of the International Monetary Fund, they will be particularly attuned to possible economic disruptions stemming from decisions being made just a few blocks away at the White House.\n\nIn a report released Tuesday morning, the International Monetary Fund said stronger business investment and trade were buoying the world\u2019s economy. Global growth is on track to reach an annual rate of 3.9 percent this year and next, propelled by the economies of Europe, Japan, China and the United States. That would be up from 3.8 percent in 2017, which was the strongest growth since 2011.\n\nBut the spring version of the World Economic Outlook, the fund\u2019s semiannual report card on the health of the international economy, outlined big risks \u2014 including the growing likelihood of a trade war and government policies that could overheat the United States economy.\n\nThough the report did not mention President Trump by name, some of the risks \u2014 including a trade war \u2014 are linked to his policies. Mr. Trump maintains that trading partners have not treated the United States fairly and that his administration must take tough action to level the playing field, including imposing tariffs on steel imports and products from China.", "title": "I.M.F. The technology failure essentially brought the nation\u2019s tax machinery to a halt on a day when millions of Americans were expected to file their tax returns, undermining the Trump administration\u2019s plan to use Tax Day to promote its recent $1.5 trillion tax overhaul.\n\nThe I.R.S. said in a statement that taxpayers would be given an additional day to file their returns.\n\nOn Tuesday, taxpayers could still file the old-fashioned way: by sending their returns and payments through the mail. But for most of the day, those seeking to make a payment online ahead of the midnight deadline were greeted with the message: \u201cThis service is currently unavailable.\u201d The website said it was undergoing a \u201cplanned outage\u201d beginning on Tax Day that would last until Dec. 31, 9999, but said tax payments were still due on April 17, despite the system\u2019s inability to process them.", "title": "I.R.S. According to the Jowzjan deputy police chief, Hafiz Khashi, after Mr. Hekmatullah\u2019s death, three factions of his Islamic State followers began fighting one another to determine who would take his place.\n\nHe said those factions included foreign fighters from places including Chechnya and Syria, followers of Mr. Hekmatullah from his home district, and Islamic State fighters from elsewhere in Afghanistan who had joined his forces in the north.\n\nThe governor of Jowzjan, Maulvi Lutfullah Azizi, said the killing of Mr. Hekmatullah, and the infighting that resulted, had come just in time to prevent Mr. Hekmatullah\u2019s fighters from overrunning government forces holding the district center of Darzab.\n\n\u201cHe was very powerful and commanded up to 500 armed fighters,\u201d Mr. Azizi said. \u201cWhen he and his bodyguard were killed, his forces were within 50 meters of the district center.\u201d\n\nHundreds of miles to the southeast, the district of Achin, in Nangarhar, heavily dominated by the Islamic State in Khorasan a year ago, is now largely under government control, according to officials and village elders there. Mohammad Ismail Shinwari, the governor of Achin, said schools were reopening and 4,000 displaced families had returned, although another 2,000 families were yet to come back.\n\n\u201cISIS is no longer strong in this district,\u201d he said.\n\nA spokeswoman for the American military, Col. Lisa Garcia, said the coalition had cut the group\u2019s numbers in half over the past two years and had reduced its territory. \u201cIS-K has wanted and tried to expand their presence, but they have been unable to do so,\u201d she said.\n\nThe Islamic State has proved capable of replenishing its forces in the past, however. Here\u2019s the sign-up.)\n\nGood morning.\n\n\n\nHere\u2019s what you need to know:\n\nThe ISIS files\n\n\u2022 During five trips to Iraq, Times journalists scoured former offices of the Islamic State, gathering more than 15,000 pages of documents abandoned by the militants as their \u201ccaliphate\u201d crumbled.\n\nWe\u2019ve just published the results of our yearlong investigation. It shows that ISIS, known for its brutality, was also effective at wielding power through paperwork. Here\u2019s a closer look at some of the documents we collected, including tax collection forms, religious edicts and the will of a suicide bomber.\n\nWe also have a new audio series, \u201cCaliphate,\u201d which follows our reporter Rukmini Callimachi as she covers the Islamic State and the fall of Mosul, Iraq. He dropped plans for an immediate withdrawal, but instructed military commanders to wrap up the mission within a few months.", "title": "ISIS, Brazil, Facebook: Your Thursday Briefing", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-05 00:00:00", "text": "\u2022 The ISIS files.\n\nOn five trips to battle-scarred Iraq, New York Times journalists scoured old Islamic State offices in 11 cities and towns, gathering thousands of documents abandoned by the militants as their \u201ccaliphate\u201d crumbled.\n\nFollowing a paper trail that led through booby-trapped streets near the front lines of battle, they found suicide bomber forms, birth certificates, tax records, school books teaching English words like \u201cgun\u201d and \u201cmartyr,\u201d and papers from the Ministry of War Spoils. (Here\u2019s a closer look at the documents.)\n\nThe records reveal how the terrorist group combined brutality and paperwork to wield power over territory that at one point was the size of Britain, with a population estimated at 12 million people.\n\nAbove, papers littered a room in the bombed-out remnants of the Directorate of Agriculture in Mosul, Iraq, last September.", "title": "ISIS, Britain, Monkeys: Your Thursday Briefing", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-01 00:00:00", "text": "HUMBLE, Tex. \u2014 Ian Poulter delivered another big moment Sunday, this one for himself.\n\nDown to his last putt, Poulter made a 20-foot birdie on the 18th hole and forced a playoff with Beau Hossler, and he then won the Houston Open with a par on the first extra hole and earned the final spot in the Masters.\n\nA week after Poulter was mistakenly told that he had locked up a spot at Augusta National through the world ranking, he left no doubt in the matter by winning with a clutch moment reminiscent of his Ryder Cup heroics at Medinah in 2012.\n\n\u201cI had to dig deep today,\u201d said Poulter, who closed with a five-under-par 67.\n\nHossler, who also shot a 67, overcame a three-shot deficit with four straight birdies on the back nine. He had a chance to win on the 18th in regulation with a 30-foot birdie putt that trickled over the right edge of the cup.\n\nThat set the stage for Poulter, and the 42-year-old Englishman lived up to his nickname, the Postman, by delivering his biggest putt in years. Poulter pounded his chest five times when the putt dropped, and all Hossler could do was smile.", "title": "Ian Poulter Defeats Beau Hossler in Houston Open Playoff", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-14 00:00:00", "text": "Other western European countries have had trouble squarely facing such history; many Belgians were unaware of the atrocities in Congo under Belgian rule until the past generation. But Denmark, with less of a colonial record to confront than some countries, has had more trouble confronting it, according to Mr. Palsson.\n\n\u201cSomehow it annoys them more than others knowing about this background,\u201d he said.\n\nHans Jonathan was born in 1784 in St. Croix, then a Danish possession and now part of the United States Virgin Islands. His mother was a black house slave owned by the Schimmelmanns, a Danish-German family, and his father was a white man.\n\nWhen he was about 7, the Schimmelmanns took him to Copenhagen. In 1801, he volunteered to fight with the Danish navy, and emerged unharmed from a fierce battle with British ships.\n\n\u201cIt was crazy warfare,\u201d said Mr. Palsson, whose biography of Hans Jonathan was published in Icelandic in 2014, and in English in 2016. \u201cThe ship was bombarded heavily.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nHans Jonathan earned the support of his superior officers, who spoke on his behalf to the royal household. Denmark\u2019s crown prince and de facto ruler, the future King Frederik VI, wrote in a letter that Hans Jonathan \u201cis considered free and enjoys rights.\u201d\n\nThe French revolution had unleashed new ideas about equality and liberty. Like several other colonial powers, Denmark still allowed slavery in the Caribbean, but abolition movements at home were gaining ground, and the status of slaves brought to Europe from the colonies was murky.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHenrietta Schimmelmann tried to reclaim Hans Jonathan and take him back to St. Croix, and he went to court to assert his freedom, in a case that was famous in its time. But he could not produce the letter from Prince Frederik, for reasons unknown, and in 1802, the court dismissed his claim and ordered him to return to the Schimmelmanns, who wanted to sell him in St. Croix.\n\nInstead, he fled, sailed to Iceland, settled in the small village of Djupivogur, married a local woman, had children, and lived as a free man until his death in 1827.\n\nThough he was largely forgotten in Denmark, in Iceland he became a well-known figure in local folklore, said Kari Stefansson, head of the company deCode Genetics, whose father grew up in Djupivogur.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cPeople think it\u2019s a beautiful story,\u201d he said. \u201cIt shows that racism isn\u2019t innate. It\u2019s a learned behavior.\u201d\n\nDeCode published a study this year that takes advantage of Iceland\u2019s highly homogeneous gene pool, its remarkably thorough genealogical records, and Hans Jonathan\u2019s unique place in the country\u2019s history.\n\nResearchers identified some 780 living descendants of Hans Jonathan, took DNA samples from 182 of them, and isolated snippets that were characteristically African, and could only have come from him. They said they were able to reconstruct 38 percent of his mother\u2019s genome, and trace it to parts of West Africa.\n\n\u201cIt is certainly of interest how bits and pieces of an African genome are found in genomes of current Icelanders,\u201d Mr. Stefansson said.\n\nSome Icelanders knew of Hans Jonathan already, but many of his descendants, who are spread among several countries, lived most of their lives unaware that they had an ancestor who was a black slave.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Race/Related Newsletter Join a deep and provocative exploration of race with a diverse group of New York Times journalists. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nAmong them was Kirsten Pflomm, a communications manager from Connecticut, who did an online search of her own name 15 years ago, and found herself and entire family listed on a website written in Icelandic. She contacted the site\u2019s administrator and learned the dramatic story of her five-times-great-grandfather.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201dI clearly look very white,\u201d she said. \u201dSo I can\u2019t claim to ever have experienced anything\u201d resembling racism.\n\nMs. Pflomm is not seeking an official apology for Hans Jonathan\u2019s time in shackles, or hoping to achieve greater Danish awareness of slavery and colonization. \u201cThat\u2019s a bigger conversation that doesn\u2019t include me,\u201d she said.\n\nBut she petitioned Prime Minister Lars Lokke Rasmussen, asking him to award Hans Jonathan his freedom. In a letter back to her, the prime minister wrote last month that her ancestor was a \u201cbeacon of liberty,\u201d but that he \u201ccannot reverse time or the verdict of the past, no matter how incomprehensible it may seem.\u201d\n\nBut Astrid Nonbo Andersen, an expert on colonial history at the Danish Institute for International Studies, said that Danish views may have begun to change last year, during the centennial of the sale of the Denmark\u2019s Caribbean islands to the United States.\n\n\u201cThere was an explosion of events like never before,\u201d she said. \u201cBut if it was just a news interest or something lasting remains to be seen.\u201d\n\nThe wealth of the colonial era is visible in the elegant Rococo and Baroque mansions of Copenhagen. The first tribute to the people who suffered to create that wealth appeared on April 2, when a statue was unveiled of a black woman who led a 19th-century rebellion against Danish rule on St. Croix.\n\nThe statue, 23 feet tall, may be hard to ignore.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s really big and right on the waterfront,\u201d Ms. Andersen said. \u201cTourists will begin to ask, and tour guides will have to add a new chapter to their guiding.\u201d", "title": "Iceland\u2019s 1st Black Citizen? An Ex-Slave and War Hero Denmark Now Disregards", "authors": ["Martin Selsoe Sorensen"]} {"date": "2018-04-12 00:00:00", "text": "Personnellement Montr\u00e9alais d\u2019origine, je suis r\u00e9cemment retourn\u00e9 au Qu\u00e9bec, 28 ans apr\u00e8s avoir quitt\u00e9 le Canada, et j\u2019ai pris la route pour tenter de mieux cerner l\u2019identit\u00e9 de la province. Et c\u2019est ainsi qu\u2019un beau jour, je me suis retrouv\u00e9 dans le village que tant de Qu\u00e9b\u00e9cois pr\u00e9f\u00e9reraient oublier. Je voulais voir si la mentalit\u00e9 avait chang\u00e9.\n\nL\u2019accueil que j\u2019ai re\u00e7u \u00e0 mon arriv\u00e9e a \u00e9t\u00e9 aussi glacial que le vent de mars.\n\n\u00ab Il ne se passe jamais rien ici : on a une \u00e9glise et quelques chalets, et c\u2019est \u00e0 peu pr\u00e8s \u00e7a, m\u2019a dit la premi\u00e8re habitante que j\u2019ai crois\u00e9e. Qu\u2019est-ce que vous venez faire ici? \u00bb\n\nLe code, qui a polaris\u00e9 le Qu\u00e9bec, a provoqu\u00e9 un d\u00e9bat national houleux et a m\u00eame d\u00e9clench\u00e9 une commission provinciale visant \u00e0 d\u00e9finir les \u00ab accommodements raisonnables \u00bb, soit les mesures \u00e0 prendre ou non pour respecter les cultures et les traditions des immigrants. Par exemple, est-ce que les \u00e9l\u00e8ves musulmanes pouvaient porter le voile \u00e0 l\u2019\u00e9cole? Est-ce qu\u2019un YMCA de Montr\u00e9al aurait d\u00fb faire installer des vitres givr\u00e9es \u00e0 la demande des juifs ultra-orthodoxes qui ne voulaient pas voir les femmes s\u2019entra\u00eener en tenue sportive?", "title": "Ici on ne br\u00fble pas les femmes : un avertissement aux immigrants hante toujours un village du Qu\u00e9bec", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-28 00:00:00", "text": "When most Americans imagine lynching, they envision the tortured and mutilated body of a black man accused of raping a white woman. They rarely think of a black woman \u201cstripped naked and hung.\u201d Wells, however, was well aware that black women were victims of Southern mob violence and also targets of rape by white men.\n\nIn 1892, when mobs across the South murdered more than 200 African-American men and women, including one of Wells\u2019s closest friends, she began to systematically investigate lynchings. As I\u2019ve noted in my academic work, she soon discovered that few victims had even been accused of rape. In an editorial, she wrote that \u201cnobody in this section of the country believes the old threadbare lie that Negro men rape white women.\u201d In retaliation, a white mob destroyed her press and warned Wells, who was in New York at the time, not to come back or risk death.\n\nWells was not intimidated. Instead, she crossed the country lecturing on the evils of mob violence. She traveled to Britain, where she started an international crusade against lynching. She initiated one of the first public hearings to address both racial and sexual violence. Wells also sought to protect black women against rape by white men.\n\nFrom the start, she relied on the support of a network of black women. At a fund-raiser at Lyric Hall in New York, Wells described the group as \u201cthe greatest demonstration ever attempted by race women for one of their own number.\u201d The proceeds from the event allowed her to publish \u201cSouthern Horrors: Lynch Law in All Its Phases,\u201d the first anti-lynching pamphlet.\n\nIn \u201cSouthern Horrors,\u201d Wells made clear that white men perpetrated sexual violence against black women, while black men were brutalized by white mobs for having consensual sex with white women. And by showing that only about 30 percent of the black victims of lynch mobs had actually been accused of rape, Wells challenged the idea that lynchings resulted from it.", "title": "Opinion | Ida B. Wells and the Lynching of Black Women", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-04 00:00:00", "text": "BORACAY, Philippines \u2014 A Philippine island that became famous for the white sand beaches and coral reefs that made it a haven for travelers, and then for the rapid development and pollution that threatened its idyllic shores, has been ordered closed to tourists for six months.\n\nPresident Rodrigo Duterte \u2014 who has said that inadequate sewage treatment on the island, Boracay, has turned its beaches into a \u201ccesspool\u201d \u2014 directed that it be closed to tourism starting on April 26, his spokesman, Harry Roque, said Wednesday.\n\nThat decision threatens the livelihoods of thousands of people on Boracay, a speck of an island in the central Philippines that has become a travel destination to rival Phuket, in Thailand, and Bali, in Indonesia.\n\nMr. Duterte has said that Boracay must be cleaned up, but officials have given no indication that there is a plan to do so. Yet last month, the government signed an agreement with Galaxy Entertainment, a Macau-based casino operator, and a Philippine partner to begin construction next year on a $500 million beachfront casino that would add to the burdens on the island\u2019s infrastructure.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cMaybe the timing was just coincidence, but I can say that it is very odd,\u201d said Nenette Graf, president of an alliance of Boracay\u2019s hotels, restaurants and other businesses. \u201cYou want to close the island, but at the same time allow a casino operator in?\u201d", "title": "Idyllic Philippine Resort Island of Boracay Is Closed to Tourists", "authors": ["Felipe Villamor"]} {"date": "2018-04-15 00:00:00", "text": "Oladipo and Sabonis have provided the Pacers with more punch than anyone could have reasonably projected. During the regular season, Oladipo \u2014 liberated from the various challenges of playing alongside Russell Westbrook in Oklahoma City \u2014 averaged career highs in points (23.1), rebounds (5.2), assists (4.3) and steals (2.4), and was named to his first All-Star team.\n\n\u201cIt goes to show you the importance of being in the right situation, of playing for a coach that puts you in good positions,\u201d Redick said, referring to the Pacers\u2019 Nate McMillan. \u201cFor 80 to 90 percent of the league, that\u2019s what it\u2019s all about.\u201d\n\nSabonis made a seismic jump in his own development, averaging 11.6 points and 7.7 rebounds while shooting 51.4 percent from the field, mostly off the bench.\n\n\u201cHe\u2019s been everything we thought he would be and more,\u201d Bayno said.\n\nThere is a unique kinship between Oladipo and Sabonis, who have been traded together \u2014 twice. Sabonis\u2019s rights were included in a draft-night trade in 2016 that sent him and Oladipo, along with Ersan Ilyasova, from the Orlando Magic to the Thunder.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s just a special bond, man,\u201d Oladipo said. \u201cHe\u2019s like my little big brother. I can talk to him about anything, and he can talk to me about anything.\u201d\n\nThe Pacers acquired them last summer when Paul George, a five-time All-Star who had spent his entire career with the team, made it clear that he wanted out of Indiana. Given George\u2019s trade demand, the Pacers did not have a ton of leverage. They eventually struck a deal with the Thunder, who agreed to trade Oladipo and Sabonis for George. No player was more synonymous with the franchise. Now, he was gone.\n\nAt the time, words like \u201cfleeced\u201d and \u201cpathetic\u201d were used in various reports to describe the transaction. In fairness, neither Oladipo nor Sabonis seemed capable of coming close to filling the void left by George.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nOladipo, in his lone season with the Thunder, averaged 15.9 points and 2.6 assists a game toiling in Westbrook\u2019s shadow. And Sabonis, as a first-year player, averaged 5.9 points a game while shooting 39.9 percent from the field.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThis was the grand haul the Pacers collected for George? It was almost incomprehensible.\n\n\u201cEverybody thought we were going to be a lottery team,\u201d Bayno said.\n\nYet Bayno said he had no doubt that last summer\u2019s trade affected both players.\n\n\u201cI think it motivated Vic and Domantas,\u201d Bayno said, \u201cbecause they both have supreme confidence in their abilities.\u201d\n\nNot long after he was traded, Sabonis, who is from Lithuania, took himself off the roster for the country\u2019s appearance at the FIBA EuroBasket tournament so he could move to Indianapolis and start working with the coaching staff several weeks ahead of training camp.\n\nIt was not an easy decision. The head of the Lithuanian basketball federation happens to be his father, Arvydas Sabonis, the Hall of Fame center.\n\n\u201cTo miss that really hurt,\u201d Domantas Sabonis said. \u201cIt\u2019s a big deal for the country. It means more than anything.\u201d\n\nBut Sabonis and the Pacers clearly benefited from his early arrival. Sabonis found Bayno waiting for him at the team\u2019s practice facility with those pads, which he used to batter Sabonis on drives to the basket. Bayno was trying to teach Sabonis to use his shoulder to initiate contact and knock his defenders off-balance.\n\nBy December, Bayno was challenging Sabonis to become \u201cthe best passing big man\u201d in the league. Bayno could sense that Sabonis had rare vision and touch for a player his size. More growth is ahead.\n\n\u201cWe\u2019re working on finding that balance between shooting when he\u2019s open and kicking it out when he draws a crowd,\u201d Bayno said. \u201cBecause there are times where he\u2019ll attack and have three guys on him, and that\u2019s the only time when he has a tough time making those decisions.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSabonis does not shy away from physical play. Before a recent game against the 76ers, he wore a gash on his face \u2014 an artifact of one such collision. Then, during the game itself, he went out and sprained his left ankle.\n\nSabonis has since returned, showing more polish than ever. Against the Charlotte Hornets on April 8, he scored a career-high 30 points and grabbed eight rebounds.\n\n\u201cI\u2019m still learning,\u201d Sabonis said. \u201cI\u2019m not even close. I experience new things every game.\u201d\n\nWith a playoff matchup looming against LeBron James and the Cavaliers, Sabonis is about to experience even more.", "title": "If Anybody Beats the Pacers, It Might Be an Assistant Coach", "authors": ["Scott Cacciola", "On Pro Basketball"]} {"date": "2018-04-06 00:00:00", "text": "Modern-day tastemakers, unlike their forebears, shower love on comics and graphic novels without a hint of condescension. This is true even of works intended mainly for children, a category that includes \u2014 let\u2019s be honest \u2014 most of the superhero sagas that dominate pop culture\u2019s most lucrative precincts. I\u2019m not complaining, by the way (I love comics too), just observing. But picture books are another story. Even the genius likes of Beatrix Potter and Maurice Sendak are shunted off to the critical equivalent of the Thanksgiving kids\u2019 table, smiled at but not often engaged with. Yet the best picture books, far from being baby food, display a pictorial sophistication that puts many graphic novels to shame; think of them as visual haiku, an art form of juxtaposition and implication, bright colors notwithstanding. And here are three examples to prove the point \u2014 books full of surface delight that also reward close reading. Kids might love them, but I\u2019m guessing all three will resonate even more with grown-ups.\n\nStanding in the outfield and waiting to catch a high fly ball is among the more agonizing but ubiquitous rituals of American childhood: not quite as dire as doctors\u2019 shots or puberty, but still bad. (That anyone sticks with baseball long enough to get good at it is a tribute to either the human spirit or masochism.) In I GOT IT! (Clarion Books/Houghton Mifflin Harcourt, 32 pp., $17.99; ages 4 to 8), David Wiesner slows time down and finds a world of drama in those five or so hellish seconds between ball leaving bat and settling \u2014 or not \u2014 into mitt. Surely even capable athletes will relate to the interplay between body and mind, muscle and emotion, which \u201cI Got It!\u201d captures with beauty, fluidity, wit and suspense.\n\nWiesner is the only living three-time winner of the Caldecott Medal \u2014 for \u201cTuesday\u201d (1991), \u201cThe Three Pigs\u201d (2001) and \u201cFlotsam\u201d (2006). Like most of his books, \u201cI Got It!\u201d is wordless, apart from the title phrase, which appears first as aspirational shout and once again, many pages later, as triumphant cry. (I hope that\u2019s not a spoiler, but Wiesner is no Charles Schulz.) The hero is a boy who, when we first see him, is standing on the wrong side of a backstop fence, longing to join a sandlot game. He looks to be a year or two younger than the rest of the kids; a team captain banishes him to the farther reaches of the field, somewhere around Pluto\u2019s orbit, where he can presumably do no harm. But the inevitable ball is hit his way, and Wiesner\u2019s illustrations begin to shift subtly between actual playing field and interior landscape. In the boy\u2019s mind, as he races to make the catch, he suffers several catastrophic failures. Then, as teammates also converge on the ball, he takes flight in a rush of surreal images \u2014 focus emerging amid fear and distraction.", "title": "If Graphic Novels Are Hip for Adults, Why Not Picture Books?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-18 00:00:00", "text": "Still, Mr. Trump conspicuously declined to make their release a precondition of his meeting with Mr. Kim. He also did not demand any new concessions from North Korea beforehand, underscoring how determined he is to make history by convening with the leader of a country he threatened with war a few months ago.\n\nIn preparing for the planned event, Mr. Trump\u2019s decision to dispatch his C.I.A. director reflected the president\u2019s trust in and comfort with Mr. Pompeo, as well as how diplomats were sidelined in brokering what could be a landmark encounter.\n\n\u201cMeeting went very smoothly and a good relationship was formed,\u201d Mr. Trump said in an early morning Twitter post before he went golfing with Mr. Abe. \u201cDetails of Summit are being worked out now. Denuclearization will be a great thing for World, but also for North Korea!\u201d\n\nMr. Pompeo is still awaiting confirmation to his new post, and faces a challenging vote in the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, where several Democrats have come out against him. The White House and Republicans seized on Mr. Pompeo\u2019s trip as another reason for the Senate to confirm him, while Democrats said he had misled them by failing to disclose his mission, even in private conversations.\n\nBut the visit underlines the confidence that Mr. Trump has developed in Mr. Pompeo, a former Tea Party congressman who has emerged as one of the president\u2019s closest advisers \u2014 a stark contrast to Rex W. Tillerson, whom Mr. Trump fired as secretary of state days after he accepted Mr. Kim\u2019s invitation to meet.\n\nIt also underlines Mr. Trump\u2019s unorthodox approach to one of the riskiest diplomatic gambits of his presidency. However trusted by the president, Mr. Pompeo is hardly a traditional emissary. He is not yet the nation\u2019s chief diplomat but a lame duck as the nation\u2019s spymaster.\n\nMr. Pompeo met with Mr. Kim on Easter Sunday, a senior official said, bringing along several aides from the C.I.A. \u2014 but nobody from the State Department or the White House.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSome former administration officials expressed surprise that he returned from Pyongyang with no visible concessions, like the release of the three Americans detained in North Korea. Mr. Pompeo raised the issue, another official said, adding that the White House would continue to push for their release.\n\nIn 2014, James R. Clapper, then the director of national intelligence, traveled secretly to North Korea to negotiate the release of two Americans, Kenneth Bae and Matthew Todd Miller. Three Korean-Americans \u2014 Kim Dong-chul, Kim Sang-duk and Kim Hak-song \u2014 are currently being held on charges of espionage and committing hostile acts toward the North Korean state.\n\nThe administration also has not agreed on a date for the meeting between Mr. Trump and Mr. Kim, which officials said pointed to problems in settling on a site for the encounter. On Tuesday, Mr. Trump told reporters that the White House was looking at five potential locations.\n\nThe White House has begun narrowing the list of options, a senior official said, eliminating sites like Pyongyang and the Demilitarized Zone between North and South Korea, which could pose an optics problem for Mr. Trump. Meeting somewhere in the United States remains a possibility, though that could raise similar issues for Mr. Kim.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe administration is studying several third countries \u2014 Singapore and Vietnam, in Asia; Sweden and Switzerland, in Europe \u2014 though all are far from North Korea, posing a challenge to Mr. Kim\u2019s fleet of rickety aircraft. Mongolia, which is closer to the North, is a long shot, the official said.\n\nWithout a site, however, the White House has been unable to announce a date, though officials are sticking to Mr. Trump\u2019s recent declaration that the meeting will be in late May or early June.\n\nOn Tuesday, Mr. Trump added to the mystery surrounding the visit by appearing to confirm that he had been in direct contact with Mr. Kim himself. He later clarified that while the talks were at \u201cthe highest levels,\u201d he would \u201cleave it a little bit short of that.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMr. Pompeo\u2019s involvement with North Korea predated Mr. Trump\u2019s decision to meet Mr. Kim, several officials said. He has been dealing with North Korean representatives through a channel that runs between the C.I.A. and its North Korean counterpart, the Reconnaissance General Bureau.\n\nHe also has been in close touch with the director of South Korea\u2019s National Intelligence Service, Suh Hoon, who American officials said brokered Mr. Kim\u2019s invitation to Mr. Trump.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWhile a meeting between the leaders would be one of the boldest diplomatic gambles in recent years, it was orchestrated largely by the intelligence services of the three countries.\n\nOfficials said Mr. Suh laid the groundwork for Mr. Kim\u2019s invitation in negotiations and a subsequent meeting in Pyongyang with Kim Yong-chol, a powerful general who leads inter-Korean relations and used to run North Korea\u2019s intelligence service.\n\nMr. Suh was one of two South Korean envoys who visited the White House to brief Mr. Trump on their meeting with Kim Jong-un in Pyongyang \u2014 which led to the president\u2019s impromptu decision to accept Mr. Kim\u2019s invitation.\n\nFor Mr. Pompeo, who now has an office at the State Department, the choice to use the intelligence channel was mostly a convenience \u2014 allowing him to be involved in the planning as he awaited his move to the department.\n\nStill, some officials expressed concern that the C.I.A. had taken the lead in orchestrating a leader-to-leader meeting \u2014 work that would normally fall to the State Department. The intelligence officials on the North Korean side, they said, are shadowy figures, not least Kim Yong-chol himself, who is accused of masterminding a torpedo attack that sank a South Korean Navy ship in 2010, killing 46 sailors.\n\nThe State Department\u2019s role in North Korea dwindled after Mr. Trump publicly split with Mr. Tillerson over his efforts to open a diplomatic channel to the North, initially to obtain the release of the three Americans but also to set the stage for a broader negotiation.\n\nIn October, while Mr. Tillerson was in Beijing, Mr. Trump tweeted, \u201cI told Rex Tillerson, our wonderful Secretary of State, that he is wasting his time trying to negotiate with Little Rocket Man...\u201d\n\nThe State Department recently lost its chief North Korea negotiator, Joseph Yun, who retired from the Foreign Service, in part because of his frustration with his agency\u2019s diminished role.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe timing of Mr. Tillerson\u2019s departure, officials said, was not coincidental. Mr. Trump wanted to have Mr. Pompeo in place to oversee an opening to North Korea. But Mr. Pompeo has expressed extremely hawkish views about North Korea, suggesting over the summer that the United States should push for regime change.\n\n\u201cIt would be a great thing to denuclearize the peninsula, to get those weapons off of that, but the thing that is most dangerous about it is the character who holds the control over them today,\u201d Mr. Pompeo said at the Aspen Security Forum. \u201cSo from the administration\u2019s perspective, the most important thing we can do is separate those two.\u201d\n\nLast week, Mr. Pompeo insisted to the Senate Foreign Relations Committee that he had never advocated such change.\n\n\u201cJust to be clear, my role as a diplomat is to make sure that we never get to a place where we have to confront the difficult situation in Korea that this country has been headed for now for a couple of decades,\u201d he added.", "title": "If North Korea Talks Are Not Fruitful, \u2018I Will Respectfully Leave,\u2019 Trump Says", "authors": ["Mark Landler"]} {"date": "2018-04-05 00:00:00", "text": "Until Thursday afternoon, there had been a reassuring sense of restrained, tit-for-tat reciprocity in the trade skirmish between the United States and China.\n\nBut if this spirals into a bigger conflict between the world\u2019s two biggest economies \u2014 something that seemed to become more likely Thursday evening with President Trump\u2019s threat to add $100 billion more in tariffs \u2014 it\u2019s worth keeping something in mind: In a trade war, the usual rules of commerce may not apply.\n\nThat is doubly true in a potential trade war with China, for several reasons.\n\nBecause the country exports far more in goods to the United States than it imports, China simply doesn\u2019t have as much room to keep up with escalating American tariffs, especially given the Chinese government\u2019s desire to cushion its citizens from higher prices for food staples.\n\nMoreover, China has in the past proved willing to use a wide range of government powers to achieve commercial objectives \u2014 from campaigns against out-of-favor companies in state media to selective, stepped-up regulatory enforcement. And if things really get nasty, the United States and China are financially intertwined in ways that China could seek to exploit \u2014 though not without creating risks for a country holding $1.2 trillion in United States Treasury bonds.", "title": "If There\u2019s a U.S.-China Trade War, China May Have Some \u2018Unconventional Weapons\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-16 00:00:00", "text": "This article is part of the Opinion Today newsletter. You can sign up here to receive the newsletter each weekday.\n\nIn a New Yorker piece this weekend, Adam Davidson predicted that the final stage of the Trump presidency had already begun. The investigation into Michael Cohen, the president\u2019s personal lawyer and longtime fixer, marks the beginning of the end, Davidson argued.\n\n\u201cI am unaware of anybody who has taken a serious look at Trump\u2019s business who doesn\u2019t believe that there is a high likelihood of rampant criminality,\u201d Davidson wrote. \u201cHe had a small, sad operation, mostly run by his two oldest children and Michael Cohen, a lousy lawyer who barely keeps up the pretenses of lawyering and who now faces an avalanche of charges, from taxicab-backed bank fraud to money laundering and campaign-finance violations.\u201d\n\nIf that forecast is correct, there is little wonder that President Trump seems to be thinking more seriously about firing Rod Rosenstein, the deputy attorney general, and perhaps Robert Mueller, the special counsel. Doing either could disrupt the investigations into his 2016 campaign and his businesses.", "title": "Opinion | If Trump Fires Rosenstein ...", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-19 00:00:00", "text": "The pessimism among policymakers \u2014 who are attending spring meetings of the I.M.F. and World Bank in Washington this week \u2014 contrasts with financial markets. Despite a bumpy couple of months, stocks and most other financial assets are still priced at levels that suggest growth will continue apace for some time to come.\n\n\u201cEconomists are paid to worry,\u201d said Nathan Sheets, chief economist at PGIM Fixed Income and a former official at the United States Treasury and the Federal Reserve. \u201cWe\u2019re paid to find problems and challenges. I think the markets, on the other hand, are pretty good at living in the moment.\u201d\n\nWhat are these policymakers so worried about? Is this just a bunch of economists living up to their field\u2019s reputation as the dismal science \u2014 or worse, letting their own policy preferences shape their forecasts? Or is the world economy, for all its apparent prosperity, actually in peril?\n\nLet\u2019s look at the interrelated threats the economists see.\n\nTrade War Worries\n\nPresident Trump tweeted last month that trade wars are \u201cgood, and easy to win,\u201d but it is safe to say that leading economic policymakers do not agree. They instead see the risk of ruin in the administration\u2019s tariff threats \u2014 a cycle of retaliation that could disrupt companies\u2019 supply chains and cause global commerce to falter.\n\nImage Steel coils for car production in Emden, Germany, last month. A steep tariff on steel imports is among the threats from President Trump that have unnerved economists. Credit David Hecker/Epa-Efe, via Rex, via Shutterstock.\n\nMs. Lagarde argued in a speech last week that the global trading system has had tremendous benefits in terms of reducing poverty and creating higher-wage jobs. \u201cBut that system of rules and shared responsibility is now in danger of being torn apart,\u201d she said.", "title": "If the World Economy Is Looking So Great, Why Are Global Policymakers So Gloomy?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-11 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nYour April 11 editorial \u201cThe Law Is Coming, Mr. Trump\u201d was brilliant. The problem is nobody cares. Nobody cares how he does business and the kinds of people he surrounds himself with. Nobody cares about his prevarications, his hypocrisy, his misogyny, his illiteracy, his rants and, most of all, his lack of a moral compass.\n\nNobody cares. Not Congress, not the evangelicals who are eager to give him all the mulligans he needs, and certainly not his 40 percent base.\n\nThe results of the Mueller investigation won\u2019t matter. President Trump will never be impeached, and all of his minions currently under investigation will be pardoned.\n\nThe only way to contain Mr. Trump until 2020 is to elect a veto-proof Democratic Congress in 2018. Until we can find a new set of leaders equipped with a backbone and a conscience who understand and support the word \u201ccompromise,\u201d \u201cfake\u201d government will continue.", "title": "Opinion | Ignoring Trump\u2019s Faults", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-06 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nNEVER REMEMBER\n\nSearching for Stalin\u2019s Gulags in Putin\u2019s Russia\n\nBy Masha Gessen\n\nPhotographs by Misha Friedman\n\n160 pp. Columbia Global Reports. $27.99.\n\nHuman beings have long slaughtered each other with gusto, but almost always choose mass victims from a group defined as alien. The Nazis killed about six million Jews; Japanese invaders massacred millions of Chinese; European settlers in the Americas enslaved millions of Africans; the list goes on. But the striking thing about Joseph Stalin\u2019s Soviet Union, as the Russian-American journalist Masha Gessen observes in her new book, \u201cNever Remember,\u201d is that \u201cRussians exerted the force of state terror against themselves. \u2026 The millions who died anonymously in the Gulag were not necessarily members of ethnic or religious minorities, or even homosexuals: The population of the camps largely corresponded to the population of the country.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nAlthough at times the dictator\u2019s venom did target particular groups, like Ukrainians, Crimean Tatars and, at the very end of his life, Jews, this is largely true. The mass deaths at Soviet execution sites or in labor camps were a self-inflicted genocide: \u201cRussians had no other nation to blame for their nightmare.\u201d When, as Gessen adds, \u201cevery museum, indeed every country, ultimately aims to tell a story about the goodness of its people,\u201d how, then, do you remember a system that led to the outright execution of somewhere around a million people and the deaths by starvation or exposure in the Gulag of an unknown additional number, generally reckoned far into the millions? The answer, in Vladimir Putin\u2019s Russia, is hardly at all.\n\nThis wasn\u2019t always so. In 1991, I lived in Russia for five months, working on a book about how Soviets were coming to terms with the Stalin era. There was still some exhilaration in the air at how, under Mikhail Gorbachev, you could now discuss and explore things that had been off limits for some 70 years. I met dozens of researchers studying that dark era, including an imaginative high school history teacher who staged a mock trial of Stalin in his class and people who were digging up mass graves (at one in Siberia I could see the bullet hole in each earth-stained skull). Activists in Moscow put on an evening of poetry and music performed by, or in honor of, Gulag survivors. Museums displayed prison camp artifacts. In the Kolyma region of Russia\u2019s far northeast I visited the most desolate place I have ever seen, Butugychag, a barren, rocky valley streaked with snow even in June, where thousands of prisoners had been worked to death mining tin and uranium, their bodies thrown down unused mine shafts. But the man with me from the Memorial Society, a human rights group, eagerly talked about how places like this could be turned into remembrance sites with lessons for today, as has happened at Auschwitz and other Nazi death camps.\n\nGessen and Misha Friedman, who took the grainy, haunting photographs for this book, also visited Butugychag, but found no memorials there. Virtually the only place in Russia where this has happened is a former labor camp outside of Perm, in the Urals, carefully restored over some years. But then something occurred that was never anticipated. Under Putin \u2014 whose motto might as well be \u201cMake Russia Great Again\u201d \u2014 Stalin\u2019s rule is now remembered as a time of glory and order. Scores of new books and films portray the era in glowing colors, and vintage secret police uniforms are on sale. The husband-and-wife team who spearheaded the restoration at Perm lost their jobs, and the rebuilt camp has now become a site of pilgrimage for those who want to celebrate the old days. It is a grim reminder that once again, as in the 1930s, all over the world authoritarian strongmen are riding high.", "title": "Illuminating the Dark World of the Soviet Gulag, in Photos and Text", "authors": ["Adam Hochschild", "Masha Gessen", "Misha Friedman"]} {"date": "2018-04-19 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nAfter the drama of diagnosis passes and the preliminary offers of assistance dissipate, a few hardy souls hang in with cancer patients for the long haul. If we are lucky, they tender surprisingly creative acts and gifts.\n\nImaginative caregiving is welcome because of the debilitation of prolonged treatment but also because of the barrage of clich\u00e9d responses patients receive from chance acquaintances. There I am, minding my own business in the drugstore, when someone pops up: \u201cMy aunt had your kind of cancer and died in two months.\u201d \u201cYou don\u2019t look sick!\u201d \u201cDid you eat red meat?\u201d \u201cThe good Lord never gives us more than we can bear.\u201d Those of us with chronic disease learn to block out this type of noise.\n\nPhoto\n\nIn the process of sidelining inane comments, though, we may exacerbate the loneliness of the long-distance cancer patient, for dealing with the disease can be an isolating business. Colleagues in social situations can be tongue-tied about my condition, afraid of saying the wrong thing or respectful of my privacy. At a reception, I retreat into myself because of an unspeakable physical problem: a rash, a swelling, a hidden bag, enervating but boring fatigue, invisible neuropathies or joint pain. I feel further quarantined by an overwhelming consciousness of impending mortality that healthy men and women often cannot comprehend or desperately want to flee.\n\nWhile conversations rarely penetrate the bell jar of my self-containment, inventive forms of caregiving do. Over the years, relatives and friends have scoured my refrigerator, weeded my closet, shaved my head, emailed jokes, brought over pets, read aloud a cherished book, served as my personal grocery shopper and taken me to concerts. Others have given me a gentle yoga session, a shell from Sanibel Island, a potboiler, an outrageous wig, a microwaveable hot pad, and (unexpectedly effective) battery-operated socks.\n\nPhoto\n\nWit is one of the most treasured characteristics of thoughtful caregiving, and Bob Carey\u2019s Tutu Project offers a generous dose of it. After his wife, Linda, began dealing with a breast cancer diagnosis, Mr. Carey, a commercial photographer, began taking photographs of himself wearing only a pink tutu in public places. He wanted to make her laugh. Since the images also amused the other patients she met in the hospital, they decided to publish them as a coffee-table book called \u201cBallerina.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBoth photographer and subject, Mr. Carey poses in a variety of landmark settings: on the Brooklyn Bridge, at the Little Grand Canyon in Utah, on Newport Beach, Calif., at the Rock & Roll Hall of Fame in Cleveland. The pictures suggest that those dealing with cancer take it with them wherever they go.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe juxtaposition of our idea of the stereotypically sleek ballerina and Mr. Carey\u2019s burly, hairy body is playful, but the images simultaneously convey his isolation and vulnerability. Usually solo, he appears at a distance in vast spaces that dwarf him, decked out in a flimsy costume that exposes his fleshiness and that might put him at risk. The pink of breast cancer and the pink-washing of the marketing of breast cancer should not be considered gender-specific concerns limited to medical environments.", "title": "Imaginative Caregiving for the Cancer Patient", "authors": ["Susan Gubar", "Living With Cancer"]} {"date": "2018-04-17 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nRe \u201cPlan to Make Overdose Drug Accessible Falters\u201d (front page, April 13):\n\nNew York City has made it easier to obtain naloxone, an easy-to-use medication that reverses opioid overdoses as part of HealingNYC, a comprehensive plan to prevent overdose deaths and save lives. Most large chain pharmacies can dispense naloxone without a prescription and are putting thousands of kits in the hands of the people who need them most.\n\nHaving a naloxone kit on hand can save a life. It is unacceptable that some participating pharmacies are unaware that they can distribute naloxone to anyone without a prescription and without insurance.\n\nIf naloxone is not in stock, the pharmacies should inform New Yorkers that they will order it. The Health Department has followed up with all participating pharmacies to correct any issues with dispensing this lifesaving medication.\n\nSince July, the city has distributed over 100,000 naloxone kits to local organizations and city agencies that serve people who use drugs. Firefighters, ambulances, emergency medical technicians and every Police Department patrol officer now carry naloxone.", "title": "Opinion | Improving Access to a Lifesaving Drug", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-11 00:00:00", "text": "The authorities in Austria raided the headquarters of biathlon\u2019s global governing body following a tip from the World Anti-Doping Agency that its leaders may have been involved with the vast Russian doping scandal that continues to roil international sports.\n\nThe Salzburg-based International Biathlon Union, which has long had close links to Russian sports, confirmed the investigation in a news release on Wednesday, in which it also announced that its longtime secretary general, Nicole Resch, had requested a leave of absence. The I.B.U. said the investigation focused on Resch \u2014 who had publicly questioned sports regulators\u2019 conclusions about Russia\u2019s systematic cheating \u2014 and the group\u2019s president, Anders Besseberg, a former biathlete and cross-country skier who is also a board member of the antidoping agency.\n\nThe raid escalates the Russian doping scandal at a time when sports officials have tried to put it in the rearview mirror. Investigators have established that huge amounts of corruption within Russia\u2019s system tainted track and field. The raid in Austria signals that the investigation has extended to other sports\u2019 governing bodies and could raise additional questions about possible bribery in other federations.\n\nBiathlon had been at the center of a number of allegations related to Russian doping years before the 2016 revelations of a state-sponsored scheme that corrupted dozens of sporting events, including to the 2014 Winter Olympics in Sochi, Russia.", "title": "In Austria, Police Raids Stemming From Russian Sports Corruption Inquiries", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-14 00:00:00", "text": "The Bathroom\n\nSomewhere between a Manhattan subway station and a colonial lodge, the small but appealing bathroom was lined with white rectangular tile and wood-slat blinds over the windows. The sizable shower was big enough to host an editorial meeting, but a tub would have been more conducive to scribbling and reading. The hotel-brand shampoo and shower gel are made with Thai white charcoal, a substance said to \u201cemit negative ions that increase your sense of well-being, \u201d according to the overwrought text in the room\u2019s guest services guide.\n\nImage The rooftop garden at Bangkok Publishing Residence. Credit Bangkok Publishing Residence\n\nAmenities\n\nCrowded rooftop bars fill this teeming, tall city.\n\nThe hotel bucks the trend with a private and lushly planted rooftop garden, complete with fruit trees, a small library lounge and a whirlpool tub. You can grab a banana (from the source), a best-seller (Charles Dickens, Stephen King, Agatha Christie) and plunge into cool, bubbly waters as you plunge into fictional worlds.\n\nImage The lobby where breakfast is served at Bangkok Publishing Residence. Credit Bangkok Publishing Residence\n\nDining\n\n\u201cOne cannot think well, love well, sleep well, if one has not dined well,\u201d as Virginia Woolf wrote in \u201cA Room of One\u2019s Own.\u201d Alas, it seems that Bangkok Publishing Residence missed that week of book club: The hotel has no restaurant, and the (free) minibar offers just some small packets of candies, nuts and sliced fruits, along with water and juice.
