Bangkok Publishing Residence does have a kitchen, however, and a copious breakfast of eggs, meats and fruits, staves off total hunger.", "title": "In Bangkok, an Intimate Hotel With an Inky Past", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-18 00:00:00", "text": "It is not unusual for sitting presidents to skip funerals for former first ladies. Mr. Obama did not attend funerals for Betty Ford or Nancy Reagan. George W. Bush did not go to Lady Bird Johnson\u2019s funeral. Mr. Clinton did not go to Patricia Nixon\u2019s service, although he did attend the funeral for Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis. Ronald Reagan did not go to Bess Truman\u2019s service.\n\nGeorge W. Bush said on Wednesday that he spoke with Mrs. Bush by telephone shortly before her death to tell her he loved her, and she replied that she loved him too.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s the end of a beautiful life,\u201d Mr. Bush told Maria Bartiromo on Fox Business Network on Wednesday morning in his first interview following Mrs. Bush\u2019s death. \u201cShe truly believes that there\u2019s an afterlife, that she\u2019ll be wonderfully received in the arms of a loving God and therefore did not fear death. And as a result of her soul being comforted on the deathbed, my soul is comforted.\u201d\n\nHe appeared beside his wife, Laura Bush, who noted that she learned how to be first lady from her mother-in-law. \u201cShe was a great role model for me,\u201d she said.\n\nThe former president said his two daughters \u2014 Barbara Bush, who was named for her grandmother, and Jenna Bush Hager \u2014 were dealing with the loss of Ganny, as they called her. \u201cThey\u2019re emotional but as I explained to them, we ought to be joyful that we had such a wonderful woman in our lives and, two, that she passed with such strong beliefs. She truly was peaceful.\u201d\n\nMs. Hager, a correspondent on NBC\u2019s \u201cToday\u201d show, posted on Instagram a photograph of her as a child sitting next to her grandmother. \u201cI already miss this FORCE of a woman \u2014 the \u2018enforcer\u2019 because she was the glue that held our family together,\u201d she wrote. \u201cShe taught me to use my voice but also to value the opinions of others. She adored her friends and family; her loyalty was unwavering. Humor helps, she often said and it does, Gans, but I will miss your laugh terribly.\u201d\n\nAnother grandchild took to Twitter to offer a tribute. \u201cMy grandmother didn\u2019t just live life; she lived it well,\u201d wrote George P. Bush, the land commissioner in Texas and the son of Jeb Bush. \u201cAnd the sorrow of her loss is softened by the knowledge of her impact on our family and our country. I will miss you, Ganny \u2014 but know we will see you again.\u201d", "title": "In Barbara Bush\u2019s Final Days, Faith, Courage and a Little Last Needling", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-24 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cIt was such a vibrant cultural place in the 1920s,\u201d said Monika Spr\u00fcth, the Cologne-based dealer who co-owns the gallery Spr\u00fcth Magers and operates a branch in Berlin. \u201cThe early days of modernism were lived there, and it still retains that atmosphere.\u201d\n\nThe cultural flowering was short lived, targeted by the Nazis as \u201cdegenerate art\u201d as part of the horrors leading up to World War II. Then large parts of the city were destroyed during the war. And the Cold War gave the city its most famous single feature: the Berlin Wall, which stood from 1961 to 1989.\n\nMr. Biesenbach was there just after the wall fell, an event that precipitated a decade of artistic production perhaps not rivaling that of the 1920s, but significant nonetheless.\n\n\u201cThe \u201990s were a legendary time,\u201d Mr. Biesenbach said. \u201cIt was a time when East Berlin seemed abandoned, and it was an empty canvas for artists. That\u2019s very seductive. And at that time, New York rents were getting expensive.\u201d\n\nIn the early 1990s, Mr. Biesenbach co-founded the arts organization Kunst-Werke Institute for Contemporary Art (KW), which later spawned the Berlin Biennale; both are still going strong. Part of their success was positioning Berlin as an international artist center, not just a German one.\n\nImage Klaus Biesenbach, the director of MoMA PS1 and the chief curator at large for the Museum of Modern Art in New York, lived in Berlin for some 15 years and called it \u201cthe most liberal, artist-friendly place I have ever been.\u201d Credit Birgit Kleber\n\n\u201cWhen we started KW, I made it an institutional policy to speak English,\u201d Mr. Biesenbach said. \u201cSome people thought I was crazy. It was a bit early for that. But the last 20 years have proved the strategy right.\u201d", "title": "In Berlin, Artists Find a Home", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-24 00:00:00", "text": "For the chapter \u201cMaking Paradise. Places of Longing, from Paul Gauguin to Tita Salina,\u201d the museum has acquired paintings by Mr. Spies on permanent loan. At the other end of the spectrum is Ms. Salina, a young Indonesian artist whose video artwork \u201c1001st Island \u2014 The Most Sustainable Island in Archipelago\u201d casts a critical light on the Western longing for island paradise.\n\n[READ MORE: In Berlin, Artists Find a Home]\n\nUdo Kittelmann, director of the Nationalgalerie, the umbrella organization that includes five of Berlin\u2019s museums, and a curator of \u201cHello World,\u201d called it a \u201cduty in these changing times\u201d to represent artistic movements on all continents, from Asia to South America. He said that while the collecting preferences of German museums were \u201cstrongly shaped by American influence\u201d after the Second World War, institutions in the United States were meanwhile working to \u201cexpand the canon.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nThe Nationalgalerie has touched upon the need for placing non-European art on equal footing with established works, but never on this scale. The 2010 exhibit \u201cIntolerance,\u201d curated by Willem de Rooij, explored the parallels between 17th-century Dutch paintings and 18th-century Hawaiian ceremonial objects.\n\nMr. de Rooij, a Dutch artist based in Berlin, lauded \u201cHello World\u201d for taking on a \u201cpublic investigation\u201d of the Nationalgalerie\u2019s collections and expressed hope that the initiative would generate an \u201congoing discussion\u201d within the organization. He noted the potential for Berlin\u2019s museums to take a leading role in the canonization of artwork in nearby countries such as Poland.\n\n[READ MORE: Berlin Galleries Find a Way to Lure the World]\n\nThe retrospective brings together eight on-site curators with five guests whose specialties include African and Eastern European art. The art historian and guest curator Cl\u00e9mentine Deliss, in her chapter, \u201cPortable Homelands. From Field to Factory,\u201d exhibits the works of the German painter Heinrich Vogeler alongside the results of a community-outreach project she initiated at an abandoned factory in the town of Dilijan, Armenia. While best known for his \u201cJugendstil\u201d or Art Nouveau period, Vogeler produced paintings for the Socialist cause in the 1930s from the Soviet Union \u2014 including Armenia, a Soviet republic at the time.\n\nBy juxtaposing the work of artists as different as Vogeler, the Australia-based design team Perks and Mini, and the Armenian filmmaker Vardan Danielyan, Ms. Deliss hopes to above all explore the \u201ctransversal connections\u201d between artists, also as they existed before the internet and the age of easy world travel. Artists of different countries \u201cmay have known more about each other than one presumes,\u201d she said.\n\nPhoto\n\nMr. Kittelmann also emphasized that globalization was underway as early as the 19th century, quoting the modern art patron Harry Graf Kessler, who in 1898 noted that \u201cthe picture remains amazingly similar from one part of the world to another\u201d during his travels in Mexico.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn Mr. Kittelmann\u2019s exhibit chapter, titled \u201cWhere Do We Come From? Adapting Sculptural Forms,\u201d he explores the influence of non-European art on modern sculpture. Rather than pairing museum works with artifacts that may have been intended for spiritual rituals, however, he prefers to allow these connections to speak for themselves.\n\nThe selection includes objects from the permanent collection that have never been exhibited, such as \u201cVenus Negra,\u201d by the 20th-century Bolivian sculptor Marina N\u00fa\u00f1ez del Prado. The headless, curvy torso sits around the corner from \u201cHelmet Head No. 6\u201d by Henry Moore, known for his abstracted depictions of the female body.\n\nBy bringing works that are \u201calways in storage to daylight\u201d and reconsidering their place in history, Mr. Kittelmann hopes that \u201cHello World\u201d will provoke thought about the very credibility of a museum \u201cat a time when credibility is thrown into question almost every day.\u201d\n\n\u201cWe, another generation of museum staff, have different tasks to face than perhaps was the case 20 years ago.\u201d", "title": "In Berlin, Looking at a Familiar Art Collection With New Eyes", "authors": ["Rebecca Schmid"]} {"date": "2018-04-25 00:00:00", "text": "The assailant was arrested and detained and charged with attempting serious bodily injury.\n\nOn Tuesday, the head of Germany\u2019s Central Council of Jews, the largest umbrella Jewish organization in the country, warned Jews against openly wearing skullcaps. The official, Josef Schuster, urged them to \u201cwear a baseball cap or something else to cover their head instead.\u201d\n\nThe comment triggered an angry response from international Jewish groups, who decried it as an indication of failure on the part of German authorities.\n\n\u201cThe fact that the head of the Central Council of Jews in Germany has advised against wearing a kipa in public must serve as a final wake up call for German and European society to take action,\u201d said Moshe Kantor, president of the European Jewish Congress.\n\nDespite the demonstrations on Wednesday, many among the more than 100,000 Jews who now call Berlin home worry that the outward display of solidarity will remain largely symbolic. They do not expect it to change the threats they face daily, in a political climate in which the far-right has been resurgent and incidents of anti-Semitism and racism have increased, even in a city that celebrates diversity as key to its modern identity.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s nice, it\u2019s meaningful, to see people stand up and say that Jewish life should be here,\u201d said Andrew Mark Bennet, a doctoral law student in Berlin and member of its youngest Jewish Orthodox community. He came to Berlin from Maryland, by way of Israel. \u201cBut at the end of the day, tomorrow I\u2019m still putting a cap over my kipa, because it\u2019s not safe to walk the streets of Berlin with it.\u201d\n\nSince the fall of the Berlin Wall in 1989, Berlin has seen a flourishing of Jewish life. An Orthodox community was founded in 2013. Kosher stores and restaurants have sprouted, and young Jews and artists have arrived from Israel. But even as Berlin has welcomed the return of a culture the Nazis sought to eradicate, Jews living in Berlin say discrimination, both subtle and violent, is part of daily life.\n\nThe government has sought to respond. Felix Klein, the newly appointed commissioner for anti-Semitism, plans to establish a national network to help identify causes of discrimination and racism targeting Jews as a key first step in combating the problem. \u201cWe need to quickly establish a system where victims can turn to to report incidents,\u201d Mr. Klein said. \u201cBecause in order to develop an effective strategy to combat anti-Semitism, we need to know exactly where it lies.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMany point to the arrival of more than 1 million migrants and refugees, many of them from the conflict-ridden Middle East, who have been taught to hate Jews and seek Israel\u2019s demise. However, police statistics from 2017 show that of 1,453 anti-Semitic crimes, nine out of 10 were attributed to members of far-right or neo-Nazi groups. Anti-Semitism has also become more prevalent in pop culture.\n\nGermany\u2019s Music Industry Association announced on Wednesday that it was scrapping its annual music prize, the Echo, after outrage over its decision to award a trophy to a rap duo whose album included a song about how their bodies are \u201cmore defined than Auschwitz prisoners,\u201d and another, in which they vow to \u201cmake another Holocaust, show up with a Molotov.\u201d\n\nNumerous internationally recognized musicians, including the orchestra director Daniel Barenboim, have been handing back their prizes in protest in recent weeks, apparently prompting the organization to backtrack on its original assertion that the song lyrics, while problematic, were protected as artistic expression.\n\nAlong with the arrival of the refugees, Germany has also recently experienced the rise of a far-right political party, the Alternative for Germany, whose leaders have for the first time questioned the country\u2019s post-World War II culture of remembrance. Together, these forces have caused a shift in what is acceptable in German society.\n\nMichal Friedlander, a curator at the Jewish Museum, said she recently found herself seated in a first-class train carriage next to a German man reading a newspaper article about the anti-Semitic attack in Berlin. Without being asked, the man turned to her, and explained what he would do to all of the Jews and Arabs living in Germany, demonstratively drawing his finger across his throat. \u201cThis is the shift,\u201d said Ms. Friedlander, who has lived in Berlin for 17 years. \u201cPeople are not ashamed to say these things out loud.\u201d\n\nIn such a climate, many fear, shows of solidarity will go only so far. The demonstration of support in Berlin was held on a street cordoned off by police. As they left the area and passed the police line, many demonstrators could be seen taking their skullcaps off.", "title": "In Berlin, a Show of Solidarity Does Little to Dampen Jewish Fears", "authors": ["Melissa Eddy"]} {"date": "2018-04-24 00:00:00", "text": "NORRISTOWN, Pa. \u2014 Lawyers for Bill Cosby attacked his accuser, Andrea Constand, during closing arguments in his sexual assault retrial Tuesday, calling her a \u201ccon artist\u201d and asking jurors to ignore the social changes occurring outside the courtroom so they could focus on the case before them.\n\nMs. Constand, they said, had converted a consensual affair into a lucrative payday with a false accusation that threatened Mr. Cosby, once a beloved entertainer, with \u201cabsolute ruin.\u201d\n\nBut prosecutors in their final statements to the jury said it was Mr. Cosby who was the manipulator, describing him as a man who hid behind his genial image as America\u2019s Dad even as he used drugs to incapacitate and assault women.\n\n\u201cShe is not the con,\u201d Kristen Gibbons Feden, a special prosecutor, told the court. \u201cHe is.\u201d\n\nAs the first high-profile trial since the #MeToo movement began, the case is being closely watched by experts interested in whether there is any notable impact on the jury, which will begin deliberations Wednesday.", "title": "In Bill Cosby\u2019s Case, Who\u2019s the Con Artist? Both Sides Close by Pointing Fingers", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-04 00:00:00", "text": "LIVERPOOL, England \u2014 They started arriving in the late afternoon, three hours before kickoff. They filled every spare inch of space they could find. When there was no room left on the ground, they clambered up traffic signal poles and scurried onto walls.\n\nWhere Arkles Road turns into Anfield Road and Liverpool\u2019s stadium suddenly looms up into the sky, they unfurled their banners and draped their flags, and they sang their songs.\n\nTwo hours earlier, they had set off so many flares and smoke bombs already that the smell of cordite was wafting down Lower Breck Road, half a mile from the stadium, and the sky seemed to have been dyed red, as if something was burning.\n\nThen, a little over an hour before the opening whistle, their moment came. First, Manchester City\u2019s team bus turned the corner and began its slow, nervous progression toward Anfield, guarded by mounted police. Thick red smoke clogged the air. Firecrackers exploded. Pyrotechnics sputtered into life, their sodium light cutting through the fog. Bottles and beer cans flew, a handful clattering off the sides of the bus. But nostalgia for the fishing industry permeates the place. So the result seemed inevitable when 70 percent of residents voted to leave the European Union. Britain\u2019s fishermen have complained for years about regulations imposed on all members.\n\nThe surprise came later when a local business group began lobbying to avoid tariffs, customs and the other burdens of departing the European Union. Social media scorn ensued. In thousands of tweets across the country, the people of Grimsby were derided as dummies and hypocrites. Either they wanted the upsides of Brexit with none of its costs, or they didn\u2019t grasp the harm that leaving would cause until it was too late.\n\n\u201cGrimsby residents branded \u2018idiots\u2019 for Brexit vote as seafood industry seeks free trade deal,\u201d read a headline in a local newspaper.", "title": "In Brexit Vote, Town\u2019s Nostalgia for Seafaring Past Muddied Its Future", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-12 00:00:00", "text": "BRISBANE, Australia \u2014 The restaurant\u2019s name will be a single word: stark, vaguely industrial, somewhat meaningless. There will be some sort of sculptural tartare on the menu, and probably a kingfish ceviche. Saltbush and kangaroo and finger lime will all make appearances. The format is a tasting menu or shared plates or a combination of both; the wines are natural. Ben Shewry has a lot to answer for.\n\nMr. Shewry\u2019s Melbourne restaurant, Attica, has helped transform Australia\u2019s dining landscape, with an emphasis on native ingredients and inventive local winemakers and a penchant for layered, unexpected flavors. It also has spawned a thousand imitators.\n\nPerhaps it would be more generous to say that Attica has inspired a new generation of Australian chefs. (Some of the blame, or credit, should be spread around; the chef Dan Hunter, of Brae, is similarly influential, and Ren\u00e9 Redzepi\u2019s brief Australian iteration of Noma left an indelible mark.)\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Subscribe to the Australia Letter Newsletter Damien Cave, our new Australia bureau chief, shares insights on global news, local recommendations and feedback from readers in this weekly newsletter. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nAustralia now has a style of dining that is immensely recognizable. But it can be very difficult to tell one \u201cmodern Australian\u201d restaurant from another. Much like the natural wines that dominate their lists, this crop of restaurants has a lot of potential, and plenty of intrigue and newness. But sometimes exploring the brave new world of natural wine will have you thinking: \u201cI probably like this? I know I\u2019m supposed to like it.
