The resolution would also serve as a formal recognition by the City Council, which organizers hope will make it easier to work with tourism and business improvement officials.\n\n\u201cPeople are stepping all over us so we\u2019ve got to empower ourselves,\u201d Ms. Bichotte said during a meeting of the Little Haiti BK organizing committee at her district office on Flatbush Avenue.\n\nBut even as the push for a designation grows, the area\u2019s Haitian character is already eroding, as gentrification and the movement of Haitians to the suburbs trigger changes. While the number of Haitian-Americans grew to 1.1 million in 2016, from 623,000 in 2000, New York\u2019s place in the Haitian diaspora has been falling. In 2016, 20 percent of the country\u2019s Haitians lived in New York, down from 30 percent in 2000. In contrast, the Haitian population in Georgia and Pennsylvania more than tripled to over 30,000 people each in 2016.\n\nStill, Brooklyn now has more than 90,000 Haitian-Americans, giving it the third highest concentration in the country, according to an analysis by the Migration Policy Institute, a Washington, D.C.-based think tank.", "title": "In Brooklyn, Push for a Special Haitian District Hits Resistance", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-13 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cThey\u2019re coming,\u201d Christina Blaustein said to her 4-year-old son, Reife, who was practically jumping out of his white beekeeper\u2019s suit just after dawn Friday in Bryant Park in Midtown Manhattan.\n\nReife pulled off his mesh hood and ran to meet a box truck bearing a mural on its side of animated bees buzzing in front of the New York City skyline.\n\nThe truck\u2019s back door opened to reveal its cargo: 3 million Italian honeybees.\n\nThey did not seem that happy after having endured a 15-hour drive up from Georgia, but Reife was delighted, as he examined the hundreds of wood-and-screen boxes, each one holding more than 10,000 bees.\n\nHe picked out two boxes. His mother paid the bee man $150 apiece for them and drove them off to Long Island, where the family keeps hives.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThey were among roughly 150 beekeepers who flocked to Bryant Park for the bee delivery, to replenish hives across the city and the region: on building rooftops, in small urban backyards and sometimes even indoors.", "title": "In Bryant Park, 3 Million Bees, Sold From the Back of a Truck", "authors": ["Corey Kilgannon"]} {"date": "2018-04-07 00:00:00", "text": "BUKHARA, Uzbekistan \u2014 The ancient Silk Road city of Bukhara has two synagogues, a primary school that teaches Hebrew, a Jewish cultural association and a sprawling Jewish cemetery with more than 10,000 graves. What it lacks are Jews.\n\n300 miles KAZAKHSTAN UZBEKISTAN Tashkent Bukhara TURKMEN. TAJIKISTAN Samarkand AFGHANISTAN IRAN\n\nHome to one of the world\u2019s oldest and, in centuries past, biggest Jewish communities, Bukhara \u2014 a fabled city of ancient ruins and Islamic architectural treasures in central Uzbekistan \u2014 has a Muslim population of more than 270,000 people but, according to most estimates, only 100 to 150 Jews.\n\nEven that, said Lyuba Kimatova, an observant Jew whose son and older daughter emigrated to Israel, is a big exaggeration. Ms. Kimatova said there were only four or five families left who kept kosher and followed Jewish traditions. The rest, she said, \u201cdo not really live like Jews anymore.\u201d\n\nThat is not entirely their fault, she quickly added, but mostly the result of the fact that there is nobody left who can slaughter animals for food according to Jewish law. Until last month, the city had two dueling rabbis who knew the rituals of slaughter, but each was old and very sick, and too feeble to wield a butcher\u2019s knife.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe older rabbi has now died, delivering yet another blow to a community with a storied history stretching back millenniums but steadily running out of living members.", "title": "In Bukhara, 10,000 Jewish Graves but Just 150 Jews", "authors": ["Andrew Higgins"]} {"date": "2018-04-14 00:00:00", "text": "The dispute has been festering for months. But the tension peaked when the pipeline\u2019s owner, Kinder Morgan of Houston, said last weekend that it is suspending all nonessential spending on the program.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe company gave British Columbia until the end of May to end its attempts to delay or block the project. If not, the company said it would cancel its plan to add a second pipeline along aroute that opened in 1953.\n\nTo try to resolve the standoff, Mr. Trudeau has summoned Rachel Notley, the premier of Alberta, and John Horgan, her counterpart in British Columbia, to Ottawa for talks on Sunday.\n\nGiven the intransigence of both sides, even Mr. Trudeau\u2019s top officials are downplaying the idea that the conversation will end the battle. But it may provide a glimpse of how Mr. Trudeau intends to grapple with an issue in which any resolution will inevitably alienate some voters, and on which there isn\u2019t a clear national consensus.\n\n\u201cCanadians are quite divided,\u201d said Shachi Kurl, the executive director of the Angus Reid Institute, a nonprofit polling firm based in Vancouver. \u201cSo much of this debate is rural versus urban Canada.\u201d\n\nLike the Keystone XL pipeline to the Gulf Coast of the United States, which was quashed by President Barack Obama and revived by Mr. Trump, the expansion of the existing Kinder Morgan pipeline is the latest attempt by the oil sands industry to push more of its product out to market. The pipelines have not expanded at the same rate as output from the oil sands, leaving many producers relying on expensive rail shipments to get their product to the United States, which currently buys almost all of Canada\u2019s oil and gas exports.\n\nTankers filled by the current Kinder Morgan pipeline now sail to refineries on the West Coast of the United States. The extra capacity from an expansion could, in theory, allow oil sands companies to also begin shipping to Asian markets where demand for oil is growing, said Andrew Leach, an energy and environmental economist at the University of Alberta.\n\nPhoto\n\nMs. Notley, and her left-of-center New Democratic Party, surprised the Canadian political world in 2015 by bringing four and a half decades of Progressive Conservative rule to an end in Alberta. While she vowed in her campaign to take on the big oil interests in the province, politically she has no choice but to be a booster of the pipeline. Polls show that Albertans overwhelmingly want the expansion to go ahead.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nTo defend the expansion, the premier has shown a willingness to get tough with her provincial neighbor to the west. Earlier this year, Ms. Notley briefly banned imports of wine from British Columbia.\n\nAnd unless the meeting Sunday changes her mind, Ms. Notley\u2019s government is expected to introduce legislation next week that will give it the ability to restrict oil and gas shipments to British Columbia, and so driving up prices in the province.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cIf the national interest is given over to the extremes on the left or the right, if the voices of the moderate majority of Canadians are forgotten, the reverberations of that will tear at the fabric of Confederation for many, many years to come,\u201d Ms. Notley said on Monday, referring to the power-sharing system that Canada adopted in 1867.\n\nThis past week, Ms. Notley suggested that if Kinder Morgan decides not to go ahead with the expansion, the provincial government may buy and build the pipeline. Officials in Mr. Trudeau\u2019s cabinet have suggested that the federal government might support such a plan.\n\nFor Mr. Horgan in British Columbia, the political calculus surrounding the pipeline expansion was more complex. The project is widely opposed in the areas around Vancouver and Victoria, the provincial capital, according to Ms. Kurl, the pollster. But support is strong for it elsewhere in the province, where resource industries are big employers.\n\nPhoto\n\nPerhaps tipping the scale in his decision to try to block the project is that Mr. Horgan, also a member of the New Democratic Party, relies on the support of three Green Party members to pass legislation. That party, like many environmental groups, argues that Canada should not be building oil pipelines while it is attempting to reduce greenhouse gas emissions.\n\nSo Mr. Horgan plans to ask a court to determine if British Columbia can use local permits and provincial environmental laws to block the pipeline.\n\nMr. Trudeau\u2019s government has cited several decisions, including some from the Supreme Court, that it contends give Ottawa complete authority over interprovincial pipelines. But it appears that the federal government can do nothing to stop Mr. Horgan from going to court. Any judicial review could at least delay the project.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe sparring between the two premiers may prove to be the least of Mr. Trudeau\u2019s worries in the pipeline fight, as he tries to balance Canada\u2019s economic dependence on the energy industry with his climate change commitments.\n\nEnvironmental groups and some indigenous groups have vowed to stop the pipeline expansion through widespread civil disobedience. Those arrested already for breaking court orders to keep back from Kinder Morgan property include Elizabeth May, the leader of the federal Green Party.\n\nMany environmental groups are using the pipeline expansion as a proxy in the fight against the oil sands, a source of fossil fuels that they condemn as excessively polluting.\n\n\u201cIn an ideal world, we would like to see the federal government recognizing that it made an egregious mistake in approving this pipeline,\u201d said Cam Fenton, a Canada strategy manager for 350.org, a nonprofit that opposes new fossil fuel projects. \u201cAt the end of the day polls change, science doesn\u2019t. And it says we cannot deal with climate change and build pipelines.\u201d", "title": "In Canada, 2 Provinces Feud Over Pipeline: Will It Bring Jobs or Spills?", "authors": ["Ian Austen"]} {"date": "2018-04-25 00:00:00", "text": "Charleston is nice \u2014 \u201cthe jewel of the Lowcountry,\u201d a travel writer recently proclaimed. But can a place so nice become too precious? There\u2019s a point on the third or fourth visit when the perfection and elegance of the \u201cHoly City\u2019s\u201d streetscapes, its meticulously restored and uniformly classical houses, begin to close in on your brain\u2019s right hemisphere.\n\nYou may find yourself craving a moment of weirdness, modernism or merengue. And with the real estate stakes so high \u2014 the median sale price of a home on the lower peninsula was over $850,000 in January \u2014 whimsy, experimentation and indolence seem to struggle for a foothold. The dazzling restaurant scene is so competitive, dining out on a Friday or Saturday can be as premeditated as a trip to the moon .\n\nThose of us who live here may feel these limitations most acutely. Some recall a time in the last century when things were a little less battened-down, almost beachy, the pace decidedly slower. True, Charleston may have been even more formal and less sophisticated in many ways then \u2014 a Heineken and a platter of fried shrimp was the best you could hope for in the average restaurant \u2014 but Charleston fundamentally lived up to its billing as a hub of Southern adventure.\n\nFortunately, anyone \u2014 local or visitor alike \u2014 who chafes at Charleston\u2019s stateliness and decorum today can find an instant remedy: its beer, served fresh from the tank in a largely industrial neighborhood two miles north of the city\u2019s tourist center.", "title": "In Charleston, Beer Gets Its Own Neighborhood", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-03 00:00:00", "text": "When Didi Gregorius was growing up on Cura\u00e7ao, his friends used to laugh at how, no matter how steamy the weather was on the Caribbean island, Gregorius always showed up to play ball in a long-sleeve shirt.\n\nIt is a habit that still persists. Whether he\u2019s deep in the humid heart of Texas in July or sweltering in Kansas City in August, Gregorius takes his position at shortstop for the Yankees wearing long sleeves.\n\nOn Tuesday, Gregorius found himself in conditions for which he was appropriately equipped. With those long sleeves \u2014 and a booming bat \u2014 nobody looked more comfortable in the drizzling, dank and bone-chilling weather than Gregorius, who belted two home runs and drove in a career-high eight runs in the Yankees\u2019 11-4 victory over the Tampa Bay Rays.\n\nGregorius\u2019s home runs gave the Yankees a win despite another hiccup from their bullpen, a five-strikeout performance from Giancarlo Stanton in his Yankee Stadium debut and dreadful conditions for their home opener, which was postponed by snow on Monday.", "title": "In Chilly Home Opener, Didi Gregorius Brings the Heat for the Yankees", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-21 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cI definitely wanted to get to know her better on a personal level,\u201d Mr. Lin said. He was attempting to do just that when the train doors opened at her Bergen Street stop, and Ms. Morgenshtern got off.\n\n\u201cI\u2019ll just ask her next time,\u201d Mr. Lin remembered thinking.\n\nThe following month, Mr. Lin returned to the session only to learn that Ms. Morgenshtern was not there. \u201cI didn\u2019t know what happened to her, and the only person who had her contact information was our volunteer project organizer, and all of that was kept private,\u201d Mr. Lin said. \u201cBeing a single man in New York, I was used to the ups and downs of dating, and I thought it was a lost opportunity.\u201d\n\nIn April 2016, Ms. Morgenshtern finally resurfaced at the cooking class. Since five long months had passed, Mr. Lin felt it best to keep the heat out of the kitchen. \u201cI didn\u2019t say anything to her about missing her or about how I was feeling,\u201d he said.\n\nThe following month, she invited him, along with other friends, to a bar in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, to watch the Kentucky Derby. (By now, they were both unattached.) \u201cI remember thinking, \u2018Uh-oh, am I getting friend-zoned?\u2019\u201d Mr. Lin recalled. \u201cSo I politely declined and suggested one-on-one drinks instead in the coming week.\u201d\n\nMs. Morgenshtern accepted, and only then did she realize that Mr. Lin had romance on his mind. \u201cI tend to be oblivious about these things,\u201d she said, laughing.\n\nAfter visiting a few bars, they shared a first kiss in front of the McDonald\u2019s outside the Delancey Street subway station. \u201cIt was the most romantic kiss in the least romantic spot,\u201d Mr. Lin said.", "title": "In Cooking Class, the Right Ingredients", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-20 00:00:00", "text": "Marc L. Mukasey, who has practiced law with Mr. Giuliani for more than a decade, most recently at the law firm Greenberg Traurig, noted that while Mr. Giuliani was \u201cnot often in the courtroom these days, he\u2019s a counselor and he\u2019ll be a great counselor to the president.\u201d\n\n\u201cHe has a track record of being a guy who can get things done,\u201d Mr. Mukasey said, \u201cand right now, getting this investigation done is important.\u201d\n\nThe Zarrab case \u2014 which was prosecuted in Mr. Giuliani\u2019s old stamping grounds, Federal District Court in Manhattan \u2014 could offer a clue to how he will approach the Russia matter. In that proceeding, Mr. Giuliani has said in court filings that he and Michael B. Mukasey, a former United States attorney general, were retained by Mr. Zarrab to try to negotiate a diplomatic resolution to his case, outside of the court.\n\nMr. Giuliani and Mr. Mukasey, who is Marc Mukasey\u2019s father, said in court papers that they had traveled to meet with President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey, and also discussed the Zarrab case with Trump administration officials who were outside of the prosecutors\u2019 office.\n\nBut their efforts appear to have been unsuccessful, as Mr. Zarrab ultimately pleaded guilty and agreed to cooperate with prosecutors.\n\nFor several months now, Mr. Trump has been having trouble retaining legal talent, especially as the Russia investigation \u2014 and a separate inquiry into his longtime lawyer and fixer, Michael D. Cohen \u2014 has started heating up. And according to officials at the White House, one reason that Mr. Giuliani was brought onboard was to beat back the narrative that the president\u2019s legal ship is sinking.\n\nWith his connections in the Justice Department and his prosecutorial chops, Mr. Giuliani adds some ballast to a legal team that is currently composed of lesser lights. Mr. Trump\u2019s other lawyers \u2014 at least, for the moment \u2014 include Jay Sekulow, who spent much of his career as a radio and TV host, and Jane Serene Raskin and Martin R. Raskin, who worked as federal prosecutors but are otherwise unknown.", "title": "In Defending Trump, Giuliani Will Lean on His Rolodex and Reputation", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-29 00:00:00", "text": "Free hay arrived last year in Kansas after the state\u2019s largest wildfire on record left thousands of cows dead and countless others with nothing to graze. It came by the truckload to eastern Montana last summer when flames destroyed huge swaths of grassland.\n\nPhoto\n\nWithout the bales now arriving in Oklahoma, many ranchers would likely have to sell their herds.\n\n\u201cWe may not be able to feed the cows enough to gain weight,\u201d said Michael Kelsey of the Oklahoma Cattlemen\u2019s Association, which has been taking donations to provide hay and other supplies. \u201cBut if we can feed the cows enough to maintain, we\u2019re in good shape. That\u2019s just the reality of the disaster.\u201d\n\nRhett Smith\u2019s ranch on a gravel road outside Taloga, Okla., was directly in the flames\u2019 path. Unlike some of his neighbors, Mr. Smith saved his house and his 100 cows. But his grass was gone.\n\nSo when two tractor-trailers carrying 64 bales of hay rolled down Mr. Smith\u2019s winding driveway, a sense of relief washed over him. The hay would be enough to feed his cattle and his neighbors\u2019 herds for at least a few weeks.\n\nThe trucks were driven by Levi Smith and his brother, Blake, who raise cattle about 100 miles from Vici, along the Kansas-Oklahoma border. The brothers had never met Rhett Smith before \u2014 and are no relation to him \u2014 but they said they empathized with all he was going through. Their family\u2019s land burned last year, the brothers said. And donated hay had gotten their cattle through it.\n\n\u201cThey think it can\u2019t get any worse,\u201d Levi Smith said, \u201cbut when these loads of hay come in, it gives you hope.\u201d\n\nIn the sparsely populated counties where cattle roam, people rely on neighbors and take pride in giving help without being asked.\n\nPhoto\n\nSigns around Vici (which is pronounced \u201cVy-Sigh\u201d) offer free meals, free clothes, free care for orphaned calves.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn nearby Lenora, hay bales are stacked along the side of a road for whoever might need them. As eager as people are to assist, they also seem reluctant to receive.\n\n\u201cNobody wants to take any help if they don\u2019t have to,\u201d said Nick Campbell, a town trustee in Vici. \u201cWe\u2019re trying to get them to understand that we\u2019re there for them, whatever they need.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe Oklahoma fires, which burned an area about the size of Chicago and New York City put together, made relatively few national headlines. But in agricultural circles \u2014 and especially in places that have seen their own fires \u2014 word of the destruction spread swiftly.\n\nPrairie fires are a fact of life on the Great Plains, but recent years have brought a series of unusually strong, multiday blazes that set records and spread out of control.\n\nWhen Travis Brown lost much of his pasture in Montana\u2019s fires last summer, other ranchers sent hay.\n\nPhoto\n\nSo when Mr. Brown heard about the new fires in Oklahoma, he and three other Montana ranchers paid about $940 each to send more than 100 hay bales to Oklahoma.\n\n\u201cI remember the feeling of just being overwhelmed after seeing so much of our livelihood burned,\u201d Mr. Brown said. \u201cThe smoke hadn\u2019t even cleared away yet, and people are saying, \u2018You\u2019re going to be O.K.\u2019\u201d\n\nAround Vici and Taloga, where drivers greet passing trucks with a wave and the skyline is dotted with wind turbines and oil pumpjacks, the flames have subsided. But the damage remains.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe fire\u2019s timing was especially cruel, coming in the midst of an extreme drought. Dead cows appear along roadsides, hooves pointed to the sky. Driveways lead to piles of rubble. When the wind blows, it smells a bit like a campfire.\n\n\u201cYou can see across the river and just see the black as far as you can see,\u201d said Lori White, a Putnam, Okla., rancher who lost a calf and about a third of her pasture in the fire, and who has been helping coordinate hay deliveries for ranchers who fared worse.\n\nLast weekend, as a much-needed rainstorm tamped down the last of the flames, Matt Schaller delivered hay to ranchers around Vici.\n\nMr. Schaller, who works on a grain farm, had driven more than 1,100 miles from Michigan with a load of donated bales, part of a nonprofit group he helped start last year after making deliveries during the Kansas fires.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s just what you do,\u201d Mr. Schaller said.", "title": "In Fire-Scorched Oklahoma, Help Comes One Bale at a Time", "authors": ["Mitch Smith"]} {"date": "2018-04-04 00:00:00", "text": "Gigantic dinosaurs frolicked and splashed some 170 million years ago in the lagoons of what is now Scotland. That\u2019s what a team of paleontologists has determined after discovering dozens of jumbo-sized footprints belonging to long-necked sauropods on the Isle of Skye. Mixed with the herbivores\u2019 tracks were a few clawed impressions left behind by two-legged meat-eaters known as theropods.\n\nThe footprints present a snapshot of life during an important period in dinosaur history that has yielded relatively few fossil remains. In the mid-Jurassic, sauropods necks grew longer and the first birds were figuring out flight.\n\nPhoto\n\nIdentifying two types of footprints in the same place also challenges the idea that long-necked dinosaurs waded into shallow, muddy waters to escape predators, said Stephen Brusatte, a paleontologist at the University of Edinburgh in Scotland and an author of the new study.\n\n\u201cWe\u2019re actually seeing these dinosaurs interacting with each other and interacting with their environment,\u201d he said. The team reported their findings Monday in the Scottish Journal of Geology.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nOne of Dr. Brusatte\u2019s graduate students, Davide Foffa, stumbled upon the first tracks in 2016 while the team explored the coasts for bones and teeth. Amid the tidal pools, he found a large impression that had been colored pinkish-purple by algae. Upon closer inspection, he discovered the outlines of toes and a fleshy heel pad \u2014 a sauropod footprint.\n\nMore Reporting on Paleontology\n\nThat print became known as \u201cthe money track.\u201d\n\n\u201cOnce I saw that track, it was like I put on a different kind of glasses or something,\u201d said Paige dePolo, who was then a master\u2019s student working under Dr. Brusatte and is lead author of the new paper. \u201cIt helped me to see these other less distinct tracks.\u201d", "title": "In Footprints on Scotland\u2019s Isle of Skye, Signs of a Dinosaur Playground", "authors": ["Nicholas St. Fleur"]} {"date": "2018-04-11 00:00:00", "text": "He came prepared with stock answers: \u201cSenator, that\u2019s a great question\u201d; \u201cI\u2019ll have my team get back to you.\u201d (That team is going to be busy.) He repeatedly alluded to having begun Facebook in his dorm room at Harvard, framing the company as a bootstrap success story rather than a global supra-state with a population larger than any country\u2019s.\n\nAnd he faced a panel of senators who did not always seem to understand the platform\u2019s functions \u2014 the distinction between selling data and using that data to sell targeted ads, for instance \u2014 or how to phrase questions to press their points.\n\nIt was a far cry from the film \u201cThe Social Network,\u201d written by Aaron Sorkin, in which an arrogant, fictionalized Mr. Zuckerberg (Jesse Eisenberg) had little patience for a lawyer deposing him: \u201cYou have part of my attention. You have the minimum amount.\u201d\n\nMr. Zuckerberg was all attentiveness. That\u2019s not the same as openness. He was slippery when it came to the tension between the company\u2019s business model \u2014 which depends on access to granular personal data \u2014 and privacy concerns.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nBut he answered with white-noise-machine calm, like a tech-support representative asking legislators if they\u2019d tried turning their democracy off and turning it back on again.\n\nAt least one audience was happy with the uneventful session. On some channels on Tuesday, Mr. Zuckerberg was split-screened with a graph of Facebook\u2019s stock price, which rose in inverse proportion to the hearing\u2019s newsworthiness.\n\nDenied any explosive Sorkinian moments or news-breaking exchanges, the networks peeled off one by one in mid-hearing: first the broadcast networks, then CNN and MSNBC. (Fox News stuck around longer.)\n\nThe second day of testimony, on Wednesday, before the House Commerce Committee, was much more aggressive and heated. From the left, Representative Bobby Rush, Democrat of Illinois, likened Facebook to J. Edgar Hoover\u2019s Cointelpro surveillance program; from the right, several Republicans criticized Facebook for deeming that videos from the Trump boosters \u201cDiamond and Silk\u201d were \u201cunsafe.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut there were a lot fewer eyes on it. None of the broadcast networks carried Mr. Zuckerberg\u2019s testimony. On cable, it was relegated to HLN and CNBC.\n\nMr. Zuckerberg had help from Wednesday\u2019s crowded news cycle. The House speaker, Paul D. Ryan, announced that he would not seek re-election, and President Trump tweeted that he planned to fire missiles at Syria, giving the embattled head of Facebook an indirect assist from his competitor Twitter.\n\nMr. Zuckerberg did not escape the two days unscathed. Senator Richard J. Durbin, Democrat of Illinois, created a shareable moment Tuesday by asking if Mr. Zuckerberg would mind revealing which hotel he\u2019d stayed at, eliciting a flustered \u201cNo\u201d from the executive, who said, in 2010, that privacy was no longer a \u201csocial norm.\u201d\n\nBut the networks cut away from their coverage anyway, which may have been just fine with Facebook. The hearings didn\u2019t do much to clear up how the mass of us, in the social-media era, can minimize unwanted attention. But they showed that Mr. Zuckerberg has a few hacks to do just that.", "title": "In Front of the Cameras, Mark Zuckerberg Avoids Going Viral", "authors": ["James Poniewozik"]} {"date": "2018-04-03 00:00:00", "text": "Rubble is about all that is left of St. Nick\u2019s Jazz Pub, the venerable Harlem hangout whose blood-red facade once beckoned jazz greats like Lena Horne and Miles Davis during the Harlem Renaissance.\n\nThe basement pub had been closed for seven years before a fire on March 22 engulfed the landmark townhouse on St. Nicholas Avenue at West 149th Street, killing a firefighter. Afterward, contractors chiseled away what remained.\n\nFire marshals continue to search for the cause of the fire in what\u2019s left of the building in Sugar Hill, a celebrated neighborhood where prominent African-Americans like W.E.B. Du Bois, the scholar and activist, and George Schuyler, a journalist, once lived. Neighbors, musicians and historians have begun asking what will rise in its place.", "title": "In Harlem, Mourning Another Historic and Cultural Marker", "authors": ["Ashley Southall"]} {"date": "2018-04-26 00:00:00", "text": "WADE IN THE WATER\n\nPoems\n\nBy Tracy K. Smith\n\n83 pp. Graywolf Press. $24.\n\nTracy K. Smith\u2019s previous collection of poems, \u201cLife on Mars,\u201d was awarded the Pulitzer Prize in 2012. With an ambition and range unequaled among her contemporaries, that book more than realized the promise of two earlier, somewhat more uneven volumes, \u201cThe Body\u2019s Question\u201d (2003) and \u201cDuende\u201d (2007), both of which also contained some stunningly beautiful poems. There has been quite a bit of good poetry written over the last 20 years in this country, and Smith \u2014 who since June 2017 has also served as the United States poet laureate \u2014 has produced among the most original of it.\n\nExpectations are high, in other words, for her new collection, \u201cWade in the Water.\u201d\n\nSmith was born in Falmouth, Mass., and grew up in Fairfield, Calif., a small city midway between San Francisco and Sacramento. She was the youngest of five children. Her father grew up in Alabama and escaped the segregated South by enlisting in the Air Force. Her mother was a seriously religious person who went to church regularly and read the Bible every day. After Smith\u2019s father retired from the military, he went to work as an optical engineer on the Hubble Space Telescope for NASA, which after its launch in 1990 helped scientists pin down the age of the universe and discover the so-called dark energy that counters gravity and keeps galaxies from colliding.\n\nImage\n\nReading the poems in \u201cLife on Mars\u201d \u2014 with titles like \u201cThe Universe Is a House Party,\u201d \u201cEverything That Ever Was,\u201d \u201cMy God, It\u2019s Full of Stars,\u201d \u201cThe Universe as Primal Scream\u201d and so on \u2014 one can\u2019t help being reminded of the father who spent years looking at the stars; in that light, his daughter\u2019s book is both an extended conversation with him and an elegy. \u201cAwe\u201d was Emily Dickinson\u2019s favorite word. She fretted about being a speck on a ball floating in darkness as much as the Smith of \u201cLife on Mars\u201d does. They both savor the thrill and terror of thinking about this mystery we are all in some way a part of, this mystery we call by different names without ever reducing the mystery, because it\u2019s bigger than language and has no need of our words. This is how Smith sees it, in a poem from \u201cLife on Mars\u201d called \u201cIt & Co.\u201d:\n\nWe are a part of It. Not guests.\n\nIs It us, or what contains us?\n\nHow can It be anything but an idea,\n\nSomething teetering on the spine\n\nOf the number i? It is elegant\n\nBut coy. It avoids the blunt ends\n\nOf our fingers as we point. We\n\nHave gone looking for It everywhere:\n\nIn Bibles and bandwidth, blooming\n\nLike a wound from the ocean floor.\n\nStill, It resists the matter of false vs. real.\n\nUnconvinced by our zeal, It is un-\n\nAppeasable. It is like some novels:\n\nVast and unreadable.\n\nIn her very good new book, Smith\u2019s concerns are more earthbound. Numerous poems in the collection are based on the letters and statements of African-Americans who served as soldiers in the Civil War and their wives, widows, parents and children, as well as correspondence between members of a white family regarding the sale of their various slaves. Smith shortens the letters, preserves the original spelling and punctuation, then titles and resets them so they look like poems. Here is one called \u201cI Will Tell You the Truth About This, I Will Tell You All About It\u201d:\n\nCarlisles, Pa. Nov 21 1864 Mr abarham lincon\n\nI wont to knw sir if you please\n\nwhether I can have my son relest\n\nfrom the arme he is all the subport\n\nI have now his father is Dead\n\nand his brother that wase all\n\nthe help I had he has bean wonded\n\ntwise he has not had nothing to send\n\nme yet\n\nnow I am old and my head is blossaming\n\nfor the grave and if you do I hope\n\nthe lord will bless you and me\n\ntha say that you will simpethise\n\nwithe the poor he be long to the\n\neight rigmat colard troops\n\nhe is a sarjent\n\nmart welcom is his name\n\nWhat I have always liked about Smith\u2019s poetry is her interest in other people\u2019s lives. The lone self has been the sacred cow of lyric poetry since the ancient Greeks, and there\u2019s no way to sever that link permanently, but a vacation now and then from self-absorption to look around and see what the rest of the human race has been up to can do wonders to one\u2019s poetry. Of course, mostly they\u2019ve been up to no good \u2014 \u201cThe worst in us having taken over / And broken the rest utterly down,\u201d as Smith says here in a poem called \u201cAn Old Story.\u201d\n\nSmith once told an interviewer that when she had finished writing her first book, she felt she had gotten off her chest all she had to say and was tired of herself. \u201cI\u2019m going to let go of the first person,\u201d she told herself. Of course, she didn\u2019t. She turned to photography for about a year during an extended writer\u2019s block, and when she did get back into writing, everything felt different. She realized that vivid imagery could go far toward condensing a poem\u2019s narrative and conveying feelings. In her last two books we see the results of that lesson. The poems in \u201cWade in the Water\u201d are full of memorable images nimbly put together by Smith\u2019s exquisite sense of timing and her feel for the kind of language appropriate to the poem.", "title": "In Her New Work, a Public Poet Balances the Personal and Political", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-07 00:00:00", "text": "The courts, for instance, found that the E.P.A. had ignored clear legal statutes when they ruled that Mr. Pruitt had illegally delayed a regulation curbing methane emissions from new oil and gas wells and that the agency had broken the law by missing a deadline last year to enact ozone restrictions.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Climate Fwd: Sign up for our newsletter to get our latest stories about climate change \u2014 along with answers to your questions and tips on how to help. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nIn other cases \u2014 including one in which a federal court ordered the E.P.A. to act on a Connecticut request to reduce pollution from a Pennsylvania power plant, and one where judges demanded quick action from the agency on new lead paint standards \u2014 the courts warned Mr. Pruitt that avoiding enacting regulations already on the books was an inappropriate effort to repeal a rule without justifying the action.\n\n\u201cThe E.P.A. has a clear duty to act,\u201d a panel of judges of the San Francisco-based Court of Appeals for the 9th Circuit wrote in a 2-1 decision finding that the agency must revise its lead paint standards in 90 days, as regulations required. The agency had tried to delay the revisions for six years.\n\nIn an interview on Friday, the White House spokeswoman, Sarah Huckabee Sanders, said that Mr. Trump felt that Mr. Pruitt had done a satisfactory job at the EPA. Her comments suggested that Mr. Pruitt\u2019s work checking off items on the president\u2019s agenda \u2014 including rolling back a large number of environmental protections \u2014 may weigh heavily as a counterbalance to the ethics questions related to his travel expenses, management practices and his rental of a living space from the wife of a prominent lobbyist.\n\nDescribing Mr. Trump\u2019s view of Mr. Pruitt, she said: \u201cHe likes the work product.\u201d\n\nLiz Bowman, an E.P.A. spokeswoman, disputed the criticisms of the agency\u2019s work. \u201cE.P.A. does its due diligence, consults with O.M.B. and other federal agencies to ensure that its work is legally defensible,\u201d she said in an email, referring to the Office of Management and Budget, the office that coordinates and evaluates policy across the executive branch.\n\nOne of the chief examples cited by Mr. Pruitt\u2019s critics came this week when the E.P.A. filed its legal justification for what is arguably the largest rollback of an environmental rule in the Trump administration: the proposed undoing of an Obama-era regulation aimed at cutting pollution of planet-warming greenhouse gases from vehicle tailpipes.\n\nMr. Pruitt made his case for the rollback in a 38-page document filed on Tuesday that, experts say, was devoid of the kind of supporting legal, scientific and technical data that courts have shown they expect to see when considering challenges to regulatory changes.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cThere\u2019s an incredible lack of numbers,\u201d said James McCargar, a former senior policy analyst at the E.P.A. who worked on vehicle emissions programs and remains in close touch with career staffers who work on those programs. \u201cIf this gets challenged in court, I just don\u2019t see how they provide anything that gives a technical justification to undo the rule.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nThe rules Mr. Pruitt is targeting would require automakers to nearly double the average fuel economy of passenger vehicles to 54.5 miles per gallon by 2025. Automakers have argued the rule is onerous, forcing them to invest heavily in building hybrid and electric vehicles.\n\nAs part of the process, Mr. Pruitt filed the 38-page document, which is meant to supply the government\u2019s legal justification for rolling back the rule. About half the document consists of quotations from automakers laying out their objections to the rule. By comparison, the Obama administration\u2019s 1,217-page document justifying its implementation of the regulation included technical, scientific and economic analyses justifying the rule.\n\nExperts in environmental policy said the lack of analytical arguments in this week\u2019s E.P.A. filing surprised them. \u201cThis document is unprecedented,\u201d said Mr. McCargar, the former E.P.A. senior policy analyst. \u201cThe E.P.A. has just never done anything like this.\u201d\n\nJohn M. DeCicco, a professor of engineering and public policy at the University of Michigan Energy Institute, said the filing was a departure from the practices of previous Republican and Democratic administrations.\n\n\u201cA president or an administrator or somebody can\u2019t just say, \u2018I\u2019m going to change the rule,\u2019 without justifying it very, very carefully,\u201d Mr. DeCicco said. \u201cAs a scientist who\u2019s worked on these issues, I\u2019m saying, where are the numbers? Where\u2019s the data?\u201d\n\nMost of the document consists of arguments quoting directly from public comments made by automaker lobbyists, the Alliance of Automobile Manufacturers and the Global Automakers, that the pollution rules will be unduly burdensome on the auto industry, as well as public comments from Toyota, Fiat Chrysler, Mercedes-Benz and Mitsubishi.\n\nWhile it does include arguments opposing the regulatory rollback from groups including the Union of Concerned Scientists and the state of California, it does not contain what environmental experts say is the critical element of a legally strong justification for changing an E.P.A. regulation: Technical analysis of both sides of the argument leading to a conclusion aimed at persuading a judge that the change is defensible.\n\nSeth Michaels, a spokesman for the Union of Concerned Scientists, suggested that, in its reuse of arguments by the automakers\u2019 lobby, the emissions-rollback document echoed Mr. Pruitt\u2019s modus operandi when he was the Oklahoma Attorney General.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s reminiscent of the 2011 letter Scott Pruitt sent as Oklahoma AG to the E.P.A., in which he took a letter drafted by lawyers for Devon Energy and stuck his name on it with minimal edits,\u201d Mr. Michaels said.\n\nA 2014 investigation by The Times found that lobbyists for Devon Energy, an Oklahoma oil and gas company, drafted letters for Mr. Pruitt to send to the E.P.A., the Interior Department, the Office of Management and Budget and President Obama, outlining the economic hardship of various environmental rules.\n\nBetween 2011 and 2017, Mr. Pruitt filed suit against the E.P.A. 14 times, and lost almost all of the cases.\n\nMost were filed in conjunction with the Republican attorneys general of a dozen or more other states, making it difficult to know precisely which legal arguments his office contributed, legal experts said. Mr. Pruitt frequently took a lead role in the cases.\n\nIn the end, \u201ca lot of those arguments were losers,\u201d said Richard L. Revesz, an expert in environmental law at New York University.\n\nIn particular, Mr. Revesz noted a case brought by the group against President Obama\u2019s signature climate change regulation, the Clean Power Plan, which Mr. Pruitt is now working to overturn from within the E.P.A. The lawsuit challenged a draft proposal of the regulation, which was an unprecedented move that a federal court quickly struck down, saying that they could not legally challenge a draft.\n\nPhoto\n\nWhile the attorneys general, including Mr. Pruitt, garnered media attention for the case, \u201cThe argument they had was ludicrous,\u201d Mr. Revesz said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe group did, however, score one major victory: After the Obama administration issued its final version of the Clean Power Plan, it successfully petitioned the Supreme Court to temporarily halt implementation of the rule.\n\nSince taking the helm of E.P.A., Mr. Pruitt has barnstormed the country, meeting with farmers, coal miners and local leaders and promising an end to his predecessor\u2019s regulatory approach. He also has favored closed-door policy speeches to conservative think tanks, like the Heritage Foundation, to roll out policy initiatives.\n\nThe Heritage Foundation was the venue Mr. Pruitt chose this year to say that he would make changes to how scientific studies are considered at the agency. Both critics and supporters of Mr. Pruitt said that, by making the proposal in a political fashion rather than changing the rules in a quieter but potentially more lasting way means that changes like these are more vulnerable to being undone by a future administration.\n\nEnvironmental groups have welcomed Mr. Pruitt\u2019s court losses. Joanne Spalding, chief climate counsel for the Sierra Club, said she was pleased by what she called \u201csloppy\u201d and \u201ccareless\u201d E.P.A. legal work. \u201cIt\u2019s fine with us,\u201d she said. \u201cDo a bad job repealing these things, because then we get to go to court and win.\u201d\n\nThomas J. Pyle, a supporter of Mr. Pruitt\u2019s and the president of the Institute for Energy Research, a think tank that promotes fossil fuels, described that as spin. \u201cThe environmental left portrays Scott Pruitt as a devil incarnate in their fund-raising solicitations, yet brag about how ineffective he is in dismantling Obama\u2019s climate rules,\u201d he said. \u201cWhich is it?\u201d\n\nStill, some conservatives said they were worried that Mr. Pruitt was more interested in media attention than policy and feared more legal losses. \u201cIf the goal is to generate temporary relief and to make a splash, then what they\u2019re doing is terrifically fine,\u201d said Jonathan H. Adler, director of the Center for Business Law & Regulation at Case Western Reserve University School of Law.\n\nBut if the Trump administration wants to permanently change the regulatory environment for business, he said, the E.P.A. cannot take such a \u201cquick and dirty approach\u201d to unraveling regulations. \u201cI\u2019m suspicious that two, three years down the road there\u2019s going to be much to show for all the fireworks we\u2019re getting now,\u201d Mr. Adler said.", "title": "In His Haste to Roll Back Rules, Scott Pruitt, E.P.A. Chief, Risks His Agenda", "authors": ["Coral Davenport", "Lisa Friedman"]} {"date": "2018-04-13 00:00:00", "text": "Yet that total number of foreign nationals makes up less than 2 percent of Japan\u2019s population of 127 million, a lower proportion than in South Korea, for example, where foreigners make up about 3.4 percent of the population. The share is much higher in the United States, at 14 percent, and it is close to 40 percent in Hong Kong, according to data from the United Nations Department of Economic and Social Affairs.\n\nObtaining Japanese citizenship is extremely difficult. Since 1952, just over 550,000 people have managed to naturalize as Japanese citizens, most of them ethnic Koreans whose families have lived in Japan for several generations since the colonial occupation of Korea.\n\nPhoto\n\nAnd despite recent efforts to allow highly skilled foreigners to obtain permanent residency more quickly, Prime Minister Shinzo Abe has declared that he will not relax immigration policy to address the country\u2019s falling population.\n\nDr. Sacko says he believes Japan needs to allow in more outsiders, simply as an act of self-preservation.\n\n\u201cJapanese people think they have to protect something,\u201d he said during an interview in English before a reception recently to celebrate his appointment. But, \u201csomeone who has a broad view from outside on your culture can maybe help you objectively improve your goals,\u201d he said, occasionally interrupting the interview to greet his guests, switching effortlessly between English, French and Japanese.\n\nDr. Sacko, the eldest son of a customs officer and homemaker, grew up in Bamako, the capital city of Mali. A strong student, he won a scholarship from the Malian government to attend college abroad.\n\nHe had never been anywhere other than the neighboring country of Senegal. With 13 other students from Mali, he was assigned to study in China and landed in Beijing in 1985 to study Mandarin before embarking on a degree in engineering and architecture at Southeast University in Nanjing.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nOn a vacation to Japan after obtaining his undergraduate degree in 1990, Dr. Sacko found himself enchanted by what he observed as strong community ties and the hospitality toward guests. Although he had begun graduate studies in China, he was frustrated that a government minder always shadowed him when he conducted field research in local villages.\n\nHe had also met and started to date a Japanese woman, Chikako Tanaka, whom he later married and with whom he has two sons.\n\nDr. Sacko moved to Osaka, Japan, for six months of language lessons before enrolling in a master\u2019s degree program at Kyoto University. In meetings with colleagues, he was often asked to take minutes, which helped him improve his listening comprehension and writing ability. At night, he watched Japanese television shows and socialized with Japanese classmates.\n\nPhoto\n\nHis dedication to becoming fluent distinguished him from other foreigners. \u201cThey said, \u2018If you speak Japanese, they will put you in meetings and on committees and that\u2019s not interesting,\u2019 \u201d he said. Many foreigners, he added, \u201cspend too much time among ourselves.\u201d\n\nDr. Sacko said he had hoped to return to Mali someday, but after a military coup in 1991, his employment options were limited. As he pursued a doctorate in Japan, he worked to understand a culture where people can say the exact opposite of what they mean. \u201cYou don\u2019t always catch things from the meanings of the words,\u201d he said. \u201cYou have to go deeper.\u201d\n\nAlong the way, there were some misunderstandings.\n\nAfter hosting a few parties at his apartment, his neighbors remarked that he and his friends always seemed happy and that they were envious. Dr. Sacko urged them to join his next party.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nInstead, they called the police.\n\n\u201cThe police said, \u2018You are too noisy,\u2019 \u201d Dr. Sacko recalled. \u201cAnd I said \u2018But my neighbors like that!\u2019 \u201d\n\nHe applied for a job at Kyoto Seika, which specializes in the arts, and started as a lecturer in 2001. Colleagues say that over the years he has worked very hard to adapt to Japanese social codes while also retaining his own sensibility.\n\n\u201cHe deeply understands Japanese culture and the way of thinking,\u201d said Emiko Yoshioka, a professor of art theory whom Dr. Sacko appointed as vice president at Kyoto Seika. \u201cBut he also is able to poke fun at the fact that he is a foreigner.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe faculty vote for president was extremely close, with Dr. Sacko winning by just one vote. At his inaugural reception, a group of musicians played Malian music on a patio, and Dr. Sacko stood quietly on a small stage during a parade of speeches from the mayor of Kyoto; the Malian ambassador to Japan; and various academic colleagues, including a professor from Kyoto University who repeatedly slipped up and called him \u201cProfessor Mali.\u201d\n\nRyo Ishida, chairman of Kyoto Seika\u2019s board, noted that the university had recently started a campaign to embrace diversity.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cBut I don\u2019t think his election was much to do with the university\u2019s promotion of diversity,\u201d Mr. Ishida said. \u201cHe was elected as the best leader of the university among his colleagues.\u201d\n\nIn a practical sense, Dr. Sacko\u2019s appointment could help Kyoto Seika appeal to more foreign students at a time when many universities across Japan are struggling to maintain enrollment.\n\nAlready, 20 percent of its student body comes from abroad, much higher than the 4 percent overall ratio of foreign students in Japanese higher education. Dr. Sacko said he hoped to raise Kyoto Seika\u2019s level to 40 percent within a decade.\n\n\u201cI think he will help shrink the distance between Japanese and foreigners,\u201d said Chihiro Morita, 18, an illustration major from Hyogo Prefecture.\n\nOther black residents of Japan said that Dr. Sacko could help improve race relations in a country where performers still appear on television in blackface.\n\n\u201cThe fact that he has been placed in such a prominent position will have a significant impact on how we\u2019re perceived,\u201d said Baye McNeil, a Brooklyn-born black columnist for the English-language Japan Times who has lived in Japan for 13 years.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nDr. Sacko said he had not experienced racism in Japan but said he was treated differently simply because he does not look Japanese. Despite his Japanese citizenship, for example, he says he is automatically routed to lines for foreigners at the airport when he returns from trips abroad. \u201cIt\u2019s not because you\u2019re black,\u201d he said. \u201cIt\u2019s because you\u2019re different.\u201d\n\nHe said he considered it his mission to foster differences beyond race. When recruiting Ms. Yoshioka as vice president, he told her he wanted her for the job because she was a woman and a single mother.\n\n\u201cIf we don\u2019t have a person like you in the top administration of the university, the board will just be filled with men,\u201d he told her when she first hesitated to take the job. \u201cAnd that doesn\u2019t fit my vision.\u201d", "title": "In Homogeneous Japan, an African-Born University President", "authors": ["Motoko Rich", "The Saturday Profile"]} {"date": "2018-04-13 00:00:00", "text": "A waiver of their bank debt was among the key demands of the marchers in Mumbai. It would cost the state $5.23 billion \u2014 about $758 each for 6.9 million farmers. Another key demand was from farmers from the indigenous tribal communities who have for generations cultivated forest lands that are not officially vested in their names. They seek the implementation of India\u2019s Forest Rights Act of 2006, which could confer them title deeds to those lands.\n\nAnd the marchers, like all farmers across India, demanded minimum support prices for their produce at levels that governments have long promised. Prices received by farmers have seen repeated collapses. Dependence on the monsoon has been joined by an even sharper vulnerability to a rigged market. A severe water crisis, often driven more by unequal access than by poor rainfall, has further damaged agriculture.\n\nThe census in 2011 showed that for the first time since Indian independence in 1947, urban India added more people to its population than rural India did. Millions have left their villages for other villages, small towns and cities in search of jobs that are not there. As many male farmers moved out of their villages, the burdens of female farmers rose in ways numbers cannot capture. Between 1995 and 2015, the National Crime Records Bureau logged over 300,000 farmer suicides.\n\nSuccessive governments have connived at and hastened the corporate hijacking of Indian agriculture, privileging the profits of a few over countless livelihoods. Millions of poor rural Indians whose transactions are almost entirely in cash were badly hurt after Prime Minister Narendra Modi in November 2016 banned two bills that account for a vast majority of all currency in circulation and decided to introduce new bills. The expansion of existing bans on cow slaughter wrecked the livelihoods of millions of farmers who bought and sold cattle.\n\nRural India\u2019s deepening distress unfolds against the canvas of policy-driven inequality over the past two decades. The roughly five-member Indian farm household, according to the National Sample Survey Organization, a federal data collection agency, had an average monthly income of $99 in 2013.\n\nThe number of Indian billionaires on the Forbes annual list rose from 55 in 2011 to 121 in 2018. The collective net worth of our 121 billionaires was estimated by the magazine to be $440.1 billion, equal to roughly 22 percent of India\u2019s gross domestic product. We now rank fourth in the world on the Forbes billionaires list and 131st on the United Nations Human Development Index.\n\nThe net worth of India\u2019s richest man, Mukesh Ambani, rose to $40.1 billion on the 2018 Forbes billionaires list from $23.2 billion in 2017. To cumulatively make the amount Mr. Ambani added to his income in a year, 18.7 million rural Indians working under the Mahatma Gandhi National Rural Employment Guarantee Scheme, the country\u2019s flagship employment program, would have to work for 12 months without a day off.\n\nIndian elites and rulers largely ignore rural distress except in election years and when it causes them embarrassment in the West, where they desperately seek acknowledgment and applause. But there are solutions they could turn to.", "title": "Opinion | In India, Farmers Face a Terrifying Crisis", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-02 00:00:00", "text": "Bombay Perfumery \u201ctook this very strong tradition of scents in India, and they packaged it in a European way,\u201d said Cecilia Morelli Parikh, one of the founders of Le Mill, a Mumbai fashion boutique that sells the label\u2019s eight fragrances alongside clothing by high-end foreign and Indian designers. \u201cBut it\u2019s not a European product; it\u2019s strongly both.\u201d\n\nMr. Gandhi\u2019s business is one of several independent perfume brands that have sprung up recently in India, a country with a strong domestic perfuming tradition but a luxury fragrance sector dominated almost exclusively by imports.\n\nBombay Perfumery\u2019s fragrances, which sell online for $80 to $90 for 100 milliliters, do not exclusively feature Indian ingredients. The fragrance Sulawesi is named for the Indonesian island where Mr. Gandhi buys patchouli, for example, while Moir\u00e9 highlights a synthetic ingredient engineered in a laboratory to resemble the smell of leather.\n\nPhoto\n\nYet the fragrance line is full of subtle allusions to Indian scents, places and history. Mr. Gandhi said the aim of his branding and marketing was to conjure nostalgia for bygone eras and local fragrance traditions. Calicut, for example, highlights black pepper and uses the former name of the southern Indian city of Kozhikode, while Madurai Talkies pays homage to jasmine from around the southern city of Madurai.\n\n(And \u201ctalkies\u201d was slang for \u201ctalking pictures,\u201d the term used in the 1920s for the first movies with sound. \u201cIt\u2019s a very romantic fragrance,\u201d Mr. Gandhi said, \u201cand Indian movies, at least in the past, were all about romance.\u201d)\n\nThe nostalgic theme is enhanced by the collages printed inside the perfume boxes, juxtaposing images of the ingredients with those of old Mumbai buildings. And the glass perfume bottles are made in the shape of a matka, a jug commonly used in Indian villages to store water.\n\nYet, Mr. Gandhi said, he tried to avoid the \u201ckitschy, traditional stereotype of what Western people have about India,\u201d in part by using a minimalist design on the outside of the boxes \u2014 a look that matches the aesthetic of his sleek office in central Mumbai.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHe also commissioned a modern twist on chai, a milky sweet tea ubiquitous in India. Mr. Gandhi said his Chai Musk fragrance includes two actual chai ingredients \u2014 ginger and lemongrass \u2014 along with sandalwood to suggest what he called a \u201cmilky note\u201d and osmanthus for a \u201cfruity pop.\u201d\n\nThe fragrance \u201creminds me of home a little bit, which I find quite nice,\u201d said Lekha Washington, an artist from southern India who lives in Mumbai and has collaborated with the brand.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nShe added that she appreciated how Bombay Perfumery played on a range of emotions beyond the one that perfume brands typically target: lust.\n\nMr. Gandhi said the eight fragrances were created, after much trial and error, by two French perfumers in Grasse and two in Paris. He gave them general guidance on which ingredients to highlight, he said, but more creative license than they normally receive from major perfume brands and fragrance houses.\n\nHe said the overall idea was to make the final creations \u201cpolarizing enough for people to remember,\u201d and that Chai Musk, what he called the line\u2019s most \u201cout there\u201d fragrance, was suggested by a Paris perfumer who had traveled widely in India and wanted to celebrate a citrusy chai she once tasted in Mumbai.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cMaybe a lot of brands would have been like, \u2018No, we don\u2019t want anything to do with that,\u2019\u201d Mr. Gandhi said over chai in his office. \u201cBut I was like, \u2018Yeah, let\u2019s go ahead \u2014 why don\u2019t we explore that direction?\u2019 So it was really fun for them because they had a chance to really go wild.\u201d\n\nMaurice Roucel, a master perfumer in France who has created fragrances for major luxury brands (but not Bombay Perfumery), said he was impressed by the quality of the label\u2019s fragrances and that they certainly could appeal to consumers in Europe, the United States and South America.\n\n\u201cPerhaps not France,\u201d he added, \u201cbecause in France we are very picky.\u201d\n\nAlthough Mr. Gandhi plans eventually to introduce his perfumes in Europe and the United States, for now his primary market is young, fashion-forward Indians who, he said, are embracing other homegrown independent labels in clothing, food, music and design.\n\n\u201cWhen we were younger there was this notion that all things luxury were better only if they were European, but now it\u2019s not the case,\u201d he said, referring to his own generation of Indian consumers. \u201cMost young people now give homegrown brands a chance \u2014 as long as they ensure the quality is there.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHowever, he added, he sees his competition as independent foreign perfume labels, not Indian ones. As for the most popular ones in India now, he listed Amouage, a fragrance company based in Oman; the Dutch brand Nasomatto; Tom Ford; and Jo Malone London as among the top choices.\n\nHe declined to provide sales figures, but said Bombay Perfumery was adding nearly one new boutique a month and making 40 percent of its sales online, mostly to clients in India.\n\nTo help grow a domestic fan base, the label holds occasional events at cafes, boutiques and art galleries in major Indian cities. Mr. Gandhi said the goal was to encourage leaders in various creative fields to use fragrance as a muse for artistic projects.\n\nMs. Washington, for example, created an experiential installation that featured a wall covered with drawings of windows. A collection of about 200 stamps, some of which were meant to represent Bombay Perfumery fragrances, sat on a nearby table, and visitors were encouraged to select stamps that reflected their impressions of Mumbai\u2019s \u201csmell and vibe\u201d and use them on the wall.\n\nAnother event was a storytelling workshop geared to olfactory memories. Mr. Gandhi said some participants came away saying that it helped them remember their childhoods \u2014 an aquatic scent, for example, triggered a distant memory of the Goa seaside.\n\nHe said the events were primarily brand-building exercises.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s not a hard sell,\u201d an audience member told him after the storytelling workshop. \u201cYou\u2019re not even trying to sell me perfume.\u201d", "title": "In India, Perfumes That Smell \u2018Like Home\u2019", "authors": ["Mike Ives"]} {"date": "2018-04-02 00:00:00", "text": "Winning in all three of these states has taken on added urgency after the unanticipated retirements of Republican senators in Tennessee, Arizona and Mississippi left open seats that could suddenly be competitive.\n\nIn Indiana, Representative Todd Rokita started airing a television ad this week that labeled one of his opponents, Representative Luke Messer, a \u201cNever Trump lobbyist\u201d and the other, Mike Braun, a business executive, as voting for either Hillary Clinton or Barack Obama. His slogan: \u201cDefeat the Elite.\u201d\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s a legitimate three-way race,\u201d said John Hammond, a lawyer and member of the Republican National Committee from Indiana, \u201cand everybody will probably go right up to the line with rhetoric and negative message. It\u2019s happening and it\u2019s intensifying.\u201d\n\nHe added, \u201cAll the opposition research will have been done for Joe Donnelly at that point.\u201d\n\nMr. Rokita said he had no concerns that the attacks would help the incumbent Democrat. \u201cI think this primary is very cleansing,\u201d he said. \u201cI want voters to know about these two guys. And I want them to know about me.\u201d\n\nReferring to two previous Republican presidential candidates, John R. Kasich and Mitt Romney, Mr. Rokita added: \u201cMesser at this point is like all losing candidates, like Kasich or Romney, \u2018if you beat up on me, we are all going to lose.\u2019 Absolutely wrong. I am not waiting for Joe Donnelly to stick a knife in Luke Messer or Mike Braun in November. I am getting it all out now. Because Donnelly will stick in a knife in them.\u201d\n\nThat kind of language has prompted concern among some of the state\u2019s most influential Republicans.\n\nMr. Grand, who supports Mr. Messer, was particularly critical of Mr. Rokita trying to claim a populist mantle by deriding so-called elites. Mr. Rokita\u2019s \u201celites\u201d are something else to Mr. Grand: \u201cPeople that know what\u2019s good for the Republican Party, yes, longstanding Republicans, yes. People who know how to elect Republican candidates.\u201d\n\n\u201cOr,\u201d he asked, does Mr. Rokita \u201cwant to go back to the group that gave us Mourdock?\u201d\n\nThat was a reference to Richard E. Mourdock, a candidate whose backing from Tea Party groups and national conservative organizations six years ago led to the defeat of a longtime incumbent Republican, Senator Richard G. Lugar, in the Indiana primary. Mr. Mourdock went on to lose to Mr. Donnelly.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Mourdock painted Mr. Lugar as out of touch with the state, and emphasized the fact that he lived in Virginia, a theme that Mr. Rokita has reprised against Mr. Messer. He has also made an issue of the fact that Mr. Messer\u2019s wife, a lawyer, is on the payroll of an Indianapolis suburb even though she, too, lives in Virginia.\n\nMr. Messer, the father of two teenage daughters, said he was raised by a single parent and felt it important to be closer to his children, and said voters would understand.\n\nA competitive primary or multicandidate field can sometimes actually reflect party strength and enthusiasm, but if the contest becomes too negative, the party can suffer.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cWhere there are particularly competitive or divisive primaries, it is bad for the parties when they go to the general,\u201d said Andrew B. Hall, a political scientist at Stanford University who has studied the subject. \u201cThings are getting put on record that make you look weak. You alienate some of your own base. You\u2019ve expended some of your resources.\u201d\n\nMr. Donnelly has no serious opposition for the Democratic nomination, though he is already under assault from Republican-aligned groups that are spending millions of dollars to defeat him.\n\nEach of the Republican candidates has tried to emphasize ties to Mr. Trump in a state the president won by 19 percentage points. Mr. Braun claims a Trump-like background, having built a logistics company in southern Indiana that now employs 850 people and gave him wealth that he can spend heavily on his own campaign.\n\nHe said Mr. Messer and Mr. Rokita were professional politicians, lawyers who \u201cnever practiced\u201d but always had their eyes on the next political rung. Mr. Braun served briefly in the State Legislature.\n\nIn a candidate debate, in which Mr. Braun wore jeans and a denim shirt, he made the case harshly. In a new ad, he uses humor, carrying cardboard cutouts of the two men \u2014 dressed identically in white shirt, red tie and dark suit \u2014 and asked voters if they could tell the difference between them.\n\n\u201cWhere is your real world experience?\u201d Mr. Braun said in an interview. \u201cThey don\u2019t have any.\u201d He added: \u201cThey are creating a large avenue up the middle between two career politicians. That was a gift that kept on giving.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Braun dismissed Mr. Rokita as a \u201csmash mouth.\u201d\n\n\u201cHe\u2019ll do and say things that might impress,\u201d he said. \u201cIf he\u2019s trying to act like Trump it\u2019s kind of a poor impression.\u201d\n\nHe also said there could be lingering damage: \u201cWhen you\u2019ve got sharp elbows, that creates a long memory for the people hit by those elbows.\u201d\n\nHe rejected Mr. Rokita\u2019s charge that he was a recent Republican convert, saying he had never voted for a Democrat for a federal office.\n\nMr. Messer, whose campaign so far has been the most measured of the three, accused Mr. Rokita of \u201ctrying to make things up.\u201d\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s crazy,\u201d Mr. Messer said. \u201cYou can\u2019t find one interview in the entire campaign where I didn\u2019t make the point that we need to elect President Trump. Do I agree with every single President Trump tweet? No. I\u2019ve expressed a few times my concerns about the president. But throughout, I have supported him and voted for the president in the primary.\u201d\n\nAll the candidates embrace some of the president\u2019s core positions, like the need for a wall along the Mexican border, and all pledge to be a solid voice for the president\u2019s agenda.\n\nMr. Rokita\u2019s opponents say his voting record suggests otherwise: Mr. Rokita voted against the budget deal that Mr. Trump signed this year\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHe said he did so because the bill contained too much federal spending. But, Mr. Rokita added, because he supported Mr. Trump before his rivals and has the endorsement of people who ran the Trump campaign in the state, he can disagree with the president, something he said Mr. Messer could not do.\n\n\u201cNow he has to do everything he can to pander to the president and Mike Pence,\u201d Mr. Rokita said. \u201cOh, the president wanted this terrible spending bill. Whereas I, in a very healthy way, can say no to things like the spending bill and still be on the side of the president.\u201d\n\nEven with all the friction in the primary so far, if there are safe places for the midterm elections to be a referendum on Mr. Trump, Indiana is surely among them. Republicans will pour extraordinary resources into the effort to oust Mr. Donnelly, and the president and Vice President Mike Pence, the former Indiana governor, will be able to give the senate nominee added firepower.\n\nThat gives Republicans comfort that they can endure a fractious primary. \u201cPeople are very energized,\u201d Mr. Grand said. \u201cThey are not playing into this thing that \u201918 is going to be a bad year.\u201d", "title": "In Indiana and Beyond, Bruising G.O.P. Primary Fights Worry Party Leaders", "authors": ["Michael Tackett"]} {"date": "2018-04-02 00:00:00", "text": "Few American reporters have spent more time reporting from Iraq in the last 15 years than Alissa J. Rubin, who served as both a correspondent and the Baghdad bureau chief for The New York Times at the height of the conflict. Rubin returned to Iraq in 2014 to cover the rise of the Islamic State and was severely injured in a helicopter crash on Mount Sinjar while reporting on targeted attacks against the Yazidi population. She once again returned to the region in January 2018 for a coming article in The Times Magazine. On a drive to the Iraq-Syria border during her last trip, Rubin found that competing military and militia groups had set up checkpoints everywhere, making travel increasingly difficult. The following is an account of the nine hours it took her and her companions to drive 130 miles through more than 26 checkpoints.\n\n[The Times is reintroducing At War, a forum for the firsthand experiences of global conflict.]\n\nWe were headed from Dohuk, a city in Iraqi Kurdistan, to Sinjar, near the Syrian border \u2014 a journey, at slightly more than 130 miles, that should be traversable in three hours. Before leaving, I asked around about the route. Answers were ominous. \u201cIt\u2019s impossible to get there,\u201d one person said. Another seconded that we\u2019d never get through. \u201cThere are 40 checkpoints,\u201d another man said.\n\nA professor described a circuitous route. \u201cI went around through Syria, but I don\u2019t think you can do that.\u201d", "title": "In Iraq, I Found Checkpoints as Endless as the Whims of Armed Men", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-05 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cReasoning that it could be helpful to have a prison guard indebted to him,\u201d the complaint said, Mr. Zarrab directed one of his Turkish lawyers to provide about $5,000 to Mr. Casado. Overseas associates of Mr. Zarrab wired the money to the lawyer, and it was eventually given to Mr. Casado, the complaint added.\n\nThe lawyer has not been identified, but when Mr. Zarrab testified in December as a government witness at the trial of a Turkish banker, Mehmet Hakan Atilla, who was also charged in the sanctions scheme, Mr. Zarrab briefly described using a female Turkish lawyer to pay the bribes.\n\nMr. Casado told Mr. Zarrab that if he \u201cneeded anything, to let Casado know,\u201d according to the complaint.\n\nOver the next few months, Mr. Zarrab made two or three additional payments to Mr. Casado, the complaint noted.\n\nThe Metropolitan Correctional Center has housed many prominent inmates, including some charged in terrorism and mob cases. The Mexican drug lord known as El Chapo is awaiting trial in the jail\u2019s most secure wing. A jail spokesman declined to comment, as did lawyers for Mr. Casado and Mr. Zarrab.\n\nIn return for the bribes, prosecutors said, Mr. Casado, on more than five occasions, smuggled alcohol into the jail for Mr. Zarrab in plastic water bottles.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box.
