Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe complaint said Mr. Casado also asked Mr. Zarrab for $25,000 to help one of his family members in the Dominican Republic, and that Mr. Zarrab, working through the lawyer, gave Mr. Casado $15,000 in cash.\n\nMr. Zarrab also regularly used Mr. Casado to smuggle a cellphone into the jail for his use, the authorities said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Zarrab\u2019s lawyer would provide the phone to Mr. Casado, who, at the beginning of his shift, would hand it to another inmate, who then passed it to Mr. Zarrab, according to the complaint.\n\nA third inmate often held the phone and charged it, the complaint said. Near the end of Mr. Casado\u2019s shift, Mr. Zarrab would pass the phone back to Mr. Casado through the second inmate.\n\nMr. Zarrab paid the second inmate $10,000, using the lawyer to send the money to the inmate\u2019s wife, the complaint noted.\n\nIn his trial testimony in December, Mr. Zarrab said he used the phone to call family members, including his wife and his young daughter.\n\nThe complaint said that the inmate who would charge Mr. Zarrab\u2019s phone also stood in line for him at a jail computer. Mr. Zarrab, in return, arranged to send money to that inmate\u2019s commissary account.\n\nMr. Casado also smuggled food, vitamin C, over-the-counter pain medication and DayQuil into the jail for Mr. Zarrab, the complaint said.\n\nMr. Zarrab\u2019s wealth was an issue throughout his case. After Mr. Zarrab\u2019s arrest, Judge Richard M. Berman of Federal District Court denied his request to be granted a $50 million bond and to live in a leased apartment under 24-hour armed guard and GPS monitoring, all at his own expense. Mr. Zarrab also retained more than a dozen lawyers to defend him, before he decided to plead guilty.", "title": "In Jail, a $45,000 Bribe Buys a Cellphone, Alcohol and Vitamin C, Prosecutors Say", "authors": ["Benjamin Weiser"]} {"date": "2018-04-09 00:00:00", "text": "Part of that responsibility has fallen upon advocacy groups like Safe Streets JC, which was started by Kara Hrabosky and Paul Bellan-Boyer in 2013, after a neighbor, Stephen A. Clifford, who was 24, was struck and killed on Kennedy Boulevard.\n\n\u201cWe went through the process to get speed bumps on our two blocks, but Kara and I started to notice that this is something people were really energized about, once they noticed it,\u201d Mr. Bellan-Boyer said. \u201cBecause traffic to a city dweller is like water to a fish \u2014 we\u2019re just in it all the time. So we\u2019re inclined to not notice it, unless something very dramatic happens.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMs. Hrabosky, who is a member of a Vision Zero task force formed by the city, said pleas from Ms. Gonzalez and other victims\u2019 family members have strengthened the push for improved street safety. The news from the city so far has been encouraging, she added, but she worries about the timeline. \u201cI don\u2019t want everything to be put on hold while we study this thing, and write a plan for a year,\u201d she said.\n\nPatrick Conlon, the president of a bicycling safety group, Bike JC, and a member of the Vision Zero task force, said the city needs to start work soon to prevent any more deaths. Although the first one is planned for the busy Grand Street corridor, there are still no protected bike lanes in Jersey City, he said. \u201cWe\u2019re seeing plenty of shovels to build new residential buildings all over,\u201d he said. \u201cBut we really need to see shovels in the road.\u201d\n\nIf it were up to Ms. Gonzalez, there would be better enforcement targeting dangerous drivers along Kennedy Boulevard. In the case of her son\u2019s death, the driver of the bus, Raul Delatorre-Galarza, who worked for a service called Pyramids Express, had a previous record of crashes. He was charged with causing a death while driving with a suspended license and his trial is scheduled to begin this month.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s not only up to the state and the city, but also, the people in society themselves. It\u2019s something that everyone should be involved in,\u201d she said. \u201cBecause it\u2019s not even just kids. A lot of people are losing their lives here.\u201d", "title": "In Jersey City, Working to Stem the Rise in Traffic Deaths", "authors": ["John Surico"]} {"date": "2018-04-08 00:00:00", "text": "When Mr. Bush was re-elected, Mr. Cheney pressed Ms. Rice, the incoming secretary, to give Mr. Bolton another senior job. She was wary, believing Mr. Bolton had been a \u201cconstant source of trouble for Colin,\u201d as she put it in her memoir, and \u201cI wasn\u2019t sure that I could fully trust John to follow my lead at State.\u201d Instead, she tapped him for the United Nations.\n\nThat provoked a revolt among former colleagues, who told the Senate that Mr. Bolton had been rough on subordinates and politicized intelligence, citing in particular a report on biological weapons in Cuba. Mr. Bolton flatly denied that, but Mr. Powell quietly told senators that he did not think Mr. Bolton was right for the job, and the Senate refused to confirm him.\n\nMr. Bush gave Mr. Bolton a recess appointment, sending him to the United Nations, where he jousted with diplomats and functionaries to overhaul the organization and block moves he thought undermined American sovereignty. Inside the administration, he resisted negotiations with North Korea, deeming it appeasement. When North Korea denounced him as \u201chuman scum\u201d or Venezuela called him \u201cthe most sinister figure in the U.N.,\u201d he took it as a badge of honor.\n\n\u201cHe was a practitioner, sometimes along with others, of sledgehammer diplomacy, a take-it-or-leave-it approach to diplomacy,\u201d said R. Nicholas Burns, who as under secretary sparred regularly with Mr. Bolton. Mr. Burns argued for compromise and patient work with allies. \u201cYou can\u2019t just default to leverage, pressure and force.\u201d\n\nWhen his recess appointment expired after 17 months, the Senate was still disinclined to confirm Mr. Bolton, who was privately upset that Mr. Bush did not push more. He left his post and became an outspoken critic of the president who appointed him, lamenting what he saw as the drift from Mr. Cheney\u2019s assertiveness to Ms. Rice\u2019s accommodation, especially on North Korea.\n\nNow the North Korea brief falls to him as his new boss prepares to meet with its leader, Kim Jong-un. In Fox appearances before his appointment, Mr. Bolton said the only topic of discussion should be the logistics for how North Korea would surrender its nuclear weapons program to the United States.\n\nThe meeting, he suggested, should be held in the same room in Geneva where Mr. Baker confronted Iraq\u2019s foreign minister shortly before the Gulf War of 1991. \u201cI think Kim Jong-un ought to sit in that room and look around,\u201d he said, \u201cand think about what happened when he stiffed a former U.S. president.\u201d", "title": "In John Bolton, Trump Finds a Fellow Political Blowtorch. Will Foreign Policy Burn?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-17 00:00:00", "text": "The search for her killers posed a test for Malta, its political parties and institutions, and for the European Union, of which the country is a member. It is a test the family claims the country is failing. Three men the police call career criminals were arrested in December and charged with planting and detonating the bomb. But questions about who was behind them and why they wanted Ms. Caruana Galizia dead remain unanswered.\n\n\u201cThe brutal assassination of Daphne Caruana Galizia was aimed at instilling fear in everyone,\u201d a European Parliament delegation to Malta said in a report released in January, \u201cespecially those involved in investigating and prosecuting cases of money laundering and corruption.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nAfter her death, 45 journalists from 18 news organizations agreed to work together to pursue leads from her work on corruption and international money-laundering networks, as well as look into the circumstances surrounding her death. Forbidden Stories, an investigative nonprofit in Paris devoted to completing the work of jailed and murdered journalists, coordinated the collaboration, in which The New York Times took part.\n\nToday, the once-barren field where the burning wreck of Ms. Caruana Galizia\u2019s car came to rest has sprouted green and lush, dotted with yellow and red spring wildflowers. The men charged with the killing \u2014 the brothers George and Alfred Degiorgio, and Vincent Muscat, no relation to the prime minister, who shares the surname \u2014 have pleaded not guilty but have otherwise refused to talk, and they remain in custody.\n\nBut the police say the three men were tipped off to their imminent arrest, according to evidence gathered in the investigation. Among the allegations the victim\u2019s family passed to investigators is that Mr. Cardona, the economy minister, and two of the suspects in the killing were regulars at the same out-of-the-way bar.\n\nIn a written response, Mr. Cardona said that the bar, Ferdinand\u2019s, \u201cwelcomes patrons from all walks of life, including other politicians.\u201d He added, \u201cI do not, however, recall having any discussions with any of these individuals, and have definitely never had any meetings with them.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nMr. Cardona said that he had not been interviewed in connection with the case. The police have chosen to work their way up from the evidence at the crime scene rather than look for motives in the journalist\u2019s reporting. A person with knowledge of the investigation who was not authorized to speak publicly on the matter confirmed that the police were not actively looking into whether the crime had been motivated by Ms. Caruana Galizia\u2019s reporting on politicians. They still have a dozen investigators working on the case \u2014 half of them full time \u2014 while other authorities are combing financial and communications records to try to find links to the killers.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMs. Caruana Galizia\u2019s family says that the police are content to let the three suspects in custody take the fall without investigating deeper and potentially uncovering wrongdoing by the governing party. They fear that with time, the urgency to uncover why she was killed, and who was behind the attack, has already begun to recede. Six months after her death, neither the bomb maker nor the person or people who wanted her dead have been found.\n\n\u201cThere is now a sense of impunity, a culture of impunity,\u201d said Simon Busuttil, the former leader of the opposition Nationalist Party. \u201cSo everyone thinks they can get away with murder,\u201d he added, \u201cperhaps even literally.\u201d\n\nUnderscoring the point, a Russian woman identified as one of Ms. Caruana Galizia\u2019s sources has applied for political asylum in Greece, where she fled in fear for her life after the assassination, and she is fighting extradition.\n\nPhoto\n\nIn her years as a muckraking journalist, Ms. Caruana Galizia angered countless people on this island, not to mention an Iranian-born banker, drug-trafficking syndicates and the president of Azerbaijan. Ms. Caruana Galizia was no stranger to threats. In 1995, someone slit her dog\u2019s throat and laid its body on her doorstep. In 2006, unidentified perpetrators stacked five large tires filled with bottles of gasoline against the back of her home and set them ablaze.\n\nIn an interview she gave to a researcher from the Council of Europe shortly before her death, Ms. Caruana Galizia, 53, described \u201ca climate of fear\u201d in Malta, a country where people were afraid of the consequences of speaking out.\n\n\u201cThere have been periods where literally I would feel like, \u2018Oh my God, I\u2019m going to get a stomach ulcer,\u2019\u201d she said. \u201cThat churning, churning nerves all the time. Because you\u2019re living under it constantly, you know?\u201d\n\nMs. Caruana Galizia dedicated herself to uncovering what she saw as a web of corruption in the country, on her blog, Running Commentary, where her reporting veered from tabloid to investigative to partisan and back again \u2014 sometimes in a single article. Hated by many but read by all, her post about Mr. Cardona had 547,146 page views; Malta has 460,000 people.\n\nPhoto\n\nBut she also reported on how Prime Minister Joseph Muscat\u2019s chief of staff and energy minister had used the Panama-based law firm Mossack Fonseca to set up shell companies there shortly after the Labor Party came to power in 2013, which they have acknowledged was true. She said that a third company that had been set up belonged to Mr. Muscat\u2019s wife, Michelle, which the couple vehemently denied. The Muscats demanded a formal inquiry to clear their name, and it is still underway.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nJeffrey Pullicino Orlando, a former lawmaker who switched from the Nationalist Party to the Labor Party and who was a regular subject of Ms. Caruana Galizia\u2019s blog, shared a view expressed by many here: that Ms. Caruana Galizia engaged in loosely sourced personal attacks rather than in sober, careful journalism.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s not exactly what\u2019s called a journalistic gem,\u201d he said. \u201cMost of it is mainly insults and denigrating any opponent to her clique.\u201d\n\nMr. Orlando also pointed out that Labor, which won elections called after her disclosures about the offshore accounts, had nothing to gain from her death, as it would bring only renewed criticism and attention. \u201cNo one in the political sector of Malta had any interest in her death,\u201d he said.\n\nPhoto\n\nAfter the murder, foreign law-enforcement experts arrived to help with the investigation. A team from the Netherlands assisted with forensics at the crime scene. The F.B.I. sent a team to analyze cellphone data. Europol, the European Union law-enforcement agency, had people on the ground working with its Maltese counterparts out of a command center set up at Police Headquarters.\n\nSignificant evidence was gathered from cellphones used to coordinate the bombing, and from surveillance videos linking the three suspects to the killing. But little progress has been made in discovering who was behind them.\n\nThe inquiry has been hampered by the family\u2019s distrust of the police, which means that investigators have not had the chance to examine her laptop, which might contain clues to who might have betrayed her, or had an interest in silencing her.\n\n\u201cDaphne would never have handed over her laptop,\u201d Corinne Vella, Ms. Caruana Galizia\u2019s sister, said in a statement on Monday. \u201cShe always said, \u2018If anything happens, if the police ever come to the house, I will throw my laptop into a well,\u2019 and she meant it.\u201d\n\nShe added: \u201cIt was about protecting her sources. She knew that whatever information the police got hold of would go straight to the same people in government she was investigating.\u201d", "title": "In Journalist\u2019s Murder, a Test for Malta, and the European Union", "authors": ["Nicholas Kulish"]} {"date": "2018-04-26 00:00:00", "text": "MASAYA, Nicaragua \u2014 The revolutionary, many Nicaraguans say, is suddenly facing a revolution of his own.\n\nThe insurrection that led to the rise of President Daniel Ortega and his Cold War struggles with the United States began here in Masaya 40 years ago. Mr. Ortega\u2019s brother died fighting in this town, and an old national guard post still stands as a landmark to the uprising that brought their leftist guerrilla movement to power.\n\nBut in recent days, the guard post has been turned into a charred, vandalized mess. Protesters have even taken a famous war slogan and spray-painted it on the walls in a mocking warning to Mr. Ortega.\n\n\u201cLet your momma surrender,\u201d it says.\n\nNicaragua is undergoing its biggest uprising since the civil war ended in 1990.", "title": "In Just a Week, \u2018Nicaragua Changed\u2019 as Protesters Cracked a Leader\u2019s Grip", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-27 00:00:00", "text": "Referring to the lack of meaningful celebrity endorsements for the right before Ms. Barr and Mr. West, Mr. Shapiro added: \u201cIf you haven\u2019t had a drink of water for a really, really long time, when you first drink water again it tastes really sweet \u2014 even though it\u2019s just water. I think there\u2019s some of that going on right now.\u201d\n\nStill, he said, it was \u201crefreshing\u201d to see Mr. West stand up against what Mr. Shapiro called \u201cenforced conformity\u201d on the left. \u201cAnybody who fights back against that is being treated as a fellow traveler,\u201d he added.\n\nHowever, risk in aligning with Mr. West, the son of a Black Panther father and a mother who taught at a historically black university, is that his ideological allegiances have typically been mercurial, and even apolitical. When he first declared his interest in Mr. Trump, during concerts right after the 2016 election, he praised the president-elect\u2019s communication style and disdain for the mainstream media, but noted that he had not voted.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Louder Newsletter Every week, stay on top of the latest in pop and jazz with reviews, interviews, podcasts and more from The New York Times music critics. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nHis most potent political statement before this week, when he unleashed a torrent of posts on Twitter each day and also announced two new albums, was declaring \u201cGeorge Bush doesn\u2019t care about black people\u201d during a telethon for victims of Hurricane Katrina. And even amid praising Mr. Trump on Wednesday, he added, \u201cI love Hillary too.\u201d\n\nThe journalist Alex Wagner, a host of the Showtime series \u201cThe Circus\u201d and a former editor in chief of the culture magazine The Fader, said that the right latching on to Mr. West\u2019s statements was no surprise given the dearth of options.\n\n\u201cDo you remember how hard a time Donald Trump had getting celebrities for his inauguration?\u201d she said. \u201cSo to have an incredibly powerful and influential musician \u2014 and a black musician at that \u2014 come out and don a Make America Great Again cap, it\u2019s a gift to Trump.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cAs far as whether it\u2019s grounded in any particular political ideology, I don\u2019t think it is,\u201d she added. \u201cIf there\u2019s one thing Kanye West and Donald Trump have in common, it\u2019s unpredictability and a love of the spotlight.\u201d\n\nMr. West, whose representatives declined to comment, began his latest foray into politics last weekend. He praised the thinking of the black conservative commentator Candace Owens, who has spoken out against the Black Lives Matter movement. He went on to compliment Peter Thiel, the Silicon Valley billionaire and Trump supporter, as well as the \u201cDilbert\u201d cartoonist Scott Adams, who has rebranded himself as a conservative thinker.\n\nAbout the president, he wrote admiringly that they both shared \u201cdragon energy\u201d and that \u201che is my brother.\u201d He also posted a photo of his Trump-autographed \u201cMake America Great Again\u201d cap.\n\nThe backlash came quickly as fans on social media and the culture publications that follow Mr. West closely made their dismay clear: \u201cKanye West Doesn\u2019t Care About Black People,\u201d read a headline on The Root, while The Ringer explored \u201cThe Kanye West Delusion.\u201d\n\nThe singer Janelle Mon\u00e1e criticized Mr. West\u2019s comments in a radio interview on Wednesday. \u201cI believe in freethinking,\u201d she said. \u201cBut I don\u2019t believe in freethinking if it\u2019s rooted in, or at the expense of the oppressed.\u201d And in text messages posted on Twitter by Mr. West, John Legend told the rapper, \u201cSo many people who love you feel so betrayed right now because they know the harm that Trump\u2019s policies cause, especially to people of color.\u201d\n\nCharlie Kirk, the founder of Turning Point USA, a conservative student movement that has worked with Ms. Owens, was unreserved in calling Mr. West\u2019s support \u201ca pretty extraordinary moment.\u201d\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s important to recognize that black Americans, and in particular black celebrities, should be allowed to have different opinions without being called mentally unhealthy or crazy,\u201d Mr. Kirk said, referring to reports that some in Mr. West\u2019s circle were again worried about his mental health following his late 2016 hospitalization, which also coincided with expressing his support for Mr. Trump. \u201cI think we should embrace celebrities that challenge groupthink and monolithic perspectives on political issues.\u201d\n\nMr. West\u2019s refusal to back down in the face of criticism was markedly different than the reaction of the Canadian country singer Shania Twain, who apologized on Sunday after she was quoted in an interview saying that she would have voted for Mr. Trump if she could. Following a fan backlash online, Ms. Twain issued a statement: \u201cAs a Canadian, I regret answering this unexpected question without giving my response more context,\u201d she said. \u201cI do not hold any common moral beliefs with the current president.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. West, on the other hand, was defiant. \u201cYou don\u2019t have to agree with trump but the mob can\u2019t make me not love him,\u201d he wrote on Twitter.\n\nChance the Rapper, a frequent collaborator, backed him up: \u201cBlack people don\u2019t have to be democrats,\u201d he wrote, though he backtracked on Friday, after Mr. Trump thanked him by name, writing that his initial tweet \u201cwas a deflection from the real conversation.\u201d Though Chance said he had hoped to stand by his mentor Mr. West, \u201cit\u2019s not my job to defend or protect him,\u201d he wrote, but rather to \u201cpick up the phone and talk to him about it.\u201d\n\nMr. Shapiro warned that this moment could be fleeting. \u201cIs this going to be a serious movement? I highly doubt it,\u201d he said.\n\n\n\nSome conservative groups sought to take advantage right away. On Thursday, a text advertisement for one of the president\u2019s campaign fund-raising organizations included the message \u201cDON\u2019T BE SILENCED,\u201d adding, \u201cWe support Kanye speaking his mind, even if sometimes we do not agree on the issues.\u201d Alex Jones, the right-wing conspiracy theorist behind Info Wars, has invited the rapper on his broadcast while posting positive messages about him on Twitter more than 30 times since Sunday. (Mr. West has not publicly responded to the invitation.)\n\nEbro Darden, a popular radio personality from the New York rap station Hot 97, said, \u201cThey are exploiting Kanye West, and yes, Kanye West is O.K. with being exploited.\u201d\n\n\u201cHe\u2019s down for the shenanigans,\u201d Mr. Darden said of the rapper, with whom he spoke by phone about politics multiple times this week. \u201cHe\u2019s an opportunist, a provocateur, a troll, a challenger of conventional thought and somebody who wants to be seen at all times, when he\u2019s ready to be seen.\u201d\n\nBut Mr. Darden cautioned that Mr. West\u2019s endgame was likely not Republican politics. \u201cI think he\u2019s trying to take people on a journey,\u201d he said. \u201cWhat I\u2019ve expressed to him is that he better hurry up and get to his destination.\u201d", "title": "In Kanye West, the Right Sees Truth-Telling and a Rare A-List Ally", "authors": ["Joe Coscarelli"]} {"date": "2018-04-02 00:00:00", "text": "The law at issue gives California the right of first refusal in any sale of public lands, an effort to prevent resource exploitation or development that would hurt the state\u2019s interests. The state would have to raise the money to buy the property at market value, or find a buyer.\n\nJustice Department officials said they were prompted to sue after seeing notes that the state put out to federal agencies. The department said in its lawsuit that Congress had given federal agencies the power to control the purchase and sale of federal land, including the parties involved in the deals, the use of the land and when the sales occurs.\n\nAccording to the lawsuit, the California law has interfered with federal land sales at least four times since it was enacted. In Alameda County, the Army had planned to convey 78 acres of land to a developer who will construct facilities, and the Navy is trying to sell property to a land developer. The Veterans Affairs Department is hoping to lease part of its land in Los Angeles to provide housing for veterans. And the Post Office\u2019s plan to auction off a 1.7-acre parcel in Sacramento is at a standstill.\n\nMr. Sessions assailed California\u2019s political leaders in an unusually fiery statement, saying that the fight is distracting Justice Department officials from their work combating illegal gun sales, drug abuse and national security threats. The flurry of legal briefs being filed between the two sides is a waste of taxpayer dollars, he said.\n\n\u201cI regret the need to file yet another lawsuit against the State of California today,\u201d Mr. Sessions said, adding, \u201cWe are forced to spend our resources to bring these lawsuits against states like California that believe they are above the law.\u201d", "title": "In Latest Clash With California, Justice Dept. Apol, acting director of the Office of Government Ethics, in the letter sent Monday morning to the E.P.A. \u201cThe American public needs to have confidence that ethics violations, as well as the appearance of ethics violations, are investigated and appropriately addressed.\u201d\n\nThe letter walks through the three areas of concern. Simon Critchley writes that \u201cthe curious thing about money is how something so real can at the same time be so illusory.\u201d\n\nImage Credit Wenjia Tang\n\n\u201cIf you stop thinking about what you might want, it\u2019s a whole lot easier to see what other people don\u2019t have.\u201d Ann Patchett on what it was like to take some time off from consumerism.\n\nImage Credit Matt Chase\n\nA sociologist researched the habits of the affluent. They presented the state with a challenge, wanting their dead to be remembered individually, on the day they had fallen.\n\nSo each inscribed brick has a light beside it, which is illuminated on the personal anniversary. At 11 a.m. every day, a brief remembrance ceremony is held for those killed on that date, as their names and images appear on digital screens mounted on 12 pillars. The screens, and a smartphone app, provide more information about the dead.\n\nThe wall begins with rows upon rows of blank white bricks, waiting ominously for more names; the design imposes no limit. The first names a visitor sees are the most recent fatalities, and then the wall spirals back to the 1870s, commemorating the earliest casualties of the Zionist struggle and the soldiers of Zionist militias who fought and died before independence.\n\n\u201cWe decided to begin from the end, with what most speaks to us today,\u201d said Michal Kimmel-Eshkolot of Kimmel Eshkolot Architects, which designed the monument. The inscribed bricks are no higher than about six feet from the floor, she said during a recent tour of the site, \u201cso a mother can reach up and touch the name.\u201d\n\nEtan Kimmel, the chief architect of the project, wrote in the brochure that the challenge had been to create a space \u201cin a way that touches everyone, but without imposing a uniform interpretation.\u201d", "title": "In Memorial to War Dead, Israel Avoids Addressing Its Conflicts", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-21 00:00:00", "text": "The European Union and Mexico said they had reached an agreement in principle on the most important elements of the agreement, with some technical details yet to be resolved. They are aiming to finalize it by year\u2019s end, after which it must be ratified by the European Parliament and the Mexican Senate.\n\nThe original trade pact, signed in 1997, was relatively narrow, mainly eliminating tariffs on cars and machinery. The deal came into force in 2000 and was the first free trade pact between Europe and a Latin American country.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Get the Morning Briefing by Email What you need to know to start your day, delivered to your inbox Monday through Friday. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nSince then, the European Union has added 13 members, and the internet has dramatically changed global business. In May 2016, the countries started negotiations to update the pact. The revised deal adds in a variety of new rules governing agricultural goods, telecommunications, digital trade, intellectual property, climate change, anti-corruption measures, finance and energy.\n\nThe deal is particularly notable for giving Mexico access to another wealthy market similar to the United States. The European Union is Mexico\u2019s second-biggest export market after the United States. Yet it is a distant second to the United States, where roughly 80 percent of Mexican exports go.\n\nMr. Trump has called those close economic ties into question by starting an ambitious renegotiation of the North American Free Trade Agreement. Nafta negotiators say they may be close to finalizing a deal in the coming weeks. But much uncertainty remains, as the United States, Mexico and Canada continue to advocate for vastly different measures.\n\nFredrik Erixon, director of the European Centre for International Political Economy, a Brussels-based research organization, said that Mr. Trump\u2019s aggressive posture on trade had pushed Mexico toward negotiations with Europe.\n\n\u201cThe E.U. has for at least 10 years been knocking on the door of Mexico to upgrade the trade agreement, and it is only very recently that they have come along,\u201d he said. \u201cIt\u2019s perfectly obvious that what has prompted them to change their minds is Donald Trump.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBoth Europe and Mexico have actively been pushing forward with new trade deals amid a global resurgence of skepticism about the benefits of free trade.\n\nMexico remains part of the Trans-Pacific Partnership, a multicountry trade deal that President Trump criticized and withdrew from on his fourth day in office. The remaining members, including Canada, Japan, Australia and Chile, signed a deal without the United States in March. Mexico is also negotiating with Argentina and Brazil, and has sought out potential alternatives to purchases of American grain and meat if Nafta were to fall apart.\n\nThe European Union now has close ties with both of America\u2019s Nafta partners, after a new pact with Canada went into force in September.", "title": "In Message to Trump, Europe and Mexico Announce Trade Pact", "authors": ["Ana Swanson", "Milan Schreuer"]} {"date": "2018-04-14 00:00:00", "text": "MOSCOW \u2014 Moscow met the limited American-led airstrikes against Syria before dawn on Saturday with plenty of bluster and heated rhetoric, starting with an uncharacteristically quick response from President Vladimir V. Putin condemning the attack and accusing the United States of aggravating the humanitarian situation.\n\nBut there was also a palpable sense of relief.\n\nThe sun was barely up before the Defense Ministry, not famous for speedy reactions, pumped out a statement underscoring that none of the thousands of Russian troops garrisoned in Syria had been threatened by the American, British and French attack and that none of its air defense systems had been mobilized.\n\n\u201cIt looks like both sides were playing according to their prescribed roles and managed to limit the harm from this kind of confrontation,\u201d said Aleksandr M. Golts, an independent Russian military analyst and deputy editor of Yezhednevny Zhurnal, an online current affairs magazine. \u201cSyria will not be the starting point for some kind of global confrontation.\u201d\n\nThe American ambassador to Russia, Jon M. Huntsman Jr., released a statement on Facebook on Saturday confirming that the two sides had taken steps before the assault to made sure they stayed out of each other\u2019s way. \u201cBefore we took action,\u201d he said, \u201cthe U.S. communicated with the R.F. to reduce the danger of any Russian or civilian casualties.\u201d", "title": "In Moscow, a Sense of Relief After a Limited Syria Attack", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-16 00:00:00", "text": "In her summation, Ms. Ortega\u2019s lawyer, Valerie Van Leer-Greenberg, argued Ms. Ortega had been experiencing paranoid delusions and hallucinations, as well as bouts of severe depression, going back to 1978. She had never been treated, however, and hid her symptoms from her employers and all but her closest family members.\n\nIn the weeks before the murder, Ms. Ortega had been hearing voices, including one she thought was Satan\u2019s, commanding her to kill the children, Ms. Van Leer-Greenberg said. Several family members and friends testified that Ms. Ortega\u2019s behavior became more and more bizarre during that period: She complained of shadows following her, cried frequently and spoke cryptically of a \u201cblack man\u201d who was trying to split up her family.\n\n\u201cShe was coming apart at the seams,\u201d Ms. Van Leer-Greenberg said. \u201cIt was getting more chaotic in her head. The voices were overtaking her. Then on Oct. 25, 2012, she capitulated.\u201d\n\nTwo psychiatrists for the defense testified that Ms. Ortega was psychotic at the time of the murders and had a break with reality, entering what they called \u201ca dissociative state.\u201d\n\n\u201cHer mind and her body separated metaphysically,\u201d Ms. Van Leer-Greenberg said. \u201cThat is what the evidence has shown.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nBut Mr. Silberg pointed out that when Ms. Ortega woke in the hospital days later, after being treated for a self-inflicted neck wound, she had a litany of petty complaints about her working conditions, but never asked about the children. \u201cShe didn\u2019t have to ask,\u201d he said. \u201cShe knew what had happened to them.\u201d\n\nMs. Ortega, 55, never disputed that she had killed Leo Krim, 2, and his sister, Lucia, 6, using two kitchen knives. Their mother, Marina Krim, arrived home at about 5:30 p.m., with her third child in tow, after Ms. Ortega had failed to show up with Lucia at a ballet class. Ms. Krim opened the bathroom door to find her other two children lying bloodied and lifeless in the tub. Ms. Ortega was standing nearby and jammed a knife into her own throat.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cShe put the children in the tub knowing Marina was going to open that door and see them,\u201d Mr. Silberg told the jury. \u201cIt was about hurting Marina in the worst possible way you can hurt Marina, or any mother.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nTo be found not responsible by reason of mental disease of defect, Ms. Ortega must prove she had a mental illness that prevented her from grasping the nature and consequences of her actions or from knowing they were wrong.\n\nThe defense\u2019s case during the six-week trial centered on expert testimony from two psychiatrists, Karen Rosenbaum and Phillip J. Resnick, who determined Ms. Ortega suffered from an undiagnosed psychosis for decades.\n\nMs. Ortega\u2019s lawyer also called as witnesses eight of the defendant\u2019s family members and friends, who described Ms. Ortega\u2019s past mental breakdowns in 1978 and 2008, when she became a paranoid shut-in after people close to her died. Her family members also described her crying fits, nervousness and paranoia about \u201cshadows\u201d following her in the days before the killings.\n\nMs. Van Leer-Greenberg pointed out that four psychiatrists at NewYork-Presbyterian/Weill Cornell Medical Center, where Ms. Ortega was treated for her neck wound, came to the conclusion she had symptoms of psychosis, a diagnosis later confirmed by doctors at Elmhurst Hospital Center.\n\nYet Mr. Silberg argued that Ms. Ortega\u2019s sisters, Delci Ortega and Miladys Garcia, came forward with information about Ms. Ortega\u2019s past symptoms of mental illness only after speaking with her defense lawyers months after the killings. \u201cAll the stories that were told to you by Delci Ortega and Miladys were made up,\u201d he told the jury. \u201cThose are the witnesses the defense wants you to believe.\u201d\n\nMs. Van Leer-Greenberg argued that the idea all of Ms. Ortega\u2019s friends and family members \u2014 some of whom were subpoenaed to testify \u2014 were lying about her symptoms seemed far-fetched. \u201cYou have to believe these eight separate lay witnesses that have no background in psychiatry made up symptoms that were consistent with paranoid delusions, audio hallucinations, visual hallucinations, tactile hallucinations, major depressive disorder and dissociation,\u201d she said.\n\nShe suggested insanity was the only explanation for the crime, since Ms. Ortega had repeatedly told her sisters and other relatives she loved the Krim children. \u201cThe lack of a motive is the hallmark of her mental illness,\u201d she said.\n\nMr. Silberg reminded jurors that Kevin and Marina Krim had testified they saw no sign Ms. Ortega was losing her mind. He also noted Ms. Ortega appeared to be managing her life without trouble, enrolling her son in a private high school, moving houses twice that year and handling her own finances.\n\nMr. Silberg suggested Ms. Ortega was simply furious with Marina Krim over her schedule and workload and planned to kill the children and herself to get back at her. \u201cIf she loved them, she wouldn\u2019t have killed them,\u201d he said. \u201cThe defendant\u2019s rage and resentment reached a boiling point.\u201d", "title": "In Nanny Murder Trial, Jury Hears Closing Arguments", "authors": ["James C. It also reported that Mr. Arnault had leaked information about the winner of the prize seven times since 1996.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe Swedish police are looking into the abuse allegations; Mr. Arnault has denied any wrongdoing. His wife agreed on Thursday to withdraw from the academy\u2019s activities.\n\nIn the wake of the allegations, Ms. Danius, 56, cut the academy\u2019s ties with Mr. Arnault, and hired a law firm to conduct an investigation into its ties with the private club. The law firm found what it called financial irregularities in that relationship, and recommended that the academy file a police report, but the academy did not take such action.\n\nThe divisions within the august body, which is usually known more for literary prestige than for scandal-driven acrimony, erupted into the open last week when three members quit in protest, including Peter Englund, Ms. Danius\u2019s predecessor as permanent secretary.\n\nOn the other side are two former permanent secretaries, Sture Allen and Horace Engdahl, who have made lacerating statements in recent days, calling the reaction to the allegations overblown and denouncing Ms. Danius as a weak leader.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nAsked how the members would restore the academy\u2019s reputation, one member, the writer Anders Olsson, said: \u201cWe don\u2019t know. But we have to talk to one another much more.\u201d\n\nComplicating matters, there is no provision for the 18 members of the academy to officially resign. Members are elected to life terms, and if they choose to stop participating in the activities of the academy, their seat is left vacant until death.\n\nEven before the scandal, two seats were occupied by inactive members. With the five recent departures, including that of Ms. Danius, the academy will be down to 11 active members \u2014 one short of the 12-member quorum needed to elect new members in the event of a vacancy. King Carl XVI Gustaf signaled this week that he would resolve the problem by using his authority to amend the academy\u2019s rules to allow members to resign and be replaced.\n\nIn an interview, Bjorn Wiman, culture editor at Dagens Nyheter, said of the scandal: \u201cThis is a complete and utter tragedy for cultural life in Sweden.\u201d He added, \u201cThe public\u2019s trust for the academy is perhaps below rock bottom.\u201d\n\n\u201cThere has always been the consensus that this has been a competent group and that they have judgment, and that the literary judgment is solid,\u201d Mr. Wiman added. \u201cWith this scandal you cannot possibly say that this group of people has any kind of solid judgment.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nEbba Witt-Brattstrom, a professor of Nordic literature at the University of Helsinki, said in an interview that the ouster of Ms. Danius represented a backlash by men.\n\n\u201cWhat they did was orchestrate a palace revolution, a coup to get rid of her, because she\u2019s too headstrong,\u201d she said. \u201cA headstrong woman is not what they are used to in the Swedish Academy.\u201d\n\nShe cited, as an example, the novelist Kerstin Ekman, who stopped taking part in the academy\u2019s work in 1989 in protest over what she called a failure to adequately speak up for the writer Salman Rushdie, who faced death threats.\n\n\u201cSara Danius really tried to open up and, in a way, to renew the Academy,\u201d said Professor Witt-Brattstrom, who used to be married to Mr. Engdahl. \u201cShe made some very good initiatives. She should have had a few more years.\u201d\n\nSvetlana Alexievich, who was awarded the prize in 2015, told the newspaper Svenska Dagbladet, \u201cThose who have broken the rules should be scrutinized.\u201d She said she had learned from Dostoyevsky \u201cthat human beings are unreliable creatures, so laws and rules are needed to ensure that this does not repeat itself.\u201d", "title": "In Nobel Scandal, a Man Is Accused of Sexual Misconduct. A Woman Takes the Fall.", "authors": ["Christina Anderson"]} {"date": "2018-04-12 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cCluny Brown,\u201d her sparkling 1944 upstairs-downstairs social comedy of changing midcentury mores, set in the aristocratic Devon country house of Friars Carmel, became a classic Ernst Lubitsch comedy. In the film, Jennifer Jones played the heroine, in her maid\u2019s cap and apron, and French actor Charles Boyer was Adam Belinski, the refugee Czech intellectual roue, on the Hollywood assumption that one European accent is as good as another.\n\nPhoto\n\nIt\u2019s a delightful movie, but it\u2019s an even better book, shifting deftly from the concerns of Squire and Lady Carmel and Andrew the young heir, to the real center of the novel, Cluny, the plumber\u2019s niece from London who is sent into \u201cgood service\u201d as a parlormaid right before the World War II because she \u201cdon\u2019t seem to know her place,\u201d and who turns out to be able to navigate a wider and more rapidly evolving world than anyone around her anticipates.\n\nSharp had her devoted following; when \u201cThe Eye of Love\u201d was published in 1957, she was a sufficiently established writer for Kirkus to comment, \u201cMargery Sharp addicts may find this to their taste.\u201d Actually, this postwar novel is one of her best, a lapidary work about the shattered affair between Dolores Diver, who sees herself as a \u201cSpanish type,\u201d (she changed her name from Dorothy Hogg) and her adoring lover Harry, who must marry another woman to save his business.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSharp, who as a narrator reliably has her Jane Austen moments, comments on the first page of \u201cThe Eye of Love\u201d: \u201cLadies of ambiguous status have by convention hearts of gold, and Miss Diver was nothing if not conventional; but a child in an irregular household is often an embarrassment.\u201d\n\nThe child is Martha, who moves to the foreground in the two sequels, \u201cMartha in Paris,\u201d and \u201cMartha, Eric and George.\u201d Martha is a stolid plump child, and an artistic prodigy; as she learns to paint, and faces the conventional dilemmas of love and sex (and the consequences of sex) and professionalism, she offers a completely unique portrait of female genius, in all its single-minded dedication and selfishness. \u201cMartha would chop us all up for India rubber, if we were made of India rubber,\u201d says her patron approvingly.\n\nPhoto\n\nSharp is interested in how her characters are shaped by their fantasies of themselves (Cluny Brown takes herself to tea at the Ritz, scandalizing her uncle; Dolores Diver treasures her carved tortoiseshell comb and her signature Spanish shawl), but also how they react when those fantasies bring them up against reality. And this combination of interior life and social reality makes for what may be her greatest portrait in \u201cBritannia Mews,\u201d her novel of life on a disreputable London street from 1875 through to the Blitz; the book is a love letter to London and Londoners, and the central character, Adelaide, is an extraordinarily distinct creation, determined and definite in her passions, her actions and her ambitions.\n\nWriting in the Book-of-the-Month Club News, the novelist John P. Marquand hailed the book as \u201ca fine novel along traditional lines in a beautifully cultivated style that is both polite and biting, and yet its whole complexion is devastatingly clear and modern.\u201d\n\nAs always, Sharp takes on potentially sentimental subjects with a tone which is almost shockingly unsentimental; never has the trope of a Victorian drawing master romancing his sheltered female pupil been rendered less romantic. Adelaide\u2019s life unfolds in the sordid surroundings of Britannia Mews as a consequence; she pursues the hapless drawing teacher, despite his attempts to warn her off.\n\n\u201cI drink like a fish,\u201d he tells her, and she assures him that she will put a stop to all that: \u201cYou don\u2019t know what a very strong character I have.\u201d She\u2019s wrong about being able to stop his drinking, but she\u2019s certainly right about her own character. It\u2019s one of Sharp\u2019s great talents, creating female characters of toughness and complexity. She gave us profound \u2014 and sympathetic \u2014 portraits of mothers who feel notably unmoved by motherhood, for example, and realistic stories of women deeply motivated by money, by art, and yes, by sex, even as she created other gentler women in counterpoint, more daunted by convention, but sometimes tougher in the end.\n\nMargery Sharp is sometimes compared to Barbara Pym and to Elizabeth Taylor, and there are certainly overlaps (the retreat for Anglican gentlewomen in \u201cSummer Visits,\u201d her last novel, published in 1977, seems like it could be peopled with Barbara Pym characters), but Sharp has a touch all her own when it comes to taking on social class, sex and its consequences, and the changes that the 20th century brought to both those arenas, most especially for women. She remained, always, both polite and biting, looking at the intoxications and delusions of life and love with wit and clear-eyed sympathy. And if you try a novel and you like it, you can experience the delightful certainty that there are more than two dozen of them waiting, without even counting the mice.\n\nPhoto", "title": "In Praise of Margery Sharp", "authors": ["Perri Klass", "The Enthusiast"]} {"date": "2018-04-18 00:00:00", "text": "Republican voters in Tennessee \u201cdon\u2019t consider him an evil liberal person,\u201d said Victor H. Ashe, a Republican and former longtime mayor of Knoxville. He predicted a tight race and said Ms. Blackburn could not afford to lose a significant chunk of Republican voters.\n\nIn a nominal show of support for Ms. Blackburn, Mr. Corker wrote on Twitter last week that he was sending a donation to her campaign and wished her well in the Senate race. But in a brief interview, he said he would not campaign against Mr. Bredesen, recounting their long history working together and describing him as a friend.\n\n\u201cHe was a very good mayor, very good governor, very good businessperson,\u201d Mr. Corker said, adding, \u201cHe would be successful at anything that he did and is someone I consider to be very thoughtful.\u201d\n\nBut there is ample reason for skepticism about Mr. Bredesen\u2019s chances: No Democrat has won a statewide race in Tennessee since his successful re-election bid in 2006, and the state has turned more Republican since then. He will have to avoid being portrayed as being in lock step with national Democratic figures like Barack Obama and Hillary Clinton, as well as the top Democrats in Congress, Senator Chuck Schumer of New York and Representative Nancy Pelosi of California.\n\nMs. Blackburn and her allies \u201cknow that Bredesen is popular; they know that the national brand of the Democratic Party is not,\u201d said Kent Syler, who teaches at Middle Tennessee State and was a longtime aide to the former Democratic congressman Bart Gordon. \u201cSo they will work very hard to connect him to that national brand, and he will work very hard to avoid that.\u201d\n\nMr. Bredesen, 74, jumped into the race after Mr. Corker, a two-term Republican, decided to retire. A wealthy former health care executive who served as mayor of Nashville before becoming governor, Mr. Bredesen said he concluded that he was probably the only Democrat who would have a reasonable shot at winning the seat. In a video announcing his candidacy, he reminded voters of the successes of his tenure, including reining in the soaring cost of TennCare, the state\u2019s Medicaid program, which had been financially troubled.\n\nHis decision to run for the Senate was a coup for Democrats in Washington who have been mapping out how to flip control of the chamber in November\u2019s elections, even as their caucus defends 26 seats, 10 in states won by Mr. Trump, while the Republicans must guard only nine. Once seen as far-fetched, winning a majority is at least mathematically possible, especially after a Democrat, Doug Jones, won a special election in Alabama in December.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSkepticism of a Democratic takeover of the Senate has come from an unlikely voice in Tennessee: Mr. Bredesen. To Republicans who suggest a vote for him is a vote to make Mr. Schumer the majority leader, he pushed back on the idea.\n\n\u201cI don\u2019t think it\u2019s possible, I\u2019ll be honest with you,\u201d he said, naming Florida, Missouri and North Dakota as states where Democratic incumbents could be in danger. \u201cMy expectation is that I will be in the minority in the Senate.\u201d\n\nMr. Bredesen is walking a careful line when it comes to Mr. Trump, who defeated Mrs. Clinton by 26 percentage points in Tennessee. \u201cLook, I\u2019m not running against Donald Trump,\u201d he says in a television commercial that is textbook Bredesen sobriety.\n\nIn the interview, he emphasized his attentiveness to rural voters who feel as if elected leaders are not doing anything to help them, recalling his own upbringing in upstate New York and offering a pointed critique of today\u2019s Democratic Party.\n\n\u201cMy party, I think, has gotten way too far to the left and needs to learn how to win elections,\u201d he said. \u201cI think we Democrats have gotten too elitist. We\u2019ve gotten too narrow. We\u2019ve gotten too involved in litmus tests.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nHe continued: \u201cI\u2019d like to belong to a church that\u2019s bringing new members in, not routing out dissidents or heretics or something like that, and I\u2019m afraid we\u2019ve gotten too much in the latter.\u201d\n\nStill, there are clear policy differences between Mr. Bredesen and the president. Mr. Bredesen said Mr. Trump\u2019s promised wall along the border with Mexico was \u201cpolitical theater, not anything practical.\u201d He also criticized the Republican tax overhaul for providing \u201ccrumbs\u201d to the middle class \u2014 echoing a description previously used by Ms. Pelosi that Republicans eagerly seized on.\n\n\u201cI think they did something which was clever politically, but I couldn\u2019t have swallowed morally, which is I think they threw a few crumbs to the middle class to give these huge breaks to wealthier people and corporations and so on,\u201d Mr. Bredesen said. \u201cAnd I think I would have called that out as strongly as I possibly could have.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMs. Blackburn speaks proudly of the tax overhaul, and she has allowed little distance between her and Mr. Trump.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cWhat we need in the U.S. Senate is a senator who is going to stand with President Donald Trump,\u201d she told the crowd at a county Republican Party dinner in Murfreesboro this month, where a handful of young supporters wore red T-shirts that said \u201cMarsha Marsha Marsha\u201d on the back.\n\nFirst elected to Congress in 2002 after serving as a state senator, Ms. Blackburn, 65, is a frequent presence on cable news channels. She has been a leading opponent of abortion, overseeing a House panel that investigated Planned Parenthood and the sale of fetal tissue for medical research. She once debated climate change with the television personality Bill Nye.\n\nIn a video announcing her candidacy, she described herself as a \u201chard-core, card-carrying Tennessee conservative,\u201d spoke of carrying a gun in her purse, declared she was \u201cpolitically incorrect\u201d and said, with a note of pride, that liberals call her a \u201cwing nut.\u201d\n\nBut Ms. Blackburn\u2019s full-throated conservatism is distinctive compared with the relatively moderate tone of Republicans whom Tennessee voters have sent to the Senate in the past \u2014 a group that includes Howard H. Baker Jr., a former Senate majority leader who became known as \u201cthe great conciliator\u201d; another majority leader, Bill Frist; Mr. Corker; and Tennessee\u2019s senior senator, Lamar Alexander.\n\nIn a Vanderbilt University poll conducted last year, 76 percent of Tennessee voters said they preferred that their legislators worked with the other party, even if it meant compromising on some of their values.\n\nMs. Blackburn is sending a different message. \u201cReal conservative leadership,\u201d promises a palm card for her campaign. \u201cNo compromise, no apologies.\u201d\n\nRepresentative Steve Cohen, a Democrat from Memphis, questioned whether Tennessee voters would embrace a candidate in that mold over someone with a middle-of-the-road, business-friendly image.\n\n\u201cWe\u2019ve never had a politician on that level of anybody that\u2019s been kind of mocked for their antediluvian ways,\u201d he said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMs. Blackburn suggested that people in Tennessee needed to get accustomed to the idea of being represented in the Senate by a woman.\n\n\u201cThis is one of the things that you\u2019ll hear people talk about from time to time, because Tennessee\u2019s never had a female senator,\u201d she said. \u201cSo it is going to be a little bit different, if you will. An approach will be different.\u201d\n\nThen there is the unresolved question of just how much Ms. Blackburn will be able to exploit Mr. Bredesen\u2019s party affiliation \u2014 even if Mr. Bredesen himself is not eager to dwell on it.\n\nVoters may have fond memories of Mr. Bredesen as governor, but will they want to help expand the ranks of the Senate Democratic caucus? Mr. Schumer personally courted Mr. Bredesen to run.\n\n\u201cYou can\u2019t talk one way at home and go to D.C. and support Chuck Schumer and expect that to be what the people of this state want,\u201d Ms. Blackburn told the crowd in Murfreesboro. \u201cAnd let me tell you something: Chuck Schumer as majority leader would be an absolute disaster.\u201d\n\nMr. Bredesen scoffed at the idea that he would fall in line with Mr. Schumer, noting that he has a history of breaking with his party, including over the Affordable Care Act, which he roundly criticized.\n\n\u201cI\u2019ve got a
