"authors": ["Thomas Kaplan"]} {"date": "2018-04-18 00:00:00", "text": "SAN JUAN, P.R. \u2014 The major league baseball games this week between the Minnesota Twins and Cleveland Indians here had dual goals: to affirm the Puerto Rican government\u2019s position that the island was open for business again after the devastation of Hurricane Maria seven months ago, and to showcase this American territory\u2019s unique relationship with baseball.\n\nAnd then lights across the island went out again.\n\nThe second and final game went on \u2014 the mayor of San Juan promised it would \u2014 but sitting in the stands on Wednesday, it was hard to miss the disparity: running on generators earlier in the day, Estadio Hiram Bithorn, the storied stadium where the games were played, was back on the power grid by game time, while across the highway, apartment buildings and businesses disappeared in the dark, save for a few lit windows.\n\nRather than anger, several people in and around the stadium, accustomed to months at home without electricity and perhaps feeling a bit of the baseball fever that the games have engendered, shrugged at the imbalance of power.\n\n\u201cWe\u2019ll see what the government\u2019s priorities are,\u201d said Sylma Le\u00f3n, 60, who lives in the Eleanor Roosevelt neighborhood across from the stadium, where a capacity crowd of 19,537 people gathered for Minnesota\u2019s 2-1 victory over Cleveland in 16 innings. She was one of nearly 1.5 million customers of the Puerto Rico Electric Power Authority to lose power on Wednesday morning when a crew working to help restore power in Puerto Rico accidentally knocked out electricity.", "title": "In Puerto Rico, Stadium Lights Glow, Homes Do Not", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-24 00:00:00", "text": "Sunscreens with a rating of SPF 100 may be more effective than ones rated SPF 50, according to a randomized trial, even though the Food and Drug Administration says that any SPF above 50 offers no additional protection.\n\nThe study, in the Journal of the American Academy of Dermatology, included 199 men and women given two tubes of sunscreen, one marked \u201cright\u201d and one \u201cleft.\u201d They applied the cream to the indicated side of the face and neck, and then went about their normal activities on a sunny day at a ski resort. One of the tubes contained SPF 50 cream, the other SPF 100.\n\nThe next day, a dermatologist rated the severity of burn on a 5-point scale from none to most severe. On average, the score was more than twice as high for the SPF 50 side of the face as for the SPF 100.\n\nThe reason may be that in practice, people almost never put on enough sunscreen.\n\n\u201cIf you look at the laboratory results, you don\u2019t see much of difference between 100 and 50,\u201d said the senior author, Dr. Darrell S. Rigel, a professor of dermatology at New York University. \u201cBut in the real world, the higher SPFs are much more forgiving, and since people are under-applying sunscreen, they\u2019re much more likely to protect.\u201d", "title": "In Real Life, SPF 100 Sunscreens May Work Better Than SPF 50", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-11 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cI think those that are hypersensitive to this issue are likely not going to be voting for us anyway, and I understand that, because there are voters who believe that any discussion of the Second Amendment is the compromising of the Second Amendment,\u201d said Walt Maddox, a Democratic candidate for governor of Alabama. \u201cBut I believe the vast majority of Democrats, independents and Republicans are not fearful of a discussion on this matter, especially if it\u2019s reasonable, measured and common sense-oriented.\u201d\n\nFor his own part, Mr. Maddox declares allegiance to the Second Amendment, but he declined to fill out the questionnaire that the N.R.A. sends to candidates. In the N.R.A.\u2019s view, refusing to complete the questionnaire is \u201coften an indication of indifference, if not outright hostility, to gun owners\u2019 and sportsmen\u2019s rights.\u201d\n\nOther Democrats have mounted far more pointed critiques of the group. The Democratic Party in Virginia, a state that retains a conservative streak despite recent Democratic successes, recently issued a statement referring to N.R.A. \u201cblood money\u201d and declaring that Virginians were excited about \u201ckicking out politicians who value National Rifle Association money over the safety of their sons and daughters, mothers and fathers.\u201d\n\nAnd in Kentucky, a Democratic state representative from an overwhelmingly conservative district stood on the House floor in February to call for new gun control measures, and said he was surrendering his A rating from the N.R.A.\n\nSome Republicans have also calculated that they can now afford to cross the group to some extent. Gov. Rick Scott of Florida, who is running for the Senate this year, recently signed a Republican-backed gun-control package that was almost immediately challenged in a lawsuit by the N.R.A.\n\nThe mass shooting in Parkland, which helped prompt the legislation Mr. Scott signed, appears to have been a political turning point even in places like Montana, which has one of the nation\u2019s highest rates of gun ownership and where candidates often talk about their hunting credentials.\n\nAt a candidates\u2019 forum less than a week before the Parkland shooting, the Democrats vying for the party\u2019s House nomination \u2014 there were then five \u2014 were asked whether they supported expanded background checks for gun purchasers. None said yes. Then came the rampage in Florida.", "title": "In Red-State Races, Democrats Seek an Edge by Defying the N.R.A.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-11 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cYou cannot understand how cool you are before you drive in the middle of this road,\u201d Mr. Teplygin said, sitting in a burger restaurant. \u201cSpotting this is like sports for us.\u201d\n\nThe highway was built in the 1950s to link the Kremlin with government residencies west of Moscow. Along the road are grand Stalinist buildings, constructed for members of the Soviet elite. The median lane was reserved for government cars in the beginning, too, but the traffic was much lighter at the time and so there were not as many accidents.\n\nToday, the road reflects the hierarchy that organizes life in Russia into a top-down structure.\n\nTraffic gets fully blocked for cars carrying Mr. Putin and Prime Minister Dmitri A. Medvedev. Only certain cars with special license plates are permitted to use the middle lane, and violators are swiftly moved aside by the police, say advocates for traffic safety. Government ministers drive with the general traffic, some of them surrounded by a few police cars, depending on their rank.\n\nA special traffic police regiment patrols the road, which is also peppered with CCTV cameras. In 2013, Gadzhi N. Makhachev, deputy prime minister of Dagestan, a Russian republic in the North Caucasus, collided with another car in the special lane. He and two people in the other vehicle all died.\n\nSergei A. Medvedev, now a popular commentator and TV host (and no relation to Prime Minister Medvedev), grew up in one of the imposing buildings near the highway and has seen many of the crashes on it. Leonid I. Brezhnev, the former Soviet leader, lived nearby.\n\n\u201cIn Russia, you always have to prove your status,\u201d said Mr. Medvedev, who is also a professor at the Higher School of Economics in Moscow. \u201cOne of the main questions of the Russian life is: Who are you? Who are you to drive this way, live in this house, walk with this woman?\u201d", "title": "In Russia, a \u2018Special Highway\u2019 Helps the Privileged Avoid Traffic", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-22 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nTimes Insider delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how news, features and opinion come together at The New York Times.\n\nMURUTHALAWA, Sri Lanka \u2014 Every story needs a protagonist. When we came to Sri Lanka to report on the spate of Facebook-linked violence in the developing world, we thought we\u2019d found ours in a young Buddhist monk from a small mountain town.\n\nBut, we would soon learn, that monk\u2019s story was more morally complicated than we\u2019d anticipated \u2014 and our story on Facebook larger and darker than what we\u2019d initially planned.\n\nA week earlier, mobs of Sinhalese-speaking Buddhists, the country\u2019s majority group, had risen up, inspired by anti-Muslim misinformation and hate speech on Facebook. They destroyed mosques and Muslim homes in several towns, killing one man.\n\nBut, here, the monk we\u2019d heard about, Nelligala Dhammaratne, had met the mob in the street. Drawing on his religious authority and sway with the community, he admonished its members to disperse. The local mosque was saved.\n\nMr. Dhammaratne was meant to provide a heroic contrast to our story\u2019s villains: the extremists who\u2019d dominated social media here and in other developing countries, using it to whip people into paranoid rages that sometimes became deadly.\n\nWe thought we had a story about good guys and bad guys battling for control of the vast information spaces that Facebook opens up in countries like Sri Lanka. That was in line with Facebook\u2019s own worldview, that the platform heightens any society\u2019s pre-existing tendencies for good and bad. In this view, Facebook has a responsibility to mitigate the bad, but could hardly be blamed for creating it.\n\nBut Mr. Dhammaratne was not what we\u2019d expected. Spending time with him at his mountaintop temple, overlooking rolling green hills, we realized that our understanding of Facebook\u2019s role in societies with weak institutions went far beyond magnifying good and bad alike.\n\nYes, he\u2019d stopped the mob. But he also recited to us, as unvarnished truth, some of the very anti-Muslim rumors that had spread in viral Facebook memes before the attack. Muslim shop owners put chemicals in bras to sterilize Buddhist women. Muslim doctors sterilized Buddhist patients without their knowledge. Muslims in government were secret extremists.\n\nHow did he know this? \u201cThe whole country heard about this\u201d on Facebook, he answered. Had he discussed this with his constituents in the run-up to the violence? Of course.\n\nWe came to understand that Facebook\u2019s algorithm-driven newsfeed, by pushing out whatever content drew the most engagement from users, does more than amplify existing prejudices or boost extremists.\n\nBy pushing out content charged by negative, primal emotions like anger or fear \u2014 which, studies show, perform best on the algorithm \u2014 the platform can change how people see the world and relate to one another. In countries with weak institutions but where Facebook use is widespread, that can allow misinformation to run rampant. And in societies with histories of deep social distrust, it can turn deadly.\n\nMr. Dhammaratne, meant to show how society\u2019s gatekeepers guard against those forces, turned out to exemplified that even the well-intentioned are overwhelmed by these forces. This would not be a story of heroes and villains, we learned, but of victims on both sides of the violence.\n\nFacebook, designed to deliver dopamine hits like a casino slot machine, had inadvertently enlisted everyday Sri Lankans in constructing an alternate reality out of the emotionally charged rumors and us-versus-them hate that performed best on the algorithm.\n\nWho were they \u2014 suddenly plugged into one of the most sophisticated media platforms in history, which presented itself as a portal for news and information \u2014 to resist?\n\n\u201cSinhalese people who had been perfectly fine were getting provoked into action,\u201d Mr. Dhammaratne said, referring to emotionally charged Facebook content, which had made it difficult for members of his congregation to distinguish truth from reality.\n\nWe would see that pattern, of otherwise well-meaning bystanders provoked by online anger and fear, play out in a number of cases we tracked across the developing world.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s the ability of these apps to transmit messages, especially audio and video, so quickly and to such large groups, that is how this wave of violence was created,\u201d Mr. Dhammaratne said.\n\nHe said the government had been right to temporarily block social media; \u201cThat\u2019s how this got controlled.\u201d\n\nBut Facebook has become too essential for day-to-day life to be shut down, he added. It will have to be regulated or better policed, though he was unsure how. Otherwise, this might happen again.", "title": "In Search of Facebook\u2019s Heroes, Finding Only Victims", "authors": ["Max Fisher", "Amanda Taub"]} {"date": "2018-04-01 00:00:00", "text": "NAIROBI, Kenya \u2014 Islamist militants in Somalia carried out multiple coordinated attacks against African Union peacekeeping forces on Sunday and claimed to have killed at least 59 Ugandan soldiers.\n\nCeaser Olweny, a spokesman for the Ugandan peacekeepers, said four soldiers had been killed, and six wounded.\n\nThe Shabab, a Somali terrorist group affiliated with Al Qaeda, made the attacks on three military bases and two Somali government outposts in the Lower Shabelle region, a Shabab stronghold near Mogadishu, the country\u2019s capital.\n\nMr. Olweny said the attacks were coordinated.\n\nSomali officials confirmed the attacks to the local news media.", "title": "In Somalia, Shabab Attacks Leave Ugandan Peacekeepers Dead", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-04 00:00:00", "text": "In the escalating economic showdown between the United States and China, President Trump is trying to put American shoppers first. The administration did not place tariffs on necessities like shoes and clothes, and mostly spared smartphones from the 25 percent levy on Chinese goods announced this week.\n\nBut by shielding consumers, Mr. Trump has put American manufacturers \u2014 a group he has championed \u2014 in the cross hairs of a potential global trade war. If the measures stand, along with China\u2019s retaliatory tariffs, they could snuff out a manufacturing recovery just beginning to gain steam.\n\n\u201cIf you want to spare the consumer so you don\u2019t get this massive backlash against your tariffs, then there goes manufacturing, because that\u2019s what\u2019s left,\u201d said Monica de Bolle, an economist at the Peterson Institute for International Economics. \u201cThe irony is, you cannot spare manufacturing from anything because manufacturing is globally integrated. The sector sources its parts and components from all over the world.\u201d\n\nThat intricate supply chain often runs directly between the two countries, sometimes in both directions. Chinese factories make wing panels and doors for Boeing\u2019s Next Generation 737 planes, which are assembled by union workers in Renton, Wash. General Motors makes its Buick Envision, a sport-utility vehicle, in Shandong Province, and sells it to American consumers. Construction workers in Denver use building materials manufactured in China, made in part from ethane gas produced in Texas.", "title": "In Sparing Consumers Tariff Burden, Trump Hit Manufacturing", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-05 00:00:00", "text": "Silver-haired and hulking in his prison-issue shirt, Mr. Le Roux spoke about Ms. Lee in his first few moments on the stand, saying he had ordered her murder because he believed she had stolen from him. \u201cI had her killed,\u201d he said matter-of-factly, adding that Mr. Hunter handled the details and that Mr. Samia and \u201ca partner\u201d did the actual work.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe chilling testimony was part of Mr. Le Roux\u2019s cooperation with the government. In late 2012, he was arrested by the Drug Enforcement Administration after being lured to Liberia. Ever since, Mr. Le Roux, 45, has been assisting the authorities in rounding up the members of his sprawling organization in an effort to reduce a possible life sentence.\n\nIn 2013, he helped the D.E.A. launch a sting operation in Thailand that led to Mr. Hunter\u2019s first arrest and eventual sentence of 20 years in prison. In that case, the drug agency caught Mr. Hunter and three others agreeing to murder one of its agents and an informant. Because the charges included a plot to bring cocaine to New York, the case was handled by prosecutors in Manhattan. They are also handling Ms. Lee\u2019s murder, claiming it evolved from the same investigation.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe trial so far has focused on the car bombs, arsons and assassinations that Mr. Le Roux employed to protect his smuggling routes \u2014 violence that was previewed so unnervingly in opening arguments on Tuesday that a juror told the judge she feared for her safety and was excused the following day.\n\nThe trial has also pulled back the veil on the covert world of mercenary work. Mr. Le Roux testified that he paid his guns-for-hire $5,000 to $10,000 a month, plus expenses. He said he paid an extra $25,000 for \u201cbonus work,\u201d which he described as \u201cacts of killing and any other acts of violence.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cThe word \u2018mercenary,\u2019\u201d he explained, \u201cmeans a trained person with military experience and an aggressive posture who will beat, shoot, intimidate or kill anyone on instruction.\u201d\n\nOn Wednesday afternoon, Mr. Le Roux said that for two years his chief mercenary was a man named David Smith who in 2008 formed a company called Echelon Associates to recruit what amounted to a private Praetorian guard. Its members traveled the globe \u2014 from Mozambique to Papua New Guinea \u2014 often using false passports and code names like Daddy Mac and Rambo to scout locations for Mr. Le Roux, watch his assets and maim or murder on his behalf.\n\nAmong those murdered was Mr. Smith, Mr. Le Roux admitted. He said he had his henchman killed in 2010 after finding out that Mr. Smith was cheating him. Mr. Le Roux subsequently named Mr. Hunter his security chief.\n\nA former Army sergeant with Special Forces training, Mr. Hunter, 52, had served in the military and with two private security firms in Iraq. During the sting in Thailand, he was caught on camera boasting of the vicious acts he committed for Mr. Le Roux: how he waterboarded one man, shot a second in the hand and pitched a third \u2014 another suspected thief \u2014 overboard at sea.\n\nOn Thursday, Mr. Le Roux testified that after two men on his hit team \u2014 a gunman from New Zealand and a former member of the French Foreign Legion \u2014 quit their jobs, he instructed Mr. Hunter to replace them. Mr. Hunter, emails show, reached out to Mr. Samia, a onetime Army sniper, who lived near Mr. Stillwell, a firearms instructor, in the small town of Roxboro, N.C.\n\nFlight records indicate that Mr. Samia, 43, and Mr. Stillwell, 50, flew to Manila in January 2011, where, Mr. Le Roux recalled, he supplied the men with a rifle (for long shots), a pistol (for close-range shots) and an MP5 submachine gun from a weapons warehouse he maintained. He also gave them Ms. Lee\u2019s address.\n\nOne month later, Mr. Le Roux said, the two men followed the plan he had concocted: posing as real-estate buyers, they lured Ms. Lee in a Toyota van into the countryside near Las Pi\u00f1as. Mr. Stillwell later told the D.E.A. that he was driving the van as Mr. Samia fired the pistol into Ms. Lee\u2019s face.\n\nIn early March, Mr. Hunter drove both men to the airport and put them on a plane, Mr. Le Roux said. Three years later, the D.E.A. tracked them down in Roxboro \u2014 with arrest warrants.", "title": "In Spellbinding Testimony, Crime Lord Details Mayhem and Murders", "authors": ["Alan Feuer"]} {"date": "2018-04-28 00:00:00", "text": "Rates\n\nFrom about 1,350 Swedish kronor , or about 161 U.S. dollars.\n\nBasics\n\nThe most promising property to emerge from Stockholm\u2019s recent hotel boom is At Six, a 343-room hotel in a high-rise Brutalist building that formerly housed a bank. Opened in March 2017, the ambitious hotel is part of an urban renewal project aimed at transforming Brunkebergstorg, a once-dreary square in the city center, into a lively gathering point for visitors and locals alike. Polished and modern, the hotel\u2019s monochrome gray interiors were designed by the London-based Universal Design Studio. An in-house curator chose artworks, including Sol LeWitt prints in the restaurant and an eight-foot-tall marble bust by the Catalan sculptor Jaume Plensa that sits on the lobby\u2019s grandiose white-granite staircase.\n\nImage At Six hotel in Stockholm. Credit Andy Liffner\n\nLocation\n\nAs central as it gets in Stockholm, Brunkebergstorg is within walking distance of most city sights. It\u2019s a 10-minute walk to the central train station, and five minutes to the nearest subway station.\n\nThe Room\n\nOn the 13th floor, my deluxe room (a middle-priced room category) was a study in moody hues, with dove-gray walls and drapes, smoked-glass mirrors, a charcoal rug and wardrobes cloaked in soft indigo fabric. A black leather headboard framed a fluffy king-size bed with crisp white linens and a half-dozen pillows. Along one wall, a long green-marble desk offered a small work space with built-in outlets beside a TV, Bluetooth-enabled speakers, and a wooden tray with glassware and cocktail-making accouterments. Large glass sliding doors opened onto a balcony with two chairs and a small table overlooking the square below.", "title": "In Stockholm, a Hotel That\u2019s Solid and Social", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-13 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nAMERICAN HISTORIES\n\nStories\n\nBy John Edgar Wideman\n\n192 pp. Scribner. $26.\n\nJohn Edgar Wideman\u2019s new story collection begins like this:\n\n\u201cDear Mr. President,\n\n\u201cI send this note along with some stories I\u2019ve written, and hope you will find time in your demanding schedule to read both note and stories. The stories should speak for themselves. The note is a plea, Mr. President. Please eradicate slavery.\u201d Later in the same piece: \u201cMy guess is that slavery won\u2019t disappear until only two human beings are left alive, neither one strong enough to enslave the other. Anyway, please read on and enjoy the stories that follow. \u2026 No obligation to free a single slave of any color.\u201d\n\nWith this blunt, furious opening, Wideman puts us on notice: Wherever we\u2019re going with him, we\u2019re going to engage with America\u2019s unhealed wounds of slavery and racism \u2014 and it\u2019s not going to be comfortable or easy. Wideman\u2019s stories range widely over experiences from slavery to the present day. Among the tales of the past: \u201cJB & FD,\u201d an imagined dialogue between John Brown and Frederick Douglass, and \u201cNat Turner Confesses,\u201d a disturbing voyage into the rebellion leader\u2019s mind. Among the present-day tales, two of the most striking are \u201cWilliamsburg Bridge,\u201d the musings of a man considering suicide, and \u201cMaps and Ledgers,\u201d which touches on the discomfort of an African-American writing teacher in a largely white institution. All are illumined by a searching intelligence and a willingness to test the boundaries of the short story form.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cAmerican Histories\u201d is a hard book to categorize. Part of the difficulty is that Wideman often uses the facts of his life in a way that makes readers question what is true and what isn\u2019t. I usually avoid considering how a writer\u2019s personal life relates to his or her fiction, but with a number of the stories, most notably \u201cMaps and Ledgers,\u201d it\u2019s hard not to do. The narrator refers to his youngest brother and his son both having committed murder. Readers who have followed Wideman\u2019s career know that both of those things are, sadly, true. In 1986, at the age of 16, Wideman\u2019s son Jacob killed another teenager; he was only recently paroled. And Wideman\u2019s brother Robert is serving a life sentence in prison for murder, a situation Wideman grappled with in his tough-minded memoir \u201cBrothers and Keepers.\u201d Is including this information in the story a challenge to get the reader to set aside what he knows of the author\u2019s history? Or is it an invitation to consider what the horrors and triumphs of real life bring to bear on one\u2019s fiction?\n\nThe reader is encouraged to step out of the text in other ways as well. In the heart of \u201cWillamsburg Bridge,\u201d there is a reference to AlexReisner.com/NYC2. As would another other soul living in 2018, I put the book down immediately and went to the website, where the young man who owns it describes at length a suicide he saw on the bridge. Reisner, the viewer, is white, the fictional suicide a young black man, the contrast no doubt deliberate. These invitations to leave the text behind (for this is not the only one) seem to be part of Wideman\u2019s method of holding readers at bay, keeping them always guessing, always a little uncertain.\n\nI found the digressiveness of this collection frustrating at times \u2014 it\u2019s not a likable or easily accessible book. But in this case, that\u2019s not a criticism. \u201cAmerican Histories\u201d is not here to be liked. It\u2019s here to challenge you. And that it does.", "title": "In Stories About Slavery and Its Legacy, Hints of the Author\u2019s Life", "authors": ["Martha Southgate", "John Edgar Wideman"]} {"date": "2018-04-19 00:00:00", "text": "On display at the opening will be works of 20 artists, mostly from the West Bank and Gaza, who are either still living there or are working as expatriates.\n\nThe range of media includes paintings, textiles, installation pieces and photography. The unifying, and qualifying, theme of the artwork is that it is either by Palestinian artists or represents Palestinian life.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cThis is a dream,\u201d said the artist Manal Deeb, whose mixed-media works \u2014 incorporating photographs, oil paint and Arabic calligraphy \u2014 hang in the gallery. Her work was also exhibited at the United Nations Visitors Center in New York in 2012\u20142013. Born in Ramallah, Ms. Deeb moved to America as a teenager in 1986. Speaking by telephone from her studio in Fairfax, Va., she said the new Palestinian museum will provide her and other Palestinian artists with an outlet where there was none before.\n\n\u201cAs Palestinians, we all have the same core search for identity, and this is a way for us to all come together and save that identity,\u201d she said.\n\nMr. Saleh said that the museum\u2019s agenda is neither political or religious, but few of the artists on display have avoided the historic and ongoing conflicts between Palestinians and the State of Israel. The impacts of war on women and children are a theme of Ms. Deeb\u2019s art, as well as that of 47-year-old Rana Bishara, born in 1971 in the Upper Galilee village of Tarshiha where she still lives part time. Her paintings in the museum feature abstracts that explore memories of childhood growing up amid political demonstrations, contrasted with the beauty of the natural world. To this end, much of her work features actual pieces of cactus, a symbol of razed villages where nothing remains but the prickly vegetation.\n\n\u201cFor me, cactus means to be patient,\u201d said Ms. Bishara, speaking by telephone during a recent visit to Savannah, Ga., where she earned an M.F.A. at the Savannah College of Art in 2003. \u201cOne of my famous works has pieces of pickled cactus, packed tightly in a jar, which depicts Palestinians who are living in Israel under the pressure of laws that treat us like second-class citizens or worse,\u201d Ms. Bishara said.\n\nPhoto\n\nYet for every statement of political resistance, there are images that simply evoke the human experience. In a vaguely Post-Impressionist interior by Ayed Arafah, a painter from the Dheisheh refugee camp, near Bethlehem, a cat looks up mischievously from an unraveled roll of toilet paper. A series of boldly colored portraits by the gallery\u2019s youngest painter, 18-year-old Malak Mattar, recall the stylistic primitivism of high Modernism. Ms. Mattar, a resident of Gaza, started painting therapeutically when she was 13, amid shelling during the 51-day military conflict with Israel in 2014. So despite the playfulness of her art, Ms. Mattar\u2019s life story draws gallery visitors back to the turmoil she and other Palestinian artists can face, which in turn informs their art.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cVery often, when artists are under that kind of war pressure, they produce some of their best work,\u201d said James Harithas, director of the Station Museum of Contemporary Art in Houston. In 2003, the Texas gallery hosted \u201cMade in Palestine,\u201d probably the first museum exhibition of Palestinian art in the United States. The exhibit then toured nationally, and \u201cwas the most popular show we\u2019ve ever had,\u201d Mr. Harithas said.\n\nAmong the 23 artists in the Houston show, and one of its major organizers, was a Jerusalem native, Samia Halaby, whose work is also on display in the Woodbridge museum. Ms. Halaby now lives in New York and, at 81, is something of a doyenne of the Palestinian art world. In her 2001 book, \u201cLiberation Art of Palestine: Palestinian Painting and Sculpture in the Second Half of the 20th Century,\u201d she traced the roots of modern Palestinian art to American abstract expressionism and the social activism of the Mexican muralists of the early 20-century. The powerful, revolutionary works of Diego Rivera, David Alfaro Siqueiros, as well as Picasso and the Cubists \u2014 whose blocky abstractions echoed the geometric patterns of classical Islamic art \u2014 planted seeds of inspiration for Palestinian artists of the 1970s and 1980s, Ms. Halaby said.\n\n\u201cIt was a high period for Palestinian artists, and one of the very important things to them was that their own people understood what they were doing,\u201d she said. \u201cToday, there are Palestinian artists who are now concerned with explaining the Palestinian issue to the outside world and a Western audience, which is why this new museum is so important.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Race/Related Newsletter Join a deep and provocative exploration of race with a diverse group of New York Times journalists. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nBoth Ms. Halaby and Mr. Saleh are aware of how quickly that message can become controversial. When the \u201cMade in Palestine\u201d exhibit traveled to New York in 2005, two state legislators and at least one assemblyman raised objections to the show, suggesting that it endorsed terrorism.\n\nSo far, the museum has faced no blowback from the local community, Mr. Saleh said. In fact, he enjoys good relations with one of his nonprofit neighbors, the Jewish Federation of Greater New Haven. When the organization\u2019s Jewish Community Center needed a temporary home last year after a fire, Mr. Saleh rented the Center space in his Woodbridge building, across the hall from the new museum.\n\nIn an email, the organization expressed appreciation for Mr. Saleh\u2019s support of the community center, and the Jewish Federation\u2019s chief executive, Judy Alperin, affirmed that she hoped there would be opportunities for bridge-building and dialogue once the museum opens.\n\nFor her part, Ms. Halaby said her art is not as much informed by any specific political agenda as it is by her fondness for Cubism, medieval Islamic art and Soviet Constructivism. Yet at the same time, she does not back away from her identity.\n\n\u201cI\u2019m never going to let you forget that I\u2019m Palestinian,\u201d she said. \u201cSo if you look at my art, I am saying I\u2019m Palestinian, like it or hate it, here\u2019s what I do, and I do it very well,\u201d she said.", "title": "In Suburban Connecticut, the Palestinian Avant-Garde", "authors": ["Tom Verde"]} {"date": "2018-04-17 00:00:00", "text": "Its job is to monitor compliance with that treaty, and to work toward ridding the world of chemical weapons. It also has a role in verifying the elimination of those weapons.\n\nThe group describes itself as \u201can independent, autonomous, international organization with a working relationship with the United Nations.\u201d\n\nIn 2013, Syria signed the convention and agreed to eliminate its chemical weapons stockpiles. On a joint mission with the United Nations, the organization arranged for the transport of all chemical weapons the Syrian government had declared for disposal overseas.\n\nOver 96 percent of state-declared stockpiles around the world have been destroyed under the watch of the organization. However, as seems to be the case in Syria, that doesn\u2019t necessarily mean that countries no longer have chemical weapons, because there is no way to guarantee that they declared everything they had.\n\nPhoto\n\nHow can inspectors work in a war zone?\n\nThe organization was not created to work in battle zones and has had to adapt to send its inspectors to countries at war. In 2014, allegations of chemical weapons use in Syria prompted the group to dispatch a fact-finding mission to the country, the first time it had sent a team to an area of active conflict. (They first visited Syria in 2013.)\n\nCollecting samples while making sure they can be used for evidence takes time, and such missions can turn investigators into targets. While working in Syria in 2014, for example, their convoy came under fire.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nLast year, while looking into further allegations of chemical weapons use in Syria, investigators did not visit the town of Khan Sheikhoun because of security fears. Instead, they relied on witness accounts and samples collected from the site. That opened their conclusions to criticism from Russia and Syria, which contended that Damascus had disposed of all its chemical weapons.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Wake Up With The Times, Anywhere in the World. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nCan the O.P.C.W. point the finger?\n\nNo. The organization\u2019s job is to establish whether chemical weapons were used, not who used them.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s dealing with things it wasn\u2019t really intended to deal with,\u201d said Richard Guthrie, a chemical weapons expert and editor of CBW Events, a website that tries to document uses of chemical and biological weapons.\n\nWhen the Chemical Weapons Convention was being negotiated, Mr. Guthrie said, \u201cthe concern was large-scale use of chemical weapons on the battlefield \u2014 that had happened in the Iran-Iraq war.\u201d But that is different from identifying the relatively small-scale use of chemical weapons, like the alleged case in Syria, or the attack on the spy and his daughter in Britain.\n\nUntil the end of last year, the organization had a mandate to pass on its findings to a Joint Investigative Mechanism, established by the United Nations Security Council, which would try to identify the perpetrators of attacks. But last year Russia vetoed the extension of that mandate.\n\nThat leaves a disconnect: Even if the organization finds that chemical weapons were used in Douma, the question of who is to blame could remain unresolved.", "title": "In Syria, O.P.C.W. Is Asked to Arbitrate: Chemical Attack or Not?", "authors": ["Palko Karasz"]} {"date": "2018-04-09 00:00:00", "text": "A world grown numb to the slaughter of civilians in Syria has been roused in the last 48 hours by photographs on social media of lifeless men, women and children in the rebel-held town of Douma, many with white foam coming from their mouths and nostrils, victims of chemical weapons. Outraged Western nations blame President Bashar al-Assad\u2019s regime and demand retaliation.\n\nRussia and Iran, Mr. Assad\u2019s callous enablers, have denied that he has once again used these horrific weapons on his own people. But Douma is surrounded by Syrian forces, whom experts have blamed for most of the 85 chemical attacks in the country over the past five years. Syria had a major chemical weapons program before pledging to surrender it after chemical attacks in 2013, a commitment it failed to fully honor.\n\nPresident Trump took limited military action against Syria after a chemical weapons attack last year, largely ignored the issue after that and then last week surprised his military commanders by announcing plans to soon withdraw 2,000 troops in the fight against the Islamic State. Mr. Trump vowed on Sunday on Twitter that there would be a \u201cbig price to pay\u201d for the latest killings, estimated at up to 70 people dead, according to aid groups.\n\nBut the president should know by now that tough talk without a coherent strategy or follow-through is dangerous.", "title": "Opinion | In Syria, Trump Faces the Limits of Bluster", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-03 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cCruz has built-in name identification, conservative credentials and an \u2018R\u2019 behind his name, so his candidacy was effectively born on third base,\u201d said Brandon Rottinghaus, a professor of political science at the University of Houston. \u201cThese advantages give him a serious head start, but he doesn\u2019t want to be the hare who naps while the tortoise passes him by. O\u2019Rourke\u2019s fund-raising should be an eye opener for Senator Cruz.\u201d\n\nTexas Democrats have been in this position before. In 2014, Democrats had believed that Wendy Davis would become the first Democratic governor in decades, but Ms. Davis lost and Greg Abbott won. In 2016, Democrats had believed that Hillary Clinton could win Texas in the presidential race, but she lost and Donald Trump won the state.\n\nThe issue often comes down to voter turnout. In last month\u2019s primary elections, Democrats surged to the polls in record-breaking numbers. More Democrats voted early this year than voted early in the presidential election year of 2016. In the end, though, they were still outvoted: A total of 1.5 million votes were cast by Texas Republicans in the primary, compared to 1 million by Democrats.\n\n\u201cRight now, history and recent elections are still on Ted Cruz\u2019s side, and the dynamics of this state are still on Ted Cruz\u2019s side, for Republicans to win at a statewide election from the governor\u2019s office to senator and on down,\u201d said Ted Delisi, a Republican strategist in Austin who was the national field director for former Gov. Rick Perry\u2019s 2012 presidential campaign.\n\nAt an event in Waco on Tuesday, Mr. O\u2019Rourke suggested to The Texas Tribune that one of the differences between his race and Ms. Davis\u2019s failed bid for governor in 2014 was the backlash against the Trump White House. \u201cShe did not have the benefit of this year, where, I hope you\u2019ll agree, we\u2019ve never seen this level of urgency, this level of motivation,\u201d Mr. O\u2019Rourke said.\n\nAsked if he was running against Mr. Cruz or Mr. Trump, Mr. O\u2019Rourke replied, \u201cNeither.\u201d He added: \u201cI\u2019m not running against anybody. That just doesn\u2019t get me going. It doesn\u2019t energize me.\u201d", "title": "In Texas, Ted Cruz Is Facing an Unusual Challenge: A Formidably Financed Democrat", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-20 00:00:00", "text": "Such name-dropping continues throughout the book, as Ketzel\u2019s late husband \u2014 Morty Tittelman, a dirty-joke connoisseur some 20 years Ketzel\u2019s senior \u2014 once rubbed elbows with Picasso, Dal\u00ed and Alfred Kinsey. While some of this plays on a nostalgia factor for readers of Ketzel\u2019s generation, it\u2019s a device that gets old rather quickly, especially for anyone unfamiliar with midcentury Jewish comedians.\n\nImage\n\nKetzel\u2019s brother Potsie lives in Las Vegas, and that\u2019s where her parents send her to look for him with the help of Ebby, an old high school crush who has conveniently left the L.V.P.D. to become a private eye. The novel rather often relies on such conveniences, as when Ketzel\u2019s cabby from the Vegas airport just happens to tell her one of the jokes that Ketzel\u2019s late husband invented \u2014 moreover, he claims to have heard the joke from the source himself.\n\nAt the time of Morty\u2019s death Ketzel thought they were the loves of each other\u2019s lives, but she has since discovered receipts indicating that he cheated his way up and down the country with strippers and prostitutes. What she finds even more offensive, though, is that during his research into dirty jokes he acquired several incredibly valuable sex toys of yore that he could have sold off rather than relying on Ketzel\u2019s meager income to support them. Instead Ketzel spent her life waitressing, giving up her dream of becoming a comedian like the men she idolized in her childhood.\n\nAs Ketzel and Ebby go about their investigation, she becomes even further disillusioned with the people she loves. Both Ebby and her parents\u2019 beloved valet, Leo, turn out to have committed murder; and her brother Potsie isn\u2019t just a gambler with a candy addiction, but a bookie who runs in a sleazy circle that includes their miscreant cousin Perry. Ketzel discovers that this despised Perry, who runs a strip joint catering to the naughty schoolgirl fantasy, has also disappeared \u2014 but considering that he once persuaded her to dance naked on film for him when he was a teenager and she only 10, she doesn\u2019t mind his absence too much, linked to Potsie\u2019s though it may be.\n\nAround the middle of the novel, Ketzel becomes the full-time caretaker for her teenage niece, Meryl \u2014 another convenient device, as it gives Ketzel the child she always wanted but never had because Morty wasn\u2019t into the idea. Meryl is a great kid even though her mother has gone to live in a literal hole in the ground and changed her name to ValZorah and her latest stepmother flew the coop after Potsie disappeared. She is so easily pleased by her Aunt Ketzel\u2019s abilities to stock the fridge and make grilled cheeses that it\u2019s clear she hasn\u2019t been well cared for in a good while. The relationship between Ketzel and Meryl is one of the highlights of the book, and does something to make up for Ketzel\u2019s increasingly annoying observations about everything modern that she finds distasteful.\n\nAlthough the plot seems fairly innocent \u2014 woman goes to find her brother, begins to flirt with an old flame, takes care of her niece \u2014 it does take place in Las Vegas, and Pollack is good at describing the ironies of the city: the glitzy facade hiding a slew of sad, tired characters beaten down by life. But it\u2019s also a place of opportunities and chance, and one of the most endearing moments in the book is when Ketzel gets to perform a new comedy act, albeit in a club called Nips. It\u2019s the culmination of Ketzel\u2019s growth from a grieving widow who relied on her husband\u2019s opinions to a modern feminist who is becoming more aware of the realities of the women supporting sex-obsessed men.", "title": "In This Novel, a Grieving Widow Becomes the Detective Hero", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-24 00:00:00", "text": "In the class that I teach on the history of the digital revolution, the students discuss whether innovation is driven more by big government projects or by nimble entrepreneurs. The answer, of course, is that it usually involves a symbiotic mix, like the semiconductor industry, which arose out of the Pentagon and NASA\u2019s need to put guidance systems in the nose cones of rockets. Vannevar Bush was the dean of engineering at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, a co-founder of Raytheon, and oversaw the government science programs that resulted in the atom bomb and electronic computer. He wrote a seminal paper in 1945, called \u201cScience \u2014 the Endless Frontier,\u201d which described how a collaboration of all three sectors he had been part of \u2014 academia, business and government \u2014 would drive innovation. Government funding of basic research in university labs would lead to discoveries in fundamental science that would be the \u201cseed\u201d for future inventions.\n\nMany innovations have progressed along that path. The ENIAC computer funded by the United States Army and built at the University of Pennsylvania was the genesis for UNIVAC and then most other electronic computers. The network funded by the Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency and designed by a consortium of academic and private labs led eventually to today\u2019s internet. The National Science Foundation, started based on Vannevar Bush\u2019s paper, created a multiagency Digital Library Initiative that funded the academic research of Larry Page and Sergey Brin, which led to Google. The sequencing of the human genome, largely funded by the National Institutes of Health, planted the seeds for the biotech industry.\n\nPhoto\n\nNow space endeavors are following this \u201cinnovation progression,\u201d as we can call it. \u201cJust as Darpa served as the initial impetus for the internet and underwrote a lot of the costs of developing the internet in the beginning, it may be the case that NASA has essentially done the same thing by spending the money to build sort of fundamental technologies,\u201d Musk said a year after launching SpaceX. \u201cOnce we can bring the sort of commercial, free enterprise sector into it, then we can see the dramatic acceleration that we saw in the internet.\u201d\n\nOne of the first private pioneers was Burt Rutan, a mutton-chopped aircraft designer who regarded NASA as a bloated and unimaginative bureaucracy and in 1982 founded a company called Scaled Composites that designed aircraft so innovative that, as Davenport writes, \u201cit was as if his inspiration came not just from the laws of aerodynamics but from Picasso.\u201d One of his ideas was for a manned aircraft that could reach the edge of space and then fold its wings upward to act as a feather allowing the craft to re-enter the earth\u2019s atmosphere, land on a runway, and be reused. It would become his entry in the Ansari X Prize, which offered $10 million for the first private company that could launch a reusable vehicle to space twice within two weeks.\n\nRutan attracted two billionaire partners. The first was the Microsoft co-founder Paul Allen, who as a schoolboy in Seattle yearned to become an astronaut but, being nearsighted, realized that was impossible so spent his time coding in the school\u2019s computer room with his friend Bill Gates. Rutan\u2019s second partner was the toothy goldilocked Richard Branson, a thrill-addicted serial adventurer and entrepreneur who was as enthusiastic about publicity as Allen was averse to it. Branson\u2019s personal motto for his company, Virgin, was \u201cScrew it, let\u2019s do it,\u201d which was no longer a guiding principle at NASA, and he created Virgin Galactic with the goal of taking tourists into space. \u201cPaul, isn\u2019t this better than the best sex you ever had?\u201d Branson asked Allen during one test flight as the spaceship climbed higher.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nIn 2004, Rutan\u2019s craft (with a Virgin logo on its tail) flew twice to space and back to win the X Prize. At the celebration, Rutan took a shot at NASA. \u201cI was thinking a little bit about that other space agency, the big guys,\u201d he said. \u201cI think they\u2019re looking at each other now and saying, \u2018We\u2019re screwed.\u2019\u201d Branson began selling tickets at prices that started at $200,000 to those who wanted to ride in a similar plane he began building, the launch date of which always seems to be about a year away.\n\nElon Musk\u2019s love of adventure came partly from his maternal grandfather, an accomplished amateur pilot in South Africa who in 1952 completed a 22,000-mile journey across the globe with no electronic instruments. Musk founded SpaceX in 2002 with the eventual goal of colonizing Mars. \u201cThe more Musk studied, the more he realized that there had been very little advancement in rocket technology in the past 40 years,\u201d Davenport writes. \u201cTo a self-made Silicon Valley tech entrepreneur, this was stunning.\u201d His company\u2019s mantra was, \u201cSet audacious, nearly impossible goals and don\u2019t get dissuaded.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMusk\u2019s entrepreneurship had a social purpose. SpaceX, Tesla, his electric car company, and SolarCity, his renewable energy company, Fernholz writes, \u201cwere explicitly intended to further human civilization.\u201d Along the way, he developed a cultlike following. When SpaceX managed to launch a space capsule into orbit and dock it at the International Space Station in 2012, something NASA could no longer do on its own, the employees at his headquarters broke into a chant, \u201cWe love Elon!\u201d\n\nBezos was likewise inspired by his own maternal grandfather. Lawrence Preston Gise, an upright but loving naval commander, helped develop the hydrogen bomb during a stint at the Atomic Energy Commission and then retired to his sprawling Texas ranch to enjoy his family \u2014 and in particular his insatiably curious little grandson with very big ears, smile and laugh. Bezos\u2019 passion for space began when he was 5 and he watched with his family the launch of Apollo 11, the manned moon mission commanded by Neil Armstrong. \u201cIt really was a seminal moment for me,\u201d he said. \u201cI remember watching it on our living room TV, and the excitement of my parents and my grandparents. Little kids can pick up that kind of excitement.\u201d\n\nBezos spent every summer at his grandfather\u2019s ranch, where he fixed windmills, castrated cattle and geeked out on the tiny county library\u2019s surprisingly large sci-fi collection. His high school valedictorian speech was about space: how to colonize planets, build space hotels and save our fragile planet. \u201cSpace, the final frontier, meet me there!\u201d he concluded.\n\nWhen Bezos founded Blue Origin in 2000, naming it after that pale blue planet where humans originated, he called upon one of his favorite science fiction writers, Neal Stephenson, to be an adviser. They kicked around wildly novel ideas, such as using a bullwhip-like device to propel objects into space. Eventually Bezos focused on reusable rockets. \u201cHow is the situation in the year 2000 different from 1960?\u201d Stephenson asked him. \u201cWhat\u2019s different is computer sensors, cameras, software. Being able to land vertically is the kind of problem that can be addressed by those technologies that existed in 2000 that didn\u2019t exist in 1960.\u201d\n\nBezos began putting together a huge tract of ranch land in Texas where he could build his reusable rockets in secret. One of the great scenes in Davenport\u2019s book is the description of the helicopter trip Bezos took to find the land, which ended with a terrifying crash. He survived, and it conditioned him to the fact that flying machines sometimes fail. Among Bezos\u2019 many strengths is to be exuberant patiently, to have a long-term horizon, as he has done at Amazon. At his Texas ranch, he has begun construction of a 10,000-year \u201cClock of the Long Now\u201d designed by the futurist Danny Hillis, which has a century hand that advances every hundred years and a cuckoo that comes out every millennium. In the mission statement for his space company, he wrote, \u201cBlue will pursue this long-term objective patiently, step by step.\u201d As Elon Musk pushed forward with very public fits and starts, Bezos advised his team, \u201cBe the tortoise and not the hare.\u201d\n\nAt the end of 2015, within a month of each other, Musk and Bezos both launched rockets that returned safely to earth and were reusable. For the moment, Musk the hare had darted ahead: His powerful Falcon 9 rocket had lifted a payload into orbit, whereas Bezos\u2019 smaller New Shepard craft had merely gone up into the edge of space and returned. But as happens with scrappy entrepreneurial business competitors, in contrast to government bureaucracies, Bezos and Musk were goading each other on. And unlike the race between the tortoise and the hare, they can both triumph \u2014 as can, one hopes, Richard Branson and others.\n\nIndeed, even NASA and its big corporate contractor, the United Launch Alliance, a venture between Lockheed Martin and Boeing, can come out winners from competition. As is often the case with the innovation progression, the greatest technological advances come when a symbiosis is reached that combines the resources of a visionary government and the scrappiness of risk-taking entrepreneurs, each spurring the other onward and upward.", "title": "In This Space Race, Jeff Bezos and Elon Musk Are Competing to Take You There", "authors": ["Walter Isaacson"]} {"date": "2018-04-10 00:00:00", "text": "Turning to the Soviet side, readers will learn how and when Soviet intelligence began to concentrate on getting its agents into the American labs that were working to create an atomic weapon. In the early 1940s Russia\u2019s station chiefs in the West were ordered to gather evidence on any atomic work undertaken by American scientists. For example, a Soviet \u201cspook working under student cover\u201d went to see a professor at Columbia University, who asked him what he would think of a bomb that could completely destroy the center of New York City. The agent thought that was impossible, but the professor blurted out: \u201cThere is such a bomb. I\u2019m working on it.\u201d\n\nIn Moscow, the Soviets quickly set up a lab run by the scientist Igor Kurchatov to try to develop the bomb first. Kurchatov immediately saw that his team needed aid \u2014 that is, espionage from the United States. The deputy intelligence chief Leonid Kvasnikov was sent to the New York office to lead the effort, and once there, he helped establish a connection to Julius Rosenberg.\n\nImage\n\nBy the time Lamphere began working with him, Gardner had already found one important clue. It was a code name \u2014 \u201cLib?? (Lieb?) or possibly LIBERAL\u201d or \u201cANTENNA.\u201d Gardner noted that a message of Nov. 27, 1944, \u201cspeaks of his wife ETHEL, 29 years old.\u201d\n\nWith that, Gardner and Lamphere were off and running, and after months of grueling decoding work they were confident that they had uncovered a Soviet spy network put together by Julius Rosenberg. Eventually, both Julius and Ethel Rosenberg were arrested and sentenced to death.\n\nBlum says that Lamphere and Gardner both \u201cknew beyond any doubt the wrongness of Ethel Rosenberg\u2019s death sentence,\u201d and he concludes his book by describing a reunion years later when the two men supposedly expressed regret that Ethel\u2019s execution could not have been stopped. Today, students of the case all agree that her involvement was only peripheral, and that her execution was unwarranted. Nonetheless, various Soviet archives do show that she urged her sister-in-law Ruth to recruit her husband, David Greenglass, into Julius\u2019s circle and that she also provided names to the Russians of those she thought were potential recruits. She was, then, guilty of being part of the conspiracy.", "title": "In This True-Life Spy Story, It\u2019s America vs. Russia, the Early Years", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-07 00:00:00", "text": "On a raw, rainy afternoon in Verona, Italy, this past November, a polyglot gaggle of photo-snapping tourists unfazed by the weather jammed the courtyard of Verona\u2019s 14th-century Casa di Giulietta, supposedly the home of the real-life inspiration for Shakespeare\u2019s Juliet.\n\nDown a side street just three blocks away, was a far superior attraction that most presumably missed: Sapor\u00e8 DownTown, an intriguingly experimental contemporary pizzeria that hours later was so packed with locals there was a one-hour wait. And that despite the fact the place had not even appeared yet on Google Maps.\n\nI almost missed it too \u2014 spotting an online mention minutes before hopping a bus from Verona to San Martino Buon Albergo, the small town nearby where 51 year-old chef Renato Bosco opened the original Sapor\u00e8 in 2006. It has since appeared on several best-pizza-in-Italy lists and made him a nationally recognized chef.\n\n\"Sapor\u00e8\u201d is an amalgam of the Italian word for flavor and Mr. Bosco\u2019s nickname, R\u00e8. But it\u2019s a bit of a misnomer: he is more obsessed with crunch and pliability, lightness and heft. In other words, he is a crust man, whose years of experimentation have rendered a wild range of results, including some that are definitely pizza and others that are rather out-there interpretations.", "title": "In Verona, Pizza That Is All About the Crust", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-09 00:00:00", "text": "The outcome of the trial seems to rest on the testimony of experts from the two sides, who have presented contrasting opinions about Ms. Ortega\u2019s mental state during the crime. Ms. Ortega must prove that she did not have the capacity to understand her actions that day or to know they were wrong. If a jury finds that she is not responsible for the murders, she would be committed to a secure psychiatric facility. If convicted, she faces life in prison.\n\nThe video presented to the jury on Monday undermines statements made by two psychiatrists for the defense who testified last week. They said Ms. Ortega was in a dissociative and psychotic state and had been overcome by voices, particularly Satan\u2019s, in the weeks before the murders.\n\nPhoto\n\nIn his interview with Ms. Ortega on July 27, 2016, Mr. Khadivi asked: \u201cIn September, until the time of the incident, you were not hearing any kind of voices telling you to harm yourself or experiencing the Devil taking over your body?\u201d Ms. Ortega, twisted her face, shook her head and said through a translator: \u201cNo.\u201d\n\nMr. Khadivi repeated the question in different ways, multiple times, asking her if she heard voices, or the Devil, or if she had seen shadows, or a \u201cblack man\u201d trying to \u201cseparate the family,\u201d as she had told the defense experts. Each time she said: \u201cNo.\u201d\n\nShe also told Mr. Khadivi she had no memory of picking up the knife and was unsure of how she got into the Krims\u2019 apartment. Yet, Mr. Khadivi noted, she told the defense experts that she did remember seeing Ms. Krim enter the bathroom.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMr. Khadivi determined that Ms. Ortega suffered from anxiety and depression. Her anxiety increased significantly in the weeks before the murders, he said. She was not psychotic and did not experience paranoia, delusions or a dissociative episode, he said.\n\n\u201cMs. Ortega did not lack the capacity. She had a capacity to appreciate the consequence and wrongfulness of her actions,\u201d Mr. Khadivi said. \u201cAnd she had the capacity to form intent.\u201d\n\nMs. Ortega did not tell Ms. Krim that she was not feeling well, Mr. Khadivi noted. She had also left behind with her sister a purse containing her valuable belongings, and before she left for work, had asked her sister to take care of her son. Those actions, Mr. Khadivi said, were \u201cindicative of someone making a plan to end her life.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nPsychiatrists for the defense had testified that Ms. Ortega had been having auditory hallucinations and struggling with bouts of deep depression since she was a teenager in the Dominican Republic.\n\nBut Mr. Khadivi said those hallucinations were ones any person might have, since she reported hearing them when she was asleep or falling asleep. He pointed out that she had been able to attend college, work and continue with her regular activities.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s hard to imagine you\u2019re an honor student playing volleyball while having a major depressive episode with psychosis,\u201d he said. \u201cWhen it comes to explaining psychotic symptoms, she shows considerable unreliability and gross inconsistency most consistent with feigning.\u201d", "title": "In Video Interview, Nanny Denied Hearing Commands to Murder Children", "authors": ["Jan Ransom"]} {"date": "2018-04-26 00:00:00", "text": "It would create a 10-day window within which a special counsel could petition a panel of judges to determine if the firing was for good cause. If it were judged not to have been, the counsel would be reinstated. The bill would ensure that the special counsel\u2019s staff and investigative materials would be preserved in the interim.\n\nThe senators also voted to include an amendment by Mr. Grassley that would require special counsels to produce to the attorney general and to Congress a report at the end of their investigation or in the event that they are fired. Such a report would include significant findings of the case, as well as information about decisions to file charges or not to file charges, among other details. Currently, special counsels like Mr. Mueller are required to make a report to the attorney general, but that information will not necessarily be shared with Congress or the public.\n\nThe committee voted to reject another amendment that would have replaced the bill with a nonbinding resolution saying it was the sense of the Senate that Mr. Mueller should be allowed to finish his work.\n\nSeveral Republican senators raised concerns about the bill\u2019s constitutionality and the ability of Congress to shield a special prosecutor from being fired by the attorney general at the president\u2019s direction.\n\nCongress, in the wake of the Watergate scandal, created the position of an independent counsel who answered to a panel of judges, not to the attorney general. The Supreme Court upheld that arrangement in 1988. But after the Iran-contra and Whitewater investigations, both parties came to view the position as far too powerful, and Congress let the independent counsel statute lapse in 1999.\n\nMr. Grassley said he shared some of the constitutional concerns, but gave the bill his stamp of approval anyway.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s possible the bill goes too far, and I understand the position of those with strong constitutional objections who will vote against it,\u201d Mr. Grassley said ahead of the vote on Thursday. \u201cBut, at the very least, if my amendment is adopted, it will require the executive branch to give more information to Congress.\u201d", "title": "In Warning to Trump, Senators Advance Bill to Protect Mueller", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-05 00:00:00", "text": "Eric L.
