It appears to me that when I use bar soap exclusively, the shower drain gets clogged, while it stays open when I use liquid soaps. Why would this be?\n\nA. Plumbers would agree with this observation, especially when the water supply is \u201chard,\u201d meaning that it contains chemicals, usually calcium or magnesium, that react with those in bar soap to yield scum.\n\nHard and soft soaps are each produced differently. In a process called saponification, an alkali is used to cause changes in animal or vegetable fats, leaving behind soap and glycerol.\n\n\n\nIf the alkali is sodium hydroxide, the result is a hard soap, relatively difficult to dissolve. Potassium hydroxide, on the other hand, produces an easily soluble soft soap.", "title": "In Your Bathroom, the Scum of the Earth", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-02 00:00:00", "text": "In the shadow of the Bruckner Expressway in the South Bronx, behind a metal fence topped with barbed wire, is a tow pound with a pivotal role in the city\u2019s campaign to close the notorious jail complex on Rikers Island.\n\nThe city plans to build a jail on the lot it owns at Concord Avenue and East 141st Street, in a residential and industrial area of the Mott Haven neighborhood. The preliminary proposal, announced in February, is a key prong in the city\u2019s plan to close Rikers and replace it with smaller, safer jails in Manhattan, Brooklyn, Queens and the Bronx.\n\nBut opposition is brewing among residents in the once-blighted neighborhood, who say the city\u2019s plan is an unwelcome step backward for the South Bronx as it works to shed its synonymity with urban decay. Residents and some elected officials, concerned about safety and quality-of-life in an area saturated with homeless shelters and methadone clinics, and near a sewage plant, said they regard the plan as an effort by the city to use their home as a dumping ground.\n\n\u201cIt doesn\u2019t belong here; a jail is the last thing we need,\u201d said Arline Parks, a resident of the Diego Beekman Apartments within a stone\u2019s throw of the lot. Ms. Parks is chief executive of the tenant-run complex, which encompasses more than 1,200 units spread among 38 prewar buildings. The nonprofit tenant group was formed in the 1990s as the South Bronx was reeling from fiscal and drug crises. Poverty and crime soared as violent gangs like the Wild Cowboys competed for turf, landlords abandoned buildings and blocks were burned down.", "title": "In a Changing South Bronx, Residents See New Jail as Step Backward", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-10 00:00:00", "text": "It is one of several key entry points that Russia is seeking to exploit, Mr. Kupchan said, as the leader of the Serb semiautonomous region known as Republika Srpska, Milorad Dodik, continues to press for an independence referendum. The others include Macedonia, where relations between ethnic Albanians and ethnic Slavs remain tense, and between Kosovo and Serbia.\n\nWary of Russian meddling, the European Union is holding out a renewed prospect of membership to Bosnia and to the other five nations of the Western Balkans \u2014 Serbia, Montenegro, Macedonia, Albania and Kosovo \u2014 in return for fundamental structural reform.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe skepticism among these countries about Brussels is deep. Many doubt the sincerity of a European Union that is turning more populist, more wary about migration and more cautious, after Romania and Bulgaria, about taking in nations before they are ready for membership.\n\nNo one believes any of these countries is yet ready to join. But the urgency for reform fell away as the goal receded.\n\nFour years ago, the head of the European Commission, Jean-Claude Juncker, said there would be no more quick enlargement of the bloc, sending the process into somnolence.\n\nIt has been, as the Macedonian foreign minister, Nikola Dimitrov, often says, like \u201cbeing locked in a waiting room with no exit.\u201d\n\n\u201cJuncker made a mistake to say that he was not interested in enlargement,\u201d said Carl Bildt, a former Swedish foreign minister and United Nations special envoy to the Balkans. \u201cThe E.U. took its eye off the ball for several years, with detrimental effects.\u201d\n\nBut with Britain leaving the bloc and Russia playing on the fissures of the region, the European Union has now laid out a relatively detailed plan for the Balkans.\n\nIt has even gone on record to say that if all goes well, Serbia and Montenegro, the only two countries now engaged in an accession process and hence the front-runners, could join by 2025.\n\nThe bloc\u2019s strategy for the Western Balkans, published in February, laid out six initiatives: rule of law; security and migration; socio-economic development; transport and energy connectivity; digital agenda; and \u201creconciliation and good neighborly relations.\u201d", "title": "In a New Cold War With Russia, Balkans Become a Testing Ground", "authors": ["Steven Erlanger"]} {"date": "2018-04-10 00:00:00", "text": "Roughly 94 percent of Parliament is of Anglo-Celtic or European heritage, making the body more white than the United States Congress (where 19 percent of lawmakers identify as racial or ethnic minorities) and the British Parliament (where 8 percent of the House of Commons and around 6 percent of the House of Lords do).\n\nAmong Australia\u2019s federal and state government department heads, the homogeneity is even more pronounced: 99 percent of the leadership is Anglo-Celtic or European.\n\n\u201cThe statistics are frankly dismal,\u201d said Tim Soutphommasane, Australia\u2019s race discrimination commissioner and the lead author of the report. \u201cThese are not what you\u2019d expect from one of the world\u2019s greatest multicultural countries.\u201d\n\nDr. Soutphommasane, a political philosopher with a Ph.D from the University of Oxford who was born in France and raised in Sydney, said the new report goes beyond a 2016 study that first tried to assess multiculturalism in the country. Researchers went beyond the chief executive level, for example, to look at those who might be on the rise in Australian corporations.\n\nDr. Soutphommasane (pronounced Soot-pom-ma-sarn) said he had hoped that would show greater diversity. But the second corporate tier was nearly as homogeneous as the first.\n\n\u201cTime alone isn\u2019t going to lead to significant change,\u201d he said.\n\nRather, the report says, Australia needs to confront the fact that its promise of egalitarianism faces barriers like prejudice.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Subscribe to the Australia Letter Newsletter Damien Cave, our new Australia bureau chief, shares insights on global news, local recommendations and feedback from readers in this weekly newsletter. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nAustralia could start by collecting data more rigorously, Dr. Soutphommasane and other scholars argue. It has already mandated more reporting around gender, and race and ethnicity could follow. Such questions could be incorporated into the census, and employers could be required to report diversity statistics, much as American companies with more than 100 employees do.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMany of those who have broken through Australia\u2019s barriers to reach senior positions argue that more also needs to be done at human and institutional levels.\n\nDr. Anne Aly, one of few members of Parliament from a non-European background (she was born in Egypt), said that Australia\u2019s political leaders needed to become more comfortable with being challenged about their biases and cultural blind spots \u2014 and with the fact that Australia is more a part of Asia than Europe.\n\nShe added that political parties and the Australian news media needed to be more inclusive of non-European voices, and not just on issues like immigration or crime.\n\n\u201cYou get pushed into these conversations about language and immigration and population levels because they\u2019re the only conversations we\u2019re included in \u2014 the problem conversations,\u201d she said.\n\nWithout diversity in broader discussions, she added, \u201cWhat you end up with are policies that marginalize and exclude a significant part of the population.\u201d\n\nAustralia\u2019s Indigenous leaders have made a similar argument for years, most recently with a proposal to add an Indigenous advisory body to Parliament. The plan was rejected in October.\n\nSome business leaders argue for a less confrontational approach.\n\nVivek Bhatia, the chief executive of the Australia and New Zealand operations of QBE Insurance, said he sees measuring diversity in positions of power as just the first stage of a evolution.\n\n\u201cDiversity is being invited to the party,\u201d he said. \u201cInclusiveness is being asked to dance.\u201d\n\nDr. Soutphommasane said that progress could ultimately depend on deeper connections and conversations.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nPart of the reason there has been so little progress in Australia, he said, is that the country \u2014 like many others \u2014 is still learning to talk about differences, biases and how to incorporate multiculturalism into its national identity.\n\n\u201cThe default for many Australians is still colorblindness,\u201d he said, \u201can insistence that we don\u2019t see ethnic or racial difference and moreover we should not point out ethnic or racial difference \u2014 and that stifles examination and prevents Australians from taking more muscular action on multiculturalism.\u201d\n\n\u201cWe don\u2019t quite have the language or sophistication to talk about this with tact and sensitivity,\u201d he added.", "title": "In a Proudly Diverse Australia, White People Still Run Almost Everything", "authors": ["Damien Cave"]} {"date": "2018-04-24 00:00:00", "text": "And then there is Jacqueline Rose\u2019s own new book, \u201cMothers: An Essay on Love and Cruelty,\u201d a sort of Rosetta Stone for the moment that examines the particular mix of fascination and dread that mothers engender.\n\nPhoto\n\nRose is a calm and stylish writer whose rangy essays in the London Review of Books on violence and identity, #MeToo, the trial of Oscar Pistorius and other subjects have become indispensable reading during the current reckoning around power and sexuality. She has written at length about Sylvia Plath, Hannah Arendt and Marilyn Monroe, as well as several books on Zionism and the conflict in the Middle East. Her specialties are personalities and philosophies that attract (sometimes court) extreme idealization and revulsion. These larger-than-life figures bear our projections and our fears, she says, and allow us to maintain a fantasy of innocence in our own lives.\n\nHow appropriate, then, is this turn to motherhood \u2014 that site in the culture \u201cwhere we lodge, or rather bury, the reality of our own conflicts, of what it means to be fully human,\u201d Rose writes. \u201cIt is the ultimate scapegoat for our personal and political failings, for everything that is wrong with the world, which it becomes the task \u2014 unrealizable, of course \u2014 of mothers to repair.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThese aren\u2019t original points; this scapegoat argument in particular is one that has been made about every minority group you can imagine (it\u2019s also the premise of Toni Morrison\u2019s superb \u201cPlaying in the Dark: Whiteness and the Literary Imagination\u201d). But \u201cMothers\u201d is a useful synthesis of and loving engagement with many of the writers who have shaped our thinking on motherhood \u2014 Morrison, Simone de Beauvoir and Adrienne Rich, whose unsurpassed \u201cOf Woman Born\u201d (1976) is a template for Rose. \u201cMothers\u201d follows the same arc, arguing for the radical potentialities in motherhood, how women\u2019s initiation into the relentless, often invisible labor of caretaking produces not the solipsistic, bourgeois creature of myth but something close to the ideal citizen \u2014 more responsive to the community and naturally inclusive.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMothers \u201care not in flight from the anguish of what it means to be human,\u201d Rose writes. She quotes Julia Kristeva: \u201cTo be a mother, to give birth, is to welcome a foreigner, which makes mothering simply \u2018the most intense form of contact with the strangeness of the one close to us and of ourselves.\u2019\u201d\n\nIsn\u2019t it pretty to think so? Recent books on motherhood, however, frequently and sometimes unwittingly, illustrate a different phenomenon: how motherhood dissolves the border of the self but shores up, often violently, the walls between classes of women.\n\n\u201cSome problems we share as women, some we do not,\u201d Audre Lorde wrote in an essay addressed to white feminists in 1984. \u201cYou fear your children will grow up to join the patriarchy and testify against you, we fear our children will be dragged from a car and shot down in the street, and you will turn your backs upon the reasons they are dying.\u201d\n\nRose acknowledges this issue: \u201cSolidarity among mothers, across class and ethnic boundaries, is not something Western cultures seem in any hurry to promote.\u201d But so many of these books (almost all of them are by white, middle-class women) seem wary of, if not outright disinterested in, more deeply engaging with how race and class inflect the experience of motherhood. Thrillers and horror, the genres that serve as our cultural unconscious, are left to pick up the slack; \u201cmom thrillers\u201d so often hinge on the anxieties of child care and racial privilege.\n\nThese omissions are especially troubling because the rift between mothers is only growing. The fastest growing pay gap is between black women and white women. And research shows that regardless of class, black mothers and babies are more than twice as likely to die than their white counterparts \u2014 a gulf that has grown since slavery, and which researchers attribute to the lifelong stresses of enduring racism.\n\n\u201cLook at me,\u201d the author of every new book on motherhood asks us. We should \u2014 and how could we not? Each testimony is valuable. But it\u2019s with a strange pleasure that the reader will realize that so many of the taboos these writers hope to shatter \u2014 about the ambivalence of motherhood, for example \u2014 are, by now, familiar. The real work, the daring work, might be for these mothers to look at each other.", "title": "In a Raft of New Books, Motherhood From (Almost) Every Angle", "authors": ["Parul Sehgal", "Books Of The Times"]} {"date": "2018-04-11 00:00:00", "text": "A judge\u2019s pet peeve about lawyers saying \u201cO.K.\u201d was one of several reasons the state Commission on Judicial Conduct recommended on Wednesday that he be removed from his seat on the New York City Civil Court in Queens.\n\nIn a rare decision, the commission found that the judge, Terrence C. O\u2019Connor, the son of a former district attorney, habitually mistreated lawyers, abused his power and failed to follow the law.\n\nBeyond those infractions, the commission cited the judge for failing to cooperate with its investigation, refusing to take an oath to the tell the truth to investigators and then failing to show up to a disciplinary hearing.\n\n\u201cJudges are obliged to cooperate with official disciplinary inquiries into their behavior,\u201d the commission\u2019s administrator, Robert H. Tembeckjian, said in a statement. \u201cFailing to cooperate, and acting in a manner intended to thwart an ethics inquiry, is itself misconduct, often more serious than the underlying behavior. Judge O\u2019Connor was removed from office for his intransigence.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nJudge O\u2019Connor, who was elected in 2009 and whose term ends in December, has a month to appeal the decision to the state Court of Appeals. The high court has the final say on whether Judge O\u2019Connor remains in office, but is required to follow the commission\u2019s determination if he does not appeal.", "title": "In a Rare Step, Commission Recommends Removal of Queens Judge", "authors": ["James C. Mckinley Jr."]} {"date": "2018-04-11 00:00:00", "text": "BEIRUT, Lebanon \u2014 For two days and a night, the computer science student had been huddling with his family in the basement of their apartment building as pro-government forces rained bombs down on their rebel-held Syrian town.\n\nAfter night fell, they heard the whirring of helicopter blades followed by the whistling sounds of objects falling from the sky. Chemicals!\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-19 00:00:00", "text": "A Boycott America plan could be much tougher to pull off.\n\nWhile competition from Chinese-made smartphones is rising, iPhones remain popular. Shopping mall developers, eager for the extra cachet, clamor for Starbucks to open stores. Nike dominates the sportswear market in China. Chevrolet is one of the country\u2019s most popular brands.\n\nPhoto\n\nAnd notably, many of those products are made by Chinese workers. Factories in China assemble iPhones, stitch up Nike apparel and footwear and make Chevrolets and Fords. It isn\u2019t clear how many jobs this creates, but the American Chamber of Commerce in China said that more than one-third of its 800-plus member companies have more than 1,000 employees in the country.\n\n\u201cChina needs the U.S., the U.S. needs China,\u201d said Max Baucus, a former United States ambassador to China. \u201cWe are joined at the hip economically.\u201d\n\nThe United States has also supplied much of the investment underpinning China\u2019s economic growth. Between 1990 and 2017, America pumped more than $250 billion into China, according to a report by the Rhodium Group and the National Committee on United States-China Relations.\n\n\u201cThe U.S. multinationals have been playing a very critical part of China\u2019s development story, providing investment, technology, brands,\u201d said Erlend Ek, trade research manager of China Policy, a Beijing-based advisory firm. \u201cThey have a very good relationship with each other.\u201d\n\nThere\u2019s another reason that Beijing may be reluctant to try a boycott: American multinationals are aiding the Chinese government in some important projects. IBM and Walmart, for example, are collaborating with the e-commerce company JD.com and Tsinghua University to improve food safety in China, a priority for Beijing.\n\nThat isn\u2019t to say that the idea is off the table.\n\nThe Global Times, a nationalist tabloid controlled by the People\u2019s Daily, the Communist Party\u2019s official newspaper, warned that a \u201cpeople\u2019s war\u201d could be waged against the United States. That Could Backfire.", "authors": ["Sui-Lee Wee", "Zhang Tiantian"]} {"date": "2018-04-28 00:00:00", "text": "Unlike some of Mr. Trump\u2019s previous rallies, which were part lobbying for Republican candidates, part freewheeling return to fiery campaign speeches, this rally was solely for him: indulging in a greatest hits of triumphs and grievances in front of a crowd of autoworkers, farmers and others.\n\nCrowded on the AstroTurf of a sports complex, supporters chanted \u201cLock her up\u201d at the mention of Hillary Clinton, booed every reference to a Democrat, and chanted \u201cNobel\u201d when the president boasted that he deserved virtually all the credit for the historic summit meeting between Kim Jong-un of North Korea and President Moon Jae-in of South Korea on Friday.\n\nWhile the two leaders agreed to pursue a peace treaty and work toward ridding the peninsula of nuclear weapons, experts have warned that it is unclear whether Mr. Kim is sincere about giving up his nuclear arsenal or is instead leveraging the talks for relief from severe economic sanctions. But Mr. Trump claimed to have made more progress in the longstanding conflict than anyone ever had.\n\n\u201cWhat do you think President Trump has to do with it?\u201d Mr. Trump said, paraphrasing a newscast earlier this week.\n\n\u201cI\u2019ll tell you what,\u201d he answered to roaring applause. \u201cEverything.\u201d\n\nBut even as Mr. Trump lauded the success of the tax cuts passed last year and the impact of his push to roll back regulations, he often descended into a darker portrait of the country. He returned repeatedly to the theme of immigration, asserting that the country was being overwhelmed by migrants coming into the country illegally.\n\nBut at the same time he railed against weak borders and \u201ccorrupt\u201d laws, he advocated allowing in \u201cguest workers\u201d to take jobs that are hard to fill with unemployment so low, particularly to help farmers.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cWe\u2019re going to have your guest workers,\u201d he told the crowd. \u201cBut then they have to go out.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIt was the most striking example of the dueling visions of America that Mr. Trump toggled between during his rally. Now the tourism industry is focusing on empowerment, with new tours and programs designed specifically for women travelers .\n\nOn March 8 \u2014 International Women\u2019s Day 2018 \u2014 Exodus Travels, a London-based adventure tourism operator, launched a series of all-female departures to locations as diverse as Iran, Myanmar and the French Riviera. The guided tours, which range from eight days to just over two weeks, cost an average of $2,500 and will pair groups of 4 to 16 women with local female guides on high-adrenaline itineraries.\n\n\u201cTravel is a male-dominated profession, so it\u2019s very important to us that we hire female guides, which also helps educate the community in the places that we visit on the importance of females in the workplace,\u201d said Robin Brooks, Exodus Travels\u2019 marketing and public relations manager. \u201cWomen are feeling more empowered than ever and we wanted to be a part of that.\u201d\n\nIntrepid Travel, an adventure travel operator focused on small-group itineraries, also chose International Women\u2019s Day this year to respond to the #MeToo movement with its own line of female-only tours. The operator is launching three specialized itineraries for women only \u2014 to Morocco, Iran and Jordan \u2014 which promise to deliver a \u201csense of sisterhood\u201d to travelers while they explore sites like the foothills of Azourki, Persepolis and the Dead Sea.", "title": "In an Era of Empowerment, More Trips for Women", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-13 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cWe could have gone further,\u201d he added. \u201cIt\u2019s a disappointment.\u201d\n\nThe proposed law would make it possible for minors under 15 who have intercourse to prove that an adult took advantage of them, that they did not consent and that therefore they were raped. It would also extend the statute of limitations for bringing rape charges to 30 years from 20.\n\nFrance\u2019s law prohibiting adults from having sexual contact with minors under 15 carries penalties of up to five years in prison and a fine of 75,000 euros, about $92,000. The new law would increase the penalty to 10 years in prison and a fine of 150,000 euros, about $184,000.\n\nThe legislation could be amended when it is debated in Parliament in mid-May.\n\nThe problems with how France prosecutes sexual violence involving minors go beyond the wording of any laws, jurists and legal experts say.\n\nRape charges can take as many as eight years or more to go to trial and are heard by juries, who tend to judge women and girls more harshly than do magistrates or judges who hear cases involving the lesser crimes of sexual contact and sexual assault.\n\nAnd it is common to see the character of the girls or women (or in smaller numbers, boys) put on trial, rather than the actions of the men.\n\nThe result is that lawyers for rape victims who are minors often accept a lesser charge \u2014 like one of sexual contact or sexual assault that does not include rape \u2014 to avoid having the client further traumatized by having to testify before a jury and potentially seeing the attacker acquitted.\n\nThere is such frequent bias against the women and girls on the part of juries that convictions can be almost impossible, unless \u201cyou have a client who is as white as a goose,\u201d said Ms. Durrieu Diebolt, the lawyer for Sarah, the 11-year-old in the Pontoise case. (The girl has been widely identified in the news media by the given name Sarah, but her full name has been withheld.)", "title": "In the #MeToo Era, France Struggles With Sexual Crimes Involving Minors", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-20 00:00:00", "text": "The Cleveland Cavaliers, with an assist from a New York-based designer, made their first big play on Friday night just by entering the arena. As they paraded into Bankers Life Fieldhouse in Indianapolis before Game 3 of their playoff series with the Indiana Pacers, the Cavaliers wore coordinated ensembles: made-to-measure suits, ties, shoes, bags and eyewear by Thom Browne.\n\nThe scheme was hatched a while ago by Dwyane Wade and Browne, then kept alive by LeBron James after Wade was traded back to the Miami Heat in February.\n\n\u201cAll of us suiting up together was just a new idea and something we all wanted to try,\u201d James, a four-time winner of the league\u2019s Most Valuable Player Award, wrote in an email.\n\nFor players at the top of the professional basketball food chain, just showing up has become an opportunity to preen. No matter that the corridors may be lined with trash cans. The walk from the team bus to the locker room is a runway, with attendant paparazzi.", "title": "In the N.B.A., a Game of Clothes Horse", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-08 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cGuys have different ways of collecting and different reasons for collecting,\u201d Ronnie Price, a 12-year N.B.A. veteran, said. \u201cI don\u2019t think that it\u2019s as big of a secret as it used to be. I think guys are into learning more about their world. Because basketball players have an extremely creative mind and I think most basketball players you see with tattoos, they appreciate art. They have art all over their body.\u201d\n\nSo what was once a small niche of N.B.A. collectors has flourished into something larger. Numbers are difficult to come by, but Price estimated that two players on each team he\u2019s played for \u2014 he\u2019s been with Sacramento, Utah, Phoenix, Portland, Orlando and the Los Angeles Lakers \u2014 have had collections. And in the middle, serving as a liaison to the art world, is the longtime New Yorker Gardy St. Fleur.\n\nPhoto\n\nBorn in Port-au-Prince, St. Fleur grew up with art as a central part of his life. His father collected Haitian masters and commissioned work for local artists. His family moved to Brooklyn when he was a child, and St. Fleur spent his adolescence and early adulthood learning from artists. He befriended Ionel Talpazan, the New York City artist famous for painting extraterrestrial life, worked as a studio manager for Villalongo and, he said, regularly grabbed coffee with Emmanuel Benador, an art dealer.\n\nAnd he became just as interested in the artists as in their work.\n\n\u201cWhy do they do the things that they do?\u201d he said. \u201cFascinated with the way they think. As I get more information from them, I gravitate closer and closer to them. That helps me understand a little more.\u201d\n\nAfter a job out of college working in e-commerce, St. Fleur decided to follow his passion. Villalongo introduced him to Peggy Cooper Cafritz, who had a prestigious African-American art collection, and she gave him an assignment: Help her find new artists who were finishing graduate school.\n\nNot long afterward, he decided to push into the art business full time. And from there came his involvement in the N.B.A. ecosystem, a relationship built in part from the days when St. Fleur would hang around the Rucker Park and West Fourth Street basketball courts in Manhattan, meeting people who eventually became player agents. Getting to know Deron Williams, the former Nets guard, became fruitful, too. Williams was looking to build an art collection, not just acquire a few pieces.\n\nSo St. Fleur got involved, and soon his name began to hopscotch around the league.\n\nHe has worked with Houston Rockets forward P. J. Tucker, Hall of Famer Alonzo Mourning and Yankees pitcher C. C. Sabathia, among others, he said. Knicks guard Courtney Lee was connected with him through the team, St. Fleur said, after he had previously built a relationship with Carmelo Anthony, the former Knicks star. N.B.A. veteran Dahntay Jones started talking to St. Fleur about art while he was working out at Manhattan\u2019s Sky gym last summer, where Anthony held his popular \u201cHoodie Melo\u201d scrimmages.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nIn his work, St. Fleur has tried to be as much teacher as salesman. He introduces athletes to artists, trying to break through the intimidation that affects some players. St. Fleur sends out newsletters to enlighten players, ships books to display different artists and styles, and texts photos of works to players if he believes one or more of them might be interested. Sometimes, he\u2019s there to caution a player against overpaying.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nYou don\u2019t need millions to buy art, he often says.\n\nWhen Jay-Z released his latest album, \u201c4:44,\u201d St. Fleur was flooded with text messages. A song, \u201cThe Story of O. J.,\u201d with its references to buying artwork, had served as a jolt to some players, reinforcing what St. Fleur had been telling them for years: that art can also be an investment and a way for generations to create something to pass down.\n\n\u201cWhen guys start understanding the history of families collecting,\u201d St. Fleur said, \u201cmaybe it can be bigger than sports and who I am.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nThis evolution all took a while. In the mid-1990s, when Perry was in the middle of his N.B.A. career, he was virtually alone as he started his collection.\n\nHe had turned to art almost by accident. In 1996, Perry was seated next to Darrell Walker, the former Knicks guard, on a long flight to Japan for an exhibition tour led by Charles Barkley. Walker asked him if he knew anything about art.\n\nHe did not.\n\nThe next season, Walker began helping Perry explore. When Perry came to New York, Walker called with instructions on which gallery to visit. When he went to Boston, Walker recommended a studio. Perry got to be so insatiable that he would arrive in a new city, drop his bags in his hotel room and go studio-hopping to find new works. He began reading, too, learning about Renaissance artists and American painters who emerged in the 1930s with the support of the federal Works Progress Administration.\n\nStill, it took a year until Perry was comfortable enough to buy his first piece. Entering the art world had been overwhelming.\n\nAt first, Perry built a collection from works by African-American artists. Motivated by a quote in a catalog he had received at a showing of works owned by Walter O. Evans, a renowned African-American collector, Perry later decided to purchase only work from artists he could meet in person, get to know and support. He called Walker the day he decided to take that approach.\n\n\u201cThis is a journey,\u201d said Perry, who is now a limited partner and executive with the Memphis Grizzlies. \u201cEven though you have the resources, that doesn\u2019t mean anything. You still want to take your time. You want to buy the right pieces. You\u2019re going to make some mistakes, but that\u2019s part of the journey.\u201d\n\nThe heightened interest in art from N.B.A. players would seem to dovetail with their increased influence on American culture. And it has made art something of a conversation starter in N.B.A. locker rooms, where, not long ago, Lee, Michael Beasley and Jarrett Jack of the Knicks were discussing kre8artafax, an artist they discovered on Instagram.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cHe\u2019s like a basketball player,\u201d Dahntay Jones said of kre8artafax. \u201cHe feels something every time he starts painting, so that\u2019s just passion in its purest form. That\u2019s part of what we do \u2014 passion about our game.\u201d", "title": "In the N.B.A., the Court and the Canvas Are Increasingly Intertwined", "authors": ["Mike Vorkunov"]} {"date": "2018-04-18 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nWhen I arrive at the Dumbo, Brooklyn building where the artist Elliott Puckette keeps a studio, it\u2019s as if I\u2019ve traveled back in time \u2014 to, say, 1989, when Puckette first rented the Pearl Street space and the building was still a working paper factory. Warped wooden floorboards creak under my feet, and exposed pipes and electrical wiring line the unfinished hallway. It smells of paint and turpentine. The contrast to the sleek, granite-floored lobby is striking. \u201cThey\u2019re renovating the building in the most absurd way, floor-by-floor,\u201d she explains good-naturedly. \u201cEventually I\u2019m getting kicked out.\u201d\n\nIt\u2019s a few weeks before Puckette\u2019s upcoming show, \u201cNew Work,\u201d at Paul Kasmin Gallery, and I expect to interrupt the artist in somewhat of a frenzied state, paint-spattered and anxious. Instead, she is serene. Dressed neatly in a short white skirt and red V-neck sweater (not, she confirms, her painting clothes), her blonde hair in a French twist and a silk scarf knotted around her neck, Puckette looks more like a gallery owner than an artist. She has the erect posture and gently turned out feet of a ballet dancer and, as we enter her studio, the air of a straight-A student who finished the assignment long ago.\n\nPhoto\n\nPuckette has good reason to be at ease. This is her eighth solo show with Kasmin, which first exhibited her work shortly after she earned her B.F.A. from Cooper Union in 1989. \u201cHe has been very good to me all these years,\u201d she says of the dealer, \u201cand he knows to just leave me alone.\u201d\n\nA bit like her top-floor studio, which has resisted the insistent creep of luxury Brooklyn redevelopment, Puckette makes paintings today much like she did 25 years ago. She layers her large-scale square and rectangular boards with thick coats of gesso. Initially, she made the gesso herself from rabbit-skin glue and whiting, a traditional method she learned while studying old master techniques at Cooper. When this recipe started to affect her asthma, she developed her own variation using white kaolin clay. Once the surface has hardened, she applies a translucent wash of ink \u2014 lately, in muted shades of gray, black-blue and very deep purple. \u201cI have a weird relationship with color,\u201d she says. \u201cIt\u2019s always sort of an afterthought.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAt top of mind has always been the line, Puckette\u2019s career-long fascination. She doesn\u2019t know, she says, why it intrigues her. But more than color or form, the line is both central formal element and subject \u2014 mapped out with chalk and then painstakingly etched into the surface of her pieces with a single-edge razor blade.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cI always start on the upper left-hand corner,\u201d says Puckette, \u201cas if I was writing.\u201d We\u2019re standing with our faces inches from \u201cLove Letter,\u201d a 15-foot-long triptych that is the largest piece in the upcoming show. A tangle of wavering, looping marks wends its way across the three panels. To demonstrate, Puckette scoops up a stray razor from the floor (\u201cI tried to clean up!\u201d) and begins lightly scratching at a section of line. Watching her work, it\u2019s clear that what appears, from a distance, to be a strong line carving a single path is, in fact, made up of thousands of tiny marks.", "title": "In the Studio With an Artist Devoted to the Line", "authors": ["Merrell Hambleton"]} {"date": "2018-04-18 00:00:00", "text": "But that rightward tug has more to do with gerrymandering and cynical pols than with demographics. The state is becoming more urban and less white. \u201cIt should be as reliably blue as California,\u201d Wright says. \u201cInstead, it is the Red Planet in the political universe.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nWright rattles off the familiar stereotypes: \u201ccowboy individualism, a kind of wary friendliness, superpatriotism combined with defiance of all government authority, a hair-trigger sense of grievance, nostalgia for an ersatz past that is largely an artifact of Hollywood.\u201d He concedes they\u2019re all true. But they\u2019re not all there is. \u201cGod Save Texas\u201d also depicts \u201ca culture that is still raw, not fully formed, standing on the margins but also growing in influence, dangerous and magnificent in its potential.\u201d\n\nThe book rambles far and wide, and it\u2019s a testament to Wright\u2019s formidable storytelling skills that a reader will encounter plenty of information without ever feeling lost. A bride and groom emerging from a chapel leads to a disquisition on the Spanish conquistadors and the explorer Cabeza de Vaca; a chapter on Texas radio turns into a discussion of Texas gun laws and a consideration of Texas snakes.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cIt sometimes seems that every living thing can bite or poke or sting or shoot you,\u201d Wright says of the state where he lives. He has a deep knowledge of the terrain; he has been hoarding details over a lifetime, consulting history books, his reporter\u2019s notes, his own memories and what one imagines is a massive clippings file of truly strange stuff.\n\nPoliticians offer up much by way of raw, often confounding, material. Sometimes all Wright has to do is relay the facts, arranged just so, and the hypocrisies come shining through. Describing the Republicans\u2019 obsession with their failed \u201cbathroom bill,\u201d which would have forced transgender people to use the restroom that corresponded with the sex on their birth certificates, his deadpan delivery cuts deep: \u201cAttorney General Ken Paxton, who is under indictment for securities fraud, added, \u2018This is a spiritual war.\u2019\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nOther details showcase what Wright calls the \u201cburlesque side\u201d to Texas politics, which sometimes finds its way to the national stage. Wright recalls the 2016 video of Sen. Ted Cruz wrapping a strip of bacon around the barrel of an AR-15, pulling the trigger, peeling the bacon off the smoking gun and eating it with a plastic fork. \u201cThe object of the video apparently was to show a jollier and more human side of the candidate,\u201d he writes, knowing he doesn\u2019t have to say more than that; the senator, the bacon and the gun have done all the work.\n\nBut the book isn\u2019t only about current affairs, and Wright \u2014 who was born in Oklahoma and moved to Abilene, Tex., as a child in the 1950s \u2014 weaves in his own intimate history with the state. He fled Texas after high school, doing \u201ceverything I could to cleanse myself of its influence.\u201d\n\nThat influence included its long shadow of racism. In 1845, the bankrupt Texas Republic chose to be annexed by the United States as a slave state; the alternative was a bailout from the British, which would have preserved Texas\u2019s independence but required it to switch to a system of non-slave wage labor. Texas, at this crossroad and others, chose slavery every time.\n\nWright has ancestors who fought for the Confederacy. In Abilene, he kept a portrait of General Robert E. Lee on his bedroom wall. He would later cover the civil rights movement for The Race Relations Reporter in Nashville. \u201cI still feel ashamed of the prejudices that I struggled to shed,\u201d he writes. He doesn\u2019t say much here about that struggle, though in his 1987 memoir, \u201cIn the New World,\u201d he explores his Texas upbringing with vulnerability and candor.\n\nSince returning to Texas in 1980, Wright has lived in Austin, the state capital that serves as a scapegoat for state lawmakers, who routinely attack the city in showy attempts to establish their conservative bona fides. They\u2019re almost as fixated on Austin as they are on California. To them, as Wright puts it, \u201cAustin is a spore of the California fungus that is destroying America.\u201d\n\nWright doesn\u2019t counter the moral panic with moral panic. His tone is gentle, occasionally chiding, and he seems most comfortable in the center lane, allowing the road hogs to pass by while he holds steady at the wheel.\n\nCertain readers might crave more righteous anger from someone writing about Texas, especially now, when there\u2019s little room for agreement and plenty at stake. But Wright\u2019s project is perspective, not conquest. In a chapter on Texas culture, he praises the work of contemporary artists who have returned to their Texas roots \u201cwith knowledge, self-confidence, and occasionally, forgiveness.\u201d \u201cGod Save Texas\u201d is his vivid bid to do the same.", "title": "In \u2018God Save Texas,\u2019 Lawrence Wright Ranges Far and Wide", "authors": ["Jennifer Szalai", "Books Of The Times"]} {"date": "2018-04-19 00:00:00", "text": "In 2014, Denzel Washington took over Edward Woodward\u2019s \u201980s TV role as the retired spy turned revenge specialist Robert McCall for a big-screen version of \u201cThe Equalizer.\u201d The film earned $192 million worldwide. Now he\u2019s back in \u201cThe Equalizer 2,\u201d which has just released its first trailer, and \u2014 stop us if you\u2019ve heard this one before \u2014 this time, it\u2019s personal.\n\nAfter his friend and fellow former operative (Melissa Leo) is murdered by C.I.A.-trained assassins, McCall vows, \u201cI\u2019m going to kill each and every one of them, and the only disappointment is that I only get to do it once.\u201d Cut to scenes of guns blazing and bones snapping.", "title": "In \u2018The Equalizer 2\u2019 Trailer, Denzel Washington Travels the Globe", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-26 00:00:00", "text": "Melissa Broder wanted to meet underneath the fiberglass whale.\n\n\u201cI am #dtw (down to whale),\u201d the 38-year-old writer wrote, suggesting a rendezvous in the Hall of Ocean Life, at the American Museum of Natural History in Manhattan. She thought being surrounded by ancient marine specimens might be generative when it came to discussing her new novel, \u201cThe Pisces.\u201d\n\nThe book, due out May 1, tells the story of a catatonically depressed woman named Lucy, also 38, who slumps around modern-day Venice Beach, Calif., aimless and alone. Unable to complete her dissertation on Sappho and dazed after a messy breakup, Lucy agrees to dog-sit for her sister who lives near the beach, hoping the brackish Pacific breeze might enliven her spirits. Instead, she gets the itch to toss herself into the ocean. One night, she crawls onto a jagged rock jutting out into the sea foam, but before she can jump into the waves, she meets a comely young surfer. His name is Theo, and soon the two are meeting regularly under the stars \u2014 she on the rock, he always bobbing in the ocean. Lucy begins to wonder why she has never seen him out of the water, or even from the waist down. Then, the truth emerges: Theo is a merman. Yes, an actual merman, with flippers, who has been alive for centuries. The love between a human woman and a sea-bound man echoes the plotline of the recent Oscar-winning film \u201cThe Shape of Water,\u201d but Ms. Broder infuses her narrative with a sardonic, youthful twist.\n\nIt made sense, then, that Ms. Broder would want to meet underneath a gargantuan sea creature as she was passing through town. She currently lives in Los Angeles \u2014 with her husband and a rescue dog named Pickle \u2014 but she was determined for us to have an oceanic adventure. Unfortunately, we could only view the leviathan from behind a velvet rope at the museum, as a private event was in progress. As we walked through the beige hallways filled with artifacts, Ms. Broder\u2019s sense of humor began to emerge. \u201cAt least you can say we got whale adjacent,\u201d she said, as we strolled through the dioramas of African mammals.\n\nAnyone already familiar with her work as a poet and essayist would not be shocked to find that Ms. Broder radiates an immediate, cozy candor. In 2012, then living in New York and working as a book publicist at Penguin, she started an anonymous Twitter account called So Sad Today. While she had been publishing poetry for years under her own name, she decided to hide behind an avatar so that she could have an unfettered medium through which to confront her anxieties at a safe distance. On the account she posts crystalline koans about depression and self-doubt (sample tweets: \u201cmy thighs have never not touched\u201d; \u201cin a threesome with anxiety and depression\u201d). It quickly grew into a viral sensation, with over half a million followers and a book deal with Grand Central Publishing.\n\nIn order to do a press tour for \u201cSo Sad Today,\u201d her frank, sly book of essays from 2016 about mental health, internet addiction and the complexities of female friendship, she decided to reveal herself in an interview with Rolling Stone. \u201cI was like, \u2018Am I ever going to be respected as a poet again?\u2019\u201d she told Rolling Stone about coming clean. Instead, she garnered even more praise, becoming something of an overnight folk hero to women who felt isolated in their darkest insecurities. \u201cBroder\u2019s essays often left me with a sharp sense of feminine recognition,\u201d the writer Haley Mlotek wrote on The New Yorker\u2019s website. \u201cI would read her accounts of heartbreak, sexual dissatisfaction, and alienation and think, Same.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cThe topics that interest me are the things that have been going on for a really long time and are universal to all humans,\u201d Ms. Broder tells me over a light lunch (we were, of course, eating fish; I had salmon, she ordered branzino). \u201cWe\u2019re all born, we all die, a lot \u2014 most, many \u2014 of us fall in love, many of us have sex. These have always been my obsessions.\u201d", "title": "In \u2018The Pisces,\u2019 a Woman and a Merman Fall in Love. Aquatic Erotica Ensues.", "authors": ["Rachel Syme"]} {"date": "2018-04-18 00:00:00", "text": "Weiss details the tribalism within the women\u2019s movement as personified by Catt and the more militant and provocative Alice Paul, who led the National Woman\u2019s Party. Though Paul was short on money and didn\u2019t travel to Nashville for the special session, she dispatched the native Tennessean Sue Shelton White, an activist who could, with her very accent, dispel accusations about meddling outsiders. Weiss depicts another native daughter of Tennessee, this one a committed Anti: Josephine Pearson, who presided over multiple Anti groups and believed that in fighting against ratification, she was obeying both God and her deceased mother.\n\nWeiss is a clear and genial guide with an ear for telling language (\u201cI\u2019d rather see my daughter in a coffin than at the polls,\u201d declares one Anti, while a newspaper headline about a pretty, young Suff reads \u201c110 Pounds of Femininity to Hit Legislators for Vote\u201d). She also shows a superb sense of detail, and it\u2019s the deliciousness of her details that suggests certain individuals warrant entire novels of their own.\n\nFor example, Annie Nathan Meyer and Maud Nathan, New York sisters, were respectively an Anti and a Suff, who didn\u2019t speak to each other except when \u201cclashing publicly.\u201d Luke Lea, the swaggering publisher of a Nashville newspaper, a onetime senator and a member of the Men\u2019s Ratification Committee, had concocted a plan to kidnap Kaiser Wilhelm after the armistice. He abandoned the kidnapping attempt, returned to Nashville and married his dead wife\u2019s sister. Or how about Louisine Havemeyer, a grandmother who lived in a Fifth Avenue mansion in New York and used her fortune, acquired via her sugar magnate husband, to support Suff radicals and who once found herself, by design, in jail? (While participating in an effigy-burning of President Wilson outside the White House, Havemeyer said she felt \u201cas placid and calm as if I were going out to play croquet on a summer afternoon.\u201d)\n\nImage\n\nThese are just a sampling of the many characters Weiss introduces. Because of the number of major players, it can become hard to remember who is who. There\u2019s also a somewhat awkward structure to the book in that almost everything before Page 219 is back story, and in places, the back story has a back story. Routinely, a person is depicted in a specific moment \u2014 the governor of Tennessee is donning a jacket, say \u2014 then there are several pages of history before rejoining the governor, who is still donning his jacket. But storytelling, like democracy, is sometimes messy, and Weiss\u2019s thoroughness is one of the book\u2019s great strengths. So vividly had she depicted events that by the climactic vote (spoiler alert: The amendment was ratified!), I got goose bumps.\n\nI\u2019m almost certain that the name Hillary Rodham Clinton appears only once, in the last few pages. Yet it is, of course, impossible to read \u201cThe Woman\u2019s Hour\u201d without thinking of the 2016 presidential election, of the symbolic and literal impact of Clinton\u2019s candidacy, the consequences of her loss, the way she was and still is portrayed in the news media. Clinton\u2019s decision to wear the Suffs\u2019 color of white for the most important events of her campaign (and to Donald Trump\u2019s inauguration) suggests that she perceives herself as part of an ongoing legacy.", "title": "In \u2018The Woman\u2019s Hour,\u2019 the Battle Over the 19th Amendment Comes to Life", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-19 00:00:00", "text": "Infinitely elastic in its casting, this stripped-back, ultraslick production has since become the longest-running American musical in Broadway history; its 1997 London iteration bounced from one West End theater to the next before calling it quits in 2012. That closing, it turns out, was temporary: Here \u201cChicago\u201d is again, this time at the Phoenix Theater and with a newfound celebrity draw in the Oscar-winner Cuba Gooding Jr. (He and his fellow principals are contracted through June 30, with subsequent casting to be announced.)\n\nA relative theatrical neophyte with only one Broadway credit, Mr. Gooding might seem tailor-made for the assignment as the smooth-talking, press-savvy lawyer Billy Flynn. After all, he recently played O.J. Simpson in a TV mini-series whose depiction of the media circus that can be made out of the American justice system is directly prefigured by this musical\u2019s portrait of two murderous chorus girls, Roxie Hart and Velma Kelly, in 1920s Chicago.\n\nIn fact, Mr. Gooding is the least satisfying aspect of a reboot that otherwise finds Walter Bobbie\u2019s decades-old production in shape, with every swiveled hip calibrated to within an inch of the finely drilled ensemble\u2019s lives. Playing the Windy City\u2019s leading criminal lawyer in a tabloid-happy era seemingly not that different from our own, Mr. Gooding isn\u2019t called upon to dance much, and he just about survives the vocal demands of John Kander and Fred Ebb\u2019s score. More than once, you hold your breath to see if the gravelly-voiced performer will hit, and hold, the necessary note.\n\nThere are no such doubts when it comes to Mr. Gooding\u2019s colleagues, many of whom have appeared in the show before \u2014 and, in the case of Ruthie Henshall, in varying roles, as well. London\u2019s original Roxie, Ms. Henshall later played Velma and has now graduated to the smaller, if choice, part of the prison warden Mama Morton, who partners with Velma on the song \u201cClass,\u201d a paean to a bygone age when manners \u2014 remember them? \u2014 were seen to matter.\n\nOf the two leading ladies, \u201cChicago\u201d veterans both, the Belgian performer Sarah Soetaert makes for an unusually hard-edged Roxie, the Kewpie-doll killer who believes in murder as \u201can art.\u201d You don\u2019t feel, as you do with the most memorable interpreters of this part, the tremulous self-discovery that overtakes Roxie as she joins Velma when showbiz gives them a second chance.\n\nVelma, Josefina Gabrielle, is a onetime Roxie who brings to her current assignment an age-defying physicality, doing a cartwheel and the splits in quick succession. Entirely at home in the shape-shifting demands of Ann Reinking\u2019s choreography, famously patterned after Bob Fosse\u2019s original moves, Ms. Gabrielle transmits the razzle dazzle that is the title of one of the score\u2019s best songs.\n\nAnd if anyone thinks the piece itself has dated, try this query on for size: \u201cAre you going to believe what you see or what I tell you?\u201d asks Roxie\u2019s woebegone victim, a cue straight from today\u2019s \u201cfake news\u201d playbook. At a time when even the president of the United States owes a debt to reality TV, the intersection of life and showbiz celebrated by \u201cChicago\u201d nowadays seems all too real. It\u2019s good to have the show back.", "title": "In \u2018Tina: The Tina Turner Musical,\u2019 a Pop Star\u2019s Life as Victory Parade", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-24 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nSeemingly one of the only Marvel characters who\u2019s not in Disney\u2019s soon-to-be-unleashed \u201cAvengers: Infinity War,\u201d Venom is getting his own stand-alone film from Columbia Pictures. But Sony made a deal with Marvel Studios to share Spidey, which is why Tom Holland can be seen slinging webs in \u201cInfinity War.\u201d\n\nConfused yet? But long before the \u201cRing\u201d cycle, Bayreuth had another operatic visionary.\n\nWilhelmine, Margravine of Brandenburg-Bayreuth, was the eldest daughter of King Frederick William I of Prussia, and the sister of Frederick the Great. An ambitious polymath who composed music, wrote verse and corresponded with Voltaire, she built Bayreuth\u2019s intimate yet elaborate Margravial Opera House, one of the most outstanding surviving examples of Baroque theater architecture in Europe.\n\nOn Tuesday, the nearly 300-year-old opera house \u2014 a Unesco World Heritage site since 2012 \u2014 reopens to the public after a six-year renovation that cost 29.6 million euros ($36.6 million) and returned its dazzling ornamental details, murals and trompe l\u2019oeil effects to something approximating their original brilliance.", "title": "Inch by Inch, an Operatic Jewel Is Polished", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-15 00:00:00", "text": "Faced with a sprawling investigation by the special counsel in Washington, President Trump must also contend with an independent-minded office of federal prosecutors in his hometown, New York, who are investigating his longtime personal lawyer and fixer, Michael D. Berman, after Mr. Trump made an unusual request to interview him personally.\n\nSoon after assuming the Southern District post in January, Mr. Berman notified Justice Department officials in Washington of a possible appearance of conflict of interest in the then-undisclosed Cohen investigation, and officials concluded that he should be recused, according to people briefed on the matter.\n\nThe Justice Department has not specified the reason for the recusal, which left Mr. Berman\u2019s handpicked deputy, Robert S. Indian officials say the agreement could be finalized as soon as this week, with India purchasing five S-400 Triumf systems, an antiaircraft missile array that can also intercept missiles.\n\nIf the purchase goes through, the Trump administration would have to choose between punishing India for violating the sanctions or granting an exemption to avoid souring the relationship.\n\nThe United States has been trying to cultivate India as a strategic ally and a hedge against Chinese military expansion. Washington has typically dangled defense deals as a way to improve military ties with countries, and it has courted India aggressively.
