Shortly before coming to power in 2014, Prime Minister Narendra Modi positioned himself as a digital governance evangelist.\n\nA few months into his tenure, the Indian government began using biometric devices to tell on government employees who didn\u2019t turn up for work. The state of Gujarat, which Mr. Modi had ruled for more than a decade, took to using biometrics to red-pen students who skipped school. Mr. Modi has argued that digital payments will check \u201cblack money\u201d \u2014 the Indian term for unaccounted, often illegally acquired wealth \u2014 and other forms of corruption.\n\nUnder Mr. Modi\u2019s government, Aadhaar, India\u2019s enormous biometric identification system, which was initially promoted as a voluntary program to refine the delivery of public services and curb corruption, is increasingly seen as necessary for public and private services \u2014 giving birth in a hospital, enrolling a child in preschool, collecting your college degree, maintaining a telephone connection or a bank account, and collecting a death certificate. The government seems to be in a war of attrition with itscitizens, breaking down their resistance to the biometric identification program.\n\nMr. Modi, who has spoken relentlessly of his dream of a digital India and flaunted the miracle of technology by appearing in public as a three-dimensional hologram in numerous places at the same time, has described data as \u201creal wealth\u201d that would confer \u201chegemony\u201d on \u201cwhoever acquires and controls\u201d it.", "title": "Opinion | India Loves Data but Fails to Protect It", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-08 00:00:00", "text": "India makes more movies than anywhere else. Bollywood and its smaller cousins (such as Mollywood, Tollywood and Gollywood \u2014 all named after the areas where the films are shot or the languages they use) represent a hugely influential industry.\n\nThough the #MeToo movement has not shaken society in India the way it has in the United States, several Indian actresses, after abuse allegations were made against the American producer Harvey Weinstein, stepped forward to complain about a pervasive culture of sexual harassment.\n\nThe allegations included claims they had been groped, propositioned and forced to demean themselves to get work. Ms. Reddy, 28, has been one of the most vocal. In recent days, she has lobbed serious accusations against powerful men in the film business.\n\nAfter videos and pictures of a topless Ms. Reddy spread quickly on the internet, the question turned to what would be the impact. Ms. Reddy is not widely known across India, and she staged her protest in Hyderabad, a big city in the south-center of the country, but not nearly as important for the movie industry as Mumbai.\n\nDeepa Narayan, a social scientist who has recently published a book on how women are treated in India, said Ms. Reddy might face problems. \u201cThe first thing that happens when a woman in India takes a bold move, she is dismissed,\u201d Ms. Narayan said.", "title": "Indian Actress Stages a Topless #MeToo Protest", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-25 00:00:00", "text": "NEW DELHI \u2014 An Indian court on Wednesday sentenced an influential guru to life in prison for the rape of a teenage girl, putting to rest a long legal battle that has been marred by the murder of at least two witnesses connected to the case.\n\nThe conviction of the white-bearded guru, Asaram Bapu, in the 2013 rape of a 16-year-old follower who was studying at one of his ashrams comes during a time of national reckoning on sexual assault in India.\n\nOver the past few weeks, the rape and murder of an 8-year-old girl belonging to a nomadic community in northern India has dominated the news, spurring heated discussions about how rape should be handled in the country\u2019s courts.\n\nThe verdict was read out Wednesday inside the prison where Mr. Bapu is being held in the city of Jodhpur in Rajasthan State. The court said Mr. Bapu had \u201cdented the image of saints among the common masses.\u201d Mr. Bapu\u2019s followers said his legal team would appeal the verdict. The court also sentenced two of Mr. Bapu\u2019s aides to 20 years in prison and dropped charges against two others.", "title": "Indian Guru Sentenced to Life in Prison for Raping Teenage Girl", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-03 00:00:00", "text": "The penalties in the original announcement did not apply to independent or partisan digital media outlets, some of them regarded in India as major disseminators of fake news. These platforms are not regulated by the two main media regulatory bodies, the Press Council of India or the News Broadcasters Association. Instead, the rules would have been felt primarily by large, established outlets.\n\nIn its original announcement, since taken offline, the Ministry of Information and Broadcasting said that guidelines for the accreditation of journalists were being amended to counter \u201cincreasing instances of fake news in various mediums.\u201d The statement did not define fake news or provide guidelines about who could lodge complaints against journalists.\n\nThe statement said a journalist\u2019s accreditation would be revoked for six months after a first violation, one year after a second violation and permanently after three violations. It also said that once a complaint against a journalist was registered, his or her accreditation would be suspended until a determination had been made.\n\nAn accreditation is not required in India but is regarded as critical for access to news makers. Accredited journalists in India face fewer security clearances when visiting government offices and are eligible for subsidized train travel, among other benefits.\n\nSmriti Irani, who runs the Ministry of Information and Broadcasting, had said on Twitter that complaints against journalists would be handled by the Press Council of India and the News Broadcasters Association. She said neither body was controlled by the government.\n\nRajat Sharma, the president of the News Broadcasters Association, said that his group had not been consulted before the announcement on Monday. M. V. Shreyams Kumar, the vice president of the association, called the announcement \u201cridiculous.\u201d\n\n\u201cThis whole exercise is to curb the freedom of the press,\u201d Mr. Kumar said.\n\nMs. Irani, after arguing the measure\u2019s merits on Twitter with journalists and opposition figures, was taking a more conciliatory tone by midday Tuesday, inviting journalists to meet with her and provide \u201csuggestions so that together we can fight the menace of \u2018fake news\u2019 & uphold ethical journalism.\u201d", "title": "India\u2019s \u2018Fake News\u2019 Crackdown Crumbles Over Journalists\u2019 Outrage", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-04 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nOne of the most gratifying aspects of hip-hop\u2019s relentless growth and expansion has been variety \u2014 the genre no longer has a true conceptual or geographic center, which means the rules are constantly up for debate and reinvention, and a host of unusual ideas manage to find a home under what\u2019s become a big umbrella.\n\nPhoto\n\nAnd yet that has been something of a setback for those making hip-hop indebted to the idiosyncracies of the mid-to-late 1990s hip-hop underground. In that era, that scene served as a quasi-moral counterweight \u2014 sometimes implicit, sometimes explicit \u2014 to the mainstream wing of the genre, just then arriving into the pop klieg lights. It was proposed as an alternative (even if there were more consonances than were openly discussed at the time), and was bolstered by being the opposition to something too grand.\n\nAs hip-hop\u2019s growth steps have become more micro, though, truly resistant rap countermovements have been shunted even further to the fringes. It is perhaps tougher than ever to be truly outr\u00e9. That makes a pair of impressive new albums by veterans of the 1990s underground even more refreshing.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cMoosebumps: An Exploration Into Modern Day Horripilation\u201d is the proper follow-up, 22 years later, to the fantastically screwy Dr. Octagon debut album, \u201cDr. Octagonecologyst.\u201d It restores the original lineup: Kool Keith, one of the great non sequitur rappers of all time (Dr. Octagon is one of his many aliases); the lavish producer Dan the Automator; and the turntablist innovator DJ Qbert.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nLike some amalgam of science fiction fabulist and pornographer, Kool Keith \u2014 a 1980s innovator turned \u201990s eccentric turned 2000s mystery \u2014 pinballs among topics, sentiments and scenes. His tone is amelodic, declarative and a touch absent-minded, as if starting fresh with each rhyme. A random sample of touchstones: Lynn Swann, Tyrannosaurus rex, laundry detergent, onion rings. He finds magic in the absurd and the minute. It is a style almost impossible to emulate.\n\nPhoto\n\nThat it sounds natural over Dan the Automator\u2019s production is a real feat. He is a meticulous pastiche artist, playing with the lusciousness of 1970s orchestral soul, the boom-bap of late-80s and early-90s hip-hop, and the left-field ambience of library records and film scores. His drums and strings are intermingled with roars and squeaks and bleeps, all orderly and not cacophonous. Qbert, when given room, is ferocious, an aggressor who understands his place as part of the symphony.", "title": "Indie Rap Veterans Return to a Genre Still in Need of Opposition", "authors": ["Jon Caramanica"]} {"date": "2018-04-14 00:00:00", "text": "Five months later, the Indonesian government has yet to implement the Constitutional Court ruling, although officials say they are working on it.\n\nPhoto\n\nIn a country where religion plays a large part in public life, followers of traditional beliefs, known generally as aliran kepercayaan, hope the ruling will finally end decades of unofficial discrimination that makes it difficult for them to get permits to open gathering places, obtain marriage licenses and get access to public services like health care and education. It also complicates efforts by those believers to get military, police or civil service jobs, or even burial plots in cemeteries.\n\nThere are hundreds of different forms of aliran kepercayaan spread across the vast Indonesian archipelago. In Java, the most populous island, it is often a mix of animist, Hindu-Buddhist and Islamic beliefs.\n\nForms of kepercayaan can include certain periodic religious observances, such as communal meals or acts that could be compared to Muslim men praying together on Fridays or Sunday Christian services. These may include ritual offerings to appease spirits, even though the practitioners could also be registered as Muslims, Catholics, Buddhists or one of the other recognized religions.\n\nIt is estimated that at least 20 million of Indonesia\u2019s 260 million people practice local traditional beliefs, but the numbers could be much higher, according to analysts, as some are also followers of Islam, Christianity and other major religions.\n\nReligion is so omnipresent in Indonesia that citizens are required to declare on their national ID cards which of the six approved religions they adhere to, though in some regions they are allowed to leave that section blank. However, doing so can invite discrimination and bureaucratic hassles, so many traditional believers simply state on their ID cards the religion that is dominant in the area where they live. In Java, it is likely to be Muslim, but in parts of the islands of Sumatra or Sulawesi, it could be Catholic or Protestant, while on Bali it would be Hindu.\n\nBut such workarounds should be unnecessary, some legal experts say.\n\n\u201cThe court decision underlines that freedom of belief is a constitutional right, not a right that is given by the government,\u201d said Bivitri Susanti, head of the Jakarta chapter of the Indonesian Association of Constitutional Law Lecturers.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cSecond, it states that the right to belief in aliran kepercayaan, or faiths other than the six government-recognized religions, is inherent with the rights to religion as stated in Article 29 of the Indonesian Constitution,\u201d she added.\n\nPhoto\n\nBut clouding that point of view is the fact that about 90 percent of Indonesians are Muslim, giving Islamic religious leaders outsize political clout. The Indonesia Ulema Council, the country\u2019s top body of clerics, has been adamant, for example, that traditional beliefs should not be seen as on par with Islam.\n\n\u201cThe Constitutional Court ruling was not considered carefully and hurt the feelings of the faithful, especially Indonesian Muslims, because the ruling has placed aliran kepercayaan as equals,\u201d said Zainut Tauhid Sa\u2019adi, the council\u2019s vice chairman.\n\n\u201cThe decision has legal consequences and an impact on our society,\u201d he said.\n\nSome hard-line Islamic groups want to go even further and change the Constitution to make Islam the official state religion.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nHowever, key leaders within Nahdlatul Ulama, Indonesia\u2019s largest Islamic organization, support the court ruling.\n\nReligion has always been a hot-button issue in Indonesia, which despite its Muslim majority has small but influential Christian, Hindu and Buddhist minorities. There have been hundreds of religiously motivated attacks on religious minorities in recent years, some resulting in death, as well as the forced closures of houses of worship and the passage of local bylaws viewed as discriminatory against religious minorities.\n\nThat tension has also reached the political realm: In May last year, Basuki Tjahaja Purnama, the Christian governor of Jakarta, Indonesia\u2019s capital, was sentenced to two years in prison for blasphemy against Islam in a highly controversial case that his supporters say was concocted by radical Islamic groups bent on destroying his career.\n\nAs such, Indonesia\u2019s Ministry of Home Affairs appears to be erring on the side of caution with the Constitutional Court\u2019s November ruling.\n\nPhoto\n\nArief M. Edie, a ministry spokesman, said that the government respects and is implementing the ruling \u2014 but only by redesigning the national ID to accommodate the aliran kepercayaan as a choice in the section on religious status. It will not be recognized as the state\u2019s seventh official religion.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s acknowledged only as a culture, not a religion,\u201d Mr. Arief said.\n\nThat narrow interpretation is not going over well with aliran kepercayaan followers, who say that local governments in Indonesia\u2019s far-flung regions will continue to discriminate in the delivery of public services.\n\n\u201cThe problem with any controversial ruling or policy lies in implementation down to the lowest level of government,\u201d said Johannes Nugroho, an Indonesian political analyst and writer.\n\nMr. Nugroho, a former follower of both Christianity and kejawen, a traditional belief system, said he tried in vain to have Christianity removed from the religion section on his national identity card, preferring to have it left blank or, in an attempt to make a statement, changed to Hindu.\n\nHe said a clerk at his local government office flatly refused, then slyly suggested that if Mr. Nugroho would recite an Islamic creed to convert to Islam, he would put down Muslim on his identity card. Today it still identifies him as a Christian.\n\nStill, traditional belief organizations say they are emboldened by the Constitutional Court ruling and see an opening to push for official acceptance.\n\n\u201cWe\u2019ll keep fighting for equality; we have equality, legally speaking, but in reality we don\u2019t,\u201d said Endang Retno Lastani, an elder with one Java-based group, whose national identity card is blank in the religious affiliation section.\n\n\u201cOur belief is the unity of God and people, just like other religions,\u201d he said. \u201cSo what\u2019s wrong with that?\u201d", "title": "Indonesia\u2019s Ancient Beliefs Win in Court, but Devotees Still Feel Ostracized", "authors": ["Joe Cochrane"]} {"date": "2018-04-25 00:00:00", "text": "But wider use of antibiotics would raise some serious concerns. Would handing out tens of million of doses in poor countries speed the emergence of antibiotic-resistant bacteria? And could it be done without the drugs being stolen or misused?\n\nThe study\u2019s authors \u2014 from top American, British and African medical schools, and the Atlanta-based Carter Center \u2014 argue that those risks are small and much outweighed by the greater good of saving children\u2019s lives.\n\n\u201cAt one time, people said you couldn\u2019t give out H.I.V. drugs in Africa because it would create drug resistance,\u201d said Dr. Thomas M. Lietman, an ophthalmologist at the University of California, San Francisco, and the study\u2019s lead author. \u201cThat implied that we should just let Africans die so we could keep giving out the drugs in the U.S.\u201d\n\nAbout 35 million youngsters, Dr. Izadnegahdar said, live in the countries most likely to be targeted \u2014 those where a child now has a 1-in-10 chance of dying before age 5.\n\nIn the study \u2014 known as the Mordor trial and published in the New England Journal of Medicine \u2014 190,238 children under age 5 in 1,500 villages in Malawi, Niger and Tanzania were given one dose of azithromycin or a placebo every six months for two years.\n\nOverall, there were 14 percent fewer deaths among children getting the antibiotic; the reduction was strongest in Niger, where infant mortality is highest.\n\nThe protection appeared to be greatest for infants aged 1 month to 5 months; the antibiotic prevented one in four deaths in this group.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe researchers could not say definitively why it worked. Azithromycin, made by Pfizer and sold as Zithromax in the United States, kills many species of bacteria that cause pneumonia and diarrhea, which are major killers of newborns. It also kills malaria parasites.\n\nThe new trial grew out of a 2009 study of ways to prevent trachoma, a blinding eye disease, in 18,000 Ethiopian children. The group of children there who got one dose of azithromycin as part of their regimen suffered about half as many deaths as other children.\n\n\u201cThat was groundbreaking, just quite amazing,\u201d said Kelly Callahan, who runs the Carter Center\u2019s trachoma program and helped oversee the Ethiopia study. \u201cIt was beyond saving sight \u2014 it was saving lives.\u201d\n\nOther small studies have shown similar benefits. A 2014 study of Gambian women given one antibiotic dose during labor showed that both they and their babies had fewer overall infections and less often harbored the bacteria responsible for lethal neonatal sepsis.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nSome experts argued that distributing antibiotics could hasten the appearance of drug-resistant bacteria. The W.H.O.\u2019s panel would look hard at that, Dr. Ashorn said, \u201cbecause this would be broadening rather drastically the way we use antibiotics.\u201d\n\nSabiha Essack, director of antimicrobial research at the University of KwaZulu-Natal in South Africa, said it was \u201cunclear whether the benefits will outweigh the costs\u201d and noted that the study did not look at the effects on the infants\u2019 microbiomes, or bacterial makeup.\n\nBut other experts said they considered the risk relatively low, for several reasons.\n\nThe drugs would be given only to youngsters, only infrequently and probably only for a few years.\n\nDr. Charles Knirsch, vice president for clinical research at Pfizer, said his company had donated more than 700 million azithromycin doses to the International Trachoma Initiative, which gives them to people of all ages. No permanent resistance mutations have emerged in any bacteria.\n\nSuch mutations \u201care more of a concern in I.C.U.\u2019s in New York City than in places like Niger, where\u2019s there such low access to antibiotics,\u201d he said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nEach year, when azithromycin is given out, some pneumococcal bacteria resistant to it appear, said Paul Emerson, the trachoma initiative\u2019s director. But those strains fade out within weeks or months, he said.\n\nAlso, he noted, the resistance is only to macrolides, the drug class to which azithromycin belongs. Macrolides are not heavily used in Africa, where W.H.O. guidelines still recommend penicillins and even older sulfa drugs because they are cheap and effective.\n\nPharmaceutical supply chains in some poor countries are plagued by theft, and antibiotics are tempting targets because they cure sexually transmitted diseases and other ills. But less than 1 percent of Pfizer\u2019s donations have been lost to theft or expiration, Dr. Emerson said.\n\nFor enhanced security, azithromycin is distributed in special purple packaging saying it is to be used only for trachoma. Also, he noted, pediatric doses are liquids, which adults do not normally take.\n\nDr. Emerson said his initiative would be happy to handle distribution if the W.H.O. approves routinely giving antibiotics to infants.\n\n\u201cHow many times do you get an offer to help save tens of thousands of lives?\u201d he said.\n\nAlthough azithromycin is not approved by the Food and Drug Administration for children under 6 months old, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention recommends it for infants of any age with whooping cough.\n\nThe trial\u2019s gloomy nickname, Mordor, comes from J.R.R. Tolkien\u2019s \u201cLord of the Rings\u201d trilogy, in which it is the shadowy land of Mount Doom. The initials stand roughly for \u201cMortality Reduction Through Oral Azithromycin.\u201d (In French, \u201cMacrolides Oraux pour R\u00e9duire les D\u00e9c\u00e8s avec un Oeil sur la R\u00e9sistance\u201d \u2014 \u201cOral Macrolides to Reduce Deaths With an Eye on Resistance.\u201d)\n\nThe acronym was coined before the initials were chosen, authors said, because the 2009 trial was done in Ethiopia\u2019s Gondar region. In Tolkien\u2019s trilogy, Gondor, the land of men, battles Mordor. (Some readers think Tolkien used Ethiopian place names, Dr. Izadnegahdar said; according to a biographer, he denied consciously doing so.)\n\n\u201cSome team members thought the name was creepy, but the study is about death,\u201d Dr. Lietman said. \u201cIt took on a life of its own, and we never looked back.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe study\u2019s name, Dr. Izadnegahdar said, might be changed to Reach, for \u201cResilience Through Azithromycin for Children.\u201d", "title": "Infant Deaths Fall Sharply in Africa With Routine Antibiotics", "authors": ["Donald G. Mcneil Jr.", "Global Health"]} {"date": "2018-04-23 00:00:00", "text": "PORTLAND, Ore. \u2014 By the time her mother received the doctor\u2019s email, Yuna Lee was already 2 years old, a child with a frightening medical mystery. Plagued with body-rattling seizures and inconsolable crying, she could not speak, walk or stand.\n\n\u201cWhy is she suffering so much?\u201d her mother, Soo-Kyung Lee, anguished. Brain scans, genetic tests and neurological exams yielded no answers. But when an email popped up suggesting that Yuna might have a mutation on a gene called FOXG1, Soo-Kyung froze.\n\n\u201cI knew,\u201d she said, \u201cwhat that gene was.\u201d\n\nAlmost no one else in the world would have had any idea. But Soo-Kyung is a specialist in the genetics of the brain\u2014\u201ca star,\u201d said Robert Riddle, a program director in neurogenetics at the National Institute of Neurological Disorders and Stroke. For years, Soo-Kyung, a developmental biologist at Oregon Health and Science University, had worked with the FOX family of genes.\n\n\u201cI knew how critical FOXG1 is for brain development,\u201d she said.\n\nShe also knew harmful FOXG1 mutations are exceedingly rare and usually not inherited \u2014 the gene mutates spontaneously during pregnancy. Only about 300 people worldwide are known to have FOXG1 syndrome, a condition designated a separate disorder relatively recently. The odds her own daughter would have it were infinitesimal.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cIt is an astounding story,\u201d Dr. Riddle said. \u201cA basic researcher working on something that might help humanity, and it turns out it directly affects her child.\u201d", "title": "Infinitesimal Odds: A Scientist Finds Her Child\u2019s Rare Illness Stems From the Gene She Studies", "authors": ["Pam Belluck"]} {"date": "2018-04-27 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cI could relate to Laurie\u2019s work from the get-go,\u201d Ms. Sherman recalled in an email. \u201cShe was using miniature dolls to set up scenes of domesticity, riffing on role playing and traditional expectations, while I was using myself to riff on similar questions. I had also made some series of photographic paper dolls, so we were both toying with nostalgia and a playfulness in our work. Using dolls and photography was still somewhat uncharted territory, a counterpoint to what our male peers were doing in painting and sculpture, making \u2018high art.\u2019\u201d\n\nMs. Simmons\u2019s black-and-white photography of dolls came with its own tradition, including the Surrealist images of Man Ray and Hans Bellmer, in which the replicas of women are the objects of male erotic desire, and the uncanny child-dolls of outsider artists like Dare Wright and the belatedly discovered Morton Bartlett. But for a woman artist working with dolls, any sociopolitical critique was softened and complicated by the nostalgic recall of girlhood play. \u201cShe loves femininity and the trappings of femininity and the performance of femininity,\u201d Grace Dunham said. As children, Grace and Lena would watch with awed fascination whenever their mother dressed up to go to a party.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThis ambivalence deepens Ms. Simmons\u2019s art and keeps it from falling into simplistic agitprop. \u201cLaurie\u2019s work doesn\u2019t only look prescient, it looks current,\u201d said Madeleine Grynsztejn, director of the Museum of Contemporary Art Chicago, which will host a Simmons retrospective next year, following its opening at the Modern Art Museum of Fort Worth in October. \u201cThe work has a way of touching cross-generationally on the construction of femininity, feminine sexuality and the role of women in today\u2019s world. It walks this very fine line between being playful and searing.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nAs she progressed, Ms. Simmons broadened her vocabulary by acquiring new tools and props: color Cibachrome prints, rear-projected backdrops, digital manipulation. A fateful jump came in 2005-6, with the making of a 45-minute musical film, \u201cThe Music of Regret,\u201d that gave movement and narrative to the dummies of her photographs. Meryl Streep (part of Ms. Simmons\u2019s wide-reaching network of friends) wore a black wig to portray the artist, and interacted with different avatars of the male ventriloquist dummy.\n\nAn off-kilter hybrid, \u201cThe Music of Regret\u201d is only partly successful, but it kick-started Ms. Simmons\u2019s dormant cinematic ambitions. After being on her mother\u2019s set, Lena Dunham wanted to make a movie, too: the result was \u201cTiny Furniture,\u201d produced for $50,000. In it, Ms. Simmons played an artist who photographs miniature dollhouse scenes. The movie tracks with emotional accuracy what was happening in Lena\u2019s life at the time. One place that Ms. Simmons saw room for expansion and improvement was its depiction of her character, a midcareer woman artist.\n\n\u201cMy Art,\u201d which was made on a budget of roughly $400,000, aims at a more multifaceted portrayal. Ms. Simmons plays a woman, stalled in her personal life and artistic career, who spends a month in a borrowed country house to regenerate. It is the artist\u2019s passion for her work, not some halfhearted romance, that pulls her through.\n\n\u201c\u2018My Art\u2019 is the most accurate depiction of an artist\u2019s life I\u2019ve seen,\u201d the painter and writer David Salle said in an email. \u201cLaurie managed to catch the complexity, the loneliness and near-absurdity of it, as well as the tenderness.\u201d\n\nMs. Simmons shot most of \u201cMy Art\u201d at her brick Colonial Revival house in Connecticut. \u201cI always say I\u2019m an artist with the soul of a realtor,\u201d she quipped. She knew she wanted to buy and renovate the dilapidated former school as soon as she saw it in 2005, but it took \u201ctwo years of nonstop convincing\u201d to win over her husband.\n\nEven more courageous was the move into a new art form. \u201cOnce artists get into a specific lane it can be very difficult for them to make the choice to get out of it,\u201d Lena Dunham said. \u201cI was deeply impressed by her motivation and by her passion \u2014 and by the final product.\u201d\n\nMaking the movie was also a way for Ms. Simmons to deal with a succession of heartbreaking losses that began with the sudden death in June 2013 of her close friend the artist Sarah Charlesworth, and continued, over the span of little more than a year, with the deaths of her nephew, brother-in-law and mother. \u201cWhen I got the call that Sarah had died, there was complete shock and also the thought, \u2018I\u2019m going to make my movie,\u2019\u201d Ms. Simmons said. \u201cThe movie supplanted grief.\u201d\n\nShe was pivoting away from dolls and dummies to photograph human models, in what has been a gradual, jerky transition. \u201cThe whole idea of finding something in someone that is the essence of them, that looking for something, I never understood before,\u201d she said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHaving observed Japanese \u201cdollers,\u201d who as a form of \u201ccosplay\u201d (costume play) paint their closed eyelids to resemble the wide-open eyes of Barbies or anime figures, Ms. Simmons made a sequence of portraits she called \u201cHow We See,\u201d in 2015. Her photographs depict young women who appear preternaturally attentive. The simulated eyes are so convincing that on first glance, you recognize only that there is something weirdly soulless about them, as beautifully vacant as Stepford wives.\n\nPhoto\n\nAs a way station between dolls and real women, \u201cHow We See\u201d led to the current portraits at Salon 94 of people (and a dog) who are all close to Ms. Simmons, and are seen naked emotionally and, in some instances, physically. Even to her family, the directness of the portraits came as a surprise.\n\n\u201cMy mom processes her emotions through her art,\u201d Grace Dunham said. \u201cIn some ways, her emotions have been mysterious to me. They have been interior. Her work is potentially the most intimate part of her life.\u201d\n\nThe other work in the Salon 94 show, \u201cThe Mess,\u201d attests to Ms. Simmons\u2019s longstanding love affair with plastic. In a 20-foot-long photographic print, accompanied by a drone video, she depicts an assemblage of cheap disposable household items arranged by color. \u201cIt\u2019s a rainbow gradient mess,\u201d she said.\n\nPhoto\n\nOn a shopping day, she would go with an assistant and buy merchandise in a designated Day-Glo hue, and lay it all out on the floor of the barn. Over it, she displayed the numerals \u201c2017,\u201d a year in which she addressed the health problems of one daughter and the gender transition of another, along with the political fallout of an election that she said horrified everyone she knew.\n\nYet while \u201cThe Mess\u201d is undeniably a mess it is also luridly gorgeous. \u201cPlastic has been such an incredibly key part of what I\u2019ve done,\u201d Ms. Simmons said. \u201cI treat it like marble and light it and make it look beautiful and luxurious. For me, it still has that kind of beauty, which is a surface beauty with a toxicity underneath.\u201d\n\nShe might say the same of the trappings of traditional femininity. On that contradiction rests Ms. Simmons\u2019s unsettling art.", "title": "Influenced by Her Children, Laurie Simmons Exits Her Comfort Zone", "authors": ["Arthur Lubow"]} {"date": "2018-04-20 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cYou should take my apartment,\u201d Miwako said.\n\nI was standing between her Mount Sinai Hospital bed and the window. A winter sky had darkened the leafless tree branches outside. I turned to my friend of 10 years, her black hair a crew cut, her body shrunken beneath the thin bedsheet. We had bonded over our single, child-free status, shared creativity \u2014 she crafted jewelry, I designed my clothes \u2014 and our love of Chelsea galleries and hikes near Cold Spring, N.Y. We had caught Mardi Gras beads in New Orleans and cheered on the New York Giants from our seats in the Meadowlands stadium. Miwako was more sister than friend.\n\n\u201cTalk to my landlord,\u201d she whispered, closing her eyes.\n\nMy living arrangements had been volatile for two years after I lost my job as a systems manager at a lingerie company and ditched my expensive Midtown studio, stored my possessions and set out to tour a string of Airbnbs, ostensibly to \u201ccheck out other New York City neighborhoods.\u201d\n\nBut instead, I stayed in a series of apartments in Harlem, because Miwako lived nearby and I liked the one-of-a-kind stores like African Paradise and Bebenoir. We listened to jazz at the Shrine, ate at Yuzu, her favorite sushi restaurant, and gathered ginkgo nuts from trees on Lenox Avenue.\n\nI stayed until New Year\u2019s that first year, 2016, and then wintered in Florida with my mother \u2014 my free writer\u2019s retreat. Afterward, I faced the dreaded apartment search, but landlords, understandably, requested pay stubs, which I lacked, not savings account balances.", "title": "Inheriting an Apartment", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-29 00:00:00", "text": "Addiction has long afflicted rural east Tennessee, where the rolling hills and mountains are woven with small towns suffering from poverty and poor health. Prescribing rates for opioids are still strikingly high, and the overdose death rate in Roane County, where Ms. Whitefield lives, is three times the national average. Jobs go unfilled here because, employers say, applicants often cannot pass a drug test.\n\nAcross Tennessee, some 163,000 poor adults remain uninsured after state lawmakers refused to expand Medicaid under the Affordable Care Act. For them, and even for many covered by Medicaid, as Ms. Whitefield is, evidence-based opioid addiction treatment remains meager. More common are cash-only clinics, or abstinence-based programs that bank on willpower instead of the addiction medications that have proved more effective.\n\nTreatment for endocarditis usually involves up to six weeks of intravenous antibiotics, often in the hospital because doctors are wary of sending addicted patients home with IV lines for fear they would use them to inject illicit drugs. Many, like Ms. Whitefield, also need intricate surgery to repair or replace damaged heart valves. The cost can easily top $150,000, Dr. Pollard said.\n\nAdvice from specialty groups, like the American Association for Thoracic Surgery and the American College of Cardiology, about when to operate remains vague. For now, \u201cit\u2019s just a lot of anecdote \u2014 surgeons talking to each other, trying to determine when we should and when we shouldn\u2019t,\u201d said Dr. Carlo Martinez, who is one of Dr. Pollard\u2019s partners and who operated on Ms. Whitefield at Methodist Medical Center of Oak Ridge.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nTheir practice, owned by Covenant Health, will almost always operate on someone with a first-time case of endocarditis from injecting drugs, Dr. Pollard said. But repeat infections, when the damage can be more extensive and harder to fix, make it a tougher call. Dr. Mark Browne, Covenant\u2019s senior vice president and chief medical officer, said, \u201cEach patient is evaluated individually and decisions regarding the appropriate course of care are determined by their attending physician.\u201d\n\nIn the nearly two years since she got sick, Ms. Whitefield has felt physically diminished and been prone to illness. She also feels harshly judged by a medical system that saved her life but often treats her with suspicion and disdain.\n\nOver the same stretch of time, Dr. Pollard has grown increasingly disillusioned with hospitals that consider addiction treatment beyond their purview, and haunted by the likelihood that many of his drug-addicted patients will die young whether they get heart surgery or not. He set up a task force in 2016 to address the problem but has faced obstacles, especially concerning cost and, he believes, a societal reluctance to spend money on people who abuse drugs.\n\n\u201cEverybody has sympathy for babies and children,\u201d he said. \u201cNo one wants to help the adult drug addict because the thought is they did this to themselves.\u201d", "title": "Injecting Drugs Can Ruin a Heart. How Many Second Chances Should a User Get?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-17 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cI had a lot of things on my list that I really want to do, and suddenly I had a lot of time on my hands to do them,\u201d said Siegemund, who has ranked as high as 27th in the world. \u201cAll of these things came to my mind at the same time, so it kind of pushed away the negative about it.\u201d\n\nSiegemund, 30, relished spending more time with loved ones and further exploring psychology, the subject of the bachelor\u2019s degree from the University of Hagen. She hopes to pursue an advanced degree in the field someday, but during her time off, she read books on the topic and emphasized it in corporate speaking engagements.\n\n\u201cI was speaking in front of companies and also the tennis federation, different kinds of audiences about psychological subjects,\u201d Siegemund said. \u201cOf course it was from the perspective of a professional athlete, but I tried to take it a little further, transferring what we experience on the court. I think you can transfer it to any area of life and business. I kind of liked that, to give my perspective on these things.\u201d\n\nSiegemund\u2019s undergraduate thesis focused on a topic intrinsic to her life as a tennis player: choking under pressure. She says her expertise in the area does not necessarily protect her from collapsing.\n\n\u201cIt does help me to have extra knowledge, but being able to apply it in these situations is a whole different thing,\u201d she said. \u201cTheory and practice are two completely different things. But it\u2019s good to have the theory to try to apply it.\u201d\n\nOn court, Siegemund is known as a dogged competitor with a ruthlessness that often unnerves her opponents.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cI think part of her game is to find out how to irritate the other person a little bit,\u201d said Naomi Osaka, a recent opponent.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSiegemund said she had applied some of that same relentlessness to her rehabilitation process.\n\n\u201cI drive the people around me crazy sometimes because I\u2019m very impatient, and if it\u2019s not going forward, I can be a hard one to deal with,\u201d she said. \u201cBut I\u2019m getting up at 7, and I\u2019m the first one to go in the place and the last one to go out. That\u2019s a good thing about it also, but maybe sometimes it would be nice to be more relaxed and not be so competitive with it.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nWorking diligently, Siegemund was ready for a return last month, but decided to wait until the tour shifted away from hardcourts.\n\n\u201cI had the doctors\u2019 recommendation that I have to start on clay,\u201d she said. \u201cAnd also this is my favorite surface, so those two things came together.\u201d\n\nAfter playing one small tournament in Italy, Siegemund returned to the WTA Tour and won her first match on April 2 at the Volvo Car Open in this island community near Charleston. She lost in the second round to Osaka, the recent Indian Wells champion, after holding four set points in the second set.\n\nSiegemund feels confident in her knee, she said, but still wears a large brace on her right leg for some physical and mental reassurance.\n\n\u201cI do want to take it off,\u201d she said, laughing. \u201cIt doesn\u2019t look very pretty, it\u2019s really ugly. Maybe a shout-out to all the people that make braces, maybe they can do something nice instead of this.\u201d\n\nSiegemund, who notched five wins against top-10 players on clay last year, said she did not dwell on what might have been during her recovery, even though the French Open yielded many upsets, including the championship victory by an unseeded Jelena Ostapenko.\n\n\u201cI\u2019m not on that hypothetical trip so much,\u201d Siegemund said. \u201cWhat happened to me, I had to deal with it. I saw it as a task I had to manage, and I think that helped me to get through all of it in a positive way, and really come back stronger, a little bit, from it.\u201d\n\nSiegemund\u2019s next tournament will be next week in Stuttgart, where last year she won her second WTA title. In addition to the trophy and prize money, Siegemund earned a car from Porsche, the title sponsor of the event. The company did a custom paint job in \u201cfrozen berry,\u201d a color that Siegemund described as purplish taupe, and by the time the car was finished, its owner could not bend her knee enough to get in.\n\nSiegemund said she was not putting pressure on herself to succeed quickly, but she has not dimmed her expectations after returning to tour as what she considers a better-rounded player and person, while still hungry for on-court success.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cI don\u2019t want to be where I was before \u2014 I want to be better than that,\u201d she said. \u201cBut maybe in a different way.\u201d", "title": "Injured in Tennis, She Put Her Psychology Degree to Use", "authors": ["Ben Rothenberg"]} {"date": "2018-04-13 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cI think we\u2019re comfortable for the very short term,\u201d General Manager Sandy Alderson said. \u201cWe\u2019ll see how things go. A strong hitter, Realmuto is close to returning from a back injury. Trades rarely happen this early in the season, but with the everything-must-go Marlins, that might not matter.\n\n\u201cAs we\u2019ve noted in baseball over the off-season and early in the season, there\u2019s some teams that probably aren\u2019t trying that hard,\u201d Alderson said, without citing a particular team. \u201cSo I\u2019m not sure the calendar\u2019s even relevant in those cases.
