You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cI think she\u2019s been a stronger figure in that role than any platform has ever had,\u201d Mr. Smith said.\n\nAs much as those soirees may include needling from her, Ms. Brown\u2019s daytime summits with publishers tend to be more overtly contentious. At one recent meeting, two publishers complained about having lost a lot of online traffic after changes to Facebook\u2019s News Feed. According to one publisher who was present, Ms. Brown told them the company would give them more traffic if they stopped doing clickbait.\n\nStill, the media industry has been so beaten down by Facebook that some said they were happy to just have someone in the company who talks to them.\n\n\u201cWe see some small movement in the right direction in terms of at least improving transparency,\u201d said Jim Bankoff, chief executive of Vox Media. There had not been \u201creal movement in terms of providing better business opportunity,\u201d he added. \u201cBut at least we\u2019re being listened to.\u201d\n\nMs. Brown recently helped arrange a meeting between Mr. Zuckerberg and several members of The Washington Post management team: Martin Baron, the editor; Fred Ryan, the chief executive; and Shailesh Prakash, the chief product officer. The group discussed whether a Facebook user should hit a paywall on Post content after clicking on three, five or 10 articles. Mr. Zuckerberg said 10, but The Post executives wanted a paywall to start after 3 articles, according to a person who was in the meeting.\n\nMs. Brown went for the middle ground, pushing Mr. Zuckerberg to give The Post a test run of paywalls that kick in after three and five Post articles are read. She won. Since March 1, The Post has been doing just that, according to Mr. Prakash.\n\n\u201cShe\u2019s helped us,\u201d Mr. Prakash said.\n\nBut Ms. Brown\u2019s biggest project is developing a news apparatus within Facebook\u2019s premium video section, called Watch.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nShe is negotiating with BuzzFeed, Vox, CNN, Fox News and others to partner on creating about a half-dozen Facebook-exclusive shows, which will launch in May and June.\n\nBuilding off these shows, Ms. Brown is pushing to create a curated breaking news destination and envisions a cohesive daily Facebook newscast using partner content highlights \u2014 paid for by Facebook, made by media partners, and edited by a growing editorial team, according to a person familiar with her thinking.\n\nDiscussing Facebook\u2019s reticence to put paywalls in and engage with publishers transparently, Ms. Brown said at the February media and tech conference that it had taken too long for the social network to come around to a workable news strategy.\n\n\u201cI\u2019m having a hard time with patience right now,\u201d she said. \u201cAnd I know publishers are too.\u201d", "title": "Is Facebook\u2019s Campbell Brown a Force to Be Reckoned With? Or Is She Fake News?", "authors": ["Nellie Bowles"]} {"date": "2018-04-12 00:00:00", "text": "The speaker of the House\u2019s institutional responsibilities date to the founding of our country, but the modern speakership is focused largely on its political roles: protecting the House majority and advancing the party\u2019s policy goals. Success in one dimension \u2014 as Speaker Paul Ryan\u2019s decision to retire reflects \u2014 does not always translate into success in the other.\n\nIn the context of protecting Republican control, there\u2019s little reason to think that Mr. Ryan would be a liability to Republicans\u2019 prospects of holding a majority. A February Politico/Morning Consult poll put Mr. Ryan\u2019s national favorability at an anemic 36 percent, but he has not been used \u2014 at least to this point \u2014 as a high-profile symbolic figure in Democrats\u2019 campaigns to retake the House of Representatives. A recent analysis by the Wesleyan Media Project of roughly 300,000 House and Senate campaign ads aired since January 2017 indicates that unfavorable mentions of Mr. Ryan (0.3 percent of airings) were much less common than negative depictions of President Trump (6 percent) and the minority leader, Nancy Pelosi (2.4 percent).\n\nThe biggest factors affecting what happens in November, according to political science research, are not things like the speaker of the House but so-called fundamentals, like presidential approval, the state of the economy and the number of seats the majority party is defending. And the president\u2019s party is almost always likely to take a beating; in only three midterm elections since 1934 has the party controlling the White House gained seats. Mr. Ryan\u2019s retirement is not likely to break these trends.\n\nSo let\u2019s assume Mr. Ryan isn\u2019t an exceptional Republican political liability. What about on policy? We can assess his record by looking at what bills the speaker decided to consider in the House. For that, there are two dynamics to assess: One involves keeping things off the agenda that could split the party, even if they could pass the House with votes chipped in from the other party. As Dennis Hastert, a former speaker, put it, \u201cThe job of the speaker is not to expedite legislation that runs counter to the wishes of the majority of the majority.\u201d The second dynamic entails advancing policies favored by his party.", "title": "Opinion | Is It Even Possible to Succeed as House G.O.P. Speaker?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-07 00:00:00", "text": "Margery Eagan, a radio host, put it more bluntly in a recent column for The Boston Globe. \u201cIt\u2019s time to rethink N.F.L cheerleaders and their barely covered breasts being ogled on the sidelines by drunken men with binoculars,\u201d she wrote. \u201cIt\u2019s embarrassing for us all. Or should be.\u201d\n\nTo make it in a man\u2019s world, the saying goes, women must do everything men do \u2014 but backward and in high heels. For N.F.L. cheerleaders, there\u2019s a further twist: They must stand on the sidelines, in high heels, cheering for the men for very little money in a world where players rake in millions and even the mascots make up to $65,000 a year.\n\nAs The Times and others have noted, the rules placed on cheerleaders today are reminiscent of a different era, with weigh-ins, mandatory manicures, advice on the proper use of tampons and suggestions for how to politely respond to fans who are prying or engaging in harassment. Were a person to sift through the 1960s-era rule books of Hugh Hefner\u2019s Playboy clubs \u2014 rules created for the female servers called \u201cbunnies\u201d \u2014 they would find striking similarities: the bunnies were issued \u201cdemerits\u201d for chewing gum, dirty fingernails or unkempt hair. But even they got a salary and benefits.\n\n\u201cWhat\u2019s so hard about being an N.F.L. cheerleader is that not only do you have to be a technically trained dancer, but you have to look good while doing it,\u201d Ms. Davis said. \u201cYou have to wear three-inch heels while doing it. Your makeup has to be full on, you have to constantly be smiling, even when you\u2019re just standing there.\u201d\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s such a double standard,\u201d said Kate Mayfield, 37, a former cheerleader for the Baltimore Ravens who is now a hedge fund consultant. \u201cThey explain it to us like the rules are in place to keep us out of trouble, because the league is going to protect the player if something happens. Because the players are, if it comes down to it, more important, even though we\u2019re also on the field. I don\u2019t think I questioned it back then. I was 22.\u201d\n\nA 2012 Raiders etiquette handbook reviewed by The Times advised cheerleaders to \u201csit in a ladylike manner \u2014 cross your ankles or cross your legs but keep your legs together.\u201d A rule book for the Bengals, submitted as part of a lawsuit in 2014, noted \u201cyou are given a 3 lb leniency weight,\u201d \u201cno gum chewing,\u201d \u201cno slouching breasts.\u201d Both teams said this week that the rule books had been revised but would not provide specifics.\n\n\u201cFor me, and many of my teammates, the real killer was body dysmorphia and eating disorders, and the depression and anxiety which stem from that,\u201d said Lyndsey Raucher, a college student who cheered for the New England Patriots from 2016 to 2017. \u201cI fear that I will never fully be the same.\u201d", "title": "Is It Time to Rethink the Rules for N.F.L. Cheerleaders?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-11 00:00:00", "text": "Would you be surprised to hear that a study found that research subjects were more upset by stories of a dog beaten by a baseball bat than of an adult similarly beaten? Or that other researchers found that if forced to choose, 40 percent of people would save their pet dog over a foreign tourist? Why or why not?\n\nIn \u201cChoosing Animals Over People?,\u201d Nicholas Kristof writes:\n\nThe cutest primates on earth may be Inguka and Inganda, gorilla toddler twins who playfully tumble over each other here in the vast Dzanga Sangha rain forest, one of the best places to see gorillas, antelopes and elephants play. The only risk: They are so heedless and unafraid of people that they may tumble almost into your lap \u2014 and then their 375-pound silverback dad may get upset. His name is Makumba and he expresses displeasure with a full-speed charge, hurtling toward you until he\u2019s only inches away. This area where Central African Republic, Cameroon and the Republic of Congo come together is one of the wildest and most remote parts of the world, and the three countries have established bordering national parks. I also visited a forest glade filled with 160 elephants and a large herd of bongo antelopes, plus a few African buffalo. It was like a scene from a Disney movie, and I felt myself melting. Yet when I turn sentimental at the majesty of wildlife, I sometimes feel uneasy. I wonder: Does honoring animal rights come at the expense of human rights? One study found that research subjects were more upset by stories of a dog beaten by a baseball bat than of an adult similarly beaten. Other researchers found that if forced to choose, 40 percent of people would save their pet dog over a foreign tourist. When the shooting of Cecil the Lion in Zimbabwe attracted far more outraged signatures on a petition than the shooting of 12-year-old Tamir Rice by a Cleveland police officer, the writer Roxane Gay tweeted, \u201cI\u2019m personally going to start wearing a lion costume when I leave my house so if I get shot, people will care.\u201d\n\nStudents: Read the entire article, then tell us:\n\n\u2014 Considering the causes about which you care most, are you more dedicated to helping animals or humans? Why?\n\n\u2014 Why do you think many people are more empathetic toward the suffering of animals than that of people?\n\n\u2014 In your opinion, is it wrong to focus on animal welfare when humans are suffering? Why do you think so?\n\n\u2014 Mr. Kristof writes: \u201cAt the broadest level, it\u2019s a mistake to pit sympathy for animals against sympathy for humans. Compassion for other species can also nurture compassion for fellow humans. Empathy isn\u2019t a zero-sum game.\u201d\n\nDo you agree with this statement? Why or why not?", "title": "Is It Wrong to Focus on Animal Welfare When Humans Are Suffering?", "authors": ["Natalie Proulx", "Student Opinion"]} {"date": "2018-04-10 00:00:00", "text": "It was an ambitious idea by Mayor Bill de Blasio and the focus of his 2016 State of the City speech: a sparkling streetcar running along the waterfront in Brooklyn and Queens.\n\nBut two years later, there has been little progress on one of Mr. de Blasio\u2019s key transportation initiatives.\n\nMr. de Blasio has said little about the streetcar in recent months and his office has not identified a route, leading to persistent speculation that the proposal is dead. At the very least, it is delayed. Supporters now question whether a groundbreaking could happen before Mr. de Blasio leaves office at the end of 2021.\n\nIn a recent radio interview, Mr. de Blasio insisted that the streetcar was still on.\n\n\u201cWe\u2019re moving forward, but we have to get the exact details right,\u201d the mayor said on WNYC on Friday, calling the proposal \u201ca big complicated endeavor.\u201d", "title": "Is Mayor de Blasio\u2019s Brooklyn-Queens Streetcar Dead?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-27 00:00:00", "text": "Light bulbs are just the beginning. I could get a Colgate Connect toothbrush to map my mouth and give me pointers; a Roomba vacuuming robot to clean up after me; or a smart refrigerator to warn me that the milk might curdle. I could swap out my doorbell for one with a camera, delivering me live footage of the UPS driver dropping off a Bluetooth-enabled Instant Pot that can monitor how quickly the rice cooks.\n\nAll those sleek boxes and digital keypads carry the promise that, with just one more purchase and a swipe right, our lives will be easier, and our homes will run more smoothly. When we are at home, \u201cour desires are right up front and we want those desires satisfied,\u201d said Paul Levinson, a professor of communication and media studies at Fordham University and the author of \u201cNew New Media.\u201d \u201cThat is the basis for all these things that we have in the house.\u201d\n\nWould my life be easier if I could keep track of dinner on my iPhone? I don\u2019t know. But it probably would be more monitored. Even as we are in the midst of a collective freakout about the data that Facebook has been gathering and sharing without our permission, many of us are busily installing equipment that potentially bugs our homes and tracks our movements, conversations and routines.\n\n\u201cPretty much anything that I say in my living room could be recorded and could be transferred somewhere else,\u201d said Craig A. Shue, an associate professor of computer science at Worcester Polytechnic Institute, referring to devices with speakers and microphones like Google Home and Amazon Echo. \u201cThe risks are substantial.\u201d\n\nLast December, a Gizmodo reporter turned her one-bedroom San Francisco apartment into a smart home, connecting as many appliances and belongings to the internet as possible, including her mattress and coffee maker. While she found the experience mostly annoying, another reporter kept tabs on all the data that left her apartment. Not a single hour went by when her router was quiet \u2014 at all times, at least one gadget was communicating with its home server.\n\nAll that data mining has given some Americans pause. Seventy percent of consumers worry that hackers might access their smart devices at home, and 58 percent fear a lack of privacy from manufacturers that have access to their data, conversations, voice patterns and search history, according to iQor, a customer service outsourcing provider.\n\nBut anxiety alone hasn\u2019t been a deterrent, since we keep buying the stuff. We rationalize this uncomfortable truth because smart technology does have the potential to make life easier and, perhaps, safer.", "title": "Is My Not-So-Smart House Watching Me?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-12 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nOverall, do you believe the world is becoming a better or worse place to live? Why do you think so? What evidence do you have to support your opinion?\n\nIn \u201cScared by the News? Take the Long View: Progress Gets Overlooked,\u201d David Bornstein writes:\n\n\u201cI\u2019m taking a break from the news.\u201d It\u2019s a refrain I hear more and more often. Last week, Dan Rather sent out a tweet saying that \u201ceven I feel I need a break\u201d from the news sometimes. His remedy: a walk in the woods. Last year, the Reuters Institute for the Study of Journalism found that over a third of American respondents avoid the news, the main reason being the \u201cdepressing nature of the content itself.\u201d The solution isn\u2019t to soften the news, of course. But if journalism provided a more comprehensive view of the world, it might not be so oppressive. That\u2019s one of the central arguments in Steven Pinker\u2019s new book, \u201cEnlightenment Now,\u201d which assesses many forms of progress that have been made to improve the human condition in recent centuries and decades \u2014 progress that many people (in some cases most people) are unaware of or have lost sight of. I spoke with Mr. Pinker last week about some of the themes of his book. David Bornstein: What\u2019s the main point of \u201cEnlightenment Now\u201d? Steven Pinker: There\u2019s a coherent alternative to religious, nationalist and reactionary movements, namely the ideals of the Enlightenment: that we can use knowledge to enhance human flourishing. The Enlightenment, moreover, worked: We live longer, healthier, safer, wealthier, freer, more peaceful and more stimulating lives than those who came before us. And by \u201cwe\u201d I don\u2019t just mean we in the West. This progress is encompassing the world.\n\nStudents: Read the entire article, then tell us:\n\n\u2014 Are you surprised by Mr. Pinker\u2019s claim that the world is actually becoming a better place? Why or why not?\n\n\u2014 How would you respond to the question posed by Barack Obama: If you had to choose a time to be born and you didn\u2019t know who you\u2019d be or where you\u2019d be, what time would you choose? Do you agree with him that now is the best time to be alive? Why or why not?\n\n\u2014 In your opinion, what have been three of the most important advances in human history? How have these made the world a better place to live?\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u2014 Do you think acknowledging progress makes people unmotivated to continue improving society? Or does ignoring it actually prevent development? Why do you think so? How did you feel after reading this article?\n\n\u2014 Why do you think journalism tends to focus more on problems than progress? Do you think journalists have a responsibility to present a more comprehensive view of the world? If so, why and how can they do this? If not, why not?", "title": "Is Now the Best Time in Human History to Be Alive?", "authors": ["Natalie Proulx", "Student Opinion"]} {"date": "2018-04-03 00:00:00", "text": "Here is how a veteran Russian foreign policy expert, Vladimir Frolov, described Putin\u2019s Syria fix in a March 5, 2018, essay in The Moscow Times:\n\nIn Syria, Russia is discovering that winning the war might be easier than winning the peace. Each time President Putin declares victory or announces a drawdown of Russian forces, like he did in December, the fighting flares up with a new intensity and Moscow is required to fly in reinforcements \u2026 Moscow is now struggling to parlay its military gains into an internationally legitimate political settlement that would help Russia recoup its investments in the conflict. For now, Syria remains ungovernable and splintered into fiefdoms run by regional players with their own interests.\n\nPutin\u2019s latest beef-for-sugar trade was his apparent ordering of the use of a military-grade nerve agent, produced only in Russia, to poison the former Russian spy Sergei V. Skripal and his daughter, Yulia, in the English city of Salisbury. The Western response has been what British Prime Minister Theresa May described as the biggest collective expulsion of alleged Russian intelligence officers ever \u2014 over 100 from more than 20 countries.\n\nWhether timed or coincidental, the poisoning attack and the Western backlash helped Putin run up his vote totals in his latest phony presidential re-election \u2014 another sugar high. But the morning after, Putin\u2019s Russia is more isolated than ever. Also, Putin\u2019s cronies and other Russian oligarchs \u2014 whose game is to make tons of dirty money in Russia and then take it to London, where it can be laundered for safekeeping \u2014 are now getting more scrutinized than ever by British authorities.\n\nAnd then there is Putin\u2019s long-range strategy \u2014 to bet against Mother Nature, human nature and Moore\u2019s Law, all at once. He\u2019s betting against Mother Nature \u2014 that the world will indefinitely remain addicted to his oil and gas in an age of disruptive climate change. He\u2019s betting against human nature \u2014 that his young people won\u2019t want to be free to realize their full potential, not just live off sugar-high memories of historical greatness. And he\u2019s betting against Moore\u2019s Law \u2014 that the steady growth of technology won\u2019t empower Russia\u2019s youth to connect and collaborate, and see through his charade.\n\nPutin\u2019s troubles are nothing I celebrate. I was against NATO expansion; I wanted Russia integrated into the family of European democracies. A weak, isolated and humiliated Russia is a dangerous animal. But to thrive in the long term, Russia needs a \u201creset,\u201d and it can come only from within, but Putin won\u2019t press the button.\n\n\u201cWithout reform, there is little reason to be optimistic about Russia\u2019s long-run growth trend, given its poor demographic profile, weak institutions and abject failure to diversify its economy, despite having an enormously talented and creative population,\u201d Kenneth Rogoff, the Harvard University economist, wrote in The Guardian last year. \u201cIf the world continues to move toward a low-carbon future, Russia will confront an inevitable choice: launch economic and political reforms or face continuing marginalization, with or without Western sanctions.\u201d\n\nIt\u2019s sad to see a country that gave us Tchaikovsky, Tolstoy, Spassky, Sakharov, Stravinsky, Shishkin, Dostoyevsky, Solzhenitsyn, Pushkin, Nureyev and the Google co-founder Sergey Brin become better known for giving the world Novichok, the deadly Russian nerve agent used in Britain; \u201clittle green men,\u201d the disguised Russian soldiers who seized Eastern Ukraine; and Guccifer 2.0, the Russian cyberagent who hacked the Democratic National Committee in 2016.\n\nIt\u2019s all beef for sugar \u2014 and that\u2019s Putin\u2019s legacy.", "title": "Opinion | Is Putin a C.I.A. Agent?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-19 00:00:00", "text": "Despite the imposition of unprecedented sanctions against Russia by the Trump administration and Congress over the past year, President Vladimir Putin only seems more intent on causing grievous harm to international peace and stability.\n\nAlongside increased financial sanctions against Mr. Putin and his cronies, there is another arrow in the American quiver that would add diplomatic pressure against Russia: The State Department should consider adding the country to its list of state sponsors of terrorism, alongside its close allies Iran and Syria.\n\nThe moral case for such a designation is sound. Russia has invaded its neighbors Georgia and Ukraine, it supports the murderous regime of Bashar al-Assad and our enemies in Afghanistan, and it is engaged in active information warfare against Western democracies, including meddling in the 2016 United States elections.\n\nThis week, the Organization for Prevention of Chemical Weapons announced that the Kremlin had crossed yet another previously unimaginable line, when it confirmed findings by the British government that a Russian military-grade nerve agent, which British authorities identified as Novichok, was used to poison a former Russian intelligence agent, Sergei Skripal, and his daughter in the English city of Salisbury. How much about your interests, background, culture, experiences and ideas are you able to express?\n\nIn \u201cThe Soul-Crushing Student Essay,\u201d Scott Korb writes:\n\n\u2026 We expect college freshmen to feel at least as comfortable with self-expression as the burbling bloggers and writers of yesteryear. Something beyond stylized selfies must populate their social media streams, after all. But every year I find that getting them to admit to feeling devoted or frustrated, to being peculiar in any way (much less in a large way), verges on impossible. And as someone who has read thousands of student essays over the past 10 years, few things are more dispiriting \u2014 and as the pages mount, soul-crushing \u2014 than those written by 18-year-olds who can\u2019t see themselves as peculiar. But why can\u2019t they? One reason reveals itself when someone finally asks the clarifying question: \u201cDo you mean we can write with the word \u2018I\u2019?\u201d The class looks up in wonder. This happens every semester. Somewhere along the way, these young people were told by teachers that who they are in their writing ought to be divorced from who they are on their phones, or as the writer Grace Paley may have said, with their families and on their streets. They know a private \u201cI\u201d who experiences devotion and frustration. I see them text in class and talk and laugh and sometimes cry in the halls. They wear band T-shirts, often from my era, so I assume they have taste. I watch them read. But no matter who they are in private, when I first encounter their writing, they use only the public passive voice: The text was read. The test was taken.\n\nStudents: Read the entire article, then tell us:\n\n\u2014 Do any of Mr. Korb\u2019s ideas about writing essays resonate with you? Which ones and how so?\n\n\u2014 Do you feel like school is a place for self-expression? Are you encouraged to question and articulate your \u201cdevotions, frustrations, little triumphs, and large peculiarities\u201d? Why or why not? How much of what you care about outside school emerges in your work in school?\n\n\u2014 Do you feel that your personality, culture, family, experiences and ideas are appreciated in school? If so, what assignments or activities have allowed you to connect your life with school in a meaningful way? If not, how do you think your classes could give you more opportunities to explore and discuss the things you care about?\n\n\u2014 In what places and with whom do you feel the best able to express yourself? How do you like to convey your thoughts, questions, ideas and emotions?", "title": "Is School a Place for Self-Expression?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-30 00:00:00", "text": "The numbers and the history show the folly of that approach. By insisting on the strategy of appealing to white Republican and moderate voters, Democrats have lost over and over again with a population that is nearly a majority of people of color \u2014 specifically, voters of color who make up nearly half of the Democratic Party membership in Georgia and nationally. Even casual observations of these numbers and trends would indicate that Democrats do not need to persuade a single Trump voter to win.\n\nStacey Abrams had the vision to see the value of voters that are more often than not ignored by both parties. They are young people, black people and other voters of color \u2014 all of whom are part of the 1.2 million eligible and unregistered voters in Georgia. Some 700,000 of those voters live outside the metropolitan Atlanta area. Ms. Abrams had the foresight to see those voters as an untapped electoral resource. In 2014, while serving in the leadership of the Georgia House, she founded the nonprofit New Georgia Project to register and talk to them. If we reach those voters, listen to them and register them, she argued, they will become deeply engaged in our democratic process. In other words, they will vote.\n\nFurthermore, with the emerging voters engaged, Democrats could establish and enact an agenda beyond Atlanta. Ms. Abrams has addressed issues of racial justice, economic inequality, L.G.B.T. rights and gender discrimination in an integrated platform. Her vision for \u201ceconomic mobility\u201d directly takes on the structural barriers keeping people in poverty.\n\nAlso as part of her platform, she has advocated equal pay for women. For example, she\u2019s proposing to provide state dollars to entrepreneurs to start local businesses, with a focus on rural and low-income communities. She advocates providing health care to the working poor by expanding Medicaid coverage as well as securing the Affordable Care Act in the state to benefit an additional half million people and create tens of thousands of jobs. It would also provide a stronger economic base in rural counties. Finally, it\u2019s worth noting that she is boldly advocating access to obstetricians and gynecologists, is an abortion rights advocate and wants to attract medical personnel to underserved areas of the state.\n\nThe Abrams campaign has also forged a connection with these voters on the ground: She has not poured millions into trivial television and radio ads but has instead stressed face-to-face meetings. Dozens of Ms. Abrams\u2019s campaign staffers and volunteers have been on the ground for months knocking on doors, organizing community meetings and connecting with the voters. A recent poll shows the innovation is working: Ms. Abrams is leading Ms. Evans by 20 points.\n\nWhen President Barack Obama\u2019s campaign used social media and online organizing as a central way to motivate and direct volunteers and build momentum, it was an innovation that changed electoral campaigning for good. Ms. Abrams\u2019s innovation is no less impactful. The Abrams idea \u2014 that black women leading a multiracial bloc of voters will establish a new base \u2014 may also revolutionize American electoral politics.", "title": "Opinion | Is Stacey Abrams Assembling a New Democratic Majority?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-13 00:00:00", "text": "So, is he a prisoner in his own house, surrounded by real-life supervillains?\n\n\u201cI\u2019m the luckiest guy in the world,\u201d Mr. Lee said, chuckling and sounding like a 95-year-old teenager. \u201cNobody has more freedom.\u201d\n\nHe also defended his daughter, known as JC, against claims that she has been physically abusive and a financial drain. \u201cMy daughter has been a great help to me,\u201d he said. \u201cLife is pretty good.\u201d\n\nA House in Disarray\n\nFor four decades, Mr. Lee has lived in a relatively modest two-story house in the middle of what has become some of Los Angeles\u2019s most valuable real estate. Dr. Dre is a neighbor, and Leonardo DiCaprio lives down the block, on a street where houses can list for north of $30 million.\n\nInside the suburban-style home, a nurse and a maid bustled in the kitchen. Although Mr. Lee seemed at ease, the armed guard lent an air of surveillance that made it difficult to entirely relax.\n\nThe house is a time capsule of late 1970s Hollywood. Decorated by his late wife, it is dotted with ceramic animals, carved figures in African and Asian styles, and large gilt-framed mirrors hung on mirrored walls. Empty hooks surrounded by dusty outlines sit amid prints and original works by noted artists \u2014 Joan Mir\u00f3, Pablo Picasso, Alexander Calder, Salvador Dal\u00ed and Roy Lichtenstein \u2014 suggesting a home being slowly eroded.\n\n\u201cMy wife, she\u2019s the only person in the world that I would know of who would put a big mirror on top of a big mirror,\u201d Mr. Lee said. \u201cAnd when she was here, she had so many paintings, all over. My daughter took a lot of them, and a lot of them have gone elsewhere.\u201d", "title": "Is Stan Lee Being Held Prisoner by Real-Life Villains?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-24 00:00:00", "text": "TORONTO \u2014 Monday morning, all we could talk about was the weather: Toronto woke up to a bright and warm day. Just a week earlier, as a nasty coda to a very long winter, an ice storm had battered and smattered the city for three days. Yards were strewn with debris and broken branches, and streets were clogged with snow and water and ice. Seven days later, and at last! \u2014 the weather turned. Toronto\u2019s bike lanes and patios and sidewalks were full again.\n\nBy bright and warm Monday afternoon, the city\u2019s conversation had changed, and it won\u2019t go back to easy weather chatter anytime soon. The midday attack on pedestrians along a northern stretch of Yonge Street, the city\u2019s main drag, was terrible and terrifying. This is the case whenever and wherever such things happen in the world today. But it\u2019s fundamentally shocking in this city, for this city. This is not supposed to happen here. After all, this is Toronto.\n\nWith 10 dead and 15 injured by a man who \u2014 while his motives are not yet determined \u2014 clearly found inspiration in weaponizing a rental van to run down innocent civilians, the city has experienced the sort of horrifying event that we have long since accepted happens in the world, only elsewhere. Indeed, in a profoundly felt if rarely discussed way (we retain at least this part of our British heritage), that\u2019s the point of Toronto itself: Whether it\u2019s the Great Irish Famine in the 19th century or Syria\u2019s civil war in the 21st, tragic events and traumatic histories happen elsewhere, and that\u2019s why you come here, to make a life for yourself and your family in peace.\n\nIn doing so, and in accepting that you\u2019re doing so alongside people from all over the world committed to the same idea, you contribute to and benefit from being part of a success story now in its third century and going strong \u2014 a flourishing, cosmopolitan urban center in a country committed to peace, order and good government. We argue about how we\u2019re doing with those second and third components, but very rarely about the first. In a world brutalized and shredded by sectarian conflict, Toronto can feel at times like an urban amusement park: It\u2019s the most ethnically diverse and pluralist city on the planet, and also, as residents and visitors alike have long both assumed and experienced, the friendliest and safest.", "title": "Opinion | Is This Toronto?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-12 00:00:00", "text": "BEIJING \u2014 In an elegantly furnished back room at a conference in eastern China in December, a member of the Chinese leadership asked American tech executives for help.\n\nThe official, Wang Huning, a Communist Party strategist who has spent much of his career sizing up the United States as a geopolitical rival, wanted to know whether President Trump was serious about a trade war with China \u2014 and whether his American visitors could serve as a channel of communication to the White House.\n\nHe has not been alone.\n\nFor the past few months, some of the most powerful men in China \u2014 allies of President Xi Jinping with longstanding ties and deep experience with the United States \u2014 have been casting about for a better understanding of Mr. Trump and how to respond to his combative trade agenda, according to several people they have consulted.\n\nVice President Wang Qishan has met in recent weeks with a series of American business leaders and former cabinet officials to question them about Mr. Trump\u2019s trade threats. China\u2019s Leaders Hunt for Answers", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-06 00:00:00", "text": "Realistically, the 2,000 American troops have not made a huge difference to the landscape of the war in terms of humanitarian assistance, because the United States never had a vested interest in protecting the Syrian population; the troops were not deployed in a way that, say, could ensure the delivery of food or medicine, or open up besieged towns. But the signal their sudden withdrawal sends to the Syrian people, especially the Syrian Kurds, and the rest of the world will be damning.\n\nKassem told me that living under the Assad dictatorship for 40 years, the national ideology taught him and his friends that America was the devil. \u201cWe were taught that America was the enemy,\u201d he said. \u201cThen we figured out it was all propaganda. But after seven years of atrocities, do you know what my friends and people around the Middle East are saying? That America is the enemy again. Because they see the Russians bombing us and the United States doing nothing. Now they pull out \u2014 when they could have been our friend or ally.\u201d\n\nOf course, Mr. Trump is not concerned about these things; his sole metric for success is defeating the Islamic State \u2014 though the vast majority of Syrian civilians were killed by Mr. Assad\u2019s forces. But any claim of victory over the Islamic State is premature and na\u00efve. As Kassem and others note, the seeds of \u201cISIS 2.0\u201d are already planted in the thousands of angry people who have lost their families, their homes, their country. \u201cWhen there are a million people dead,\u201d Kassem said, \u201cwhen most have lost everything, ISIS will say, \u2018We told you so.\u2019\u201d\n\nMr. Trump has said that with America gone, its regional allies, especially Israel and Saudi Arabia, should pick up the slack. But that could make things even worse. Israel has a long and complicated relationship with Syria, and it has shown little willingness to get more involved. And Mr. Trump is perhaps forgetting that Saudi Arabia is the birthplace of the hard-core Wahhabi branch of Islam, which has inspired jihadists around the globe and could turbocharge a revived Islamic State.\n\nAs long as America has had troops in Syria, there was at least hope for a peaceful resolution to the war. Now the bottom is falling out. Kassem says he hears talk about the coming of the Mahdi, whom many Muslims believe will bring about Judgment Day, because the region is engulfed in chaos \u2014 a precondition for his arrival. \u201cEveryone is talking end of days,\u201d he says.", "title": "Opinion | Is Trump Sowing the Seeds for ISIS 2.0?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-17 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cThey hurt,\u201d Lizzy said. \u201cIf you ever put Band-Aids on your nipples, those things are stiff. Any time you move around you can just feel it. It\u2019s like an annoying, rubbing feeling, especially in a sensitive area.\u201d She wore the bandages for 45 minutes before she began crying in class. Her best friend took her to the bathroom and Lizzy lifted her shirt to show her the bandages. Then she peeled them off and contacted her mother.\n\n\u201cI got a text from Lizzy saying, \u2018This is not a dress code violation and I feel completely attacked,\u2019\u201d said Ms. Knop. She was adamant that if Lizzy had been wearing a see-through or form-fitting shirt without a bra, she wouldn\u2019t have allowed her daughter to leave the house. \u201cThe fact is that she wore a long sleeve T-shirt that was not see-through. It wasn\u2019t even flattering,\u201d said Ms. Knop. \u201cSo to say she was trying to be a distraction is absolutely absurd.\u201d\n\n\u201cShe didn\u2019t even tell me about the Band-Aids until 28 hours later,\u201d she said. \u201cShe was so embarrassed.\u201d\n\nIn a prepared statement, Braden River High School officials said that the situation \u201cshould have been handled differently.\u201d They maintained that Lizzy was in \u201cviolation\u201d of the dress code and that their intention was to \u201cassist the student in addressing the situation.\u201d\n\nThe incident happened two weeks ago \u2014 Lizzy\u2019s initial tweet about the incident went viral \u2014 but the backlash is still going strong. On Monday, Lizzy and some of her classmates held a silent protest in support of \u201cthe destigmitization of natural bodies.\u201d Despite threats of disciplinary action, about 30 female students opted not to wear bras, and a number of students decorated their backpacks with Band-Aids in the shape of an X. What are its rules? Do you consider them fair? Why or why not?\n\nIn \u201cIs Your Body Appropriate to Wear to School?,\u201d Hayley Krischer writes:\n\nIt started with a sunburn. Lizzy Martinez, 17, a junior at Braden River High School in Bradenton, Fla., had been swimming and tanning all weekend at a water park in Orlando. But when Monday morning came and she had to get dressed for school, Lizzy\u2019s bra felt painfully constricting on her burned skin. So she ditched the bra and purposely chose to wear something dark and loose \u2014 a long sleeve, oversize, crew neck gray T-shirt \u2014 so she wouldn\u2019t draw attention to her chest. But around 10 a.m., about 15 minutes into her veterinary assistance class, Lizzy was called out of the classroom for a meeting with two school officials, Dean Violeta Velazquez and Principal Sharon Scarbrough. They asked her why she wasn\u2019t wearing a bra. She said she told her school administrators about the sunburn. They insisted that she was violating the school dress code. (The 2017-2018 Code of Student Conduct does not say bras must be worn by female students.) They told her to put on an undershirt because boys were \u201clooking and laughing\u201d at her, a detail she later challenged. \u201cNo one said a thing to me until I got to the dean\u2019s office,\u201d Lizzy said. She was crying and wanted to go home, so Lizzy\u2019s mother, Kari Knop, a registered nurse, was called at work. \u201cI said, \u2018Lizzy, I\u2019m working,\u2019\u201d Ms. Knop said in a phone interview. \u201cI told her, \u2018Can you just put the undershirt on and call it a day?\u2019\u201d Lizzy was embarrassed and angry but she relented. When she returned wearing the undershirt, the school principal had left. The dean, according to Lizzy, instructed her to \u201cstand up and move around for her.\u201d \u201cI looked at her and said, \u2018What do you mean?\u2019\u201d Lizzy said. \u201cI was a little creeped out by that.\u201d The school has a strict disciplinary policy and she didn\u2019t want to appear defiant. (School officials refused to comment, except in a statement.) The dean told her that her nipples were still showing through her T-shirt and she should use bandages to cover them up. \u201cShe told me, \u2018I\u2019m thinking of ways I could fix this for you.\u2019 She said, \u2018I was a heavier girl and I have all the tricks up my sleeve,\u2019\u201d Lizzy said.\n\nStudents: Read the entire article, then tell us:\n\n\u2014 What do you think about the way Lizzy\u2019s school handled her so-called dress code violation? Should it have been considered a violation in the first place? If so, how should administrators have addressed it? If not, why not?\n\n\u2014 Do you think Lizzy\u2019s story or any of the others in the article are examples of discrimination based on sex? Why or why not?\n\n\u2014 In your opinion, is your school\u2019s dress code appropriate or too strict? Why do you think so?\n\n\u2014 Have you or your classmates ever stood up to practices or policies at your school that you thought were discriminatory? If so, what was that experience like? If not, why not?\n\n\u2014 Galen Sherwin, a senior staff attorney at the Women\u2019s Rights Project of the A.C.L.U., says that students speaking up against restrictive dress codes is \u201cpart of the sea change we\u2019re seeing nationwide in speaking up and challenging discriminatory treatment based on sex in all different areas of life.\u201d Do you agree that we are in the midst of a watershed moment in our culture? Why or why not?", "title": "Is Your School\u2019s Dress Code Too Strict?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-13 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Ryan is part of a wave of representatives and senators from both parties who have announced plans to retire at the end of their terms, and research suggests that Democrats can make significant gains in the 2018 midterm elections.\n\nGiven how much is at stake for both parties during the next election, we want to hear from voters in districts where these retirements are occurring. We Want to Hear From You", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-06 00:00:00", "text": "Even by Trumpian standards, the president has been in high dudgeon this week, railing about everything from illegal immigrants to unfair Chinese trade practices. For that, at least some Trump watchers blame his smashing defeat in the passage on March 23 of the omnibus spending bill.\n\nThat legislation, approved to avert a government shutdown, brushed aside all of President Trump\u2019s plans to restructure the federal government (except for his push for higher military spending). Even his treasured border wall got virtually nothing.\n\nAt its core, the bill was simply another exercise in kicking the can down the road with a new twist: Congress blasted through longstanding spending caps, dispensing goodies to all.\n\nWhile proponents of more military spending got their wish, to win needed Democratic votes the Republicans were compelled to permit a similar increase in domestic spending.", "title": "Opinion | Is the Spending Bill Responsible for Trump\u2019s Bad Mood?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-06 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Takahata\u2019s slow pace sometimes caused resentment \u2014 Mr. Miyazaki jokingly compared Mr. Takahata to \u201ca real slugabed sloth\u201d in 1990 \u2014 but it also led to meticulously crafted films.\n\nPhoto\n\nMany of Mr. Takahata\u2019s movies were popular, particularly in Japan, and many critics praised his work, especially \u201cGrave of the Fireflies\u201d (1988), a harrowing tale of a brother and sister trying to survive after Japan is devastated by American firebombing during World War II.\n\nThe film, written and directed by Mr. Takahata and adapted from a story by Akiyuki Nosaka, dealt frankly with cruelty and death but also had moments of innocence, beauty and grace.\n\nThe critic Roger Ebert of The Chicago Sun-Times called the film \u201can emotional experience so powerful that it forces a rethinking of animation.\u201d\n\n\u201cThis film proves, if it needed proving, that animation produces emotional effects not by reproducing reality, but by heightening and simplifying it, so that many sequences are about ideas, not experiences,\u201d Mr. Ebert wrote.\n\nMr. Takahata\u2019s other films include \u201cOnly Yesterday\u201d (1991), a contemplative tale of a woman who reminisces about her past on a trip to the countryside, and \u201cPom Poko\u201d (1994), an environmentalist fantasy about shapeshifting raccoon-like animals called Tanuki that struggle to maintain their lifestyle against encroaching suburbs.\n\nBoth films were drawn in naturalistic styles, even when they depicted fantastical subjects, a hallmark of a lot of anime and many of Studio Ghibli\u2019s films.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Takahata, who was not an animator himself, chose a different approach in later films like \u201cMy Neighbors the Yamadas\u201d (1999), a surrealistic family story drawn like a comic strip; and his last film, \u201cThe Tale of the Princess Kaguya\u201d (2013), a dreamy, watercolored portrayal of a Japanese folk tale.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cIt is about the essence that\u2019s behind the drawing,\u201d he said of his aesthetic in \u201cPrincess Kaguya\u201d in an interview with The Associated Press in 2015. \u201cWe want to express reality without an overly realistic depiction, and that\u2019s about appealing to the human imagination.\u201d\n\n\u201cThe Tale of the Princess Kaguya\u201d took Mr. Takahata about a decade to finish, though he worked on other films at the same time. It was nominated for an Academy Award for best animated feature in 2015.\n\n\u201cThe film\u2019s tone \u2014 the sense of characters grasping to hold on to innocence as the civilized world whisks it away \u2014 is all Takahata,\u201d the critic Ty Burr wrote in The Boston Globe in 2014.\n\nMr. Takahata was reported to have been born on Oct. 29, 1935, in Mie Prefecture, in southern Japan. He grew up further west in the city of Okayama.\n\nHe told The Japan Times in 2015 that as a boy during World War II he fled an American bombing raid that killed more than 1,000 people in Okayama. He remembered rushing, barefoot and in his pajamas, past piles of bodies \u2014 an experience he drew on for \u201cGrave of the Fireflies.\u201d\n\nHe graduated from the University of Tokyo, then started his career in animation in the late 1950s at Toei studio, where he met Mr. Miyazaki.\n\nMr. Takahata worked on television anime series like \u201cLupin the 3rd\u201d and \u201cHeidi: A Girl of the Alps,\u201d and also directed the film \u201cGauche the Cellist\u201d (1982), before the two men created Studio Ghibli.\n\nThere was no immediate information on survivors.", "title": "Isao Takahata, Leader in Japanese Animation, Dies at 82", "authors": ["Daniel E. Slotnik"]} {"date": "2018-04-08 00:00:00", "text": "Ordering China to adapt to United States tariffs could take a turn for the worse for President Trump as Beijing retaliates with tariffs of its own.", "title": "Opinion | Isn\u2019t the Panda Cute, Mr. Trump?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-26 00:00:00", "text": "Dr. Jackson\u2019s medical unit operates inside the White House, not far from the West Wing, where the president and his aides work. But an isolated managerial bubble allowed Dr. Jackson to serve three presidents for a decade while escaping scrutiny of alleged abuses of power and position. Dr. Jackson\u2019s employees were not subordinates of the White House chief of staff or the president\u2019s lawyer. Instead, the medical unit reported through a military chain of command to the little-known White House Military Office.\n\nWhen work conditions grew intolerable in the unit, it was the Navy\u2019s inspector general that stepped in, rendering a judgment in 2012 that the environment was \u201ctoxic\u201d and that one or both of the top two doctors, including Dr. Jackson, should go. But little appears to have changed.\n\nIn interviews with more than 24 people \u2014 including some of Dr. Jackson\u2019s former subordinates and a dozen White House political aides in the Trump and Obama administrations \u2014 officials said members of the medical and political staffs hardly came into contact with one another outside of routine medical treatment. They operated under different rules of behavior and rarely socialized together, even on long trips to foreign countries.\n\nMr. Trump\u2019s decision to nominate Dr. Jackson to lead the Department of Veterans Affairs, the second-largest bureaucracy in the federal government, brought the two worlds into collision, surfacing allegations against Dr. Jackson that may otherwise never have emerged.\n\nThe aftermath has raised difficult questions for officials in all three administrations, who either did not know about the accusations or looked the other way. Some said they were vaguely aware of complaints from Mr. Jackson\u2019s subordinates about his abrasive manner, which several described as frat-boy behavior; most said they largely dismissed it as griping from employees who belonged to a separate chain of command.\n\n\u201cI didn\u2019t see any of the alleged behaviors,\u201d said David Axelrod, who served as Mr. Obama\u2019s senior adviser from 2009 to 2011. \u201cMy experience was consistently positive.\u201d\n\nA few said they had heard whispers of drinking, though all of the former White House officials said they never saw him drunk on the job. But many said Dr. Jackson earned the nicknames \u201cCandyman\u201d and \u201cDr. Feelgood\u201d because he dispensed sleeping pills, muscle relaxants and other drugs with such ease.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nOne former senior White House aide who traveled regularly with the president said Dr. Jackson was known to be an eager and generous provider of Ambien, a sleep aid, and Provigil, a drug that promotes wakefulness, to staff members on presidential trips, which he would dispense in plastic baggies on Air Force One. The former aide said Dr. Jackson also doled out stronger substances, such as Xanax and the addictive opioid Percocet, readily offering them when he believed they might be helpful.\n\n\u201cHey, you\u2019re going through a tough time,\u201d he would say, according to the former aide, who spoke on the condition of anonymity. \u201cWhy don\u2019t you take a bottle of this?\u201d\n\nMr. Trump lamented on Thursday Dr. Jackson\u2019s decision to withdraw from consideration, calling him \u201can admiral, highly respected, a real leader\u201d during a telephone call to \u201cFox & Friends.\u201d The president added: \u201cThese are all false accusations. These are false. They\u2019re trying to destroy a man.\u201d\n\nAnd friends of Dr. Jackson said that they were stunned by the allegations, and insisted that he must be the victim of disgruntled former colleagues who are trying to derail a successful career.\n\n\u201cI\u2019ve literally never heard a bad word said about him by anybody that I know who\u2019s worked with him,\u201d said Dr. Gregory Ciottone, an associate professor of emergency medicine at Harvard Medical School. \u201cBy my own personal experience, he\u2019s really incredibly highly respected and just a good person.\u201d\n\nDr. Darling, who said he had breakfast recently with Dr. Jackson at the Army and Navy Club in Washington, said he never heard any rumors or speculation about alcohol abuse. He said it was unlikely to be true given the kind of security clearances that Dr. Jackson requires to do his job.\n\n\u201cTop Secret, it\u2019s called Yankee White,\u201d Dr. Darling said. \u201cThat means you\u2019ve got direct access to the president of the United States. We go up to his personal residence. We can go there unaccompanied without the Secret Service or anything. Not too many people get to do that.\u201d\n\nDr. Jackson\u2019s appointment to the White House medical unit came after a stint in western Iraq from 2005 to 2006, during some of the worst months of the conflict, where Americans were killed and maimed almost daily from roadside bombs, insurgent attacks and snipers.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHe was stationed at Al Taqaddum air base, a key hub wedged between Falluja and Ramadi, where he worked with a shock trauma platoon as the physician in charge of resuscitative medicine. In 2005, Al Taqaddum was one of three bases in one of the more volatile parts of Anbar Province that had such a platoon.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Get the Morning Briefing by Email What you need to know to start your day, delivered to your inbox Monday through Friday. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe small team of doctors and nurses often acted as the first line of medical care after an American was injured on the battlefield, providing emergency-room level care and conducting field surgical procedures before stabilizing patients and airlifting them to a larger air base.\n\nAt the White House, his service was hailed by the three presidents he served. In 2016, as President Barack Obama prepared to leave office, he called Dr. Jackson \u201can exceptional physician and leader\u201d who as the official presidential doctor had \u201cearned my complete trust and respect.\u201d\n\nBut those who worked closely with Dr. Jackson in the medical office insist that he was skilled at promoting himself to the president and top White House aides, even as he treated his nurses and doctors badly.\n\nThree former employees of the medical unit said Thursday that they had made official complaints with the legal counsel of the White House Military Office or other leaders in the unit as far back as the Obama administration. All three said the complaints seemed to go unaddressed. Officials with the military office did not respond to requests for comment.\n\nOne person familiar with the medical unit recalled an overseas trip during the Obama administration in which Dr. Jackson showed up to board Air Force One after a day of drinking. The person, who had firsthand knowledge of the episode, said there was no choice given Dr. Jackson\u2019s place in the chain of command but to give him the medical bag and allow him to board the plane, where he would be the primary physician attending to Mr. Obama on a long international flight.\n\nThe same person expressed awareness of multiple episodes in which Dr. Jackson asked subordinates to write themselves prescriptions for controlled drugs, pick them up, then deliver them to him for administration to patients. One former colleague described similar situations.\n\nThe person also had \u201cfirsthand knowledge\u201d of Dr. Jackson verbally abusing subordinates, including nurses, physicians assistants and doctors, sometimes for extended periods of time, with swear words.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWhite House officials said Thursday that despite the allegations, Dr. Jackson remains in his role as the president\u2019s physician, one he has filled since 2013. In January, Dr. Jackson praised Mr. Trump\u2019s \u201cexcellent\u201d health after conducting a battery of tests and examinations for his annual physical, earning plaudits from the president and scorn from Mr. Trump\u2019s critics.\n\nSarah Huckabee Sanders, the White House press secretary, said in a statement only that Dr. Jackson \u201cis a doctor in the United States Navy assigned to the White House and is here at work today.\u201d\n\nIvanka Trump, the president\u2019s daughter and senior adviser at the White House, tweeted her support for Dr. Jackson.\n\n\u201cAdmiral Ronny Jackson is a man of exceptional integrity, character and intellect,\u201d she wrote on Thursday. \u201cWe are grateful for his long and distinguished service to our Nation and look forward to continuing to see his warm smile each day at the White House!\u201d", "title": "Isolation of White House Medical Unit Hid Ronny Jackson From Scrutiny", "authors": ["Michael D. Shear", "Nicholas Fandos", "Sheri Fink"]} {"date": "2018-04-17 00:00:00", "text": "For many Israelis the undignified backdrop was just the latest indication that the country\u2019s leadership had forfeited any semblance of stateliness for partisanship and politics, and a sign of the country\u2019s many divisions.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s supposed to be about Israel and our story and not who takes credit for it,\u201d said Micah Goodman, a popular Israeli philosopher of Jewish thought. \u201cInstead of a moment that transcends tribalism and politics it became somehow very political. This is how you ruin the birthday party.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nOthers, however, view the ruckus as part of the usual maelstrom and the informal, freewheeling spirit that is quintessentially Israeli.\n\n\u201cThis is very typical for Israel \u2014 something that epitomizes Israeli culture,\u201d said Avi Shilon, an Israeli historian who teaches at Ben-Gurion University of the Negev and N.Y.U. Tel Aviv.\n\n\u201cWhen you think of Israeli achievements it starts from the balagan in Israeli society,\u201d he said, using a Hebrew term for mess or chaos, borrowed from Russian. \u201cEveryone wants to take it to their own direction. Sometimes this helps you to invent new methods.\u201d\n\n\u201cThe problem,\u201d he added, \u201cis of course if you want to be a serious state \u2014 and we are already 70 years old \u2014 you can expect to maintain some tradition.\u201d\n\nIsrael declared independence on May 14, 1948, but the holiday, like all national holidays here, will be observed according to the Hebrew calendar.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nPalestinians generally mark what they call the Nakba, or the catastrophe, of 1948, when hundreds of thousands of them became refugees, on May 15, the day after Israel\u2019s declaration of independence according to the Gregorian calendar. But some Arab citizens of Israel, who make up more than 20 percent of the population, are planning to hold a Nakba march on Thursday.\n\nThe ceremony promises to be a spectacle of almost Olympic proportions. On stage, three live orchestras and 1,600 people will render the digitally augmented story of Israel from Mount Sinai to the so-called start-up nation, while 300 drones are on standby to create illuminated symbols in the sky.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe main organizer of the event is Miri Regev, Israel\u2019s minister for culture and sport, an often provocative, populist politician \u2014 the newspaper Haaretz has called her \u201cTrump in high heels\u201d \u2014 and a fierce loyalist of Mr. Netanyahu.\n\nOne day last week, she strode across the stage during a tour of the site at Jerusalem\u2019s Mount Herzl, flanked by reporters and television cameras. A former brigadier general in the Israeli military, she told the chief engineer that she wanted \u201czero casualties\u201d in this event. In 2012, an Israeli Army officer was killed during a rehearsal for the ceremony\u2019s flag parade when a lighting rig fell on her.\n\nOn the way out Ms. Regev instructed an aide to check on the number of portable toilets and quantity of toilet paper, so there wouldn\u2019t be problems like in the past. \u201cWrite that down!\u201d she said.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box.
