Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cThis will be a breathtaking display, the likes of which we have never seen before in Israel,\u201d she told reporters.\n\nBut many people apportion much of the blame for the brouhaha on her campaign to have her patron, Mr. Netanyahu, lead the ceremony instead of Mr. Edelstein, whom Ms. Regev views as a potential rival within Likud.\n\nMr. Edelstein said he would boycott the ceremony if Mr. Netanyahu gave the keynote speech. Carmi Gillon, a former chief of Israel\u2019s Shin Bet internal security agency, called on Israelis to switch off their televisions while Mr. Netanyahu spoke. Netanyahu supporters said Mr. Gillon should be the last person to preach about prime ministers, since Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin was assassinated on his watch.\n\nLast week, the two sides announced a compromise that was to have ended the feud.\n\nThe prime minister\u2019s office said that Mr. Netanyahu would light one of 12 torches, representing the 12 tribes of Israel, in the name of all the governments of Israel and, like the other torch lighters, make brief remarks relating to Israel\u2019s Declaration of Independence.\n\nPhoto\n\nMr. Edelstein said in a video statement that the Parliament, \u201cwhich represents all the state\u2019s citizens, will lead the ceremony. To my regret the arguments that arose have clouded the public atmosphere and I am sorry for that.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut that was not the end of the blunders and mishaps.\n\nThe idea of inviting world leaders was quietly dropped after it appeared that few would respond positively, and the organizers belatedly realized that a large foreign presence would snarl traffic and disrupt the festivities for ordinary Israelis.\n\nYet President Juan Orlando Hern\u00e1ndez of Honduras somehow made it to the prestigious list of torch lighters, the first foreign leader given that honor.\n\nHonduras was one of nine countries to vote against a United Nations resolution condemning the Trump administration\u2019s recognition of Jerusalem as Israel\u2019s capital, and its congress passed a measure last week urging the government to move its embassy to Jerusalem. The formal reason given for the honor was that Mr. Hern\u00e1ndez is the only graduate of an Israeli government leadership development course to have become president.\n\nStill, the choice baffled many Israelis, not least because Honduras abstained from the 1947 United Nations vote for the partition of Palestine, paving the way for Israel\u2019s creation. Last week, after Israeli critics noted Mr. Hern\u00e1ndez won his second term in a disputed election and raised questions about his country\u2019s corruption and human rights record, he canceled.\n\nIsrael often tries to include an Arab citizen as a torch lighter, though many would not want to be associated with the celebration. This year, the spiritual leader of the small but loyal Druze community will light a torch.\n\nSome Israelis raised questions about another torch lighter, the Israeli actor Ze\u2019ev Revach, who has been accused of sexual harassment. The case against him was closed for lack of evidence.\n\nMayim Bialik, the American actress and neuroscientist who stars in \u201cThe Big Bang Theory,\u201d was chosen to represent the Jewish diaspora but was invited only recently. She could not change her filming schedule and so isn\u2019t going.\n\nMs. Regev said the lessons had been learned for next year.", "title": "Israel Celebrates Its 70th Israeli Style: With Rancor and Bickering", "authors": ["Isabel Kershner"]} {"date": "2018-04-18 00:00:00", "text": "The Israeli educational system perpetuates the Nakba by refusing to teach about Palestinian society before 1948. Children in public schools throughout the country, Arab and Jewish, learn about European Zionists like Theodore Herzl, who died well before the establishment of Israel, but nothing about Palestinians before 1948. One would think there was not a Palestinian artist, poet or author before Israel\u2019s founding.\n\nThe residents of the small village of Umm al-Hiran, whose 1,000 residents are Palestinian citizens of Israel, tasted the continuing Nakba bitterly last week. They have been battling with the Israeli government for years to receive recognition for their village, which would allow it to finally be connected to the water and electrical grids, and to benefit from public infrastructure like paved roads. But the state dug in its heels in and refused, bulldozing the village over and over.\n\nFinally, desperate to end the uncertainty and pain of living and raising families so precariously, the village residents signed an agreement with the government to move to a nearby town. Umm al-Hiran will be demolished, and a new town called Hiran will be built in its place. According to the planned town\u2019s bylaws, it will be home to religious Jews only; these racist requirements are legal under current Israeli law.\n\nPalestinians living in the occupied territories feel the continuing Nakba constantly, at each checkpoint that makes travel unbearable and keeps them contained, at each funeral for an unarmed protester killed by Israeli snipers and each time a settlement is built on stolen land with the blessing of the Israeli government. And if the government of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu follows through on its desires to annex the West Bank without providing full equal rights to its Palestinian residents, it won\u2019t be a new Nakba. It will be the continuation of one that has never fully ended.\n\nI don\u2019t believe that my grandparents could have imagined 70 years ago that I would become a member of Knesset, representing Palestinian citizens of Israel, a minority voice in the parliament of the country we did not ask for but that came to us on the land we have always called home. I can\u2019t know what place my children and grandchildren will have in their society in the future. But I am sure that to be able to create the kind of future I want for them \u2014 one in which they can live with equality and in peace \u2014 Israelis will have to do more than recognize the Nakba. They will have to end it.", "title": "Opinion | Israel Celebrates Its Independence, We Mourn Our Loss", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-02 00:00:00", "text": "Palestinians in Gaza are among the world\u2019s most desperate people. For more than a decade, their 140-square-mile strip has been blockaded by Israel and Egypt, sharply restricting the flow of goods and people. Indeed, many Gazans have never left the enclave, a grim measure of their prolonged isolation.\n\nUnemployment is more than 40 percent for the general population and nearly 60 percent for Palestinian youths. Last month, the United Nations warned of an imminent humanitarian disaster if global donors did not contribute $539 million for fuel for critical water, sanitation and health facilities, most for Gaza and its two million people. The remainder of the money would go to Palestinians in the West Bank and East Jerusalem.\n\nUnder such conditions, it is no wonder that pent-up frustrations would erupt in protests, as they did last Friday. Responding to the demonstrations, Israeli forces killed 17 Palestinians at the border fence that separates Israel from Gaza. More than 1,000 Palestinians were injured. It was the worst violence since the Gaza war of 2014.\n\nIsrael has a right to defend itself and maintain civil order, but it also has an obligation to respect peaceful protests and not use live ammunition on unarmed demonstrators. Israel\u2019s response appears to have been excessive, as human rights groups have asserted.", "title": "Opinion | Israel Courts Catastrophe in Gaza Protests", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-10 00:00:00", "text": "JERUSALEM \u2014 The Israeli military on Tuesday censured soldiers who filmed and cheered the shooting of a Palestinian man across the barrier fence in Gaza several months ago, in a video that added to the scrutiny of Israel over its killing of nearly 30 Palestinians in protests in the past two weeks.\n\nBut at the same time, the military defended the shooting of the man, who was standing motionless and appeared to pose no obvious threat to the soldiers at that moment. It said he was shot during a violent, two-hour riot on Dec. 22 and that the man, described as a suspected organizer, was hit in the leg and injured.\n\nThe military said the protesters hurled rocks and tried to sabotage the security fence, adding that the shooting was preceded by verbal warnings, calls to halt, riot dispersal means and warning shots.\n\n\u201cAfter none of these were successful,\u201d it said, \u201ca single bullet was fired toward one of the Palestinians who is suspected of organizing and leading this incident, while he was a few meters from the fence.\u201d", "title": "Israel Faults Soldiers Who Filmed and Cheered Shooting of Palestinian", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-30 00:00:00", "text": "Iran\u2019s deputy foreign minister, Abbas Araghchi, a top Iranian negotiator of the nuclear agreement, called Mr. Netanyahu\u2019s remarks \u201ca very childish and even a ridiculous play.\u201d\n\nIn a telephone interview with state-run television, he said Mr. Netanyahu\u2019s presentation was \u201ca prearranged show with the aim of impacting Trump\u2019s decision, or perhaps it is a coordinated plan by him and Trump in order to destroy the J.C.P.O.A.,\u201d the Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action, the nuclear agreement\u2019s formal name.\n\nMr. Netanyahu, in a highly theatrical presentation from the Israeli Defense Ministry in Tel Aviv, played clips of Iranian leaders repeatedly attesting that their country harbored no ambition for building nuclear weapons \u2014 and then pointed to photos, videos, blueprints and other evidence Israeli agents had harvested, he said, that showed the Iranians had been deceitful all along.\n\n\u201cThese files conclusively prove that Iran is brazenly lying when it said it never had a nuclear weapons program,\u201d Mr. Netanyahu said, pointing to copies of what he said were 55,000 printed pages and 183 compact discs.\n\nHe said Israel had passed the information on to the United States, which \u201ccan vouch for its authenticity.\u201d\n\nMr. Netanyahu said that Iran had intensified its efforts to hide evidence of its weapons program after signing the nuclear deal in 2015, and in 2017 moved its records to a secret location in Tehran that looked like \u201ca dilapidated warehouse.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cFew Iranians knew where it was, very few,\u201d Mr. Netanyahu said proudly. \u201cAnd also a few Israelis.\u201d\n\nThe senior Israeli official, who spoke on the condition of anonymity to discuss a secret mission, said that Israel\u2019s Mossad intelligence service discovered the warehouse in February 2016, and had the building under surveillance since then.\n\nMossad operatives broke into the building one night last January, removed the original documents and smuggled them back to Israel the same night, the official said.\n\nMr. Trump was informed of the operation by the Mossad chief, Yossi Cohen, on a visit to Washington in January, the official said. The official attributed the delay in making the material public to the time it took to analyze the documents, the vast majority of which were in Persian.\n\nBut the Iranian program to design and build nuclear weapons was hardly a secret; its existence was the reason that the United States, under President George W. Bush and then President Barack Obama, moved to block it. Both presidents said publicly that Iran had a bomb project underway, and the United States mounted, with Israel, a vast covert program to undermine the Iranian effort with one of the world\u2019s most sophisticated cyberattacks.\n\nAmerican intelligence agencies concluded in 2007 that Iran suspended the active portion of the bomb effort after the beginning of the Iraq war, in 2003, and Mr. Netanyahu confirmed that in his presentation. But he said that other elements of what Iran had called \u201cProject Amad\u201d went ahead, directed by Mohsen Fakhrizadeh, an Iranian scientist.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe documents he showed were not the first to leak out of the Iranian archives, or to document Mr. Fakhrizadeh\u2019s role.\n\nA decade ago, in early 2008, the chief inspector of the International Atomic Energy Agency gathered diplomats from around the world to a meeting at the agency\u2019s Vienna headquarters and showed them images from a similar trove, including sketches of bomb designs and memos and budget documents from Mr. Fakhrizadeh\u2019s project. That presentation included sketches of a \u201cspherical device\u201d that could be detonated using high explosives, similar to plans Mr. Netanyahu showed on Monday.\n\nThe I.A.E.A. presentation included documents showing the arc of a missile that detonates a warhead at an altitude of about 600 meters, roughly that at which the Hiroshima bomb was detonated.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Netanyahu went beyond that on Monday, and brandished what he described as Iranian plans to build up to five nuclear weapons.\n\nBut he cited no evidence that those plans were pursued.\n\nUnder the nuclear deal that Secretary of State John Kerry reached in the summer of 2015 in Vienna, Iran was required to ship about 97 percent of its nuclear fuel out of the country \u2014 a task it accomplished the next year \u2014 and to dismantle all but a small portion of the nuclear centrifuges that enrich uranium.\n\nMr. Netanyahu\u2019s best case for a violation of the Iran deal came when he insisted that the Iranians had falsified their declarations to the I.A.E.A. in late 2015, by denying they had ever planned to build a weapon.\n\nStill, even that would come as little shock to those who negotiated the deal: In effect, the agreement was made possible by allowing Iran to lie about the past, while imposing verification on it for the future.\n\n\u201cThere is nothing new in Bibi\u2019s presentation,\u201d Rob Malley, a former senior official in Mr. Obama\u2019s National Security Council and a member of the negotiating team with Iran, wrote in a Twitter post on Monday, using Mr. Netanyahu\u2019s nickname. \u201cAll it does is vindicate need for the nuclear deal.\u201d\n\n\u201cBut,\u201d Mr. Malley continued, \u201cthe Israeli prime minister has an audience of one: Trump.\u201d\n\nOn Monday night, Secretary of State Mike Pompeo said that American intelligence agencies had been going through the material, concluded that it was authentic and that \u201cat the very least the Iranians continued to lie to their own people\u201d about the existence of a nuclear weapons program.\n\nBut he conceded that the material dated to a project that had formally ended around 2003. Asked whether there was evidence that Iran was in violation of the 2015 accord, Mr. Pompeo said, \u201cI\u2019ll leave that to the lawyers, and the president will ultimately have to make a determination about that, too.\u201d But he added that Iran\u2019s refusal to turn over the archive voluntarily to international inspectors showed that the country could not be trusted with nuclear materials after the 2015 accord expires.\n\nA former senior Israeli intelligence official said the documents were significant because they revealed that Iran\u2019s nuclear program \u201cwas a far larger project\u201d than anyone knew, and proved that the Iranians were \u201con a clear path to the bomb.\u201d The official said that while none of the documents were currently operational, they provided a sort of lending library for future generations of Iranians who might want to build a nuclear weapon when restrictions in the agreement expire.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Netanyahu had a spring in his step as he strode back and forth in front of a large projection screen and yanked back a black cloth to reveal shelves and cases stacked with copies of what he said was the evidence his spies had retrieved. He described the cache, which he said amounted to a half ton of documents, as \u201cone of the biggest intelligence achievements ever by the state of Israel.\u201d\n\nHe is awaiting what is likely to be an indictment on corruption charges. He is damaged politically, and has counted for his political survival on being seen as the only leader who can be trusted to keep Israelis safe. He has been agitating single-mindedly against the nuclear deal, even at the risk of fraying Israel\u2019s close ties with the United States during the Obama administration.\n\nIranian diplomats greeted Mr. Netanyahu\u2019s accusation with derision.\n\n\u201cHa, ha, ha,\u201d said Mohammad Marandi, a University of Tehran professor who is close to Iran\u2019s leaders and participated in the nuclear talks in Vienna. He said that Israel had \u201cfabricated evidence\u201d before and might have again. He called the timing of the Israeli disclosure suspect, and raised the idea that it might have been orchestrated in cooperation with the Trump administration.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s very convenient to bring this up two weeks before the decision on the nuclear deal is made,\u201d Mr. Marandi said. \u201cNo one in their right mind will take this seriously, unless there is a prearranged deal with the White House.\u201d\n\nThe senior Israeli official also said that Israel\u2019s government believed that Mr. Trump had already decided to abandon the nuclear agreement. Israel was thus not hoping to \u201cpressure\u201d Mr. Trump by publicizing evidence of Iran\u2019s lies but rather to \u201csupport\u201d him, the official said.\n\nThe official also said that Mr. Netanyahu had intended to publicize the Iranian nuclear files a day later, but moved it up partly in response to missile strikes in Syria late Sunday night, for which suspicion has fallen on Israel. The Israeli government calculated that Iran would feel less confident in retaliating militarily, possibly setting off a full-fledged regional war, if it were on the defensive in the international arena.", "title": "Israel Says Secret Files Detail Iran\u2019s Nuclear Subterfuge", "authors": ["David M. Halbfinger", "David E. Sanger", "Ronen Bergman"]} {"date": "2018-04-05 00:00:00", "text": "Muhammad Thuraya, a Hamas representative on the organizing committee for the demonstrations, said the payments were the least the group could do. \u201cThis is our duty to our people, to ease the suffering of our citizens,\u201d he said in an interview. \u201cThis does not mean that we are promoting people for death. We will offer what we can for our people.\u201d\n\nDemonstrators set up a symbolic cemetery at the staging grounds for Friday\u2019s protest to commemorate those killed last week. But the scene was otherwise almost festive. A volleyball court was set up for a competition between teams of amputees, sponsored by the son of Ismail Haniyeh, the Hamas political director. A speaker at a mock court pronounced sentences on absent \u201cIsraeli war criminals\u201d while a small crowd watched approvingly. And Mr. Thuraya said a bride and groom would celebrate their wedding at the demonstrations on Friday afternoon.\n\nUmm Muhammad Marzoug, 44, took her four children to the site late Thursday to look around and said they would return on Friday, despite the risks. She said the economic, social and political pressures of life in Gaza had brought her to this point.\n\n\u201cWe live together, or we die together,\u201d she said.\n\nIn Israel, meanwhile, a debate broke out over the military\u2019s use of live ammunition after B\u2019Tselem, an Israeli human rights group, placed ads in the newspapers Haaretz and Maariv calling on soldiers to disregard orders to shoot. Quoting a legal precedent as well known in Israel as the My Lai massacre is in the United States \u2014 stemming from the massacre of dozens of Arab civilians in Kafr Qasim in 1956 \u2014 the group warned that some orders were so blatantly illegal that it \u201cpains the eye and outrages the heart, if the eye be not blind and the heart be not callous or corrupt.\u201d\n\n\u201cThis is part of the moral ethos of this country, something Israelis are taught in school, that army officers are taught as part of their training and that is the moral compass we\u2019re all supposed to follow,\u201d said Hagai El-Ad, B\u2019Tselem\u2019s executive director. \u201cAnd we\u2019re stating that front and center and demanding that we will follow it now.\u201d\n\nGeneral Manelis would not discuss the rules of engagement for Israeli soldiers, and particularly snipers, on when to use live ammunition as opposed to rubber bullets, tear gas or other means of riot control.\n\nBut former Israeli military lawyers argued that there were plenty of situations in which firing on unarmed demonstrators could be justified.", "title": "Israel and Gaza Brace for Round 2 of Protests at Border Fence", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-03 00:00:00", "text": "No, we\u2019re not talking about President Trump\u2019s tweets.\n\nBefitting the current era of strongmen, President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey also has a well-honed strategy for winning public support. Its flag takes a similar hybrid approach.\n\n\n\nThe flag was approved by the Chinese national legislature 28 years ago this week. It was first raised on July 1, 1997, the day Hong Kong was returned to Chinese rule after more than 150 years as a British colony and territory.\n\nThe flag was designed to reflect Hong Kong\u2019s new relationship with the People\u2019s Republic of China. It is the same shade of red as the Chinese national flag.\n\nIn the center is a white flower from the Bauhinia blakeana, or Hong Kong orchid tree. (The real flower is a purplish pink and is not actually an orchid.) Stars on each of the five petals echo the five stars on the Chinese flag.\n\nThe flag\u2019s two colors are said to represent the \u201cone country, two systems\u201d principle under which China agreed to rule Hong Kong for the first 50 years.\n\nIn recent years, Hong Kong protesters have waved the British colonial flag to express their displeasure with the way Beijing governs. Since the handover in 1997, lawmakers and activists in Hong Kong have also been prosecuted for desecrating the Chinese and Hong Kong flags.\n\nJennifer Jett contributed reporting.\n\n_____\n\nYour Morning Briefing is published weekday mornings and updated online.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nCheck out this page to find a Morning Briefing for your region. Contact us at europebriefing@nytimes.com.", "title": "Israel, Winnie Mandela, Seduction: Your Tuesday Briefing", "authors": ["Dan Levin"]} {"date": "2018-04-02 00:00:00", "text": "He said he was suspending the deal with the United Nations refugee agency pending a meeting on Tuesday morning with the veteran residents of south Tel Aviv, where many of the African migrants are concentrated, and that he would then review the understandings reached with the agency.\n\nThe European Union\u2019s delegation in Israel was incredulous.\n\n\u201cGuess it\u2019s just one of those days,\u201d the delegation wrote on Twitter. \u201cAt 20:57 you congratulate #Israel & @refugees on their agreement, at 21:46 you like @IsraelMFA announcement on the deal, at 22:50 the PM suspends it and blames, among others, #EU (where #UNHCR hoped to resettle significant number of refugees).\u201d\n\nThe New Israel Fund accused Mr. Netanyahu of lying, saying the organization, which has offered support for the asylum seekers in Israel, \u201chad nothing to do with Rwanda\u2019s decision to refuse to participate in the Prime Minister\u2019s cruel mass deportation plan.\u201d\n\n\u201cIt is pathetic, shameful, and a stain on Israel in the global arena that the Prime Minister would blame Israel\u2019s human rights defenders for his ineptitude and his immoral policies,\u201d the New Israel Fund said in a statement.\n\nEarlier, at the news conference, Mr. Netanyahu revealed details of the new deal.\n\n\u201cThe agreement states that for every person who leaves, one will stay,\u201d he said, noting that the refugee agency would be financing the departure. \u201cI think it\u2019s a good solution, a proper solution.\u201d\n\nThe plan was to be carried out in three phases, with the first 6,000 migrants expected to leave over the next 18 months.\n\nWilliam Spindler, a spokesman for the United Nations refugee agency in Geneva, said there was no agreement in place with other countries to take any of them. He said that the agency would need countries to come forward with offers, but that \u201cwe are confident we will be able to find places for these 16,000 people.\u201d", "title": "Israeli Leader Is Forced to Retreat on African Migrant Deal", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-25 00:00:00", "text": "More than three dozen Palestinians have been killed along the Gaza border since March 30, including two 14-year-olds. A Gaza journalist who was shot in mid-April succumbed to his wounds and died on Wednesday, according to Gaza health officials. He was the second Palestinian journalist to have been killed during the Friday protests.\n\nThe verdict also came more than a year after a military court convicted Sgt. Elor Azaria of manslaughter for shooting a Palestinian assailant in the head as he lay wounded on the ground in the West Bank city of Hebron, in a case that polarized Israelis. Sergeant Azaria received an 18-month prison sentence that was later reduced to 14 months.\n\nMr. Deri, who was 21 at the time of the shooting in Beitunia, was initially charged with manslaughter and was accused of deliberately shooting live rounds. Under the plea deal, he admitted to firing a live round by accident after failing to check that his magazine contained only blanks and after failing to load a rubber bullet into an adapter affixed to the muzzle of his rifle.\n\nAccording to court documents, Mr. Deri expressed regret for aiming and firing at the young man but provided no motive.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe shooting of the teenager, as he strode on a road during a break in the stone-throwing, a school bag on his back and his arms by his side, was caught on video taken by a security camera at a business along the road. The court found that he had thrown a stone toward the security force a few minutes before he was shot.\n\nA second protester was killed about an hour later during the same demonstration, but that case was closed for lack of evidence.\n\nNadeem\u2019s father, who ran a hair salon, pored over video footage and news photographs from the protest for months and submitted his findings to the Israeli police to help build a case against those responsible for his son\u2019s death. He also allowed the Palestinian authorities to hand over a bullet he had found lodged in his son\u2019s backpack to the Israelis for forensic testing.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nAfter attending the sentencing at the Jerusalem District Court on Wednesday, Mr. Nawara said he had expected the verdict after the plea deal was reached between the defendant and the prosecution.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cWe presented the court with all of the evidence and even with photos of Ben Deri loading his weapon and shooting at Nadeem,\u201d he said. \u201cIn addition, witnesses confirmed he is a very meticulous person in his behavior and this stands at odds with the \u2018negligent killing\u2019 clause.\u201d\n\nAhmad Tibi, an Arab legislator in the Israeli Parliament, called the verdict \u201cridiculous,\u201d writing on Twitter, \u201cYou could get a harsher punishment for texting while driving.\u201d\n\nHanan Ashrawi, a senior Palestine Liberation Organization official, said Mr. Deri\u2019s nine-month sentence was \u201cludicrous\u201d given that Ahed Tamimi, a Palestinian teenager from the West Bank village of Nabi Saleh, was sentenced last month by an Israeli military court to eight months in prison for slapping, punching and kicking an Israeli soldier at the entrance to her home. Ms. Tamimi has become a feisty symbol of resistance against the Israeli occupation.\n\nMr. Deri was also ordered to pay the Nawara family 50,000 shekels (about $14,000).\n\nHis lawyer, Zion Amir, described Mr. Deri as \u201can outstanding combat soldier who fulfilled his mission and was there to defend us.\u201d\n\nIn his verdict, the judge, Daniel Teperberg, recounted the events of that afternoon in Beitunia. \u201cAt about 13:41 the deceased threw a stone toward the force,\u201d he wrote in the judgment. \u201cThe stone throwing stopped at about 13:45. Then the accused decided to hit the deceased by firing a rubber bullet.\u201d\n\n\u201cAgainst the regulations, although no danger was posed to the force by the deceased, the accused aimed his weapon at the center of the deceased\u2019s torso and fired at him with the intention of injuring him.\u201d\n\nThe weapon held a live round, the judge said.\n\n\u201cThe live bullet fired by the accused penetrated the chest of the deceased, who collapsed on the spot,\u201d he wrote.", "title": "Israeli Who Shot Palestinian Teenager Is Sentenced to 9 Months in Prison", "authors": ["Isabel Kershner"]} {"date": "2018-04-24 00:00:00", "text": "TEL AVIV \u2014 It\u2019s been obvious to me for some time that the Israeli-Arab conflict is to wider global geopolitical trends what Off Broadway is to Broadway. If you want a hint of what\u2019s coming to a geopolitical theater near you, study this region. You can see it all here in miniature. That certainly applies to what\u2019s becoming the most destabilizing and morally wrenching geopolitical divide on the planet today \u2014 the divide between what I call the \u201cWorld of Order\u201d and the \u201cWorld of Disorder.\u201d\n\nAnd Israel is right on the seam \u2014 which is why the last major fence Israel built was not to keep West Bank Palestinians from crossing into Israel but to keep more Africans from walking from their homes in Africa, across the Sinai Desert, into Israel.\n\nSo many new nations that were created in the last century are failing or falling apart under the stresses of population explosions, climate change, corruption, tribalism and unemployment. As these states deteriorate, they\u2019re hemorrhaging millions of people \u2014 more refugees and migrants are on the road today than at any other time since World War II \u2014 people trying to get out of the violent and unstable World of Disorder and into the World of Order.\n\nThe Broadway versions are the vast number of migrants from failing states in Central America trying to get into the U.S. and from the Arab world and Africa trying to get into Europe. The Off Broadway version is playing out in Israel, to which, since 2012, roughly 60,000 Africans from Sudan, Eritrea and Ethiopia have trekked \u2014 not to find kosher food, Al Aqsa Mosque or the Via Dolorosa, but stability and a job.", "title": "Opinion | Israel\u2019s Got Its Own Refugee Dilemma: African \u2018Dreamers\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-11 00:00:00", "text": "But in general, the protests have been peaceful, with many demonstrators staying far back from the heavily fortified fence to picnic and hold a tent camp sit-in. There has been no apparent reason for Israel to use live ammunition.\n\nThe government claims that the protests are a cover for a more violent Hamas agenda, including encouraging Gazans to penetrate the fence and push into Israel. Israel has a right to defend its border, but in the face of unarmed civilians it could do so with nonlethal tactics common to law enforcement, such as the use of high-powered fire hoses.\n\nSince the protests began, Israeli forces have killed at least 29 Palestinians and wounded more than 1,000. On the day Mr. Murtaja died, eight other Palestinians were killed and five other journalists were among a thousand injured. There have been no known Israeli casualties.\n\nThe fact that Mr. Murtaja and the wounded journalists wore protective vests with signs proclaiming \u201cPRESS\u201d on the front has prompted suspicion that Israel deliberately targeted the journalists, as Reporters Without Borders, an activist group, and Rushdi Al Sarraj, Mr. Murtaja\u2019s friend and sometime collaborator, have alleged. In an interview with The New Yorker, Mr. Al Sarraj recalled how the Israeli Army had earlier boasted that its soldiers were so precise and competent they \u201cknow where they put every bullet and where every bullet landed.\u201d\n\nThe Israeli military has said its forces did not intentionally shoot journalists. But that assertion was undercut by Avigdor Lieberman, the Israeli defense minister, who said on Tuesday that Mr. Murtaja was a Hamas captain who had used a drone to collect intelligence on Israeli forces. That volatile charge is at odds with independent news reporting and, if it is false, could put other journalists at grave risk. Mr. Lieberman provided no proof for the claim and further demonstrated his disdain for justice, rule of law and the role of a free press by arguing on Sunday that there are \u201cno innocent people\u201d in Hamas-run Gaza.", "title": "Opinion | Israel\u2019s Violent Response to Nonviolent Protests", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-11 00:00:00", "text": "Bytedance \u2014 which investors valued at more than $30 billion recently, putting it more in the financial league of Airbnb or SpaceX than of Buzzfeed or Vice \u2014 has assembled a confederation of these buzzy new apps. And it has made no secret of its desire to dominate phone screens across the rest of the world, too.\n\nThe company says it uses artificial intelligence technology to figure out what users like, then makes sure they are fed more and more of it. Read a few articles on the trade spat between the United States and China, and soon your Toutiao feed will be populated with news on international relations. Watch a bunch of stand-up comedy shows, and before long the app will suggest new comics who might appeal.\n\nBytedance has spent top dollar hiring engineers and software experts to fine-tune its recommendation technology.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s like having a chef in your house who knows what kind of food you like,\u201d said Xu Qinglu, a 22-year-old student and Toutiao user in Beijing.\n\n\u201cI think the app is not harmful,\u201d she added. \u201cThe people who use it should be responsible for their own behavior.\u201d\n\nAt an event in Beijing last month, Mr. Zhang said he hoped that more than half of the company\u2019s users would come from outside China within the next three years. At the moment, he said, one in 10 of its users was overseas.\n\nFirst, though, the company needs to continue thriving in China. Bytedance\u2019s detractors say that salty, unwholesome material \u2014 the sort that has the Chinese government on edge these days \u2014 is exactly what the company\u2019s apps have specialized in, and is a major reason for its popularity.", "title": "It Built an Empire of GIFs, Buzzy News and Jokes. China Isn\u2019t Amused.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-19 00:00:00", "text": "The dispute over who was the first to score one million points in the classic Donkey Kong arcade game has captivated gamers for more than a decade.\n\nThe battle was even the subject of an award-winning 2007 documentary, \u201cThe King of Kong: A Fistful of Quarters.\u201d\n\nEarlier this month, after an extensive forensic analysis, the video game adjudicator Twin Galaxies handed off the long-ago title \u2014 or the bragging rights at least \u2014 to Steve Wiebe, the mild-mannered math teacher familiar to fans of that film.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s a sweet victory now to have it finally recognized,\u201d Mr. Wiebe, 49, said.\n\nHis rival in the movie, Billy Mitchell, 52, the hot-sauce entrepreneur and former champion known for his thumbs-up poses and patriotic ties, has been cast from the record books and barred for life from being listed on Twin Galaxies leader boards.", "title": "It Could Be Game Over for a Onetime King of Donkey Kong", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-01 00:00:00", "text": "Higher education in the United States is largely decentralized, dependent on about 75 regional, national and specialized accrediting agencies to serve as watchdogs for postsecondary institutions that have access to federal student aid. The agencies are relied upon to regularly evaluate the quality of institutions to ensure they comply with federal education law. The accreditors are responsible for flagging and penalizing schools that do not.\n\nMost public, private and nonprofit higher education institutions are regionally accredited, while national and specialized accreditors tend to draw for-profit and trade schools. To receive federal financial aid funding, schools must be accredited by an Education Department-recognized agency. The Accrediting Council for Independent Colleges and Schools was responsible for about 240 institutions that received $4.7 billion in taxpayer money when it came under scrutiny in 2015.\n\nFor-profit accreditation has faced scrutiny dating back to the early years of the G.I. Bill, when the institutions were accused of preying on veterans who received large sums of federal education funding when they returned from war.\n\nBut it had been decades since the for-profit sector felt as targeted as it did under the Obama administration, industry leaders say. And they contend that a reinstatement of the banished accrediting council could remedy the unfair treatment meted out by the previous White House. A federal judge recently ruled that the department had acted \u201carbitrarily and capriciously\u201d in determining the council\u2019s fate.\n\n\u201cAll we have ever asked for is due process and fairness,\u201d said Steve Gunderson, a former Republican congressman who leads the trade organization Career Education Colleges and Universities. \u201cWe now hope the current secretary will recognize the need to work with A.C.I.C.S. and the schools impacted by this ruling.\u201d\n\nThe independent advisory committee that vets accrediting bodies, called the National Advisory Committee on Institutional Quality and Integrity, will consider the council\u2019s application in May, just a few weeks before dozens of schools serving at least 100,000 students that are still operating under its purview will lose accreditation.\n\nThe chairman of the bipartisan committee is Arthur Keiser, a political appointee who challenged the panel\u2019s original recommendation to terminate the council\u2019s recognition. He also formerly ran a for-profit college, Keiser University, that settled claims of misrepresentation before he sold it to a nonprofit organization started by his family.", "title": "It Oversaw For-Profit Colleges That Imploded. Now It Seeks a Comeback.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-30 00:00:00", "text": "Seventeen years after nearly 3,000 freelance journalists filed a class-action lawsuit claiming copyright infringement by some of the country\u2019s biggest publishers, the checks are finally in the mail.\n\nThe 2,500 writers who made it through the tortuous legal process will start receiving their pieces of a settlement totaling $9 million this week.\n\n\u201cWe\u2019ve been at the finish line for this lawsuit for a very long time, and so it is great that it\u2019s finally happening,\u201d said the writer James Gleick, the president of the Authors Guild and one of the named plaintiffs in the case. \u201cBut it\u2019s also certainly a victory tinged with bitterness, because 17 years doesn\u2019t make sense.\u201d\n\n\n\nThe Authors Guild filed the suit \u2014 along with the American Society of Journalists and Authors, the National Writers Union and 21 freelance writers named as class representatives \u2014 in 2001 after publishers licensed articles by freelancers to the electronic database Lexis/Nexis and other digital indexers without getting the writers\u2019 approval. But there also could be something to the makeup of their lineup.\n\nOn Wednesday, the Mets\u2019 second through seventh hitters were all over 30 years old. Players decline in their 30s, as we know, which is why older players found such lukewarm interest in free agency last winter. But perhaps if those players are good enough \u2014 and well rested \u2014 their experience can make a difference.\n\n\u201cEverybody talks about age, but I feel like I\u2019m one of the hardest workers out there at age 32, and some of these other guys too on this team,\u201d said third baseman Todd Frazier, who signed with the Mets in February for two years and $17 million, after earning more than $20 million the last two years.\n\n\u201cIt was a tough off-season, it was terrible, people don\u2019t really know what we went through. I\u2019m not trying to prove anything, but at the same time, I\u2019m trying to show I can still do it and still put up numbers at this age.\u201d\n\nHis numbers are stellar \u2014 a .291 average, 13 runs batted in and a team-high 15 walks \u2014 like those of second baseman Asdrubal Cabrera, whose $8.25 million option the Mets exercised in November. Cabrera is hitting .343 with four homers, and while his average almost certainly will fall, Cespedes, at .217, will almost certainly improve.\n\n\u201cThe reason we believe is we have a lot of different ways to score runs and prevent runs and win games,\u201d right fielder Jay Bruce said.\n\nWell, he was told, the Mets don\u2019t have much speed.\n\n\u201cBut we run the bases,\u201d Bruce said. \u201cLook at Asdrubal. You don\u2019t have to be fast to run the bases well. Guys are getting base hits; we\u2019re not all or nothing. We\u2019re taking good at-bats, Todd is walking. You don\u2019t want to be the guy to take the bad at-bat. It\u2019s a concerted effort of not letting the game speed up on us.\u201d", "title": "It\u2019s Early, but the Mets Are Starting to Believe Again", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-10 00:00:00", "text": "The special counsel\u2019s indictments of Paul Manafort, Rick Gates and Alex van der Zwaan outline a system of international graft. Mr. Manafort and Mr. Gates are charged with laundering millions of dollars gained from their work for unscrupulous oligarchs. Mr. van der Zwaan entered the picture when Mr. Manafort commissioned his law firm to help clean up the image of the corrupt Ukrainian government \u2014 an effort in which numerous well-connected Washington lobbyists were involved, though none disclosed their work publicly.\n\nMr. Mueller is also investigating the money that came in to Mr. Trump\u2019s business and campaign from Russia and Eastern Europe, in some cases examining whether wealthy Russians provided campaign donations improperly. On Monday, The Times reported that Mr. Mueller is looking into contributions made to the Trump Foundation by the Ukrainian steel magnate Victor Pinchuk in exchange for a video campaign speech by Mr. Trump at a conference in Kiev, raising questions over whether Mr. Trump allowed the line to be blurred between charitable donations and political influence.\n\nMr. Mueller hasn\u2019t hinted at any conclusions, but it is clear that the Russian trolls indicted in February were able to run political advertisements on Facebook in part because of lax and under-enforced regulations that failed to constrain foreign spending in American elections. Senator Sheldon Whitehouse, Democrat of Rhode Island, has argued that it will be difficult to restrict such spending in the future, even on grounds of national security, because stricter campaign finance legislation runs counter to the interests of donors on whom lawmakers rely for funds.\n\nThen, of course, there\u2019s Stephanie Clifford, also known as Stormy Daniels. On Monday, F.B.I. agents raided the home, office and hotel room of Mr. Trump\u2019s longtime attorney, Michael Cohen, who is reportedly being investigated for bank fraud, wire fraud and violations of campaign finance law. Among the materials reportedly seized by the F.B.I. were documents relating to Ms. Daniels, to whom Mr. Cohen made a $130,000 payment under the terms of a nondisclosure agreement to prevent her from speaking out about her sexual encounter with Mr. Trump. As legal analysts have written, whoever was behind the payment to Ms. Daniels \u2014 Mr. Cohen claims that his client, then running for president, had no knowledge of the agreement \u2014 it\u2019s likely that it ran afoul of disclosure requirements for campaign contributions.\n\nThough Ms. Daniels has disclaimed any connection to the #MeToo movement, Mr. Trump\u2019s efforts to keep her quiet are strikingly similar to what has been uncovered about the legal mechanics used to silence victims of Harvey Weinstein\u2019s abuse. Her experience is an illustration of how powerful men use money and connections to shield themselves from consequences, perhaps straying over the line of what the law allows. Part of Ms. Daniels\u2019s appeal is her willingness to explain how these things work, recalling Mr. Trump\u2019s own insistence that he could \u201cdrain the swamp\u201d precisely because he knew how it was filled.", "title": "Opinion | It\u2019s Mueller, Not Trump, Who Is Draining the Swamp", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-06 00:00:00", "text": "Verizon is trying to determine how a portable 4G LTE hot spot could work in an area \u201cwhere a disaster had impacted Verizon service and there is no other way to get cellular coverage to that location,\u201d said Christopher Desmond, a principal engineer for the company. The trial in Cape May was the company\u2019s second in New Jersey and it reaffirmed the viability of the concept, Mr. Desmond said.\n\nVerizon is not alone in exploring the use of drones to help when disasters strike.\n\nIn 2017, AT&T won a $7 billion federal government contract to construct a nationwide disaster readiness network called FirstNet. Parts of the program will include technology to provide cell service from the sky. When Hurricane Harvey struck Houston and Hurricane Maria battered Puerto Rico, AT&T relied on mobile hot spots driven to sites and raised onto masts to provide cellphone service. The company also can launch a remote four-rotor hovering drone known as a Cell on Wings, which is tethered to ground cables for data exchange and power. (Verizon service was not knocked out by Harvey and the company does not provide cellphone service in Puerto Rico).\n\n\u201cA vast majority of the time\u201d the combination of a truck and a mast will solve the communications problem, said Chris Sambar, a senior vice president at AT&T. \u201cBut there are times where what\u2019s needed is a drone.\u201d\n\nIn addition to providing phone and other data services for emergency responders, Verizon is pursuing other possible uses for drones.\n\n\u201cWe envision the ability for the aircraft to have a camera onboard to collect the photographic data and beam it to the ground,\u201d Mr. Desmond said, providing situational awareness at the scene and also at a command center. That, he said, would enable better collaboration between those inside and outside a disaster zone.", "title": "It\u2019s Not a Bird or a Plane. It\u2019s a 17-Foot Drone, and It\u2019s Here to Save Your Cellphone Service.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-03 00:00:00", "text": "It\u2019s always sweater weather for Samuel Barsky.\n\nOh look! There he is standing in front of the skating rink at Rockefeller Center wearing a sweater adorned with ice skaters. That\u2019s him too at the Luxor hotel in Las Vegas with a pyramid on his chest. And last summer he posted a photograph on Instagram in front of Niagara Falls with a sweater depicting (what else?) the famous waterfalls.\n\nCoincidence? No.\n\nFor nearly 20 years Mr. Barsky, 43, has been knitting sweaters of familiar landscapes and, in recent years, posting photographs of himself posing in front of them, wearing his matching jumper.\n\nSo far, he has created 119 sweaters in all \u2014 including scenes of the Golden Gate Bridge, the Twin Towers, Stonehenge and Jerusalem\u2019s Western Wall \u2014 which he has chronicled by year on his website.", "title": "It\u2019s Sweater Weather Forever", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-17 00:00:00", "text": "Thoreau, a committed abolitionist and conductor on the Underground Railroad, denounced the American government\u2019s tolerance of the institution of slavery, as well as \u201cthe present Mexican war, the work of comparatively a few individuals using the standing government as their tool.\u201d\n\nFor abolitionists, slavery and the Mexican-American War were not unrelated; they worried the mammoth new territory acquired from Mexico at gunpoint \u2014 the current states of Texas, New Mexico, Utah, California and Nevada and parts of Arizona, Colorado, Kansas, Oklahoma and Wyoming \u2014 would spread slavery to the Pacific. (It\u2019s demoralizing to realize how much of American political history is animated not by the question of should there be slavery but rather should there be slavery in the West.)\n\nTo protest, for six years Thoreau did not pay his taxes. He asks, \u201cWhen I meet a government which says to me, \u2018Your money or your life,\u2019 why should I be in haste to give it my money?\u201d And so he went to jail \u2014 for a single night. \u201cFor some one\u201d \u2014 probably his aunt \u2014 \u201cinterfered, and paid that tax.\u201d\n\nRereading \u201cCivil Disobedience\u201d annually, around tax time, is on the same to-do list as sending forms to my accountant and gathering the wadded-up receipts that suggest that my job is not writing but drinking tea in airports. Because the point of Thoreau\u2019s admitted \u201charsh and stubborn and unconciliatory\u201d rant is worth remembering at least once a year: Our money makes us complicit. You and I paid for the rope at Abu Ghraib just as our forebears footed the bill for Gen. Winfield Scott and Capt. Robert E. Lee to dock at Veracruz in 1847 and follow the trail blazed by Hern\u00e1n Cort\u00e9s to storm Mexico City because the guy in the White House really needed Utah.\n\nFor those of us more wishy-washy than Henry Thoreau \u2014 and that would be all of us \u2014 the bright side of our fiscal complicity is that we also get to chip in for things we believe in. Two words: Pell Grants. While I\u2019m irked about shelling out for the president\u2019s racist shenanigans on the Mexican border, I would happily fund boring ambassadors to South Korea, Jordan, Saudi Arabia, Turkey, Cuba, Egypt, the European Union, etc. Curious to hear about how Alexander Hamilton might not have single-handedly won the Battle of Yorktown? Head to Yorktown Battlefield National Park and catch one of Linda Williams\u2019s taxpayer-supported ranger talks.\n\nOr if, every year, you file taxes wondering how much of your money will end up subsidizing appalling policies and covert operations you will eventually hear about from that cool customer who narrates \u201cFrontline,\u201d take heart that you are also partly funding \u201cFrontline.\u201d For now.", "title": "Opinion | It\u2019s Tax Day. Don\u2019t Forget to Read Thoreau.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-23 00:00:00", "text": "If we did create conscious beings, conventional morality tells us that it would be wrong to harm them \u2014 precisely to the degree that they are conscious, and can suffer or be deprived of happiness. Just as it would be wrong to breed animals for the sake of torturing them, or to have children only to enslave them, it would be wrong to mistreat the conscious machines of the future.\n\nBut how will we know if our machines become conscious? Descartes argued that one\u2019s own consciousness is beyond any possibility of doubt. In the case of others, we\u2019re never absolutely sure. Many of us have entertained, if only for a moment, the idea that everyone else might be a zombie: laughing, crying, complaining, rejoicing, but with no one home. Perhaps scientists will eventually discover the signature of consciousness, and then we will be able to test for it in our robots, as well as in animals and one another. But it is certain that we will build machines that seem conscious long before we arrive at that point.\n\nAnything that looks and acts like the hosts on \u201cWestworld\u201d will appear conscious to us, whether or not we understand how consciousness emerges in physical systems. Indeed, experiments with AI and robotics have already shown how quick we are to attribute feelings to machines that look and behave like independent agents. Multiply that temptation to anthropomorphize a thousandfold: Think not of a machine with visible wires, cartoonish eyes and a voice that sounds like Siri but of a beautiful stranger who engages you in intelligent conversation and who may be more aware of your emotions than your spouse or best friends ever were. It would be irresistible to see this creature as a person, whatever your philosophical views and regardless of what its creators told you about how it was built.\n\nThis is where actually watching \u201cWestworld\u201d matters. The pleasure of entertainment aside, the makers of the series have produced a powerful work of philosophy. It\u2019s one thing to sit in a seminar and argue about what it would mean, morally, if robots were conscious. It\u2019s quite another to witness the torments of such creatures, as portrayed by actors such as Evan Rachel Wood and Thandie Newton. You may still raise the question intellectually, but in your heart and your gut, you already know the answer.\n\nWatching the show, you also discover how you feel about the people who rape, torture and kill these robots. We have no idea how many people would actually behave this way in a place like Westworld (the show implies that there\u2019s no shortage of such customers), but there is something repugnant about those who do. In this scenario, the robot hosts are the most human and the humans who abuse them are monsters.\n\nKant had odd views about animals, seeing them as mere things, devoid of moral value, but he insisted on their proper treatment because of the implications for how we treat one another: \u201cFor he who is cruel to animals becomes hard also in his dealings with men.\u201d We could surely say the same for the treatment of lifelike robots. Even if we could be certain that they weren\u2019t conscious and couldn\u2019t really suffer, their torture would very likely harm the torturer and, ultimately, the other people in his life.\n\nThis may seem like an extreme version of the worry that many have about violent video games. It has long been speculated that enacting violence in a virtual world desensitizes people to violence in the real one. The evidence for such an effect turns out to be weak. In fact, as video games have become increasingly realistic, the rate of violent crime has dropped.\n\nBut the prospect of building a place like \u201cWestworld\u201d is much more troubling, because the experience of harming a host isn\u2019t merely similar to that of harming a person; it\u2019s identical. We have no idea what repeatedly indulging such fantasies would do to us, ethically or psychologically \u2014 but there seems little reason to think that it would be good.", "title": "Opinion | It\u2019s Westworld. What\u2019s Wrong With Cruelty to Robots?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-09 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cThat this bloodsucking worm might suddenly advance conservation efforts is something few would have predicted,\u201d he said.\n\nTerrestrial leeches are found in humid regions stretching from Madagascar to southern Asia to a number of Pacific islands. Some 70 species have been described, with many more likely awaiting discovery.\n\nThey\u2019re a diverse bunch: some are drab brown, others strikingly patterned in greens, reds and blues. Some crawl across the forest floor in search of a meal, while others occupy leafy perches and leap onto unsuspecting hosts.\n\nPhoto\n\nThey all share a taste for blood. The tiny vampires may swell to 10 times their body weight after feeding, transforming from agile, threadlike worms into engorged blood sausages. Remnants of a leech\u2019s last gluttonous meal may remain in its body for months \u2014 a boon for researchers curious to see what it previously fed on.\n\nThe idea of using leech blood meals as an identification tool may have been inspired by a criminal case in Tasmania in 2009. Investigators recovered DNA from a blood-filled leech to link a suspect to a robbery.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSeveral years later, researchers published the first field study showing that the method worked to identify wildlife, too. While encouraging, the initial study was based on a sample of just 25 leeches caught in Vietnam.\n\nEager to see if the method might be applicable on a much broader scale, Dr. Tessler and his colleagues set out to conduct an investigation in Bangladesh, China and Cambodia.\n\nThe first step \u2014 collection \u2014 was simple, said Sarah Weiskopf, a biologist at the United States Geological Survey and co-author of the new papers: \u201cYou just get to your spot in the forest and look around for things crawling toward you.\u201d\n\nOf the thousands of leeches Ms. Weiskopf, Dr. Tessler and their colleagues captured, 750 were selected for genetic analysis. The researchers cut out the parasites\u2019 digestive tracts and filtered them to extract DNA.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThey used primers \u2014 short, known sequences of genetic material \u2014 to separate mammal from leech DNA, and then they sequenced the results and compared them to a genetic database of known species.\n\nLeeches, the researchers reported in the journal Systematics and Biodiversity, are far from picky eaters: the parasites had fed on 26 different mammal species, plus three birds.\n\nNguyen Quang Hoa Anh, a project manager for the World Wildlife Fund in Vietnam who was not involved in the research, has been using leeches for several years to survey wildlife in remote jungles near the Lao border. He confirmed their utility as a monitoring tool, especially when paired with other methods.\n\n\u201cWe need as much information as we can possibly get if we are going to identify endangered species and head off the extinction crisis,\u201d he said.\n\nResearchers have traditionally made such identifications by catching animals, collecting hair or dung samples, or setting up camera traps. Capture stresses out and sometimes injures animal subjects, however, and hair and dung can be difficult to find.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nCamera traps are the current gold standard in tropical rain forests, but they tend to require significant time and expense.\n\nIn the second study, published in The Journal of Applied Ecology and led by Ms. Weiskopf, then at the University of Delaware, the researchers aimed to compare camera traps to leech collection. The researchers set up 30 camera trap sites in four forest reserves in Bangladesh and captured 200 leeches in the same spots.\n\nWhile the leeches produced evidence of 12 species of mammals (including a small rodent, the Tanezumi rat, that the camera traps missed), the cameras documented 26 species. But Ms. Weiskopf pointed out that the cameras were rolling for nearly nine months, while the leeches were collected in just four days.\n\nSimply collecting a few more leeches, Ms. Weiskopf said, could potentially put the method on par with camera trapping \u2014 especially when time and money are taken into account. The leech work cost just $3,770, while the camera traps came in at $24,800.\n\nGiven these advantages, Ms. Weiskopf said, \u201cleeches could really complement some of our already existing biodiversity-monitoring methods, and move forward some existing biodiversity conservation efforts.\u201d\n\nFuture studies, Dr. Tessler added, could be made even more efficient by blending hundreds of leeches into a slurry and genetically sequencing all of their blood meals in one go.\n\n\u201cI don\u2019t know how big this will become, but I think leeches have quite a bit of potential,\u201d he said. \u201cThis is just a fascinating method.\u201d", "title": "It\u2019s the Latest in Conservation Tech. And It Wants to Suck Your Blood.", "authors": ["Rachel Nuwer"]} {"date": "2018-04-09 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Guest, however, researching the archives of the Paris Opera, found the violin arrangement for a pas de deux that the ballerina Fanny Elssler had added to \u201cLa Fille\u201d in the 1830s; this music used items from Donizetti\u2019s opera \u201cL\u2019Elisir d\u2019Amore.\u201d\n\nThe conductor-composer John Lanchbery, who was working with Mr. Ashton, incorporated the piece into his new arrangement for \u201cLa Fille.\u201d The suite became known as \u201cthe Fanny Elssler pas de deux,\u201d and contains the ballet\u2019s greatest display of ebullient virtuosity.\n\nIvor Forbes Guest was born on April 20, 1920, in Chislehurst, Kent, England. As a lawyer he became a senior partner at Tweedie & Prideaux, with offices at Lincoln\u2019s Inn Fields, London. But he was best known for historical research, and it was his birthplace that inspired him to follow his passion.\n\nAfter Mr. Guest learned that Napoleon III of France had spent his last days in Chislehurst, in the 1870s, he wrote \u201cNapoleon III in England,\u201d published in 1952. His enthusiasm for ballet led him to later investigate the ballet of Napoleon III\u2019s era.\n\nBallet also had triumphant periods in England, and Mr. Guest wrote a number books on 19th- and early-20th-century ballet in London. The most important of these is \u201cThe Romantic Ballet in England\u201d (1953), which covers the phenomenal period in the 1840s when the impresario Benjamin Lumley, hiring the young dancer-choreographer Jules Perrot as his ballet master, briefly made Her Majesty\u2019s Theater in London into a more prestigious center for ballet than the Paris Opera.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWith the young Queen Victoria often in the audience, the world\u2019s foremost ballerinas appeared there, sometimes in duets, trios and quartets, with Perrot making creative breakthroughs in terms of both narrative ballet and pure-dance divertissements.\n\nNonetheless, the Paris Opera Ballet generally remained the central institution of ballet as a professional art form for at least two centuries after its inception in 1672. Mr. Guest soon became the leading authority on the history of Parisian ballet, writing two overall histories \u2014 the first published in French, \u201cLe Ballet de l\u2019Op\u00e9ra de Paris\u201d (1976).\n\nMore valuable yet, and far more detailed, are his four books on individual periods of the Paris Opera Ballet. Though not written in the order of the eras they cover, they amount to a sequential tetralogy of the history of ballet at the Paris Opera between 1750 and 1870: \u201cThe Ballet of the Enlightenment\u201d (1996), \u201cBallet Under Napoleon\u201d (2001), \u201cThe Romantic Ballet in Paris\u201d (1966), and \u201cThe Ballet of the Second Empire, 1858-1870\u201d (1974), an amalgamation of two earlier books on the topic. In all of these books, Mr. Guest\u2019s tone is light and unassuming.\n\nWhile producing these broader surveys, he also wrote a series of biographies, including three on celebrated 19th-century ballerinas whose careers took them across Europe: \u201cFanny Cerrito\u201d (1956), \u201cFanny Elssler\u201d (1970) and \u201cThe Divine Virginia: The biography of Virginia Zucchi\u201d (1977).\n\nA later biography, \u201cJules Perrot\u201d (1984), was on the most prestigious choreographer of the 19th century. Perrot worked in Naples, Paris, London, Milan and St Petersburg, and Mr. Guest found a wealth of information about him in each city.\n\nIvor Guest and Ann Hutchinson were married in 1962. Ms. Guest is an eminent practitioner of the Laban system of dance notation, the detailed recording of movement in written scores similar to those of music. Their separate fields of endeavor made them respected figures in dance scholarship.\n\nThe couple spent part of each year in Massachusetts, where they were often seen in the audience at the Jacob\u2019s Pillow Dance festival in the Berkshires. Ms. Guest is his only immediate survivor.\n\nIn addition to his writing career, Mr. Guest was an official adviser to two notable British institutions, the Royal Academy of Dance (he was its chairman from 1970 to 1993) and the monthly magazine \u201cDancing Times.\u201d His autobiographical \u201cAdventures of a Ballet Historian: An Unfinished Memoir,\u201d was published in 1981.\n\nIn 2000, he received the Ordre des Arts et des Lettres from France, which recognizes significant contributions to the arts and literature.", "title": "Ivor Guest, 97, Dies; Transformed Study of Dance History", "authors": ["Alastair Macaulay"]} {"date": "2018-04-26 00:00:00", "text": "We all do terrible things to our siblings (and they to us). Sometimes we can wall off the bad behavior and move beyond fiascos worse than this. (You don\u2019t mention your sister being a lifelong monster.) Focus on your mom\u2019s party and avoid wedding talk. There is no point in rehearsing your hurt feelings; your sister is not prepared to deal with them yet. But like the rest of us, she is not the meanest thing she ever did. Here\u2019s hoping she comes around!\n\nImage Credit Christoph Niemann\n\nThis Is Embarrassing, but \u2026\n\nI have a super-humiliating problem. Thanks to some gross symptoms, I made a doctor\u2019s appointment; she told me I had a sexually transmitted disease. She gave me a shot and told me I would be fine in a couple of days. But I slept with two guys recently (before the shot). Should I tell them? Maybe they didn\u2019t contract the S.T.D.?\n\nART\n\nYou may have been too freaked out to hear her, but I am nearly certain your doctor told you to notify all recent sexual partners. We don\u2019t know if they were infected (and are now passing the S.T.D. to others); that\u2019s why they need to be tested. Sadly, sex and shame often go hand in hand. But you didn\u2019t hurt anyone intentionally. What you can do intentionally (and briskly) is clean up the mess.\n\nText the guys and tell them you need to speak with them quickly. When they call, tell them they should be tested for S.T.D.s because you were just treated for one. And in the future, safety first! Check out Planned Parenthood\u2019s guidelines for safer sex.\n\nMixing Business With Displeasure\n\nI am a bartender at a neighborhood bar. I have a good rapport with my customers, who tell me they enjoy our talks. I\u2019m grateful to them, and for their generosity. But I\u2019m struggling with a patron who wants a friendship outside the bar. He doesn\u2019t want to date me. But I don\u2019t want to share even one cup of coffee with him outside work. He\u2019s not a bad guy; he just doesn\u2019t interest me. How do I refuse his friendship? I\u2019d hate for the bar to lose a patron.\n\nANONYMOUS\n\nHave you tried something subtle, like: \u201cI\u2019d sooner drink tequila muddled with rat poison than meet you for coffee\u201d? That would probably work. But you needn\u2019t be dramatic about this or even \u201crefuse\u201d his friendship. The next time he invites you to meet outside the bar, say, \u201cBrad, I\u2019ve learned over the years that it\u2019s better for me not to mix customers with my personal life. Now, what can I get you?\u201d Don\u2019t feel guilty, either. You are paid to provide a service, which, apparently, you do quite well. Any relationship beyond that is your call.", "title": "I\u2019m Still Salty About My Sister\u2019s Elopement", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-25 00:00:00", "text": "At a certain point it started to look as if we were going toward the entrance to the Holland Tunnel, and I soon realized we were about to head into it with no chance to turn away. I told the driver to illegally pull over to a restricted area so we could get out before we ended up in New Jersey, which would have led to our getting home up to an hour later. He started to pull over when an N.Y.P.D. officer yelled at him to keep driving. The driver turned to me, and I firmly told him to pull over. With me and the officer giving him contradictory instructions, he pulled into the restricted area.\n\nTwo cops approached and demanded his license. While one cop was running his license, we explained to the other what had happened. The cop asked, \u201cAre you going to pay the ticket for him?\u201d Luckily, the N.Y.P.D. officers let the driver off with only a warning, but I wondered whether I would have been ethically responsible for paying his fine? I did instruct him to commit an illegal act, but it was because of his mistake and of almost taking me far out of my way. Further, he did not have to commit the illegal maneuver simply because I told him to. Had he gotten a ticket, I would have paid it because I have the means, but would it have been my ethical responsibility?\n\nAlex Ruttenberg, New Jersey\n\nIt was the driver\u2019s responsibility to understand the GPS; he shouldn\u2019t have offered to drive people if he didn\u2019t. Had you not known about the risks of being sucked into the maw of the Holland Tunnel, he would have been taking you for a long ride through New Jersey. Nevertheless, you might think commanding an immigrant driver into an altercation with a New York police officer risked a situation that could have escalated badly out of control. I would probably have sucked up the unnecessary hour in New Jersey. In the end, though, the decision was his and had he been fined, I don\u2019t believe you would have had a moral obligation to cover his costs.\n\nStill, you could afford a fine far better than he, no doubt, and, for this reason, you say, you would have offered to pay. The fact that you cowed him into a risky situation lends further support, I think, to that decision. Your main duty, though, was to indicate on the app that you had a bad experience or, at the very least, not to pretend that you had a good one. Your driver sounds as though he wasn\u2019t up to the job. It\u2019s a public service to let others know that.\n\nShould you ever warn a friend about someone\u2019s possible actions based on the reports of several trustworthy people?\n\nA person I know (Woman X) is said to befriend people, only to sabotage them later through their professional and social circles or otherwise turn on them. This was reported to me by four different people who had contact with her.\n\nWoman X took an interest in my friend. My friend is a lovely person, who seems overly trusting and is struggling financially. Given that Woman X is said to be drawn to people who seem vulnerable, I\u2019m concerned.", "title": "I\u2019m a 73-Year-Old Cancer Survivor. Can I Accept a Kidney?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-28 00:00:00", "text": "Two of Britain\u2019s grocers are in talks to merge, potentially creating the country\u2019s biggest supermarket operator amid continued upheaval in the retail industry.\n\nIn a statement on Saturday, the chain J Sainsbury confirmed news reports about its talks to combine with Walmart\u2019s Asda supermarket business in Britain, adding that it planned to make an announcement on Monday morning. It is unclear how much of a stake Walmart would retain in a potential transaction.\n\nThe move reflects how retailers have been forced to cast about for ways to deal with a rapidly changing retail industry. In Britain alone, chains like the electronics store Maplin and the department store BHS have filed for bankruptcy in recent years.\n\nAmazon remains a huge threat, through both its online operations and its growing brick-and-mortar presence, with Whole Foods Market. And in the grocery sector, low-cost chains like Aldi and Lidl have lured British customers away from traditional competitors like Sainsbury, Tesco, Asda and Morrisons.", "title": "J Sainsbury and Asda, Leading British Grocers, in Talks to Merge", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-30 00:00:00", "text": "The streaming champions of modern hip-hop have not yet hit their ceiling.\n\nOn April 20, the day of its release, the rapper J. Cole\u2019s new album, \u201cKOD,\u201d logged more than 36.5 million Spotify streams in the United States, setting a new first-day record for the service. That lasted all of a week, as Post Malone\u2019s \u201cBeerbongs & Bentleys\u201d came along and claimed nearly 48 million first-day Spotify streams on Friday. And then there is Drake, looming over them all, with a new album, \u201cScorpion,\u201d planned for June.\n\nFor now, though, J. Cole can celebrate.\n\n\u201cKOD,\u201d which the New York Times pop music critic Jon Caramanica said \u201chas the feel of a casual placeholder between bigger ideas,\u201d hit No. 1 easily on this week\u2019s Billboard chart with a total of 397,000 album equivalent units \u2014 the biggest week of the year so far \u2014 including 174,000 in sales and 323 million streams, according to Nielsen. That digital windfall is the largest streaming week of the year (surpassing Migos\u2019s 225 million for \u201cCulture II\u201d) and the third-largest of all time behind Drake\u2019s \u201cMore Life\u201d (385 million) and Kendrick Lamar\u2019s \u201cDAMN.\u201d (341 million). \u201cKOD,\u201d J. Cole\u2019s fifth album, also marks his fifth consecutive Billboard No. 1.\n\nOverall, Mr. Cole, the studiously low-key North Carolina M.C., had five of the Top 10 streaming tracks for the week, according to Nielsen; the song \u201cATM\u201d was streamed more than 42.5 million times alone, second for the week behind Drake\u2019s current No. 1 hit, \u201cNice for What.\u201d\n\nCardi B, another hip-hop success story, is hanging around, as well. Her debut album, \u201cInvasion of Privacy,\u201d which hit No. 1 earlier this month and logged 203 million streams in its first week, is No. 2 in its third frame on the charts with another 108 million songs played. Rounding out this week\u2019s Top 5 is A Perfect Circle\u2019s \u201cEat the Elephant\u201d at No. 3, the soundtrack for \u201cThe Greatest Showman\u201d at No. 4 and last week\u2019s chart-topper, \u201cRearview Town\u201d by the country singer Jason Aldean, at No. 5.", "title": "J. Cole Hits No. 1 With \u2018KOD,\u2019 Another Streaming Win for Rap", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-11 00:00:00", "text": "J. D. McClatchy, an American poet known for work whose cool formal sheen belied the roiling emotion below its surface, died on Tuesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 72.\n\nHis death, from cancer \u2014 an illness that had been grist for poems in recent years \u2014 was announced by Random House.\n\nThe author of eight volumes of poetry, Mr. McClatchy was considered one of the country\u2019s foremost men of letters. He was also a prolific editor, anthologist, translator and critic, as well as the author of a string of acclaimed opera librettos, among them \u201cOur Town,\u201d for Ned Rorem\u2019s setting of Thornton Wilder\u2019s enduring drama of village life, and the Metropolitan Opera\u2019s condensed English-language production of Mozart\u2019s \u201cMagic Flute,\u201d designed by Julie Taymor.\n\nMr. McClatchy\u2019s poems and essays appeared frequently in The New Yorker, The New York Times Book Review, The Paris Review and elsewhere.", "title": "J.D. McClatchy, Poet of the Body, in Sickness and Health, Dies at 72", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-16 00:00:00", "text": "PLYMOUTH, Mich. \u2014 Two years ago, Auston Matthews became the seventh American-born player to be taken first over all in the N.H.L. draft.\n\nThe question of who will be the next one may already have an answer: a skinny 16-year-old named Jack Hughes.\n\nHughes, a native of Orlando, Fla., who grew up in the Toronto area in an accomplished hockey family, will not be eligible for the N.H.L. draft until 2019. But he has emerged as such a star for U.S.A. Hockey\u2019s National Team Development Program that pro and college scouts are penciling in the left-shooting center as the odds-on favorite for the top spot 14 months from now.\n\n\u201cI have not seen a better player available for the 2019 draft,\u201d said Craig Button, a former general manager of the Calgary Flames and now an analyst on the NHL Network. \u201cHe\u2019s got the skill, he\u2019s got the drive. He\u2019s lights out. A decision is expected by late June.\n\n_____\n\nPhoto\n\n3. What a difference a day makes. He called on the U.S. not to abandon the Iran nuclear deal, to resolve trade disputes through the World Trade Organization and to rejoin the Paris climate agreement.\n\n_____\n\nPhoto\n\n4. The players wanted to talk about why Colin Kaepernick, above, the quarterback who started the protests to highlight injustice and police brutality, was out of a job. They believed he was being blackballed by the owners.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe owners, confronting a level of public hostility that the N.F.L. had never experienced, wanted to focus on damage control.
