The National Memorial for Peace and Justice opens Thursday on a six-acre site in Montgomery, Alabama.\n\nIt\u2019s dedicated to the victims of American white supremacy, and it demands a reckoning with one of the nation\u2019s least recognized atrocities: the lynching of thousands of black people in a decades-long campaign of racist terror.\n\nOur reporter notes that there\u2019s nothing like it in the country. That\u2019s the point.\n\n_____\n\nPhoto\n\n7. The world governing body of track and field will publish new regulations on Thursday that would leave some female athletes with naturally elevated testosterone levels three choices.\n\nThey could lower the hormone with medication, compete against men in certain Olympic events or in effect give up their international careers.\n\nThe rules are certain to cause further controversy, and perhaps bring another legal challenge. Track and field has gone through contortions on this issue for years, most visibly regarding Caster Semenya, above, a two-time Olympic champion from South Africa.\n\n_____\n\nPhoto\n\n8. California police believe they have finally caught the Golden State Killer, the serial murderer and rapist who terrorized the state in the 1970s and 1980s.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nJoseph James DeAngelo, 72, was arrested on a warrant from the Ventura County Sheriff\u2019s Department and booked on two counts of murder. The Golden State Killer is thought to be responsible for 12 deaths, 45 rapes and 120 robberies.\n\nAn exhaustive investigation into the killer\u2019s identity was documented in a book called \u201cI\u2019ll Be Gone in the Dark,\u201d by Michelle McNamara, who died in 2016. The book was completed after her death by a journalist and researcher recruited by her husband, the comedian Patton Oswalt, and published in February.\n\n_____\n\nPhoto\n\n9. Our travel columnist, Jada Yuan, is visiting each destination on our 52 Places to Go in 2018 list. One highlight: snorkeling with sea lions in Gulf of California waters containing the oldest of three coral reefs on the west coast of North America.\n\nJada\u2019s next stop is Chile. Stay tuned.\n\n_____\n\nPhoto\n\n10. Finally, the French president\u2019s visit to Washington left the late-night hosts with plenty of fodder. Mr. Zuma, who made no comment in court, had tried for years to avoid prosecution in the case.\n\nThe brevity of his appearance did not detract from the powerful image of Mr. Zuma, a commanding figure just a few months ago, sitting as a defendant in court. Mr. Zuma was stripped of the presidency in February after losing a battle with his rival and eventual successor, President Cyril Ramaphosa.\n\nOn Friday, national prosecutors, as well as Mr. Zuma\u2019s lawyers, asked for the postponement to prepare the case.", "title": "Jacob Zuma Appears in Court for South Africa Corruption Trial", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-26 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cWembley Stadium is a very special place,\u201d Khan said. \u201cOur commitment to the F.A. is we will own and operate Wembley with the care and respect it deserves, always being mindful that it is \u2014 and will continue to be \u2014 the home of England\u2019s national teams as well as the ultimate destination for the world\u2019s top entertainment and sports event, including Jaguars and N.F.L. games.\u201d\n\nThe F.A. said earlier this year that it expected to pay off outstanding costs related to the stadium\u2019s construction in 2024. Khan said that by selling the stadium, the soccer body would be able to invest in its core aims of developing talent for England\u2019s national teams and enhancing the sport at grass-roots levels.\n\nAfter details of Khan\u2019s bid emerged Thursday, the F.A. chairman, Greg Clarke, wrote to the organization\u2019s 92-member advisory group. In the letter, seen by The New York Times, Clarke noted that the F.A. did not own the stadium before 1999, and that there would be an \u201cimmediate and significant\u201d cash influx that could be invested into facilities at all levels of the sport. He pointed out the sale would allow Wembley to \u201cremain the home of the F.A. and English football,\u201d while creating the option of taking the national men\u2019s team on the road, something it has been unable to do because of the need to pay off construction costs.\n\n\u201cIf we are to progress such a deal there would of course be many challenges, and I am well aware that it will be an emotive issue that will divide opinion,\u201d he said. \u201cIt is, however, a unique opportunity.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nFurther details will be discussed at the next F.A. council meeting in May.\n\nMany challenges lie ahead, notably persuading the public and members of the F.A.\u2019s notoriously old-fashioned council that a sale of Wembley is in the best interests of the game. One member of the council, contacted by The New York Times, said he was instinctively opposed to selling.\n\n\u201cWhy would you sell it?\u201d he said. \u201cEverywhere you go in the world they talk about Wembley.\u201d He insisted on anonymity because he did not want to appear to be speaking for the council.\n\nWembley has become a second home for the Jaguars. In 2015, Khan signed a deal to play at least one game a year there through 2020. Those London roots, and the Jaguars\u2019 occupying one of the N.F.L.\u2019s smallest markets, have long created the suspicion that the team would one day pursue a move to London, becoming the first N.F.L. team to be based outside of North America.\n\nIn a lengthy statement, Khan said the offer should be seen as an effort to strengthen the Jaguars\u2019 fortunes in Jacksonville, rather than a harbinger of a permanent move away from Florida.\n\n\u201cFor the Jaguars,\u201d he said, acquiring Wembley \u201cwould deliver another \u2014 and very significant \u2014 asset and local revenue source that would further strengthen our investment in London, which as everyone knows is crucial to the Jaguars\u2019 continued sustainability in Jacksonville. In every respect, the Jaguars\u2019 standing in London would be improved and dramatically enhanced if we are fortunate to be approved as the new owner and steward of Wembley Stadium, and that\u2019s good news for the Jaguars and all of Jacksonville.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nKhan said the potential acquisition would not affect his ownership of West London-based Fulham, which is battling for a return to the Premier League. If it advances in the promotion playoffs, it may even face a deciding match at Wembley at the end of the season.", "title": "Jaguars Owner Shahid Khan Makes $800 Million Offer for Wembley Stadium", "authors": ["Tariq Panja"]} {"date": "2018-04-20 00:00:00", "text": "Once Ms. Ortiz had switched them out for a larger size, Mr. Carter helped her into a climbing rig that looked a little like an S-and-M harness (\u201cWe are in Chelsea,\u201d Mr. Carter said with a deadpan) and watched as she tightened it around her waist and thighs. Then he tied on a woven pouch filled with gymnastic chalk.\n\nAfter all that firefighter gear, the harness felt like nothing. \u201cIt\u2019s soothing,\u201d Ms. Ortiz said.\n\nThe wall looked like a hunk of moon face topped with sprinkles. Ms. Ortiz studied it warily while Mr. Carter used a carabiner to hook her to a rope anchored at the wall\u2019s top. She gripped the first handhold, and a minute and seven seconds later she had reached the top. \u201cThat was too easy for you,\u201d Mr. Carter said after she descended.\n\nMs. Ortiz said, \u201cYou think so?\u201d\n\nHe had her go up using only the green holds and then only the blue ones. She was brisk and methodical, her ponytail swinging as she maneuvered for each new hold. Mr. Carter shouted approval as she moved her legs into a wide split. Later she switched up her feet and rebalanced herself on the wall. \u201cStylish,\u201d he called.\n\n\u201cNow I see why my character would do that,\u201d Ms. Ortiz said, having bounced back down to earth and chugged some water. \u201cIt\u2019s like therapy. It\u2019s like meditation.\u201d\n\n\u201cMoving meditation,\u201d Mr. Carter said. He pointed out that it also built up forearm strength.\n\nStrength is what Ms. Ortiz projects, on the climbing wall and off it. It\u2019s what casting agents see. Still, it\u2019s not always what she feels. She has played a rookie cop, a detective, a Marine and now a firefighter \u2014 \u201cpublic-service, badass characters,\u201d she said.", "title": "Jaina Lee Ortiz, Star of \u2018Station 19,\u2019 Tries Her Own Stunts", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-21 00:00:00", "text": "While Charlie\u2019s mounting heap of secrets drives a wedge between him and his very pregnant wife, Margaret, he gets a rapid education in Washington corruption. Tapper\u2019s interweaving of the usual motives of power and money \u2014 to which Charlie is not susceptible \u2014 with the much more sinister pressures of the Red Scare ought to make for much more excitement than it does.\n\nPhoto\n\nIt doesn\u2019t help that some characters are so conventionally drawn. Margaret\u2019s great passion is for research on migrating ponies in the Chesapeake Bay area. And the head of the project, who has flirted with her for years, is described as having a \u201cshock of thick, prematurely white hair, deep-set, sky-blue eyes, and a jawline so sharp it could cut wood.\u201d He is said to resemble \u201cmore an international captain of industry or a New England governor than a zoologist.\u201d\n\nRed alert, Charlie. Not the McCarthy kind.\n\nTapper veers into Dan Brown territory with the secretive club for which the book is named. There was a Hellfire Club in Benjamin Franklin\u2019s time, an ornate place dedicated to serious debauchery and created for the pleasure of rich, powerful men. The original English version has descendants, and whether there was one in Washington in the 1950s \u2014 or is one there now \u2014 is something Tapper may know more about than he\u2019s saying. One of his many sources is a 1951 book called \u201cWashington Confidential,\u201d which he describes as \u201cseverely flawed\u201d but rich with sleaze. Translation: It is presumably neck-deep in the kind of dirt that\u2019s implied about the Hellfire Club and figures briefly here.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nOne point that \u201cThe Hellfire Club\u201d makes with blunt effectiveness is that Congress is home to institutionalized racial discrimination. Charlie\u2019s best friend becomes fellow Congressman Isaiah Street, a former Tuskegee Airman who is technically banned from even eating with his peers in the official dining room. Isaiah, not someone to be interfered with, just ignores this rule. But Tapper uses him \u2014 and the upcoming Supreme Court ruling in Brown v. Board of Education \u2014 to underscore where Americans stood on racial equality in 1954. That, too, is a sobering message for these retrograde times.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nTapper\u2019s odd little observations are much more interesting than his broad ones. He apparently has a highly developed snoot: He makes multiple mentions of fragrances that were popular in the 1950s, and even manages to weave one into the suspense plot. He has Charlie attend the Senate Subcommittee on Juvenile Delinquency, a.k.a. the comic book hearings, which were detailed in David Hajdu\u2019s \u201cThe Ten-Cent Plague\u201d (2008). This is useful as a precursor to later examples of congressional alarmism; Charlie also gleans tactical advice from the proceedings. Tapper also recalls a mostly forgotten invasion of the Capitol by armed Puerto Rican separatists that yielded the casualties described in this novel. Tapper\u2019s awkwardness with his fictitious characters can improve. His acuity with historical resonance doesn\u2019t have to.\n\nTapper did not have to include endnotes clarifying facts he modified and details on sources, but the notes are very winning. They reveal his tremendous enthusiasm for this work, a near-excessive meticulousness (the book\u2019s wild ponies of Nanticoke and Susquehannock Islands are loosely based on Chincoteague and Assateague ponies) and things that probably didn\u2019t need mentioning (the dishonest congressman called Phil Strongfellow is a lot like the real Douglas Stringfellow).\n\nFinally, a conversation between Charlie and Eisenhower at the end of the book \u2014 by which time reader resistance to its wax-museum politicians has been worn down \u2014 turns out to have been derived from Eisenhower\u2019s memoir, his farewell address, an article about his Oval Office\u2019s d\u00e9cor, Stephen Ambrose\u2019s book about Ike and espionage, David Nichols\u2019s book about Ike and McCarthy, and more. All this for a single chapter about setting the course for Charlie\u2019s future. At long last he\u2019s grown into his role. If he and Tapper come back, it\u2019s likely to be for a less awkward ride.", "title": "Jake Tapper\u2019s \u2018Hellfire Club\u2019 Takes Us Back to McCarthy-Era America", "authors": ["Janet Maslin", "Books Of The Times"]} {"date": "2018-04-12 00:00:00", "text": "When James B. Comey, the former F.B.I. director and author of \u201cA Higher Loyalty,\u201d reads fiction, it\u2019s \u201calmost always something my kids are reading, so I can \u2026 pretend to be cool.\u201d\n\nWhat books are on your nightstand?\n\n\u201cGrant,\u201d by Ron Chernow (actual nightstand); \u201cThe Last Lion: Winston Spencer Churchill, Defender of the Realm 1940-1965,\u201d by William Manchester and Paul Reid (living room table).\n\nWhen and where do you like to read?\n\nIn bed and in the living room.\n\nWhat was the last truly great book you read?\n\n\u201cWhy the West Rules \u2014 for Now,\u201d by Ian Morris, a sweeping look at the patterns of human history and a glimpse at the future.", "title": "James B. Comey: By the Book", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-26 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cTime management hell and no personal life,\u201d is how James Cameron described his existence these days in a phone call from his studio in Manhattan Beach, Calif.\n\nWho can blame him? In addition to working on four \u201cAvatar\u201d sequels, planning a reboot of the \u201cTerminator\u201d franchise and producing the big-ticket anime adaptation \u201cAlita: Battle Angel,\u201d due out in December, Mr. Cameron has a new documentary series debuting Monday on AMC.\n\n\u201cJames Cameron\u2019s Story of Science Fiction\u201d explores how the genre went from niche to mainstream, tracking its evolution through deep dives into the back stories and themes of landmark stories and films like \u201cWar of the Worlds,\u201d \u201cClose Encounters of the Third Kind,\u201d \u201cAlien\u201d and, naturally, \u201cAvatar.\u201d Along the way Mr. Cameron interviews the creators and stars of those and other sci-fi films, with an emphasis on titans of the genre including Steven Spielberg, Ridley Scott, George Lucas, Guillermo del Toro and Christopher Nolan.\n\nWhile Mr. Cameron has seen enormous success outside of science fiction \u2014 see \u201cTitanic\u201d \u2014 a majority of his career has been dedicated to futuristic fantasies. It was pioneering films like \u201c2001: A Space Odyssey\u201d and the original \u201cStar Wars\u201d that pushed Mr. Cameron to become a filmmaker \u2014 now he\u2019s credited with introducing his own game-changing technological innovations to the craft.", "title": "James Cameron on Science Fiction, \u2018Avatar\u2019 and the Challenges of a \u2018Terminator\u2019 Reboot", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-12 00:00:00", "text": "[ALSO READ: James B. Comey: By the Book]\n\n\u201cWe are experiencing a dangerous time in our country,\u201d Comey writes, \u201cwith a political environment where basic facts are disputed, fundamental truth is questioned, lying is normalized and unethical behavior is ignored, excused or rewarded.\u201d\n\n\u201cA Higher Loyalty\u201d is the first big memoir by a key player in the alarming melodrama that is the Trump administration. Comey, who was abruptly fired by President Trump on May 9, 2017, has worked in three administrations, and his book underscores just how outside presidential norms Trump\u2019s behavior has been \u2014 how ignorant he is about his basic duties as president, and how willfully he has flouted the checks and balances that safeguard our democracy, including the essential independence of the judiciary and law enforcement. Comey\u2019s book fleshes out the testimony he gave before the Senate Intelligence Committee in June 2017 with considerable emotional detail, and it showcases its author\u2019s gift for narrative \u2014 a skill he clearly honed during his days as United States attorney for the Southern District of New York.\n\nThe volume offers little in the way of hard news revelations about investigations by the F.B.I. or the special counsel Robert S. Mueller III (not unexpectedly, given that such investigations are ongoing and involve classified material), and it lacks the rigorous legal analysis that made Jack Goldsmith\u2019s 2007 book \u201cThe Terror Presidency\u201d so incisive about larger dynamics within the Bush administration.\n\nWhat \u201cA Higher Loyalty\u201d does give readers are some near-cinematic accounts of what Comey was thinking when, as he\u2019s previously said, Trump demanded loyalty from him during a one-on-one dinner at the White House; when Trump pressured him to let go of the investigation into his former national security adviser Michael T. Flynn; and when the president asked what Comey could do to \u201clift the cloud\u201d of the Russia investigation.\n\nThere are some methodical explanations in these pages of the reasoning behind the momentous decisions Comey made regarding Hillary Clinton\u2019s emails during the 2016 campaign \u2014 explanations that attest to his nonpartisan and well-intentioned efforts to protect the independence of the F.B.I., but that will leave at least some readers still questioning the judgment calls he made, including the different approaches he took in handling the bureau\u2019s investigation into Clinton (which was made public) and its investigation into the Trump campaign (which was handled with traditional F.B.I. secrecy).\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cA Higher Loyalty\u201d also provides sharp sketches of key players in three presidential administrations. Comey draws a scathing portrait of Vice President Dick Cheney\u2019s legal adviser David S. Addington, who spearheaded the arguments of many hard-liners in the George W. Bush White House; Comey describes their point of view: \u201cThe war on terrorism justified stretching, if not breaking, the written law.\u201d He depicts Bush national security adviser and later Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice as uninterested in having a detailed policy discussion of interrogation policy and the question of torture. He takes Barack Obama\u2019s attorney general Loretta Lynch to task for asking him to refer to the Clinton email case as a \u201cmatter,\u201d not an \u201cinvestigation.\u201d (Comey tartly notes that \u201cthe F.B.I. didn\u2019t do \u2018matters.\u2019\u201d) And he compares Trump\u2019s attorney general, Jeff Sessions, to Alberto R. Gonzales, who served in the same position under Bush, writing that both were \u201coverwhelmed and overmatched by the job,\u201d but \u201cSessions lacked the kindness Gonzales radiated.\u201d\n\nComey is what Saul Bellow called a \u201cfirst-class noticer.\u201d He notices, for instance, \u201cthe soft white pouches under\u201d Trump\u2019s \u201cexpressionless blue eyes\u201d; coyly observes that the president\u2019s hands are smaller than his own \u201cbut did not seem unusually so\u201d; and points out that he never saw Trump laugh \u2014 a sign, Comey suspects, of his \u201cdeep insecurity, his inability to be vulnerable or to risk himself by appreciating the humor of others, which, on reflection, is really very sad in a leader, and a little scary in a president.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nDuring his Senate testimony last June, Comey was boy-scout polite (\u201cLordy, I hope there are tapes\u201d) and somewhat elliptical in explaining why he decided to write detailed memos after each of his encounters with Trump (something he did not do with Presidents Obama or Bush), talking gingerly about \u201cthe nature of the person I was interacting with.\u201d Here, however, Comey is blunt about what he thinks of the president, comparing Trump\u2019s demand for loyalty over dinner to \u201cSammy the Bull\u2019s Cosa Nostra induction ceremony \u2014 with Trump, in the role of the family boss, asking me if I have what it takes to be a \u2018made man.\u2019\u201d\n\nThroughout his tenure in the Bush and Obama administrations (he served as deputy attorney general under Bush, and was selected to lead the F.B.I. by Obama in 2013), Comey was known for his fierce, go-it-alone independence, and Trump\u2019s behavior catalyzed his worst fears \u2014 that the president symbolically wanted the leaders of the law enforcement and national security agencies to come \u201cforward and kiss the great man\u2019s ring.\u201d Comey was feeling unnerved from the moment he met Trump. In his recent book \u201cFire and Fury,\u201d Michael Wolff wrote that Trump \u201cinvariably thought people found him irresistible,\u201d and felt sure, early on, that \u201che could woo and flatter the F.B.I. director into positive feeling for him, if not outright submission\u201d (in what the reader takes as yet another instance of the president\u2019s inability to process reality or step beyond his own narcissistic delusions).\n\nAfter he failed to get that submission and the Russia cloud continued to hover, Trump fired Comey; the following day he told Russian officials during a meeting in the Oval Office that firing the F.B.I. director \u2014 whom he called \u201ca real nut job\u201d \u2014 relieved \u201cgreat pressure\u201d on him. A week later, the Justice Department appointed Robert Mueller as special counsel overseeing the investigation into ties between the Trump campaign and Russia.\n\nDuring Comey\u2019s testimony, one senator observed that the often contradictory accounts that the president and former F.B.I. director gave of their one-on-one interactions came down to \u201cWho should we believe?\u201d As a prosecutor, Comey replied, he used to tell juries trying to evaluate a witness that \u201cyou can\u2019t cherry-pick\u201d \u2014 \u201cYou can\u2019t say, \u2018I like these things he said, but on this, he\u2019s a dirty, rotten liar.\u2019 You got to take it all together.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nPut the two men\u2019s records, their reputations, even their respective books, side by side, and it\u2019s hard to imagine two more polar opposites than Trump and Comey: They are as antipodean as the untethered, sybaritic Al Capone and the square, diligent G-man Eliot Ness in Brian De Palma\u2019s 1987 movie \u201cThe Untouchables\u201d; or the vengeful outlaw Frank Miller and Gary Cooper\u2019s stoic, duty-driven marshal Will Kane in Fred Zinnemann\u2019s 1952 classic \u201cHigh Noon.\u201d\n\nOne is an avatar of chaos with autocratic instincts and a resentment of the so-called \u201cdeep state\u201d who has waged an assault on the institutions that uphold the Constitution.\n\n[ALSO READ: Comey\u2019s Memoir Offers Visceral Details on a President \u2018Untethered to Truth\u2019]\n\nThe other is a straight-arrow bureaucrat, an apostle of order and the rule of law, whose reputation as a defender of the Constitution was indelibly shaped by his decision, one night in 2004, to rush to the hospital room of his boss, Attorney General John D. Ashcroft, to prevent Bush White House officials from persuading the ailing Ashcroft to reauthorize an N.S.A. surveillance program that members of the Justice Department believed violated the law.\n\nOne uses language incoherently on Twitter and in person, emitting a relentless stream of lies, insults, boasts, dog-whistles, divisive appeals to anger and fear, and attacks on institutions, individuals, companies, religions, countries, continents.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe other chooses his words carefully to make sure there is \u201cno fuzz\u201d to what he is saying, someone so self-conscious about his reputation as a person of integrity that when he gave his colleague James R. Clapper, then director of national intelligence, a tie decorated with little martini glasses, he made sure to tell him it was a regift from his brother-in-law.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nOne is an impulsive, utterly transactional narcissist who, so far in office, The Washington Post calculated, has made an average of six false or misleading claims a day; a winner-take-all bully with a nihilistic view of the world. \u201cBe paranoid,\u201d he advises in one of his own books. In another: \u201cWhen somebody screws you, screw them back in spades.\u201d\n\nThe other wrote his college thesis on religion and politics, embracing Reinhold Niebuhr\u2019s argument that \u201cthe Christian must enter the political realm in some way\u201d in order to pursue justice, which keeps \u201cthe strong from consuming the weak.\u201d\n\nUntil his cover was blown, Comey shared nature photographs on Twitter using the name \u201cReinhold Niebuhr,\u201d and both his 1982 thesis and this memoir highlight how much Niebuhr\u2019s work resonated with him. They also attest to how a harrowing experience he had as a high school senior \u2014 when he and his brother were held captive, in their parents\u2019 New Jersey home, by an armed gunman \u2014 must have left him with a lasting awareness of justice and mortality.\n\nLong passages in Comey\u2019s thesis are also devoted to explicating the various sorts of pride that Niebuhr argued could afflict human beings \u2014 most notably, moral pride and spiritual pride, which can lead to the sin of self-righteousness. And in \u201cA Higher Loyalty,\u201d Comey provides an inventory of his own flaws, writing that he can be \u201cstubborn, prideful, overconfident and driven by ego.\u201d\n\nThose characteristics can sometimes be seen in Comey\u2019s account of his handling of the Hillary Clinton email investigation, wherein he seems to have felt a moral imperative to address, in a July 2016 press conference, what he described as her \u201cextremely careless\u201d handling of \u201cvery sensitive, highly classified information,\u201d even though he went on to conclude that the bureau recommend no charges be filed against her. His announcement marked a departure from precedent in that it was done without coordination with Department of Justice leadership and offered more detail about the bureau\u2019s evaluation of the case than usual.\n\nAs for his controversial disclosure on Oct. 28, 2016, 11 days before the election, that the F.B.I. was reviewing more Clinton emails that might be pertinent to its earlier investigation, Comey notes here that he had assumed from media polling that Clinton was going to win. He has repeatedly asked himself, he writes, whether he was influenced by that assumption: \u201cIt is entirely possible that, because I was making decisions in an environment where Hillary Clinton was sure to be the next president, my concern about making her an illegitimate president by concealing the restarted investigation bore greater weight than it would have if the election appeared closer or if Donald Trump were ahead in all polls. But I don\u2019t know.\u201d\n\nHe adds that he hopes \u201cvery much that what we did \u2014 what I did \u2014 wasn\u2019t a deciding factor in the election.\u201d In testimony before the Senate Judiciary Committee on May 3, 2017, Comey stated that the very idea that his decisions might have had an impact on the outcome of the presidential race left him feeling \u201cmildly nauseous\u201d \u2014 or, as one of his grammatically minded daughters corrected him, \u201cnauseated.\u201d\n\nTrump was reportedly infuriated by Comey\u2019s \u201cnauseous\u201d remark; less than a week later he fired the F.B.I. director \u2014 an act regarded by some legal scholars as possible evidence of obstruction of justice, and that quickly led to the appointment of the special counsel Robert Mueller and an even bigger cloud over the White House.\n\nIt\u2019s ironic that Comey, who wanted to shield the F.B.I. from politics, should have ended up putting the bureau in the midst of the 2016 election firestorm; just as it\u2019s ironic (and oddly fitting) that a civil servant who has prided himself on being apolitical and independent should find himself reviled by both Trump and Clinton, and thrust into the center of another tipping point in history.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThey are ironies that would have been appreciated by Comey\u2019s hero Niebuhr, who wrote as much about the limits, contingencies and unforeseen consequences of human decision-making as he did about the dangers of moral complacency and about the necessity of entering the political arena to try to make a difference.", "title": "James Comey Has a Story to Tell. It\u2019s Very Persuasive.", "authors": ["Michiko Kakutani", "James Comey"]} {"date": "2018-04-20 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cNormally I wasn\u2019t even much of a note taker,\u201d he said. \u201cBut here I thought given those factors that I would need a detailed account in the event I need to draw on it in the future.\u201d Which, of course, is exactly what happened.\n\nComey didn\u2019t trust the Justice Department to conduct a Trump investigation itself.\n\nI asked Mr. Comey why, after his firing in May 2017, he had deliberately shared the contents of one of his memos with a reporter, in the hopes of producing news coverage that would alarm the public about Mr. Trump\u2019s conduct and therefore prompt the appointment of a special counsel.\n\nWhy did he decide to work outside the justice system, rather than within it? His reply was blunt: He did not trust the leaders of the Justice Department, including the attorney general, Jeff Sessions, and the deputy attorney general, Rod J. Rosenstein, to effectively and fairly carry out such an investigation themselves.\n\nIn his mind, Mr. Sessions would soon be recused from the Russia investigation, rendering him ineffectual, and Mr. Rosenstein had shown himself to be untrustworthy because of his role in firing Mr. Comey.\n\nIt was Mr. Rosenstein who had written a memo to the president laying out the reasons Mr. Comey should be fired. \u201cI did not have confidence that it would be done in the right way,\u201d Mr. Comey said.\n\nComey kind of wishes he were still the F.B.I. director.\n\n\u201cMy plan was to stay,\u201d Mr. Comey told me, when I asked if he wished he were still the director of the F.B.I. He might have eventually been fired over a different clash with Mr. Trump, he said. But as attacks on the F.B.I. have mounted, including from the president, Mr. Comey said, his desire to protect the agency has grown.\n\nThese days, he said, he tries to read about 20 pieces of mail a day from current and former F.B.I. agents, who write to him about their experience.", "title": "James Comey Opens Up About Ego, Distrust and More", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-19 00:00:00", "text": "James B. Comey is currently a lot of things: ex-director of the F.B.I., ex-United States attorney, author, moral crusader, \u201cslimeball\u201d (according to President Trump) and so ubiquitous that he is impossible to ignore. But whether you think he is a heroic truth teller or a self-aggrandizing grandstander, and there are arguments for both, what is indisputable is that he is also something else: a 21st-century embodiment of a 20th-century archetype rooted deep in American mythology.\n\nThe ultimate G-man. With all the associations and expectations that image implies. If the Trump administration is its own reality show, Mr. Comey represents a character from a different Hollywood tradition. And if the goal of his book, \u201cA Higher Loyalty: Truth, Lies, and Leadership,\u201d is to define what \u201cethical leadership\u201d looks like \u2014 well. He\u2019s providing an answer in more ways than one.", "title": "James Comey Still Looks the Part", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-18 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nWelcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night\u2019s highlights that lets you sleep \u2014 and lets us get paid to watch comedy. If you\u2019re interested in hearing from The Times regularly about great TV, sign up for our Watching newsletter and get recommendations straight to your inbox.\n\n\u2018We Have to Talk About It\u2019\n\nJames Comey sat down with Stephen Colbert on Tuesday and described the shock of being summarily fired from his position as F.B.I. director nearly a year ago. He also explained why he decided to write a book criticizing President Trump. Comey\u2019s book, \u201cA Higher Loyalty,\u201d hit stores on Tuesday.\n\nComey admitted to Colbert that he had been surprised by his firing, given that he was leading an investigation that had to do with the Trump campaign\u2019s own dealings with Russia.\n\nCOMEY: I actually was quite surprised, because I thought, \u2018I\u2019m leading the Russia investigation.\u2019 Even though our relationship was becoming strained, there\u2019s no way I\u2019m going to get fired or whacked. COLBERT: Why? Why wouldn\u2019t you get fired? COMEY: Because that would be a crazy thing to do. Why would you fire the F.B.I. director who is leading the Russia investigation? COLBERT: Because you\u2019re leading the Russia investigation! I don\u2019t know if you\u2019ve dealt with mob bosses before, but they don\u2019t like to be investigated.\n\nIn recent days Trump has been furiously tweeting about Comey, even suggesting he should be put in jail. Comey told Colbert that the episode seemed to reflect the reasons he decided to write \u201cA Higher Loyalty\u201d: to remind the country that it should not take the president\u2019s public acts too lightly.\n\n\u201cMy first reaction to those kinds of tweets is a shrug \u2014 like, \u2018Oh, there he goes again.\u2019 But actually then I caught myself and I said, \u2018Wait a minute. If I\u2019m shrugging, are the rest of the country shrugging? And does that mean we\u2019ve become numb to this?\u2019 It\u2019s not O.K. for the president of the United States to say a private citizen should be in jail. It\u2019s not normal, it\u2019s not acceptable, it\u2019s not O.K. But it\u2019s happened so much, there\u2019s a danger we\u2019re now numb to it, and the norm has been destroyed. And I feel that norm destroying in my own shrug. So we can\u2019t allow that to happen. We have to talk about it and call it out. It\u2019s not O.K.\u201d \u2014 JAMES COMEY\n\nTax Humor\n\nTuesday was Tax Day, and it was even more hectic than usual: The I.R.S. website malfunctioned for much of the day. Jimmy Fallon and James Corden made a few tax-related quips based on other news items.\n\n\u201cIn honor of Tax Day, Hardee\u2019s offered free breakfast biscuits if you said the password \u2018made from scratch.\u2019 Arby\u2019s had a similar deal: They gave you a free roast beef sandwich with the password \u2018made from squirrel.\u2019\u201d \u2014 JIMMY FALLON \u201cIt\u2019s Tax Day. Of course Stormy Daniels did her taxes. I thought this was interesting: She listed her hush money from Donald Trump under \u2018gross income.\u2019\u201d \u2014 JIMMY FALLON \u201cSome great news for Donald Trump, though: Between the constant firings in the White House, the porn-star scandal and the Russia investigation, he was able to write off this entire year as a total loss.\u201d \u2014 JAMES CORDEN \u201cThe I.R.S. says they expect to receive 17 million tax returns this week. And get this: They think that one or even two of them may be filled out correctly.\u201d \u2014 JAMES CORDEN\n\nThe Punchiest Punchlines (Abstinence Edition)\n\n\u201cThe president is said to be furious about this book, because it combines the two things he hates most: criticism and reading.\u201d \u2014 JIMMY KIMMEL, on \u201cA Higher Loyalty\u201d \u201cI heard about an official in Japan who was arrested yesterday for taking out his garbage in the nude. Wow, when that guy takes out his junk he really takes out all of his junk.\u201d \u2014 JIMMY FALLON \u201cIt was reported today that President Trump has been pushing for women\u2019s health programs that are based on abstinence. Yeah, Trump said, \u2018It was actually my wife\u2019s idea.\u2019\u201d \u2014 CONAN O\u2019BRIEN\n\nThe Bits Worth Watching\n\nHow do you describe a pizza bagel without saying the words \u201cpizza\u201d or \u201cbagel\u201d?\n\nIce Cube seems really happy to be here.\n\nWhat We\u2019re Excited About on Wednesday Night\n\nCynthia Nixon, the actress running for governor of New York, will talk to Colbert on Wednesday.\n\nAlso, Check This Out\n\nPhoto\n\nEach year the Tribeca Film Festival brings a crippling array of choices for attendees. Here are the films \u2014 new and old \u2014 that the festival\u2019s co-founder Robert De Niro would see if he were you, complete with commentary.", "title": "James Comey Tells Colbert Why Trump\u2019s Presidency Is \u2018Not O.K.\u2019", "authors": ["Giovanni Russonello", "Best Of Late Night"]} {"date": "2018-04-15 00:00:00", "text": "When President Trump fired James B. Comey as the director of the F.B.I. last May, that did not mean the end of Mr. Comey\u2019s time in the public eye \u2014 far from it. His memoir, \u201cA Higher Loyalty,\u201d is about to be released and Mr. Comey was featured in a wide-ranging interview with ABC News that aired on Sunday .\n\nWhile ABC broadcast an hour of its conversation with Mr. Comey, it conducted a five-hour interview with him, a transcript of which was obtained by The New York Times. In it, Mr. Comey called Mr. Trump a serial liar who treated women like \u201cmeat,\u201d and described him as a \u201cstain\u201d on everyone who worked for him.\n\n[Read more from The Times\u2019s Michael D. Shear and Peter Baker and read annotated excerpts from the interview \u00bb]", "title": "James Comey vs. President Trump: How It Came to This", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-16 00:00:00", "text": "The move follows American-led attacks against the government of President Bashar al-Assad of Syria over the weekend. Here are seven takeaways from the strikes, which were conducted with Britain and France.\n\n\u2022 The airstrikes, which hit three targets, were intended to keep the West from being dragged further into Syria\u2019s seven-year war. But they didn\u2019t alter the overall dynamics of the conflict.\n\nPhoto\n\nA new legal threat with long arms\n\n\u2022 President Trump has more than Robert Mueller to worry about.\n\nWe look at the U.S. attorney\u2019s office for the Southern District of New York, known for its impartiality, and the threat it poses to Mr. Trump.\n\n\u2022 Today, a federal judge is to consider a request by Michael Cohen, Mr. Trump\u2019s personal lawyer, that investigators be blocked from reviewing materials they gathered when searching his office and hotel room.\n\nPensions leave states in a pinch\n\n\u2022 An eye surgeon who served as president of a public university in Oregon receives the state\u2019s largest government pension: $76,111. Per month.\n\nMany states and cities are still hurting from the 2008 financial crisis, which hammered pension funds and tax revenues. But it didn\u2019t reduce the amounts they owe retirees.\n\n\u2022 As a result, local residents are paying more taxes but getting scantier services.\n\nCorruption in South Africa: \u201cThey eat money\u201d\n\n\u2022 Since apartheid ended in 1994, tens of billions of dollars in public funds \u2014 intended to develop the economy and improve the lives of black South Africans \u2014 have been siphoned off by the African National Congress, the very organization that had promised an equal and just nation.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nOur correspondents write about a fraudulent dairy project that is emblematic of South Africa\u2019s corruption and entrenched inequalities.\n\n\u2022 \u201cWe managed to bring democracy, which is not working for us now. It\u2019s working for individuals,\u201d one South African said, laughing. \u201cI cannot cry. When I\u2019m crying, it\u2019s just the same. It\u2019s better I must laugh.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nThe Daily Listen to \u2018The Daily\u2019: California vs. the E.P.A. She is 92.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u2022 A prominent civil rights lawyer, David Buckel, died after setting himself on fire in a park in Brooklyn. In a letter, he said he wanted to make a statement about protecting the environment.\n\n\u2022 Thousands of Hungarians took to the streets, calling for Prime Minister Viktor Orban to step down just a week after he was elected to a third consecutive term.\n\n\u2022 The chief executive of Starbucks apologized after a video of two black men being arrested in a Philadelphia branch on suspicion of trespassing quickly drew outrage.\n\n\u2022 The N.B.A. and N.H.L. playoffs are underway. Here\u2019s a selection of what they said.\n\n\u2022 In memoriam\n\nMilos Forman challenged Hollywood with a subversive touch, directing the Oscar-winning \u201cOne Flew Over the Cuckoo\u2019s Nest\u201d and \u201cAmadeus.\u201d He was 86.\n\nJean Marzollo sent millions of children searching through elaborate photo collages in her \u201cI Spy\u201d rhyming picture books. She was 75.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story The Evening Briefing by Email Get a nightly rundown of the day\u2019s top stories, delivered to your inbox every Monday through Friday. Its fall from relevance has been startling, and sad. This article in The Ringer takes us through the magazine\u2019s difficult, and worrying, future.\u201d\n\n\u2022 Quotation of the day\n\n\u201cIt used to be legs, limbs and hair coming at you, but now it\u2019s legs and limbs.\u201d\n\n\u2014 Travis d\u2019Arnaud, the New York Mets catcher, on his teammate Jacob deGrom, the gangly, 190-pound flame-throwing pitcher who lopped off his trademark long locks over the winter.\n\n\u2022 The Times, in other words\n\nHere\u2019s an image of today\u2019s front page, and links to our Opinion content and crossword puzzles.\n\nBack Story\n\nHollywood has the Oscars, journalism has the Pulitzers.\n\nThere will be no red carpet or ball gowns, but newsrooms around the U.S. will gather this afternoon for the announcement of the Pulitzer Prizes, which honor the best journalism and arts of the previous year.\n\nPhoto\n\nEstablished in 1917, the prizes are given in 21 categories, which include breaking news photography, fiction and editorial writing. (Here\u2019s a look at how The Times selects the work it puts forward for consideration.)\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe top prize, which wins a gold medal, is the public service award. Previous winners include The Arkansas Gazette\u2019s coverage of school integration, The Boston Globe\u2019s expos\u00e9 of sexual abuse by priests and The Times\u2019s reporting of the aftermath of the Sept. 11, 2001, terrorist attacks.\n\nThe awards were created by Joseph Pulitzer, publisher of The St. Louis Post-Dispatch and The New York World, at the turn of the 20th century as an \u201cincentive to excellence.\u201d Hawkish, with an eye for rooting out public abuses, Pulitzer is widely regarded as one of the founders of modern American journalism.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s my duty to see that they get the truth,\u201d he once said, \u201cso that they may be wisely guided by its light.\u201d\n\nRemy Tumin contributed reporting.\n\n_____\n\nYour Morning Briefing is published weekdays and updated all morning. Moscow blamed the United Nations for the delay.\n\nWashington plans to impose new sanctions on Russia for enabling the Syrian government\u2019s use of chemical weapons, as relations with the Kremlin continue to sour.\n\nAnd U.S.-led attacks over the weekend, which hit three targets, were intended to keep the West from being dragged further into Syria\u2019s seven-year war. But our correspondent says the airstrikes didn\u2019t alter the overall dynamics of the conflict.\n\n_____\n\nPhoto\n\n\u2022 Lung cancer researchers have made a major discovery: Patients can survive much longer if they receive immunotherapy alongside chemotherapy.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe drugs \u2014 including an immunotherapy agent made by Merck (which paid for the study) \u2014 cost more than $100,000 a year and help only some patients.\n\nBut they\u2019re seen as a potential key in the fight against lung cancer, the leading cause of cancer death globally.\n\n_____\n\nVideo\n\n\u2022 And the search for alien worlds and perhaps alien life will take another step outward this week when TESS, the Transiting Exoplanet Survey Satellite, is launched by NASA into orbit around the Earth.\n\nThe satellite will spend at least two years scrutinizing the sky for exoplanets \u2014 planets around other stars \u2014 within about 300 light years from our own.\n\nThe launch was postponed from Monday, and rescheduled for Wednesday. It should be available on NASA\u2019s website.\n\nBusiness\n\n\u2022 China releases quarterly G.D.P. figures today.\n\n\u2022 The Department of Commerce banned American companies from selling components to ZTE Corp, a leading Chinese telecom equipment maker, for seven years. ZTE pleaded guilty last year to conspiring to violate U.S. sanctions by shipping U.S. technology to Iran.\n\n\u2022 Sina Weibo, the Chinese social media giant, reversed its ban on gay-themed content after intense pressure from millions of internet users.\n\n\u2022 With Dropbox and Spotify successfully going public, tech investors are confident that a bonanza of initial public offerings lies ahead.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u2022 Signing off: Credit card signatures are (finally) going extinct in the U.S.\n\n\u2022 U.S. stocks were up. Here\u2019s a snapshot of global markets.\n\nMarket Snapshot View Full Overview\n\nIn the News\n\n\u2022 \u201cThey eat money.\u201d Since apartheid ended in South Africa in 1994, tens of billions of dollars in public funds have been siphoned off by leaders of the African National Congress, the organization that had promised an equal and just nation. [The New York Times]\n\n\u2022 Barbara Bush, 92, the wife of the 41st U.S. president and mother of the 43rd, is seriously ill and has decided to stop seeking medical treatment to prolong her life. [The New York Times]\n\n\u2022 In Australia, a baffling flesh-eating bacteria has caused a \u201cworsening epidemic.\u201d Researchers say they need immediate funding to study the bacteria, which causes a disease called Buruli ulcer. [SBS]\n\n\u2022 In eastern India, a freight train barreled into a herd of elephants, killing a calf and three adult animals. Indian wildlife experts say such accidents are increasingly common because mining and development projects are forcing elephants to forage farther from their natural habitats. [The New York Times]\n\n\u2022 The story of six Chinese men who survived the wreck of the Titanic \u2014 and then vanished \u2014 is the subject of a new documentary by a Shanghai-based filmmaker. [South China Morning Post]\n\n\u2022 Paris. Milan. Riyadh? Saudi Arabia had its first fashion week \u2014 with female-only audiences and no social media \u2014 but as one observer said, \u201cWomen here have been waiting for years for a time to shine.\u201d [The New York Times]\n\nSmarter Living\n\nTips, both new and old, for a more fulfilling life.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u2022 Some empathic advice: Cut yourself some slack.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u2022 Recipe of the day: Salmon with sesame and herbs has an easy marinade that hits all the right notes.\n\nNoteworthy\n\nPhoto\n\n\u2022 \u201cLet\u2019s cut to the chase,\u201d our pop music critic writes. \u201cThere\u2019s not likely to be a more meaningful, absorbing, forceful and radical performance by an American musician this year, or any year soon, than Beyonc\u00e9\u2019s headlining set at the Coachella Valley Music and Arts Festival.\u201d (Here are some clips.)\n\n\u2022 Pulitzer Prizes: Applause rang out in The Times newsroom as we celebrated three awards, including public service (shared with The New Yorker) for reporting on sexual harassment that ushered in a reckoning about the treatment of women by powerful men in the uppermost ranks of Hollywood, politics, media and technology.\n\n\u2022 Yuki Kawauchi of Japan won the Boston Marathon \u2014 his fourth this year \u2014 in 2:15:53. Desiree Linden became the first American woman to win the race in 33 years.\n\n\u2022 And friends forever. Scientists have made astonishing discoveries about the nature and evolution of friendship, getting provocative clues about what makes it so healthy and social isolation so harmful.\n\nBack Story\n\nPhoto\n\nEach week, The Times\u2019s crossword column, Wordplay, highlights the answer to one of the most difficult clues from the previous week\u2019s puzzles.\n\nThis week\u2019s word: babas.\n\n\u201cBaba au rhum\u201d are rich, rum-flavored cakes that are largely popular in France and Italy. Babas is the plural.\n\nThe baba originated in France, and was supposedly inspired by the Polish king Stanislaw I, whose daughter, Marie, married King Louis XV. It is said that Stanislaw was partial to the Alsatian Gugelhupf cake, though he discovered that the dry dough tasted better when dipped in liquor.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe Parisian baker Nicolas Stohrer went on to popularize this combination, and one of his descendants eventually established rum as the alcohol of choice. Stohrer\u2019s patisserie is still around today.\n\nBabas have continued to be a staple of French baking, and the success of the cake has carried over to Italy and the United States. Babas are now often made with raisins in their dough, and they usually resemble Bundt cakes or doughnuts in shape. Variations may use sweet wine or liqueur in place of rum.\n\nDeb Amlen contributed reporting.\n\n_____\n\nYour Morning Briefing is published weekday mornings and updated online. He\u2019s also a longtime friend of Mr. Trump.\n\nAre North Korean sanctions enough?\n\n\u2022 There\u2019s no doubt that the latest U.N. sanctions on Pyongyang are causing pain that earlier measures did not.\n\nLess clear is whether the pressure is forcing the North\u2019s leader, Kim Jong-un, to make concessions, and whether it\u2019s enough to persuade him to give up his nuclear arsenal. Our correspondent in South Korea explains.\n\nOn Thursday, the North dropped its longtime demand that the U.S. withdraw its 28,500 troops from the Korean Peninsula, according to the South\u2019s president, Moon Jae-in. But U.S. officials don\u2019t consider that a concession.\n\n\u2022 Economic pressure alone might not bring change: \u201cIf you think the North Koreans would revolt or the regime would collapse because of sanctions, you don\u2019t know anything about the North Koreans,\u201d one defector said.\n\nNo charges in Prince\u2019s death\n\n\u2022 Almost exactly two years after the musician accidentally overdosed on the painkiller fentanyl, the authorities in Minnesota said on Thursday that no one would be criminally charged.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cWe have no direct evidence that a specific person provided the fentanyl to Prince,\u201d a county attorney said, adding that the investigation uncovered \u201cno sinister motive, intent or conspiracy to murder Prince.\u201d\n\n\u2022 A doctor who treated the musician just before his death, at 57, has agreed to pay $30,000 to settle a federal civil violation for an illegal prescription.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe Daily Listen to \u2018The Daily\u2019: James Comey on Ego, Distrust and More In an interview with Michael Barbaro, the former F.B.I. director explains his decision to make public his notes of his interactions with President Trump. The Times Magazine discusses the idea known as carbon farming.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u2022 The week in good news\n\nA nurse who was running only her second marathon finished second at the Boston Marathon on Monday. Stephen Colbert would rather she didn\u2019t.\n\n\u2022 Quotation of the day\n\n\u201cWhen I tell colleagues from other states, they are just shocked that we have a bridge that is so expensive. They ask, \u2018What\u2019s on Staten Island? Are they giving away gold on the streets? Or is it some kind of utopia?\u2019 \u201d\n\n\u2014 Nicole Malliotakis, the New York assemblywoman whose district encompasses both ends of the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge. The toll is $17.\n\n\u2022 What we\u2019re reading\n\nKim Severson, national food correspondent: \u201cI came across this conversation on Epicurious, between the writer Julia Turshen and the Spelman College professor Ashant\u00e9 Reese, while I was researching the role grocery stores play as cultural barometers. It\u2019s an enlightening discussion of race and class through the lens of the grocery store aisle.\u201d\n\n\u2022 The Times, in other words\n\nHere\u2019s an image of today\u2019s front page, and links to our Opinion content and crossword puzzles.\n\nBack Story\n\n\u201cOld soldiers never die; they just fade away.\u201d\n\nGen. Douglas MacArthur took those words from an old Army ballad and made them famous 67 years ago this week in his farewell address to Congress.\n\nPhoto\n\nLittle did that five-star American general know that he had just given rise to an army of so-called snowclones, a relatively new linguistic phenomenon that\u2019s tougher to explain than it is to use.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nA snowclone, as defined by the linguistics professor Geoffrey K. Pullum in 2003, is a \u201ccustomizable, instantly recognizable, timeworn, quoted or misquoted phrase or sentence that can be used in an entirely open array of different jokey variants.\u201d (Mr. Pullum also called them \u201csome-assembly-required adaptable clich\u00e9 frames for lazy journalists.\u201d)\n\nLet\u2019s try one. Using General MacArthur\u2019s template, \u201cOld golfers never die, they just lose their drive,\u201d would be a snowclone. Using X and Y as stand-ins, snowclones are easy to spot: X is my middle name, a few Xs short of a Y, and so on.\n\nIt\u2019s unclear who first said \u201cpink is the new black,\u201d but it is now one of the most popular snowclone templates, notably producing the title of the book and the Netflix series \u201cOrange Is the New Black.\u201d\n\nStudy of the subject appears half-serious: One article was titled \u201cSnowclone Is the New Clich\u00e9.\u201d\n\nCharles McDermid wrote today\u2019s Back Story.\n\n_____\n\nYour Morning Briefing is published weekdays and updated all morning. Above, a Baduy tribesman in Banten, Indonesia, in 2015.\n\n\u201cWhy can these big global religions spread and be recognized,\u201d one traditional believer said, \u201cbut the original religion of Indonesia cannot?\u201d\n\nBusiness\n\n\u2022 One hammer and sickle at a time: China\u2019s newly empowered Communist Party has gained direct decision-making power over some of the international firms doing business in the country.\n\n\u2022 Australia\u2019s waste industry is pushing for a new national focus on domestic recycling, given that China stopped accepting waste and recycling imports.\n\n\u2022 Facebook isn\u2019t the only tech company under congressional scrutiny in the U.S. Google and Twitter have until April 25 to answer a senator\u2019s questions about how they handle data collection and privacy, and other companies expect similar challenges soon.\n\n\u2022 \u201cRampage,\u201d a PG-13 cheesefest involving mutant animals marketed squarely around the actor Dwayne Johnson, led the weekend box office with a global take of $174.5 million.\n\n\u2022 World leaders are heading to Washington for meetings of the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank, and Japan\u2019s prime minister, Shinzo Abe, meets with President Trump at his Florida resort on Tuesday. Now it\u2019s an unlikely \u2014 but safe \u2014 tourist destination.\n\n\u2022 In memoriam. Milos Forman, 86, the Czech-born, Oscar-winning director of \u201cOne Flew Over the Cuckoo\u2019s Nest\u201d and \u201cAmadeus\u201d; Rev. Daniel J. Berrigan, 94, a Jesuit priest and poet whose defiant protests against the Vietnam War landed him in prison.\n\n\u2022 And meet Oussouby Sacko, who is believed to be the first African-born president of a Japanese university.\n\nBack Story\n\nPhoto\n\nHollywood has the Oscars, journalism has the Pulitzers.\n\nThere will be no red carpet or ball gowns, but newsrooms around the U.S. will gather this afternoon for the announcement of the Pulitzer Prizes, which honor the best journalism and arts of the previous year.\n\nEstablished in 1917, the prizes are given in 21 categories, which include breaking news photography, fiction and editorial writing. (Here\u2019s a look at how The Times selects the work it puts forward for consideration.)\n\nThe top prize, which wins a gold medal, is the public service award. Previous winners include The Arkansas Gazette\u2019s coverage of school integration, The Boston Globe\u2019s expose of sexual abuse by priests and The Times\u2019s reporting of the aftermath of the Sept. 11, 2001, terrorist attacks.\n\nThe awards were created by Joseph Pulitzer, above, publisher of The St. Louis Post Dispatch and The New York World at the turn of the 20th century, as an \u201cincentive to excellence.\u201d Hawkish, with an eye for rooting out public abuses, Pulitzer is widely regarded as one of the founders of modern American journalism.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s my duty to see that they get the truth,\u201d he once said, \u201caccurately so that they may be wisely guided by its light.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nRemy Tumin contributed reporting.\n\n_____\n\nYour Morning Briefing is published weekday mornings and updated online.
