Contact us at asiabriefing@nytimes.com.", "title": "James Comey, Syria, North Korea: Your Monday Briefing", "authors": ["Charles Mcdermid"]} {"date": "2018-04-16 00:00:00", "text": "By the time ABC aired an hourlong interview with James B. Comey on Sunday night, his feelings on President Trump were clear: that he was volatile, immoral, fixated on allegations made against him, akin to a mob boss.\n\nWhen excerpts from Mr. Comey\u2019s forthcoming memoir emerged last week, Mr. Trump pounced, labeling Mr. Comey \u201cweak\u201d and an \u201cuntruthful slime ball.\u201d He later suggested Mr. Comey deserved jail time.\n\nThe disclosures in the book, many of which were amplified in extraordinary detail in Sunday\u2019s interview, were a stunning assault on a sitting president by a former high-ranking law enforcement official.\n\n[Read our full coverage of the interview \u00bb]\n\nThe ABC interview, conducted by the anchor George Stephanopoulos and filmed at Mr. Comey\u2019s Virginia home, was the first major interview the former F.B.I. director has granted since his firing last May.", "title": "James Comey\u2019s ABC Interview: Five Highlights", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-16 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cIn a time when almost every public debate is defined by people lining up with their respective tribes,\u201d Mr. Steel added, \u201che\u2019s managed to alienate both.\u201d\n\nMr. Comey, in remarks promoting the book, says he is trying to rouse the country to see Mr. Trump through the lens of \u201cethical leadership,\u201d arguing that the president \u201cdoes not reflect the values\u201d of Democrats, Republicans or independents. Asked on ABC if Mr. Trump should be impeached, Mr. Comey said he hoped it would not happen because voters were \u201cduty bound\u201d to \u201cgo to the voting booth and vote their values.\u201d\n\nMr. Comey has cast himself as a truth-teller before, sometimes to the irritation of colleagues or superiors. He threatened to quit his job at the Justice Department in the George W. Bush administration rather than sign off on a domestic surveillance program the White House demanded, and he refused Mr. Trump\u2019s entreaties to back off of the investigation of Michael T. Flynn, his former national security adviser. Mr. Trump fired Mr. Comey a few months later, calling him a \u201cgrandstander\u201d and citing the F.B.I.\u2019s investigation into his administration\u2019s ties to Russia.\n\n\u201cAfter he was fired, he finally became the martyr he always held himself out to be,\u201d said Matthew A. Miller, who served as a top Justice Department official under President Obama when Mr. Comey led the F.B.I. \u201cBy doing a tour like this where you kind of get down in the gutter the way he has, you sacrifice your claim on being a martyr.\u201d\n\nEven before the release of his book, \u201cA Higher Loyalty,\u201d the White House, working in concert with the Republican National Committee, began an all-out campaign to besmirch \u201cLyin\u2019 Comey\u201d \u2014 the name of a website the party created to make the case \u2014 as dishonest, self-serving and driven by partisanship. But with his one-liners and cutting asides about the president, Mr. Comey only appeared to play into the hands of allies of Mr. Trump, who are eager to paint the former F.B.I. director as just another figure working for the president\u2019s defeat.\n\nAnd Mr. Comey has drawn bipartisan criticism with his latest efforts to explain \u2014 and, to some degree, recast \u2014 his much-criticized handling of the investigation into Hillary Clinton\u2019s use of a private email server. Mark Mellman, a longtime Democratic pollster, said Mr. Comey\u2019s standing had been undermined by the one-two punch of liberal attacks over his role in the 2016 election and the more recent assault led by Mr. Trump and his Republican allies.\n\n\u201cTrump has tried to define him as a bad operator, and the problem for Comey is that you can quote a lot of Democrats saying the same,\u201d Mr. Mellman said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAt this point, it seems unlikely that Mr. Comey\u2019s book or his performance in interviews to promote it will sway public opinion in a country that is already intensely polarized along partisan lines. Mr. Trump\u2019s approval ratings have been similar for months, and the roughly 40 percent of Americans who support him have proven remarkably unshakable, while the 56 percent who disapprove will probably not change their views on Mr. Comey's account.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nWhile Mr. Comey is sure to captivate the public for a few days with his biting descriptions of the president and dramatic of interactions with him, the combination of the supercharged news cycle and the looming \u2014 and far more consequential \u2014 investigation by Robert S. Mueller III, the special counsel probing Russia\u2019s meddling in the 2016 election, is sure to eventually overshadow his memoir.\n\n\u201cIt keeps the story of cover-ups and corruption on the public radar while Mueller is doing his investigation, but Comey is just a pit stop along the way of that,\u201d said Stephanie Cutter, a veteran Democratic strategist. \u201cMuch to Comey\u2019s chagrin, his moment has passed. There\u2019s nothing in this book we don\u2019t already know. He just adds one more hole to a ship that\u2019s already sinking.\u201d\n\nMr. Comey plainly considers himself to be a figure who is above the political fray, driven and guided solely by facts. His friends and advisers say he wants the book to stir a conversation about the value of honesty.\n\n\u201cTelling the truth should not be seen as a political act,\u201d said Keith Urbahn, Mr. Comey\u2019s book agent. \u201cIt should just be the truth.\u201d\n\nYet there is a twist: While he professes to be uneasy with the country\u2019s growing polarization and appears to disdain partisanship, Mr. Comey has in effect weaponized himself against a Republican president by calling for him to be voted out of office. Mr. Comey may not want to be used as anybody\u2019s \u201cpolitical battering ram,\u201d as one associate put it, but he recognizes that is precisely how his book will be deployed.\n\nFriends say Mr. Comey expected his memoir would be criticized because of how it would inevitably be construed: either as airbrushing history and not being honest about Mr. Trump\u2019s transgressions, or as a self-serving and score-settling account with the man who ended his career in law enforcement.\n\nStill, Mr. Comey\u2019s former colleagues rejected any notion that he has transformed himself into a political actor or hurt his reputation.\n\n\u201cJim Comey is as upright, honest and decent a person and public servant as I have ever met,\u201d said Jack Goldsmith, who served with him in the Bush Justice Department.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAs for his willingness to engage in Trumpian insults, invoking the size of the president\u2019s hands, his allies argue that he is simply attempting to paint vivid scenes and does the same with the other presidents he served.\n\nMr. Miller, however, said Mr. Comey tends to be \u201cat his best when he\u2019s coloring inside the lines and following the rules,\u201d as prosecutors are trained to do.\n\n\u201cWhat you see in the book is not just a factual recitation, but also a lot of spin on the ball,\u201d he said.", "title": "James Comey\u2019s Attacks on Trump May Hurt a Carefully Cultivated Image", "authors": ["Julie Hirschfeld Davis", "Jonathan Martin"]} {"date": "2018-04-25 00:00:00", "text": "WASHINGTON \u2014 \u201cThis is my first and only book party, and I didn\u2019t do the invites,\u201d the former F.B.I. director James Comey said Tuesday night, peering out over a sparse crowd on the seventh floor of the Newseum. (This was easy for him to do as he is, famously, 6-foot-8.)\n\nMr. Comey, by now a bona fide bipartisan pariah, was sipping California pinot noir from a paper cup and celebrating the remarkable success of his juicy new memoir, \u201cA Higher Loyalty,\u201d with perhaps the last crowd left in town who will gladly have him: journalists.\n\nIn a city not known for snappy dressing, Mr. Comey cut a sharp figure in a bespoke blue plaid suit made by the haberdasher The Tailored Man of Alexandria, Va., and brown R.M. Williams Chelsea boots he says were given to him by friends from the Australian police force (not to be confused with the black Chelsea boots Mr. Comey wore for his prime time \u201c20/20\u201d interview, which earned him plaudits from Esquire and GQ).\n\nAs a late-April rain lashed the museum\u2019s panoramic windows, the man of the hour cheerily recounted tales from his whirlwind media tour. \u201cThe clutch of people coming up to me in airports, that\u2019s probably the hardest thing to get used to,\u201d he said.", "title": "James Comey\u2019s Book Party Was Larded With Journalists", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-15 00:00:00", "text": "On Trump\u2019s Monologues\n\n\u2018It was him talking almost the entire time.\u2019\n\nIt was him talking almost the entire time, which I\u2019ve discovered is something he frequently does. And so it would be monologue in this direction, monologue in that direction, monologue in a different direction. And a constant series of assertions that \u2014 about the inauguration crowd, about how great my inauguration speech was, about all the free media \u2014 earned media, I think was his term, that I got during the campaign. On and on and on and on. Everyone agrees, everyone agrees, I did this, the \u2014 I never assaulted these women, I never made fun of a reporter. And \u2014 I\u2019m sure you\u2019re wondering what question did I ask that would prompt those? None, zero. I didn\u2019t ask any questions that I recall.\n\nOne of the most interesting observations by Mr. Comey during the interview was that Mr. Trump delivers monologues that are intended to leave the impression that those listening agree completely with him.\n\nMr. Comey notes on several occasions that in private conversations, the president simply makes assertions \u2014 often falsely \u2014 without giving the people he\u2019s talking to a chance to interject or object. It\u2019s an interesting observation because it is similar to what Mr. Trump does in public.\n\nWhen he is giving remarks to a small group around a table at the White House, he often rambles from one topic to the next, making assertions that often are not true but cannot be challenged at the time because they come in such rapid-fire fashion.\n\nAnd Mr. Comey notes that the president often says contradictory things in the same monologue. He noted that over dinner, the president told him that Reince Priebus, the chief of staff at the time, didn\u2019t know they were having dinner together. But later, Mr. Trump told Mr. Comey to follow up with Mr. Priebus, who knew they were having dinner together.\n\n\u201cOne of those things is not true. One of those things is a lie,\u201d Mr. Comey says in the interview.\n\nOn Those Who Work With the President\n\n\u2018He will stain everyone around him.\u2019\n\nThe challenge of this president is that he will stain everyone around him. And the question is, how much stain is too much stain and how much stain eventually makes you unable to accomplish your goal of protecting the country and serving the country? So I don\u2019t know.\n\nMr. Comey reveals in his book that John F. Kelly, the current White House chief of staff, said he wanted to resign in protest when Mr. Comey was fired. In the interview, he says he urged Mr. Kelly to stay for the good of the country.\n\nOn informing President-Elect Trump about Russia\u2019s Meddling in the Election\n\n\u2018I don\u2019t remember any questions about, \u201cSo what are they going to do next. How might we stop it?\u201d\u2019\n\nNo one, to my recollection, asked, \u201cSo what \u2014 what\u2019s coming next from the Russians?\u201d You\u2019re about to lead a country that has an adversary attacking it and I don\u2019t remember any questions about, \u201cSo what are they going to do next? How might we stop it? What\u2019s the future look like? Because we\u2019ll be custodians of the security of this country.\u201d There was none of that. It was all, \u201cWhat can we say about what they did and how it affects the election that we just had.\u201d\n\nMuch has been written about the meeting in Trump Tower on Jan. 6 when Mr. Comey and other intelligence officials briefed Mr. Trump and his top aides about Russian interference. Mr. Comey says that the president-elect and his aides were more concerned about how to \u201cspin\u201d it publicly. And he says that he got the feeling that Mr. Trump wanted to talk about the public relations effort with the intelligence chiefs there to send a message that they were part of the spin effort as well.\n\nOn Whether the Russians Are Blackmailing the President\n\n\u2018I think it\u2019s possible. I don\u2019t know.\u2019\n\nSTEPHANOPOULOS: Do you think the Russians have something on Donald Trump? COMEY: I think it\u2019s possible. I don\u2019t know. These are more words I never thought I\u2019d utter about a president of the United States, but it\u2019s possible. STEPHANOPOULOS: That\u2019s stunning. You can\u2019t say for certain that the president of the United States is not compromised by the Russians? COMEY: It is stunning and I wish I wasn\u2019t saying it, but it\u2019s just \u2014 it\u2019s the truth. I cannot say that. It always struck me and still strikes me as unlikely, and I would have been able to say with high confidence about any other president I dealt with, but I can\u2019t. It\u2019s possible.\n\nSome of Mr. Comey\u2019s assertions in the interview, and the book, are sure to be assailed by his critics. Among the most damning is that he cannot say for sure whether the president is being blackmailed by the Russians. He offers no proof that there is such blackmail.", "title": "James Comey\u2019s Interview on ABC\u2019s \u201820/20\u2019: Annotated Excerpts", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-24 00:00:00", "text": "Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night\u2019s highlights that lets you sleep \u2014 and lets us get paid to watch comedy. If you\u2019re interested in hearing from The Times regularly about great TV, sign up for our Watching newsletter and get recommendations straight to your inbox.\n\n\u2018Fifth in Line\u2019\n\nJames Corden welcomed Britain\u2019s new prince with a few good-natured jokes on Monday\u2019s \u201cLate Late Show.\u201d Then he expressed hope that Prince William and Catherine, the duchess of Cambridge \u2014 who haven\u2019t announced the baby\u2019s name yet \u2014 might go with one particularly familiar British name: James.", "title": "James Corden Welcomes Britain\u2019s New Prince, Enviously", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-29 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cI heard the voices of black blood crying out to God and to humanity,\u201d he said last year.\n\nHis 1969 book, \u201cBlack Theology & Black Power,\u201d is considered the founding text of black liberation theology. In an introduction to an updated edition in 1997, Dr. Cone wrote that he had \u201cwanted to speak on behalf of the voiceless black masses in the name of Jesus, whose Gospel I believed had been greatly distorted by the preaching theology of white churches.\u201d\n\nAs a professor, he encouraged his students to pursue their own ideas rather than imitating his, said the Rev. Dr. Kelly Brown Douglas, an author, priest and the dean of the Episcopal Divinity School at Union Theological Seminary.\n\nImage Dr. Cone\u2019s 1969 book \u201cBlack Theology & Black Power\u201d is considered the founding text of black liberation theology.\n\n\u201cHe gave many of us the opportunity to study and find our own theological voice at a time when we would not have had an opportunity to do so,\u201d Dr. Douglas said.\n\nBlack liberation theology made headlines in 2008 when it became known that one of its proponents, the Rev. Jeremiah A. Wright Jr., had been a minister for Barack Obama, then a presidential candidate.\n\nMr. Obama\u2019s past association with Mr. Wright became a campaign liability when Mr. Wright was quoted as having suggested that the United States was attacked on Sept. 11 because it had engaged in terrorism of its own, and that the government could have used the virus that causes AIDS as a tool for genocide against minorities. Mr. Obama renounced Mr. Wright in April 2008.\n\nThe next month, Dr. Cone described the theology to The New York Times as combining the views of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. and Malcolm X. \u201cYou might say we took our Christianity from Martin and our emphasis on blackness from Malcolm,\u201d he said.\n\nHe added that while he disagreed with Mr. Wright\u2019s more incendiary comments, \u201cdeep down in all of us is that Malcolm X who cries out in such strong language.\u201d", "title": "James H. Cone, a Founder of Black Liberation Theology, Dies at 79", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-29 00:00:00", "text": "HOUSTON \u2014 James Harden proved once again that Utah\u2019s vaunted defense was no match for him.\n\nLed by Harden\u2019s 41 points, the Houston Rockets sailed to a 110-96 win over the Jazz on Sunday in Game 1 of their Western Conference semifinal series.\n\nHouston was ahead by 25 at halftime behind a combined 34 points from Harden and Chris Paul. The Jazz, who did not wrap up their first-round series against Oklahoma City until late Friday, looked sluggish and struggled to keep pace with the top-seeded Rockets, who had not played since eliminating Minnesota on Wednesday.\n\nThe Jazz tied for second in the N.B.A. in the regular season by allowing just 99.8 points a game, but they failed to stop Harden in any of their four meetings. Harden averaged 34.3 points against Utah in the regular season, led by a 56-point performance in a 137-110 win in November.\n\n\u201cTheir defense is really good \u2014 their defense is super,\u201d Houston Coach Mike D\u2019Antoni said. \u201cBut James is James.\u201d", "title": "James Harden\u2019s 41 Points Lead Rockets Over Jazz", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-29 00:00:00", "text": "James Hylton, the 1966 Nascar rookie of the year, was killed in a traffic accident on Saturday in Carnesville, Ga. He was 83. His son, James Jr., 61, also died in the crash.\n\nThe Georgia State Patrol said the truck the Hyltons were riding in went off the road and hit an embankment. The driver, whose name was not released, was severely injured.\n\nThe three men had to be extricated from the GMC truck, which was pulling a trailer carrying a racecar and other equipment, the authorities said.\n\nNo other vehicles were involved in the wreck. The State Patrol said it was still investigating and had not determined whether to cite the driver.", "title": "James Hylton, 1966 Nascar Rookie of the Year, Dies at 83", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-12 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cI have never seen anything like it,\u201d Pallotta said. \u201cPeople just going bananas.\u201d\n\nHe did not leave the Stadio Olimpico for some time that night. There were news media interviews to do, guests to greet, each of them passing on breathless congratulations. He went to the locker room to celebrate with his players and his coach, Eusebio Di Francesco.\n\nIt was deep into the small hours of Wednesday morning when he arrived back at the steps of his hotel, the Hotel de Russie, around the corner from Piazza del Popolo. He has stayed there on every visit to Rome since he took control of the club, in 2012. When he returned, the Roma fans among the staff were decked out in the club\u2019s colors \u2014 yellow and a red verging on burnt orange \u2014 to welcome him.\n\n\u201cOne of them, Alessandro, told me that there were thousands of people on the piazza,\u201d Pallotta said. \u201cHe said, \u2018You go, you go.\u2019 \u201d Pallotta obeyed. On the way, a member of his coterie suggested he should jump in the fountain that sits in the center of the square. Pallotta, 60, thought it sounded like a great idea.\n\nHe took off his jacket and removed his cellphone and credit cards from his pockets: This, it turns out, was not his first rodeo. He strolled up to the fountain, sat on its lip, and tumbled in. \u201cAnd then I thought: Let\u2019s get something to eat,\u201d he said.\n\nIt was only later, in his hotel room, that it occurred to him that Rome\u2019s authorities do not take kindly to people jumping in its fountains. On Wednesday, he apologized to the city\u2019s mayor and accepted his $280 fine. He also pledged $280,000 to help restore another fountain, in front of the Pantheon.\n\n\u201cI do not condone people jumping in fountains,\u201d he said. \u201cBut if you do, you should pay to fix them.\u201d\n\nTuesday night was that kind of night in Rome. Roma had not reached the last four of the European Cup since 1984, and few had given the team a hope against mighty Barcelona, against Lionel Messi and Luis Su\u00e1rez and the rest. \u201cWhen the draw was made, all of the Spanish newspapers said it was easy,\u201d Pallotta said. \u201cOne of the headlines was \u2018Roman Candy.\u2019 \u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBy the time he had eaten, dried off and gone to bed, he could still hear gleeful fans singing in the streets. It was the sort of night, in other words, when the billionaire American owner of an Italian soccer team jumping into a fountain felt like a \u201cgreat idea.\u201d\n\nIf Pallotta\u2019s celebration was exuberant, though, the work that made it possible was significantly cooler-headed. Since taking control almost six years ago \u2014 he first invested in Roma, in a minority, passive role, in 2008 \u2014 Pallotta has done all he can to turn what was once a debt-ridden, chaotic club into a sleek, sophisticated outfit.\n\nPhoto\n\nIt seems a strange gauge, but Roma\u2019s approach to social media and its business endeavors offer an insight into Pallotta\u2019s vision.\n\nIn 2015, the club recruited Paul Rogers from a similar role at Liverpool to oversee its digital content. Last summer, Rogers\u2019s team produced a run of videos during the transfer window that went viral: a spoof of the ubiquitous, homemade highlight reels that litter YouTube; a film of midfielder Lorenzo Pellegrini playing as himself on the video game FIFA; a pastiche of a video made by Southampton to skewer Roma\u2019s own satirical announcements, featuring quite a lot of goats. Rogers described Roma as \u201cowning weirdness.\u201d\n\nFunny as those films were, the strategy was significant. Pallotta, like many American owners in soccer, sees his team as a content company. The premium content, of course, is the sport itself, but that is just one element. \u201cIf you want to be a worldwide brand, you have to create content 24/7,\u201d he said.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nPallotta now believes Roma creates more content than most of its peers. Its website was named Best in Class at last year\u2019s Interactive Media Awards. It is, Pallotta said, one of the \u201cfastest growing teams in social and digital media.\u201d Roma is starting to rival clubs of far greater resources and historical scope.\n\nThat is not the only advancement. Roma has recruited specialists in ticketing, marketing and branding, a quiet revolution in the staid, conservative world of Italian soccer. Pallotta hopes to break ground on a new stadium, after considerable delays, in December; it will be an entertainment and retail venue, and he believes it will be one of the most-used facilities in Europe.\n\nRoma is also investigating machine-learning to try to refine its scouting processes. Pallotta hired a Canadian statistician, Luke Bornn, as head of data, analytics and software, then replaced him last year with a Scot, Stephen McCarthy.\n\nThe work is still in its comparative infancy, but proved crucial in Pallotta\u2019s greatest coup: tempting Monchi, the longtime sporting director of the Spanish side Sevilla, and widely regarded as a man with a golden touch in the transfer market, to Rome last year. Monchi, Pallotta explained, had pursued in Seville a version of what Roma was trying.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMonchi was impressed when he saw what Pallotta\u2019s data scientists were doing at their Boston war room. \u201cHe saw that we could take what he was thinking and bring it to fruition,\u201d said Pallotta, who is confident that Roma\u2019s analytics work is more sophisticated than that of \u201c99 percent\u201d of its peers.\n\nThere is, here, a parallel with one of the three teams that Roma might face in the Champions League semifinals. Pallotta has known John W. Henry and Tom Werner of Fenway Sports Group, owner of Liverpool, for years. Henry, whose own team knocked off Manchester City on Tuesday, called Pallotta to offer congratulations after Roma\u2019s defeat of Barcelona. \u201cI missed the call,\u201d Pallotta said. \u201cI think I was in the fountain.\u201d\n\nF.S.G. has spent much of its tenure aware that it cannot outspend clubs backed by vast commercial revenues, oligarchs or sovereign wealth funds, just as Roma cannot hope to compete financially with Juventus, at least while the new stadium remains mired in red tape.\n\nThough it has taken several missteps, F.S.G., too, has discovered that it has to be smarter than its rivals, if it cannot be richer. It has adopted a data-driven recruitment strategy, revamped its commercial team and found new ways of monetizing its passionate support. Manager Jurgen Klopp, hired in 2015, has helped plenty, too.\n\nThe reward, for both, is a place in the final four of the world\u2019s most prestigious club competition. Both would, of course, reject the assertion that they were punching above their weight \u2014 Liverpool has won the European Cup five times \u2014 but, in financial terms, both remain underdogs when compared with their prospective opponents, Real Madrid and Bayern Munich, and their recent victims, Manchester City and Barcelona.\n\nThat they are both here, within touching distance of a final, of glory, is vindication for all they have done; it also offers hope to others that the latter stages of the Champions League are not an entirely closed shop.\n\nNot that Pallotta, at least, is quite satisfied. Not long after he took charge of Roma, he gathered together the club\u2019s staff at its training facility, Trigoria. He gave a presentation outlining his ambition for the team, then spoke with another 150 or so employees outside, by another fountain.\n\n\u201cI said that at the end of the day, all I wanted was to be celebrating titles with them by jumping in the fountains of Rome,\u201d he remembered. He took that as his cue, and duly leapt into the water. \u201cI thought it was heated,\u201d he said. \u201cIt wasn\u2019t. This was the middle of January.\u201d\n\nShould Roma reach the final, should the unthinkable happen, Rome\u2019s mayor can expect another apology, and another donation, by the end of May.", "title": "James Pallotta Soaks In Roma\u2019s Stunning Win", "authors": ["Rory Smith", "On Soccer"]} {"date": "2018-04-09 00:00:00", "text": "Prosecutors will not file criminal charges against the director and screenwriter James Toback in five cases in which he has been accused of sexual abuse because their statutes of limitations have expired, the Los Angeles County district attorney\u2019s office said on Monday.\n\nMr. Toback, 73, was accused by five women of crimes ranging from misdemeanor indecent exposure to felony sexual battery, according to documents provided to The New York Times by a spokesman for the district attorney\u2019s office. The crimes were alleged to have occurred between 1978 and 2008.\n\nAccording to the documents, Mr. Toback rubbed his groin, while clothed, on women\u2019s legs until he ejaculated; pushed one woman against a wall and asked her for sex; instructed one woman to masturbate; and touched the chest and buttocks of one woman and tried to kiss her.\n\nStill, prosecutors said, the statute of limitations had expired in each case. They noted that the statute of limitations for the alleged sexual battery violations \u2014 two of which were said to have occurred in 2008 \u2014 was one year. In one of the cases, they said the woman who had alleged abuse did not appear for a scheduled interview and could not be reached by an investigator.", "title": "James Toback Won\u2019t Face Sex Crime Charges in Los Angeles", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-05 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Dimon made a point of saying that part of the problems facing the country is that too many people are talking past each other.\n\n\u201cWhen people argue as if there are binary solutions, the argument is almost always wrong,\u201d he wrote, advocating that people try to look at all sides of a situation. \u201cI tell my liberal friends to read columnists like Arthur Brooks and George Will. And I tell my conservative friends to read writers like Tom Friedman.\u201d\n\nIf Mr. Dimon were to run, he would likely have to do so as an independent. It is hard to see how liberal Democrats would embrace much of his deregulatory positions. And yet many of his positions \u2013 and especially some of his social positions not enunciated in his letter \u2014 may not be far right enough to capture the interest of Republicans.\n\nMaybe the country needs someone in the middle, but history has not been kind to third-party candidates.\n\n\u2014 Andrew Ross Sorkin\n\nDimon chafes under liquidity rules.\n\nJamie Dimon, in his annual letter to JPMorgan Chase\u2019s shareholders, had much to say about political issues like trade and immigration.\n\nBut he also addressed a policy area much closer to home \u2013 bank regulation. Mr. Dimon often has expressed skepticism about aspects of the banking overhaul that took place in the wake of the financial crisis. But his remarks on regulation arguably carry more weight now. Congress is closer to modifying the post-crisis rules than at any point since Dodd-Frank was signed into law in 2010. An important regulatory requirement Mr. Dimon criticized, therefore, might become a focus for those wanting to roll back the rules.\n\nMr. Dimon in this year\u2019s letter zeroed in on regulations that require banks to have a certain amount of liquidity, the financial term for access to cash or low-risk assets that can be easily sold for cash.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn 2008, some large financial firms were crippled when customers, depositors and creditors withdrew their money. The Federal Reserve and taxpayers had to step in to support the banks. To help prevent a repeat of this, post-crisis rules require that banks hold a certain amount of liquid assets to cover a theoretical level of outflows. Mr. Dimon is in favor of banks having more liquidity than before the crisis, but in the letter, released Thursday, he wrote:\n\nLiquidity requirements, while much higher, now have an element of rigidity built in that did not exist before. Banks will be unable to use that liquidity when they most need to do so \u2014 to make loans or intermediate markets. They have a \u201cred line\u201d they cannot cross (they are required to maintain hard and fast liquidity requirements). As clients demand more liquidity from their banks, the banks essentially will be unable to provide it.\n\nNotably, legislation currently in Congress would tweak liquidity rules. If it passes, bankers may press for more loosening. And, as they have before, bank lobbyists may deploy Mr. Dimon\u2019s main argument here \u2013 that regulation can lead to less lending. But there are flaws in this line of attack, especially when it comes to liquidity rules.\n\nFirst, a bank that lacks liquidity is in no position to lend. When a bank\u2019s creditors and customers fear it doesn\u2019t have enough cash in reserve, they will most likely withdraw their money. This not only deprives the bank of the money it needs to lend, it also sharply reduces its chance of survival. Or as Gregg Gelzinis of the left-leaning Center for American Progress puts it, \u201cYou won\u2019t be able to take this action if you fail.\u201d\n\nPerhaps more importantly, Mr. Dimon leaves out some crucial context. Congress designed the whole post-crisis overhaul to ensure that banks have the funds on hand to lend during a downturn. Dodd-Frank\u2019s architects saw that when banks stop lending, it makes a recession far worse. And that is one reason why banks now have much higher levels of capital. Regulators expect that they will use up some of that capital to keep lending through the economic tumult. This is why the Federal Reserve said after its last bank stress tests:\n\nThe nation\u2019s largest bank holding companies have strong capital levels and retain their ability to lend to households and businesses during a severe recession.\n\nAndrew Gray, a JPMorgan spokesman, followed up with more material on Mr. Dimon\u2019s thinking on liquidity.\n\nHe re-emphasized Mr. Dimon\u2019s point about having to tie up funds that could be used to make loans. Mr. Gray noted that a bank facing outflows would be expected to keep refilling its pool of liquid assets to be in compliance with a liquidity regulation. This would leave fewer funds for lending and making markets, Mr. Gray asserted.\n\nHe also addressed the argument that higher capital levels, not liquidity, will largely determine the extent to which banks will lend through a downturn. Mr. Gray asserted that liquidity rules play an important role in ensuring banks have the resources to participate in wider financial markets. Rules forcing the hoarding of liquidity may, thus, crimp that activity.\n\n\u2014 Peter Eavis\n\nPhoto\n\nYou get a raise. You get a raise.\n\nMick Mulvaney, the acting director of the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, has complained that the regulator engages in \u201cwasteful spending.\u201d He even submitted a quarterly budget request recently of $0.\n\nThat attitude apparently didn\u2019t apply to two of his recent hires.\n\nMr. Mulvaney appointed two senior staff members who are paid salaries far above what they had been earning in their previous government jobs in Washington, according to agency documents obtained by The New York Times through a public records request.\n\n\u2022 Kirsten Sutton was hired in January to be the agency\u2019s chief of staff. Mr. Mulvaney agreed to pay her $259,500 a year. Her salary is the highest allowed under the consumer bureau\u2019s pay scale and represents a raise of more than 50 percent working for one of the C.F.P.B.\u2019s fiercest critics, Representative Jeb Hensarling of Texas, the Republican chairman of the House Financial Services Committee. It is also 22 percent more than her predecessor.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u2022 Brian Johnson is another new deputy. In late December, Mr. Mulvaney signed paperwork that awarded Mr. Johnson a salary of $239,595. Mr. Johnson previously worked on the House Financial Services Committee. In his most recent job there, as policy director, he earned about $170,000 a year, according to LegiStorm. Of the 20 people at the bureau with the title of senior adviser, Mr. Johnson is the second-highest paid. (Another adviser, whose name wasn\u2019t disclosed in the public records reviewed by The Times, is paid $240,000.)\n\nContext\n\nThe consumer bureau, as well as fellow financial regulators like the Securities and Exchange Commission and the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency, is allowed under federal law to pay employees significantly more than other government agencies can pay. The rationale is that the higher salaries are necessary to recruit skilled employees who otherwise might land jobs on Wall Street.\n\nAs a result, the C.F.P.B. is stocked with employees who earn more than the average Washington bureaucrat. Of the agency\u2019s 1,600 employees, 219 make more than $200,000, according to the records reviewed by The Times.\n\n\u2014 Stacy Cowley\n\nPhoto\n\nGun-free funds.\n\nBlackRock, the world\u2019s largest money manager, plans to offer a series of new products allowing individuals and institutions to invest in market indexes without putting money into manufacturers and retailers of firearms.\n\nThey include:\n\n\u2022 a new exchange-traded fund that will track the performance of the MSCI USA Small Cap Extended ESG Focus Index, composed of small stocks with favorable environmental, social and governance standards, while specifically excluding producers and large retailers of civilian firearms.\n\n\u2022 a similar credit-focused ETF that eschews the debt of gunmakers and distributors.\n\n\u2022 an option to take the guns out of institutional strategies tracking major market indexes, including the S&P 500, the Russell 2000 and three others.\n\nCritic\u2019s corner\n\nRob Cox of Breakigviews writes:\n\n\u201cBlackRock\u2019s moves may spark criticism from gun-rights supporters, who lashed out at companies like Delta Air Lines that severed ties with the National Rifle Association. But it\u2019s hard to see how offering customers more choice is ever a bad idea. Moreover, by getting out early, BlackRock makes clear to those young people lobbying for tighter gun laws \u2013 who it hopes will be customers for decades to come \u2013 that it has something for them. Far from virtue signaling, it\u2019s simply good business.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\n\u2018That was a huge mistake, and it was my mistake\u2019\n\nWhat emerged from Facebook yesterday \u2014 in Mark Zuckerberg\u2019s conference call with reporters and in a company blog post \u2014 were revelations that users\u2019 public data was more compromised than previously thought.\n\n\u2022 Facebook said Cambridge Analytica harvested the data of 87 million users, not 50 million.\n\n\u2022 A vulnerability in search and account recovery functions may have exposed \u201cmost\u201d of Facebook\u2019s 2 billion users to unauthorized harvesting of their public profile information.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Zuckerberg, ahead of his testimony to Congress, struck a conciliatory tone. But regulators in Australia, the U.S. and elsewhere are investigating whether the company broke privacy rules.\n\nFacebook also outlined steps to prevent misuse of its platform. Among the most significant: restriction of access to so-called A.P.I.s that let developers plug into its network. The Verge\u2019s take: \u201cEffectively, Facebook has put a nail in the coffin of its app platform.\u201d\n\nThe most immediate effect: Tinder users couldn\u2019t log in.\n\nA brighter note for Facebook: Its shares are up in premarket trading today, after Mr. Zuckerberg said that #DeleteFacebook didn\u2019t appear to be having much effect.\n\nThe Facebook calendar\n\n\u2022 April 9: Alerts should start popping up for users whose information may have been shared with Cambridge Analytica.\n\n\u2022 April 10: Mr. Zuckerberg is scheduled to testify before the Senate\u2019s Commerce and Judiciary committees.\n\n\u2022 April 11: He will testify before the House Energy and Commerce Committee.\n\nElsewhere in tech and regulation: A closer look at Margrethe Vestager, the public face of Europe\u2019s tech clampdown. And the privacy advocate Max Schrems says the fight over user data has just begun.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe White House remains committed to trade saber-rattling\n\nPresident Trump and the White House insist that the U.S. isn\u2019t in a trade war with China. But it hasn\u2019t backed off from its tariff threats, and the White House press secretary, Sarah Huckabee Sanders, said the U.S. may feel \u201ca little bit of short-term pain.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story The All-New DealBook Newsletter Our columnist Andrew Ross Sorkin and his Times colleagues help you make sense of major business and policy headlines \u2014 and the power-brokers who shape them. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMore from behind the scenes, by Ana Swanson and Keith Bradsher of the NYT:\n\nPeople familiar with the negotiations say Steven Mnuchin, the Treasury secretary, and Wilbur Ross, the commerce secretary, have at times argued for more dialogue with the Chinese and quicker concessions that would help diminish the trade deficit. \u2026 Other top trade advisers, including longtime China critics like Robert Lighthizer and Peter Navarro, have taken a tougher stance.\n\nCalming the markets has mostly fallen to Larry Kudlow, the White House\u2019s national economic adviser of less than a week.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nPeter Eavis\u2019s take: We can take lessons on the U.S.-China trade skirmish from Brexit. Looking back, the panicky early reaction to that seems to have sprung more from a fear of the unknown than any big threats to the global trading system.\n\nAnd Greg Ip of the WSJ, who says China started the trade fight, had an informative tweetstorm about each side\u2019s vulnerabilities:\n\nPhoto\n\nBut Neil Irwin of the Upshot warns that China has other ways of retaliating.\n\nTrade deficit hits a 9 1/2 year high in February.\n\nThe United States trade deficit rose 1.6 percent to $57.6 billion, its highest level since October 2008. The deficit has now risen for six straight months, the longest such streak since 2000.\n\nThe merchandise-trade gap with China narrowed to $34.7 billion in February from $35.5 billion. The Trump administration wants to cut $100 billion, or about 25 percent, from the annual deficit with China, Bloomberg points out. During President Trump\u2019s first year in office, the United States\u2019 trade deficit with China rose to $375.2 billion in 2017, a record high.\n\nPhoto\n\nWhither Blackstone\u2019s giant infrastructure fund?\n\nLast May, Blackstone announced with great fanfare that it planned a $40 billion fund with Saudi Arabia to invest in U.S. infrastructure: up to $20 billion from the Saudis, who would match commitments by other outside partners. But as of now, Blackstone has secured just $575 million in such commitments \u2014 and missed two fund-raising deadlines.\n\nWhat\u2019s happened, per Kate Kelly and Andrew:\n\n\u2022 The Saudis wanted the fund overseen by an investment committee, with a seat for them. Blackstone refused.\n\n\u2022 Many potential investors balked at committing money until an investment team was in place, a process that took some time.\n\nIn other infrastructure news: D.J. Gribbin, the Trump administration\u2019s infrastructure point person, is leaving the White House, which looks to have delayed its investment plan until after the midterms.\n\nThe political flyaround\n\n\u2022 The E.P.A. chief Scott Pruitt, the subject of some unhappy rumblings from the White House, has begun a media pushback against claims about his spending. (Politico)\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u2022 George Nader, the U.A.E.-connected businessman cooperating with Robert Mueller\u2019s investigation, has links to Russia, too. He\u2019d previously said it would be \u201cour military.\u201d (NYT)\n\n\u2022 John Kasich is eating at diners in New Hampshire, for some reason. (NYT)\n\n\u2022 Amalgamated Bank became the latest restrict gun sales by its business customers, following guidelines published by the Mike Bloomberg-backed Everytown for Gun Safety. (Amalgamated)\n\nPhoto\n\n\u2018Google should not be in the business of war\u2019\n\nMore than 3,100 Googlers have signed a petition protesting the tech colossus\u2019s A.I. work with the Defense Department.\n\nMore from Scott Shane and Dai Wakabayashi of the NYT:\n\nThat kind of idealistic stance, while certainly not shared by all Google employees, comes naturally to a company whose motto is \u201cDon\u2019t be evil,\u201d a phrase invoked in the protest letter. But it is distinctly foreign to Washington\u2019s massive defense industry and certainly to the Pentagon, where the defense secretary, Jim Mattis, has often said a central goal is to increase the \u201clethality\u201d of the United States military.\n\nThe company line: \u201cWe\u2019re actively engaged across the company in a comprehensive discussion of this important topic.\u201d\n\nIn other defense tech news: Oracle\u2019s Safra Catz reportedly argued to Mr. Trump over dinner Tuesday night that the Pentagon\u2019s process for choosing a cloud services contractor was tilted toward Amazon. (Oracle is also bidding.)\n\nThe tech flyaround\n\n\u2022 On balance, the U.S. Postal Service probably does pretty well out of Amazon. Its real problem, Barry Ritholtz argues, is Congress.\n\n\u2022 Spotify shares ended down yesterday at $144.22, but still up on private stock trades earlier this year. (Bloomberg)\n\nPhoto\n\nThe YouTube suspect had complained about ad policies\n\nThe woman suspected of shooting three people at YouTube headquarters before killing herself had become angry with the company\u2019s policies. Police did not say which ones, but she had posted about YouTube pulling ads from videos that it said did not meet its standards.\n\nThe woman, Nasim Najafi Aghdam, was a social media video star in Iran and had called YouTube a dictatorship because she was making less money from her posts.\n\nAlso of note: The attack highlighted the tension between Silicon Valley giants\u2019 love of big, open campuses and their security needs.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe hot take: Les Moonves shouldn\u2019t run CBS-Viacom\n\nAs the two corporate siblings jostle over a potential union \u2014 Viacom has reportedly rejected CBS's offer and is preparing a counter bid \u2014 who would run the combined company remains a sticking point. Prosecutors introduced the other accounts saying they demonstrate Mr. Cosby\u2019s signature pattern of predatory behavior.\n\nBut Mr. Cosby has denied any inappropriate behavior and said the sex with Ms. Constand was consensual. His first trial, last summer, ended with a hung jury.\n\nHis defense team made a sustained effort to shake Ms. Dickinson\u2019s credibility, pushing her to acknowledge that a memoir she published in 2002 made no mention of an assault. Reading from the book in the courtroom, Thomas A. Mesereau Jr., a defense lawyer, said that Ms. Dickinson wrote she never entered Mr. Cosby\u2019s room and ended up taking two quaaludes in her own room, alone.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cYou told a tale to the jury today that is completely different from the book,\u201d he said. \u201cYou made things up to get a paycheck.\u201d\n\nBut Ms. Dickinson said she had been advised by her publishers to leave out the assault for legal reasons.\n\n\u201cYou take poetic license in what you do,\u201d she said. \u201cToday I am on a sworn Bible.\u201d\n\nFour other women have told the jury of being drugged and assaulted by Mr. Cosby.\n\nMs. Dickinson, now 63, a reality TV celebrity, said she was working as a model in New York in 1982 when Mr. Cosby approached her through her agency and invited her to his Manhattan house to talk about acting.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSoon afterward, she said Mr. Cosby flew her to Lake Tahoe where she watched him perform, and they had dinner and discussed her career. She said she went to his hotel room to continue their conversation, and there she snapped some pictures \u2014 which were shown to the courtroom \u2014 of Mr. Cosby in a colored bathrobe and cap talking on the telephone.\n\nMs. Dickinson said that because she was knocked out by the drugs, she does not fully remember the sexual assault. But when she woke up, she said, she found herself back in her own room, alone. \u201cI noticed semen between my legs, and I felt anal pain,\u201d she said. \u201cI felt very, very sore.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe publisher of Ms. Dickinson\u2019s memoir, Judith Regan, has confirmed there were discussions about putting the rape accusation in the book.\n\nThe defense has suggested that Mr. Cosby\u2019s accusers are motivated by media attention and even money. On Thursday, the team carried the argument to the steps of the courthouse, where Mr. Cosby\u2019s publicist, Andrew Wyatt, accused Gloria Allred, the civil rights attorney who is representing three of the five accusers, of being \u201cpart of the con.\u201d Ms. Allred\u2019s daughter, Lisa Bloom, represents Ms. Dickinson.\n\nAt one point, Mr. Wyatt asked Ms. Allred to explain her proposal to have Mr. Cosby set up a fund to compensate the women who have accused him of abuse.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cI\u2019m so glad you asked that,\u201d she shot back, \u201cbut you need to listen, and don\u2019t interrupt.\u201d\n\n\u201cI\u2019m not your child,\u201d Mr. Wyatt responded, and walked off.\n\nMs. Dickinson is one of about a dozen women who have outstanding civil suits against the entertainer, most of which are on hold pending the outcome of this criminal trial. Ms. Dickinson, like most of the other women, is suing him for defamation because she says his representatives characterized her as a liar when she came forward.\n\nIn the criminal case, Mr. Cosby\u2019s lawyers have tried to show to the jury that there were holes in each of the women\u2019s accounts. Mr. Mesereau confronted one accuser, Janice Baker-Kinney, on Thursday about what he described as discrepancies between the accounts she had given her sister and later the police and news media.\n\nMs. Baker-Kinney told the jury on Wednesday that Mr. Cosby drugged and sexually assaulted her in Reno in 1982 after giving her two pills. She was 24 at the time and working as a bartender.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cIs it true that you told your sister,\u201d Mr. Mesereau asked, \u201cyou went there and drank too much and didn\u2019t mention the pill?\u201d\n\nMs. Baker-Kinney said she could not recall what she had told her sister.\n\nBut Mary Chokron, a friend, testified she had received a call soon after the encounter and that Ms. Baker-Kinney said she had been knocked unconscious by some kind of party drug. \u201cShe blamed herself for taking the pill,\u201d Ms. Chokron said.\n\nMs. Baker-Kinney, a sports broadcast stage manager who now lives near San Francisco, said she did not speak out at the time because she feared she would be blamed for having put herself in that position and would be fired.\n\n\u201cThat was the culture then,\u201d she said, \u201cand was for a very long time.\u201d\n\nLise-Lotte Lublin, a teacher, told of an encounter with Mr. Cosby in a Las Vegas hotel room in 1989, when she was 23. She said she was there for an acting lesson, that he gave her two drinks and asked her to sit between his legs, and began to stroke her hair. She said she remembered little else. \u201cWhen I woke up, I was at home,\u201d she said, but she assumes she was sexually assaulted.\n\n\u201cYou have no recollection of sexual assault?\u201d Kathleen Bliss, a defense lawyer, asked several times.\n\n\u201cI would not have the memory because I was drugged,\u201d Ms. Lublin replied.", "title": "Janice Dickinson at Cosby Trial: \u2018Here Was America\u2019s Dad on Top of Me\u2019", "authors": ["Graham Bowley", "Jon Hurdle"]} {"date": "2018-04-03 00:00:00", "text": "Janka Nabay, a singer, songwriter and bandleader from Sierra Leone who modernized an ancient tradition called bubu and carried it worldwide, died on Monday in the Kambia District in northern Sierra Leone. He was 54.\n\nHis American record company, Luaka Bop, said the cause was a stomach illness that had not been diagnosed.\n\nDuring the 1990s, Mr. Nabay took the speedy beat of music that had been heard for centuries in parades and celebrations and transferred it to Western instruments. His songs became hits as civil war tore Sierra Leone apart and were claimed by both sides, although his music increasingly held direct antiwar messages.\n\nMr. Nabay emigrated from Sierra Leone in 2002. Living in New York City, he started a band, the Bubu Gang, that introduced bubu to an international audience.", "title": "Janka Nabay, 54, Dies; Carried an African Dance Music Worldwide", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-18 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Abe hoped to secure Mr. Trump\u2019s commitment on two issues: curtailing the North\u2019s nuclear and ballistic weapons programs, and facilitating the return of Japanese citizens abducted by North Korea in the 1970s and \u201980s.\n\nOn Wednesday in Tokyo, critics were skeptical that Mr. Trump would give Japan much consideration once he got into a room with Mr. Kim.\n\n\u201cThe possibility of the U.S. thinking about Japan is zero,\u201d said Terry Ito, a commentator on Nippon Television, from Tokyo.\n\nThere was a sense in Tokyo on Tuesday that Japan has been sidelined as Mr. Trump cultivates relationships elsewhere in Asia. Though sitting next to Mr. Abe at Mar-a-Lago, Mr. Trump spent nearly as much time effusively praising China\u2019s president, Xi Jinping, as \u201cincredibly generous\u201d and \u201ca very special person to me\u201d as he did discussing Japan.\n\nMr. Trump is \u201ccertainly not approaching this summit from the perspective of \u2018Japan is one of our most important allies and how do I keep this relationship strong,\u2019\u201d said Mintaro Oba, a former State Department diplomat and now a speechwriter in Washington.\n\nPhoto\n\nIt might also be a sign that Mr. Trump tends to lump countries in the region together. In a Twitter post Tuesday night, Mr. Trump signaled he was no longer interested in rejoining the Trans-Pacific Partnership, a multicountry trade deal strongly supported by Japan.\n\nMr. Trump wrote: \u201cWhile Japan and South Korea would like us to go back into TPP, I don\u2019t like the deal for the United States.\u201d But South Korea is not currently a party to the agreement.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Trump\u2019s reversal on the trade deal, less than a week after he suggested the United States could enter the pact, reinforced the view that he sees Japan\u2019s interests as expendable.\n\nThe leaders\u2019 meeting in Florida comes at a time when Mr. Abe needs a political bounce, as domestic scandals have driven approval ratings for his cabinet down as low as 27 percent, according to one poll. Mr. Abe is now even less popular than Mr. Trump.\n\nAs a world leader who has consistently maintained a strong personal relationship with Mr. Trump, Mr. Abe arrived at Mar-a-Lago with the burden of high expectations.\n\n\u201cThe consequence of Prime Minister Abe looking so effective with President Trump in previous summits,\u201d said Mr. Oba, the speechwriter, \u201cis that he has a higher level from which to fall.\u201d\n\nMr. Abe, however, managed one small victory: A verbal commitment from Mr. Trump that he would bring up the issue of Japanese citizens abducted by North Korean spies during his meeting with Mr. Kim.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe kidnappings resonate strongly with the Japanese public and Mr. Abe has made it one of his personal priorities to seek the return of the abductees.\n\nAnalysts said that Mr. Abe would most likely proclaim Mr. Trump\u2019s commitment as a victory when he returned home, but the strategy could backfire.\n\n\u201cMr. Abe will probably exaggerate his success on the abduction issue when he comes back to Japan,\u201d said Takashi Kawakami, a national security expert at Takushoku University in Tokyo. \u201cBut it\u2019s not enough.\u201d\n\nOn Wednesday in Tokyo, Shigeo Iizuka, a brother of Yaeko Taguchi, one of the abducted Japanese citizens, said he wanted concrete results.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cI want him to get a definite promise to return the Japanese citizens as well as bringing it up at the table,\u201d Mr. Iizuka told reporters about his hopes for Mr. Trump\u2019s meeting with Mr. Kim. \u201cThis is the first and last chance of a lifetime, and I don\u2019t want him to miss this chance.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn addition to the abductees, Japan is also counting on Mr. Trump for security guarantees. One of Tokyo\u2019s fears is that Mr. Trump might agree to a freeze in North Korea\u2019s weapons program that would leave the country with shorter range missiles that could still reach Japan and South Korea.\n\nFor now, Japan has been left out of North Korea\u2019s recent charm offensive.\n\n\u201cNorth Korea is now talking to the South Koreans, talking to the Chinese, and talking to the Americans, but seems to be trying to isolate Japan,\u201d said Narushige Michishita, director of the Security and International Studies Program at the National Graduate Institute for Policy Studies in Tokyo. \u201cSo that\u2019s another negative element or factor\u201d for Mr. Abe.\n\nAnalysts said Mr. Trump would very likely view a commitment to bring up the abductees with Mr. Kim as a gift to Japan that warranted something in return.\n\nWith Wednesday\u2019s talks likely to focus on trade, and Mr. Trump already indicating he was no longer interested in returning to the multilateral TPP, analysts said Mr. Abe might be forced to engage in two-way discussions as South Korea has already done.\n\n\u201cI fear that Japan may be pushed toward getting into talks about a bilateral agreement,\u201d said Jun Saito, a senior research fellow at the Japan Center for Economic Research. \u201cMr. Abe might think that it\u2019s better to get into some kind of negotiation rather than losing Japan\u2019s status in regional politics.\u201d\n\nMr. Abe already expended considerable domestic capital to persuade farmers \u2014 traditional supporters of his Liberal Democratic Party \u2014 to accept more foreign agricultural products as part of the TPP.\n\nPushing for more concessions from Japan in a bilateral deal with the United States could put Mr. Abe in an even more politically sensitive position.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cCapitulation to Trump here, I would think, would sign his political death warrant,\u201d said Jeffrey Wilson, the head of research at the Perth USAsia Center at the University of Western Australia.\n\nMr. Abe\u2019s biggest headaches still remain back in Tokyo, where he is fighting off allegations that he helped friends at two educational institutions gain preferential treatment from the government. Several leaks of tampered files and previously missing documents have deepened the scandals. Additional allegations of sexual harassment by a top official in the Ministry of Finance are also tarring the prime minister\u2019s leadership.\n\nIn rounds of golf and meetings on Wednesday in Palm Beach, Mr. Abe is likely to try to showcase his friendship with Mr. Trump in the hopes that it will remind voters back home that he is still the best man for the job.\n\n\u201cAs for his strong leadership in diplomacy, I think people appreciate that,\u201d said Ichiro Fujisaki, a former Japanese ambassador to Washington. \u201cBut people also think that no one is above the law.\u201d", "title": "Japan Fears Being Sidelined by Trump on Trade and North Korea", "authors": ["Motoko Rich"]} {"date": "2018-04-25 00:00:00", "text": "Last week, he traveled to President Trump\u2019s Mar-a-Lago estate in Palm Beach, Fla., to secure Mr. Trump\u2019s agreement to seek the total abandonment of North Korea\u2019s nuclear and missile programs in his talks with Mr. Kim, and to press for the return of Japanese citizens abducted by the North decades ago.\n\nOn Tuesday, in a phone call, Mr. Abe asked President Moon Jae-in of South Korea, who will meet with the North Korean leader on Friday, for a similar commitment.\n\nIn principle, both Mr. Trump and Mr. Moon have agreed to Mr. Abe\u2019s requests. But given how unpredictable at least two of the players are, Japan is by no means assured that it will be happy with the outcome.\n\nIn general, the Japanese are very skeptical that North Korea would stick to any deal, given its history of going back on commitments to stop its nuclear program.\n\n\u201cWe never trust the words of North Korea,\u201d said Tsuneo Watanabe, a senior research fellow at the Sasakawa Peace Foundation in Tokyo. \u201cWhat we can trust is the actions of North Korea. That is probably a sentiment shared among all Japanese, including ordinary citizens.\u201d\n\nAnd while Japan is accustomed to dealing with mercurial North Korean leaders, Mr. Trump represents a new volatility from the American side.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cWith this President Trump, there is a sense in Japan that he has a little bit different sense of the alliance,\u201d said Fumiaki Kubo, a professor of political science at the University of Tokyo.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nUnder Presidents Barack Obama, George W. Bush and Ronald Reagan, said Mr. Kubo, the sense was that \u201cif your ally is in trouble, you feel that you must help your ally. But in this president, if your ally is in trouble, it might suggest that this is a good time for him to exploit this ally.\u201d\n\nAnalysts said that Japan\u2019s biggest worry might be an impulsive desire on Mr. Trump\u2019s part to declare a quick victory, even at the cost of Japan\u2019s or the region\u2019s security. Though Mr. Trump has said that he is committed to North Korea\u2019s complete denuclearization, Japan is concerned he might accept something short of that.\n\n\u201cI think it may be that the Abe cabinet is still a little nervous that Trump is still going to say, \u2018See, I did it,\u2019 claim a win and walk away,\u201d said Sheila A. Smith, a Japan expert at the Council on Foreign Relations in Washington.\n\nMr. Kim\u2019s recent announcement that North Korea no longer needs to test nuclear weapons or long-range missiles has left Japan acutely concerned that the North intends to keep what nuclear weapons it already has, and to maintain its arsenal of short- and medium-range missiles that can reach Japan.\n\nAn editorial in the right-leaning newspaper Yomiuri Shimbun called Mr. Kim\u2019s announcement \u201ca tactic to weaken the pressure of the international community\u2019s sanctions,\u201d adding that \u201cthere was no mention of any intention to abandon nuclear and ballistic missiles\u201d in the statement.\n\nJapanese officials \u201care trying to keep the conversation very focused on what \u2018denuclearization\u2019 means,\u201d Ms. Smith said. \u201cThe experts that have been here before have had these conversations multiple times. They understand that when Kim Jong-un is talking about denuclearization he doesn\u2019t necessarily mean the same thing that we mean, so there\u2019s a lot of pressure to just put the brakes on, be cautious, make sure you know what you\u2019re doing.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nCommentators in Japan speculated that Mr. Trump might also see some value in keeping Japan nervous.\n\n\u201cFor President Trump, it may be favorable to keep Japan feeling left behind and facing a threat,\u201d Park Il, an economics professor and expert on the Korean Peninsula at Osaka City University, said on a Tokyo Broadcasting System news program. \u201cJapan will possibly have to buy more weapons for whatever price the United States sets.\u201d\n\nBesides the security concerns, the return of the Japanese citizens who were abducted by North Korea in the 1970s and \u201980s is a top priority of Japan and Mr. Abe in particular.\n\nMr. Abe scored what appeared to be a diplomatic victory in Mar-a-Lago when Mr. Trump promised he would raise the issue directly with Mr. Kim.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cWe\u2019re going to do everything possible to have them brought back, and bring them back to Japan,\u201d Mr. Trump said in a joint news conference with Mr. Abe. \u201cI gave you that promise.\u201d\n\nAnalysts said that the most Mr. Trump could do is mention the abductees, and that it was extremely unlikely he would insist on any specific action. \u201cYou had Trump voicing and saying the words that Abe wanted him to say,\u201d said Jeffrey W. Hornung, a political scientist at the RAND Corporation.\n\nPhoto\n\nBut if Mr. Kim offered, for example, to extend a testing freeze for a year but insisted the United States set aside any demands about the abductees, \u201cwould Trump say, \u2018Nope, sorry, you\u2019ve got to do the abduction issue too?\u2019\u201d Mr. Hornung said.\n\n\u201cI can\u2019t imagine Trump, who wants a success here and who really wants the big win, throwing away any big deal on denuclearization or missiles for the sake of a Japanese priority,\u201d he said.\n\nMr. Moon has also said he would raise the issue of the Japanese abductees in his meeting with Mr. Kim on Friday.\n\nBut with South Korea talking about negotiating a peace treaty to formally end the Korean War, analysts said Japan would be watching closely for signs of concessions on a bigger issue: the United States military presence on the Korean Peninsula.\n\nAlthough Mr. Kim has said he would not demand the withdrawal of American troops as a prerequisite for discussing the North\u2019s nuclear program, some supporters of Mr. Moon\u2019s liberal administration have long wanted the United States to reduce or withdraw its presence in the South, where about 28,500 American troops are stationed. Such a move would alarm Japan, which benefits from United States military protection in the region.\n\nAnalysts in Japan also worry that South Korea, in an effort to unify the peninsula, could start to pull away from the United States and be drawn further toward China, a North Korean ally.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cIf South Korea becomes a Chinese ally in the most extreme scenario, how can we defend ourselves?\u201d said Narushige Michishita, director of the Security and International Studies Program at the National Graduate Institute for Policy Studies in Tokyo.\n\n\u201cWe would be put in a very, very difficult position,\u201d Mr. Michishita said. \u201cIf the Korean Peninsula gets inside the Chinese sphere of influence and there are no U.S. forces on the peninsula, life for the U.S. and Japan would be very difficult, but especially for Japan.\u201d\n\nHoping to have some say in the course of events, Japan has been seeking to set up its own summit meeting between Mr. Abe and Mr. Kim. So far, the North has not responded.\n\nAnalysts said that Japan may get its moment if the North indeed comes out of isolation, and starts looking for financial support to fulfill Mr. Kim\u2019s promise of building the country\u2019s economy.\n\n\u201cIf North Korea is serious about having a totally different life from now on, they need some financial help from someone and it must be, in the end, Japan,\u201d said Mr. Kubo, the University of Tokyo professor.\n\nJapan, which until its defeat in World War II ruled the Korean Peninsula as a colony, paid reparations to South Korea in 1965 but has yet to pay any to the North, Mr. Kubo noted. \u201cSo then, logically, they should be interested in talking with Japan in the end.\u201d", "title": "Japan Worries It\u2019ll Be Forgotten as Its Allies Talk to North Korea", "authors": ["Motoko Rich"]} {"date": "2018-04-14 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cI\u2019m not worried in the least that Ohtani\u2019s departure will in any way lower the level of play in Japan,\u201d said Ted Heid, an executive in the Seattle Mariners\u2019 Pacific Rim operations, who has been scouting Japanese players for more than two decades. \u201cI\u2019m still very excited by Japanese baseball and excited to see how young, talented players who have been drafted into their game develop over the next five or so years.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nIndicators of baseball\u2019s popularity in Japan are strong. The National High School Baseball Tournament is preparing for its centennial celebration later this year, and the Tokyo Organizing Committee got baseball reinstated as a medal sport for the 2020 Olympics.\n\nOhtani confounded American expectations by coming to Major League Baseball at 23, instead of waiting for a bigger payday in two years, when his salary would not have been constrained by the league\u2019s international signing rules for players under 25. Already with five years of pro experience in Japan, he is seven years younger than the average age of the 56 Japanese players to debut in M.L.B. before him.\n\nWith wins in his first two pitching starts and three home runs in his first four games as designated hitter, Ohtani is quickly quieting those who doubted that anyone other than Babe Ruth could thrive playing both ways. His next impact may be inspiring players with an interest in Major League Baseball to consider going at a younger age.\n\nBut the pipeline from Japan has noticeably slowed down. The streak of at least one new Japanese player debuting in North America\u2019s top league every year since Hideo Nomo with the Dodgers in 1995 ended last season at 22. A new one has already begun this year with the Padres\u2019 Kazuhisa Makita and the Diamondbacks\u2019 Yoshihisa Hirano joining Ohtani in M.L.B.\n\nBut pitching has long been Japan\u2019s forte. No position player from Japan has debuted in M.L.B. since 2013, far and away the longest drought since Ichiro Suzuki first played in Seattle in 2001.\n\nSetting aside Ohtani\u2019s two-way aspirations \u2014 he has been used as a designated hitter this season but not in the field \u2014 Suzuki, now 44 and back in Seattle, is the lone position player from Japan in the big leagues.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cKazuo Matsui was the best middle infielder of his time,\u201d said Aki Inose, a longtime baseball commentator in Japan. \u201cI think Japanese people were shocked when his game didn\u2019t translate, and that had a big impact on other position players\u2019 thoughts about trying to make the jump to America.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nMets fans remember Matsui all too well. Considered the answer at shortstop when he signed in 2004, the Mets shifted Jose Reyes to second base. Unable to fulfill his potential, Matsui was traded to the Colorado Rockies during his third season.\n\nHe performed his best after the trade, batting near .300 with an on-base percentage of .350 in 2007 and \u201908. Matsui played seven M.L.B. seasons, the fourth-longest stint for a Japanese position player behind Suzuki, Hideki Matsui and So Taguchi. Matsui returned to Japan in 2011 and at 42 is a player-coach for his original team, the Seibu Lions.\n\nM.L.B.\u2019s reliance on power, a longtime shortcoming in Japan, helps explain why more position players have not come, but Heid said Japanese infielders, in particular, were at a disadvantage.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cThey play on all-dirt infields,\u201d he said. \u201cFrom an early age and then growing up through high school, it\u2019s an all-dirt infield, so they never really practice with grass infields that are the norm in the U.S. Middle infielders in Japan don\u2019t have to have great range because the ball gets through the infield so quickly.\u201d\n\nThe journey of one of the few infielders to follow Matsui underscores that. Munenori Kawasaki signed with Seattle in 2012. At 5-foot-10 and 165 pounds, he had a typical Japanese physique, and he was popular for his determination and positive spirit. Despite just one career home run, he persevered, willing himself into lineups for five consecutive seasons, playing games for the Mariners, the Toronto Blue Jays and the Chicago Cubs.\n\nKawasaki had more at-bats in Class AAA than in the majors, but he was intent on staying in North America. He was doing this in his mid-30s as he was starting a family. Few players who have achieved stardom are willing to toil in the minors at that stage of their careers and lives.\n\n\u201cAs Japanese, we take pride in the strong fundamentals we are taught growing up,\u201d said Kawasaki, who returned to Japan\u2019s Fukuoka SoftBank Hawks last year and announced his retirement a few weeks ago. \u201cBut the flip side is we are not encouraged to make backhanded plays, jumping throws off balance, et cetera. In the minors I watched guys do it and practiced every day. When I finally made an out from shortstop on a running, backhanded stop where I twisted my body in midair and threw underhanded all the way to first, it was the happiest moment for me. Who cares if it was the minor leagues? As a professional baseball player, I made a big league play and became confident I could do it again.\u201d", "title": "Japanese Baseball Reloads After Shohei Ohtani. But Who Will Follow His Path?", "authors": ["Brad Lefton"]} {"date": "2018-04-01 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nJared William Wehrle and Lee Arwood Tracy II were married March 31 at a private residence owned by Miranda Brown in Galveston, Tex. Brian J.
