He graduated from Concordia University in Montreal and received a law degree from the University of Victoria in British Columbia, Canada.\n\nHe is a son of Christine J. Wehrle and Mark W. Wehrle of Winnipeg, Manitoba. His father retired as the president of Perimeter Aviation, a Canadian regional airline based in Winnipeg.\n\nMr. Tracy, 24, is a registered nurse in the neuro-oncology unit at Dell Seton Medical Center, a Trauma I level hospital in Austin, Tex. He has a bachelor of science degree from Sam Houston State University and a bachelor of nursing from the University of Texas.\n\nHe is the son of Laura Michelle Soto-Reyes of Houston and Mr. Tracy of Magnolia, Tex. His mother is the area director of sales for Hyatt Hotels Caribe in San Juan.\n\nThe couple met in March 2017 at a cafe in Galveston.", "title": "Jared Wehrle, Lee Tracy II", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-23 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cRearview Town,\u201d the new album by the country star Jason Aldean \u2014 his first since the Route 91 Harvest Festival in Las Vegas in October, when a gunman opened fire as Mr. Aldean was performing \u2014 opened at No. 1 on this week\u2019s Billboard album chart, making it the first country No. 1 of 2018.\n\n\u201cRearview Town,\u201d released by the Broken Bow label, a division of BMG, had the equivalent of 183,000 album sales in the United States last week, according to Nielsen. That total includes 162,000 copies sold of the full album, and about 20 million streams of its songs. The album is Mr. Aldean\u2019s fourth No. 1 in a row.\n\nLast week\u2019s No. 1, Cardi B\u2019s \u201cInvasion of Privacy,\u201d fell to No. 2 in its second week out. Also on this week\u2019s chart, the band Breaking Benjamin opens at No. 3 with \u201cEmber\u201d and the veteran singer-songwriter John Prine opened in fifth place \u2014 his highest chart position in a nearly five-decade career \u2014 with \u201cThe Tree of Forgiveness.\u201d\n\nThe soundtrack to \u201cThe Greatest Showman,\u201d which has been hovering near the top of the chart since January, is No. 4.", "title": "Jason Aldean Earns the First Country No. 1 of 2018", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-29 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nSAN DIEGO \u2014 Starter Jason Vargas had a rough debut with the Mets on Saturday, five weeks after breaking a bone in his glove hand in spring training. The left-hander allowed nine runs and nine hits, four for extra bases, in three and two-third innings as the Mets lost, 12-2, to the San Diego Padres.\n\nVargas, 35, tied for the major league lead with 18 wins last year with Kansas City. On Saturday, he gave up three walks in addition to the nine hits and he struck out five.\n\nThe Padres\u2019 Franchy Cordero hit a three-run homer estimated at 453 feet, Christian Villanueva had a two-run shot, and Austin Hedges drove in a career-high five runs.\n\nThe rookie lefthander Joey Lucchesi (3-1) limited the Mets to four hits in five and two-third innings while striking out six and walking two. He exited two batters after surrendering a two-run homer to Yoenis Cespedes that sailed into the Padres\u2019 bullpen beyond the fence in center field.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHedges, the light-hitting catcher, came up big with a two-run single in the third, a two-run double in the fourth and an R.B.I. single in the sixth. He raised his average from .143 to .176.\n\nVillanueva extended his hitting streak to 11 games hit a two-run homer to left-center with one out in the first, his eighth. He was robbed of another two-run shot when Juan Lagares made a nice leaping catch against the fence in left-center.", "title": "Jason Vargas Makes a Rough Debut as the Padres Crush the Mets", "authors": ["The Associated Press"]} {"date": "2018-04-12 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nI first read \u201cThe Great Gatsby\u201d as a teenager; I imagine this is when most Americans encounter F. Scott Fitzgerald\u2019s seminal work. Our teachers, rightly so, hail the novel as a masterpiece, so we read it under their influence, when we are young. We read it when we are bewildered and delighted at our changing bodies, flush with burgeoning sexuality, heady with the certainty of our ascendancy, the prospect of our future greatness shining off in the distance like a great green star.\n\nIt is easy for young people to see themselves in Gatsby. His earnestness is familiar. His ambition, twinned with desperation, resonates with any teenager who wants to journey off to college or move states away for work, in a bid to escape youthful boundaries. Poverty made Gatsby ravenously desperate for difference, for possibility. Some, perhaps from similar circumstances, will recognize that and see themselves. Others will empathize because they feel driven away by parents who don\u2019t understand them, by peers who underestimate or limit them, by the larger culture that ostracizes them for one reason or another. Their hearts will be, as Gatsby\u2019s was, \u201cin a constant, turbulent riot.\u201d The \u201cinstinct toward \u2026 future glory\u201d leads them out into the world. They burn to flee, to grow beyond their birth circumstances. In some ways, adolescence is one great flight.\n\nTeenage readers are especially understanding of Gatsby\u2019s fixation on recreating that moment when his life was most open to possibility, when he could become and do anything. When he believed that if he worked hard enough, he could remake himself. He could ascend to a different social class, a class where life seemed to be an enchanted necklace, each moment a pearl on an endless string. It seems to be a universal sentiment of youth: the belief that, given the luxury of time and focus, one can become anything. Young readers walk down tree-lined Louisville streets with Gatsby and Daisy as the leaves fall. They see a ladder \u201cmounted to a secret place above the trees. \u2026 Once there he could suck on the pap of life, gulp down the incomparable milk of wonder.\u201d The young know that golden moment when anything can happen, and they understand its allure because they are living it.\n\nBy the end of the book, the reader\u2019s empathy has burned to love. Young readers fall for Gatsby\u2019s passion, his insistence that life should be relished, should be executed well. They have fallen in love with the persistence of his devotion to Daisy. I imagine they like to think they are capable of such a great love, one that smolders, lasting from year to year. They adore him so much, they feel a quiet disdain for those who do not possess his virtues: perhaps most of all for Tom, who embodies the worst excesses of the moneyed elite, the misogynistic, the racist. They pity Nick, too, because they understand he has fallen in love with Gatsby; readers understand that Nick doesn\u2019t deserve Gatsby. Even though he insists he is not carelessly violent like Tom or Daisy, the young understand that Nick is as much a product of his social class as Tom, that its backwardness and insularity mark him as much as they do Tom and Daisy.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut the experience I had while reading \u201cThe Great Gatsby\u201d as an adult was very different. I would argue that this reading was deeper, more emphatically felt. While most young people admire Gatsby\u2019s youthful love for Daisy \u2014 for the possibility associated with her economic and social class, and for who he was with Daisy, too, in that shining moment in time \u2014 there is much subtext that becomes clearer with age, subtext Fitzgerald must have been acutely aware of when he wrote \u201cThe Great Gatsby.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nOne of the first great lessons of my adulthood was this: I change. As I grow, my dreams change, as do my ideas about who I can be and what I want during the short time I am alive. Gatsby has not learned this. It is a lesson he has closed himself to. From the moment he meets Daisy, his ideas about who he is and what he wants and what he can become are immutable. It\u2019s ironic that he is so in love with the moment of greatest possibility in his youth, the moment he kissed Daisy, but his love for that moment has rendered all other avenues of possibility impossible, has fossilized him, sealed him in amber, turned him to stone \u2014 made it possible for him to see only one version of himself. After years of underhanded dealing and shady business, he is wealthy, popular, feared, respected. On West Egg, he hosts glittering parties where old money and new money engage in raucous revelry together. He owns the newest, most exquisite cars and he has mannerisms and a wardrobe to match his new social station. When we meet Gatsby, he has worked furiously to make himself into the man who, on the surface, high society would have deemed a good match for Daisy. And in the end, this immutability, this blindness to change, the fact that Gatsby can picture himself as only one thing, limits him.", "title": "Jay Gatsby: A Dreamer Doomed to Be Excluded. The Novelist Jesmyn Ward Explains.", "authors": ["Jesmyn Ward"]} {"date": "2018-04-26 00:00:00", "text": "While Jean Dalton was growing up on the South Side of Chicago, her parents became so disgusted by Mayor Richard J. Daley\u2019s ethnocentric and monolithic Democratic machine that they not only enrolled as Republicans but also hid their Irish ancestry from their five children.\n\nAs an adult, Jean Gump, as she was known by then, and her husband, Joseph, even voted for Richard M. Nixon in the 1960 presidential election, rejecting John F. Kennedy and his Democratic Party despite the ethnic heritage and Roman Catholicism he shared with her.\n\nWithin just a few years, though, Ms. Gump had an epiphany.\n\nPerhaps it was inspired by the birth of her 12th and last child in 1964, after Kennedy\u2019s assassination, that nonplused her about what kind of world her children would inherit. Maybe it was the rumblings of social justice reverberating from the ecumenical Vatican II council in Rome.\n\nOr maybe it was the inconvenient question posed by her son Joseph one day in 1965, when he turned to her despairingly from the brutal television images of blacks being mistreated in the South and asked what she was going to do about it.", "title": "Jean Gump, Tireless Fighter for Social Justice, Dies at 90", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-13 00:00:00", "text": "Her signature, though, was the \u201cI Spy\u201d series, begun in 1992, in which Ms. Marzollo\u2019s rhyming text invited the reader to try to find various objects and shapes in elaborate scenes photographed by Walter Wick. Every page was a visual adventure, the images often staged like an artwork.\n\nOne page suggested backstage at a theater, with evocative masks and costumes. Another was an aerial view of a seaside town, complete with clam shack and lighthouse. And the \u201cI Spy\u201d tasks Ms. Marzollo gave youngsters were more than just a game.\n\n\u201cWhile kids perceive that they are simply hunting for objects in a picture,\u201d Jinny Gudmundsen, a columnist for Gannett Newspapers, wrote in 2006, describing a video-game version of the books, \u201cthis visual puzzle game actually teaches young children about visual discrimination, rhyming, vocabulary, word-object association and reading.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nJean Martin was born on June 24, 1942, in Manchester, Conn. Her father, Richard, was Manchester city manager and had also been a state water commissioner. Her mother, the former Ruth Palmer Smith, taught high school biology.\n\nJean received a bachelor\u2019s degree at the University of Connecticut in 1964 and a master\u2019s degree in teaching at the Harvard Graduate School of Education in 1965. After teaching high school in Arlington, Mass., and serving as assistant director of Harvard\u2019s Upward Bound program, she moved to New York City in 1967 to work on early childhood development projects for the General Learning Corporation. In New York she also met a sculptor, Claudio Marzollo; they married in 1969.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nShe and some friends formed a company to write educational material for and about children, including a parent/teacher guide to \u201cSesame Street,\u201d which had premiered on public television in 1969.\n\nThat led Ms. Marzollo into book writing, first for grown-ups. \u201cLearn Through Play\u201d was published in 1972, and she would write others for adults, like \u201cFathers & Babies\u201d (1993), a baby-care book for dads, and \u201cYour Maternity Leave\u201d (1989), which carried the forthright subtitle \u201cHow to Leave Work, Have a Baby, and Go Back to Work Without Getting Lost, Trapped or Sandbagged Along the Way.\u201d\n\nBut children\u2019s books were her main interest. In 1972 she became editor of \u201cLet\u2019s Find Out,\u201d a monthly magazine for kindergartners, and 1978 brought her first children\u2019s book, \u201cClose Your Eyes\u201d (illustrated by Susan Jeffers), about a boy having trouble falling asleep.\n\nOf the many that followed, one of her favorites was \u201cPierre the Penguin: A True Story\u201d (2010, illustrated by Laura Regan). It is about a penguin at a California zoo whose caretaker makes the animal a wet suit because it is missing feathers.\n\n\u201cUsing a cute (and catchy) rhyme, author Marzollo tells the true story of a bedraggled penguin and the human caretaker who hits upon the perfect solution to his problem,\u201d wrote Terri Schlichenmeyer, author of the Bookworm Sez syndicated review column. She added that children \u201cwho have a problem with teasing will be able to identify with Pierre.\u201d\n\nAnother that Ms. Marzollo was particularly pleased with, her family said, was \u201cHappy Birthday, Martin Luther King\u201d (1993, illustrated by J. Brian Pinkney). In it she recognized the sensitivity of writing for a young audience. When dealing with King\u2019s death, the text is sparse but straightforward.\n\n\u201cMartin Luther King Jr. was shot and killed in 1968,\u201d it says. However, in the book\u2019s foreword, she advises those reading it to preschoolers to use their judgment.\n\n\u201cIf you feel that the words \u2018shot and killed\u2019 on page 30 are inappropriate for the child or children you plan to read this book to, you may want to change the words and say simply that Martin Luther King \u2018died\u2019 in 1968,\u201d she wrote. \u201cIt isn\u2019t, after all, necessary for us to tell very young children the harsh details about Reverend King\u2019s death in order to convey to them the central message of his inspirational leadership.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nBut softening reality for young readers had its limits for her. In 1993, she and another children\u2019s author, Kate McMullan, were invited to speak at Sag Harbor Elementary School on Long Island for an \u201cauthor\u2019s day.\u201d But the ostensibly harmless event caused a local uproar when school officials objected to two small illustrations in Ms. McMullan\u2019s book \u201cThe Noisy Giants\u2019 Tea Party,\u201d one of a boy running away after breaking a window with a basketball, the other of three men staggering out of a tavern.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWhen a school official explained that the intent of the event (which was eventually canceled) was not to prompt a discussion of social issues and values, Ms. Marzollo took umbrage.\n\n\u201cAll literature is about values,\u201d she told The New York Times. \u201cI can\u2019t name a picture book that is not about values. That\u2019s why people read. Kindergarten teachers impose values on children all day long. They say, \u2018Let\u2019s clean up.\u2019 \u2018Let\u2019s not hit each other.\u2019 \u2018Let\u2019s not run in the hall.\u2019 If something in a book triggers a discussion, that\u2019s a teachable moment.\u201d\n\nThere was no controversy surrounding Ms. Marzollo\u2019s \u201cI Spy\u201d books, just a demand for more of them. The eight original \u201cI Spy\u201d books led to spinoffs like an \u201cI Spy Challenger\u201d series, with extra-hard puzzles. The concept was adapted for the digital age, first with a CD-ROM, then with video-game version for Nintendo, Leapster and other platforms. The original \u201cI Spy\u201d books have been translated into more than 20 languages.\n\nMs. Marzollo is survived by her husband; two sons, Dan and David; a brother, Allen Martin; a sister, Katherine Martin Widmer; and three grandchildren.\n\nLast year the Butterfield Memorial Library in Cold Spring, in Putnam County, where the Marzollos had lived for many years, announced that its newly renovated children\u2019s room would be named for Ms. Marzollo.\n\nShe had served for eight years on the Haldane School Board, which encompasses Cold Spring, including two as its president. Representative Sean Patrick Maloney, whose district includes Cold Spring, this week called Ms. Marzollo \u201ca passionate voice for education and a stalwart booster of the Haldane School District.\u201d\n\nAt the end of \u201cI\u2019m a Seed,\u201d the marigold explains to the pumpkin what is inside each of them.\n\n\u201cSeeds,\u201d the marigold says. \u201cWhen my seeds are planted, they will become new marigolds.\u201d\n\nTo which the pumpkin replies, \u201cWhen my seeds are planted, they will become new pumpkins. There should be a name for it.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSays the marigold: \u201cThere is. It\u2019s called life.\u201d", "title": "Jean Marzollo, 75, Dies; Her \u2018I Spy\u2019 Books Challenged Children", "authors": ["Neil Genzlinger"]} {"date": "2018-04-18 00:00:00", "text": "Macy\u2019s Thanksgiving Day Parade, which dates to 1924 and is often called \u201cthe longest-running show on Broadway,\u201d became a celebrated national event under Ms. McFaddin, telecast by NBC to 60 million viewers and attracting tourists from across the country and around the world.\n\nThe stars were a changing cast of helium-filled balloons that Ms. McFaddin developed with Manfred Bass, Macy\u2019s chief balloon and float designer. Over the years they included Kermit the Frog, Snoopy, Spider-Man, Betty Boop and later Cassie the Dragoness, Clifford the Big Red Dog, Tom Turkey and Blue, the star of Nickelodeon\u2019s \u201cBlue\u2019s Clues.\u201d\n\nThe biggest of the marvelous monsters were held down and guided by ropes and strong men trained in what Ms. McFaddin called \u201cballoonology.\u201d Still, many of the characters were obstreperous.\n\n\u201cWhen you\u2019re 60 feet tall and 30 feet wide, you go where you like, or try to, despite the 50 people hanging on to your 35 guidelines,\u201d The New York Times reported her saying in 1995.\n\nMs. McFaddin oversaw everything: financing, sponsors and broadcast rights; decisions on who, what and how many would join the parade (some years she auditioned 300 bands); construction of balloons and floats in a warehouse in Hoboken, N.J.; the transporting of everything before dawn into Manhattan; liaison with police, fire and safety units; promotion and publicity; and on and on. It took months.\n\n\u201cThe world was Jean\u2019s stage,\u201d said William Schermerhorn, Macy\u2019s creative director for special events, who worked with her for 17 years. \u201cComing from a background in street theater, she could transform a parking lot, a department-store marquee, a park lawn or 34th Street into a wondrous showcase. Above all, I remember the heart, joy and scale she brought to Macy\u2019s events. She shaped the events into what they are today.\u201d\n\nWith the wisdom of experience, she urged parents to dress children in layers of bright clothing and to pin name tags (with phone numbers) on them, just in case.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cBring garbage bags,\u201d she advised. \u201cThey\u2019re easy to carry. You can sit on them or use them as windbreakers and then use them to collect any trash you left on the street after the parade. They are the ultimate in Thanksgiving Day wear.\u201d\n\nBy 6 a.m. every Thanksgiving Day, the balloons were inflated, the floats were lined up and 3,000 volunteer cheerleaders were ready. At 9 a.m., Ms. McFaddin, usually dressed in Macy\u2019s colors \u2014 a red coat, black slacks and a black cowboy hat \u2014 made her way to 77th Street and Central Park West, cut a red ribbon and stepped off, leading the parade on its proud two-and-a-half-mile march to Herald Square.\n\nAl Roker, who covered the parade for NBC for years, recalled Ms. McFaddin as an outsize personality with a deep Texas drawl.\n\n\u201cAs marchers, balloon handlers, clowns and myriad parade workers got ready,\u201d Mr. Roker said in an email, \u201cshe would be weaving in and out among them with a look of pleasant professionalism, and then she\u2019d spot me, break out into a grin and greet me with, \u2018Al, darlin\u2019, we are gonna have us a beautiful parade!\u2019 \u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nMs. McFaddin and her entourage braved bitter cold, drenching rains and, once, a snowstorm that drove crowds away. Gusting winds often blew down balloons, sometimes injuring spectators. In 1997, the Cat in the Hat struck a lamppost, parts of which hit a woman, who suffered a serious head injury. After that, balloon sizes were limited and restrictions were imposed in high winds.\n\nThere were other mishaps. Ms. McFaddin once grabbed the trailing rope of a runaway balloon and was briefly carried aloft. Another year, as TV cameras caught the action for a national audience, a little girl trying to catch Santa accidentally pulled his pants down. (To everyone\u2019s relief, he wore jeans underneath.)\n\nBut the sun was bright and there were no calamities at Ms. McFaddin\u2019s last parade, in 2000. To celebrate her 24th anniversary as its organizer-director, the City of New York renamed Macy\u2019s corner, 34th Street and Broadway, \u201cJean McFaddin Way\u201d for a month.\n\nOn her watch, the parade had doubled in size to 8,000 marchers, balloons had jumped tenfold to 85 and spectators had swelled into the millions. Ms. McFaddin shared more than a dozen Emmy Awards with NBC for the parade telecasts, and in 1999 she was inducted into the International Festivals and Events Association Hall of Fame, the industry\u2019s most prestigious honor.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAfter a night\u2019s rest, she began her next project \u2014 Santaland. From the day after Thanksgiving until Christmas Eve, 300,000 children and parents visited Macy\u2019s eighth-floor setting for the rites of seeing Santa. They received tickets for the North Pole Express, saw an enchanted forest, chatted with elves who told stories of Santa\u2019s workshop, and finally met St. Nick.\n\n\u201cIt was about keeping the magic and miracle of Christmas alive for the thousands of children who came to believe that this was the true Santa,\u201d Mr. Krauss said.\n\nA few months later, Ms. McFaddin\u2019s indoor flower show at Macy\u2019s \u2014 filling the main floor with lilac bushes, azaleas, rhododendrons, tulips, amaryllis, primrose and begonias \u2014 unfolded in the first flush of spring. It was an enormous hit every year.\n\n\u201cMove over Central Park, the Macy\u2019s Flower Show is back in town,\u201d Herbert Muschamp wrote in a review for The Times in April 1996. \u201cFor two weeks each year, the world\u2019s biggest store is home to New York\u2019s most fantastic park: a colorful hybrid of commerce and nature in full and fragrant bloom. For those too old for Santa, the Flower Show is the true miracle on 34th Street.\u201d\n\nJean Eleanor McFaddin was born in Lufkin, Tex., on July 13, 1942, the second of three children of Ora Lance McFaddin, a real estate developer, and the former Eleanor Clark. Jean and her siblings, Janet and Lance, attended Lufkin High School, from which Jean graduated in 1960.\n\nIntending a career in theater, she received an associate arts degree at Stephens College in Columbia, Mo., in 1962 and, at the University of Texas at Austin, earned a bachelor of fine arts degree in 1964 and a master\u2019s in theater production in 1966.\n\nShe acted in companies in Oklahoma and California, and in Los Angeles directed the Liquid Theater, whose cast interacted with audiences in unplanned talking and touching. It ran in New York, London and Paris. \u201cIt embraced you,\u201d Ms. McFaddin recalled. \u201cIt asked strangers to be friends and to trust one another.\u201d\n\nShe produced \u201cCoucou Bazaar\u201d in New York with the French artist Jean Dubuffet. It caught audiences in psychedelic swirls of pictures flashing on walls and Kabuki-like dancers. She directed a 1975-76 Bicentennial program for the National Endowment for the Arts in Washington and oversaw New York City\u2019s Fourth of July Land Festival in 1977. That drew the attention of Macy\u2019s, a festival sponsor, and she was hired to revive the store\u2019s faded parade.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMs. McFaddin was soon inspiring all of Macy\u2019s holiday celebrations. She rose to senior vice president of public relations and events for Macy\u2019s East, comprising scores of stores. Events included \u201cTap-O-Mania,\u201d a summer gathering of thousands of tap dancers performing on 34th Street.\n\nHer Macy\u2019s fireworks display every Fourth of July dazzled millions. Launched from barges in the Hudson River or New York Harbor after dark, it was the city\u2019s biggest pyrotechnic display of the year \u2014 a booming, scintillating barrage of rockets and starbursts that bathed the awed crowds in eerie light and echoed off the facades of a city that lived on imagination.\n\nIn 2010, she and her companion of 37 years, Susan Falk, were married at their home in Ridgefield, Conn. Besides Ms. Falk, she is survived by her brother, Lance, four nieces and two nephews.\n\nVideo\n\nIn her later years, Ms. McFaddin continued to produce events for corporations, civic groups and charities like the Cystic Fibrosis Foundation.\n\nBut she had officially retired in April 2001, a few weeks after her last flower show. Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, at a City Hall news conference, proclaimed \u201cJean McFaddin Day in the City of New York.\u201d\n\nAnd she received a handwritten note from Maureen O\u2019Hara. \u201cYour wonderful contributions to Macy\u2019s, to New York City and to womanhood will never be forgotten,\u201d it said, and signed off, \u201cfrom one Parade Lady to another.\u201d", "title": "Jean McFaddin, Who Made the Macy\u2019s Parade What It Is, Dies at 75", "authors": ["Robert D. Mcfadden"]} {"date": "2018-04-25 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cRadio can be a real sewer pit, and there\u2019s a lot of back-stabbing and knife-throwing and all that other stuff that goes on,\u201d Mr. Esiason added. \u201cWe try to stay above all that stuff, but unfortunately you can\u2019t, and three people basically have gotten screwed.\u201d\n\nThe decision to bring back Mr. Francesa, known for his ability to fill five hours of airtime with endless sports rants, about everything from horse racing to free throws, and his sometimes caustic exchanges with scores of daily callers, comes after slumping listener numbers from his replacements.\n\nThe station had high hopes for the Afternoon Drive crew, a younger trio with racial and gender diversity, which executives had hoped would attract younger fans, and more of them. But the group has received mixed reviews as listener numbers have plummeted \u2014 to the point that the closest competitor, ESPN radio\u2019s \u201cMichael Kay Show,\u201d which had routinely finished behind Mr. Francesa\u2019s show in the Nielsen rankings, had in recent months routinely eclipsed the show that replaced it.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nNews of Mr. Francesa\u2019s return induced a schism at the station, with those in the new hosts\u2019 corner, like Esiason and Mr. Giannotti, complaining that the new hires would be marginalized, and their show given short shrift and a smaller time slot with Mr. Francesa added back to the lineup. In a statement, WFAN said that no decisions have been made regarding time slots or programming, and that negotiations with Mr. Francesa are still in process.\n\n\u201cEvery day they walk in here they\u2019re going to feel like, \u2018Wow, everybody looks at us like a failure,\u2019 and that\u2019s just the perception of what it\u2019s going to be, and that\u2019s not fair,\u201d Mr. Giannotti said during Wednesday\u2019s broadcast. And at one point in the show, he fretted for his own future. \u201cNext thing you know I\u2019ll be doing 4 a.m. to 6 a.m.,\u201d he said.\n\nIn its statement, the station acknowledged that it was in discussions with Mr. Francesa about his return, adding, \u201cWe also confirm that we are very proud of our current lineup at WFAN and that any potential future engagement with Mike will not result in any talent departures.\u201d\n\nDrama and vituperation seem as much a part of sports radio as peanuts and crackerjacks are to baseball. In 2008, Mr. Francesa split from his longtime co-host Chris Russo, known as Mad Dog, breaking up a 19-year partnership over contract issues and interpersonal strife that played out over the airwaves. A representative for Mr. Russo, who now hosts Mad Dog Sports Radio on Sirius XM, said he was unavailable to respond because he was on the air.\n\nMr. Francesa did not respond to messages left at his home phone requesting comment. Mike Levine, an agent with Creative Artists Agency, which is representing Mr. Francesa, declined to comment.\n\nIn an interview with Newsday on April 24, Mr. Francesa seemed to suggest that the resistance to his return to the air is what spurred him to come back. \u201cThis is for those who started this campaign in recent days,\u201d Mr. Francesa told Newsday. \u201cI didn\u2019t decide to go back to WFAN until I was told I better not go back.\u201d", "title": "Jeering, at Least From the Press Box, as Mike Francesa Returns", "authors": ["Sarah Maslin Nir"]} {"date": "2018-04-24 00:00:00", "text": "And unlike several other members of the Trump cabinet, Mr. Sessions has not sullied the administration with headlines over first-class jet travel, exorbitant office furnishings, lobbyist-furnished housing \u2014 or all of the above. When he is in Washington, Mr. Sessions has a turkey sandwich from the Justice Department cafeteria (base price: $5.29) for lunch, which he eats at his desk. When his team works late, he hands out granola bars, which his wife buys in bulk at Costco.\n\nWhen meeting with the police, border patrol officers and the victims of crime, Mr. Sessions gives Mr. Trump all of the credit for a law-and-order crackdown he has put into effect with a speed that thrills supporters and appalls critics. With Mr. Trump, he has said, Americans are getting \u201csupport for law enforcement like we haven\u2019t seen in many years.\u201d He leaves out the fact that Mr. Trump\u2019s support does not extend to him.\n\nA Republican former senator from Alabama, Mr. Sessions was an early, fervent backer of Mr. Trump. But as attorney general, Mr. Sessions said it was his legal duty to protect the Russia investigation, even if his boss would prefer that Mr. Sessions protect him. The president\u2019s firing of James B. Comey, the F.B.I. director who was in charge of the Russia investigation, led to Robert S. Mueller III\u2019s appointment as special counsel. But Mr. Trump blames Mr. Sessions.\n\nMr. Sessions\u2019s staff declined to make him available for an interview for this article.\n\nMr. Sessions laid out his philosophy for the sheriffs: \u201cThe United States of America is not an idea \u2014 it\u2019s a nation-state. We have a Constitution, we have laws, we have borders,\u201d and it is his job to help protect them.\n\nMr. Sessions has lost no time. As the opioid crisis continues to spread, he has reversed the Obama Justice Department\u2019s \u201csmart on crime\u201d initiative that encouraged prosecutors to seek lighter penalties for nonviolent drug offenders. Instead, Mr. Sessions has instructed prosecutors to seek the harshest possible sentences. He opposes criminal justice overhaul efforts championed by Jared Kushner, the Koch brothers and Republican former colleagues, including Senator Charles E. Grassley, Republican of Iowa, who has defended Mr. Sessions against Mr. Trump\u2019s attacks. Like Mr. Trump, Mr. Sessions favors the death penalty for certain drug kingpins.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMr. Sessions has withdrawn Obama administration guidance, known as the Cole memo, discouraging prosecutors from enforcing federal marijuana laws in states that have legalized it. That drew him into conflict with Senator Cory Gardner, Republican of Colorado, which legalized recreational marijuana in 2014. Mr. Gardner blocked confirmation votes for some 20 Justice Department appointees for months, backing down only after a phone call from Mr. Trump this month, assuring him that Colorado\u2019s marijuana industry would not be targeted.\n\nIt was Mr. Sessions who announced Mr. Trump\u2019s decision to end the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals program, an Obama executive order shielding from deportation immigrants brought to the United States illegally as children. He is suing the state of California over its sanctuary laws: \u201cIt cannot be, as it seems to be today, that someone who illegally crosses the border here on a Monday and ends up in San Francisco on Wednesday can never be deported,\u201d Mr. Sessions said in Las Cruces. \u201cEven if they were hauling dope to San Francisco and they got arrested, they can\u2019t be deported. Now, how illogical and insane, really, is that?\u201d\n\nUnaccompanied children from Central America are flooding across the border, he warned, exploiting loopholes in the law so that they \u201care not able to be returned quickly,\u201d Mr. Sessions said, citing arrests of juveniles accused of smuggling drugs. \u201cI have ordered each United States attorney\u2019s office along the southwest border to have a zero-tolerance policy toward illegal entry. Our goal is to prosecute every case that is brought to us. There must be consequences for illegal actions.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nTodd A. Cox, director of policy at the NAACP Legal Defense and Educational Fund Inc., said Mr. Sessions was ably carrying out Mr. Trump\u2019s plans. \u201cHe\u2019s put in place policies that will return us to the discredited war on drugs, which had catastrophic impacts on communities of color,\u201d Mr. Cox said in an interview. \u201cHe is doing precisely what this administration has pledged to do.\u201d\n\nSome Justice employees, however, see Mr. Sessions\u2019s stoicism as capitulation. In a survey last year of employee morale conducted by the United States Office of Personnel Management and compiled by the Partnership for Public Service, the Justice Department was ranked 11th among 18 large agencies, down from sixth in 2016. Rod J. Rosenstein, the deputy attorney general, who supervises Mr. Mueller, is also fighting for his job, pressed by Mr. Trump\u2019s congressional allies to produce hundreds of thousands of documents related to politically delicate F.B.I. investigations.\n\nIn Las Cruces, Mr. Sessions ended his speech to the sheriffs with a favored line: \u201cWe have your back. You have our thanks.\u201d\n\nThere is no such comfort for Mr. Sessions. Congress cannot stop Mr. Trump from firing him, though Republican leaders have warned that Mr. Trump would pay a heavy political price if he does. Potential replacements for Mr. Sessions are, in the meantime, circling, including Rudolph W. Giuliani, who joined Mr. Trump\u2019s legal team last week.\n\nMr. Sessions\u2019s allies say he is not distracted. Though Mr. Trump now regrets it, he gave Mr. Sessions the law enforcement job of a lifetime, and Mr. Sessions remains focused on serving \u2014 and ignoring \u2014 the president for as long as he can.", "title": "Jeff Sessions Is Serving, and Doing His Best to Ignore, Trump", "authors": ["Elizabeth Williamson"]} {"date": "2018-04-15 00:00:00", "text": "Jennifer Anne Crutchfield and Brian Duncan Worth were married April 14 at First Presbyterian Church in San Antonio. She graduated from the University of Virginia, from which she also received an M.B.A. She also received a master\u2019s degree in economic development from Boston University.\n\nShe is the daughter of Jana Heischman Crutchfield and William G. Crutchfield Jr., both of Charlottesville, Va.\n\nMr. Worth, 37, was until April 6 a developer of computer software at the Mountain View, Calif., office of Addepar, a financial technology firm. He graduated from Stanford.", "title": "Jennifer Crutchfield, Brian Worth", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-15 00:00:00", "text": "Jennifer Young Zeckendorf and Michael Benjamin Tannenbaum were married April 14 at the Union Club of the City of New York, a private club. Rabbi Dr. Ronald Sobel officiated.\n\nMs. Zeckendorf, 29, is a junior architecture professional in the San Francisco office of the architecture firm Skidmore Owings & Merrill, where she primarily works on residential buildings. She graduated from Yale and received a master\u2019s degree in architecture from Columbia.\n\nThe bride is the daughter of Constance H. Zeckendorf of East Hampton, N.Y., and Arthur W. Zeckendorf of New York. The bride\u2019s father is a co-chairman of Zeckendorf Development, a real estate developer there, and Terra Holdings, a company that owns and operates Brown Harris Stevens and Halstead Property, two New York residential brokerage companies. Her mother retired as a real estate agent in New York.\n\nMr. Tannenbaum, 30, is the chief financial officer of Brex, a financial technology and credit card company in San Francisco. He graduated summa cum laude from Columbia.", "title": "Jennifer Zeckendorf, Michael Tannenbaum", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-03 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cHe appears to be someone who is unwilling to do the most modest things to shut down the story and who, in fact, does the opposite,\u201d said Steven Fielding, a professor of political history at Nottingham University in England.\n\nMr. Corbyn, he added, \u201cis either incredibly obtuse or he just doesn\u2019t care,\u201d and he has created a crisis he could have averted simply by \u201ctaking the advice of people he doesn\u2019t like.\u201d\n\nIn an appearance on Tuesday in Swindon, in southern England, Mr. Corbyn defended his decision to attend the Seder. \u201cIt was very interesting talking to a lot of young people about their experiences of modern Britain, and I learned a lot,\u201d he said. \u201cIsn\u2019t that a good thing?\u201d\n\nIn a statement via Facebook, Jewdas described Mr. Corbyn as \u201ca 10/10 guest,\u201d who had provided \u201cdelicious maror\u201d \u2014 bitter herb for the Seder.\n\n\u201cWe are unhappy with the pervasive anti-Semitism that still remains on the left but continue to remain very much involved because we are committed to a better world and a better left,\u201d the statement said.\n\nSince his election as Labour leader, Mr. Corbyn has been at war with a sizable section of his party, some of whom say he lacks credibility as a potential prime minister. However, he has brought thousands of new supporters to the party, confounded critics by running a much more successful election campaign last year than expected and has since tightened his control of the Labour apparatus.\n\nYet, even if Mr. Corbyn is in a position of internal strength, the anti-Semitism dispute, along with his reluctance to blame Russia for the poisoning of a former spy in Salisbury, England, has rekindled debate about his leadership.", "title": "Jeremy Corbyn, Labour Leader, Defends Sharing Seder With Jewdas", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-27 00:00:00", "text": "The Russian-born Balanchine, heterosexual and subtly aristocratic, embodied \u2014 and extended \u2014 the classical orthodoxy of ballet. He effortlessly created stage hierarchies; specialized in effects of grandeur, scale and formality; and glorified women. Robbins, born in New York in a Jewish immigrant family and raised in New Jersey, embodied many aspects of the traditional American story: He discovered high culture through education and never lost his connection with ornery behavior after he became famous. (One source of torment had been the trauma of acknowledging his homosexuality.)\n\nRobbins had begun as a brilliant outsider, often with a superlative flair for caricaturing character and situation. \u201cFancy Free\u201d (1944) and \u201cThe Concert\u201d (1956) are masterpieces of this Robbins style. (A YouTube clip of the \u201cMistake Waltz\u201d sometimes makes the rounds without labeling to explain that it comes from \u201cThe Concert.\u201d Non-dance people, finding it hilarious and assuming it\u2019s a TV comedy sketch, are often amazed to find it was formally choreographed for the stage.)\n\nRobbins matured. Yet he had already made a breakthrough with his \u201cAfternoon of a Faun.\u201d This classic pas de deux isn\u2019t about a mythological faun\u2019s pursuit of nymphs, as Nijinsky\u2019s 1912 \u201cL\u2019Apr\u00e8s-Midi d\u2019un Faune\u201d had been \u2014 and yet Robbins is recreating aspects of that ballet\u2019s story, sometimes to the same moments in Debussy\u2019s music. The difference is that Robbins sets it in a ballet studio. A male dancer, after stretching on the studio floor, goes to sleep. A woman enters, dances with him, feels his sexual attraction to her and withdraws. Remembering the kiss he planted on her cheek, he returns to sleep. The whole thing might well be the man\u2019s dream.\n\nI especially love the way one phrase develops in \u201cFaun.\u201d The man places his arms and hands around the woman\u2019s face like a frame \u2014 but she then stretches through that frame into the air beyond. Following her thought, he lifts her, horizontally before his chest, and carries her across the stage while she continues to reach ahead. Suddenly, on a quiet \u201cping\u201d in the Debussy music, she does a subtle contraction in the air: She breaks the line of her arms and one knee (bending them) and turns her gaze down.\n\nPhoto\n\nThis has often seemed to me quintessentially Robbins. Like some of his wonderful images of involuntary jazz-style impulsiveness in \u201cWest Side Story,\u201d it occurs like a spasm and, in its break from formality, shows his sympathy for the young.\n\nGuess what? Last year, I found that this moment was actually choreographed by Balanchine. And Robbins, even 30 years later, loved to tell his dancers that this moment came from Balanchine.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMany dancers have recalled how Robbins, in \u201cFaun\u201d and other ballets, was a coach of genius, awakening their imagination and sense of motivation; he would spend days guiding a dancer through his or her own conception of a role. More than most choreographers, he was prepared to change or omit certain choreographed details \u2014 if they seemed not to suit the vision of the dancer in question.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nRobbins finally withdrew from much Broadway activity in the late 1960s. \u201cDances at a Gathering,\u201d made for City Ballet to an hourlong selection of Chopin music, was a departure for him \u2014 and for ballet. \u201cDances\u201d was a new kind of dance theater: Though by no means the first plotless ballet to suggest multiple plots, its sustained naturalness gave it a miraculous spontaneity. A loosely structured ensemble, full of human intimacy, it\u2019s framed by two \u201cmemory\u201d solos (one at the start, for a man, and another halfway through, for a woman). Robbins, as with \u201cFiddler on the Roof,\u201d was revisiting in art an Eastern European society he had seen as a child on a visit to family there. Decades later, when touring Europe, he went to revisit the Jewish village he had known, only to find it had been wiped out.\n\nRobbins, often inspired by Balanchine, sometimes remarked that he felt like a beginner beside Balanchine\u2019s prodigious example. Yet influence went two ways: You can see traces of \u201cDances at a Gathering\u201d in Balanchine choreography. In both \u201cDuo Concertant\u201d (1972) and \u201cSonatine\u201d (1975), a Balanchine male-female couple moves with the pronounced informality and spontaneity of Robbins dancers; and in one of Balanchine\u2019s last ballets, \u201cRobert Schumann\u2019s \u2018Davidsb\u00fcndlert\u00e4nze,\u2019 \u201d the eight dancers \u2014 almost never focused out front (as Balanchine dancers usually are) \u2014 make a community that is more Robbins than Balanchine.\n\nSoon after Balanchine\u2019s death, Robbins made \u201cGlass Pieces.\u201d City Ballet\u2019s first work to Minimalist music (Philip Glass), it has stood the test of time: Robbins leads his audience into the layerings and structures of three of the composer\u2019s works, with some of his most haunting theatrical imagery. The second movement is dazzling in the tiny steps and patterns given to a corps de ballet who closely cross the back of the stage. You could spend hours analyzing what\u2019s going on here. It\u2019s easy to take your eyes off the lead couple in the foreground, b ut do watch them: For in the way the man bears the ballerina across the stage, at chest-height, Robbins is referring to the second movement of Balanchine\u2019s \u201cSymphony in C.\u201d It\u2019s his homage to the classic that changed his career 35 years before.", "title": "Jerome Robbins, Ballet\u2019s Mr. \u2018Take It Easy, Baby,\u2019 at 100", "authors": ["Alastair Macaulay"]} {"date": "2018-04-07 00:00:00", "text": "In an Op-Ed article this week, the Rev. Jesse Jackson wrote about the need to remember the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. as a radical, ecumenical, antiwar, pro-immigrant and scholarly champion of the poor. Readers shared their own reminiscences about Dr. King and their thoughts on the changes in the country since his assassination 50 years ago. Here are some of their comments and Mr. Jackson\u2019s responses. \u2014 The Editors\n\nThank you for sharing your witness to these powerful events. Before the recent Alabama election, the secretary of state attempted to move tens of thousands of voters onto inactive rolls. Fortunately, lawsuits brought by the N.A.A.C.P. and tireless efforts of black women to get out the vote denied the state\u2019s Republicans another stolen election. In the 21st century, the need for vigilance is as keen as ever and there is still much work to do. \u2014 Ann, California\n\nJesse Jackson: With the changing demographics in the country there is a concerted effort by Republicans to make it harder for people of color, women, workers, students, young people, seniors and the disabled to vote. This is mostly a result of our states-rights and local-control voting systems. It will probably surprise you, but the explicit individual right to vote is not in the U.S. Constitution. The Supreme Court\u2019s Heller ruling in 2008 gave individuals the right to own a gun, but we still don\u2019t have a right to vote. That\u2019s why I\u2019m fighting to add a right-to-vote amendment to the Constitution. Congress would then be obligated to pass voting laws with minimum common-sense national standards.\n\nKing was not a statue. He was a man of flesh and blood. A man who had fears and hopes. A man who had failures and successes. A man whose wife and kids sacrificed their family time for his struggle for racial justice. To make more of him is to diminish his achievement and give us an excuse for not doing a thing because we have no leader of his stature.", "title": "Opinion | Jesse Jackson on Race Relations, Trump and the Right to Vote", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-03 00:00:00", "text": "As the nation prepares to commemorate the 50th anniversary of the assassination of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., we should dwell not merely on how Dr. King died but also on how he lived.\n\nHe mobilized mass action to win a public accommodations bill and the right to vote. He led the Montgomery bus boycott and navigated police terror in Birmingham. He got us over the bloodstained bridge in Selma and survived the rocks and bottles and hatred in Chicago. He globalized our struggle to end the war in Vietnam.\n\nHow he lived is why he died.\n\nAs he sought to move beyond desegregation and the right to vote, to focus his work on economic justice, antimilitarism and human rights, the system pushed back hard. In the last months of his life, he was attacked by the government, the press, former allies and the military industrial complex. Even black Democrats turned their backs on him when he challenged the party\u2019s support for the war in Vietnam.\n\nA growing number of Americans had a negative view of Dr. King in the final years of his life, according to public opinion polls. A man of peace, he died violently. A man of love, he died hated by many.", "title": "Opinion | Jesse Jackson: How Dr. King Lived Is Why He Died", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-29 00:00:00", "text": "Jessica Willow Killin and Rajeev Date were married April 28 in the Riviera Maya of Mexico. She was until last year the lead Democratic lobbyist for USAA, a financial services group of companies based in San Antonio that provide military members and their families with insurance, banking and investment services. She also served in the Army, completing five years of active duty in Mannheim, Germany, with the rank of captain. She graduated from the University of Tampa and received a law degree from Georgetown.\n\nThe bride is a daughter of Terry E. Killin of Castle Rock, Colo., and a stepdaughter of Elizabeth A. Barnes. He also received an M.B.A. from the University of Maryland.", "title": "Jessica Morris, Graham Garlinghouse", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-24 00:00:00", "text": "In every draft since, with the exception of 2012, at least one quarterback has gone in the top three. And of those eight quarterbacks, only Jameis Winston of Tampa Bay (2015) and Mitch Trubisky, who as a rookie started Chicago\u2019s final 12 games last season, have failed to guide the team that drafted them to the playoffs.\n\nThe clearest path to perennial contending doubles as the best value in the league: a great quarterback on a rookie contract, with its slotted salary and modest cap charge. The financial flexibility allows teams to allocate the saved money toward fortifying their rosters. It\u2019s how the Philadelphia Eagles, with Carson Wentz, the No. 2 pick in 2016, assembled a Super Bowl champion roster, and how the Los Angeles Rams, with Jared Goff, the No. 1 pick in 2016, are trying to overtake them.\n\nIt\u2019s also how the Jets intend to return to prominence. Even after this off-season\u2019s free-agent splurge, which included cornerback Trumaine Johnson and quarterback Teddy Bridgewater, the Jets could have more than $100 million in cap space for 2019, according to overthecap.com, that they can spend to aid their new quarterback.\n\nThe potential pitfall, for Maccagnan and Gettleman, is that while this year\u2019s quarterback class is loaded with potential, there is no consensus favorite, no certain future star \u2014 no one quite like Wentz or Andrew Luck, whom the NFL Network draft guru Mike Mayock in a recent conference call called his two easiest quarterback evaluations over the last decade. It\u2019s conceivable that the first quarterback chosen will be the top quarterback on his team\u2019s board and fourth \u2014 or lower \u2014 on others\u2019.\n\nGettleman called the notion of feeling obligated to take a quarterback \u201chogwash,\u201d and yet he may not get a better chance to draft Manning\u2019s eventual replacement. He must evaluate how close the Giants are to contending this season, whether the team is talented enough to help a player like Barkley emulate Ezekiel Elliott of Dallas and Leonard Fournette of Jacksonville, two running backs who went fourth and thrived as rookies.\n\nThe mystery will end Thursday night, when the Giants and the Jets choose players, most likely one right after the other, who will share a media market, a stadium and, perhaps, a position. And if the Giants do not take a quarterback before the Jets do, the longtime personnel executive Phil Savage said, they must be convinced that their choice will be an exceptional player.\n\n\u201cBecause,\u201d said Savage, now the executive director of the Senior Bowl and a SiriusXM analyst, in a telephone interview, \u201cthat\u2019s going to be the comparison for at least a decade.\u201d", "title": "Jets and Giants Share Something Else: High Stakes at the Draft", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-03 00:00:00", "text": "NEW DELHI \u2014 Nirav Modi brightened Kate Winslet\u2019s earlobes and made Taraji P. Henson\u2019s collarbone glitter.\n\nA jeweler to the stars, Mr. Modi attained wealth and fame at home in India in a few short years. He socialized with British royalty and rubbed elbows with Donald Trump Jr. He opened an opulent outlet on Madison Avenue in New York. In January, he met with Narendra Modi, India\u2019s prime minister and no relation, at the annual gathering of the world\u2019s elite in Davos, Switzerland.\n\nPhoto\n\nToday, he is on the run.\n\nAbout a week after Mr. Modi grinned for the cameras with the prime minister, a state-run Indian bank told regulators that it had found nearly $1.8 billion in fraudulent transactions linked to the jeweler\u2019s account. Indian officials now accuse Mr. Modi, his family and business associates of assembling a global empire with nearly $3 billion in money obtained illegally, mostly from government-run banks. He denies wrongdoing.\n\nThe chase has enraged and captivated India at a time when the public increasingly believes the country\u2019s debt-laden government banks are enriching its flashiest, most corrupt business tycoons. Parliament sessions have deteriorated into screaming matches, with political opponents exchanging accusations of collusion with the jeweler.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nFinding Mr. Modi has become something of a national pastime. Reporters in New York camped outside a luxury hotel, the JW Marriott Essex House, where they believed Mr. Modi was staying. One who rang the bell outside what they believed to be his room found only a servant and a fluffy white dog.\n\nFor many Indians, the allegations against Mr. Modi further cement the notion that taxpayer-owned banks are footing the bill for the lavish lifestyles of a rising elite. That idea has particular resonance in a country where stark poverty \u2014 India is home to a third of the world\u2019s poorest people \u2014 remains dire.", "title": "Jeweler to the Stars Flees as India Seethes Over Bank Fraud", "authors": ["Maria Abi-Habib"]} {"date": "2018-04-20 00:00:00", "text": "There\u2019s a limit to how many armed guards can be deployed indefinitely to protect synagogues or stop Holocaust memorials from being vandalized. There\u2019s a limit, also, to trying to cure bigotry with earnest appeals to tolerance. The German government is mulling a proposal to require recent arrivals in the country to tour Nazi concentration camps as a way of engendering a feeling of empathy for Jews. It doesn\u2019t seem to occur to anyone that, to the virulent anti-Semite, Buchenwald is a source of inspiration, not shame.\n\nAll this comes to mind as Israel this week marks (in the Hebrew calendar) the 70th anniversary of its independence. There are many reasons to celebrate the date, many of them lofty: a renaissance for Jewish civilization; the creation of a feisty liberal democracy in a despotic neighborhood; the ecological rescue of a once-barren land; the end of 1,878 years of exile.\n\nBut there\u2019s a more basic reason. Jews cannot rely for their safety on the kindness of strangers, least of all French or German politicians. Theodor Herzl saw this with the Dreyfus Affair and founded modern Zionism. Post-Hitler Europe still has far to fall when it comes to its attitudes toward Jews, but the trend is clear. The question is the pace.\n\nHence Israel: its army, bomb, and robust willingness to use force to defend itself. Israel did not come into existence to serve as another showcase of the victimization of Jews. It exists to end the victimization of Jews.\n\nThat\u2019s a point that Israel\u2019s restless critics could stand to learn. On Friday, Palestinians in Gaza returned for the fourth time to the border fence with Israel, in protests promoted by Hamas. The explicit purpose of Hamas leaders is to breach the fence and march on Jerusalem. Israel cannot possibly allow this \u2014 doing so would create a precedent that would encourage similar protests, and more death, along all of Israel\u2019s borders \u2014 and has repeatedly used deadly force to counter it.", "title": "Opinion | Jewish Power at 70 Years", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-04 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nSince the beginning of the 20th century, New York has had the largest Jewish urban community in world history. Three new books explore the influence of the Jews and other immigrants on the city, from Jewish refugees first arriving here in the 17th century, to the 20th-century arrival of the Puerto Ricans and Dominicans, which substantially changed the demographics of the city going into the new millennium.\n\nIn \u201cJewish New York: The Remarkable Story of a City and a People\u201d (New York University Press), Deborah Dash Moore, Jeffrey S. Gurock, Annie Polland, Howard B. Rock and Daniel Soyer start with the arrival of 23 Jewish refugees from Recife, Brazil, in 1654, and then chronicle the growth of Jewish influence on the city through the 21st century, citing the success of several prominent New Yorkers, including two former Brooklynites, Ruth Bader Ginsburg and Bernie Sanders.\n\nThe authors acknowledge that much of this history has been well-trodden, which is why this synthesis of the three-volume \u201cCity of Promises\u201d (by the same authors) intentionally focuses on the periods before and after the great waves of immigration from the 1840s through the 1920s, which created what the essayist Milton Klonsky called the \u201cGhetto of Eden.\u201d\n\nThe mid-20th-century Jewish experience is also explored by Stephen B. Shepard, the founding dean of the City University of New York\u2019s Graduate School of Journalism, in \u201cA Literary Journey to Jewish Identity: Re-Reading Bellow, Roth, Malamud, Ozick and Other Great Jewish Writers\u201d (Bayberry Books). Inviting readers along on his personal intellectual odyssey, Mr. Shepard reappraises what he read growing up in the Bronx and at City College and how it shaped who he is. He quotes Samuel Norich, president of The Forward: \u201cLiterature is our liturgy. It\u2019s the way we identify.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cJewish New York\u201d concludes that the state\u2019s 1777 wartime constitution made it \u201cthe first state in the western world to confer total citizenship upon the Jews.\u201d The book acknowledges the role of Jews as slave owners and their complicity with the owners of Southern cotton plantations.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Race/Related Newsletter Join a deep and provocative exploration of race with a diverse group of New York Times journalists. Marcus, whose Bank of the United States failed in 1931, arguably worsening the Depression.", "title": "Jews, Latinos and the Making of Modern New York", "authors": ["Sam Roberts"]} {"date": "2018-04-29 00:00:00", "text": "Jillian Jihan Bell and Stephen Andrew Wood were married April 28 in an outdoor ceremony at Red Mountain Park in Birmingham, Ala. William Anthony Bell Jr., the brother of the bride and a district judge with the 10th Judicial Circuit in Jefferson County, Ala., officiated, with Kathryn Allison Wood, the sister of the groom, taking part in the ceremony.\n\nMs. Bell, who is 36 and works in Greenwich, Conn., is the Schoolyard Habitat Program coordinator with the National Audubon Society, which is based in New York. She graduated from the University of Alabama and received a master\u2019s degree in environmental education from Antioch University in Keene, N.H.\n\nShe is the daughter of Sharon Carson Bell and William A. Bell of Birmingham. The bride\u2019s father served as the mayor of Birmingham from 2010 to 2017. Her mother, who is retired, was the director of student support services for Birmingham City Schools.\n\nDr. Wood, 33, is a scientist for both the Nature Conservancy and the Yale School of Forestry and Environmental Studies in New Haven. From 2007-9 he worked as a sustainable agriculture volunteer for the Peace Corps in Senegal.", "title": "Jillian Bell, Stephen Wood", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-07 00:00:00", "text": "Why was it important to you to be involved in this race?\n\nI think anything we can do to make it known that St. Barts is on the way back is good, and as my friend said, \u201cI guess your house will be ready just in time for the next storm.\u201d\n\nAnd I was going, \u201cPlease God, don\u2019t let it be a big one.\u201d\n\nI think there\u2019s a little bit of that apprehension in everybody there who went through Irma but you\u2019ve got to keep moving on forward, breathe in and breathe out and move on. That\u2019s kind of the way I think about it.\n\nPhoto\n\nIf you\u2019ve been exposed to hurricanes the way people down there have and the way I have all my life, that\u2019s what we choose to do.\n\nIt is hard to imagine anything resisting winds of 200 miles an hour.\n\nI\u2019ve never seen any storm like that, and I\u2019ve been in storms as a kid and down on the Gulf Coast with 100- and 125-mile-an-hour winds, and they did enough damage of their own.\n\nBut I wish everybody well all over the region. I\u2019m actually going to do some shows in Puerto Rico in January. Lin-Manuel Miranda is doing \u201cHamilton\u201d down there to refinance the arts in Puerto Rico, so when Hamilton is in town, on their dark nights I will take my band over so we will be the entertainment when they are not up.\n\nThere are still so many blue tarps in place of roofs in Puerto Rico. St. Barts is obviously a much smaller place, a place of greater means, but when you see how far they\u2019ve come in seven months, how do you feel about what\u2019s happened in Puerto Rico?\n\nIt is a disgrace is what it is, the reaction to it. I don\u2019t think there is enough attention being paid to the problem, but this administration in Washington, it\u2019s pretty obvious to me that they don\u2019t give a damn. I believe it will come back to bite them.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nWhat goes around comes around, but they are great folks down there in Puerto Rico, and I\u2019m going to do as much as I can. I spent time in all those islands: Puerto Rico, the Virgin Islands, St. Barts, St. Martin. It\u2019s a great part of my life, and I\u2019m going to do what I can to help them get back.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWhen did you first come to St. Barts?\n\nIt was 1978. I had a boat, a Cheoy Lee Clipper 48, and we had sailed from Bermuda down to St. Martin and I remember in those days there was very little technology other than charts and books. I was reading this book that had a short but very interesting little paragraph describing St. Barts. And I said, \u201cWell, let\u2019s check it out.\u201d\n\nI remember sailing in, and where Maya\u2019s restaurant is now, there was a cemetery, and I remember saying that\u2019s where I want to get buried when I die because it\u2019s the prettiest place I\u2019ve ever seen.\n\nPhoto\n\nA couple of kids came out from a boat and they brought me croissants and coffee and said welcome to the island and there were parents living on board and home schooling their kids and so it just had a magic to it that I loved.\n\nWe sailed on, and my whole idea was to go to Martinique. I was infatuated with Martinique because I\u2019ve got some French Creole on one side of my family. We sailed down there and almost to Trinidad, and we just looked at each other and said, \u201cWell, the coolest place we\u2019ve seen is St. Barts.\u201d So we turned around and went back. I stayed a long time.\n\nI know \u201cAutour du Rocher\u201d is about a club on St. Barts. How much of your work has been about the island over the years?\n\nIt\u2019s a great place to write. I rented a house for years in St. Jean at the top of the hill and my oldest daughter kind of grew up down there.\n\nIt was a small place, so I rented a room in the old Eden Rock hotel before they renovated it and had a little studio in there, and I wrote most of my first book in there. And the last album we did, Songs from St. Somewhere, we did most of the vocals in the studio in the new Eden Rock hotel.\n\nSo it has always been a very inspirational place for me to either write songs or other things.\u201d\n\nA lot of people in St. Barts think you wrote \u201cCheeseburger in Paradise\u201d on the island.\n\nThere are many stories out there about \u201cCheeseburger.\u201d A lot of people want it to be written in their bars, but I know exactly where I wrote it. I wrote it in Tortola back in 1972, when I sailed there for the first time on a little 33-foot boat.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nDo you still have your open tab at the restaurant Le Select in St. Barts?\n\nI have a deal at Le Select. I used to play there, just play at the bar, and Eddie, when he was running Le Select, he came to me and said, \u201cI want to start a cheeseburger stand and is it O.K. if I call it, \u2018Cheeseburger in paradise?\u2019 \u201d And I don\u2019t even know if we had any franchises at that point or not. But I said, \u201cHere\u2019s the deal, you can do it, but me and my immediate family eat and drink for free at Le Select for the rest of our lives.\u201d And we shook hands, and the deal still exists.", "title": "Jimmy Buffett\u2019s Support Helps St. Barts Move Forward", "authors": ["Christopher Clarey"]} {"date": "2018-04-24 00:00:00", "text": "You were the president during the Cold War. Who\u2019s the greater threat: the Soviet Union then, or Russia now? I think the Soviet Union then was more of a threat. Both Brezhnev and I, when in office, faced the immediate prospect of conflagration that would deteriorate into a nuclear exchange.\n\nJimmy Carter is the 39th president of the United States. His latest book, \u201cFaith: A Journey for All,\u201d is now available from Simon & Schuster. Age: 93 Occupation: Former president, author Hometown: Plains, Ga. $10.2 million: The amount Carter raised privately during the primaries for his 1976 presidential campaign. That\u2019s the equivalent of about $46 million in today\u2019s dollars.\n\nYou helped broker one of the only Middle East peace deals that has actually worked \u2014 the agreement between Egypt and Israel. Do you think Jared Kushner has a shot at finishing the job in the Middle East? I don\u2019t have any confidence in it. I obviously hope that he can make some breakthroughs, but the prospect of it has been damaged, I believe, by Trump\u2019s declaration that he wants to move the embassy to Jerusalem.\n\nAs one of the few Americans to have met with North Korea\u2019s leaders, what advice do you have for President Trump when he meets with Kim Jong-un? I\u2019ve shared my advice with Trump\u2019s national security adviser. The North Koreans want a binding agreement that the United States will not attack them so long as they stay at peace with their neighbors and with other countries. If they can get that and the insurance and proof of it, then I think that they might very well give up that nuclear program.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHow do you think that meeting will go? I don\u2019t have any way to predict what will happen when they get together. They\u2019re both apparently kind of brash people who speak off the cuff without careful consideration or without adequate advice from their own responsible associates.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nHas Trump done anything as president that you support? Well, yeah, he has. Of course. I disagree with much that he\u2019s done, but there\u2019s some things along the way he\u2019s done that I approve of.\n\nWould you care to single out any of them? Well, I don\u2019t want to get into a delineation of the things that I either strongly approve or strongly disapprove.\n\nEvery year, historians release their rankings of American presidents. Do you ever check to see where you\u2019re ranked? Yeah, I look. I don\u2019t worry about them. I think, in the long term, the presidents who have taken our country to war are looked upon as stronger and more able than the ones who tend toward peace. But that doesn\u2019t bother me.\n\nHow do you think you would fare running for president in 2020? I wouldn\u2019t have a chance.
