Why don\u2019t you rant a little about that, Sean Hannity?\u201d \u2014 JIMMY KIMMEL\n\nWhite House Shake-Up\n\nThe quick pace of change in the White House gave Seth Meyers an idea on Thursday: Maybe President Trump would enjoy firing the most powerful man in the world.", "title": "Jimmy Kimmel to Sean Hannity: If I\u2019m a Clown, What Are You?", "authors": ["Giovanni Russonello", "Best Of Late Night"]} {"date": "2018-04-20 00:00:00", "text": "Subscribe: iTunes | Google Play Music\n\nBook Review Jo Nesbo Reimagines \u2018Macbeth\u2019 James Shapiro discusses Nesbo\u2019s new novel, and Leila Slimani talks about \u201cThe Perfect Nanny.\u201d Audio\n\nIt\u2019s hard to think of a more courageous (or audacious) job for a writer than to reimagine Shakespeare. The best-selling thriller writer Jo Nesbo is the latest to give it a try, in \u201cMacbeth,\u201d reviewed for us by James Shapiro, a Shakespeare scholar and the author of several acclaimed books about the Bard.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cI think Nesbo is the greatest contemporary writer of the thriller, and he understands that Macbeth is the great grandaddy of the thriller, the murder mystery,\u201d Mr. Shapiro says on this week\u2019s podcast. \u201cHe gets that as well as any writer can.\u201d\n\nNonetheless, Mr. Shapiro says, there is \u201calways a price to pay when you are turning a Shakespeare play into something else.\u201d He discusses what he considers the many strengths of Mr. Nesbo\u2019s novel along with that price to pay.\n\nLeila Slimani joins us this week to discuss her novel \u201cThe Perfect Nanny,\u201d which won the Prix Goncourt award in France. The book echoes a real-life tragedy, the case of Yoselyn Ortega, who was recently convicted of the murder of two children left in her care.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cIn France, there is a tradition of writers who are inspired by the reality and then try to imagine and build a fiction,\u201d Ms. Slimani says, going back to the classics of Flaubert and Zola.\n\nPhoto\n\nMs. Slimani says the reaction from readers in the United States has included a question she never gets in France: \u201cWhat is the message of the book?\u201d Other readers have emphasized their moral judgment of the characters. \u201cI think it\u2019s very surprising to judge characters so much, to have a moral way of reading a novel,\u201d Ms. Slimani says. \u201cThere is no message. I think that literature is here to ask questions, not to answer questions. A novel is not a trial. We are not here to judge characters, and maybe that\u2019s why I write, because literature is a space where you can stop judging people and try just to understand them, even people who are very, very different from you, even people who are monstrous.\u201d", "title": "Jo Nesbo Reimagines \u2018Macbeth\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-16 00:00:00", "text": "It\u2019s tougher than it looks to create a world that is faithful to Shakespeare\u2019s original while also feeling modern and real. Placing Shakespeare\u2019s story in a late-20th-century world of drugs, gangs and corrupt civic leaders goes a long way toward solving this problem. \u201cBrew\u201d \u2014 the term used for the drug to which so many are addicted \u2014 is at the heart of Nesbo\u2019s novel and neatly straddles the murky world of Shakespeare\u2019s witches, with their caldron, and that of modern drug labs. By making addiction so central to his plot, Nesbo also makes Macbeth\u2019s paranoia and hallucinatory visions, so crucial to Shakespeare\u2019s play, not just believable but meaningful in a contemporary way.\n\nGang warfare also informs Nesbo\u2019s retelling and is well suited to the extreme violence of Shakespeare\u2019s original, in which the fighting that is described and staged is ferocious. In this dangerous world of ever-shifting loyalties and ill-gotten gains, it\u2019s easy to become morally compromised. Such is the fate of Nesbo\u2019s Macbeth, who at the outset is a good cop, but soon enough hungers for promotion and power \u2014 which prove more addictive than the drugs and alcohol that trap so many in the world of this novel.\n\nIn \u201cMacbeth,\u201d Shakespeare was unusually stingy when it came to sharing his characters\u2019 back stories and motivations. Did Lady Macbeth have a child that died? Was the idea of killing Duncan planted in Macbeth\u2019s mind by the witches or by Lady Macbeth, or had it been there, dormant, all along? Why does Macduff abandon his family? What Shakespeare withholds, Nesbo delves into deeply, taking one of Shakespeare\u2019s shortest and most enigmatic plays and expanding on what brought his characters to this point in their lives.\n\nImage\n\nSo, for example, we think of Macbeth a lot differently once we imagine that he spent part of his childhood in an orphanage. And Duff (Macduff) becomes more sympathetic when we see him torn between personal loyalties and the demands of the heart. The price paid by developing these intertwining back stories is that it takes Nesbo almost 450 pages to connect them, though the pace rarely lags. He is gifted at using casual details to define character: It makes perfect sense that Banquo drives an old Volvo, while Malcolm prefers a muscle car, a secondhand Chevelle.\n\nMinor characters like the demonic Seyton and Caithness (here a woman, and in love with Duff) have more significance and are brought to life. Surprisingly, although both Macbeth and his wife, Lady, are vividly drawn, Nesbo doesn\u2019t give the couple much of a history together \u2014 they\u2019ve only known each other for a few years \u2014 which may explain why their relationship feels far less intense and electric than it does in Shakespeare\u2019s original.", "title": "Jo Nesbo Sculpts \u2018Macbeth\u2019 Into Shadowy Crime Noir", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-20 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cShe had to fight for every inch of acceptance before she broke through the barriers to produce her first documentary,\u201d Mr. Moyers wrote in an email on Friday. \u201cShe showed women it could be done, but they had to be better than men at what they did. That drove her passion and paved the way for hundreds \u2014 maybe thousands \u2014 of other women journalists to rise in the field.\u201d\n\nMs. Konner also wrote or edited a half-dozen books, including \u201cThe Atheist\u2019s Bible\u201d in 2007 and \u201cYou Don\u2019t Have to Be Buddhist to Know Nothing\u201d in 2009. She described her books as \u201ctakeout gourmet food for thought.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nJoan Barbara Weiner was born on Feb. 24, 1931, in Paterson, N.J., the daughter of Martin Weiner, who was in the textile business, and the former Tillie Frankel, an artist.\n\nShe earned a bachelor\u2019s degree in 1951 from Sarah Lawrence College in Bronxville, N.Y., and a master\u2019s from the Columbia journalism school.\n\nIn addition to her daughter, from her first marriage, which ended in divorce, she is survived by her husband, Alvin H. Perlmutter, an independent television producer with whom she collaborated on many projects, including \u201cThe Power of Myth\u201d; three grandchildren; three stepchildren, Stephen, Tom and James Perlmutter; and seven step-grandchildren. Another daughter, Catherine, died in 2003.\n\nMs. Konner\u2019s first job out of journalism school was on the women\u2019s page of The Bergen Record in New Jersey. After six months, she began writing editorials, but left within two years for public television. When she was laid off, she took a job writing and reporting at WNBC-TV in New York before returning to public television in 1977.\n\nIn 1988, when she became dean of the Columbia journalism school and a professor there, she was already a trustee of the university.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMs. Konner was only the second broadcast journalist to be appointed dean of the school. (The first, in the 1970s, was Elie Abel, a former Times reporter who became a prominent correspondent for NBC News.)\n\nShe was credited with recruiting new faculty, creating a new doctoral program, instituting a part-time two-year curriculum for working journalists and generating $20 million in gifts and endowments. She stepped down in 1997 but remained publisher of the Columbia Journalism Review until 2000.\n\nIn 2001, she was one of three experts commissioned by CNN to examine the cable network\u2019s 2000 presidential election-night coverage. They concluded that the coverage had been a \u201cnews disaster\u201d that contributed to a climate of \u201crancor and bitterness\u201d and recommended that exit polls no longer be used to project winners before the voting was over.\n\nMs. Konner summed up her journalistic credo in her inaugural address as the Columbia dean. \u201cMost people are looking for good answers,\u201d she said, \u201cgood journalists look for the right questions.\u201d", "title": "Joan Konner, 87, TV Producer and Journalism Dean, Dies", "authors": ["Sam Roberts"]} {"date": "2018-04-11 00:00:00", "text": "Would a strident Joan be so bad? We won\u2019t know this season. Because Ms. Rashad, 31, doesn\u2019t see Joan as strident. Or even angry. \u201cShe\u2019s not angry,\u201d she said, \u201cShe\u2019s honest.\u201d She could recognize Joan\u2019s hurt and frustration and passion and clarity and force, but not her anger. \u201cI don\u2019t know that it\u2019s anger,\u201d she said. She said it more than once.\n\nPhoto\n\nAs for \u201cSaint Joan\u201d as a #MeToo play, she wanted it noted that for every man who burned Joan, there were many more who fought with her. \u201cWe can\u2019t just look at one side because it feels better,\u201d she said.\n\nI met Ms. Rashad \u2014 who has a straight-arrow supporting role in the Showtime series \u201cBillions,\u201d plays a sympathetic preacher\u2019s wife in the new Netflix film \u201cCome Sunday\u201d and leads the alternative band Condola and the Stoop Kids \u2014 on a recent afternoon that felt more like winter than spring. Sartorially, she\u2019d split the difference: black coat, flowered pants, turquoise eyeliner.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nShe had a break from rehearsal \u2014 it was a week before previews began, stagehands were loading in the set \u2014 and she\u2019d taken a car to a traffic triangle on the Upper West Side. That\u2019s where the city\u2019s Parks Department plunked the Joan of Arc memorial, sculpted by Anna Vaughn Hyatt Huntington in 1915, five years before Joan was canonized, eight years before Shaw wrote his play.\n\nMs. Rashad led Penny, her bitty, swaggering cockapoo, around the statue, noticing Joan\u2019s feet straining against the stirrups, Joan\u2019s hand clutching the sword she never used, her eyes and face upturned toward her God. \u201cVery appropriate,\u201d Ms. Rashad said approvingly.\n\nThe daughter of the actress and director Phylicia Rashad and the sportscaster and former N.F.L. player Ahmad Rashad, she has the preternatural composure of a person who meditates daily, practices yoga weekly and has given up even occasional drinking in order to \u201cfeel clearer than I\u2019ve ever felt.\u201d (And while I didn\u2019t think to ask about skin care, she definitely had that Maid of Orl\u00e9ans shimmer.)\n\nPhoto\n\nShe doesn\u2019t mind being practically the only woman in the rehearsal room, if that\u2019s what it takes to tell Joan\u2019s story, she said. (Her cast mates in the Manhattan Theater Club production include Adam Chanler-Berat, Patrick Page and Jack Davenport.) She doesn\u2019t mind being one of the few people who are not white. \u201cOf course I want there to be more people of color in the room, but there\u2019s also the thing of \u2018Well, I\u2019m here. Let\u2019s make the most of it,\u2019 \u201d she said.\n\nWhen her casting was announced, a few French ultranationalist Twitter users and some bullying Reddit posters accused her of cultural appropriation. She read a few of the comments and then she stopped. The abuse didn\u2019t make her mad. Actually, she mostly felt sorry for the complainers, she said. \u201cYou guys are missing out.\u201d\n\nIt is tempting to want to poke at Ms. Rashad\u2019s extraordinary poise, to wonder if it\u2019s innate or a necessary adaptation to a business and a culture that doesn\u2019t always applaud female truth-telling. Where does serenity stop and really solid media training begin?\n\nWell, a potential manager once told Ms. Rashad that she was too elegant to play prostitutes, which is an icky way of suggesting that she carries herself with a certain reserve. But she isn\u2019t cold, and she isn\u2019t snooty. I spoke to five directors who worked with her and they threw around nouns like maturity and intelligence and strength and dignity and humanity and authenticity and, in Mr. Sullivan\u2019s words, \u201ca wonderful simplicity.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nSo I don\u2019t think the equanimity is an act. Or if it is, she has everyone fooled. Even her mother. The elder Ms. Rashad, speaking by telephone on a break from shooting \u201cCreed II,\u201d said that her daughter had always spoken her mind and that \u201cshe has always been given to kindness\u201d and to empathy. She told a childhood story of watching Condola standing in the driveway, waiting for a butterfly to alight on her fingers. The butterfly did.\n\nStill, the denial of Joan\u2019s anger nagged at me. Could Ms. Rashad be great in a great part if she refused to play the full range of it?\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHer Broadway roles have included a sweetie-pie Juliet in a muddled Shakespeare, a grief-struck daughter in \u201cStick Fly,\u201d a melancholy young bride in \u201cThe Trip to Bountiful.\u201d She has a strong affinity for good characters (with typical humility she disputes this: \u201cI don\u2019t want to say I\u2019m captain good guy\u201d), and she has the rare ability to make goodness fascinating. When characters act dishonorably, it throws her.\n\nThis season, Kate Sacker, the assistant United States attorney she plays on \u201cBillions,\u201d makes some less-than-aboveboard moves, and she found the filming hard. I\u2019d watched her rehearse the first scene of \u201cSaint Joan,\u201d and her Joan had been determined, girlish, joyful. Would she be more?\n\nI worried about it all the way home, from the Upper West Side back to Brooklyn, and then I read the play again. Now I\u2019m pretty sure Ms. Rashad is right about the anger and the character and probably some other things. Joan is good at converting doubters to her cause. Ms. Rashad is, too.\n\nI shouldn\u2019t have been surprised. I had seen her in every play from \u201cRuined,\u201d her New York debut, to last year\u2019s \u201cA Doll\u2019s House, Part 2,\u201d a canny and assertive turn that brought her toe to toe with Laurie Metcalf and earned her a third Tony nomination. (Here\u2019s her mother on that part: \u201cIt was the bomb! My God, girl, where did you get that all from?\u201d) So I knew her as a persuasive performer whose incisive instincts were typically matched by scrupulous technique. She makes you feel and know and warm to her characters without ever showing how she does it.\n\nPhoto\n\nPhoto\n\nBecause Ms. Rashad doesn\u2019t go in for emotional fireworks. As with Joan and her sword, they are an armament she doesn\u2019t use. Her style, which she honed at the experimental training program at the California Institute of the Arts (she grew up in Westchester and \u201cwanted to be in a place my parents would have to take a plane,\u201d she said) is more grounded and more granular. As Kenny Leon, a frequent director and a family friend said: \u201cCondola never reminds you that she\u2019s acting. She engages you because it looks like she\u2019s not.\u201d\n\nJoan is her first Broadway lead since Juliet. In the fall, when her casting was confirmed, she cleared her schedule and read book after book about Joan of Arc, becoming so fluent in medieval history that she now serves as the play\u2019s unofficial dramaturge. On the day I visited rehearsal, I saw a hand-drawn map of the siege of Orl\u00e9ans. She had sketched it from memory the day before.\n\nDespite her research and her training, Ms. Rashad is not an analytical actor. She believes that every character exerts a particular energy and that it\u2019s her job to \u201cmerge with that energy and trust that whatever that energy field tells you, you need to be told,\u201d she said. (She said it while wearing a hunk of black tourmaline that was supposed to connect her to her root chakra.)\n\nSo yes, the woo-woo runs deep and it extends to how she sees Joan. \u201cI think she\u2019s someone who had a very high energy quotient,\u201d she said. \u201cShe was someone open to her intentions.\u201d Maybe that all sounds pretty New Age-y, but it\u2019s rare to receive three Tony nominations by the time you turn 30, so the woo-woo seems to be working.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nTo merge with Joan, she has connected not to any righteous anger or Time\u2019s Up timeliness, but to the idea of being called, of aligning herself with a larger purpose. \u201cThere is a divine energy and we are all connected to it and we are all made of it,\u201d she said.\n\nObviously, Ms. Rashad and her character have different to-do lists. Joan was turning around the Hundred Years\u2019 War. Ms. Rashad is trying to prove herself as a Broadway leading lady. No one is going to burn her. Not literally anyway. But she believes that she has been called to this task just as Joan was called to hers.\n\n\u201cI\u2019m also someone doing what I think I\u2019m supposed to do,\u201d she said. \u201cSo I do it with intense joy.\u201d", "title": "Joan of Arc, Superstar? Not to the Woman Playing Her", "authors": ["Alexis Soloski"]} {"date": "2018-04-27 00:00:00", "text": "[For more on women, gender and society, subscribe to the Gender Letter newsletter.]\n\nSUPERVISOR: This position reports to co-workers younger and less qualified than you. They will also have little regard for your personal space; may pull your shirt up in public; slap you on the bum (also in public); wonder aloud why your arms, legs and/or stomach are so \u201csquishy\u201d; and will not at all listen to your opinions. They may, on occasion, order you around and be clearly unappreciative of your efforts. You\u2019re a woman; you should be used to this sort of thing in the workplace by now.\n\nSKILLS AND EXPERIENCE: Nothing will prepare you for this. Not babysitting, not having a dog, and certainly not your childbirth class. Maybe get some sleep or eat chocolate-covered pretzels in your underpants?\n\nTYPE OF EMPLOYMENT: This is a volunteer, unpaid, full-time job. If you have paid employment outside the home, this is still a full-time job. You will have to sort that out for yourself. The primary purpose of this position is to train your co-workers to become more competent, independent, well adjusted and successful than you. Don\u2019t be afraid to occasionally whisper \u201cMarry for money\u201d to them when no one\u2019s around. Who cares? Times change, love is fickle and working is hard.\n\nHOW WE MEASURE SUCCESS: Success in this position \u2014 while prematurely announced by those who are currently breast-feeding 5-year-olds \u2014 may be accurately measured only roughly 10 or 20 or 30 years after your last co-worker has left his or her in-house position. Please note: Once your co-worker has moved on, you will no longer be allowed into a majority of his or her waking moments and certainly not the sleeping ones. Your former co-workers will typically not be terribly vocal about whether they feel your tenure was a success, or what they\u2019re doing now on a day-to-day basis. Sometimes they won\u2019t even tell you what they\u2019ve had to eat or who they are with! Honestly, the feedback process and yearly reviews for this position are a nightmare, if they happen at all. Many employees find Thanksgiving to be an unusually popular time for performance reviews, but we do not recommend it.\n\nSUMMARY: The primary purpose of this position is to train the people you love most in this world to leave you. Forever.\n\nTold you it was dumb.", "title": "Opinion | Job Description for the Dumbest Job Ever", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-01 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cYou realize that you cannot possibly take all the children with you,\u201d he said. \u201cYou know for a fact that the children you leave behind are going to die. I took 12 with me. Later on, I asked myself, \u2018Why not 13?\u2019 \u201d\n\nNearly 70 years later, when Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel visited the Netherlands in 2012, he met Mr. van Hulst and told him: \u201cWe say those who save one life saves a universe. You saved hundreds of universes.\u201d\n\nMr. van Hulst died on March 22 in Amsterdam, the Dutch Senate announced. He was 107.\n\nMr. van Hulst started teaching at the Reformed Teachers\u2019 Training College in 1938. Two years later, he was named deputy principal. But after the Nazi occupation of the Netherlands began in May 1940, the school came under great financial pressure. The Dutch government eliminated a subsidy for teachers\u2019 salaries, seemingly dooming the school to closing.\n\nBut Mr. van Hulst came up with a plan to ask the students\u2019 parents to fund the school, and it succeeded, saving the school and helping him rise to principal.\n\nWhen Germany invaded the Netherlands, there were about 140,000 Jews, and by September 1944, more than 100,000 of them had been sent to concentration camps, according to Yad Vashem. Jews from Amsterdam were taken to the transit camp in Westerbork, in the Netherlands, before being transported to Nazi extermination centers in Poland like Auschwitz.\n\nThe teachers\u2019 college represented one side of the children\u2019s rescue triangle. The deportation center \u2014 a former theater \u2014 was managed by Walter S\u00fcskind, a German refugee. The nursery was run by Henri\u00ebtte Pimentel, who asked Mr. van Hulst to let the children play in the college\u2019s garden and take naps in a classroom. Then, as the plan took hold, the children were whisked to safety.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe plan necessitated deception \u2014 and led to difficult conversations with parents whose children had been wrested from them.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cS\u00fcskind\u2019s role was to let the children disappear from the lists,\u201d Bart Wallet, a historian at Vrije Universiteit in Amsterdam, wrote in an email, referring to the administrative records he altered to help save the children.\n\nMs. Pimentel, he added, \u201cconvinced the parents to let their children be smuggled out. Van Hulst was the one who did the actual smuggling \u2014 of course, together with his team of students and fellow resistance workers.\u201d\n\nTo avoid suspicion, Mr. van Hulst sent only a few children at a time to safety; not all of them at any given time in the nursery could be saved.\n\n\u201cWe had to make a choice,\u201d he told the Dutch broadcaster NOS last year, \u201cand one of the most horrible things was to make a choice.\u201d\n\nEmile Schrijver, general director of the Jewish Cultural Quarter in Amsterdam, said in an email that Mr. van Hulst had demonstrated that \u201cwe all have a choice to do the right thing at any time; even in times of enormous trouble; he used the power of disruption; disruption of an evil system and of the arrogance it entailed.\u201d\n\nThe teachers\u2019 college where Mr. van Hulst was the principal is now the National Holocaust Museum.\n\nJohan Wilhelm van Hulst was born on Jan. 28, 1911, in Amsterdam, to Gerrit van Hulst, a furniture upholsterer, and the former Geertruida C. Hofman. His education included master\u2019s degrees in psychology and pedagogy from Vrije Universiteit and a Ph.D. in humanities there.\n\nAfter the war, he continued to teach but also entered politics, serving in the Dutch Senate and the European Parliament.\n\nHe was also an accomplished chess player and the chairman of a chess club in Amsterdam. When Jewish members faced restrictions from the Germans, he told the website Chess Vibes in 2010, \u201cwe decided to secretly play at their houses instead of at the club.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cLater this had to stop as well,\u201d he said.\n\nHe is survived by his daughters, Diane Schoonemann-van Hulst and Catherine Koot-van Hulst; two grandchildren; and three great-grandchildren. His wife, the former Anna Janette Donker, died in 2006.\n\nMr. van Hulst was interviewed frequently about his wartime activities but was modest in assessing them.\n\n\u201cI was at the center of a particular activity,\u201d he told the Dutch newspaper Het Parool two years ago. \u201cIt\u2019s not about me. I don\u2019t want to put myself in the foreground or play Resistance hero. All I really think about is the things I couldn\u2019t do \u2014 the few thousand children I wasn\u2019t able to save.\u201d", "title": "Johan van Hulst, Who Helped Save 600 Children From the Nazis, Dies at 107", "authors": ["Richard Sandomir"]} {"date": "2018-04-22 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nJohannah Kathleen Chase and Tim Allen Coates were married April 21 at Deity, an events space in Brooklyn. The Rev. Nick Coates, a brother of the groom who was ordained by the United Church of Canada, officiated.\n\nThe bride, who is 36 and works in Manhattan, is a program officer for the Walton Family Foundation, a philanthropic organization begun by the Walmart founders Sam and Helen Walton. The foundation, based in Arkansas, invests in the education of children, kindergarten through 12th grade, and works to protect rivers and oceans and the communities they support. She graduated from Cornell and received a master's degree in teaching secondary mathematics from Pace University.\n\nShe is a daughter of Tamara S. Hill of Dixon, Ill., and John W. Chase of Mount Morris, Ill. The bride\u2019s mother is an English teacher at Reagan Middle School in Dixon. Her father, who worked in Rockford, Ill., retired as associate deputy of foster care and agency licensing for the Department of Children and Family Services of Illinois. The bride is a stepdaughter of Beth Nelson Chase. Her stepmother is the vice president of Bright Stars of Bethlehem, a nonprofit Christian organization.\n\nThe groom, who is 38 and also works in Manhattan, is a product marketing leader for government, which is a part of IBM\u2019s public sector business. He graduated from St. Thomas University in Fredericton, New Brunswick, and received a master of public policy degree from Harvard.\n\nHe is a son of Judy R. Coates and John F. Coates of Fredericton. The groom\u2019s mother, who is retired, was the founding board chair of the Fredericton chapter of Children's International Summer Villages, a Cincinnati-based nonprofit organization that promotes peace education. His father, who is also retired, was a professor of social work in Fredericton for St. Thomas University.\n\nThe groom\u2019s first marriage ended in divorce.\n\nThe couple met in October 2015 through a mutual friend in Brooklyn.", "title": "Johannah Chase, Tim Coates", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-17 00:00:00", "text": "The longtime Rangers anthem singer John Amirante has died. He was 83.\n\nHis wife, Annie, told the Rangers he died of natural causes Tuesday in New York after about a week in the hospital.\n\nThe Bronx-born Amirante sang \u201cThe Star-Spangled Banner\u201d before Rangers games at Madison Square Garden from 1980 until he retired in 2015 and on special occasions afterward. He also sang before Knicks, Yankees and Mets games.\n\nIn a statement posted on the Rangers\u2019 Twitter feed, goaltender Henrik Lundqvist said it was \u201calways special to hear his name, see him walk out and sing the way he did.\u201d", "title": "John Amirante, Longtime Anthem Singer for the Rangers, Dies at 83", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-06 00:00:00", "text": "The poet John Ashbery, who died in September at the age of 90, cultivated a spirit of impish collision in his work \u2014 sometimes building whole poems (known as centos) out of other people\u2019s lines, other times incorporating fragments of found language or swerving suddenly to a new topic in a spasm of surreal free association. The resulting poems were like high-performance cars assembled from junkyard parts, or runway fashions with the stitches intentionally showing. They were, essentially, collages.\n\nSo it felt fitting for the world to find out, late in his life, that Ashbery had for decades devoted himself to making visual collages as well, starting as a student at Harvard in the 1940s and culminating in gallery shows in his last decade. Some of these works have now been paired with poems and collected in a new book, THEY KNEW WHAT THEY WANTED: Poems & Collages (Rizzoli Electa, $35), edited by Mark Polizzotti.\n\nAshbery\u2019s images demonstrate the same sense of gleeful mischief that\u2019s everywhere in his poetry, mixing fine art with advertising and comic strips and picture postcards, all of it married with the artist\u2019s sure eye for color and mood and perspective. The result is an entire oeuvre of fantasy landscapes, such as the one in \u201cPromontory,\u201d pictured here, from 2010.\n\n\u201cI\u2019m firmly eclectic in these and in most things,\u201d Ashbery told the poet John Yau once, in an interview included at the front of the book (itself aptly pasted together from various conversations over 10 years). At the end of that interview, Yau said to Ashbery, \u201cIn a number of your recent collages, it\u2019s like you are about to undertake a journey or begin a dream.\u201d\n\nAshbery\u2019s reply: \u201cThat\u2019s how I feel much of the time.\u201d", "title": "John Ashbery, a Poet With Paper and Glue", "authors": ["Gregory Cowles"]} {"date": "2018-04-11 00:00:00", "text": "John A. Boehner, the speaker of the House from 2011 to 2015, reversed a long-held stance against marijuana legalization on Wednesday, saying on Twitter that \u201cmy thinking on cannabis has evolved.\u201d\n\nMr. Boehner, a Republican leader who in 2011 told a constituent he was \u201cunalterably opposed\u201d to legalization, joined the board of advisers of Acreage Holdings, a cannabis corporation that operates in 11 states.\n\nWhile the announcement might be viewed as a sign that cannabis is becoming a big business that can afford to ally with prominent names from the world of politics, Mr. Boehner cast it as a genuine change of heart.\n\nIn a statement, he and William F. Weld, the former Massachusetts governor, who also joined the Acreage Holdings board, said \u201cthe time has come for serious consideration of a shift in federal marijuana policy.\u201d", "title": "John Boehner\u2019s Marijuana Reversal: \u2018My Thinking on Cannabis Has Evolved\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-05 00:00:00", "text": "Two hours before the W.W.E. Live Road to WrestleMania took over Madison Square Garden last month, John Cena, its star wrestler, burst into a backstage room. Stopping only for a quick handshake and amiable greeting (\u201cGrab a seat! Let\u2019s talk!\u201d), he sat before a stack of self-portraits, grabbed a Sharpie and began feverishly scribbling his autograph like a teenager rushing to finish his homework.\n\nDressed in a neon green T-shirt, matching wrist bands, denim shorts and black kneepads, Mr. Cena looked like an action-figure version of himself, as he pumped himself up for a long night of engagements, both in and out of the ring.\n\nThere was a fan meet-and-greet for Make-a-Wish, wrestling executives to confer with and a promotional video to shoot, not to mention a Mixed Tag Team Match before 13,000 fans with his fianc\u00e9e, Nikki Bella. They would face off against the guitar-strumming Elias and Bayley.\n\nMr. Cena\u2019s schedule had been nonstop in recent days. After a 30-hour stay in London to promote the film \u201cBlockers,\u201d a raunchy comedy about parents hellbent on saving their teenage daughters\u2019 virginities (he plays one of the overbearing fathers), he was in New York to reclaim his wrestling throne.", "title": "John Cena Grants a Wish Before His Wrestling Match", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-12 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Ehle\u2019s cycle began with \u201cThe Land Breakers\u201d (1964), which takes place in the late 18th century, and ended with \u201cLast One Home\u201d (1984), which brought his characters into the Great Depression.\n\nCritics praised Mr. Ehle (pronounced EE-lee) for the epic sweep of his stories, their vivid detail, realistic dialogue and the dignity with which he invested mountain people who have often been stereotyped as hillbillies.\n\nKirkus Reviews called \u201cThe Land Breakers\u201d \u2014 whose main character, Mooney Wright, settles land in the Appalachian wilderness in 1779 \u2014 a \u201cfull novel of birth, death, laughter and sadness spun out by a storyteller with a rare ability to convey \u2018the way it must have been.\u2019 \u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nMr. Ehle\u2019s books were usually well-reviewed and earned him a place in the canon of Appalachian literature. But he did not find a vast readership in the United States.\n\nOne fan, though, was Harper Lee, who lauded \u201cThe Land Breakers\u201d when it was republished in 2006 by Press 53, a small Winston-Salem publisher.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cJohn Ehle\u2019s meld of historical fact with ineluctable plot-weaving makes \u2018The Land Breakers\u2019 an exciting sample of masterful storytelling,\u201d Ms. Lee wrote.\n\nAnd, three years later, the Canadian writer Michael Ondaatje told The Globe and Mail that \u201cThe Land Breakers\u201d was \u201ca great American novel, way beyond anything most New York literary icons have produced.\u201d But, he lamented, Mr. Ehle remained \u201cshockingly unknown.\u201d\n\nKevin Morgan Watson, the publisher and editor in chief of Press 53, had been unaware of Mr. Ehle before he reprinted \u201cThe Land Breakers.\u201d\n\n\u201cI had just started the press four months prior and then I met with John and read his bio,\u201d he said in a telephone interview. \u201cI couldn\u2019t believe I hadn\u2019t heard of this man. From the first chapter, I knew I was dealing with a masterful writer.\u201d\n\nPress 53 has republished six other books by Mr. Ehle.\n\nThe next book in his Appalachian cycle was \u201cThe Road\u201d (1967), a Reconstruction-era novel about Weatherby Wright, a white mountaineer who uses inventive engineering methods and convict labor to build a railroad from the lowlands to an isolated mountain region near Asheville, N.C.\n\nIn a review in The Chicago Tribune, the author James Stokely described \u201cThe Road\u201d as an \u201cepic\u201d that brought to life \u201cthe minutiae of every day events\u201d and \u201cthe physical ordeal of mud-stained animals\u201d and \u201cmen blasting, cutting and bleeding the mountainside.\u201d\n\nJohn Marsden Ehle Jr. was born in Asheville on Dec. 13, 1925, to John Sr., an insurance salesman, and the former Gladys Starnes. He grew up in West Asheville.\n\n\u201cThe Bible was the main book, the only book, that my mother really wanted in the house,\u201d Mr. Ehle told The Appalachian Journal in 2005. \u201cShe suspected that the others contained materials that, had she read them, she would not have approved.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAfter serving as an Army rifleman in Europe and Asia with the 97th Infantry Division during World War II, Mr. Ehle received a bachelor\u2019s degree in radio, television and motion pictures and a master\u2019s in dramatic arts at U.N.C. He taught there from 1951 to 1963.\n\nHis reputation as an advocate for the arts got a public airing in May 1961, when he wrote a two-part article in The Raleigh News and Observer saying that the university was failing to inspire its students of creative writing, dramatic art, music and languages.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cThe University hasn\u2019t been doing very well of late \u2014 I hear that wherever I go,\u201d he wrote. \u201cState College booms along. Raleigh has a good spirit. Not this place, just 27 miles away.\u201d\n\nJoel Fleishman, a legal assistant to Terry Sanford, the Democratic governor of North Carolina at the time, recalled in an email that at the time he had already known Mr. Ehle and his concerns about the arts at the school and invited him to the governor\u2019s mansion in 1962 to talk about improving the state on many fronts as Mr. Sanford headed into his last two years in office.\n\nMr. Ehle said the governor had asked the 10 or 12 invitees what they thought should be done.\n\n\u201cWell, sir, there were various views expressed,\u201d Mr. Ehle said to an interviewer in 1995 for the Southern Oral History Program at U.N.C. \u201cSomebody thought he should do something about highway safety. Somebody said we should do something about pig farms, that if we could get more pig farms and we all agree on the same kind of pigs, we could rival Denmark or somewhere, with their pigs. I didn\u2019t have any ideas when he came to me.\u201d\n\nMr. Fleishman, now a professor at the Duke University School of Law, said in an email that Mr. Ehle may have been modest in his recollection. Nonetheless, Mr. Ehle soon after joined the Sanford administration as a special consultant despite his concern that the position would deprive him of the time he needed to finish a novel.\n\nAs an adviser he became a font of ideas that led to the creation of what is now the University of North Carolina School of the Arts; summer Governor\u2019s Schools for the state\u2019s brightest high school students; a state-run Learning Institute to provide research on improving education; and a state film board. He also helped develop an antipoverty program called the North Carolina Fund.\n\n\u201cJohn definitely was the quarterback who drove the development\u201d of those initiatives, Mr. Fleishman said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Ehle left Gov. Sanford\u2019s office in May 1964, after about 18 months, and told U.S. News & World Report: \u201cWith a creative state government you can start tremendous educational and cultural programs almost beyond the imagination.\u201d\n\nHe soon began to write \u201cThe Free Men\u201d (1965), his civil rights book.\n\nBut he continued to do educational work. At the Anne C. Stouffer Foundation, which was dedicated to finding qualified black students to integrate white preparatory schools, he and Ms. Harris traveled together and audiotaped their interviews with candidates. In one recording, Mr. Ehle asked one student about his experience with integration.\n\n\u201cWell, several summers ago, I went to a camp that was integrated,\u201d the student said. \u201cBut other than that I haven\u2019t been in contact very much with, um, many white boys and girls.\u201d\n\n\u201cYou don\u2019t really have any dislike for them, though, do ya?\u201d Mr. Ehle asked.\n\n\u201cNo,\u201d the student responded. \u201cI don\u2019t understand why Negroes and whites can\u2019t get along.\u201d\n\nBesides Ms. Harris \u2014 who has won Tony, Emmy and Golden Globe Awards \u2014 Mr. Ehle\u2019s survivors include a daughter, Jennifer Ehle, a two-time Tony Award-winning actress, and two grandchildren. His marriage to Gail Oliver ended in divorce.\n\n\u201cWhen we got married,\u201d Ms. Harris told The New York Times in 1986, \u201cJohn and I had a fantasy that we would sit on either side of the fireplace in the evenings and he would read me what he\u2019d written during the day and I would make helpful comments. But the first time that happened, we had an argument. So we decided that, since we had managed to get so far in our careers without each others\u2019 advice, we would continue that way.\u201d", "title": "John Ehle, Who Rooted His Novels in Appalachia, Is Dead at 92", "authors": ["Richard Sandomir"]} {"date": "2018-04-01 00:00:00", "text": "KEY BISCAYNE, Fla. \u2014 John Isner punctuated his unexpected run to the Miami Open title with a surprising display of agility on Sunday, dancing across the court while basking in a breakthrough.\n\nThe 6-foot-10-inch Isner looked twice as tall skipping about with a grin that seemed as bright as the Florida sunshine. He had just won the biggest title of his 14-year career, holding every service game and rallying past Alexander Zverev, 6-7 (4), 6-4, 6-4.\n\nIsner, who will turn 33 this month, had been 0-3 in ATP Masters 1000 finals.\n\n\u201cYou can\u2019t replicate moments like this,\u201d Isner said during the trophy ceremony. \u201cI\u2019m toward the latter part of my career; this is the best moment of my career.\u201d\n\nIsner\u2019s win came in the last singles match on Key Biscayne before the Miami Open moves next year to the Miami Gardens home of the N.F.L.\u2019s Dolphins.", "title": "John Isner Calls Miami Open Win \u2018Best Moment of My Career\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-04 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cI think I\u2019m increasingly viewed now as not just a Republican but as something different, kind of a hybrid,\u201d he said in a half-hour interview on Tuesday, shuttling between stops in an S.U.V. \u201cI have people of all shapes, sizes, philosophies and party preferences that approach me. But what does that mean? I don\u2019t know. I\u2019m on television, so all the sudden they want to talk to me. Television moves everybody up, right?\u201d\n\nThat remains to be seen, electorally. A University of New Hampshire poll released in February found that 60 percent of the state\u2019s Republicans would support Mr. Trump again in a primary; 18 percent planned to vote for someone else. Another recent poll was more generous to Mr. Kasich, though it still showed Mr. Trump with a clear edge. And while some prominent Republicans in the state, like former Senator John E. Sununu, remain vocal Kasich defenders, few sitting officeholders have made a point of consistently challenging Mr. Trump.\n\nMr. Kasich\u2019s case against Mr. Trump rests as much on tone as substance. The governor, a longtime supporter of free-trade deals like the Trans-Pacific Partnership, has been sharply critical of the president\u2019s tilt toward protectionism on trade, saying it runs afoul of the Republican Party he knew. He has also lamented the president\u2019s bid to dismantle DACA, the program aimed at protecting young undocumented immigrants from deportation.\n\nOn this and other issues, though, Mr. Kasich has sought to contrast himself with Mr. Trump most pointedly as a spokesman for national decency. Rarely was he more animated on Tuesday than during a discussion of the president\u2019s Easter morning tweet declaring, \u201cNO MORE DACA DEAL.\u201d \u201cOn Easter,\u201d the governor said on Tuesday, later adding, \u201cCome on, leaders don\u2019t do that.\u201d\n\nOfficially, Mr. Kasich says, another run for president is not on his immediate radar, but he is keeping his options open, maintaining the relationships required for any prospective campaign.\n\nRegardless of his eventual choice, Mr. Kasich has succeeded, at least, in installing himself permanently in the grand drama of the Trump era, drawing a pack of reporters to New Hampshire in an off-year on the pretext of a question-and-answer session at a college and ensuring that the news media will continue to track his doings once his term expires in January.\n\n\u201cHe enjoys being consequential,\u201d said Tom Rath, a senior national adviser to Mr. Kasich\u2019s 2016 campaign and a former attorney general of New Hampshire. \u201cThat alone would be enough to continue this effort, whatever you want to call this effort.\u201d", "title": "John Kasich Is Back in New Hampshire. It\u2019s Not for the Foliage.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-05 00:00:00", "text": "You have been called the \u201cdean of Cold War historians.\u201d Besides your own, what books (fiction or nonfiction) best capture the Cold War? Have any books on the subject caused you to change your views?\n\nThat title originated as a prank by an evil colleague and is the only deanship I haven\u2019t managed to dodge. The best overall book now is Odd Arne Westad\u2019s \u201cThe Cold War: A World History.\u201d But anyone working on that topic \u2014 or any other in recent history \u2014 should be prepared to rethink as new sources appear. I once wrote a book on my own rethinking (\u201cWe Now Know\u201d), but found that it made graduate students and international relations theorists nervous. So I\u2019ve tried since to be a bit more discreet.\n\nYou co-teach a famous seminar on grand strategy. What is your favorite book to assign and discuss with your students?\n\nMachiavelli\u2019s \u201cThe Prince,\u201d because it so shakes the students. Young as they are, they\u2019re ambitious enough to see themselves in it.\n\nWhich genres do you especially enjoy reading? And which do you avoid? Ever tried the other Gaddis (William)?\n\nI\u2019ll try anything that\u2019s not shrill or self-indulgent, although these days that excludes a lot. I have attempted the other Gaddis but never got beyond the first few pages. Fortunately, he wasn\u2019t a relative.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nWhat books might we be surprised to find on your bookshelves?\n\nTrain books. I\u2019ve been a fanatic since the age of 5 (months) and in recent years have become addicted to the locomotive cab ride videos that are part of the Slow Television movement. They\u2019re great for viewing without having to think, as on the exercise bike. I especially recommend the six-hour run from Omsk to Novosibirsk, on which nothing happens.\n\nWho is your favorite fictional hero or heroine?\n\nPierre in \u201cWar and Peace\u201d and Anna in \u201cAnna Karenina.\u201d But I also like Virginia Woolf\u2019s hero/heroine Orlando, with whom I\u2019ve always begun my undergraduate seminar in biography.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWhat kind of reader were you as a child? Your favorite books and authors?\n\nPrecociously discriminating. Therefore, A. A. Milne\u2019s \u201cWinnie-the-Pooh.\u201d\n\nIf you had to name one book that made you who you are today, what would it be?\n\n\u201cWinnie-the-Pooh.\u201d\n\nIf you could require the president to read one book, what would it be?\n\nThucydides\u2019s \u201cThe History of the Peloponnesian War,\u201d or at least the Cliff Notes.\n\nYou\u2019re hosting a literary dinner party. Which three writers are invited?\n\nMachiavelli, Elizabeth I and Isaiah Berlin. They would have a blast!\n\nDisappointing, overrated, just not good: What book did you feel as if you were supposed to like, and didn\u2019t? Do you remember the last book you put down without finishing?\n\nTo the dismay of my students, the Harry Potter novels. I fail to finish books frequently, but it wouldn\u2019t be charitable for me to specify which ones.\n\nWhat books do you find yourself returning to again and again?\n\nC. P. Snow\u2019s now sadly neglected Strangers and Brothers novels, as well as the naval history epics \u2014 not neglected at all \u2014 of Patrick O\u2019Brian. Also Jack Miles\u2019s \u201cGod: A Biography,\u201d with which I always end my undergraduate seminar.\n\nWhat books are you embarrassed not to have read yet?\n\nIt\u2019s not that I haven\u2019t read the Jane Austen novels \u2014 I have \u2014 but it\u2019s still embarrassing to have to be told by well-meaning friends and my wife what I\u2019m supposed to get from them.\n\nWhom would you want to write your biography?\n\nThe first Yale student to get into my voluminously indiscreet diary when it\u2019s opened for research a hundred or so years from now.", "title": "John Lewis Gaddis: By the Book", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-13 00:00:00", "text": "But calling himself a \u201cmoderate,\u201d he supported many conservative ideas. He voted in his first Senate term for a constitutional amendment to require balanced federal budgets, and for President Ronald Reagan\u2019s nuclear buildup and sale of early-warning Awacs planes to Saudi Arabia. He was also a strong ally of Montana\u2019s timber, oil and gas interests.\n\nAs Senator Melcher ran for re-election in 1982, the far-right John Birch Society gave him a 63 percent favorable rating, fifth highest among Senate Democrats. Many Democratic voters grumbled over his conservative leanings. President Reagan went to Montana to campaign for Larry Williams, the Republican candidate, but Dr. Melcher was narrowly re-elected.\n\nIn 1988, with Montana\u2019s economy down in a recession and polls showing voters leaning toward conservative solutions, Dr. Melcher, running for a third term, seemed eager to avoid being tagged a liberal: He noted that he opposed abortion and backed prayers in public schools. Conrad Burns, his Republican challenger, called him \u201csoft on drugs, soft on defense and very high on social programs.\u201d\n\nIn an upset, Dr. Melcher lost by 13,000 votes out of 357,000 cast, and was the Senate\u2019s only Democratic incumbent turned out of office that year. He tried to reclaim the seat in 1994 but was defeated in the Democratic primary by Jack Mudd, a former law school dean. Mr. Mudd then lost the general election to Mr. Burns, who won a second term.\n\nJohn David Melcher was born in Sioux City, Iowa, on Sept. 6, 1924, one of three sons of Anthony Melcher and the former Nell Mentor. His parents were divorced when John was 8, and he and his brother, Robert, stayed with relatives when their father, a traveling salesman of farm pumps, went on the road. Another brother, Patrick, had died earlier.\n\nPhoto\n\nJohn grew up in Dubuque and Ashton, Iowa, and on a ranch 10 miles outside Oelrichs, S.D. Members of his family recalled that he rode a horse to and from Oelrichs High School, from which he graduated in 1942.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nOn summer vacations, John sometimes accompanied his father on business trips, and on one journey to the West he fell in love with the prairies and mountains of Montana.\n\nHe attended the University of Minnesota for a year, but left to join the Army in World War II. He served with the 76th Infantry Division in Europe and participated in the invasion of Normandy in 1944. Wounded near Trier, Germany, in 1945, he won the Purple Heart, the Combat Infantryman\u2019s Badge and the Bronze Star. He was discharged and hospitalized at Santa Barbara, Calif.\n\nAfter recuperating in late 1945, he married Ruth Klein, a former high school classmate. They had six children.\n\nBesides his daughter Joan, Mr. Melcher is survived by two other daughters, Teresa Thompson and Mary Melcher; his sons, Robert and John; a brother, Robert; a half sister, Virginia DiNovis; a half brother, Thomas Melcher; 10 grandchildren and five great-grandchildren. His wife died in 2015. Another son, David, died of Reye\u2019s syndrome at 6.\n\nDr. Melcher earned a degree in veterinary medicine from Iowa State University at Ames in 1950. Drawn by memories of a childhood trip with his father, he moved with his family to Forsyth, a community of under 2,000 in eastern Montana. There he established his Yellowstone Veterinary Clinic and treated horses, cattle, pigs and sheep until his election to Congress in 1969.\n\nPhoto\n\nIn 1953, he was elected to the Forsyth City Council. Finding a liking and a talent for public service, he won a string of elections, and served as Forsyth\u2019s mayor from 1955 to 1961, as a member of the Montana House of Representatives from Rosebud County from 1961 to 1963, and as a state senator in Helena, the capital, from 1963 to 1967.\n\nHe then returned to the lower house for two years, but with encouragement from Democratic and legislative colleagues he had his sights set on the national stage. He was a square-jawed, down-to-earth politician whose interests in animals and agriculture grew out of long associations with farmers, ranchers and small-town people in sparsely populated eastern Montana.\n\nDr. Melcher lost his initial race for a seat in Congress in 1966. But in 1969 he won a special election to replace Representative James F. Battin, a Republican who had resigned to take a federal judgeship.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nDr. Melcher settled in Missoula after his years in Washington. He founded a lobbying and consulting firm and worked for the Association of American Veterinary Medical Colleges and for various veterinary medical groups for many years.\n\nIn an interview for this obituary in 2017, Dr. Melcher recalled his 1984 amendment to the Animal Welfare Act of 1966, requiring that the psychological well-being of nonhuman primates be considered in research.\n\n\u201cIt was just something I could do,\u201d he said of his measure, which prohibited long periods of isolation in cages and other mental cruelties.\n\nJane Goodall, the primatologist and authority on chimpanzees, hailed his amendment. She visited Dr. Melcher in Washington, gave him a copy of her book \u201cThe Chimpanzees of Gombe\u201d (1986) and wrote in an inscription: \u201cWhen this bill is well and truly implemented, the difference in the lives of hundreds of animals will truly be great.\u201d", "title": "John Melcher, Montana Democrat in House and Senate, Dies at 93", "authors": ["Robert D. Mcfadden"]} {"date": "2018-04-18 00:00:00", "text": "The album seems to start jauntily enough, with \u201cKnockin\u2019 on Your Screen Door,\u201d a Johnny Cash-style country march. But the lyrics that Mr. Prine cackles through begin with \u201cI ain\u2019t got nobody\u201d and mention that his wife and family have left him; now he\u2019s knocking at someone\u2019s door just hoping for company, even though he knows, \u201cYou don\u2019t got to answer.\u201d The album ends with the jovial bounce of \u201cWhen I Get to Heaven,\u201d complete with kazoo, which Mr. Prine imagines as a place where he can open up a nightclub called the Tree of Forgiveness \u2014 and forgive a lot of people \u2014 and where he can \u201csmoke a cigarette that\u2019s nine miles long.\u201d The catch, he also recognizes, is that he has to die first.\n\nMortality looms throughout \u201cThe Tree of Forgiveness.\u201d It\u2019s played for comedy in \u201cEgg & Daughter Nite, Lincoln Nebraska, 1967 (Crazy Bone),\u201d with honky-tonk piano rippling behind a closing verse about dementia and deterioration in a nursing home, while \u201cIn a local cemetery/They already got your name carved out in stone.\u201d It also suffuses \u201cCaravan of Fools,\u201d a haunted minor-key tune (written with Dan Auerbach, from the Black Keys, and Pat McLaughlin) with guitar picking and enigmatic lyrics that envision \u201cthe pounding of the hooves/the silence of everything that moves.\u201d\n\nOther songs grapple with loneliness, estrangement and regret. In \u201cNo Ordinary Blue,\u201d written with Keith Sykes, he contemplates the aftermath of an argument and separation: \u201cI hope we don\u2019t find it\u2019s the last time we ever say goodbye,\u201d he sings. In \u201cGod Only Knows\u201d \u2014 the completion of a long-ago songwriting collaboration with none other than Phil Spector \u2014 he muses over hidden transgressions, the times \u201cwhen I\u2019m not true/To the things that I say and the things that I do.\u201d\n\nThe album\u2019s quietly desolate centerpiece is \u201cSummer\u2019s End.\u201d It\u2019s a recognition of vanishing time; it\u2019s a plea to a past love. \u201cCome on home,\u201d Mr. Prine sings, and continues, stoically. \u201cNo, you don\u2019t have to be alone.\u201d The folky melody hints at solace and resolution. But his words, and his weary voice, don\u2019t deceive themselves.", "title": "John Prine Returns to Songwriting, Jaunty and Dark, on \u2018The Tree of Forgiveness\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-03 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cMy father wasn\u2019t here to sing those melodies, but they were there. I heard his voice again \u2014 that, and I believed there were artists out there who loved him who could do his words justice.\u201d\n\nThe album opens augustly, with Kris Kristofferson intoning the words to \u201cForever,\u201d an eight-line poem that Cash wrote in 2003, just weeks before he died.\n\n\u201cYou tell me that I must perish/Like the flowers that I cherish/Nothing remaining of my name/Nothing remembered of my fame,\u201d Mr. Kristofferson begins in a craggy baritone. Then, as Willie Nelson lightly fingerpicks the tune to Cash\u2019s 1959 hit, \u201cI Still Miss Someone,\u201d on gut-string guitar, Mr. Kristofferson goes on to assert: \u201cBut the trees that I planted/Still are young/The songs I sang/Will still be sung.\u201d\n\nHope abounds here, an unshakable faith of almost biblical proportions, in the persistence of some form of life \u2014 some sort of enduring relevance \u2014 beyond the grave.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Louder Newsletter Every week, stay on top of the latest in pop and jazz with reviews, interviews, podcasts and more from The New York Times music critics. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe ease with which Mr. Kristofferson and Mr. Nelson inhabit Cash\u2019s poem is hardly surprising given their decades-long friendship with him and their mutual membership in the outlaw country supergroup, the Highwaymen. For some, however, being invited to enter the artistic consciousness of \u2014 and, in a sense, to collaborate with \u2014 someone who is no longer alive, especially someone as imposing as Cash, proved too daunting a proposition, making several prospective contributors decide not to participate.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cEach artist has their own understanding of the creative process, and, for some, this just wasn\u2019t something they would do,\u201d said Mr. Cash. \u201cTo them, it would have been like asking Picasso to pick up a paint brush and finish a painting started by Monet. They\u2019d say, \u2018No way. I can\u2019t go there.\u2019\u201d\n\nMost of the musicians who were asked to contribute, though, relished the chance to do so, among them the perennial Grammy-winner Alison Krauss. Procuring the songwriting skills of her frequent collaborator, Robert Lee Castleman, Ms. Krauss said that she approached her track \u2014 \u201cThe Captain\u2019s Daughter,\u201d a poem rendered as an old Anglo-Celtic-style ballad \u2014 less like she was completing something that was unfinished and more like she was creating something new.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nA similarly inventive approach guided Elvis Costello in his jazz-inflected reimagining of the poem, \u201cI\u2019ll Still Love You.\u201d \u201cI looked at the lyric and, before I could stifle the thought, the melody appeared in my head,\u201d Mr. Costello wrote in an email. \u201cI left Steve Berkowitz sitting at our kitchen table and went downstairs to the piano and had most of the tune completed in about 10 minutes.\u201d\n\n\u201cMy father\u2019s words pulled the artists there,\u201d said Mr. Cash of the inspiration for the music written for the project. Much of it was recorded at the Cash Cabin Studio his father built in Hendersonville, Tenn., some 20 miles northeast of Nashville, four decades ago.\n\n\u201cThe Brad Paisley song,\u201d Mr. Cash added, referring to \u201cGold All Over the Ground,\u201d one of several tracks based on romantic verses that Cash wrote for his wife, June Carter Cash, \u201cis, note for note, what came out of the guitar the moment he read the poem. I was there. I was sitting right there with him.\u201d\n\nEach of the artists who appear on the record identified strongly with the poem he or she set to music, but maybe no one so much as the Soundgarden singer Chris Cornell. Indeed, listening now, it\u2019s hard not to hear his despairing contribution, \u201cYou Never Knew My Mind,\u201d in light of his 2017 suicide.\n\n\u201cI\u2019ve had those dark moments myself, just as my father had dark moments and just as Chris did,\u201d said Mr. Cash. \u201cHe and I both connected with the honesty of those lyrics.\u201d\n\nClosing the album on an aptly mystical note is the country singer Jamey Johnson\u2019s ghostly arrangement of \u201cSpirit Rider,\u201d a poem that evokes just the sort of immortality Cash longs for in \u201cForever.\u201d\n\n\u201cIf you cry out I might hear you on the wind,\u201d Mr. Johnson begins. \u201cAnd if the mountains echo your love to me/Wave your heart and/I\u2019ll be riding back again.\u201d\n\n\u201cJohnny Cash\u2019s music has, and continues to have, a stubborn staying power,\u201d said Mr. Johnson, \u201cand that\u2019s because it preaches. It speaks to our souls. That\u2019s why we keep coming back to it. It feeds us.\u201d", "title": "Johnny Cash\u2019s Poems Get a Second Life as Songs", "authors": ["Bill Friskics-Warren"]} {"date": "2018-04-06 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nThe next selection for the Big City Book Club is \u201cHappiness Is a Choice You Make: Lessons From a Year Among the Oldest Old,\u201d by John Leland, a reporter for The New York Times.\n\nAn online discussion will take place Monday at 6:30 p.m. Eastern time.\n\nTo join the club and receive regular email updates:\n\nnytimes.com/marketing/bigcitybookclub", "title": "Join the Live Online Discussion of \u2018Happiness Is a Choice You Make\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-06 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Kaufmann and Ms. Nylund are both Wagner veterans, but neither has sung this opera before. In the interview, they said that the love duet has challenges unlike any other in Wagner\u2019s major works. Here are edited excerpts from the conversation.\n\nWhat is Wagner saying about love here?\n\nNELSONS The first \u201cTristan\u201d score I had was the \u201cVorspiel\u201d [prelude] in Russian, with a written Wagner quotation, like: \u201cI don\u2019t really believe in love as a feeling. But it is so strong, I want to write an opera about it.\u201d I wonder whether he actually thought that it\u2019s a crazy state of mind which is not healthy. But I find that this goes beyond the norm of what we expect of love. It\u2019s all exaggerated, over the top. It is as if it is not a real thing in life, not possible. I think he doesn\u2019t believe in this himself.\n\nKAUFMANN For that, I think he did it very well.\n\nNYLUND Maybe Wagner was also looking for something. What is love? It has to be something more than this love we speak about, the usual stuff. It\u2019s something more. But it\u2019s not something you can achieve here in your life.\n\nListen to the entire love duet\n\nHow do these ideas play out in the text?\n\nNYLUND I think they are playing some kind of word game.\n\nKAUFMANN This has alliteration and all these games Wagner loved to play, like nine-syllable words that I\u2019ve never heard put together, because sometimes he wanted to express things in a way that probably was never done before. It\u2019s like children that play a game and try to overtake each other with something more. It\u2019s insane. By the end of Act II he\u2019s completely cuckoo.\n\nThat doesn\u2019t sound like romance in other Wagner operas.\n\nKAUFMANN Real love, or even straightforward love, doesn\u2019t exist in Wagner. In \u201cTannh\u00e4user\u201d you have love: one is innocent and pure, and the other is sexual. In \u201cWalk\u00fcre\u201d you have brother-and-sister love. Then you have Siegfried\u2019s love for the old lady, Br\u00fcnnhilde. All kinds of strange loves.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nNYLUND And betrayals.\n\nKAUFMANN Of course opera lives for that. But usually you have the happy innocent moment of love, and then destiny strikes.\n\nNYLUND Which is here in \u201cTristan,\u201d kind of. It makes this moment of happiness even worse.\n\nHow do you pace yourselves?\n\nNYLUND You can never lose control.\n\nNELSONS For the orchestra it is challenging. Wagner writes a lot of \u201cpi\u00f9 forte,\u201d but then you have to drop down without losing any of the intensity. But it\u2019s also like when you run a marathon and there is a moment when you think you can\u2019t anymore \u2014 once you overcome that, then you lose time and go on.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nKAUFMANN It\u2019s not a marathon. It\u2019s like one high jump after another. And you don\u2019t have time in between to come properly back to the ground and accelerate for the next one. It\u2019s just jump, jump, jump. If on just one of those notes you hesitate \u2014 you wait a little bit because you\u2019re not sure where the harmony is or whatever \u2014 you can completely break your neck and lose your voice in a second.\n\nIs it the same with the orchestra?\n\nNELSONS Yes, but I also always think that when conducting or hearing Wagner\u2019s music it actually takes you to another psychic world as well. I feel these emotions that I cannot put into words, and the music has to show that, how you think this is going to explode. It\u2019s orgasmic.\n\nNYLUND It\u2019s actually very dangerous to drive a car and listen. You always drive much too fast.\n\nNELSONS A few conductors have died during \u201cTristan.\u201d The reason is Act II. It might seem relaxing, but actually the heartbeat and the intensity and level of excitement \u2014 it\u2019s so high that you can\u2019t stand it for a long time. So I don\u2019t want yet to die, but I might.\n\nKAUFMANN Do it on Saturday, so at least we\u2019ve done one concert.", "title": "Jonas Kaufmann: Wagner\u2019s \u2018Tristan\u2019 Is \u2018Like a Drug\u2019", "authors": ["Joshua Barone"]} {"date": "2018-04-18 00:00:00", "text": "You\u2019re the only single one in the \u201cQueer Eye\u201d group. What is that like? It makes me acutely aware of how many 14-year-old girls want to be my best friend. O.K.?\n\nI ask because one thing people love about the show is how it explores the ways that men can have intimacy and love in their lives outside romantic partnerships. Yes. I call this the \u201cSex and the City\u201d syndrome. We all think that we need that connection, that all-encompassing love so deep that a mountain or the ocean would be jealous, but connection does come in so many forms.\n\nThe show is filmed in Georgia, and a lot of the guys that you made over seem like jocks \u2014 guys who had friends but weren\u2019t necessarily used to opening up to other men. How did you help them with that? I\u2019m the youngest of three boys, both of the older two are very heterosexual football-watching, married, child-rearing, cornfed Midwestern guys. A lot of times people have asked me, \u201cDid you feel culture shock going to Atlanta?\u201d But I think it was much more shocking for a lot of people in small towns in Georgia to see me \u2014 a 6-foot-2 gay man with a really fierce blow dry and a midriff-baring top \u2014 than it was for me to be there.\n\nBut even though you grew up in a similar environment, you never felt pressure to pass or hide your sexuality? I literally cannot do it. Like, if you picture me at 13, imagine big curly hair, imagine buck teeth, imagine me at 5-foot-4; I could not stop talking about, like, Miss Alabama, who had won the Miss America pageant. I could not pass if you held a gun to my head. I can\u2019t do it.\n\nWas Quincy a good environment to be out? No, not at all. It was a terrible environment. I don\u2019t think it\u2019s overdramatic to say that I was verbally abused, like, very constantly on an hour-to-hour basis, especially in school. Since 2014, Spieth has always seemed to be the one to watch \u2014 even when he has begun the day as an afterthought, as on Sunday.\n\nAll eyes did not turn to him immediately. The attention was on the final-group pairing of Reed and Rory McIlroy, whose Masters aspirations fizzled yet again. But Spieth began his day with birdies on the first and second holes.\n\nThen he birdied the fifth, eighth and ninth holes, capping a torrid opening nine-hole score of five-under-par 31. Spieth was still four strokes behind Reed, who did not appear rattled. Late-season Santa Ana winds had scoured the winter skies to a marine blankness. Surface streets, too, were uncommonly empty as Mr. Peskowitz headed toward the Santa Monica Airport and a choice monthly flea market held there.\n\nMr. Peskowitz, a native New Yorker, was on an expedition to ferret out local experiences: the flea market; a visit to Arcana, a bookstore that is an Aladdin\u2019s cave of rare finds; a trip up the coast to the Reel Inn, a fish shack he called \u201ca little bit of Sheepshead Bay in Malibu.\u201d\n\nLike many Angelenos, Mr. Peskowitz is a recent West Coast transplant and a particularly avid one. And that\u2019s coming from the Oval Office right now.\u201d\n\nMs. Reid\u2019s posts emerged on social media this month via the Twitter user @Jamie_Maz. The massacre occurred during violent attacks on Rohingya Muslims by Myanmar\u2019s military and local Buddhist mobs that drove hundreds of thousands of refugees into Bangladesh in what is broadly seen as calculated ethnic cleansing.\n\nIn uncovering the massacre, the two reporters obtained photos of the 10 victims kneeling before their execution with their hands tied behind their backs. Lowy of the Massachusetts Supreme Judicial Court, was the last step needed for the museum to sell a significant number of works, a plan the Massachusetts attorney general\u2019s office had agreed to in February after a seven-month investigation.\n\nIn his decision, Justice Lowy acknowledged \u201cserious concerns\u201d by some who objected to the planned sale but added that the museum, in Pittsfield, Mass., had demonstrated that selling the works was vital to its survival.\n\n\u201cThe art displayed in the Berkshire Museum enriches the lives of the entire community, and the museum is a reservoir of cultural nourishment for all who visit,\u201d he wrote. \u201cThe museum\u2019s charitable purpose of aiding in the study of art, natural sciences and cultural history must be protected.\u201d", "title": "Judge Allows Berkshire Museum to Sell Rockwell Painting and Other Works", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-19 00:00:00", "text": "WASHINGTON \u2014 A federal judge blocked the Trump administration on Thursday from transferring an American citizen detainee \u2014 who has already been held in Iraq as a suspected Islamic State member for seven months \u2014 to the custody of another country against his will.\n\nThe decision, by Judge Tanya S. Chutkan, of the Federal District Court for the District of Columbia, was a significant ruling in a case that has raised novel questions about national security and individual rights. It was also a milestone in the unusual case of the man, whose name has not been made public, and which will now most likely go before a federal appeals court.\n\nThe man was captured by a Syrian militia in September and turned over to the American military. My wife corrects me in public when I call a color by the \u201cwrong\u201d name. But I believe that our senses are notoriously unreliable \u2014 who can say whose colors are \u201cright\u201d and whose are \u201cwrong?\u201d\n\nMany believe these days that we are living in a computer simulation anyway, so in a sense the colors you see are no more real than everything that has transpired for roughly the last year and a half. That is a comfort, and so, probably false. Instead we must all strive to live in the same reality and honor objective truths. But there is no need for your wife to correct you in public if it makes you uncomfortable. \u201cHelp in the way you are asked to help,\u201d goes the longtime maxim of this court, \u201cnot just in the ways that embarrass your husband.\u201d If she disagrees, you may show her my ruling, printed right here in red and green.", "title": "Judge John Hodgman on Correcting the Color Blind", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-11 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nZack writes: My brother and sister-in-law have two toddlers. The yard backs up against an elementary school, which creates additional problems.\n\nWhile the court appreciates the iron law of not waking a sleeping toddler, and while your sister is probably correct that you truly are a Shrek-like clumsy oaf who constantly knocks over lamps and wardrobes full of silverware every time you lurch to the bathroom, there is a larger law of hospitality at work: Do not make your guests pee in the backyard! I told her my dream when we first started dating, so it shouldn\u2019t surprise her.\n\nIf you\u2019re not currently an astronaut or a billionaire, you aren\u2019t going to space. Unless you\u2019ve been lying to your wife about these things, she knows this. Thus the court orders her to allow your flights of fancy RE: fancy flights. But I also order you, James, to A. work harder to show your wife that you love her more than the empty void, and B. stop hiding in the trunks of Teslas. That spaceship has sailed. I do this because I have a libertarian streak and value self-sufficiency above all. She believes that our lifestyle is actually creating a positive environmental impact. I do feel good about that part of it, but I don\u2019t believe that we actually have any impact on climate change. I seek judgment from the court regarding the true value of our lifestyle.\n\nI appreciate that you haven\u2019t entertained any delusions that your life together in perpetual, smelly, cramped discomfort will magically reverse decades of carbon emissions and energy policy. He left office eight years ago with a record approval rating of 87 percent, and he has held an ample lead in polls for October\u2019s presidential election.\n\nMr. da Silva\u2019s imminent imprisonment also sends a chilling message to other prominent political figures caught up in corruption investigations. The threat of jail time has been one of the most important tools in the large-scale investigation known as Lava Jato, or Car Wash, which has ensnared not only Mr. da Silva, but also dozens of business and political leaders, including President Michel Temer.\n\nLast July, Mr. da Silva was convicted on corruption and money laundering charges and sentenced to almost 10 years in prison. In January, an appeals court unanimously upheld the conviction and increased the sentence to 12 years. Mr. da Silva maintains that the prosecution was an underhanded ploy masterminded by rivals to keep him off the ballot.", "title": "Judge Orders Brazil\u2019s Ex-President \u2018Lula\u2019 to Begin Prison Term on Friday", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-17 00:00:00", "text": "The housing authority will contest the record at a hearing next week, Jasmine Blake, a spokeswoman for the agency, said.\n\nBefore her ruling from the bench, Justice Edmead questioned Nycha\u2019s ability to carry out the inspections without a court order.\n\n\u201cThere is a whole credibility issue if we should leave this to Nycha or a Nycha-selected contractor,\u201d she said.\n\nA spokeswoman for Mayor Bill de Blasio defended the mayor\u2019s role in the lead paint inspections.\n\n\u201cThis administration did not start these problems, but we\u2019re the one that\u2019s fixing them,\u201d Olivia Lapeyrolerie, the spokeswoman, said. \u201cWe restarted inspections in 2016 and they are now happening every single year.\u201d\n\nDuring the hearing, Justice Edmead said she believed Nycha\u2019s inspection failures likely constituted an irreparable harm to children, and she questioned the agency\u2019s competency to remediate the harm.\n\n\u201cWe can\u2019t redo the past,\u201d said one of Nycha\u2019s attorneys, Nancy Harnett, adding that the Housing Authority began taking corrective measures last year.\n\nSince October 2017, a contractor hired by the agency has inspected almost all of the 8,900 apartments where children younger than 6 reside, in compliance with local law, Nycha lawyers said.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box.
