Western policymakers until recently held out hope that Mr. Putin would prove an ally in conflicts in Syria and Iran.\n\nBut beginning in 2014, Western governments began to embrace her central thesis: that a network of corrupt oligarchs centering on Mr. Putin formed the basic structure of his political system.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cWhat wasn\u2019t understood was that it went back to this St. Petersburg inner circle,\u201d said Charles G. Davidson, the executive director of the Kleptocracy Initiative at the Hudson Institute in Washington. \u201cThe contention in Karen\u2019s book that was so controversial at first \u2014 much less so now \u2014 is that there was a plan all along by Putin to take over the place.\u201d\n\nOfficials in Congress and the State Department consulted with Professor Dawisha after the book was published, Mr. Davidson said, and the president of Lithuania, Dalia Grybauskaite, distributed copies of it to members of the European Parliament.\n\nProfessor Dawisha had spent much of her career on more conventional subjects, like Russia\u2019s electoral system, but relished the chance to roll up her sleeves and do primary research, said her husband, a retired distinguished professor of political science at Miami University. Unlike most investigative journalists, he said, she had the advantage of extended time to do the spadework and access to sources who were reluctant to speak to reporters.\n\nKaren Dawisha knew that the project would be controversial, he said, but felt that her professional status allowed her to take the risk.\n\n\u201cIt was not as though she worried she wouldn\u2019t get tenure,\u201d her husband said. \u201cIt was sort of like, \u2018At the end, let me do something I\u2019m really interested in, and not be burdened by the rules of my profession.\u2019 \u201d\n\nKaren Hurst was born on Dec. 2, 1949, in Colorado Springs to the former Paula Keene, a schoolteacher, and Harry Hurst, a jazz pianist. She became interested in Russia after taking a Russian-language course in high school.\n\nShe went on to study Russian politics at the University of Colorado at Boulder and spent her junior year at the University of Lancaster in England, where she met Adeed Dawisha, an Iraqi political scientist who had grown up in Baghdad. She received her doctoral degree at the London School of Economics and won a full professorship at the University of Maryland at College Park before joining Miami University in 2000.\n\nShe and her husband both retired in September 2016.\n\nProfessor Dawisha was the author or co-author of six books before \u201cPutin\u2019s Kleptocracy,\u201d including \u201cEastern Europe, Gorbachev, and Reform: The Great Challenge\u201d (1988) and \u201cSoviet Foreign Policy Towards Egypt\u201d (1979).\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn addition to her husband, she is survived by her daughter, Nadia Dawisha; her son, Emile; and a grandson.\n\nEven after she learned she had cancer, Professor Dawisha remained intensely engaged in discussions about Russia, and received invitations to speak at conferences even in the final months of her life, her husband said.\n\n\u201cIt made her happy, but also disappointed,\u201d Adeed Dawisha said. \u201cShe would write a very nice reply, and say, \u2018I would love to come, if I get stronger and can fly, but at the moment I am not able.\u2019 They would write back and say, \u2018We don\u2019t take your response as a decline, we will just keep it open.\u2019 \u201d", "title": "Karen Dawisha, 68, Dies; Traced Roots of Russian Corruption", "authors": ["Ellen Barry"]} {"date": "2018-04-22 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nDr. Kathleen Marie Fenn and Joseph John Scala were married April 21 at St. Thomas More, the Roman Catholic chapel at Yale University in New Haven. The Rev. Karl Davis, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.\n\nThe bride, 30, is a first-year fellow in hematology and oncology at Columbia University Medical Center in New York. She graduated from Yale, from which she also received a medical degree.\n\nShe is the daughter of Carol A. Fenn of Oxford, Conn., and the late Robert J. Fenn. The bride\u2019s mother is associate professor and chair of the department of chemistry at Quinnipiac University in Hamden, Conn. Her father retired as a research chemist for Arch Chemicals in Cheshire, Conn.\n\nThe groom, 31, is a vice president of the Garrison Investment Group in New York. He graduated from Amherst College.\n\nHe is the son of Carol K. Scala and Joseph C. Scala of Pequannock, N.J. The groom\u2019s mother is a certified public accountant at the Professional Economic Growth Group, a financial services firm in Edison, N.J. His father is a software engineer for Crestron Electronics, a technology company in Rockleigh, N.J.\n\nThe couple met in San Francisco in 2011 while both were visiting friends from college who happened to be dating each other.", "title": "Kathleen Fenn, Joseph Scala", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-11 00:00:00", "text": "LONDON \u2014 Depending on whom you ask, the director Katie Mitchell is either a guiding light or a destructive force of the British stage. Though she mostly works abroad now, her staging of the new opera \u201cLessons in Love and Violence\u201d \u2014 composed by George Benjamin and written by Martin Crimp \u2014 opens at the Royal Opera House here on May 10. It\u2019s a story of the medieval King Edward II\u2019s relationship with a young man.\n\nBackstage, between rehearsals, Ms. Mitchell, 53, spoke about her career, sitting next to a modern set with dark blue paneling and an Ikea-style double bed. The following conversation has been edited and condensed.\n\nWhy did you accept this commission?\n\nI very much love working with George and Martin. They make amazing operas, so who would say no? It\u2019s a really exciting reimagining of a bit of English history, with exceptional music.\n\nYou often like to reinterpret plays. Are operas more constraining?\n\nDifferent art forms have different constraints. When you\u2019re working on a new opera and you\u2019re doing the first production, you are really wanting to realize the vision of the person who wrote the text and the person who composed it. You could call that constraint. I would just say that\u2019s a given circumstance.", "title": "Katie Mitchell on \u2018Lessons in Love and Violence,\u2019 and More", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-18 00:00:00", "text": "GEOFFREY L. WERTIME, NEW YORK\n\nTo the Editor:\n\nYour April 8 print edition had three articles about housing: the front-page story about evictions; an editorial, \u201cAmerica\u2019s Federally Financed Ghettos\u201d; and \u201cThe Gendered Politics of New York\u2019s Emasculator in Chief,\u201d by Ginia Bellafante (Big City column), which discusses Gov. Andrew Cuomo\u2019s comments about public housing in New York City. These are related.\n\nFederal, state and local governments created and maintain racially separate and unequal residential communities, and they provide far too few housing subsidies \u2014 enough for just one in four eligible, needy households.\n\nAs a society, we provide only a fig leaf of support. We condemn children and parents to be poisoned by lead and mold in federally financed housing. We pretend that evictions are part of a \u201cjustice\u201d system, but no justice is provided to the poor by anyone.\n\nThe solution to these housing problems is a commitment to a fourfold increase in housing subsidies and true housing choice, as well as a determined effort to eliminate racial discrimination and segregation in housing. Absent these solutions, we should expect the whirlwind we have created.\n\nFLORENCE WAGMAN ROISMAN\n\nINDIANAPOLIS\n\nThe writer is a law professor at Indiana University.\n\nTo the Editor:\n\nYour editorial correctly criticizes decades of housing policies that encouraged racial segregation. Unfortunately, some government officials and public-minded lawyers use these critiques to thwart efforts to restore low-income communities.", "title": "Opinion | Keeping a Roof Over More Heads", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-10 00:00:00", "text": "After a night of celebrating with teammates, Murdoch, in the early morning hours, went into the kitchen of the Angel Hotel in Cardiff seeking further refreshment.\n\nThere he encountered a security guard who, several All Blacks later reported, was clearly spoiling for a fight. There are conflicting accounts as to what was said and done next, but there was little doubt that the brawny Murdoch had gratified the guard\u2019s wish and left him with a black eye.\n\nGiven the guard\u2019s provocation, most teammates expected Murdoch to face limited disciplinary action. Instead he was ordered to leave the tour and go home. His teammates accused the tour manager, Ernie Todd, who was struggling with the cancer that would kill him, of caving in to pressure from British officials and the news media.\n\nTo this day Murdoch remains the only All Black to have been sent home from an international tour.\n\nBut Murdoch, in fact, did not go home. Issued with a ticket back to New Zealand, he got off the plane in Singapore and diverted to Australia \u2014 to the city of Darwin, on the northern coast, the gateway to the vast, sparsely populated Northern Territory.\n\nPhoto\n\nAnd there, for all intents and purposes, he disappeared. He \u201cwent bush,\u201d as the Australians say. He became a rugby version of Bigfoot and the subject of a play, his legend growing in inverse proportion to the confirmed sightings of him.\n\nIndeed, the world outside the drilling sites and sheep stations of the Outback heard about him only a handful of times and not at all after 2001. Until, that is, on March 31, when the All Blacks, having received word from members of his family, announced on its Twitter feed that Murdoch had died the day before at 74.\n\nDoug Baughan, the chairman of Zingari Richmond, the club for which Murdoch once played in his home city, Dunedin, said of the death that \u201cthe exact circumstances are not yet clear\u201d \u2014 a statement that could have applied to almost the last 46 years of Murdoch\u2019s life.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nKeith Murdoch was born in Dunedin on Sept. 9, 1943. He was educated at King Edward Technical College and played his first adult rugby match for Zingari Richmond before breaking onto the Otago team in 1964. Vying to join the vaunted All Blacks, he played in several trials, but it wasn\u2019t until 1970 \u2014 when he toured with Otago in South Africa \u2014 that he was invited to join the national team.\n\nThe Wales match was his third and last international contest for the All Blacks.\n\nAfter \u201cgoing bush,\u201d Murdoch dropped from sight until the late 1970s, when Terry McLean, the dean of New Zealand\u2019s rugby writers, tracked him down. McLean came upon him at an oil-drilling site near Perth, capital of the state of Western Australia, only to be advised, firmly and crisply, what he should do to preserve life and limb.\n\n\u201cI got back on the bus,\u201d McLean wrote.\n\nMurdoch was reported to have returned briefly to New Zealand a few years later, and to have rescued a child from drowning in a swimming pool. But he was soon back in Australia.\n\nIn 1990, Margot McRae, a journalist who was then working as a television researcher, found Murdoch working on a farm in a remote part of Queensland, in northeastern Australia. She found him more receptive than McLean had, describing him as \u201cvery happy in himself.\u201d But she likened extracting information from him during a 45-minute conversation, conducted entirely off-camera, as \u201cgetting blood from a stone.\u201d\n\nShe quoted him as saying, \u201cI don\u2019t need to tell my story to anyone.\u201d\n\nMcRae went on to write a play about him, \u201cFinding Murdoch,\u201d which had its premiere in Wellington, New Zealand, in 2007.\n\nMurdoch resurfaced publicly for the final time in 2001, following the death of a 20-year-old man who had last been seen trying to break into Murdoch\u2019s home in Tennant Creek, in the Northern Territory. After being questioned twice by the police and called to testify at an inquest, he broke his media silence to insist that he had been called purely as a witness. No charges were filed for lack of evidence, the authorities said, and the investigation was closed in 2002.\n\nThe rugby historian Lindsay Knight once wrote of Murdoch, \u201cNo All Black has been more controversial, more enigmatic and more tragic.\u201d", "title": "Keith Murdoch, Rugby Bruiser Who Vanished in the Outback, Is Dead at 74", "authors": ["Huw Richards"]} {"date": "2018-04-17 00:00:00", "text": "WOOLFE There have been so many missed opportunities. The year after it turned down Ellington \u2014 the main Pulitzer board rejected the music jury\u2019s recommendation \u2014 it could have given the regular prize to Coltrane\u2019s \u201cA Love Supreme.\u201d How about Joni Mitchell\u2019s \u201cBlue,\u201d which could have won in 1972 \u2014 she\u2019s Canadian and therefore ineligible, but remember, this is my fantasy world \u2014 over a decade before the prize finally got around to recognizing a female composer? Philip Glass, never quite beloved in the academic realm, remains Pulitzer-less. And I\u2019ll just leave this right here: Kanye.\n\nYou could play these games forever. It is belated and necessary that the award widen to encompass a fuller picture of what music is. But if that widening further marginalizes noncommercial work \u2014 which doesn\u2019t view itself as exclusive but simply as endangered in an economic system that conspires against it \u2014 something important will be lost. Responsible eclecticism is what I\u2019d want going forward from Pulitzer juries, for whom the \u201cDAMN.\u201d award will hopefully be freeing in the best sense.\n\nPARELES What were the pieces from the other two finalists, Ted Hearne and Michael Gilbertson?\n\nWOOLFE Like Mr. Lamar, who\u2019s 30, these guys are strikingly young. Mr. Gilbertson, 30 as well, wrote a string quartet that veers from glassy to robust, and Mr. Hearne, 35, wrote \u201cSound From the Bench,\u201d a cantata for chamber choir, electric guitars and drums. Like Mr. Lamar\u2019s album, the finalists are politically charged: Mr. Hearne, always socially conscious, here mashes up texts from Supreme Court decisions to suggest the ambiguities of identity and humanity. (A corporation has speech, you say?) And Mr. Gilbertson has said that he adjusted his initial sketches for his quartet after the 2016 election, making them \u201cmore introspective and comforting.\u201d Almost as significant as Mr. Lamar\u2019s win, for me, is the trio taken together: a new generation, turning the world around it into music.\n\nPARELES I\u2019ll have to put them in a playlist. I\u2019m not suggesting that the Pulitzers mirror the Top 10 or the Grammys. (Please, no.) And next year, sure, give the prize to an album that sold 11 copies after a lone college gig somewhere. But I think we\u2019re seeing a shifting perspective on the way contemporary classical and jazz composition often draw on the ideas of hip-hop or world music or pop, as if to elevate them by carrying them into the concert hall.\n\nAccording to the Pulitzer reporting, \u201cDAMN.\u201d got added to consideration when the jury was looking into a composition with hip-hop influences, and decided to go to the source \u2014 where the ideas, in this case, are even stronger, both rawer and smarter. The prize citation praises \u201cDAMN.\u201d for its \u201cvernacular authenticity and rhythmic dynamism,\u201d which to me has a whiff of condescension \u2014 there\u2019s all sorts of brainpower and artifice in there, too \u2014 but let\u2019s enjoy the win. Regarding noncommercial outreach, Mr. Lamar often collaborates with first-rate, innovative jazz musicians, like Kamasi Washington, who not only are happy to work with him but also benefit \u2014 in their own audience growth \u2014 from showing up in his album credits.", "title": "Kendrick Lamar Shakes Up the Pulitzer Game: Let\u2019s Discuss", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-16 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cDAMN.,\u201d which featured Rihanna and U2, along with kinetic production from Sounwave and Mike WiLL Made-It, among others, topped the charts and was among last year\u2019s most-streamed albums, while also tackling thorny issues both personal and political, including race, faith and the burdens of commercial success. Though his work is often serious \u2014 and searing \u2014 Mr. Lamar, a dense and bruising lyricist, has managed to become a pop-cultural juggernaut as well, performing during halftime of this year\u2019s college football national championship and overseeing the soundtrack for \u201cBlack Panther.\u201d\n\nThe music finalists, selected by a five-person jury and then presented to the board for a winner selection, also included the composer Michael Gilbertson\u2019s \u201cQuartet\u201d and the singer and composer Ted Hearne\u2019s \u201cSound From the Bench.\u201d\n\nDavid Hajdu, one of the music jurors this year and a critic for The Nation, said that the group considered more than 100 compositions, including \u201csome pieces of classical music that drew upon hip-hop as a resource,\u201d leading to a philosophical discussion among the jurors about what could be considered.\n\n\u201cThat led us to put on the table the fact that this sphere of work\u201d \u2014 rap music \u2014 \u201chas value on its own terms and not just as a resource for use in a field that is more broadly recognized by the institutional establishment as serious or legitimate,\u201d he said.\n\nWhen someone mentioned Mr. Lamar\u2019s \u201cDAMN.,\u201d there was \u201cquite a lot of enthusiasm for it,\u201d Mr. Hajdu said, though some members of the jury were less familiar with hip-hop than others. (The jury also included the violinist Regina Carter; Paul Cremo of the Met Opera commissioning program; Farah Jasmine Griffin, a Columbia professor of English and African-American studies; and the composer David Lang.)\n\n\u201cBut we listened to it and there was zero dissent,\u201d Mr. Hajdu said. \u201cA lively and constructive conversation, but no dissent.\u201d\n\nHe added: \u201cIt was a beautiful moment. I left the deliberations on a cloud.\u201d\n\nThe news of the prize sent a jolt through the classical music world, where living composers often struggle to be heard \u2014 competing not only against those who work in more popular genres, but also the long-dead greats who make up the classical canon. Some pooh-poohed Mr. Lamar\u2019s win \u2014 one classical composer called it \u201cinsulting\u201d on his Facebook page \u2014 but many others embraced it.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nCaroline Shaw, a frequent collaborator of Kanye West\u2019s whose \u201cPartita for 8 Voices\u201d won the Pulitzer in 2013, posted a YouTube video of Mr. Lamar on her Twitter feed with one word: \u201cYes.\u201d\n\nMr. Hearne, whose cantata \u201cSound From the Bench\u201d was a finalist, praised the decision to award the Pulitzer to Mr. Lamar, calling him \u201cone of the greatest living American composers, for sure.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Louder Newsletter Every week, stay on top of the latest in pop and jazz with reviews, interviews, podcasts and more from The New York Times music critics. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cThe work that\u2019s on that album is every bit as sophisticated and experimental as any music,\u201d he said in a telephone interview. \u201cThe idea that that\u2019s not classical music, or that\u2019s not experimental music, or that\u2019s not art music is completely unfounded.\u201d\n\nIt was not until 1997 that the Pulitzer Prize for music went even to a jazz work: Wynton Marsalis\u2019s oratorio \u201cBlood on the Fields.\u201d In 1965, the Pulitzer jurors recommended awarding a special citation to Duke Ellington, but were rejected.\n\nMr. Hajdu, the juror, said that in recent years, those behind the Pulitzers have sought to \u201cassertively think and listen more expansively, with more open ears,\u201d pointing to wins in the music category by the experimental jazz musicians Ornette Coleman in 2007 and Henry Threadgill in 2016. Other popular musicians have been recognized by the Pulitzers with special awards for their influence, including Bob Dylan, who also won a Nobel Prize in Literature; Lin-Manuel Miranda\u2019s hip-hop musical \u201cHamilton\u201d won in the Pulitzer drama category two years ago.\n\nAnd while \u201cDAMN.\u201d has sold more than 3.5 million albums, including digital streams, since its release, according to Nielsen, \u201cThere was no talk about recognizing something that was already popular,\u201d Mr. Hajdu said. \u201cJust: \u2018Listen to this \u2014 this is brilliant.\u2019 This is the best piece of music.\u201d", "title": "Kendrick Lamar Wins Pulitzer in \u2018Big Moment for Hip-Hop\u2019", "authors": ["Joe Coscarelli"]} {"date": "2018-04-13 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nFRANKFORT, Ky. \u2014 With the chants of hundreds of teachers ringing in their ears, Kentucky lawmakers voted on Friday to override the Republican governor\u2019s veto of a two-year state budget that increases public education spending with the help of a more than $480 million tax increase.\n\nThe votes came as thousands of teachers rallied at the Capitol, forcing more than 30 school districts to close as the state continued the chorus of teacher protests across the country.\n\nThe two-year state operating budget includes record new spending for public education, fueled by a 50-cent increase in the cigarette tax and a 6 percent sales tax on some services, including home and auto repairs. But Gov. Matt Bevin vetoed the budget and revenue bills, calling the latter \u201csloppy\u201d and \u201cnon-transparent.\u201d He said it would not raise enough money to cover the new spending.\n\nThe veto put Republican lawmakers in a tough position by asking them to vote a second time on a tax increase in an election year. But 57 House Republicans, later joined by just enough Senate Republicans, voted to override.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cWe have to have this revenue to fund our schools,\u201d said Representative Regina Huff, a Republican and middle school special education teacher.", "title": "Kentucky Lawmakers Override Budget Veto in Win for Teachers", "authors": ["The Associated Press"]} {"date": "2018-04-27 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nNAIROBI, Kenya \u2014 The first Kenyan entry ever nominated for an award at the Cannes Film Festival will debut in France in two weeks \u2014 but it is now illegal for Kenyans back home to watch it.\n\nThe Kenya Film Classification Board on Friday banned the film, \u201cRafiki,\u201d a drama about two Kenyan girls who fall in love. Ezekiel Mutua, the board\u2019s chief executive officer, said the film \u201clegitimizes homosexuality against the dominant values, cultures and beliefs of the people of Kenya.\u201d\n\nMr. Mutua said the film board\u2019s ruling did not represent a ban on homosexual content.\n\n\u201cHomosexuality is a reality,\u201d he said. \u201cWhat we are against is the endeavor to show that as a way of life in Kenya.\u201d\n\nIn the film, directed, written and co-produced by Wanuri Kahiu, the girls are separated by their communities, which oppose their relationship.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMs. Kahiu said the film included several scenes of kissing and intimacy between the two girls. The board did not object to those, she said, but asked her to change the ending, which, she said, the board found \u201ctoo hopeful.\u201d She refused.", "title": "Kenya Bans Film About 2 Girls in Love Because It\u2019s \u2018Too Hopeful\u2019", "authors": ["Jina Moore"]} {"date": "2018-04-06 00:00:00", "text": "Kenya Barris, the A-list writer-producer behind the ABC comedy \u201cblack-ish,\u201d has grown frustrated with his home network and is examining the possibility of making an early exit from his contract, according to three people familiar with the negotiations.\n\nMr. Barris, 43, has also begun talks with Netflix, the streaming titan that has poached superproducers like ABC\u2019s Shonda Rhimes and Fox\u2019s Ryan Murphy with eye-popping pay packages and promises of artistic freedom.\n\nMr. Barris\u2019s deteriorating relationship with ABC stems, in part, from the network\u2019s decision to pull an episode of the show that examined race relations in America in pointed fashion, according to the people briefed on the situation, who spoke on the condition of anonymity to discuss behind-the-scenes friction. ABC aired a \u201cblack-ish\u201d rerun in place of the shelved episode on Feb. 27.\n\nA critical hit, \u201cblack-ish\u201d centers on the Johnsons, an upper-middle-class family living in a mostly white suburb. The series has increasingly embraced hot-button story lines centered on race. It has delved into police brutality, the fallout from the election of President Trump and the use of the N-word among children. After users objected, Mr. Huffman had to add a clarification: \u201cTo be perfectly clear, while racism itself isn\u2019t against the rules, it\u2019s not welcome here.\u201d\n\nUber Branches Out\n\nIn Uber\u2019s continuing quest to dominate all non-ambulatory modes of transportation, it reached another milestone this week with the acquisition of Jump Bikes, an electric bike-sharing start-up. The deal, reported by TechCrunch to be for more than $100 million, is the first acquisition made by Dara Khosrowshahi as the company\u2019s chief executive, and it follows a successful bike-sharing test in San Francisco.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Interested in All Things Tech? View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe company is also branching into car rentals, through a partnership with the car-booking service Getaround, and public transportation, with a deal with a mobile ticketing start-up called Masabi. Soon, Uber users will be able to buy bus and train tickets and rent cars inside the Uber app.\n\nNotably, as my colleague Daisuke Wakabayashi pointed out, the Jump Bikes acquisition will be Uber\u2019s first experience with actual inventory. In its core car-hailing business, drivers own their cars and connect them to Uber\u2019s network, but Uber will own the bikes itself, and will need to learn how to manage its own fleet of two-wheeled vehicles.\n\nChina Cracks Down on Bytedance\n\nMy colleague Raymond Zhong had a great story this week about Bytedance, a Chinese internet start-up that has \u201cmastered the art of keeping people glued to their smartphones.\u201d Bytedance, which operates a collection of apps that connect users with news, viral videos and other forms of entertainment, drew the anger of Chinese internet censors.\n\nThe agency ordered Bytedance to shut down Neihan Duanzi, an app for silly videos and joke memes that \u201ccaused strong dislike among internet users,\u201d according to China\u2019s State Administration of Radio and Television. At least two other Bytedance apps have also disappeared from app stores.\n\nIt\u2019s a fascinating look at the opposition faced by Chinese tech start-ups, which makes Facebook\u2019s grilling before Congress look positively mild. And it\u2019s a glimpse of the kind of dilemmas that could await Facebook if it ever does fulfill Mr. Zuckerberg\u2019s long-held goal of getting into China.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u2018Despacito\u2019 Goes M.I.A.\n\nIn devastating news for fans of catchy summer jams, the music video for \u201cDespacito,\u201d the Luis Fonsi and Daddy Yankee song, briefly disappeared from YouTube on Tuesday after hackers broke into the account of Vevo, the company that hosted the video. Other Vevo videos, by artists like Selena Gomez, Drake, Katy Perry and Taylor Swift, were also defaced by hackers calling themselves Prosox and Kuroi\u2019sh.\n\nVevo told The Verge that it was investigating the source of the security breach. Meanwhile, the \u201cDespacito\u201d video, YouTube\u2019s all-time most viewed video, has been restored. Whew.\n\nKevin Roose writes a column called The Shift and is a writer at large for The New York Times Magazine. You can follow him on Twitter here: @kevinroose.", "title": "Kevin\u2019s Week in Tech: Another Facebook-Free Edition", "authors": ["Kevin Roose"]} {"date": "2018-04-06 00:00:00", "text": "First, it\u2019s an unusually clear example of the double-edged nature of artificial intelligence. Google has spent billions of dollars teaching computers to play Go, drive cars and translate languages on the fly. The company has been extremely proud of its advances in machine learning, even releasing some of its tools to the public via open-source frameworks like TensorFlow, which provides a fascinating contrast to what\u2019s happening inside the company now. When its image-classification algorithms are used to spot tumors on radiology scans, Google puts out a press release, and engineers cheer. But when these same types of algorithms are used by the Pentagon to improve the accuracy of drone strikes, it\u2019s a moral outrage.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Interested in All Things Tech? The Bits newsletter will keep you updated on the latest from Silicon Valley and the technology industry. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nYonatan Zunger, a former Google engineer, had an interesting op-ed the other day in The Boston Globe about the \u201creckonings\u201d that various scientific fields have undergone, as the scientists who develop powerful tools begin to see how those tools can be used for evil purposes. He used the examples of the atomic bomb, which forever changed the way that physics was taught in universities, and dynamite, which made chemists aware of the consequences of their expertise. It\u2019s not hard to see A.I. as a similar kind of turning point for computer scientists \u2014 and if it is, the Google-Pentagon issue might be the first of many similar fights.\n\nSecond, the Google-Pentagon incident is a revealing story about the leverage that Silicon Valley engineers have over their companies. Because the labor market for engineers in the Bay Area is so tight, and because companies live and die on their ability to attract and retain talent, these employees have much more say in how a company like Google governs itself than, say, regulators or outside activists. If an antiwar group protests outside Google\u2019s headquarters, it\u2019s an annoyance. But if 3,000 engineers walk out, it\u2019s a crisis. And as the tech industry goes through its moral reckoning, executives of these companies should bear in mind that their biggest risk isn\u2019t regulation, it\u2019s rebellion from within.\n\nAmazon and the Postal Service\n\nI\u2019ve also been following the feud between Amazon and President Trump this week, which has led to a bull market for explainers about the business models of the United States Postal Service. My colleague Nick Wingfield wrote that, contra President Trump, the available evidence suggests that \u201cAmazon has been a boon to the Postal Service.\u201d But Vox\u2019s Jen Kirby added that, because the exact details of the contract between Amazon and the Postal Service aren\u2019t known, it\u2019s possible that President Trump is partly right: \u201cMaybe the U.S.P.S. isn\u2019t actually making the best deals.\u201d Meanwhile, Matt Stoller, a fellow at the Open Markets Institute, says President Trump is \u201cactually right\u201d that Amazon is ripping off the federal government through its U.S.P.S. contracts.\n\nI\u2019m a nonexpert on the subject of parcel shipping, so my opinion on Amazon\u2019s the -U.S.P.S. probably isn\u2019t worth one first-class stamp. But it\u2019s possible, and maybe plausible, that all of these analyses are partly correct \u2014 that the Postal Service benefits from Amazon\u2019s dominance, and that Amazon is getting a sweetheart deal that should be re-examined. Anyway, Amazon\u2019s stock dipped sharply after President Trump started tweeting angry things about it, but it has now recovered to its pre-tweetstorm levels, meaning that investors may be as confused as I am.\n\nThe YouTube Shooting\n\nLast, and most obvious, the horrific shooting at YouTube on Tuesday, which injured three people and left the company badly shaken. As more details have emerged on Nasim Najafi Aghdam, whom the police have identified as the attacker, it has become increasingly clear that this was a new kind of violence \u2014 an act of revenge by an internet creator against the platform that she felt controlled her economic destiny. As my colleagues Nellie Bowles and Jack Nicas wrote, \u201cMs. Aghdam\u2019s complaints echoed what a wide range of YouTube posters \u2014 from self-described animal rights activists like her to right-wing political provocateurs \u2014 have increasingly been protesting over the last year.\u201d\n\nIt\u2019s a tragic reminder that social platforms aren\u2019t just websites anymore. They\u2019re powerful economies unto themselves, and even seemingly minor policy decisions can alter the lives of millions of people, a few of whom might be disturbed enough to act on their darkest impulses.\n\nKevin Roose writes a column called The Shift and is a writer-at-large for The New York Times Magazine. You can follow him on Twitter here: @kevinroose.", "title": "Kevin\u2019s Week in Tech: Extra! Extra! News Beyond Facebook!", "authors": ["Kevin Roose"]} {"date": "2018-04-20 00:00:00", "text": "The company also disclosed, for the first time, the number of Prime subscribers it has: more than 100 million. Those members bought five billion items in 2017, making it the company\u2019s biggest year on record.\n\nWhile the median salary at Facebook, a company full of well-fed engineers, is a whopping $240,430, Amazon\u2019s median worker salary is only $28,446, reflecting its reliance on an army of low-paid workers at its fulfillment centers. Amazon has been criticized for grueling labor conditions and creepy employee-tracking practices, but the workers keep showing up. As a result, Amazon has become America\u2019s second-largest private employer, behind only Walmart.\n\nAs Jason Del Rey at Recode noted, many of Amazon\u2019s fulfillment center employees likely aren\u2019t Prime subscribers, since the service has \u201cskewed way more popular among higher-income households\u201d than among working-class families. Amazon is trying to broaden its appeal beyond the mass affluent by introducing monthly payment plans and discounts for people on government assistance, but there is still room for competition on the lower end of the market. (Personally, I\u2019m fascinated by Wish, the online dollar store that has given American consumers direct access to a flood of cheap goods produced in China.)\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Interested in All Things Tech? View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nOther notable findings from Mr. Bezos\u2019 letter:\n\n\u25a0 Amazon doesn\u2019t allow PowerPoint slides during meetings. \u201cInstead, we write narratively structured six-page memos,\u201d then silently read them before meetings begin, Mr. Bezos wrote.\n\n\u25a0 Mr. Bezos spent a lot of time talking about his standards \u2014 specifically, high ones. \u201cI believe high standards are domain specific,\u201d he wrote, \u201cand that you have to learn high standards separately in every arena of interest.\u201d He continued: \u201cYou can consider yourself a person of high standards in general and still have debilitating blind spots.\u201d\n\n\u25a0 Mr. Bezos gave updates on Amazon\u2019s acquisition of Whole Foods, and said Amazon was working on ways to \u201crecognize Prime members\u201d at Whole Foods checkout counters, which sounds both exciting and extremely creepy.\n\n\u25a0 Mr. Bezos took inspiration from an unlikely source \u2014 a \u201chandstand coach\u201d who helped a friend of his learn how to do a full handstand. The coach, he wrote, warned his friend that realistically, she would need to spend six months practicing. The story taught him that \u201cto achieve high standards yourself or as part of a team, you need to form and proactively communicate realistic beliefs about how hard something is going to be.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nOne thing notably absent from Mr. Bezos\u2019 letter was any mention of HQ2, the company\u2019s much-ballyhooed search for a second headquarters. Amazon officials reportedly visited Newark this month, and have also visited Philadelphia and other finalist cities as they try to make a final decision this year.\n\nAmazon\u2019s economic dominance \u2014 made clear by the staggering facts and figures in Mr. Bezos\u2019 letter \u2014 makes the billions of dollars in tax breaks and incentives that have been offered to Amazon by job-hungry cities look even more ridiculous. If there\u2019s one company that doesn\u2019t need your city\u2019s largess, it\u2019s Amazon.\n\nA few other tech stories of note this week:\n\n\u25a0 Cambridge Analytica, the sketchy political data firm that has been at the center of Facebook\u2019s recent privacy scandal, has sought to develop its own cryptocurrency and conduct an initial coin offering, because of course it has.\n\n\u25a0 Speaking of Facebook, my colleague Sapna Maheshwari reports that its advertising team has been quietly reaching out to big clients, trying to keep them from jumping ship as the social network struggles with its public image. Carolyn Everson, a Facebook ad executive, has reportedly \u201creceived many public messages of support and praise for her leadership on Twitter and on her Facebook page from agency executives and chief marketing officers, including those at General Electric and Toys \u2018R\u2019 Us.\u201d Truly, I am touched.\n\n\u25a0 Marissa Mayer, the former chief executive of Yahoo, emerged from the Witness Protection Program to give an interview to my colleague David Gelles.\n\nKevin Roose writes a column called The Shift and is a writer at large for The New York Times Magazine. You can follow him on Twitter here: @kevinroose.", "title": "Kevin\u2019s Week in Tech: Jeff Bezos Reminds Tech Who\u2019s Boss", "authors": ["Kevin Roose"]} {"date": "2018-04-27 00:00:00", "text": "Twitter\u2019s Good Quarter\n\nTwitter reported its earnings and showed \u2014 for the second straight quarter, and the second time in its history \u2014 that it is capable of turning a profit.\n\nThat profit was minuscule by Facebook standards: just $61 million in the quarter, compared with the $3 billion Facebook pulled in. But the fact that Twitter is in the black at all is enough to stave off the doomsday narrative that once swirled around it.\n\nInterestingly, one of the factors driving Twitter\u2019s growth this time around is strong performance in its data licensing business, which has grown 20 percent year over year.\n\nData licensing \u2014 or, more accurately, data donating \u2014 is the part of Facebook\u2019s business that got it into trouble because of Cambridge Analytica. And although Twitter\u2019s data licensing program is substantively different from Facebook\u2019s \u2014 it collects a narrower set of personal information from users, and licenses only users\u2019 tweets, which are already public \u2014 it\u2019s interesting that Twitter is leaning into the business of making user data available to third parties at the same time that Facebook is leaning out of it. It also creates a dilemma for lawmakers and regulators. If they try to prevent future Cambridge Analytica data leaks by restricting social platforms\u2019 abilities to license data to third-party developers, they could end up hurting Facebook\u2019s rivals more than Facebook.\n\nSnapchat\u2019s Spectacles Do-Over\n\nSnap, the parent company of Snapchat, doesn\u2019t report earnings until next week. But ahead of its report, the company announced a surprising move: a new version of its camera-equipped sunglasses, Spectacles. The first version of Spectacles was famously a commercial flop, leading the company to take a $40 million write-down on unsold pairs.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Interested in All Things Tech? You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nSo why is it trying again?\n\nMark Randall, Snap\u2019s vice president of hardware, told TechCrunch that, as the news site\u2019s writer put it, \u201cthe true purpose of V1 was to get people comfortable wearing and being recorded by a face computer.\u201d Mr. Randall added that the second version of Spectacles would improve on the hardware, while adopting some of the sales and distribution lessons that the company learned the hard way the first time around.\n\nThe more interesting Snap news, to me, was that the company is apparently testing a re-redesigned version of Snapchat that looks \u2026 a lot like the original version. In its previous redesign, Snapchat separated user-generated Snap stories from professional publisher stories on its Discover tab. In the new test version, those stories live together on the Discover tab.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nZoom out a bit, and you can see the bigger shift at work here. After an attempt to distinguish itself from platforms like Instagram and Facebook \u2014 both of which feature algorithmically sorted feeds that intermingle content from your friends and content from celebrities and publishers \u2014 Snap may be finding that users liked Snapchat better when it was more like every other social feed.\n\nYouTube\u2019s Profitable Trust Crisis\n\nYouTube, which has long insisted that it\u2019s not a social network, is yet another example of a social platform\u2019s prospering financially despite deepening mistrust among users.\n\nIts parent company, Alphabet, doesn\u2019t break out YouTube-specific numbers. But in its earnings report this week, the company said overall advertising revenue, which includes YouTube ads, grew 24 percent year over year.\n\nSundar Pichai, Google\u2019s chief executive, also boasted that the company\u2019s algorithms had pulled down millions of YouTube videos that violated the platform\u2019s rules before they were seen by humans. Still, the company clearly has much more work to do. As BuzzFeed News reported this week, YouTube is still host to tons of horrible, offensive and dangerous videos, including a number of bestiality videos apparently aimed at children.\n\nYouTube has tried to address the problem in part by introducing new parental controls, but history tells us that this may be an unwinnable battle. As its algorithms get more sophisticated at detecting objectionable content, the makers of those videos will learn ways to evade the system, and new forms of objectionable videos will appear (at least until journalists find them and point them out).\n\nMore broadly, despite not thinking of itself as a social network, YouTube is perhaps the network that is most similar to Facebook right now, in terms of the challenges it faces and the disconnect between what many of its users want (more active moderation, less objectionable content) and what investors want (more of the same, please!).\n\nI\u2019ve been reading an early copy of Jaron Lanier\u2019s excellent new book, \u201cTen Arguments for Deleting Your Social Media Accounts Right Now.\u201d Mr. Lanier, a well-known technologist who did pioneering work in virtual reality, has become a kind of Cassandra for the tech industry. He says that the current crop of social media giants have become profit-driven behavioral modification machines that undermine truth, destroy empathy and turn their users into jerks, and that until healthier systems emerge, we should all stay off them.\n\nI\u2019m predisposed to disagree with that kind of generalized argument. Despite everything we\u2019ve learned this year, I still believe that social networks, when designed and managed properly, can be a positive force. Moreover, I\u2019m skeptical that getting users to boycott these services is possible, given how addictive they are.\n\nBut it\u2019s not hard to see where Mr. Lanier is coming from, especially during a week like this, when the opposing forces pulling on social networks are clear. Social media companies are being urged to behave more responsibly by users, lawmakers and occasionally their own employees. But investors have no stake in maximizing the long-term health of society. They\u2019re just happy to see growth.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nKevin Roose writes a column called The Shift and is a writer at large for The New York Times Magazine. You can follow him on Twitter here: @kevinroose.", "title": "Kevin\u2019s Week in Tech: Let\u2019s Check In on the Other Social Networks, Shall We?", "authors": ["Kevin Roose"]} {"date": "2018-04-18 00:00:00", "text": "In the coming months, there are a number of important dates at which the Trump administration has to decide whether it wants to retreat, delay, negotiate, fight on or escalate. To help assess the stance of the United State in this trade standoff, DealBook has compiled these dates.\n\nBefore looking ahead, it\u2019s important to note that the Trump administration has imposed new restrictions on some countries.\n\nOn March 23, tariffs were applied to imports of steel and aluminum from countries that were not granted an exemption. Those currently enjoying the reprieve are Canada, Mexico, Australia, South Korea, Brazil and members of the European Union.\n\nThe next big deadline is May 1, which is when the exemptions on steel and aluminum tariffs expire. Between now and then, members of the Trump administration have to decide whether they want to take an action that could upset staunch allies of the United States. The United States may extend the exemptions if discussions occur or make them permanent if, say, countries agree to side with the United States in its trade offensive against China.\n\nBut holding off on the steel and aluminum tariffs for a long time might embolden China, which the United States has targeted with separate actions that focus on China alone. These include two sets of tariffs, one on $50 billion of goods and a threated second set on products worth $100 billion, as well as an action at the World Trade Organization.\n\nThe administration can\u2019t announce a final list of goods for the $50 billion of tariffs until May 22. That is when the period for public responses to the tariffs ends. Trade law gives President Trump the power to then impose the tariffs quickly, but it also provides him significant flexibility on the timing.\n\nThe trade legislation states that the United States would have to act within 12 months of the date at which the United States trade representative initiated its investigation of Chinese trade practices. This implies the Trump administration has until August 18.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut the legislation suggests it has even more latitude. Once the administration has determined what actions it will take, it can in theory delay putting them into effect by 180 days. Hypothetically, President Trump could stretch things into early next year.\n\nMuch remains up in the air, though.\n\nMr. Trump has the power to pursue trade policy almost at whim. He could argue for extended exemptions for Canada and Mexico, which are also involved in negotiations over the North American Free Trade Agreement. South Korea may also end up with significant tariff exemptions as a result of a trade agreement that country is apparently close to forging with the United States. And that action against China at the World Trade Organization could take years.\n\n\u2014 Peter Eavis\n\nPhoto\n\nMorgan Stanley has done it. Sort of.\n\nOne of Wall Street\u2019s biggest (and nerdiest) contests is between Goldman Sachs and Morgan Stanley. With each quarter\u2019s earnings, the banks disclose their return on equity, a number that shows the profitability of the equity capital they have deployed in their businesses.\n\nGoldman usually wins. From 2010 until 2017, Morgan Stanley\u2019s annual return on equity was stronger in only two of those eight years, and those two years were not good ones for Wall Street overall.\n\nA big test was going to be how these banks fared in unambiguously good conditions, like those that existed in the first quarter of this year, when trading activity was strong and the economic outlook bullish. Goldman\u2019s return on equity in the first quarter was 15.4 percent, compared to 14.9 percent for Morgan Stanley.\n\nIn other words, Goldman clinched the bragging rights. But with some rounding, they both achieved a 15 percent return.\n\n\u2014 Peter Eavis\n\nRecord profit for Morgan Stanley\n\nThe Wall Street firm reported record revenue and profit for the first quarter driven by a jump in trading and the new tax law.\n\n\u2022 Morgan Stanley reported profits of $2.58 billion, up 40 percent from a year ago. That also topped analysts\u2019 expectations of $2.2 billion in earnings, according to Thomson Reuters.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u2022 Earnings per share came in at $1.45, beating the $1.25 analysts had expected.\n\n\u2022 Revenues increased 13.7 percent to $11.08 billion. Analysts expected revenue of $10.36 billion.\n\n\u2022 Total trading revenue rose 26 percent to $4.40 billion.\n\n\u2022 Equity trading revenue increased to $2.6 billion, up 30 percent from a year ago\n\n\u2022 Fixed-income trading revenue rose 9 percent to $1.8 billion.\n\n\u2022 Fees from investment banking rose 7 percent to $1.51 billion.\n\n\u2022 Fees from advising on mergers and acquisitions gained 16 percent to $574 million.\n\n\u2022 Underwriting revenues rose 2 percent.\n\n\u2022 Wealth management revenues increased 8 percent to $2.37 billion.\n\nThe U.S. debt profile could be worst than Italy\u2019s by 2023.\n\nBloomberg reports that the latest data from the International Monetary Fund projects U.S. debt-to-GDP ratio to \u201cwiden to 116.9 percent by 2023 while Italy\u2019s is seen narrowing to 116.6 percent.\u201d\n\nThe I.M.F. numbers are just the latest highlighting the negative impact the $1.5 trillion in tax cuts could have on the fiscal outlook of the United States.\n\nPhoto\n\nSo much for the U.S. rejoining the Trans-Pacific Partnership\n\nThat seems out \u2014 for now, anyway, given President Trump\u2019s tweet from Mar-a-Lago yesterday: \u201cToo many contingencies and no way to get out if it doesn\u2019t work.\u201d Here are a few takeaways about the end of a public flirtation:\n\n\u2022 Trade partners and allies are again left wondering about the White House\u2019s trade policy. That\u2019s especially pertinent as the U.S. continues to feud with China; yesterday the F.C.C. blocked wireless carriers from using federal subsidies to buy Chinese telecom equipment.\n\n\u2022 The tweet put Prime Minister Shinzo Abe of Japan, who\u2019s at Mar-a-Lago with Mr. Trump, in an awkward position. Japan has been leery of a bilateral trade pact with the U.S., since it risks having to make more concessions than in the TPP with little hope of much in return. Tokyo would like exemptions from potential U.S. tariffs, however.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nFact-check: Despite Mr. Trump\u2019s tweet, South Korea isn\u2019t in the TPP.\n\nElsewhere in trade: China\u2019s plans to relax foreign ownership rules for carmakers could be great for Elon Musk and bad for Warren Buffett. Or, in Mr. Musk\u2019s case, maybe not.\n\nPhoto\n\nWill other tech giants take a turn in the hot seat?\n\nFacebook has born the brunt of fury over the tech industry\u2019s practices, particularly after the Cambridge Analytica scandal shed light on how user data is shared. But another behemoth\u2019s practices could come under scrutiny, particularly if Democrats take back Congress in the midterm elections.\n\nMore from Mark Bergen and Ben Brody of Bloomberg:\n\nTwo years ago, Google altered its offerings in a way that makes it more vulnerable to data-sharing scrutiny. Advertisers using its DoubleClick system to target and measure ads could start anonymously combining web-tracking data (from \u201ccookies\u201d that follow users online) with potent Google information including search queries, location history, phone numbers and credit card information. Until then, Google had steadfastly kept that data separate.\n\nAnother thought on Google\u2019s weaknesses, from our colleague Mike Isaac:\n\nPhoto\n\nElsewhere in privacy: Facebook has previewed how its privacy policies are changing to comply with European regulations. Those same rules have emboldened the company to resume face-scanning photographs in Europe \u2014 if consumers opt in. Eduardo Porter argues that Facebook is creepy, but still potentially good for you.\n\nPhoto\n\nHow will the Supreme Court rule in the state sales tax case?\n\nJustices appeared split yesterday over whether U.S. states could force online retailers to collect sales tax somewhere they had no physical presence.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story The All-New DealBook Newsletter Our columnist Andrew Ross Sorkin and his Times colleagues help you make sense of major business and policy headlines \u2014 and the power-brokers who shape them. Alexander Nix, appears to be on hold.)\n\nMore from Nathaniel Popper and Nicholas Confessore of the NYT:\n\nThe goal of Cambridge Analytica\u2019s own coin offering? Raise money that would pay for the creation of a system to help people store and sell their online personal data to advertisers, Brittany Kaiser, a former Cambridge Analytica employee, said in an interview. The idea was to protect information from more or less what the firm did when it obtained the personal data of up to 87 million Facebook users.\n\nExtra credit: Cambridge Analytica helped Dragon Coin, a virtual currency for gamblers linked to a notorious Macau gangster whose street name was \u201cBroken Tooth.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe tech flyaround\n\n\u2022 The Supreme Court will not decide whether federal prosecutors can force Microsoft to turn over digital data stored outside the U.S. (NYT)\n\n\u2022 Harbor, a blockchain platform for creating securities based on real-world assets, raised $28 million in a round led by Founders Fund. (BuzzFeed)\n\n\u2022 IBM posted a second consecutive quarter of higher revenue after nearly six years of decline, an indication that Ginni Rometty\u2019s turnaround may be taking hold. (WSJ)\n\n\u2022 The cryptocurrency exchange Kraken has stopped trading services for Japanese residents after regulators there stepped up oversight. (WSJ)\n\nPhoto\n\nDid Goldman\u2019s trading business perform too well?\n\nThe Wall Street firm\u2019s first-quarter earnings raise a familiar dilemma. As Goldman moves to diversify its operations beyond high-risk trading \u2014 one notable example is its Marcus online bank \u2014 the strength of its trading shop in the first quarter threatens to overshadow those efforts, Peter Eavis writes.\n\nStock and bond markets are unpredictable, even in good times, so the helpful trading conditions this quarter may not last. What can Goldman\u2019s senior executives offer to persuade investors that the bank far more than a trading house? Please email thoughts and suggestions to bizday@nytimes.com.", "title": "Key Dates to Watch in China-U.S. Trade Dispute: DealBook Briefing", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-25 00:00:00", "text": "The travel ban is not the only one of the Trump administration\u2019s immigration policies under challenge. Several federal judges, including one on Tuesday, have blocked its efforts to end a separate program that shields some undocumented young adults from deportation. Those cases on the program, called Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals, or DACA, are also likely to reach the Supreme Court.\n\nMr. Trump\u2019s first travel ban, issued in January 2017, was promptly blocked by courts around the nation. A second version, issued two months later, fared little better, though the Supreme Court allowed part of it to go into effect in June when it agreed to hear the Trump administration\u2019s appeals from two appeals court losses. But the Supreme Court dismissed those appeals in October after the second ban expired.\n\nThe current ban initially restricted travel from eight countries \u2014 Iran, Libya, Syria, Yemen, Somalia, Chad, Venezuela and North Korea \u2014 six of which were predominantly Muslim. Chad was recently removed from the list.\n\nThe restrictions vary in their details, but, for the most part, citizens of the countries are prohibited from immigrating to the United States, and many are barred from working, studying or vacationing here.\n\nIn December, in a sign that the Supreme Court may uphold the latest order, the court allowed it to go into effect as the case moved forward. The decision effectively overturned a compromise in place since June, when the court said travelers with connections to the United States could continue to travel here notwithstanding restrictions in an earlier version of the ban.\n\nJustices Sonia Sotomayor and Ruth Bader Ginsburg dissented from the December ruling.\n\nHawaii, several individuals and a Muslim group challenged the latest ban\u2019s limits on travel from the predominantly Muslim nations; they did not object to the portions concerning North Korea and Venezuela. They prevailed before a Federal District Court in Hawaii and before a three-judge panel of the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit, in San Francisco.\n\nThe appeals court ruled that Mr. Trump had exceeded the authority that Congress had given him over immigration and had violated a part of the immigration laws barring discrimination in the issuance of visas.", "title": "Key Justices Seem Skeptical of Challenge to Trump\u2019s Travel Ban", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-01 00:00:00", "text": "President Trump was sidelined as North Korea\u2019s leader, Kim Jong-un, made a secret visit to President Xi Jinping of China. The unexpected meeting took place ahead of Mr. Trump\u2019s plans for talks with Mr. Kim about denuclearization of the Korean Peninsula.", "title": "Opinion | Kim Jong-un Does the Locomotion", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-17 00:00:00", "text": "SEOUL, South Korea \u2014 Kim Jong-un, North Korea\u2019s leader, plans to formally announce his willingness to denuclearize his country when he meets with President Moon Jae-in of South Korea this month, an official from the South said on Tuesday.\n\nThe statement is expected to be part of a joint declaration that the two leaders will adopt when they meet on April 27, said Mr. Moon\u2019s chief of staff, Im Jong-seok. Negotiators from both Koreas have agreed on a rough framework for the joint declaration, he said.\n\nThey are still discussing other aspects of the joint statement, such as whether the two Koreas would commit to holding summit meetings on a regular basis, Mr. Im said. South Korea is also trying to convince North Korea that Mr. Moon and Mr. Kim should hold a joint news conference at the end of their meeting in Panmunjom, the so-called truce village on the inter-Korean border.\n\nIf necessary, Mr. Moon\u2019s national security adviser, Chung Eui-yong, and his spy chief, Suh Hoon, will visit the North Korean capital, Pyongyang, again to resolve any significant issues before the summit meeting, Mr. Im said.", "title": "Kim Jong-un Plans Formal Nod to Denuclearization, South Korea Says", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-27 00:00:00", "text": "Other alternatives? Last July, I asked then-C.I.A. Director Mike Pompeo to suggest some. \u201cFrom the administration\u2019s perspective,\u201d he replied, \u201cthe most important thing we can do is \u2026 separate capacity, and someone who might well have intent, and break those two apart.\u201d\n\nIt was an unmistakable call for regime change, and Pompeo promised that the intelligence community would provide \u201ca wide range of options for the president about how we might go about that.\u201d Apparently they came up short. Hence the interest in negotiation.\n\nYet the fact that all the options are bad does not, as some argue, make negotiations the \u201cleast bad\u201d among them. Sanctions relief and economic concessions help keep the Kim regime in power and in business, funding the nuclear programs those concessions are supposed to stop.\n\nNegotiations also dignify and legitimize a regime that, alongside Syria\u2019s Bashar al-Assad, is the worst violator of human rights in the world today. Spare a thought, while watching the two Korean presidents behave like old friends, for the 80,000 to 130,000 prisoners enslaved in Pyongyang\u2019s gulags.\n\nWorst of all, the negotiations will tempt Trump to indulge his worst isolationist impulses. Last month, he again hinted that he would withdraw U.S. troops from South Korea if he doesn\u2019t get better trading terms. That would have been music to Kim\u2019s ear, since a fundamental goal of North Korean policy is to drive a wedge between Seoul and Washington.\n\nA peace deal between the United States and North Korea to establish formal relations and end the Korean War would be hailed, even by many liberals, as a signal diplomatic triumph. Fox News would clamor for Trump to be awarded a Nobel Peace Prize. But it would advance a central aim of North Korean and Chinese foreign policy by undercutting the rationale for maintaining sizable U.S. forces in South Korea.\n\nThat might be a worthwhile price to pay in exchange for the complete, verifiable and irreversible denuclearization of the North. But as The Washington Post\u2019s Richard Cohen aptly noted the other day, \u201cNorth Korea without a nuclear arsenal is like Saudi Arabia without oil.\u201d It isn\u2019t going to happen unless Kim has lost his taste for power or gained a sense of remorse. That wasn\u2019t the confident young dictator who stepped into South Korea yesterday.", "title": "Opinion | Kim Jong-un Sells a Peace Bridge", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-22 00:00:00", "text": "Movement as the Trump administration prepares for a summit between the president and North Korea\u2019s leader and sizes up a potential peace treaty between the two Koreas. On Saturday, Kim Jong-un announced he would not launch any more nuclear tests. It remains unclear if he\u2019ll surrender the country\u2019s weapons arsenal.", "title": "Opinion | Kim Jong-un Strings America Along", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-15 00:00:00", "text": "SEOUL, South Korea \u2014 The North Korean leader Kim Jong-un offered a personal welcome to a senior envoy from Beijing, feting him and a visiting Chinese art troupe with a gala dinner, the North\u2019s state-run news media reported on Sunday, as the estranged Communist allies continued efforts to mend ties.\n\nMr. Kim exchanged \u201cdeep thoughts\u201d on international issues of concern to North Korea and China and vowed to improve bilateral relations during the meeting on Saturday with the senior Chinese diplomat, Song Tao, the Korean Central News Agency reported.\n\nThe report did not say if they discussed the North Korean dictator\u2019s upcoming summits with President Trump and President Moon Jae-in of South Korea to defuse a standoff over the North\u2019s development of nuclear bombs and ballistic missiles.\n\nThe warm reception was a reciprocal gesture. Last month, when Mr. Kim visited China to meet with President Xi Jinping on his first trip abroad as North Korea\u2019s leader, it was Mr. Song who greeted him on the border and accompanied him in his special train to Beijing. That surprise visit by the secretive Mr. Kim was apparently an effort to improve ties with China, which had also cooled over the North\u2019s weapons programs, ahead of the summits.", "title": "Kim Jong-un of North Korea Fetes Chinese Envoy as Ties Warm", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-20 00:00:00", "text": "_____\n\nPhoto\n\n\u2022 If the world economy is looking so great, why are global policymakers so gloomy?\n\nWorries about trade and debt are the top concerns for officials, above, gathering in Washington for the I.M.F. and World Bank meetings. Beyond the threat of a trade war, they are worried about growing financial imbalances, like Germany\u2019s export surplus, that could spur the next downturn.\n\nThe Trump administration\u2019s policies have effectively crippled the Export-Import Bank, an 84-year-old Washington institution.\n\n_____\n\nPhoto\n\n\u2022 \u201cShut up, Satan!\u201d\n\nYelling at the devil is just one way to rid a friend or loved one of demonic possession, or so 300 Roman Catholics, above, learned in an exorcism master class in Rome. [The New York Times]\n\n\u2022 In Spain, the supermarket chain Carrefour introduced a new range of insect-based foods, including spicy chili buffalo worms and smoked crickets. New E.U. regulations paved the way for such products. [The Guardian]\n\n\u2022 The Cannes Film Festival ended a ban on Lars von Trier, the Danish film director, whom it declared persona non grata in 2011 for remarks about Hitler. [The New York Times]\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u2022 Brexit: The E.U. rejected British proposals for solving the Northern Ireland border issue, the latest challenge for Prime Minister Theresa May\u2019s government as it tries to prepare for leaving the bloc. [Politico]\n\nSmarter Living\n\nTips, both new and old, for a more fulfilling life.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u2022 Recipe of the day: Close out the week with a sheet-pan meal of roasted chicken, potatoes, arugula and a garlic yogurt.\n\n\u2022 Here\u2019s how to help colleagues who don't know they need help.\n\n\u2022 Leftovers? Make a savory tart.\n\nNoteworthy\n\nPhoto\n\n\u2022 Can dirt save the world? Farming could pull carbon out of the air and into the soil, but that would mean a new way of thinking about how to tend the land.\n\n\u2022 In memoriam: Rob Matthews, 56, a blind British runner who won eight Paralympic gold medals and broke 22 world records. \u201cRunning turned back the fear,\u201d he said.\n\n\u2022 A Frenchman has become the first person in the world to receive two full facial transplants.\n\nBack Story\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cOld soldiers never die; they just fade away.\u201d\n\nGen. Douglas MacArthur, above, took those words from an old Army ballad and made them famous 67 years ago this week in his farewell address to Congress.\n\nLittle did that five-star American general know that he had just given rise to an army of so-called snowclones, a relatively new linguistic phenomenon that\u2019s tougher to explain than it is to use.\n\nA snowclone, as defined by the linguistics professor Geoffrey K. Pullum in 2003, is a \u201ccustomizable, instantly recognizable, timeworn, quoted or misquoted phrase or sentence that can be used in an entirely open array of different jokey variants.\u201d (Mr. Pullum also called them \u201csome-assembly-required adaptable clich\u00e9 frames for lazy journalists.\u201d)\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nLet\u2019s try one. Using General MacArthur\u2019s template, \u201cOld golfers never die, they just lose their drive,\u201d would be a snowclone. Using X and Y as stand-ins, snowclones are easy to spot: X is my middle name, a few Xs short of a Y, and so on.\n\nIt\u2019s unclear who first said \u201cpink is the new black,\u201d but it is now one of the most popular snowclone templates, notably producing the title of the Netflix series \u201cOrange Is the New Black.\u201d\n\nStudy of the subject appears half-serious: One article was titled \u201cSnowclone Is the New Clich\u00e9.\u201d\n\nCharles McDermid wrote today\u2019s Back Story.\n\n_____\n\nYour Morning Briefing is published weekday mornings and updated online.\n\nCheck out this page to find a Morning Briefing for your region. (In addition to our European edition, we have Australian, Asian and U.S. editions.)\n\nSign up here to receive an Evening Briefing on U.S. weeknights, and here\u2019s our full range of free newsletters.\n\nWhat would you like to see here? Bolton, Mr. Trump\u2019s new national security adviser.", "title": "Kim Says He\u2019d End North Korea Nuclear Pursuit for U.S. Truce", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-04 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cJust because two people live at the same time, and are engaged in two different worlds, and talk to each other 10 times during the course of their lives,\u201d Kathleen Kennedy Townsend cautioned David Margolick, \u201cdoes not make a book.\u201d\n\nBut Mr. Margolick is a stubbornly contrarian journalist. So despite Ms. Townsend\u2019s skepticism, he was game when the filmmaker Lawrence Schiller suggested that this seductive paradigm of two opposites whose legacies not only intersected but were also bound together would, indeed, make a book. As a journalist himself, Mr. Schiller photographed those two contemporaneous figures \u2014 the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. and Robert F. Kennedy, Ms. Townsend\u2019s father.\n\nMr. Schiller had envisioned a modest 40,000 words to contextualize a lavishly illustrated volume to memorialize the assassinations of King and Kennedy 50 years ago this spring. Mr. Margolick wrote 120,000 words.", "title": "King and Kennedy Weren\u2019t Friends, but They Were Bound by History", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-20 00:00:00", "text": "Kirk Simon, a documentary filmmaker who turned luminaries in the arts into teachers and brought cameras into the classroom, memorably in an Academy Award-winning film about a multinational school in Israel, died on April 14 in Manhattan. He was 63.\n\nHis brother, Ron, said Mr. Simon suffered cardiac arrest and was declared dead after he was taken to a hospital.\n\nMr. Simon directed and produced documentaries for PBS, National Geographic and HBO, tackling a wide range of topics. But he often returned to education, as he and his creative partner, Karen Goodman, his first wife, did in 2010 with \u201cStrangers No More,\u201d which won the Oscar for best short documentary.\n\nThat film focused on the Bialik-Rogozin School in Tel Aviv, where children, many of them refugees or migrants from more than 48 countries, came together to learn and adapt to life in their new home. Many had endured extreme hardship and had little schooling.", "title": "Kirk Simon, 63, Oscar-Winning Documentarian, Dies", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-15 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nKiyomi Lillian Sakai Burchill and Joseph Daniel Couk were married April 14 at Beatnik Studios, an art gallery and event space in Sacramento.
