She graduated with distinction from Stanford and received a master\u2019s degree in public administration from the University of Southern California.\n\nShe is a daughter of Naomi J. Sakai and Jim W. Burchill of Davis, Calif. The bride\u2019s father retired as the president and chief executive of a public affairs firm bearing his name. Her mother retired as an administrator and a counselor in the counseling and psychological services department at the University of California, Davis.\n\nMr. Couk, also 34, is an information technology consultant in the Sacramento office of KPMG, the auditing, accounting and consulting firm. He graduated from California State University, Chico.\n\nHe is a son of Jane E. Couk and Dr. Richard S. Couk of Chico. The groom\u2019s mother manages his father\u2019s private dental practice there.\n\nThe couple never ran into each other during the six months in 2014 that they lived only three doors away from one another. They met at a local crowded music venue a year after she moved.", "title": "Kiyomi Burchill, Joseph Couk", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-12 00:00:00", "text": "Brown is the Philadelphia 76ers\u2019 coach and perhaps the greatest survivor of continuous losing in the history of the league. In his first head coaching position after years as a trusted assistant to Gregg Popovich of the San Antonio Spurs, Brown compiled a 75-253 record while braving the franchise\u2019s so-called process \u2014 a lose-large-to-eventually-win-big approach \u2014 begun by Sam Hinkie, who didn\u2019t last long enough to enjoy the fruits of his failure.\n\nWith his weathered face and thick New England accent, Brown determinedly stayed on message until the electrifying combination of Joel Embiid and Ben Simmons overcame early career injuries, fortified by enough role players to win 52 games this season. The Sixers earned the third playoff seeding in the Eastern Conference.\n\nPhiladelphia by reputation is not the most tolerant of towns, though mostly relative to the ups and downs of the Eagles. New York is a far greater challenge made worse by nearly two decades of organizational dysfunction begetting public disdain. And while Dolan has been the common denominator since the late 1990s, mistrust and infighting between coach and front office has been a staple \u2014 or sickness \u2014 of the Garden for decades.\n\nIs it something in the walls, or the water? Knicks chroniclers could write books on the epic feuds between Hubie Brown and Dave DeBusschere; Rick Pitino and Al Bianchi; Pat Riley and Dave Checketts; Jeff Van Gundy and Ernie Grunfeld; Larry Brown and Isiah Thomas.\n\nMost were the result of mismatched egos, while a couple of the relationships began in unity and fractured in the heat of the fray. And then there was Jackson, who handpicked two coaches and subverted both of them.\n\nIf ever anyone stepped into a no-win situation, it was Hornacek, who signed on in June 2016, months after Jackson removed Derek Fisher, his first hire.\n\nThat summer, Jackson added the Chicago veterans Noah and Rose, telling friends he had assembled the fourth-best team in the East. At least one of those friends told Jackson he probably shouldn\u2019t share that evaluation with Dolan, just in case he happened to be off on his projection.", "title": "Knicks Coaching Job Criteria: The Best Qualified for Losing", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-12 00:00:00", "text": "GREENBURGH, N.Y. \u2014 The Knicks have developed an April tradition: While other teams prepare for the playoffs, the Knicks erect a temporary dais at their practice facility here to explain why, after another lackluster season that brought another early summer break, they are making coaching or management changes.\n\nAt this year\u2019s installment, the team president, Steve Mills, and general manager, Scott Perry, wrung their hands while explaining the latest firing: Jeff Hornacek, the team\u2019s 11th head coach in the past 16 years. They informed him of their decision in a conference room at Westchester County Airport at about 2 a.m. Thursday, after the team returned from its season-ending game in Cleveland.\n\nKurt Rambis, the associate head coach, was also dismissed.\n\n\u201cWe thought it was important, and the timing was right, to get a new voice and a new presence in this locker room to lead our vision for this team moving forward,\u201d Perry said. \u201cWe are in the early stages of the building process for this team and this organization.\u201d\n\nKnicks fans might find it difficult to keep track of which stage of which building process the team is in. The Knicks\u2019 perpetual state of rebuilding \u2014 involving so many people making so many missteps over so many years \u2014 makes Boston\u2019s Big Dig seem like a simple driveway repaving by comparison.", "title": "Knicks Fire Coach Jeff Hornacek", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-27 00:00:00", "text": "BEIJING \u2014 A man wielding a knife killed nine children and injured 10 others outside a middle school in central China on Friday, the authorities said, in one of the worst attacks at a Chinese school in recent years.\n\nThe episode took place shortly after 6 p.m., officials said, as students were being dismissed at the Mizhi County No. 3 Middle School in Shaanxi Province, about 500 miles southwest of Beijing.\n\nThe police said they had taken into custody a suspect, a man with the surname Zhao, born in 1990. They said the man was a graduate of the middle school and that he had told the police he was seeking revenge because he was bullied during his time there.\n\n\u201cHe attacked students because he hated the students there,\u201d said a statement by the Mizhi County police posted on Weibo, a popular microblogging site.", "title": "Knife Attack at Chinese Middle School Leaves Nine Children Dead", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-12 00:00:00", "text": "Beyond the typical political gridlock that has stymied action in Congress, technology and the companies that sell access to it are particularly protected.\n\nThe Facebook hearings this week revealed a vast knowledge gap between Silicon Valley and the nation\u2019s capital, where lawmakers struggled to grasp how the technology works and which problems \u2014 misinformation, sharing of data to third parties or political biases coded into algorithms \u2014 needed to be addressed.\n\nInaction does not reflect a lack of will so much as a failure of expertise.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s the first time I\u2019ve seen an issue where everybody seemed to be on the same sheet of music,\u201d Senator Lindsey Graham, Republican of South Carolina, said Thursday.\n\nIf Congress does not follow through with new rules for internet companies, \u201cwe\u2019ll look like a bunch of idiots,\u201d Mr. Graham added.\n\nAvoiding that dunce cap will be difficult. Lawmakers will confront Silicon Valley\u2019s powerful new lobbying establishment. Facebook, Google, Amazon and Apple now hold the biggest corporate lobbying budgets in Washington and spent a combined $49.7 million in 2017 on direct lobbying, which does not include their outside lobbying trade groups, up 24 percent from the previous year. They have hired top privacy experts into their lobbying troops to defeat privacy and other internet laws.\n\nFacebook has said it would embrace some regulation, with Mr. Zuckerberg saying this week that rules for internet companies were \u201cinevitable.\u201d But he also indicated that it would have to be the \u201cright\u201d regulations, and he was not willing to commit on the spot to several ideas posed by lawmakers.\n\nThe hearings spurred new momentum for the introduction of privacy laws. On Thursday, Senators Amy Klobuchar, Democrat of Minnesota, and John Kennedy, Republican of Louisiana, introduced legislation that would allow consumers to opt out of getting tracked on a site. The bill would also mandate simpler privacy policies.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nOne new bill would restrict data collection of students using classroom technology, and another would require companies to get permission before collecting and sharing user data. That would move the United States closer to rules about to take effect next month in Europe. An earlier bill would mandate more disclosure on Facebook advertising purchases.\n\nMr. Zuckerberg said this week that the company would make tools for the European privacy rules available for all users, but Facebook has not specified if stronger privacy would be the default for global users. Other internet and online advertising firms have criticized the European rules known as General Data Protection Regulation as onerous.\n\nNevertheless, the creation of any regulations in coming months is doubtful. Most lawmakers said in the hearings that they were concerned about privacy and foreign interference on social media during the 2016 election. But several Republicans also expressed anxiety over regulations that could slow the growth of Silicon Valley, a beacon for the American economy.\n\n\u201cThese are tough ones. Privacy versus innovation versus security versus freedom \u2014 these are always tough questions,\u201d said Senator Jeff Flake, Republican of Arizona. He said he would most likely support the political ad disclosures bill but added, \u201cWhen we step in, are we always late?\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nThis week, Senator Richard Blumenthal, Democrat of Connecticut, introduced the Consent Act, which would require companies to get permission before tracking and sharing data. But even he pointed to Washington\u2019s short attention span. Companies like Facebook, he said, would try to stand in Congress\u2019s way.\n\n\u201cThey will try to make it more complex than it is,\u201d he said.\n\n\u201cThe question is timing,\u201d Mr. Blumenthal added, pointing to the difficult midterm elections in November and the desire by many legislators to do as little as possible until then. \u201cThis session, everybody says, is over as far as serious legislating is concerned.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMr. Graham, who said regulations were necessary, also acknowledged the pitfalls of moving too fast.\n\n\u201cI\u2019d hate to be the senator that killed an effort to have reasonable regulation,\u201d Mr. Graham said. But, he conceded, \u201cYou really need to know what you are signing up for.\u201d\n\nBeyond the short term, the hearings may have laid the foundation for broader privacy regulations in coming years, analysts said. The most likely action to follow Mr. Zuckerberg\u2019s grilling is the passage of a bill that requires financial disclosures of political advertising on social media, a law similar to broadcast television and radio political ad disclosures.\n\nNarrow regulatory ideas could gain momentum that prevent online location tracking, strengthen privacy protections for children and teens and require stronger disclosures for data breaches. But the government\u2019s light hand on Silicon Valley will continue for some time even as the European Union prepares to enact comprehensive privacy rules that limit data collection and push companies to ask permission before sharing information about users.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nEven if seats in the House and Senate shift after the midterm elections, any privacy laws would be at least a couple of years away, said Paul Gallant, a technology policy analyst at the Cowen Group.\n\n\u201cIf Democrats win the House in November, the chances of legislation would rise, although a likely Republican Senate would still make passage an uphill battle,\u201d Mr. Gallant said.\n\nA big problem is the lack of technological expertise in Congress, and the informational imbalance with the tech companies\u2019 lobbyists.\n\nIn 2011, tech lobbyists blanketed the Senate Judiciary Committee after former Senator Al Franken, Democrat of Minnesota, introduced a geolocation privacy bill.\n\nInternet firms brought in engineers and deployed their outside lobbying groups to warn lawmakers that Mr. Franken\u2019s bill was dangerous and technically flawed, said Alvaro Bedoya, a former staff member for Mr. Franken who is now the executive director of the Georgetown Center for Privacy and Technology.\n\nAnother obstacle to action is a disagreement on regulatory priorities.\n\nIndeed, Mr. Graham identified a grab bag of problems that he wanted addressed with Facebook, most of which are not being addressed by any current legislative proposals.\n\nHe mentioned terrorism content, Facebook\u2019s \u201cmonopoly\u201d and political bias as regulatory targets. At Mr. Zuckerberg\u2019s hearings on Tuesday and Wednesday, other lawmakers brought up data breaches, foreign interference and censorship, particularly of the pro-Trump internet personalities Diamond and Silk.\n\n\u201cI want somebody to look at how they set these machines up, not just for Facebook, but other people, to make sure that the algorithms are not being politically motivated,\u201d Mr. Graham said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe lack of technological knowledge was glaring. Members mostly comprised lawyers or former business people, and many are just getting acquainted with social media, artificial intelligence, autonomous self-driving cars, drones and other technologies that they are charged to oversee.\n\nDiversity in government has become a platform issue for Brianna Wu, a former software designer who is running for the 8th House district in Massachusetts.\n\nMs. Wu watched Mr. Zuckerberg\u2019s hearings and was struck by the basic lack of knowledge members had in how the site works, such as the business model of ad-supported websites and how messaging apps like Facebook\u2019s WhatsApp works. Before the hearings, many of the members brought in technology experts from academic institutions to prepare them for Mr. Zuckerberg\u2019s appearance.\n\n\u201cMost people can understand why guns are a threat,\u201d she said. \u201cWith technology, people don\u2019t understand fundamentally what the threat is. That is a threat to democracy.\u201d", "title": "Knowledge Gap Hinders Ability of Congress to Regulate Silicon Valley", "authors": ["Cecilia Kang", "Thomas Kaplan", "Nicholas Fandos"]} {"date": "2018-04-13 00:00:00", "text": "Women throughout Sweden on Friday wore pussy-bow blouses, known as knytblusar, in a show of feminist solidarity with the deposed head of the Swedish Academy, Sara Danius.\n\nThe previous day, Ms. Danius had been forced from her role as permanent secretary of the academy, which awards the Nobel Prize in Literature, after weeks of acrimony over accusations of sexual abuse by a man with longstanding ties to the group.\n\nMs. Danius, the first woman to head the centuries-old body, had steered the response to the scandal, hiring a law firm to investigate and cutting all ties to Jean-Claude Arnault, the accused man. That Ms. Danius lost her position while Mr. Arnault remains under investigation led her defenders to say that she had been made a scapegoat.\n\nThe academy\u2019s deliberations are highly secretive, and it is unclear who exactly was responsible for Ms. Danius\u2019s ouster. But two of her predecessors as permanent secretary had said that the scandal surrounding Mr. Arnault was overblown and called Ms. Danius weak.", "title": "Knytblus, Sweden\u2019s Take on the Pussy-Bow Blouse, Rallies a Nation", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-25 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nTOKYO \u2014 The Japanese authorities are investigating the data falsification scandal at Kobe Steel, the company said on Wednesday, potentially broadening an episode that has undermined the country\u2019s reputation for high-quality manufacturing.\n\nKobe Steel said in a statement that the company \u201cis currently under investigation by the investigation authorities in Japan.\u201d It said it would cooperate but declined to comment further.\n\n\u201cKobe Steel once again deeply apologizes for causing substantial trouble to all relevant parties,\u201d it said.\n\nIt did not specify which authority was investigating the company. But the statement came the same day as the Japanese news media reported that prosecutors in Tokyo had requested records related to the scandal. Kobe Steel\u2019s shares fell 3.5 percent on Wednesday.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAn inquiry could deepen the problems at Kobe Steel. The company already faces an investigation in the United States, where the Justice Department has asked its American unit for records related to any substandard metal sold there.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nKobe Steel said last year that some of its managers lied about the quality of aluminum, copper and other products it sold to companies around the world in order to meet its own lofty quality targets. The metals have gone into products including passenger jetliners, cars and high-speed trains.", "title": "Kobe Steel Faces Japan Government Inquiry Over Data Scandal", "authors": ["Makiko Inoue"]} {"date": "2018-04-26 00:00:00", "text": "Then, Mr. Kim stepped across the border.\n\nAfter the two leaders posed for photos, they crossed briefly into the North\u2019s territory at Mr. Kim\u2019s suggestion, another highly symbolic moment. They then stepped back into South Korean territory, holding hands, and walked down a red carpet to inspect a South Korean military honor guard and enter the Peace House.\n\nPhoto\n\n[The Korean leaders\u2019 meeting was a carefully choreographed dance, with a surprise step. Read more here.]\n\n\u201cI came here to put an end to the history of confrontation,\u201d Mr. Kim was quoted as saying during the meeting, according to Mr. Moon\u2019s spokesman, Yoon Young-chan. Mr. Moon suggested they hold more meetings, and Mr. Kim said he would visit South Korea\u2019s presidential Blue House \u201cif the president invites me.\u201d\n\nWhile Mr. Moon\u2019s meeting with Mr. Kim on Friday \u2014 their first face-to-face talk \u2014 is rich with symbolism, Mr. Kim is not expected to capitulate on Mr. Trump\u2019s key demand: total and immediate nuclear disarmament.\n\nMr. Moon\u2019s other challenge, with Mr. Trump, turns on how best to deal with North Korea and its leader \u2014 who is expected to meet with Mr. Trump in the next few months.\n\nThe South Korean president favors an \u201caction for action\u201d strategy in which the North takes steps to dismantle its nuclear arsenal and is rewarded for each move with economic benefits and security guarantees. South Korean officials said that the entire process could take about two years.\n\nMr. Trump\u2019s national security team, by contrast, has insisted that North Korea must scrap its weapons programs before any relief from the sanctions that isolate the nation can be granted. And they say that \u201csubstantial dismantlement\u201d should be completed much more quickly, perhaps in six months.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Moon sees himself less as a negotiator with Mr. Kim and more as a mediator shuttling between two men who believe that keeping others guessing gives them an edge: a volatile American president with no experience in nuclear negotiations, and a hotheaded young North Korean leader with no experience on a global stage.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cWhat we can do is to try to help the North and the United States reach an agreement, helping them narrow their differences and seeking and presenting practical ideas both sides can accept,\u201d Mr. Moon said recently, adding that he may have only one shot to get it right. \u201cThis is an opportunity that will not come again.\u201d\n\nThe challenge is stark. No nation that has openly tested a nuclear device has ever surrendered its arsenal, and North Korea has conducted six underground explosions, each more powerful than the last, and has test-fired missiles that can reach the mainland United States.\n\nBut Mr. Trump and Mr. Kim have both already defied conventional wisdom about what is possible. If they meet in June \u2014 most likely in Singapore, according to American and South Korean officials \u2014 it would be the first direct encounter between the leaders of the two nations, as well as a chance to test the argument that making progress with North Korea in the nuclear standoff requires starting at the top.\n\nThe meeting between Mr. Kim and Mr. Moon is the third summit meeting between leaders of the two countries, but the first in which denuclearizing the Korean Peninsula tops the agenda.\n\n\u201cI hope we can have open-minded talks on issues of concern and produce good results, not the kind of results we saw in the past that were not implemented and made us start from scratch again,\u201d Mr. Kim said as the talks began on Friday. For his part, Mr. Moon said he hoped that the two leaders could engage in \u201cbroad-minded\u201d discussions and produce \u201ca big gift\u201d for those yearning for peace on the Korean Peninsula.\n\nMr. Moon hopes to emerge from Friday\u2019s summit meeting with a formal but vague denuclearization commitment from Mr. Kim and perhaps a path to negotiating a peace treaty or a plan to reduce military tensions. Some have suggested a pullback of troops from the Demilitarized Zone between the North and South is possible.\n\nBut Mr. Moon has acknowledged that there is a limit to what the two Koreas can agree on without American involvement. \u201cPeace on the Korean Peninsula cannot be achieved by agreements between South and North Korea alone,\u201d he said last month. \u201cIt has to have American endorsement.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nOne measure of success will be whether Mr. Moon can persuade Mr. Kim to set a timetable for denuclearization in his talks with Mr. Trump.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cConfirming a willingness to denuclearize is not enough. What matters is an agreement on by when the North will denuclearize,\u201d said Cheong Seong-chang, a North Korea specialist at the Sejong Institute, a South Korean think tank.\n\nSome who have tried and failed to persuade North Korea to abandon its nuclear program worry that Mr. Trump, having threatened the North with nuclear annihilation, has now swung too far to the other side and may be too eager to make a deal. Having derided Mr. Kim previously as \u201cLittle Rocket Man,\u201d Mr. Trump described the North Korean leader as \u201cvery honorable\u201d this week.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cI find it impossible to believe that Kim is prepared to give up what his father and his grandfather bequeathed to him,\u201d said Gary Samore, a veteran of negotiations with North Korea as the top arms control aide in the Clinton and Obama administrations, speaking at the Asan Institute for Policy Studies in Seoul.\n\nBut he added that Mr. Kim \u201cmay now calculate he has enough of a nuclear arsenal\u201d \u2014 and so can afford to put more on the table than in the past.\n\nOne possibility that causes consternation in the region is that Mr. Trump will settle for dismantling North Korea\u2019s small fleet of intercontinental ballistic missiles, eliminating its ability to strike the United States \u2014 but leaving South Korea and Japan vulnerable. \u201cIt would be the \u2018America First\u2019 way,\u201d Mr. Samore said, referring to Mr. Trump\u2019s campaign slogan.\n\nIf skepticism is rampant in Washington, the Moon administration is somewhat more optimistic. To South Korean policymakers, Mr. Kim\u2019s recent decisions suggest that he is willing to trade his nuclear arsenal for economic growth, which the young leader may see as necessary to preserving his rule for decades. They also argue that Mr. Trump\u2019s threats of military action have proved more effective at changing Mr. Kim\u2019s calculations than anticipated.\n\nPhoto\n\nSouth Korean officials say they have spent far more time and energy coordinating with the Trump administration before the Friday summit meeting than with the North Koreans, an effort complicated by the White House shake-up that included the departure of Lt. Gen H.R. McMaster as national security adviser and the firing of Rex W. Tillerson as secretary of state.\n\nThe focus on Washington also reflects concern about General McMaster\u2019s successor, John R. Bolton, who joined the administration after arguing for military strikes to destroy North Korea\u2019s nuclear arsenal, ridiculing South Korean leaders as \u201cputty in North Korea\u2019s hands,\u201d and calling North Koreans \u201cthe biggest con men in the world.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Moon\u2019s national security adviser, Chung Eui-yong, described Mr. Bolton as an \u201chonest broker\u201d after their first meeting this month, and he traveled again to Washington this week for further discussions with Mr. Bolton.\n\nOne mystery is what, if any, progress was made in a secret meeting in Pyongyang, the North\u2019s capital, this month between Mr. Kim and Mike Pompeo, the former C.I.A. director who was confirmed Thursday as secretary of state. Mr. Trump said Thursday that Mr. Pompeo was not scheduled to see Mr. Kim but had \u201ca great meeting\u201d that lasted more than an hour.\n\nThough Mr. Moon and Mr. Trump have outlined different approaches to negotiating with North Korea, they agree on the need to avoid the pitfalls that doomed previous rounds of talks.\n\nOne area of consensus is an attempt to more clearly establish the talks\u2019 desired outcome from the outset, giving all parties greater incentive to move forward. Previous negotiations were open-ended, without specific goals that everyone agreed on.\n\nSouth Korea and the United States also want to push the North to accept a timetable that would move quickly from the suspension of weapons tests \u2014 which it announced last week \u2014 to the dismantlement of its nuclear program. Some in the Trump administration have argued for completion in six months, but that may be an opening negotiating position given the challenges involved.\n\nPhoto\n\nMr. Bolton has occasionally cited the example of Libya, which shipped most of its nuclear equipment to an American weapons lab in Tennessee over the course of several weeks in late 2003. But much of that equipment was still in crates; there was little to dismantle.\n\nIran took a bit more than six months to take apart much of its program and ship 97 percent of its nuclear material from the country. But, like Libya, it had not yet built nuclear weapons.\n\nNorth Korea is believed to have 20 to 60 such weapons \u2014 American intelligence agencies cannot agree on the number \u2014 in addition to a vast infrastructure of fuel production and weapons manufacturing facilities, much of it hidden in the mountains or underground. Mr. Samore argued that the North should be asked to hand over an inventory that the United States and its allies could compare with intelligence reports and seek to verify. That process would offer a first sign of whether Mr. Kim is coming clean, but could take years to complete.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cI do not know of any way of unilaterally verifying an agreement whereby North Korea gives up its nuclear arsenal,\u201d said William J. Perry, a former defense secretary. \u201cWe do not know how many nuclear weapons North Korea has operational or under construction. We do not know where all of their nuclear facilities are located.\u201d\n\nMr. Moon\u2019s aides have argued that it is unrealistic to expect North Korea to simply surrender its arsenal without an \u201caction for action\u201d process that offers immediate benefits and builds trust. Early steps by the North could include the dismantlement of missile production facilities and allowing the return of international inspectors to nuclear sites, while the United States could begin normalizing diplomatic relations and easing some sanctions, like those that primarily affect North Korea\u2019s population rather than officials, analysts say.\n\nMr. Kim has also endorsed \u201cphased, synchronized steps\u201d toward denuclearization.\n\nBut White House officials have repeatedly rejected the incremental approach, saying past administrations have tried it without success.\n\nThere have been hints of friction between the Trump administration and Mr. Moon\u2019s team over the issue, with local news outlets in South Korea reporting that Mr. Bolton had pressed Seoul \u201cnot to move too far ahead\u201d in its talks with Mr. Kim. A senior aide to Mr. Moon firmly denied the reports.", "title": "Korea Talks Begin as Kim Jong-un Crosses to South\u2019s Side of DMZ", "authors": ["David E. Sanger", "Choe Sang-Hun"]} {"date": "2018-04-19 00:00:00", "text": "\u2022 A robot conquered one of humanity\u2019s most difficult tasks: assembling Ikea furniture. But user concerns about privacy are forcing companies to re-examine how they work with the social network.\n\n\u2022 The German authorities raided the offices of Porsche, one of Volkswagen\u2019s most profitable units, in a widening investigation into an emissions-cheating scandal.\n\n\u2022 Southwest\u2019s fatal accident this week is renewing scrutiny of inspections. Farming could pull carbon out of the air and into the soil, but that would mean a new way of thinking about how to tend the land.\n\n\u2022 A hip-hop duo whose album features anti-Jewish lyrics won an award at the German equivalent of the Grammys, setting off a debate about the rise of anti-Semitism.\n\n\u2022 The Times publishes nearly 30 film reviews a week. Here\u2019s a selection of what to see (or skip) for Australian viewers.\n\nBack Story\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cOld soldiers never die; they just fade away.\u201d\n\nGen. Douglas MacArthur, above center, took those words from an old Army ballad and made them famous 67 years ago this week in his farewell address to Congress.\n\nLittle did that five-star American general know that he had just given rise to an army of so-called snowclones, a relatively new linguistic phenomenon that\u2019s tougher to explain than it is to use.\n\nA snowclone, as defined by the linguistics professor Geoffrey K. Pullum in 2003, is a \u201ccustomizable, instantly recognizable, timeworn, quoted or misquoted phrase or sentence that can be used in an entirely open array of different jokey variants.\u201d (Mr. Pullum also called them \u201csome-assembly-required adaptable clich\u00e9 frames for lazy journalists.\u201d)\n\nLet\u2019s try one. Using General MacArthur\u2019s template, \u201cOld golfers never die, they just lose their drive,\u201d would be a snowclone. Using X and Y as stand-ins, snowclones are easy to spot: X is my middle name, a few Xs short of a Y, and so on.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIt\u2019s unclear who first said \u201cpink is the new black,\u201d but it is now one of the most popular snowclone templates, notably producing the title of the Netflix series \u201cOrange Is the New Black.\u201d\n\nStudy of the subject appears half-serious: One article was titled \u201cSnowclone Is the New Clich\u00e9.\u201d\n\nCharles McDermid wrote today\u2019s Back Story.\n\n_____\n\nYour Morning Briefing is published weekday mornings and updated online. Sign up here to get it by email in the Australian, Asian, European or American morning. You can also receive an Evening Briefing on U.S. weeknights.\n\nAnd our Australia bureau chief offers a weekly letter adding analysis and conversations with readers.\n\nBrowse our full range of Times newsletters here.\n\nWhat would you like to see here? Contact us at asiabriefing@nytimes.com.", "title": "Korea, Volcano, Cuba: Your Friday Briefing", "authors": ["Inyoung Kang"]} {"date": "2018-04-28 00:00:00", "text": "China, which has been enforcing United Nations economic sanctions against North Korea, its longtime but wayward ally, urged the two Koreas and other countries to \u201cmaintain the momentum for dialogue and work together to promote the denuclearization of the peninsula.\u201d\n\n\u201cChina welcomes it and extends its congratulations,\u201d Lu Kang, the spokesman for the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, said of the accord.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe Japanese prime minister, Shinzo Abe, described the commitment to denuclearization as a \u201cpositive move toward the comprehensive settlement of various issues surrounding North Korea.\u201d\n\nIn Russia, the Kremlin hailed the agreement as \u201cvery positive.\u201d Dmitri S. Peskov, spokesman for President Vladimir V. Putin, said Mr. Putin \u201chas stressed many times that sustainable conflict resolution on the Korean Peninsula can only be based on direct dialogue of both sides.\u201d\n\nThe accord set no timetable for denuclearization but said that the two sides planned to achieve a permanent peace within the year. Talks to end the 1950-53 Korean War would require negotiations involving the main combatants: North and South Korea, China and the United States.\n\nIn Japan, there was caution about the lack of specifics in the inter-Korean accord. The document fell far short of the Trump administration\u2019s demands for the dismantlement of the North\u2019s arsenal and of the need for inspections to verify that the weapons no longer existed, officials and commentators said.\n\nThe Japanese foreign minister, Taro Kono, called for North Korea to take \u201cconcrete actions for the dismantlement of all weapons of mass destruction, including biological and chemical weapons, and ballistic missiles of all ranges in a complete and irreversible manner.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAnalysts in the Japanese news media also expressed doubts that Friday\u2019s meeting was more than symbolic.\n\n\u201cHarmony was fully shown, but it\u2019s a big mistake to interpret that there was big progress substantially,\u201d an editorial in the right-leaning newspaper Sankei said, adding, \u201cIt\u2019s very doubtful that the \u2018denuclearization\u2019 mentioned in the joint statement matches what has been discussed between Mr. Abe and Mr. Trump.\u201d\n\nVideo\n\nMr. Abe, who has strained relations with South Korea, implied that the new accord may not be too different from a similar commitment in 2007 between a previous South Korean president, Roh Moo-hyun, and Kim Jong-il, the father of the current North Korean leader. That accord fell apart soon after it was signed.\n\n\u201cWe would like to think about how we respond to the current statement, analyzing and comparing it with the past statement,\u201d Mr. Abe said.\n\nOf all the North\u2019s neighbors, Japan is perhaps the most uneasy about the process that began at the inter-Korean summit meeting. It fears Washington could agree to trade away the North\u2019s long-range intercontinental missiles that can hit the United States, but allow Pyongyang to keep its medium-range missiles, leaving Japan vulnerable.\n\nMr. Abe went out of his way to remind reporters that he had spent 11 hours with Mr. Trump this month, insisting his proximity to the American president meant he had not been left out of the negotiations over North Korea.\n\nOn Saturday morning, President Trump wrote in a Twitter post that he \u201cjust had a long and very good talk with President Moon of South Korea,\u201d and added that he had also spoken with Mr. Abe \u201cto inform him of the ongoing negotiations.\u201d\n\nIn China, the state-run news media, which generally reflects the attitudes of the government, stressed the need for the United States to quickly enter the picture and seal the deal made between South Korea\u2019s president, Moon Jae-in, and Mr. Kim.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cThe Kim-Moon summit will write the goal of denuclearization and strive to end the state of war in the Declaration of Panmunjom,\u201d one Chinese newspaper, the Global Times, said in an editorial. \u201cBut they are all writing about the vision rather than the exact plan.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nCheng Xiaohe, a professor of international relations at Renmin University, said it was too much to expect the two Korean leaders to come up with a definitive prescription for ending the North\u2019s nuclear program in just one day.\n\n\u201cKim Jong-un has to leave some gifts for Trump,\u201d Mr. Cheng said. \u201cThis summit got a lot of results for an inter-Korean meeting.\u201d\n\nBut there was no question that China remained sidelined in the rapprochement between North and South, and it was nowhere to be seen in the prelude to the meeting between Mr. Trump and Mr. Kim, said Shen Zhihua, a prominent Chinese historian who has written extensively on North Korea.\n\nNorth Korea\u2019s goal was to keep its nuclear weapons and to be recognized as a nuclear power, Mr. Shen said in an interview broadcast by Voice of America.\n\nIn the end, the North could persuade other countries to let it keep its nuclear arsenal, or at least part of it. And in the process, Mr. Shen said, China could be left permanently on the outside \u2014 with North Korea leaning toward the United States.\n\n\u201cMany Chinese people are very optimistic now,\u201d he said, but added: \u201cIt does not seem that simple. If North Korea holds a nuclear weapon, it will not hit South Korea. Will it hit Japan? It does not dare. It also will not dare to fight the United States. If you look at history, North Korea is not sure about China and has a mind of revenge toward China.\u201d\n\nIn addition, families of Japanese citizens abducted by North Korean spies four decades ago had hoped that Mr. Moon would raise the issue in his meeting with Mr. Kim. That seemed a distant hope. Human rights activists who asked Mr. Moon to get commitments from Mr. Kim on reforming the North\u2019s vicious prison system were also disappointed.\n\nSpeaking to reporters in front of his home in Saitama, a suburb of Tokyo, Shigeo Iizuka, a brother of Yaeko Taguchi, one of the kidnapped, said that he was \u201cdisappointed\u201d the abductions were not mentioned in the joint statement.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe summit meeting, Mr. Iizuka said, \u201cwas a big event that will be remembered as a page of history. I got the impression it was a superficial performance without substance.\u201d", "title": "Korean Accord Draws Praise, and Caution, From North\u2019s Neighbors", "authors": ["Jane Perlez"]} {"date": "2018-04-22 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nSEOUL, South Korea \u2014 Two sisters accused of abusing Korean Air employees will be removed from management positions in their family-run corporate empire, the company announced on Sunday, four years after one of them became notorious for an episode of \u201cnut rage.\u201d\n\nThe executives, Cho Hyun-ah, 43, and Cho Hyun-min, 35, have become lightning rods for South Koreans who say that leaders of the family-run conglomerates known as chaebol, which dominate the country\u2019s economy, often act as though they are above the law.\n\nCho Hyun-ah became infamous in 2014 when, as a Korean Air vice president, she flew into a rage after she was served macadamia nuts in an unopened package, rather than on a plate, in first class. Officials said she threw documents and insults at members of the flight crew and ordered flight attendants to kneel and beg for forgiveness.\n\nMs. Cho then ordered the Korean Air plane back to its gate at Kennedy International Airport in New York so that she could have the chief flight attendant removed.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nShe was later accused of violating airline safety laws and spent several months in prison, though she recently made a quiet return to the Hanjin conglomerate for which her father, Cho Yang-ho, is chairman, managing a hotel business that he controls.", "title": "Korean Air Heiresses, One Known for \u2018Nut Rage,\u2019 Lose Their Jobs", "authors": ["Choe Sang-Hun"]} {"date": "2018-04-27 00:00:00", "text": "On Friday at NATO, on his first full day as secretary of state, Mr. Pompeo suggested for the first time that the North Korean leader was ready to deal. \u201cI did get a sense that he was serious,\u201d he told reporters. \u201cThe economic pressure that has been put in place by this global effort that President Trump has led has led him to believe that it\u2019s in his best interest to come to the table and talk about denuclearization.\u201d\n\nYet talking is different from denuclearizing. And talking about denuclearizing is hardly new. The North promised the same in a 1992 agreement, and many in Seoul, the South\u2019s capital, wondered then if the nightmare of living under the constant threat of artillery barrage was about to end. In fact, the agreement reached on Friday picks up language from the 1992 accord, and has similar provisions about reuniting families separated during the Korean War and nonaggression agreements. Little of it happened.\n\nThere were two agreements with the George W. Bush administration, each described at the time as breakthroughs. Since then the North has amassed 20 to 60 nuclear weapons, up from zero when those commitments were made.\n\nNo one knows those numbers better than Mr. Pompeo, who spent a lot of time with the C.I.A.\u2019s Korea Mission unit, assessing the scope and imminence of its nuclear capabilities. \u201cThere\u2019s a lot of history here, where promises have been made, hopes have been raised and then dashed,\u201d the new secretary of state told reporters.\n\nMr. Trump\u2019s solution to not getting \u201cplayed,\u201d the phrase he so often uses about his predecessors and North Korea, is to keep what he calls a \u201cmaximum pressure campaign\u201d on the North until denuclearization happens. The South Koreans say they agree. But the documents issued Friday hint at benefits that begin to flow to the North as they move toward a peace agreement, and a reduction of tensions.\n\nChina, which is largely interested in maintaining the status quo, could also loosen the restrictions on oil and goods, as long as negotiations play out.\n\nAll this suggests that Mr. Trump\u2019s challenge when he meets Mr. Kim, probably in early June, is growing. He must establish the process for the actual dismantlement of weapons, the removal of stockpiled uranium and plutonium bomb fuel from the country and a verification program that will be one of the most complex in history, given the vastness of North Korea\u2019s mountains.", "title": "Koreans Set the Table for a Deal That Trump Will Try to Close", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-27 00:00:00", "text": "Even President Trump was caught up in the euphoria. \u201cKOREAN WAR TO END!\u201d he exultantly tweeted. \u201cThe United States, and all of its GREAT people, should be very proud of what is now taking place in Korea!\u201d\n\nYes, Mr. Kim is still a murderous ruler of a brutally isolated state who will do anything to retain absolute control, and most experts suspect that, in the end, nothing will change since he will not surrender a lever his family spent years and millions of dollars developing.\n\nThe denuclearization he has in mind is \u201cprogressive and synchronous,\u201d which seems to mean it will move forward in partial steps, in exchange for economic benefits and security guarantees, and that the United States would withdraw its nuclear umbrella from South Korea. Those would be major challenges to deal with in negotiations and not at all what the Trump administration has in mind.\n\nAt the same time, Mr. Kim is evidently serious about trying to raise the living standards of his impoverished country and is prepared to use his nuclear weapons as barter to lift onerous economic sanctions and obtain American assurances that would allow his regime to continue.\n\nNot long before he was brought in as the new national security adviser, John Bolton, told an interviewer that a Trump-Kim summit meeting would inevitably fail, which, he said, would clear the way to the next phase \u2014 presumably a pre-emptive strike.\n\nThat in itself is reason to hope that new opening in the long-running confrontation of North and South Korea so dramatically staged at Panmunjom does confound expectations and lead to real and fruitful negotiations, not just between the two Koreas but also between the United States and North Korea. The success of that meeting puts pressure on Mr. Trump to continue the momentum toward peace by patiently pursuing serious negotiations with North Korea, not making unilateral demands and issuing threats. It\u2019s a long shot, but even if talks just keep two impetuous and unpredictable men like Mr. Kim and Mr. Trump away from their nuclear buttons, the world is better off.", "title": "Opinion | Koreans\u2019 Talk of Peace Raises Hopes and Doubts", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-03 00:00:00", "text": "RUD, Kosovo \u2014 Fetah Rudi, a former schoolteacher and political activist, has been using a wheelchair for 17 years, ever since unidentified gunmen unloaded 14 bullets into his stomach and shoulder in a drive-by shooting near his small village in central Kosovo.\n\nHe has no hope of ever walking again but, thanks to a new war crimes tribunal, he finally has some hope that, after 10 years as an independent country, Kosovo will belatedly grapple with a singularly taboo topic: why ethnic Albanians like him kept getting attacked and in some cases killed even after their Serbian tormentors had fled.\n\nHe has watched in dismay over the years as the United Nations and then the European Union \u2014 which have both tried to establish the rule of law in this tiny Balkan nation since it broke free from Serbia in 1999 \u2014 failed to deliver justice for a wave of violence that followed Serbia\u2019s retreat.", "title": "Kosovo\u2019s War Ended, but the Shooting Didn\u2019t. A Court Promises Justice.", "authors": ["Andrew Higgins", "Valerie Hopkins"]} {"date": "2018-04-18 00:00:00", "text": "Kris W. Kobach, the secretary of state of Kansas and face of the Trump administration\u2019s efforts to clamp down on supposed voter fraud, was found by a federal judge on Wednesday to have disobeyed orders to notify thousands of Kansans in 2016 that they were registered to vote.\n\nMr. Kobach, who served last year as the vice chairman of the Trump administration\u2019s short-lived presidential commission on voter fraud, was reprimanded in a 25-page ruling by Federal District Judge Julie A. Robinson of Kansas, who held him in contempt of court.\n\nMr. Kobach has championed restrictive laws on voting around the country, warning that voting fraud is rampant and unchecked, despite widespread agreement from election experts that it is extremely rare. But voting rights advocates pointed to the judge\u2019s findings as a counter to Mr. Kobach\u2019s efforts to position himself as a protector of the voting process.\n\n\u201cSecretary Kobach likes to talk about the rule of law,\u201d Dale Ho, director of the Voting Rights Project at the American Civil Liberties Union, said in a statement. \u201cTalk is cheap, and his actions speak louder than his words.\u201d", "title": "Kris Kobach, Face of Trump\u2019s Voter Fraud Panel, Is Held in Contempt by Judge", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-22 00:00:00", "text": "Krista Elise Zegura and Adam Sowlati were married April 21 in Tucson. His father is a technician for Eversource Energy, an electric utility in Hartford.", "title": "Kristen Lappas, Russell Dinallo Jr.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-12 00:00:00", "text": "WASHINGTON \u2014 In the Oval Office on Tuesday, as fears of a trade war with China roiled markets and panicked American farmers and lawmakers, Larry Kudlow, President Trump\u2019s new top economic adviser, scored what passes for a major coup in a White House whipsawed by angry presidential tweets.\n\nHe helped get the president to say something nice on Twitter about President Xi Jinping of China.\n\n\u201cVery thankful for President Xi of China\u2019s kind words on tariffs and automobile barriers,\u201d Mr. Trump tweeted, referring to a trade speech that Mr. Xi had just delivered. \u201cWe will make great progress together!\u201d\n\nIt was a sign of the early fingerprints of Mr. Kudlow, the Wall Street economist best known as a CNBC television personality who is now the director of the White House\u2019s National Economic Council. Mr. Kudlow, barely two weeks into the job, casts himself as a \u201chappy warrior\u201d trying to give the best economic counsel he can to a president who has proved disinclined to follow advice.\n\n\u201cThe way this has worked so far, we\u2019ve been pretty close, but we have had differences,\u201d Mr. Kudlow said of himself and the president during an interview in his West Wing office on Thursday. Asked what those were, he replied: \u201cOh, Lord\u2026. I\u2019m not sure I want you to know that.\u201d", "title": "Kudlow Plays \u2018Happy Warrior\u2019 Role in Counseling Trump", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-26 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cOne that functions outside the commercial gallery box,\u201d she said. \u201cAnd one that resists people\u2019s expectations of what it means for an international gallery to open a space in New York.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nMs. Zucker said that they had chosen the Upper East Side because it is outside the mass of Chelsea. It is, of course, a neighborhood where many curators and collectors stay when they visit New York, but \u201cthe Upper East Side is an area redefining itself.\u201d\n\n\u201cFor artists, this presents an interesting opportunity,\u201d she added.\n\nThe inaugural exhibition, \u201cAbraham Cruzvillegas: Autocontusi\u00f3n,\u201d is a good introduction to the Kurimanzutto ethos. Suspended from the ceiling throughout the space are 55 wooden constructions that look like a cross between Aleksandr Rodchenko\u2019s Constructivist sculpture and a torn-up fruit vendor\u2019s stand. Painted pink and green, the colors pay homage to the Brazilian artist H\u00e9lio Oiticica.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe dangling sculptures were made from found scraps and festooned with objects donated by Mr. Cruzvillegas\u2019s friends and associates. Some are perishable: turmeric, ginger, avocados, or a whole prosciutto ham. There is also a prickly pear cactus, which is native to parts of the Northeast. Other objects are oddball silly, like an old snowshoe or a deflated basketball.\n\nMaking art, which is theoretically prized and precious, out of cast-off objects is one of the basic paradoxes central to many projects that have appeared in the Mexico City gallery, which has presented work by artists like Sarah Lucas, Dami\u00e1n Ortega, Allora & Calzadilla, Adri\u00e1n Villar Rojas, Danh Vo and Dr. Lakra (Jer\u00f3nimo L\u00f3pez Ram\u00edrez).\n\nThe new gallery is based around a different bunch of paradoxes: from being a big fish in a small pond to another gallery in a vast sea of art; from having a deluxe art space to a more modest one. \u201cThe Mexican gallery scene is relatively small but incredibly vibrant,\u201d Ms. McClure said, \u201cand Kurimanzutto is at the heart of that scene and deeply entrenched in the cultural identity of the city. We\u2019re able to take risks that are more challenging in New York.\u201d\n\nMoving to New York, she added, \u201cwill bring us back to the fundamentals of Kurimanzutto when it first opened in Mexico City, where we\u2019ll look for spaces around the city according to the artists\u2019 ideas and projects.\u201d\n\nBoth women see New York as providing an international platform and a larger audience for their artists. Ms. Zucker said that she was initially drawn to Kurimanzutto because it represented \u201cmovers and shakers from all over Latin America.\u201d The gallery is intent on carrying the discussion that\u2019s sprung from their work and ideas farther north.", "title": "Kurimanzutto Expands (Way) North", "authors": ["Martha Schwendener"]} {"date": "2018-04-06 00:00:00", "text": "Vornado declined further comment through a spokeswoman. A spokeswoman for Kushner Companies said Charles Kushner, an Orthodox Jew, was unavailable to comment because he was observing the Sabbath.\n\nThe Kushners made a huge splash in 2007 when they bought 666 Fifth for $1.8 billion, setting a record price for an office tower. Before then, Mr. Kushner was known mainly as a developer of garden apartments in New Jersey, where he lived, and a major Democratic Party contributor.\n\nThe Fifth Avenue building was meant to signal a significant change in direction for the Kushners, who moved into Manhattan, installed the family headquarters on the building\u2019s 15th floor and went on a real estate shopping spree that has left them with properties in Brooklyn, Jersey City and Maryland.\n\nBut 666 Fifth was bought mostly with borrowed money. To pay off some of the debt, the Kushners sold the building\u2019s most valuable asset, the retail space, to Carlyle Group and Crown Acquisitions for $525 million.\n\nThe family had expected to boost rents in the building. But as the 2008 recession set in, the building lost some of its largest tenants and the financial bleeding started. Fearing a possible default, its lender appointed a \u201cspecial servicer\u201d to oversee the building.\n\nIn 2011, the Kushners sought to restructure their debt. Vornado bought a 49.5 percent interest in the building\u2019s office space and agreed to invest up to $80 million and take responsibility for a portion of the mortgage. The mortgage was divided into a $1.1 billion note and a $115 million secondary loan.\n\nBut Vornado imposed stiff terms. It was getting 11 percent interest on money it actually invested in the building, and a 3 percent return on the remaining money, if any, according to a financial report from Trepp, a company that tracks real estate debt.", "title": "Kushner Partner in 666 Fifth Ave. Says It Has Deal to Sell", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-09 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Kushner acknowledged that he had abandoned plans to demolish the existing aluminum-clad office tower to make way for an 80-story, ultraluxury skyscraper designed by the architect Zaha Hadid. The tower was to include a lush retail mall, a high-end hotel and the pricey apartments, at a prime location in the city.\n\nThat will not be built, he said on Monday. \u201cIt\u2019s definitely not a knockdown,\u201d Mr. Kushner said. \u201cIt\u2019s definitely not the original plan.\u201d\n\nSo what is going to happen?\n\n\u201cWe don\u2019t know what we\u2019re going to do,\u201d he said. \u201cWe\u2019re weighing our options.\u201d\n\nAccording to real estate executives who have spoken to the developer but who requested anonymity for fear of becoming embroiled in a dispute potentially involving Mr. Trump, Mr. Kushner plans to upgrade the office space at the base of the building and is considering converting the top floors into condominiums.\n\nBut, anything Mr. Kushner does at 666 Fifth \u2014 renovate and sign new leases for the office space, create condominiums or some combination of the two \u2014 could cost hundreds of millions of dollars, at a time when most analysts say the building may not be worth as much as its mortgage.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s tough. It\u2019s an iconic asset in a prime location, but it probably needs a substantial investment to compete with newer, shinier office product at Hudson Yards, downtown or near Grand Central,\u201d John P. Kim, a real estate analyst at BMO Capital Markets, said of 666 Fifth.\n\nStephen B. Siegel, chairman of global brokerage at CBRE Group, a real estate company, said, \u201cIt\u2019s an eminently leasable office building, if updated to modern standards, from the lobby to the elevators.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut upgrades cost money, potentially $200 million, Mr. Siegel said.\n\nAs for luxury condominiums, Jonathan J. Miller, a residential real estate appraiser, said that the challenge is that \u201cthe high end of the residential market has been overbuilt since 2014.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nVery few Midtown office buildings trade hands so it is difficult to make a comparison between 666 Fifth and other deals. But real estate executives say that the building, which has a 30 percent vacancy rate, is worth anywhere from $800 a square foot to $1,000 a square foot, or as much as $1.4 billion \u2014 the amount of the mortgage.\n\nThe clock is ticking on that loan, which comes due in February. Revenue from the building only covers about half of the annual payments, according to a financial report by Trepp, which tracks real estate debt.\n\nIf he refinanced, Mr. Kushner could probably get a new mortgage at a lower interest rate than the current 6.3 percent. But experts say that Mr. Kushner would only be able to finance about 80 percent of the building\u2019s value, or about $1.12 billion.\n\nHe must also pay off his partner, Vornado Realty Trust, as much as $89 million. In 2012, when it became a partner in the building, Vornado agreed to invest up to $80 million in it at 11 percent interest. If bought out, Vornado would no longer be liable for its share of the mortgage, which amounts to $699 million, according to BMO Capital Markets.\n\nVornado, however, would retain ownership of the building\u2019s most valuable asset, most of the Fifth Avenue retail shops. Vornado declined to comment on Monday.\n\nThe Kushners\u2019 purchase of the building in 2007 for $1.8 billion announced their arrival into the rarefied ranks of New York real estate.\n\nBut the leap into Manhattan from New Jersey, where the company owned a vast portfolio of garden apartments, has been fraught. Kushner Companies sold the valuable Fifth Avenue retail shops at the base of the building and lost some of its biggest office tenants in the recession.\n\nA year ago, Mr. Kushner and Anbang Insurance Group, a Chinese financial conglomerate with close ties to the country\u2019s ruling circles, mutually agreed to terminate their discussions of a possible $4 billion deal.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe deal foundered because of the publicity surrounding it, which the Chinese had hoped to avoid. But it also suffered from concerns raised by Democratic lawmakers that the deal could be a breach of federal ethics rules, because of Jared Kushner\u2019s involvement in the negotiations before he went to the White House.\n\nBrokers and real estate executives who know him say that Mr. Kushner is \u201cdetermined\u201d to get a deal done that would leave him in control of the tower, which serves as the headquarters for his real estate empire.\n\nMr. Kushner believes that he could have struck a deal long ago if not for the shadow of the Trump administration, people close to him say.\n\n\u201cThere\u2019s a cloud because of the White House,\u201d said Arthur J. Mirante, tristate president of Avison Young, an international real estate firm, and a friend of Mr. Kushner. \u201cA lot of people just don\u2019t want to deal with it.\u201d", "title": "Kushners \u2018Negotiating Now,\u2019 Over Sale of Flagship Building", "authors": ["Charles V. Bagli"]} {"date": "2018-04-13 00:00:00", "text": "Though much of his plans are still unclear, he spoke excitedly about goals for his newspaper\u2019s new space.\n\nHe wants lots of light, a day care center, a museum to honor the newspaper\u2019s history and modern technology. Eventually, he said, he would like to build a basketball court \u2014 he has one below his Brentwood mansion, as well \u2014 and open the campus up to the public to allow readers to see how the newspaper is put together.\n\nAnd while he is still grappling with whether The Times should be a local or regional newspaper versus a national or global news outlet, he said he thought the country needed a major news organization on the West Coast to countervail the powerful institutions, like The Wall Street Journal, The New York Times and The Post \u2014 on the East Coast.\n\n\u201cI think we will make each other\u2019s boats rise and save this whole industry,\u201d he said.\n\nSeveral people who have spoken to Dr. Soon-Shiong about the newspaper characterized him as smart, tech savvy and eager to learn about a business in which he has until now largely admired from afar. But many of his inquiries have revealed his inexperience in running a newspaper: He has, for instance, asked how journalists put together coverage and whether the same newsroom staff can work on print and digital.\n\nDr. Soon-Shiong\u2019s wife, Michele Chan, a former actress, has accompanied him to some of the meetings about The Times, and also seemed to be involved in decision-making, Mr. Pearlstine said. \u201cShe talks really eloquently about wanting the workplace to be more diverse and more reflective of the community it covers,\u201d he said.\n\nMr. Pearlstine said that in their discussions about the newspaper, Dr. Soon-Shiong \u201ctalked a lot about this desire for a legacy.\u201d\n\nNot exactly an unknown in Los Angeles, Dr. Soon-Shiong remains a largely obscure figure in a city that values celebrity and personal achievement. His philanthropy has been mainly focused on health care \u2014 his name adorns a hospital in Santa Monica. And he prefers to pal around with ballplayers (he owns a piece of the Lakers) rather than Hollywood types. First Up, Relocating to the Suburbs.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-06 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nLa Wilson, an enigmatic assemblage artist who took ordinary objects \u2014 from dice, plastic forks and alphabet blocks to bullet casings, fake guns and jewelry \u2014 and arranged them in boxes, giving them enthralling new life, died on March 30 in Hudson, Ohio, a suburb of Akron. She was 93.\n\nHer daughter, Jenny Wilson, said the cause was most likely complications of two recent strokes.\n\nMs. Wilson did not plan her elaborate constructions, which hinted at Surrealism and Modernism. She did not explain their meaning (if they had any \u2014 she left that up to the observer). And she did not say why she chose particular items and arranged them as she did in boxes and other containers.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s just trial and error,\u201d she said in a short biographical film made in 2011 for the Cleveland Arts Prize, which she won in 1993. She added, \u201cI don\u2019t have anything in my head that I want them to say, but it\u2019s entirely what happens when they get together that makes the story, so the story is brand new to me.\u201d\n\nMany of Ms. Wilson\u2019s works are in the permanent collections of several museums \u2014 including the Akron Art Museum \u2014 and have been the subject of numerous exhibitions.", "title": "La Wilson, 93, Dies; Made Art in Elaborate Assemblages", "authors": ["Richard Sandomir"]} {"date": "2018-04-19 00:00:00", "text": "If he had lost in court, Armstrong faced the possibility of paying treble damages under the terms of the False Claims Act, which is aimed at recovering government money obtained by fraud. The government could have demanded nearly $100 million.\n\nThe settlement averted a trial scheduled to begin with jury selection in about two weeks in Federal District Court in Washington.\n\n\u201cI am particularly glad to have made peace with the Postal Service,\u201d Armstrong said in a statement issued by Peters\u2019s law firm. \u201cWhile I believe that their lawsuit against me was without merit and unfair, I have since 2013 tried to take full responsibility for my mistakes, and make amends wherever possible. I rode my heart out for the Postal cycling team, and was always especially proud to wear the red, white and blue eagle on my chest when competing in the Tour de France. Those memories are very real and mean a lot to me.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe prospect of losing his fortune had loomed over Armstrong, 46, since the case was filed in 2010. It was the most daunting of the legal woes that have dogged him since he confessed. A statement from Peters\u2019s law firm said the settlement had ended \u201call litigation against Armstrong related to his 2013 admission that during his career as a professional cyclist he had used performance-enhancing substances.\u201d\n\nFloyd Landis, a former teammate of Armstrong\u2019s, was the original plaintiff in the case, acting as a whistle-blower with a chance to receive a share of any money recovered by the government.\n\nThe government chose to join the case after Armstrong\u2019s confession in 2013, and the Postal Service claimed it would not have sponsored the team if it had known Armstrong was doping.\n\nLandis, who also doped during his cycling career and was stripped of the 2006 Tour de France title, will receive $1.1 million of the government\u2019s $5 million. In addition to the $5 million settlement, Armstrong will pay $1.65 million to cover Landis\u2019s legal costs, according to lawyers for both Landis and Armstrong.\n\n\u201cIt has been a difficult ordeal, and public opinion was not always on my side,\u201d Landis said in a statement from his lawyer\u2019s office. \u201cBut it was the right thing to do and I am hopeful that some positive changes for cycling and sport in general will be the result.\u201d\n\nThe government considered pursuing criminal fraud charges against Armstrong almost a year before he confessed, but it dropped the case.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cNo one is above the law,\u201d Chad A. Readler, the acting assistant attorney general for the Justice Department\u2019s civil division, said Thursday in a statement. \u201cA competitor who intentionally uses illegal P.E.D.s not only deceives fellow competitors and fans, but also sponsors, who help make sporting competitions possible. This settlement demonstrates that those who cheat the government will be held accountable.\u201d", "title": "Lance Armstrong Settles Federal Fraud Case for $5 Million", "authors": ["Juliet Macur"]} {"date": "2018-04-19 00:00:00", "text": "The chairwoman of the Landmarks Preservation Commission announced on Thursday that she was stepping down from her post, after nearly four years of a sometimes tumultuous stewardship.\n\nThe chairwoman, Meenakshi Srinivasan, had faced fierce opposition to a set of proposed rule changes that critics said would weaken protections for historic buildings in New York City.\n\nThose changes would, among other things, put the commission staff in charge of some types of landmarks decisions.
