Watch the video from our most recent post below, and follow us at@nytimes.", "title": "Lar Lubovitch Is Looking for Poets", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-13 00:00:00", "text": "Early on, in addition to dancing with Donald McKayle, Pearl Lang, John Butler and various ballet companies, you were a go-go dancer at a nightclub in Greenwich Village. What was that like?\n\nYes, Trude Heller\u2019s. I wore white bell-bottoms and white go-go boots. In those days, go-go dancers stood on a ledge above the dance floor and demonstrated the latest dances. I was really good at it. Go-go dancing was where my spirit of dance came alive. I became more interested in choreographing because there was no other place I could dance where I felt that free.\n\nDid you always think of yourself as a choreographer?\n\nI made up my first dance when I was about 3. I first heard the word \u201cchoreography\u201d as a child in a movie theater with my parents. It was a movie with Danny Kaye and he was doing a parody of Martha Graham, and the name of the dance parody was \u201cChoreography.\u201d I asked my father, \u201cWhat does that word mean?\u201d And he said, \u201cThat\u2019s the guy who makes up the steps.\u201d\n\nWhat qualities do you value in movement?\n\nMy style of movement is very fluid. I always knew that one step had to come out of another, with a sense of inevitability. All of the movement comes out of itself and delivers the next idea.\n\nYou\u2019ve said that \u201cA Brahms Symphony\u201d (1985) was a turning point for you. In what way?\n\nDance was exploding, and things were going in this much more conceptual direction. And I had to ask myself, was that really me or not? And I said, no, it isn\u2019t me. So I went in the opposite direction and took this music by Brahms and did this very passionate, very sentimental, very physically expressive dance. It was a statement to myself and whoever was watching that this was my truth.\n\nSome of your most well-received dances, like the duet from \u201cConcerto Six Twenty-Two\u201d (1986), \u201cMen\u2019s Stories\u201d (2000) and \u201cLittle Rhapsodies\u201d (2007), were made for men.", "title": "Lar Lubovitch: Confessions of a Former Go-Go Dancer", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-28 00:00:00", "text": "Early on, the event became popular with the digital subculture, lending credence to the belief that primitivism \u2014 even ironic primitivism \u2014 and great technological leaps make happy bedfellows. Mr. Harvey saw a connection.\n\n\u201cBoth Burning Man and the internet make it possible to regather the tribe of mankind,\u201d he told The Times in 1997. He also saw a \u201cdeep parallel between desert and cyberspace.\u201d\n\nThe festival\u2019s so-called gift economy is central to the experience. There may be whiskey bars and sandwich shops at Burning Man, but everything is free. Burners, as the participants call themselves, offer their products and services as gifts. (The only things for sale, by the organizers, are coffee and ice.) No one is allowed to display a corporate logo or even wear one on a T-shirt.\n\nPhoto\n\nMr. Harvey preferred to call the system a \u201cgift culture,\u201d because visitors spend plenty of money ahead of time on the supplies they bring. But he believed even a temporary experience with that culture was worthwhile \u2014 to counter economic norms.\n\n\u201cIf all your self-worth and esteem is invested in how much you consume, how many likes you get or other quantifiable measures,\u201d he told The Atlantic in 2014, \u201cthe desire to simply possess things trumps our ability or capability to make moral connections with people around us.\u201d\n\nMr. Harvey was born on Jan. 11, 1948, and adopted as an infant by Author Harvey and the former Katherine Langford. His parents were farmers near Portland, Ore., and his father also worked as a carpenter. In an article that Mr. Harvey wrote for the British newspaper The Independent in 2014, he said that he and his brother, Stewart, who was also adopted, \u201cfelt like exchange students: Everyone treated us well, but we didn\u2019t quite fit.\u201d\n\nRural life did not suit him, and his parents were not exactly spiritual adventurers. \u201cThe heart can really expire under those conditions,\u201d Mr. Harvey told Inc. magazine in 2012. \u201cI always felt like I was looking at the world from the outside.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHe escaped by serving in the Army. He gave college (Portland State University) a try, with the help of the G.I. Bill, but was disillusioned by what he saw as his professors\u2019 small-mindedness.\n\nPhoto\n\nHe and a girlfriend, Janet Lohr, moved to San Francisco in the 1970s, and he took jobs as a bike messenger, a taxi driver, a cook and eventually a landscape gardener. He made friends with artists who were making a living as blue-collar workers.\n\nThe first Burning Man, held at Baker Beach (famous for its Golden Gate Bridge views and nude-sunbathing section), was a cozy affair hosted by Mr. Harvey and a friend, Jerry James. It consisted of burning a scrap-lumber statue of an eight-foot-tall man and was attended by fewer than a dozen people \u2014 including Mr. Harvey\u2019s son, Tristan, who was 5 \u2014 although a crowd soon gathered to watch. It was a summer solstice celebration; Mr. Harvey sometimes said it also commemorated a romantic breakup.\n\nMr. Harvey was married once, briefly, to Patricia Johnson, and he raised their son, Tristan, who survives him, as a single father. He is also survived by his brother, Stewart.\n\nMr. Harvey remained fully involved with his creation until his stroke, supervising design decisions and choosing this year\u2019s theme, \u201cI, Robot.\u201d\n\nThe 2018 festival, scheduled for Aug. 26-Sept. 3, will go on, the organization said in a statement: \u201cIf there\u2019s one thing we know for sure, Larry wants us to burn the man.\u201d", "title": "Larry Harvey, the Man Behind Burning Man, Is Dead at 70", "authors": ["Anita Gates"]} {"date": "2018-04-05 00:00:00", "text": "The last of three major lawsuits over the surveillance of Muslims by the New York Police Department was settled on Thursday, ending years of litigation over a broad, decade-long spying program in which Intelligence Division detectives eavesdropped on conversations in cafes, asked people about their views on drone strikes and designated mosques as potential terrorist organizations.\n\nAs part of the settlement of Hassan v. City of New York, the police will use \u201creasonable and diligent efforts\u201d to expunge certain information pertaining to Muslim communities in New Jersey that the Intelligence Division gathered. The Department will also give plaintiffs a chance to propose revisions to a policy guide on compliance with the Handschu Guidelines, which govern how the police may investigate political and religious activity.\n\nSenior police officials will attend a public meeting with the plaintiffs, and the city will pay 10 businesses, mosques, student groups and individuals amounts ranging from $1,250 to $22,500 to satisfy their claims for damages. The settlement confirms that New York Police Department investigations involving political activity in New Jersey are subject to the Handschu Guidelines.\n\nNeither the city nor the police admitted any misconduct or violation of the law.\n\n\u201cToday\u2019s settlement marks a monumental victory for American-Muslim communities far and wide who have demanded fair and equal treatment by law enforcement,\u201d said Farhana Khera, executive director of Muslim Advocates, which filed the suit and was later joined by the Center for Constitutional Rights and the law firm Gibbons P.C.", "title": "Last Suit Accusing N.Y.P.D. of Spying on Muslims Is Settled", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-20 00:00:00", "text": "They fetch his takeout meals and draw him into conversation. They buy him warm coats and scarves and sneakers. Some trade emails about his health, which has been remarkably robust despite an occasional scare. (\u201cHe didn\u2019t get to the corner until 5:30 instead of his usual 3,\u201d a neighbor messaged to another on a morning in 2014. \u201cHe said he has to down cough syrup twice in the night now, and this time it knocked him out.\u201d)\n\nA physician in the White House arranged for a free chest X-ray. The superintendent at another building lets Mr. Singh into the basement for bathroom breaks. Customers stand guard over his papers until he returns.\n\nA man of quiet ways, Mr. Singh can be gloomy and taciturn one day, lively and opinionated the next; his mood varies with the weather and the headlines. Yet his regulars, most of them middle-aged or older, speak of him with warmth, and something more.\n\n\u201cI\u2019ve stayed with Singh out of loyalty,\u201d said Ken Coughlin, who runs a legal-information website and has been buying The New York Times from him every day for at least 20 years, at a cost now of about $1,250 a year. \u201cHe\u2019s a fixture in the neighborhood, a fixture in my life. I want to support him.\u201d\n\nLee Herman, a curator emeritus at the American Museum of Natural History, has been a patron since Mr. Singh first showed up. \"You see this guy, with wind chill of 11 below, out there selling papers,\u201d Mr. Herman said. \u201cHe\u2019s got a life that\u2019s extraordinary \u2014 what he has to go through to live.\u201d\n\nThese neighbors know little about that life, or one another\u2019s, but Mr. Singh knows all their preferences and quirks. He notices when they miss a day, and offers to save their papers. He serves noncustomers, too \u2014 clearing trash from the sidewalk, warning subway riders when trains aren\u2019t running, feeding the birds and dogs (\u201cmy other customers,\u201d he calls them), holding the door when White House residents need a hand.\n\nHis own home is a rent-controlled apartment in an S.R.O. hotel 20 blocks north, where he lives alone. He has no family in the United States. For Mr. Singh, it\u2019s all about the corner.", "title": "Last of the Newsies?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-02 00:00:00", "text": "RIO DE JANEIRO \u2014 A new Netflix series about a sprawling corruption investigation has muscled its way into Brazil\u2019s heated politics, outraging supporters of a leftist former president who is trying to make a comeback and stirring debate about how closely a docudrama should adhere to the facts.\n\nThe series, \u201cThe Mechanism,\u201d has drawn heat since it was released on March 23. Critics say its inaccuracies are unfair to a former president, Luiz In\u00e1cio Lula da Silva, who is the leading candidate in the polls for the election this fall. Others see in the show a more or less fair, if depressing, depiction of an intricate investigation that has so far seen more than 100 people convicted, including senior political figures like Mr. da Silva.\n\nStill others say the publicity \u2014 however negative \u2014 has only been a boon for Netflix, and lament the frivolity of talking about a television show instead of poverty, violence, environmental conflicts and the myriad other challenges that face Brazil, Latin America\u2019s most populous nation.\n\nThe debate has been fierce.\n\nPaulo Roberto Pires, a left-leaning columnist at the newsmagazine \u00c9poca, called the series misleading, adding that it reduced complex political, historical and social issues to the fight against corruption.", "title": "Latest Uproar in Brazil\u2019s Raw Political Debate: A Netflix Series", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-14 00:00:00", "text": "And so leaders at the summit were left facing a difficult question: What could be done about Venezuela?\n\nDisinviting its president was one step. Peru, saying that it and a dozen other countries felt democracy was unraveling there, clawed back its invitation. Mr. Maduro vowed to crash the event anyway \u2014 \u201cby air, land or sea,\u201d he said \u2014 but ultimately decided not to try to attend.\n\nOther countries have taken steps to isolate Venezuela further.\n\nIn late March, Panama put Mr. Maduro and other government officials on a list of potential money launderers; in doing so, it joined the United States and Canada, which have both issued targeted sanctions. Most large countries in the region have refused to recognize the Constituent Assembly, a new body Mr. Maduro created last year to replace the country\u2019s National Assembly, which was controlled by his opposition.\n\n\u201cThe response of the region has been unprecedented,\u201d said David Smilde, a sociology professor at Tulane University and an analyst at the Washington Office on Latin America, a human rights group.\n\nBut, he added, \u201cExternal pressure goes only so far \u2014 you have to have a viable opposition from within.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nHopes among opposition politicians reached their peak last year when hundreds of thousands of Venezuelans poured into the streets to demand food and new elections. The protests continued for months, despite a deadly crackdown by the government that left more than 100 dead in street clashes.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut Mr. Maduro eventually gained the upper hand, and when the protests ended, the opposition was left divided on what to do next. The most pressing decision was the presidential election on May 20, which the main coalition of opposition parties has chosen to boycott.\n\nYet even the boycott has provoked disagreement, with some opposition politicians running anyway, including Henri Falc\u00f3n, a former state governor in Mr. Maduro\u2019s party who is now challenging the president, though his candidacy is considered a long shot.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cThere\u2019s no conditions for transparent elections,\u201d said Margarita L\u00f3pez Maya, a retired political scientist who taught at the Central University of Venezuela. \u201cMaduro will get whatever numbers he decides on Election Day.\u201d\n\nThe region\u2019s leaders have been watching what role the United States will play in the crisis.\n\nLast year, President Trump said he might consider using the military against Mr. Maduro. Though considered an empty threat, it was the kind of rhetoric that allowed Mr. Maduro to characterize his opponents as American pawns.\n\nVice President Mike Pence, who traveled to the meeting after Mr. Trump abruptly canceled to manage the military operation in Syria, told reporters on Saturday that the coming election in Venezuela was a \u201csham.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cThe world is not deceived,\u201d said Mr. Pence, who had earlier announced a new round of American aid to deal with the refugee crisis and promised tougher sanctions against the Maduro government. \u201cDemocracy has collapsed, dictatorship has arisen.\u201d\n\nDuring his closing speech at the summit meeting, Mr. Pence called on nations throughout the region to band together with the United States to further isolate Mr. Maduro. \u201cUnder the Maduro regime, Venezuela is essentially a failed state,\u201d Mr. Pence told the attendees.\n\nOn Friday, Mr. Pence met with exiled Venezuelan opposition leaders, saying \u201cwe\u2019ll continue to do everything in our power to provide sustenance and support to those who have fled this tyranny.\u201d\n\nAntonio Ledezma, the former mayor of Caracas, now living in exile in Spain, made an impassioned plea to Mr. Pence to ratchet up pressure on the Maduro government, and provide \u201cnot only humanitarian aid, but humanitarian intervention.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHe argued that additional sanctions should target the Maduro government\u2019s wealth, including actions to \u201cseize planes, yachts, mansions.\u201d\n\nOther leaders attending the summit pointed to Mr. Pence\u2019s presence as an attempt at foreign meddling in the region.\n\n\u201cThe principal threat to peace, to Mother Earth and multilateralism is the United States. They seek more flexibility to admit candidates they think are promising but who do not necessarily fit a conventional profile.\n\nA showdown of sorts is set for later this month when the American Bar Association\u2019s accrediting body plans to hold a public hearing where both sides can air their views.\n\nThe University of Arizona James E. Rogers College of Law, in Tucson, where Mr. Holm is a student, was a leader in moving beyond the LSAT requirement. In 2016, the school said it would allow applicants to present results of the GRE, which is taken around the world by about six times more students than the 126,000 or so who take the LSAT annually.\n\nTest scores are combined with other measures, including grade-point average, to admit students for the three-year juris doctoral degree.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSome schools value the LSAT\u2019s record of predictability and will keep the test, but many law schools \u201care looking to innovate and experiment,\u201d said Christopher P. Chapman, president and chief executive of AccessLex Institute, the nonprofit organization representing most of the more than 200 accredited law schools.\n\nSupporters of the LSAT, administered since 1948, say they believe it already allows law schools to take into account a broad spectrum of education and experiences in deciding who can study to become a lawyer.\n\n\u201cIt provides a common measure for all applicants,\u201d said Christina B. Whitman, a professor at the University of Michigan Law School and chairman of the board of trustees of the Law School Admissions Council, which oversees the LSAT. \u201cHow else could admissions directors evaluate students, like me, who attended massive state universities,\u201d she said. .\n\nNearly 20 law schools, including Harvard\u2019s, have embraced the GRE as an alternative. More than 150 law school deans, including those from many elite schools that had no shortage of applicants, vigorously backed Arizona\u2019s effort two years ago to introduce the alternative.\n\nIn March, the Education Testing Service, the Princeton, N.J., organization that administers the GRE and other standardized tests, unveiled a tool to help schools compare the results of the GRE and the LSAT.\n\nSupporters of the GRE say fewer restrictions will make law school more readily available to people of more varied backgrounds as well as more races, ethnicities and income levels to offset the small percentages of minorities in law school. Black and African Americans make up only about 8.5 percent of law students; Asians and Hispanics make up an additional 20 percent of law students in 2017.\n\nLearning: A Special Section Welcome to the new Learning section \u2014 a deep dive into the joys, excitement, challenges and opportunities in the world of education and learning. This is the first of four refreshed and redesigned sections we will publish this year. Drawing on the commitment to the subject and the expertise across The New York Times, we want Learning to be a place where educators, students and parents can join a vigorous conversation around the best ways to educate people, whether children or adults. (You can reach us at learningsection@nytimes.com with comments and ideas.) - Jane Bornemeier, Editor\n\nArizona has admitted students with academic backgrounds in disciplines like math, engineering and science who had not typically considered law school as an educational path.\n\nMany are older than their early to mid-20s, which was once a more traditional age to enter law school, and already have graduate degrees and skills from previous careers.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cA number of them are people in mid-careers, with families, looking for a career change,\u201d said Marc L. Miller, the school\u2019s dean. \u201cHalf or more are making a career shift, from disciplines like accounting or careers in the military,\u201d he said, adding, \u201cWe have a Ph.D. chemist, a geneticist and a doctoral student in rhetoric.\u201d\n\nStudents with such academic backgrounds often test well on the LSAT, where scores of 160 or higher are generally considered desirable for law school admissions. But they frequently choose the GRE because it can be used to apply to graduate and business schools as well as some law schools.\n\nSo far, Arizona has enrolled 25 students \u2014 12 in the first year and 13 in the second year \u2014 who applied on the basis of their GRE scores. It is too early to tell how they will fare because the first group of students will not take their state licensing exams until next year \u2014 after they receive their degrees.\n\nMr. Miller said the students \u201care randomly distributed around the classes, which have around 80 people each, and their performance is well within what we normally see.\u201d\n\nIn the first group, he said, many seemed to avoid saying they had taken only the GRE. \u201cBut by the second class, no one was the least bit worried to say so.\u201d\n\nMr. Holm, who has been a teacher, nonprofit executive and a budget official, said he was never asked about what test he took.\n\n\u201cIt was hard enough being the first,\u201d recalled Mr. Holm, about his early law student days, \u201cbut I was mindful that there was a stigma that someone might not be qualified enough.\u201d", "title": "Law Schools Debate a Contentious Testing Alternative", "authors": ["Elizabeth Olson"]} {"date": "2018-04-12 00:00:00", "text": "WASHINGTON \u2014 Scott Pruitt, the Environmental Protection Agency administrator, insisted on staying in luxury hotels that were costlier than allowed by government standards, while also pushing to fly on an airline not on the government\u2019s approved list so he could accrue more frequent flier miles, one of his top former deputies at agency has told congressional investigators.\n\nThe new allegations are detailed in a scathing six-page letter signed by two senators and three House lawmakers \u2014 all Democrats \u2014 whose staff members met this week with Kevin Chmielewski, who served as the E.P.A.\u2019s deputy chief of staff until he was removed from his post after raising objections to this and other spending.\n\nIn a separate letter on Thursday, Democratic lawmakers also demanded information about two previously unknown E.P.A. email addresses that have been used by Mr. Pruitt, asking if they were a tool for withholding public information from records requests. Their letter echoes a controversy in 2012, during the Obama administration, when Lisa P. Jackson, who was E.P.A. chief at the time, was criticized for a similar use of an undisclosed E.P.A. email account.\n\nJahan Wilcox, a spokesman for the E.P.A., said the agency had consistently searched all email addresses associated with Mr. Pruitt when responding to records requests. Head, Scott Pruitt", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-25 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nA lawsuit accusing the music mogul Russell Simmons of rape was dropped from federal court in Los Angeles on Wednesday.\n\nThe complaint was filed in January by Jennifer Jarosik, 37, who sought $5 million in damages. She said that she had first met Mr. Simmons in 2006 when he had offered to help her produce a documentary. Ms. Jarosik said that Mr. Simmons raped her at his home in Los Angeles in 2016 and that afterward she felt humiliation, fear and depression.\n\nOn April 4, Mr. Simmons\u2019s legal team submitted an answer in court that strongly denied the accusations, saying that the complaint was \u201cfilled with lies against Mr. Simmons, who has only ever tried to help her.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Louder Newsletter Every week, stay on top of the latest in pop and jazz with reviews, interviews, podcasts and more from The New York Times music critics. An additional lawsuit accusing Mr. Simmons of rape was filed in March; the complainant, a woman identified as Jane Doe, is seeking $10 million in damages.", "title": "Lawsuit Accusing Russell Simmons of Rape Is Dropped", "authors": ["Andrew R. Chow"]} {"date": "2018-04-25 00:00:00", "text": "Jenn Rolnick Borchetta, the deputy director of impact litigation for the Bronx Defenders, said that allowing the police to handle sealed records unchecked undermines efforts in New York City to promote fairness and limit unnecessary harm in the criminal justice system. A court ruling, she said, is needed to remind the Police Department of its obligation under state law.\n\n\u201cThere\u2019s such a push in New York to get people disentangled from the criminal justice system for crimes of poverty like jumping a turnstile,\u201d she said, \u201cand the N.Y.P.D. is overriding it based on sealed arrests that, under longstanding privacy rules, are supposed to not be used in any way, particularly in ways that continue to harm people when they\u2019ve already had their cases dismissed.\u201d\n\nThe sealing statutes curtail access to official records of sealed cases \u2014 except for published court decisions or opinions, or records and briefs on appeal \u2014 for people other than the accused and for public and private agencies. The laws also require fingerprints and photos in the files to be destroyed or returned to the accused.\n\nBut the statutes do not conceal the records completely and forever: Lawmakers carved out several exceptions for access, including for law enforcement agencies to get permission from a court.\n\nNick Paolucci, a spokesman for the city Law Department, said the agency would \u201creview the lawsuit and respond in the litigation.\u201d The city has 60 days to do so.\n\nThe Police Department declined to comment. But the case cites a memorandum from a federal lawsuit over dismissed summonses that the city settled for $75 million last year. In it, city lawyers said the Police Department uses sealed arrest data for a variety of reasons, including to solve crimes and apprehend suspects.\n\nJeffrey A. Fagan, a professor at Columbia Law School who testified against the city in litigation over its stop-and-frisk tactics, said that claim appears to never have been challenged. \u201cAbsent some showing of some statutory authorization to contravene the statute, then the plaintiffs seem to have a pretty strong claim,\u201d he said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe outcome of the lawsuit could affect millions of case files. Just between 2014 and 2016, as the police scaled back stop-and-frisk, over 400,000 cases were supposed to be sealed, according to the complaint. Almost 83 percent, or 330,000 cases, involved black and Latino defendants, who are more likely to live in communities where police activity is highest and for whom being arrested can have a detrimental impact on their employment, housing, immigration status and eligibility for public benefits.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Race/Related Newsletter Join a deep and provocative exploration of race with a diverse group of New York Times journalists. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMost of the sealed cases involved minor offenses \u2014 such as fare evasion \u2014 which made up 750,000 of the 1.1 million arrests effected by the Police Department between 2014 and 2017.\n\nA court ruling could resonate across the country at a time when police departments are increasingly amassing data and using it to drive investigations and to make enforcement and policy decisions. Most states have laws requiring some criminal cases to be expunged or sealed, but compliance varies, observers say.\n\n\u201cThey\u2019re sharing data across their networks, and this introduces just a more vast and fast dissemination of personal information than existed 10 years ago or before that,\u201d Ms. Borchetta said. \u201cThese technologies represent great advancements in law enforcement but they also create new privacy concerns.\u201d\n\nEugene O\u2019Donnell, a former city police officer who now teaches at John Jay College, said the information contained in arrest reports is indispensable to investigators because it can help them track patterns, determine affiliations and examine particular crime spikes.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s a treasure trove of information for investigators, whether you\u2019re talking about street crime, terrorism or more sophisticated investigations,\u201d said Professor O\u2019Donnell, who was also a prosecutor in Brooklyn and Queens. \u201cIt\u2019s not something you want to put out of your reach.\u201d\n\nEven though a sealed case did not result in a conviction, he said, that does not always mean a person did not commit a crime or other egregious act.\n\n\u201cIf you want to hire someone for a position of trust, do you want to be blind to that or see what was on file?\u201d he said. \u201cThere are very clear cases where someone got away with a very serious crime for whatever reason.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nNarrow exceptions in the sealing statutes allow access to someone\u2019s sealed case records for prosecutors, parole and corrections agencies, gun licensing authorities, and employers that hire peace officers and police officers. For instance, prosecutors may see the sealed records of someone to whom they are considering offering a deal to dismiss a subsequent case if the person stays out of trouble for a certain period of time. In another example, police departments are permitted to access the sealed arrest records of people who apply to become officers.\n\nBut the process for the police to obtain a court order for individuals\u2019 records can be burdensome, Professor O\u2019Donnell said, and the lawsuit could spur the Legislature to amend the statutes, which lawmakers expanded last year to include nonviolent criminal convictions more than 10 years old. Or, he said, it might prompt a streamlining of the process to obtain court approval for sealed records, much as the process for getting warrants has been simplified.\n\nThe Police Department\u2019s use of sealed records has attracted a legal challenge before, and it agreed to scrub that kind of information from a database of street stops as part of a settlement with the New York Civil Liberties Union in 2013.\n\nThe Police Department handbook for detectives details how to request a court order to unseal photos and court records, but it also outlines a process for investigators to obtain an authorization code to access sealed arrest records without court approval. And, according to the lawsuit, the sealed arrests also appear on the rap sheets that patrol officers consult during street stops to decide whether to make an arrest or issue a violation for minor infractions.\n\nPolice officials often anonymously reveal information about sealed arrests to the media in big cases like fatal police shootings. But defense lawyers say the practice is also common in everyday cases that do not capture the spotlight.\n\nIn interviews, public defenders said they often found sealed records in police documents turned over by prosecutors, or evidence suggesting they have been used, such as a phone number from a sealed file or video of detectives interrogating their clients about sealed cases.\n\nOne of the plaintiffs in the lawsuit, identified as R.C., was living and working in Wappinger Falls, N.Y., when he was arrested in connection with an April 2015 robbery in the Bronx. R.C.\u2019s picture had been used in three photo arrays shown to the victim, who finally chose it two weeks after the incident. But the image the police used was from a 2011 arrest that was sealed, and therefore required to be destroyed or returned to R.C., according to the complaint.\n\nFriends told investigators that R.C. had stayed in Danbury, Conn., on the night of the robbery, and prosecutors ultimately dropped the case in November 2016. But, the complaint said, commuting for his 10 court appearances cost R.C. his job and the experience left him scarred.", "title": "Lawsuit Challenges Police Use of Sealed Arrest Records", "authors": ["Ashley Southall"]} {"date": "2018-04-27 00:00:00", "text": "Ms. Veselnitskaya had long insisted that she met the president\u2019s son, son-in-law and campaign chairman in a private capacity, not as a representative of the Russian government.\n\n\u201cI operate independently of any governmental bodies,\u201d she wrote in a November statement to the Senate Judiciary Committee. \u201cI have no relationship with Mr. Chaika, his representatives and his institutions other than those related to my professional functions as a lawyer.\u201d\n\nBut that claim had already been undercut last fall by revelations that her talking points for the Trump Tower meeting \u2014 detailing tax and financial fraud accusations against two Democratic Party donors tied to a Kremlin opponent \u2014 matched those in a confidential memorandum circulated by Mr. Chaika\u2019s office.\n\nAnd a sheaf of Ms. Veselnitskaya\u2019s email correspondence released Friday appeared to show that her relationship with Mr. Chaika\u2019s office is far closer than she has described.\n\nThe emails were obtained by Dossier, an organization set up by Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky, a former tycoon who was stripped of his oil holdings, imprisoned and then exiled from his native Russia. He has emerged as a leading opponent of President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia.\n\nShown copies of the emails by Richard Engel of NBC News, Ms. Veselnitskaya acknowledged that \u201cmany things included here are from my documents, my personal documents.\u201d She told the Russian news agency Interfax on Wednesday that her email accounts were hacked this year by people determined to discredit her, and that she would report the hack to Russian authorities.\n\nThe Russian prosecutor general\u2019s office did not respond to requests for comment. In an email, Ms. Veselnitskaya said she would respond in two weeks.\n\nThe exchanges document Mr. Chaika\u2019s response to a Justice Department request in 2014 for help with its civil fraud case against a real estate firm, Prevezon Holdings Ltd., and its owner, Denis P. Katsyv, a well-connected Russian businessman.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nFederal prosecutors say Ms. Veselnitskaya was the driving force on Mr. Katsyv\u2019s defense team, a description she has echoed in court filings. In a declaration to the court, she identified herself as a lawyer in private practice, representing Mr. Katsyv and his firm.\n\nThe Justice Department prosecutors charged Mr. Katsyv\u2019s firm in 2013 with using real estate purchases in New York to launder a portion of the profits from a tax scheme in Russia. They were seeking Russian bank, tax and court records, the type of documents that typically form the crux of civil money-laundering cases. The Justice Department asked the Russian government to keep the matter confidential, \u201cexcept as is necessary to execute this request,\u201d according to court documents. Russia and the United States have a mutual legal assistance treaty governing law-enforcement requests.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe emails indicate that a senior prosecutor on Mr. Chaika\u2019s staff, Sergei A. Bochkaryov, worked closely with Ms. Veselnitskaya to craft the Russian government response. She knew him well enough to address him in friendly terms.\n\n\u201cDear Sergei Aleksandrovich!\u201d Ms. Veselnitskaya wrote on Aug. 2, 2014, in one of at least 11 emails exchanged. \u201cI am sending you the edits in the draft response, as per instructions. I am ready to answer any questions that arise, at any time convenient for you.\u201d\n\nThe language in their final email exchange matches that of the prosecutor general\u2019s official response to the Justice Department.\n\nThe judge in the case later wrote that the Russian government had \u201cspurned\u201d the Justice Department\u2019s request for evidence, instead sending a lengthy treatise on why Ms. Veselnitskaya\u2019s client was innocent.\n\nMs. Veselnitskaya\u2019s involvement in the official communications with the Russian government \u201craises serious questions about obstruction of justice and false statements,\u201d said Jaimie Nawaday, a former assistant United States attorney in Manhattan who was a prosecutor on the case.\n\nShe said Ms. Veselnitskaya\u2019s actions should be referred to the United States attorney\u2019s office for investigation, including whether she misrepresented herself to the court. \u201cIt\u2019s completely outrageous,\u201d Ms. Nawaday said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAsked about the Russian government\u2019s culpability, Andrew Keane Woods, a professor at the University of Kentucky law school who specializes in international law, said, \u201cIf there was funny business, then they are not really complying with the terms of the treaty.\u201d But, he added, \u201cthere is no clear sanction\u201d for failing to comply.\n\nMoscow\u2019s refusal to provide records to the American prosecutors dealt a severe blow to the case. In the end, the Justice Department agreed to settle it for about $6 million. Prevezon did not admit fault.\n\nAlthough Ms. Veselnitskaya appears to have influenced how the Russian prosecutor general\u2019s office justified its decision, its refusal to cooperate was not unexpected. The tax fraud was uncovered by Sergei L. Magnitsky, a Russian lawyer who was imprisoned and died in custody after disclosing the theft. Russian officials contend that the Magnitsky case, which became a cause c\u00e9l\u00e8bre in Washington, was a fraud concocted by the West to justify sanctions against Russian citizens.\n\nThe release of Ms. Veselnitskaya\u2019s emails by Mr. Khodorkovsky marks a second foray by Russian opposition figures into the controversy over Russia\u2019s interference in the 2016 election. In a telephone interview, Mr. Khodorkovsky said someone had deposited the email records anonymously into an electronic drop box maintained by his organization.\n\nThis year, Aleksei A. Navalny, a key opposition leader in Russia, also publicized videos that he said hinted at a role for Oleg V. Deripaska, a well-known Russian oligarch, in the Russian government\u2019s efforts to meddle in the American political process. A spokesman for Mr. Deripaska said Mr. Navalny\u2019s accusations were utterly false.", "title": "Lawyer Who Was Said to Have Dirt on Clinton Had Closer Ties to Kremlin Than She Let On", "authors": ["Andrew E. Kramer", "Sharon Lafraniere"]} {"date": "2018-04-11 00:00:00", "text": "Since last year, immigration agents have been making arrests far more frequently in New York City\u2019s courthouses, sparking outrage from lawyers, district attorneys and activists.\n\nTheir fight has been with the federal authorities. But now, a rift has erupted along local lines.\n\nIt started when agents for United States Immigration and Customs Enforcement, known as ICE, detained two undocumented immigrants who had come to Queens Criminal Court on minor charges. In protest, lawyers for the Legal Aid Society of New York and Queens Law Associates staged a walkout, saying ICE should stay out of courthouses. It was the second such walkout this week, and the fifth in the last year.\n\nThe Office of Court Administration, which oversees the courts in New York State, responded by fulfilling a warning it had made an hour earlier: if the public defenders walked out on the job while court was still in session, cases would be reassigned to private defense lawyers under contract to represent the poor. Ten cases were reassigned.\n\nThe public defense organizations saw it as punishment for political advocacy; court administrators saw it as a matter of keeping the courts running.", "title": "Lawyers Walk Out to Protest ICE, and Court Objects", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-24 00:00:00", "text": "WASHINGTON \u2014 The couple seemed happy to be together again.\n\nWhen President Trump welcomed President Emmanuel Macron of France to the White House on Tuesday for the first official state visit of the Trump administration, their body language went beyond the usual respectful handshakes of two world leaders meeting for high-level talks and bordered on the intimate.\n\nThere was a mutual kiss on the cheek in the East Room, where Mr. Macron clasped hands with Mr. Trump, pulling him in for an embrace and a brief peck as Mr. Trump puckered his lips slightly to reciprocate.\n\n\u201cI like him a lot,\u201d Mr. Trump explained to reporters and officials looking on.\n\nEarlier in the Oval Office, the president had gently brushed what he said was dandruff off Mr. Macron\u2019s shoulder.\n\n\u201cWe have to make him perfect,\u201d Mr. Trump, 71, said of the trimmer Mr. Macron, 40. \u201cHe is perfect.\u201d\n\nMoments later, as they sat side by side, Mr. Macron placed his hand on Mr. Trump\u2019s knee.", "title": "Le Bromance: Trump and Macron, Together Again", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-18 00:00:00", "text": "Kyle Korver added 12 points, all on 3-pointers, and made several hustling plays for the Cavs.\n\nOladipo scored 22 points \u2014 he was in early foul trouble \u2014 and Myles Turner 18 for the Pacers, who stunned the Cavaliers with an overpowering win in Game 1.\n\nIndiana clawed back from an 18-point deficit on Wednesday and was within 95-92 when Oladipo, who scored 32 in the opener, somehow came free but missed maybe his easiest shot in two games. How the ball was inbounded with three seconds left. How each player caught the pass before drifting to his left, taking exactly two dribbles before rising over a helpless defender near the top of the arc.\n\nAnd how two former players, separated by time and fate, happened to be in the same arena to see the play that binds them essentially play out again right there on the court.\n\nBrad Sellers, a former center for the Chicago Bulls who was watching Wednesday\u2019s game with his daughter and her friends at Quicken Loans Arena, needed only a nanosecond to make the connection once LeBron James drained his buzzer-beating 3-pointer to lift the Cavaliers to a 98-95 victory against the Indiana Pacers in Game 5 of their first-round playoff series.\n\nOr was it May 7, 1989, again with Michael Jordan draining his buzzer-beating jumper to lift the Chicago Bulls to a 101-100 victory against the Cavaliers in Game 5 of their first-round playoff series?", "title": "LeBron James and Michael Jordan Now Have Another Thing in Common: The Shot", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-26 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cHe really did impose his will throughout the game,\u201d Pacers Coach Nate McMillan said.\n\nKyle Korver added 19 points and Cleveland\u2019s much-maligned defense tightened just in time as the Cavaliers seized their first lead in the first-round series after being down by 1-0 and 2-1.\n\nCleveland can close out Indiana with a win Friday night in Indianapolis.\n\nDomantas Sabonis scored 22 points, and Young had 16 for the Pacers.\n\nOladipo, who shot just 2 of 15, drove the left side and was at the rim when James swooped in for a block on a play reminiscent of his Game 7 block on Andre Iguodala in the 2016 N.B.A. finals.\n\nOladipo felt his shot hit the backboard first, which would make the block illegal.\n\n\u201cI got a step on him and I felt I even got grabbed,\u201d Oladipo said. \u201cIt hit the backboard and he blocked it. Some themes fall into place more easily than others.\n\nToday we get to solve a puzzle that just poured out of our constructor in one of those lucky instances. Lynn Lempel returns with a theme that might give solvers the impression that she doesn\u2019t want them around. But we all know that\u2019s not true.\n\nToday\u2019s Theme\n\nSometimes a constructor notices a common oddity in the language and the theme is set before the revealer, but today Ms. Lempel confides that the revealer inspired the theme. Four phrases make up a set in which a synonym for the exclamation \u201cGo!\u201d is at the beginning of the phrase, but is not an obvious, stand-alone word.", "title": "Lead Off", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-20 00:00:00", "text": "On assignment in Montgomery, Ala., recently, I toured the Rosa Parks Museum with a capacity student crowd; sang \u201cWe Shall Overcome\u201d in the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.\u2019s former church with tour-goers from Ohio, California and China; and waited 10 minutes in line at the Southern Poverty Law Center museum to buy my souvenir water bottle (for a good cause).\n\nMy experience, it turns out, is indicative of the current excitement surrounding civil rights tourism in the United States 50 years after the assassination of the movement\u2019s leader, Dr. King.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s a part of American history, not just African-American history,\u201d said Andrea Taylor, the chief executive of the Birmingham Civil Rights Institute in Birmingham, Ala. \u201cThere seems to be a convergence of interest in telling a more complete version of American evolution to include communities of color and particularly African-American communities.\u201d\n\nThe institute is part of the U.S. Civil Rights Trail, which launched in January, and identifies 110 locations associated with Civil Rights history in the 1950s and 60s across 14 states. They range from the F.W. Woolworth lunch counter in Greensboro, N.C., where peaceful protesters staged sit-ins, to the house of Daisy Bates, an organizer of the desegregation effort at Little Rock Central High School in Arkansas.", "title": "Learning About the Civil Rights Era Through Travel", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-19 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nLee Holley, who created an idyllic picture of postwar American teenage life through \u201cPonytail,\u201d a syndicated cartoon panel and Sunday comic strip that appeared in hundreds of newspapers around the world, has died in a plane crash in Marina, Calif. He was 85.\n\nMr. Holley, an amateur pilot, was flying his single-engine plane when it crashed at Marina\u2019s municipal airport on the morning of March 26. His daughter, Karen, confirmed the death in the last week as DNA tests were being performed on the remains. There were no passengers aboard the plane. Marina is about 10 miles north of Monterey, Calif.\n\nMr. Holley was an assistant and ghost illustrator for Hank Ketcham\u2019s \u201cDennis the Menace\u201d strip in 1960 when he conjured up \u201cPonytail.\u201d In single- and multi-panel comics, he depicted a lanky teenage girl immersed in postwar suburban life: cruising in hot rods to drive-in movie theaters and burger joints, attending school football games, negotiating with teachers at Watson Hill High School (about completing her homework), and managing diplomatic concerns with her parents (like the size of her allowance).\n\nMr. Holley, drawing on his own adolescent years, recognized a growing interest in teenage humor comics at the time, perhaps best exemplified by the strips \u201cEmmy Lou\u201d and \u201cPenny\u201d and the \u201cArchie\u201d comic book franchise.\n\nPhoto\n\nHis \u201cPonytail\u201d panels were windows on teenage sensibilities. In one scene his heroine tells her father why she is justified in watching a live performance by the Beatles: to stay on top of current events.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn another, she corners him on the couch to ask for money: \u201cDaddy, I need five dollars. \u2026 I\u2019m in a hurry, so could you give me your lecture about money TOMORROW?!\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nMany of Ponytail\u2019s narratives revolved around dating, with her focus on her main beau, Donald Dawson. By high school hallway lockers she tells him: \u201cOf course I\u2019ll love you forever, Donald. \u2026 Well, at least until someone with a better CAR comes along!\u201d", "title": "Lee Holley, Cartoonist of Teenage Life in \u2018Ponytail,\u2019 Dies at 85", "authors": ["Matthew Sedacca"]} {"date": "2018-04-29 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cHey, Superman,\u201d Mr. Kucinich said.\n\nPhoto\n\nSince the election of President Trump, certain conflicts have been inevitable for a Democratic Party asking itself how to win again: liberal or moderate candidates? Populist or pragmatist? Establishment or insurgent? But in the race between Mr. Cordray and Mr. Kucinich \u2014 one of the year\u2019s most closely watched Democratic primaries \u2014 a more basic tension has consumed the collective left: Who has the truest claim to progressivism in 2018, when both candidates can credibly grab at the label? Is it better to be liberal on guns (Mr. Kucinich) or the bane of the banks (Mr. Cordray)? To be a fire-breather or a bit of a square?\n\n\u201cThere\u2019s no stigma in being competent,\u201d said Kevin Davis, 63, of Akron, a Cordray supporter and fund-raiser who has gravitated toward the candidate\u2019s work-within-the-system defense of responsive government. \u201cDennis just promises everything.\u201d\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s hard not to be pulled into the vortex of Dennis Kucinich,\u201d said Nina Turner, a former state senator and the president of Our Revolution, a group that was formed out of Mr. Sanders\u2019s presidential campaign and that has endorsed Mr. Kucinich. \u201cHe\u2019s infectious.\u201d\n\nAs Democrats look to reclaim a purple state shading red, recent history suggests a slog. Mr. Trump won Ohio by eight points. It has a Republican-controlled legislature and has had a Republican governor for all but four years since 1991. But the prospect of a Democrat-friendly election year and a whiff of scandal in Columbus \u2014 where the House speaker resigned this month as federal investigators questioned his conduct \u2014 has convinced strategists that even a proudly liberal candidate could win in November.\n\nThe Democratic primary has also doubled as an early proxy test for supporters of Ms. Warren and Mr. Sanders, two possible presidential candidates in 2020, and a peek at precisely what kind of figure can speak to today\u2019s party base in a Midwestern bellwether.\n\nMr. Cordray, 58, a former state attorney general before his time in Washington, has campaigned with Ms. Warren, who devised the bank-regulating agency he oversaw under President Barack Obama. He is leaning heavily on support from labor groups like the Ohio Federation of Teachers and the Ohio A.F.L.-C.I.O., specking public appearances with protect-the-little-guy anecdotes from his watchdog role in the hope that voters will not mistake boring for moderate.\n\nThere is talk of task forces and pension protections, of government \u201cbeing a force for good\u201d again. He can appear most animated condemning an \u201congoing war on local communities\u201d from budget-slashing state officials. And, like Mr. Kucinich, he has proposed making community college free for all Ohioans.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cHe\u2019s unassuming,\u201d Ms. Warren said in an interview, recalling Mr. Cordray\u2019s habit of wandering his office without shoes when pressed for a humanizing detail. \u201cBut he\u2019s a fighter.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nMr. Kucinich is, as ever, a less traditional case \u2014 Cleveland\u2019s ubiquitous thrower of bombs, shaker of hands and enemy of animal products, now entering his second half-century in politics.\n\n\u201cStrange Political Amalgam in Ambitious Young Man,\u201d read a 1972 headline about him in The Akron Beacon Journal.\n\n\u201cHe defends Trump, sees UFOs,\u201d read another from The Cincinnati Enquirer in March, alluding to Mr. Kucinich\u2019s recent career as a Fox News pundit and his claim to have seen an unidentified flying object at the home of a friend, the actress Shirley MacLaine. \u201cCan Kucinich win?\u201d\n\nHe can, however improbably. Mr. Kucinich has emerged as the most persistent threat to Mr. Cordray, the presumed favorite, spooking party officials who fear Mr. Kucinich would stand little chance in the fall. Primary polling has been inconsistent: One recent survey showed the race effectively tied; another gave Mr. Cordray a double-digit edge, though more than half of respondents were undecided.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMr. Kucinich is betting on a coalition of still-loyal former constituents: A brief stroll through Cleveland\u2019s West Side Market recently included interactions with a woman whose father Mr. Kucinich once caddied for, a produce vendor who attended school with his sister and a police officer who worked security at his third wedding. He has also built a nascent following awakened to his politics since Mr. Sanders\u2019s run.\n\nMr. Sanders himself has not endorsed Mr. Kucinich. \u201cDennis is his own man,\u201d Mr. Sanders said in an interview with journalists from The New York Times, calling him an old friend. \u201cDennis is a very \u2014 what\u2019s the word? \u2014 unusual politician.\u201d\n\nBut Our Revolution, the Sanders-aligned group, has held up Mr. Kucinich as a kind of progressive seer, who pushed ideas like tuition-free college long before they came into wider fashion, rallying behind the storm-the-castle populism familiar to admirers of both men.\n\nIn an interview, Mr. Kucinich rejected any suggestion that this is a race between two generally analogous progressives on policy. He described himself, unsubtly, as a leader \u201cfor a couple of decades\u201d on issues like single-payer health care. And since the Parkland, Fla., massacre in February, he has made gun safety central to his campaign, repeatedly reminding voters of Mr. Cordray\u2019s past \u201cA\u201d rating from the National Rifle Association and his refusal to embrace an assault weapons ban.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cIf there was indeed truth-in-labeling in elections, Richard Cordray would be running as a Republican,\u201d Mr. Kucinich said.\n\nAt a recent candidate forum, he affixed an \u201cF\u201d pin to his lapel to signal his own N.R.A. grade. Mr. Kucinich\u2019s wife, Elizabeth, three decades younger than her husband and six inches taller, mouthed instructions from the front row while filming him. (Two other Democrats \u2014 Joe Schiavoni, a state senator, and Bill O\u2019Neill, a former Ohio Supreme Court justice \u2014 are also competing to replace Gov. John R. Kasich, a term-limited Republican. The leading Republican candidates are Mike DeWine, the state attorney general, and Mary Taylor, the lieutenant governor.)\n\nYet Mr. Kucinich, more than most Democrats, has run afoul of perceived liberal doctrine himself through the years.\n\nHe once opposed abortion rights. He has echoed Mr. Trump\u2019s concerns about a \u201cdeep state\u201d plot. And he has reported receiving $20,000 for a speech from a group sympathetic to President Bashar al-Assad of Syria, whom Mr. Kucinich has traveled to see. (Mr. Kucinich, who has since promised to return the money, said in the interview that he always met with leaders \u201cin the cause of peace\u201d and did not answer directly when asked if Mr. Assad was a bad actor.)\n\nIn conversations with voters, many framed their preferences as a matter of temperament as much as vision. \u201cHe\u2019s not a hell-raiser,\u201d Matt Rado, 34, said of Mr. Cordray, for whom he plans to vote anyway. \u201cIt would be nice to see some more passion.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nEven playful flourishes from Mr. Cordray seem intended to evoke a certain hyper-diligence. His campaign literature cites his five \u201cJeopardy\u201d championships in the 1980s. In a past race, he rewarded dedicated volunteers with DVD copies of his triumph.\n\nHe is said to enjoy a good parade \u2014 \u201cI\u2019ve always been a parade-ophile,\u201d he allowed \u2014 and recently demonstrated his levity to a reporter by pledging to squeeze himself down a children\u2019s slide at a Canton playground after a speech to ironworkers. He kept his word against the advice of a press aide.\n\n\u201cThe buttoned-down world of the federal financial regulators is very different,\u201d Mr. Cordray said in an interview. \u201cThere\u2019s more emotion in this. And it\u2019s been something I\u2019ve had to learn and improve.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHis opponent appears committed to his own instincts and eccentricities, in politics and lesser affairs.\n\nDiscussing his campaign over a vegan veggie burger and coconut water \u2014 \u201cI like it right out of the coconut. Have you ever had it?\u201d he asked the waitress, who had not \u2014 Mr. Kucinich set off on a consumption strategy that confounded even his wife, seated beside him: He cut around the bun with a knife and fork to eat only the patty, waited several minutes, then returned to the bun on its own, again with a knife and fork.\n\n\u201cThere\u2019s no method,\u201d he confirmed.\n\n\u201cJust madness,\u201d Mrs. Kucinich said.", "title": "Left vs. Left: Richard Cordray and Dennis Kucinich Battle for Governor of Ohio", "authors": ["Matt Flegenheimer"]} {"date": "2018-04-14 00:00:00", "text": "The arrival of an abortion bill in the Chamber of Deputies, the lower house of Argentina\u2019s Congress, is widely seen as a direct outgrowth of a broader women\u2019s rights movement in the country that started in 2015 with a campaign against femicides called \u201cNi Una Menos,\u201d \u201cNot One Less.\u201d\n\nHundreds of thousands of women have taken to the streets in recent years to raise awareness about domestic violence and press for stronger laws to protect women.\n\n\u201cThe Ni Una Menos movement led to a surge of adherence to the feminist movement and a generalized demand for more equal rights,\u201d said Dora Barrancos, 77, a sociologist at the National Scientific and Technical Research Council, a government agency. \u201cThis change is very overwhelming.\u201d\n\nFor Andrea Schenk, 28, who joined the abortion rights demonstrators outside Congress, the link between Ni Una Menos and the abortion debate unfolding among lawmakers is undeniable.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cFighting against femicides led us to fight against all forms of violence against women \u2014 and not letting us decide over our bodies is a form of violence,\u201d she said.\n\nThe prospect of legalization became more politically plausible earlier this year, when President Mauricio Macri, who opposes legalizing abortion, freed allied lawmakers to \u201cvote their conscience\u201d on the issue.\n\nIf the bill does pass \u2014 by no means certain \u2014 it would be, in part, because of a coalition of unlikely allies in Argentina\u2019s notoriously divided Congress.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe rise in activism among the country\u2019s women encouraged a few female lawmakers who support legalizing abortion to join forces. They include Victoria Donda, a leftist; Brenda Austin, from Mr. Macri\u2019s center-right Cambiemos coalition; Romina del Pl\u00e1, from the Workers\u2019 Party; and M\u00f3nica Macha, an ally of the center-left former president, Cristina Fern\u00e1ndez de Kirchner.\n\n\u201cAlthough we have lots of political differences, we also have a profound agreement on this issue,\u201d Ms. Macha said.\n\nHundreds of experts and witnesses are scheduled to appear before a special commission that will meet twice a week over the next two months to consider the bill.\n\nSeveral countries in Latin America allow abortions under limited circumstances, like pregnancy that results from rape or when the mother\u2019s life is threatened. Argentina would become the fourth nation in the region to allow abortion without such restrictions, if the procedure were to be legalized, joining Cuba, Uruguay, Guyana and some parts of Mexico.\n\nProponents of legalization in Argentina say their main motivation is to save lives. Complications from clandestine abortions account for 18 percent of maternal deaths in the country, making it the leading cause, said Mariana Romero, a researcher at the Center for the Study of the State and Society, a nonprofit organization. In 2016 and 2015, at least 98 women died as a result of botched abortions.\n\n\u201cThere are between 45,000 to 60,000 hospitalizations derived from clandestine abortions every year,\u201d said Ms. Austin, the lawmaker from the president\u2019s coalition. \u201cThose who are against legal abortion are in favor of clandestine abortions.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nAlthough women who have been raped or have potentially lethal pregnancy complications are allowed to have abortions in Argentina, few doctors perform the procedure because they are afraid of running afoul of the law.\n\n\u201cIn practice those exceptions are not actually honored, and what we see is a near total ban on abortions,\u201d said Salil Shetty, the secretary general of Amnesty International, who visited the country this past week.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSupport for legalizing abortion appears to have grown in Argentina in recent years as the Roman Catholic Church has lost clout.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nA 2006 survey by the Center for the Study of the State and Society showed 37 percent of Argentines said women should be allowed to have an abortion regardless of the cause, a number that increased to 49 percent in a poll the nonprofit carried out in March.\n\nAnother nationwide survey this year by the National University of General San Mart\u00edn found that about 55 percent of Argentines favor legalizing abortion, although attitudes vary widely by geography.\n\nIn the more rural northern provinces, 40 percent are in favor, a sharp contrast with the 67 percent in Buenos Aires.\n\n\u201cThere is a very clear correlation: More modern, urban areas are more likely to approve of legalization,\u201d said Lucas Romero, who leads Synopsis, a consultancy.\n\nThe high level of support to legalize abortion caught some experts on the issue off-guard.\n\n\u201cThe number really surprised me,\u201d said Vanesa V\u00e1zquez Laba, head of the gender and sexual diversity department at the National University of General San Mart\u00edn, referring to the university\u2019s poll. \u201cEvidently, the increased attention to gender violence led the abortion issue to suddenly take a more prominent role in society as a whole.\u201d\n\nSuch polling numbers, and the increase in the influence of the abortion rights movement, likely prompted Mr. Macri to assume what amounts to a neutral position as Congress takes up the debate.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cAs I\u2019ve said more than once, I\u2019m pro-life,\u201d Mr. Macri said in his annual speech before Congress on March 1. \u201cBut I\u2019m also in favor of the mature and responsible debates that we owe ourselves as Argentines.\u201d\n\nChurch leaders have been vocal in their opposition to the bill, and they have recently argued that improving sex education in schools is a better strategy for addressing unwanted pregnancies.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe first legislative hearing on the issue this month was unusually calm by the standards of Argentina\u2019s rancorous Congress. Hoping to keep acrimony to a minimum, Daniel Lipovetzky, the government-allied congressman who will lead the debate in committee and is in favor of abortion rights, insisted that all questions to experts be submitted in writing.\n\nOutside Congress, a smaller group of protesters urged lawmakers to listen to the \u201cvoice that is never heard,\u201d as they clapped to the sound of a heartbeat and danced to songs celebrating life.\n\n\u201cNo one has a right to kill a life,\u201d said Sabrina Soulier, 28. \u201cMurder also exists, but that doesn\u2019t mean we have to legalize it.\u201d\n\nSome 36 lawmakers out of 256 eligible to vote have yet to say where they stand, according to a count by Mr. Lipovetzky, who is optimistic that most of the undecideds will wind up in the yes column.\n\n\u201cAnything could happen,\u201d Mr. Lipovetzky said. \u201cThe result will depend on how those undecideds end up voting.\u201d\n\nMany foresee the real battle playing out in the Senate, where rural provinces have more sway. A count by Econom\u00eda Feminista, which advocates for gender equality, shows only 16 senators have spoken up in favor of legalization, while 27 have expressly said they are against the measure, and 29 have yet to say how they would vote.\n\nBut activists are convinced it will be difficult for senators to vote against the bill if it gathers a large margin of support in the lower house.\n\n\u201cNo senator is suicidal,\u201d Ms. Donda said. \u201cWe\u2019re going to win because we have the most solid arguments in our favor.\u201d", "title": "Legal Abortion in Argentina? A Long Shot Is Suddenly Within Reach", "authors": ["Daniel Politi"]} {"date": "2018-04-12 00:00:00", "text": "It was so cold in January in A\u2019seelah Diamond\u2019s apartment at Fiorentino Plaza, a public housing development in East New York, that she, her husband and their three daughters all piled into one bed every night to keep warm.\n\nThe radiators did not work, the carbon monoxide detector sounded an alarm when the family turned the oven on for heat, and if they tried to run more than one space heater at a time, the electricity would shut off.\n\n\u201cThe cold was unbearable,\u201d Ms. Diamond said. \u201cMy daughters would bring the blankets from their rooms and everyone would be in the bed like a big burrito.\u201d\n\nDuring a New York City winter with the most days below freezing since 1961, Ms. Diamond, 31, put in at least 10 requests to repair the heat and hot water with her landlord, the New York City Housing Authority, to no avail, she said. On Jan. 4 when the temperature outside was 19 degrees, her apartment had no heat or hot water.\n\nPhoto\n\nTenants such as Ms. Diamond and her husband, Tyrone, 30, who pay $1,282 a month in rent, deserve a refund, according to a lawsuit filed Thursday in State Supreme Court in Manhattan by the Legal Aid Society. The class-action lawsuit comes after the authority refused a demand from Legal Aid to abate from $2.5 million to $15 million in rent to tenants who were left without basic services during heating season.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cThe law is very clear, it requires they provide heat at a certain level, and if they don\u2019t, they are subject to a claim,\u201d said Jennifer Levy, supervising attorney for Legal Aid\u2019s civil reform unit.", "title": "Legal Aid Demands Rebates for Nycha Tenants Left in the Cold", "authors": ["Jeffery C. Mays"]} {"date": "2018-04-02 00:00:00", "text": "Jamison places a mental asterisk next to every achievement and all-nighter. These indicate how deeply unhappy she frequently was, drinking her way into regular blackouts, cutting and starving herself, crying in closets and alleys, having sex with strange men. That night chained up at the Advocate? She blacked out and had to be told, later, that she\u2019d vomited in a friend\u2019s car.\n\nImage Leslie Jamison Credit Beowulf Sheehan\n\nJamison had romanticized the \u201cunhinged sparks of luminous chaos\u201d she saw in the lives and work of writers like the poet John Berryman. She wanted a sliver of the authenticating chaos all to herself; she got it, and more.\n\nIn \u201cThe Recovering,\u201d Jamison\u2019s story is braided with the larger story of addiction in America. We read about Nixon\u2019s war on drugs and about narcotics prisons. Theorists, clinicians and neuropharmacologists are cited. The career arcs of artist-drinkers like Berryman, Jean Rhys and Billie Holiday are traced.\n\nThis material has been hashed over many times in previous books, and in the first half of \u201cThe Recovering\u201d Jamison brings little that\u2019s new to this discussion. You frequently feel you\u2019re reading filler; mental sawdust.\n\nThe first half is off-putting in other ways. Jamison is close to humorless as a writer, and she rubs and rubs our noses in her bad-girl bona fides. Every lily is painted, black. She performs a down-and-out version of what the essayist and critic Logan Pearsall Smith called a \u201cswimgloat,\u201d a triumphal glide through society.\n\nThe two aspects of this memoir don\u2019t mix particularly well. I would have dropped this book gently behind the sofa if I weren\u2019t contractually obligated to finish it. But I\u2019ll admit that I\u2019m glad I did clean my plate.\n\nThe great surprise of \u201cThe Recovering\u201d is that the second half is close to magnificent, and genuinely moving. This is that rare addiction memoir that gets better after sobriety takes hold.\n\nJamison joins Alcoholics Anonymous and, after a relapse, gets sober. She is a powerful describer of the kind of community she enters with A.A. meetings. She evokes the church basements and Styrofoam cups of coffee and day-old pastries as well as any writer since David Foster Wallace.", "title": "Leslie Jamison\u2019s Memoir Finds Its Footing in Sobriety", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-11 00:00:00", "text": "Shopping online can make you feel like little more than a data set with a bank account. That\u2019s partly because we do it in private, behind screens \u2014 immune to texture and smell, no friends to keep binges in check \u2014 but also because the interactions it facilitates say everything and nothing about us. \u201cLast Chance!\u201d warns the vitamin-subscription ad I once clicked on accidentally. \u201cA romantic getaway?\u201d asks the hotel newsletter, one week post-breakup.\n\nBut there\u2019s one place on the internet where I feel less like Alice the Bodiless Cursor and more like Alice in Wonderland: AliExpress, the Chinese e-commerce site. Sixty million people spent $10 billion there in 2017, bewildering figures that only begin to make sense once you\u2019ve clicked through 17 pages of direct-from-Guangdong cocktail shakers. AliExpress has just about every product you could imagine, and plenty you probably couldn\u2019t, presented in no particular order. You\u2019ll discover everything from rain galoshes that fit over high heels to motion-activated toilet-seat lights. Shopping there feels like playing croquet with a flamingo or swimming in a pool filled with tears \u2014 bizarre but special, and if you find the right thing, you might feel special, too.\n\nAliExpress is not a destination so much as a hobby. While some people watch TV, count their pores or call their grandparents, I spend evenings savoring bot-translated product copy. (\u201cCan lay a beanbag chair ... Makeup nail beauty.\u201d Or perhaps you\u2019d prefer a \u201cFunny Pet High Temperature Wire Wig Hair Cat Exploding Hair Fancy Dog Wig.\u201d) I once uploaded a selfie into the app\u2019s reverse-image search and found that one of my face\u2019s nearest matches was a chaise longue. The chair was made by a company called DAMEDAI Fascinating Store, in Zhejiang Province. DAMEDAI\u2019s products were popular around the world: Its reviews featured praise from Russia, New Zealand, India, the United Arab Emirates and Iceland. Reading them, I wondered how many others were looking at this chair simultaneously, and whether any of their dimples happened to match its beige synthetic-suede folds as precisely as mine.\n\nWhile many websites generate the illusion of intimacy with personalized recommendation lists and curated feeds of familiar brands, AliExpress taps you directly into manufacturing hubs and supply chains \u2014 the sweep of global capitalism itself. Jack Ma, who co-founded the Alibaba Group, AliExpress\u2019s parent company, named it after the character in \u201cOne Thousand and One Nights.\u201d Today its sales are more than six times as large as eBay\u2019s. In addition to AliExpress, it encompasses Alibaba.com, which sells to businesses worldwide; Taobao Marketplace and Tmall, which primarily do business domestically; a film studio; an e-payment app; a grocery chain; Hong Kong\u2019s newspaper of record; and, with Ford, a vending machine that sells cars. Tmall can deliver groceries within hours in Beijing, but if you order something from AliExpress to New York City, it could take months. When it does arrive, the box will be collaged with port stamps, and when you open it, it will emit a chemically smell.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn recent years, as Western awareness about AliExpress has grown, websites trying to organize its chaos have emerged. One, Thieve, offers AliExpress listings \u201ccurated by creatives.\u201d Its logo is clean, and its selection of products is blandly chic: velvet throw pillows, geometric planters, leather MacBook accessory pouches. In essence, Thieve is a skin layered atop AliExpress. Of course, all brands are myths, and to shop is to swallow them, trading knowledge for convenience. I\u2019d rather hunt for treasure and make up my own stories about what it means.", "title": "Letter of Recommendation: AliExpress", "authors": ["Alice Hines", "Letter Of Recommendation"]} {"date": "2018-04-25 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nWhen my coffin lid was slammed shut and padlocked, I didn\u2019t panic. It was dark, and my wrists were chafing from the handcuffs. Nearby, I could hear my husband, Teddy, scrabbling about in his own coffin, testing to see if his lid was sealed securely (from the sound of it: yes). The air smelled like a warm shoe. Teddy shouted my name, and I shouted back. Entombment did nothing to dull our communication skills. Which, I suppose, would be comforting if I believed in the afterlife.\n\nThe coffins were part of an escape game called \u201cBoxed Up,\u201d hosted by a venue in Brooklyn that offers a variety of such amusements. Escape games work like this: You enter a room (or coffin) and are given a limited amount of time to find your way out by solving puzzles and clues planted within. It\u2019s basically the \u201990s computer game Myst, but in real life. Escape games come in all sorts of themes, most with a cinematic flair: crypt, haunted hotel, underground bunker, spaceship, sanitarium, zombie apocalypse, archaeological dig. In Detroit, there\u2019s one designed to resemble a 1980s rec room; if you don\u2019t get out, the promotional materials warn, you\u2019ll be stuck playing Atari forever. Another, in Kansas City, is set inside the Truman presidential campaign.\n\nLike dreams and traffic disputes, escape rooms are scandalously dull to summarize. But try it once, and everything else will suddenly pale in comparison. You\u2019ll see. A perfectly nice friend will text to see if you want to grab a drink, and you\u2019ll be thinking: You want to sip a beverage and chat when we could be jimmying open an armoire that contains a bloody doll with an anagram carved into her left foot that we have to chant three times holding hands before an amulet falls from the ceiling? Please!\n\nGenerally, the games begin with an employee gathering you and your friends at a door to give you a spiel. (\u201cPlease do not use physical force to escape.\u201d) Then a clock starts, and you start looking for puzzles: hidden compartments, trick mirrors, two-way radios, carpets woven with concealed messages. (The hard part isn\u2019t solving the puzzles; it\u2019s figuring out what is a puzzle. One time I wasted eight minutes examining a bowl of plastic vegetables that turned out to be d\u00e9cor.) Each puzzle leads to the next, which eventually leads to a key to unlock the door.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThink of all the ways you already insert pleasurable, circumscribed bursts of risk into your life. Maybe you watch horror movies, consume hot sauce, jaywalk. Maybe you pursue casual sex or steal Splenda packets from Starbucks or treat the speed limit as a cute suggestion. An escape game is like stacking these things atop one another and rounding out the itinerary with a medium-scary roller coaster. The panic is real even if the pressure is an illusion. You won\u2019t die or get stuck in the 1980s if you fail to escape; an employee will simply unlatch the door and let you out with a \u201cBetter luck next time.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nBecause escape games are cheap to create and fairly lucrative to operate, they\u2019ve proliferated since their invention (apparently in Japan, where else?) around 2007. There\u2019s probably one near you. And while they have a reputation as dorky corporate team-building exercises, I would urge you to approach them as a regular form of dorky recreation. For our bout of endangerment in the coffins, my husband and I paid little more than the price of a fussy restaurant dinner. We weren\u2019t totally unsupervised; an employee of the venue listened through hidden microphones to offer hints and intervene if something disastrous happened. But still. What if there had been a fire? What kind of twist ending would it be if we died after paying someone to entomb us for fun \u2014 the legendary kind of twist ending, or the horrifying kind?", "title": "Letter of Recommendation: Escape Rooms", "authors": ["Molly Young", "Letter Of Recommendation"]} {"date": "2018-04-17 00:00:00", "text": "Lurking on my phone is an app I didn\u2019t put there, one I wouldn\u2019t have touched were it not for a few glasses of wine and a pointer-fingered dare from an insolent friend named Jeff. He was visiting from San Francisco, and as we sat in the white-brick backyard of a bar, he urged me to disclose my location to him on Find My Friends, a function that Apple began quietly placing on all iPhones in 2015.
