In a world where we use social media to broadcast highly curated versions of ourselves, the app offers a frightening antithesis: to tell the people in our lives, via a small orange dot moving across a map, exactly where we are at all times. \u201cWhat are you hiding?\u201d Jeff asked me, giggling and snapping his gum like some teenage villain.\n\nAt first I objected to Jeff\u2019s challenge with profanity. But then I asked myself why. What was I hiding? He lived across the country, so at the very least the app couldn\u2019t make our friendship worse. It wouldn\u2019t keep me from the sort of white lies that keep society lubricated: I\u2019m going to turn in early, but have fun at the party, we say, even if what we really mean is, I need company but not yours, or There\u2019s a walk I\u2019d like to take alone, a book I\u2019d rather read. Jeff is something like a sibling to me, the sort of friend who offers a ride to a faraway doctor\u2019s appointment, then spends the ride gleefully mocking my haircut. Relenting to his taunt, I pulled out my phone and pressed a button that posed a terrifying question: Share location indefinitely?\n\nIn the next few weeks, I was more in touch with Jeff than I had been in the half-decade since I left California. During his visit, we\u2019d spoken about all the hiking I wasn\u2019t doing and all the hiking that he was, so I took the opportunity, when I saw him stuck in gridlock traffic on the freeway at the foot of Potrero Hill, to text: \u201cHow\u2019re those great outdoors treating you, bud?\u201d During a week when I had dodged a call, claiming the careerist busyness of a New Yorker, he caught me strolling through Central Park at 3 on a Tuesday, and he volleyed back. Sometime in July, Jeff and his wife, Evyan, went up to the Russian River, where as a kid I learned to swim crosscurrent. It\u2019s a place I dream of often, and when I saw him there, I wrote to say that I missed them, missed the river. \u201cSend a picture,\u201d I wrote, and he did. It felt so much better to see it this way, a piece of their lives I\u2019d asked for, than to encounter it on Instagram and absently double-tap.", "title": "Letter of Recommendation: Find My Friends", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-03 00:00:00", "text": "I cannot watch \u201cBlack Mirror\u201d anymore. Its metaphors have grown stale, its winks are now klaxons and its messages \u2014 once distorted and eerie \u2014 now land with a thud. The same holds true for most so-called \u201cprestige\u201d television, from the violent, misogynist dystopia of \u201cThe Handmaid\u2019s Tale\u201d to the violent, misogynist dystopia of \u201cWestworld.\u201d They feel inevitable and manipulative, and watching them does nothing but intensify my already simmering anxieties \u2014 which I suspect is the point. So nowadays, when the kitchen is clean and the cats are fed and my brain is on its downward spiral toward sleep, all I want to do is sink into the couch and turn on \u201cHouse Hunters,\u201d a show about a specific kind of darkness I have complete control in avoiding. It provides all the thrill of a dystopian hellscape with none of the fear.\n\n\u201cHouse Hunters\u201d is on HGTV, a channel whose mission is to make all Americans not only want to own a home but also to be perpetually dissatisfied with it once they do. Over the past decade, the network\u2019s slate of personality-driven home-improvement shows \u2014 \u201cProperty Brothers,\u201d \u201cFlip or Flop\u201d and \u201cFixer Upper\u201d \u2014 has made it the ninth-most-popular channel on basic cable. The faces of these shows are on morning shows and lifestyle brands and the covers of tabloid magazines. But \u201cHouse Hunters,\u201d which has been broadcast since 1999, remains its purest, most magnetic property.\n\nInstead of a host yearning for celebrity, there is only a soothing, nameless narrator who functions as a Greek chorus to support the rotating cast of laymen who populate the screen. Each episode follows a tidy formula: Potential home buyers, usually a couple, tour and critique three homes (and, inevitably, each other) while a real estate agent looks on. By the end of each episode, they decide on one of the three and put in an offer; a home, any home, is always purchased \u2014 that\u2019s the point. Suddenly, through the magic of video editing, the homeowners\u2019 things materialize, and the show fades to black before the home has the chance to disappoint its new occupants. Every episode I\u2019ve seen (there are nearly 2,000) is a thrilling cultural artifact, a tiny parable about the way we romanticize the stresses of modern American life and pile on more in hopes of assuaging those festering below.\n\nRecently I watched a young couple look for their first home in Cincinnati. Matt, a dapper toothpaste salesman, and his wife, Kim, a soft-spoken physical therapist, seemed helplessly in love with each other, but the hunt quickly turned passive-aggressive. He wanted a move-in-ready Craftsman or a Cape Cod; she wanted a historic Victorian that begged for renovations. He set the max at $400,000, but she felt they could spend more. With every opened door \u2014 and the host of surprises behind each \u2014 they were reminded that no house could possibly compare with whatever each of them had imagined. Eventually they settled on something neither really wanted in the first place: a Craftsman for $389,900 that needed a new kitchen and substantial cosmetic improvements to nearly every room. In the final sequence, we see Matt applying a layer of paint to an old door frame. \u201cSure happy we bought a house that requires all this work,\u201d he says, a hint of sadness in his voice.", "title": "Letter of Recommendation: \u2018House Hunters\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-20 00:00:00", "text": "Erasmus and Luther\n\nTo the Editor:\n\nI appreciate Rebecca Newberger Goldstein\u2019s complimentary review of my book \u201cFatal Discord\u201d (April 1) and her lively description of my account of the rivalry between Erasmus and Luther. At the end, however, she seriously mischaracterizes my views on Erasmus. She writes that I \u201comitted Erasmus\u2019s strongest lines\u201d in his dialogue with Luther on free will and thus failed to make clear that Erasmus doubted \u201cLuther\u2019s absolute rule of faith\u201d and was \u201cjustifiably skeptical of a self-verifying criterion for truth that can generate the kind of knowledge Luther claimed for himself.\u201d In fact, I spend several pages describing and quoting from Erasmus\u2019s text. I note that he considered free will \u201cone of many abstract matters in the Bible\u201d whose meaning \u201cremained elusive and about which he would consider himself a skeptic if the church allowed it.\u201d While Goldstein states that my book presents Erasmus as a \u201cself-protective pragmatist,\u201d I actually emphasize his principled opposition to Luther\u2019s dogmatism, his exasperation with Luther\u2019s \u201cpassing off his own interpretation of the Bible as God\u2019s Word\u201d and his embrace of pluralism and concord. Goldstein also writes that I consider Erasmus\u2019s influence on today\u2019s world \u201cfaint.\u201d Yet I devote an entire chapter to showing how his humanist ideals (and his support for a united, borderless Europe), which were suppressed or forgotten for centuries after his death, were revived after World War II, becoming a foundation for the European Union. One of my main goals in this project was to restore Erasmus\u2019s place in the Western intellectual tradition.\n\nMICHAEL MASSING\n\nNEW YORK\n\nNaming Names\n\nTo the Editor:\n\nAs a footnote to Dava Sobel\u2019s review of Claire L. Evans\u2019s \u201cBroad Band\u201d (March 25), note that Yale University, having \u201cunnamed\u201d Calhoun College for the slaveholding John C. Calhoun, renamed it for Rear Adm. Grace Hopper, whom Sobel calls \u201cthe Navy\u2019s much decorated queen of software.\u201d\n\nJAYLYN OLIVO\n\nBROOKLINE, MASS.\n\nThe Common Good\n\nTo the Editor:\n\nReading Michael J. Sandel\u2019s review of \u201cThe Common Good,\u201d by Robert B. Reich (April 8), I was reminded of a quote by Thomas Jefferson: \u201cBut every difference of opinion is not a difference of principle. We have called by different names brethren of the same principle.\u201d\n\nIt seems that Reich may be on to something that all our concerned American \u201cbrethren\u201d need to hear!\n\nR. A. ERBETTA\n\nMARBLEHEAD, MASS.", "title": "Letters to the Editor", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-27 00:00:00", "text": "Hannah Arendt\n\nTo the Editor:\n\nIn his review of Hannah Arendt\u2019s \u201cThinking Without a Banister: Essays in Understanding, 1953-1975,\u201d edited by Jerome Kohn (April 15), George Prochnik writes, \u201cRecent historical scholarship suggests that Arendt did, indeed, underestimate Eichmann\u2019s ideological passion for National Socialism: Much of his clownish bumbling in Jerusalem may have been a conscious, self-exculpating performance.\u201d It is an unthinking canard that Arendt was duped by Eichmann\u2019s act and underestimated his commitment to National Socialism. Exemplar of banality that he was, Eichmann embraced the ideology completely, even though he had hitherto never hated Jews. That\u2019s what a banal person does: decides to follow Adolf Hitler wherever he leads and, having no moral compass, takes up that of his icon.\n\nSTEPHEN KENNAMER\n\nFORT DEFIANCE, VA.\n\n\u2666\n\nTo the Editor:\n\nIn George Prochnik\u2019s review of Hannah Arendt\u2019s essays, he cites her analysis of the consequences of eliminating a people\u2019s national identity, citizenship and land itself. He then mentions the current plight of the Dreamers and other long-term undocumented immigrants in the United States. Might it not be more appropriate to mention the current status of the Palestinian people in this regard? The Palestinians have remained in refugee camps in other Arab countries and in occupied territories in Israel for 70 years. Is our focus to be directed away from this injustice?\n\nPATRICIA MUREEBE\n\nNAPLES, FLA.\n\nMatter Over Mind\n\nTo the Editor:\n\nIn her review of Lauren Slater\u2019s \u201cBlue Dreams\u201d (April 8), Maggie Jones opines that \u201cdoctors tend to talk about depression as if the science is settled\u201d and that these doctors advise, \u201cif you\u2019re depressed you take a pill.\u201d Neither claim applies to the way most psychiatrists think about depression or its treatment. We realize that the nature and causes of clinical depression are many and complex, and that we have much yet to learn. Optimal treatment involves a comprehensive \u201cbiopsychosocial\u201d approach, often involving a combination of psychotherapy and medication. And while there is no \u201csettled science\u201d of depression, psychiatry has come a long way from the so-called chemical imbalance theory of depression, which was more an invention of pharmaceutical companies than an actual theory propounded by psychiatrists. We now know that major depression involves a complex interaction of a person\u2019s genes, brain function and psychosocial environment. The good news is that we have safe and effective treatments for major depression that involve far more than \u201ctaking a pill.\u201d\n\nRONALD W. PIES, M.D.\n\nLEXINGTON, MASS.\n\nThe writer is the author of \u201cPsychiatry on the Edge.\u201d", "title": "Letters to the Editor", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-06 00:00:00", "text": "Impeachment\n\nTo the Editor:\n\nIn his otherwise instructive review of Cass Sunstein\u2019s \u201cImpeachment\u201d and \u201cCan It Happen Here?\u201d (March 18), Andrew Sullivan trivializes the impeachment and trial of President Andrew Johnson, calling it \u201cpreposterous.\u201d On the contrary, Congress impeached and tried President Johnson for subverting congressional reconstruction of the South through his violation of the Tenure of Office Act and for publicly assailing Congress as an illegitimate institution responsible for the savage white-on-black New Orleans riot of 1866.\n\nJohnson sought to restore white supremacy in the South; Congress meant to build a biracial democracy. There was nothing \u201cpreposterous\u201d about the impeachment crisis. Further, the trial of the president succeeded in changing his behavior so that he was no longer a destructive force in American politics.\n\nRICHARD VALELLY\n\nSWARTHMORE, PA.\n\nThe writer is Claude C. Smith \u201914 Professor of Political Science at Swarthmore College.\n\nBarbara Tuchman\n\nTo the Editor:\n\nReading Jon Meacham\u2019s \u201cFolly Marches On\u201d (March 18) reminds me of the day Irwin Yellowitz at City College of New York took his class to visit Barbara Tuchman, who showed us drawers containing thousands of index cards for \u201cThe Guns of August.\u201d \u201cHistory,\u201d she told us, \u201cis written by which cards I select for filing and in what order I file them\u201d \u2014 in other words, it\u2019s a critical art, not a science.\n\nMONTE WASCH\n\nNEW LEBANON, N.Y.\n\nBrick by Brick\n\nTo the Editor:\n\nThe review of \u201cBuilt: The Hidden Stories Behind Our Structures\u201d (March 18) mentions Othmar Ammann, who designed the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge. Readers might like to know that he also designed the Triborough Bridge and the George Washington Bridge. And he could see all three from his penthouse apartment in the Carlyle Hotel!\n\nHAROLD SHAMES\n\nDOBBS FERRY, N.Y.", "title": "Letters to the Editor", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-13 00:00:00", "text": "The Dark Side of Foreign Policy\n\nTo the Editor:\n\nThe thesis of Robert D. Kaplan\u2019s new book, \u201cThe Return of Marco Polo\u2019s World,\u201d as reviewed by Bret Stephens (April 1), seems to be that we live in a dark, evil world and we must do dark, evil things to survive in it. That is indeed a depressing observation, but it\u2019s hardly accurate.\n\nThe United States was born in the Age of Enlightenment; its founding fathers were determined not to follow the European model of \u201cmight makes right\u201d and transactional morality. We had a pretty good thing going for a while. Our ancestors even fought a war to preserve the Union based on our ideals and to end slavery. But power does corrupt. Now our president doesn\u2019t just use the bully pulpit, he acts like a bully \u2014 threatening everyone, including fellow Americans who don\u2019t go along with his contemporary version of the doctrine of Realpolitik.\n\nIt doesn\u2019t have to be this way, of course. America could return to its ideals and reject war as an extension of foreign policy, the political strategy of divide-and-conquer and the worship of the rich. But it would take courage and a rejection of those who define \u201crealism\u201d as the acceptance of the status quo.\n\nJOHN E. STAFFORD\n\nRYE, N.Y.\n\nSemitism\n\nTo the Editor:\n\nIn his critique of Jonathan Weisman\u2019s \u201c(((Semitism)))\u201d (April 1), Simon Schama raises the bar for what \u201cbeing Jewish\u201d means to such a height that only a minuscule number of highly cultured, Talmudically conversant Jewish history scholars such as himself are likely to make the cut. I\u2019m afraid the net will have to be cast much wider if American Jewish continuity, in any meaningful but also realistic sense, is to be achieved.", "title": "Letters to the Editor", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-31 00:00:00", "text": "To the Sports Editor:\n\nRe \u201cA Great Power-Hitting Duo, Lost in Time,\u201d March 28: I really enjoyed your tribute to Josh Gibson and Buck Leonard. As you report, Leonard is considered \u201cthe best first baseman in Negro leagues history and Gibson as the best catcher in baseball history.\u201d\n\nIn my Army days, in the 1960s, I got to know a veteran sergeant who told stories of the many Negro leagues games he attended as a youngster. \u201cThey called Josh Gibson the black Babe Ruth,\u201d I piped up one morning over coffee in the mess hall. The old sarge smiled and said, \u201cIn my neighborhood, they called Babe Ruth the white Josh Gibson.\u201d\n\nJohn E. Stafford\n\nRye, N.Y.\n\nTo the Sports Editor:\n\nLeft unsaid about the Negro National League is that Major League Baseball was racially integrated into the early 1890s.\n\nA key benchmark, circa 1888, involved a scheduled matchup between the Chicago White Stockings and the Toledo Mud Hens, both major league teams.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe playing manager of the visiting Chicago squad \u2014 Adrian \u201cCap\u201d Anson \u2014 announced that his team refused to take the field because the Mud Hens intended to field Moses Fleetwood Walker, an African-American player on their roster.", "title": "Letters to the Editor", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-03 00:00:00", "text": "Rebecca Dallet, a Milwaukee County Circuit judge favored by liberals, was elected on Tuesday to the Wisconsin Supreme Court, The Associated Press reported, reducing the hold of conservative justices over the state\u2019s highest court.\n\nJudge Dallet\u2019s defeat of Michael Screnock, a Sauk County Circuit judge who had the backing of conservatives, was immediately being held up as a sign of Democratic enthusiasm ahead of the November elections, in a state that narrowly chose President Trump in 2016.\n\nThe election was officially nonpartisan, and it involved candidates who were little known in Wisconsin until a few weeks ago. It was held during an off season for voting, on a day when snow and freezing rain were predicted in parts of the state.\n\nStill, the realities of this race fell firmly along partisan lines, as have many Wisconsin Supreme Court races in recent years. And it came at a moment when seemingly every contest across the country is being examined through the lens of the approaching midterm elections. A series of recent races in states like Pennsylvania, Alabama and Virginia has shown Democratic strength.", "title": "Liberal Judge Wins Wisconsin Supreme Court Seat, Buoying Democrats", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-29 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nRe \u201cWhen Liberals Become Progressives,\u201d by Greg Weiner (Op-Ed, April 14):\n\nI wince when I hear my fellow liberals describe themselves as \u201cprogressive,\u201d but not because I believe that the term \u201cliberal\u201d is inherently superior, as Mr. Weiner does. After all, political labels are just shorthand: We use them for convenience, even at the loss of some precision.\n\nRather, what I find objectionable is the na\u00efve belief that liberalism will somehow magically triumph if we just call it something else.\n\nIt is true that verbal sleight-of-hand sometimes works, and American business has perfected the technique (that is why McDonald\u2019s sells Quarter Pounders, not Four Ouncers), but that is no guarantee of success in the political realm.\n\nIndeed, results of the last few elections suggest that liberals should focus on refining their policies rather than on simply relabeling them. Now that would be progress.", "title": "Opinion | Liberal, or Progressive?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-25 00:00:00", "text": "My grandfather\u2019s parents came west from Arkansas, looking for healthier climes after a malarial disaster, and the family never had much money and always voted Democratic. Today their middle-class equivalents would likely be making the same migration in reverse (or at the very least lighting out for rural, Trumpier parts of the West Coast, as a Californian uncle of mine did), having been priced out of what was once their promised land. And the fact that many of these migrants might be natural Trump constituents is a good example of the futility of reducing Trump\u2019s appeal to an either-or of racism or economic grievance. Is an ex-Californian who\u2019s doing O.K. economically but lives in a hotter, flatter, less glamorous and ocean-breeze-kissed part of the country than his parents, and who gripes that what was once his middle-class hometown is now all immigrants speaking Spanish and the liberal superrich, worried about ethnic or socioeconomic displacement? The answer really can be both.\n\nSo the same trends that have made California so uniformly liberal have also encouraged Trumpism elsewhere \u2014 and not only elsewhere, since as Jason Willick and James Hitchcock pointed out in 2016 in The American Interest, Trumpism-the-ideology is very much a made-in-California affair. Not many members of the right-wing intelligentsia backed Trump, but the writers and thinkers who did \u2014 from mainstream conservatives to the alt-right fringe \u2014 were heavily Californian: the Claremont Institute\u2019s West Coast Straussians, Michael \u201cFlight 93 Election\u201d Anton, Mickey Kaus, Victor Davis Hanson, Ron Unz, Steve Sailer, Scott Adams, Curtis \u201cMencius Moldbug\u201d Yarvin \u2026 and of course the one and only Peter Thiel.\n\nThis clutch of internal dissidents doesn\u2019t pose a threat to liberal hegemony in California. But the state\u2019s larger exile population does present a problem for the \u201cmake America California\u201d project, because while you can displace Republican-leaning voters from one state, you can\u2019t do the same for the country as a whole. There will be no white-middle-class out-migration to, say, Hungary to ease the path to a Democratic supermajority. A fully ascendant liberalism would have co-opt or crush groups that in California politics simply diminished or disappeared.\n\nAnd ambitious liberals will have to do so while evangelizing on behalf of a social-political model that right now looks nothing like the ideal egalitarian society liberalism claims that it can build. Under one-party liberal rule, California is presently as unequal as a Central American republic, with one of the highest poverty rates in the country once you control for its exorbitant cost of living. Its educational performance is lousy and its racial gaps are stark \u2014 which is why it\u2019s not only lower-middle class whites moving back to red America, and why black complaints about white liberal gentrifiers in SoCal or the Bay Area can resemble the complaints of Trump-leaning ex-Californians. As in other enclaves where Democrats are dominant, its ruling party has proved itself pretty good at rentier-friendly environmentalism and kicking social conservatives while they\u2019re down, O.K. enough at redistribution, and completely terrible at figuring how to build an information-age middle class.\n\nTo visit the West Coast, now and always, is to be overwhelmed by its beauty \u2014 the blue water and blue skies, the temperate air and the beaches and the looming mountains not so far away. But to imagine America remade in California\u2019s image is to imagine the state\u2019s social and political order, its upper class-service class-underclass hierarchy, expanded to landscapes that lack the balm of all that beauty, and lack an easy exit for the discontented as well.\n\nSuch an expansion might be in our future; as went California after Pete Wilson and Ah-nuld, so might America after Trump. But I suspect a new order along these lines would be uglier and more unstable, its ruling party far more easily undone or overthrown, than in the sun-kissed aristocracy that liberals have built for themselves in what was once, but no longer, the proving ground for the American dream.", "title": "Opinion | Liberalism\u2019s Golden Dream", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-29 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cI heard directly from the Chinese that the Libyan model did not inspire confidence in Pyongyang,\u201d said Antony J. Blinken, a deputy secretary of state under Mr. Obama. \u201cI would be very concerned that the combination of Libya and then Trump tearing up the Iran agreement sends exactly the wrong message to Kim Jong-un and undermines whatever hope exists for negotiations.\u201d\n\nMr. Bolton raised the Libya example in weekend interviews on \u201cFace the Nation\u201d on CBS and \u201cFox News Sunday,\u201d his first television appearances since becoming national security adviser early this month.\n\n\u201cWe have very much in mind the Libya model from 2003, 2004,\u201d he said on Fox. \u201cThere are obviously differences. The Libyan program was much smaller, but that was basically the agreement that we made.\u201d\n\nThe most important comparison, he said, would be testing North Korea to see if it had genuinely made an unqualified determination to abandon its nuclear weapons. \u201cIt would be a manifestation of the strategic decision to give up nuclear weapons,\u201d Mr. Bolton said on CBS. \u201cDoesn\u2019t have to be the same as Libya, but it\u2019s got to be something concrete and tangible. It may be that Kim Jong-un has some ideas and we should hear him out.\u201d\n\nIn the history of the atomic age, only four countries have voluntarily given up nuclear weapons. South Africa ended its secret nuclear program in 1989, destroying a half-dozen bombs. Ukraine, Belarus and Kazakhstan all gave up the nuclear weapons that were stationed on their territory after the Soviet Union collapsed in 1991 and they became independent nations.\n\nBut Ukraine has found reason for second-guessing. The Budapest Memorandum that sealed its denuclearization in 1994 included promises by the United States, Britain and Russia to respect the country\u2019s sovereignty and borders. But in 2014, Russia annexed Crimea and supported Russian separatists in eastern Ukraine. Given that, a member of Ukraine\u2019s Parliament said at the time that \u201cnow there\u2019s a strong sentiment in Ukraine that we made a big mistake\u201d in giving up its weapons.\n\nOthers like Brazil and Taiwan sought nuclear weapons but abandoned the efforts short of building bombs. Iran was not known to have weapons but did have a nuclear program that seemed intended to develop them when it signed an agreement with Mr. Obama\u2019s administration in 2015 to give up its program \u2014 the same agreement Mr. Trump has excoriated and threatened to rip up by May 12.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSimilarly, Libya did not have nuclear weapons but had a program to develop them when it changed course in 2003. Colonel Qaddafi initiated secret negotiations with the Bush administration and the British to dismantle his program in exchange for easing international sanctions.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe decision reflected years of effort to end the country\u2019s isolation. But the key agreement came just days after Iraq\u2019s deposed leader, Saddam Hussein, was found in a spider hole in Iraq after an American invasion that had been justified as an effort to rid a dangerous regime of weapons of mass destruction. Colonel Qaddafi signaled that he did not intend to suffer the same fate.\n\nRobert Joseph, the national security aide who brokered the deal for Mr. Bush with the support of Mr. Bolton, said on Sunday that his former colleague was right to look to Libya. \u201cI do think John\u2019s onto something here,\u201d he said.\n\n\u201cLook, Libya is not North Korea,\u201d he added. \u201cThe Libyan program was far more advanced than we had thought it was, but it\u2019s far less advanced than where North Korea is today. No question, Libya does not represent the sort of military threat that North Korea does. The two situations are different.\n\n\u201cBut you\u2019re not saying we\u2019re going to do everything just like we did with Libya,\u201d he added. \u201cWhat you\u2019re doing is you\u2019re drawing lessons from that experience. If you don\u2019t do that, we\u2019re going to end up right where we\u2019ve ended up before multiple times over the last 25 years, which is failure.\u201d\n\nAmong the lessons of Libya that apply to North Korea, he said, echoing Mr. Bolton\u2019s comment, is the need for a genuine decision by Mr. Kim to completely give up his program, not just hedge. Another is to use all the tools available, including intelligence, economic leverage, diplomacy and threat of force. Another is to insist on complete \u201canywhere, anytime\u201d access for inspectors to all potential nuclear sites.\n\nBut other specialists find the situations so different that the comparison is unhelpful. \u201cLibya hardly had a nuclear weapons program,\u201d said Robert J. Einhorn, a special adviser for nonproliferation and arms control in Mr. Obama\u2019s State Department and now a scholar at the Brookings Institution. \u201cIt had crates with centrifuge parts it didn\u2019t know what to do with. U.S. transport planes could land and carry the entire \u2018program\u2019 away.\u201d\n\nBy contrast, said Mr. Einhorn, \u201cNorth Korea has nuclear weapons. We don\u2019t know how many. It has nuclear production facilities. We don\u2019t know where they all are. Verifying what they have and dismantling all of it would take years.\u201d\n\nColonel Qaddafi\u2019s violent end was not directly related to the 2003 deal. Nearly eight years after his agreement with Mr. Bush, the Libyan dictator was confronted with a popular uprising as part of the Arab Spring 2011. He vowed to crush his opponents, including civilians, prompting Mr. Obama and European allies to intervene to stop him.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe Obama administration at the time denied any connection between the intervention and the previous nuclear disarmament. But Mr. Joseph said Mr. Obama should have given more thought to the consequences. \u201cThey made the decision to intervene without a day-after plan or any sense of what nonproliferation message that would send,\u201d he said.\n\nNorth Korea has made this connection before. In 2011, North Korea\u2019s official news agency carried comments by a Foreign Ministry official calling the earlier nuclear bargain with Libya \u201can invasion tactic to disarm the country,\u201d in effect a bait-and-switch. \u201cThe Libyan crisis is teaching the international community a grave lesson,\u201d the ministry official said.\n\nEach side sees its own very different lessons.", "title": "Libya as a Model for Disarmament? North Korea May See It Very Differently", "authors": ["Peter Baker"]} {"date": "2018-04-19 00:00:00", "text": "But the attack was widely interpreted as a possible opening salvo in a battle to succeed General Hifter.\n\n\u201cThere are clear signs that a leadership contest has started,\u201d said Tarek Megerisi, a Libya analyst at the European Council on Foreign Relations. \u201cThe conversation has moved on from whether Hifter is dead or alive, to whether he will be able to return to the same role as before. Most people believe he won\u2019t.\u201d\n\nThe mystery over General Hifter\u2019s health is a sharp blow to the authority of a domineering if divisive figure and threatens the contentious stability he brought to eastern Libya.\n\nAfter Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi was ousted from power in 2011, Libya shattered into a patchwork of rival towns, tribes and militias. General Hifter restored a kind of order to its eastern half by vanquishing his Islamist enemies.\n\nA former military officer who led a failed C.I.A.-backed effort to oust Colonel Qaddafi in the late 1980s, General Hifter launched an audacious bid for control of Benghazi in 2014 with the help of a coalition of tribal, neighborhood and religious militias.\n\nAfter three years of grinding battle that left large parts of the city in rubble and displaced thousands of residents, he finally defeated the last Islamist militias in December.\n\nBut supporters have long worried that his age might diminish his fitness for the hectic pace of Libya\u2019s notoriously complex battle for supremacy. Even if he does prove fit enough to return to work, his illness has dealt a blow to his carefully cultivated persona of a leader with the muscle to rule.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cHis strongman image has been ruined,\u201d Mr. Megerisi said. \u201cNow he\u2019s the sick man of Libya.\u201d\n\nGeneral Hifter has no obvious successor. He groomed two sons in recent years, promoting them to command positions in his Libyan National Army. But the sons, Khalid and Saddam, have seen little front-line combat, and experts say it is unclear whether they enjoy the authority to take over.\n\nPhoto\n\nAlthough General Hifter styles himself as a military virtuoso who forged Libya\u2019s only disciplined army, in practice his Libyan National Army is a loose coalition of militias headed by strong-willed commanders. Now, every day that he is absent from Benghazi, speculation grows that his coalition could crack as rival commanders turn on each other.\n\nThere have been hints of internal tensions in recent months as commanders have publicly chafed under General Hifter\u2019s rule or criticized one another. The growing prominence in his administration of religious conservatives who have tried to impose restrictions on women and burn books has become a source of worry among city residents.\n\nOne special forces commander, Mahmoud al-Werfalli, is wanted by the International Criminal Court for his role in seven summary mass executions in which 33 people were killed.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nTribal politics are also a factor, with simmering resentment from some quarters over the dominance of General Hifter\u2019s Furjan tribe, from western Libya, in the senior ranks of the army based in eastern Libya.\n\nThe crisis has also left General Hifter\u2019s foreign allies, which supplied him with planes, ammunition and fighters during the battle for Benghazi, scrambling to protect their investment in Libya\u2019s post-Qaddafi order.\n\nEgypt has bet on General Hifter to protect its long western border, and prevent infiltration by Islamist extremists. The United Arab Emirates has stationed warplanes and drones at several air bases in eastern Libya to shore up General Hifter\u2019s forces. France sent paramilitary forces to help him defeat the Islamists in Benghazi, where three French officers were killed in a helicopter crash in 2016.\n\nAmerican diplomats have largely kept their distance from General Hifter in public, viewing him as a hindrance to political talks, although the C.I.A. has renewed its ties with him and established a presence in Benghazi, as have a handful of American Special Forces commandos at an air base outside the city.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAny sidelining of General Hifter could have a domino effect across Libya, potentially affecting oil production and efforts to strike a political peace deal. Yet the refusal of his aides to release even a photo or a video to support their claims that he is well only fueled conjecture about his health.\n\nLast week, several French news outlets reported that General Hifter had suffered a serious stroke in Jordan. On Thursday, the website Middle East Eye, citing a European diplomat, said he had been partly incapacitated. A senior United Nations official said they had received similar reports.\n\nThe French government has seemed determined to say as little as possible. French officials would confirm only that General Hifter was being cared for in a hospital in the Paris region but offered no information about his condition.\n\nIn a closed meeting on Wednesday, France\u2019s foreign minister, Jean-Yves Le Drian, told Parliament that General Hifter was \u201cdoing better,\u201d Radio France International reported.\n\nFor several years France openly sided with General Hifter, to the detriment of the United Nations-backed unity government in Tripoli, in an effort to project French power while forming alliances with local forces fighting Islamist extremism.\n\nMore recently, Paris has taken a more evenhanded approach. President Emmanuel Macron hosted peace talks in Paris last July that brought together General Hifter and Fayez Serraj, who leads the unity government in Tripoli.\n\nOn Thursday, the French ambassador to Libya, Brigitte Curmi, and the United Nations envoy, Ghassan Salam\u00e9, visited Tripoli to discuss the latest round of those discussions, although their meeting was overshadowed by a rocket attack on the city airport that damaged a parked civilian airliner.\n\nAsked whether elections would be held in Libya this year, Mr. Salam\u00e9 said: \u201cSure. We promised this to the U.N. Security Council.\u201d He declined to offer any details.", "title": "Libyan Strongman\u2019s Illness Stokes Fears of a Succession Feud", "authors": ["Declan Walsh"]} {"date": "2018-04-07 00:00:00", "text": "STOCKTON, Calif. \u2014 In California, known for decades as one of the nation\u2019s most avid jailers, the trajectory of law and order is shifting. Through litigation, legislation and a series of ballot initiatives, the state\u2019s prison population has dropped 25 percent over the past decade.\n\nThe photographer Joseph Rodriguez has been documenting crime and punishment in California for years and recently focused his gaze on the migration home, in Stockton \u2014 a barren outpost in California\u2019s Central Valley.\n\nGretchen Newby, executive director of the Stockton-based nonprofit Friends Outside, which provides support to prisoners and their families, said the city was experiencing a \u201ccluster effect\u201d: Large-scale arrests two or three decades ago have combined with newly relaxed parole requirements, leading to the release of long-term prisoners back to the city. Those who have family tend to find their way. But long stretches behind bars leave many without support. \u201cIt\u2019s common to come out with untreated illness, chronic conditions due to age and neglect,\u201d Ms. Newby said. \u201cHow are they going to live?\u201d Friends Outside case managers work to answer this question, lining up job interviews and transitional housing.", "title": "Opinion | Life After \u201817 to Life\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-09 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cOther parents see this in terms of the things they can and can\u2019t bring to school for their child or bring to a birthday party,\u201d she said, but for parents who have a child with a food allergy, \u201cit affects everything from food to child care.\u201d\n\nChildren with allergies or asthma \u2014 problems which also represent revved-up immune systems \u2014 are at higher risk to have anaphylaxis, and a child who has had anaphylaxis in the past, even a comparatively mild bout, is at higher risk to have it again, and perhaps more severely.\n\n\u201cI do recommend an EpiPen for anybody who has a history of anaphylaxis or severe reaction or has a history of significant food allergy,\u201d Dr. Volerman said. When she prescribes one, she goes over the potential signs and symptoms of an allergic reaction. \u201cI talk about lip swelling, hives in combination with nausea or coughing, or throat discomfort, tongue swelling, throat tightening, trouble breathing, dizziness, lightheadedness.\u201d\n\nAnd it\u2019s most important that it be with the child, and be used if necessary \u2014 or even if possibly necessary. She tells parents: \u201cIf you think about using an EpiPen, go ahead and use it if you notice any of these signs and symptoms.\u201d\n\nMany more children in the Blue Cross Blue Shield study had allergies of the type that do not cause anaphylaxis, with common diagnoses including allergic rhinitis and seasonal allergies, and also allergic dermatitis; 25 percent of the children up to the age of 2 had an allergy diagnosis, but the percentage dropped in older children.\n\nAnd the suggested clinical guidelines on preventing peanut allergy, which is the leading cause of fatal anaphylaxis from a food allergy, now include introducing peanut-containing foods earlier than we used to give them; children with severe eczema or egg allergy need to be evaluated first for peanut allergy, and depending on the results, the doctor may recommend introducing peanut-containing foods at 4 to 6 months. (Of course, no babies or toddlers should ever get actual peanuts, which present a choking hazard.)\n\n\u201cFor a long time we thought we should avoid foods,\u201d Dr. Volerman said. \u201cThe guidelines now reflect that we should be exposing children to peanuts early. It could lower the chances of your child developing an allergy.\u201d\n\nBut for children who do have allergies, parents and teachers \u2014 and the children themselves \u2014 need to be vigilant and quick to act when it comes to anaphylaxis; this is a diagnosis that is much better to overcall than undercall. And many of the children in the Blue Cross Blue Shield survey had not previously been given diagnoses of allergies, Dr. Haywood said. So anaphylaxis, a potentially life-threatening reaction that can be effectively treated if you treat it promptly, is also a diagnosis that everyone should be ready to recognize, history of allergy or not.", "title": "Life-Threatening Allergic Reactions Rising in Children", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-23 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nMayor Bill de Blasio\u2019s Brooklyn Queens Connector light rail proposal is a visionary project, with some of New York City\u2019s best transportation and urban design minds behind it (news article, April 12). Traveling at grade along the waterfront, the light rail would especially benefit people living and working at a distance from the subways.\n\nWith level boarding at each stop, seniors and those with disabilities would be well served. The route would interconnect with the mayor\u2019s citywide ferry network at numerous stops along the water\u2019s edge. At a cost one-tenth as much per mile as a new subway, light rail could meet the demand throughout the city for more rail service.\n\nCritical to successful functioning of surface transit is providing separate rights of way for buses or light rail. Private cars are our most space-consuming mode. The vision of the light rail needs to be matched by the mayor\u2019s clear commitment in his call for a just society by allocating street space for light rail.\n\nIn Midtown Manhattan, a light rail project for 42nd Street has been under study since 1978, taken up in 1999 by the Institute for Rational Urban Mobility, or IRUM, as vision42, a river-to-river, auto-free light rail boulevard. These two projects \u2014 the Brooklyn Queens Connector and vision42 \u2014 should be at the forefront of transportation planning for New York City.", "title": "Opinion | Light Rail for New York", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-09 00:00:00", "text": "Jasmine, says the Parisian-born perfumer Fr\u00e9d\u00e9ric Malle, \u201cis like butter in French cuisine \u2014 add a little in the end or at the beginning and it will fill up the holes in your formulas.\u201d This was one of the first lessons he learned at perfumery school in Grasse, he says, before starting his own fragrance house, Editions de Parfums Fr\u00e9d\u00e9ric Malle, in 2000. A favorite ingredient for many perfumers, jasmine is \u201cthe epitome of white flowers,\u201d Malle says.\n\nThis spring, the flower makes its way into a fresh crop of perfumes. In Louis Vuitton\u2019s Le Jour Se L\u00e8ve ($240), the sweetness of the bud is heightened with a plump black-currant accord, while in Ex Nihilo\u2019s Viper Green ($225) jasmine notes combine with vetiver and patchouli for a green, woodsy scent inspired by a vegetal poison. Tom Ford\u2019s Jasmin Rouge ($312), by contrast, is full-throttle and sensual, underlaid with warm spices like ginger and cardamom.\n\nThose who wish to branch out from traditional perfumes can find other ways to experiment with the floral, too. Malle has pumped Egyptian jasmine into his Superstitious Hair Mist ($215), a lighter version of his heady Superstitious fragrance that contains less alcohol \u2014 which can dry out hair \u2014 but still has \u201ca lavish, Parisian air.\u201d Meanwhile, In Fiore\u2019s face and body oil Fleur Vibrante Solution ($175) taps into the flower\u2019s healing benefits. The formula is infused with hydrodistilled jasmine, which is rich in antioxidants and promotes circulation, says the brand\u2019s founder Julie Elliott. She recommends rubbing the potion between your hands and breathing in deeply for a calming, on-the-go remedy. Or, for a springtime boost, try exfoliating with a dry brush and then anointing your limbs with the aromatic oil. \u201cYour skin will be so beautifully plumped and dewy,\u201d says Elliott. And, she adds, you will smell like \u201cheaven.\u201d", "title": "Light, Jasmine Scents That Are Perfect for Spring", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-18 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nA feisty Nikita Kucherov scored two goals, set up another and knocked the Devils\u2019 top defenseman out of the game with a big hit, and the Tampa Bay Lightning moved within a game of making the Devils\u2019 first trip to the playoffs in six years a short one with a 3-1 road victory on Wednesday night.\n\nJ. T. Miller also scored and had two assists, and the Vezina Trophy finalist Andrei Vasilevskiy stopped three breakaways in making 27 saves as the Lightning bounced back from a loss in Game 3 to take a 3-1 lead in the first-round series.\n\nTampa Bay can wrap up the best-of-seven series in Game 5 at home on Saturday.\n\nKyle Palmieri scored on a five-on-three advantage for the Devils, who are back in the playoffs for the first time since reaching the Stanley Cup Final in 2012. It was the only time they beat Vasilevskiy, whose 44 wins in the regular season shared the league lead with Winnipeg\u2019s Connor Hellebuyck. Cory Schneider made 34 saves for the Devils in starting his second straight game.\n\nThis game might have been the roughest of the series, especially in the first period when the Lightning took a 2-1 lead in a session with a lot of scrums.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nA play the N.H.L. probably will look at is Kucherov\u2019s hit on Sami Vatanen late in the first. No penalty was called, but the league\u2019s No. 3 scorer appeared to jump before hitting Vatanen in the shoulder and head area. Devils Coach John Hynes screamed at the officials after the play.", "title": "Lightning Put the Devils on the Verge of Elimination", "authors": ["The Associated Press"]} {"date": "2018-04-27 00:00:00", "text": "Through interviews with those who managed to escape, Mikhail has created a searing portrait of courage, humanity and savagery, told in a mosaic of voices. We learn of the slave markets where women are bought and sold, and of the online auction sites where they are listed simply as \u201cGirl #1\u201d or \u201cGirl #2.\u201d Fetching anywhere from a dollar to $500, they are raped, \u201crented\u201d and used as forced labor. For ISIS fighters (referred to here as Daesh), such are the spoils of war.\n\nImage\n\nLinking their stories is a Yazidi Schindler named Abdullah, a beekeeper who has made it his mission to rescue the enslaved women after many of his family members were taken, including his sister. \u201cEvery day that I save a captive woman I save her, too,\u201d he tells Mikhail. Using his extensive contacts and knowledge of roads throughout Iraq and Syria, he organizes a \u201chive\u201d of smugglers of both sexes to engineer cunning rescue operations. There are many such heroes in these varied accounts, not least the women themselves, and details so astounding that it was wise of the author to include photographs bearing witness to their truth.\n\nThe smugglers are paid by the Kurdistan Region of Iraq\u2019s Office of Kidnapped Affairs. (Yes, there is such a thing, established in response to the captive-taking.) It is dangerous work, and many smugglers lose their lives in ambushes and airstrikes. But even more remarkable in this heart of darkness are the selfless acts of mercy by strangers who help the women elude their captors.\n\nOne beneficiary of such kindness is Zuhour, sold as a house slave along with her three small children to a man who starves them. (The children in these accounts are typically employed to make munitions or, in the case of older boys, sent to training centers where their swift conversion to ISIS ideology is as unsettling as the battle skills they are taught.) After running away, terrified of armed patrols sent to round her and her children up, Zuhour enters a sewing shop situated inside a house, begging the seamstress there to give them shelter. \u201cI would like to help you,\u201d the young woman replies, \u201cbut the trouble is that my father is a member of Daesh.\u201d\n\nShe helps anyway. Her father fights on three-week rotations, returning to the house for a few days of rest. On those days the seamstress hides Zuhour and her children in her sewing room \u2014 the only place her father never sets foot. This goes on for two months, until the women get hold of a Kurdistan phone book and start calling numbers at random. (A common problem for the captives is not being able to remember numbers from their confiscated phones.) The first person to answer contacts Zuhour\u2019s uncle, who calls the beekeeper, who sends a female smuggler to pose as a customer.\n\nThis is one story among many, which together illuminate a human catastrophe that might otherwise be a mere footnote to the still-unfolding consequences of the Iraq war. Mikhail, whose gifts as a poet infuse these narratives with unexpected beauty, is interested in the little things: \u201cI mean the little things with their big shadows.\u201d", "title": "Like a Schindler for Iraq, This Unlikely War Hero Freed Women From ISIS", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-10 00:00:00", "text": "The dancers Lil Buck and Jon Boogz \u2014 Buck and Boogz for short \u2014 share a mission: nothing less than to improve the world through dance. Both emerged from the street-dance scenes in their hometowns, Memphis (Buck) and Miami (Boogz). They met at an open jam session at the Debbie Reynolds Dance Studio in Los Angeles almost 10 years ago. As they put it, they recognized each other\u2019s skills but also connected on a higher plane, as two idealists who believe that dance can bring people closer and perhaps even change the way they think.\n\nBuck does Memphis jookin\u2019 and Boogz\u2019s background is in popping. But despite their different styles, they started performing together along the tourist-filled 3rd Street Promenade in Santa Monica. Their shows aimed to touch people rather than just entertain them. \u201cPeople would cry watching our performances,\u201d Buck said about those open-air events. \u201cIt was a whole different experience for them.\u201d\n\nThey both have busy careers, but alongside touring with big-name rock stars like Madonna (Buck) and Gloria Estefan (Boogz), taking part in the Vail Dance Festival (Buck), and collaborating on a recent Rag & Bone fashion campaign that featured Mikhail Baryshnikov, the two started to plot ways to reach new audiences with dances that addressed larger societal issues like racism, police violence, immigration and the destruction of the environment.\n\nTogether, they founded MAI (Movement Art Is), a nonprofit that produces dance videos, and now live performances, for which they share choreographic credit. Their film \u201cColor of Reality,\u201d made in conjunction with the painter Alexa Meade, was inspired by their dismay at police shootings of black men, and has been seen online more than 300,000 times. They are also featured in Terrence Malick\u2019s short virtual reality film, \u201cTogether,\u201d which will have its New York debut at the Tribeca Film Festival later this month. (There will also be a 2D version.)\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThis year, too, Buck and Boogz made their first evening-length show, \u201cLove Heals All Wounds,\u201d which has been touring the country since January and comes to the Skirball Center at New York University on Saturday. It is structured as a series of dance scenes punctuated by poetry, composed and performed by Robin Sanders. Each section deals with a contemporary social ill. \u201cA lot of the things we\u2019re talking about,\u201d Boogz said, \u201cfrom police brutality to mass incarceration to gender equality and racial equality, we grew up with that. There\u2019s a certain struggle that is passed down.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nI caught up with Buck, 29, and Boogz, 30, on Skype after a recent performance of \u201cLove Heals All Wounds\u201d in West Palm Beach, Fla. What follows are edited excerpts from that conversation.", "title": "Lil Buck and Jon Boogz, Dancing to Improve the World", "authors": ["Marina Harss"]} {"date": "2018-04-09 00:00:00", "text": "Equal Pay Day \u2014 the day up to which the typical woman must work in a particular year to catch up with what the average man earned the previous year \u2014 always brings back a rush of memories. Not surprisingly, many of them I\u2019d rather forget: the pit in my stomach, for example, that developed when I read the anonymous note left in my mailbox that told me I was being paid a fraction of what other, male supervisors at Goodyear were making. And when the Supreme Court denied me justice in my pay discrimination case.\n\n(Some of them are happier memories, like when President Barack Obama signed into law the Lilly Ledbetter Fair Pay Act to ensure other women would not receive the same treatment.)\n\nBut this year, Equal Pay Day, which falls on April 10, has brought back a whole different set of memories:\n\n\u201cYou\u2019re going to be my next woman at Goodyear.\u201d\n\n\u201cOh, you didn\u2019t wear your bra today.\u201d\n\n\u201cIf you don\u2019t go to bed with me, you won\u2019t have a job.\u201d\n\nThose words, spoken to me by one of my supervisors many years ago, still crawl through my ears and down my spine. I remember my fear, both for my personal safety and because if I lost my job, I didn\u2019t know how I would pay my kids\u2019 college tuition, our mortgage and other bills. I remember how that fear led me to keep a phone number for the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission tucked in my pocket at all times, in case I needed legal help.", "title": "Opinion | Lilly Ledbetter: My #MeToo Moment", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-06 00:00:00", "text": "Brought in from outside the arts, Ms. Spar is leaving after a rocky year. Lincoln Center dramatically scaled back plans to rebuild David Geffen Hall; ended one of its summer mainstays, the Lincoln Center Festival; endured tensions between longtime senior staff and members of Ms. Spar\u2019s new team; and grappled with financial challenges, projecting a deficit this year.\n\nHer departure comes only six months after the decision to scuttle the expensive gut renovation of Geffen Hall, the New York Philharmonic\u2019s home at the center, and seek simpler ways to improve it. When Ms. Spar, who started a $400 million capital campaign at Barnard, took over, the plans for the hall were considerably more ambitious, with most of the money needed for the project \u2014 estimated at more than $500 million \u2014 still to be raised.\n\nBut in October, Lincoln Center and the Philharmonic, spooked by the rising price tag and projections that the orchestra would need to leave the hall for several years during construction, announced they were drastically scaling back. It was a major setback for a project that has been mulled for nearly 20 years, and threw cold water on the fire finally ignited by a $100 million gift from the entertainment mogul David Geffen in 2015. After the decision to abandon the gut renovation, Mr. Geffen expressed frustration at the lack of additional support for the project from other wealthy donors.\n\nLincoln Center has insisted the more minimal plan is not an admission of failure. \u201cWe\u2019ve got some great plans that everyone is very excited about,\u201d Katherine Farley, Lincoln Center\u2019s chairwoman, who led the center and oversaw the Geffen Hall rebuilding plans for almost a year between Mr. Bernstein\u2019s departure and Ms. Spar\u2019s arrival, said in an interview.\n\nThe revision of the hall\u2019s plans was driven by Deborah Borda, the powerful arts leader who was named president and chief executive of the Philharmonic last year. He received a law degree from the University of Michigan.", "title": "Lisa Miller, Drew Bradylyons", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-09 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nThe prestigious Richard Tucker Award often goes to high-flying sopranos, like Nadine Sierra and Ren\u00e9e Fleming, or to acrobatic tenors like Michael Fabiano and Lawrence Brownlee.\n\nBut this year, the Richard Tucker Music Foundation is honoring a bass-baritone, Christian Van Horn. He is just the third bass-baritone to be awarded in the prize\u2019s 40-year history. The award comes with a cash prize of $50,000 and a celebratory performance at Carnegie Hall on Oct. 21.\n\nAt 39, Mr. Van Horn is significantly older than past winners. Ms. Sierra, who won last year, is currently 29. But there\u2019s a good reason for this discrepancy: \u201cIt takes a long time for a low voice like his to mature, and it\u2019s been a privilege to watch and hear him grow,\u201d Barry Tucker, the president of the foundation (and the son of the award\u2019s namesake), said in a statement.\n\nMr. Van Horn has performed with opera companies across the globe, including the Met Opera, the Los Angeles Opera, the Bavarian State Opera and the Netherlands Opera. He won first place at the 2003 Metropolitan Opera National Council Auditions.\n\nThis year, Mr. Van Horn has performances scheduled with the Canadian Opera Company and Opera Philadelphia before he returns to the Met Opera in November to play the diabolical title character in Boito\u2019s \u201cMefistofele.\u201d And in December he will stay at the Met to revisit the role of Colline in \u201cLa Boh\u00e8me.\u201d In a 2014 New York Times review, Anthony Tommasini wrote that his portrayal of Colline \u201creveals his sturdy voice and commanding presence.\u201d\n\nWatch him sing as Zaccaria in Verdi\u2019s \u201cNabucco\u201d at the Seattle Opera in 2015:", "title": "Listen to This Award-Winning Bass-Baritone Opera Singer", "authors": ["Andrew R. Chow"]} {"date": "2018-04-27 00:00:00", "text": "In late 1979, when the D.J. Justin Strauss first brought a bag of records to spin at the Mudd Club, the downtown New York City bar that\u2019s now the stuff of underground lore, the term \u201cdisc jockey\u201d didn\u2019t mean much yet \u2014 and it certainly didn\u2019t evoke celebrity status. \u201cIt wasn\u2019t anything that anyone thought about \u2014 I didn\u2019t think about it,\u201d Strauss says now. \u201cI didn\u2019t wake up and go, \u2018I want to be a D.J.\u2019 It just sort of happened naturally.\u201d He had left New York, his hometown, to live in Los Angeles with his power-pop group Milk \u2019n\u2019 Cookies. The band eventually split and his then-girlfriend persuaded him to come back to the city. \u201cShe said, \u2018You gotta come. This club opened up and you\u2019d be great to play your records there,\u2019\u201d he remembers. This was the era of the slick, moneyed glamour of Studio 54, and the Mudd Club was, in many ways, a reaction to it. \u201cThere were no rules \u2014 you could play a rockabilly song next to a rap song or a reggae song or the Buzzcocks or whatever it was \u2014 it all made sense and everyone danced,\u201d he said. As for the crowd, it \u201cwas just a mix of downtown kids, artists \u2026 Keith Haring, Jean-Michel [Basquiat].\u201d Strauss spent the rest of the decade spinning at big \u2014 and now shuttered \u2014 clubs like Area, the Ritz, Tunnel and Limelight. He ultimately began remixing and producing original tracks; he still D.J.s around the world and has a show on the Lot Radio, based in Brooklyn.\n\nWhile Strauss was hanging out at the Mudd Club in the early \u201980s, Marea Stamper was just a toddler in Kentucky. \u201cMy parents are total record-heads,\u201d says Stamper, who grew up to become the dance-scene-famous D.J. and producer the Black Madonna. She remembers listening to New Order, George Clinton, Yazoo, Depeche Mode and Sylvester. As a \u201990s teen, she sold mixtapes at raves in the Midwest and along the East Coast; by the mid-aughts she had taught herself to D.J. and moved to Chicago, the birthplace of house music, where she realized how the sounds of her childhood had evolved into contemporary dance music. This connection informs her sets, which seamlessly blend genres like classic Chicago house, New York disco, synth-pop and new wave.", "title": "Listen to the Early \u201980s: Two Playlists Inspired by Our Culture Issue", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-07 00:00:00", "text": "How do I listen?\n\nIf you don\u2019t see an audio player on this page or to subscribe to \u201cDear Sugars\u201d for free, follow the instructions below.\n\nOn your iPhone or iPad:\n\nOpen the pre-loaded app called Podcasts; it has a purple icon. Audio\n\nFor the first time on the podcast, the Sugars answer a voice mail message from the Dear Sugars hotline.
