If you\u2019re on an Android device, tap this link to listen in Stitcher or this link to listen in RadioPublic.", "title": "Listen to \u2018The Daily\u2019: Weighing the Risks of a Syria Strike", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-06 00:00:00", "text": "SATURDAY PUZZLE \u2014 It has been an entire business week since I\u2019ve seen you, and last weekend\u2019s flight of fancy has lost altitude and landed in this minefield of a puzzle by Mark Diehl. There are debuts galore, unfamiliar \u201cnotable names,\u201d and endearing but hardly simple running references to noshing. As icing on the cake, it\u2019s a pangram; every letter appears at least once in the grid.\n\nI loved some of the clues today, like for LEGO, TUNE, WINDUP, SQUIB, FAIR DICE and OPENS WIDE. I knew nothing about ALDEN or RANKIN and look sideways, a little, at HOSE and HEWER, which sounds like a certain kind of law firm.\n\nTricky Clues\n\n17A: Well, when I first sussed out this clue I cringed a little, only because I\u2019m a bit of a margarita purist (on the rocks with some salt, always nice on a balmy evening, if one of those ever happens again) and not much of a beer fan. Once I\u2019d pieced together BEERGARITA, a term I\u2019d never seen, I figured this had to be a Homer Simpsonism, but after reading some enthusiastic reviews my interest is (a little) piqued. It doesn\u2019t sound very posh, though, does it, and they\u2019re probably $18 at the bar in spite of that. Must make at home.\n\n20A: Supplier of the critical Z and a tiny history lesson, TANZANIA did not formally exist before 1964, when Tanganyika, which had been part of German East Africa on the continent\u2019s mainland, combined with the Zanzibar archipelago to form a nation. German East Africa was essentially a corporate name for a huge trading company that colonized a large area of Africa in the late 1800s. Zanzibar is one of those places that are like a Grand Central Station of human history.", "title": "Little Firecracker", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-12 00:00:00", "text": "We did not even own our uniforms. Instead we paid a $100 rental fee, refundable only if the uniform was returned in good condition. If special outfits were required for private events, we had to buy them (and weren\u2019t reimbursed). When I left after six years, I could not take my uniform with me because it was still in good condition; it was used for two more seasons by another Ben-Gal before I could purchase it.\n\nTo supplement the low pay, I could bring in extra money by signing up for special events with fans, which came to several hundred dollars per season. But at these events, groping, sexist comments and ogling were par for the course (sometimes literally, since we often made appearances at golf courses). And while there was a security person provided for us at stadium events, at off-site events, which could draw hundreds of fans, we were on our own.\n\nAt our orientation, our captain told us to expect harassment from fans. \u201cWhen a fan gets too close or gropes you,\u201d she said, \u201calways smile. If a guy grabs you too tightly, take his hand off you and put your arm around him instead.\u201d We were told to be polite and courteous, and to never get angry with fans, no matter what they did.\n\nSome male fans leered, stared at our breasts and tried to grab us when we posed for photos with them. Bar events were particularly unpleasant because the men were often inebriated. When I posed with them, they would try to do a \u201cboob hug,\u201d reaching their hands around, raising them slowly and trying to touch the side of my breast. I had to delicately (but never angrily) move the hand to my waist or arrange myself far enough away that they couldn\u2019t touch me.\n\nFan interactions could even be punishment for breaking the rules. On the Ben-Gals, once the cheerleaders were chosen for the four corners of the field, any women who did not \u201cmake corner\u201d (often because of their weight) were not allowed on the field for the game. Instead, they had to go to the private suites to mingle with fans, who could be rude and ungracious. One of the reasons we all worked so hard to \u201cmake corner\u201d was to avoid having to make a suite appearance.\n\nIn the past, most cheerleaders put up with these brutal conditions, figuring that cheering was a temporary job and there was no point fighting to change it when it was meant to be a steppingstone. Those who did complain were often shunned or punished. The overriding message we received from our directors and captains was that complainers were replaceable. Some of the more vocal women would be disqualified (by the captains) from participating in paid events, as punishment for speaking out.\n\nFortunately, cheerleader conditions are improving. The Seattle Seahawks were the first to offer minimum wage to their cheerleaders, in 1997. Cheerleaders for the Oakland Raiders and Tampa Bay Buccaneers now get minimum wage and overtime, as do the Ben-Gals, after lawsuits and settlements. After one of my fellow cheerleaders initiated a class-action suit against the Bengals for violation of federal employment laws, we received $255,000 in back pay. My own payout was $7,500 for three years of cheering. Today a minimum-wage cheerleader can make several thousand per year, which might cover a chunk of the cost of pantyhose, hair extensions, cosmetics and gasoline that they buy with their own money.\n\nSome football fans adore us and can\u2019t envision the game without us. Others think we\u2019re bad dancers and relics of a more sexist era. But one thing is indisputable: Cheerleaders bring in money. A 2003 Forbes magazine article estimated that N.F.L. teams with cheerleaders bring in $1 million in revenue per team in calendar sales, appearances, sponsorships and clothing lines. Cheerleaders also bring traffic to team websites with blogs, photos and contests. Public events and web traffic can lead to increased ticket sales for games and a higher profile for team sponsors.", "title": "Opinion | Little to Cheer About", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-01 00:00:00", "text": "Take, for example, an April 2016 concert in Nashville where Ticketmaster added a $14.75 fee on top of a $36 ticket for a show in an amphitheater Live Nation owned. Even Michael Rapino, Live Nation\u2019s chief executive, called that fee \u201cnot defendable,\u201d according to an internal email.\n\nHolding onto venues is critical to a company that relies so much on ticket fees. Mr. Rapino has repeatedly boasted to Wall Street that the number of venues it tickets around the world \u2014 a statistic it does not release \u2014 is constantly growing.\n\nFor the live music market, a larger question going forward is whether Live Nation is now so big, so empowered by the merger, that competition in ticketing at the major venues is effectively blocked. Jared Smith, the president of Ticketmaster in North America, said no, that evidence of vibrant competition can be seen in the innovative technology and better deals that his company must now offer venues to keep them from switching to a rival.\n\n\u201cThe space is more competitive than it\u2019s ever been,\u201d he said. \u201cWe\u2019re working harder each and every year.\u201d\n\nAEG acknowledges that some part of its difficulty in securing contracts is rooted in its own missteps in developing a competitive ticketing system. And certainly, at the lower reaches of the market, Ticketmaster\u2019s share is not nearly so commanding.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut it\u2019s clear that Ticketmaster, by whatever means, has kept its rivals from gaining a meaningful foothold in the market for major music venues.\n\nPreserving competition in the ticketing market was a chief concern for regulators when the Live Nation-Ticketmaster merger was proposed in 2009. Live Nation, which had long stayed in its lane as a promoter and venue operator, had just begun to sell tickets and was taking on that role at some 110 venues.\n\nIf the two companies merged, that competition \u2014 a healthy marketplace development, as regulators saw it \u2014 would disappear.\n\nSo, as part of the consent decree, Justice officials ordered steps that they hoped would enable two new robust challengers. One measure required Ticketmaster to license its ticketing software \u2014 the proprietary system that allowed it to service swarms of customers when a popular concert went on sale \u2014 to its competitor AEG.\n\nIt was also required to divest a ticketing subsidiary, Paciolan, to another competitor.\n\nBut, as it turned out, AEG never licensed the Ticketmaster software because, it said, it did not view the technology as cutting edge. The company that Ticketmaster sold off, Paciolan, remained a niche player in the music end of the business.\n\n\u201cIt has now been eight years since the merger and the world does not look a lot different,\u201d said John E. Kwoka Jr., a professor of economics at Northeastern University and a longtime critic of the merger.\n\nMs. Varney declined to comment on the effectiveness of the agreement she had shepherded. But the antitrust division\u2019s former chief counsel, Gene Kimmelman, said the Justice Department had been hampered in what it could do to create competition in an industry already so dominated by one company.\n\n\u201cThe people who came in to oversee this transaction were very interested in doing everything imaginable to create more competition in ticketing in the marketplace,\u201d he said, \u201cand were frustrated that the options were unbelievably limited.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nTalent Needs\n\nFew buildings in Louisville are as important to the local economy as the KFC Yum! Center, a 22,000-seat arena on the banks of the Ohio River that features a mix of events, from Louisville Cardinals basketball games to concerts by Garth Brooks.\n\nIn 2012, Live Nation submitted a joint bid with another company for a contract to manage the arena. Three people who listened to Live Nation\u2019s pitch said in interviews that the company said some of its tours might skip the arena if it lost the deal.\n\n\u201cOne of their main selling points was the relationship with the talent that they had and their ability to determine where that talent chose to play,\u201d said Larry Hayes, who was then chairman of the Louisville Arena Authority, which oversees the venue.\n\nThe arena picked AEG anyway.\n\nMr. Fikre and other AEG officials say that two years later, when their company considered replacing Ticketmaster with their own ticketing service, AXS, Live Nation gave a warning.\n\nOver dinner on the night of a Miley Cyrus concert in August 2014, they said, a Live Nation executive told AEG\u2019s local venue manager that some Live Nation tours would likely bypass Louisville if AEG made good on its plan to replace Ticketmaster.\n\nThis is one of the incidents that AEG complained about to the Justice Department, pointing out that the consent decree specifically forbids Live Nation from threatening to withhold shows from venues that do not hire Ticketmaster.\n\nThe AEG account is supported by an internal email in which its employee reports being warned that the Yum! Center might lose \u201ctoss of the coin shows\u201d \u2014 the kind that could go to a nearby arena \u2014 if Ticketmaster was dumped.\n\nMr. Hayes said in an interview that he had not been aware of a second warning. He had, in fact, endorsed retaining Ticketmaster, he said: It had served the arena well. But the letter of endorsement he wrote to AEG made plain that he understood there was a nexus between employing Ticketmaster and retaining access to Live Nation talent.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cDue to the relationship between Ticketmaster and Live Nation,\u201d Mr. Hayes wrote, \u201cand knowing how important content is to our financial stability, the Louisville Arena Authority is requesting that AEG receive a formal bid from Ticketmaster to retain its business at the KFC Yum! Center.\u201d\n\nAEG officials say they ultimately ditched the plan to replace Ticketmaster because they worried the venue might lose show revenue.\n\nLive Nation disputed the account of warnings and supplied data showing that since 2012 the number of tours it has sent to the KFC Yum! Center has only increased. (Even at the Gwinnett Center outside Atlanta, now known as the Infinite Energy Center, the number of Live Nation shows rebounded after dropping off in 2014.)\n\nThere is little evidence, actually, of Live Nation retaliation. Competitors say that is because venues so rarely stray.\n\nCritics say enforcement of the consent decree has been complicated by what they call its ambiguous language. Though it forbids Live Nation from forcing a client to buy both its talent and ticketing, the agreement lets the company \u201cbundle\u201d its services \u201cin any combination.\u201d So Live Nation is barred from punishing an arena by, say, steering a star like Drake to appear at a rival stop down the road. But it\u2019s also allowed, under the agreement, to redirect a concert if it can defend the decision as sound business.\n\nMr. Buffier, of the New York Attorney General\u2019s office, said the ambiguity creates \u201chigh burdens to prove violations in court.\u201d\n\nCompetitors assert that the bundling lets Live Nation pressure venues without ever uttering a threat.\n\n\u201cThey don\u2019t need to,\u201d said Marc Leibowitz, co-owner of One Percent Productions, an independent concert promoter in Omaha. \u201cIt\u2019s just implied.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nDavid Willis, a former ticketing executive who left Ticketmaster in 2014, said the company was always careful to instruct the sales staff to respect the rules as to how talent could be mentioned when pitching an arena for business.\n\n\u201cWe were not saying, certainly, \u2018If you don\u2019t go with us you are losing that,\u2019\u201d he said. But he acknowledged, \u201cI would imagine that that is what they assumed to be the case.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nA Regulator\u2019s Quandary\n\nLive Nation and AEG both have their headquarters in Los Angeles, and last summer the companies faced off in a contract dispute over a new Major League Soccer team there, the Los Angeles Football Club.\n\nTrouble began brewing when the team began looking for someone to ticket its new stadium downtown, due to open this month.\n\nTicketmaster put in a bid. But the team insisted that Live Nation bring in some concerts as well. Live Nation balked \u2014 soccer stadiums, executives said, were a poor fit for concerts \u2014 but it struck a preliminary deal that included ticketing and a commitment to provide a few shows each year.\n\nThen the plan hit a snag. AEG owned another professional soccer team in Los Angeles \u2014 the Galaxy \u2014 and had an agreement with Major League Soccer: If another franchise from Los Angeles joined the league, AEG had the right to match any competitor\u2019s ticketing offer.\n\nWielding that clause as leverage, AEG blocked the selection of Ticketmaster, and the contract instead went to SeatGeek, an upstart company that had deals with a number of M.L.S. teams.\n\nThe Ticketmaster executives were furious and threatened to sue. They told the team owners that, if there was no Ticketmaster contract, they would not be getting the Live Nation shows. The team then complained to Major League Soccer that Live Nation had threatened to withhold talent, according to a statement by the league.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nLive Nation denied it had made any kind of threat and pointed out that the soccer league has a small equity stake in SeatGeek. It said the arena had simply pulled out of a package deal that covered both ticketing and concerts \u2014 just the sort of bundling, it said, the Justice Department settlement had allowed. Without ticketing, according to Live Nation officials, it simply made no economic sense to put concerts in a space built for soccer.\n\nBut the consent decree, which expires in 2020, also says Live Nation cannot \u201ccondition or threaten to condition the provision of live entertainment events\u201d if a venue decides to use another company for ticketing.\n\nSo is this a case of bullying, or just a business decision?\n\n\u201cLive Nation and Ticketmaster,\u201d the company said in a statement \u201cdo not \u2018condition\u2019 the placement of concerts at venues on becoming the venue\u2019s ticketing provider. Venues, on the other hand, often condition the ticketing contract on guaranteed content.\u201d\n\nAntitrust experts said this was the kind of thicket that Justice officials must navigate as they reviewed the antitrust complaints.\n\nSince the dust up, Live Nation has returned to the table and is discussing bringing acts to the stadium. The team declined to comment on the dispute. SeatGeek ended up holding onto the contract.\n\nBut the perception that Live Nation might withhold talent is prevalent enough that SeatGeek now structures some bids to address the concerns of venues who fear losing big stars, and revenues.\n\nFor example, last year, when SeatGeek tried to unseat Ticketmaster from its contract at the TD Garden in Boston, it included in its bid a promise to pay the arena $250,000 for every show that Live Nation pulled, according to a bid document reviewed by the Times and three people with knowledge of the negotiations.\n\nTicketmaster still won. TD Garden officials said the contract was awarded on the merits, and they had not received threats.\n\nA SeatGeek spokesperson declined to discuss the negotiations. But Russ D\u2019Souza, a founder of the company, said he has seen evidence that competition in the market is less than open.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cWhen we sell to teams,\u201d he said, \u201cwe have heard fears about losing concerts if they choose us.\u201d", "title": "Live Nation Rules Music Ticketing, Some Say With Threats", "authors": ["Ben Sisario", "Graham Bowley"]} {"date": "2018-04-10 00:00:00", "text": "It was not to be. Guardiola, later, was right to point out a handful of refereeing decisions that went against his team \u2014 most notably a second goal, just before halftime, that was incorrectly ruled out by an offside call \u2014 but, ultimately, that did not explain quite why City wilted so notably in the second half. One Liverpool goal, from Mohamed Salah, drew City\u2019s sting; another, from Roberto Firmino, broke its hearts, and Liverpool walked away with a 2-1 victory for a 5-1 aggregate win.\n\nIn Rome, though, something remarkable was happening. Roma had started the evening down 4-1 after a calamitous first leg in Barcelona in which it had scored three own goals.\n\nThere was precious little hope, even in Italy, for a comeback. \u201cLittle Italy and Great Spain,\u201d ran the headline in Gazzetta dello Sport, the Italian sports daily. Nobody gave the team sitting fourth in Serie A much of a chance against Lionel Messi and the rest.\n\nAnd yet, as Klopp said, the Champions League \u201cis quite fair.\u201d Everybody has a chance, no matter how slim, no matter what team they are playing. An 82nd minute goal from Kostas Manolas, the Greek defender, sealed a 3-0 win for the host and eliminated Barcelona on the away-goals rule.\n\nFans inside the Stadio Olimpico cried tears of joy. Cengiz \u00dcnder, the Turkish winger signed in the summer to replace Salah, as it happens, cradled his head in his hands, as if in shock. Roma had not reached the semifinal of this tournament since 1984. That year, it lost to Liverpool in the final.\n\nPhoto\n\nA repeat still remains a distant prospect, of course \u2014 Real Madrid and Bayern Munich, both likely to progress on Wednesday, were most likely not too disappointed to see both Barcelona and City eliminated \u2014 but it provides a salutary reminder that nothing can be taken for granted in this competition.\n\nKlopp, after all, was not merely being polite when he insisted, once again, that Liverpool had beaten perhaps the best team in Europe to progress. What Guardiola has achieved with City in his second season should not be masked by a disappointing week: three defeats, two to Liverpool and one, on Saturday, to Manchester United, depriving City of the chance to claim a Premier League title against its fiercest rival.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nLike Barcelona, City will still end the season as a domestic champion, without question, but it will do so with less of a triumphant air than perhaps it deserves.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nIt is an anticlimax, to some extent, of its own making. Over the last 10 months, as Guardiola said, City has been \u201cpretty good.\u201d It set a Premier League record for most consecutive wins. It established a lead at the top of the table that has reached as high as 18 points. It has scored three or more goals in 23 separate games. It has been a glorious season.\n\nWhether the Premier League is the \u201cmost prestigious\u201d competition in the world \u2014 as Guardiola labeled it \u2014 is debatable; that City has dominated a league that contains a handful of outstanding teams, including one good enough to make the Champions League semifinal, is not.\n\nThat it did not win the title in perfect style, that it has faltered a little at the end, that Liverpool eventually had the will and the wit to win out over two legs does not mean all of that is wiped off the slate; it does not make the paeans of praise it has won any less valid.\n\nThat City could not quite live up to the exalted status bestowed upon it \u2014 Guardiola, after all, was being asked before Christmas whether his team could win all four competitions it entered \u2014 is not failure: It is simply proof that it is not, yet, perfect.\n\nThe same could be said for Barcelona, of course, though the reaction in Catalonia is likely to be less sanguine than it will be in Manchester. There will be calls for the overhaul of the squad, for a new coach, for revolution. Guardiola will not have to deal with any of that: he will simply come back and try to be better next year.\n\n\u201cLast year we made the last 16, this year the quarterfinals,\u201d he said afterward. \u201cHopefully next year we can make the semis.\u201d He said it with a smile, though. He is aiming higher.\n\nHe must, though, endure the disappointment of another abortive European campaign, another year in which this competition has brought nothing but pain to Manchester City. It will be of little solace \u2014 and none at all to Barcelona \u2014 but that is, in a way, a mark of how far this club has come.\n\nTo Liverpool and Roma, reaching the Champions League semifinals is an unexpected bonus, an impossible dream. To Manchester City, as to Barcelona, not doing so is in some way falling short. That is the company City keeps now, the sights it has set. Barcelona going out shocked Klopp, as it shocked Europe. But seeing City fall, too, will have had almost the same effect.", "title": "Liverpool, and Champions League, Dent Manchester City\u2019s Lofty Status", "authors": ["Rory Smith", "On Soccer"]} {"date": "2018-04-04 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cWe\u2019re basically telling their family history,\u201d said Joe Maddalena, the C.E.O. of Profiles in History. \u201cIt\u2019s a giant collection from the birth of Liza to what this woman became, plus the flash of when she met Halston. You\u2019ll be able to see a celebration of her life, her parents\u2019 lives, and how all this came about. Think about the talent among the three of them!\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nThe vast number of items, including clothes not only by Halston but also Bob Mackie, Gianni Versace, Gucci, Isaac Mizrahi and Donna Karan, Mr. Maddalena said, distinguishes this auction from most others. \u201cBy the time most celebrities sell, you\u2019re usually getting junk, their furniture and their castoffs,\u201d he said. \u201cThe stuff of importance is usually donated and gone. But Liza kept everything.\u201d\n\nRene Reyes, a production executive at the Paley Center, described the \u201cLove, Liza\u201d exhibit as \u201ca lot of fabulousness stuffed into this building.\u201d Included will be costumes from the John Kander and Fred Ebb musical \u201cCabaret,\u201d the film version of which earned Ms. Minnelli the Best Actress Oscar in 1973, and from her string of 1991 concerts at Radio City Music Hall, along with her 1999-2000 Broadway show, \u201cMinnelli on Minnelli: Live at the Palace.\u201d\n\nAlso: selections from Ms. Minnelli\u2019s vast wardrobe of vintage Halston, like a red sequin tuxedo she wore in concert, showcased on mannequins sporting her signature short hair and long eyelashes, in a specially created setting evoking Studio 54, the Manhattan disco she frequented in the 1970s.\n\nHalston Heritage, which is overseeing part of the installation, will be lending an actual mirror ball it acquired from Studio 54. \u201cIf that ball could speak,\u201d said Angela Pih, the chief marketing officer at Halston Heritage.\n\nMs. Minnelli and Halston, who were introduced by her godmother, the actress and author Kay Thompson, were the best of friends for decades. She was his muse. The designer, who died of Kaposi\u2019s sarcoma in 1990, was her mentor.\n\n\u201cNo one matters more to her than Halston,\u201d Mr. Feinstein wrote in an email. \u201cLiza says that, with Fred Ebb and Kay Thompson, Halston created her. Sharing his work is her way of reminding people of his importance to her life and the world of fashion. The vibrations in the clothes and drawings are damned powerful.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWhether singing standards on \u201cThe Ed Sullivan Show\u201d in the 1960s, teaming up with Goldie Hawn for the 1980 musical one-off \u201cGoldie and Liza Together\u201d (now a YouTube curiosity) or suffering from chronic vertigo as the pratfall risk Lucille Austero on more than 20 episodes of the sitcom \u201cArrested Development\u201d between 2003 and 2013, Ms. Minnelli has long tickled at-home audiences.\n\nPhoto\n\nHer two guest appearances on her mother\u2019s 1963-64 variety series, and her own Emmy Award-winning TV concert, \u201cLiza With a Z,\u201d a 1972 NBC special directed by Bob Fosse, are standout moments in television history. \u201cYou can\u2019t overestimate how those appearances established her as an artist,\u201d Mr. Reyes said.\n\nMr. Feinstein said that although Ms. Minnelli has \u201cmade a conscious choice to simplify\u201d her life since relocating to Los Angeles from New York several years ago, she isn\u2019t parting with all of her cherished possessions.\n\nMs. Minnelli, he said, is retaining such items as the christening Bible she received from Ms. Thompson, Ms. Garland\u2019s music library, Mr. Minnelli\u2019s 1959 Academy Award for \u201cGigi,\u201d a movie poster for 1945\u2019s \u201cThe Clock\u201d (on which Ms. Minnelli\u2019s parents collaborated) and a Richard Avedon portrait of Ms. Garland.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nBut getting rid of so much stuff, which had been housed for decades in more than a half-dozen storage spaces on the East and West Coasts, has been good for Ms. Minnelli, Mr. Feinstein said. \u201cAfter a lifetime of nonstop work she is, from my view, happier than I have ever seen her.\u201d\n\nThis \u201cpurge with a capital P,\u201d as he said she calls it, \u201cdid not come without much thought and soul-searching. The conclusion was that she could sit on these things and they would never see the light of day again, or send them out into the world and see them live again with others who would appreciate them.\u201d\n\nA share of the auction proceeds, he added, will go to the Great American Songbook Foundation, a music organization that he founded seven years ago with Ms. Minnelli\u2019s help.\n\nIt is unclear whether Ms. Minnelli will attend the exhibit at the Paley Center. Blaming an \u201cextreme viral infection,\u201d she canceled a March 30 performance with Mr. Feinstein a few days before the event.\n\nBut Ms. Minnelli seems pleased to be relinquishing past clutter. \u201cIt was time to go there and I have,\u201d she said, \u201cand it feels good.\u201d", "title": "Liza Minnelli Goes Marie Kondo; Old Holdings to Be Shown and Sold", "authors": ["Frank Decaro"]} {"date": "2018-04-09 00:00:00", "text": "A state ethics panel investigating the activities of Mayor Bill de Blasio\u2019s political nonprofit announced Monday that it had reached settlements with two prominent donors to the organization, known as the Campaign for One New York.\n\nThe settlements are the first to come out of a lengthy investigation by the Joint Commission on Public Ethics, which enforces state lobbying laws. The commission was looking into whether the nonprofit, now defunct, that Mr. de Blasio formed to back his prekindergarten initiative and other efforts lobbied the city in 2015 without registering to do so.\n\nThe investigation, which has stretched past two years, had been stalled, officials said, after it emerged that state and federal prosecutors were talking to many of the same organizations and donors as part of their inquiries into whether Mr. de Blasio solicited campaign contributions in exchange for official city actions. No charges were ever filed in those cases, and Mr. de Blasio has maintained he acted appropriately. He repeated that stance during in an interview Monday on NY1 in which he was asked about the settlements.\n\nThe panel reached its settlements in recent days with James F. Capalino, one of the top-earning lobbyists in New York City, and with New Yorkers for Clean, Livable and Safe Streets, an animal rights organization known as Nyclass, whose 2013 campaign spending against Mr. de Blasio\u2019s opponent, Christine C. Quinn, helped to propel his first successful mayoral run.", "title": "Lobbyists Who Donated to de Blasio Nonprofit Settle With Ethics Panel", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-05 00:00:00", "text": "He hoarded artifacts he found on the street and stashed them on the roof of his apartment building: locks, segments of pipe, a boiler casting, fingernail clippers, a razor blade, a bicycle chain and a shoe. Among his possessions there were also soiled latex gloves from his mother\u2019s medical job and an envelope addressed to his father.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nCarlos Simone, 59, a friend, said he had seen Mr. Vassell point things at people and play like they were guns. But his father said Mr. Vassell never touched real guns, and friends said he could be talked down when he was excited.\n\n\u201cHe had a mental issue that was challenging,\u201d said Kirk McLeod, 34, who knew Mr. Vassell for six years. \u201cAnd sometimes it\u2019s just a simple conversation with someone can deter them from doing something stupid. If I saw this in his hand, I would have taken that from him.\u201d\n\nDian Burgess, 34, an employee at Diamond Krust, a Jamaican restaurant where Mr. Vassell picked up food for workers at nearby barbershops and hair salons, said one officer was particularly close to Mr. Vassell.\n\n\u201cMost of the police I saw liked him and had a one-on-one rapport with him,\u201d Mr. Burgess said.\n\nMr. Vassell was known as quirky and occasionally erratic, but never violent, friends said. Almost every morning he visited St. Matthew Roman Catholic Church near Utica Avenue and Eastern Parkway, showing up before 7:30 a.m. Mass. He would walk in, cross himself and then pace the aisles of the church, bobbing his head without ever stopping to sit in the pews.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Race/Related Newsletter Join a deep and provocative exploration of race with a diverse group of New York Times journalists. He would clasp his hands before them and give them a kiss.\n\nWhy he started pretending to point a gun at people on Wednesday was not clear. The first 911 calls came in at 4:40 p.m.: One caller reported that others had said he had a gun, while another told the dispatcher, \u201cHe\u2019s like popping it as if, like, if he\u2019s pulling the trigger.\u201d The three plainclothes officers were not assigned to the incident, but saw an alert about it in their car and decided to respond. They asked a dispatcher for more details and reached the scene by 4:42 p.m., the police said.\n\nBecause the officers were sent to an intersection rather than a street address, they lacked information about previous calls regarding a person with mental illness.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nUniformed officers from the Strategic Response Group, which handles major events and hot spots of crime, happened to be in the area and responded to the scene, too.\n\nWhen they arrived at the corner of Montgomery Street and Utica Avenue, the officers saw Mr. Vassell assume a shooting stance, the police said. Four of them \u2014 three plainclothes officers and one uniformed officer \u2014 rapidly fired a total of 10 shots. Witnesses said they did not hear the officers say anything.\n\nThe shooting left residents deeply distrustful of the notion that neighborhood policing would protect them from fatal police shootings. Charles Hampton, 55, said he thought it was nothing more than a public relations ploy by the city to prevent civil unrest.\n\n\u201cThat\u2019s just to keep your mind settled, to stop the riots,\u201d he said.\n\nMr. Vassell\u2019s death left a void at Kev\u2019s Unique Barber Shop, where he often swept for a few dollars, and on his Crown Heights corner.
