When I start my Windows 10 computer, there is a background picture I must click on before I can enter my password. The screen then defaults to a Bing page explaining all about the photo. How can I sign in directly to my desktop when I turn on the computer?\n\nA. The Windows 10 system settings include several ways to personalize the PC, including changing the image on the lock screen, where you enter your password each time you start Windows. You can see what the lock screen is set to display by pressing the Windows and I keys on the keyboard to open the Settings box. Select the Personalization icon and choose Lock Screen in the left side of the window.", "title": "Locking Up Your Lock Screen", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-06 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nThe Popcast is hosted by Jon Caramanica, a pop music critic for The New York Times. It covers the latest in pop music criticism, trends and news.\n\nLast month, the earnest rapper Logic released \u201cBobby Tarantino II,\u201d which made its debut at the top of the Billboard album chart. It was the culmination of a determined climb from backpack-rap obscurity to pop-rap ubiquity, and perhaps early notice of an imminent realignment of rap\u2019s power structure.\n\nPopcast Logic, XXXTentacion and Hip-Hop Morality in 2018 A conversation about the earnest rapper and the SoundCloud renegade, both successes of modern internet-driven rap fandom. Audio\n\nIts reign was short, though. After just one week, it was knocked out of the top spot by a rapper working the polar opposite of the moral spectrum: XXXTentacion, the most versatile artist of the SoundCloud rap generation, and also the one with the most heinous allegations of criminal behavior.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Louder Newsletter Every week, stay on top of the latest in pop and jazz with reviews, interviews, podcasts and more from The New York Times music critics. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThese two artists are both successes of modern internet-driven fandom. And even though their musical and thematic approaches are very different, they have things in common that might not be evident from a surface read, in terms of the emotional language they deploy and the way they connect with young hip-hop fans.\n\nTo discuss these artists, and how they relate to examples of male frailty in earlier generations of pop music, Mr. Caramanica is joined on this week\u2019s Popcast by Lindsay Zoladz, a staff writer at the Ringer and former pop music critic for New York magazine.\n\nEmail your questions, thoughts and ideas about what\u2019s happening in pop music to popcast@nytimes.com.", "title": "Logic, XXXTentacion and Hip-Hop Morality in 2018", "authors": ["The New York Times"]} {"date": "2018-04-11 00:00:00", "text": "Lois Wheeler Snow, a former actress and writer whose criticism of human rights abuses in China was amplified by the legacy of her husband, the American journalist Edgar Snow, the author of the landmark book \u201cRed Star Over China,\u201d died on April 3 at a hospital in Nyon, Switzerland. She was 97.\n\nHer daughter, Sian Snow, confirmed the death. Her mother had lived in Switzerland since 1959.\n\nLois Wheeler was an up-and-coming Broadway actress in 1949 when she married Mr. Snow, who was best known for \u201cRed Star Over China\u201d (1937), a sympathetic portrayal of China\u2019s struggling young Communist revolutionaries. It introduced many Western readers to Mao Zedong, Zhou Enlai and others who would go on to lead the People\u2019s Republic of China.\n\n\u201cChina became part of my life when I met and married Edgar Snow,\u201d Ms. Snow wrote in an essay in 2011.\n\nOn her first visit to that country, in 1970, she and her husband were treated like royalty. She attended a Ping-Pong match with Zhou, the first premier of the People\u2019s Republic; dined with Soong Ching-ling, the wife of Sun Yat-sen; and, notably, stood with her husband alongside Mao on the Tiananmen rostrum during the National Day Parade \u2014 a gesture later understood to be a signal from Mao to President Richard M. Nixon that Beijing was willing to reopen ties with Washington.", "title": "Lois Wheeler Snow, Critic of Human Rights Abuses in China, Dies at 97", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-07 00:00:00", "text": "A year with 200 homicides, for a city of more than 8.5 million people, would be far from a shocking high in the United States. New York City, with a roughly comparable population size, had 292 murders last year, according to the 2018 Police Commissioner\u2019s Report, and that was a record low. In Britain, however, the prospect has been enough to alarm politicians and command newspaper front pages.\n\nAnalysts say that the surge in violent crime has been driven by several factors, including rivalries between drug gangs, cuts to youth services and social programs, and even the ease with which teenagers can now taunt and provoke one another on social media.\n\n\u201cIt is difficult to address the causes of violence without addressing important social questions about the choices facing young people in terms of opportunities,\u201d said Roger Grimshaw, the research director at the Center for Crime and Justice Studies in London.\n\nDavid Lammy, a lawmaker for the north London district of Tottenham, which has been hit hard by violent crime in recent weeks, said there was not one single cause for the surge, but that drug gangs were a major factor.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cWhat drives the gangs and the turf wars is an 11 billion pound cocaine drugs market,\u201d he said in an interview with BBC Radio 4\u2019s \u201cToday\u201d program. Eleven billion pounds is about $15.5 billion.\n\n\u201cDrugs are prolific,\u201d Mr. Lammy added. \u201cThey\u2019re as prolific as ordering a pizza. You can get them on Snapchat, WhatsApp. That, in the end, is driving the turf war; and it\u2019s driving the culture of violence.\u201d\n\nHe suggested that the police had lost control of the drugs market, which he said was largely controlled by Eastern European gangs. Gangs increasingly use children and teenagers to carry drugs around the country, making them potential casualties in fighting between groups.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMost of the killings in London so far have been stabbings, most apparently carried out by young people. A majority of the victims were in their 20s or younger, and many have been black or from ethnic minorities.\n\nMr. Grimshaw warned that sudden increases in crime could cause a type of \u201ccontagion\u201d among communities. \u201cIf a sufficient number of people feel frightened, they can look on knife-carrying as a way to make themselves feel safe, but it actually makes them less safe,\u201d he said.\n\nKnife crime in Britain rose by 21 percent last year, and stabbings in London were at their highest level in six years, according to figures released in September by the Office for National Statistics, which compiles an authoritative survey of crime in England and Wales.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nA current government poster campaign in some parts of London promotes the virtues of \u201cliving knife free,\u201d linking to a website with a \u201cquick close\u201d button for those ashamed or afraid to be seen viewing it.\n\nThis past week, the Metropolitan Police promised a new task force of specially selected, dedicated police officers to focus on \u201cviolent crime, weapon-enabled crime and serious criminality.\u201d\n\n\u201cYou will see us being even more proactive out on the streets,\u201d the force\u2019s leader, Commissioner Cressida Dick, said in a statement. \u201cWe will have a greater presence in the hot spots of violence and a focused effort, including intelligence-led stop-and-search and the use of specialists in covert tactics.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nCommissioner Dick told Sky News on Friday that 300 more officers would be deployed each day on the streets of London.\n\nThe increased use of stop-and-frisk tactics, reduced in London and elsewhere in Britain in recent years, has been a frequent demand of some Conservative lawmakers and other critics in the face of shocking crime reports.\n\nBut some community workers and politicians argue that would be counterproductive, damaging trust in the police in deprived areas without necessarily finding many weapons.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cRandom stop-and-search has poisoned relationships between the police and the community,\u201d Diane Abbott, the home affairs spokeswoman of the opposition Labour Party, told the BBC. \u201cIn the end, we need the cooperation of the community to deal with the issues.\u201d\n\nSome experts say that increased police patrols are also unlikely to deter crime, although they may help to reassure communities.\n\nThe Labour mayor of London, Sadiq Khan, has blamed central government cuts in the policing budget for the rise in crime; police budgets in England and Wales have been cut by an average of 20 percent, accounting for inflation, since 2010.\n\n\u201cSince 2014, we have seen an increase in violent crime in London and across the country,\u201d Mr. Khan said in an interview with the Press Association news agency. \u201cSince I first became mayor, I have been saying to the government that it\u2019s not sustainable to make the level of cuts they have been making to London.\u201d\n\nSteve O\u2019Connell, the chairman of the London Assembly\u2019s Police and Crime Committee, said that while the Metropolitan Police deserved better funding, it still had the resources to deal with the recent spate of violent crime.\n\n\u201cThey are taking this very seriously, but it\u2019s much more complicated that just arresting people,\u201d he said in a phone interview. \u201cWe need to get to the root cause of why so many young men use knives to settle their differences and why they are willing to inflict serious damage on people.\u201d\n\n\u201cOnce we understand this,\u201d he continued, \u201cwe need to make sure these people are taken off the street and put away for a long time.\u201d", "title": "London Confronts a Spate of Murders, With Most Victims Killed by Knives", "authors": ["Ceylan Yeginsu"]} {"date": "2018-04-20 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Oakes did not respond to requests for comment. A spokesman for Cambridge Analytica endeavored to distance the company from Mr. Oakes and his comments, saying he \u201cnever had any role at Cambridge Analytica, has never worked for Cambridge Analytica and did not work on the Trump campaign in any way whatsoever.\u201d\n\nImage Nigel Oakes of SCL Group, the parent company of Cambridge Analytica.\n\nThe company said his comments were made \u201cin a personal capacity about the historical use of propaganda to an academic he knew well from her work in the defense sphere.\u201d\n\nThe hearings marked a sudden public exposure for Mr. Oakes, an upper-crust Englishman whose air of mystery was also a selling point. From its inception, the central promise of the SCL Group was to shape public opinion without being seen. Dr. Briant, who interviewed Mr. Oakes repeatedly for her book \u201cPropaganda and Counter-Terrorism: Strategies for Global Change,\u201d said she suspected that for Mr. Oakes, the hearings had been a painful experience.\n\n\u201cYou need to bear in mind, these are powerful, arrogant men,\u201d she said. \u201cThey think they own the world. I honestly think they thought they were invincible.\u201d\n\nAs a young man, Mr. Oakes cut a rakish figure. Raised in rural gentility \u2014 his father was once the high sheriff of Warwickshire \u2014 and educated at Eton, he had \u201ca kind of smoothness and charm and charisma that you associate with people who have that kind of education,\u201d his former colleague Barrie Gunter said.\n\nAfter Eton, instead of continuing on to college, he embarked on a racy career as a disc jockey and music producer and dated Lady Helen Windsor, a cousin of Queen Elizabeth and 40th in line to the throne.\n\nThe business idea he brought to the team of psychologists was \u201cMarketing Aromatics,\u201d a service that pumped in fragrances \u2014 of pine trees, the ocean, or new-mown grass \u2014 on the principle that \u201csmells can influence attitudes and therefore behavior.\u201d Mr. Oakes was \u201ca young man in a hurry,\u201d under pressure to repay his investors, said Professor Gunter, of the department of mass communications at the University of Leicester.\n\nHe was also anxious over his lack of a university diploma, pressing the professors to suggest a \u201cshort cut\u201d that would save him years of study. \u201cHe was what the English would call economical with the truth,\u201d said Mr. Furnham, a professor of psychology at University College London.", "title": "Long Before Cambridge Analytica, a Belief in the \u2018Power of the Subliminal\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-03 00:00:00", "text": "Often these issues do not break along party lines, which make them interesting in a city where today\u2019s battle lines are so clear.\n\nOne small example: Ms. Yates pushed for more lenient sentencing laws and an expanded educational system in federal prison. Mr. Sessions is adamantly opposed. But another of her signature decisions was ordering prosecutors not to go easy on Wall Street executives. That fits neatly with Mr. Sessions\u2019s philosophy. \u201cI was taught, if they violated the law, you charge them,\u201d he said in 2010.\n\nThe politics of law enforcement are as murky now as ever. In the 1980s and 1990s, both parties united in the face of the crack epidemic to pass strict laws and mandatory minimum sentences. President Bill Clinton signed a bipartisan crime bill in 1994 that toughened sentences and paid for more prisons.\n\nAs a cub reporter in New Bedford, Mass., I covered the cops in a city surrounded by heroin addiction. My editor rightly saw it as the paper\u2019s job to question the local government\u2019s response. The result was a steady drumbeat of stories and editorials about the district attorney\u2019s reluctance to use laws that would prompt mandatory minimum sentences. My editor was a Massachusetts liberal, hardly a law-and-order hard-liner. Like so many people, he was simply at his wit\u2019s end.\n\nWhen prison populations soared \u2014 a trend that disproportionately affected young African-American men \u2014 politicians began reconsidering their policies. Mr. Clinton said his law went too far. And Mr. Holder found common ground with libertarian-minded Republicans who say long prison sentences are an ineffective and expensive way to fight crime. Conservative states like Texas have helped lead a criminal justice reform movement.\n\nMr. Sessions is not having it. He cut his teeth as a prosecutor during the 1980s, and he credits that era\u2019s laws with lowering crime nationwide. I recently wrote about how his views have put him at odds with Jared Kushner, the president\u2019s son-in-law and adviser. The politics are changing around Mr. Sessions, but he retains the views of justice and fairness that he has held for decades.\n\nFor many conservatives, that makes him a man of principle. For many liberals, that makes him dangerous.\n\nFor me, that makes for a great story.", "title": "Looking for Justice in the Building That Bears Its Name", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-13 00:00:00", "text": "Like the president, I did not have the honor of serving in our armed forces. No problem. This might be my chance to put on a uniform, maybe one with lots of shiny medals and ribbons to commemorate the seamless steel pipe skirmishes I\u2019ve been involved in. Or maybe I could do what the young people do \u2014 some kind of cosplay that lets me suit up as a Viking, or a \u201cStar Wars\u201d storm trooper, or even the rampaging DC Comics character Harley Quinn, girding my loins for economic battle.\n\nThe problem was that I don\u2019t know enough about economics to understand what exactly I\u2019m supposed to do. My mind must be insufficiently deep or subtle to understand these issues, I decided. And so I called a couple of experts, actual economists.\n\nFirst I called Douglas Holtz-Eakin, a conservative economist who served in the George W. Bush administration. He told me that my personal trade deficit is not as bad as I think it is. \u201cI have a tens-of-thousands-of-dollars trade deficit with P.F. Chang\u2019s every year, but I\u2019m a very happy loser,\u201d he said.\n\nThe problem with trying to engage in a personal trade war, he explained, is that individuals don\u2019t often produce things that are easy to put a value on and barter.\n\n\u201cI give lectures in economics,\u201d he said, so \u201cI need to find those suckers who are willing to take them so I can eat.\u201d As for me, he said, I have only one product \u2014 basically, paragraphs. \u201cYou\u2019re in worse shape than I am! You should be afraid,\u201d he said.\n\nThen the conversation began to get uncomfortable. He said that if I were to try to impose a tariff, this interview we were conducting would cost him money because \u2014 bear with me \u2014 he would essentially be importing me. I liked that part, until he added that if I went down that route, there would be consequences: \u201cIt\u2019ll be the last interview I ever do,\u201d he said.\n\nThat, he said, is the lesson of trade wars: \u201cTrade stops, and things that used to benefit both of us go away.\u201d", "title": "Looking for an Easy-to-Win Trade War of My Very Own", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-02 00:00:00", "text": "Josh Kallmer, the senior vice president for global policy at the Information Technology Industry Council, an advocate for companies like Google, Facebook, Apple, Microsoft and IBM, said his group had been largely supportive of the administration\u2019s targeting of China\u2019s unfair trade practices. But the group had made it clear to the White House that it would not be pleased with any measure that had tariffs \u201cas the primary or even a significant remedy.\u201d\n\n\u201cThe reason is that it would be a tax on consumers,\u201d Mr. Kallmer said, \u201cprecisely the people we are trying to support.\u201d\n\nMany of the trade measures that Mr. Trump has proposed, including the steel and aluminum tariffs, have divided his advisers, the business community and the Republican Party. But the White House has boasted that its targeting of China\u2019s trade practices has broad support from industries on the losing end of the Chinese approach.\n\nThat theory could make it more difficult for American companies to operate in a country that already puts up steep barriers.\n\nAmerican companies and business groups have frequently complained that China blocks off valuable markets from American competition, including technology, media and finance, and that it does so in violation of commitments it made when it joined the World Trade Organization in 2001. China has imposed regulations that require American companies to share their technology with Chinese partners, for example, mandating that foreign companies operate through joint ventures if they want access to Chinese consumers. At times, the Chinese have resorted to stealing vital technologies through cyberwarfare, according to United States authorities.\n\nLate last month, the White House said it would crack down on that behavior, outlining a series of actions aimed at punishing China for its trade barriers.\n\nAs Mr. Trump advances a series of tough trade measures to confront these behaviors, however, cracks have appeared in American industry\u2019s seemingly united front.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nCompanies in technology, investment and other industries now say that the measures the administration is taking to help them may actually end up doing irreparable harm to supply chains they have built up over decades. Any American company that wants to be a global player cannot afford to lose access to China\u2019s growing market, executives say.\n\nPhoto\n\nTechnology companies argue that the restrictive measures the administration is taking to help protect them could end up penalizing American manufacturing, raising costs and making their companies less competitive globally. And industries most vulnerable to retaliation, like agriculture, are protesting about losing valuable export opportunities. While the Chinese did not target soybeans in their initial tariffs list, many in the soybean industry worry they will be penalized in a trade dispute given China\u2019s importance as a market for exports.\n\nThe 25 percent tariff on pork that China imposed on Monday is expected to be particularly harmful, including in regions that supported the president, like Iowa, North Carolina and Indiana. Last year, American farmers sent more than a billion dollars\u2019 worth of pork to China, their largest export market by value after Japan and Mexico.\n\n\u201cBecause we\u2019re so blessed to have America feed the world, we\u2019re also the first industry to get slammed whenever there are trade difficulties between the U.S. and other countries,\u201d Denise Bode, the coordinator for the American Fruit and Vegetable Processors and Growers Coalition.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cAmerican farmers appear to be the first casualties of an escalating trade war,\u201d said Max Baucus, a former Democratic senator from Montana and a chairman of a group called Farmers for Free Trade. \u201cWith farm incomes already declining, farmers rely on export markets to stay above water. These new tariffs are a drag on their ability to make ends meet.\u201d\n\nSince Mr. Trump announced the China measures on March 22, American officials, including Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin and the United States trade representative, Robert Lighthizer, have been in talks with the Chinese about ways to resolve their differences. The sides have discussed concessions like reducing China\u2019s tariffs on American cars, opening up its market for financial services and purchasing more semiconductors or natural gas, people familiar with the talks said.\n\nHowever, analysts and companies involved in China said that these measures appeared unlikely to adequately resolve American concerns about China\u2019s longstanding encroachment on American intellectual property.\n\nCompanies are waiting anxiously for the administration to release a list of Chinese products this week that will be subject to tariffs \u2014 most likely the kind of high-tech products that the administration has accused China of targeting. The retail industry, which lobbied the administration and Congress against an early plan to impose tariffs on Chinese-made apparel and footwear, is now cautiously optimistic that its products will be exempt.\n\nRestrictions on Chinese investment are expected to follow in the coming weeks. Administration officials have said those rules will aim to restore reciprocity with the Chinese, though it is not clear if the United States will go so far as to bar Chinese companies from investing in the same industries that China restricts. The White House is also considering the use of an emergency economy powers act that could allow it to restrict Chinese investments.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe measures come on top of proposed legislation in Congress to expand the authority of the Committee on Foreign Investment in the United States, which reviews foreign deals for national security concerns. Last month, the committee stalled a hostile takeover of Qualcomm, a California-based chip maker, by a Singapore company, largely over concerns about ceding semiconductor prowess to China.\n\nG.E. and IBM, which operate through joint ventures and other partnerships in China and around the world, have both lobbied against the expansion of Cfius over concerns that restrictions on joint ventures with foreign companies that include the transfer of valuable skills or technology could weaken the position of American companies abroad.\n\nFinancial firms, including Goldman Sachs and the Carlyle Group, have also expressed concern about investment restrictions, saying they could provide a drag on the United States economy.\n\nWhite House advisers, in turn, have complained that previous approaches to dealing with China have not worked, and that companies are overreacting to legitimate trade measures.\n\nSpeaking Monday on CNBC, the White House trade adviser, Peter Navarro, defended the administration\u2019s tough actions on China and said investors should not fear a trade war.\n\n\u201cEverybody needs to relax,\u201d Mr. Navarro said. \u201cThe economy is as strong as an ox.\u201d", "title": "Looming China Trade Action Divides Industry and Roils Markets", "authors": ["Ana Swanson"]} {"date": "2018-04-12 00:00:00", "text": "LONDON \u2014 In his award-winning biography, \u201cThe Hare With Amber Eyes,\u201d the British ceramic artist Edmund de Waal tells the story of his family through its collection of Japanese netsuke carvings.\n\nNetsuke are ornamental toggles made mainly out of ivory or wood and used to fasten things to the sash of a kimono. Each one is \u201ca small, tough explosion of exactitude,\u201d as Mr. de Waal memorably wrote. Charles Ephrussi, a cousin of the author\u2019s great-grandfather, bought a complete collection of 264 of these carvings from a Paris dealer in the late 19th century. Among them was an ivory netsuke of a trembling hare with amber-inlaid eyes.\n\nExtraordinarily, the entire collection has remained intact, surviving World War II in Vienna, hidden in the mattress of a family servant. It spent further years in the apartment of an uncle in Tokyo, before being bequeathed to Mr. de Waal, who keeps it in his London home.\n\nHe writes in his book how a disapproving neighbor, surprised by the sight of such precious objects in a private house, suggested that the netsuke should be returned to Japan. \u201cNo,\u201d replied Mr. de Waal. \u201cObjects have always been carried, sold, bartered, stolen, retrieved and lost,\u201d he said. \u201cIt is how you tell the stories that matters.\u201d", "title": "Looming Ivory Ban Will Create a Mountain of Unsellable Antiques", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-16 00:00:00", "text": "I doubt Comey wants these salacious details to be the main message of his earnest tome, in which he comes off as a somewhat tragic figure who, in striving for decency, makes errors of judgment that helped put the singularly indecent Trump in the White House. Yet the book\u2019s most significant new information is about Trump\u2019s obsession with the rumored tape, which he brought up with Comey again and again, and the lies Trump told about why it couldn\u2019t be real.\n\nIn one conversation, Trump insisted to Comey that it was unimaginable that he would sleep with prostitutes. (The former Playboy model Karen McDougal, who claims to have had an affair with Trump, has said that he tried to pay her the first time they had sex.) In another, he said he\u2019d just remembered that he never even stayed overnight in Moscow: \u201cHe claimed he had flown from New York, had only gone to the hotel to change his clothes, and had flown home that same night,\u201d Comey writes.\n\nThough Comey doesn\u2019t mention it, this contradicts the story that Trump\u2019s former bodyguard, Keith Schiller, reportedly told the House Intelligence Committee about that night. Schiller said that a Russian associate offered to send five women to Trump\u2019s room, but was turned down. \u201cSchiller said the two men laughed about it as Trump went to bed alone,\u201d NBC reported. \u201cSchiller testified that he stood outside Trump\u2019s hotel room for a time and then went to bed.\u201d\n\nTrump\u2019s lies here are of more than voyeuristic interest. The possible existence of the tape isn\u2019t relevant because it would prove that Trump is sexually debauched and longs to desecrate everything Obama touched; we already know that. It matters because, like the former director of the F.B.I., we don\u2019t know if Trump has been compromised by Russia.\n\nEvidence that the tape might be real isn\u2019t limited to Trump\u2019s phony alibi. In their book \u201cRussian Roulette,\u201d the investigative journalists David Corn and Michael Isikoff report that five months before the pageant, Trump and his entourage, including his Russian associate Emin Agalarov, visited a louche Las Vegas nightclub called the Act. It was later shut down after a judge issued an injunction against the \u201clewd\u201d and \u201coffensive\u201d performances it was known for.", "title": "Opinion | Lordy, Is There a Tape?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-29 00:00:00", "text": "The Fickett Street play street, the neighborhood\u2019s fourth since the LADOT pilots began in 2016, was sought by Union de Vecinos as a safe and celebratory refuge. Perched on a bluff overlooking downtown and separated by the Los Angeles River, Boyle Heights, a neighborhood of about 100,000 residents, has long suffered from a host of land-use inequities, including its proximity to polluting freeways that decimated housing and sliced the community\u2019s largest park in half.\n\nThree-quarters of the housing units in Boyle Heights are currently rentals. And the fact that the neighborhood is near the downtown Arts District across the river has brought the issue of displacement to the fore. Art galleries and house flippers have moved in and longtime tenants have received eviction notices, raising the specter of \u201cIkea catalogs in the barrio,\u201d as Josefina L\u00f3pez, the artistic director of Casa 0101 Theater and the writer of \u201cReal Women Have Curves,\u201d put it.\n\nPhoto\n\nIn her play \u201cHipsteria,\u201d Ms. L\u00f3pez imagined the last building in Boyle Heights 20 years hence, occupied by hipsters wanting to turn it into a dog hotel. \u201cBoyle Heights is not a blank canvas,\u201d she observed. \u201cIt\u2019s a rich tapestry of immigrant history, culture and activism.\u201d\n\nIt has long been an immigrant hub: The historic Breed Street Shul was the oldest Orthodox synagogue west of Chicago. (The rear building is now a community center.) The neighborhood\u2019s landscape is distinctly Latino, with artful front-yard altars dedicated to the Virgin of Guadalupe and Mexican-American murals bringing vibrant life to peeling walls.\n\nIn recent years, Union de Vecinos has been deeply involved in pro-tenant and antigallery activism, some of it confrontational. (Several galleries, including the artist-run 356 Mission, have announced they will close here.) But over the past two decades, its leaders have also worked hard to make the neighborhood cleaner and safer in the face of longstanding disinvestment. The alleyways crisscrossing the neighborhood were especially dangerous, filled with trash by people pulling off the freeways to dump construction waste, and had become magnets for illegal activity.\n\nThe group got rid of the litter and gang graffiti, installed brightly painted speed bumps and, in an alley near a liquor store, planted a garden full of spiky cactuses.\n\nPhoto\n\nBut improving the neighborhood has become a delicate proposition. As the area becomes more habitable for residents, it grows more appealing to outsiders, putting more pressure on housing. On Avenue Cesar E. Chavez, the primary commercial street, for instance, young people with laptops and earbuds sip coffee across the street from a lone Norte\u00f1o accordionist in a sombrero standing beneath a red awning.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cThere\u2019s a difference between making something beautiful to sell it and making it useful,\u201d said Leonardo Vilchis, co-director of Union de Vecinos. \u201cSo the question is, can we make this place more livable for people living here now?\u201d\n\nWith tensions about gentrification running high, the community\u2019s decision to embrace the play street concept was not a casual one.\n\n\u201cSo many people want to come in and modify this place,\u201d said Ofelia Platon, 45, a Union de Vecinos leader who lives around the corner from Fickett Street. \u201cSo there\u2019s always a question of what would we need to give up?\u201d A mother of three, she recalled taking her son Esteban, now 17, to a nearby park and having to drop on the grass because of a shooting.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe residents chose Fickett Street with the intention of providing a safe space not just for children but for the community, said Chelina Odbert, KDI\u2019s co-founder and executive director.\n\n\u201cWhat a play street is not is a replacement for permanent parks,\u201d she said. \u201cBut it bridges the gap in a way that\u2019s really needed.\u201d\n\nScarlett De Leon, a director for the Koreatown Immigrant Workers Alliance, grew up there and said she spent much of her childhood glued to television, a pattern she now observes in her younger siblings and her great-grandmother.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s a cycle that affects different generations in one family,\u201d she said. \u201cSo having a space to be creative and interact is important for emotional health.\u201d\n\nAt the play street event earlier this month, Fickett Street was alive with fathers pushing play bins down the street with children riding in them. The scent of taquitos drifted from Maria Lopez\u2019s kitchen \u2014 she made enough for everyone \u2014 and young men helped carry jars of watermelon agua fresca down the steps.\n\nMiguel \u00c1ngel Jim\u00e9nez, 18, attempted to jump a wobble with his skateboard. \u201cI feel better when people are interested in each other,\u201d he said of the street. \u201cThere\u2019s a time to be indoors and a time to be out.\u201d", "title": "Los Angeles Tests the Power of \u2018Play Streets\u2019", "authors": ["Patricia Leigh Brown"]} {"date": "2018-04-11 00:00:00", "text": "The photographer, Linda Silvestri, did not respond to requests seeking comment. She did respond on a Facebook post, explaining she did not mean to body shame the couple: \u201cMy post was not fat shaming them. I am overweight. My frustration was unrealistic expectations on their part. Their weight was the issue that led to the difficulty in shooting the session and getting creative with posing. I never ever body shame anyone and am sorry if anyone thought I was doing so.\u201d\n\nWhat the incident did show was increasing exasperation by bigger brides at the bridal industry\u2019s refusal to respect them \u2014 and a groundswell of determination to stop pretending that disrespect is O.K.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s one thing if you ask to have yourself photoshopped; it\u2019s a whole other thing if someone takes liberties to quote-unquote fix you,\u201d said Lauren Chan, a newly engaged size 16 from Brooklyn who is a former fashion editor at Glamour magazine.\n\nMs. Chan, like her friend Kelsey Miller, a size 16 newlywed and the author of the 2016 book \u201cBig Girl: How I Gave Up Dieting and Got a Life,\u201d was not surprised by what happened to Ms. Liepold, but no less horrified. \u201cIt\u2019s galling and everybody should be appalled, but it happens every day,\u201d said Ms. Miller, who is also from Brooklyn. \u201cIt\u2019s popular to declare yourself \u2018body positive\u2019 and accepting of yourself, but the truth is: Bias is still very much out there.\u201d\n\nEspecially, she said, in the bridal business. \u201cEverything in the bridal world is two sizes smaller than in the real world and seven times more expensive.\u201d\n\nBrides-to-be like Ms. Liepold and Ms. Chan are refusing to play along, and finding ways to bypass what Ms. Miller called \u201cthe whole subsection of the bridal industry that is completely devoted to weight loss.\u201d Instead of shelling out for bridal boot camp or sweating for the wedding videos, they are cleansing their social media accounts of images that make them feel unlovely; exercising for \u201cthe joy of movement,\u201d as Bevin Bralandingham, a bride-to-be in Los Angeles who teaches a class called \u201cFat Kid Dance Party,\u201d said; and signing on to online bridal forums that better represent their body types.\n\nPhoto\n\nAnd they are far from alone. Shannelle Armstrong-Fowler, the 6-foot, size 16 owner of Haute & Co. Bridal Boutique in Chicago, makes her living outfitting and styling brides sizes 14 to 32. Since opening the shop in 2013 after her own trials with finding a dress for her 2012 wedding, Ms. Armstrong, also the star of the PeopleTV series \u201cThe Perfect Fit,\u201d has familiarized more than 400 plus-size brides with her sassy catchphrase: \u201cStyle, snatch and slay.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cThe style part is finding each bride her perfect gown,\u201d she explained. \u201cSnatch means altering each dress to hug and accentuate all the right curves. And slay is ensuring each bride looks fierce and is ready to make the aisle her own personal runway.\u201d\n\nThe path to slaying does not include steering brides toward gyms and personal trainers so a dress will fit better, or insisting on an A-line silhouette, the style most often thrust at bigger brides. Instead, it usually involves finding the right undergarments. Also letting discriminating designers know they should take notice because business is booming.\n\n\u201cA lot of the discord in this business comes from designers who won\u2019t design above a certain size,\u201d Ms. Armstrong-Fowler said. \u201cBut they\u2019re becoming more aware that the average woman in America is a size 16. I\u2019ve had this conversation with a lot of designers: I say, if you\u2019re not designing above a 14 or 16, you\u2019re leaving behind an enormous part of the marketplace.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Of the Moment The lifestyle newsletter from the Styles, Travel and Food sections, offering the latest trends to news you can use. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThat includes brides like Ms. Chan, 27, who said the gowns she found in her size when she started shopping for her Labor Day wedding in the Bahamas skewed \u201cyoung and poofy.\u201d She described a scenario familiar to many curvy brides deflated by the trying-on process. \u201cI had been through Pinterest and all that fun stuff you do when you get engaged,\u201d she said. \u201cI would find a gown I loved on a size 6 model, and when I would go to a store to look for it there was nothing anywhere near my size to try on.\u201d After settling on a dress she saw online, she emailed the designer asking for customization in her size. \u201cI said, instead of a beaded top I want just a chiffon top. And they stopped answering me. I must have emailed 10 times.\u201d\n\nMs. Miller, 34, recalls being wrenched into a size 6 before her 2017 wedding to get a sense of how the gown might look. \u201cI couldn\u2019t put my arms down,\u201d she said.\n\nBesides being demoralizing, the lack of inclusivity at bridal boutiques is mystifying, Ms. Chan said, because it\u2019s bad business. \u201cThis is a time when the consumer is spending more money than she\u2019ll ever spend in her life on a piece of clothing. So why aren\u2019t these brands giving them something to buy?\u201d she asked.\n\nThat goes for jewelry designers, too.\n\nAlysia Cole, a size 16 stylist at Panache Bridal in Beverly Hills who was married in 2017, said, \u201cI remember a stylist trying a gorgeous bridal choker on me. It didn\u2019t fit around my neck.\u201d Some designers will add hooks or links so a necklace or bracelet fits, she said. \u201cBut it\u2019s hard when you can\u2019t try it on.\u201d Shopping for rehearsal dinner and bachelorette party outfits was also an exercise in disappointment: \u201cI couldn\u2019t find anything cute in my size.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nFor Ms. Cole, the news of Ms. Liepold\u2019s recent public scuffle with her engagement photographer felt redeeming. \u201cI\u2019m glad she recognizes she should be proud of how she looks,\u201d she said. Ms. Cole was also not as immune to fat-shaming when she planned her wedding. \u201cIt felt like each shop I talked with was hellbent on crushing my self worth.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMs. Liepold, and brides like Ms. Bralandingham of Los Angeles, a size 22, have become less susceptible.\n\n\u201cI look at it as a really great opportunity to change your life,\u201d Ms. Bralandingham, 39, said of the planning process that will lead to her 2019 destination wedding at Dollywood in Tennessee. \u201cNow\u2019s the time to curate your social media feed and curate your thoughts. I\u2019m planning my whole wedding around collaborating with people who validate me.\u201d\n\nMs. Miller offered advice for plus-size brides who are not quite there yet: \u201cDon\u2019t let insecurity be the boss of you.\u201d", "title": "Lose Weight? No Way. Proud to Be a Bigger Bride.", "authors": ["Tammy La Gorce"]} {"date": "2018-04-17 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Rumsby knew that World War II dead were typically buried in temporary cemeteries close to the fighting, in rows usually filled chronologically. He used an old map of the plots on Okinawa to look for unknowns buried shortly after Private Mulligan died. There were only two, and one of them, in a grave labeled X-35, looked promising.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAfter the war, the Army recorded details of each set of unknown remains in records known as X files that are now digitized and widely shared by researchers. The files showed that X-35 had been exhumed and sent to Saipan to be identified, along with thousands of others. Although the grave contained socks stenciled with the name Mulligan, no match was made, and the remains were reburied in 1950 in an American cemetery in Manila.\n\nMr. Rumsby compared the file for X-35 to Private Mulligan\u2019s personnel file in 2016 and found several points of agreement. A group of dentists then volunteered to examine dental records, and found that they matched.\n\nThe Patterson family submitted the findings to the agency in the fall of 2016 with fingers crossed, knowing that strong evidence was no guarantee that the agency would take action. Some seemingly rock-solid cases have languished for decades.\n\nPressed by the family and their senators and congressmen, the agency exhumed X-35 in the spring of 2017 and sent a section of tibia to the military\u2019s DNA lab in Maryland to be compared with the sample supplied by James Patterson (he died in July 2017). The results were a match.\n\n\u201cI don\u2019t believe in closure, I don\u2019t think we ever really get over anything,\u201d Mr. Maharidge said a few days after hearing the news. \u201cBut this feels pretty good.\u201d\n\nEarlier this month, Mr. Maharidge, the author who started the quest, walked through the ghostly marble headstones of Arlington National Cemetery with Mr. Rumsby, the researcher who had connected the crucial dots. They stopped at the grave of Mr. Maharidge\u2019s father and Mr. Maharidge produced a bottle of respectable 10-year-old bourbon.\n\nThere was an empty plot three spaces to the north, where they hoped to bury Private Mulligan. The sun was setting, and in the distance, a bugler sounded taps at the Tomb of the Unknowns.\n\nMr. Maharidge poured glasses of bourbon, then paused to splash a bit from the bottle onto the grass.\n\n\u201cThe dead drink first,\u201d he said.", "title": "Lost in Battle, Found by Amateur Sleuths: An \u2018Unknown\u2019 Marine", "authors": ["Dave Philipps"]} {"date": "2018-04-12 00:00:00", "text": "The adage says if you teach a man to fish, he eats for a lifetime.\n\nToday, if you teach a man to fish, or a woman for that matter, they\u2019ll end up on Instagram.\n\nSocial media has become the newest place for anglers to document every whopper, track the finest fishing holes and meet like-minded pals who swap secrets about everything from the best bait and lures to the most picturesque seaside villages.\n\nRecreational fishing is on the rise in United States: The Fish and Wildlife Service reported last year that the number of anglers had grown eight percent, to 35.8 million in 2016 from 33.1 million in 2011.\n\nOne of those new to the sport is Noelle Coley, 26, the manager of a medical marijuana dispensary who lives in Wheat Ridge, Colo. She said she took up fishing a few years ago after an ex-boyfriend gave her a rod and reel.", "title": "Lots of Fish on the Screen", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-27 00:00:00", "text": "After the prince was born on Monday, St. George\u2019s Day, named after England\u2019s patron saint, some members of the public had anticipated that George would feature in the new prince\u2019s name.\n\nVideo\n\nBut one bookmaker was so confident about Arthur that it paid out on the name for anyone who bet before 7 p.m. local time on Monday, according to news reports.\n\nAs with the first two children of the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge, the baby\u2019s name had been expected to follow the royal tradition of choosing names that honor past monarchs or other royals.\n\nLouis is Prince William\u2019s fourth name and was apparently chosen by his father, Prince Charles, as a tribute to Lord Louis Mountbatten, a mentor of Prince Charles\u2019s, a prominent British naval officer and the Duke of Edinburgh\u2019s uncle.\n\nCharles was most likely chosen in honor of William\u2019s father. Both Prince William and Prince Charles have Arthur in their names.\n\nExperts said that the name Arthur was most likely chosen to pay homage to the legend of King Arthur and the Knights of the Roundtable, a legendary fictional figure admired by British royals.\n\n\u201cWhat\u2019s wonderful about Arthur is it conjures up a kingship that never existed \u2014 Camelot was an egalitarian paradise \u2014 and, of course, there was the quest for the Holy Grail,\u201d the royal commentator Richard Fitzwilliams told the BBC. \u201cIt\u2019s one of the great royal legends.\u201d\n\nPrince Louis\u2019s older brother, Prince George Alexander Louis, 4, was named after six King Georges in the British royal family, including Queen Elizabeth II\u2019s father, King George VI.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe names of Princess Charlotte Elizabeth Diana, 2, are an apparent tribute to her grandmother Diana, Princess of Wales; and her great-grandmother Queen Elizabeth II.\n\nPrince William told reporters on Wednesday that Catherine and the baby were doing \u201cvery well\u201d when questioned during an Anzac Day service to honor New Zealand and Australian war veterans.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. My heart once housed similar fears of separation.\n\nHe and I first smiled at each other one night almost 20 years ago in Caf\u00e9 Remy, a favorite downtown Manhattan spot for the area\u2019s financial workers. With the humid August air making his dark thick hair a cherubic mess, I thought, \u201cHey, Angel Boy, you look so cute. Where did you get that crazy hair?\u201d\n\nI was feeling happy and bold because I was finally free from my previous boyfriend, who had broken up with me but kept me tethered with claims of \u201cI love you\u201d and \u201cI miss you\u201d and \u201cI just need time.\u201d He failed to mention that he needed time to pursue someone else. I spent the next few months rolling around on my floor, drinking wine and crying into my journals.\n\nBut in his absence, I started to understand how stifled I had been with someone who was happiest staying at home with his computer and television shows. In social situations with my friends, he always seemed adorably awkward, until the day he said, \u201cI\u2019m not shy. I just don\u2019t want to expend my energy on them.\u201d", "title": "Love Forged by the Threat of Deportation", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-11 00:00:00", "text": "Watching is The New York Times\u2019s TV and film recommendation website. Sign up for our thrice-weekly newsletter here.\n\nThe political thriller \u201cScandal\u201d has broken some of television\u2019s most tenacious barriers during its seven seasons on ABC. In casting Kerry Washington as the D.C. fixer Olivia Pope, the series\u2019s creator, Shonda Rhimes, gave network TV drama its first black female lead in almost 40 years. The show has tackled difficult subjects from abortion to police violence against African-Americans with startling candor. But it also earned a reputation for its rapid-fire plot twists, often providing more shocking revelations in a single episode than many dramas do in a full season.\n\nvia Giphy\n\nBefore \u201cScandal\u201d wraps its final season, on April 19, revisit some of its wildest moments, in chronological order below. (Be warned if you aren\u2019t caught up: Spoilers abound.)\n\nFitz Makes an Executive Decision\n\nTony Goldwyn in \u201cScandal.\u201d ABC\n\nSeason 2, Episode 13: \u2018Nobody Likes Babies\u2019\n\nIt took about a year for \u201cScandal\u201d to become a cultural phenomenon, and one of the scenes that cemented its reputation as TV\u2019s twistiest drama came about midway through Season 2. Fitzgerald Grant (Tony Goldwyn), the president of the United States and Olivia\u2019s sometime boyfriend, has narrowly survived an assassination attempt ordered by his former ally, Justice Verna Thornton of the United States Supreme Court (Debra Mooney). When Fitz visits the cancer-stricken judge in the hospital, she warns him that she\u2019s about to blow the whistle on a voter-fraud conspiracy that put him in the White House. So, the sitting president removes her oxygen mask and watches as she suffocates to death.\n\nSally Commits a Sin\n\nKate Burton in \u201cScandal.\u201d ABC\n\nSeason 3, Episode 9: \u2018YOLO\u2019\n\nFitz\u2019s original vice president, Sally Langston (Kate Burton), is a piece of work. A born-again Christian who delivers operatic sermons against homosexuality, Sally eventually learns that her husband, Daniel Douglas Langston (Jack Coleman), is sleeping with the spouse of Fitz\u2019s gay chief of staff. Curiously, it\u2019s also that chief of staff, Cyrus Beene (Jeff Perry), whom she phones, her face spattered with blood, after fatally stabbing her husband with a letter opener in a fit of rage.\n\nJerry, We Hardly Knew Ye\n\nMadeline Carroll and Dylan Minnette in \u201cScandal.\u201d ABC\n\nSeason 3, Episode 18: \u2018The Price of Free and Fair Elections\u2019\n\nMany deaths on \u201cScandal\u201d are genuinely upsetting. But, every once in a while, a minor character drops dead in entertainingly bizarre fashion. Such is the fate of Fitz\u2019s teenage son, Jerry Grant Jr. (Dylan Minnette), in the show\u2019s third season finale. Onstage at an event for his father\u2019s re-election campaign, he suddenly sneezes blood, his eyes roll back in his head, and he collapses, a victim of murder by meningitis poisoning. And that\u2019s it for Jerry. It\u2019s a tragedy for the Grants, of course, but it plays as pure camp.\n\n0\n\nRead more: Shonda Rhimes, the show\u2019s creator, and three of its stars discuss its twists, its nuanced handling of racial issues and its legacy.\n\nKidnapped!\n\nKerry Washington and Scott Foley in \u201cScandal.\u201d ABC\n\nSeason 4, Episode 9: \u2018Where the Sun Don\u2019t Shine\u2019\n\nIn this, the last episode before the midseason hiatus in Season 4, \u201cScandal\u201d left viewers with quite the cliffhanger. Olivia has finally gotten out from under the thumb of her father, Eli Pope (Joe Morton) \u2014 no easy task, considering that he heads a top-secret spy agency. To celebrate her freedom, she and her other sometime boyfriend, Eli\u2019s rogue agent Jake Ballard (Scott Foley), decide to have sex on the piano in her living room. While Jake is in the bedroom grabbing a blanket, she disappears. Two months later, the next episode revealed that she had been kidnapped in a ploy to manipulate Fitz.\n\nThe Vice President Gets the Chair\n\nKerry Washington in \u201cScandal.\u201d ABC\n\nSeason 5, Episode 17: \u2018Thwack!\u2019\n\nOlivia becomes a darker character after she is kidnapped, and late in Season 5, she exacts her long-awaited revenge on the man who subjected her to violence, humiliation and many consecutive bad hair days: Fitz\u2019s treacherous second vice president, Andrew Nichols (Jon Tenney). He knows that Fitz took the country to war over Olivia, and the job of bribing Andrew to keep that secret falls to her. When things get nasty, she starts bashing him over the head with a metal chair and doesn\u2019t stop until his skull is crushed.\n\nOlivia to Vice President: \u2018Kill Yourself\u2019\n\nFrom left, Tessie Santiago, Scott Foley and Kerry Washington in \u201cScandal.\u201d ABC\n\nSeason 6, Episode 16: \u2018Transfer of Power\u2019\n\nMellie Grant (Bellamy Young) begins her tenure in the White House as Fitz\u2019s cold, critical first lady. By the end of Season 6, they\u2019re divorced, and she is America\u2019s first female president. But Mellie only makes it to the Oval Office because her opponent, Frankie Vargas (Ricardo Antonio Chavira), is assassinated just after winning the election. It takes the entire season for Olivia to figure out that it was his widow, Luna (Tessie Santiago), who orchestrated the murder. The problem is that Luna is now Mellie\u2019s vice president. All of these developments are kooky, but even kookier is the fact that Olivia \u201chandles\u201d Luna by calmly persuading her to lethally poison herself.\n\nPapa Pope Does the Dinosaur\n\nJoe Morton in \u201cScandal.\u201d ABC\n\nSeason 7, Episode 9: \u2018Good People\u2019\n\nThe magic of \u201cScandal\u201d isn\u2019t only in the twists. Rhimes and her writers also have a knack for creating stand-alone spectacles that can make viewers wonder whether their eyes and ears are deceiving them. One such moment occurs in the show\u2019s seventh and final season, when Eli seems to lose his mind. The circumstances surrounding his apparent unraveling are complicated, but the bizarre and delightful experience of watching the dignified Joe Morton shimmy as he raps lines from Langston Hughes\u2019s \u201cI, Too\u201d at a tiny plastic dinosaur figurine requires no context.", "title": "Love \u2018Scandal\u2019? Relive Its 7 Wildest Moments Before the Series Finale", "authors": ["Judy Berman"]} {"date": "2018-04-28 00:00:00", "text": "Allison Delores McCracken and Raed Jarrar were married April 28 at the District of Columbia\u2019s War Memorial, in Washington. Sarah R. Novick was authorized by the United States District Court for the District of Columbia as a temporary officiant.\n\nThe bride and groom both work in the Washington office of Amnesty International, the human rights organization. She is the campaigner for North America, and operates as the liaison between the Amnesty branches in the United States and Canada and the rest of the organization. He works in the American branch of Amnesty as the advocacy director, and as a lobbyist, for Middle East and North African issues. They also both volunteer for the refugee resettlement program in Hyattsville, Md., of Lutheran Social Services.\n\nMrs. Jarrar, 29, graduated from Hobart and William Smith Colleges.\n\nShe is a daughter of Rebecca J. McCracken and Douglas S. McCracken of Old Saybrook, Conn. Her father, an electrical engineer, is an operations director in Berlin, Conn., for Eversource Energy, a gas and electric utility. Her mother is an optometric assistant at Professional Eyecare in Waterford, Conn.\n\nMr. Jarrar, 40, graduated from the University of Baghdad and received a master\u2019s degree in architectural engineering with an emphasis on postwar reconstruction from the University of Jordan.
