It soon turned ugly.\n\nYoung men barricaded railroad tracks, burned buses and hurled bricks at police officers. Caught off guard, the Indian authorities did what they often do. They sent phalanxes of club-wielding officers charging into the crowds. And in several states, they shut down the internet.\n\nBy the time the Dalit mutiny had been quelled, at least 11 people were dead \u2014 most of them Dalits. Dozens more were hurt, and hundreds were arrested.", "title": "Lower-Caste Fury Shakes India, and Hints at Fiery Election Ahead", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-11 00:00:00", "text": "LOS ANGELES \u2014 The mystery buyer that arranged to purchase Norman Rockwell\u2019s celebrated painting \u201cShuffleton\u2019s Barbershop\u201d from the financially troubled and legally scrutinized Berkshire Museum in Western Massachusetts has just stepped forward: The Lucas Museum of Narrative Art, which broke ground last month and is expected to open here in about four years, has bought the work for an undisclosed sum.\n\n\u201cWe are very excited to have it join our collection,\u201d said Don Bacigalupi, director of the Lucas Museum. \u201cThis will be one of the anchor works of our museum, which we\u2019re delighted to share with the public.\u201d The museum\u2019s founder, George Lucas, of \u201cStar Wars\u201d fame, is already known as the leading private collector of Rockwell\u2019s work. He owns dozens of Rockwell paintings, most of which are promised gifts to his museum.\n\nPainted in 1950 as a cover for The Saturday Evening Post, \u201cShuffleton\u2019s Barbershop\u201d is one of Rockwell\u2019s most popular works. Mr. Bacigalupi sees it as one of his most complex compositions as well: a glimpse into small-town life after business hours, which doubles as a reflection on the history of painting, rife with \u201creferences to modernism\u201d like the prominent windowpane structure that echoes a Mondrian grid.", "title": "Lucas Museum Comes Forward as Buyer of Rockwell Painting", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-07 00:00:00", "text": "Laurel Dalley-Smith, who performs opposite Ari Mayzick in the first duet, said that Ms. Childs was extremely clear about her choreographic pathways. \u201cIt\u2019s about being in space and relating to each other, to directions,\u201d Ms. Dalley-Smith said. \u201cBut I feel this is different from her work. It is more emotional. It\u2019s not just form. It is about personal relationships. And even though there\u2019s a story, it\u2019s not Greek mythology.\u201d\n\nGraham often used mythology as inspiration for dances, including for \u201cNight Journey\u201d and \u201cClytemnestra.\u201d In \u201cHistoire,\u201d the performers are presented as ordinary people, which was very much a tenet of Judson, known for its celebration of the pedestrian body. Of course, Ms. Childs\u2019s choreography is complicated all the same.\n\n\u201cYou have these steps that you do on a regular basis as a dancer,\u201d the Graham dancer Lloyd Knight said, \u201cbut I find that in her work, she might take 15 steps and then rearrange them five times.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nIn the coming months, more of Ms. Childs\u2019s intricate choreography will be on display. This summer, the Mostly Mozart Festival will feature the revival of \u201cAvailable Light,\u201d her 1983 collaboration with the composer John Adams and the architect Frank Gehry, which hasn\u2019t been seen in New York in 33 years. In the fall, the Museum of Modern Art will present \u201cJudson Dance Theater: The Work Is Never Done,\u201d an exhibition that will include performances of Ms. Childs\u2019s works from the 1960s and \u201970s.\n\nShe has also started working with the ballet dancer Wendy Whelan on a solo project featuring the music of David Lang with the cellist Maya Beiser. \u201cI\u2019m very happy about it,\u201d Ms. Childs said. \u201cShe looks wonderful, and we\u2019ve done about nine minutes so far. She\u2019s amazing.\u201d\n\nFor Graham dancers like Ms. Dalley-Smith, so is Ms. Childs. Ms. Dalley-Smith said that the experience of working on \u201cHistoire\u201d had been freeing. \u201cWhat I love about it is that there\u2019s not a huge story, but there is a story,\u201d she said. \u201cIt\u2019s not just movement for movement\u2019s sake, and it\u2019s not just about how far can I push my body because I\u2019m an athlete. No. It\u2019s form. It\u2019s line. It\u2019s understanding partnering, understanding what you want to portray.\u201d\n\nBut there is also something else: being in the room with Ms. Childs.\n\n\u201cTo work with someone that has such understanding of her art?\u201d Ms. Dalley-Smith said. \u201cIt\u2019s not even about being well respected. This woman did it: Lucinda was bold enough to develop her own form.\u201d", "title": "Lucinda Childs Gets Off the Floor in Piece for the Graham Company", "authors": ["Gia Kourlas"]} {"date": "2018-04-13 00:00:00", "text": "After two years developing a script, without securing financing and the necessary rights, Ms. Martel abandoned \u201cEl Eternauta.\u201d It was then that she discovered Antonio Di Benedetto\u2019s 1956 novel, \u201cZama,\u201d which sat unread on her shelf for five years before she brought it with her on a trip along the Paraguay River, where much of the book is set. Asked if she saw a film in it, she replied in English: \u201cImmediately!\u201d\n\nIf Ms. Martel\u2019s earlier work challenged reality, \u201cZama\u201d \u2014 a costume drama set in the late 18th century made for $3.5 million, a modest budget though more than double that of \u201cThe Headless Woman\u201d \u2014 is a movie in which the director challenged herself. She spent four years writing the script and raising money. (Eight nations helped produce the movie; among the many co-producers are Pedro and Agust\u00edn Almod\u00f3var, Gael Garc\u00eda Bernal and Danny Glover.) The shoot, which lasted a bit more than two months, was arduous, plagued by bad weather; postproduction was delayed by illness. (Ms. Martel has said she was treated for cancer and is reportedly in remission.)\n\nMs. Martel\u2019s first digitally shot film, her first set outside Salta, her first period film and her first adaptation, \u201cZama\u201d is also her first centered on a man, although, as she points out, the frustrated Don Diego de Zama, a South American-born functionary of imperial Spain posted in a remote Paraguayan backwater, resembles many of her female characters. Played by the Mexican actor Daniel Gim\u00e9nez Cacho in a state of wounded dignity, Zama is a confused provincial, frustrated, self-deluded and clinging to a precarious sense of cultural superiority.\n\nAs the Kafkaesque drama of a man unable to get a transfer, \u201cZama\u201d shares the dislocation and torpor characteristic of the Salta Trilogy. But disconcertingly beautiful and at times otherworldly, the movie\u2019s spacey final movement recalls Werner Herzog adventures like \u201cAguirre, the Wrath of God\u201d and \u201cFitzcarraldo.\u201d Ms. Martel does not take this as a compliment. \u201cHis films bother me,\u201d she said, citing what she sees as their \u201cirresponsible treatment of animals and indigenous people.\u201d\n\nThe veteran Argentine film critic and festival director Eduardo Antin, who writes under the name Quintin, noted that however faithful to the Di Benedetto novel the film is, Ms. Martel made the material \u201cconsistent with her political interests\u201d by bringing \u201cthe background to the foreground.\u201d Di Benedetto focused on Zama and his would-be European milieu and largely ignored the colony\u2019s enslaved people and indigenous inhabitants. Martel includes Africans and Indians, most often women, in nearly every frame. Zama\u2019s story is also theirs. \u201cSuch a change requires great will and precise thinking,\u201d Mr. Antin wrote in an email. It also serves to set up the movie\u2019s horrifying \u201cHeart of Darkness\u201d ending.\n\nMs. Martel hopes to return to Salta, where she has been working on a documentary about Javier Chocobar, an indigenous activist who was killed in a land dispute in 2008. \u201cThe history of our country is broken,\u201d she said, referring to Argentine identification with Europe. \u201cIt\u2019s a conflict for every white man\u201d \u2014 and crucial to an understanding of the existential antihero Zama.", "title": "Lucrecia Martel: A Director Who Confounds and Thrills", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-04 00:00:00", "text": "The country is still deeply divided over the impeachment of Mr. da Silva\u2019s chosen successor, Dilma Rousseff, who was removed from office in 2016 on charges of manipulating the federal budget to hide the nation\u2019s growing economic problems.\n\nHer ouster put an end to 13 years of governments led by the leftist Workers\u2019 Party, a period when Brazil\u2019s economy soared, millions of people entered the middle class and the country\u2019s profile rose on the global stage.\n\nBut enormous corruption scandals and the worst economic crisis in decades left Ms. Rousseff and her party battered, with little support to fend off a power grab by their political rivals.\n\nMr. da Silva, who is known commonly as Lula, has been trying to reclaim the presidency. But last July, he was convicted of corruption and money laundering, and sentenced to almost 10 years in prison. In January, an appeals court unanimously upheld the conviction and increased the sentence to 12 years.\n\nPhoto\n\nMr. da Silva, who served as president from 2003 to 2011, appealed the sentence to the country\u2019s top court, the Supreme Federal Court, asking to be allowed to remain free while additional appeals are pending \u2014 a process that could drag on for years.\n\nThat forced the justices to wrestle with a question with far-reaching implications for scores of other powerful figures ensnared in the large-scale corruption investigation known as Car Wash, including the current president, Michel Temer: At what point in the appeals process may a defendant be imprisoned?\n\nOn Thursday, the court gave its answer: It decided to maintain the status quo, which holds that defendants can be imprisoned after an appeals court upholds a verdict against them. With the ruling in hand, S\u00e9rgio Moro, the federal judge who presided over Mr. da Silva\u2019s trial, is expected to issue an arrest warrant for the former president in a matter of days.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cDon\u2019t think the fight will be easy,\u201d Mr. da Silva told supporters at a rally in Rio de Janeiro on Monday. \u201cIt\u2019s O.K. if we lose one round, but we cannot lose our willingness to fight.\u201d\n\nProsecutors regard Mr. da Silva\u2019s case as the highest-stakes prosecution in their long crackdown on corruption, an effort that enjoys widespread support among Brazilians.\n\nIf the court had allowed Mr. da Silva to remain free, it would have enraged the crusading prosecutors and judges who have tried since 2014 to stamp out Brazil\u2019s entrenched culture of graft.\n\nThousands of the former president\u2019s critics demonstrated Tuesday night, demanding that the justices uphold their 2016 ruling that allows trial judges to jail defendants after a first appeal has been rejected. More than 5,000 prosecutors and judges have signed a petition supporting that position.\n\nBut Mr. da Silva still commands the loyalty of millions of Brazilians. His supporters contend that removing the country\u2019s most popular presidential candidate from the ballot would be an affront to democracy. They say the case against him is nothing more than political persecution, and they vowed to take to the streets if the court ruled he can be imprisoned.\n\nBefore the ruling, Chief Justice Rocha called for calm in a rare televised speech.\n\n\u201cWe are living in times of intolerance and intransigence,\u201d she said. \u201cThe strengthening of Brazilian democracy depends on civic unity for the peaceful coexistence of everyone. Different opinions must be respected.\u201d\n\nJustice Roberto Barroso, who voted against Mr. da Silva, noted that the president left office with high approval ratings and an impressive set of accomplishments.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cWe are not debating about a political legacy,\u201d he said. \u201cIt is whether jurisprudence that the court settled must be applied to all people. It is a test of our democracy.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe ruling does not technically disqualify Mr. da Silva\u2019s candidacy. Instead, a different body \u2014 the Supreme Electoral Tribunal \u2014 will review each candidate\u2019s eligibility forms starting in mid-August. It is widely expected to reject Mr. da Silva\u2019s bid for office under the \u201cclean slate\u201d law, which disqualifies anyone who has a criminal conviction that has been upheld by an appeals court.\n\nLegal experts say that Mr. da Silva could try to fight the electoral court\u2019s ruling if he remained free, but that his imprisonment makes that quest all but impossible.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cThe Brazilian people have the right to vote for Lula, the candidate of hope,\u201d Mr. da Silva\u2019s party said in a statement issued early Thursday as it vowed to \u201cdefend this candidacy in the streets and in all spheres.\u201d The statement added: \u201cHe who has the backing of the people, who has the truth on his side, knows that justice will ultimately prevail.\u201d\n\nThousands of people on both sides of the issue had gathered in Bras\u00edlia, the capital, for the court\u2019s decision.\n\nPassions have been running high as Mr. da Silva\u2019s candidacy has become increasingly embattled. Last week, the former president\u2019s campaign buses were hit by gunshots as he campaigned in southern Brazil. No one was hurt.\n\nGen. Eduardo Villas B\u00f4as, the chief of the army, raised tensions higher still with his posts on Twitter on Tuesday, declaring that the military \u201crepudiates impunity.\u201d\n\nIt was a rare venture into politics that was widely interpreted as saying that the Supreme Federal Court should rule against Mr. da Silva.\n\nIn a country that was ruled by the military from 1964 to 1985, critics reacted with alarm, calling the comment inappropriate pressure at best, and at worst a veiled threat of military intervention if the former president prevailed in court.\n\nRodrigo Janot, a former attorney general, responded on Twitter. \u201cThis definitely isn\u2019t good. If it is what it seems, another 1964 would be unacceptable,\u201d he said, referring to the coup that ushered in Brazil\u2019s military dictatorship.\n\nPhoto\n\nBut many others backed the army chief. His posts were shared more than 10,000 times and liked by more than 20,000 people in just three hours.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMany people, including other military leaders, posted messages with their support. \u201cWe\u2019re in the trenches together!!! We think alike!!! Brazil above all!!!\u201d wrote Gen. Antonio Miotto.\n\nIn Mr. da Silva\u2019s trial, Judge Moro found that the former president had accepted bribes \u2014 in the form of an oceanfront apartment \u2014 in return for steering contracts to a construction company.\n\nThe corruption allegations against Mr. da Silva are only a small part of the wide-ranging Car Wash investigation.\n\nThe inquiry, which began in 2014 with a seemingly routine look into money-laundering accusations, has ensnared scores of powerful business executives and politicians across the political spectrum.\n\nBut Mr. da Silva\u2019s case carries tremendous legal and political implications for the country.\n\nIn an editorial published in the Folha de S. Paulo newspaper on Wednesday, Prosecutor General Raquel Dodge said that allowing defendants to remain free after repeated appeals had been rejected was an \u201cexaggeration that annihilates the justice system because then justice is delayed, and for this, it fails.\u201d\n\nJorge Oliveira, 50, a former army paratrooper, said he hoped that Mr. da Silva would be jailed soon and that his downfall would be the first step toward a drastic political transformation.\n\n\u201cThe guy needs to be jailed,\u201d Mr. Oliveira said. \u201cThen a general needs to take power, oust Temer, hold things together for three years and call for new elections.\u201d\n\nJ\u00e9ssica da Silva Facundo, by contrast, said she had been rooting for Mr. da Silva, largely out of nostalgia for the prosperity Brazil experienced during his time in power.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cDespite the fact that he stole, during his government I was doing better,\u201d said Ms. da Silva, who is not related to the former president.", "title": "Lula, Brazil\u2019s Ex-President, Can Be Jailed, Court Rules", "authors": ["Ernesto Londo\u00f1o", "Shasta Darlington"]} {"date": "2018-04-16 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cI\u2019ve been treating lung cancer for 25 years now, and I\u2019ve never seen such a big paradigm shift as we\u2019re seeing with immunotherapy,\u201d said Dr. Roy Herbst, Chief of Medical Oncology at the Yale Cancer Center. He was not involved in the pembrolizumab study.\n\nLung cancer is the leading cause of cancer death globally, causing 1.7 million deaths a year. In the United States, it is expected to kill more than 154,000 people in 2018.\n\nPatients in the study had an advanced stage of non-squamous non-small-cell lung cancer. The immune-activating drug was a checkpoint inhibitor called pembrolizumab, or Keytruda, made by Merck, which paid for the study. The chemotherapy was a drug called pemetrexed, plus either carboplatin or cisplatin.\n\nDr. Gandhi said chemotherapy alone had only a \u201cmodest benefit,\u201d and could add only a few months of life, with most patients surviving about a year or less. The combination treatment is a significant improvement, she said. It is already approved as a first-line treatment for this disease, so it should be covered by health insurers.\n\nShe was scheduled to present the results on Monday in Chicago at a meeting of the American Association for Cancer Research, and they were also published in The New England Journal of Medicine.\n\nOther studies presented at the meeting also highlighted advances in immunotherapy against lung cancer, but were at earlier points in the research and less likely to bring about immediate changes in medical practice.\n\n\u201cIf you want to see long-term survival, you\u2019ve got to give immunotherapy as soon as possible,\u201d Dr. Herbst said. \u201cChemotherapy has limitations. Immunotherapy has the ability to cure. I lead the Yale lung team. We have patients on these immunotherapies alive more than eight years.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nOther studies in lung cancer have involved another checkpoint inhibitor, nivolumab, or Opdivo (made by Bristol-Myers Squibb), which works in a similar way to pembrolizumab. The data are not conclusive, but Dr. Herbst said, \u201cIn lung cancer, my suspicion is these drugs are the same, like Coke vs. Pepsi.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMost patients stay on the drugs for two years, he said. One Yale patient who has survived for eight years took the drug for two years and has remained well ever since. Another had to stop because of side effects after two or three months, but is well two years later.\n\nDr. Herbst offered several theories about why chemotherapy and immunotherapy could work well together. He said that tumor cells were like bags of hidden proteins that, if exposed, the immune system could use as targets to find and attack cancer. By killing some tumor cells, chemotherapy could pop open the bags, release the contents and help immune cells \u2014 unleashed by the checkpoint drugs \u2014 to identify their prey. It is also possible, he said, that chemotherapy may kill some immune cells that interfere with the cancer-killing action of other parts of the immune system.\n\nDr. Gandhi\u2019s study included 616 patients with advanced lung cancer, ages 34 to 84, from medical centers in 16 countries. Their tumors lacked certain mutations that would have made them eligible for other, so-called \u201ctargeted\u201d treatments. They were picked at random to receive either chemotherapy plus immunotherapy, or chemotherapy plus a placebo, with two thirds receiving the combination that included immunotherapy.\n\nAfter a median follow-up of 10.5 months, those in the immunotherapy group were half as likely to die. The median overall survival was 11.3 months in those who did not receive immunotherapy, whereas survival in the immunotherapy group was longer and the median has not yet been reached.\n\nBut patients in the immunotherapy group had more kidney problems, more immune-related adverse events and were more likely to stop treatment because of side effects.\n\nThe estimated survival at 12 months was 69.2 percent in the group that received immunotherapy, and 49.4 percent in those who did not.\n\n\u201cI think we were all surprised at the magnitude of benefit and how clear the difference was at an early analysis, and that we could tell there was an overall survival difference,\u201d Dr. Gandhi said, adding that there was \u201ca lot of excitement\u201d at the conference about her study and several others involving immunotherapy.\n\n\u201cIt represents a sea change in the way we think about treating lung cancer,\u201d she said. \u201cAll of it is better than what we\u2019ve been using for years. Going forward, it will only get better.\u201d\n\nPatients were tested for a biomarker used to predict whether pembrolizumab is likely to help them. The drug alone is already approved to treat patients with high levels of those markers. But this study included patients with varying levels. Those with high levels of the marker fared somewhat better with immunotherapy than those with low levels \u2014 but even those with low levels were helped.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cThe data are impressive,\u201d Dr. Herbst said. \u201cWe\u2019re making progress, but still only benefiting 30 to 40 percent of patients. There\u2019s a lot more room to do better. We have to keep looking for new things and new approaches.\u201d", "title": "Lung Cancer Patients Live Longer With Immune Therapy", "authors": ["Denise Grady"]} {"date": "2018-04-04 00:00:00", "text": "You can read his final speech, delivered in Memphis the night before his death, or you can listen to it. Don\u2019t settle for the usual quick outtakes. The famous lines \u2014 like \u201cI\u2019ve been to the mountaintop\u201d \u2014 aren\u2019t the only worthwhile ones.\n\n\u201cLet us rise up tonight with a greater readiness. Let us stand with a greater determination,\u201d King said. \u201cAnd let us move on in these powerful days, these days of challenge, to make America what it ought to be.\u201d\n\nAnother option: If you haven\u2019t yet read Taylor Branch\u2019s great book, \u201cParting the Waters,\u201d you can start it. It remains one of my 10 favorite books, on any subject.\n\nYou can also watch the new HBO documentary that Branch created along with Trey Ellis, Jackie Glover and others. (If you don\u2019t have HBO, you\u2019ll need to wait a bit.) \u201cFor thirty years, I have been trying and failing to help move authentic civil rights history to film,\u201d Branch tweeted last weekend. \u201cIt\u2019s not the familiar, \u2018sanitized\u2019 MLK.\u201d\n\nYou can also read the collection of Op-Eds that The Times has published in recent days, by Wendi Thomas and others. We\u2019ve linked to each of those pieces in Related Coverage below. If you have questions for Jesse Jackson, who wrote one of the pieces, leave them in the Comments section of his article; he will be replying to some of them in coming days.\n\nIn other news, The Washington Post has a scoop: Robert Mueller has informed President Trump\u2019s lawyers that the president is not currently a criminal target of his investigation. It\u2019s a nice bit of reporting, but it doesn\u2019t change the big picture.", "title": "Opinion | M.L.K.\u2019s Unsanitized Lessons", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-23 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Cuomo, a Democrat who controls the Metropolitan Transportation Authority and is facing a re-election challenge focused on his management of the subway, has been hungry for a quick fix. During a recent speech, Mr. Cuomo declared that ultra-wideband testing in the subway was going well and could be installed as quickly as eight years.\n\nHinting at his urgency on the matter, Mr. Cuomo said he had not yet told the subway\u2019s new leader, Andy Byford, who previously led Toronto\u2019s transit system, that he thought even eight years was too long to wait for modern subway signals.\n\n\u201cI don\u2019t want to say that to Andy because he just started, and I\u2019m afraid he\u2019ll run back to Toronto,\u201d Mr. Cuomo said. \u201cBut this is an exciting development of a new type of technology.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nMr. Cuomo, who is running for a third term, has received a barrage of criticism over the subway\u2019s dismal performance from the actress Cynthia Nixon, who is running against him in the Democratic primary. A modern signal system is viewed as a key fix because it would be more reliable and allow more trains to run closer together, increasing capacity on the overburdened system.\n\nSubway officials noted that ultra-wideband technology had been used by the military for years and it was also being tested on Boston\u2019s transit system. During testing on tracks in New York, the technology was able to determine where a train was located \u201cdown to the little micrometer\u201d and how fast the train was moving, according to Joseph J. Lhota, the authority\u2019s chairman.\n\nSubway officials must now test the technology under different scenarios and connect it with hardware on trains, Mr. Lhota said.\n\n\u201cBased on what I\u2019m seeing, I\u2019m optimistic,\u201d Mr. Lhota told reporters during a recent tour of a subway yard in Manhattan. \u201cWe\u2019re getting the information we need.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nUltra-wideband technology is a wireless radio system that uses a small amount of energy to transmit large amounts of data. Devices called nodes could be placed about 1,000 feet apart in tunnels and communicate with each other by \u201chopping\u201d data from node to node, according to a proposal from Metrom Rail, a company that develops rail technology and was a winner of the authority\u2019s recent subway genius competition.\n\nA new report by the Center for Technology in Government at the University at Albany found that ultra-wideband technology could provide a cheaper alternative to existing signal technologies.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cThis is promising for something like mass transit,\u201d said G. Brian Burke, the center\u2019s managing director. \u201cHowever, if mass transit is going to use it, they would need to pilot it in their own environment.\u201d\n\nThe eight-month study, which tested the technology at the university\u2019s underground tunnel system used by students to get around during winter months, found that ultra-wideband could measure distance precisely within about four inches. The report recommended studying whether the signal could be affected by the size of trains and interference from passengers\u2019 cellphones, among other potential issues.\n\n\u201cIf you\u2019re using it within a mass transit system, you have to be precise 100 percent of the time,\u201d Mr. Burke said.\n\nPhoto\n\nSince late last year, the M.T.A. has been testing ultra-wideband radio on test tracks on the Culver Line in Brooklyn and on the shuttle that runs between Times Square and Grand Central Station, subway officials said. They are testing equipment from several vendors, including Metrom Rail.\n\nMr. Byford said he wants to study the new technology while moving quickly to upgrade signals on crowded routes like the Lexington Avenue line using the traditional approach.\n\n\u201cI want to use proven technology to deliver improvements quickly while ultra-wideband is tested and proven in parallel in another area,\u201d Mr. Byford said in a statement.\n\nJoe Pesaturo, a spokesman for the Massachusetts Bay Transportation Authority, which runs Boston\u2019s subway, said the agency had tested ultra-wideband radio on its Green Line and planned to award a contract this summer for a new train-protection system on the line that could incorporate the technology.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIf Boston or New York embraces the technology, other transit systems could follow. But subway officials in New York have often been cautious to be the first to adapt new technology because they oversee the nation\u2019s largest subway, with nearly six million daily riders. Any hiccups could have a huge impact.\n\nThe M.T.A.\u2019s effort to upgrade signals has been plagued by problems. Only one line \u2014 the L train \u2014 has a modern signal system, known as communications-based train control, or C.B.T.C., after nearly two decades of work. A similar plan for the No. 7 line has been repeatedly delayed and might finally be completed by the end of the year.\n\nMr. Barone, of the Regional Plan Association, said that signal work could be done more quickly if the M.T.A. truly makes it a priority. But that would also mean that riders would have to tolerate longer station closures.\n\n\u201cI\u2019m concerned that we\u2019re going to spend a lot of time focusing on this one little piece,\u201d Mr. Barone said of ultra-wideband radio. \u201cIt\u2019s not about this one little piece. It\u2019s about streamlining the process so that we can install this system fast.\u201d\n\nFacing a subway crisis and a demanding Mr. Cuomo, the M.T.A. has started to take chances on newer technology. Officials quickly installed countdown clocks using Bluetooth receivers, which has led to many complaints about their accuracy.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s not like the installation of a countdown clock \u2014 it works but it\u2019s not all that accurate,\u201d Mr. Barone said. \u201cWhen it comes to the train operation, it\u2019s a much higher standard.\u201d", "title": "M.T.A. Pins Its Hopes on Unproven Technology to Fix Subway", "authors": ["Emma G. Fitzsimmons"]} {"date": "2018-04-24 00:00:00", "text": "Back in December, after a series of homophobic posts on her defunct, decade-old blog resurfaced on social media, the MSNBC host Joy Reid apologized for them. But this week, when Ms. Reid was confronted with a new batch of homophobic writings from that same period, she said she had been the victim of hackers.\n\nThat claim was called into question on Tuesday, when the Internet Archive, the meticulous online record-keeping nonprofit that hosted the archived version of her site, said it had found no evidence to support her claim.\n\nLate Tuesday night, MSNBC provided documents that show Ms. Reid\u2019s lawyers alerted Google and the Internet Archive to the alleged hacking in December, shortly after her public apology but long before the latest batch of posts appeared on social media.\n\nThe latest group of alleged blog posts includes a great deal of material that might embarrass a prominent liberal figure like Ms. Reid, including expressions of disgust at the thought of homosexuality, opposition to gay marriage, claims that gay men prey on \u201cimpressionable teens\u201d and criticism of political correctness.", "title": "MSNBC Host Joy Reid Blames Hackers for Anti-Gay Blog Posts, but Questions Mount", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-25 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Macron acknowledged that the deal had not addressed crucial concerns, including future nuclear activities in Iran, the use of ballistic missiles and the country\u2019s destabilizing activities in the region. \u201cBut we should not abandon it without having something substantial, and more substantial, instead,\u201d he added. \u201cWhat we decided, together with your president, is that we can work on a more comprehensive deal addressing all these concerns.\u201d\n\nLater, in a news conference before wrapping up his three-day visit to the United States \u2014 the first formal state visit of the Trump era \u2014 Mr. Macron told reporters that while he could not be certain, he expected that Mr. Trump would disregard his entreaties and withdraw from the nuclear deal after all, given that scrapping it was a campaign promise.\n\nOn Capitol Hill, Mr. Macron was greeted warmly with a three-minute standing ovation, and he drew several more ovations throughout his speech as he outlined his vision of global affairs and the alliance between the United States and France, in nearly flawless English.\n\nHe opened with a humorous nod to the much-discussed embraces he and Mr. Trump shared at the White House on Tuesday, comparing their interactions to those between the French philosopher Voltaire and Benjamin Franklin when they met in Paris in 1778.\n\n\u201cThey embraced each other by hugging one another in their arms, and kissing each other\u2019s cheeks,\u201d Mr. Macron said, pausing for effect. \u201cIt can remind you of something.\u201d", "title": "Macron Critiques Trump\u2019s Policies in Speech to Congress", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-19 00:00:00", "text": "BRUSSELS \u2014 Last September, the enthusiastic new French president, Emmanuel Macron, laid out big plans for the European Union, intended to give fresh spark and purpose to a bloc preoccupied with migration, populism and Britain\u2019s exit, and to breathe new life into Franco-German leadership.\n\nThen, as so often with the 28-nation bloc, reality and national interests got in the way. Last fall\u2019s German election badly weakened Chancellor Angela Merkel, who needed six months to assemble a governing coalition, one that is even more wary about overhauls to the eurozone.\n\nLast month\u2019s Italian election gave the upper hand to populist, Euroskeptic parties that want to abandon pension changes and expand Italy\u2019s worrisome national debt, adding to German jitters.\n\nSo after all the hoopla, Mr. Macron\u2019s proposed overhaul has been gutted. If not \u201cas dead as a dormouse,\u201d as the German weekly Der Spiegel opined before his visit to Berlin on Thursday, his European initiatives have been heavily watered down, like the small glass of red wine French parents give to children.", "title": "Macron Had a Big Plan for Europe. It\u2019s Now Falling Apart.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-23 00:00:00", "text": "PARIS \u2014 On April 23, 2017, Emmanuel Macron stunned the world by leading in the first round of a presidential election that had looked unwinnable by him. He went on to win the second round and carry his movement, En Marche!, to a landslide victory in parliamentary elections. France, the new young president promised, was finally ready to be transformed and would soon be fit for the 21st century.\n\nA year after his first victory, the French president is on a state visit to Washington, and is a changed man. He has turned 40 and has toured the world, where he can still bask in appreciation. At home, though, the glory is largely gone. The president, who prides himself on talking the talk and walking the walk, has been pushing reforms at a dizzying pace since he arrived in the \u00c9lys\u00e9e Palace. But his fellow countrymen also like to walk their walk \u2014 a very different one. True to their reputation, they have taken to the streets to protest and resist changes organized from the top. It has taken a full year for President Macron to meet his moment of truth.\n\nSpring is in the air and strikes are back, as are anniversaries. One anniversary in particular is on some people\u2019s minds: May \u201968, which is widely seen here as a cultural revolution. Those protests started with a student rebellion at the Sorbonne in Paris; soon enough, the clashes spread and the students were joined by workers. Within weeks, a general strike paralyzed France and challenged President Charles de Gaulle. The general never fully recovered. He resigned the following year after losing a referendum.\n\nIs French revolutionary fervor back? In 1968, Mr. Macron had not yet been born, but he does know what \u201cconvergence des luttes\u201d means. Literally a \u201cconvergence of struggles,\u201d this slogan epitomized the unity of bourgeois students and the proletariat that made 1968 unique. Fifty years later, some people at the far ends of the French political spectrum still dream of its magic. Indeed, there\u2019s no shortage of protest in France this spring, putting Mr. Macron\u2019s reformist agenda to the test.", "title": "Opinion | Macron Meets His Moment of Truth", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-22 00:00:00", "text": "And the verdict on the French president\u2019s subtle calculus toward Mr. Trump is distinctly mixed. Almost alone among Europe\u2019s leaders, Mr. Macron has struck an apparent rapport with the mercurial American president, who has taken pride in testing, even alienating, some of the United States\u2019 oldest and truest allies.\n\nMr. Macron has made a gamble, given Mr. Trump\u2019s unpopularity, that he can court him but not be tarnished by him \u2014 or even that he can burnish his own reputation as a leader who is so psychologically astute that he can gain the ear of an American president who is in many respects his polar opposite.\n\nA year into a sustained charm offensive, Mr. Macron has won a trip to Washington, occasioned by an invitation from Mr. Trump for a formal state visit, the first the American leader has extended during his presidency.\n\nBut other than that, he has little to show for his courtship of Mr. Trump. Mr. Macron has gotten \u201cnothing\u201d was the unsparing judgment of Denis Lacorne, who teaches at Sciences-Po in Paris and is among the most seasoned observers of Franco-American relations.\n\nMr. Macron pitched hard to bring Mr. Trump around on climate change, the antinuclear proliferation deal with Iran and trade tariffs on steel and aluminum, Mr. Lacorne noted.\n\nVideo\n\nBut the American president withdrew from the Paris climate accord; is on the verge of abandoning the Iran deal and potentially could force the Europeans to leave it, as well; and is moving ahead with tariffs on aluminum and steel that will hurt some European allies.\n\n\u201cYou don\u2019t see concrete results,\u201d said Laurence Nardon, the director of the North America program at the French Institute of International Relations.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut Mr. Macron, in her view, may get something intangible. \u201cWhat Macron gets is that he is seen as being close to the U.S. and even to Trump, and that gives his presidency and France bigger clout,\u201d Ms. Nardon said.\n\nMr. Macron has built a career out of offering respectful, flattering attention to older power figures. Mr. Trump is only the latest in a succession of such men \u2014 Fran\u00e7ois Hollande, the former French president; Jacques Attali, a former presidential counselor \u2014 Mr. Macron has cleverly used and then leapfrogged over.\n\nThe French leader had the insight that Mr. Trump would be thrilled by the military might, pomp and circumstance of France\u2019s annual Bastille Day Parade, with its show of military hardware, and invited him to share a front-row seat last July.\n\nMr. Trump was so taken with it, he ordered up one of his own for this year, now tentatively scheduled for Nov. 11, Veterans Day, but with details still in flux.\n\nThe French president also took Mr. Trump and his wife to dinner in a formal restaurant in the Eiffel Tower, a canny recognition of Mr. Trump\u2019s attraction to glitz.\n\nNo one should confuse Mr. Macron\u2019s attention to Mr. Trump\u2019s likes and dislikes with a genuine bromance, however, and Mr. Macron\u2019s staff bristles at the suggestion that the two are friends.\n\nAsked at a media luncheon about purported closeness between the two leaders, Benjamin Griveaux, the government\u2019s spokesman, responded: \u201cI don\u2019t think they are buddies. The goal is not to have affectionate relations, but to establish some sort of personal connection.\u201d\n\nMr. Macron himself makes selective criticisms of Mr. Trump as if to send a clear signal to the French that he is not na\u00efve. He said publicly that Mr. Trump had made a mistake to deride Haiti and African nations as \u201cshithole countries.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHis tone in talking about the Iran nuclear nonproliferation pact and the Paris climate accord brushes aside Mr. Trump\u2019s positions. \u201cThere is no Plan B,\u201d his aides say of the Iran deal, echoing Mr. Macron\u2019s frequent comment about the climate pact, \u201cThere is no Planet B.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nThe Janus-faced approach \u2014 at once warm and friendly to Mr. Trump but at the same time keeping his options open \u2014 in some ways reflects the French love-hate relationship with the United States.\n\nFrance disdains America\u2019s brashness and unilateralism but also admires its popular culture and the fluidity of a society where it is easier to rise to wealth and power than in France.\n\nIn foreign policy, France\u2019s independent line, forged by the former president and general Charles de Gaulle, was clearest in France\u2019s refusal to go along with the American invasion of Iraq.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMore recently, however, France and the United States have found themselves on the same page when it comes to terrorism and working closely together on the problems in North Africa, as well as in the Middle East.\n\nSo as genuine allies on the defense front, Mr. Macron \u201chas to try\u201d to bring Mr. Trump along, Ms. Nardon said.\n\nIf he can move Mr. Trump a little on policy, so much the better, but as Mr. Macron has said himself, Mr. Trump is not easy to persuade.\n\n\u201cSometimes I manage to convince him, sometimes I fail,\u201d he told a BBC interviewer in January.\n\nThe accommodating dynamic between the two men, and perhaps the limits of the relationship, were evident during their joint appearance at the \u00c9lys\u00e9e Palace in July before the Bastille Day celebration.\n\nAs they stood side by side, there was a lot of shoulder-patting back and forth. But Mr. Trump\u2019s breezy suggestions of acquiescence to the French point of view \u2014 on climate change, for instance \u2014 turned out to be no more substantive than the off-the-cuff way in which they were delivered.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cSomething could happen with respect to the Paris accord,\u201d Mr. Trump said. \u201cWe\u2019ll see what happens.\u201d Nothing ever did.\n\nThe risk, said Thomas Gu\u00e9nol\u00e9, a political scientist who follows geopolitics closely and teaches at the University of Paris-East at Cr\u00e9teil, is that Mr. Macron gives too much to Mr. Trump and gets little in return.\n\n\u201cEmmanuel Macron doesn\u2019t risk being unpopular for trying to get things from Donald Trump and trying to negotiate with him,\u201d said Mr. Gu\u00e9nol\u00e9.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cThe problem would come if, like Tony Blair, he tried to get things by developing a strong relationship with the U.S. president, but afterward got too little,\u201d said Mr. Gu\u00e9nol\u00e9, referring to the former British prime minister who allied himself with President George W. Bush\u2019s decision to remove Saddam Hussein and found himself and his country mired in a yearslong war in Iraq.\n\nMr. Gu\u00e9nol\u00e9, Ms. Nardon and other analysts say that Mr. Macron is taking advantage of the vacuum left in Europe by Prime Minister Theresa May\u2019s preoccupation with how to get Britain out of the European Union and Chancellor Angela Merkel\u2019s focus on maintaining an unwieldy coalition in Germany.\n\nIn a way, that fits well with the Trump White House.\n\n\u201cFrance\u2019s cooperation with the United States has always been pragmatic,\u201d said Alexandra de Hoop Scheffer, a senior trans-Atlantic fellow and director of the Paris office of the German Marshall Fund.\n\n\u201cSo in a certain way, the French pragmatic way mirrors Trump\u2019s transactional approach,\u201d she added. \u201cIt\u2019s why they can succeed in getting along while they have very deep policy disagreements.\u201d\n\nIf the rhetoric is stripped away, Mr. Macron in fact has set rather modest goals, although the show of friendship with Mr. Trump can be distracting, she said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s to keep the U.S. engaged in the international system, the multilateral system, and not give the U.S. the sense that the Europeans are trying to isolate Washington,\u201d she said.\n\nMr. Macron will be in Washington for three days, with a State Dinner planned for Tuesday and a speech to a joint session of Congress on Wednesday. Still, a senior aide at the \u00c9lys\u00e9e tried to lower expectations.\n\nIt would be a mistake to judge the success of the trip by what the French president could get from Mr. Trump, the aide said. Instead, the visit will allow time for the two leaders to luxuriate in the pomp and circumstance that they both enjoy and for them to talk in a more personal way with their wives present.\n\nIn a January television interview, Mr. Macron waxed about how the two men talked often and how he felt \u201cattached\u201d to Mr. Trump. But when the interviewer questioned how he could be friendly with the American president, Mr. Macron laid out his colder, strategic assessment.\n\n\u201cThe United States is the premier power; it is our most important partner in multilateral endeavors; it\u2019s our first partner in the fight against terrorism; it is important for collective security,\u201d he said.\n\n\u201cWe can be angry with the United States, we may disagree about the methods as we do on Iran, but at the end, we are in agreement,\u201d he said.", "title": "Macron Takes a Risk in Courting Trump, but Has Little to Show for It", "authors": ["Alissa J. Rubin", "Adam Nossiter"]} {"date": "2018-04-24 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nRe \u201cCozying Up to Trump, Macron Gets Little Reward\u201d (front page, April 23):\n\nHaving lived in and reported on France, I don\u2019t believe for a minute that President Emmanuel Macron is \u201cclose\u201d to President Trump in the sense of having a personal rapport. Mr. Trump is the epitome of vulgarity, a loathed trait in France, especially in the upper levels of society (note how Nicolas Sarkozy was ridiculed as \u201cle pr\u00e9sident bling-bling\u201d).\n\nAt the same time, Mr. Macron surely sees how desperately Mr. Trump wants to be seen as \u201cclassy,\u201d and France still represents classiness. So he may lay on la bise \u2014 the kiss on both cheeks \u2014 and other superficial trappings of French culture, while feeling disgust and contempt, to try to achieve his ends.\n\nI\u2019m not privy to Mr. Macron\u2019s inner thoughts, but it seems na\u00efvely America-centric to assume that he and Mr. Trump are good friends.\n\nJULIA LICHTBLAU, BROOKLYN", "title": "Opinion | Macron and Trump as Pals? Non!", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-24 00:00:00", "text": "Dr. Ronny Jackson, above, has been accused of overseeing a hostile work environment as the White House physician, allowing the overprescribing of drugs and possibly drinking on the job.\n\nMr. Trump accused adversaries on Capitol Hill of going after Dr. Jackson because they failed to block Mike Pompeo, the president\u2019s nominee to become the next secretary of state.\n\n_____\n\nPhoto\n\n3. Amazon has begun delivering packages to parked cars.\n\nThe service is available in 37 American cities and surrounding areas, to customers with recent-model cars that use technology allowing satellite location-tracking and digital access to the locks.\n\nA delivery person will unlock the car using a smartphone and leave the package in the trunk or on the back seat. That helps customers who don\u2019t want to risk \u201cporch pirates\u201d or who can\u2019t get deliveries at work.\n\nMarket Snapshot View Full Overview\n\n_____\n\nPhoto\n\n8. Their proposal would also prohibit teams from disbanding cheerleading squads as a way to retaliate against women who raise complaints.\n\n_____\n\nPhoto\n\n9. Scott notes that as the 19th installment in a series, the movie was never meant to be viewed or judged in isolation.\n\nAfter all, it\u2019s not just a movie; it\u2019s a \u201csynergistic expression of the corporate interests of Marvel Studios and the Walt Disney Company.\u201d\n\n\u201cI\u2019m supposed to tell you, in this review, how much fun you\u2019ll have at \u2018Infinity War,\u2019\u201d he writes. \u201c(Yes, you will have some.
