Grimsby\u2019s seafaring nostalgia was a vivid demonstration of the way emotions can transform politics and affect the economy.\n\nAnother group caught in the tailwinds of Britain\u2019s move to the right was the \u201cWindrush generation\u201d \u2014 Caribbeans invited to Britain to help rebuild after World War II \u2014 which faced harsh treatment under a migration crackdown.\n\n_____\n\nPhoto\n\n\u2022 A portrait is emerging of Alek Minassian, the 25-year-old suspect in Monday\u2019s vehicular attack in downtown Toronto.\n\nProsecutors charged him with 10 counts of first-degree murder and 13 counts of attempted murder, but did not disclose a motive. Above, a memorial.\n\nWe spoke to people who knew him and saw his now-suspended Facebook page, which showed he was socially isolated and had expressed hostility toward women. He had briefly joined the armed forces, but quit after 16 days of basic training.\n\n_____\n\nPhoto\n\n\u2022 Finland captured global attention with its test of universal basic income, handing out cash, no strings attached. Now, the experiment is ending.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe conclusion of the trial does not necessarily signal an end of interest in the initiative (other trials are underway around the world) but rather public discomfort over the idea of giving out government money without requiring recipients to seek work. Above, a co-working space in Finland.\n\nFinnish social services are already notoriously generous, which could be the main reason that basic income lost momentum: It is effectively redundant. The experiment will conclude at the end of the year.\n\nBusiness\n\nPhoto\n\n\u2022 Our Glass Ceiling Index, in which we counted the women and men in important leadership roles, found that the number of U.S. chief executives named John \u2014 a group that is overwhelmingly white \u2014 is very similar to the total number of female executives.\n\n\u2022 The authorities in a number of European countries say Facebook is unfairly using its leverage over consumers to coerce personal information from them. Our columnist\u2019s take on Mark Zuckerberg\u2019s assessment that privacy is up to the user: \u201cHe must be kidding.\u201d\n\n\u2022 The U.S. Food and Drug Administration is cracking down on the sales of e-cigarettes to minors, especially the popular vaping brand Juul.\n\n\u2022 U.S. stocks sank for the fourth straight day, as investors looked past a series of outwardly positive earnings reports and fixated on threats to the nine-year-old bull market. Here\u2019s a snapshot of global markets.\n\nIn the News\n\nPhoto\n\n\u2022 It took nearly 200 years, but Parliament Square in London has its first statue of a woman. Millicent Fawcett, an unsung hero who led campaigning for women\u2019s right to vote, now stands among 11 statues of men in the historic center. [The New York Times]\n\n\u2022 Some 100,000 people have bet on the name of Prince William\u2019s youngest son, born earlier this week. James, Albert and Philip are in the mix, but the \u201cwisdom of crowds\u201d says it\u2019s Arthur. [The New York Times]\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u2022 The footballer Mohamad Salah spent two years in Rome before moving to England, training alongside Roma\u2019s defenders every day. But even with a close study of the forward, Salah carried Liverpool to a 5-2 win over Roma in the first leg of a Champions League semifinal. [The New York Times]\n\n\u2022 Following a spate of anti-Semitic attacks, the leader of Germany\u2019s Jewish community advised Jews not to wear yarmulkes \u2014 skullcaps \u2014 in large German cities. [BBC]\n\n\u2022 The United Arab Emirates is donating $50 million to rebuild the centuries-old Al Nuri Grand Mosque in Mosul, Iraq, which was destroyed last year in combat between Iraqi security forces and the Islamic State. [The New York Times]\n\n\u2022 A training program in Russia that tests the endurance of President Vladimir V. Putin\u2019s potential new cabinet members has selected its final pool of candidates. But only after having them jump off a cliff and duck under armored cars. [Moscow Times]\n\nSmarter Living\n\nPhoto\n\nTips, both new and old, for a more fulfilling life.\n\n\u2022 Using a standing desk may benefit your brain.\n\n\n\n\u2022 Here are some tools to help protect your data from advertisers.\n\n\u2022 Recipe of the day: Tonight, aim for big flavor with a meal of chicken thighs with mango, rum and cashews.\n\nNoteworthy\n\nPhoto\n\n\u2022 When Noma opened in Copenhagen in 2003, it created a movement and a new cuisine. The restaurant closed last year as its chef reimagined what a new Noma could look like. Now reopened, our critic explains what it\u2019s like to eat in the second incarnation of the rule-defying restaurant.\n\n\u2022 About two million people made their way to Rotterdam harbor between 1880 to 1920 to begin a trans-Atlantic journey that would often end at Ellis Island. A plan would transform an old Holland America Line warehouse in the Netherlands into a sister site dedicated to those who made the passage to America.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u2022 \u201cAvengers: Infinity War,\u201d the 19th installment in the blockbuster series, opens across Europe this week. And our critic says: \u201cI\u2019m supposed to tell you, in this review, how much fun you\u2019ll have at \u2018Infinity War,\u2019\u201d he writes. \u201c(Yes, you will have some. Will you have enough? Almost.)\u201d\n\nBack Story\n\nPhoto\n\nBefore Michael Jordan, one of the world\u2019s most famous basketball players was another native of the North Carolina city of Wilmington: Meadowlark Lemon.\n\nLemon, who was born on this day in 1932, never played in the National Basketball Association. That\u2019s because when Lemon (third from left in the front row, above) joined the Harlem Globetrotters in 1954, their mix of comedy and basketball legerdemain was the biggest draw in the game. (Check out some of his signature moves.)\n\nThe team played thousands of exhibitions around the world for millions of fans \u2014 and even helped America fight Communist propaganda during the Cold War.\n\nThe Globetrotters were founded in Chicago in 1926 and didn\u2019t play a game in Harlem until 1968. Lemon led the team to the height of its fame in the 1970s. Their roster wasn\u2019t just filled with court jesters, either. They could play.\n\nThe Globetrotters have been credited with integrating the N.B.A. by beating the all-white Minneapolis Lakers in 1948 and 1949. The next year, the Globetrotters\u2019 Nat Clifton, called Sweetwater, became the first black player to sign a contract with the league.\n\nLemon, who died in 2015, wrote in his memoir about the Globetrotters: \u201cThey had done more for the perception of black people and for the perception of America than almost anything you could think of.\u201d\n\nRobb Todd wrote today\u2019s Back Story.\n\n_____\n\nYour Morning Briefing is published weekday mornings and updated online.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nCheck out this page to find a Morning Briefing for your region. (In addition to our European edition, we have Australian, Asian and U.S. editions.)\n\nSign up here to receive an Evening Briefing on U.S. weeknights, and here\u2019s our full range of free newsletters.\n\nWhat would you like to see here? Contact us at europebriefing@nytimes.com.", "title": "Macron, Trump, Toronto: Your Wednesday Briefing", "authors": ["Remy Tumin"]} {"date": "2018-04-18 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Macron\u2019s crushing defeat of France\u2019s reactionary National Front last May raised hopes that the tide of illiberalism was turning in Europe. But Prime Minister Orban\u2019s easy win in Hungary\u2019s national election on April 8 and the success of antiestablishment parties in Italy a month earlier have signaled otherwise. To the east, Russia\u2019s brazen violation of international norms has only increased despite broad economic sanctions \u2014 witness the chemical assault on a double agent in Britain, while to the west, the Trump administration relentlessly pursues its chaotic assault on American values and traditions.\n\nMr. Macron said political change was inevitable, but it should not mean abandonment of democratic principles.\n\n\u201cIndeed, in these difficult times, European democracy is our best chance,\u201d he said. \u201cThe worst possible mistake would be to give up on our model and our identity.\u201d\n\nHe added, \u201cWe see authoritarians all around us, and the answer is not authoritarian democracy, but the authority of democracy.\u201d\n\nMr. Macron is not without political weaknesses. He has been called \u201cJupiter\u201d for his haughty style, and his economic reforms at home are being challenged by a wave of strikes. His proposals for a closer financial convergence in the eurozone have been met with a cool response in Germany. Yet the French president is one of the rare European leaders who unabashedly believe in Europe\u2019s future, especially as Britain prepares to exit the European Union and America\u2019s leadership erodes. Though he has cultivated a strategic rapport with President Trump, providing French forces for the punitive strike on Syria last weekend, for example, Mr. Macron drew a distinction in his speech between Europe and an America that was \u201crejecting multilateralism, free trade and climate change.\u201d\n\nIt may be that the West is going through a temporary backlash against globalization, terrorism, migration, social upheavals and technological change that have swept so rapidly around the world, and that Mr. Macron is exaggerating when he sees a \u201ccertain European civil war\u201d in the political turmoil. Yet, in Hungary, Mr. Orban opened his fourth term as prime minister with a national hate campaign against George Soros, the Hungarian-American funder of liberal projects, and with plans for a legislative campaign against nongovernmental groups that help immigrants and refugees. Late last year the European Union formally put Poland on notice that its assault on the judiciary was a serious breach of union rules. And the vulgar soap opera in Washington shows no signs of ending.", "title": "Opinion | Macron, at the Barricades, Warns of Rising Nationalism in Europe", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-13 00:00:00", "text": "Madeleine Albright, the former secretary of state, was born into a totalitarian age. She was only a toddler when she and her parents, who were of Jewish descent but later converted to Catholicism, fled Czechoslovakia after Hitler\u2019s invasion in 1939. They returned following the war, but fled again in the wake of the Communist coup in 1948.\n\nHer father, the diplomat Josef Korbel, sought asylum for the family in the United States, writing in a letter to an American official that if they returned home he\u2019d be arrested \u201cfor my faithful adherence to the ideals of democracy.\u201d America took them in as refugees. Korbel became an eminent foreign policy scholar, and in 1997 Bill Clinton made Albright the country\u2019s chief diplomat, the first woman to hold that position.\n\nAt the time, the Cold War was over and the great ideological battles of the 20th century appeared settled. Liberal democracy was ascendant, and Albright\u2019s adopted country was its most powerful champion. The arc of her life seemed to coincide with a global evolution from widespread tyranny toward expanding freedom.\n\nSo it is sad and jarring that Albright, now 80, has just published a book with the stark title \u201cFascism: A Warning.\u201d The book is not just a warning about Donald Trump; Albright is concerned with the eclipse of liberal democracy all over the world and told me in a recent interview that she had planned to write on the subject before Trump\u2019s election. But the president looms over her project. \u201cIf we think of fascism as a wound from the past that had almost healed, putting Trump in the White House was like ripping off the bandage and picking at the scab,\u201d she writes.", "title": "Opinion | Madeleine Albright Is Worried. We Should Be, Too.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-29 00:00:00", "text": "Madeline Louise Cronin and Matthew Edward Aaronson were married April 28 at the Picnic House in Brooklyn. Joni Brenner, an ordained rabbinical chaplain, officiated.\n\nMrs. Aaronson, 29, is a manager of organic growth in San Francisco for thredUP, an online fashion resale platform. She graduated from McGill University.\n\nShe is a daughter of Cynthia Bogdanovich and Brian Cronin of Jersey City. The bride\u2019s father owns Mobile Ski and Golf Network, an advertising firm based in Jersey City. Her mother is a teacher at Blue School, an independent preschool, elementary and middle school in Manhattan.\n\nMr. Aaronson, also 29, is a director for product marketing at Demandbase, an online marketing technology platform in San Francisco. He graduated from the University of Michigan.", "title": "Madeline Cronin, Matthew Aaronson", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-10 00:00:00", "text": "Rather than showing sympathy, she said, antidoping authorities have responded with threats to punish her for uncooperative behavior.\n\nAfter the blood was drawn, Brengle\u2019s right foot badly swelled and bruised, which she documented with photos. Her next blood test, at the United States Open, caused such swelling in her arm that she was forced to retire from her first-round match. Her hand still swells and burns, she said, and she cannot feel her middle, ring or pinkie fingers.\n\n\u201cThis is the test my body never recovered from,\u201d Brengle said. \u201cThis is the one that changed my career, changed my life, more than you can know.\u201d\n\nLater that fall, Brengle was given a diagnosis of C.R.P.S. Though her suit contends that the defendants were \u201cknowing and ignoring that she suffers from a rare medically-diagnosed physical condition,\u201d it does not seem that she underwent any blood tests after her diagnosis, which was verified by an I.T.F.-picked doctor.\n\nIn Brengle\u2019s complaint she said she received an agreement from Miller last August on behalf of the I.T.F. and antidoping agencies to give her \u201ca one-year conditional exemption from venipuncture blood testing after years of Brengle\u2019s pleas and requests.\u201d\n\nBrengle wants to extend that exemption for the remainder of her career. In the closing of the complaint she filed Monday, Brengle seeks \u201centry of a Permanent Injunction restraining Defendants from performing and threatening to perform a venipuncture blood test\u201d on her.\n\nBrengle\u2019s serve was never a primary weapon for her, but it has gotten much weaker of late.\n\nAccording to Tennis Abstract, from the start of the 2015 until the 2016 U.S. Open, Brengle hit at least one ace in 48 of 72 tracked matches (66.6 percent) and won less than 50 percent of first-serve points only 10 times (13.9 percent). Since then, she has hit an ace in just 8 of 61 tracked matches (13.1 percent) and has won less than 50 percent of first serves 17 times (27.9 percent). Her serve speed has also dipped.", "title": "Madison Brengle Sues I.T.F. and WTA Over Injury From Blood Testing", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-24 00:00:00", "text": "However, Ms. Lutz added, \u201cShe didn\u2019t take the route that Beyonc\u00e9 did\u201d \u2014 a reference to the pop star\u2019s exhaustive personal archiving system.\n\nMadonna\u2019s representatives did not immediately respond to a request for comment. The singer had previously said she did not know Ms. Lutz was in possession of the items until last year when the gossip site TMZ published the letter from Shakur.\n\nDated Jan. 15, 1995, the letter was written during Shakur\u2019s incarceration at New York\u2019s Clinton Correctional Facility for sexual assault, the year before his shooting death at age 25 in September 1996. In the letter, he alludes to his reasons for ending a relationship with Madonna.\n\n\u201cFor you to be seen with a black man wouldn\u2019t in any way jeopardize your career, if anything it would make you seem that much more open and exciting,\u201d Shakur wrote. \u201cBut for me at least in my previous perception I felt due to my \u2018image\u2019 I would be letting down half of the people who made me what I thought I was.\u201d\n\nA second letter in the lot was an unsent draft written by Madonna to another former boyfriend, the actor John Enos. In it Madonna described two of her rivals, Whitney Houston and Sharon Stone, as \u201chorribly mediocre,\u201d adding, \u201cThey\u2019re always being held up as paragons of virtue and some sort of measuring stick to humiliate me.\u201d\n\nMs. Lutz said she came into possession of the items while frequently hanging around during that time in Madonna\u2019s orbit, where she \u201ctended to be a repository for a lot of stuff where people just thought: \u2018Get rid of it.\u2019\u201d That included large piles fan mail that were often not examined at all, Ms. Lutz said. \u201cI knew all of the assistants and stuff would get thrown in boxes and they would just go, \u2018Hey, here\u2019s some more.\u2019\u201d", "title": "Madonna Loses Legal Battle Over Tupac Shakur Breakup Letter", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-25 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cI leave with a bitter feeling from a personal point of view,\u201d Ms. Cifuentes said.\n\nAfter being accused five weeks ago of improperly receiving her degree, Ms. Cifuentes not only denied wrongdoing but also said that she would sue the journalists at Eldiario.es, an online publication, who questioned the degree awarded to her by King Juan Carlos University. The university, a Madrid state institution, is overseen by Ms. Cifuentes\u2019s administration.\n\nHowever, the case soon snowballed into a broader scandal over the management of universities in Spain and how politicians have used their influence to bolster their academic credentials. Several politicians from different parties found themselves accused of either inventing or exaggerating their credentials on their official r\u00e9sum\u00e9.\n\nPrime Minister Mariano Rajoy had defended Ms. Cifuentes this month, saying that she had given sufficient explanations about her degree. On Wednesday, after the release of the shoplifting video, Mr. Rajoy said that Ms. Cifuentes had \u201cdone what she needed to do\u201d by resigning.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nPolls have shown declining support for Mr. Rajoy and his party, though the next general election could be more than two years away. The party held a majority in Parliament from 2011 to 2015, but elections in 2015 and 2016 gave no party anything close to a majority, and Mr. Rajoy struggled for months to form a government.\n\nHe has also been engaged in a struggle with separatists in Catalonia, taking an approach that critics contend has prolonged the political deadlock. After trying unsuccessfully to suppress an independence vote last year, he dissolved the Catalan Parliament and called new elections, only to see separatists again win a narrow majority.\n\nMs. Cifuentes is expected to stay on as a regional lawmaker, ahead of regional and municipal elections across Spain in 2019.\n\nThe case of Ms. Cifuentes is \u201cexactly the opposite of the exemplary attitude that one expects from somebody who intends to be a true leader,\u201d wrote Francesc-Marc \u00c1lvaro in a recent column for the newspaper La Vanguardia. If a politician was found to have a bogus degree, he added, \u201cin other countries like Germany and Britain, we know how these things end: with the immediate resignation of the person who deceives.\u201d\n\nProsecutors are now investigating the broader practices of King Juan Carlos University, which had been attended by other politicians from Spain\u2019s governing party. There are also concerns about financial mismanagement at the institution, known in Spanish as Rey Juan Carlos University, which was hit by a major plagiarism scandal in 2017.\n\nOn Wednesday, Ms. Cifuentes acknowledged for the first time that she received her degree as a result of \u201cagreements with the professors,\u201d but she did not elaborate. When Ms. Cifuentes had defended herself over the past month, some university professors said that their signatures had been forged on documents relating to her degree.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe case of Ms. Cifuentes \u201cis doing a lot of damage not only to the Rey Juan Carlos but to all the universities of this country,\u201d Miguel Sebasti\u00e1n, a former Socialist minister and university professor, recently told La Sexta, a television channel. He called it an affront to students who worked hard to get their degrees and their families who had supported them.", "title": "Madrid Leader Resigns After Shoplifting Video Emerges", "authors": ["Raphael Minder", "Richard P\u00e9rez-Pe\u00f1a"]} {"date": "2018-04-27 00:00:00", "text": "In an article about the collective sentiment among Special Forces soldiers in 1969, Henry Kamm of The New York Times wrote: \u201cThe feeling is widespread that the Army hypocritically turned against the men actually involved in the death, which they think was ordered by the C.I.A., and charged them with murder, and that Colonel Rheault then said that actions taken by his men were his responsibility and challenged the Army to charge him with them.\u201d\n\nCol. Alexander Lemberes, who was not a Green Beret or a paratrooper, was appointed to replace Colonel Rheault as the unit\u2019s commander, but his brief tenure did little to bolster morale.\n\nThat began to change, however, after Colonel Lemberes broke a bone in a parachute jump and was replaced by General Healy, who was a colonel at the time.\n\nCol. Jack Tobin, who at the time was a Special Forces sergeant in the coastal city of Nha Trang in South Vietnam, said in a telephone interview on Friday that he had known almost immediately that General Healy would be a good leader for the Green Berets in Vietnam.\n\n\u201cHe said, \u2018I\u2019m giving you a direct order: You are not allowed to die,\u2019 \u201d Colonel Tobin recalled. \u201cAnd one of the guys said, \u2018What if we die?\u2019 And he said, \u2018Then I\u2019ll be very disappointed in you.\u2019 \u201d\n\nGeneral Healy made sure his soldiers were adequately supplied and supported by higher-ups in Saigon, and even though Special Forces work was deadly by definition, he did all he could to protect his troops, Colonel Tobin said. As a result, he said, the Green Berets had more success.\n\n\u201cHe made us so invaluable to Abrams that Abrams had to back off,\u201d he said.\n\nGeneral Healy commanded Special Forces for nearly 20 months, receiving a Distinguished Service Medal. He spent some months as an assistant division commander with the 82nd Airborne Division at Fort Bragg, N.C., before General Abrams asked him to return to Vietnam once again. He stayed until American combat forces were ordered out of the country in 1973.", "title": "Maj. Gen. Michael Healy, Paragon Among Green Berets, Dies at 91", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-05 00:00:00", "text": "LONDON \u2014 This week, as the final hours ticked down to the deadline for British companies to report their gender pay gap data or face a fine, a flurry of last-minute filings revealed a stark and unflattering trend: Fashion and beauty brands, predominantly focused on female consumers and audiences, and often employing an overwhelmingly female staff, are among the worst offenders in the country when it comes to paying men more than women.\n\nThe explanation, according to several companies? A coterie of men in a handful of top-tier executive roles, while the majority of entry-level, retail, design and distribution center jobs are held by women, creating a gendered, pyramid employment structure reflected across sectors in the fashion industry.\n\nTake Cond\u00e9 Nast Publications Limited, publisher of magazines such as Vogue, Vanity Fair, Glamour and GQ. The company reported data on Tuesday that revealed it to have the largest mean gender pay gap favoring men among all British media publishers and broadcasters, despite having more women than men at every pay quartile.\n\nThe company reported a mean gender pay gap of 36.9 percent (in other words, when comparing mean hourly rates, women earn 63 pence, or 83 cents, for every 1 pound, or $1.40, that men earn) and a median gap of 23 percent (when comparing median hourly rates, women earn 77 pence, or $1.08, for every \u00a31, or $1.40, that men earn).\n\nPhoto\n\nIn a statement published alongside the data, Cond\u00e9 Nast attributed its salary skew to its longstanding and male-dominated senior leadership team. The chairman of Cond\u00e9 Nast Britain, Nicholas Coleridge, for example, has held various roles across the executive team since 1991. Jonathan Newhouse has led Cond\u00e9 Nast International for over 30 years. The statement said that across three-quarters of its business, the company had not found evidence of an appreciable gender pay gap. Three-quarters of all Cond\u00e9 Nast employees are female, with the bottom two salary quartiles particularly dominated by women.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe disparity of wages that exist within most fashion businesses was further underscored by the figures produced by many brands and retailers. The middle market women\u2019s wear brand Karen Millen pays women 49 percent less than men on a median hourly basis, meaning that, companywide, men\u2019s median pay was double that of women. Women made up 84 percent of the company\u2019s top positions, with a female C.E.O. and C.F.O., and the same proportion of men and women received bonuses, yet women\u2019s median bonus pay was 96 percent lower than men\u2019s.", "title": "Major Fashion Names Among Worst Offenders in Britain Gender Pay Gap", "authors": ["Elizabeth Paton"]} {"date": "2018-04-22 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nRe \u201c10-Year Baby Window Is Key to Women\u2019s Pay Gap\u201d (The Upshot, April 11):\n\nThe gender pay gap is deeply connected to having a family and the lack of paid family leave, as illuminated in your article. The American family and economy have quickly changed, but policy has not. Women give birth later, and more stay in the work force. Yet simple policy solutions lack bipartisanship, and only five states, including New York, have passed paid-leave legislation.\n\nIn the 1970s, women gave birth to their first child around age 21, and only 34 percent were working. Today, the average is 28 and at least 61 percent work. By your own analysis, the American mother is at a permanent disadvantage. You write, \u201cWhen women have their first child between age 25 and 35, their pay never recovers.\u201d\n\nAmericans know that we have a paid-family-leave problem. It is estimated that one in four women go back to work within two weeks of giving birth.\n\nRepublicans and Democrats talk about tackling the gender pay gap and helping working families. With clear data guiding the way, bipartisan legislation for paid family leave should be a priority.", "title": "Opinion | Make Paid Family Leave a Priority", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-30 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nAt an age when most kids spend their waking hours playing video games, the ceramist Marc Armitano Domingo \u2014 not yet in high school, and living in Northern California \u2014 was learning a 15th-century instrument and yearning to take Communion. \u201cI wished I was more Catholic. My older brothers had to go to Communion and I wanted to be cool like them, but my parents didn\u2019t make me. And so I begged them. I wanted to dress up in the little suits!\u201d says Armitano Domingo, now 21.\n\nAs for the Renaissance instrument, it was a viola da gamba, a bowed string instrument which he continues to play today, and which he first encountered in the studio of his seventh-grade cello teacher. \u201cIt was for nobility,\u201d he explains. \u201cFrance has my favorite repertoire. You have to be so beautiful and expressive and delicate with everything.\u201d\n\nDelicacy is central to Armitano Domingo\u2019s creative approach \u2014 not just in his playing, but also in the new collection of handmade porcelain plates and cups that he recently launched under the name Botticelli Ceramics. He is currently training on the viol at the Peabody Conservatory in Baltimore as a part-time student. He spends the rest of his time in New York with his boyfriend, the photographer Ryan McGinley, and at pottery workshops at Columbia Teachers College, firing plates in unusual, even uncomfortable, motifs.\n\nPhoto\n\nArmitano Domingo has been making amateur ceramics and clay figurines since childhood \u2014 and says he has often been inspired by the stop-motion animation of Tim Burton \u2014 but Botticelli represents the first time he is selling his work, which includes dishes, tumblers and mugs. There are plates depicting angelic scenes accented with gold leaf; one dish features a pair of raised breasts in the style of Saint Agatha, who, in paintings by artists like Francisco de Zurbar\u00e1n, displayed her martyrdom by serving her chest on a platter. Many pieces have deliberate chips and cracks that give them a fragile appearance. Some are also decorated with colorful three-dimensional worms and insects. \u201cI take class with mostly old ladies,\u201d the ceramist says. \u201cEveryone was grossed out at first, but now they think they\u2019re cute.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nThe pieces are inspired by Renaissance and Baroque art, as well as late 17th-century Dutch still-life paintings. \u201cPaintings of flowers and foods often had nasty slugs in them,\u201d Armitano Domingo says. \u201cThey were into the grotesque back then. In the Petit Trianon at Versailles, they have a mini tea set with little painted bugs.\u201d Indeed, the works of artists like Pieter Claesz, Jan van Kessel, Maria Sibylla Merian and Jacob Gerritsz Cuyp in the late 1600s often featured bountiful displays of fruit being overrun by insects, said to be symbols of the fleeting nature of beauty and the inevitability of decay. \u201cThere\u2019s an irony,\u201d says Armitano Domingo of his work. \u201cPeople think bugs aren\u2019t a good thing to have around food, but I always eat off my bug plate.\u201d It\u2019s also, perhaps, a vision of the future, when it is possible that we will all be eating caterpillars as protein when meatier options are endangered. \u201cMy parents are from Venezuela, and there I had a red ant sauce that was really spicy and nice,\u201d he says.\n\nThere is an alluring, if unnerving, sense of decay in Armitano Domingo\u2019s work, but it\u2019s only skin deep; the plates, he assures, are dependably sturdy because he uses a rare high-temperature gas kiln that reaches highs of around 2,300 degrees. \u201cI expect people to eat off of them!\u201d he says of his pieces. \u201cThey\u2019re just like every other plate you\u2019ve ever had.\u201d Yes, except for the shimmering iridescent worms.", "title": "Maker to Know: A Ceramist Creating Insect-Adorned Plates", "authors": ["Alex Frank", "On The Verge"]} {"date": "2018-04-23 00:00:00", "text": "Dear Diary:\n\nI was in New York for a meeting. I stopped for coffee near 53rd Street and First Avenue. After placing my order, I handed the very pleasant woman behind the counter a $20 bill, and she gave me my change: $14.92.\n\nWe both smiled.\n\n\u201cFourteen hundred and ninety-two,\u201d the woman said. \u201cNot many remember that one.\u201d\n\n\u201cFourteen hundred and ninety-two, Columbus sailed the ocean blue,\u201d I replied.\n\nI could not remember what came next. It had been a long time since I was in grade school. It had only been a couple nights, though, since I had watched a television special about the Vikings, so I improvised.\n\n\u201cFourteen hundred and ninety-two, Columbus sailed the ocean blue,\u201d I repeated, \u201cbut I\u2019m sure you know, because it\u2019s been said, he was centuries behind Eric the Red.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe woman behind the counter asked where I had heard that version. I told her I had just made it up.\n\n\u201cYou must be a poet,\u201d she said.\n\n\u201cPlease don\u2019t spread that ugly rumor,\u201d I said.\n\nWe both laughed out loud, as did some other people who were standing nearby. There were a few faces with blank expressions.", "title": "Making Change", "authors": ["Ron Bailey", "Metropolitan Diary"]} {"date": "2018-04-23 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nRe \u201cDon\u2019t Fear Classical Music,\u201d by Miles Hoffman (Op-Ed, April 19):\n\nI was a conscientious, if mediocre, piano student as a child; I devour the program notes before every concert I attend; I have taken courses in music theory and music appreciation; I resumed piano lessons nearly a decade ago, in my late 50s. All to little avail: I still don\u2019t \u201cget it.\u201d\n\nBut thank you, Mr. Hoffman, for aptly describing my lifelong struggle with Classical Music Insecurity Complex (your term), and for confirming the validity of the delight I feel at the end of a concert, or at the sound of my own piano, assuredly far short of what the composer intended but, in my mind\u2019s ear, pure joy.\n\nROSA OPPENHEIM, RIDGEWOOD, N.J.\n\nTo the Editor:\n\nAs a musician, a music teacher and an announcer of classical music on the radio, I often get the apologetic \u201cI don\u2019t know anything about music\u201d confession along with the perceived shame in such an admission. I like to point out that Handel didn\u2019t write for musicians any more than Shakespeare wrote for playwrights or actors, or teams in the National Football League play for football players.\n\nIf their audiences were that limited, concert halls and theaters and stadiums would be nearly empty. In all cases, the aim is bringing pleasure and excitement to people, and opening doors to exploration and discovery into the bargain.", "title": "Opinion | Making Classical Music and Art Accessible to All", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-20 00:00:00", "text": "Ms. Reggie\u2019s enterprises have caught the attention of the magazine Southern Living, which recently named her one of 30 Southern food women to watch. She also was mentioned in Garden & Gun magazine\u2019s look at how to do New Orleans like a local.\n\nBefore the market, Ms. Reggie helped create Cleaver and Company, a butcher shop, and the New Orleans branch of Good Eggs, the San Francisco organic food delivery company. She sold her interest in the butcher shop, which is now closed, and Good Eggs subsequently shut its operations in New York, Los Angeles and New Orleans to focus on its home base.\n\nThe market came to life while Mr. Brooks was renovating a pair of old buildings in the Central Business District to form the 35-room Catahoula Hotel, which opened in 2016. Ms. Reggie had planned to open her market around the corner, but that location fell through at the last minute.\n\nWithin a week, Ms. Reggie found a spot on emerging Oak Street, in the Uptown neighborhood, which required the installation of a commercial kitchen, custom-built shelving and a front counter. Including inventory, Ms. Reggie said, the venture cost around $600,000.\n\nHer goal is to earn net margins of 3 to 5 percent a year, though some customers complain that her local products cost too much. (A small jar of Poirier\u2019s cane syrup goes for $16.99; a pint of Quintin\u2019s ice cream costs $4.99.) But that reflects doing business with small vendors, Mr. Brooks said.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cEverything is curated,\u201d he said. \u201cYou\u2019re dealing with a person at the other end, and usually an owner, not a sales rep for a big corporation.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMs. Reggie\u2019s parents divorced when she was 2, and her childhood was split between New Orleans, her mother\u2019s home base, and Lafayette, where her father owned a restaurant. He subsequently became the head of St. Jude\u2019s Dream Home Giveaway, a fund-raising program for St. Jude Children\u2019s Research Hospital in Memphis.\n\nThe family connection to St. Jude\u2019s traces to her grandfather Emile, who knew St. Jude\u2019s founder, the actor Danny Thomas. (The two were of Lebanese descent.) He wasn\u2019t the family\u2019s only notable association.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nOne of Ms. Reggie\u2019s cousins is Victoria Reggie Kennedy, the widow of Senator Edward M. Kennedy. Another is Mikie Mahtook, an outfielder in the Detroit Tigers organization.\n\nMs. Reggie has an impressive network in New Orleans, where her annual Mardi Gras open house draws chefs, food writers, photographers and other assorted friends. They came to her aid when her mother, Mary, known as Missy, died last fall.\n\n\n\nAs soon as word spread, food began to arrive from the city\u2019s top restaurants. On the funeral day, Ms. Reggie arrived at the luncheon afterward to find that it was catered by her mentor, the restaurateur John Besh.\n\nPhoto\n\nMr. Besh has since been enveloped in a sexual harassment scandal, causing him to leave the Besh Restaurant Group and lose his association with PBS, whose stations carried his television programs.\n\nMs. Reggie declined to comment on the allegations against Mr. Besh, but said she remained grateful for what she had learned from him over the years.\n\n\u201cI wouldn\u2019t be here today if it wasn\u2019t for him pushing me to follow my dream and open a business,\u201d said Ms. Reggie, who also ran a microloan program for local growers. \u201cIt\u2019s because of him that I learned about the struggles of local farmers to produce their product.\u201d\n\nMs. Reggie envisions more Simone\u2019s Markets across New Orleans, whose food shopping scene is dominated by major grocers such as Whole Foods and a local chain, Rouses.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut, as with every small business, the odds for her market are uncertain. One in three small businesses closes within two years, and half fail within five years, according to data from the Small Business Administration.\n\nGetting people in the door is a constant worry. \u201cYou wake up every morning thinking, \u2018Will they come?\u2019\u201d Ms. Reggie said.\n\nYet she believes anxiety is motivating. \u201cThere\u2019s got to be a level of fear,\u201d she said. \u201cIf you\u2019re not scared, you\u2019re not thinking it all the way through.\u201d", "title": "Making Her Own Way, Nearly 100 Years Later", "authors": ["Micheline Maynard"]} {"date": "2018-04-27 00:00:00", "text": "Q. On my Nook device, I have about 40 percent of my storage space left. I like some books quite a bit, so I don\u2019t want to delete them. But where do these books go after all the memory is filled up or the device gets too old?\n\nA. Like its Amazon Kindle competitor, the Barnes & Noble Nook line of tablets and e-readers keeps copies of your digital-book purchases online. Even if you delete or archive a book from the device to free up space, you can download and read it again from the cloud backup. You can also read the book in your web browser if you would like to see it on a bigger screen.\n\nThe way to remove books from the Nook varies by model, so check the support pages on the Barnes & Noble site for specific instructions. On the current Nook Tablet, tap open the Apps icon on the home screen, select the Nook Library app, press your finger on the book you want to archive and select Remove. (Note that if you choose the Delete From Account option, the book is permanently removed from your collection.)\n\nTo archive multiple books at once, go to the Library\u2019s Grid view screen, tap the three-dot menu icon in the upper-right corner and choose Manage Storage so you can remove books from your list. You can see all the Nook books in your collection by choosing Archive from the same corner menu. The books that are not physically on your device anymore appear with a cloud-download arrow on the cover.", "title": "Making More Room for a Nook Library", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-12 00:00:00", "text": "After a chemical attack in Syria on Saturday that killed dozens and is suspected to have been launched by the Assad government, President Trump is warning that the United States may strike back. These books will get you up to speed on the seven-year war and highlight those most affected: the country\u2019s people.\n\nImage\n\nTHE SYRIAN REBELLION\n\nBy Fouad Ajami\n\n240 pp. Hoover Institution Press. (2012)\n\nIn this book, the Middle East scholar Ajami provides crucial historical context for the uprisings in 2011, which precipitated the present war in Syria. Ajami predicted that the country\u2019s complicated history would prove difficult to reconcile. Syria is a religiously and ethnically diverse country composed primarily of Sunni Arabs and a sizable Christian minority, but since the 1970s, it has been ruled by the Assad family, who are members of a Shiite sect called Alawites that make up 12 percent of the population. Hafez al-Assad established a brutal regime from the onset of his reign, and a pivotal moment occurred in 1982, when he squashed an Islamic insurgency in the city of Hama, killing an estimated 30,000 people. When he died in 2000, his son, Bashar, inherited the throne. Bashar\u2019s regime has been no less repressive and much more decadent; his military has killed so many people that the United Nations has had to stop counting. Our reviewer called Ajami\u2019s an \u201celegant and edifying book, written on the fly, by an observer who retains an almost loving intimacy with his subject.\u201d\n\nImage\n\nNO TURNING BACK\n\nLife, Loss, and Hope in Wartime Syria\n\nBy Rania Abouzeid\n\n378 pp. W.W. Norton & Company. (2018)", "title": "Making Sense of the Syrian Civil War", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-05 00:00:00", "text": "In the horror film \u201cA Quiet Place,\u201d a family is afraid of themselves going bump in the night.\n\nThe postapocalyptic tale, which opens April 6, is propelled by one central menace: creatures with enhanced hearing that attack when they detect noise. Living isolated in the woods, a couple and their children have crafted a very hushed existence to keep the threat at bay: they walk barefoot, communicate via sign language, and play Monopoly with cotton game pieces.\n\nWhen characters have to keep mum to stay alive, sound design can go to some innovative places. Anxious moments are created from the slightest creaks of a floor, footsteps on sand or even a heartbeat. Being inventive with sound, and frequently with the absence of it, was the idea that propelled the director, John Krasinski, who also stars in the movie with his wife, Emily Blunt.\n\n[Read our review of \u201cA Quiet Place.\u201d]\n\n\u201cWe live in a world now where you see all these movies, like Marvel movies, and there\u2019s so much sound going on, so many explosions,\u201d Mr. Krasinski said during an interview in New York. \u201cI love those movies, but there\u2019s something about all that noise that assaults you, in a way. We thought, what if you pulled it all back? Would that make it feel just as disconcerting and just as uncomfortable and tense?\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nTo help make quiet frightening, Mr. Krasinski worked with the sound editors Ethan Van Der Ryn and Erik Aadahl, who have experience with the loud (\u201cGodzilla\u201d) and the louder (\u201cTransformers\u201d), but were interested in taking things down more than a few notches.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThey worked to create what they called \u201csound envelopes,\u201d putting audiences in a character\u2019s shoes to hear what they hear and how they might hear it. The most intriguing one was for the young Regan, who is deaf and played by the deaf actress Millicent Simmonds. Regan wears a cochlear implant that gives her extremely minimal hearing; she has more of a physical sense of presence than an auditory one. For that, the editors wanted to mimic the feeling of being in an anechoic chamber, a room that absorbs sound to the point where all you can hear are the heightened noises of your own body. Regan\u2019s envelope is rendered with a kind of low, muffled feel punctuated by the gentle pulse of her heart. But when she takes the hearing aid out, we experience a moment of complete screen silence, an idea that Mr. Krasinski debated with his colleagues.", "title": "Making the Sound of Silence in \u2018A Quiet Place\u2019", "authors": ["Mekado Murphy"]} {"date": "2018-04-06 00:00:00", "text": "Even before the order to dissolve Parliament was announced on Friday, flags for the National Front began appearing at overpasses and major intersections in Kuala Lumpur, the nation\u2019s capital. Banners for opposition parties, which are expected to band together under the People\u2019s Justice Party in order to contest the elections, were not on display.\n\nTwo controversial bills were passed in the waning days of Parliament. One rejiggered voting districts so drastically that the opposition derided it as gerrymandering. Another piece of legislation made creating or circulating \u201cfake news\u201d punishable by up to six years in prison. The definition of \u201cfake news\u201d has not been made clear.\n\nEarlier this week, Mr. Najib promised to give raises to Malaysia\u2019s 1.6 million civil servants, most of whom are Malay. The prime minister also vowed to lavish hundreds of millions of dollars on police officers and certain companies run by bumiputra, or sons of the soil, as Malays and indigenous peoples are known.\n\nDr. Mahathir was the architect of the affirmative action program for Malays, who were discriminated against during British rule. Encouraging mass immigration by Chinese and Indians, the British also gave some prime jobs in the colonial administration and business sphere to non-Malays, fostering resentment that festers to this day.\n\nPakatan Harapan, Malaysia\u2019s opposition coalition, is an unwieldy collection of disparate forces that includes Chinese liberals, Islamists and nationalist Malays. Meaning \u201calliance of hope\u201d in Malay, it is led by Dr. Mahathir, even though some of the coalition\u2019s most prominent members are veteran opposition leaders who were jailed or harassed during the former prime minister\u2019s long tenure.\n\nChief among them is Anwar Ibrahim, a former deputy prime minister to Dr. Mahathir who fell out of favor and was jailed on sodomy and graft charges that were widely seen as politically motivated. Mr. Anwar famously appeared in court in 1998 with a black eye that Dr. Mahathir\u2019s allies insisted was self-inflicted.\n\nMr. Anwar is now back in prison after a second sodomy conviction. He is scheduled to be released in June. Even though the conviction brought an end to a two-week trial in which prosecutors introduced testimony from police detectives, medical experts, grieving relatives and one of the victims \u2014 Mikayla Capers, now 11 \u2014 the question of why Mr. St. Hubert attacked the children with an eight-inch knife largely remained a mystery.\n\nFrom the start, it seemed like an inexplicable crime. On a sunny Sunday in June 2014, someone followed Mikayla, then 7, and her best friend, P.J. Avitto, 6, from a playground at the Boulevard Houses in East New York into the elevator in P.J.\u2019s building as the two were headed upstairs to fetch some Icees. On the witness stand, Mikayla said the person who had stepped in behind them \u2014 \u201cthe bad man,\u201d as she called him \u2014 told her and P.J. to shut up. When they did not, he pulled out the knife and started stabbing them.\n\nAfter the attacker escaped, the police launched a four-day hunt using a sketch drawn from the accounts of eyewitnesses who had seen the man flee and interrogated dozens of potential suspects. The customer, James Shaw Jr., 29, seized the moment when he saw Mr. Reinking apparently trying to reload his rifle. Mr. Shaw burst out from behind a swinging door where he had been hiding, wrested the weapon away and threw it over a countertop.\n\n\u201cI kind of made up my mind, because there was no way to lock that door, that if it was going to come down to it, he was going to have to work to kill me,\u201d Mr. Shaw said at the news conference.\n\nMr. Reinking fled on foot, and apparently returned to his apartment nearby to put on pants. He was last seen shirtless and shoeless, Police Chief Steve Anderson said. Investigators had yet to determine a motive for the killings.\n\nOfficials could not fully explain how Mr. Reinking regained possession of his weapons after they were taken away following his episode near the White House last year, which prompted federal authorities to work with county officials in Illinois to investigate Mr. Reinking. The detective had told Mr. Tankleff during his interrogation that investigators had found forensic evidence incriminating him, and that his father had woken from a coma and accused him of the killing. In fact, his father had never woken up. According to the lawsuit, Mr. Tankleff was \u201cencouraged by the detectives to believe he could have experienced a \u2018blackout\u2019 and killed his parents without remembering it.\u201d\n\nThe detectives then described their version of events to Mr. Tankleff, persuaded him to acknowledge it, and wrote out a confession that made it seem as though Mr. Tankleff had volunteered the account, according to the lawsuit. Mr. Tankleff never signed the confession and quickly renounced it, but was still convicted.\n\nSeventeen years later, an appellate court overturned his conviction on the basis of new evidence, and New York officials decided in 2008 not to retry Mr. Tankleff.\n\nThe settlement the committee approved Thursday stems from a lawsuit Mr. Tankleff filed nearly a decade ago, in 2009. That day, she had left a purse containing her valuables, identification cards and keepsakes for her son and an envelope of important personal documents for her sister Delci Ortega. She had also recently pleaded with Delci to take care of her teenage son and \u201craise him well.\u201d\n\nMs. Van Leer-Greenberg, however, noted that Ms. Ortega had expressed to several family members how much she loved the Krim children, and suggested to jurors that the only possible explanation for such an atrocity was severe mental illness.\n\nJurors heard six weeks of testimony from 53 witnesses, including the wrenching accounts of Ms. Krim, who described discovering the horrific scene in the bathroom, and Mr. Krim, who spoke of his deep anger that members of Ms. Ortega\u2019s family had lied to him and his wife about Ms. Ortega\u2019s qualifications and background. Both said they had noticed that Ms. Ortega was upset in the weeks before the murders but saw no indication she was losing her mind.\n\nBefore her arrest, Ms. Ortega had never been hospitalized for psychiatric problems; the only medical record regarding her mental health was one page of notes from a psychologist she visited three days before the crime. The therapist, Thomas Caffrey, said he saw no signs of delusional or psychotic thinking. He determined she was suffering from depression and anxiety. \u201cShe didn\u2019t tell me about any concerns about voices or visions,\u201d he testified.\n\nLacking medical records, the defense team relied on testimony from Ms. Ortega\u2019s family members and friends to show that she had had two mental breakdowns in the Dominican Republic, one in 1978 after her young sister died and a second in 2008 after a close family friend committed suicide.\n\nIn both cases, she slipped into deep depression and refused to leave her family\u2019s house, her sisters and friends said. In 1978, she received treatment from a doctor and recovered. During the second episode, witnesses said she started expressing irrational fears about people coming to get her and returned to New York City.\n\nMs. Ortega\u2019s siblings and other family members also testified that she appeared to be unraveling in the six months before the killings, crying frequently, asking people to pray for her and speaking of \u201cshadows\u201d and a \u201cblack man\u201d following her and attempting to split up her family.", "title": "Manhattan Nanny Is Convicted in Murders of Two Children", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-22 00:00:00", "text": "Instead, he threw his support behind the new party formed by Emmanuel Macron, who was later elected president, and Mr. Valls won re-election to the French Parliament as an independent lawmaker.\n\nAlbert Rivera, the leader of the Ciudadanos party, told a party conference that Mr. Valls could be one of several outsiders drafted in next year, saying, \u201cWe need talent.\u201d The candidacy of Mr. Valls would be that of \u201ca convinced democrat and friend of Spain in the midst of the crisis of Catalan separatism,\u201d Mr. Rivera said.\n\nSome recent polls also suggest that Ciudadanos, which was founded a decade ago in Catalonia on an anti-secession platform, would win a national election if one were held now.\n\nThe party is also leading some polls in the Madrid region, where the president of the regional government, Cristina Cifuentes, once seen as a potential successor to Prime Minister Mariano Rajoy, has resisted calls from Ciudadanos and other parties to resign after being accused of fraudulently obtaining her master\u2019s degree.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nIn December, pro-independence parties retained their narrow majority in the Catalan Parliament in a snap election called by Mr. Rajoy. Mr. Rajoy\u2019s Popular Party came last in the vote, while Ciudadanos emerged as the largest single party.\n\nCatalonia is now caught in a political deadlock, which will lead to a new election if separatist parties fail to form a new administration next month.\n\nUnder Spanish law, residents who are citizens of another European country can vote \u2014 and run for office \u2014 in municipal elections, as long as they meet the local standard for residency, but separatist politicians attacked Ciudadanos for trying to parachute Mr. Valls into the top job in Barcelona.\n\nNeus Munt\u00e9, a Catalan politician who backs secession, told local reporters that \u201ca candidate for City Hall must feel the city of Barcelona as if it were his \u2014 and somebody who hasn\u2019t lived in it for many years cannot know its reality and what worries citizens.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Valls, she added, \u201ccannot connect from Paris with the needs of the people of Barcelona.\u201d\n\nThe issue of Catalan independence has split the region, with separatist parties falling short of a majority of votes and gaining most of their support in smaller towns in the countryside rather in Barcelona.\n\nThe mayor of Barcelona, Ada Colau, has not commented about the possible candidacy of Mr. Valls, but the choice was questioned by Xavier Garc\u00eda Albiol, the leader of Mr. Rajoy\u2019s party in Catalonia.\n\n\u201cIf he thinks that a city hall is there to continue an identity debate, he is wrong,\u201d Mr. Garc\u00eda Albiol wrote on Twitter. \u201cA city hall is there to solve the real problems of neighbors.\u201d", "title": "Manuel Valls, Ex-French Premier, Plots a Comeback ... in Barcelona", "authors": ["Raphael Minder"]} {"date": "2018-04-07 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cWhat you see is the number of long-term users just piling up year after year,\u201d said Dr. Dr. Mark Olfson, a professor of psychiatry at Columbia University. Dr. Olfson and Dr. Ramin Mojtabai, a professor of psychiatry at Johns Hopkins University, assisted The Times with the analysis.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nStill, it is not at all clear that everyone on an open-ended prescription should come off it. Most doctors agree that a subset of users benefit from a lifetime prescription, but disagree over how large the group is.\n\nDr. Peter Kramer, a psychiatrist and author of several books about antidepressants, said that while he generally works to wean patients with mild-to-moderate depression off medication, some report that they do better on it.\n\n\u201cThere is a cultural question here, which is how much depression should people have to live with when we have these treatments that give so many a better quality of life,\u201d Dr. Kramer said. \u201cI don\u2019t think that\u2019s a question that should be decided in advance.\u201d\n\nAntidepressants are not harmless; they commonly cause emotional numbing, sexual problems like a lack of desire or erectile dysfunction and weight gain. Long-term users report in interviews a creeping unease that is hard to measure: Daily pill-popping leaves them doubting their own resilience, they say.\n\n\u201cWe\u2019ve come to a place, at least in the West, where it seems every other person is depressed and on medication,\u201d said Edward Shorter, a historian of psychiatry at the University of Toronto. \u201cYou do have to wonder what that says about our culture.\u201d\n\nPatients who try to stop taking the drugs often say they cannot. In a recent survey of 250 long-term users of psychiatric drugs \u2014 most commonly antidepressants \u2014 about half who wound down their prescriptions rated the withdrawal as severe. Nearly half who tried to quit could not do so because of these symptoms.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn another study of 180 longtime antidepressant users, withdrawal symptoms were reported by more than 130. Almost half said they felt addicted to antidepressants.\n\n\u201cMany were critical of the lack of information given by prescribers with regard to withdrawal,\u201d the authors concluded. \u201cAnd many also expressed disappointment or frustration with the lack of support available in managing withdrawal.\u201d\n\nDrug manufacturers do not deny that some patients suffer harsh symptoms when trying to wean themselves from antidepressants.\n\n\u201cThe likelihood of developing discontinuation syndrome varies by individuals, the treatment and dosage prescribed,\u201d said Thomas Biegi, a spokesman for Pfizer, maker of antidepressants like Zoloft and Effexor. He urged that patients work with their doctors to \u201ctaper off\u201d \u2014 to wean themselves by taking shrinking doses \u2014 and said the company could not provide specific withdrawal rates because it did not have them.\n\nDrugmaker Eli Lilly, referring to two popular antidepressants, said in a statement the company \u201cremains committed to Prozac and Cymbalta and their safety and benefits, which have been repeatedly affirmed by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration.\u201d The company declined to say how common withdrawal symptoms are.\n\nNausea and \u2018Brain Zaps\u2019\n\nAs far back as the mid-1990s, leading psychiatrists recognized withdrawal as a potential problem for patients taking modern antidepressants.\n\nAt a 1997 conference in Phoenix sponsored by drug maker Eli Lilly, a panel of academic psychiatrists produced a lengthy report detailing the symptoms, like balance problems, insomnia and anxiety, that went away when the pills were restarted.\n\nWe Want to Hear From You If you are interested in sharing your experience with long term prescriptions of antidepressants, sleeping pills or drugs for anxiety, please fill out this form. We may publish a selection of the responses. You are agreeing that we can use your submission in all manner and media of The New York Times and that we shall have the right to authorize third parties to do so. And you agree to our Terms of Service. Thank you for your submission.\n\nBut soon the topic faded from the scientific literature. And government regulators did not focus on these symptoms, seeing rampant depression as the larger problem.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cWhat we were concentrating on was recurrent depression,\u201d said Dr. Robert Temple, deputy director for clinical science in the F.D.A.\u2019s Center for Drug Evaluation and Research. \u201cIf people\u2019s heads went through the roof from withdrawal, I think we would have seen it.\u201d\n\nDrug makers had little incentive to mount costly studies of how best to quit their products, and federal funding has not filled the research gap.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nAs a result, the drugs\u2019 labels, on which doctors and many patients rely, provide very little guidance for ending a prescription safely.\n\n\u201cThe following adverse events were reported at an incidence of 1 percent or greater,\u201d reads the label for Cymbalta, a leading antidepressant. It lists headaches, fatigue and insomnia, among other reactions in patients trying to stop.\n\nThe few studies of antidepressant withdrawal that have been published suggest that it is harder to get off some medications than others. This is due to differences in the drugs\u2019 half-life \u2014 the time it takes the body to clear the medication once the pills are stopped.\n\nBrands with a relatively short half-life, like Effexor and Paxil, appear to cause more withdrawal symptoms more quickly than those that stay in the system longer, like Prozac.\n\nIn one of the earliest published withdrawal studies, researchers at Eli Lilly had people taking Zoloft, Paxil or Prozac stop the pills abruptly, for about a week. Half of those on Paxil experienced serious dizziness; 42 percent suffered confusion; and 39 percent, insomnia.\n\nAmong patients who stopped taking Zoloft, 38 percent had severe irritability; 29 percent experienced dizziness; and 23 percent, fatigue. The symptoms appeared soon after people were taken off the drugs and resolved once they resumed taking the pills.\n\nThose on Prozac, by contrast, experienced no initial spike in symptoms when they stopped, but this result was not surprising. It takes Prozac several weeks to wash out of the body entirely, so one week\u2019s interruption is not a test of withdrawal.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn a study of Cymbalta, another Eli Lilly drug, people in withdrawal experienced two to three symptoms on average. The most common were dizziness, nausea, headache and paresthesia \u2014 electric-shock sensations in the brain that many people call brain zaps. Most of these symptoms lasted longer than two weeks.\n\n\u201cThe truth is that the state of the science is absolutely inadequate,\u201d said Dr. Derelie Mangin, a professor in the department of family medicine at McMaster University in Hamilton, Ontario.\n\n\u201cWe don\u2019t have enough information about what antidepressant withdrawal entails, so we can\u2019t design proper tapering approaches.\u201d\n\nIn interviews, dozens of people who had experienced antidepressant withdrawal recounted similar stories: The drugs often relieved mood problems, at first. After a year or so, it wasn\u2019t clear whether the medication was having any effect.\n\nYet quitting was far harder, and stranger, than expected.\n\n\u201cIt took me a year to come completely off \u2014 a year,\u201d said Dr. Tom Stockmann, 34, a psychiatrist in East London, who experienced lightheadedness, confusion, vertigo and brain zaps, when he stopped taking Cymbalta after 18 months.\n\nTo wind the prescription down safely, he began opening the capsules, removing a few beads of the drug each day in order to taper off \u2014 the only way out, he decided.\n\n\u201cI knew some people experienced withdrawal reactions,\u201d Dr. Stockmann said, \u201cbut I had no idea how hard it would be.\u201d\n\nRobin Hempel, 54, a mother of four who lives near Concord, N.H., began taking the antidepressant Paxil 21 years ago for severe premenstrual syndrome on the recommendation of her gynecologist.", "title": "Many People Taking Antidepressants Discover They Cannot Quit", "authors": ["Benedict Carey", "Robert Gebeloff"]} {"date": "2018-04-11 00:00:00", "text": "Dorothy Solinger, a political-science professor who specializes in Chinese politics at the University of California, Irvine, said some people in China still want Mao \u201cto remain above the fray and be superhuman.\u201d\n\n\u201cIt could be that the people who are protesting something about Mao\u2019s personal life object to this trivializing of him by making him seem human,\u201d Ms. Solinger said.\n\nThe \u201cTrust in China\u201d show features celebrities reading the letters of more than 100 national heroes and heroines from 1921, the year the Communist Party of China was founded. The show is intended to display the \u201chumanitarian side\u201d of party members, according to the Chinese news media.\n\nOn one website, the episode on Mao was viewed 1.7 million times. The Chinese actress Han Xue recited the letter against a simulated backdrop of a forest, where it was supposedly found. Before her performance, she said she felt a \u201clittle stressed\u201d about having to read it to the public.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. One person published a statement online under the name Yunfeiyang2046, saying that the show \u201cpained him\u201d and caused him to lose sleep. He demanded a public apology.\n\n\u201cInstead of remembering the martyrs and defending their dignity and inheriting their spirit, you\u2019re giving fodder to gossips and using the opportunity to gain eyeballs and ratings,\u201d he wrote.\n\nBut many were supportive of the letter, saying that it presented a more rounded image of Mao.\n\n\u201cPeople are complicated, you can have a glorious side and an ordinary side, but heroic leaders are all produced among the people,\u201d Zhang Ding, head of the family letter research center at Renmin University in Beijing, said in a telephone interview.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nUnder President Xi Jinping, the Communist Party has imposed even tighter restrictions on any debate about Mao. Katz, the director of the Princeton University Center for Arts and Cultural Policy Studies, described Ms. Thompson as, \u201cmostly beneath the surface, a sort of godmother to the emergence of the modern nonprofit arts structure.\u201d\n\nMarcia Aldrich Thompson was born on Oct. 2, 1923, in the Central Chinese city of Hankou (now part of Wuhan) where her father, Newell, was an executive with the Standard Oil Company of New York.\n\nAfter her parents returned to New Jersey, she grew up there. Her father died when she was young. Her mother, the former Edith Pyke, sold Bibles door to door.\n\nMs. Thompson attended a Katharine Gibbs School and was hired in 1946 as an assistant to Lester Markel, the editor of The New York Times Magazine. He also sent her to help out at the International Press Institute, a free-press advocacy group in Zurich that he supported.\n\nThere she first met Mr. Lowry, whom she encountered again after joining the Ford Foundation in 1953. He was credited with making the foundation America\u2019s largest nongovernmental arts patron and the first foundation to support dance.\n\nIn 1955, she married a man who shared her surname, Ralph Thompson, a former book critic and columnist for The New York Times and the Times\u2019s Book Review section in the 1930s and \u203240s. He became an executive with Book-of-the-Month Club in the 1950s. He died in 1979.", "title": "Marcia Thompson, Prudent Promoter of the Arts, Dies at 94", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-17 00:00:00", "text": "In an interview on Tuesday, Mr. Rubio said that since his presidential campaign ended in March 2016, he has spent a lot of time contemplating what Mr. Trump got right and what he misjudged. And while Mr. Rubio insisted he had no plans to run for president again \u2014 \u201cIt\u2019s so far-off in the future, I don\u2019t know where my mind will be\u201d \u2014 he said he believed that the conservative movement\u2019s tenets need to evolve beyond sterile economic arguments of low taxes and high economic growth.\n\n\u201cI think the challenge is how the policies that come from those principles, by necessity, have to look different in the 21st century than they did in 1980 or 1985,\u201d Mr. Rubio said. \u201cAmerica is not an economy. It\u2019s a country,\u201d he added, channeling some of Mr. Trump\u2019s populism. \u201cAnd we have a bigger job than just to increase G.D.P.\u201d\n\nMr. Needham said he agreed with that diagnosis.\n\n\u201cAny fair-minded observer of the last several years would say conservatives have work to do in order to assure our principles remain relevant,\u201d Mr. Needham said in an interview. \u201cThere was truth in candidate Trump\u2019s declaration that this is the Republican Party, not the Conservative Party. Our challenge as conservatives is to build a movement that inspires a majority coalition of Americans.\u201d\n\nBut beyond their shared views on the party\u2019s need to have a better 20-year plan, the two have taken very distinct approaches to leadership. Mr. Needham has been a leading practitioner of the uncompromising, scorched-earth style of political combat that was a trademark of Tea Party-inspired politicians and activists. He frequently clashed with the Republican leadership in Congress and challenged it to drive a harder bargain on issues like defunding the Affordable Care Act, which led to a two-week government shutdown in 2013 that most Republicans came to see as ill advised.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMr. Rubio, who professed to be one of those shutdown-wary Republicans even though he voted against several bills that would have kept the government open, has been more accommodating in his dealings as a senator. He has worked with Democrats like Senator Chuck Schumer of New York, the minority leader, on immigration reform. And he remains close to his party\u2019s Senate leaders. His bid for president had the backing of some of the Republican Party\u2019s most establishment-friendly \u2014 and anti-Trump \u2014 donors.\n\nMr. Needham and Mr. Rubio have often had very different things to say about Mr. Trump. Given his anti-establishment sensibilities, Mr. Needham has largely lauded the president\u2019s agenda of low taxes and a hard-line posture toward China. He has praised Mr. Trump for helping the Republican Party forge a stronger bond with Americans who feel socially and economically disconnected and who are eager to shine a light on the corruption and cronyism they believe is rampant in Washington.\n\nMr. Rubio, who has been running for office more or less since he was a West Miami city commissioner in his 20s, clashed bitterly and personally with Mr. Trump during the 2016 campaign. He denounced Mr. Trump as someone who operated from the same playbook as \u201cthird-world strongmen\u201d who ruled Latin America. He said Mr. Trump had preyed on vulnerable students by selling them worthless degrees from Trump University. In one of the more memorable but desperate moments of Mr. Rubio\u2019s campaign, he also ridiculed Mr. Trump\u2019s tendency to misspell things on Twitter and suggested he once wet his pants at a debate.\n\nLately, however, Mr. Rubio has done what many other Republicans have done and tried to work with the president on the parts of his agenda that they do not find objectionable. He won concessions from the White House to make the child tax credit more generous in last year\u2019s tax overhaul.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe senator has also been generally supportive of the president\u2019s efforts to punish China for what they say is its disadvantaging of American products and causing of job losses with unfair trade practices.\n\nMr. Needham and Mr. Rubio both agree there is a need now to work with the president as much as possible while also looking beyond him to plan for what the party and the country look like once he is gone.\n\n\u201cAs someone who\u2019s lived his career in the movement, the challenge is preserving the principles that Reagan fought for while also being able to refresh that pool of ideas to keep pace with our times,\u201d Mr. Needham said. \u201cThat\u2019s a bigger effort than any one president or any one person.\u201d\n\nMr. Rubio\u2019s chief of staff position has been vacant since January, when he fired the previous occupant of the job after allegations of inappropriate conduct surfaced.", "title": "Marco Rubio, Darling of G.O.P. A publicist for Ms. Carey did not immediately respond to a request for comment.\n\nMs. Carey was a teenager in the late 1980s when she was recruited by Tommy Mottola, the president of what was then CBS Records, to become a pop star. Her fame was swift with the backing of the label, and that placed enormous pressure on her from the beginning.\n\nShe spent long hours in the studio recording her debut, \u201cMariah Carey,\u201d and was nominated for four Grammys in 1991. She won two that year, including the award for best new artist. Her third album, 1993\u2019s \u201cMusic Box,\u201d was also an enormous commercial success. By 2000, Billboard had crowned her the artist of the decade.\n\nBut the money behind Ms. Carey\u2019s rise led to suspicion. They compared the number of fatal accidents between 4:20 p.m. and midnight on April 20 each year with accidents during the same hours one week before and one week after that date.\n\nBefore 4:20 p.m. there was no difference between the number of fatalities on April 20 and the number on the nearby dates. But from 4:20 p.m. to midnight, there was a 12 percent increased risk of a fatal car crash on April 20 compared with the control dates. The increased risk was particularly large in drivers 20 and younger.\n\n\u201cThese crashes really don\u2019t have to happen,\u201d said the senior author, Dr. Donald A. Redelmeier, a professor of medicine at the University of Toronto. \u201cIn the Netherlands, they\u2019ve had legalized marijuana for years, but they have many more interventions \u2014 speed cameras, radar, sobriety checkpoints. The roads in the Netherlands are now much safer than those in the U.S.\u201d", "title": "Marijuana Use Tied to Fatal Car Crashes", "authors": ["Nicholas Bakalar"]} {"date": "2018-04-18 00:00:00", "text": "Larry and Sergey just yelled at us until we became what they needed us to become, and get done what they needed to be done. And so I said, look, I\u2019m going to just rinse and repeat that, hopefully with less yelling. We ultimately brought in management coaches and all kinds of mentoring.\n\nI think you can have high expectations as a leader, and as long as they\u2019re consistent and clearly communicated, a lot of people find that really inspiring. I always knew what Larry and Sergey wanted. I knew what good looked like to them, and so I never got discouraged by them saying, \u201cWait, I don\u2019t think this is ready\u201d or \u201cI think this is overly ready.\u201d At a start-up you never really know when should you launch something. So Google built the philosophy of launching early and often. Try things out and see what works.\n\nAs Google grew, how did you work to maintain a cohesive culture?\n\nThere are different phases of companies. When you\u2019re in the tens of people, the idea itself either attracts people or it doesn\u2019t. People are there because they think the problem you\u2019re trying to solve is just that important.\n\nThe next phase is where it\u2019s really critical and it\u2019s hard. Getting from 100 employees to 1,000, you have to be very careful. There\u2019s a strategy around compensation at that point, where you really want somebody who\u2019s coming for the right reasons. To get the people who are really aligned with the mission, you want to make sure that they\u2019re fairly compensated, but not necessarily motivated by that compensation. I had a strategy both at Yahoo and at Google of \u201cmeet, not beat.\u201d It\u2019s the trade-off between mercenaries and missionaries.\n\nAnd then around 1,000 people, the culture and the mission become self-reinforcing. At Google I\u2019d always ask new people, \u201cWhy did you come?\u201d When we were about 1,200 people, all of a sudden, for the first time, I actually heard the answer, \u201cI came for the culture.\u201d\n\n\u201cI\u2019m proud of what we achieved at Yahoo. That said, we had a quickly decaying legacy business. All we really managed to do was offset the declines.\u201d\n\n\u2014 Marissa Mayer\n\nWhy did you leave Google?\n\nI was 37, and I had been working at Google for 13 years. I had been on search for 10 of those years and just had very recently made the change over to focus on Maps as a search technology. And I was like, \u201cYou know, I\u2019m just not sure that I want to be like the 50-year-old search girl.\u201d\n\nI\u2019d always had huge respect for Yahoo as a company. When we were here in this office, we dreamed of maybe getting the Yahoo contract, maybe one day powering Yahoo search. In 1999, Yahoo was the internet. And I knew that while there were a lot of things going wrong for the board and leadership at Yahoo, there were a lot of really good people there working on the products.", "title": "Marissa Mayer Is Still Here", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-22 00:00:00", "text": "Maritza Carol Ebling and Matthew William Hillard were married April 21 at the Old South Church in Boston.
