Jrue Holiday added 16 points for New Orleans, which shot 53 percent (46 of 87).\n\nThe volume was high early in the arena with the crowd revved up for the first playoff game in New Orleans since 2015 \u2014 and eager to see if the Pelicans could push Portland to the brink of elimination.\n\nThe Trail Blazers did nothing to silence the place, shooting about 35 percent and committing six turnovers in the opening quarter.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nNew Orleans raced to an 18-point lead in the period, thanks in part to Mirotic making five of his first seven shots for 14 early points.\n\nMirotic had 21 by halftime, giving him a playoff career high with 24 minutes still to play. He hit three of his first four 3-point attempts and triumphantly raised his fist to the exuberant crowd after one of his long-range rainbows went through.\n\nRondo ran New Orleans\u2019 offense with a tempo that gave Portland fits, and even when he was forced to settle for a deep 3 late in the shot clock, it went down, pushing the Pelicans\u2019 lead to 20 in the first half.\n\nPortland never got closer than 13 after that and trailed by as many as 33 in the fourth quarter.", "title": "Masked Joel Embiid Leads 76ers to Easy Win Over Heat", "authors": ["The Associated Press"]} {"date": "2018-04-04 00:00:00", "text": "Among the factors that have complicated the fund\u2019s launch: Saudi officials told Blackstone last year that they wanted to create an investment committee \u2014 including one or more Saudi representatives \u2014 that would oversee the fund, according to four people briefed on the talks who weren\u2019t authorized to discuss them publicly.\n\nThe idea was a non-starter for Blackstone officials, who have consistently avoided outside influence over their investment decisions, said three of the people briefed on the talks.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cWe\u2019ve had a long and broad-based relationship with the Kingdom that\u2019s, frankly, never been stronger,\u201d said Christine Anderson, a spokeswoman for Blackstone. \u201cThey\u2019ve been exceptional partners.\u201d She declined to discuss the details of the firm\u2019s fund-raising efforts, citing legal restrictions that apply during marketing periods.\n\nA spokesman for the kingdom\u2019s Public Investment Fund declined to comment.\n\nBlackstone \u2014 whose co-founder and chief executive, Stephen A. Schwarzman, is a prominent supporter of President Trump \u2014 rushed to unveil the infrastructure fund during the pomp-filled presidential visit to Saudi Arabia last May. Wall Street titans including Mr. Schwarzman attended opulent ceremonies to celebrate the two countries\u2019 financial and political ties.\n\nThe deal fit neatly into the White House\u2019s efforts to coax foreign countries to invest in the United States. Blackstone\u2019s president at the time, Hamilton E. James, predicted that the fund would spur infrastructure projects that would \u201ccreate well-paying American jobs and will lay the foundation for stronger long-term economic growth.\u201d\n\nIn the joint Blackstone-Saudi news release, H.E. Yasir Al Rumayyan, the head of the Public Investment Fund, said that the $20 billion Saudi pledge \u201creflects our positive views around the ambitious infrastructure initiatives being undertaken in the United States as announced by President Trump.\u201d\n\nThe venture\u2019s $40 billion target drew skepticism from Blackstone\u2019s rival firms. But the company said it could pull it off. \u201cBlackstone has the talent, scale and experience to be an effective private sector partner in filling the massive infrastructure funding gap,\u201d Mr. James, now executive vice chairman of the company, said in the announcement.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn public, Blackstone is sticking with its goals of creating an immense fund and deepening its relationship with the Saudi regime, which has drawn criticism for its human rights record.\n\n\u201cWe\u2019re very confident in the long term we\u2019ll reach the $40 billion capacity,\u201d Mr. James told a group of reporters in February. He added that Blackstone hoped to hit that target \u201cover the next decade or so.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nA week earlier, Mr. Schwarzman had heaped praise on Mohammed bin Salman, the crown prince of Saudi Arabia who chairs the kingdom\u2019s Public Investment Fund. When Prince Mohammed was in New York last week, Mr. Schwarzman hosted a lunch for the prince at his New York home.\n\nBlackstone began contacting big institutional investors such as pension funds last spring as it sought contributions to the fund. But some balked at putting money in until Blackstone had a team in place to run the infrastructure fund, according to a person briefed on the process. Blackstone had promoted Sean Klimczak, a partner who had brokered previous infrastructure investments, to run the infrastructure group around the time of the fund\u2019s unveiling. Other hires took longer.\n\nBy February, the news release announcing the $40 billion fund had disappeared from Blackstone\u2019s website, although a version remained on the Public Investment Fund\u2019s site. (The release reappeared on Blackstone\u2019s site on Wednesday after The Times asked about it.)\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cThey announced it with such fanfare and certainty, and clearly things were dragging,\u201d said Colin C. Blaydon, director of the Center for Private Equity and Entrepreneurship at the Tuck School of Business at Dartmouth. \u201cI wondered what on earth was going on. If anybody ought to be able to pull something like this off, you\u2019d think Blackstone would be the one to do it.\u201d\n\nThe only two investors to firmly commit to the infrastructure fund, according to Preqin, are the Pennsylvania Public School Employees\u2019 Retirement System, which committed up to $500 million in January, and the Parochial Employees\u2019 Retirement System of Louisiana, which committed $75 million but was still finalizing the details.\n\n\u201cFor us, I think it was a good fit,\u201d said Troy Searles, chief investment officer of the Louisiana fund. He said he liked the idea of focusing on North American infrastructure and thought Blackstone would succeed.\n\nLast month, Mr. Schwarzman mentioned the fund-raising efforts at a New York investment conference with about 200 people in the room.\n\n\u201cWe\u2019re raising other money,\u201d he said, according to a transcript of the event. He invited anyone in the audience who was interested to come forward after his speech. \u201cDon\u2019t be hesitant. Don\u2019t be embarrassed.\u201d", "title": "Massive United States-Saudi Infrastructure Fund Struggles to Get Going", "authors": ["Kate Kelly", "Andrew Ross Sorkin"]} {"date": "2018-04-19 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Sitar said he was a boy when his father died, so he began working when he was 12 at a locksmith shop in Passaic where an old instructional manual, \u201cThe Art of Manipulation,\u201d ignited his obsession.\n\n\u201cWhile other kids were going to the movies, I was going to junkyards looking for safes to practice on,\u201d said Mr. Sitar, who by 18 began to take on local jobs.\n\n\u201cBack then, I couldn\u2019t believe people knew about me three towns away,\u201d he said. \u201cNow I get calls from Paris.\u201d\n\nWith intense practice, he said, \u201cI could feel things in safes that other guys didn\u2019t feel.\u201d\n\nOne television special tested his touch skills by setting up lock cylinders to rub against a toothpick, a Post-it note and a feather. Mr. Sitar detected them all, while turning the lock dials.\n\nInside his modest home in Clifton, much of the furniture consists of heavy, antique safes, and in his basement there are hundreds of locks that have been removed from safes. His dog is a mixed breed named \u2014 what else? \u2014 Combo.\n\nMr. Sitar said he has opened safes for law enforcement agencies, the military, sheikhs and celebrities. He was evasive about many details, he said, because of client confidentiality and the concern that his skills could be co-opted by trickery or forced into criminal activity.\n\nHis policy is to open a client\u2019s safe and step aside to let the owner discover what is inside.\n\n\u201cI don\u2019t want to know,\u201d he said. \u201cPay me and let me go to my next job.\u201d", "title": "Master Manipulator", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-03 00:00:00", "text": "What you do need to know is how to cook on low heat, which, in a modern kitchen, isn\u2019t as easy as you would think. Preindustrial recipes assume that you are cooking on a wood-fired or coal-fed stove; for a home cook, simmering a stew to tenderness could take hours or even days.\n\nFor most of my life as a cook, whether making a stew, a braise, a daube or a rag\u00f9, I found it impossible to sustain \u201cgentle\u201d cooking on my gas burners. All those delicious French words for simmering: mijoter, to murmur; fr\u00e9mir, to shiver; mitonner, to cook quietly, were out of my reach. All I could do was bouillir (boil).\n\nI\u2019d tiptoe away from a barely simmering stew \u2014 as from a baby who has finally gone to sleep \u2014 and be summoned back five minutes later to find a heaving, splattering mass. While some cooks are on an eternal quest for more B.T.U.s, hotter surfaces and bigger flames, I wish for the stovetop equivalent of a Sterno can.\n\nSo the first time I baked a stew in the oven, I felt as if someone had reinvented the wheel for me.\n\nWhen I made a Roman-style oxtail stew, baked in a tightly covered pot, I was bowled over by its taste and texture, not to mention by how much easier it was to manage the heat. After that, there was no looking back.\n\nMost of us rarely set our ovens below 325 degrees, but baking a stew at 300, or even 275, is ideal. The meat softens, but never collapses or becomes stringy. The liquid and aromatics are fused into the kind of rich, complex sauce that professional chefs used to spend decades learning to achieve.\n\nMy favorite recipe has hints of rosemary, thyme, orange peel and juniper berries, uses a whole bottle of wine, and is thickened simply by crushing the long-cooked potatoes and carrots into the sauce at the end. (It has been cobbled together from recipes by several South-of-France-loving food writers, like Richard Olney, Mireille Johnston and Patricia Wells.) Any herbs, vegetables and spices of your liking are equally viable.\n\nIt does take a good three to five hours to cook a big batch of stew this way. I am quite comfortable leaving my house with the oven on low; many people are not. But beef stew is a movable feast: You can cook it at night or over the weekend; or cook it for half the time, then refrigerate (or, in cold weather, leave it in the turned-off oven overnight). The cooking process can be completed the next evening, or beyond, and the finished stew can wait days (in the refrigerator) before being served. (Like gingerbread, dark chocolate brownies and other dishes with powerfully flavored ingredients, red-wine beef stew benefits from a rest before serving.)\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nIn the oven, heat comes from all directions, not just from below, so there is no need to stir. All you need to capture it is a heavy pot with a heavy lid, like a Dutch oven or a cocotte. Because of the tight seal between pot and lid, the pressure in the pot seems to help the liquid penetrate the meat.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAll of which brings us to the elephant on the page: using electric pressure cookers to speed up or simplify the stew-making process. Watchers of this space will not be surprised that I have been a holdout on the electric pressure cooker. The last new appliance I adopted was a miniature microwave, in 2002. (I still use it.)\n\nMy kitchen work surface is the size of a two-page spread of The New York Times, and neither a rice cooker nor a slow cooker ever made it through the counter-space test. But when trusted friends and colleagues like Melissa Clark fall hard for a new technology, eventually the FOMO becomes overwhelming.\n\nSo I got one.\n\nIt is true that (unlike the Crock-Pots of yore), these machines can saut\u00e9 just as well as most skillets; possibly better. Instead of having to raise and lower the heat as ingredients are added, a good saut\u00e9 function adjusts it for you.\n\nFor a long-cooked stew, \u201cslow cookers have the low-heat thing down,\u201d said the Georgia-based chef Hugh Acheson, who recently dedicated a book to them, \u201cThe Chef and the Slow Cooker\u201d (Clarkson Potter, 2017). In most, as long as the lid is not locked, you can get the slow evaporation that cooks and reduces the liquid. As long as the ingredients are well browned beforehand (Mr. Acheson says there\u2019s just no way around that step), you can make a good, wine-infused beef stew that is a blank slate for bright, brilliant garnishes.\n\nBut, he acknowledged, only the intense, circulating heat of a traditional oven produces the kind of caramelized, varied texture in the meat that makes a stew truly great.\n\nFor a weeknight, high-pressure cooking does tenderize chuck meat in 45 minutes, instead of four to five hours, as proved by the food writer and researcher J. Kenji L\u00f3pez-Alt in his admirable take on the dish.\n\nAnd yet. To achieve his simulacrum of a slow-cooked, wine-infused stew, Mr. L\u00f3pez-Alt adds a slurry of Worcestershire sauce, soy sauce, anchovies and powdered gelatin to the cooking liquid. I have nothing against these ingredients, but I did not want to use them as a back channel to the perfect beef stew.\n\nEating it was rather like wearing a perfect knockoff of an expensive handbag: It may look and feel the same, and you may receive just as many compliments. But you know it\u2019s not the same, and that knowledge, if not the stew itself, leaves an odd aftertaste. It\u2019s worth saving up for the real thing.\n\nRecipe: Slow-Cooked Red Wine Beef Stew\n\nAnd to drink ...\n\nConventional wisdom would suggest that you drink the same wine used to marinate the beef. But a modest bottle would be best for the marinade, and this stew offers an opportunity to drink an excellent red. The ideal accompaniment would be dry, intense and structured enough to stand up to the rich beef, but not powerfully fruity or oaky. I think first of a red from the Northern Rh\u00f4ne Valley, like a Cornas or a Hermitage, both with the depth to match the stew. You could try an aged Barolo or Brunello di Montalcino, or perhaps even an older Bandol. A good cabernet sauvignon from the Santa Cruz Mountains would be delicious, as would a restrained Napa cabernet. If you\u2019re not a fan of red wine, good stout might be your best option. ERIC ASIMOV\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nFollow NYT Food on Facebook, Instagram, Twitter and Pinterest. Get regular updates from NYT Cooking, with recipe suggestions, cooking tips and shopping advice.", "title": "Mastering the Art of Beef Stew", "authors": ["Julia Moskin"]} {"date": "2018-04-04 00:00:00", "text": "Phil Mickelson\n\nPhoto\n\nAt a place where Jack Nicklaus\u2019s triumph at age 46 remains one of the game\u2019s special moments, Mickelson has a chance to displace him as the oldest Masters winner amid his best spring in years.\n\nMickelson, 47, has already become the oldest winner of a World Golf Championships event, ending a 4\u00bd-year drought without a win when he prevailed a month ago in Mexico. That was the apex in a run of four consecutive top-10 finishes. Though it\u2019s been eight years since his last green jacket, Mickelson tied for third in 2012 and shared runner-up honors in 2015. The Hall of Famer has 11 top-five finishes at Augusta.\n\nRory McIlroy\n\nPhoto\n\nA Sunday romp at the Arnold Palmer Invitational reaffirmed McIlroy among the favorites, and the Northern Ireland pro needs a Masters victory to complete the career Grand Slam.\n\nThe nagging rib injury that hampered McIlroy\u2019s 2017 season appears healed, though his results were hot-and-cold before Bay Hill. After two top-3 finishes on the European Tour\u2019s Middle Eastern swing, he didn\u2019t place higher than 20th in the United States before landing in Orlando. A green jacket could have been McIlroy\u2019s first major prize \u2014 he was leading by four strokes heading into the final round in 2011 before shooting an 80 that included a triple bogey on No. 10, as Charl Schwartzel won.\n\nBubba Watson\n\nPhoto\n\nThe two-time Masters winner wasn\u2019t on many radars after a dismal 2017 when he struggled with health issues and equipment problems. Two victories in a six-week span, most recently the WGC Match Play, changed that.\n\n[READ MORE: Matt Parziale Is an Amateur at the Masters, but a Pro Fighting Fires]\n\nA slow West Coast start dropped Watson out of the world\u2019s top 100 for the first time since 2009, before he found his form at the Genesis Open. His third victory at Riviera ended the slide, and he reached the 18th hole only once in seven rounds of match play.\n\nWatson\u2019s revival follows a period in which he says an undisclosed medical condition caused him to drop weight and had him mulling retirement. A new golf ball deal also had backfired, and he was unable to shape shots the way he had before.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nShubhankar Sharma\n\nPhoto\n\nThe 21-year-old pro from India became the first man since 2014 to receive a special invitation from Augusta National, given the strength of two European Tour wins this season and holding the 54-hole lead at the WGC Mexico Championship.\n\nThe son of an Indian army colonel, Sharma was introduced to golf at age 7 after a chance conversation his father had with Anirban Lahiri\u2019s father \u2014 a doctor who was treating Sharma\u2019s mother. Sharma took to the game, turned pro at age 16 and barely qualified for the Asian Tour two years ago. He was ranked outside the world\u2019s top 400 as recently as December before capturing the Joburg Open. Another win two months later in Malaysia got him into the WGC Mexico field.\n\nJoaquin Niemann\n\nPhoto\n\nThe 19-year-old from Chile figures to make Augusta National his final amateur start, having stood atop the world amateur rankings since last May.\n\nNiemann might already have started his professional career, but a five-shot victory in the Latin American Amateur Championship \u2014 held in his hometown Santiago \u2014 earned him a Masters invitation.\n\nHe already has secured partial status on the Web.com Tour.\n\nNiemann had planned to play college golf at the University of South Florida, but his test score for English proficiency left him short of admission standards. Zack Wheeler has sputtered, but he has pitched better than Harvey. And Jason Vargas, whom the Mets signed to a two-year $16-million deal this winter, will make his season debut on Saturday as he returns from a hand injury.\n\nSo Harvey, who had a 6.00 earned run average through four starts this season, was sent to the bullpen this weekend. After five years as a starting pitcher \u2014 once one of the best in the sport before injuries and ineffectiveness dented his status \u2014 Harvey was mad but said he would do what the team needed.\n\nHis first appearance came with the score tied in the fifth inning on Tuesday, and Harvey responded by giving up a run on two hard-hit doubles. The Mets later won the game in extra innings.\n\nIn all, Harvey walked one and struck out two over two innings. He was aggressive and threw a lot of fastballs (92 to 94 miles per hour) and sliders, two pitches that are no longer what they once were before the injuries. His pitch selection and command still needed sharpening.\n\nHe did not appear in Wednesday\u2019s game, a sloppy affair in which starter Steven Matz gave up seven runs (three earned) over three and one-third innings.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe Mets have encouraged Harvey to locate his fastball to both sides of the strike zone and use his changeup more, a pitch that was effective in spring training but one that he has thrown at the lowest rate of his career.\n\n\u201cHe\u2019s going to have to do that if he wants to have success,\u201d said Dave Eiland, the Mets pitching coach.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSince they took over this winter, Eiland and Mickey Callaway, the new Mets manager, have vouched for Harvey.\n\nWhen the front office fielded offers for Harvey over the winter, Callaway, a former pitching coach, and Eiland thought they could help Harvey. Even as they demoted Harvey to the bullpen, they stressed that they still might need him in the rotation later in the season. They had experience with starting pitchers who moved to the bullpen and returned better, such as Trevor Bauer, Carlos Carrasco and Danny Duffy.\n\nTo make this work, Eiland said Harvey needed to channel the expected anger into improvement and to \u201cbuy into\u201d the new duties. After Tuesday\u2019s game, Callaway thought Harvey had done so.\n\n\u201cWe\u2019re optimistic this is going to work, but to think this is going to happen in 24 to 48 hours, I don\u2019t think any of us here believe that,\u201d Eiland said. \u201cWe think it can happen for him pretty quick. He\u2019s not doing this alone. I told him that: We\u2019re behind you. We\u2019re going to do all we can to help you get through this.\u201d\n\nBut after Tuesday\u2019s game, Harvey was not in the mood to discuss his performance in a role he did not like, so Callaway and the rookie catcher Tomas Nido, who had never caught Harvey before, answered questions about it.\n\nIt was not the first (or second) time Harvey had declined to speak with reporters following a less-than-stellar outing during his Mets tenure. Teammates, such as injured captain David Wright, and team officials have spoken to him in the past about the value of accountability. Perhaps because of that, some were either oblivious or indifferent about Harvey\u2019s additional refusal this week.\n\nHarvey\u2019s body has certainly dealt with a lot \u2014 Tommy John and thoracic outlet syndrome surgeries, and shoulder weakness. Injuries force players to adapt. Scheduled to be a free agent this off-season, Harvey is in an uncomfortable position, with a reputation for poor behavior and a pattern of poor results on the field.\n\nAsked before the game if he had discussed with Harvey the refusal to talk to reporters, Callaway said that he had not because the rules did not require it. He showed he could recover from Tommy John surgery in 2013, but he had not been the same since a 2016 surgery to treat thoracic outlet syndrome.\n\nDuring a 2017 season in which Harvey posted a career-worst 6.70 earned run average and dealt with a weak shoulder, only one of his 19 starts was scoreless. He matched that feat in his first start of the new season.\n\n\u201cGoing five innings and not giving up a ton of runs is definitely a plus and something I haven\u2019t been used to,\u201d Harvey said with a smirk, adding later: \u201cI\u2019m happy I was able to do that without my good stuff or feeling that great.\u201d\n\nHarvey did not earn the win, leaving the game in a scoreless tie. Reliever Jerry Blevins ended a Phillies\u2019 scoring threat in the sixth inning by striking out Odubel Herrera with two runners on base.\n\nIn the bottom of the frame, Todd Frazier and d\u2019Arnaud gave the Mets (3-1) a 2-0 lead with run-scoring hits. On base after each hit, Frazier and d\u2019Arnaud twisted their hands in the direction of the home dugout, as if using a pepper grinder, enacting the team\u2019s new salt-and-pepper celebration for the 2018 season.\n\nHarvey could have pitched deeper into the game, but Callaway pulled him after a relatively manageable pitch count of 86.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Jeurys Familia pitched out a jam in the ninth inning to secure the victory.\n\nSince taking over, Callaway and the new pitching coach Dave Eiland have worked diligently to improve Harvey, both on the mound and between the ears.\n\nOver the winter, the Mets listened to trade offers for Harvey but opted to keep him, in part, because of the recommendations of Callaway and Eiland. They still saw potential in Harvey\u2019s worn body and psyche.\n\nHarvey reported to spring training in a jovial mood. He proclaimed that he was healthier and stronger than ever after enjoying his first normal off-season in a while. He flashed 94-96 m.p.h. fastballs. He thanked Callaway and Eiland for their support. They lifted Harvey\u2019s confidence at every turn.\n\n\u201cHe is going to throw 96, but today it was a tough day to pitch and have your best, crisp stuff,\u201d Callaway said Tuesday. \u201cIf it were a warm summer day, you would see a little bit more velo out of him.\u201d\n\nIn spring training, Harvey refused to talk about the past (he was suspended three games without pay last season for failing to show up to Citi Field after a night of partying) or the future (his upcoming free agency). Callaway and Eiland noted progress in Harvey, watching him break bad habits from when he did not have the proper shoulder strength. It showed on Tuesday.\n\n\u201cI\u2019m healthy, I\u2019m not in pain and there\u2019s no issue,\u201d Harvey said. \u201cJust going out there and battling and just really concentrating on pitching.\u201d", "title": "Matt Harvey Looks Like His New Self in Mets\u2019 Win", "authors": ["James Wagner"]} {"date": "2018-04-25 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cI think Matt can be an asset to our team,\u201d Bruce said, adding later: \u201cI just want him to do well and I know everyone on the team wants the same.\u201d\n\nThe Mets have said all the right things about Harvey, that he is upset about the move but willing to improve for the team\u2019s sake, but his actions after the game said otherwise. He declined to speak with reporters, via a spokesman.\n\nHe lost his place in the rotation through a combination of his own ineffectiveness, the solid pitching of Wheeler, who had begun the season in Class AAA, and the anticipated return of Vargas, who has been out since mid-March with surgery to remove a broken bone in his non-throwing hand.\n\nPhoto\n\nBut Harvey\u2019s demotion did not eliminate all competition for a spot in the rotation. His fastball sat between 92 and 94 miles per hour, about the same as they had the rest of the season. He tossed a second inning, a scoreless frame that included a walk. He finished with two strikeouts.\n\n\u201cThere\u2019s no doubt that he went out there and attacked and tried to help the team,\u201d Callaway said. \u201cHe\u2019s manned up and he\u2019s gonna go do the job.\u201d\n\nThe Mets erased that run in the eighth inning when Frazier drew a walk, took third base on a single by Bruce, and scored on Gonzalez\u2019s sacrifice fly. The win also secured a spot at the United States Open and in the U.S. Amateur Championship at Pebble Beach.\n\n\u201cPeople get where they are for a lot of different reasons,\u201d Parziale said. \u201cI\u2019ve always just worked as hard as I possibly could. I never hated it or got discouraged.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nNone of this makes Parziale nervous, he said. Not Augusta\u2019s refined pageantry, the elite level of play or the intimidation factor of Amen Corner. \u201cI approach each tournament the same way, whether it\u2019s a club championship or the Masters. I\u2019m just trying to be prepared and do the best I can each time,\u201d he said.\n\n\u201cNervous isn\u2019t bad. Nervous doesn\u2019t mean you aren\u2019t able to perform,\u201d Parziale said. \u201cNervous means you care. I enjoy being nervous. But it isn\u2019t about that, it\u2019s about being prepared. Firefighters or golfers. Everyone is just a player on the course. It doesn\u2019t matter where you\u2019re from or what you do. It\u2019s just about performing that day and in that moment.\u201c\n\nParziale started playing golf as a child, continued through high school and attended Southeastern University in Lakeland, Fla., where he led his team to a national championship in 2007.\n\nAfter school he became a professional golfer but struggled with money. He quit in 2013 and a year later joined the Brockton Fire Department where his father, Vic Parziale, was captain. With the job he found more stability playing tournaments and finally had a steady paycheck.\n\n[READ MORE: At the Masters\u2019 12th Hole, Shots Are Left Twisting in the Wind]\n\nAt the U.S. Mid-Amateur in Atlanta in October, he played aggressively and was decisive, and thanks to a new belief in his driver, won with one of the widest margins of victory in the event\u2019s history.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nShawn Hester, Parziale\u2019s swing coach since 2011, had been pushing him to use a driver and challenged him to use it \u201clike a weapon and be aggressive,\u201d he said. \u201cIf he wanted to play at the highest level and compete against the best golfers in the world, then he had to start hitting the driver and figure this thing out,\u201d Hester said.\n\nAfter winning the tournament, Parziale took a leave from fighting fires. \u201cI\u2019ve got hurt at work before and I didn\u2019t want to get hurt again. Not now,\u201d he said. \u201cI also needed to get away and practice and play as much as possible.\u201d\n\nTo pay the bills, a group of benefactors, including the Massachusetts Amateur Golf Alliance, have made contributions to help with expenses.\n\nPhoto\n\nHe has no routine or grueling set schedule. There are no punishing workouts or motivational coaches. He also hasn\u2019t exactly parlayed his physical demands as a firefighter into his golf game. He doesn\u2019t overthink it and keeps it simple.\n\nThis low-key, no-nonsense approach might help him on the course, where he and his father, who is now retired from the fire department and caddies for his son, will talk about the latest emergency calls or sports. \u201cWe\u2019ll talk about anything but golf right up until he\u2019s at the ball. It keeps him loose,\u201d his father said.\n\nAlong the way, there has been encouragement. His colleagues in the fire department celebrated his success. He also received a note from Tiger Woods congratulating him on the amateur title. \u201cThat was incredible. It was very special and kind of him. We might sneak a practice round together at Augusta,\u201d Parziale said.\n\nAnother surprise arrived in the mail on Christmas Eve, making it official. \u201cThe Board of Governors of the Augusta National Golf Club cordially invite you to participate in the Two Thousand and Eighteen Masters Tournament.\u201d\n\nHe posted a photo on Twitter, holding the finely embossed invitation in front of a roaring fireplace with his dog looking on. \u201cThe best Christmas present ever,\u201d he said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nParziale won\u2019t talk much about how he\u2019ll specifically prepare for his first major; he just likes the process of preparing. Hester thinks Parziale will thrive in competition. \u201cI think Matt has the personality that the more things get tense, the better he can do,\u201d he said. \u201cHe\u2019ll get locked in and focus. He\u2019s capable of hitting the shots and capable of handling the stage.\u201d\n\nHester also thinks Parziale\u2019s father will be a big factor. \u201cHis father is a grounding and stabilizing force that keeps Matt comfortable,\u201d he said. \u201cHaving his dad on the bag is important. His father helps him feel normal. As normal as you can feel playing in front of 25,000 people watching on one of the biggest stages of golf.\u201d\n\nAll of this, of course, will ultimately be up to Parziale.\n\nIf he plays well \u2014 if he wins and delivers a true Cinderella story \u2014 would he quit fighting fires and turn pro once again?\n\n\u201cNo,\u201d he said, without hesitation. \u201cThat\u2019s just not in the picture.\u201d", "title": "Matt Parziale Is an Amateur at the Masters, but a Pro Fighting Fires", "authors": ["John Clarke"]} {"date": "2018-04-12 00:00:00", "text": "Hours later, after Mr. Mattis detailed his concerns at the White House, the president\u2019s top national security advisers ended an afternoon meeting without a decision to attack, said Sarah Huckabee Sanders, the press secretary.\n\nDiplomatic efforts continued deep into the evening, with Mr. Trump agreeing in a phone call with Prime Minister Theresa May of Britain that \u201cit was vital that the use of chemical weapons did not go unchallenged,\u201d Downing Street said in a statement. The two leaders committed to \u201ckeep working closely together on the international response,\u201d the statement said.\n\nMr. Trump was also expected to speak on Thursday with President Emmanuel Macron of France, the other key ally weighing military action.\n\n\n\nDefense Department officials said Mr. Mattis urged consideration of a wider strategy. They said he sought to persuade allies to commit to immediate help after striking Mr. Assad\u2019s government in response to Saturday\u2019s suspected chemical weapons attack on a suburb of Damascus, the capital.\n\nNikki R. Haley, the United States ambassador to the United Nations, said that \u201cwe definitely have enough proof\u201d of a chemical weapons attack.\n\n\u201cBut now, we just have to be thoughtful in our action,\u201d Ms. Haley told Andrea Mitchell of NBC News.\n\nVideo\n\nIn the White House meeting, according to three administration officials, Mr. Mattis said the United States, Britain and France must provide convincing proof that the Syrian government used chemical weapons to attack the rebel-held town of Douma, where more than 40 people died and hundreds were sickened.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIt was an acknowledgment of a lesson from the Iraq war about what can go wrong after a military assault without a plan, one senior Defense Department official said, speaking on the condition of anonymity to discuss the sensitive plans. It also sought to ensure that the United States and European allies could justify the strike to the world in the face of withering criticism by Russia \u2014 Mr. Assad\u2019s most powerful partner.\n\n\u201cDefense officials are right to worry about escalation,\u201d said Kori Schake, a former national security aide to President George W. Bush and author of a book with Mr. Mattis.\n\n\u201cThe Russians are heavily invested in sustaining Bashar Assad in power, have made their case as the essential power in the Middle East, and a U.S. or allied strike would be a reminder of how much stronger the West is than Russia,\u201d Ms. Schake said.\n\nMr. Mattis also assured House lawmakers that they would be notified before any strikes against Syrian weapons facilities and airfields. The Pentagon alerted lawmakers before an April 2017 cruise missile attack on Shayrat air base after a similar chemical attack on Syrian civilians.\n\nBefore the White House meeting, Mr. Trump told reporters he would make a decision \u201cfairly soon\u201d about a strike. Earlier, in a tweet, he insisted that he had never telegraphed the timing of an attack on Syria, which \u201ccould be very soon or not so soon at all!\u201d\n\n\u201cWe\u2019re looking very, very seriously, very closely at that whole situation and we\u2019ll see what happens, folks, we\u2019ll see what happens,\u201d he told reporters at the White House.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s too bad that the world puts us in a position like that,\u201d he said. \u201cBut you know, as I said this morning, we\u2019ve done a great job with ISIS,\u201d Mr. Trump added. \u201cWe have just absolutely decimated ISIS. But now we have to make some further decisions. So they\u2019ll be made fairly soon.\u201d\n\nIn Paris, Mr. Macron cited unspecified proof that the Syrian government had used chemical weapons in Douma, and said that France was working in close coordination with the Trump administration on the issue.\n\n\u201cWe have proof that last week, 10 days ago even, chemical weapons were used \u2014 at least chlorine \u2014 and that they were used by the regime of Bashar al-Assad,\u201d Mr. Macron said in an interview on TF1, a French television station.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut time may be of the essence in London, where Britain\u2019s Parliament will return from its Easter vacation on Monday. Although Mrs. May is under no legal obligation to consult Parliament before ordering any military action, her predecessors have done so in recent years.\n\nLawmakers from both Mrs. May\u2019s Conservative Party and the opposition Labour Party have demanded to be consulted before strikes.\n\nPhoto\n\nGermany announced that it would not be part of any coordinated military action in Syria, even as Chancellor Angela Merkel stressed the importance of a message from the West that using chemical weapons \u201cis unacceptable.\u201d\n\n\u201cGermany will not take part in possible military action \u2014 I want to make clear again that there are no decisions,\u201d Ms. Merkel said in Berlin.\n\nThe White House meeting included John R. Bolton, the new national security adviser, who favored strikes against Mr. Assad when ordered last year by Mr. Trump but opposed them in 2013 when considered by President Barack Obama.\n\nEven with Mr. Mattis\u2019s urging of caution, administration officials said it was hard to envision that Mr. Trump would not move ahead with strikes, given that he has promised retaliation.\n\n\u201cIn my view, the train has left the station,\u201d said Cliff Kupchan, chairman of the Eurasia Group, a political risk consulting and advisory firm. \u201cIf Trump now decides not to strike, he\u2019s Obama 2.0 from 2013. That\u2019s the ultimate anathema to President Trump, and I expect him to hit Syria in the next few days.\u201d\n\nMr. Trump has previously belittled American leaders for giving the enemy advance warning of a strike. Heeding Mr. Trump\u2019s warning on Wednesday about an American response, Syria has moved military aircraft to the Russian base near Latakia, and is working to protect important weapons systems.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nRussian and Iranian forces are stationed in Syria, ostensibly to support Mr. Assad\u2019s fight against Islamic State extremists whom he considers part of the rebellion that has sought to oust him in the country\u2019s seven-year war.\n\nThe Trump administration\u2019s delay in acting has given the Russians and Iranians more time to prepare for an American strike.\n\nThis month, Mr. Trump surprised even his own advisers when he said he wanted to immediately withdraw the estimated 2,000 American troops that are currently in Syria, where they are focused on fighting the Islamic State. He softened that demand hours later after a National Security Council meeting, setting a goal of bringing the troops home within a few months.\n\nSaturday\u2019s attack, however, enraged the president, and he promised a decision on a response this week.\n\nMr. Macron also said France would continue to push for a cease-fire at the United Nations and for humanitarian aid for Syrian civilians to avoid what he described as \u201cthe terrible images of crimes that we saw, with children and women who were dying by suffocation, because they were subjected to chlorine.\u201d\n\nThe French have warplanes equipped with cruise missiles in Jordan and in the United Arab Emirates, which are within striking range of Syria.", "title": "Mattis Tries to Put Brakes on Possible Syria Strike, to \u2018Keep This From Escalating\u2019", "authors": ["Helene Cooper", "Thomas Gibbons-Neff", "Peter Baker"]} {"date": "2018-04-17 00:00:00", "text": "Administration and congressional officials said the hawkish Mr. Bolton is not expected to defer to the defense secretary; already, neoconservative members of the Republican foreign policy establishment have started to air concerns that Mr. Mattis is ceding strategic territory to Iran and Russia in Syria.\n\nMr. Mattis is widely viewed by global leaders as the strongest and perhaps most credible voice on foreign policy in an administration that has been rocked by firings and resignations among senior presidential advisers. The recent exits of both General McMaster and Rex W. Tillerson as secretary of state have focused more attention on Mr. Mattis\u2019s role in the cabinet.\n\nOn Tuesday, Mr. Mattis and Gen. Joseph F. Dunford Jr., chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, briefed lawmakers on Capitol Hill about the Syria airstrikes in closed-door meetings.\n\n\u201cWe\u2019ve got to put a check on this president, on any president, when it comes to Congress\u2019s constitutional responsibility to wage war,\u201d Representative Barbara Lee, Democrat of California, said in an interview on Tuesday. She called last week\u2019s Syria\u2019s strikes \u201cillegal.\u201d\n\nAs he pressed his case last week, before the allied strikes with Britain and France, Mr. Mattis lost the battle over getting congressional authorization. But he won the larger war.\n\nMr. Mattis prevailed in limiting the strikes to three targets that did not risk endangering Russian troops scattered at military installations around Syria. Nor did the 105 missiles hit Syrian military units believed to be responsible for carrying out an April 7 suspected chemical weapons attack on Douma, near Damascus.\n\nIn the end, the narrowly targeted strikes belied Mr. Trump\u2019s description Friday night of a larger coordinated response that could take days or weeks.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cThe combined American, British and French response to these atrocities will integrate all instruments of our national power \u2014 military, economic and diplomatic,\u201d Mr. Trump said in an address to the nation as the strikes were underway. \u201cWe are prepared to sustain this response until the Syrian regime stops its use of prohibited chemical agents.\u201d\n\nBut there have been no additional strikes since then, and the Pentagon said no more are being planned. \u201cThis is a one-time shot,\u201d Mr. Mattis said on Friday, calling the airstrikes \u201ca very strong message to dissuade\u201d President Bashar al-Assad of Syria from using chemical weapons against his own people.\n\nMr. Trump\u2019s drumbeat of threats last week of a sharp response to the suspected gas attacks all but guaranteed that the United States military would strike Syria, according to two Defense Department officials who spoke on condition of anonymity.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nEven so, Mr. Mattis pushed to get congressional authorization, according to people with knowledge of the internal debate. In several White House meetings last week, he underscored the importance of linking military operations to public support \u2014 a view Mr. Mattis has long held.\n\nCol. Patrick S. Ryder of the Air Force, a spokesman for General Dunford, on Tuesday declined to discuss the internal debate between the Pentagon and the White House over the strikes\u2019 reach before they were launched.\n\nIt marked the second public divergence of views between Mr. Trump and Mr. Mattis over Syria in the past two weeks.\n\nJust days before the suspected chemical attack, the president said he was ready for the estimated 2,000 American troops currently in Syria to leave the battlefield, where they have been fighting alongside Kurdish allies against the Islamic State. Mr. Mattis and other aides quickly talked him out an immediate withdrawal.\n\nPentagon officials said there was also worry that congressional opposition to American military engagements that still rely on authorizations approved after the 2001 terrorist attacks could grow without getting Capitol Hill onboard before striking at Mr. Assad\u2019s chemical weapons program.\n\nMr. Trump did not necessarily want to hit Syria hard enough to bring Russia into the war, administration officials said. But he did want to appear aggressive in his response.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cHe just wants the big show,\u201d said Derek Chollet, an assistant secretary of defense in the Obama administration. \u201cSo Mattis was probably pushing on an open door.\u201d\n\nMr. Mattis is particularly concerned about overextending the American military in Syria. He does not want the United States to veer from its stated policy of focusing only on the fight in Syria against the Islamic State \u2014 and avoid delving into the country\u2019s seven-year civil war.\n\nRussian forces and Iranian militias have helped Mr. Assad remain in power against Syrian opposition fighters who accuse him of a brutal siege against the country.\n\n\u201cThe strike was really just enough to cover the president politically, but not enough to spark a war with the Russians,\u201d said Jon Soltz, a two-tour veteran of the Iraq war who is chairman of the liberal veterans group VoteVets. \u201cIt was clear the military had tight constraints on the operation, and that everybody in the military seemed to know that except the president.\u201d\n\nMr. Mattis publicly disputed suggestions on Tuesday that the limited strikes amounted to little more than a public relations punch at Mr. Assad.\n\n\u201cThe French, the United Kingdom, the United States, allies, all NATO allies, we worked together to maintain the prohibition on the use of chemical weapons,\u201d Mr. Mattis said at the Pentagon. \u201cWe did what we believe was right under international law, under our nation\u2019s laws.\n\n\u201cAnd I hope that this time, the Assad regime got the message,\u201d Mr. Mattis said.", "title": "Mattis Wanted Congressional Approval Before Striking Syria. He Was Overruled.", "authors": ["Helene Cooper"]} {"date": "2018-04-02 00:00:00", "text": "Dear Diary:\n\nIt was about 9:30 a.m. on a Saturday. I was scattering matzo crumbs for the birds in the parking lot of a Key Food supermarket on Riverdale Avenue in the Bronx.\n\nAn older man approached me.\n\n\u201cThe birds could use some bread crumbs after all that rain,\u201d he said.\n\n\u201cThese are matzo crumbs,\u201d I said, \u201cbecause Passover is around the corner.\u201d", "title": "Matzo for the Birds", "authors": ["Sidney Greenberg", "Metropolitan Diary"]} {"date": "2018-04-05 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nDirk Nowitzki of the Dallas Mavericks had season-ending surgery on his left ankle Thursday, the team announced.\n\nA 39-year-old forward, Nowitzki elected to have the surgery now and miss the Mavericks\u2019 final four regular-season games to begin the rehabilitation process as soon as possible. The Mavericks were eliminated from playoff contention nearly a month ago.\n\nIn an interview with The New York Times last week, on the subject of returning for what would be a record 21st consecutive season with one team, Nowitzki said: \u201cAs of now, I\u2019m planning to come back. I feel great. I\u2019ve only missed one game all season. I signed a two-year contract because I wanted to play two more years. And here we are.\u201d\n\nIn a statement, the team said the procedure was a \u201csurgical debridement of his left ankle.\u201d The surgery is expected to improve Nowitzki\u2019s chances of playing next season.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nNowitzki, who turns 40 on June 19, averaged 12.0 points and 5.7 rebounds in 24.7 minutes per game this season and remained an efficient and effective offensive player despite his declining mobility. He ranks sixth on the N.B.A.\u2019s career scoring list, just 232 points behind No. 5 Wilt Chamberlain (31,419).\n\nNowitzki\u2019s lateral movement, especially on defense, has been affected throughout the season by what the team has called a left ankle impingement. I respect his choice. I support his choice.\u201d\n\nThe mayor presented Mr. Ponte\u2019s departure as a retirement, a decision made by the then-70-year-old for purely personal reasons. That it came after weeks of unflattering headlines was a coincidence, Mr. de Blasio insisted.\n\n\u201cCommissioner Ponte had gotten to a point after years of service to the city and many, many years before that elsewhere, that it was time for him to retire,\u201d the mayor told reporters. The cars had nothing to do with it, he said.\n\nSimilarly, Mr. de Blasio said the deaths of two children in close succession, both beaten at home, did not precipitate the departure of the children\u2019s services commissioner, Gladys Carri\u00f3n, in late 2016.\n\n\u201cI think for Gladys \u2014 just a life of this very grueling, tough work, really \u2014 it became a point where she just felt exhausted, and she felt she had done all she could do, and that she needed to retire,\u201d the mayor said at the time.\n\nElected officials have long been reluctant to air the back-room grievances and failures that lead a subordinate to be pushed out of a public job, in part because highlighting such shortcomings could reflect poorly on the person at the top.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. de Blasio, when he was first running for mayor in 2013, was asked by The New York Times what it would take to get fired from a de Blasio administration.\n\n\u201cWell, I fired plenty of people in my day,\u201d he said. \u201cI don\u2019t relish it, but I\u2019ve done it all the time. Where I\u2019ve had to let people go is if they are not vigorous enough, if they\u2019re not productive enough, if they\u2019re not following through on instructions.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nBut as mayor, he has never made such reasons public when bidding adieu to a subordinate. A person with direct knowledge of the mayor\u2019s approach to personnel decisions said that Mr. de Blasio believes that it makes him look better \u2014 politically and as a manager \u2014 to praise and defend departing employees publicly even as he or she is being booted.\n\n\u201cThere are times when people are fired, and there\u2019s times when people make a choice to leave,\u201d the mayor said on Thursday when asked about his approach during an unrelated news conference in Brooklyn.\n\n\u201cI don\u2019t like to parade out there if I got to the point that someone was fired,\u201d Mr. de Blasio added. \u201cI just want the outcome. If someone is not working out, and I want them out, we find a way.\u201d\n\nThere are other factors as well, including whether admitting to firing someone would be taken as evidence of a bad management decision in their hiring.\n\nMr. de Blasio has also put a premium on diversity in hiring \u2014 and he may fear, said a person familiar with the mayor\u2019s thinking, that publicly firing a woman or a prominent African-American or Latino official like Ms. Olatoye, Mr. Taylor or Ms. Carri\u00f3n, could alienate some voters.\n\nSeveral top officials have been given interim jobs to ease their exit.\n\nThe commissioner of the Mayor\u2019s Office to Combat Domestic Violence, Rosemonde Pierre-Louis, was shunted aside in October 2015 and made a senior adviser on gender equity, as the mayor called her \u201ca tireless advocate for victims and survivors of domestic violence.\u201d\n\nStacey Cumberbatch, the commissioner of the Department of Citywide Administrative Services, told co-workers that she had been abruptly pushed out; she nonetheless landed a job, for the same salary, as an assistant vice president of NYC Health & Hospitals. According to her LinkedIn page, she stayed on that job just four months.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s almost as if you would like there to be firings,\u201d Mr. de Blasio said when asked on Thursday specifically who in his administration he had fired. The mayor and his staff declined to name anyone.\n\nCynthia Lopez, the head of the mayor\u2019s office of media and entertainment, was pushed out in 2015 after a little more than a year on the job. The number of television pilots filmed in the city had fallen and she was criticized for not networking well with the industry. Peter Wertheim, the chief of staff for deputy mayor Alicia Glen, was sent to tell Ms. Lopez that she was failing at her job, according to two people informed of the issue at the time. In August 2015, she was fired.\n\nYet Mr. de Blasio praised her in a statement: \u201cI want to thank Cynthia for her incredible passion and focus,\u201d he said.\n\nPerhaps the one time that Mr. de Blasio came closest to using the f-word \u2014 fired, that is \u2014 in public was in discussing a senior member of the Department of Citywide Administrative Services, Ricardo Morales, who was fired in 2017. Mr. Morales cooperated with federal investigators looking into how the mayor did favors for campaign donors, and he was fired on the same day that Mr. de Blasio was interviewed by F.B.I. agents working on that probe.\n\n\u201cI think there was a performance issue and there was a desire to change the way the agency was structured,\u201d Mr. de Blasio said of Mr. Morales, who is suing the city over his firing. \u201cBut again, I can\u2019t speak to the details because I wasn\u2019t involved.\u201d", "title": "Mayor de Blasio\u2019s Message, Even Amid Scandal: \u2018You\u2019re Not Fired!\u2019", "authors": ["J. David Goodman", "William Neuman"]} {"date": "2018-04-19 00:00:00", "text": "WASHINGTON \u2014 Federal prosecutors are examining whether they have sufficient evidence to open a criminal investigation into Andrew G. McCabe, the former F.B.I. deputy director, his lawyer said on Thursday, after a Justice Department inspector general report repeatedly faulted him for misleading investigators.\n\nThe inquiry is certain to add to an already corrosive atmosphere pitting Mr. McCabe and other current and former law enforcement officials against President Trump. The president has accused them of concocting a baseless investigation into possible links between his associates and Russia\u2019s election interference.\n\nThe inspector general referred his findings on Mr. McCabe to prosecutors in the United States attorney\u2019s office for the District of Columbia in recent weeks, according to Mr. McCabe\u2019s lawyer, Michael R. These days, there are green, sriracha and scorpion versions, among others. But the fanciest one on the list has just been introduced to celebrate the 150th anniversary of the McIlhenny Company, the producer based on Avery Island, La. Bottled with gold foil and packed in a box to suggest Champagne, it is made from specially selected peppers that are mashed with salt and aged for up to 15 years instead of the usual three, then mixed with sparkling wine vinegar, not the garden variety. The result is thicker and definitely more complex: Tabasco Diamond Reserve Sauce, $34.95 for six ounces, tabasco.com.\n\nFollow NYT Food on Facebook, Instagram, Twitter and Pinterest. McLaren\u2019s road models also use aerodynamic techniques first developed in racing, like wings or spoilers placed in the rear to create down force to help the car stay planted on the road.\n\nMcLaren\u2019s new Senna \u2014 a \u00a3750,000 hypercar named for Ayrton Senna, who won three Formula One titles driving for McLaren \u2014 is track worthy but street legal. The aerodynamic features of the Senna even go beyond what is allowed in racing, Mr. Parry-Williams said, with adjustable blades on the front end to complement the wing on the rear.\n\nMcLaren says it will make only 500 examples of the Senna. It is an aggressive-looking vehicle with a large air intake snorkel on top along with the huge back fin. Top speed: 211 m.p.h. With only enough storage space for two helmets and two racing suits, \u201cit is not really the ideal thing to go and buy your furniture in,\u201d Mr. Parry-Williams said.\n\nTechnologies developed for these high-priced vehicles are rolled out to other cars in McLaren\u2019s line. For instance, the Senna\u2019s predecessor, the P1, which was introduced in 2013, used an electric motor coupled to a gasoline engine to improve the car\u2019s performance as well as reduce emissions. While McLaren is not currently making a hybrid vehicle, the company says hybrid engines will power half of its vehicles by 2022.", "title": "McLaren\u2019s Formula One History Drives It on the Streets", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-06 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nRe \u201cGreater Pain if Medicare Pulls Back on Opioids\u201d (front page, March 28):\n\nAs a palliative care nurse practitioner, I can tell you that it isn\u2019t just doctors who fear that pain patients will suffer. I regularly see patients who are already being denied these medications by wary providers. And that\u2019s even before this new rule goes into effect.\n\nLost in all the concern about the opioid crisis is that these are medications approved by the Food and Drug Administration with clear indications for use. And it isn\u2019t just people with cancer or on hospice who need them. Many living with advanced illness have serious pain, and these drugs are the best we have to treat that.\n\nYet we don\u2019t have a good way to identify such patients so they may be excluded from opioid restrictions. We have to develop such exclusions, and the national palliative care organizations I work with are advocating for that with policymakers in Washington.\n\nI just wish that some of those policymakers could see the tragic cases I see and find ways to reduce what will be additional and unnecessary suffering.", "title": "Opinion | Medicare Opioid Restrictions: Many Would Suffer", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-24 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nMeek Mill, the Philadelphia rapper whose incarceration on a decade-old drug and guns conviction set off a wave of protests from his fans and supporters, was granted bail on Tuesday after the Pennsylvania Supreme Court ordered his release.\n\n\u201cAs we have said all along, Meek was unjustly convicted and should not have spent a single day in jail,\u201d his lawyer, Joe Tacopina, said in a statement.\n\nMeek Mill, whose given name is Robert Rahmeek Williams, had been incarcerated in a state prison in Chester, Pa. He was convicted in 2008 on charges related to the possession of drugs and guns, serving eight months in prison before being placed on probation for five years, a period that has been extended several times.\n\nIn November, Judge Genece E. Brinkley sentenced him to two to four years in prison for parole violations, including two arrests, one of which was on a reckless driving charge while shooting a music video in New York.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut in a hearing last week, prosecutors said his conviction should be vacated because of questions about the credibility of his arresting officer.", "title": "Meek Mill Is Released From Prison on Bail", "authors": ["Daniel Victor"]} {"date": "2018-04-18 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cIt\u2019s really hard if you only have a 2,000-mile radius,\u201d said David H. Rank, who previously served as the acting United States ambassador to China.\n\nLocations in the United States and Europe were in the running, a senior administration official said on Wednesday, though the situation was fluid. Here are some options being discussed:\n\nEurope\n\nIn theory, a neutral location like Sweden or Switzerland would be ideal. Both maintain diplomatic relations with the United States and North Korea and have signaled a willingness to facilitate the meeting.\n\nThose locales have been the sites of some of the most significant diplomatic achievements in history \u2014 Geneva hosted the 1985 meeting between President Ronald Reagan and the Soviet leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev. It could provide the dramatic backdrop that both leaders appear to crave.\n\nBut to get there, one needs a plane.\n\n\u201cHe\u2019s not going to fly commercial,\u201d Ms. Terry said of Mr. Kim.\n\nAmerican Territory\n\nWith the expected range of Mr. Kim\u2019s planes, a trip to Hawaii or Guam, the closest United States territory to North Korea, would almost certainly require a refueling stop or a borrowed plane. Korea experts call that an indignity that Mr. Kim would not accept.\n\n\u201cI have trouble believing they would do that. It would be embarrassing,\u201d said Joel S. Wit, a senior fellow at the U.S.-Korea Institute at Johns Hopkins University. \u201cThey\u2019ve got to borrow an airplane? I mean, what does that look like?\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nThe Korean Peninsula\n\nTwo locations in the Korean Peninsula have been floated as options. The Demilitarized Zone, a 2.5-mile-wide, 150-mile-long stretch of land dividing the peninsula, already has a facility that could serve as a meeting site: the Peace House in Panmunjom, a border village that is the only place in the contested strip where North and South Korean soldiers operate in proximity. The Peace House lies just across the demarcation line on the South Korean side.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIt would be about a three-hour drive for Mr. Kim \u2014 no planes required. The stark setting, though, is hardly Trumpian.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cYou have to think from Trump\u2019s perspective,\u201d Ms. Terry said of Panmunjom. \u201cIt\u2019s just not sexy.\u201d\n\nPyongyang best serves Mr. Kim\u2019s interests. The Americans would be coming to him \u2014 the first official visit by a sitting American president to the capital.\n\nBut such a trip has obvious pitfalls for Mr. Trump. Bowing to Mr. Kim\u2019s needs puts him in a weaker negotiating position and is unlikely to sit well with the president, whose bellicose foreign policy leaves little room for deference.\n\nForeign policy experts fear that a visit to Pyongyang risks legitimizing the authoritarian government of Mr. Kim, whose country has not had diplomatic relations with the United States since establishing itself as a separate state in 1948. But that argument could lose credence if the meeting moves forward.\n\n\u201cOne could argue you have already legitimized the regime by having a summit,\u201d Ms. Terry said.\n\nThe senior administration official said the two sites were probably out of the running.\n\nElsewhere in Asia\n\nA venue in Asia might be the easiest compromise. It frees Mr. Kim from the political headache of traveling by plane and keeps Mr. Trump away from North Korea. The options are limited if he wants to maintain his own political capital, though. Vietnam and Singapore are being considered rather than more obvious choices like China or Japan.\n\nChina is politically problematic because of the rocky relationship between Mr. Trump and Beijing. Seeking Chinese help in arranging such a historic event would do little to polish the Americans\u2019 credibility, and Mr. Kim\u2019s own relations with the Chinese are tenuous at best.\n\n\u201cThe politics of doing this kind of summit under the protective wing of the Chinese just strikes me as pretty implausible,\u201d Mr. Rank said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nJapan is not an option given its longstanding historical tensions with North Korea. Russia presents a similar problem to China; amid tensions with the Kremlin, Mr. Trump would be ill-served in relying on Russia to host what could be a crowning diplomatic achievement.\n\nA long shot, Mongolia, could serve all parties, and its government has offered to play host to the meeting in its capital of Ulan Bator.\n\n\u201cAt least politically, the easiest place for everyone would be Mongolia and Ulan Bator,\u201d Mr. Wit said, \u201cbecause the Mongolians like to think of themselves as the Switzerland of Asia.\u201d", "title": "Meet Me in Mongolia: How Aging Aircraft May Dictate Kim-Trump Venue", "authors": ["Ali Watkins"]} {"date": "2018-04-06 00:00:00", "text": "MOSCOW \u2014 The Trump administration on Friday announced new sanctions against a list of Russian business tycoons, government officials and corporations, part of the continuing political and economic fallout from the nerve agent attack on a former Russian spy and his daughter in England last month.\n\nThe roster includes some of the most powerful people and entities in Russia, with ties to President Vladimir V. Putin and his government. Many of them are suspected of corruption sanctioned by the Kremlin.\n\nBritain has said that Moscow was likely behind the poisoning of Sergei V. Skripal and Yulia Skripal, and has persuaded its allies on both sides of the Atlantic. Russia denies any connection to the attack.\n\nHere are some of the biggest names on the new sanctions list, and where their money came from.\n\nVladimir L. Bogdanov, secretive leader of an oil giant\n\nMr. Bogdanov, 66, is the director general and co-owner of Surgutneftegas, the fourth-biggest oil producer in Russia, which has an unusually opaque ownership structure, even by Russian standards. On paper, Mr. Bogdanov, an associate of Mr. Putin\u2019s since the days when the president was a local official in St. Petersburg, owns just 0.37 percent of the company, with a majority of its shares controlled by a web of \u201cnoncommercial partnerships.\u201d", "title": "Meet the 7 Russian Oligarchs Hit by the New U.S. Sanctions", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-04 00:00:00", "text": "Yet the Dreamers kept fighting. Wides-Mu\u00f1oz expertly describes the broader reform movement, through vivid thumbnail portraits of key students. The walk to Washington by the four activists provides one of the more dramatic sections of her narrative. The students believed Obama might sympathize with them because he had a Kenyan father. But they knew comprehensive reform would be a tough sell. At the same time, asking for passage of the Dream Act felt like a betrayal of the family members who had sacrificed so much on their behalf. The Dreamers did not want to choose between saving their parents and saving themselves.\n\nPhoto\n\nOne of the walkers, Gaby Pacheco, had an idea: Instead of picking between competing solutions, one that would grant a path to citizenship to minors only, the other that would grant it to every undocumented immigrant regardless of age, why not ask for \u201cdeferred action\u201d for all Dreamers \u2014 in other words, a guarantee that law-abiding students would not be targeted for deportation. Then they could continue to support both comprehensive reform and the Dream Act. Gaby and a friend hatched the idea after getting to know Marie Gonzalez, a Missouri student who had been allowed to remain in the United States even after her undocumented status was publicly revealed. Marie\u2019s father had overstayed a visa, and wound up on the evening news because he worked for the state governor. After Marie began blogging about the family\u2019s ordeal, federal officials deferred her deportation because she had not broken laws of her own volition (though they deported her parents). The four students from Miami envisioned making deferred action available to all who shared Marie\u2019s circumstances. And that was what they asked for when they finally made it to Washington: deferred action for childhood arrivals, or DACA, as the program eventually became known.\n\nWides-Mu\u00f1oz covered immigration for The Associated Press, and she capably depicts how the Dreamer movement grew out of two decades\u2019 worth of political activity by students, attorneys, politicians and grass-roots advisers, all of whom helped make DACA a reality. That program, which went into effect in 2012, transformed the lives of hundreds of thousands of undocumented students by granting them temporary permission to remain in the country and to work legally, even though it offered them no path to citizenship.\n\nIt is deeply ironic that a book about the achievements of these student activists must conclude with the election of Donald J. Trump, who campaigned on the idea of ending DACA entirely. While Trump has since expressed sympathy for Dreamers, one of his first actions as president was to appoint as his attorney general Senator Jeff Sessions of Alabama. Sessions appears throughout Wides-Mu\u00f1oz\u2019s saga as one of the primary critics of the immigrant rights movement, a figure who blocked any attempt at comprehensive reform and every iteration of the Dream Act.\n\nEven as Trump vacillates, it seems likely that his administration will take a hard stance against immigrants who lack legal status, and the tenuous victory for belonging that the student activists worked so hard to achieve is likely to unravel. The only real solution to structural illegitimacy that will adequately protect these immigrants is comprehensive reform with a path to citizenship. For that to pass Congress, however, these brave kids and their allies will have to take up the fight once more. Wides-Mu\u00f1oz reminds us that thanks to the ability of young people to dream, what seems impossible today may yet prove achievable tomorrow.", "title": "Meet the Dreamers Who Walked 1,500 Miles to Stay in America", "authors": ["Helen Thorpe", "Laura Wides-Mu\u00f1oz"]} {"date": "2018-04-09 00:00:00", "text": "Since then, he has been interested in quotidian objects (old photographs, rope, pegboard, folding fans) in his art-making: He generally uses an array of these materials and textiles as the surfaces of his paintings. Mack calls the works \u201cfabric collages,\u201d and styles them into sculptures and monumental installations that explore histories of both art and fashion and transform the spaces they take up. \u201cI constantly think about how I could make a work in a space that would be as effective as like, a number of Lil\u2019 Kim looks,\u201d he says of the rap legend who challenged preconceived notions of beauty, dress and presentation when she famously wore a single nipple pastie (that Hylton created from Indian bridal fabric) to the MTV Video Music Awards in 1999.\n\nThe artist has shown some of these conceptual works in various museums \u2014 and earned a spot in the Studio Museum\u2019s prestigious artist-in-residence program. His art has also caught the attention of the British designers Duro Olowu and Grace Wales Bonner. During the latter\u2019s fall/winter 2018 presentation, models paraded past one of Mack\u2019s fabric installations, which was inspired by nautical flags and African-American migration. Mack says that Wales Bonner\u2019s consideration of her wearers and her interest in identity and fabric is \u201can affirmation to the language I\u2019ve been working through this year.\u201d (He recently collaborated with her on another blues-inspired piece for the retailer Totokaelo.)\n\nA few feet away, spread across the floor of the studio, sits \u201cMenagerie,\u201d one of his signature fabric works, which is almost complete. Its surface is a blue packing blanket, which Mack found at U-Haul and dyed with red, blue and green abstract shapes. On top of it are paper media: images of his sister wearing a shirt he created, a photograph of a Richard Tuttle installation and a sly reference to Hylton\u2019s styling prowess in the form of Mary J. Blige on a \u201990s cover of Pulse! magazine.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s about a set of questions,\u201d Mack says of his work, glancing around his studio. \u201cI\u2019m trying to be free, and I\u2019m trying to bring forth things that are interesting and beautiful. I\u2019m also really keyed into what presence does to change a space, or to change an object. That\u2019s the thing about painting: It doesn\u2019t mean anything for something to be painted unless it actually is able to change the system of value spoken through the paintings to the viewers. I think paint is extraordinary, I think paint should be extraordinary.\u201d", "title": "Meet the Mixed-Media Painter Inspired by Lil\u2019 Kim", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-26 00:00:00", "text": "By 2016, however, the amount raised by the three Republican committees stagnated at $652.4 million, while the cash raised by conservative groups grew sevenfold to $810.4 million.\n\nIn practical terms, the creation of a new and massive source of campaign support freed candidates to defy the establishment. This is just what the Tea Party did in 2010 and 2014.\n\nThere is considerable disagreement over whether deregulated campaign finance and the mobilization of the angriest segment of the Republican electorate will inflict permanent damage on the Republican establishment.\n\nMichael Tanner, a senior fellow at the libertarian Cato Institute, wrote me by email. \u201cThe establishment, such as it is, still exists, but its influence has been permanently weakened by changes in the media,\u201d not just by conservative media, but by social media that \u201cenables candidates to reach their respective bases in an inexpensive way. Endorsements and money mean less and less.\u201d\n\nIdeological media outlets on both the left and right, Tanner argues \u201ccarry more weight than ever before,\u201d displacing establishment influence over candidate selection, because both sides are now more dependent on mobilizing base voters than in persuading the ever-smaller faction of uncommitted voters.\n\nA colleague of Tanner\u2019s, Emily Ekins, director of polling at Cato, argued in an email that\n\nIt\u2019s useful to not think of the G.O.P. establishment as a cohesive bloc but rather as a coalition that has been fracturing long before Trump arrived. We saw this with the rise of the tea party, the push to oust former Speaker John Boehner, the House Freedom Caucus, the inability of House Republicans to agree on health care reform, etc. Without cohesion it\u2019s hard for it to control the process.\n\nEkins points out that Trump\u2019s successful defiance of the establishment in winning the nomination has not resulted in the abandonment of policies favored by the traditional power brokers.\n\n\u201cWhen it comes to policymaking, traditional establishment priorities appear to maintain influence over agenda setting,\u201d she wrote:\n\nAlthough reforming the tax system and repealing the ACA (Obamacare) are traditional Republican priorities, these were ranked far lower, below a border wall, among Trump\u2019s core set of supporters. So while the establishment may be hanging back such that they avoid conflicts with Trump, they are still engaged in the policymaking process.\n\nExpanding on this theme in \u201cIntraparty Democracy and the 2016 Election,\u201d Julia Azari and Seth Masket, political scientists at Marquette and the University of Denver, argue that the breakdown of establishment forces has endangered the workings of the political system. Democratization, in other words, has undermined democracy:\n\nIt is not without irony that the most recent presidential election produced a result that so violated a great many substantive ideas about democracy. From his campaign promises to jail his opponent to his pre-election lamentations that the general electoral contests were rigged to his vows to strip citizens of their rights for expressing unpopular political views, Donald Trump proved to be one of the most hostile presidential candidates toward basic democratic norms in the modern age.\n\nHow \u201cdid such democratic parties produce such an anti-democratic result?\u201d Azari and Masket ask. Their answer:\n\nThe parties\u2019 moves toward internal party democracy, we maintain, helped create an environment in which a candidate like Trump could succeed. We believe that several aspects of party democratization are responsible for the inability of the Republican Party to thwart Trump\u2019s candidacy.\n\nPut another way, the demotion of Republican power brokers opened the door to the Trump presidency.\n\nIn a separate essay, \u201cWeak parties and strong partisanship are a bad combination,\u201d Azari wrote:\n\nVoters do not have to listen to elite signals. Elites do not have to listen to each other\u2019s signals. Parties have been stripped (in part by their own actions) of their ability to coordinate and bargain.\n\nNot only have party establishments lost their ability to coordinate and bargain, but Trump has successfully pushed the Republican Party elite into a corner. As Masket wrote in an email,\n\nTrump has access to a group of voters that they\u2019ve been courting for decades \u2014 working class whites. They\u2019re eager to claim the support of this demographic and, more importantly, terrified to offend it by turning on Trump.\n\nThe Trump insurgency, in this context, amounted to an internal realignment or revolution within the Republican Party. What is now the party\u2019s largest bloc of voters \u2014 whites without college degrees \u2014 wrested power from the establishment.", "title": "Opinion | Meet the New Boss. Actually Quite Different From the Old Boss.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-30 00:00:00", "text": "WASHINGTON \u2014 Matt Schlapp, the pro-Trump chairman of the American Conservative Union, had a remarkable on-air clash not long ago with his old friend Michael Steele, an anti-Trump former chairman of the Republican National Committee.\n\nAt issue was Mr. Schlapp\u2019s defense of Ian Walters, the conservative union\u2019s communications director, who told an audience: \u201cWe elected Mike Steele to be the R.N.C. chair because he\u2019s a black guy. And do you know how they then equate that level of stupidity to conservatism?\u201d Mr. Schlapp apologized, and pointed out that Mr. Walters had, too.
