Awaiting her is not a British prince, but rather the lawyer Mike Ross (Patrick J. Adams), the romantic interest of Rachel Zane, a character that Ms. Markle imbued with a mix of charm, conscientiousness and grace over her seven-year run on the show.\n\nThe appearance doubled as the capstone on Ms. Markle\u2019s career. She has said she has given up acting to be a full-time royal, which will become official with her marriage to Prince Harry on May 19.\n\nAt first glance it seems like a scant acting legacy. But, as Rachel, she was a subtly influential force on a pulpy legal drama that quietly had one of the most diverse casts on television. Debuting in the role of the ing\u00e9nue, Ms. Markle actively repositioned Rachel out of the eye-candy slot, and by the end, her character had become the show\u2019s moral conscience.\n\nWith the departure of Rachel and Mike, gone to start a do-gooder firm in Seattle, \u201cSuits\u201d not only loses a fan favorite (Ms. Markle) and one of its leads (Mr. Adams, who is also leaving the show), it also risks sacrificing the nuanced themes of class, race and corporate outsiders that their characters came to represent.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nKeeping in line with USA\u2019s former \u201cblue skies\u201d motto, \u201cSuits\u201d never billed itself as a political show. Rather, it built itself around a surreal plot: Mike is a brilliant, scrappy, upstart lawyer at one of New York\u2019s most elite firms who pretends to have graduated at the top of his class at Harvard Law School. Despite this implausible premise, the show\u2019s lasting appeal for me was something equally unbelievable: \u201cSuits\u201d rarely called attention to the prominent roles that its African-American actresses played on the show.\n\nPhoto\n\nDebuting in 2011 \u2014 a full year before \u201cScandal\u201d \u2014 Jessica Pearson (Gina Torres), decked out in exquisitely tailored, textured dress suits, appeared as the managing partner at Pearson Hardman, and the African-American mentor of Harvey Specter (Gabriel Macht). Over time, she would eventually shepherd Rachel, the firm\u2019s hardworking paralegal, into becoming a lawyer, making them part of a small group of women of color operating in the high echelons of corporate law on TV. And while \u201cThe Good Wife\u201d (another legal drama I watched until the very end), would eventually address the absence of African-Americans in both its fictional Chicago law firm and its real cast in its final two seasons, \u201cSuits\u201d began with Ms. Torres and Ms. Markle as two of its three female leads. (USA is currently developing a \u201cSuits\u201d spinoff for Ms. Torres.)", "title": "Meghan Markle Left \u2018Suits.\u2019 Here\u2019s What She Took With Her.", "authors": ["Salamishah Tillet"]} {"date": "2018-04-25 00:00:00", "text": "On Wednesday night Meghan Markle finally walked down the wedding aisle, resplendent in a lacy, sparkling white dress. It was, of course, the \u201cSuits\u201d season finale, and she was marrying her on-show fianc\u00e9.\n\nBut it was also a mere three weeks or so before Ms. Markle herself \u2014 biracial American, now former actress, divorc\u00e9e, United Nations women\u2019s advocate \u2014 will walk down the aisle in Windsor Castle to to marry her real fianc\u00e9, Prince Harry (beloved royal soldier and hell raiser turned mental health activist). That made for a digital frenzy about what may be coming, which is only going to grow as the days wind down.\n\nAfter all, the drip-drip-drip of details has already sped up. The betting is closed. On what? The still outstanding question: What will she wear? There are economic and cultural repercussions riding on the answer.\n\nAnd you thought it was just a dress. Pshaw.\n\nFirst, odds were on Ralph & Russo, makers of Ms. Markle\u2019s official engagement dress. Then Erdem Moralioglu. After all, he is a Canadian \u2014 Ms. Markle lived in Toronto while she filmed \u201cSuits\u201d \u2014 who has become a stalwart of London Fashion Week, famous for his way with a romantic lace dress, and Ms. Markle told Vanity Fair she had been wearing his clothes for years. Mrs. Trump, for example, seems to have taken what was originally a jumpsuit from the Chanel spring 2018 couture collection and had it remade as a dress.\n\nBut in a world of Trumpian excess, where the first lady once wore a coat that cost $51,500, maybe such a willingness to spend should have been expected (besides, the dress can be donated to the national archive by the designer, which defrays the cost). Mrs. Trump has always been unapologetic about the price of her clothes, and this gown had a dual purpose.\n\nAs Louise Linton, wife of the Treasury secretary, Steven Mnuchin, said when she and her husband made their entrance, she was excited for \u201ceverything French!\u201d\n\n[Read more about President Trump\u2019s first state dinner.]\n\nThere was something ironic about the fact she said that while wearing a silver beaded gown from Roberto Cavalli, an Italian brand designed by an Englishman, but it may not have occurred to her.\n\nIn any case, Mrs. Trump\u2019s decision to wear Chanel was smart, given that her counterpart, Brigitte Macron, had her entire trip wardrobe \u2014 from stilettos to handbags to the ivory gown she wore to the dinner, embroidered with a lattice of gold chains across the arms and shoulders \u2014 made by Louis Vuitton. \u201cIt is a huge honor for me to see Brigitte Macron wearing my designs while on this trip,\u201d said Nicolas Ghesqui\u00e8re, the artistic director of Louis Vuitton. \u201cI love her style and fashion sensibility,\u201d which now represents her country.", "title": "Melania Trump, at the State Dinner in Chanel, Gave Everyone Something to Chew On", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-05 00:00:00", "text": "Perhaps more so than many other leaders, Mr. Churchill has been a continued source of fascination for so many people. Why do you think that is?\n\nWorld War II is a crucial part of world history, and he had a key role in the war. He became prime minister on May 10, 1940, when the war had already been going on for several months. It was a difficult moment for the country. The British Army was marooned on the beaches of Dunkirk, in France, and surrounded by Germans. My grandfather ordered a fleet of small boats to go across the Channel and pick up the soldiers. The Air Force flew overhead to help protect the boats.\n\nIncredibly, many of the soldiers survived, which was a huge boost to England\u2019s morale because everyone thought that they would either die or be taken as prisoners. The success of Dunkirk gave my grandfather an incredible boost at the start of his premiership and increased his popularity on the international stage, where he still plays his part.\n\nImage Celia Sandys. Credit Sophie Garland\n\nHow often did you travel with your grandfather and to what destinations?\n\nWe took five trips together. He had nine other grandchildren, but they were either too young or had other commitments. I happened to be of the right age and available and feel very lucky that I had a lot of one-on-one time with him.\n\nOur first trip, in 1959, was a monthlong vacation on the Onassis yacht sailing around the Greek Islands. We were a group of a dozen, including my mother, Diana, and the opera singer Maria Callas, and her husband. Aristotle Onassis was our host. We visited Mykonos and Delos and many other islands and eventually ended up in Istanbul. During the cruise, my grandfather would sit on the boat\u2019s deck and puff a cigar every day and take in the scenery.", "title": "Memories of Traveling With Churchill", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-04 00:00:00", "text": "Community activists and city leaders are also divided. Activists filed lawsuits last year after they learned that the city had kept a list of people, including Black Lives Matter advocates, who would not be allowed in City Hall without an escort.\n\nPoverty remains endemic. Memphis is the poorest large metropolitan area in the country. More than a third of children live in poverty, including nearly 50 percent of black children. The income gap between black and white residents of Shelby County, which includes Memphis, has remained the same over the last 40 years, with black median income about half of what it is for white people.\n\n\u201cHe probably would feel sad about Memphis, as so many other places where he did a lot of his work,\u201d Ms. King said of her father. \u201cThe concentration of this poverty that we as a country never really confronted, we haven\u2019t dealt with.\u201d\n\nDr. King\u2019s death only hastened the decline of predominantly black communities that were starved of resources.\n\n\u201cWe didn\u2019t have this in Memphis,\u201d said Al Lewis, 64, a retired postal worker, pointing to an empty lot next to a bungalow home enveloped in weeds and trees in a southeast Memphis neighborhood. \u201cThe soul of the city died.\u201d\n\nMr. Lewis remembered hearing the news that Dr. King had been shot while he was at his aunt\u2019s house. Johnson, said this week that what happened to the men was wrong.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s my responsibility to understand what happened and what led to that, and ensure that we fix it,\u201d Mr. Johnson said.\n\nStarbucks has announced it would close its stores in the United States on May 29 to give anti-bias training to 175,000 employees.\n\nThe scene was recorded in a video that has been viewed more than 11 million times on Twitter. The arrests prompted a #BoycottStarbucks campaign and protests at the store, in Philadelphia\u2019s Center City.", "title": "Men Arrested at Starbucks Hope to Ensure \u2018This Situation Doesn\u2019t Happen Again\u2019", "authors": ["Christine Hauser"]} {"date": "2018-04-26 00:00:00", "text": "Among other things, Mr. Menendez intervened when Dr. Melgen was accused of overbilling Medicare by nearly $9 million. On Dr. Melgen\u2019s behalf, he lobbied the secretary of health and human services and officials at the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services. (Dr. Melgen was eventually convicted of Medicare fraud and sentenced to 17 years in prison.) The senator also helped arrange visas for the doctor\u2019s girlfriends to come to the United States. Both men argued that their actions were tokens of friendship, not bribery.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Get the Morning Briefing by Email What you need to know to start your day, delivered to your inbox Monday through Friday. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMarc E. Elias, a lawyer for Mr. Menendez, said in a statement that many of the committee\u2019s conclusions were at odds with the earlier legal proceedings.\n\n\u201cAs those who followed the 11-week trial know, many of the findings in the letter were not only contradicted by the presiding judge and rejected by the jury, but the proceedings clearly demonstrated that there was no violation of any law,\u201d Mr. Elias said. \u201cThis was further underscored when the Department of Justice dropped its baseless charges in January.\u201d\n\nMr. Menendez is \u201cglad that this Ethics Committee process that began nearly six years ago is now finally resolved,\u201d Mr. Elias added, and \u201clooks forward to continuing to serve the people of New Jersey.\u201d\n\nRepublicans, not unexpectedly, drew a different conclusion about Mr. Menendez, who is up for re-election in November.\n\n\u201cBob Menendez\u2019s scandalous conduct laid out in this letter should outrage every New Jersey voter,\u201d Bob Salera, a spokesman for the National Republican Senatorial Committee, said in a statement. \u201cThe Senate Ethics Committee found what was already crystal clear from Menendez\u2019s criminal trial \u2014 Bob Menendez is a crook and an embarrassment.\u201d\n\nThe letter of admonition came after a long dormant period for the Ethics Committee, which rarely publicly chastises sitting senators. According to the committee\u2019s records, it last took a similar action in 2012, when it issued a \u201cqualified admonition\u201d of then-Senator Tom Coburn. Mr. Coburn, Republican of Oklahoma, had participated in a meeting with a former Senate aide who was improperly lobbying senators.\n\nRare though the censure may be, however, Mr. Menendez is not the first senator from New Jersey to face it. In 2002, the committee similarly admonished Senator Robert G. Torricelli for actions that closely resembled Mr. Menendez\u2019s: secretly accepting gifts from a wealthy businessman, David Chang, while using his power as a senator to help Mr. Chang.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHis reputation badly tarnished, Mr. Torricelli ended his re-election campaign later that year. The political fallout for Mr. Menendez, who announced last month that he would run for re-election, remains to be seen. His most prominent Republican challenger is Bob Hugin, a former pharmaceutical executive.", "title": "Menendez Is \u2018Severely Admonished\u2019 by Senate Panel for Accepting Gifts", "authors": ["Maggie Astor"]} {"date": "2018-04-24 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nRe \u201cYears of Bizarre Behavior, but He Got Guns Back\u201d (front page, April 24), about the Nashville shooter: I\u2019m sure I\u2019m not the only person wondering how a mentally disturbed person\u2019s firearms are given to one of his family members. Shouldn\u2019t the state confiscate those weapons? Am I missing something here?\n\nPETER MCCABE\n\nEAST BRUNSWICK, N.J.\n\nTo the Editor:\n\nOnce more we woke up to an article about a mass killing in the United States, and once more we hear that the gunman was mentally deranged. While mental health issues may no doubt play a role, it is important for the public to know that rates of mental illness are essentially similar in countries throughout the globe. However, \u201conly in America\u201d are weapons of mass destruction readily available in stores, online and in gun shows.\n\nMoreover, even if the United States were an outlier for mental illness, the public should keep in mind that our president last year supported the repeal of an Obama-era rule that would have made it more difficult for mentally ill persons who are not capable of managing their own Social Security benefits to purchase weapons.\n\nClearly, what distinguishes us from every other country is not mental illness, but the ability of our people, regardless of their mental or emotional state, to purchase and, in some cases, to openly carry pistols, rifles and semiautomatic rifles. Until the leadership of our country gains the courage to oppose the wishes of the National Rifle Association and its supporters, newspaper headlines about mass murder of children, teenagers and adults will continue to greet us in the morning.", "title": "Opinion | Mental Illness, Access to Guns and Mass Murder", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-03 00:00:00", "text": "British cabinet reshuffles have nothing on the men\u2019s wear world. On Tuesday, LVMH Mo\u00ebt Hennessy Louis Vuitton announced that Kris Van Assche would become the new artistic director of Berluti, completing the final move in what may be the biggest reinvention yet of the men\u2019s side of the world\u2019s largest luxury group.\n\nNot that the announcement put it that way, exactly. What Antoine Arnault, chief executive of Berluti, said in a brief statement was simply, \u201cI am delighted to welcome Kris Van Assche to Berluti. I have known him for several years, have always admired his work at Dior Homme and I am looking forward to working with him.\u201d\n\nLook at the bigger picture, however.\n\nHedi Slimane, who spent seven years as designer at Dior Homme (2000-2007) and was a mentor of Mr. Van Assche, returned to the fold in January via C\u00e9line, the women\u2019s brand to which Mr. Slimane will now add men\u2019s wear.", "title": "Men\u2019s Wear Just Had a Huge Designer Reshuffle: What Does It Mean?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-16 00:00:00", "text": "The Merce Cunningham Trust announced Monday, on what would have been Cunningham\u2019s 99th birthday, a global centennial celebration of his legacy, beginning this fall. More than 60 presenting organizations and dance companies from around the world are expected to participate, and the Royal Ballet in London will be one of several to tackle Cunningham for the first time.\n\nThe celebration will consist of performances, film screenings, discussions, education initiatives, new works by other artists in conversation with Cunningham\u2019s work, and new productions. At least two works will be performed for the first time in over 30 years. The films include several discovered in archives across the world since Cunningham\u2019s death in 2009 at age 90.\n\nCunningham established the autonomy of dance by making choreography that was independent from music. He created works that, by being about dance itself, were variously hailed as radical, modernist, musical, theatrical and classical (and also as anti-musical, anti-theatrical and anti-classical).\n\nMuch of his work\u2019s essence lay in solos, created for himself and for others: indeed, in soloism. A highlight of the centennial will be a \u201cNight of 100 Solos\u201d to be performed on the evening of Cunningham\u2019s 100th birthday, April 16, 2019. One hundred dancers will perform anthologies (called Events) of solos from the 1950s to 2009 in New York (Brooklyn Academy of Music), Paris (the Op\u00e9ra-Comique), London (the Barbican Center) and Los Angeles (Center for the Art of Performance at the University of California, Los Angeles).", "title": "Merce Cunningham\u2019s Centennial Will Bring a Global Celebration", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-26 00:00:00", "text": "The talks will signal to the world whether Mr. Kim is willing to give up his nuclear weapons. But experts see them mostly as a prelude to a meeting between Mr. Kim and President Trump.\n\nFrom dessert to d\u00e9cor, we looked at the symbolism that\u2019s been embedded in virtually every detail of the meeting.\n\n_____\n\nPhoto\n\n\u2022 Protests erupted across Spain after a court sentenced five men for sexually abusing a woman during the bull-running festival of Pamplona but cleared them of rape, in a case seen as a bellwether of women\u2019s rights.\n\nThe men, who called themselves a \u201cwolf pack\u201d and used a cellphone to film the attack in 2016, were given sentences condemned as too lenient by feminist groups, police departments and politicians, who declared that the ruling would legitimize machismo violence. Above, protesters in Pamplona.\n\nMeanwhile, Catalans have come together on the feast of Jordi, their patron saint, for centuries. But this year, after months of secessionist turmoil, the celebrations were colored by political division.\n\n_____\n\nPhoto\n\n\u2022 A brain-damaged baby in Britain is at the center of a national debate and legal battle over who has the right to make life-or-death medical decisions.\n\nA British court ordered that the baby, Alfie Evans, above, who has a degenerative neurological condition, be taken off life support. Defying expectations, he kept breathing, but his parents are legally barred from seeking more medical care, despite an offer from a hospital in Rome.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe case has drawn attention from the Vatican, Poland and Italy, and it is the latest to test British law, which does not hold that life should be prolonged at all costs.\n\n_____\n\nPhoto\n\n\u2022 \u201cBrother, we need Greenpeace out here.\u201d\n\nIn Siberia, winter roads made of ice are melting earlier each year, a growing danger for long-haul truck drivers, who blame climate change. (Every year, at least one big rig goes through the ice of a lake or big river.)\n\nThe ice highways are integral to the mining and oil economy in Russia\u2019s far north, just as they are in Canada and Alaska, where ice roads are also freezing later and thawing sooner.\n\nAbove, a truck on a winter road in Siberia in March.\n\n_____\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Morning Briefing What you need to know to start your day, delivered to your inbox. She is the latest of the remarkable people whose lives are being remembered in our belated-obituary project.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u2022 The vertical migration of brine shrimp was once dismissed as \u201csynchronized swimming for sea monkeys\u201d (by a politician who thought studying them was a waste of money). Now research suggests that the tiny crustaceans\u2019 daily commute plays a vital role in the planet\u2019s health.\n\nBack Story\n\nPhoto\n\nMary Wollstonecraft \u2014 an English philosopher, author and feminist \u2014 was born into a financially unstable household with a violent alcoholic father at its helm in London on this day in 1759.\n\nWollstonecraft rejected the notion that women were incapable of reason, and she promoted women\u2019s education. She also opposed marriage, which she considered a form of slavery.\n\nIn the end she did marry \u2014 her husband was William Godwin, now seen as one of the first modern proponents of anarchism \u2014 when she was pregnant with her second child. (Wollstonecraft had a daughter from an affair with an American.)\n\nWollstonecraft died at 38, less than two weeks after giving birth to a second daughter, Mary, who would grow up to write \u201cFrankenstein.\u201d\n\nAmong the works for which Wollstonecraft is known are two (angry) public letters: \u201cA Vindication of the Rights of Men\u201d (this was published anonymously in 1790) and \u201cA Vindication of the Rights of Woman,\u201d published in 1792.\n\nHer goal for women: \u201cI do not wish them to have power over men, but over themselves.\u201d\n\nClaire Moses wrote today\u2019s Back Story.\n\n_____\n\nYour Morning Briefing is published weekday mornings and updated online.\n\nCheck out this page to find a Morning Briefing for your region. Contact us at europebriefing@nytimes.com.", "title": "Merkel, Spain, Ice Roads: Your Friday Briefing", "authors": ["Dan Levin"]} {"date": "2018-04-14 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cI think we always want to make sure that we can figure out ways to keep this the people\u2019s building, and not make it too intrusive to get in to it,\u201d he said.\n\nThere has been a trend toward tightening. Fewer than two dozen states had metal detectors at the public entrances of their capitols in 2008, according to the National Conference of State Legislatures; now the figure is more than 30. The North Carolina General Assembly is putting them in this month at its building in Raleigh. Officials there said they were meant \u201cto make the building safe for all who have business with the General Assembly.\u201d\n\nSecurity experts say state capitols could be appealing targets, and that screening visitors is a must. But some public officials worry that metal detectors \u2014 and long lines to get through them \u2014 might deter people from visiting and demonstrating in halls of power that have always been accessible.\n\n\u201cI\u2019m afraid it will make us appear less open,\u201d said Darren G. Jackson, the Democratic leader of the North Carolina House of Representatives. \u201cBut I hope the day-to-day impact will be less.\u201d\n\nOfficials in states that have used metal detectors for years say the inconvenience is usually minimal.\n\n\u201cIt gives them a sense of security that they are protected, that we are here,\u201d said Sgt. Michael Moore of the Capitol Police unit in Springfield, Ill., where detectors were put in after an unarmed statehouse guard was killed in 2004. \u201cWe rarely get any complaints.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nAnd states do not necessarily require everybody to pass through them. In Texas, people who are licensed to carry concealed weapons get to use a special lane to skip the screening that schoolchildren and sightseers get.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn Illinois, frequent visitors to the Capitol complex \u2014 including state employees, journalists and lobbyists \u2014 are issued badges that let them bypass the security line.\n\nAnd the Colorado Senate approved a measure this year that would have allowed anyone with a felony-free record to pay $250, submit fingerprints and get an ID card to let them enter the Capitol without being searched.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThat bill faltered in the House, but if it had become law, legislative staff members estimated that hundreds of lobbyists would have bought the cards, in a state where an armed man was shot and killed outside the governor\u2019s office by state troopers in 2007.\n\nFor now, Utah doesn\u2019t need any such exceptions. The Capitol in Salt Lake City may not have metal detectors, but in other ways it has the makings of a hilltop fortress: armed troopers in the driveway, bollards to keep vehicles away, a network of surveillance cameras, even an engineering system to guard against earthquake damage.\n\nState officials say there have been occasional security episodes, including one when a man drove a pickup truck up the Capitol\u2019s west steps (thus the bollards). And they say they have considered adding metal detectors, only to conclude that they are unnecessary and cloistering.\n\n\u201cQuite frankly, it\u2019s the environment we live in in the state of Utah, and that it is the people\u2019s house,\u201d said Maj. Jess Anderson of the Utah Highway Patrol, who has been involved with Capitol security for more than a decade. \u201cWe certainly still want to keep the atmosphere inviting and warm to those that are visiting the Capitol building.\u201d\n\nMajor Anderson said the Utah authorities are \u201cnot na\u00efve\u201d to threats, and seek \u201ca fine balance\" of security and openness.\n\nEven so, at the granite and marble Capitol within sight of the snow-capped Wasatch Range, the absence of detectors that are so common elsewhere can be a bit bewildering for residents and visitors alike.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s kind of surprising, truly, these days, because there are so many nuts,\u201d Jill Forker, who lives just southeast of Salt Lake City, said as she left the Capitol.\n\n\u201cBut it\u2019s nice not to have to be able to go through them, and you can kind of just wander around,\u201d said her husband, John, who works at a theater where customers\u2019 backpacks are searched.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cBut these are the state\u2019s most important officials,\u201d Ms. Forker continued, \u201cand to not have a metal detector is kind of odd.\u201d", "title": "Metal Detectors the Norm at Schools and Ballparks. Adrian Gonzalez led off the eighth with a homer off Lucas Sims.", "title": "Mets Batters Baffled by a Call-up in Blowout Loss to Braves", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-29 00:00:00", "text": "It was an impressive showing from an offense that entered Sunday near the league average in runs scored per game. A power-hitting lineup in the past, they had just 23 home runs, the fifth-lowest in baseball, because Bruce, Frazier and Conforto, who is returning from shoulder surgery, had combined for only six homers \u2014 though Frazier added one in the eighth inning on Sunday. (Frazier and Conforto have been more effective at drawing walks.)\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s not always about having the big numbers; it\u2019s about getting the key hits,\u201d Gonzalez said.\n\nIn an effort to bolster the offense, Callaway said he would give more playing time to the backup outfielder Brandon Nimmo, who has hit well in limited chances. That would mean Bruce would play at first base \u201cevery now and again,\u201d Callaway said, along with Wilmer Flores and Gonzalez, who have thus far formed a platoon at the position.\n\n\u201cI came into this year knowing I\u2019m not the everyday guy and I\u2019m just ready to go whenever they call me,\u201d Gonzalez said.\n\nGonzalez, 35, a veteran left-handed hitter with a balky back and a one-year contract, and Flores, a right-handed hitter, both entered Sunday\u2019s game batting .200 or lower. Advanced metrics, however, showed Gonzalez was hitting the ball better than his numbers indicated.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s for the benefit of everyone to keep Adrian rested and to make sure Nimmo gets in the game as much as he should be playing and keep Bruce in there as often as possible,\u201d Callaway said. \u201cIt\u2019s a fine balance.\u201d\n\nOn the mound, the Mets\u2019 rotation had a 4.13 earned run average entering Sunday, 15th in baseball \u2014 a low figure for a group that was expected to be among the best in the N.L. entering this season.\n\nThe Mets are 9-3 in games started by deGrom (2.06 E.R.A.) and Syndergaard (2.86 E.R.A.) but 8-6 in games started by anyone else. Matt Harvey was moved to the bullpen to keep Wheeler in the rotation and to make room for the newcomer Jason Vargas.", "title": "Mets Finish April on a High Note, but Some Tinkering Remains", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-07 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nWASHINGTON \u2014 A good number of the Mets\u2019 main position players are older than 30 and while they bring assets to the lineup \u2014 smarts, experience, power \u2014 speed is not something they generally possess. So in spring training, the Mets\u2019 new manager, Mickey Callaway, and his coaching staff emphasized the importance of smart, aggressive base running, the kind that can make slow-footed players seem a little faster.\n\nAnd in the Mets\u2019 3-2 win over the Washington Nationals on Saturday afternoon that approach was on full display in the seventh inning, when alert decisions on the basepaths by Asdrubal Cabrera and Michael Conforto produced the runs that put the Mets ahead.\n\nThe heady base running complemented the team\u2019s stellar pitching, with starter Steven Matz allowing only an unearned run over five innings while striking out eight batters, and closer Jeurys Familia doing yeoman\u2019s work with a five-out save. And so after a disheartening 2017 season filled with injuries and defeats, the Mets have now begun the 2018 campaign with a 6-1 record, including two straight victories over the rival Nationals, the prohibitive favorites to win the National League East.\n\nThe Mets were trailing, 2-1, in the top of the seventh when shortstop Amed Rosario, who is only 22 and does have speed, singled and scored on a double by Cabrera. When Yoenis Cespedes then hit a ground ball to the left side of the infield \u2014 a play that normally keeps runners frozen at second base \u2014 Cabrera nevertheless advanced to third.\n\nPhoto\n\nConforto then came up as pinch-hitter, and Nationals reliever Brandon Kintzler intentionally walked him, with third baseman Todd Frazier up next. The Mets\u2019 first base coach, Ruben Amaro Jr., and Conforto then decided that Conforto should try to get a head start from first during Frazier\u2019s at-bat to avoid the possibility of an inning-ending double play.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSure enough, Frazier proceeded to hit a ground ball up the middle. Nationals second baseman Howie Kendrick bobbled the ball momentarily but still might have gotten the double play if Conforto had not been running. Instead, all Kendrick could do was throw out Frazier at first while Conforto took second and Cabrera scored to give the Mets a lead they would not relinquish.", "title": "Mets May Be Lacking in Speed, but They\u2019re Off to a Very Fast Start", "authors": ["James Wagner"]} {"date": "2018-04-02 00:00:00", "text": "As a result of the postponement, the Mets announced that Matt Harvey, who was originally scheduled to make his season debut on Monday against the Phillies, would start on Tuesday.\n\nThe Mets also revealed that they would skip Seth Lugo, the team\u2019s fifth starter to begin the season, in favor of Syndergaard, who is now slotted to pitch Wednesday against the Phillies. The Mets could have simply pushed everyone in the rotation back a day, allowing Syndergaard to face their division rival, the Washington Nationals, on Thursday. But the team opted not to let him go a week between starts.\n\nInstead, deGrom was announced as the Mets\u2019 starter for Thursday in Washington, the Nationals\u2019 home opener.\n\nLugo is the Mets\u2019 fifth starter for now, since an other option for the role, Jason Vargas, was hit on his right hand by a line drive near the end of spring training and needed surgery to remove the broken hamate bone. Vargas, a left-hander, threw a bullpen session on Saturday but still had the sutures in his right hand so he was not allowed to catch the ball for himself.\n\nVargas was originally scheduled to throw a simulated game to the outfielder Michael Conforto on Monday at Citi Field. Conforto, the Mets\u2019 lone All-Star last season, had progressed so quickly from September shoulder surgery that he was a possibility to be activated from the 10-day disabled list as soon as he was eligible on Thursday. His original return date was May 1.", "title": "Mets-Phillies Postponed by Snow", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-17 00:00:00", "text": "It was a game that featured both the Mets\u2019 expected preseason strengths \u2014 superior starting pitching and timely hitting \u2014 and one of its most pressing worries: the bullpen.\n\nApart from Harper\u2019s first-inning homer, a 406-foot blast into the Mets bullpen hit with a bat that snapped on contact with the 96-mile-per-hour fastball, deGrom had tamed a Nationals lineup that was without Daniel Murphy, Anthony Rendon and Adam Eaton.\n\nPlaying without Jay Bruce, who a had flare-up of plantar fasciitis in his left foot, and Yoenis Cespedes, given the night off, the Mets answered Harper\u2019s home run with six unanswered runs.\n\nFrazier, who is batting .313, singled in one run in the bottom of the first and doubled in another in the third. The Mets added two more in the sixth without getting a hit, and then Cabrera, hitting .356 with a 1.041 on-base-plus-slugging percentage, belted his fourth home run of the season in the seventh to make it 6-1.\n\nBut once deGrom left the game, having allowed two singles, it all caved in on the Mets. Lugo walked Howie Kendrick to load the bases. Callaway then called upon Blevins, his left-handed specialist, to face the left-handed hitting Harper. That resulted in a two-run single, a lead cut to 6-3, and another call to the bullpen, for Ramos. He began well, striking out Ryan Zimmerman, but allowed a single to Severino, loading the bases once again. Ramos then walked pinch-hitter Matt Reynolds to force in the Nationals fourth run of the game.\n\nThat prompted Callaway to bring in his closer, Familia, who surrendered a single to Wilmer Difo, bringing home two more runs and tying the game. With no one up in the pen, Callaway was forced to stay with Familia, who hit Moises Sierra with a pitch, loading the bases yet again, and then walked Michael Taylor, forcing in the go-ahead run. The inning only ended because a screaming line drive by Trea Turner happened to be hit right at Mets left-fielder Michael Conforto.\n\nThe Nationals added their eighth run on a solo home run by Kendrick off Hansel Robles leading off the ninth.", "title": "Mets\u2019 Bullpen Collapses, Wasting Jacob deGrom\u2019s Strong Night", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-18 00:00:00", "text": "Back to their winning ways, the Mets improved to 13-4 and remained in first place in the National League East.\n\n\u201cWe just went out and took it,\u201d Mets Manager Mickey Callaway said. \u201cThat\u2019s all I can say. It was totally different than what happened the other night. We went out there and the players in the clubhouse took that game.\u201d\n\nThe huge comeback also helped Callaway avoid possible criticism for a risky move he made in the fourth inning, pulling starting pitcher Steven Matz for a pinch-hitter after Matz had retired 10 batters in a row. The Mets were trailing by a run at the time, and Callaway felt the urgency to make the move then. Unfortunately, the move did not result in a run. But when asked to defend the move, Callaway said it was only partially motivated by the desire to drive a run in. He cited the fact that Matz had thrown 33 pitches in the first inning, a workload which Callaway believes almost always catches up to a pitcher.\n\nMatz appeared to stew on the bench after the decision, but later said he understood the reasoning behind it.\n\n\u201cI definitely understand,\u201d he said. \u201cI think Mickey would understand I wouldn\u2019t be happy. As a competitor you want to go out there and go as deep in the game as you can.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe win also erased a big night for Ryan Zimmerman, the Nationals first baseman, who had a hand in all of Washington\u2019s runs: He hit two home runs, tripled, knocked in four runs and scored twice. Washington starter Tanner Roark appeared destined to make that stand up.\n\nRoark limited the Mets to two runs and two hits in seven strong innings, but the Mets attacked the Washington bullpen in the eighth \u2014 especially relief pitcher Ryan Madson, who had been effective in the Nationals\u2019 win the previous night.\n\nMichael Conforto led off the pivotal inning with a single, and Cespedes and Asdrubal Cabrera followed with hits to load the bases before Frazier came to the plate. The night before Madson had struck out Frazier with two outs and runners on base in the seventh inning, but this time Frazier lashed a ground ball up the middle, scoring Cespedes and Cabrera. He said he made adjustments after the strikeout against Madson on Tuesday.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cOne of the ugliest at-bats I ever took was yesterday,\u201d he said, explaining how he backed off the plate a little bit more to account for the sink on Madson\u2019s pitches, which helped him get into a favorable 3-1 count before striking an important blow.\n\nMadson intentionally walked Adrian Gonzalez and struck out Wilmer Flores, but Lagares roped his double into right field to put the Mets ahead. By the time Cespedes came to the plate, the Mets already led by three runs, and his homer added to the festive atmosphere already filling the stadium.\n\n\u201cThat inning was unbelievable,\u201d Callaway said.\n\nThe grand slam was the sixth of Cespedes\u2019s career (five of them with the Mets) and the third of the season already for the Mets, who came from behind to win for the eighth time in 17 games. Frazier said their ability to erase deficits comes from their belief that, as long as they are within four runs, one swing of the bat can get them back into the game.\n\nOn Wednesday it took a lot more than one swing, but as Frazier\u2019s knowing look toward Henley suggested, that is what made it so much fun, at least for the Mets.\n\n\u201cThat\u2019s the excitement we bring,\u201d Frazier said.", "title": "Mets\u2019 Huge Rally Helps Avoid a Nationals Sweep", "authors": ["David Waldstein"]} {"date": "2018-04-11 00:00:00", "text": "MIAMI \u2014 Only two weeks old, the Mets\u2019 2018 season already has a distinctly different feel from last year\u2019s campaign. After yet another comeback, a 4-1 victory over the Miami Marlins on Wednesday for their eighth consecutive win, the Mets extended their franchise-best start to 10-1. With Zack Wheeler\u2019s stellar start, the Mets\u2019 oft-injured Big Five starters finally made one mostly ceremonial turn through the rotation.\n\nAnd until Wednesday, the Mets\u2019 roster has avoided a major injury, unlike a 2017 campaign that was full of them. But that run of good fortune came to an end in the afternoon, when the team announced that catcher Travis d\u2019Arnaud had been diagnosed with a partially torn ulnar collateral ligament.\n\nD\u2019Arnaud, 29, was part of a catching platoon with Kevin Plawecki. A day after complaining to the team of right elbow soreness, d\u2019Arnaud flew to New York for examination, and in the next few days he will decide on his treatment plan, which could be rest and rehabilitation or season-ending Tommy John surgery.\n\n\u201cThat\u2019s tough,\u201d Mets Manager Mickey Callaway said. \u201cThat\u2019s a long road if he goes the surgery route.\u201d", "title": "Mets\u2019 Streak Continues, but the Injury Bug Returns", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-15 00:00:00", "text": "The Mets were never going to end up 161-1, so their second loss of the season \u2014 a 5-1 defeat to the Milwaukee Brewers at Citi Field on Saturday night \u2014 was no cause for alarm in and of itself.\n\nThe Mets, their nine-game winning streak over, remained among the hottest teams in baseball: With an 11-2 record, they had the second-best record in the majors, just behind the 12-2 Boston Red Sox.\n\nAnd yet, even during the winning streak, subtle cracks in the foundation had begun to appear. Injuries knocked out both of their catchers in recent days and their starting pitchers had the disturbing tendency to last no longer than six innings.\n\nThose cracks created a feeling of discomfort that could only have increased at the sight of Matt Harvey, the erstwhile Dark Knight of the starting rotation, giving up two long home runs on Saturday.", "title": "Mets\u2019 Winning Streak Hits a Wall Against the Brewers", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-15 00:00:00", "text": "Most news outlets in Mexico rely heavily on public advertising; few would survive without it. That dependence gives officials leverage to push their owners to run favorable stories and stop others from seeing the light of day. Editors and reporters say officials routinely shape the news, telling outlets what they should or should not report.\n\n\u201cThe government has its media darlings who act as spokespeople,\u201d said Rafael Hern\u00e1ndez, a congressman with the leftist Party of the Democratic Revolution. \u201cThey reward them with substantial advertising contracts, and they asphyxiate and punish those critical voices who aren\u2019t replicating the official message.\u201d\n\nThe ads, while intended to inform people about government services, are often used to trumpet officials\u2019 own interests.\n\nThe long-governing Institutional Revolutionary Party pioneered the use of ad spending to co-opt the news media, but the practice continued after the National Action Party won the presidency in 2000. Mr. Pe\u00f1a Nieto promised to control the ad spending when he first took office, but he has ended up outspending his predecessors.\n\nThe bill pending in Congress is a response to a Supreme Court ruling last year that ordered lawmakers to regulate the flow of government money so that it is distributed in an unbiased way. The court sided with Article 19, a free-expression group that sued the government over its ad-spending practices, and told lawmakers to pass legislation by the end of this month.\n\nCongress may meet that deadline, but advocates say the measure would do nothing to fix the problem the court identified: Free expression suffers when the government can financially reward or punish news outlets.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nUnder the bill, the interior secretary would evaluate federal advertising campaigns under the principles of \u201cefficiency, economy, transparency and honesty.\u201d Agencies would also report to the secretary on how their advertising budgets are spent.\n\nCritics say the bill is notable for what it lacks: specific regulations to promote equitable ad spending and spending limits, and enforcement powers to ensure the rules are followed. Instead, they argue, it institutionalizes discretionary public advertising.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cThe court was not asking for the formalizing of the status quo \u2014 they demanded a change,\u201d said Jan Jarab, the Mexico representative for the United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights. Instead, he said, the bill legalizes \u201cwhat the court itself called indirect restriction of free expression.\u201d\n\nSupporters of the legislation say it addresses the court\u2019s concerns while giving the government a means to promote its efforts. Setting a spending cap would be counterproductive, they say, because it would encourage agencies to spend up to the limit.\n\n\u201cThe government can and should spend less than any fixed percentage \u2014 that is why it\u2019s always better to have a flexible regime,\u201d Arturo Huicochea, a congressman with the Institutional Revolutionary Party, said last week.\n\nThe Pe\u00f1a Nieto administration spent more than twice its budget in 2016 on public-service ads, according to Fundar, a transparency group that examines government data. Last year, the administration spent as much on advertising, about $500 million, as it did to support students in its main scholarship program for public universities.\n\nFor all that spending, Mr. Pe\u00f1a Nieto\u2019s approval ratings are among the lowest since pollsters began taking the measure in the 1980s, a reflection of widespread disgust with official corruption. And as the July 1 presidential election approaches, his handpicked candidate, Jos\u00e9 Antonio Meade, is in third place.", "title": "Mexico Moves to Regulate Government Ads. Critics Say It\u2019s a Sham.", "authors": ["Paulina Villegas"]} {"date": "2018-04-04 00:00:00", "text": "She had criticized YouTube for measures that decreased the number of views of her videos, some of which contained what the site\u2019s staff said were inappropriate scenes. Dr. William Barber II, a North Carolina pastor whose sermons and outreach efforts often address civil rights.\n\n\u2022 The Times, in other words\n\nHere\u2019s an image of today\u2019s front page, and links to our Opinion content and crossword puzzles.\n\nPhoto\n\nBack Story\n\nEach week, The Times\u2019s crossword column, Wordplay, highlights the answer to one of the most difficult clues from the previous week\u2019s puzzles.\n\nThis week\u2019s word: Niobe.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe Greek mythological character Niobe was the subject of a tough clue from the March 28 crossword puzzle: \u201c \u2018Like ___, all tears\u2019: Hamlet.\u201d The word has appeared in Times crosswords 139 times.\n\nNiobe is most closely associated with tears, as noted in Shakespeare\u2019s \u201cHamlet\u201d:\n\nA little month, or ere those shoes were old With which she followed my poor father\u2019s body, Like Niobe, all tears. Why she, even she \u2014 O God, a beast that wants discourse of reason Would have mourned longer! \u2014 married with my uncle\n\nThe story of Niobe\u2019s tears began at a ceremony held to honor the Titan Leto, mother of the twin gods Apollo and Artemis. In a fit of arrogance, Niobe bragged that she was superior to Leto because she had more children (either 12 or 14, depending on the version of the myth).\n\nWhen the twins heard this, they came to earth and killed all of Niobe\u2019s children. In anguish, she ran to Mount Sipylus to beg the gods to end her pain. Zeus felt sorry for her and turned her into a rock, so she would feel no more.\n\nEven as a rock, however, Niobe\u2019s tears continued to flow, and the stream that pours from the real Weeping Rock in Manisa, Turkey, symbolizes a mother\u2019s eternal mourning.\n\nDeb Amlen contributed reporting.\n\n_____\n\nYour Morning Briefing is published weekdays and updated all morning. Contact us at briefing@nytimes.com.", "title": "Mexico, YouTube, China: Your Wednesday Briefing", "authors": ["Chris Stanford"]} {"date": "2018-04-30 00:00:00", "text": "Michael Anderson, a British director whose films included the science-fiction cult favorite \u201cLogan\u2019s Run,\u201d the World War II epic \u201cThe Dam Busters\u201d and \u201cAround the World in 80 Days,\u201d which won five Academy Awards, died on April 25 at his home on the Sunshine Coast of British Columbia, Canada. He was 98.\n\nThe cause was heart disease, his family said.\n\nMr. Anderson directed dozens of films during his five-decade career. His feature debut came in 1949 with \u201cPrivate Angelo,\u201d which he directed with Peter Ustinov.\n\n\u201cThe Dam Busters,\u201d from 1955, told the story of a daring wartime bombing raid on Germany\u2019s industrial heartland. The movie\u2019s visual flair and stirring score, by Leighton Lucas, helped make it one of Britain\u2019s best-loved war films, and its thrilling climax was an inspiration for the attack on the Death Star in the first \u201cStar Wars\u201d movie.", "title": "Michael Anderson, Director of Hit and Cult Films, Dies at 98", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-26 00:00:00", "text": "Michael Che and Colin Jost, the anchors of the Weekend Update segment on \u201cSaturday Night Live,\u201d will co-host the 2018 Emmys on Sept. 17 on NBC.\n\nThis year\u2019s Emmys will be an \u201cS.N.L.\u201d affair, as Lorne Michaels, the creator of \u201cS.N.L.,\u201d will executive produce the ceremony. (Mr. Jost and Mr. Che are also co-head writers on \u201cS.N.L.\u201d) This will be the first Emmys since 2008 to feature multiple hosts \u2014 that year, a team of reality show personalities including Tom Bergeron, Heidi Klum and Ryan Seacrest led the telecast.\n\nThe four major networks rotate broadcasting the Emmys, and typically pick as host one of their late-night personalities or an actor from one of their scripted programs. But NBC\u2019s main late-night hosts, Seth Meyers and Jimmy Fallon, have already done the job. Mr. Jost and Mr. Che will be the first current \u201cS.N.L.\u201d cast members to host the Emmys since Eddie Murphy in 1983.\n\n\u201cS.N.L.\u201d is in the midst of a resurgence, partly thanks to its spoofing of \u2014 and rivalry with \u2014 President Trump. Cohen, who has said he would \u201ctake a bullet\u201d for Mr. Trump. For years Mr. Trump treated Mr. Cohen poorly, with gratuitous insults, dismissive statements and, at least twice, threats of being fired, according to interviews with a half-dozen people familiar with their relationship.\n\n\u201cDonald goes out of his way to treat him like garbage,\u201d said Roger J. Stone Jr., Mr. Trump\u2019s informal and longest-serving political adviser, who, along with Mr. Cohen, was one of five people originally surrounding the president when he was considering a presidential campaign before 2016.\n\nNow, for the first time, the traffic may be going Mr. Cohen\u2019s way. Mr. Trump\u2019s lawyers and advisers have become resigned to the strong possibility that Mr. Cohen, who has a wife and two children and faces the prospect of devastating legal fees, if not criminal charges, could end up cooperating with federal officials who are investigating him for activity that could relate, at least in part, to work he did for Mr. Trump.", "title": "Michael Cohen Has Said He Would Take a Bullet for Trump. Maybe Not Anymore.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-25 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nMichael D. Cohen, President Trump\u2019s longtime personal lawyer, will invoke his Fifth Amendment right in a lawsuit filed against the president by Stephanie Clifford, the pornographic film star better known as Stormy Daniels.\n\nMr. Cohen\u2019s decision, disclosed Wednesday in a court filing in California, where the suit was filed, came a day before a federal judge in Manhattan was set to hold a hearing regarding materials seized from Mr. Cohen during an F.B.I. raid earlier this month.\n\nMr. Cohen cited the Manhattan investigation in his filing on Wednesday, saying that, if called as a witness in Ms. Clifford\u2019s lawsuit, \u201cI will assert my 5th Amendment rights in connection with all proceedings in this case due to the ongoing criminal investigation by the F.B.I. and U.S. Attorney for the Southern District of New York.\u201d\n\nMs. Clifford was paid $130,000 to keep quiet about claims that she had an affair with Mr. Trump. She sued last month to get out of the nondisclosure agreement she signed in October 2016, alleging that it was void because Mr. Trump had never signed it.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nCiting the Fifth Amendment in the Clifford case allows Mr. Cohen to avoid being deposed and revealing sensitive information in the more important criminal investigation. That investigation \u2014 which prosecutors say has been going on for months \u2014 became public in dramatic fashion on April 9, when agents from the New York office of the Federal Bureau of Investigation raided Mr. Cohen\u2019s office, apartment and a room at the Loews Regency Hotel he had been using. The inquiry is said to be focusing on hush-money payments that Mr. Cohen made to \u2014 or helped arrange for \u2014 Ms. Clifford and Karen McDougal, a former Playboy model who has also said she had an affair with Mr. Trump.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. For the first time in 60 years, the Metropolitan Museum of Art has reached beyond its own doors for a new leader.\n\nMax Hollein, 48, currently the director and chief executive of the Fine Arts Museums of San Francisco and a veteran of Germany\u2019s oldest art foundation, will become its 10th director this summer.\n\nBorn in Vienna, he is conversant in the old masters, modern art and Minecraft too. Fear the reaper.\n\nAn upstate New York man ate a whole Carolina Reaper \u2014 the hottest pepper in the world, according to Guinness World Records \u2014 as part of an ill-advised competition.\n\nApparently extra-sensitive to the compound that causes the pepper\u2019s burn, he ended up in the hospital with a \u201cthunderclap\u201d headache \u2014 thanks to temporarily narrowed arteries \u2014 that went on for days.\n\nWe\u2019re happy to report that he made a full recovery.\n\n____\n\nPhoto\n\n10. Federal civil rights prosecutors are recommending charges against a New York police officer in the 2014 chokehold death of Eric Garner. But top Justice Department officials have reservations.\n\nMr. Garner\u2019s final gasps of \u201cI can\u2019t breathe,\u201d captured on a cellphone video, became a rallying cry for protesters around the country, and declining to indict would be certain to ignite fresh criticism. Above, Mr. Garner\u2019s mother, Gwen Carr, holding a portrait of him in 2015.\n\nBut there are serious challenges with the case, and a state grand jury previously declined to bring charges. Deputy Attorney General Rod Rosenstein is still mulling over the decision.\n\n_____\n\nPhoto\n\n4. Memos written by the former F.B.I. director James Comey and released to Congress late Thursday offer an intimate look into the early days of the Trump White House.\n\nThey show that President Trump was preoccupied with a salacious dossier compiled by a former British spy. Read the memos here. We discussed them with Mr. Comey on our podcast \u201cThe Daily.\u201d\n\nPresident Trump responded on Twitter that the memos show no collusion with Moscow\u2019s election interference, and he accused Mr. Comey of leaking classified information.\n\n_____\n\nPhoto\n\n5. Michael Cohen, President Trump\u2019s longtime lawyer and fixer, above left, once said he would \u201ctake a bullet\u201d for his famous client.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn return, Mr. Trump treated Mr. Cohen poorly for years, with gratuitous insults, dismissive statements and, at least twice, threats of being fired, according to interviews with a half-dozen people familiar with their relationship.\n\nBut the tables may be turning in light of the Justice Department investigation into Mr. Cohen\u2019s business activities. There\u2019s a strong possibility that Mr. Cohen, who faces the prospect of devastating legal fees \u2014 if not criminal charges \u2014 could end up cooperating with investigators.\n\nMarket Snapshot View Full Overview\n\n_____\n\nPhoto\n\n6. Avicii, the Swedish D.J. and electronic dance music producer, was found dead in Muscat, the capital of Oman. He was 28.\n\nHis real name was Tim Bergling, and his songs have been streamed more than a billion times on Spotify. He was nominated for two Grammy Awards for best dance recording, in 2012 and 2013, and his most well-known song, \u201cWake Me Up,\u201d reached the No. 4 spot on Billboard\u2019s Hot 100 chart. Here\u2019s our Spotify playlist of his work.\n\nIn 2015, Forbes ranked him as the sixth-highest-paid D.J. on Earth. But he retired from international touring the following year, after a series of health scares.\n\n_____\n\nPhoto\n\n7. Palestinians protested for a fourth Friday along the security fence dividing Gaza from Israel.\n\nBy evening, the Gaza Health Ministry reported that four people had been killed by Israeli sniper fire, including a 15-year-old. That brings the death toll from the protests to at least 37. Hundreds more protesters have been injured, and Israel has drawn international censure for using live fire against the mostly unarmed protesters.\n\nCiting distress over \u201crecent events\u201d in Israel, the Israeli-American actress Natalie Portman backed out of a major award ceremony meant to honor her in Jerusalem.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n_____\n\nPhoto\n\n8. Arizona educators voted in favor of a statewide walkout, as teacher protests over low pay and school budget cuts continue to sweep across the country. Above, a rally in Phoenix earlier this month.\n\nThe spread of the protests to Arizona from West Virginia, Oklahoma and Kentucky \u2014 all Republican-dominated states with weak public-sector unions \u2014 signals the depth of frustration over years of education budget cuts.\n\nWe got thousands of responses to our callout asking teachers to describe those cuts. Educators sent us photos of decrepit classrooms and 25-year-old textbooks, and one told us how she soaks old markers to create watercolor paint.\n\n_____\n\nPhoto\n\n9. The E. coli outbreak linked to romaine lettuce has grown to 53 cases in 16 states, and federal health officials are advising consumers to avoid all romaine grown around Yuma, Ariz.\n\nBut what if it\u2019s unclear where your lettuce is from, or you\u2019re at a restaurant? Officials say you should err on the side of safety, and avoid it.\n\nTake heart: Most romaine comes from California in the spring and summer, so salad should be safer soon.\n\n_____\n\nPhoto\n\n10. Finally, it\u2019s not all bad news out there. Here are seven great things we wrote about this week, including unexpected outcomes in the Boston Marathon, an unexpected Pulitzer in the music category, and the arrival of three million honeybees in a New York City park.\n\nOn the late-night shows, the hosts were unenthused about reports that the model Karen McDougal settled a lawsuit \u2014 and gained the right to speak publicly \u2014 about her alleged affair with President Trump.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cI don\u2019t need the details,\u201d James Corden declared. \u201cHer gag order may be over, but once she describes the affair, our gagging is just beginning.\u201d\n\nHave a great weekend.\n\n_____\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story The Evening Briefing by Email Get a nightly rundown of the day\u2019s top stories, delivered to your inbox every Monday through Friday.
