Let us know at briefing@nytimes.com.", "title": "Michael Cohen, North Korea, Avicii: Your Friday Evening Briefing", "authors": ["Karen Zraick", "Brent Murray"]} {"date": "2018-04-10 00:00:00", "text": "(Want to get this briefing by email? Here\u2019s the sign-up.)\n\nGood morning.\n\nHere\u2019s what you need to know:\n\nTrump\u2019s lawyer now needs a lawyer\n\n\u2022 The F.B.I. raid on Monday on the office and hotel room of President Trump\u2019s longtime personal lawyer, Michael Cohen, opens a new front for the Justice Department in its scrutiny of Mr. Trump and his associates.\n\nThe search doesn\u2019t appear to be directly related to the Russia investigation, but it\u2019s most likely the result of information that the special counsel, Robert Mueller, uncovered and gave to prosecutors in New York. It involves possible bank fraud, a person briefed on the matter said.\n\nMr. Trump angrily denounced the raids as \u201cdisgraceful\u201d and \u201can attack on our country in a true sense.\u201d Read an annotated transcript of his remarks.", "title": "Michael Cohen, Syria, Mark Zuckerberg: Your Tuesday Briefing", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-10 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Trump values few things more than loyalty, but secrecy is one of them. For years, to keep the circle of people involved as small as possible, he chose to have Mr. Cohen serve as his legal attack dog from a perch inside Trump Tower in Manhattan instead of having outside counsel deal with his problems, according to two people familiar with their relationship.\n\nIn private, Mr. Cohen has compared himself to Tom Hagen, the smooth consigliere to the mafia family in the movie \u201cThe Godfather.\u201d His detractors have used other descriptions, with one longtime Trump associate saying that the words \u201cfinesse\u201d and Mr. Cohen have rarely been yoked together in a sentence.\n\nPhoto\n\nIf nothing else, the federal investigation, which has also drawn in a tabloid company friendly to Mr. Trump, has cast a harsh light on a partnership that, until recently, at least, worked out well for both Mr. Cohen and Mr. Trump. Mr. Cohen, who met Mr. Trump nearly two decades ago when he bought units in several Trump buildings in New York, later played the role of point man and adviser on some of Mr. Trump\u2019s efforts to expand his brand internationally.\n\nMr. Cohen also became his boss\u2019s go-to guy for cleaning up messes, from local zoning disputes to negative stories. The lawyer seemed to relish his reputation as Mr. Trump\u2019s \u201cpit bull\u201d and embraced an aggressive \u2014 some say bullying \u2014 approach to solving problems.\n\nThough Mr. Cohen has been sidelined from the Trump inner circle since the election \u2014 he never got a senior administration job, which people who know him say he expected \u2014 he has remained devoted to the president. On Twitter, he regularly speaks up on his behalf and assails critics. On Sunday, the day before the F.B.I. raid on his office, Mr. Cohen posted a quote about the importance of loyalty, adding: \u201cI will always protect our @POTUS.\u201d\n\nOne such attempt at protection was his effort in July 2015 to quash a Daily Beast article about an old complaint that Mr. Trump\u2019s first wife, Ivana, had made during their divorce, in which she claimed marital rape. She later withdrew the allegation. Mr. Cohen told a reporter for the website that marital rape was not legally possible, and threatened the reporter if the story went forward.\n\nAfter that, he mostly kept out of the public eye, helping the campaign build African-American and religious coalitions and raising money.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn recent months, Mr. Cohen\u2019s efforts to protect Mr. Trump from claims by two women of extramarital affairs have emerged as a major distraction \u2014 and possibly worse \u2014 for the White House.\n\nMr. Cohen\u2019s efforts to silence the pornographic actress Stephanie Clifford, known as Stormy Daniels, began as early as 2011, when he threatened legal action against a tabloid website that tried to publish her story. During the 2016 campaign, he says, he decided on his own to draw $130,000 from a home equity line of credit and pay Ms. Clifford to keep quiet, channeling the payment through a limited liability company.\n\nPhoto\n\nMr. Cohen has repeatedly denied any impropriety around the efforts to restrain Ms. Clifford from speaking out. And he has maintained that he was simply trying to deal with a potentially damaging story even though, he said, it was false.\n\nWhat is more, Mr. Cohen has also insisted that he made the payment to Ms. Clifford without consulting Mr. Trump. Asked recently whether he knew about the payment, Mr. Trump told reporters he did not, and referred questions to Mr. Cohen.\n\nStill, Mr. Cohen\u2019s claim that he struck a nondisclosure agreement with Ms. Clifford by himself, coupled with his effort to force her to comply with it, has exposed Mr. Trump to possibly having to testify about his knowledge of what his lawyer was up to. Ms. Clifford sued Mr. Trump last month, and her lawyer, Michael Avenatti, has filed court papers seeking to depose the president.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cAs we predicted and as the F.B.I. raid shows,\u201d Mr. Avenatti tweeted on Tuesday, \u201cMr. Cohen and Mr. Trump are in a lot of trouble.\u201d\n\nIn a text message on Tuesday, Mr. Cohen said the investigation had been difficult.\n\n\u201cThis has not been easy and has taken a terrible toll on me, my wife and children,\u201d Mr. Cohen said.\n\nAnother payment that the F.B.I. is said to be investigating, for $150,000, was made by American Media Inc., the parent company of The National Enquirer. The tabloid business bought the rights to the former Playboy model Karen McDougal\u2019s story alleging an affair with Mr. Trump and never published it. David J. Pecker, now the chairman of A.M.I., was the chief executive of Hachette in the 1990s and for a time published Mr. Trump\u2019s in-house hotel magazine.\n\nMr. Trump, who was from Queens, and the Bronx-born Mr. Pecker viewed themselves as outsiders looking in at an elitist Manhattan establishment. First at Hachette and later, when he took over chairmanship of A.M.I., Mr. Pecker acquired a reputation for buying and burying stories in ways that protected associates like Mr. Trump.\n\nPhoto\n\nSeveral people close to A.M.I. and Mr. Cohen have said that the lawyer was in regular contact with company executives during the presidential campaign, when The Enquirer regularly heralded Mr. Trump and attacked his rivals. The Times reported in February that A.M.I. had shared Ms. McDougal\u2019s allegations with Mr. Cohen, though the company said it did so only as part of efforts to corroborate her story, which it said it could not do. Ms. McDougal\u2019s lawyer at the time, Keith Davidson, and Mr. Cohen communicated around the time as she and A.M.I. were finalizing their deal.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe agreements for Ms. McDougal\u2019s and Ms. Clifford\u2019s silence formed the basis of complaints by the public interest group Common Cause to the Justice Department and the Federal Election Commission. The group claims the payments amounted to improper campaign contributions.\n\nOn Monday, as news of the F.B.I. raids broke, The Times reported that the special counsel, Robert S. Mueller III, was looking into a $150,000 donation to Mr. Trump\u2019s charitable foundation from a Ukrainian billionaire that was solicited by Mr. Cohen during the 2016 campaign. In addition, Mr. Mueller has examined Mr. Cohen\u2019s postelection role in forwarding to the administration a Ukraine-Russia peace proposal pushed by a Ukrainian lawmaker.\n\nAnd Trump-Russia investigators have also examined the 2015 Moscow deal that Mr. Cohen pushed at a time when his boss was campaigning for the Republican nomination for president.\n\nMr. Trump\u2019s long-held desire to build a Trump property in Russia found new life when Felix Sater, a friend of Mr. Cohen\u2019s and a longtime associate of Mr. Trump\u2019s, surfaced with a fresh proposal. He exchanged emails and phone calls with Mr. Cohen in late 2015 saying that he had a prospective developer lined up, and that he could use his contacts in Russia to garner Kremlin support for the project.\n\nMr. Cohen wasted no time, arranging for Mr. Trump to sign a letter of intent for the Moscow tower deal. But the project seemed to stall in the coming months.\n\nRather than let it go, Mr. Cohen reached out directly to Mr. Putin\u2019s press secretary in January 2016, asking for assistance. Later, he asserted that his effort was unsuccessful.\n\n\u201cI decided to abandon the proposal less than two weeks later for business reasons,\u201d he said, \u201cand do not recall any response to my email.\u201d", "title": "Michael Cohen, \u2018Ultimate Trump Loyalist,\u2019 Now in the Sights of the F.B.I.", "authors": ["Mike Mcintire", "Jim Rutenberg", "Maggie Haberman"]} {"date": "2018-04-05 00:00:00", "text": "In all, Conforto went 1 for 4 with a walk, two runs batted in and two runs scored, solid numbers for his first game back. The Mets had initially circled May 1 as a possible return date for Conforto, who had surgery to repair the posterior capsule that tore during his shoulder dislocation. He planned differently.\n\n\u201cI never really had May 1 in my mind,\u201d Conforto said. \u201cIt was, let\u2019s see how quickly I can get ready, stay healthy at the same time and do things the right way.\u201d\n\nAnd in spring training, Conforto passed every test the Mets gave him. Although he played in only two major league exhibition games, Conforto said he was able to log about 70 at-bats, most of them in minor league contests.\n\nMets Manager Mickey Callaway had recently suggested to Conforto that he consider making his return next week. But Conforto contended that he felt ready to face the talented Nationals, and Strasburg. Callaway was persuaded, and Conforto came off the disabled list on Thursday, the first day he was eligible to do so. And he then confirmed his healthy status with his home run.\n\n\u201cThat\u2019s extremely difficult,\u201d Callaway said. \u201cIt shows what kind of talent he is.\u201d\n\nWith Conforto once again atop the Mets\u2019 lineup, the Mets improved to 5-1 this season. But until Thursday, they had been generally winning games without major contributions from their best players, save for Yoenis Cespedes.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nConsider that Noah Syndergaard has allowed six runs over 10 innings in his two starts in 2018. Or that Jacob deGrom\u2019s first start of the season was unspectacular. Or that outfielder Jay Bruce entered Thursday\u2019s game with no home runs and only four hits in 20 at-bats. Until Thursday, the Mets\u2019 strengths had been the team\u2019s depth and bullpen, which has now logged 13 consecutive scoreless innings.\n\nBut with Conforto back, other key members of the team stepped forward, too. DeGrom produced a gutsy six-inning outing, allowing just two runs, with only one of them earned. And he escaped a bases-loaded, no-out jam in his final inning without allowing anyone to score.\n\n\u201cI had to find a way to get out of it,\u201d he said.\n\nBruce misplayed a ground ball single to right field in the first inning and then missed hitting a home run by a few feet in the second. But in the top of the seventh, he didn\u2019t come up short at all, smashing a grand slam off reliever Brandon Kintzler that pushed the game out of the Nationals\u2019 reach.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nCespedes did his part, too. He hit his third home run of the season in the fourth inning on a low pitch from Strasburg, the type Cespedes excels at clobbering.\n\nBut the best development for the Mets on Thursday was provided by Conforto. He is 25, much younger than the over-30 regulars that populate the Mets\u2019 lineup. He began last season under a cloud of doubt following a disappointing 2016 campaign, but by late April, he was thriving as the Mets\u2019 everyday leadoff hitter.\n\nFrom that perch, he hit 27 home runs, drove in 68 runs and posted a .279 batting average and team-high .939 on-base-plus-slugging percentage. He was the Mets\u2019 lone representative in July\u2019s All-Star Game. And then he went down because of one errant swing.\n\nHis return, Callaway said, adds a whole other level of anxiety for the other team.\u201d And it makes the Mets more intriguing.\n\n\u201cHis first two at-bats were his rehab and by his third at-bat he was ready,\u201d Bruce said. \u201cHe\u2019s fun to watch.\u201d", "title": "Michael Conforto Returns, the Baseball Departs, and the Mets Win Again", "authors": ["James Wagner"]} {"date": "2018-04-13 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nMichael W. Ferro Jr., the former chairman of Tronc, has agreed to sell all of his shares in the company, ending his relationship with the embattled newspaper publisher.\n\nJust months ago, Mr. Ferro had envisioned the company, whose publications include The Chicago Tribune, The Baltimore Sun and, for the moment, The Los Angeles Times, as a media powerhouse with global ambitions. But Mr. Ferro\u2019s decision to sell his shares \u2014 representing more than 25 percent of the company \u2014 signifies the further decline of Tronc. A newsroom rebellion at The Times helped lead to its pending sale and a similar revolt happened at The Tribune, whose journalists went public this week with a unionization effort.\n\nTronc\u2019s chairman, Justin Dearborn, sent an email to employees on Friday saying that the move was a \u201cprivate transaction\u201d and did not alter \u201cour business strategy\u201d or the pending sale of the California News Group, which includes The San Diego Union-Tribune and smaller publications, along with The Times.\n\nNegotiations over the sale of The Times, to Patrick Soon-Shiong, a billionaire medical entrepreneur, have dragged but the deal is still expected to be completed in the coming weeks. Dr. Soon-Shiong addressed The Times newsroom in person for the first time on Friday, and employees expressed optimism about his pending ownership.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAccording to a regulatory filing on Friday, Mr. Ferro agreed to sell more than nine million shares in Tronc to McCormick Media at a price of $23 a share. The transaction is worth more than $208 million. According to The Tribune, the buyer is related to the McCormick family, one of Chicago\u2019s prominent families and a longtime steward of the newspaper.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMr. Ferro became Tronc\u2019s chairman and biggest shareholder two years ago, after buying a stake in the company, then called Tribune Publishing, worth $44 million. Soon afterward, he overhauled the senior executive ranks and reshaped the company\u2019s board so that a majority was allied with him. Mr. Ferro stepped down last month just hours before the publication of a Fortune magazine report in which two women accused him of inappropriate sexual advances.\n\nIn selling The Times, Tronc is losing its crown jewel and a linchpin in Mr. Ferro\u2019s strategy, which included opening bureaus in Lagos and Rio de Janeiro. But over the past year, the paper became a thorn in Tronc\u2019s side. In August, Tronc ousted top members of The Times\u2019 management team and installed Ross Levinsohn, a former Yahoo executive, as publisher and Lewis D\u2019Vorkin, a former chief product officer at Forbes, as editor in chief.", "title": "Michael Ferro Agrees to Sell All of His Shares in Tronc", "authors": ["Sydney Ember"]} {"date": "2018-04-28 00:00:00", "text": "That order was almost certainly not the product of intelligence analysis about the threat posed by immigrants from certain nations, but rather the president trying to fulfill a campaign promise based on exaggerated fears about immigrants and unfair criticism of the refugee vetting system. One former senior intelligence official told me that when the ban was announced internally, everyone was simply told to get on board.\n\nI joined several other former directors and acting directors of the C.I.A., two former deputy directors, a former director of national intelligence and a former head of the National Counterterrorism Center and others in filing an amicus brief opposing the ban. The people now occupying our old positions were notably silent on the merits of the order.\n\nOver time it has become clear to me that security decisions in the Trump administration follow a certain pattern. Discussion seems to start with a presidential statement or tweet. Then follows a large-scale effort to inform the president, to impress upon him the complexity of an issue, to review the relevant history, to surface more factors bearing on the problem, to raise second- and third-order consequences and to explore subsequent moves.\n\nIt\u2019s not easy. The president by all accounts is not a patient man. According to The Washington Post, one Trump confidant called him \u201cthe two-minute man\u201d with \u201cpatience for a half page.\u201d He insists on five-page or shorter intelligence briefs, rather than the 60 pages we typically gave previous presidents. There is something inherently disturbing in that. There are some problems that cannot be simplified.\n\nSometimes, almost magically, he gets it right. The president\u2019s speech last August on Afghanistan was worth listening to, clearly the product of the traditional deliberative process where intelligence sets the picture based on the best available information, and then security agencies weigh in with views that are adjudicated by the National Security Council.\n\nBut the Afghan experience has been the exception. The president continues to attack the Iranian nuclear deal and is likely to end it even in the face of intelligence that Iran has not committed a material breach of the compact, that the deal makes it more difficult for Iran to build a weapon and that it gives us visibility into its nuclear program.\n\nThen there is Russia. The president only recently and grudgingly agreed to impose sanctions on Russians believed to have interfered in the American election, and he continues to characterize the investigation as a \u201cwitch hunt\u201d while relentlessly attacking agencies of his own administration.\n\nHe humiliated the attorney general, undercut his national security adviser and engaged in personal vendettas against senior F.B.I. officials.", "title": "Opinion | Michael Hayden: The End of Intelligence", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-06 00:00:00", "text": "As the scene turns bloody, \u201cMusic of My Mind\u201d returns in the form of the side-two closer, \u201cEvil,\u201d with Mr. Wonder singing, \u201cEvil, why have you engulfed so many hearts/evil/evil, why have you destroyed so many minds.\u201d\n\nAl Jarreau, Ahmad Jamal, Nina Simone and Dionne Warwick\n\nAlso name-dropped in the episode are these titans of black music, who serve to cement the bona fides of Benny Hope, the fictional charge and onetime virtuoso who looms over the entirety of \u201cTeddy Perkins.\u201d Allegedly friends and collaborators of Hope and his brother, these stars of jazz and R&B are referenced or seen in vintage photographs, including one that seems to have been altered from an actual photo of a young Michael Jackson. (Another features Bill Clinton.)\n\nIn one of the episode\u2019s carefully deployed comic-relief moments, Perkins also plays a voice recording reminding himself to \u201cfinish that hat for Dionne Warwick,\u201d bizarre headgear being another recurring motif in the episode. (Earlier, Darius, frustrated by a Confederate flag cap reading \u201cSouthern Made,\u201d buys it and uses a red marker to make it read \u201cU Mad.\u201d)\n\nJay-Z\n\nIn another back and forth about the merits of certain music, Perkins and Darius spar over the validity of rap, with Darius offering that sometimes \u201cpeople just want to have a good time.\u201d Perkins contends that the genre \u201cnever quite grew out of its adolescence,\u201d adding, \u201cDon\u2019t you find it insufficient as an art form?\u201d Darius shoots back: \u201cWe got Jay-Z \u2014 he\u2019s like 65,\u201d a rare light moment in this episode where it feels O.K. to exhale.\n\nSammy Sosa\n\nWhen Darius calls his friends to alert them to his peculiar situation \u2014 before laying eyes on the reclusive Benny Hope himself \u2014 he posits that Perkins and his brother are one in the same. \u201cI think Benny created Teddy to make up for the fact that he made himself look like a ghoul,\u201d he says, before offering a topical example: \u201cHe looks like somebody left Sammy Sosa in the dryer.\u201d\n\nSince his retirement, Mr. Sosa, the former Chicago Cubs slugger, has become an object of derision online as his skin has appeared lighter and lighter. (Mr. Sosa has said he uses a bleaching cream, but insisted, \u201cI don\u2019t think I look like Michael Jackson.\u201d) After Googling \u201cSammy Sosa hat\u201d \u2014 go ahead, try it \u2014 Darius\u2019s friends participate in a mini-roasting session that will ring familiar to anyone who\u2019s read a tweet about Sammy Sosa in recent years.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAs for Perkins\u2019s own apparent skin-bleaching, many viewers have guessed that the character is played by Donald Glover himself in whiteface \u2014 and, despite his Jackson-like high-pitched voice, the vocal patterns do match \u2014 although the end credits list, in a final punch line, \u201cTeddy Perkins as himself.\u201d\n\n\u2018Get Out\u2019\n\nDarius is right to worry that Perkins seems \u201clike he wanna keep me here,\u201d as he relays in his phone call. It also happens that Lakeith Stanfield, who plays Darius, played a similarly captive role in the similarly unsettling, race-oriented horror film \u201cGet Out.\u201d When Perkins snaps a Polaroid of Darius entering the peculiar gift shop he has dedicated to his brother, Darius says, \u201cI\u2019m not a big photo person,\u201d recalling his brainwashed character Logan King in Jordan Peele\u2019s \u201cGet Out.\u201d\n\nStuart Woods\n\nThe stack of books lingering near Darius\u2019s head during a crucial moment was probably not arranged haphazardly, given the attention to visual detail throughout \u201cAtlanta,\u201d and especially this episode. Among a pile that also includes Joseph E. Stiglitz\u2019s \u201cThe Great Divide: Unequal Societies and What We Can Do About Them\u201d are a few books by Stuart Woods, a novelist from Georgia who happens to have created a recurring villain named Teddy.\n\nJoe Jackson, Richard Williams, Earl Woods, Marvin Gaye Sr.\n\nIn the scene that cracks open this often-befuddling episode, Perkins, who aims to turn he and his brother\u2019s mansion into a museum, shows Darius a faceless mannequin in a suit \u2014 a stand-in for the father that drove the siblings to musical greatness. \u201cHe wanted the best out of us,\u201d Perkins explains, stating plainly that there would be physical punishment if they failed.\n\n\u201cDad used to beat you to be good at piano?\u201d Darius asks. Perkins responds: \u201cTo be good at life,\u201d adding, \u201cTo make an omelet, you have to break a few eggs.\u201d (This metaphor is particularly rich given the earlier, ominous scene of Perkins picking at an oozing soft-boiled ostrich egg.) He goes on to say that he wants the museum dedicated not only to his father, but also to Marvin Gaye Sr., Tiger Woods\u2019s father, Serena Williams\u2019s father and \u201cthe father who drops Emilio Estevez off in \u2018The Breakfast Club.\u2019\u201d\n\nWhile Darius contends later that \u201cnot all great things come from great pain \u2014 sometimes it\u2019s love,\u201d Perkins has a catchall retort in defense of his own suffering and what it wrought: \u201cMost people wouldn\u2019t understand.\u201d", "title": "Michael Jackson, Stevie Wonder and the Other Cultural Allusions in the Creepiest \u2018Atlanta\u2019 Episode Yet", "authors": ["Joe Coscarelli"]} {"date": "2018-04-02 00:00:00", "text": "Michael Tree, a founding member of the Guarneri String Quartet, the remarkably long-lived group that helped rekindle interest in chamber music in the 1960s and \u201970s and continued to perform until 2009, died on Friday at his home in Manhattan. He was 84.\n\nHis wife, Jani, said the cause was Parkinson\u2019s disease.\n\nMr. Tree, a violist, founded the Guarneri in 1964 with two friends he had studied with at the Curtis Institute of Music in Philadelphia, the violinists Arnold Steinhardt and John Dalley, along with the cellist David Soyer.\n\nWith only one change in the lineup \u2014 Peter Wiley replaced Mr. Soyer, who was a decade older than the others, in 2001 \u2014 the group performed and recorded for the next 45 years, appearing all over the world and introducing countless concertgoers to the beauties of a well-played quartet.\n\nThe four men quickly became stars on the classical music circuit. A headline on a 1971 article in The New York Times read, \u201cThe New \u2018In\u2019 Group Is the Guarneri.\u201d", "title": "Michael Tree, a Founder of the Guarneri Quartet, Dies at 84", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-25 00:00:00", "text": "On Tuesday night, the comedian Patton Oswalt was in Chicago at an event to promote \u201cI\u2019ll Be Gone in the Dark,\u201d a chilling true crime book about the Golden State Killer, who committed a string of unsolved rapes and murders in California in the 1970s and \u201980s.\n\nMr. Oswalt told the crowd that he believed the killer would be caught soon, that his time was running out.\n\nIn fact, just hours before, Joseph James DeAngelo, 72, had been arrested in California on a warrant stemming from two of the murders. On Wednesday, the authorities identified him as the Golden State Killer, citing DNA evidence connecting him to the crimes.\n\nFor Mr. Oswalt, the news of Mr. DeAngelo\u2019s arrest feels deeply personal. His late wife, the writer Michelle McNamara, had spent the final years of her life chasing the Golden State Killer, hoping to identify him in her book, \u201cI\u2019ll Be Gone in the Dark.\u201d But Ms. McNamara died before she could see the killer brought to justice, or her book published.", "title": "Michelle McNamara Died Pursuing the Golden State Killer. Her Husband, Patton Oswalt, Has Questions for Him.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-30 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Trump, meanwhile, seized on the association\u2019s backtracking, tweeting that the dinner was \u201cDEAD as we know it.\u201d That might be fine with Mr. Trump, who was roasted for his bogus birtherism claims by Seth Meyers and President Obama in 2011, as he sat rigid in the audience, turning into a tomato.\n\nWas Ms. Wolf\u2019s set vicious? Absolutely. (She called Ivanka Trump, for instance, \u201cabout as helpful to women as an empty box of tampons.\u201d)\n\nBut was it gratuitous? Not at all. It drove mercilessly toward its themes: that this administration lies; that its female members are covering for a sexist president; and that journalists have enabled it all with breathless coverage.\n\nThose are points of view, and not ones that anyone needs to agree with. But comedy\u2019s job is to have a point of view, to pick a hill to die on and defend it with furiously thrown pies. Comedy is not a Page A1 news analysis. It is not its job to call the other side for comment or throw in a \u201cto be sure\u201d paragraph for balance.\n\nMs. Wolf\u2019s most controversial jokes were about the press secretary, Sarah Huckabee Sanders, partly because she made them to her face. Ms. Sanders was on the dais in place of Mr. Trump, who counterprogrammed the dinner with a campaign rally in Michigan.\n\nThe jokes were personal, yes, because character is personal.\n\nComparing Ms. Sanders to Aunt Lydia, the rigid enforcer for a misogynist state on \u201cThe Handmaid\u2019s Tale,\u201d jabs at Ms. Sanders\u2019s role, not her looks. (The regal Ann Dowd, one of TV\u2019s best character actresses, deserves better than that assumption.) Likewise her dig that Ms. Sanders \u201cburns facts, and then she uses the ash to create a perfect smokey eye\u201d (unless \u201cperfect\u201d is now an insult). And likening her to a gym coach browbeating White House reporters was, like Melissa McCarthy\u2019s imitation of Sean Spicer, a sendup of a public figure\u2019s public performance.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMs. Sanders, after all, is an adult woman who freely chose the job of spokeswoman for the president. That job once involved defending Mr. Trump\u2019s tweet that claimed the \u201cMorning Joe\u201d co-host Mika Brzezinski came to see him \u201cbleeding badly from a face-lift.\u201d The president, Ms. Sanders said, \u201cfights fire with fire.\u201d (Ms. Brzezinski nonetheless tweeted in Ms. Sanders\u2019s support.)\n\nIf only Ms. Wolf had a Sarah Huckabee Sanders of her own. Instead she has the W.H.C.A., a group whose essential work is undermined by its highest-profile event, which is perennially trapped between provocation and caution, between the thirst to be edgy and the need to be liked.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe dinner \u2014 carried, probably unwisely, on live TV \u2014 is a multicourse tasting menu of mixed messages. It argues passionately for reporting without fear or favor, but shows reporters hobnobbing with their subjects like \u201cGreat Gatsby\u201d extras. (The Times has not attended in a decade.)\n\nIt takes some doing to emerge from one event painted as simultaneously partisan and toothless, elitist and crude, adversarial and complicit. But the dinner somehow pulls it off.\n\nMeanwhile, the monologues have become bigger than the night around them, creating a tension between the room and the home audience. In 2006, Stephen Colbert gave a brutal one in front of George W. Bush that guests also panned as harsh and disrespectful. It\u2019s now part of his standard bio-hagiography.\n\nFor the journalists, the upside is less clear. The association isn\u2019t obligated to hire a comedian at all. I\u2019m sure the greater D.C. area does not lack for magicians and fire dancers. Send the cameras away. Have a nice dinner in peace.\n\nBut to hire a comic, then renounce her for doing what she does, is weak. Any reporter knows that if you don\u2019t do your homework, the consequences are on you. And to cave under pressure undermines reporters\u2019 work by suggesting, rightly or not, that the Washington press corps can be cowed by the play-for-keeps tactics of this administration.\n\nAs for political balance, it should be noted that the W.H.C.A. invited America\u2019s premiere conservative insult comic, and he chose to do a rally in Michigan instead. Mr. Trump knows the political value of a Don Rickles zinger. He intuits that audiences grant comedians a leeway they don\u2019t to the stuffier professions.\n\nComedians are powerful \u2014 and sometimes more trusted and respected than journalists, as \u201cThe Daily Show\u201d and company have shown \u2014 because they can say uncomfortable things flat-out, ditch the euphemisms, call a \u201cfalsehood\u201d a lie. Comedy isn\u2019t reporting, but it is testimony. (Ms. Wolf ended her own routine with a straight line: \u201cFlint still doesn\u2019t have clean water.\u201d)\n\nThe irony of the association\u2019s disavowing Ms. Wolf is that her routine, whether you agree with it or not, was ultimately about defending the mission of the White House press: sticking up for the truth. Michelle Wolf had the W.H.C.A.\u2019s back Saturday night, even if it didn\u2019t have hers the day after.", "title": "Michelle Wolf Did Her Job. It\u2019s the Correspondents\u2019 Dinner That Is the Problem.", "authors": ["James Poniewozik"]} {"date": "2018-04-30 00:00:00", "text": "But as soon as a comic does his or her job too well and uses comedy to speak a truth that could jeopardize the press\u2019s attempt to befriend the political players they cover, reporters put away their cellphone cameras and cry, \u201cWho invited such a rude woman?\u201d\n\nNo one who hired Siegfried & Roy was shocked when they brought a tiger onstage. So you shouldn\u2019t be shocked if you book a comedian and she points out that the emperor has no clothes. Or when she points below the emperor\u2019s waistline and makes a rude joke.\n\nContrary to what several prominent journalists said, the transcript shows that Michelle Wolf did not make a single joke at the expense of Sarah Huckabee Sanders\u2019s physical appearance. Rather, she did something much worse in the eyes of those assembled: She ridiculed the White House press secretary\u2019s mendacity, hypocrisy and complicity. And in a searing, brutally funny segment, she criticized the willingness of the press to play along:\n\n\u201cYou guys are obsessed with Trump. Did you use to date him? Because you pretend like you hate him, but I think you love him. I think what no one in this room wants to admit is that Trump has helped all of you. He couldn\u2019t sell steaks or vodka or water or college or ties or Eric, but he has helped you. He\u2019s helped you sell your papers and your books and your TV. You helped create this monster, and now you\u2019re profiting off of him. And if you\u2019re gonna profit off of Trump, you should at least give him some money because he doesn\u2019t have any.\u201d\n\nNo wonder the crowd seemed so uncomfortable.\n\nSome people noted that Ms. Wolf\u2019s routine was poorly received in the Hilton ballroom itself. But watching her at home I recognized exactly what she was doing. Every performer who has done comedy on television knows that the people in the studio don\u2019t really matter. They\u2019re uncomfortable, they\u2019re tense, and they have to be polite because they\u2019re sitting six inches away from Chris Christie. You\u2019re never getting a real laugh out of them. Instead, you focus on the audience that counts: the folks at home. And the folks at home don\u2019t want comedy that\u2019s polite and tasteful, and secures them access to an interview next Wednesday \u2014 they want comedy that stands on the rooftop and calls out hypocrisy and deceit at the top of its lungs.\n\nThe way the press corps treats the brilliant comedians it hires is an old joke by now, and we all know the punch lines. In 2016, when Larry Wilmore tore into the cable news industry\u2019s history of racist coverage and greeted President Obama in a manner some took offense to, he was deemed to have gone \u201ctoo far.\u201d In 2006, Stephen Colbert mercilessly mocked President George W. Bush from just feet away. Yet that now legendary performance was very poorly received at the time.", "title": "Opinion | Michelle Wolf Did What Comedians Are Supposed to Do", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-29 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cIt was personally offensive,\u201d Brian Kilmeade, a co-host of \u201cFox & Friends,\u201d said in the ballroom, minutes after Ms. Wolf ended her set.\n\n\u201cTo me, that was an attack to impress Jon Stewart and Stephen Colbert,\u201d Mr. Kilmeade added, previewing a line of criticism that would be dominant on Fox News by Sunday morning. \u201cCongratulations, when the three of you go out to dinner, I\u2019m sure you\u2019ll be laughing a lot. But in terms of the people here and the people at home \u2014 totally offensive, horrible choice. In fact, it\u2019s the reason why the president didn\u2019t want to go.\u201d\n\nCritics of President Trump \u2014 who is no stranger to lobbing insult-comic punch lines at his opponents and is the first president to outright skip the Correspondents\u2019 gala since Jimmy Carter \u2014 wondered what the fuss was about.\n\n\u201cBefore we criticize Michelle Wolf, let\u2019s remember that Donald Trump has done and said some of the crudest things that any president in history has ever done,\u201d said Howard Fineman, an analyst at NBC News and MSNBC. \u201cJust have a little perspective.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nBy Sunday, Ms. Wolf, a contributor to \u201cThe Daily Show With Trevor Noah\u201d whose Netflix talk show starts in May, had seemingly scandalized Washington\u2019s intersecting political and media tribes.\n\nIn one Twitter exchange, Sean Spicer, the former White House press secretary \u2014 who recently turned up at Madame Tussauds to promote a wax statue of Melania Trump \u2014 described the dinner as \u201ca disgrace.\u201d\n\n\u201cThank you!\u201d Ms. Wolf replied.\n\nProminent Washington journalists, meanwhile, took pains to defend Ms. Sanders \u2014 earning their own opprobrium from some liberals who asked why reporters were sticking up for an administration that routinely impugns their work.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAndrea Mitchell, the NBC News correspondent, tweeted that an \u201capology is owed\u201d to the press secretary. Her network colleague Mika Brzezinski wrote that \u201cwatching a wife and mother be humiliated on national television for her looks is deplorable.\u201d\n\nSeveral reporters who cover the White House approached Ms. Sanders in the Hilton ballroom to express sympathy in the immediate aftermath of Ms. Wolf\u2019s monologue. Later, at a windswept after party hosted by NBC News, Ms. Sanders appeared in good spirits as reporters swarmed her. (She even took time to chastise one journalist for asking a question at a news conference that she disliked.)\n\nLate on Sunday, Margaret Talev, president of the Correspondents\u2019 Association, issued a statement acknowledging \u201cdismay\u201d from members about Ms. Wolf\u2019s performance.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cLast night\u2019s program was meant to offer a unifying message about our common commitment to a vigorous and free press,\u201d Ms. Talev wrote. \u201cUnfortunately, the entertainer\u2019s monologue was not in the spirit of that mission.\u201d\n\nMs. Talev said her organization would consider new ideas about the future format of the dinner \u2014 a sentiment echoed by Mr. Trump in a tweet about a half-hour later.\n\n\u201cThe White House Correspondents\u2019 Dinner was a failure last year, but this year was an embarrassment to everyone associated with it,\u201d Mr. Trump wrote on Twitter, adding: \u201cPut Dinner to rest, or start over!\u201d\n\nGoing back to Stephen Colbert\u2019s blistering monologue in 2006 \u2014 delivered as President George W. Bush sat unsmiling a few feet away \u2014 the comic portion of the Correspondents\u2019 dinner has courted controversy. Roast-style humor is an odd fit for protocol-oriented Washington, and some comedians praised Ms. Wolf for discomfiting the audience of elite journalists and administration officials.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cIf you want to focus on the journalism do a boring award show,\u201d tweeted Kathy Griffin, the comedian whose own brush with crude presidential humor \u2014 posting a photo of herself holding what appeared to be Mr. Trump\u2019s decapitated head \u2014 led to her losing a CNN job. \u201cJournalism is all about the 1st amendment. If you don\u2019t see the import of what @michelleisawolf did tonight then you don\u2019t get it.\u201d\n\nThe doyens of Washington did not agree. Mike Allen, a prime voice of the city\u2019s establishment, declared in his newsletter on Sunday: \u201cMedia hands Trump embarrassing win.\u201d There were even whispers about a revolt against the Correspondents\u2019 Association by news organizations displeased by the night\u2019s events. (The New York Times stopped attending the dinner in 2008.)\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMs. Talev, speaking on CNN on Sunday, noted that the dinner had praised Mr. Trump for meeting with aspiring journalists at the White House and featured the story of an Egyptian social activist who was freed from prison with the help of the Trump administration.\n\nShe said she regretted that Ms. Wolf\u2019s monologue had overshadowed the rest of the evening, but added: \u201cWhen the entertainer is a comedian \u2014 as has been the case for the last 30 years or so \u2014 they are often controversial, they are often to some extent polarizing, or provocative, and it\u2019s a night about free speech.\u201d\n\nMs. Wolf\u2019s 19-minute set also took on Democrats and the news media itself. She quipped that \u201cit\u2019s kind of crazy that the Trump campaign was in contact with Russia when the Hillary campaign wasn\u2019t even in contact with Michigan,\u201d and joked about CNN\u2019s hyperactive approach to coverage.\n\n\u201cYou guys love breaking news, and you did it, you broke it!\u201d Ms. Wolf said. \u201cGood work! The most useful information on CNN is when Anthony Bourdain tells me where to eat noodles.\u201d\n\nHer most cutting joke came at the end, when the 32-year-old comic took direct aim at the journalists in the room. Mr. Trump, she said, \u201chas helped you sell your papers and your books and your TV. You helped create this monster and now you are profiting from him.\u201d\n\nKyle Pope, the editor of the Columbia Journalism Review, posted a message on Twitter suggesting that even journalists had had enough of the annual ritual. \u201cThe #WHCD debacle was inevitable, destined to be either sycophantic, on one extreme, or mean spirited, on the other. Neither is a good look at a time when trust in media is tenuous. Can we finally all agree to put an end to this thing?\u201d\n\nSpeaking with The Times in February, after her selection as the evening\u2019s entertainer was announced, Ms. Wolf said that comedians at the Correspondents\u2019 dinner \u201care not necessarily performing for the room.\u201d\n\n\u201cYou\u2019re performing for everyone that\u2019s watching it,\u201d Ms. Wolf said, adding: \u201cIf you\u2019re willing to say something when someone\u2019s not there, you should definitely be willing to say it to their face.\u201d", "title": "Michelle Wolf Sets Off a Furor at White House Correspondents\u2019 Dinner", "authors": ["Michael M. Grynbaum"]} {"date": "2018-04-25 00:00:00", "text": "Ms. Wolf is no fan of President Trump\u2019s, and was relieved when it was announced that for the second year, he would not be attending the dinner.\n\n\u201cI thought, oh, thank God, I don\u2019t have to hear him eat,\u201d she said.\n\nStill, she said there was limited value in standing in front of a crowd and cracking a bunch of knee-jerk jokes about Mr. Trump.\n\n\u201cThe audience cheers, but that isn\u2019t comedy,\u201d she said. \u201cIt\u2019s just a rally.\u201d\n\nMs. Wolf said she was not interested in what she called \u201ccool-teacher comedy \u2014 we\u2019re going to learn and have fun at the same time.\u201d\n\n\u201cYou don\u2019t want to say what people want you to say,\u201d she added. \u201cYou want to say what people didn\u2019t know they wanted you to say.\u201d\n\nMs. Wolf, who grew up in Hershey, Pa., has been following her own muse since she quit her career in finance (where she\u2019d worked at banks like Bear Stearns and JPMorgan Chase) to take improv classes at Upright Citizens Brigade Theater and the Pit in New York.\n\n\u201cEventually people in improv were like, \u2018You\u2019re more of a stand-up,\u2019\u201d Ms. Wolf said. \u201cI think they were gently trying to tell me I was selfish.\u201d", "title": "Michelle Wolf\u2019s Next Gig Is Hard Work: Making Washington Laugh", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-31 00:00:00", "text": "Cameron Krutwig, a freshman center, led Loyola with 17 points, while Clayton Custer, a redshirt junior, had 15 points on nine shots. On defense, the Ramblers limited Michigan\u2019s ordinarily electric shooting through much of the game with their positionless defense.\n\nBut Loyola had no answer for Wagner. He had 11 rebounds and 11 points in the first half, for 50 percent of the Wolverines\u2019 scoring. Loyola\u2019s help defense effectively prevented Michigan from getting the ball to him inside, so the Wolverines\u2019 offense consisted largely of shooting 3-pointers (they attempted 13), missing them (they made just two) and letting Wagner get the offensive rebound for the putback.\n\nThis was, in its way, part of the plan, Michigan Coach John Beilein revealed after the game. \u201cBecause they\u2019re switching, we said, \u2018Moe, you\u2019ve just got to roll more, slip more, and get down there and clean up any rebounds you can get, because they\u2019ve got a 6-foot guy on you,\u2019\u201d Beilein said.\n\nWagner finished the game with monster statistics: 24 points and 15 rebounds.\n\nMichigan slowly clawed its way back in the second half, tying the game, 47-47, with under seven minutes left. Then came the blitz, including a run during which Loyola committed turnovers on six consecutive possessions.\n\nWhen Wagner hit a 3-pointer (he had three of them) with 2 minutes, 59 seconds left, it put Michigan up by 8, and a clearly exhausted Loyola seemed done for.\n\nPhoto\n\nMichigan\u2019s defense has been its calling card this year thanks to a new assistant coach, Luke Yaklich, who was in the high school ranks as recently as 2013. Yaklich reinvigorated the Wolverines\u2019 defense, making it one of the best in the country. In the second half, his influence was especially evident as Michigan forced 11 turnovers from Loyola\u2019s veteran players.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cWe made a concerted effort to take away the 3,\u201d Beilein said. The Ramblers made just one 1 of their 10 shots from outside the arc.\n\nNear the end, Wagner hustled out of bounds for the ball, leaping off the Alamodome\u2019s elevated court. The television analyst Grant Hill, who won two N.C.A.A. championships at Duke, high-fived Wagner on his way back, almost as if welcoming him to the club.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMichigan will be seeking its second title on Monday, having beaten Seton Hall in 1989. It has played in the championship game five other times, in 2013 plus 1965, \u201976, \u201992 and \u201993, but the appearances in the \u201990s, with the so-called Fab Five, were erased by the N.C.A.A. because of infractions.\n\nIt is hard to imagine fans of any team recalling this tournament years from now and not almost instantly thinking of the Ramblers.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s special to see kind of what stage that we were able to get to,\u201d the Loyola senior Ben Richardson said. \u201cAnd despite going out this way, we\u2019re going to never forget this. And I think a lot of people will remember this run for a long time.\u201d\n\nWagner, with the kind of aplomb he showed on the court, gave Loyola its due.\n\n\u201cI don\u2019t really like the saying \u2018Cinderella story,\u2019\u201d he said, \u201cbecause it always includes somehow that they\u2019re not supposed to be there. And the way they\u2019re playing \u2014 it\u2019s incredible.\u201d", "title": "Michigan Ends Loyola-Chicago\u2019s Long, Wild Ride in the Final Four", "authors": ["Marc Tracy"]} {"date": "2018-04-08 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cWe did not cause the man-made water disaster, therefore adequate resources should continue being provided until the problem is fixed and all the lead and galvanized pipes have been replaced,\u201d she said in a statement.\n\nLines of cars formed outside distribution points on Friday as residents rushed to load up on the last of the free bottles.\n\nJoyce Wilson, 62, who lives in Flint, said she did not trust the water that flows to her taps \u2014 not for drinking, bathing or even watering her garden, where she grows food. She has been visiting the free water distribution centers for two years and bringing cases to her older or ailing relatives, friends and neighbors.\n\n\u201cThis weekend the lines are so long, it\u2019s unreal,\u201d she said. \u201cIt\u2019s like all of a sudden, panic has set in.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Climate Fwd: Sign up for our newsletter to get our latest stories about climate change \u2014 along with answers to your questions and tips on how to help. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nAlthough state officials said Flint\u2019s water supply met federal standards, the water can still pick up lead when it flows through the thousands of lead or galvanized steel lines that remain in the city.\n\nFlint is working with contractors to replace all of the affected lines by 2020. Just over 6,200 have been replaced so far, said Steve Branch, the acting city administrator. An estimated 12,000 could remain.\n\nThe governor\u2019s statement said Flint residents could still obtain free water filters.\n\nMichigan taxpayers have \u201cprovided more than $350 million to Flint, in addition to the $100 million from the federal government,\u201d the statement said. \u201cThe funding is helping with water quality improvements, pipe replacement, health care, nutritional food distribution, educational resources, job training and creation, and more.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nFlint has struggled with its water crisis since 2014, when state-appointed officials began using the Flint River, rather than the more expensive Detroit water system, as a source for tap water that was not properly treated before it reached residents\u2019 homes.\n\nOne study published in the American Journal of Public Health in 2016 found that the percentage of Flint children with elevated levels of lead in their blood doubled after the switch, which has also been linked to 12 fatal cases of Legionnaires\u2019 disease.\n\nThe city switched back to the Detroit water system in 2015, and the crisis resulted in felony charges against emergency managers who had been appointed by Mr. Snyder to help run the city.\n\nFlint was put under emergency management in 2011 because it was struggling financially, but Michigan\u2019s treasurer, Nick Khouri, said this past week that he would sign a resolution to release the city from state oversight.\n\nCity officials remain concerned about access to safe water now that the distribution of free bottles has ended.\n\n\u201cThere are still questions that remain,\u201d Dr. Pamela Pugh, Flint\u2019s chief public health adviser, said in a statement. \u201cWe have not received clear steps as to how the remaining lead in Flint schools will be remediated or how ongoing monitoring will continue for our most vulnerable populations.\u201d\n\nMs. Wilson said that after years of watching people suffer in her hometown, she was disappointed with officials at both the state and local levels.\n\n\u201cI just have no trust in anything they say, because they make these claims and then shortly thereafter, it turns out that they weren\u2019t telling the truth,\u201d she said.", "title": "Michigan Will No Longer Provide Free Bottled Water to Flint", "authors": ["Jacey Fortin"]} {"date": "2018-04-01 00:00:00", "text": "The seeds they beat to get here? Nos. 16, 9, 5, 3 and 1. In two of those games, the Wildcats won by 12; in the others, they won by more.\n\nVillanova\u2019s adjusted offensive efficiency, per the analytics site KenPom.com, is the second-best in college basketball since at least 2002 (the only superior team in that category being the 2015 runner-up, Wisconsin). That may be why the Wildcats barely even talk about it.\n\n\u201cWe don\u2019t pride ourselves on shooting the ball well,\u201d Spellman said after Saturday\u2019s 95-79 humiliation of Kansas in the semifinal. \u201cWe pride ourselves on defending and rebounding, and that\u2019s our true measure of success in playing Villanova basketball.\u201d\n\nIn terms of Xs and Os, this is a compelling matchup. Villanova accrues a greater share of its baskets from 3-point range than nearly every other college basketball team. Michigan\u2019s opponents score fewer of their points from 3-point range than nearly every other college basketball team, according to KenPom.com.\n\nGoing into the Loyola game, Michigan\u2019s coaches spoke of the importance of limiting the Ramblers\u2019 2-point shooting percentage because they took it almost as a given that they would be successful at stopping them from deep \u2014 it is what Michigan does.\n\nSo, despite the fact that, as Kansas Coach Bill Self said of Villanova on Saturday night: \u201cThey\u2019d be hard for anybody to deal with if they shoot the ball like that\u201d \u2014 \u201cthat\u201d being 18-for-40 from 3-point range \u2014 it is likely the Wildcats won\u2019t shoot the ball like that Monday against Michigan.\n\nThen again, in their round-of-8 game versus Texas Tech \u2014 like Michigan, a No. 3 seed \u2014 the Wildcats made just 4 of 24 three-point attempts. It did not matter. They outrebounded Texas Tech, a physical Big 12 team, 51-33. They got to the free-throw line, and made 29 of 35 foul shots. They limited the Red Raiders to 33.3 percent from the field. With their dominant hand tied behind their back, they won comfortably, 71-59.", "title": "Michigan vs. Villanova: Keys to the N.C.A.A. Final", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-26 00:00:00", "text": "Mulvaney isn\u2019t just the budget director. He is also the interim director of the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, the banking watchdog that the Obama administration and Elizabeth Warren created after the financial crisis. The bureau, often called the C.F.P.B., has had an impressive record since its founding, curtailing abusive lending practices by banks, among other things. It\u2019s helped level the playing field \u2014 not all the way, to be sure \u2014 between big, powerful companies and American families.\n\nBut Mulvaney has set out to dismantle the C.F.P.B. He has, as The Times reports: \u201cfrozen all new investigations and slowed down existing inquiries by requiring employees to produce detailed justifications\u201d and \u201cscaled back efforts to go after payday lenders, auto lenders and other financial services companies accused of preying on the vulnerable.\u201d\n\nOn Tuesday, he took another step, telling gleeful banking executives that he was interested in shutting down a public database where people can lodge complaints against financial companies. Bureau officials had used the database to figure out when they needed to investigate a company and to gather evidence. Mulvaney dismissively referred to it as \u201ca Yelp for financial services sponsored by the federal government.\u201d Aaron Klein of the Brookings Institution told The Wall Street Journal\u2019s Yuka Hayashi that the database was \u201can incredibly important tool that empowers consumers.\u201d\n\nFinally, in the pettiest move of all, Mulvaney said he would change the order of the words in the bureau\u2019s name \u2014 to the bulkier \u201cBureau of Consumer Financial Protection.\u201d Administration officials acknowledged to The Times that the move was meant \u201cto diminish the agency\u2019s public profile.\u201d It also seems like an unsubtle attempt to erase the old C.F.P.B. from everyone\u2019s memory.\n\nThe whole episode fits a Trump administration pattern. In describing his behavior with lobbyists, Mulvaney did something outrageous and worthy of attention. And yet he also managed to divert attention from policies doing real damage to Americans.", "title": "Opinion | Mick Mulvaney Tells the Truth", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-02 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Mulvaney also recommended the creation of an inspector general\u2019s office to monitor the activities of the bureau.\n\n\u201cBy structuring the bureau the way it has, Congress established an agency primed to ignore due process and abandon the rule of law in favor of bureaucratic fiat and administrative absolutism,\u201d Mr. Mulvaney said.\n\nRepublican lawmakers have tried for years \u2014 without success \u2014 to curb the powers of the agency, which was authorized in 2010 and enjoys broad support among congressional Democrats.\n\nWhile Mr. Mulvaney \u2014 or the person that Mr. Trump eventually selects to succeed him \u2014 can weaken enforcement efforts, the fixes that he called for would require legislation. The chances of this are slim, as Democrats in the Senate have vowed to block any bills that would harm the consumer bureau.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nOn Monday, critics of Mr. Mulvaney assailed the report as an affront to vulnerable consumers.\n\n\u201cHe wants to take away the bureau\u2019s independence and then make it harder for it to do its job,\u201d said Mike Litt of the United States Public Interest Research Groups, a consumer advocacy organization. \u201cRecommendations in today\u2019s report, if implemented, would stop the agency from protecting consumers and prevent it from ever being effective in the future.\u201d\n\nBut the banking industry, which has chafed at the bureau\u2019s enforcement powers and its approach, has been more than pleased with the direction that Mr. Mulvaney has been charting. On Monday, bank lobbyists cheered his efforts to deregulate.\n\n\u201cWe strongly believe an independent, bipartisan commission at the C.F.P.B. \u2014 not subject to the political shifts of changing administrations \u2014 is the best way forward to provide for accountability, certainty and stability at the C.F.P.B.,\u201d Richard Hunt, president of the Consumer Bankers Association, said.\n\nNext week, Mr. Mulvaney is scheduled to appear before Congress to testify about the state of the consumer bureau. The appearance will likely set up a public showdown with Senator Elizabeth Warren, the Massachusetts Democrat who helped create the agency in the wake of the 2008 financial crisis and who has been its most vocal and influential defender.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHouse Republicans passed legislation last year that would defang the bureau, but even they appear resigned to the fact that it is likely to survive largely intact. The House is considering how to move forward with a more modest bill to loosen regulations on small and medium-size banks that the Senate passed with bipartisan support in March.\n\nLast month, Representative Jeb Hensarling of Texas, the Republican chairman of the House Financial Services Committee and a longtime proponent for curbing the agency\u2019s power, said he was willing to get behind a financial regulation bill that left the consumer bureau untouched. The reason: He supports Mr. Mulvaney.\n\n\u201cRight now, I\u2019m very happy,\u201d he said of the bureau\u2019s direction under Mr. Mulvaney. \u201cMay he rule forever.\u201d", "title": "Mick Mulvaney, Consumer Bureau\u2019s Chief, Urges Congress to Cripple Agency", "authors": ["Alan Rappeport"]} {"date": "2018-04-27 00:00:00", "text": "Well, not everything. Mr. Trump pointed out that he himself participated in the pay-to-play game, but from the perspective of a person seeking access: \u201cAs a businessman and a very substantial donor to very important people, when you give, they do whatever the hell you want them to do.\u201d But in his campaign rhetoric, he was going to get rid of the permanent political class \u2014 people like lobbyists and career politicians and those who got fat and rich off the government.\n\nTrump administration officials were quick to point out that this was only part of Mr. Mulvaney\u2019s quote. In the other part, Mr. Mulvaney said that he was willing to meet with constituents without regard to their donor status: \u201cIf you came from back home and sat in my lobby, I talked to you without exception, regardless of the financial contributions.\u201d\n\nI would congratulate the man, but that\u2019s how America is supposed to work. As an elected official from the state of South Carolina, his salary was paid by the hard-earned taxes of people like those in his state. Since he works for \u201cwe the people,\u201d it would be unseemly for him to do anything but take a meeting from the people back home. Bringing that up as a point of pride shows that he really doesn\u2019t understand how self-government is supposed to work. He doesn\u2019t get a gold star for not shaking down his constituents.\n\nThe problem with Mr. Mulvaney\u2019s rhetoric is that it casts doubt on his actions as head of the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau. He has consistently used his power to either close or significantly reduce the many investigations into payday loans and discriminatory lending. The payday loan industry happened to give Mr. Mulvaney approximately $32,000 during his last election cycle. Maybe it gave to him because its members know and agree with his beliefs. But there\u2019s a chicken-and-egg problem here. If Mr. Mulvaney gets up in front of a bunch of bankers and openly admits he meets only with those with deep pockets, it taints his whole decision-making process.\n\nHe\u2019s not faring any better at the Office of Management and Budget.
