Revenue rose 16 percent to $26.8 billion in the quarter, exceeding the Wall Street consensus forecast of nearly $25.8 billion.\n\nMicrosoft\u2019s earnings per share increased 36 percent to 95 cents a share, well above the analysts\u2019 average estimate of 85 cents a share, compiled by Thomson Reuters.", "title": "Microsoft\u2019s Cloud Has Business Booming Again", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-05 00:00:00", "text": "PASADENA, Calif. \u2014 When top students from the sun-dappled suburbs that surround Pasadena, Calif., graduate from high school, they are expected to go to colleges that are prestigious, pricey and often far away. Last year, seniors from La Ca\u00f1ada High School, one of the highest rated in the state, fanned across the country to M.I.T., the University of Michigan and Yale.\n\nBut 18-year-old Annie Shahverdian, the daughter of a commercial real estate agent and a nursing administrator, started her higher ed journey closer to home, 15 minutes down the road at the local community college. To save money, she is planning to spend two years at Pasadena City College, a two-year public institution, before heading to what she hopes will be a top four-year university where she will earn her bachelor\u2019s degree.\n\n\u201cMy parents don\u2019t want to just throw money around now,\u201d Ms. Shahverdian said as she walked across Pasadena\u2019s 53-acre campus, heading toward her English class. \u201cI\u2019m getting a great education at a fraction of the cost.\u201d\n\nCommunity colleges have long catered to low-income students who dream of becoming the first in their families to earn a college degree. And for many, that remains their central mission. But as middle- and upper-middle-class families like the Shahverdians face college prices in the hundreds of thousands of dollars, more of them are looking for ways to spend less for their children\u2019s quality education.", "title": "Middle-Class Families Increasingly Look to Community Colleges", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-24 00:00:00", "text": "They had fled El Salvador because of a gang\u2019s death threats, they said, and were planning to apply for asylum when they crossed into the United States from Tijuana. Organizers had encouraged participants to seek asylum at Tijuana rather than Mexicali because it was easier to arrange for volunteer lawyers.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cWe\u2019ve almost arrived in the United States,\u201d Mr. Claros said, smiling broadly at his brother. But then he considered the legal road ahead, and his smile faded.\n\n\u201cThere\u2019s still a long way to go,\u201d he said.\n\nAnother several hundred caravan members were expected to follow later in the day in a separate convoy of buses, and a third contingent, traveling atop freight trains, later this week.\n\nThe group of migrants set off from Tapachula, Mexico, on March 25, and moved north, more or less en masse, by foot, hitchhiking, on buses and by stowing away on trains.\n\nSuch mass migrations have become an annual rite, usually around Easter week, with the size of the group providing protection against the criminals who lurk along the path and helping to draw public attention to their plight.\n\nThis year\u2019s group, which numbered upward of 1,200 in the journey\u2019s early stages, was perhaps the largest on record. Still, like all the caravans that have come before, this one might easily have gone unnoticed had it not ended up on \u201cFox & Friends,\u201d a favorite television show of President Trump.\n\nThe president posted a series of messages on Twitter that warned of dangers from the group. Mr. Trump used the caravan as a cudgel against the Mexican government, accusing it of doing little to curb illegal northward migration, and as grounds to deploy the National Guard to the southwest border of the United States.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWith the caravan nearing the Mexico-United States border this week, Mr. Trump returned to the subject, saying on Twitter on Monday that he had instructed the Department of Homeland Security \u201cnot to let these large Caravans of people into our Country.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cIt is a disgrace,\u201d he declared.\n\nHe also took another shot at Mexico, saying that it \u201cmust stop people from going through Mexico and into the U.S.\u201d and proposing that the matter be \u201ca condition\u201d of a renegotiated North American Free Trade Agreement.\n\nAbout an hour later, Luis Videgaray, Mexico\u2019s foreign secretary, rejected Mr. Trump\u2019s remarks as \u201cunacceptable.\u201d\n\n\u201cMexico decides its immigration policy in a sovereign manner,\u201d Mr. Videgaray said.\n\nTwo members of Mr. Trump\u2019s cabinet, Attorney General Jeff Sessions and the secretary of homeland security, Kirstjen Nielsen, also weighed in with tough statements about the caravan.\n\nMr. Sessions said he had ensured there would be \u201csufficient prosecutors\u201d and immigration judges to defend the nation\u2019s legal interests and handle the arriving migrants. The migrants in the caravan, he said, \u201cignored the willingness of the Mexican government to allow them to stay in Mexico\u201d and their arrival at the border was \u201ca deliberate attempt to undermine our laws and overwhelm our system.\u201d\n\nMr. Sessions\u2019s statement did not seem to allow for the possibility that some members of the caravan might have legitimate claims to asylum in the United States.\n\nCaravan organizers estimated that 100 to 300 of the migrants intended to petition for asylum when they presented themselves to American authorities at the border. The United States grants people asylum if they can prove persecution on account of their race, religion, nationality, political belief or other factors, a process that can take years.\n\nSince Mr. Trump took office last year, the administration has not ordered customs officials to turn away asylum seekers. But it has said that the asylum system encourages undocumented immigrants without valid claims to swarm the border.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Race/Related Newsletter Join a deep and provocative exploration of race with a diverse group of New York Times journalists. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nIn recent years, judges have approved fewer than half of all asylum requests, and the percentage of Central Americans who are approved is substantially lower. Many asylum seekers from Central America claim they have been victimized by gangs, which is harder to prove than political persecution.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIf their petitions are denied, asylum seekers can be deported. But since many are released while their cases are pending, some never return to court and evade deportation. The Trump administration has said that asylum seekers should be released less often, and lawyers have reported that more applicants are being detained.\n\nTristan Call, a volunteer with Pueblo Sin Fronteras, a transnational advocacy group that coordinated the caravan, said Mr. Trump\u2019s denunciation of its members reflected \u201ca policy to punish the least protected people.\u201d\n\nMexican authorities have defended their handling of the caravan, saying that they have acted within Mexican and international law. Many of the current caravan participants received temporary travel documents from the Mexican government providing protection from deportation and giving them several weeks to apply for legal immigration status in Mexico or leave the country.\n\nThe advocacy group\u2019s original plan was to push the caravan as far north as it could, accompanying those migrants who planned to settle in northern Mexican cities or hoped to cross, legally or not, into the United States. Based on such movements in the past, the organizers expected the vast majority of participants to drop out along the way, either to travel separately in smaller, more nimble groups or to stay in Mexico.\n\nGiven the size of this year\u2019s group and the intense international focus that Mr. Trump\u2019s Twitter posts brought, the coordinators announced that they would disband the caravan once it reached Mexico City, the capital.\n\nBut the caravan kept gathering momentum, which ultimately carried it beyond the capital.\n\n\u201cA large number of caravan members remained organized themselves and did not want to break up,\u201d said Alex Mensing, project coordinator for Pueblo Sin Fronteras. \u201cSince they stuck together, we made the decision to keep going with them.\u201d", "title": "Migrant Caravan Arrives at U.S. Border, but Long Road Awaits", "authors": ["Kirk Semple"]} {"date": "2018-04-29 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cBut I\u2019m going with the feeling that it\u2019s going to be worth the effort,\u201d said Mr. Quintanillo. He said his family were fleeing a gang that had attacked him and killed a close relative. \u201cIn the name of God, everything is possible,\u201d he said.\n\nOverlaying the personal struggles was a dense tangle of politics and policy \u2014 the ill will between Mr. Trump and Mexico that began the day he announced his candidacy; the acrimony between Mr. Trump and Gov. Jerry Brown of California over immigration; the politics of sanctuary cities; and the political logjam in Congress over funding Mr. Trump\u2019s proposed border wall.\n\n[Inside an Immigrant Caravan: Women and Children, Fleeing Violence]\n\nIt all plays out in the context of Mr. Trump\u2019s goal of making immigration a galvanizing issue in the midterm elections with Republicans worried about losing control of the House and perhaps the Senate.\n\nHeather Cronk, co-director of Showing Up for Racial Justice, one of several American advocacy groups that have been helping the caravan and its participants, traveled to Tijuana to support the migrants in the final stretch.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cFor us, this is all about who we are as a country,\u201d she said. She added: \u201cThis is an existential moment. This is a spiritual moment. I want it to be true that when we say, \u2018Liberty and justice for all,\u2019 we mean it.\u201d\n\nIt is a debate Mr. Trump apparently relishes.\n\nWith the migrants on the doorstep of the United States, Mr. Trump, in a tweet last week, ratcheted up his rhetoric, vowing \u201cnot to let these large Caravans of people into our Country.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Trump repeatedly came back to immigration issues at a rally in Michigan on Saturday night, saying at one point: \u201cIf we don\u2019t get border security, we\u2019ll close down the country,\u201d apparently referring to a government shutdown when a funding deadline is reached in September.\n\nOther administration officials have also been vocal.\n\nAttorney General Jeff Sessions called the caravan \u201ca deliberate attempt to undermine our laws and overwhelm our system.\u201d\n\nJoined by supporters and dozens of members of the news media, the migrants gathered in a park on the Pacific Ocean about 10 a.m. local time and then later on a pedestrian plaza in front of a community center in downtown Tijuana. Scores of supporters, some of whom had walked from as far as Los Angeles, rallied Sunday morning just north of the fence separating the United States from Mexico on the American side of the oceanfront park.\n\nPhoto\n\n[Migrant Caravan Arrives at U.S. Border, But Long Road Awaits]\n\nWhat was supposed to be the final act of the caravan began about 3:30 p.m., when more than 150 of the participants, accompanied by relatives, supporters and the press, marched several blocks to a border crossing in Tijuana called El Chaparral. As they walked, they chanted and waved Honduran flags.\n\nTo qualify for asylum, applicants must prove they have been persecuted or fear persecution based on their race, religion, nationality, political beliefs or membership in a particular group.\n\nPeople who request protection at a United States entry point must be referred to an asylum officer for a screening, known as a credible-fear interview. If the officer finds that an applicant has a chance of proving fear of persecution, the person must then present his or her case before a judge. More than three quarters of applicants pass that initial review.\n\n\u201cWe\u2019re only sending people who we think will pass the credible-fear interview,\u201d said Nicole Ramos, a volunteer immigration lawyer helping the caravan.\n\nBut Customs and Border Protection, whose officers are stationed at ports of entry, announced late Sunday that it had exhausted its capacity to handle people traveling without documents.\n\nPhoto\n\nStill, caravan organizers escorted some 50 participants along the long, elevated pedestrian walkway at El Chaparral that leads from Tijuana to the entrance to the United States in San Diego. At the gate leading into the American immigration checkpoint, American border authorities reaffirmed that they would not be able to process any more asylum-seekers on Sunday.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAlex Mensing, project coordinator for Pueblo Sin Fronteras, a transnational group that organized the caravan, told reporters gathered at El Chaparral that the migrants would remain at the gate, overnight if necessary, until border officials once again had the capacity to process them.\n\n\u201cWe wish that the United States government were capable of accepting more than a few hundred asylum seekers at any given time, since we can certainly pick up more than a 1,000 people in an ICE raid on any given day,\u201d he said, referring to Immigration and Customs Enforcement, an arm of the Homeland Security Department.\n\nMeanwhile, the rest of the asylum seekers, their relatives and supporters laid out blankets on a plaza outside the entrance to El Chaparral and prepared for a long, chilly night.\n\nWhen they get a chance to make their case, migrant families that request asylum at the port of entry are likely to be placed on buses to Texas, where they will remain in detention centers for mothers and children. Adult men are likely to be detained in any number of facilities across the country that hold undocumented immigrants.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Race/Related Newsletter Join a deep and provocative exploration of race with a diverse group of New York Times journalists. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n[\u2018You Hate America!\u2019: How the Caravan Story Exploded on the Right]\n\nIt is in these facilities that the migrants would be screened by United States immigration officials over the next several days. If they pass the credible-fear interview, the migrants will be allowed to make their case for asylum before an immigration judge, a process that unfolds over several months or longer.\n\nMigrants, typically fitted with ankle monitors, often are allowed to travel to the interior of the country, where they stay with relatives or friends while their cases run their course.\n\nMr. Trump, however, has denounced that practice because some migrants have skipped their court hearings; he dismissed it as \u201ccatch and release.\u201d In recent months, migrant advocates say, the Trump administration has kept many migrants seeking asylum in detention.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nFor all the high political stakes, the human stakes for the individual migrants planning to seek asylum Sunday were at least as high.\n\nByron Claros, a Salvadoran immigrant, joined the caravan with his 18-year-old brother, Luis Alexander Rodriguez, and their stepfather, Andres Rodr\u00edguez.\n\nMr. Claros and Mr. Rodriguez planned to petition for asylum Sunday afternoon; their stepfather, after consultation with volunteer lawyers in Tijuana, decided that his case for sanctuary was not strong enough and that he would remain behind in Mexico.\n\n\u201cThe hour I\u2019ve waited for my entire life has finally arrived,\u201d Mr. Claros said early Sunday afternoon as he, hundreds of migrants, scores of their supporters, reporters and cameramen gathered in and in front of a community center and cafe in the downtown district of Tijuana, blocks from the border crossing.\n\nMr. Rodriguez said he was nervous, \u201cbecause the United States can support our rights but can also deny us our rights.\u201d\n\nStill, he said, there was only one way to push: north.\n\n\u201cWe\u2019ve fought too much to get here,\u201d he said. \u201cAnd we\u2019re here.\u201d", "title": "Migrant Caravan of Asylum Seekers Reaches U.S. Border", "authors": ["Kirk Semple", "Miriam Jordan"]} {"date": "2018-04-22 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nA young standout infielder was the hitting star of the Yankees\u2019 5-1 victory over the Toronto Blue Jays on Sunday, but it wasn\u2019t the one many of the 43,628 fans at Yankee Stadium had come to see.\n\nThe pregame attraction had been Gleyber Torres, the jewel of the Yankees\u2019 farm system, who was recalled Saturday night from the club\u2019s Class AAA affiliate in Scranton/Wilkes-Barre to help kick-start a team that has been spinning its wheels over the first three weeks of the season.\n\nBut once the game began, the promise of Torres was eclipsed by the performance of Miguel Andujar, who arrived in the Bronx with less fanfare on April 1 but has made his presence felt.\n\nIn his 13th game of the season, and the 18th of his major-league career, Andujar had four hits, including two doubles, while scoring a run and driving in another. His offensive contributions bolstered the efforts of starting pitcher Luis Severino, who worked seven innings of three-hit, one-run ball to earn his fourth win of the season and propel the 11-9 Yankees \u2014 who won three of four games from the Blue Jays this weekend \u2014 to two games above .500 for the first time since April 4.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cWe knew he was going to hit,\u201d Manager Aaron Boone said. \u201cNow we\u2019re starting to see him gaining some traction. What exactly did you do there? DR. EVIL: Well naturally, I was going to be secretary of evil. But Steve Bannon got that job.\n\nDr. Evil said he was \u201cmore of an ideas guy,\u201d and he was the one who first thought to build a wall on the United States-Mexico border. Then he clarified, in typical Dr. Evil fashion: \u201cI wanted it to be a moat, filled with spiky blowfish.\u201d\n\nHe took some backhanded swipes at Trump\u2019s immigration policy, and at Ben Carson, the secretary of housing.\n\nDR. EVIL: All the most evil stuff was me. FALLON: Even deporting Dreamers? DR. EVIL: No, Jimmy, even I have my limits. I\u2019m evil, but I\u2019m not a monster. FALLON: That\u2019s good to know. Did you at least make any friends at the job? DR. EVIL: Well, I got along swimmingly with Ben Carson. FALLON: And why is that? DR. EVIL: We were both evil doctors who didn\u2019t know why we were there.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nDr. Evil ended the segment by declaring his own candidacy for president. Jordan is a crucial American ally \u2014 Mr. Pompeo\u2019s predecessor, Rex W. Tillerson, signed an agreement in February that guarantees Jordan nearly $1.3 billion in annual assistance for the next five years, recognizing the country\u2019s role in fighting extremism and taking in Syrian refugees \u2014 but on this issue, Mr. Pompeo did not entirely agree.\n\nMr. Pompeo called the conflict \u201cimportant,\u201d but he added, \u201cSo, precisely how to rank it among all the various challenges, I\u2019ll defer on that. I know that it is an incredible priority for the United States to provide whatever assistance we can to allow the two parties to come to a resolution to this incredibly longstanding and important conflict.\u201d\n\nProtesters in Gaza have massed along the border with Israel for five straight Fridays, part of a series of demonstrations intended to draw attention to the situation for Palestinians, leading up to a final demonstration on May 15, when perhaps tens of thousands of people might rush the fortified barrier with Israel.\n\nInitially advertised by Hamas, the militant group that runs Gaza, as peaceful protests, they have been marked by the use of homemade fire bombs by Palestinians and deadly force on the part of Israel.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nIn the most recent demonstrations, on Friday, at least four people were killed and more than 1,000 others were wounded when Israeli troops fired on protesters who tried to crash through a security barrier and cross into Israel.\n\nMr. Pompeo\u2019s principal message at every stop on the trip has been that Iran, which supports President Bashar al-Assad of Syria and the Lebanese militant group Hezbollah, is involved in \u201cmalign activities\u201d in the region.\n\nDuring his confirmation hearings, Mr. Pompeo said that he wanted to preserve the Iranian nuclear accord, which was signed in 2015 and restricts Tehran\u2019s ability to engage in the activities necessary to make nuclear weapons.\n\nAs the days have worn on, however, his comments about the nuclear deal have become increasingly critical. President Trump is widely expected to withdraw the United States from the accord on May 12, although he has coyly refused to preview his decision.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe Iranian supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, responded to Mr. Pompeo on Monday, castigating the United States and accusing the Americans of trying to pit Saudi Arabia and other countries in the region against Tehran.\n\n\u201cThey should not be deceived by the United States,\u201d Ayatollah Khamenei said, according to remarks quoted by the state-run PressTV. \u201cThe Americans do not want to suffer the cost of confronting the Islamic Republic and the powerful nation of Iran themselves; they want to make some states in the region shoulder it.\u201d\n\nMr. Pompeo has also met with NATO officials in Brussels, where he expressed support for the alliance amid conflicting signals from Mr. Trump, and with the Saudi leadership, where he called for the country to end its feud with Qatar.", "title": "Mike Pompeo Expresses Support for Israeli Response to Gaza Protests", "authors": ["Gardiner Harris"]} {"date": "2018-04-12 00:00:00", "text": "Given their differences, it\u2019s hard to believe that Mike Pompeo, the C.I.A. director and secretary of state nominee whose Senate confirmation hearing was Thursday, and Rex Tillerson, who was fired last month, were both chosen by President Trump.\n\nMr. Tillerson, the former chief executive officer of ExxonMobil, left a legacy as the worst secretary of state in modern memory by cutting the department\u2019s budget, forcing out scores of senior diplomats and marginalizing those who remained, leaving many top jobs vacant and cloistering himself with a small coterie of aides unfamiliar with the institution.\n\nHe focused too much time on bureaucratic restructuring rather than addressing the job\u2019s core mission \u2014 handling international crises and representing America on the world stage. In the process, he, along with Mr. Trump, weakened democracy and human rights as elements of American diplomacy and undermined the nation\u2019s global leadership role.\n\nMr. Pompeo, a former Tea Party congressman from Kansas, described, over several hours before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee on Thursday, an approach that would repudiate much of what Mr. Tillerson had done. He said his first priority was to ensure that State Department employees, demoralized under Mr. Tillerson, were empowered and had a clear understanding of Mr. Trump\u2019s goals.", "title": "Opinion | Mike Pompeo Works the Hill", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-17 00:00:00", "text": "WEST PALM BEACH, Fla. \u2014 President Trump dispatched the C.I.A. director Mike Pompeo to North Korea to meet with its leader, Kim Jong-un, in recent weeks to lay the groundwork for a summit meeting between Mr. Kim and Mr. Trump, two people briefed on the secret trip said on Tuesday.\n\nMr. Trump alluded to Mr. Pompeo\u2019s mission when he said on Tuesday afternoon that the United States was in direct talks with North Korea at \u201cextremely high levels,\u201d and that the White House was looking at five sites for a potential meeting of the two leaders.\n\nThe White House has used intelligence, rather than diplomatic channels, to communicate with North Korea, ever since last month, when Mr. Trump unexpectedly accepted Mr. Kim\u2019s invitation to meet.\n\nMr. Pompeo, who is awaiting confirmation as secretary of state, has been dealing with North Korean representatives through a channel that runs between the C.I.A. and its North Korean counterpart, the Reconnaissance General Bureau, according to other officials. And he has been in close touch with the director of South Korea\u2019s National Intelligence Service, Suh Hoon, who American officials said brokered Mr. Kim\u2019s invitation to Mr. Trump.", "title": "Mike Pompeo, C.I.A. Director, Met With Kim Jong-un in North Korea", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-27 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Pompeo was also blunt in his call for European countries to spend more on their own defense, something Mr. Trump has urged repeatedly. When asked whether Germany was doing enough, Mr. Pompeo said simply, \u201cNo.\u201d And he called for all countries to create plans before a leaders\u2019 summit meeting in July to increase military spending to 2 percent of their gross domestic product, a target all NATO countries have endorsed but not all have achieved.\n\nBut he emphasized that his arrival in Brussels just hours after his own confirmation demonstrated the importance of the NATO alliance to the United States.\n\n\u201cThis alliance has been an essential pillar of American security interests for decades,\u201d he said. And he said that Russian aggression in Georgia, Ukraine and the Middle East only made it more so.\n\n\u201cIn light of Russia\u2019s unacceptable actions, NATO is more indispensable than ever,\u201d he said and then referred to the recent poisoning in Britain of a former Russian spy. \u201cAs NATO allies agree, the use of military-grade nerve agent developed by Russia on U.K. territory was a reckless action that put the lives of innocent civilians at risk.\u201d\n\n\u201cThe United States has made abundantly clear that NATO should not return to business as usual with Russia until Moscow shows a clear change in its actions and complies with international law,\u201d he said.\n\nMr. Trump has frequently been critical of NATO, and his expressions of support appeared to be made grudgingly: He reaffirmed the United States\u2019 commitment to Article 5 of the NATO treaty, which requires that it defend any NATO members that are attacked, only after having first pointedly refused to do so.\n\nMr. Pompeo is now the United States\u2019 top diplomat, but he was recently the directory of the C.I.A. He was also once a tank commander in Europe dedicated to deterring Russian aggression, and his visit comes with the Russian threat looming large on the Continent.", "title": "Mike Pompeo, Wasting No Time, Warns Europe About Iran Deal", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-11 00:00:00", "text": "CAIRO \u2014 The crash of a military transport plane that killed 257 people on Wednesday was Algeria\u2019s deadliest ever, compounding the woeful air safety record of an insular country where there has been little accountability for such disasters in the past.\n\nA Russian-built Ilyushin plane carrying soldiers and civilians slammed into a field moments after it took off from Boufarik military base, about 15 miles southwest of the capital, Algiers. The plane exploded into flames, sending black smoke billowing into the air. Only a handful of people survived.\n\nThe cause of the crash was not immediately known, and Algeria\u2019s Defense Ministry began an investigation. But there was little prospect of any political repercussions in a country that has come to be seen as the region\u2019s hermitlike giant, hesitant and inward-facing, as its economic and political malaise has deepened.\n\nRich in gas and oil, and the largest country in Africa by size, Algeria should loom large over the region. It avoided the turmoil of the Arab Spring uprisings that engulfed its North African neighbors Tunisia, Libya and Egypt. And it has established itself as a bulwark against Islamist extremism.", "title": "Military Plane Crash Is Algeria\u2019s Worst Air Disaster, With 257 Dead", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-14 00:00:00", "text": "Both his mother, born Anna Suabova, and the man he believed to be his father, a teacher named Rudolf Forman, were separately seized by the Germans and killed in death camps.\n\nFor years, Mr. Forman vaguely told interviewers that he believed himself to be half-Jewish, though both parents attended a Protestant church. It was his co-writer, Mr. Novak, in researching \u201cTurnaround,\u201d who ended the mystery.\n\nAfter the 1964 release of his first feature film, \u201cBlack Peter\u201d \u2014 about the misadventures of a teenager beginning his work life \u2014 Mr. Forman was contacted by a woman who had been with his mother in Auschwitz, Mr. Novak learned. The woman explained that Mr. Forman was actually the son of a Jewish architect with whom Mr. Forman\u2019s mother had had an affair. Mr. Forman eventually found his biological father, who had survived the war and moved to Ecuador.\n\nReared by foster parents, Mr. Forman attended film school in Prague. He made his mark with a film and theater presentation at the 1958 Brussels World Exhibition. An early feature, \u201cThe Loves of a Blonde,\u201d won attention on the international festival circuit in 1965.\n\nAnother film two years later, \u201cThe Firemen\u2019s Ball,\u201d rubbed Czech officials the wrong way with its spoof of the firefighting bureaucracy. By then, though, Mr. Forman was turning to opportunities abroad.\n\nWhen the Soviet Union invaded in August 1968, Mr. Forman was in Paris negotiating to make a Hollywood film. That movie, his first American feature, a youth comedy called \u201cTaking Off,\u201d was released by Universal Pictures in 1971. It did so poorly, Mr. Forman said, that he wound up owing the studio $500.", "title": "Milos Forman, 86, Dies; Won Oscars for \u2018Cuckoo\u2019s Nest\u2019 and \u2018Amadeus\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-08 00:00:00", "text": "ST. PAUL, Minn. \u2014 Karson Kuhlman had a goal and an assist, and Minnesota Duluth beat Notre Dame, 2-1, Saturday night to win the university\u2019s second N.C.A.A. men\u2019s hockey championship.\n\nJared Thomas also scored and Hunter Shepard stopped 19 shots for the Bulldogs (25-16-3). Minnesota Duluth won the 2011 title, also at the Xcel Energy Center.\n\nAndrew Oglevie scored and Cale Morris made 33 saves for Notre Dame (28-10-2), which is now winless in two national title games. The Irish lost to Boston College in 2008.\n\nMinnesota Duluth lost to Denver in last year\u2019s championship. The Bulldogs had seven seniors on that team, and then three underclassmen departed early for the N.H.L., including the starting goaltender.", "title": "Minnesota Duluth Beats Notre Dame to Win N.C.A.A. Men\u2019s Hockey Title", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-28 00:00:00", "text": "73D: After naming Supremes at 11A and 89A, a clue about an \u201cElite court group\u201d definitely summoned judges to mind; here the court in question is a basketball court, and the group is the ALL NBA TEAM. This comprises players chosen by sports journalists, so you\u2019re highly unlikely to ever see an all N.B.A. team actually play.\n\nToday\u2019s Theme\n\nThe title today refers to an abbreviation that has been undone, lengthened back to words, but unusually so, so that the long version takes on a new meaning.\n\nPeter Wentz has found six examples of well-known phrases that start with an abbreviation consisting of two initials, like TD Bank, for example. In each case, the two initials stand for something specific \u2014 in this case, Toronto-Dominion, who knew \u2014 but can also commonly stand for something entirely different, like the way a touchdown is referred to in football stats.\n\nMr. Wentz\u2019s theme clues are for the common phrase, with the initials swapped out for the alternate words, for humorous effect. The riddles are clever but not devious. With a few crossing helps they all fell for me, but I knew both meanings for each set of initials in all but one case. The theme clues are at 22A, 38A, 55A, 80A, 100A and 117A.\n\nLet\u2019s look at 55A: \u201cGoings-on in accelerated classes?\u201d If you know that you need a phrase with some initials, and you know that accelerated classes, in high school, are called advanced placement, you\u2019ve got what you need. You can take these classes to prepare for tests, called A.P. exams, that let you skip intros in college or university. So your base initial set is AP. What else does A.P. famously stand for? Associated Press comes to mind, especially since I\u2019m in a newsroom at this moment; A.P. News is a venerated institution. So you combine these two A.P.s and come up with ADVANCED PLACEMENT NEWS.\n\nThe one that I didn\u2019t \u201cget,\u201d friends, was probably the simplest, at 117A: \u201cMorning zoo programming?\u201d The initials AM are at play here in two senses that I used every single day, probably, without thinking twice about. I therefore give Mr. Wentz credit here, and elsewhere, for causing me to DOH! a couple of times.\n\nConstructor Notes\n\nThis puzzle\u2019s genesis sprang from overhearing someone jokingly use the term \u201cPC police,\u201d and being amused at the thought of an actual militia enforcing a ban on Macs. That one was one letter too long to fit in a Sunday grid, but it opened the flood gates for theme potential. The first draft needed a few thematic edits, including a breakfast-test-violating reference to a popular action figure brand. Thankfully, there were enough two-letter acronyms out there to find a few substitutes, and I\u2019m pleased with the final result. Hope everyone enjoys and gets a chuckle or two!\n\nThe Sunday Sherpa\n\nI hope these were Pretty Good tips, but if they weren\u2019t your cup of tea, I won\u2019t take it personally if you take a peek at the answer key. While the answers are free to everyone, the Crossword puzzles require a subscription.\n\nWhat did you think?", "title": "Mis-Unabbreviated", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-30 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cThere is now so much friction between the sides that it is very natural that a single miscalculation across the board on one of these flash points could spiral out of control,\u201d said Ali Vaez, director of the Iran Project at the International Crisis Group.\n\nAmplifying these tensions, he said, was the looming May 12 deadline by which President Trump has said he will decide whether to pull the United States out of the international agreement to curb Iran\u2019s nuclear program.\n\nIran has sought to preserve the deal, which gives it significant sanctions relief, while the United States\u2019 regional allies have campaigned to have it scrapped to punish Iran for what they see as its destabilizing activities across the Middle East.\n\nThey appear to have clear support from the Trump administration in their efforts to confront Iran.\n\nOn a phone call hours before Sunday\u2019s strike, Mr. Trump spoke by phone with Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel about \u201cthe continuing threats and challenges facing the Middle East region, especially the problems posed by the Iranian regime\u2019s destabilizing activities,\u201d according to a statement from the White House.\n\nThe new secretary of state, Mike Pompeo, who was visiting Israel at the time, said in a news conference with Mr. Netanyahu that American coordination with its allies was \u201ccritical to our efforts to counter Iran\u2019s destabilizing and malign activities throughout the Middle East.\u201d\n\n\u201cThe United States is with Israel in this fight, and we strongly support Israel\u2019s sovereign right to defend itself,\u201d Mr. Pompeo said.\n\nBut it was not clear whether American officials were informed before the strikes took place.\n\nThe rivalry between Iran and its regional rivals cuts across the Middle East, from Lebanon and Syria to Iraq, Yemen and the Persian Gulf.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAnalysts say that Iran, which has few powerful allies and shares a region with hostile countries that spend much greater sums on their militaries, has instead built relationships with proxy forces that can fight on its behalf. These include Hezbollah, the Lebanese militant group and political party; a variety of Shiite militias in Iraq; and the Houthi rebels in Yemen.\n\nThis network allows Iran to project military strength abroad while deterring potential attacks on its homeland from Israel and Saudi Arabia.\n\nIran\u2019s enemies argue that these activities increase instability in the region by undermining state structures and empowering militias that operate above the law.\n\nIn recent years, Iran\u2019s greatest investments have been in Syria, where it has sent military officers to help preserve the government of President Bashar al-Assad. Israel accuses Iran of using the cover of the war to build a military infrastructure there that could be used in a confrontation with Israel.\n\nThroughout the war, Israel has frequently struck convoys believed to be carrying weapons to Iran\u2019s regional allies. In April, these attacks escalated. It first launched strikes on a Syrian military base, killing seven Iranians, including a top official in Iran\u2019s drone program.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nSunday night\u2019s attack appeared to be a further escalation, with a higher death toll.\n\nThe Syrian Observatory for Human Rights, which is based in Britain but monitors Syria through contacts there, said that the attacks killed at least 26 people, most of them Iranians.\n\nThe strikes hit munitions warehouses at the 47th Brigade military base in central Hama Province that Iran and its proxies used, destroying ground-to-ground missiles and causing large explosions, the observatory said.\n\nThe blast was large enough that it was picked up by earthquake monitors. The European-Mediterranean Seismological Center reported a disturbance in the area of the base with a magnitude of 2.6, it said, equivalent to a minor earthquake.\n\nOther reported attacks struck a fire station, also in Hama Province, and the Neirab military air base near Aleppo. But no deaths or significant destruction was reported that those sites.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAn official from the regional alliance that includes Iran, Syria and Hezbollah confirmed that the strikes near Hama had hit a storage site on the base and said they had destroyed 200 missiles and killed 16 people, including 11 Iranians. The official spoke on the condition of anonymity because he was not authorized to speak to journalists.\n\nNeither Israel nor Iran appeared interested in publicizing the strike, which analysts said was probably an effort to diminish the chances that Iran would feel the need to retaliate immediately.\n\nIsrael\u2019s military does not comment on individual attacks in Syria, and a spokesman declined to comment on Sunday\u2019s attack, most likely because if Israel claimed responsibility it could put pressure on Iranian leaders to strike back. Israel\u2019s security cabinet convened an emergency meeting on Monday, apparently to discuss the rising tensions with Israel\u2019s northern neighbors.\n\nA semiofficial Iranian news agency, ISNA, initially said that 18 of 40 people killed in the attacks were Iranian, but the report was later taken down and Iranian officials denied that any of their people had been killed.\n\nThat, too, could have been so that Iranian leaders would not feel compelled to respond immediately, said Amos Yadlin, the former director of intelligence for the Israeli military and now executive director of the Institute for National Security Studies in Tel Aviv.\n\n\u201cIf there are no Iranian casualties, you are not committed to retaliation,\u201d Mr. Yadlin said in a conference call with reporters on Monday.\n\nBut he said he expected that Iran would eventually respond to the April attacks, although it was not clear when, where or how.\n\n\u201cThe Iranian retaliation is on its way,\u201d he said.\n\nMr. Vaez, the analyst, said that his recent conversations with Iranian officials also suggested that Iran would eventually retaliate for Israel\u2019s strikes on Iranian assets in Syria.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cThey believe that this is a slippery slope, that there is a need to send a message to Israel that there is a cost associated with its pushing the envelope too far,\u201d he said.\n\nBut influencing their decision on when to respond was their concern that any action taken now could push Mr. Trump toward withdrawing from the nuclear agreement, Mr. Vaez said, adding that Israel\u2019s decision to strike on Sunday might have been intended to provoke an Iranian response for that very purpose.\n\n\u201cWe are in a vicious cycle, and the reality is that the collapse of the nuclear deal will significantly increase all these tensions,\u201d Mr. Vaez said. \u201cAll the parties will take the gloves off at that stage.\u201d", "title": "Missile Attack in Syria Reportedly Kills at Least 16, Raising Regional Tensions", "authors": ["Ben Hubbard"]} {"date": "2018-04-19 00:00:00", "text": "WASHINGTON \u2014 A barrage of missiles against Syria by American, French and British forces most likely will not stop President Bashar al-Assad\u2019s chemical weapons program, a Pentagon assessment has concluded, despite President Trump\u2019s \u201cMission Accomplished!\u201d declaration hours after last weekend\u2019s strikes.\n\nThe military intelligence report, put out less than three days after the attack, said the allied airstrikes likely set back Mr. Assad\u2019s production of sarin gas.\n\nBut it found that the Syrian president is expected to continue researching and developing chemical weapons for potential future use, according to an American intelligence analyst who has seen the document and described it to The New York Times on the condition of anonymity.\n\n\u201cThey do retain a residual capability\u201d to produce chemical weapons, Lt. Gen. Kenneth F. McKenzie Jr., the Joint Staff director, said on Thursday of the Syrian government. He said the chemical weapons are \u201cspread through the country.\u201d", "title": "Missile Strikes Are Unlikely to Stop Syria\u2019s Chemical Attacks, Pentagon Says", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-13 00:00:00", "text": "In February, prosecutors charged Mr. Greitens with invasion of privacy, a felony in Missouri, in connection with the photograph.\n\nThe woman, who worked as a hairdresser and had cut Mr. Greitens\u2019s hair, has not been publicly identified and has told officials that she did not wish to share her story with law enforcement or the public; she has repeatedly turned down requests for interviews.\n\nSubpoenaed to testify under oath before a state legislative committee investigating the governor, the woman said that she went to Mr. Greitens\u2019s home on his invitation one morning, where he suggested that they work out together; then he blindfolded her, taped her hands to pull-up rings and began kissing her. He then tore off her shirt, pulled down her pants and took a picture of her with his cellphone, she said.\n\nOfficially, Mr. Greitens is charged only with invasion of privacy, but elected officials calling for Mr. Greitens\u2019s resignation have offered concerns that seem to reach further. Some legislators have questioned whether the woman gave consent to Mr. Greitens during their initial sexual encounter. At one point, the woman said, she broke down in tears; Mr. Greitens responded by consoling her, she said, and then, as she continued crying, he undid his pants and moved his penis near her face. Asked whether she consented to performing oral sex that morning, the woman testified, \u201cIt\u2019s a hard question because I did \u2014 it felt like consent, but, no, I didn\u2019t want to do it.\u201d She went on: \u201cCoerced, maybe. I felt as though that would allow me to leave.\u201d\n\nOther lawmakers have said the scandal is a distraction from his work as governor, his political future has crumbled and the process is causing anguish for his wife and children.\n\n\u201cI am very worried as a family man about the effects that this has on his family,\u201d Mike Kehoe, the Senate majority leader and a Republican, said. \u201cThe governor\u2019s political career might have two-and-a-half years on it at best, but he\u2019s going to have a family for life.\u201d\n\nWhat does he say happened?\n\nMr. Greitens acknowledged having a consensual extramarital affair, issuing a statement \u2014 together with his wife, Sheena \u2014 shortly after delivering his State of the State address in January. He has portrayed the issue as a personal matter, not a legal violation, and his lawyers have pushed back vehemently against suggestions of criminal behavior or coercion of any kind. Mr. Greitens has dismissed the legislative committee\u2019s report, which quoted extensively from the woman he had a relationship with, as \u201ctabloid trash.\u201d He called the investigation into his behavior a \u201cpolitical witch hunt.\u201d He declined to answer questions before the same legislative committee she spoke to; his lawyers said he would be willing to answer their questions after the invasion of privacy charge against him was resolved in court.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nOn Thursday, he seemed to relish the prospect of having that case heard next month. \u201cIn 32 days,\u201d he said in a statement, \u201ca court of law and a jury of my peers will let every person in Missouri know the truth and prove my innocence.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWho has called on Mr. Greitens to resign?\n\nPretty much everybody in Missouri politics. After the release of the 24-page report this week from thelegislative committee, dozens of legislators and other elected officials \u2014 Republican and Democrat \u2014 reiterated calls for Mr. Greitens to step down. They include Josh Hawley, the attorney general of Missouri and a Republican; Senator Claire McCaskill, a Democrat; Mr. Kehoe, the Senate majority leader; and even financial backers like David Humphreys, a businessman whose family was one of Mr. Greitens\u2019s top donors, giving him more than $2 million during his run for governor.\n\nDoes anyone still support Mr. Greitens?\n\nAn inner circle of advisers to the governor, including several strategists and donors, were said to be urging Mr. Greitens to resist calls to resign. Some evangelical leaders, who supported him in 2016 along with an overwhelming number of the state\u2019s white evangelical voters, said they had maintained their support for the governor.\n\nBrandon Park, the lead pastor at Connection Point, an evangelical church in Raytown, Mo., affiliated with the Southern Baptist Convention, said he did not think Mr. Greitens should resign. He supports the governor\u2019s anti-abortion positions, and he says evangelical Christians respect him for his policies. \u201cI see a lot of these personal attacks both on Trump and Greitens as a way to take away attention from the ideals that matter most to evangelical Christians,\u201d he said. \u201cIt does seem to be a little bit of a witch hunt.\u201d\n\nOthers, though, were more critical. Phil Hopper, the pastor of Abundant Live Church near Kansas City, Mo., said he would be \u201camazed\u201d that anybody would be supporting Mr. Greitens, but said that due process must take its course.\n\nWhat happens next?\n\nOn May 14, Mr. Greitens will go on trial in St. Louis on the invasion of privacy charge. He sought a bench trial but a judge denied that, so a jury will decide his fate. If convicted, Mr. Greitens could face up to four years in prison.\n\nThen there is the threat of impeachment in a State Capitol where both chambers are dominated by Republicans. The legislative committee that investigated Mr. Greitens\u2019s case \u2014 made up of five Republicans and two Democrats \u2014 will decide whether to file articles of impeachment against him. That decision could happen at any time. In Missouri, leaders are subject to impeachment for a broad array of failings: \u201ccrime, misconduct, habitual drunkenness, willful neglect of duty, corruption in office, incompetency, or any offense involving moral turpitude or oppression in office.\u201d\n\nIf articles of impeachment were to be filed, the full House would then vote on whether to impeach the governor; if a majority votes in favor of impeachment, the case would then go to the Senate, where seven judges would conduct a trial.\n\nFive of the seven judges must vote in favor of impeachment for the governor to be removed from office \u2014 an action that has never before been taken in Missouri.\n\nWhat does Mr. Greitens\u2019s political future hold?\n\nWhatever the outcome of the criminal trial and the legislative proceedings, political strategists and elected officials said there appeared few paths ahead in politics for Mr. Greitens.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cDo you go somewhere after this?\u201d John Hancock, a political strategist and former chairman of the Missouri Republican Party, said. \u201cI don\u2019t know. I just can\u2019t see it.\u201d", "title": "Missouri Governor Eric Greitens, His Affair, and the Chaos that Followed.", "authors": ["Julie Bosman", "Monica Davey"]} {"date": "2018-04-20 00:00:00", "text": "Gov. Eric Greitens of Missouri was accused on Friday of illegally obtaining a donor list from a charity he founded and using it to raise money for his 2016 campaign, a new blow to Mr. Greitens in a deepening political and sex scandal that has threatened his grip on the governor\u2019s office.\n\nKimberly Gardner, the St. Louis circuit attorney, charged Mr. Greitens with one felony count of tampering with computer data in connection with the donor list.\n\nMr. Greitens, a Republican who was first elected governor in the 2016 race, already was facing a different felony charge, invasion of privacy. In January, he admitted that he had a sexual relationship with his former hairdresser while he was married. The woman has told a legislative committee that Mr. Greitens took a nude or seminude picture of her without her consent, then threatened to make the image public if she told anyone about their affair.\n\nThe new felony charge dates back to actions prosecutors say took place in April 2015, when Mr. Greitens, a former Navy SEAL, was running for governor and serving on the board of directors for The Mission Continues, a veterans charity that he founded. According to the charging document, Mr. Greitens directed an employee of the charity, identified only as \u201cK.T.,\u201d to take a list of donors from the charity.", "title": "Missouri Governor Faces New Charge: Misusing Charity List for Campaign", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-17 00:00:00", "text": "For most of this year, Mr. Greitens, a former Navy SEAL who was elected governor in 2016, has been the target of investigations, charges that he is unfit to serve as governor and calls for his resignation or impeachment, even from members of his own party.\n\nHis troubles burst into public view in January when a St. Louis television station broadcast a report that before he became governor, Mr. Greitens had an extramarital affair with a woman, had taken a nude or seminude photograph of her without her permission, and had threatened to make the image public if she told anyone about him.\n\nIn February, the governor was indicted by a grand jury in St. Louis on a felony charge of invasion of privacy relating to the photograph. Separately, a House legislative committee in Missouri, mostly made up of Republicans, is investigating Mr. Greitens and could begin a process to impeach him at any time. Mr. Hawley, who has called for Mr. Greitens to resign, said on Tuesday that he had also referred evidence related to the Mission Continues donor list to the committee.\n\nA report released by the House committee last week contained even more explosive allegations against Mr. Greitens. The woman who had a sexual relationship with him in 2015 told the committee that he hit her and she felt coerced into performing oral sex.\n\nMr. Greitens, a father of two, has insisted that the affair was consensual and that he and his wife, Sheena, have made peace with it.\n\nMr. Greitens faces trial on the invasion-of-privacy charge in St. Louis on May 14, and has said he views the hearing as an opportunity to clear his name. He could face up to four years in prison if convicted.\n\nMissouri Republicans are concerned that the allegations swirling around the governor could hurt the party this fall in a competitive Senate race in which Mr. Hawley is hoping to unseat Senator Claire McCaskill, a Democrat.", "title": "Missouri\u2019s Governor Was Already in Trouble. She was 87.\n\nThe club confirmed her death. Her family said through a spokeswoman that she had an undetermined neurological disorder and that earlier media reports that the cause was Parkinson\u2019s disease were incorrect.\n\nMs. Shore opened the Comedy Store, on Sunset Strip, in 1972 with her husband, the comedian Sammy Shore, in a building that had once housed the nightclub Ciro\u2019s. After they divorced in 1974, Ms. Shore took control and turned the club into a hothouse for comedy.\n\nShe was a critic, confidante and caretaker for many of the comedians who drifted through the Store. When she arrived in Brooklyn in 1996, her neighbors quickly discovered her culinary skills and began ordering her pelmeni for parties.\n\nWith the help of her husband and two sons, Ms. Tulman opened two restaurants (one now under a new name and ownership, the other shuttered) and ran factories that supplied pelmeni and crepes to the tristate area. But after her death in 2012, her younger son, Eugene, grew disenchanted with how far the factories\u2019 products had strayed from his mother\u2019s original cooking.\n\nAt Luda\u2019s Dumplings, where he is the chef, Eugene pledged to follow his mother\u2019s precepts \u2014 always use the freshest ingredients; mix everything by hand \u2014 if not exactly her recipe. The dough, for example, is made with organic flour and is \u201cnot as soft\u201d as with traditional pelmeni, he said; growing up in Sheepshead Bay, a historically Italian neighborhood, he fell in love with pasta and wanted the dumplings to have a texture closer to al dente.\n\nOf the six fillings available, the most robust and wintry in spirit is Siberian-style beef and pork, here grass-fed Angus beef shoulder and pastured pork butt, ground in-house and evenly split so neither lords over the other. One pierce, and the juices run.\n\nIn other versions, a mash of potato and Cheddar has surprising buoyancy, and spinach, melded with feta, Parmesan and mozzarella, retains its vivid green. But pulverized shrimp loses some of its briny character, muffled by Parmesan and ricotta inside a dough stained pink by beet juice.", "title": "Modern Russian Dumplings That Nod to the Past", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-20 00:00:00", "text": "Economists say that the cash shortage has no single cause, but rather is the result of a combination of factors.\n\nFollowing the 2016 currency cancellation, the government did not print enough new bank notes to keep up with India\u2019s growing economy, betting that cash-loving Indians would embrace digital transactions. (They did not.)\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMeanwhile, hoarders and black market operators started stockpiling 2,000-rupee notes, worth about $30 each. Rather than expanding the supply to compensate, the government decided to stop printing the high-value bills, forcing banks to fill A.T.M.s with lower denomination notes, which run out more quickly.\n\nPublic faith in the safety of India\u2019s banks has also faltered over the past year, prompting people to keep more cash at home.\n\nThe Modi government, warning of a growing problem with bad bank loans, last fall pledged $32 billion in taxpayer funds to bail out weak lenders. It also proposed legislation that could force depositors with more than $1,500 in an account to take a loss if their bank failed.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Interested in All Things Tech? View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nJitters rose further in February after Punjab National Bank, a major state-owned lender, and government investigators accused the jeweler Nirav Modi of stealing $1.8 billion in a scheme that went undetected for years because of poor controls at the bank.\n\n\u201cMany people got scared,\u201d said Radha Rani, a senior manager at Indian Bank, another state-owned bank, in Warangal. \u201cThey are keeping money in their houses or investing in real estate. They have fear of losing money if deposited in the bank. So many people directly told us that.\u201d\n\nG. Ravinder, 55, an architect and consultant in Warangal, said that he had issued paychecks to the laborers working on his projects but that they had been unable to cash them.\n\nHis bank, the State Bank of India, the country\u2019s largest bank, will not allow him to withdraw enough cash from the branch either. \u201cI went to the bank to withdraw 40,000 rupees, but they said, \u2018Sorry, we can give you only 20,000 rupees,\u2019\u201d he said. \u201cSo how do I do my work?\u201d\n\nThe harvest and marriage seasons are looming, increasing demand for cash. If the shortage is not quickly eased, more customers will demand their money, potentially causing a much bigger problem: a bank run.\n\n\u201cWe have deposited our own money in the bank with the assumption that whenever we need money, we can get it from the bank. When banks are not giving money, then people are scared that bank deposits are not safe,\u201d Mr. Ravinder said. \u201cThat is why people are withdrawing their money from the banks.\u201d", "title": "Modi May Pay the Price as India\u2019s A.T.M.s Run Out of Cash Again", "authors": ["Hari Kumar", "Vindu Goel"]} {"date": "2018-04-16 00:00:00", "text": "Prime Minister Narendra Modi of India tweets frequently and considers himself a talented orator. Yet he loses his voice when it comes to speaking out about the dangers faced by women and minorities who are frequent targets of the nationalist and communal forces that are part of the base of his Bharatiya Janata Party.\n\nIndians took to the streets during the weekend to protest their government\u2019s callous response to the horrifying rape and murder of an 8-year-old girl in January in which supporters of his political party have been implicated. Mr. Modi, though, has barely spoken about this crime and other cases involving his supporters.\n\nUntil last week, he declined to address the attack on the girl, in the northern state of Jammu and Kashmir, by men who wanted to frighten and drive away her nomadic Muslim community, the Bakarwals, from an area that is dominated by Hindus. To read about what happened to the girl, who was held and abused at a Hindu temple, over several days is to plumb the depths of human depravity.\n\nAs Mr. Modi remained quiet as public outrage built up for weeks, state lawmakers from his party, which is part of a coalition that governs Jammu and Kashmir, attended a rally in support of a man who had been arrested for the crime and joined in demands by locals that the investigation be taken away from state officials, some of whom are Muslim, and be turned over to federal authorities. He was assessing Salah\u2019s influence on Liverpool, not long after the Egyptian had scored twice in a Premier League game against Leicester City. Something about his low center of gravity, Wright said, the way he controls the ball, the way he seems to cast it under his spell, reminded him of Lionel Messi.\n\nWright was, of course, immediately pilloried. Drawing a comparison between Messi \u2014 or Cristiano Ronaldo, for that matter \u2014 and any player is rightly taboo; such is the status of those two, that they do not measure themselves against their peers, but against only the greats of the past.\n\nWith a quiet insistence, though, more and more professional observers have followed Wright\u2019s lead in recent weeks. Not to say that Salah is the equal of Messi \u2014 far from it \u2014 or that he has achieved, or might yet achieve, as much. It\u2019s just that, in a certain light, at certain points, it is possible to glimpse in Salah a little of Messi\u2019s afterglow.\n\nEven as the idea has gained credence, it still seems fanciful. And yet, every three days or so, Salah does something to give the idea weight. Ordinarily, it is a goal, one of those mesmerizing dribbles that have long since been Messi\u2019s hallmark. Against Roma, though, it was something else, something more significant. Great players win games \u2014 not single-handedly, but through sheer force fo personality. They bend and they shape contests to their will. Nobody does it better than Messi and Ronaldo. Against his old friends from Rome, though, Salah came close.\n\nIt was not just that he scored twice, setting Liverpool on the way to a five-goal lead that, not too long after he left the field, was reduced to a three-goal advantage. Nor is it just that he scored twice so beautifully, with the sort of aristry we associate with Messi: one precision strike from the edge of the penalty area, fizzing past Alisson, Roma\u2019s goalkeeper; one delicate chip \u2014 a dink, really, there is no other word for it \u2014 after exchanging quick-fire passes with Roberto Firmino.", "title": "Mohamad Salah Stands Tall, but Liverpool Cracks Door for Roma", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-14 00:00:00", "text": "Several candidates who are mothers cite fears for their children as the root of their support or opposition to gun control. Kelda Roys, who is running in a crowded primary for governor of Wisconsin, described picking up her daughter at preschool and hearing about how she had to hide and be very quiet. Her 3-year-old was describing an active-shooter drill.\n\nWomen running for office in both parties have long used their status as mothers to explain their policy stances. Kelly Ayotte, the former Republican senator from New Hampshire, ran an ad that cited her children as a reason to cut wasteful spending, said Kelly Dittmar, a political scientist at the Center for American Women and Politics. Representative Cathy McMorris Rodgers, Republican of Washington, who gave birth to three children while in Congress, cited her son\u2019s Down syndrome to object to those who would abort fetuses with the condition.\n\nBy and large, though, Republican portraits of motherhood have tended to be more traditional, Ms. Dittmar said.\n\nBy contrast, this newest group of Democratic candidates seems more outspoken and unconventional. They do not appear to be concerned about research suggesting that motherhood should be conveyed in safe doses \u2014 some pictures of the children but not too many lest voters doubt women\u2019s credentials.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Opinion Today Newsletter Every weekday, get thought-provoking commentary from Op-Ed columnists, the Times editorial board and contributing writers from around the world.
