Administration officials said the rebranding was an attempt to diminish the agency\u2019s public profile.\n\nMr. Mulvaney\u2019s political appointees at the agency have asked The Associated Press, which sets the style standard for many publications and broadcasters, to change how it refers to the bureau.\n\n\u201cI\u2019m trying to get in the habit of now saying the \u2018B.C.F.P.\u2019 It\u2019s really, really hard to do that when you\u2019ve said the C.F.P.B. for so long,\u201d Mr. Mulvaney told the bankers.\n\nThe consumer bureau was created by the 2010 Dodd-Frank Law as a way to prevent banks and other financial companies from preying on vulnerable consumers. But the bureau has become a target of Republican lawmakers, who complain that it has unchecked power and is too aggressive in trying to punish financial firms.", "title": "Mulvaney, Watchdog Bureau\u2019s Leader, Advises Bankers on Ways to Curtail Agency", "authors": ["Glenn Thrush"]} {"date": "2018-04-20 00:00:00", "text": "Ms. Wagstaff oversees the Met Breuer, the museum\u2019s branch on Madison Avenue and, in a telephone interview, she described her programming there as \u201cconsciously transhistorical,\u201d a term she said she started using about six years ago.\n\n\u201cWith a blending of history and contemporary art, we can reveal some of the puzzles at the centers of great art,\u201d she said.\n\nThe Breuer\u2019s 2016 exhibition \u201cUnfinished: Thoughts Left Visible\u201d presented incomplete paintings through the ages, from Titian to Lucian Freud, Gerhard Richter and Bruce Nauman. She followed up with \u201cLike Life: Sculpture, Color and the Body (1300-Now),\u201d on view until July 22, which takes a nonchronological look at 700 years of sculptures of the human body.\n\nIncluding not only fine art but also wax effigies and anatomical models, the show opens with a hyperrealistic sculpture by Duane Hanson from 1984, jumps from a 15th-century Donatello sculpture to a Spanish Renaissance work by El Greco, and juxtaposes a modern android with a 19th-century effigy of Jeremy Bentham, made with the British philosopher\u2019s bones.\n\n\u201cThe idea with this show was to open it up and to expand the canon more, with work that could be seen in a more populist way,\u201d Ms. Wagstaff said.\n\nSuzanne Sanders, an art historian in Amsterdam, who organized conferences on \u201cThe Transhistorical Museum\u201d in 2015 and 2016, calls transhistorical curating \u201cthe most urgent thing curators are doing in trying to reinvent the museum to create some sort of new paradigm.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cIt can be \u2018trans\u2019 in all these senses of the word,\u201d she explained, \u201cfrom across history, to transdisciplinary or queer, or just to represent things in an inclusive way, to find a balance between acknowledging and addressing points of view.\u201d\n\nBut James Bradburne, director of the Brera Art Gallery in Milan, said the trend was just a new term for what curators have always done: \u201cTry and bring people back to the moment when the art was contemporary.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cWe are always obliged to re-perform the art we have in our collections in a contemporary way,\u201d he said, \u201cjust as an actor, when they perform Shakespeare, has to re-perform it for a contemporary audience, whether in mafia costumes or in drag.\u201d\n\nA year ago, M, a museum in Leuven, Belgium, rehung its permanent collection as \u201cCollection M: The Power of Images,\u201d presenting new comparisons, such as a 14th-century Piet\u00e0 alongside a 16th-century Baroque painting and a conceptual art installation from 2009.\n\n\u201cWe wanted to get out of this time-chain approach,\u201d its director, Eva Wittocx, said by telephone. \u201cEven people who know these works for a long time can find new meanings or new ways of looking at them.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nThe Kunsthistorisches Museum in Vienna, whose permanent collection features art from Ancient Egypt to 1800, borrowed 22 works of contemporary art for \u201cThe Shape of Time,\u201d which runs through July 8. A nude covering herself partly with a fur coat, by the Flemish master Peter Paul Rubens in 1636-38, for example, is presented alongside a full-frontal nude portrait from the early 1970s by the Austrian artist Maria Lassnig.\n\nPhoto\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cI\u2019d like to think that we are teasing out all of the ideas and concerns and dreams and nightmares that are buried in all of the historical works that we have,\u201d said Jasper Sharp, who curates the museum\u2019s program for modern and contemporary art. But he added that the curators spent a few years trying to figure out \u201cwhat types of confrontations would be interesting, respectful,\u201d he said.\n\nPairing \u00c9douard Manet with Diego Vel\u00e1zquez, or bringing a Titian into conversation with a J.M.W. Turner seemed to work, he said, because \u201cthese are very well-documented admirations of younger artists looking at older artists.\u201d\n\nBut other choices proved riskier. Scores of art lovers responded on Instagram to the museum\u2019s juxtaposition of a Rembrandt self-portrait next to a Mark Rothko color field painting. \u201cHalf of them were saying \u2018this is absolutely abysmal,\u2019 or \u2018Rembrandt must be turning in his grave,\u2019\u201d Mr. Sharp said. \u201cSome of the connections knit together instantly; others reward more sustained looking.\u201d\n\nMs. Demeester of the Frans Hals Museum pointed out that the history of art is cacophonous in its connections and influences \u2014 with \u201cpeople talking to each other in salons and cafes and messing things up.\u201d\n\n\u201cIn creating more meaning and new stories for an audience, it\u2019s important as a museum to think more like an artist,\u201d she added. \u201cAn artist is more free, or less inhibited than an art historian, to make connections that go across time or across culture or across geography. To connect.\u201d", "title": "Museums Shake Things Up by Mixing Old and New", "authors": ["Nina Siegal"]} {"date": "2018-04-24 00:00:00", "text": "When Scott Rothkopf, chief curator of the Whitney Museum of American Art, attended the U.S. Latinx Arts Futures Symposium at the Ford Foundation two years ago, the experience had a profound impact.\n\nThe organizers \u201cwanted to draw people\u2019s attention to the fact that Latinx artists were falling into neither category \u2014 they were not part of the growing interest in Latin American artists but also not seen as American artists,\u201d Mr. Rothkopf said. \u201cI left thinking that it was extremely important that the Whitney expand its thinking in this area and, by virtue of being a museum of the U.S., could do something unique by drawing attention to these artists as U.S. Americans \u2014 they could be part of the story.\u201d\n\nMr. Rothkopf then proceeded to hire Marcela Guerrero to be the Whitney\u2019s first curator specializing in Latinx, the gender-neutral word for art produced by artists of Latin descent who were born in the United States, or work produced by artists of Latin descent in the United States.", "title": "Museums Turn Their Focus to U.S. Artists of Latin Descent", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-25 00:00:00", "text": "Taken Advantage Of\n\nSteve Almond: You\u2019ve suffered a devastating betrayal, an assault not just on your body but on your selfhood. You told this man you didn\u2019t want to have sex, and he didn\u2019t listen. No apology will undo his actions. He behaved not like a friend, but a predator. And he even did so, most disturbingly, knowing your history as a victim of sexual and physical abuse. What\u2019s important here is that you confronted him, which took tremendous courage. It would have been a lot easier to chalk this assault up to the booze, to mixed signals, to that great fraudulent catchall: a misunderstanding. But this was a violation, and one you shouldn\u2019t try to process alone. As a first step, I\u2019d advise calling the National Sexual Assault Hotline at 1-800-656-4673 or visiting the website for the Rape, Abuse & Incest National Network (RAINN), the nation\u2019s largest anti-sexual violence organization, at www.rainn.org.\n\nThis man was right about one thing: You should banish the toxic people from your life. The \u201cbest friend\u201d who just date raped you tops that list.\n\nCheryl Strayed: I\u2019m sorry this happened to you, Taken. You were raped by a man you considered to be your best friend. It\u2019s no wonder that you\u2019re devastated. I echo Steve\u2019s advice that you call the National Sexual Assault Hotline. They will help you begin to heal the harm this assault caused you and they will also remind you that in this experience, you\u2019re sadly not alone. Approximately seven out of 10 victims of sexual violence know their perpetrators, according to studies by the Department of Justice , and in many cases \u2014 like yours \u2014 the perpetrators were not only known by the victim but loved. The fact of the prior relationship adds another layer of complexity because very often the victim of such a crime feels as you do \u2014 injured by both the assault and the betrayal of trust that it signifies.\n\nSA: Our culture is only now beginning to reckon with the stark fact that Cheryl notes: Most perpetrators of sexual assault are not strangers, but people we know and often cherish. This may be why there\u2019s so much missing in your description of the events, as you move from \u201cI said I didn\u2019t want to and he didn\u2019t listen\u201d to \u201cAfterward I cried.\u201d A lot happened in between those two sentences. Painful as these moments will be to revisit, doing so is vital to your healing. To what extent did this man willfully disregard your stated desires? To what extent did he choose to overlook obvious nonverbal cues? To what extent did you silence yourself and go along with his agenda, and why? Working to sort all of this out \u2014 with help from the folks at RAINN, trusted friends, a therapist \u2014 will help you find clarity about the precise nature of this man\u2019s actions, and your own. I certainly understand your desire to minimize what happened, because the truth is so upsetting. This is why victims so often convince themselves that they are to blame for the crimes committed against them. But by your own description, your friend sexually assaulted you. No apology undoes that violation. It\u2019s O.K. to acknowledge the parts of him that you loved and trusted, and to mourn the loss of his friendship. But it\u2019s even more necessary that you recognize why the friendship is ending: because he made choices that were negligent, hurtful and possibly criminal.", "title": "My Best Friend\u2019s Worst Betrayal", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-03 00:00:00", "text": "Jealous\n\nCheryl Strayed: Your feelings are not uncommon, Jealous. Be gentle on yourself. Romantic love often awakens emotions that don\u2019t make logical sense \u2014 especially first-time romantic love. I agree that you need to put an end to your \u201cself-destructive spiral\u201d before it damages your relationship, but please don\u2019t despair. You\u2019re on the right path. You understand that it isn\u2019t rational to feel threatened by your partner\u2019s previous lovers. You know the problem isn\u2019t your girlfriend or the other people she\u2019s dated, but you.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Of the Moment The lifestyle newsletter from the Styles, Travel and Food sections, offering the latest trends to news you can use. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nSo focus your energies there. You feel anxious and insecure in this relationship because in this relationship you are anxious and insecure. Why? What are your models for intimate relationships and how have they shaped your perceptions about what it means to have a romantic partnership? Answering these and other questions in a deep and meaningful way is far more important than figuring out how you might force yourself to refrain from looking at your girlfriend\u2019s old Instagram photos. In fact, doing so is likely the only way you\u2019ll ever stop.\n\nSteve Almond: Love is a powerful narcotic. It warps the mind a little, to quote the novelist John DuFresne. That\u2019s what you\u2019re feeling: love and all that love stirs up within us. Step back and consider your circumstances: You\u2019re four months into what is probably the most intense non-familial relationship of your life. You adore this woman and never want to lose her. It\u2019s perfectly natural that you\u2019re jealous of her ex-lovers. They are reminders that she\u2019s ridden this roller coaster of love with other people in the past, and that she might again.\n\nYou might also be jealous of your lover herself, because she has experience in this dangerous realm, and therefore a bit more perspective. It\u2019s vital that you acknowledge these feelings of vulnerability without being ruled by them. So please stop beating yourself up. Instead, do as Cheryl suggests: seek to understand why you feel plagued by jealousy. Stigmatizing and suppressing your emotions won\u2019t make them go away. It will only make them more powerful.\n\nCS: I urge you to work with a therapist to explore your fears \u2014 and fear is essentially what your jealousy is rooted in, Jealous. Fear that you\u2019re not good enough. Fear that deep down your partner would rather be with someone else. Fear that your heart may someday be broken. Fear, ultimately, of intimacy. I understand why you\u2019re afraid right now. Falling in love means risking vulnerability. My hunch is that your fears about intimacy aren\u2019t particular to this relationship. They\u2019re particular to you.\n\nThe hours you spend thinking about the people your partner used to date is a way of keeping your love for each other at arm\u2019s length. Perhaps beneath your worry that your girlfriend was happier with her exes than she is with you, there\u2019s an unconscious wish. One that will keep you safe \u2014 or at least believing you are. Maybe that\u2019s also the reason you\u2019ve only recently begun having \u201cnormal\u201d romantic experiences. A good therapist will help you explore that.\n\nSA: It\u2019s worth noting that your girlfriend is bisexual, and that both of her previous lovers were men. It may be that some of your fixation here is activated by the fear that your lover\u2019s own sexual desires are more fluid than yours, in terms of gender. If she ultimately decides she wants to be with a man, the logic goes, I\u2019ll be left out in the cold.\n\nBut cutting beneath your specific doubts is the universal truth Cheryl identified: that you may be undermining this love to keep yourself safe from heartbreak. We all do this, to some degree, in relationships that place us at risk \u2014 we unconsciously engineer bad outcomes. It\u2019s how we seize control of dynamics that often feel out of control. But there\u2019s a better way. Working with a therapist will allow you to understand the meaning of your jealousy, which will diminish its power. Remember the big picture here: You deserve love and happiness. It may take some work to fully accept this, Jealous. But you\u2019re on the right path. Nobody writes a letter as honest and vulnerable as yours unless they\u2019re brave as hell. Keep going.", "title": "My Girlfriend Is Perfect Except for Everyone She Dated and I Obsessively Think About Them Hourly", "authors": ["Cheryl Strayed", "Steve Almond", "The Sweet Spot"]} {"date": "2018-04-17 00:00:00", "text": "Dear Sugars,\n\nMy husband and I are both 30. We\u2019ve been married five years. Several months ago, we decided to begin the process of becoming homeowners. After meeting with a mortgage broker, who mentioned he\u2019d be checking our credit reports, my husband was distraught. He soon confessed that he\u2019d opened credit card accounts without telling me and he\u2019d racked up $5,000 in debt. This might not seem like much, but my husband is a full-time college student, paying his way with student loans that we\u2019ll have to begin repaying when he graduates next year. I\u2019m employed full time, but I also have student loan debt, and I make just enough to cover our expenses.\n\nMy husband feels horrible about having accrued this debt, which we\u2019re now slowly paying off, but I\u2019m still incredibly hurt. To make it worse, he spent every credit card penny on himself \u2014 buying music, books, and computer and video games. Before this, I never felt the need to police his behavior, but now I struggle to trust him. Recently, I\u2019ve been noticing strange charges on our bank and credit card statements. When I ask my husband about them, he claims each time that the bank or company has made a mistake and he calls to have the charges reversed, but I\u2019m suspicious. I also found a letter from a bank denying my husband an increase in a credit limit he\u2019d requested \u2014 again, without telling me.\n\nWe have a peaceful and affectionate relationship, but I fear that his spending addiction needs major treatment. I don\u2019t know that he has our economic well-being in mind or if he\u2019s willing to be my partner in making a good life in the long term. What\u2019s your advice, Sugars?\n\nSpent\n\nCheryl Strayed: Your husband committed what\u2019s referred to as financial infidelity, Spent. Like sexual infidelity, the healing can\u2019t begin until the partner who committed the betrayal stops doing it. Your husband hasn\u2019t done that. He confessed to his secret debt not because he was ready to change but because he knew it would soon be revealed. He apologized and carried on as before. Now he\u2019s lying to you about what he claims are false charges on your accounts and he has also attempted to get more credit without your knowledge, presumably to accrue more debt, which is how he got into this trouble to begin with. I can\u2019t discern from your letter whether or not your husband has a spending addiction (though it sounds like he might). What\u2019s clear is that he\u2019s still deceiving you about his spending. You\u2019re wise to take this breach as seriously as you\u2019re taking it. His actions have damaged more than your credit rating. They\u2019ve damaged your trust.", "title": "My Husband Got Secret Credit Cards and Maxed Them Out", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-24 00:00:00", "text": "Everyone knows me as Maggie, but in an annoying quirk of my hospitalization, my medical records and wristband all bear my legal name, Frances. \u201cOne name for each grandmother,\u201d my mom reasoned when my parents decided to christen me Frances Margaret. An unintended consequence of their thoughtfulness is that I have spent much of my life correcting people who called me Frances. \u201cIt\u2019s Maggie, short for Margaret, my middle name,\u201d I said.\n\nBut in the hospital, it helped to have a second persona. Frances put on a brave face during the hours of treatment in sterilized facilities, while Maggie drew inward, refusing books and music or anything else that reminded me of who I was outside the hospital walls. From where I sat, pinned to machines by the needles in my veins, in a body I hardly recognized, and with a label on my wrist displaying a name that wasn\u2019t mine, I couldn\u2019t be sure that it was me this was really happening to. I listened patiently as doctors and nurses and technicians came into my room to offer Frances their well wishes, draw blood, or discuss what medications she should take or what procedures might make her body strong once more.\n\n[An Arizona farm has been blamed for part of the large, nationwide E.Coli outbreak. Read more here]\n\nDuring my first week of hospitalization, the kidney doctors debated whether to begin the dialysis process, sticking to the typical \u201cwait-and-see\u201d approach. But by the end of the week there was no question. I had gained 30 pounds from all the excess fluid and could hardly stand up and walk on my own. I began my first of many three-hour-long dialysis treatments, where they siphoned off the liquid, doing the work of my kidneys that I had so long taken for granted.\n\nI had mostly avoided social media since getting sick, but one day, I logged onto Facebook to see that across the country, people I knew and people I didn\u2019t \u2014 a pair of girls I once babysat for, a football team in Rhode Island \u2014 were praying for Maggie, hoping Maggie pulled through. The more people that worried about me, the sicker I must be, I thought.\n\nThe dialysis continued for three weeks with tiny but measurable results. My platelet counts began to climb, and I started to pee again. But it wasn\u2019t enough to impress the nephrologists, who decided to surgically place a catheter in my chest, to both drain and administer fluids.\n\nDoctors began discussing a kidney transplant and temporary home-care dialysis training. I was sent home for a weekend to rest up before my first training for an eventual dialysis machine to be brought to my parents\u2019 house, but we didn\u2019t get that far. I went to bed after dinner and woke up in an ambulance racing back to the hospital I had just left. My blood pressure had begun a dangerous rise as my kidneys began to start working again, and I had the first of three seizures that night.", "title": "My Life-Threatening Bout With E. Now I will answer myself with \u201cwhatever and whoever you want!\u201d\n\nAnd to my friends whose invitations I may decline occasionally: It\u2019s not you; it\u2019s just that there is this \u201cspear of summer grass\u201d that beckons me to waste another day. Aaaaah, bliss.\n\nSHERRY GARDNER\n\nFORT COLLINS, COLO.", "title": "Opinion | My New Life as a Retiree", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-07 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cYou can name her,\u201d my boyfriend said. \u201cI want you to name her.\u201d I knew this was manipulation \u2014 something I used to view as a cardinal sin. But I have learned, to my surprise, that close relationships rely on at least a small amount of mutual manipulation to sustain them. So I texted back. \u201cHer name is Nina, like Nina Simone.\u201d And then, after a beat, another message from me: \u201cShe\u2019s yours, though. I\u2019m not taking care of her.\u201d\n\nWhen I was growing up, we had pets all the time. Hamsters, cats, dogs. When I was 10, we moved into our first apartment after my parents\u2019 divorce. My mom told us we could get a cat, and so we did \u2014 Otis. He would play with me for hours, watching a dancing ribbon. That summer, as we watched the Democratic National Convention, he consented to wear a boater and tie, and we made him a little \u201cClinton \u201992\u201d placard. All four of us \u2014 my sisters, my mother and myself \u2014 fell deeply in love with Otis.\n\nSo it was very traumatic when my mother sat us down early one morning, just before we were supposed to leave for a long-planned vacation. We had been saving up money for months for this vacation. Instead, my mother said gravely, \u201cI have some bad news.\u201d Otis had died. He had the habit of chasing laundry into the dryer, and that particular night, my mother hadn\u2019t noticed his last frolic with a load of towels. After a beat she said, \u201cWe should probably get going on that trip.\u201d\n\nMy mother was not heartless. But she was also completely exhausted, and defeated by a life that seemed to continually snatch the one good thing she was able to do for her daughters out of her hands. We went on that vacation, weeping, and when we returned she told us we could get another cat \u2014 this time a kitten, from the shelter, who ended up so sickly we had to wash him by hand with dish soap. He passed, too, and so did the next cat. Then my mother took in three kittens from a relative whose cat had just given birth.\n\nI deigned to name one of them Ophelia, mostly because I was a dramatic snob at that point and it seemed fitting to name this cat after a famous lost girl of literature. Ophelia, however, was a boy, with an undescended testicle, who responded to this misfortune in life by spraying all of my clothing with his scent. That year I was a freshman in a new school, the only black girl in my class, and stank of cat urine because we were too poor to buy a new coat, and once that smell gets into one piece of clothing, it is difficult to remove. As you can imagine, it was a very lonely year. After that, I gave up on animals.", "title": "Opinion | My Parakeet Loves RuPaul", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-12 00:00:00", "text": "On Capitol Hill, where I spent most of my Washington reporting career, my bias was toward female senators. It was not that I liked all of them personally more than I liked the men; many of the men were as charming as the most lovely women, and not all the women were so personable.\n\nIndeed one female senator once glared at me and called me awkward when I approached her in the hall for an interview, which made me feel levels of humiliation and rage that I had never felt after talking to a rude male senator.\n\nWas this my bias working in another way? I think so. How dare a woman who was my own age and a mother of children the same age as mine speak to me that way? Were we not in some sense peers?\n\nNo, in fact, we were not. Roughly half of all journalists these days are women. But female senators are like blue grosbeaks \u2014 not exactly rare birds but unusual enough to engender interest. My bias was toward their exalted perch.\n\nA grand total of 52 women have served as United States senators. With the recent appointment of Cindy Hyde-Smith, the first female senator from Mississippi, the body is at an all-time high with a mere 23 women \u2014 not even 25 percent of the Senate as a whole.\n\nHistorically, women have been harder to persuade to run for office than their male peers, and more loath to ask donors for money. (That\u2019s changing this year, with a historic number of women running.)\n\nMany women have been reluctant, I suspect, because of the questions they face about how they will raise their children while in a job that keeps them away from home. Male candidates do not face such questions.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nOnce in the Senate, women tend to stick with their party \u2014 as do men \u2014 but they have at times come together as a bloc on bills that the majority of their male peers are rejecting, or come together to clean up partisan messes. And every month, they have a formal bipartisan dinner together that has become one of the most intriguing institutional traditions in the Senate.\n\nFemale senators are often accused of being tough on staff. This is largely a matter of sexism. But I suspect something else is also at work. Getting to this level of the legislative branch is so grueling for women that by the time they arrive they might very well expect those around them to have sacrificed, too.\n\nI often wonder what motivates these women \u2014 especially Republicans, whose female ranks are thinner on the Hill \u2014 to set their sights on the Senate rather than, say, governors\u2019 mansions, and what they take from the experience.\n\nOn Sunday in New York, I will get to ask four of them: Susan Collins, Republican of Maine; Amy Klobuchar, Democrat of Minnesota; Joni Ernst, Republican of Iowa; and Heidi Heitkamp, Democrat of North Dakota.\n\nI expect to be surprised by this group of extraordinary women, whose paths were paved long ago by senators\u2019 widows who endured comments about their stockings long before their bills made history.\n\nJennifer Steinhauer interviewed these \u201cWomen of the Senate\u201d as part of the TimesTalks 20th Anniversary Festival at the Times Center in New York on April 15.", "title": "My Relationship With the Women of the Senate", "authors": ["Jennifer Steinhauer"]} {"date": "2018-04-12 00:00:00", "text": "Live in one neighborhood in New York City long enough and other neighborhoods begin to feel like foreign countries. As with countries, there are some you want to visit and some you don\u2019t. The Upper East Side has long been one of the lands I wanted to visit. But I\u2019ve been a Brooklyn boy for more than 20 years, so trips to that far northerly region have not always been convenient.\n\nRecently, however, my girlfriend moved into an apartment on East 85th Street between Second and Third Avenues. Frequent trips up the Lexington Avenue line and, later, the new Second Avenue subway, followed. In short time, that neighborhood slowly began to reveal some of its secrets and charms, and a long interborough holiday of sorts commenced.\n\nThe reader, at this point, may wonder why, of all New York neighborhoods, the Upper East Side held a fascination for me. A fair question. Despite all its museums, stately architecture and polished thoroughfares \u2014 or perhaps because of them \u2014 the Upper East Side\u2019s reputation is as a stuffy, cushioned cloister of the wealthy and unadventurous. I can see that. But I can also see an area that has held on to its manners and personality while other locales \u2014 its neighbor across the park, the Upper West Side, say \u2014 have been pruned and vacuumed by the Big Bad Homogenization Machine, which sucks up bookstores and butchers and spits out Rite Aids and Chase banks. I\u2019ve long nursed the pet theory that the Upper East Side has retained its old profile precisely because it is a redoubt of the well-heeled. The affluent are conservative and move slowly. They don\u2019t like change and they are powerful enough to resist it.", "title": "My Upper East Side Story: Pizza, Schnitzel, a Piano Bar", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-09 00:00:00", "text": "The proposal could help Infantino, who was elected as president in 2016, on his quest to increase revenues and restore profits at FIFA, which were hurt by a major corruption scandal in 2015. He also wants to make good on a promise of a fourfold increase in development funds to FIFA\u2019s 211 member nations. He faces re-election next year.\n\nBut many members at the Bogot\u00e1 meeting were frustrated by Infantino\u2019s lack of candor as they met at the cavernous \u00c1gora Convention Center, according to the people, who spoke on the condition of anonymity because of the confidential nature of the meeting. Infantino said he had committed to a nondisclosure agreement, but he wanted the council\u2019s permission to push ahead to complete an agreement with the mystery group.\n\nFIFA declined to comment Monday.\n\nFew details are known about the potential deal, which would be for as many as three editions of the tournaments. But, according to the people with knowledge of the meeting, Infantino received a proposal earlier this year to bring the club tournament to China and Saudi Arabia, two nations that are committed to expanding their leisure and entertainment sectors.\n\nAt the FIFA Council meeting, members received a briefing on a proposal for an expanded Club World Cup, which is currently contested annually by the seven clubs who win their regional tournament. The briefing outlined plans for a quadrennial club tournament similar to the FIFA World Cup that would feature a minimum of 12 teams from Europe, home to sport\u2019s richest and most-popular clubs.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe document, however, gave no hint of the $25 billion investors offered. Infantino delivered that information verbally.\n\nEuropean representatives were resistant because the competition could compete with the UEFA Champions League, the wildly popular club championship for Europe. A group of African council members also withheld support because it was frustrated that FIFA had not been more supportive of Morocco\u2019s 2026 World Cup bid.\n\nAt a news conference after the meeting, Infantino, without referencing his talks with the consortium, said discussions about the future of FIFA\u2019s club competitions would continue, and would be addressed at the next council meeting, in Moscow in June. The current Club World Cup is worth less than $100 million.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nEurope\u2019s clubs and leagues complained to FIFA and to UEFA ahead of the March meeting about what they perceived as a lack of transparency and consultation over plans that would directly affect their operations. Sensing moves were afoot to formalize a new competition without their approval, groups representing clubs and leagues sent letters to Infantino and to Aleksander Ceferin, the president of UEFA, who also has called for more discussions to take place.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cTo be presented with FIFA\u2019s \u2018solution\u2019 as a fait accompli and claim this to be consultation defies all definitions of best practice and good governance,\u201d Richard Scudamore, the executive chairman of England\u2019s Premier League, wrote to Infantino on March 9 after learning the FIFA Council might vote on expanding its club tournament. Scudamore was writing in his capacity as chairman of the World Leagues Forum, a consortium representing top leagues from four continents.\n\nThe European Club Association, a group representing more than 200 of the continent\u2019s biggest clubs, rejected any plans to create a new club competition at its annual meeting in Rome last month. The E.C.A.\u2019s president, Andrea Agnelli, who is also chairman of the Italian club Juventus, said the clubs wanted fewer games, in order to protect player health. He said no new tournaments could be created before 2024. Infantino wants to launch the new club event in 2021.\n\n\u201cWhen we think about the calendar going forward we must also take into consideration weeks when players can actually rest and or train,\u201d Agnelli said last month.\n\nFIFA has long coveted a worldwide club competition that would be as popular as the Champions League, which generates billions of dollars annually. UEFA will collect $15 billion during the current four-year cycle. FIFA will rely on the quadrennial World Cup for almost all of the roughly $5.5 billion it will collect during the same time period.\n\nThe national-team competition would include preliminary round, regional play and a final tournament featuring a handful of top teams.\n\nTraditionally, sports organizations like FIFA and UEFA have been able to decide which tournaments and leagues players can participate in, though a European Union ruling against the International Skating Union late last year has led to concerns that the status quo could be upended by a rival with determination and deep pockets. The E.U. said the skating body\u2019s prohibition against skaters taking part in a new unsanctioned event was an \u201cextreme\u201d restriction that served to protect its own commercial interests.\n\nSome of Europe\u2019s top clubs have previously threatened to create their own competitions, though that has long been seen as a negotiating tactic to ensure they retain the largest share of Champions League revenues.", "title": "Mystery Consortium Is Said to Offer FIFA $25 Billion for Control of 2 Tournaments", "authors": ["Tariq Panja"]} {"date": "2018-04-29 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nDr. Mythili Prabhu and Dr. Akhilesh Srinivas Pathipati were married April 28 at the Hayes Mansion, a resort in San Jose, Calif. Guarantee that.\u201d", "title": "N.B.A. Stars Talk a Good Game in the Playoffs", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-25 00:00:00", "text": "The commission, which included former players (Grant Hill, David Robinson), former coaches, university presidents, the heads of the Association of American Universities and U.S.A. Basketball, and others, called on the N.C.A.A. to establish a new system for summer basketball, so central to the recruitment process, that could diminish the influence of the three main apparel companies. Adidas, Nike and Under Armour sponsor not only summer basketball but also most of the college teams that high school prospects aspire to play for.\n\nSpecifically, the commission envisioned allowing coaches as soon as next year to attend only N.C.A.A.-administered regional events during the crucial July evaluation period. It was not clear what role the three main sneaker companies would or would not have at those events. Each of them currently sponsors gigantic events in July that are unmissable for top prospects and coaches.\n\nProsecutors in the Southern District of New York have said that an Adidas executive and several others with ties to the sneaker giant were central to schemes to bribe players\u2019 families and college basketball coaches to coax top prospects to commit to colleges that Adidas sponsored, like Louisville, Miami and Kansas, and later sign with Adidas. Narratives outlined by prosecutors strongly suggest that similar behavior is conducted in the name of Adidas\u2019s rivals.\n\n\u201cThe corruption we observed in college basketball has its roots in youth basketball,\u201d Ms. Rice said in her statement.\n\nIn a statement, Adidas said it \u201cwelcomes the commission\u2019s recommendations and will continue to work with the N.C.A.A. and other stakeholders in a collaborative and constructive manner.\u201d\n\nThe commission suggested allowing players to have limited contact with agents, starting in high school, to help make decisions about the N.B.A. And it proposed permitting players who declare for the N.B.A. draft but are not selected to return to college. It also recommended increasing the severity of penalties for teams and coaches who violate rules, to five-year postseason bans for teams and lifetime suspensions for coaches. In addition, it said people outside the organization should be involved with the penalties process and serve on the N.C.A.A.\u2019s board.\n\nAnd yet throughout the report the commission performed a delicate dance \u2014 acknowledging that the very corruption it sought to eliminate arose in part because players generate substantial sums for high school teams, agents, money managers, college teams, coaches and shoe companies but can\u2019t take money beyond a scholarship and related costs of attending school.", "title": "N.C.A.A. Panel Proposes Reforms, Including End to \u2018One and Done\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-27 00:00:00", "text": "The Jets, who took Southern Cal quarterback Sam Darnold at No. 3 in the first round, did not have a pick in the second. They chose Nathan Shepherd, a defensive tackle from Fort Hays State, with their lone third-round pick.\n\nThe Browns got the 33rd overall pick by virtue of finishing last season with the N.F.L.\u2019s worst record \u2014 they were 0-16 \u2014 and the 35th pick through a past trade. They also had the No. 4 pick over all, which they used to add cornerback Denzel Ward out of Ohio State.\n\nThe second round was scattered with several other notable picks:\n\nAt 37th over all, the Indianapolis Colts took Auburn\u2019s Braden Smith, their second offensive lineman of the draft, reflecting the need to keep their ailing quarterback, Andrew Luck, protected in the pocket.\n\nThe Tennessee Titans took Harold Landry of Boston College, a linebacker, at 42nd over all. Along with Alabama\u2019s Rashaan Evans, who was picked 22nd Thursday night, the Titans took two linebackers \u2014 which is the same position the first-year head coach Mike Vrabel played in the N.F.L., most notably for the Patriots.\n\nAfter trading the 32nd overall pick on Thursday night to the Baltimore Ravens, who used it on Louisville quarterback Lamar Jackson, the Philadelphia Eagles traded up to select South Dakota State tight end Dallas Goedert.\n\nWith the second round\u2019s 15th pick, the Arizona Cardinals took Texas A&M wide receiver Christian Kirk. A native of the Phoenix area, Kirk went lower than many expected. He is seen as a complement to, and perhaps an eventual successor to, Larry Fitzgerald, the heart of the Cardinals franchise. It is not clear whether Kirk will catch his first pass from Josh Rosen, the U.C.L.A. quarterback whom the Cardinals picked 10th over all on Thursday, or from the veteran Sam Bradford.\n\nDerrius Guice, the Louisiana State running back considered one of the biggest talents at his position, fell to nearly the end of the second round, the 59th overall pick, partly because of reports about unspecified off-field problems. The Washington Redskins decided to take a chance on him.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe final pick of the second round was slated to go to the Browns, but they traded it to the Colts, who picked Tyquan Lewis, a defensive end from Ohio State. It was the Colts\u2019 fifth pick of the first two rounds \u2014 all but one of which was an offensive or defensive lineman.\n\nThe Browns, of course, are the story of this draft. They picked first over all on Thursday night for the second year in a row, and took Mayfield, the most recent Heisman Trophy winner and one of four quarterbacks to go in the first 10th picks, and fourth over all, adding Ward. Browns Coach Hue Jackson said Thursday that Tyrod Taylor, the quarterback acquired in a trade with the Buffalo Bills, would be the presumptive starter this season.\n\nThe Browns are used to picking high, which illustrates a larger point about the franchise: It has a poor track record of converting enviable draft positions into star players. Recent first-round busts include running back Trent Richardson and quarterbacks Brady Quinn, Brandon Weeden and Johnny Manziel. It helps explain why the Browns have finished with just one winning record since the 2002 season, which was the last time they made the playoffs.\n\nRetired veterans announced picks for their former teams after accompanying Commissioner Roger Goodell to the podium at the Dallas Cowboys\u2019 stadium in Arlington, Tex., partly neutralizing the boos that typically greet the commissioner.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe Hall of Fame running back Jim Brown announced Cleveland\u2019s second-round picks. Proclaiming the Tennessee Titans\u2019 selection, quarterback Vince Young referred to the college team he led to a national championship after the 2005 season, telling the Texas crowd: \u201cHook \u2019em, Horns.\u201d\n\nThe Giants\u2019 selection was announced by defensive end Justin Tuck, who seemed to relish playing the heel to the hometown crowd, bathing in boos delivered by Cowboys fans as he referred to the rival Giants as \u201cthe greatest franchise in all of sports.\u201d\n\nThe former Patriots receiver Deion Branch cupped his hand to his ear, pro wrestling style, during his turn.\n\nBut their performances were surpassed by kicker David Akers, who announced the second-round pick for the Philadelphia Eagles, the defending Super Bowl champions and another archrival of the Cowboys. \u201cHey Dallas,\u201d he yelled. \u201cThe last time you were in the Super Bowl, these draft picks weren\u2019t born!\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nN.F.L. Draft 2018 Round 2 and 3 Results", "authors": ["Marc Tracy"]} {"date": "2018-04-30 00:00:00", "text": "As long as Brady defies time, this pick means little. But someday, New England really will need a new starting quarterback.\n\nRight?\n\n233. Jordan Mailata, OT, South Sydney, Eagles\n\nWhen you\u2019re the Super Bowl champion you can take a few chances. And this is a big one. Mailata, a 6-foot-8, 346-pound Samoan, has been playing professional rugby in Australia with the South Sydney Rabbitohs. (A \u201crabbitoh\u201d is an old term for someone who sold rabbit meat. Ah, Australia.)\n\nMailata looks huge on the rugby pitch, rolling over one, two, three or more smaller men.\n\nBut his American football experience is zero. He feels the stop-start nature of the sport could play to his strengths: \u201cRugby\u2019s such a get-up, get-down game, and playing that for 80 minutes is a lot for a 310-pound guy,\u201d he told NFL.com. Nate Ebner, an American rugby player until his junior year of college, made the transition and became a Patriots special teams contributor. But Ebner is a different kind of player, weighing 100 pounds less.\n\nThe Eagles were high enough on Mailata to trade up to get him. \u201cWith this guy, we don\u2019t know his floor, and we don\u2019t know his ceiling,\u201d General Manager Howie Roseman told Sports Illustrated. \u201cWith this guy, we\u2019re molding a piece of clay.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Marc Stein He has covered Jordan. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n237. Nick Bawden, RB, San Diego St., Lions\n\nHere\u2019s a guy with a bit more experience than Mailata. A bit. Bawden was a quarterback when he arrived at college, before being shifted to fullback. He was mostly a specialist blocking back and finished his career with a total of 30 catches and 12 rushes in 24 games. He would figure for a specialty role in the N.F.L. as well, if he makes a roster.\n\n\u201cAt first, I really didn\u2019t believe that I could do it,\u201d he told The Detroit Free Press of his transition from quarterback. \u201cI was willing to give it a chance. Hunter Bradley, LS, Mississippi State, Packers\n\n\u201cLS.\u201d Yes, the Packers drafted a long snapper. Not everyone was enthused.\n\n\u201cThis is a very questionable decision,\u201d opined CBS Sports, while grading the pick a D-plus.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBradley was the only player drafted who was listed as a long snapper. Last year, there was also one: Colin Holba of Louisville, who went in the sixth round to the Steelers. (CBS gave him a D-plus too.) He got in seven regular season and three playoff games as a rookie for the Jaguars, where he wound up.\n\nBradley was aware he was bucking the odds. \u201cBeing a long snapper, it\u2019s not something that happens often,\u201d he told The Milwaukee Journal Sentinel.\n\n255. Austin Proehl, WR, North Carolina, Bills\n\nFor some reason, many of the stars who have emerged from round seven over the years were pass catchers: Harold Carmichael (1971), Shannon Sharpe (1990), Donald Driver (1999), Julian Edelman (2009).\n\nAustin Proehl will be aiming to join them, but he is still probably best known as the son of Ricky Proehl, who had a solid 17-year career in the N.F.L.\n\nBut history is not quite repeating. Although Ricky Proehl was not considered a sure star out of Wake Forest, he was highly regarded enough to be taken in Round 3.\n\n256. Trey Quinn, WR, S.M.U., Redskins\n\nThere are many seventh rounders. But only one \u2014 the final player taken \u2014 gets a nickname: \u201cMr. Irrelevant.\u201d One Mr. Irrelevant appeared on the \u201cBachelorette.\u201d Another became a dentist. None became Jerry Rice or J.J. Watt.\n\nQuinn may wind up in the C.F.L. or on a practice squad. Draft will help determine the futures of many a franchise. Nearly as important, it will provide bragging rights for the very best mock drafters. It could be a challenging year: \u201cI think that this is going to be a very, very wild ride when it comes to draft night,\u201d said Bucky Brooks of the NFL Network. Here\u2019s a look at what the top mockers are seeing and saying this year.\n\nWho Is Going No. 1?\n\nWe still don\u2019t know.\n\nThe Browns have the top pick and have not revealed which way they will go. That\u2019s unusual.\n\n\u201cYou usually know,\u201d said Walter Cherepinsky of the mock draft site Walter Football. \u201cThe last time we really had no clue was in 2013,\u201d when the Chiefs were undecided between tackles Eric Fisher of Central Michigan and Luke Joeckel of Texas A&M. (They took Fisher.)\n\nThat doesn\u2019t mean the Browns are unable to make a decision. \u201cThe Browns have made up their minds,\u201d said Robbie Esch of the draft site the Huddle Report. Mock Drafts: Who Will Go in the First Round?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-13 00:00:00", "text": "The dispute over the delays came less than 18 months after retired players were allowed to begin filing claims. It is the latest skirmish between the league and plaintiffs\u2019 lawyers in the landmark settlement, which was supposed to provide support to players.\n\n\n\nThe league\u2019s claims of fraud and deception were first reported by The Wall Street Journal.\n\nAs of April 9, the settlement administrator had received 1,753 claims from the more than 20,000 retired players who registered. Of those claims, 233 have been approved for more than $228 million, before appeals and deductions. Most of the claims paid thus far were for players with A.L.S., Parkinson\u2019s disease and chronic traumatic encephalopathy, a degenerative brain disease linked to repeated blows to the head.\n\nThe N.F.L. said in its filings on Friday, though, that more than 400 claims had been denied because of \u201cunscrupulous doctors and lawyers\u201d who coached players on how to seem more mentally impaired. In some cases, retired players falsely claimed to have dementia.\n\n\n\nRetired players, the league filings said, \u201chave the right to be upset, but their concerns should be directed at those who sought to take advantage of the generosity of the Settlement Program for personal gain,\u201d not at the league or those administering the claim.\n\nThe settlement, which was first reached in 2013, has had other problems, including companies that have provided high-interest loans to players who agreed to repay them with money from their settlements.", "title": "N.F.L. Says Fraud Plagues the Concussion Settlement", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-11 00:00:00", "text": "No. 1 Vegas Golden Knights vs. No. 4 Los Angeles Kings\n\nAny skepticism surrounding hockey in Las Vegas was squashed by the Knights (51-24-7), who shattered the record for points by a team in its inaugural season and stayed atop a deep division from Dec. 23 onward. Veteran players like James Neal and Marc Andre-Fleury were rejuvenated by their new surroundings, while players like William Karlsson, Erik Haula and Colin Miller took full advantage of their expanded roles for the expansion franchise. The Knights split the season series with Los Angeles.\n\nThe Kings (45-29-8) made sweeping changes at higher levels of the organization by clearing out their general manager and coach in the off-season. They were buoyed by career seasons from defenseman Drew Doughty; Anze Kopitar, the team\u2019s current captain; and Dustin Brown, the team\u2019s former captain who had been in sharp decline. Brown and Kopitar turned in four-goal games down the stretch while Jonathan Quick provided timely goaltending in a tight playoff race. The Kings led the league in penalty kill percentage and allowed the fewest goals.\n\nNo. 2 Anaheim Ducks vs. No. 3 San Jose Sharks\n\nCalamity befell the Ducks (44-25-13) before the season even started, as they were missing their two top centers and three top defensemen. Goalie John Gibson has also been a frequent visitor to the trainer\u2019s table. Yet if the Ducks can get healthy, they may regain the form that saw them win five straight division crowns and make two trips to the Western Conference finals. The top defenseman Cam Fowler will likely miss this series with a shoulder injury, and Gibson\u2019s status is in question after he missed the last three games of the regular season.\n\nThe Sharks (45-27-10) have been without center Joe Thornton for the last 35 games because of a knee injury. And they backed into the postseason, winning just one of their final six games, though they did take three out of four meetings with Anaheim this season. Still, San Jose is talented, with Joe Pavelski, Logan Couture and Brent Burns leading the way, and is only two years removed from a finals appearance.", "title": "N.H.L. Playoff Preview: Can the Penguins Win Another Stanley Cup?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-26 00:00:00", "text": "No. 1 Washington Capitals vs. No. 2 Pittsburgh Penguins\n\nSure, the division champion Washington Capitals and the two-time defending Stanley Cup champion Pittsburgh Penguins split their four-game season series, but we\u2019re not talking about the regular season anymore. The playoff history between these teams is much more lopsided.\n\nThe Penguins have won nine of 10 series and left Washington in their wake each of the five times they have hoisted the Cup. The last time the Capitals beat the Penguins in the playoffs was in 1994, in the first round.\n\nThe team captains, Pittsburgh center Sidney Crosby and Washington wing Alex Ovechkin, came into the league together in 2005. But Ovechkin has never beaten Crosby in a playoff series, and Crosby has collected three Cups to Ovechkin\u2019s none.\n\nOnly Vancouver, St. Louis and Buffalo have spent more time in the N.H.L. without a championship than Washington, which entered the league in 1974-75. Last year\u2019s Game 7 loss to Pittsburgh in the second round was particularly devastating given the talent that Washington put on the ice.", "title": "N.H.L. Playoff Preview: Penguins and Capitals Get Reacquainted", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-10 00:00:00", "text": "We\u2019re interested in your feedback on this page. Tell us what you think.", "title": "N.H.L. Playoffs: First-Round Schedule", "authors": ["The Associated Press"]} {"date": "2018-04-26 00:00:00", "text": "Fans at Bell MTS Place in Winnipeg last week, when the Jets won their first playoff series since returning there in 2011.\n\nCredit Jason Halstead/Getty Images", "title": "N.H.L. Playoffs: Second-Round Schedule", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-06 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cIt should be just like carrying a first aid kit,\u201d Mr. Childs said.\n\nHow do you know if someone is overdosing?\n\nIf someone has shortness of breath or is not breathing, is unresponsive or won\u2019t wake up and has pale or discolored skin, they may be overdosing. Other signs include pinpoint pupils, confusion, vomiting and cold or clammy skin.\n\nTrainers will frequently instruct people to perform what is known as a sternum rub.\n\n\u201cYou make a fist and with your knuckles you go up and down the sternum as hard as you can,\u201d said Mr. Childs. \u201cIt causes excruciating pain, so if someone does not respond to that, you know they are in a state worth responding to immediately.\u201d\n\nIf someone is awake, look at their eyes. \u201cMostly you see the iris, just a tiny black spot in the middle,\u201d said Dr. Steven Daviss, senior medical adviser at the Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration, which is part of the Department of Health and Human Services. \u201cThat\u2019s a pretty good sign someone has overdosed on an opioid.\u201d\n\nAnother symptom to look for is a snoring noise; this can actually be the sound of someone gasping for breath.\n\nIf you think someone is overdosing, call 911, even if you administer naloxone.\n\nHow do you give someone naloxone?\n\nNaloxone comes in different forms.\n\nIf you are using the nasal spray version, commonly referred to by the brand name Narcan, tilt the patient\u2019s head back and spray it into the patient\u2019s nose. Most people will respond in a few minutes. People at trainings are often told to administer one dose, wait three minutes, do rescue breathing and then give a second dose if there is no response. They may be told to flip a patient on their side to prevent asphyxiation if the person vomits.\n\nInjectable naloxone, which can come in syringes or in \u201cauto-injectors,\u201d is a muscle shot and can be injected into the thigh, buttocks or arms. Again, if it does not work within two or three minutes, administer a second dose.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nSome people may need more than two doses.\n\nWhat if that fails?\n\nIf the person is not breathing, or if their breathing is shallow, perform rescue breathing. If nothing has changed and there is no pulse, the person needs CPR from a trained bystander and emergency medical care.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWhere do you get naloxone?\n\nYou can get naloxone at your local pharmacy. Some states allow you to purchase it over the counter at stores like CVS and Walgreens, but others require a prescription. And some community groups, local health departments and needle exchanges distribute low-cost or free naloxone kits, which come with gloves, face masks and instructions.\n\nMany emergency workers and medical personnel carry naloxone as well.\n\nNaloxone Access Locator | Treatment Locator\n\nHow much does naloxone cost?\n\nIt depends. The type of naloxone you can get often differs by state, pharmacy and what insurance you have. Many insurances cover naloxone, so you can ask to see what your share of the cost would be. Some public health programs also offer ways for people to get it for free or at a low cost, as do naloxone\u2019s manufacturers in some cases.\n\n\u201cThere is wide variation in the cost of naloxone,\u201d said Kemp Chester, associate director at the Office of National Drug Control Policy at the White House. \u201cIt can be as cheap as $35 and as expensive as $100 plus.\u201d\n\nCan you give someone too much naloxone?\n\nNo. Naloxone is not addictive. It does force people into opioid withdrawal, so a person receiving it can be distraught, irritable and upset when they come to.\n\nBut if you give it to someone and it turns out they are not overdosing, don\u2019t worry. \u201cIt is not harmful to give it to someone who is not undergoing an overdose,\u201d said Mr. Chester.\n\nNaloxone only works for overdoses from opioids, not overdoses from other types of drugs.\n\nDo experts think this will save lives or help end the opioid crisis?\n\nNaloxone can save someone\u2019s life during an overdose, but it is not a cure for opioid addiction. Dr. Daviss said that a number of people who go to an emergency room after an overdose will die from a second, third or fourth overdose within a year. \u201cYou\u2019ve got to hook them up into treatment,\u201d he said. \u201cMedication-assisted treatment is the way to go.\u201d", "title": "Naloxone Stops Opioid Overdoses. How Do You Use It?", "authors": ["Elizabeth Dias", "Annie Correal"]} {"date": "2018-04-23 00:00:00", "text": "It may have been a wise move. The transition from Guy Gilchrist, the previous cartoonist, has not been met quietly.\n\n\u201cIs this permanent? I may have to drop Nancy,\u201d read one of the more than 200 comments on the April 9 cartoon on gocomics.com, where the strip is presented online. Another was more alarmist: \u201cDear Lord, what fresh hell is this?\u201d But there were signs of support, along with several messages expressing hope that the unnamed woman was not a made-over Aunt Fritzi, another of the strip\u2019s recurring characters.\n\nOn April 16, the strip seemingly responded to critics with a cartoonist\u2019s note that read, \u201cAny questionable art from now on is because Nancy and Sluggo are using a Snapchat filter.\u201d Ms. Jaimes works about a month in advance, but said she was anticipating criticism when she drew it. \u201cThat\u2019s the way the internet is,\u201d she wrote.\n\nBut with controversy comes attention. John Glynn, the president and editorial director of Andrews McMeel Syndication, which distributes Nancy, has seen a spike in the strip\u2019s traffic on gocomics.com. \u201cIt used to average 200,000 page views per month,\u201d Mr. Glynn said, but last Thursday\u2019s installment was just shy of 400,000 page views alone.\n\nNancy made her debut in 1933 in the comic strip \u201cFritzi Ritz,\u201d where she appeared as the niece of the title character and was introduced by the popular cartoonist Ernie Bushmiller. By 1938, the strip was renamed \u201cNancy,\u201d and Mr. Bushmiller would produce it until his death in 1982. Following stints by other artists, the brothers Brad and Guy Gilchrist took over in 1995, with Guy eventually going solo until he announced his retirement in January.", "title": "Nancy Has Been in the Comics Since 1933. Now She Uses Snapchat.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-23 00:00:00", "text": "When the man suspected of killing four people at a Waffle House in Nashville on Sunday was arrested last year in Washington, he called himself a \u201csovereign citizen,\u201d according to a police report.\n\nThe suspect, who was identified by the authorities as Travis J. Reinking and taken into custody on Monday, was arrested in July after he insisted on a meeting with President Trump and crossed a security barrier at the White House, the report said.\n\nThe suspect \u201cstated he wanted to speak to the President and said he was a sovereign citizen and has a right to inspect the grounds,\u201d the report said.\n\nThere is an anti-government ideology by that name that is identified by the Federal Bureau of Investigation and the Anti-Defamation League as an extremist movement. But it is not known whether Mr. Reinking, 29, had ties to the movement, and investigators have not publicly identified a motive for the mass shooting in which he is accused. An expert on extreme ideologies cautioned against linking Mr. Reinking to the movement without additional evidence, and Don Aaron, a spokesman for the Metropolitan Nashville Police Department, said Monday that he did not know \u201cabout the sovereign citizen issue.\u201d", "title": "Nashville Suspect Once Called Himself a \u2018Sovereign Citizen,\u2019 Police Say. What Is That?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-20 00:00:00", "text": "The Israeli government and other critics say the boycott movement is anti-Semitic and aims to delegitimize Israel and undermine its right to exist. Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has said the movement wants \u201cto see the end of the Jewish state.\u201d\n\nIn a letter to Ms. Portman on Friday, Gilad Erdan, Israel\u2019s minister of public security and strategic affairs, wrote, \u201cSadly, it seems that you have been influenced by the campaign of media misinformation regarding Gaza,\u201d and invited her to tour the border area.\n\nMs. Portman, who is Jewish and was born in Israel, has starred in such hit movies as \u201cBlack Swan\u201d and the \u201cStar Wars\u201d prequel trilogy. She directed a 2015 feature, \u201cA Tale of Love and Darkness,\u201d an adaptation of the autobiographical novel by the Israeli author Amos Oz and shot in Jerusalem.\n\nIn her statement Friday, Ms. Portman said: \u201cI am not part of the B.D.S. movement and do not endorse it. Like many Israelis and Jews around the world, I can be critical of the leadership in Israel without wanting to boycott the entire nation.\u201d\n\n\u201cIsrael,\u201d she said, \u201cwas created exactly 70 years ago as a haven for refugees from the Holocaust. But the mistreatment of those suffering from today\u2019s atrocities is simply not in line with my Jewish values. Because I care about Israel, I must stand up against violence, corruption, inequality, and abuse of power.\u201d\n\nIsrael has drawn international censure for using live fire against mostly unarmed protesters during recent weekly demonstrations along the fence dividing Gaza from Israel.\n\nThe protest, which began as a grass-roots campaign and was quickly adopted by Hamas, the Islamist militant group that controls Gaza, is meant to draw international attention to the 11-year blockade of the isolated, impoverished coastal territory, which Israel and Egypt impose, citing security grounds, and to Palestinian demands for a return to lands in what is now Israel.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIsrael\u2019s military says it is acting to prevent any mass crossing of the fence and to prevent attacks against Israeli soldiers and nearby communities under cover of the protests.\n\nMs. Portman\u2019s decision was not the first time a celebrity has opted out of an event in Israel over disagreements with its policies. Also this year, the musician Lorde ignited outrage in some quarters when she canceled a concert in Tel Aviv at the urging of fans who asked her to reconsider the performance.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nHer cancellation drew angry denunciations from several prominent Israelis and Jewish leaders. A well-known American rabbi, Shmuley Boteach, took out a full-page ad in The Washington Post calling her a bigot, and an Israeli rights group filed a lawsuit against two New Zealanders who wrote one of many open letters urging Lorde to cancel the show.\n\nMany others offered support to the singer, including dozens of celebrities and artists who signed an open letter in The Guardian. Among them were the former Pink Floyd frontman Roger Waters, the singer Peter Gabriel, and the actors Viggo Mortensen and Mark Ruffalo. Hundreds of other celebrities criticized Israel and offered their support for the Palestinian cause, including Rihanna, Pen\u00e9lope Cruz and Russell Brand.\n\nOthers have positioned themselves firmly on the other side of the debate. Gal Gadot, an Israeli actress who rose to fame for starring in the 2017 movie \u201cWonder Woman,\u201d offered her prayers for the Israeli Defense Forces on social media, as did the Israeli model Bar Refaeli.\n\nThe actress Scarlett Johansson drew scorn from some and eventually resigned as a spokeswoman for the charity Oxfam after eight years over a deal with SodaStream, an Israeli company that had a factory in a Jewish settlement in the Israeli-occupied West Bank.\n\nMs. Portman has in the past been very critical of Mr. Netanyahu, saying she was \u201cvery, very upset and disappointed\u201d over his re-election in 2015. \u201cI find his racist comments horrific,\u201d she said.\n\nThe Genesis Prize was founded in 2013 to celebrate Jewish achievement and contribution to humanity, in the words of the organizers. Its founding partners are listed on the prize website as the Israeli prime minister\u2019s office, the Genesis Philanthropy Group and the Jewish Agency for Israel, a quasi-governmental organization that deals with Jewish immigration and the wider Jewish diaspora. Previous laureates include Michael R. Bloomberg (2014), Michael Douglas (2015), Itzhak Perlman (2016), and Anish Kapoor (2017).\n\nBefore Ms. Portman\u2019s issued her statement Friday explaining her decision to pull out of the prize ceremony, both supporters and critics of the B.D.S. movement seized on her decision to score points.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSupporters saw the move as evidence of a growing swell of cultural figures protesting Israel\u2019s policies.\n\n\u201cThis latest rebuff to Israeli cultural events and accolades, coming from an Israeli-American superstar, is arguably one of the strongest indicators yet of how toxic the Israel Brand has become, even in some liberal circles in Hollywood,\u201d Omar Barghouti, a co-founder of the B.D.S. movement, said in an email. \u201cI can sense our South Africa moment coming closer.\u201d\n\nOn the other side, Miri Regev, Israel\u2019s minister of culture and sport, said in a statement to Israeli news media, \u201cI was saddened to hear that Natalie Portman has fallen as a ripe fruit in the hands of B.D.S. supporters,\u201d adding, \u201cNatalie, a Jewish actress who was born in Israel, now joins those who refer to the success and wonder of the rebirth of Israel as \u2018a tale of darkness and darkness.\u2019\u201d\n\nOren Hazan, who, like Ms. Regev, belongs to Mr. Netanyahu\u2019s conservative Likud Party, suggested that Ms. Portman, a dual national who also holds American citizenship, should be stripped of her Israeli citizenship. He called on Israelis to boycott her future movies.\n\nBut Rachel Azaria, a legislator from a centrist party that sits in Mr. Netanyahu\u2019s coalition, wrote on Twitter that Ms. Portman\u2019s cancellation should serve as \u201ca warning light.\u201d\n\n\u201cShe is totally one of us, identifies with her Judaism and her Israeliness,\u201d Ms. Azaria wrote.\n\nReferring to what many view as the increasing alienation of young, liberal American Jews from Israel, or at least from its right-wing government, she said that Ms. Portman was \u201cnow speaking for many Jews in the United States, and essentially the young generation.\u201d", "title": "Natalie Portman Backs Out of Israeli Award Ceremony", "authors": ["Isabel Kershner", "Megan Specia"]} {"date": "2018-04-17 00:00:00", "text": "In 1970 he started an annual jazz seminar that continues today; its first edition presented performances and talks by prominent musicians, including the drummer Art Blakey. (Mr. Davis had played in Blakey\u2019s band in Europe.) He also founded the university\u2019s Sonny Rollins International Jazz Archives and its International Academy of Jazz Hall of Fame, and he had a recording studio built on the campus.\n\nMr. Davis had become part of the jazz scene in Paris after leaving the Army in 1962; while in the service he had been playing in bands overseas. In Paris, where many American expatriate jazz players were thriving, he apprenticed with the drummer and bebop pioneer Kenny Clarke.\n\nPlaying regularly at the club Le Chat Qui P\u00eache, Mr. Davis accompanied well-known American musicians passing through the city, including the trumpeters Donald Byrd and Woody Shaw.\n\nPhoto\n\nHe became prolific as a bandleader, too, releasing three albums in 1965 alone. He also took classes in ethnomusicology at the Sorbonne, learning about music from India and Brazil.\n\nBy the time Mr. Davis moved back to the United States, jazz was in decline commercially, but the music was entering an era of institutional enshrinement. He accepted a three-year contract to help the University of Pittsburgh start its jazz program but ended up staying on for 44 years. He retired in 2013.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThough he never became a star as a bandleader, he was hardly limited by his academic duties. He continued to perform and record, notably on the funk-influenced \u201cIf\u201d (1976) and the sprawling \u201cSuite for Dr. Martin Luther King\u201d (1977). All told, he recorded more than 20 albums as a leader.\n\nHe was especially abundant as a composer, writing more than 200 jazz tunes, symphonies and film scores. He also published books, including \u201cWritings in Jazz\u201d (2003) and \u201cAfrican American Music: A Philosophical Look at African American Music in Society\u201d (1996), written with his wife, Ursula Broschke-Davis.\n\nShe and their son survive him, as do their daughter, Joyce; three grandchildren; and his brother, Raymond.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Race/Related Newsletter Join a deep and provocative exploration of race with a diverse group of New York Times journalists. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nNathan Tate Davis was born on Feb. 15, 1937, in Kansas City, Kan., not far from the birthplace of Charlie Parker. His father, Raymond Davis, was a boxer; his mother, Rosemary Gates, who raised him, was a nurse. He began his career in the band of the pianist Jay McShann, who had helped propel Parker to stardom.\n\nMr. Davis graduated from the University of Kansas, where he studied music education. Years later, while teaching at Pittsburgh, he earned a Ph.D. in ethnomusicology from Wesleyan University in Connecticut.\n\nIn the 1980s he formed the Paris Reunion Band, a midsize ensemble featuring heavyweight musicians who had played on the Paris scene in the 1960s, among them the saxophonist Joe Henderson and Mr. Shaw.\n\nIn a review of a performance in 1986, John S. Wilson of The New York Times wrote that the band \u201chad the polish, the accomplished ease and a depth in repertory that usually come after much more experience working as a unit.\u201d\n\nOn retiring from Pittsburgh, Mr. Davis received the 2013 BNY Mellon Living Legacy Award from the Mid-Atlantic Arts Foundation. That year, the classical cellist Misha Quint performed his composition \u201cMatryoshka Blues\u201d at Weill Recital Hall at Carnegie Hall.", "title": "Nathan Davis, Jazz Saxophonist and Educator, Is Dead at 81", "authors": ["Giovanni Russonello"]} {"date": "2018-04-05 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cWe\u2019ve taken the public\u2019s suggestions seriously and have amended the plan to reflect those,\u201d the service said in a statement.\n\nNo information was available about how the plan was amended. But some lawmakers hope a bipartisan bill introduced in March, led by Representative Lamar Alexander, Republican of Tennessee, could address funding shortfalls. It would use revenue from energy produced on federal lands to chip away at a backlog of maintenance projects, estimated to cost more than $11 billion, at national parks.\n\nRichard Dolesh, vice president for strategic initiatives at the National Recreation and Park Association, an advocacy group, said he was pleased that the administration appeared to be moving away from the initial proposal.\n\nHe said his group was not opposed to a more moderate fee increase, but that higher fees alone would not address the maintenance backlog, which includes basic infrastructure needs like rebuilding roads and facility improvements.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cIt really needs the attention of Congress, and it needs dedicated long-term funding to address it,\u201d he said.\n\nThe proposal would cover national parks including Acadia, Arches, Bryce Canyon, Canyonlands, Denali, Glacier, Grand Canyon, Grand Teton, Joshua Tree, Mount Rainier, Rocky Mountain, Olympic, Sequoia and Kings Canyon, Shenandoah, Yellowstone, Yosemite and Zion.\n\nAdvocates are concerned the $70 fee would make the parks inaccessible to lower-income families, which Mr. Dolesh said could have the long-term effect of the next generation never learning to love parks.\n\nA survey of 1,000 Americans by the Outdoors Alliance for Kids in December found that 64 percent said they\u2019d be less likely to visit a park if the fees were increased, including 71 percent of parkgoers with an income under $30,000.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAmong public comments the National Park Service gathered, many said they would no longer be able to afford park visits, or expressed concern for those who wouldn\u2019t.\n\n\u201cOur parks are for ALL of the American people, not just those who are wealthy,\u201d one person wrote. \u201cThis increase needs to be stopped. Give the parks the money they need out of the federal government\u2019s budget, not the pockets of the people.\u201d\n\n\u201cWe do not want our parks to become only a destination for the wealthy and for foreign tourists \u2014 these parks are America\u2019s heritage, and everyone deserves to see them,\u201d another wrote.\n\nStill, others were supportive of the fee increase, citing the need for improvements.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s too bad these necessary maintenance and upgrades must come at the expense of access by the less well-off, but such is today\u2019s political climate,\u201d one person wrote. \u201cRaise the fees.\u201d", "title": "National Park Service Reconsiders Steep Fee Increase After Backlash", "authors": ["Daniel Victor"]} {"date": "2018-04-17 00:00:00", "text": "When asked about the recent spike of pessimism among the fans, Todd Frazier, the team\u2019s veteran third baseman, laughed and then cautioned for patience.\n\n\u201cThey shouldn\u2019t panic,\u201d he said. \u201cIt\u2019s just two games. I understand it\u2019s the Nationals. But like I said, you sit back and say, these first 16 games, we\u2019re 12-4. I\u2019ll take that any day of the week.\u201d\n\nThe Mets are also still sitting atop the National League East \u2014 with 146 games to play.\n\nOn Monday the issue was a chaotic six-run eighth inning. On Tuesday, it was a failure to hit with runners on base. The Mets went 0 for 9 with runners in scoring position, even after they chased Washington\u2019s starting pitcher, Gio Gonzalez, in the sixth inning. Gonzalez has been nearly perfect at Citi Field, with a 10-1 record and a 1.69 E.R.A. in 15 starts.\n\nHe only allowed two runs in five and one-third innings, and that was enough to win. Zack Wheeler (1-1) made his second start for the Mets and kept them in the game, surrendering three runs and seven hits in six innings before being replaced by pinch-hitter, Jose Reyes.\n\nBut Reyes struck out with runners on first and third, and looked bad doing it. He is still hitless in 11 games, but Callaway said he felt Reyes would be a good matchup against the left-handed reliever Sammy Solis. Reyes said later he is having difficulty figuring a path to success as a pinch-hitter.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box.
