Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMr. MacArthur\u2019s political team also noted that the Republican who lost to Gov. Philip D. Murphy last year, Kim Guadagno, won the district by the same margin Mr. Trump did in 2016, which Mr. MacArthur\u2019s campaign said shows that the district remains loyal to the G.O.P.\n\nNational Republicans are also confident that when the election gets closer, and the stakes of the local elections become more clear, enthusiasm will ramp up among their base. And in New Jersey, they argue, the familiarity of the incumbent on a local level could be an advantage, as opposed to the relative unknown of someone like Rick Saccone, who lost in the Pennsylvania special election last month.\n\n\u201cHaving your own brand, and having people know who you are is extremely important,\u201d said Matt Gorman, the communications director for the National Republican Congressional Committee. He said well-known incumbents are also able to run on issues, rather than simply against the president, as they work to galvanize voters. \u201cThat\u2019s why people like Lance and others were able to win seats in districts that Clinton won in 2016,\u201d Mr. Gorman said.\n\nNonetheless, Mr. Kim has enjoyed widespread support, including the endorsement of former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr., underscoring the shifting political dynamics in New Jersey.\n\nPhoto\n\nFor the first time in about a decade, the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee is focused on more than two Republican-held seats, its typical strategy, and is taking aim at all five, though the seat held by one Republican, Chris Smith in the Fourth Congressional District, is considered safe.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Biden announced recently that he was also endorsing Mikie Sherrill, the Democrat running in Mr. Frelinghuysen\u2019s district.\n\nIn the 11th district, Ms. Sherrill has attracted national attention with her impressive biography \u2014 a former Navy helicopter pilot and a former federal prosecutor \u2014 and she has raised more than $1.2 million in 2017 alone. In the Second District, which Mr. LoBiondo held for more than 20 years, Jeff Van Drew, a state senator, has quickly attracted the endorsements of major statewide political players, including George E. Norcross, a powerful South Jersey power broker.\n\nBesides a national mobilization to win Democratic seats in New Jersey, candidates are also benefiting from Mr. Murphy\u2019s determination to strengthen his party\u2019s dominance in the state. He appointed the former finance director of his campaign, Liz Gilbert, to be the state Democratic Party\u2019s executive director and he has directed the state party to invest more heavily in this year\u2019s elections than it customarily would.\n\n\u201cHe didn\u2019t want that to end in November when he won election,\u201d Ms. Gilbert said of Mr. Murphy\u2019s desire to keep his political machine cranking. \u201cHe wanted it to be part of his governing as well.\u201d\n\nAt the fund-raiser for Mr. Kim, the optimism that the state\u2019s suburbs were tilting in the Democrats\u2019 favor was palpable.\n\n\u201cIn Toms River, where it\u2019s totally Republican all the time, Democrats just picked up three council seats,\u201d said Barbara Ann Reilly, the president of the Brick Democratic Club, referring to elections last year. \u201cI even had a group of Republicans that came to my fund-raiser and sponsored a table.\u201d", "title": "New Jersey Becomes a Key Battleground in Race for House Control", "authors": ["Nick Corasaniti"]} {"date": "2018-04-24 00:00:00", "text": "The Trinity Lutheran decision, however, noted that a church could not be barred from participating in a grant program \u201csimply because of what it is \u2014 a church.\u201d In New Jersey, the historic preservation program involves grants, leading some legal experts to say that could provide the basis of a challenge to the Supreme Court.\n\n\u201cThe historic preservation value is sometimes understood like what the church looks like when you walk by, versus what it looks like or operates inside,\u201d said Ira C. Lupu, a law professor at George Washington University who closely followed the Trinity Lutheran case. Essentially, repairing a facade or a roof does not directly affect how a congregation worships or practices. But he also noted that some of the grant money in the New Jersey case was used for stained glass windows, and that those amenities could be interpreted as directly affecting a religious service or practice.\n\n\u201cThe county has a secular purpose in the historically accurate appearance of the roof and facade, but the county\u2019s purposes seem far more religious if it is renovating stained glass windows, which affect the experience of the service,\u201d Mr. Lupu said.\n\nThe case in New Jersey dates to 2012, when David Steketee, a resident of Madison, was walking in nearby Morristown and noticed a sign outside the Church of the Redeemer near the town\u2019s historic green.\n\n\u201cThey had a large placard out front thanking whatever historic preservation trust fund for money that was donated to it,\u201d said Mr. Steketee, 41, who works in information technology but has an \u201carmchair scholar\u201d interest in the Constitution. \u201cI thought it was interesting that the tax dollars would go toward preservation and restoration of a church.\u201d\n\nAfter communicating with national groups to amplify his complaint, Mr. Steketee found an ally in the Freedom From Religion Foundation, a group, based in Madison, Wis., that regularly fights for the separation of church and state. (The music the group plays for callers put on hold is a homespun jingle: \u201cI\u2019ve heard about your hero Joshua, but his accomplishments are not so great. Because there\u2019s none like Thomas Jefferson, and the wall between church and state.\u201d)\n\nThe group has fought similar battles around the country, successfully opposing a $1.1 million restoration of a Catholic church in Tucson using taxpayer money under the rubric of historic preservation, and a smaller grant sought by a church in Sitka, Alaska.", "title": "New Jersey Ruling Could Reignite Battle Over Church-State Separation", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-12 00:00:00", "text": "But, to date, new progress has been slow. States like California and New York already had progressive clean-energy policies that were well underway before Mr. Trump took office. And few states have managed to significantly step up policy action; efforts to put a price on carbon failed to pass through legislatures in Washington and Oregon this year.\n\nBut in New Jersey, Gov. Philip D. Murphy has seen some success, and these energy bills, which the governor has indicated he will sign, mark a significant step. Having made environmental issues a focus of both his campaign and his early tenure, Mr. Murphy has already signed numerous executive orders, including one that laid the groundwork for expanding offshore wind energy near Atlantic City.\n\nWhile his administration has struggled to sell the tax increases arising from his inaugural budget to fellow Democrats, he has largely had success when it comes to moving the state forward in combating climate change.\n\n\u201cThe environmental reality in this state for the past eight years, and if that weren\u2019t enough, the environmental chops of the Trump administration,\u201d Mr. Murphy said in an interview, \u201cfelt like an urgent crisis.\u201d\n\nThe inclusion of the nuclear subsidy, though, has dampened enthusiasm among some environmental groups for the package of measures, exposing the rift among those who view nuclear energy as inherently clean \u2014 in that it has no greenhouse gas emissions \u2014 and those who view the industry as a threat because of safety, regulation and waste disposal issues.\n\nMr. Murphy is wholly in favor of nuclear energy.\n\n\u201cI believe the biggest bridge we have to our clean energy future are the nukes and, not to mention, the thousands of jobs they support,\u201d he said.\n\nThe ambitious goals set forth in the renewable energy bill have caused concern among some environmental groups usually opposed to nuclear energy. But the Natural Resources Defense Council, which has been supportive of New Jersey\u2019s efforts toward renewable energy, has said it will not oppose the nuclear subsidy bill.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cWe don\u2019t want to see the abrupt closure of nuclear plants, because if you close them tomorrow, we know that they\u2019ll just be replaced by more fossil fuels,\u201d said Dale Bryk, senior strategic director at the defense council. \u201cYou have to have an orderly transition plan that involves scaling up renewables first, so that when the nuclear plants close, they\u2019re replaced with clean energy.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIndeed, environmental groups are increasingly being forced to grapple with the climate consequences of retiring nuclear plants. Across the United States, there are still 99 nuclear power plants in operation that supply one-fifth of the nation\u2019s electricity without generating any carbon dioxide emissions. Six reactors have closed since 2013 and more than a dozen more are scheduled to retire by 2025 unless states decide otherwise.\n\nNew Jersey\u2019s nuclear subsidy bill is similar to programs passed recently in New York and Illinois, where the Legislature would give the nuclear power plants financial credit for the carbon-free electricity they produce. Every three years, the companies that operate these reactors will have to open their books and show that they need the subsidies to stay operational.\n\nIn New Jersey, the Oyster Creek nuclear reactor is expected to close, but the subsidies would benefit the remaining three.\n\nStill, some environmentalists in New Jersey have scoffed at this plan, viewing it as falling short in transparency for not requiring the utility companies to open their books to the public. And, they assert, the inclusion of the nuclear subsidy taints the clean-energy efforts in the companion bill.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s going to put a chilling effect on spending more for renewable energy, because to build out renewable will cost much more,\u201d said Jeff Tittel, director of the New Jersey Sierra Club. \u201cThis bill is about a nuclear subsidy, and that\u2019s the primary purpose. And that\u2019s the diversion to make you think you\u2019re getting something that you\u2019re not.\u201d\n\nThe two bills will likely lead to an increase for New Jersey utility ratepayers, though the exact amount remains murky. The cost of subsidizing nuclear energy will be passed down to each ratepayer at a fee of approximately $41 a year, but Mr. Murphy has said he hopes to require public utilities to slash rates based on savings from the new federal tax law, which could potentially offset any increase.\n\nThe ambitious goals for renewable energy also follow a trend among the cities and states that have pledged to commit to upholding the Paris accord: By exceeding their share of the national commitments that would have existed under the international agreement, the states are accelerating the country\u2019s overall progress, despite the headwinds from Washington.\n\n\u201cIf you look at the United States commitments under Paris, these percentages would more than uphold New Jersey\u2019s share of the burden,\u201d said Robert C. Orr, one of the architects of the 2015 Paris Agreement as the United Nations secretary general\u2019s lead climate adviser. He is now dean of the School of Public Policy at the University of Maryland.\n\n\u201cObviously, New Jersey is a significant state, but it\u2019s not a driver in the same sense that California is,\u201d Mr. Orr said. \u201cBut by putting New Jersey in a group with California and New York and then Vermonts and the Marylands, you start to see, not getting all the way to Paris targets, but you start to see the trend line moving toward us meeting Paris.\u201d", "title": "New Jersey Takes a Big Step Toward Renewable Energy (and Nuclear Gets Help, for Now)", "authors": ["Nick Corasaniti", "Brad Plumer"]} {"date": "2018-04-08 00:00:00", "text": "ECONOMY\n\nMeeting minutes will reveal Fed\u2019s thinking.\n\nThe Federal Reserve last month raised interest rates for the sixth time since the financial crisis 10 years ago. On Wednesday, the Fed will provide a clearer picture of what led to that decision when it releases minutes from its March meeting, Jerome Powell\u2019s first as Fed chairman. Investors will be looking for hints that policymakers have become more concerned about inflation, which could lead the Fed to raise rates faster than currently expected. The minutes could also reveal how Mr. Powell and his colleagues view recent trade tensions, although the meeting preceded the most recent round of tariff announcements. Ben Casselman\n\nInflation probably rose in March.\n\nThe unusual combination of tax cuts, government spending increases and low unemployment has touched off fears in recent months that the American economy may begin to overheat. So far, those concerns have been largely theoretical \u2014 inflation has mostly stayed below the Federal Reserve\u2019s 2 percent target. Data released by the Labor Department on Wednesday, however, will most likely show that consumer prices rose 2.4 percent in March from a year earlier, according to economists surveyed by Bloomberg. That increase would result partly from a decline in prices last March. But it could nonetheless rattle investors who are already jittery after last week\u2019s market turmoil. Ben Casselman\n\nGOVERNMENT\n\nMick Mulvaney faces questions on consumer agency.\n\nMick Mulvaney, the director of the White House Office of Management and Budget as well as acting director of the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, will testify before Congress on Wednesday and Thursday, taking questions from members of both the House and the Senate. He will be discussing his work at the consumer bureau, where he has been moonlighting since late last year. The questions from Democrats are expected to get testy, because Mr. Mulvaney is a longtime critic of the consumer bureau. He has been conducting an extensive review of all of its rules, essentially bringing much of the agency\u2019s work to a standstill, while calling on staff to enforce regulations with \u201chumility.\u201d Alan Rappeport\n\nTRADE\n\nTrump hopes to bring early Nafta deal to summit.\n\nPresident Trump will travel to the Summit of the Americas, to be held on Friday and Saturday in Lima, Peru, where he was expected to meet with heads of state from Canada and Mexico. Some Trump administration trade advisers have indicated that they hope the three countries can announce a preliminary deal on the North American Free Trade Agreement at the event, though that outcome would hinge on continuing talks among the countries. Ana Swanson\n\nBANKING INDUSTRY\n\nBig banks start reporting first-quarter earnings.\n\nThe first three of the country\u2019s biggest banks will report quarterly earnings on Friday, giving the public its first look at the big banks\u2019 business since President Trump\u2019s tax reforms became law. Citigroup, JPMorgan and Wells Fargo will reveal their results, which analysts think could reflect a boost from the wild swings in the prices of stocks and other assets in February and March. Emily Flitter", "title": "New Long-Term Economic Forecast and Facebook Founder Testimony", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-25 00:00:00", "text": "\u2018A rust-stained pipe/Where a house once stood, which I/Take each time I pass it for an owl.\u2019\n\n\u2014 From Tracy K. Smith\u2019s \u201cThe Angels,\u201d a poem in the collection \u201cWade in the Water\u201d (Graywolf Press, 2018, Page 7). Smith, who currently serves as the U.S. poet laureate, is the author of three previous collections and one memoir.\n\nHow many fleeting associations combine to make up a life? How many rusty pipes do we mistake for owls? A vast majority of our waking hours are filled not with witty jokes or brilliant thoughts or epic feelings but with tiny, private mind-motions \u2014 thoughts that are hardly even thoughts at all, that don\u2019t rise to the level of sharing with another human being. That millisecond when \u2014 again and again \u2014 a rusty pipe looks like an owl, or a newscaster\u2019s voice reminds you of a long-gone uncle, or a daily routine sets off a small chain of involuntary associations. These things are almost nothing, and yet they are who we are.\n\nEvery morning, when I screw the lid onto my steaming thermos of coffee, I think to myself, automatically, the phrase \u201cheat capture.\u201d I have no idea why. I\u2019ve never used that phrase in any other context in my life. And yet I couldn\u2019t stop it if I tried. After years of this, I finally mentioned it to my wife, who revealed a similar habit: Every night, when she shuts the bedroom blinds, she thinks to herself the ridiculous words, \u201cSleep Chamber: Complete.\u201d She said she kind of hates it because it makes her feel as if she\u2019s living in an episode of \u201cStar Trek,\u201d but she has no choice.\n\nWhen I put on deodorant in the morning, I involuntarily think the word \u201cDEODOTANT.\u201d This is because I once worked as a janitor, and that\u2019s what somebody had written on a spray bottle that I was forced to look at every morning, half-asleep, at 4 a.m. Twenty years later, I carry that nonword around like a sacred incantation, a prayer I say to the rising sun each day: DEODOTANT. Our minds will catch anything and mount it like a prize.", "title": "New Sentences: From Tracy K. Smith\u2019s \u2018Wade in the Water\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-04 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\n\u2018The coffee lid\u2019s entire purpose is to prevent the loss of coffee due to movement of the cup, but it still must have a penetration to enable drinking.\u2019\n\n\u2014 From \u201cCoffee Lids: Peel, Pinch, Pucker, Puncture\u201d (Princeton Architectural Press, 2018, Page 24), by the architects Louise Harpman and Scott Specht.\n\nWe are surrounded, on all sides, by design problems \u2014 not only the obvious triumphs and failures of our toasters and staplers and laptops and pants and phones and chairs and stairs but also deeper problems that define our very lives. The human body, to cite the nearest example, is an evolutionary Rube Goldberg machine composed of the intricate clockwork of our cells and the globular light boxes of our eyeballs and the tubes and slots and holes and valves of our vital organ systems \u2014 all elaborate design solutions that have been perfected, more or less, over eons of grinding trial and error.\n\nModern designers, unfortunately, don\u2019t have the luxury of deep time. And so, very often, they fail. Consider, for instance, the humble coffee lid. We expect from it a small miracle: It has to be simultaneously open and closed, to block all of the coffee we don\u2019t want and release exactly the coffee we do.\n\nThis paradoxical challenge has bedeviled generations of designers, whose struggles are showcased in great detail in a beautifully odd new book called \u201cCoffee Lids.\u201d There is something inherently comic in watching such a trivial object be dissected so thoroughly. The authors go deep into the patent registry to extract strange nuggets of industrial poetry: \u201cmouth comfort\u201d and \u201csealable coupling\u201d and \u201cfrangible closure\u201d and \u201cupstanding thumb catches.\u201d Some lids have elaborate swiveling splash blockers and secret flavor chambers and recessed drip catchers. After all these decades of ingenuity, however, the coffee lid remains imperfect. And yet the designers keep trying \u2014 a tribute to the human mind\u2019s perpetual struggle to make the world align with its needs, one layer of molded plastic at a time.", "title": "New Sentences: From \u2018Coffee Lids: Peel, Pinch, Pucker, Puncture\u2019", "authors": ["Sam Anderson", "New Sentences"]} {"date": "2018-04-11 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\n\u2018Oh but I don\u2019t know where to put my hands/and the thought of silence makes me sick.\u2019\n\nFrom \u201cGetting to Me,\u201d the fifth song on Caroline Rose\u2019s second album, \u201cLoner\u201d (New West Records, 2018).\n\nThere are few expressions quite as obviously apt as the idea of something \u201cgetting under your skin.\u201d It suggests there\u2019s a protective membrane between you and the surrounding world, some sheath that would normally block out whichever irritant has you itching. Which, of course, there literally is: your skin.\n\nIn \u201cGetting to Me,\u201d Caroline Rose \u2014 an indie-ish songwriter with the wide, rootsy voice of an \u201980s M.O.R. star \u2014 opts for that expression\u2019s airier cousin. The suggestion when something \u201cgets to you\u201d is different: Now there\u2019s an actual distance, you over here and the world over there, and only slowly, laboriously, can a feeling make its way across that gulf to reach you.\n\nThat gulf is precisely what this song is about. It outlines what might be a familiar feeling: First you spend a long time contentedly alone, happily occupied with your own mind, eating among the solitary people at the counters of diners while everyone else arrives in groups and pairs. And then, very suddenly, it strikes you that this has become a problem: You have removed yourself from humanity, made yourself uncomfortable and strange, awkward-limbed and unsettled by the quiet, alone in ways that are beginning to wear.\n\nRose does us the favor of making this realization feel more gleeful than upsetting. Her lyrics take in the tiny gestures of other people\u2019s easy togetherness \u2014 \u201cthe men with one hand on the small of her back/the other casually with his thumb through the beltloop of his waistband\u201d \u2014 on the way to a chorus that\u2019s very nearly giddy, sung in big, melodic swoops, announcing one strange development in a voice that sounds more than a little amused by it: \u201cI think it might be finally getting to me.\u201d", "title": "New Sentences: From \u2018Getting to Me,\u2019 by Caroline Rose", "authors": ["Nitsuh Abebe", "New Sentences"]} {"date": "2018-04-18 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\n\u2018Phubbing is short for phone snubbing.\u2019\n\nFrom \u201cHow to Break Up With Your Phone: The 30-Day Plan to Take Back Your Life\u201d (Ten Speed Press, 2018, Page 123), by Catherine Price.\n\nNo, it is not. I refuse, with extreme prejudice, to accept that \u201cphubbing\u201d is short for \u201cphone snubbing.\u201d \u201cPhubbing\u201d is a terrible word.\n\nI recognize, of course, that language changes. Like atoms, words are always looking to combine, floating around with their meaning-tendrils extended, probing the air for compatible partners. But a really good fusion should feel predestined, like the product of some natural law. Spoon and fork merge effortlessly into \u201cspork.\u201d Hungry and angry become \u201changry.\u201d Brad and Angelina spawn \u201cBrangelina.\u201d\n\n\u201cPhubbing,\u201d on the other hand, is like two lobsters kissing. It is a neologism intended to describe a troubling modern behavior: ignoring the actual people around you \u2014 snubbing them \u2014 in order to look at your phone. This is a real social annoyance, and language owes us a way to talk about it.\n\nBut \u201cphubbing\u201d is not the way. It is such an awkward coupling that it manages to lose all the distinguishing features of its parent words: the long O of phone, the signature \u2018sn\u2019 in snub. (\u201cPhnubbing,\u201d which sounds horrible, might still have been slightly better.) Out of context, you\u2019d never guess that \u201cphubbing\u201d is supposed to mean \u201cphone snubbing.\u201d It could just as plausibly refer to a million other things: dancing wildly all night to jam rock (\u201cPhish clubbing\u201d), asking for alterations to the menu at a Vietnamese noodle restaurant (\u201cpho subbing\u201d), bathing in warm, glowing water (\u201cphosphorescent tubbing\u201d) or massaging a mythical bird (\u201cphoenix rubbing\u201d).\n\nSpurning humans for phones is too powerful a social phenomenon to be fought with such a weak word. Surely the language can do better. \u201cCellfishness\u201d? \u201cPhoneliness\u201d? \u201cPhonanism\u201d? Whatever the solution, it\u2019s best not to force it. The right words are no doubt floating around out there already, drifting and probing, waiting to unite. Just let them find each other.", "title": "New Sentences: From \u2018How to Break Up With Your Phone\u2019", "authors": ["Sam Anderson", "New Sentences"]} {"date": "2018-04-10 00:00:00", "text": "Ever since \u201cJaws\u201d took a huge bite out of the box office in 1975, shark movies have become a cinematic staple. Two summers ago, Blake Lively\u2019s \u201cThe Shallows\u201d gobbled up $119 million worldwide, and Jason Statham will soon take on the world\u2019s largest shark in \u201cThe Meg,\u201d which has just released its first trailer.\n\nThe title is short for the Megalodon, a 75-foot-long prehistoric shark believed to be extinct \u2014 until one turns up in the Pacific. It\u2019s no coincidence the creature appears off the coast of China, as \u201cThe Meg\u201d seems to be targeting the massive Chinese market with the casting of the local star Li Bingbing (\u201cTransformers: Age of Extinction\u201d) as its female lead, an oceanographer\u2019s daughter.", "title": "New Trailer: \u2018The Meg,\u2019 With Jason Statham", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-18 00:00:00", "text": "Attorney General Eric T. Schneiderman of New York is moving to change New York state law so that he and other local prosecutors would have the power to bring criminal charges against aides to President Trump who have been pardoned, according to a letter Mr. Schneiderman sent to the governor and state lawmakers on Wednesday.\n\nThe move, if approved by Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo and the Legislature, would serve notice that the legal troubles of the president and his aides may continue without the efforts of Robert S. Mueller III, the special counsel investigating possible Russian interference in the 2016 presidential election.\n\nUnder the plan, Mr. Schneiderman, a Democrat, seeks to exempt New York\u2019s double jeopardy law from cases involving presidential pardons, according to the letter, a copy of which was obtained by The New York Times. The current law and the concept of double jeopardy in general mean that a person cannot be tried for the same crime twice.\n\nRight now, New York state law prevents people from being prosecuted more than once for crimes related to the same act, even if the original prosecution was in federal court. There are already a number of exceptions to the law, and the letter says that Mr. Schneiderman is proposing to add a new one that could be used if federal pardons are issued.", "title": "New York Attorney General Seeks Power to Bypass Presidential Pardons", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-19 00:00:00", "text": "Brooklyn renters experienced a fourth straight month of price drops in March, paying a median of $2,629 a month, or 6.3 percent less than a year before. In Manhattan, the median rent was $3,168 a month, 3.8 percent less than a year earlier \u2014 the lowest it has been since October of 2011.\n\nThose figures reflect the net-effective rent \u2014 the median monthly rent, taking into account various concessions, including months of free rent and broker commissions paid by the landlord \u2014 according to the latest Elliman Report, prepared by the real estate appraisal and consulting firm Miller Samuel.", "title": "New York City Rent Slide", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-01 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Cuomo, a Democrat, has used such language to describe the federal tax law since it passed last year. The cap on deductions of state and local taxes will hit especially hard in high-income, high-tax states like New York, New Jersey, Connecticut and California, places that, by coincidence or design, did not embrace President Trump in the 2016 election.\n\nCapping those deductions at $10,000 will certainly be felt in the metropolitan area, where property taxes of $20,000 to $30,000, on top of state income taxes, are not uncommon. New York and other states are considering litigation to fight the cap. And some others are exploring measures similar to those that passed in New York\u2019s budget.\n\nBut by being first out of the gate, New York\u2019s plan will be the test case.\n\nSeveral states have considered allowing municipalities to form nonprofit organizations that property owners would make payments to in lieu of property taxes, and then claim the \u201cdonations\u201d as charitable write-offs on their federal taxes. The I.R.S. has not issued any formal guidance on those ideas, but Jared Walczak, a senior policy analyst at the Tax Foundation, said the New York law will push the issue, and he called the plan \u201clegally fraught.\u201d\n\n\u201cI think it\u2019s quite possible that now that New York has adopted such legislation through the budget, and other states are considering it, that we may see I.R.S. guidance clearly disallowing this,\u201d Mr. Walczak said. \u201cExisting case law already makes this plain, but states have muddied the water.\u201d\n\nAnother part of the state\u2019s plan \u2014 converting the income tax paid by wage earners to a payroll tax paid by companies that could then deduct that amount on their federal taxes \u2014 seems to be on firmer legal footing. But it may not make sense to companies that must implement it and the employees who must opt in. Mr. Walczak said he suspects that it will prove difficult to convince large work forces, some with negotiated contracts, to take a cut on gross pay, even with the promise that their net pay after taxes will increase.", "title": "New York Crafts Loophole to Protect Property Tax Deductions. But the I.R.S. Could Close It.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-02 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nNew York is close to joining a growing list of states that are creating a retirement plan option for private sector employees who do not have access to 401(k)-like programs at work.\n\nThe New York program was included in Friday\u2019s budget deal, which Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo is expected to sign. The plan would enable businesses to provide workers with access to Roth individual retirement accounts overseen by the state. An estimated 3.5 million private sector employees in New York work for employers that do not offer a pension, a 401(k) plan or another savings option, according to AARP, which has lobbied in support of the plans.\n\n\u201cFor years, we have been working to develop and pass a retirement program that would give millions of New Yorkers the opportunity to save for their futures,\u201d Mr. Cuomo said in a statement. \u201cIn this year\u2019s budget, we proposed and passed a common-sense, progressive reform that will strengthen our work force.\u201d\n\nTen states, including New York, are on the verge of enacting such plans or already have them. The plans have been moving ahead even though Congress rolled back Obama-era rules meant to encourage states to create retirement programs for people without workplace savings accounts.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nOregon was the first state to begin rolling out its program last summer, and several other states are in varying stages of progress. Besides New York, they are California, Connecticut, Illinois, Maryland, Massachusetts, New Jersey, Vermont and Washington, according to the Center for Retirement Initiatives at Georgetown University.", "title": "New York Envisions a State-Run Retirement Plan for Private Workers", "authors": ["Tara Siegel Bernard"]} {"date": "2018-04-03 00:00:00", "text": "Senator Elizabeth Warren, Democrat of Massachusetts, issued a statement saying that given the importance of the job, the New York Fed should have solicited a wide set of views, but instead \u201cturned the process over to a handful of private individuals and ignored calls to choose one of many qualified alternatives who might have brought a new perspective.\u201d\n\n\u201cIf the Fed wants to regain some of its credibility around this decision,\u201d she added, \u201cit should have Mr. Williams and the co-chairs of the New York Fed search committee promptly testify before Congress.\u201d\n\nThose leading the search said they had indeed cast a wide net, and advocates for Mr. Williams argue he is well suited to the complex role. He has led the San Francisco bank for seven years and has spent virtually his entire career inside the Fed system. He is an influential expert on monetary policy who has worked closely with progressives \u2014 including Janet L. Yellen, who before her term as Fed chairwoman was Mr. Williams\u2019s predecessor at the San Francisco Fed \u2014 and with conservatives such as John B. Taylor, the Stanford economist.\n\n\u201cHis work is rigorous and thoughtful, and he discusses it carefully, considers other views,\u201d said Mr. Taylor, who was Mr. Williams\u2019s thesis adviser in graduate school. Ms. Yellen also released a statement on Tuesday praising Mr. Williams\u2019s selection.\n\nMr. Williams would also bring a seasoned policymaking hand to a Fed that is short on them. Jerome H. Powell, the Fed\u2019s newly appointed chairman, has been at the Fed since 2012, but he is a lawyer by training and not \u2014 unlike Ms. Yellen and most of her recent predecessors \u2014 an economist. The Fed\u2019s vice chairmanship is vacant, and the candidate President Trump has been reported to favor, Richard Clarida, a Columbia University economist, has little policy experience. Three other positions on the seven-member board of governors are also vacant, and several regional bank presidents are new in their roles.\n\nThe relative inexperience at the top of the Fed made finding someone with practical experience a priority, two people close to the search process said. The search committee, these people said, wanted a candidate who understood the Fed\u2019s inner workings and who would protect the Fed\u2019s independence.\n\nBut Andrew Levin, a Dartmouth economist and former Fed staff member, said there are also risks to picking an insider. Fed officials failed to appreciate the risks posed by the housing bubble in the mid-2000s, for example, even as some outside voices tried to raise the alarm.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cThe problem with picking a longtime Fed insider is it just amplifies the risk of groupthink,\u201d Mr. Levin said, \u201cand I think groupthink has been proven to be a very serious threat at the Fed.\u201d\n\nMr. Williams also has less experience with financial markets than many past New York Fed chiefs. The bank\u2019s president and its staff are traditionally responsible for communicating Fed decisions to Wall Street, and for interpreting financial markets\u2019 reactions for Fed policymakers.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMr. Williams was chosen by a search committee headed by two members of the bank\u2019s board: Sara Horowitz, founder of the Freelancers Union, a New York-based labor organization, and Glenn Hutchins, a private-equity investor and philanthropist. Under the Dodd-Frank financial reform law enacted after the financial crisis, board members who represent financial institutions regulated by the Fed are excluded from the appointment process.\n\nMr. Williams\u2019s appointment was also approved by the Fed\u2019s board of governors.\n\nIn a statement announcing the decision, Mr. Hutchins praised Mr. Williams as someone who has a rare mix of policy expertise and management experience and who \u201cunderstands the plumbing of the financial system.\u201d In a call with reporters, Mr. Hutchins and Ms. Horowitz also cited Mr. Williams\u2019s record of community engagement in San Francisco and his progress in diversifying the bank\u2019s senior leadership.\n\nProgressive groups seized on Mr. Dudley\u2019s retirement as a rare opportunity to influence an economic policy appointment that is outside Mr. Trump\u2019s control. Protesters marched on the bank\u2019s Lower Manhattan headquarters last month to demand a president who would represent working people.\n\nIn a statement Tuesday, the Fed Up campaign, a progressive group, criticized the New York Fed\u2019s board for \u201cignoring the demands of the public and choosing yet another white man whose record on Wall Street regulation and full employment raises serious questions.\u201d The group said the search process \u201ccalls into question whether the Federal Reserve can be trusted to act in the public interest.\u201d\n\nYet in one sense, the protesters got their wish. Unlike Mr. Dudley, who was chief economist for Goldman Sachs before he joined the Fed, Mr. Williams has never worked on Wall Street. And some of his positions have drawn cheers from progressives. He has, for example, pushed the central bank to consider a new approach to monetary policy that could lead the Fed to be more aggressive in fighting the next recession.\n\nBut Mr. Williams has also supported gradually raising interest rates to stave off inflation, an approach that progressive economists worry could prematurely choke off the economic recovery. And his regulatory record is also drawing scrutiny: He was president of the San Francisco Fed while Wells Fargo, which is based in San Francisco, engaged in aggressive sales practices that resulted in the opening of millions of accounts without customers\u2019 knowledge. (Regulatory policy is set in Washington, and Fed insiders say regional bank presidents play only a limited role overseeing banks in their districts.)\n\nPerhaps the loudest criticism has focused on the fact that Mr. Williams, like every other person to lead the New York Fed in the bank\u2019s century of history, is a white man.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cThe New York Fed has never been led by a woman or a person of color, and that needs to change,\u201d Senator Kirsten Gillibrand, Democrat of New York, said in a statement last week.\n\nThe search committee promised to consider a diverse pool of candidates, and the two leaders of the search said they had succeeded. Neither of the other two finalists for the job \u2014 Raymond McGuire, an executive at Citigroup, and Mary J. Miller, a former Treasury official \u2014 is a white man, and the search committee also interviewed other candidates who would have brought diversity to the Fed. One such candidate, Peter Blair Henry, who recently stepped down as dean of New York University\u2019s Stern School of Business, said that the search committee had pushed him to pursue the job, but that he had declined.\n\n\u201cI\u2019m just one data point, but if the effort they put into trying to persuade me to be a candidate is any indication, then they took diversity pretty seriously,\u201d said Mr. Henry, who like Mr. McGuire is African-American.\n\nBut Sarah Binder, a George Washington University political scientist who has studied the Fed, questioned whether there were really so few qualified candidates who weren\u2019t white men. And she said that the closed-door nature of the process made it hard for the public to evaluate how the search committee had carried out its work.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s such an opaque and pretty byzantine process,\u201d Ms. Binder said. \u201cThe fact that it is so cloistered from public view and really has very little if any public accountability for how that choice is made \u2014 given the importance of the position, it\u2019s really quite glaring.\u201d", "title": "New York Fed Names John Williams President, Bucking Calls for Diversity", "authors": ["Ben Casselman"]} {"date": "2018-04-17 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cThey are a potential source of human infection,\u201d said Dr. W. Ian Lipkin, the epidemiologist at the Mailman School of Public Health at Columbia who was the senior author on the study. \u201cThe real message is that these things are everywhere.\u201d\n\nThe mice appeared to be healthy, and Dr. Lipkin said he presumes that they are carriers of the bacteria but are not affected by them.\n\nDr. Lipkin said it was not clear whether the mice were getting the antibiotic-resistant bacteria from people \u2014 say, by eating food contaminated with the feces of someone taking antibiotics \u2014 or whether the bacteria developed resistance after mice ate discarded antibiotics.\n\nIt would be nearly impossible to conduct research directly linking a mouse pathogen with a human disease, said Charles Calisher, a professor emeritus at Colorado State University, who was not involved in the new studies.\n\nThe source of patients\u2019 infections are rarely investigated, and they are not usually asked about their contact with mice, he said. \u201cThese are not simple things to investigate,\u201d Dr. Calisher said.\n\nPeter Daszak, who heads the EcoHealth Alliance, a nonprofit that researches emerging diseases around the world, also described the research as difficult.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nIt\u2019s crucial to identify and trace these microbes, he said, to help understand how they are transmitted and how, if necessary, to protect ourselves from the diseases they may carry.\n\n\u201cIf we don\u2019t know where they originate, we can\u2019t identify what\u2019s driving them and then we can\u2019t control it,\u201d said Dr. Daszak, who was not involved in the research.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nNo one knows, for example, whether antibiotic resistance genes emerged in hospitals, in cities or in rural areas.\n\nThis research is particularly important to do in New York, Dr. Daszak said, because the city is a destination for people from all corners of the world.\n\n\u201cNew York is a major at-risk place for pathogens,\u201d he said. \u201cWe\u2019re certainly on the front line for emerging diseases.\u201d\n\nHe said that the new research should not make New Yorkers more fearful of mice. \u201cI\u2019m not worried personally,\u201d said Dr. Daszak, who lives in suburban Rockland County but works in the city. \u201cLuckily, this is a species we\u2019re already trying to control.\u201d\n\nDr. Lipkin began researching New York City\u2019s natural pathogens after the terrorist attacks of 9/11, when scientists realized they did not have a baseline to compare any changes. His lab has also studied rats on the New York City subway system and found many of the same infectious bacteria.\n\nAlthough it is impossible to completely get rid of urban mice, Dr. Lipkin said his study suggests that more should be done to control mouse populations and their interactions with people.\n\nLarge apartment buildings should fill any gaps in their foundations, and trap and control any rodents found indoors, Dr. Calisher said.\n\nShould everybody get a cat? \u201cCats have their own viruses,\u201d Dr. Calisher noted.", "title": "New York Mice Are Crawling With Dangerous Bacteria and Viruses", "authors": ["Karen Weintraub"]} {"date": "2018-04-04 00:00:00", "text": "New York Theater Workshop will stage five productions in its 2018-2019 season, ending it with a new solo show by Anna Deavere Smith.\n\nThe Off Broadway company announced Wednesday that it would lead off this fall with \u201cWhat the Constitution Means to Me\u201d by Heidi Schreck, a play about Ms. Schreck\u2019s experience giving speeches about the United States Constitution as a high school student in the hopes of getting college scholarships. He was named metro editor in 2013.\n\nSusan Chira, a senior correspondent and an editor covering gender issues, replaced Mr. Jamieson in an interim capacity.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nEileen Murphy, a spokeswoman for The Times, declined to specify the reason that Mr. Jamieson had been investigated. Susan Chira is a wonderful editor, a true New Yorker, and I know Metro will rise to even greater heights under her leadership.\u201d", "title": "New York Times Metro Editor Resigns, Citing \u2018Mistakes\u2019", "authors": ["Tiffany Hsu"]} {"date": "2018-04-16 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Trump\u2019s attacks on the press \u2014 the president has impugned reporters by name, railed against outlets whose coverage he dislikes and mused about making it easier for journalists to be sued \u2014 were an uneasy backdrop to the awards, presented annually by Columbia University to recognize excellence in journalism and letters.\n\n\u201cWinners uphold the highest purpose of a free and independent press \u2014 even in the most trying of times,\u201d Dana Canedy, the awards\u2019 administrator, said at the start of Monday\u2019s announcement.\n\nBut in its choices for the public service prize, the Pulitzer board also recognized the cultural shock waves caused by the #MeToo movement, which has reshaped the modern conversation around gender, harassment and fairness.\n\nThe board cited revelations in The Times about the Fox News host Bill O\u2019Reilly, whose history of settlements over harassment allegations had done little to affect his career as the king of cable news. After articles by The Times\u2019s Emily Steel and Michael S. Schmidt, Mr. O\u2019Reilly was ousted by Fox News last year. (Mr. Schmidt, who was also part of the Times team that won the national reporting prize, was honored twice in one year, a rare Pulitzer feat.)\n\nThe prize also recognized investigations into the film mogul Harvey Weinstein, whose predations of women \u2014 and extensive efforts to cover up his behavior \u2014 were exposed in The Times by Jodi Kantor and Megan Twohey, and in The New Yorker by Ronan Farrow.\n\nThe coverage of Mr. Weinstein, who has since lost his movie empire, set off a cascade of testimonials from women about abuse in the workplace, whether at a Beverly Hills hotel or a Ford Motor plant in the Midwest. Famed personalities, including the comedian Louis C.K. and the chef Mario Batali, saw their careers derailed after women came forward with allegations of misconduct.\n\n\u201cBy revealing secret settlements, persuading victims to speak and bringing powerful men to account, we spurred a worldwide reckoning about sexual abuse that only seems to be growing,\u201d Dean Baquet, executive editor of The Times, told hundreds of journalists who had gathered in the paper\u2019s Manhattan newsroom on Monday for the Pulitzer announcements.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe Post won the award for investigative reporting for its expos\u00e9 of Roy S. Moore, the Republican Senate candidate in Alabama, whose bid for higher office was upended after The Post uncovered that he had groped and harassed multiple women, one as young as 14. Besides unearthing the allegations against Mr. Moore, The Post\u2019s reporters foiled an attempt by the right-wing activist James O\u2019Keefe to undermine their reporting by planting false information in the paper.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cJournalists need both a soul and a spine,\u201d Martin Baron, the executive editor of The Post, said on Monday. His reporters \u201cshowed soul in their thorough dedication to our mission of getting at the truth,\u201d he said. \u201cThey showed spine by staying focused on their work in the face of denunciation, deceit and threats by politicians and their allies.\u201d\n\nMr. Baron called the Pulitzer-winning coverage \u201ca case study in why we need a free and independent press in this country.\u201d\n\nPresidential politics figured in the prizes for explanatory reporting, given to The Arizona Republic and the USA Today Network for scrutinizing the consequences of Mr. Trump\u2019s pledge to build a wall along the Mexican border; for commentary, given to John Archibald of the Alabama Media Group in Birmingham for writings on Mr. Moore\u2019s candidacy; and for criticism, awarded to the art critic for New York magazine, Jerry Saltz.\n\n[READ MORE: The winners in all Pulitzer categories.]\n\nMr. Saltz, an impish and catholic critic, often analyzes the crossroads of art and politics, particularly the cultural vectors of Mr. Trump\u2019s America. His prize was one of several top awards that went to magazines, which became eligible for all Pulitzer categories only in 2016.\n\nGQ won this year\u2019s feature writing prize for a searing profile by Rachel Kaadzi Ghansah of Dylann Roof, the white supremacist who killed nine African-American churchgoers in Charleston, S.C., in 2015. Mr. Farrow\u2019s reporting on Mr. Weinstein in The New Yorker revealed, in part, the sophisticated network of lawyers and private eyes that the producer deployed to shield his behavior from public view.\n\n\n\nThe Times received three awards in all, including the prize for editorial cartooning \u2014 a first for the paper \u2014 for a series that chronicled a Syrian refugee family\u2019s entry into the United States. The public service prize was the sixth time The Times has received the prestigious award in the more than century-long history of the Pulitzers.\n\nThe staff of The Cincinnati Enquirer won the prize for local reporting for its coverage of families ravaged by heroin addiction. Reuters won the international reporting prize for covering brutal killings ordered by President Rodrigo Duterte of the Philippines.\n\nPhotography prizes went to Reuters, for images of the violence in Myanmar, and to Ryan Kelly of The Daily Progress in Charlottesville, Va., who captured an image of a car plowing into a group of protesters at a rally that led to a national outcry over white supremacism.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n[READ MORE: The Times\u2019s winning articles.]\n\nIn the artistic categories, the award for fiction went to \u201cLess,\u201d by Andrew Sean Greer, a globe-trotting chronicle of an aging novelist confronting middle age, career disappointments and travails in love.\n\n\u201cCost of Living,\u201d an Off Broadway play by Martyna Majok, won the prize for drama. \u201cI am shaking,\u201d Ms. Majok, 33, a Polish immigrant who saw her first theater show at 17 after winning $45 from playing pool, said in an interview. \u201cI am overcome and overwhelmed. When I got the news, I didn\u2019t believe it for a solid 10 minutes.\u201d\n\nThe nonfiction prize went to \u201cLocking Up Our Own: Crime and Punishment in Black America,\u201d a book by James Forman Jr. that traced the history of contemporary criminal justice. A life of the author Laura Ingalls Wilder, \u201cPrairie Fires,\u201d by Caroline Fraser, was named the prizewinner for biography.", "title": "New York Times and New Yorker Share Pulitzer for Public Service", "authors": ["Michael M. Grynbaum"]} {"date": "2018-04-18 00:00:00", "text": "But for those of us who didn\u2019t live it firsthand, what was New York like in the early \u201980s?\n\nTo set the scene, the magazine stitched together 24 hours in the lives of some of the city\u2019s most influential artists, activists, musicians, fashion designers and others.\n\nAt night, Diane von Furstenberg could be found partying at Mudd Club while Al Sharpton was with James Brown, making sure \u201cpeople weren\u2019t ripping him off at the venues.\u201d During the day, the \u201cstarving\u201d artists David McDermott and Peter McGough were walking around the East Village, trying \u201cto get breakfast from our friends, ringing doorbells to see who was up,\u201d while the fashion designer Dapper Dan was watching music videos on VHS tapes in Harlem.\n\nThese New Yorkers made landmarks out of unassuming places like Larry Kramer\u2019s apartment, Pier 34 and a subway bench turned graffiti canvas in the Bronx. Even the daily routines of New Yorkers on grubby streets seem imbued with a bygone fabulousness.\n\nBut if you missed out on 1980s New York, don\u2019t fret.\n\nAs The Times\u2019s Frank Bruni writes, he still feels the spirit of those years.\n\nOnce again we are a city at odds with the White House, he says, with protesters today donning \u201cpussy hats and Black Lives Matter signs as well as rainbow flags.\u201d\n\n\u201cNew Yorkers, as always, come here to remake themselves \u2014 and to reinvent the city around them. It\u2019s an unfinished story, in which certain chapters are bolder and more complicated than others. One of them is now. One of them was then.\u201d\n\nHere\u2019s what else is happening:\n\nWeather\n\nToday we suggest leg warmers over stretch stirrup pants under parachute pants.\n\nAt least this morning, when fierce winds could make it feel like a barf-me-out 35 degrees.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHair forecast: crimped to the max.\n\nThe afternoon looks less grody, with mostly sunny skies and a high of 55.\n\nIn the News\n\n\u2022 A judge in Manhattan ordered that the New York City Housing Authority reinspect thousands of apartments for lead, after it had previously falsified reports. Riders feel like they haven\u2019t been heard. They also want real-time communication from us, not only with our daily service but also on incidents, the status of the incident and the actual cause of the incident. We also need to make sure we have people in our key hubs who can talk to our customers and give them the answers that they need.\n\nNYT: You commute to Queens from Smithtown on the L.I.R.R. What are other problems you\u2019ve personally experienced that you\u2019d like to fix?\n\nENG: Cleanliness. That means doing better with the appearance of our stations, with the cleanliness of the trains and the bathrooms. Also, crowded cars. That might mean schedule adjustments, and it might be taking a look at how many trains can run and how many cars we can put on the train.\n\nJohn Sadocha of East Norwich asks: I commute five days per week, and the L.I.R.R. is the worst part of my day. How will you stop the weekly breakdowns, cancellations and never-on-time schedules?\n\nENG: A lot of the weekly delays and cancellations are attributed to a failure in the system. We need to fix the signals, and fix the switches, and fix our tracks. And we need to address them proactively. Traditionally, we might find a defect \u2014 one that might not be that severe that we need to address now \u2014 and say, it can wait for a capital project [an investment in the system]. What we should be doing is repairing those defects now, and doing a permanent repair, so that we can avoid those delays that are caused by those components failing.", "title": "New York Today: A Q. & A. President", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-23 00:00:00", "text": "Updated, 10:23 a.m.\n\nGood morning on this bright Monday.\n\nAfter weeks of campaigning, millions spent and a few combative debates, New Yorkers will head to the polls tomorrow for a special election.\n\nUp for grabs are nine seats in the Assembly and two in the Senate \u2014 and with them, the opportunity for Democrats to control every branch of state government.\n\nIt\u2019s a record number of contests for a special election, and you can read more about the candidates and the most pertinent issues here.\n\nSix of the 11 races are in and around New York City. Wind gusts today are expected to reach only 25 miles per hour, leaving the storm with the less-sexy label of \u201cquick-moving low pressure system.\u201d", "title": "New York Today: April Snow Showers", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-11 00:00:00", "text": "But as atmospheric pressure drops \u2014 as it does ahead of damp, rainy or snowy weather \u2014 body tissue has more space to expand. When it does, it can push against our joints, causing some people, especially those with injuries or arthritis, to feel aches and pains.\n\nOur bodies have a harder time sensing when a brilliant day is coming. On days when the pressure is average, your joints likely wouldn\u2019t hurt, so if the pressure were to rise, there would be no change for the body to feel, Dr. Singh said.\n\nBut the sun is here to stay through Saturday.\n\nThe weatherman says so.\n\nHere\u2019s what else is happening:\n\nIn the News\n\n\u2022 There was a list of troubles and scrutiny that only seemed to accelerate in the final months of the New York City Housing Authority chairwoman. Johnson signed into law the Civil Rights Act of 1968, considered our last major piece of civil rights legislation.\n\nThe Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. had been assassinated just one week earlier, and riots were ravaging the country.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cPRESIDENT SIGNS CIVIL RIGHTS BILL; PLEADS FOR CALM,\u201d read the front-page headline of The New York Times.\n\nThe Fair Housing Act, as it was known, pushed for equality by cracking down on housing discrimination, making it illegal to refuse to rent or sell property to anyone on the basis of \u201crace, color, religion, sex, familial status or national origin.\u201d It also prevented federal spending in ways that would further segregation or racial discrimination.\n\n\u201cThe time is here. Action must be now,\u201d the president said on that day, reminding members of Congress in attendance that two years earlier, Dr. King had been at the White House meeting in which the housing law was first proposed.\n\nYou can learn more about the civil rights era and Dr. King\u2019s legacy at \u201cRebel Spirits,\u201d an exhibition on display at the New-York Historical Society until May 20, and at a lecture there on April 23, \u201cThe Supreme Court vs. Martin Luther King Jr.\u201d\n\nNew York Today is a morning roundup that is published weekdays at 6 a.m. If you don\u2019t get it in your inbox already, you can sign up to receive it by email here.\n\nFor updates throughout the day, like us on Facebook.\n\nWhat would you like to see here to start your day? Here\u2019s some advice to get your search started.", "title": "New York Today: How to Find a Rent-Stabilized Apartment", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-12 00:00:00", "text": "Dhruv Khullar, a physician at NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital, pointed to Holocaust-era doctors who justified killing the disabled in the name of public health. He said his studies \u201creframed the way that I approach my job in a hospital day to day.\u201d\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s very easy, sometimes, for us to think that certain types of lives are not worth living if people aren\u2019t able to do certain things or interact with the world in the way that we do,\u201d added Dr. Khullar, who also writes for The New York Times. \u201cBut one thing this really drove home to me is that every life has worth.\u201d\n\nBrian Hathaway, a doctoral student in business ethics at the Wharton School, said he was struck by the industrialized aspects of the Holocaust.\n\n\u201cA lot of what you would look for in terms of the modern business \u2014 efficiency, logistics, things like that \u2014 those were part of what made the Holocaust so devastatingly broad in scope,\u201d he said. \u201cIn many cases, business played a direct role.\u201d\n\nCornelia Dalton, a rabbinical student in New York, saw some of the same damaging silence in her field that Ms. Pierini saw in lawyers.\n\n\u201cOne of the connections that I saw in the role of the clergy was this reluctance to speak, this fear of crossing some sort of boundary,\u201d she said. \u201cI think that\u2019s still very present today \u2014 whether that\u2019s talking about U.S. politics or the Middle East.\u201d\n\nHere\u2019s what else is happening:\n\nWeather\n\nThe promised sunshine is delayed.\n\nA slight chance of drizzle this morning. Drive, which, thanks in part to Mr. Roosevelt, was built during the war to help connect Queens, Brooklyn and the Bronx to Manhattan.\n\nYou can learn more about President Roosevelt\u2019s influence in New York and beyond at \u201cRockwell, Roosevelt & the Four Freedoms,\u201d an exhibition opening next month at the New-York Historical Society, and at the related talks \u201cWorld War II at Sea\u201d (May 17) and \u201cF.D.R. and America\u2019s March to Victory in the Second World War\u201d (May 22).\n\nNew York Today is a morning roundup that is published weekdays at 6 a.m. If you don\u2019t get it in your inbox already, you can sign up to receive it by email here.\n\nFor updates throughout the day, like us on Facebook.\n\nWhat would you like to see here to start your day? Levine", "New York Today"]} {"date": "2018-04-16 00:00:00", "text": "Good morning on this stormy Monday.\n\nBitcoin can make you filthy rich, but it still won\u2019t buy you a buttered roll at your bodega.\n\nHow do we know? We tried.\n\nFor 36 hours last week I lived on Bitcoin alone. Surviving on the cryptocurrency, even in one of the world\u2019s financial capitals, wasn\u2019t easy. It required long subway rides to far-flung vendors where I was often the first Bitcoin-paying customer.\n\nTo get started, I bought 0.00737523 Bitcoin ($50) on Coinbase, a popular cryptocurrency exchange. It took an hour, $1.99 in fees, uploading a photo ID, and calling my bank after the charge was flagged as possibly fraudulent.\n\nCoinbase also canceled my first attempt to buy the volatile currency because the price had fluctuated in the 10 seconds or so it took me to check out.", "title": "New York Today: Living on Bitcoin", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-05 00:00:00", "text": "While we wait to find out, put on a mitten and pat yourself on your back: You\u2019ve now trudged through 40.9 inches of snow this winter and spring, nearly 16 inches more than the average snow season.\n\nThis April has already landed among the city\u2019s top 10 snowiest (at No. 8), and it\u2019s only the first week.\n\n\u201cAny snow that we pick up in these next three chances would only bump that up,\u201d Ms. Morrone said. \u201cWe definitely seem to be in a pattern where the temperatures are cold enough to support those chances.\u201d\n\nBut this is April, after all, the month that makes meteorologists look foolish, so expect plenty of chance.\n\nNo curveballs today, though. But it\u2019s been a big week for aboveground commuting.\n\nHere are a few things you should know.\n\n\u2022 You will soon be able to see the arrival time of your bus. The city announced yesterday that a Brooklyn pilot program that displayed countdown clocks on LinkNYC kiosks will be expanded to the five boroughs in the coming weeks.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u2022 Dockless bike sharing may be coming to your neighborhood.\n\n\u2022 Electric and pedal-assist bikes may soon be legal. City Hall announced on Tuesday that the mayor plans to change city law to allow them explicitly.\n\n\u2022 Cyclists will be given a seven- to 11-second head start before cars at 50 intersections around the city as part of a pilot program.\n\n\u2022 And Citi Bike is offering $3 single rides all month.\n\nIf you do travel by subway, here\u2019s one way to make your time underground more pleasant: Talk to a stranger. As we slung our feet over its edge yesterday, during what was one of the best days of spring weather yet, we wondered: How, exactly, does this thing work?\n\nThe fountain holds almost 32,000 gallons of water between its two tanks, according to George Vellonakis, executive director of the Washington Square Park Conservancy. That water is constantly moving, recirculating between a filtration system (which keeps the fountain clean) and display pumps (with jets that can shoot the water 45 feet into the air).", "title": "New York Today: Return of the Fountain", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-06 00:00:00", "text": "Updated, 8:19 a.m.\n\nGood drizzly morning to you. And happy Friday.\n\nIt\u2019s spring, and we\u2019re anticipating flings \u2026 of mucky water.\n\nIf you make it through the morning without a little sidewalk splatter, we salute you. A mix of snow and rain could pelt the pavement for the next few hours.\n\nThe rain will continue until the afternoon and picks up again tomorrow when it could be mixed with a little snow.\n\nThe snow probably won\u2019t amount to much on the ground, and snowfall totals vary throughout the city, even within the space of a few blocks. A Manhattan bodega. Times Square. The Empire State Building.\n\nAll are city spaces where New Yorkers have been shot \u2014 and survived.\n\n\u201cThese shootings occur in the Walmart parking lot, in church, in the bowling alley, in the gym \u2014 they\u2019re happening at places we go to all the time, that we never think of as unsafe,\u201d said Kathy Shorr, the Brooklyn-born photographer behind \u201cSHOT: 101 Survivors of Gun Violence in America.\u201d\n\nThe project, in which survivors are photographed at the sites where they were shot, is meant to underscore the ubiquity of gun violence \u2014 \u201cthat it can happen anywhere, at any time, to anyone,\u201d Ms. Shorr said.\n\nSeveral of the people featured in the book, published last year, were shot in New York.\n\n\u201cWe never hear about them,\u201d Ms. Shorr Society.\n\nMost visitors know her by name by the time they arrive: The company works carefully on \u201cpre-show engagement,\u201d Ms. Agnello said, posting a character guide and a video mapping out the experience of going to Lincoln Center, to make the journey feel familiar and to put theatergoers at ease.\n\nThe moment they step into the lobby, they\u2019re welcomed warmly by members of the Fogg family and music they\u2019ll hear in the show.\n\n(Actors also receive information about audience members ahead of time to understand likes, dislikes and possible triggers.)\n\nWhat comes next is an immersive, interactive theater experience with a Broadway-quality set, props that encourage audience participation (clouds, for example), and seating that allows children to get up and walk around during the show.\n\n\u201cAll of those things are taken into consideration,\u201d Mr. Granet said; but he added that the result was above all \u201ca beautiful piece of theater\u201d that anyone could enjoy.\n\nTrusty Sidekick is joined by Oily Cart, a group from England, and Sensorium Theatre, from Australia.\n\nHere\u2019s what else is happening:\n\nWeather\n\nSpring at New York City F.C. at Atlanta United F.C., 6 p.m. (MLS LIVE).\n\n\u2022 For more events, see The New York Times\u2019s Arts & Entertainment guide.\n\n\n\nAnd Finally\u2026\n\nPhoto\n\nOne downside to the warmer weather: a surge in traffic accidents, according to a new report released on Thursday by the office of Mayor Bill de Blasio.\n\nApril 29 of last year, according to the report compiled by the Department of Transportation, was the second deadliest day of the (otherwise very safe) year. Highs had climbed to the 80s after a stretch of chilly weather, and on that day, four people were killed across the city and more than 200 were injured in crashes, some of which involved speeding, the report said.\n\nThis led the city to examine the correlation between weather records and crash data; the department found that drivers and motorcyclists drive more recklessly \u2014 putting pedestrians at more risk \u2014 on weekends with warmer weather.\n\nAs part of the mayor\u2019s Vision Zero \u201cWarm Weather Weekends\u201d campaign, all eyes will be on our roads this weekend.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cN.Y.P.D. officers will be out in force on weekends to combat the behaviors most associated with traffic tragedies,\u201d said Thomas Chan, the Police Department\u2019s chief of transportation. \u201cOur goal is to ensure everyone enjoys these weekends and returns home safely.\u201d\n\nNew York Today is a morning roundup that is published weekdays at 6 a.m. If you don\u2019t get it in your inbox already, you can sign up to receive it by email here.\n\nFor updates throughout the day, like us on Facebook.\n\nWhat would you like to see here to start your day? Levine", "New York Today"]} {"date": "2018-04-20 00:00:00", "text": "Good morning on this cool and bright Friday.\n\nWhen New York City icons change, people usually take notice.\n\nAnd yet, unless you see multiple Broadway shows a year, the evolution of one of the city\u2019s most venerable publications, Playbill, may have passed you by.\n\nOver the course of a few weeks, we got a backstage look into the making of Playbill \u2014 the unmistakable, yellow-bannered magazine for theatergoers \u2014 and the transition of the 134-year-old New York institution to the mobile-first, social media-obsessed age.\n\nPlaybill has two New York offices, one digital and the other analogue, which are separated by about four miles and the East River, but at times can feel worlds apart.", "title": "New York Today: The Future of Playbill", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-03 00:00:00", "text": "Unlike the subway tracks, which are cleaned with giant battery-powered vacuums, or the platforms, which are occasionally power-washed, subway car interiors are cleaned by hand.\n\nMr. Skinner, 47, walked us through the steps. We watched as he wiped windows, scraped gum, erased graffiti and cleaned dancers\u2019 footprints off the ceiling \u2014 with care and special tools.\n\n\u201cThe doors are like wood,\u201d he said as he carefully polished them with a Doodlebug scrub brush and a Chicopee wipe. \u201cYou got to get into the grain of the door, so it pulls up all the rust and corrosion.\u201d\n\nOur eyes began to water.\n\n\u201cThat\u2019s the bleach,\u201d he said. Or perhaps at fault was the deodorizer, the steel cleanser or a Genie Wipe, used to erase graffiti and powerful enough to \u201cpeel the skin off your fingertips,\u201d Mr. Skinner said.\n\nThe cocktail of chemicals is needed to rid the cars of the residue of thousands of commuters and kill some of the more than 1,688 micro-organisms \u2014 most of them harmless \u2014 that a recent study found germinating in the subway.", "title": "New York Today: The Land of Squeaky-Clean Subway Cars", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-30 00:00:00", "text": "The officers are recruited from within the department. Lieutenant Marrero spent two years driving garbage trucks in Far Rockaway, Queens, before becoming an officer. They carry guns and can make arrests.\n\nPhoto\n\nOn a windy afternoon this month, we set off with the officers in the Bronx, on the lookout for scofflaws. In the few hours we spent with Lieutenant Marrero, he issued summonses for littering, failing to obey recycling laws and walking a dog off leash \u2014 and two for public urination.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s feast or famine,\u201d he said, but he usually writes at least five or six summonses a day.\n\nAs the sun dipped low on the horizon, and building superintendents in the South Bronx began piling trash on the sidewalks, Lieutenant Marrero pulled over.\n\n\u201cLet\u2019s take a quick peek,\u201d he said, opening a black trash bag. \u201cSee these bottles? Look at that paper mixed in. That\u2019s all recycling.\u201d\n\nLieutenant Marrero buzzed an apartment. \u201cSanitation police,\u201d he said sternly.\n\nThe officers took down the building\u2019s information and stuck a $100 summons on the entrance gate.\n\n\u201cWhen we issue a summons, people say, \u2018Oh, wow, you guys are actually enforcing these laws,\u2019 \u201d he said. They don\u2019t repeat the offense and they spread the word to their friends, he said, adding, \u201cI believe it does make a difference.\u201d\n\nThroughout the evening shift, we witnessed plenty of New Yorkers breaking sanitation laws, though some, out of necessity, got a pass.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAs we sat in traffic, a man in a motorized wheelchair passed by and tossed out an empty pack of cigarettes.\n\n\u201cWe have to use discretion,\u201d Lieutenant Marrero said. If the officers stopped for every violation, we might never have left the block.\n\nHere\u2019s what else is happening:\n\nWeather\n\nIt\u2019s cool and windy, but comfortable, with a high of 55.\n\nSpring will bloom thoroughly tomorrow with a victorious blue sky and temperatures in the 70s.\n\nAnd we could get our first taste of 80-degree weather later this week.\n\nIn the News\n\n\u2022 Today begins the retrial of Sheldon Silver, the former State Assembly speaker, whose conviction on federal corruption charges was thrown out last year. [New York Times]\n\nPhoto\n\n\u2022 A fire ripped through a Queens home, killing three occupants and critically injuring three others, including an 8-year-old girl, the authorities said. [New York Times]\n\n\u2022 The artist Tim Youd is retyping Mary McCarthy\u2019s novel \u201cThe Group\u201d word for word, with no spaces, on the campus of her alma mater, Vassar College. [New York Times]\n\n\u2022 A 2-year-old girl found unconscious in her Westchester County home died on Saturday. The girl\u2019s mother was shot after attacking officers with a knife, the police said. [New York Times]\n\n\u2022 Parts of the old Tappan Zee Bridge will be recycled and used as artificial reefs off Long Island. [New York Times]\n\nPhoto\n\n\u2022 Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo is spending the day in Puerto Rico to kick off rebuilding efforts on the island, which was ravaged last year by Hurricane Maria. [NY1]\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u2022 A public dog park in TriBeCa was taken over by a nonprofit that installed a lock, charged fees and banned nonmembers, all without the city\u2019s knowledge. But in recent years, you\u2019ve experienced droopy eyes, a drippy nose or violent sneezing during spring.\n\nAs sniffle season sets in, we wondered: Is that a sign you\u2019ve developed later-in-life allergies?\n\nWhile it\u2019s relatively common to outgrow allergies over time, the hunch that we\u2019ve picked up new ones is often a misconception, according to Dr. William Reisacher, an ear, nose and throat specialist at Weill Cornell Medicine and NewYork-Presbyterian.\n\nAllergies peak in adolescence or early adulthood, he told us, and tend to remain steady for years after that before eventually declining in older age.\n\nWhat\u2019s more likely happening, he said, is that we\u2019re not changing, but the environment is \u2014 and that\u2019s what is triggering these symptoms.", "title": "New York Today: The Real Reason You\u2019re Sneezing", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-24 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cPeople of all different races and nationalities were enjoying themselves with their families, eating food from countries they hadn\u2019t been to, seeing artwork from places they didn\u2019t know, and being amazed by things other people were dreaming up,\u201d said Joseph Tirella, the author of \u201cTomorrow-Land: The 1964-65 World\u2019s Fair and the Transformation of America.\u201d\n\nThe fair\u2019s motto, he said, was \u201cPeace through understanding.\u201d\n\n\u201cMaybe that\u2019s an out-of-date concept,\u201d Mr. Tirella said of the fair. But, he added, \u201cthe world needs more peace through understanding than ever before.\u201d\n\n\u201cThe World\u2019s Fair was about the world coming together, and that\u2019s never really a bad thing,\u201d he said. \u201cIt\u2019s never really going to go out of style.\u201d\n\nThe fair also came at a time of transformation, Mr. Tirella noted. It opened five months after the assassination of President John F. Kennedy; America\u2019s role in the Vietnam War was quickly expanding; Bob Dylan was on the radio singing about current events; and the fight for civil rights, led by the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. and Malcolm X, was central not only to daily life in the South, but also in New York.\n\n\u201cThen there\u2019s this sweet and innocent fair, this sweet moment in an otherwise very tense world,\u201d Mr. Tirella said. \u201c\u2018Peace through understanding\u2019 seemed to be at a premium \u2014 there seemed to be anything but peace, and very little understanding \u2014 so in those pavilions, in the confines of that park, it was peaceful.\u201d", "title": "New York Today: The World\u2019s Fair, a World Away", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-10 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cIt will slow things down,\u201d Mr. Robinson told us. \u201cFlowers are open, but they\u2019re not opening at the rate that they would be if it were 50-plus degrees out.\u201d\n\nBut that could mean that a stretch with high pollen levels looms around the corner.\n\n\u201cIt will only hold a lid on it for so long,\u201d Mr. Robinson said of the cold. \u201cAnd what we\u2019ve seen in past years, when we\u2019ve had this sort of pattern of weather, is that you\u2019ll then get these sustained high levels of pollen for several days in a row.\u201d\n\nThe small amounts of cypress and elm tree pollen in the air now will soon be joined by particles from birch, oak, ash and beech, Mr. Robinson said. And when that happens, according to his research from 2016, you may feel it most in Brooklyn, Queens and Staten Island.\n\nHere\u2019s what else is happening:\n\nIn the News\n\n\u2022 A look at the life of Saheed Vassell, a mentally ill man fatally shot by the police last week in Crown Heights, through the eyes of the people closest to him.
