In New York, which has the narrowest pay gap of any state, women make 89 cents for every dollar men make.\n\n(A 2016 study commissioned by Public Advocate Letitia James found that New York City women were collectively paid $6 billion less than men each year, while women across New York State earned about $20 billion less.)\n\nA law barring employers from asking potential hires about their salary history, intended to reduce pay inequities for women and minority workers, took effect in New York City in the fall. And state leaders are exploring ways to address this issue through legislation in the coming months.\n\nNew Yorkers \u2014 among them union workers, labor activists, the public advocate and Lt. Gov. Kathy Hochul \u2014 are gathering at City Hall at noon to raise awareness about the issues in New York and demand pay equity.\n\nNew York Today is a morning roundup that is published weekdays at 6 a.m. If you don\u2019t get it in your inbox already, you can sign up to receive it by email here.\n\nFor updates throughout the day, like us on Facebook.\n\nWhat would you like to see here to start your day? Levine", "New York Today"]} {"date": "2018-04-02 00:00:00", "text": "Over the course of the next few weeks, a jury in New York will hear the story of a South African crime lord who dealt in guns and gold and the team of former military men he hired to do his dirty work.\n\nThe panel may be told about a smuggling ship that sank one day in the waters off Manila or of plans to stage a rebellion in the Seychelles. There is likely to be testimony about safe houses in Africa, illegal pain pills trafficked out of Mexico and the murder of a Filipino woman who was shot in the face and then dumped from a van.\n\nThree men go on trial this week on charges connected to the murder, and the evidence is expected to tell a tale of international intrigue \u2014 one that resembles a James Bond movie, as one of the defendants was caught saying on a government recording.\n\nWith its exotic locations and cast of violent characters, the trial, in Federal District Court in Manhattan, will also provide the jurors with a privileged glimpse of a rarely seen milieu: the covert world of mercenary soldiers.", "title": "New York Trial Will Explore the Secret World of Mercenary Soldiers", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-22 00:00:00", "text": "Providing this service, however, has not always been smooth. In Minnesota, not many Medicaid beneficiaries were aware of doula coverage, and reimbursement rates were low, one study found. Additionally, doulas are not licensed in New York, which might be a challenge because Medicaid programs must pay licensed providers to receive matching federal funds.\n\nMolly Deutschbein, a doula and committee member of the Rochester Area Birth Network, was encouraged by a possible Medicaid expansion, but cautioned that it could change the essence of the doula profession because a doula might be required to work for a provider whose interests are not aligned with the mother\u2019s.\n\n\u201cWhen doulas get paid by someone other than the mother, it gets to the question of, Who does the doula work for?\u201d Ms. Deutschbein said. \u201cI\u2019d have to see more of the details.\u201d\n\nIn fact, New York\u2019s Health Department once shied away from the idea of expanding Medicaid coverage for doulas in 2011, saying it was a \u201ccomplex issue.\u201d\n\n\u201cWe see it as this really critical piece of improving outcomes most especially for most at-risk mothers,\u201d said \u00c9lan McAllister, a former doula and a co-founder of the New York Coalition for Doula Access.\n\n\u201cThere\u2019s something about having a support person who can bring humanity into a situation and who cares that you survive childbirth and get through it.\u201d\n\nThe governor is also creating the Task Force on Maternal Mortality and Disparate Racial Outcomes, which will collaborate with the Maternal Mortality Review Board, a new entity composed of health professionals that will review each maternal death in the state.", "title": "New York to Expand Use of Doulas to Reduce Childbirth Deaths", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-17 00:00:00", "text": "Dan Graham, artist\n\nI was living on Eldridge Street between Hester and Grand. It was very close to the Forward Building, which housed the important Yiddish newspaper. My apartment was four stories up, and I got a place on the floor below for Kim Gordon. Thurston Moore would take me to see hardcore groups like Black Flag. Thurston was a scholar. He\u2019s a Leo \u2014 all the Leos I know love history. An important place to have breakfast was Buffa\u2019s, on the corner of Lafayette and Prince \u2014 you\u2019d see Jim Jarmusch and Jonathan Demme in the booths there.\n\nTama Janowitz, writer\n\nThe only place that designated who you were was the Upper East Side. Otherwise neighborhood wasn\u2019t as important as finding a space \u2014 one guy I knew, the photographer Patrick McMullan, lived in the coat-check room of a former hotel. You simply traveled to where things were happening. For a while I lived on the Upper West Side, on the parlor floor of a brownstone on 71st Street between Amsterdam and Columbus. Usually I\u2019d take the bus down to Mickey\u2019s [Chinese Chance] at 1 University Place, where Julian Schnabel was the cook. You\u2019d sit at the bar and someone would say: \u201cHey, we\u2019re going to Danceteria.\u201d Or they\u2019d have a car and you\u2019d find yourself in the East Village, which was a total war zone, with junkies passed out and men building fires in trash cans.\n\nLisa Phillips, curator\n\nI was working at the Whitney and helping to open different museum branches, so I was shuttling between 42nd Street, Stamford, Conn., and the downtown branch, which was just a few blocks from where I lived, on Front Street in the South Street Seaport area. Guerrilla art activities took place all over. Creative Time ran Art on the Beach on the landfill that is now Battery Park City \u2014 back then it was just a huge field of sand. The elevated West Side Highway, meanwhile, was a place you could ski. We would get on at the ramp at Chambers Street and ski up to Spring Street to the Ear Inn. One night I saw Jack Smith do a reading, and I can still remember this line, which kind of sums up that era: \u201cThe cockroach caravan crosses the rented desert of exotic landlordism.\u201d\n\nLee Qui\u00f1ones, artist\n\nIt was all happening at the same time; there was a lot of yin and yang. I was living with my parents in the Alfred E. Smith projects on the Lower East Side\u2019s waterfront. During the day, I\u2019d get my paints at Canal Hardware or Pearl Paint. I\u2019d work for 12 hours straight, prepping for my show at Barbara Gladstone Gallery. The Mudd Club was one of my favorite spots to go out \u2014 that\u2019s where I was introduced to James Chance and the Contortions and Talking Heads. It was in this desolate area between TriBeCa and Chinatown, and I knew every alley. Sometimes, after the clubs got out, people would see a kung fu flick on 42nd Street, which we called the Deuce \u2014 We\u2019re going to the Deuce, what\u2019s up? I remember the smell of the theaters so well \u2014 popcorn and weed.", "title": "New Yorkers and Their \u201980s Routines \u2014 Block by Block", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-06 00:00:00", "text": "New Yorkers are forever mourning the death of the funky corner shop at the hands of the soulless, corporate behemoth: an independent bookstore closes, a drugstore chain takes its place. It\u2019s been a lament since at least 1871, when A.&P., probably the earliest national chain, opened its first store outside New York. Two McDonald\u2019s restaurants arrived in Queens in 1967; Starbucks showed up on the Upper West Side in 1994.\n\nIn a December 2017 report, the Center for an Urban Future counted 7,317 chain stores across the five boroughs \u2014 a 35 percent increase from 2008, when the research group published its first comprehensive statistics.\n\nAnd yet any New Yorker who has been in any of the 612 Dunkin\u2019 Donuts in the city \u2014 or the 444 MetroPCS shops, say, or the 433 Subway branches \u2014 would certainly recognize the people who work there, shop there and run the place as locals. Just because a building is emblazoned with a familiar brand does not necessarily mean the corporation is completely in charge. Many of the city\u2019s largest chains are franchises, owned and run by the moms and pops \u2014 immigrants, strivers, entrepreneurs who, in a different time, might have opened their own coffee shop or pharmacy or shoe store.\n\n\u201cSome franchising gets a bad rap, but that person is still a small-business owner,\u201d said John Armstrong, the owner of the franchising consulting firm FranNet of New York City. \u201cThey\u2019re still putting in their capital, time and effort \u2014 they\u2019re just going a different route.\u201d", "title": "New York\u2019s Corporate Mom-and-Pop Stores", "authors": ["Keith Williams"]} {"date": "2018-04-05 00:00:00", "text": "Indeed, despite the governor\u2019s carefully staged kumbaya moment, there are many logistical, political and practical questions about what the future holds for the reunited Democrats and what changes might be afoot.\n\nThe most immediate answer, of course, is not much: Despite the I.D.C.\u2019s eight senators joining with Ms. Stewart-Cousins\u2019s 21 members, the Democrats are still short of a majority in the 63-seat chamber, something that Republicans who control the chamber were quick to note, and mock, on Wednesday.\n\n\u201cSimple math tells you that 29 out of 63 is not a majority,\u201d said Senator Rich Funke, an upstate Republican, who also called Mr. Cuomo\u2019s announcement \u201cworst deal to take place in New York City since the Yankees\u2019 10-year deal with A-Rod.\u201d\n\nThe possible addition of two more Democrats through special elections on April 24 will still leave the party just shy of the magic 32 needed for a majority because of the continued defection of State Senator Simcha Felder, a Brooklyn Democrat who caucuses with the Republicans. On Wednesday, Mr. Felder, too, seemed to tamp down expectations, repeating that while he had no loyalty to any party, he seemed happy enough with the G.O.P. \u201cI think it\u2019s fair to say that I would have to feel a compelling reason to leave,\u201d he said.\n\nStill, there are some indications that things will be different \u2014 particularly for members of Mr. Klein\u2019s now-defunct faction \u2014 when the Legislature returns to Albany on April 16. Thanks to their agreement with the G.O.P., members of the I.D.C. had enjoyed the perks of committee chairmanships, which come with the power to steer legislation and handsome bonuses (known as \u201clulus\u201d in Albany parlance). Two members of Mr. Klein\u2019s conference had also been paid as vice-chairs of committees, a practice the state comptroller ruled improper in recent weeks.\n\nBut those chairmanships are likely to be taken away by the Republican leader, State Senator John J. Flanagan of Long Island, who is said to have only heard about the pending reunification early Wednesday from Mr. Klein, his longtime political partner. The I.D.C. also had enjoyed other benefits, including larger staffs and offices; the status of those perks is still under discussion, according to Scott Reif, a spokesman for Mr. Flanagan.\n\nIn an interview on Thursday, Mr. Klein himself seemed to confirm this, saying, \u201cClearly, things are going to change.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nAt the same time, the governor\u2019s election-year embrace of Democratic unity does not seem to have quelled opposition to the I.D.C., which has worked with the Republicans for most of Mr. Cuomo\u2019s time in office. On Thursday, at Foley Square in Manhattan, a succession of Democratic primary challengers to I.D.C. members blasted the deal as \u201ctoo little, too late,\u201d particularly because it came after the passage of the state\u2019s $168 billion budget, during which time Mr. Klein \u2014 then regarded as one of four leaders in top-level negotiations \u2014 was still cooperating with Republicans.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cWe\u2019re going to remember those who were in bed with the Republicans \u2014 the party of Trump,\u201d said Allan Roskoff, the president of the Jim Owles Liberal Democratic Club, which advocates for gay, lesbian, transgender and bisexual rights.\n\nOthers \u2014 including Mr. Cuomo\u2019s Democratic challenger, the actress Cynthia Nixon \u2014 have also suggested that the timing of reconciliation was orchestrated to inoculate the governor and the I.D.C. from primary challenges, a theme picked up by Republicans as well. (One speaker at the Foley Square event called the I.D.C. deal \u201cthe Democratic Primary Discouragement Act.\u201d)\n\n\u201cLet\u2019s be honest,\u201d said Mr. Reif. \u201cThe only reason that any of this is happening now is because Andrew Cuomo is scared to death of Cynthia Nixon.\u201d\n\nMr. Cuomo and his surrogates rejected this narrative, saying they had been working on a deal between Ms. Stewart-Cousins and Mr. Klein since last summer, and had fostered a tentative deal in November. \u201cIt had nothing to do with it,\u201d the governor said on Wednesday, in response to a question about Ms. Nixon.\n\nThe governor has also emphasized that the deal he announced is actually secondary to efforts in the fall to elect a wave of Democrats at every governmental level.\n\nHow the Senate might operate on a daily basis is also an open question. Under rules adopted for this session, the I.D.C. is regarded as a separate conference in the chamber and part of a ruling coalition. Indeed, even if Mr. Felder were to side with Democrats, Republicans argue that rules might not allow a change in majority leadership, because rules cannot be changed without 38 votes, beyond even unified Democrats. Democrats disagree, but legal battles could follow.\n\nThe uncertainty surrounding the Senate \u2014 and its now shifting loyalties \u2014 has also led to speculation that little, if anything, will get done between now and the end of the legislative session in June.\n\nOn Thursday, no physical changes were visible in Albany; Mr. Klein\u2019s suite of offices, on the top floor of a legislative office building, were intact. Mr. Klein said he expected to conference with his fellow Democrats in the Senate when the Legislature returns to work. He said he would also dip into the I.D.C.\u2019s campaign funds \u2014 some $1.2 million as of January \u2014 to support Democrats, as well as fending off primary challenges to his fellow I.D.C. alumni.\n\nMr. Klein said he remained proud of what the I.D.C. had accomplished \u2014 voting to pass things like paid family leave, a raise in the minimum wage and same-sex marriage \u2014 over its seven years of dissidence.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cI still believe, at the time,\u201d he said, \u201cit was a good thing.\u201d", "title": "New York\u2019s Democrats Ended a 7-Year Civil War. Now Comes the Hard Part.", "authors": ["Jesse Mckinley"]} {"date": "2018-04-12 00:00:00", "text": "The government said it would allow the existing 22 active offshore permits, covering more than 38,000 square miles, to run until their expiration, which is \u201cas far out as 2030.\u201d\n\nCompanies that find more oil and gas reserves where they already have permits could drill for decades, and new onshore permits could be issued.\n\nThe Petroleum Exploration and Production Association of New Zealand criticized the government for not consulting the industry, saying that alternative energy sources were not yet ready to meet demand and that oil would have to be imported from other countries at a higher cost.\n\n\u201cThe decision is a lose-lose for New Zealand\u2019s economy and environment, likely to threaten jobs and mean higher prices for consumers,\u201d said Cameron Madgwick, the association\u2019s chairman.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe mayor of New Plymouth, the largest city in Taranaki, the area where the country\u2019s oil and gas exploration is concentrated, called the decision \u201ca kick in the guts\u201d for the regional economy.\n\n\u201cThis announcement sends a message to some of Taranaki\u2019s major investors and employers that they do not have a long-term future in New Zealand,\u201d Mayor Neil Holdom said.\n\nSimon Bridges, the leader of the center-right National Party, New Zealand\u2019s main opposition party, said on Twitter that the decision to end oil and gas exploration was \u201ca wrecking ball\u201d that could only hurt the country.\n\nThe government said that \u201cno current jobs\u201d would be lost, as it was \u201chonoring all agreements with current permit holders.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nGovernment figures show that in New Zealand\u2019s crude oil production declined in 2016 to the lowest level in a decade, and spending on production had fallen in line with a global drop in prices stemming from the shale revolution in the United States.\n\nNew Zealand imports more oil than it exports, and it is a small player on the world stage, with industry figures putting the value of exports at $1.1 billion a year.\n\nA page on the New Zealand Trade and Enterprise website \u2014 a government agency that promotes international trade and economic development \u2014 says the government\u2019s aim is \u201cto increase the value of New Zealand petroleum exports tenfold\u201d by 2025.\n\nIn Australia, plans to drill for natural gas offshore in the Great Australian Bight, known as Australia\u2019s Gal\u00e1pagos, have drawn criticism from the fishing and tourism industries, which the potential of a spill is too great a risk.", "title": "New Zealand Cites Climate Change in Banning New Offshore Drilling", "authors": ["Charlotte Graham-Mclay"]} {"date": "2018-04-27 00:00:00", "text": "Six new paperbacks to check out this week.\n\nSOMEBODY WITH A LITTLE HAMMER: Essays, by Mary Gaitskill. (Vintage, $16.) In her first collection of nonfiction, Gaitskill, ever prescient, tackles everything from date rape to politics to her own creative process. Gaitskill borrows from Anton Chekhov for the collection\u2019s title; in a way, the essays serve to remind \u201cthat unhappy people exist, that however happy he may be, sooner or later life will show him its claws.\u201d\n\nTHE LEAVERS, by Lisa Ko. (Algonquin, $15.95.) Ko\u2019s novel opens with the disappearance of Deming Guo\u2019s mother, Polly, an undocumented Chinese immigrant in the Bronx. Deming is adopted by a well-intentioned white family, but he is soon called back to China to investigate the mysteries of his life. This novel of migration is a story of belonging, home, loss and identity.\n\nTHE BEST MINDS OF MY GENERATION: A Literary History of the Beats, by Allen Ginsberg. Edited by Bill Morgan, with a foreword by Anne Waldman. (Grove, $20.) Between 1977 and 1994, Ginsberg gave 100 or so lectures about the cultural movement he helped lead. Morgan has condensed these addresses, organizing them around the figures Ginsberg discusses: Jack Kerouac, William S. Burroughs, Gregory Corso and Ginsberg himself.\n\nTHE BARROWFIELDS, by Phillip Lewis. (Hogarth, $16.) An Appalachian family\u2019s saga is at the center of this debut novel. Henry Aster grows up in North Carolina as the son of a brilliant, troubled man, but once he leaves for college his ties to home become ever weaker, and he breaks his promise to remain close to and protect his younger sister. Years later, Henry grapples with the specter of his father\u2019s alcoholism and other demons. The tale is ultimately one of a troubled\u2019s family redemption, and of the miracle of forgiveness.", "title": "New in Paperback: \u2018Somebody With a Little Hammer,\u2019 \u2018The Leavers\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-20 00:00:00", "text": "MEXICO CITY \u2014 Extraordinary protests against the government of President Daniel Ortega of Nicaragua extended into a third day on Friday as thousands of demonstrators took to the streets in Managua, the capital, and other cities, clashing with government security forces and barricading neighborhoods in opposition to newly announced changes in the social security program.\n\nAt least three people, including a police officer, have been killed in the protests since they began on Wednesday, according to the authorities, and dozens of people have been wounded.\n\nThe demonstrations have been partly driven by students from the country\u2019s public universities, which historically have been a faithful base of support for Mr. Ortega. They have been joined by a variety of groups, including retirees. The protests are among the largest and most violent in Nicaragua\u2019s recent history.\n\nThey were set off by changes to the social security system approved by the Ortega administration this week, but they also tapped growing discontent with the government, protesters and analysts said.", "title": "Nicaragua Roiled by Protests Over Social Security Benefits", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-29 00:00:00", "text": "Nicholas Andrew Hovsepian and Robert John Postotnik were married April 28 at the Plaza Hotel in Manhattan. He wasn\u2019t there, but hours later four of the Americans were killed in an ambush that remains under investigation.\n\nThis month, Nigerien forces apprehended a man who matches the description of Mr. Cheffou, a senior lieutenant of a former affiliate of Al Qaeda that pledged allegiance to the Islamic State. The Nigerien authorities are working to verify his identity, said a senior Nigerien commander, an account that was confirmed by a retired American counterterrorism official.\n\nIn an interview on Friday at a Nigerien base outside the city of Agadez, where the United States is building a new drone base, Col. His office did not give a date for his return, leading to renewed rumors in the Nigerian capital, Abuja, that Mr. Buhari would once again be receiving medical attention in London.\n\nMr. Buhari enjoyed widespread support after winning the election in 2015, but it dissipated as Nigeria suffered through a recession in 2016 and 2017, and new attacks from Boko Haram, the Islamist rebel group.\n\n\u201cSecurity and the economy are the two main areas of disillusionment,\u201d said Sola Tayo, a fellow at Chatham House, a British foreign affairs think tank. \u201cWhilst the economy has picked up since the recession, the security situation appears to be deteriorating.\u201d\n\n\u201cThe herder-farmer conflict, rural banditry and the increase in kidnapping are being discussed more openly and government performance being judged more critically,\u201d she said.\n\nIt was predictable that Mr. Buhari would run again, said Ayisha Osori, a Nigerian author, lawyer and political activist. As for whether he would win, \u201cit is too early to say,\u201d she said. \u201cA lot will depend on the other candidates.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe highest-profile challenger to emerge so far is Atiku Abubakar, 71, a former vice president and wealthy businessman who has said he will run in 2019. The election is expected to be held in February.\n\nTo remind Nigerians of Mr. Buhari\u2019s appeal, his office has released pictures of crowds warmly greeting the president in several visits to mostly northern cities, his base of support.\n\nNigeria has an unofficial practice of alternating the presidency between the mostly Christian south and the predominantly Muslim north. Ms. Osori said that ambitious southern contenders might decide that it makes more sense to wait until the president has served two terms \u2014 the maximum allowed by law \u2014 and it is clearly the south\u2019s \u201cturn.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Buhari's return to Nigeria last August only partially eased the fevered speculation about his health. When Mr. Buhari worked from home for several weeks, his spokesman explained it was because of the presence of rats in the president\u2019s office. He became the subject of widespread ridicule in Nigeria.\n\nThat ridicule turned to anger in February, when Boko Haram abducted 110 schoolgirls in Dapchi, in the northeast. The president had insisted for nearly two years that the group had been defeated, and the abductions led to new questions about the government\u2019s security strategy and its response to the kidnappings.\n\nIn March, 104 of the girls were returned to the town after successful negotiations between Boko Haram and the government. The militants drove the girls back into the town, preaching to locals against enrolling their children to school in an unprecedented propaganda effort.\n\nUnder Mr. Buhari, the government has also negotiated the release of more than 100 of the girls Boko Haram captured in Chibok in 2014, before he took office.\n\nAs a general, Mr. Buhari headed the Nigerian government from 1983 to 1985, following a military coup. Just last week, it announced that Dr. Ellen Stofan, the former chief scientist at NASA, would be taking over as the director of the museum, which, with 7 million visitors last year, is the most popular of the Smithsonian institutions. The museum is about to begin an ambitious seven-year, almost $1 billion renovation at a time when space exploration is receiving renewed interest.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cThe goal here is really about, how do we get people that aren\u2019t interested in space to be interested in space and be interested in the museum?\u201d said Mark Kornmann, an associate director.\n\nTo attract a younger generation, the Smithsonian threw open its doors on Saturday night to celebrate the Russian cosmonaut Yuri Gagarin, who on April 12, 1961, became the first human to venture into space, a victory for the Soviet Union at the time. He scored 21 goals after the All-Star break, the most in the league, during a push to get the battered Lightning into the playoffs. They fell short, which frustrated Kucherov to the point of voicing his dismay publicly.\n\nBut this season, Tampa Bay had fewer injuries and even more production from Kucherov, who had 39 goals and 61 assists. He wanted to play with center Steven Stamkos, as he did last season before Stamkos\u2019s season-ending injury, and the two responded with the most productive 10-game stretch to start an N.H.L. season in more than two decades. They combined for 14 goals and 23 assists, and the Lightning won eight of those games.\n\nStamkos and Kucherov finished the year with the second-most points of any tandem, with 186; they were edged by a point by Philadelphia\u2019s Claude Giroux and Jake Voracek in the final game of the season.\n\nStamkos, who works closely with Kucherov and shares a private skills coach, the Hall of Fame center Adam Oates, said even he was occasionally surprised by Kucherov\u2019s inventiveness.\n\n\u201cKuch is, without question, one of the most talented players in the league and one of the most talented players I\u2019ve ever had a chance to play with,\u201d said Stamkos, who adjusted his game to let Kucherov shoot the puck more. \u201cThe feeling is mutual with me wanting to play on the same line as him.\u201d\n\nLightning Coach Jon Cooper said Kucherov stood out as a committed worker, even among other professionals, pointing to his off-season work in Florida with personal coaches.\n\n\u201cIf you\u2019ve ever been here in July, it\u2019s really hot, you\u2019ve got to be inside a lot,\u201d Cooper said. \u201cA lot of players aren\u2019t here in July and August, but one guy was, it was Kuch.\u201d", "title": "Nikita Kucherov\u2019s Next Trick? At one point, as a lightly wounded man holding a slingshot was carried off, he made an obscene gesture toward the Israeli side, prompting cheers and laughter; another held up two fingers in a victory sign.\n\nIsraeli news outlets reported that Palestinians had built an ancient war machine \u2014 a trebuchet, or slingshot-like catapult \u2014 to hurl heavy stones or even burning tires at the Israeli side. The reports included photos of the trebuchet but there was no confirmation on Friday that it had been deployed.\n\n5 miles Gaza City Shejaiya Mediterranean Sea Nahal Oz GAZA WEST BANK Jerusalem Area of detail ISRAEL ISRAEL EGYPT\n\nThe United Nations urged both sides to avoid violence and said there were \u201cstrong indications\u201d that Israeli security forces had used excessive force last week in driving back protesters, which may have breached international law.\n\nElizabeth Throssell, a spokeswoman for the United Nations human rights office in Geneva, said the high casualty toll among protesters who were unarmed or did not pose a serious threat to security forces \u2014 and in some cases were running away from the fence \u2014 suggested Israeli troops may have used excessive force.\n\nSome protesters had reportedly acted dangerously, but international law permits the use of lethal force only as a last resort in the face of an imminent threat of death or serious injury, she said. \u201cAn attempt to approach or cross the green-line fence by itself certainly does not amount to a threat to life or serious injury that would justify the use of live ammunition,\u201d she said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cIf there is unjustified and unlawful recourse to firearms resulting in death, that may amount to willful killing and that\u2019s a grave breach of the fourth Geneva Convention,\u201d she added.\n\nAt the United Nations headquarters in New York, the Palestinian ambassador, Riyad H. Mansour, condemned what he described as a failure by the Security Council to do anything to resolve the situation in Gaza, in particular its inability to vote on a joint statement condemning the violence last week.\n\n\u201cWe believe that the Security Council to continue to disregard its responsibility is encouraging the Israeli side to continue with this onslaught against our people,\u201d he said at a news conference outside of the Security Council chamber.\n\nAt the protests on Friday, despite the occasional crack of gunfire and whistle of bullets, which sent demonstrators running for cover, there was an eerily festive, almost carnival-like atmosphere on the periphery, with vendors selling food, drinks and flags. Israeli drones and surveillance balloons flew overhead, as did the occasional kite in the Palestinian national colors of red, black, white and green.\n\nOn the Israeli side, civilians sought vantage points with binoculars and cameras, straining to see the action from kibbutz watchtowers or outcroppings of farmland.\n\nFor much of the afternoon, thousands of Palestinians massed a few hundred yards from the fence, cheering and chanting like fans in a soccer stadium, applauding protesters who defied the Israelis, and jeering the Israelis\u2019 firing of tear gas canisters, as if to say it couldn\u2019t harm them. Some tried distracting Israeli snipers with mirrors reflecting the brilliant sun.\n\nAgain and again, as the sun sunk into the Mediterranean, came the sound of gunshots, the wail of sirens, the cheers in Arabic: \u201cWe are heading to Jerusalem with millions of martyrs.\u201d", "title": "Nine Killed in Gaza as Palestinian Protesters Face Off With Israeli Soldiers", "authors": ["David M. Halbfinger", "Iyad Abuheweila", "Isabel Kershner"]} {"date": "2018-04-27 00:00:00", "text": "Here are some suggestions for what it should include:\n\nImage\n\n1. The right to an itemized bill in plain English.\n\nPatients can\u2019t detect and dispute improper charges if their bills involve dozens of pages of medical abbreviations. Studies have found that 30 percent to over 50 percent of hospital bills contain errors. I interviewed a parent whose bill included thousands for his newborn\u2019s circumcision \u2014 even though his son was never circumcised. If a contractor charged you for a kitchen when he only renovated the bathroom, it would be fraud. When hospitals do the same it\u2019s regarded as an honest mistake. I have seen the bill a patient got for a hip replacement in Belgium. It is easier for me to understand than an American bill even though it\u2019s in Flemish.\n\nImage\n\n2. The right to never receive a surprise out-of-network bill.\n\nOne New Jersey couple went to a hospital, a doctor and an anesthesiologist within their insurance network for the birth of their daughter. But when their newborn had trouble breathing, requiring a stint in intensive care, they discovered that the pediatricians there were not in any network, resulting in a surprise bill for $10,000. A number of states are passing laws to shield individuals from surprise charges. But the laws put the onus on the patient to dispute the bill. The providers can still attempt to collect, and they do so aggressively.\n\nImage\n\n3. The right to accurate information about the provider network in my insurance plan.\n\nDoctors must be clearly in-network or not. I had one gastroenterologist\u2019s office tell me that she is in-network for a polyp removal but not for a routine colonoscopy, generally a far less lucrative procedure under current insurance rules. Doctors shouldn\u2019t be able to cherry pick \u2014 they must be in-network for all the procedures they normally perform and on all days of the week they practice. If a provider is listed as in-network but is not, the insurer should take care of the charge.\n\nImage\n\n4. The right to a stable network.\n\nI buy my insurance policy for a year. If my doctor or insurer stops participating in my network within that year or in the midst of treating me for an acute disease, I should still be billed as an in-network patient. This would prevent a bait-and-switch: A patient goes to a physical therapy practice for a knee injury, for instance. The first sessions are in-network. Then that therapist leaves the network or the patient is scheduled with a different therapist who doesn\u2019t participate, resulting in a $450 bill.\n\nImage\n\n5. The right to be informed of conflicts of interest.\n\nPatients should know if their doctors own a financial stake in a testing or procedure facility before a test or procedure is ordered or scheduled. They should know if a hospital is paying its doctors according to how much revenue they generate or how much they bill, and be informed of any other mutually beneficial financial relationships.", "title": "Opinion | Nine Rights Every Patient Should Demand", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-20 00:00:00", "text": "ALBANY \u2014 In her first major environmental proposal, Cynthia Nixon, who is challenging Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo for the Democratic nomination, called on New York State to commit to 100 percent renewable energy sources by 2050, a benchmark that has been something of a Holy Grail for activists concerned about the warming of the planet as a result of the burning of fossil fuels.\n\nHer announcement on Friday came just hours after the governor\u2019s office had issued its own call for increased efficiency targets to right \u201cthe devastating effects of climate change.\u201d Both moves seemed calculated to coincide with Earth Day on Sunday, but also as a means of upstaging the other\u2019s initiatives.\n\nMs. Nixon called for a complete embrace of renewable energy, like that produced by wind, water or solar. Mr. Cuomo has, to this point, committed to 50 percent renewable energy by 2030.\n\nSpeaking to a crowd in Rockaway Beach, Queens, which was badly damaged by Hurricane Sandy in 2012, Ms. Nixon said that action to prevent climate change \u201ccan\u2019t fall victim to business as usual in Albany and a political system that caters to the needs of corporate donors over the future of New York\u2019s Cohen.\n\nThe backing from his bosses was not exactly a shock: Mr. Hannity is the top ratings draw at Fox News, and he has been unapologetic about what he described as an informal, \u201cde minimis\u201d arrangement with Mr. Cohen, whom he has vigorously defended on air. His Monday night show, hours after the relationship was revealed in a Manhattan courtroom, went on as scheduled.\n\nBut in the past, Mr. Hannity had run into trouble for crossing the line from commentator to activist \u2014 and Tuesday\u2019s subdued reaction speaks to the new realities at Trump-era Fox News.\n\nIn 2010, Mr. Hannity was yanked from a Tea Party rally in Ohio after network executives objected to his appearance. \u201cI don\u2019t think we should be supporting the Tea Party or any other party,\u201d Rupert Murdoch, the channel\u2019s owner, said at the time.", "title": "No Disclosure? No Problem. Sean Hannity Gets a Pass at Fox News.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-17 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cNycha\u2019s unlawful failure to keep residents safe from toxic substances and ensure their continued access to heat and hot water constitute a public health emergency \u2014 and indeed a humanitarian crisis,\u201d the three Council members, Laurie Cumbo and Alicka Ampry-Samuel of Brooklyn and Ritchie Torres of the Bronx, wrote in their brief. \u201cThe court\u2019s immediate intervention is necessary.\u201d\n\nThe courts did intervene on Tuesday on behalf of Nycha tenants, as a judge in the public housing tenants\u2019 case ruled against the housing authority and ordered it to test thousands of apartments housing children for lead paint.\n\nBut given the Law Department\u2019s opposition to Council members filing briefs in support of plaintiffs in these sorts of cases, the Council\u2019s own lawyers decided to ask a court to settle the question \u2014 not merely in the context of this case, but for all cases.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cWe\u2019re not supposed to always agree and that\u2019s fine. But we must always be allowed to speak, including in court cases that affect our districts,\u201d Mr. Johnson said in a statement.\n\nThe argument is ultimately over whether the Council is an agency under the charter, or a separate and coequal branch.\n\nThe city\u2019s Law Department does represent the Council in many matters and has argued that the charter makes the corporation counsel \u2014 who heads the Law Department \u2014 the sole attorney for the city and every agency, which the Law Department believes includes the Council. If the corporation counsel declines to represent them, this theory holds, members could file briefs as citizens, but not in their official roles.\n\nBut the Council\u2019s lawyers argue that Council members should be allowed to hire outside counsel and express their own opinions on a given matter \u2014 on the grounds of a separation of powers and because of the members\u2019 First Amendment right to speak on behalf of their constituents.\n\nIn March, the three Council members asked the corporation counsel, Zachary W. Carter, to represent them for the purpose of filing the brief or authorize them to hire outside counsel. Mr. Carter \u201cdenied the request by not responding to it,\u201d according to the Council\u2019s suit, and in doing so \u201ccommitted an error of law and acted improperly, arbitrarily, capriciously, and unreasonably.\u201d\n\nThe Council is represented in the case by the firm Emery Celli Brinckerhoff and Abady.\n\n\u201cThe responsibility for representing the official position of the city in court is vested in the Corporation Counsel,\u201d a Law Department spokesman said in a statement. \u201cThis fundamental principle \u2014 that a government must speak with one official voice in litigation \u2014 is true at every level of government \u2014 local, state and federal.\u201d", "title": "No Friends of the Court: City Council Sues City\u2019s Top Lawyer", "authors": ["J. David Goodman"]} {"date": "2018-04-21 00:00:00", "text": "PARIS \u2014 An Algerian woman\u2019s refusal to shake hands with male officials at a French naturalization ceremony is sufficient grounds for denying her citizenship, France\u2019s top administrative court has ruled.\n\nIn its decision \u2014 issued on April 11 but reported only this week \u2014 the court, known as the Council of State, said that the woman\u2019s refusal \u201cin a place and at a moment that are symbolic, reveals a lack of assimilation.\u201d\n\nThe woman, who has not been identified, married a French citizen in Algeria in 2010 and filed for French citizenship five years later. At her naturalization ceremony in 2016 in Grenoble, in southeastern France, the woman refused to shake the hands of a local state official and of a local elected official, both male, citing her religious convictions.\n\nThe ruling did not specify the woman\u2019s religion, and it did not identify her as Muslim. Some practicing Muslims believe Islam does not permit physical contact with a person of the opposite sex, with the exception of immediate family members.", "title": "No Handshake, No Citizenship, French Court Tells Algerian Woman", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-04 00:00:00", "text": "By Carly Chilton\n\nIn January, you see them all over social media. Kids around age 5, smiling proudly under a wide, floppy hat. Their first day of school in Australia.\n\nThey\u2019re dressed in their brand new school polo or dress, and mum is usually crouched down next to them, proudly displaying their new Big Kid off to Big School with their lunchbox neatly packed into the Big Bag hanging off their backs. It\u2019s a Big Milestone.\n\nBut it was the Big Hats that got to me.\n\nRight before my oldest started school, we moved overseas to the Middle East. A family adventure! New beginnings! We were escaping the clutches of the expensive Sydney housing market and the idea that going on an overseas trip beyond Bali would take seven years to save for.", "title": "No Hat, No Play", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-25 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nI was excited to see \u201cWhat Makeup to Wear for Your Wedding? Maybe None\u201d (Sunday Styles, April 22), but disappointed to learn that most of the women profiled did indeed wear makeup on their wedding day.\n\nWas it too difficult to find a bride who simply presented her face \u2014 sans corrections or enhancements \u2014 on her wedding day?\n\nThese brides do exist. I was one of them. I wore absolutely no makeup when I got married. No light layer of lip gloss, no single coat of mascara, no hint of bronzer. Nothing.\n\nThe reasoning? If my husband\u2019s face was good enough as is for our wedding day, so was mine. Neither of us had anything to apologize for, conceal or fix.", "title": "Opinion | No Makeup at My Wedding", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-18 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cWomen are marrying later, they\u2019re a little more certain of themselves,\u201d said Amanda Miller, an associate professor of sociology at the University of Indianapolis. \u201cMany marry today not as a blushing bride, but they think of themselves as women, so they have their own set of expectations as opposed to carrying out the expectations of others. At this moment, women\u2019s voices are more valued.\u201d\n\nMs. Huff said her husband, Collin Vaughn, 44, \u201cwas really happy\u201d with her natural look. \u201cHe was glad I didn\u2019t look like a prom queen. I felt beautiful. I felt fresh and like myself.\u201d\n\nRather than hiring a makeup artist, she flew Melanie Simon, an aesthetician based in Los Angeles, to Italy for the wedding. Ms. Simon brought 70 skin care products and a bag of \u201cfacial tools.\u201d Foundation was swapped for masks and serums rich in oxygen, collagen, placenta, antioxidants and anti-aging properties. Facials were done daily before the rehearsal dinner and wedding.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cLaurie really stood to her guns, even when people tried to change her mind,\u201d said Ms. Simon, adding that she is currently working with another barefaced bride. \u201cYears ago people would have said, \u2018No way in hell. I need a makeup artist, I must have a makeup artist.\u2019 This generation cares about their skin, they\u2019re going toward cleaner products and a less-is-more thinking. They\u2019ve been brought up differently.\u201d\n\nOthers are citing skin care trends and terminology from Korean beauty (or K-Beauty) products \u2014 like Glass Skin, which focuses on moisturizing and highlighting, and Cloudless Skin, which refers to the clearness and brightness of one\u2019s skin \u2014 as no makeup incentives.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cInstagram and social media are encouraging people to make their skin more perfect,\u201d said David Ruff, a beauty and style Instagram influencer. \u201cWomen who don\u2019t wear makeup are doing it for themselves. The message they\u2019re sending is that they don\u2019t need to cover their face in makeup to feel a sense of beauty, especially if they\u2019re confident with how their skin looks.\u201d\n\nBetter skin might be one reason for the shift, another is a desire for authenticity.\n\n\u201cSociety expects women to plan this event, which can be overwhelming,\u201d said Shauna Stribula, 37, who works for the office of New York City Mayor Bill de Blasio. She married Evan Losow, 34, at the Peristyle in Prospect Park, Brooklyn, in September before 200 guests.\n\nOn her wedding day, she wore just a hint of makeup, and only after caving in to the encouragement and pleading of her friend Morgan Soloski, 36, of Los Angeles, who flew in for the event.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Of the Moment The lifestyle newsletter from the Styles, Travel and Food sections, offering the latest trends to news you can use. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cWomen shouldn\u2019t have to wear makeup to be regarded as fully formed people,\u201d Ms. Soloski agreed, \u201cbut for these milestone events I still think there\u2019s something nice about being dressed up.\u201d\n\nBefore the wedding Ms. Soloski presented Ms. Stribula with a makeup bag and Tarte makeup palette. \u201cShauna wanted to give it back to me,\u201d Ms. Soloski said. She said, \u2018I\u2019m not going to use is.\u2019\u201d\n\nMs. Stribula conceded. Yet each time Ms. Soloski applied a stroke of blush or a puff of shadow, Ms. Stribula removed it. \u201cShe fought me at every pass \u2014 I applied the lightest amount of something and she would take it off,\u201d she said. \u201cShe looked beautiful without anything. A fresh, natural bride. That\u2019s who she is.\u201d\n\nIn the end, the bride wore just a hint of lip gloss, eyeliner and powder.\n\n\u201cWeddings are performative,\u201d Ms. Stribula said. \u201cYou\u2019re up there to be viewed and judged. Not wearing makeup was a natural representation and a natural extension of me. I\u2019m publicly proclaiming my love, not my beauty.\u201d\n\nThe no-makeup (or nearly no-makeup) movement caught on with one of Ms. Stribula\u2019s wedding guests as well.\n\nPhoto\n\nDebbie Pressman, 34, a publicist at a music marketing and management agency, had very little makeup on her face when she married Jonathan Cobb, 32, on March 16 at the Meatball Shop in Manhattan\u2019s Chelsea neighborhood.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cWatching Shauna was inspiring,\u201d Ms. Pressman said. \u201cI used to be a big makeup person, but I was hiding behind the layers. Wearing it at my wedding seemed fake, especially with the filters and all this prep work, people know it\u2019s not you.\u201d\n\nMs. Pressman had her nails done (for pampering) and a stylist do her hair (for taming sake). She wore lip gloss, mascara and BB cream. \u201cI don\u2019t want my wedding to feel like a job,\u201d she said. \u201cI work hard all day. My fianc\u00e9 has seen me at my worst and still thinks I\u2019m beautiful.\u201d\n\nRegardless of the reasons for their desired appearance, the results for these women were the same: beautiful, natural and theirs.\n\n\u201cEvery person I talked to told me how beautiful I looked,\u201d Ms. Stribula said. \u201cI find it fascinating that people kept saying it was a brave statement to make at my wedding. It was the version I wanted to present to the world, which was one with very limited makeup.\u201d", "title": "No Makeup on My Wedding Day", "authors": ["Alix Strauss"]} {"date": "2018-04-24 00:00:00", "text": "All four have been making calls to potential donors, according to a person who reported receiving entreaties from each of them.\n\nAnd while the election is three and a half years away, the city\u2019s electoral calculus has changed with term limits. All three citywide officeholders, the borough presidents and the majority of City Council members, are serving their final terms.\n\n\u201cYou have pretty much the entire leadership of the government switching over,\u201d said Suri Kasirer, a political consultant.\n\nThat also means that a host of politicians are thinking about what to run for next.\n\n\u201cThree years goes quickly and everybody in this group is seasoned, so they know to get their name out and be very five-borough, and raise money in different places,\u201d said the Manhattan borough president, Gale A. Brewer, who so far is watching from the sidelines.\n\nAll four candidates are busy raising money with the hope of making a strong showing when candidates are required to make their first campaign finance report of the 2021 electoral cycle.\n\nThey are all playing catch-up to Mr. Stringer, who retained $1.4 million from his last comptroller campaign, which he is permitted to transfer to his next run for office. Mr. Diaz had $430,000 remaining in his previous campaign account and Mr. Adams had $300,000. Ms. James had only $31,000 left that she can use for her next race.\n\nAnd while most or all of the candidates have told donors and supporters in private that they are running, in public they are more circumspect.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nTwo people who attended Mr. Adams\u2019s event last week said that he stated unequivocally that he was running for mayor. The bracket included Mr. Adams, Mr. Stringer, Ms. James and Mr. Diaz, and Mr. Adams said that the contest would come down to a final showdown between him and Mr. Stringer.\n\nMr. Adams then said that Mr. de Blasio had spent so much time in African-American communities when he first ran for mayor in 2013 that he had essentially \u201cout-blacked\u201d the race\u2019s black candidate, William Thompson.\n\nMr. Adams went on to say that in the 2021 race he was going to \u201cout-white\u201d Mr. Stringer, by winning over white constituencies. Mr. Adams and Ms. James are black. Mr. Stringer is white. Mr. Diaz is Hispanic. Mr. Adams explained that his past as a police officer gave him the experience to assure white voters that he would make public safety a priority.\n\nIn an interview last week, Mr. Adams was asked about his comments.\n\n\u201cI was being colorful,\u201d he said, explaining that just as Mr. de Blasio pressed issues like stop and frisk that had an impact in black communities, he planned to take his message of public safety to white neighborhoods. \u201cPeople look at a black candidate and they think he can\u2019t go into the Baysides, Bay Ridges and Marine Parks, and I\u2019m not going to be the candidate that can\u2019t do that.\u201d\n\nMr. Adams said that other potential candidates \u201ccontinue to play coy\u201d with the public when it comes to their aspirations. But when asked whether he was running, he would not provide a simple yes or no. \u201cI want to be extremely clear, I am pursuing running for mayor,\u201d he said. \u201cIt\u2019s different from a formal announcement.\u201d\n\nMr. Diaz, the only candidate who has filed papers with election authorities indicating that he is a candidate for mayor, was also reluctant to say explicitly that he was running.\n\n\u201cIt is very early,\u201d Mr. Diaz said. \u201cThere\u2019s no secret that I\u2019m looking at it. I\u2019m exploring it. I\u2019m considering it.\u201d Pressed, he said, \u201cI\u2019m raising money for the sole purpose of running for mayor.\u201d Mr. Diaz has sent out invitations to a Yankees-themed birthday fund-raiser on May 3, encouraging supporters to commit to raising money for him, with those who can raise $25,000 designated as M.V.P.s.\n\nMr. Stringer also refused to say what office he intended to run for next.\n\n\u201cI\u2019m building a political foundation for whatever comes next,\u201d Mr. Stringer said. \u201cI love public service. I want to continue serving this city. Part of that is building the financial infrastructure to be competitive in 2021.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMs. James said that in the last few days she has held \u201ca number of meetings with individuals\u201d to discuss her possible next run for office. \u201cI am examining my options for the future and so we are exploring the possibility of running for mayor in 2021,\u201d she said.\n\nAt least one potential candidate who has not filed papers is getting the attention of political insiders: Corey Johnson, the City Council speaker. Now I\u2019m reading off the first paragraph, I said, \u2018This is boring.\u2019\u201d\n\nIf Mr. Trump has lost some interest in the $1.5 trillion tax overhaul that he signed into law last year \u2014 even though the White House keeps scheduling events to promote it, including one in Florida on Monday \u2014 well, the country is right there with him. But otherwise, by all sorts of metrics, Americans aren\u2019t talking very much about a law that Republicans had hoped to make a centerpiece of their midterm election message.\n\nConsider one of Mr. Trump\u2019s preferred yardsticks: cable news coverage. Throughout the fall, as Republicans rushed their tax bill through Congress in two breakneck months, CNN, Fox News and MSNBC routinely devoted 10 percent of their daily coverage to tax issues, according to data from the Gdelt Project. Body piercings and tattoos must be removed or covered. Water breaks can be taken only when the Panthers are on offense. TopCats must leave the stadium to change into their personal attire.\n\nBaltimore Ravens cheerleaders were subject to regular weigh-ins and are expected to \u201cmaintain ideal body weight,\u201d according to a handbook from 2009. The Cincinnati Ben-Gals were even more precise in recent years: Cheerleaders had to be within three pounds of their \u201cideal weight.\u201d\n\nSome cheerleaders must pay hundreds of dollars for their uniforms, yet are paid little more than minimum wage. Cheerleaders must sell raffle tickets and calendars and appear at charity events and golf tournaments, yet they receive none of the proceeds. Cheerleaders", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-27 00:00:00", "text": "The theory, however, has jumped species. It is increasingly being applied to pets in the United States and is gaining momentum in Britain \u2014 raising concerns that the already low vaccination rates in this country could fall further.\n\nThose who fear vaccine side effects in their dogs claim the animals could develop canine autism, thyroid disease and arthritis.\n\nThen, on Monday, the television show \u201cGood Morning Britain\u201d on ITV put out a call on Twitter to hear from dog owners who believed their pets showed symptoms of autism after receiving vaccinations, and from others who had stopped getting their pets vaccinated against dangerous diseases.\n\nThe next day, the veterinary association put out a statement on Twitter.\n\n\u201cWe are aware of an increase in anti-vaccination pet owners in the U.S. who have voiced concerns that vaccinations may lead to their dogs developing autism-like behavior. There\u2019s currently no reliable scientific evidence to indicate autism in dogs (or its link to vaccines),\u201d the association said in its tweet.\n\nIt added: \u201cPotential side effects of vaccines are rare and outweighed by the benefits in protecting against disease. BVA would be happy to provide evidence-based information on the issue.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. New measles cases popped up in Nebraska and Minnesota, New York and Marin County, Calif.\n\nFear of vaccines spread to Europe, and cases of measles rose in 2017, with the virus finding its way into areas with unvaccinated children from Romania to Britain. At least 35 children died of the disease in 2017, according to the World Health Organization.\n\nItaly had 5,006 cases of measles and three deaths last year; 88 percent of those cases were in people never vaccinated, the European Center for Prevention and Disease Control said.", "title": "No, Your Dog Can\u2019t Get Autism From a Vaccine", "authors": ["Ceylan Yeginsu"]} {"date": "2018-04-26 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cIt would be frustrating if we weren\u2019t where we\u2019re at in the standings,\u201d said Callaway, whose team sits atop the National League East with a 15-8 record. \u201cWe\u2019re still in a pretty good spot. Singles by Bruce and Frazier and walks by Adrian Gonzalez and Jose Lobaton \u2014 neither of whom swung the bat against a wild Luke Gregerson \u2014 combined for a run.\n\nBut in the bottom of the inning, the Mets could not close out the game.
