Created by the Mexican artist Pedro Reyes, it features a zany plot involving a technology contest, a contraption called the Print-a-Friend and a surprise appearance by Donald Trump. There\u2019s also plenty of high-flown debate about technology, freedom and inequality.\n\nThe play, which was scripted by Paul Hufker and directed by Meghan Finn, grew out of an artistic residency Mr. Reyes had last fall at M.I.T., Mr. Chomsky\u2019s longtime intellectual home, and a place suffused, as Mr. Reyes put it, with \u201ctechno-optimism.\u201d\n\n\u201cM.I.T. has this very beautiful culture of hands-on creativity,\u201d he said in a telephone interview. \u201cBut there is also this idea that whatever the problem is, the solution is technology.\u201d", "title": "Noam Chomsky, Elon Musk and Ayn Rand Walk Into a Puppet Show", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-20 00:00:00", "text": "The Nobel Foundation and even the king of Sweden have said that the scandal threatened to sully the reputation of the Nobel Prizes as a whole.\n\nAfter the allegations became public, the academy ended the group\u2019s work with Mr. Arnault and hired a law firm to conduct an investigation. The academy did not make the firm\u2019s report public, but described some of its findings on Friday.\n\nPerhaps most damaging, the investigation showed that a woman wrote to the academy in 1996 to complain of Mr. Arnault\u2019s conduct, but the matter was not pursued.\n\n\u201cThe Swedish Academy is deeply sorry that the contents of the letter was put aside,\u201d the statement said.\n\nThe author of the letter, Anna-Karin Bylund, has said that Mr. Arnault raped her in his apartment in the early 1990s, when she was preparing for an exhibit of her artwork at Forum. But in her 1996 letter, she did not describe the incident as rape.\n\nIn addition, the investigation found that the academy had violated its own rules by providing financial support to Forum, co-owned by one of its members, and it confirmed that Mr. Arnault had repeatedly leaked the names of literature prize winners, usually a closely held secret. It said he did not have any influence on Nobel Prize decisions.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe investigation sought to discover what members of the academy knew about the accusations of misconduct by Mr. Arnault. The group said that Mr. Arnault\u2019s activities were \u201cnot generally known in the academy,\u201d and that members were not aware of anything that could be considered criminal.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThis month, three members of the academy resigned when the panel refused to oust Ms. Frostenson.\n\nInstead, last week, the academy removed Sara Danius \u2014 who had commissioned the law firm\u2019s investigation and tried to bring more transparency to the panel\u2019s work \u2014 from her position as permanent secretary. Ms. Danius, 56, the first woman to serve as the academy\u2019s chief officer since it was created in 1786, remained a member of the academy. But she decided to end her association with the academy altogether. Ms. Frostenson also agreed to end her work with the academy.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nElise Karlsson, a writer and one of the 18 women who spoke out in the Dagens Nyheter expos\u00e9, said Friday that the academy was not doing nearly enough to repair the situation.\n\n\u201cOn the one hand, this press statement says that they take sexual harassment very seriously, and on the other hand they don\u2019t seem to want to take any measures to discourage the things that have come to light,\u201d Ms. Karlsson said.\n\nThe ouster of Ms. Danius prompted a deluge of protest and support for her. Last Friday, many Swedish women \u2014 and some men \u2014 around Sweden wore pussy-bow blouses, Ms. Danius\u2019s signature garb, or scarves and posted selfies on social media platforms.\n\nOn Thursday, hundreds of people in such blouses demonstrated outside the building where the academy holds its weekly sessions.\n\n\u201cResign, all of you!\u201d demonstrators yelled. They waved signs that read \u201cThe sisterhood sees you!\u201d and \u201cCrush the patriarchy. Together we make a difference.\u201d\n\nCecilia Ohman, 50, said the dismissal of Ms. Danius amounted to a woman taking the fall for a man\u2019s bad behavior. \u201cThe question isn\u2019t any bigger than that,\u201d she said. \u201cWe have had enough, quite simply.\u201d\n\nJames Wood, a famous literary critic, also expressed his support for Ms. Danius, telling Dagens Nyheter that her removal was \u201ca backlash from the trenches of male privilege.\u201d\n\n\u201cWho wants to accept this year\u2019s prize from a reduced, badly wounded and ill-famed group?\u201d he asked.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nOne problem faced by the academy that is now being addressed by Sweden\u2019s king is that its appointments are for life, and it has no mechanism for allowing people to leave or replacing them.\n\nIt has 18 seats in all, but after the recent resignations, it has only 11 active members, eight men and three women. That is one short of the 12-member quorum needed to elect new members.\n\nKing Carl XVI Gustaf has said that he would amend the Swedish Academy\u2019s rules to make it possible for members to leave voluntarily.", "title": "Nobel Panel Admits Inquiry Found Sexual Misconduct, but Nothing Illegal", "authors": ["Christina Anderson"]} {"date": "2018-04-20 00:00:00", "text": "The numbness was worse when we walked our little neighborhood together, and I tried to get you to discuss the prospect of leaving. All my pain and anxiety would pour into my legs until I couldn\u2019t feel them. I was walking on stumps. I couldn\u2019t believe that you wanted this life. You were baffled by my need to leave.\n\nOur friends who married in Seattle had a baby. We got the notice and cried together on the bathroom floor. I was surprised by your grief, but not by mine. I carried mine with me, grieving for something I wanted but could not have. And because I couldn\u2019t have it, I wanted a do-over. And I wanted to give you one too.\n\nBut I knew you would stay exactly where you were. And eventually find and fall in love with someone else. And have a child or two. And I would see you somewhere, years down the road, with a pair of beautiful toddlers on your hips. And you would be happy. But there would be a part of you that would want to stay with me, and a part of me that would want to stay with you, and we would leave the encounter devastated. I would go to my small, expensive apartment and cry, missing you and the life you were living.\n\nI traveled by myself, going to writers\u2019 conferences in California, where I\u2019d try to imagine a life without you. Instead, I imagined the menu items that you might order if you were there, the conversations we\u2019d have and the things you\u2019d point out to me. I sat in Golden Gate Park, in the shade of old-growth eucalyptus, and watched the pollen swirl in the filtered light. I imagined taking our children there after school each day, and walking home just in time to greet you after work.\n\nWe went to Germany and Switzerland and Holland. With each place, a new dream. We could live in Freiburg and go hiking every day. We could live in Amsterdam and run a little shop out of the ground floor of our home. Always, we would fly back to Florida, back to our lives, and I would feel that sadness touching down.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nI was trapped inside myself. Each day I would go to a job that I hated and come back to a house that didn\u2019t feel like mine and I would drink too much, climbing into a small, dark hole made for one.\n\n[ALSO READ: You May Want to Marry My Husband]\n\nI asked if it was O.K. with you if I quit my job and went to Arizona for a few months, just so I could spend some time alone, to write and think and find my foundation, the bedrock that had been surgically cut and irradiated out of me.\n\n\u201cNo,\u201d you said. \u201cIt\u2019s not O.K. We\u2019re married. We\u2019re here. I need you to stay.\u201d\n\nI didn\u2019t know it then, but I needed to stay too. I thought I wanted to be alone but what I really wanted was for you to be free of me. I wanted you to be able to move on and to have what I couldn\u2019t give you.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut I know now that you never saw it that way. When my cancer was diagnosed, you never once stopped to think about how your life might be affected by the loss of my fertility. You only thought about me, and what I needed. So you slept beside me each night in the hospital, and went home each morning to shower and walk the dog. You worked all day, went back home to the dog, and then to Whole Foods so I wouldn\u2019t have to eat hospital food, and then came back to the hospital, and slept beside me once more. I was drugged and swollen. I didn\u2019t realize how long the days were, or what it must have taken you to keep going. This is why you now say \u201cwe went through cancer.\u201d Not \u201cshe,\u201d not \u201cLauren,\u201d but us, together.\n\nLast year we were in Japan, hiking the Kumano Kodo, when it got dark. I was angry with you for causing us to miss the bus that took us to the trailhead, for causing us to spend four additional hours hiking the ancient pilgrimage route under the weight of our heavy packs. My knees, hips and shoulders were in excruciating pain. I decided I couldn\u2019t take another step. I started to cry. I was desperate and exhausted. \u201cLeave me here,\u201d I said through tears.\n\n\u201cWait,\u201d you said, and shifted your pack onto your chest, and took my pack and lifted it onto your back. Together, we descended the slippery rocks, hand-in-hand. I pointed my flashlight at our feet, and you used yours to illuminate the path ahead.\n\nIt\u2019s been 10 years since the cancer. And those sad years that followed feel almost like another sickness I went through, a fever or drug interaction. I still have no idea why you stayed. Why you tolerated me. But I\u2019m glad you did.\n\nNobody tells you how long marriage is. When you fall in love, when you have fun with somebody, when you enjoy the way they see the world, nobody ever says, \u201cThis person will change. And so you will be married to two, three, four, five or 10 people throughout the course of your life, as you live out your vows.\u201d Nobody warns you. But you, my dear. There is something deep and hard and lasting inside of you. And I wish I had known, when I was searching again for my bedrock, that all I had to do was reach out my hand.", "title": "Nobody Tells You How Long a Marriage Is", "authors": ["Lauren Doyle Owens"]} {"date": "2018-04-27 00:00:00", "text": "HAMBURG \u2014 You may remember Nora Fischer as the soprano who gave buoyant performances of Monteverdi\u2019s \u201cVi ricorda \u00f2 boschi ombrosi\u201d at prestigious concert halls across Europe this season, her sweetly vibrant voice rising over the theorbo accompaniment. Or you may have caught her at a pop festival with another version of that same 400-year-old song, this time joined by electric guitar.\n\nEither way, she is likely to have made an impression.\n\nMs. Fischer, 30, is making her mark in the blurry terrain between classical music and pop. The daughter of the conductor Ivan Fischer and the recorder player Anneke Boeke, the classics were always going to be at the root of her artistry. But, as she said in an interview after a performance at the Elbphilharmonie here, \u201cI knew I wanted to sing, but all of the carved-out paths were just not for me.\u201d", "title": "Nora Fischer Bursts the Classical Music Bubble", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-08 00:00:00", "text": "The Nordstrom family has run stores for more than a century, first selling shoes in the Pacific Northwest and later introducing fashion-forward clothing to wealthy suburbanites across the country.\n\nBut the Nordstroms, one of the last remaining dynasties of American retailing, had never made a big bet in nation\u2019s retailing capital until now.\n\nOn Thursday, Nordstrom will open its first full-line store in Manhattan, a sleek, three-floor home to men\u2019s clothing, shoes and grooming supplies at 57th Street and Broadway.", "title": "Nordstrom Opening a New York Store as Other Retailers Close Theirs", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-01 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\n\u201cDefecting From North Korea, Vowing: \u2018We Are Ready to Die\u2019 \u201d (front page, March 26) is a reminder of the unparalleled brutality of the North Korean regime, even as its supreme leader, Kim Jong-un, appears to seek diplomatic glasnost with South Korea, the United States and perhaps China.\n\nBut he may not be able to keep North Korea\u2019s human rights abuses closed to scrutiny forever.\n\nOn March 23, the United Nations Human Rights Council extended its mandate on North Korea, calling on its government to shed light on its human rights situation, which the United Nations Commission of Inquiry in 2014 found included \u201ccrimes against humanity.\u201d\n\nThe article correctly pointed out that refugee flows out of North Korea have decreased under Mr. Kim, who has greatly shored up the border through the effective use of informants, intimidation and guards ordered to shoot on sight.\n\nAs a result, the cost of hiring a broker to facilitate escape into China has risen sharply since the end of 2016.", "title": "Opinion | North Korea Defections", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-19 00:00:00", "text": "North Korea has dropped its demand that American troops be removed from South Korea as a condition for giving up its nuclear weapons, South Korea\u2019s president said Thursday in presenting the idea to the United States.\n\nPresident Moon Jae-in portrayed the proposal as a concession on the eve of talks involving the two Koreas and the United States. The North has long demanded that the 28,500 American troops be withdrawn, citing their presence as a pretext to justify its pursuit of nuclear weapons.\n\nBut in Washington, the Trump administration privately dismissed the idea that it was a capitulation by the North because an American withdrawal from the South was never on the table. Mike Pompeo, the C.I.A. director whom President Trump secretly sent to Pyongyang two weeks ago to meet Kim Jong-un, the North Korean leader, did not ask him to take such a step, senior officials said.\n\nThe move could increase pressure on the United States to support negotiations between North and South Korea on a peace treaty that would end the Korean War. While Mr. Trump gave those talks his blessing this week, officials said his ultimate goal is to force North Korea to relinquish its nuclear program. A peace treaty, they said, should be signed only after the North has given up its weapons.", "title": "North Korea Drops Troop Demand, but U.S. Reacts Warily", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-02 00:00:00", "text": "SEOUL, South Korea \u2014 South Korean reporters visiting North Korea\u2019s capital to cover a K-pop performance there received a surprise on Monday: an unusually graceful apology from a senior North Korean official.\n\nThe official, Kim Yong-chol, a vice chairman of the North\u2019s ruling Workers\u2019 Party, visited the reporters\u2019 hotel and apologized for their having been denied entry to a theater in Pyongyang, the capital, where the North\u2019s leader, Kim Jong-un, watched South Korean musicians perform Sunday evening.\n\n\u201cWe invited you and we are obliged to guarantee free coverage,\u201d Kim Yong-chol was quoted in the reporters\u2019 dispatches from Pyongyang as saying. \u201cOn behalf of the North\u2019s authorities, I offer an apology and ask for your understanding for the wrong committed.\u201d\n\nIt is extremely rare for North Korea to offer such a public apology to the South, or, for that matter, to apologize for anything. The rare gesture from a senior official reflected the North\u2019s efforts to work toward a political d\u00e9tente on the Korean Peninsula that Kim Jong-un helped start in February by sending a delegation to the Winter Olympics in Pyeongchang, South Korea.", "title": "North Korea Issues Rare Apology Over Media Access to K-Pop Show", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-08 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nWASHINGTON \u2014 North Korea has told the United States that its leader, Kim Jong-un, is willing to discuss denuclearization of the Korean Peninsula, administration officials said on Sunday, the first direct confirmation that he intends to participate in an extraordinary meeting with President Trump about his nuclear program.\n\nThe North delivered its message in secret talks between its representatives and American officials as they prepare for the summit meeting, which is expected to take place next month.\n\nSouth Korean officials had informed Mr. Trump in March that the North Korean leader wanted to meet with him for nuclear talks \u2014 an invitation that the president enthusiastically accepted \u2014 but Pyongyang has been officially silent about the meeting.\n\nOn Sunday, the administration officials said the United States government had been working to lay the groundwork for the meeting, but would offer no details about it, such as where it might take place.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nTalks between Mr. Trump and Mr. Kim would represent the first direct engagement between a sitting American president and a North Korean leader, bringing together two mercurial and headstrong leaders who have lobbed long-distance insults and bellicose threats at each other.", "title": "North Korea Said to Offer Direct Assurance It Will Discuss Denuclearization", "authors": ["Julie Hirschfeld Davis"]} {"date": "2018-04-27 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Trump and Ms. Merkel, who have had a chilly relationship, went out of their way to compliment each other \u2014 but it went only so far. Mr. Trump called the bilateral trade relationship \u201cunfair,\u201d and Ms. Merkel emerged from the White House without any notable progress on the nuclear deal with Iran or a permanent exemption for Germany from steel and aluminum tariffs that Mr. Trump imposed in March.\n\nBoth issues are time-sensitive: A temporary exemption from the tariffs for European countries expires on Tuesday, and Mr. Trump faces a May 12 deadline for recertifying the nuclear deal with Iran.\n\n_____\n\nPhoto\n\n3. The House Intelligence Committee released its report on Russian election meddling, saying it had found no evidence that the Trump campaign was involved.\n\nPartisan bickering ensued: Republicans, who control the committee, criticized the Obama administration for a \u201cslow and inconsistent\u201d response to Russia\u2019s active measures and took aim at the F.B.I. Democrats, in a dissenting document, accused the Republicans of prematurely closing the investigation to protect Mr. Trump. Read the full report here.\n\nAnd newly released emails suggest that Natalia Veselnitskaya, above, the Russian lawyer who met with Trump campaign officials in Trump Tower in June 2016, had closer ties to the Kremlin than she had let on.\n\n_____\n\nPhoto\n\n4. Hundreds of Palestinian protesters stormed the Gaza security fence and tried to cross into Israel. Israeli troops responded with lethal force.\n\nAs of Friday night, the Gaza health ministry said that three Palestinians had been killed, all of them shot in the head, and nearly 1,000 had been wounded, 178 of them by live ammunition.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe protest was the fifth in a series of weekly demonstrations, billed as the Great Return March, meant to highlight the decade-old Israeli blockade and to rekindle international sympathy for Palestinian refugees\u2019 claim of a right to return to what is now Israel.\n\nAt least 40 demonstrators were killed in the first four weekly protests.\n\n_____\n\nPhoto\n\n5. \u201cTruth prevails.\u201d\n\nThat was Andrea Constand, whose sexual assault complaint against Bill Cosby led to his conviction, as she broke her long public silence with a Twitter message thanking the local community.\n\nOur critic at large Wesley Morris remembers a time when Mr. Cosby\u2019s signature TV character \u2014 and America\u2019s favorite father figure from the 1980s \u2014 once seemed inseparable from the man who portrayed him.\n\n\u201cIf a sexual predator wanted to come up with a smoke screen for his ghastly conquests,\u201d he writes, \u201che couldn\u2019t do better than Cliff Huxtable.\u201d\n\nSo, is Mr. Cosby going to prison? Here\u2019s a look at what might come next.\n\n_____\n\nPhoto\n\n6. More on the Golden State Killer: Using DNA from crime scenes, investigators plugged a genetic profile into an online genealogy database. They found distant relatives of the suspect, Joseph James DeAngelo, and traced their DNA to him.\n\nMr. DeAngelo\u2019s arrest came more than 30 years after the killer\u2019s crime wave, confounding the belief that serial rapists and killers are incapable of stopping. Experts say that\u2019s more myth than reality.\n\nAnd here\u2019s some of the original news coverage of the Golden State Killer.\n\n_____\n\nPhoto\n\n7. The U.S. economy, which has been whacked around like a pinball in the first quarter, still grew at an annual rate of 2.3 percent, the government reported, offering a preliminary glance at the effects of the tax overhaul.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe pace is below the 2.9 percent annualized rate recorded in the fourth quarter of 2017, and short of President Trump\u2019s goal of at least 3 percent. Most forecasters, however, expect quarterly growth to float around the 3 percent mark for the rest of the year.\n\nOne economist called the 2.3 percent figure \u201cmoderately encouraging.\u201d\n\nMarket Snapshot View Full Overview\n\n_____\n\nPhoto\n\n8. In Oman, in the Arabian Peninsula, certain rocks have a special ability: They can turn carbon dioxide into stone.\n\nScientists say that if this natural process, called carbon mineralization, could be harnessed, accelerated and applied inexpensively on a huge scale \u2014 admittedly very big \u201cifs\u201d \u2014 it could help fight climate change.\n\nIn theory, the rocks could remove some of the billions of tons of heat-trapping carbon dioxide that humans have pumped into the air since the beginning of the industrial age.\n\n_____\n\nPhoto\n\n9. Report cards are in for yesterday\u2019s first round of the N.F.L. Draft.\n\nAccording to the experts, there are players who will turn their teams into winners, and others who are already terrible busts. (Sometimes it\u2019s the same player.) Read our own analysis of every pick in the first round here.\n\nBaker Mayfield, above, was the top pick, but the highest grade of the draft went to Derwin James, the safety selected by the Chargers at No. 17. With three A+\u2019s, two A\u2019s and just one B, his G.P.A. was a 3.98.\n\n_____\n\nPhoto\n\n10. Finally, New Jersey is set to proclaim Danny DeVito Day.\n\nStarting this year, Nov. 17, the day the actor was born, will be reserved for Mr. DeVito. Gov. Philip Murphy is expected to issue a statewide proclamation in his honor.\n\n\u201cI was very flattered,\u201d Mr. DeVito said. \u201cOf course, they first told me I could have a beach. Yeah, but they reneged. So I said: \u2018Oh, that\u2019s perfect. It\u2019s New Jersey.\u2019\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHave a great weekend.\n\n_____\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story The Evening Briefing by Email Get a nightly rundown of the day\u2019s top stories, delivered to your inbox every Monday through Friday. Watch our video for more.\n\nVideo\n\nWho you calling confused?\n\n\u2022 A dispute between the Trump administration and its ambassador to the U.N., Nikki Haley, widened on Tuesday after the White House contradicted her announcement that the U.S. was planning new sanctions on Russia.\n\nThe national economics adviser, Larry Kudlow, blamed her comments on \u201cmomentary confusion,\u201d but he later apologized.\n\n\u201cAs it turns out, she was basically following what she thought was policy,\u201d he told The Times. \u201cThe policy was changed and she wasn\u2019t told about it, so she was in a box.\u201d\n\n\u2022 In another sign of divisions in the administration, Defense Secretary Jim Mattis urged the president to get congressional approval before the U.S. launched airstrikes on Syria last week. The president overruled him.\n\nSan Francisco\u2019s seismic gamble\n\n\u2022 An earthquake 112 years ago devastated the city, which lives with the certainty that another Big One will come.\n\nCalifornia has made significant strides in earthquake preparedness, but because of a severe housing shortage, San Francisco has been building more skyscrapers. As a result, its downtown area is denser and more vertical \u2014 and potentially more dangerous.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u2022 How safe are San Francisco\u2019s skyscrapers? Even the engineers who design them can\u2019t provide exact answers. Using detailed photographs and maps, we explain the threat.\n\nA journalist\u2019s death and the hunt for the truth\n\n\u2022 Daphne Caruana Galizia was the most famous \u2014 and most divisive \u2014 journalist in Malta when she was killed by a car bomb in October.\n\nHer death highlighted the Mediterranean island\u2019s role as a haven for corruption and money laundering. Now, the search for her killers poses a test for the European Union, as fears of a cover-up grow.\n\n\u2022 The Times is among 18 news organizations working to pursue leads from Ms. Caruana Galizia\u2019s reporting and to look into the circumstances surrounding her death.\n\nThe Daily Listen to \u2018The Daily\u2019: Fired Over an Instagram Post The dismissal of a professional cheerleader has drawn attention to the sports industry, which seemed to be operating outside the #MeToo movement. Until now, that is. The site was down most of Tuesday, the deadline for taxpayers to file their 2017 returns. Procrastinators were given an extra day to file.\n\n\u2022 Starbucks will close its 8,000 U.S. stores for a day next month to conduct anti-bias training, after the arrest of two black men at one of its outlets prompted outrage.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u2022 U.S. stocks were up on Tuesday. It\u2019s from 1992, and the writer, Marjorie Williams, registered Mrs. Bush\u2019s \u2018brilliant grasp of image.\u2019 I can only agree with the colleague who noted that both Mrs. Bush and the writer are sorely missed.\u201d\n\nBack Story\n\nSome days, you wish the news would just stop.\n\nThat was the case for the BBC on this day in 1930, when its 8:45 evening bulletin was surprisingly brief: \u201cGood evening. Today is Good Friday. There is no news,\u201d the radio announcer said. That update was followed by 15 minutes of piano music.\n\nPhoto\n\nThere was some major world news that day, including a typhoon in the Philippines and an attempted raid on an armory by Indian revolutionaries demanding independence from Britain, but it happened too late for the BBC.\n\nAnd what made the front page of The New York Times on April 18? In addition to articles about Prohibition violations, there was one about gas masks for horses that were doing well in military testing.\n\nThe next day\u2019s front page reported on a plane crash in Jersey City, a deadly church fire in Romania, the weather forecast for Easter Sunday and a study that found that only 700 words were needed for the vast majority of telephone conversations.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThese days, it can seem as if the amount of news is limited only by the time you have to consume it. But if you need a break, here\u2019s some classical piano.\n\nJennifer Jett wrote today\u2019s Back Story.\n\n_____\n\nYour Morning Briefing is published weekdays and updated all morning. The crime scenes have already become popular tourist stops.\n\n_____\n\nPhoto\n\n\u2022 Daphne Caruana Galizia was the most famous \u2014 and most controversial \u2014 journalist in Malta when she was killed by a car bomb in October. The city knows the Big One will come, but we found that its building code doesn\u2019t protect against earthquakes as much as you might think.\n\nBack Story\n\nPhoto\n\nSome days, you wish the news would just stop.\n\nThat was the case for the BBC on this day in 1930, when its 8:45 evening bulletin was surprisingly brief: \u201cGood evening. Today is Good Friday. There is no news,\u201d the radio announcer said. That update was followed by 15 minutes of piano music.\n\nThere was some major world news that day, including a typhoon in the Philippines and an attempted raid on an armory by Indian revolutionaries demanding independence from Britain, but it happened too late for the BBC.\n\nAnd what made the front page of The Times on April 18? In addition to stories about Prohibition violations, there was one about gas masks for horses that were doing well in military testing.\n\nThe next day\u2019s front page reported on a plane crash in Jersey City, a deadly church fire in Romania, the weather forecast for Easter Sunday and a study that found that only 700 words were needed for the vast majority of telephone conversations.\n\nThese days, it can seem as if the amount of news is limited only by the time you have available to consume it. But if you need a break, here\u2019s some classical piano.\n\nJennifer Jett contributed reporting.\n\n_____\n\nYour Morning Briefing is published weekday mornings and updated online.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nCheck out this page to find a Morning Briefing for your region. Here\u2019s the sign-up.)\n\nGood morning.\n\nHere\u2019s what you need to know:\n\nLosing a foothold in the middle class\n\n\u2022 Working for a state or local government \u2014 as a teacher, firefighter, bus driver or nurse, for instance \u2014 used to provide a relatively comfortable living. Now, many government workers take second jobs to make ends meet.\n\nWith the U.S. population having grown, public sector employees now account for the smallest share of the civilian work force since 1967.\n\nSome say a diminished public sector is vital to economic growth. Others say it\u2019s a threat to health and safety. I promise, I won\u2019t ever do it again.\u201d\n\nThat\u2019s the promise of Jerika Whitefield, one of a growing number of people who developed a heart infection from injecting drugs.\n\n\u2022 With methamphetamine use resurgent and the opioid crisis in the U.S. showing no signs of abating, doctors are facing the ethically fraught question of whether costly surgery is well spent on drug users whose addiction goes untreated.\n\nPhoto\n\nIn Ohio race, it\u2019s left versus left\n\n\u2022 The Democratic primary for governor next week pits Richard Cordray, a onetime director of the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, against Dennis Kucinich, a former congressman and presidential candidate.\n\nBoth men are progressive, and the race offers a look at what type of candidate can speak to the Democrats\u2019 base in a Midwestern bellwether state.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u2022 The contest also serves as an early proxy for supporters of Senators Elizabeth Warren and Bernie Sanders, two possible presidential candidates in 2020.\n\nThe Daily Listen to \u2018The Daily\u2019: A Family Divided by the Korean War A peace treaty between North and South Korea could bring reunions for the thousands of families who have been separated for more than six decades. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u2022 Scenes unseen: the summer of \u201978\n\nSix months ago, a conservancy official came across two cardboard boxes that had been sitting around for decades.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nInside were 2,924 color slides, pictures taken in parks across New York City. Here\u2019s a selection of those images, unseen for 40 years.\n\n\u2022 Quotation of the day\n\n\u201cWe\u2019ve literally had some continue using drugs while in the hospital. That\u2019s like trying to do a liver transplant on someone who\u2019s drinking a fifth of vodka on the stretcher.\u201d\n\n\u2014 Dr. Thomas Pollard, a cardiothoracic surgeon in Knoxville, Tenn., on the difficulties of treating patients who develop a dangerous heart infection from injecting drugs like meth and opioids.\n\n\u2022 The Times, in other words\n\nHere\u2019s an image of today\u2019s front page, and links to our Opinion content and crossword puzzles.\n\n\u2022 What we\u2019re reading\n\nJenna Wortham, a staff writer on our Magazine, recommends this piece in Elle: \u201cThe Netflix documentary series \u2018Wild, Wild Country\u2019 is ostensibly a show about a controversial guru and disastrous utopia in 1980s Oregon. But the true star is his personal secretary, Ma Anand Sheela: driven, hilarious, dangerous. This essay by the writer Tana\u00efs dissects the strange satisfaction of seeing her rage unfurl onscreen.\u201d\n\nBack Story\n\nNatural wonder, honeymoon site and tourist attraction in two countries.\n\nBy the time Niagara Falls was established as a New York State park on this day in 1885, it was already popular.\n\nPhoto\n\nA French priest is credited with telling the world about the waterfalls in the late 1600s.\n\nThe region later became a place of escape for slaves fleeing the American South. (The Niagara Falls Underground Railroad Heritage Center opens this weekend.)\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn the 1800s, tourists and honeymooners began to come in large numbers, with an 1851 report of up to 100,000 seasonal visitors.\n\nDaredevils helped make it popular. People walked on cables across it and went over the edge in barrels \u2014 including Anna Edson Taylor, the first recorded person to go over the falls and survive. Eventually such stunts were banned as too perilous.\n\nJust how dangerous Niagara can be is evident in this 1954 video showing the collapse of a section of American Falls.\n\nBut despite an increase in kitschy attractions, perhaps not much has changed since a traveler in 1889 wrote: \u201cOne might, I imagine, spend two months here and not grow tired of the ever-varying beauty; but he would get tired of the ever-monotonous crowd.\u201d\n\nSarah Anderson wrote today\u2019s Back Story.\n\n_____\n\nYour Morning Briefing is published weekdays and updated all morning. Browse past briefings here.\n\nSign up here to get it by email in the Australian, Asian, European or American morning. To receive an Evening Briefing on U.S. weeknights, sign up here.\n\nCheck out our full range of free newsletters here.\n\nWhat would you like to see here? Contact us at briefing@nytimes.com.", "title": "North Korea, Sprint, Michelle Wolf: Your Monday Briefing", "authors": ["Chris Stanford"]} {"date": "2018-04-28 00:00:00", "text": "SEOUL, South Korea \u2014 In gushing coverage, North Korea\u2019s main newspaper devoted four of its six pages on Saturday to the summit meeting the day before between Kim Jong-un, the North\u2019s leader, and Moon Jae-in, the South\u2019s. It brightened its usually drab pages with 62 color photographs from the historic event.\n\nIt even printed the leaders\u2019 joint declaration professing a goal of denuclearization on the Korean Peninsula.\n\nBut, like other state-run North Korean news media, the newspaper, Rodong Sinmun, gave no hint to its readers whether Mr. Kim would genuinely consider giving up his nuclear weapons, or what he might demand in return.", "title": "North Korean News Outlets Fawn Over Kim but Offer Few Clues on Nuclear Plan", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-25 00:00:00", "text": "Seoul and Pyongyang have a long history of this. In 1992, there were the Agreement on Reconciliation, Nonaggression and Exchanges and Cooperation between the South and the North and the Joint Declaration of the Denuclearization of the Korean Peninsula. At the historic 2000 summit, there was the South-North Joint Declaration, after which President Kim Dae-jung of South Korea famously declared: \u201cThere is no longer going to be any war. The North will no longer attempt unification by force, and at the same time we will not do any harm to the North.\u201d\n\nAnd in October 2007, there was the so-called \u201cpeace declaration\u201d in the eight-point agreement signed by Kim Jong-il and President Roh Moo-hyun. \u201cThe South and the North both recognize the need to end the current armistice regime and build a permanent peace regime,\u201d it read.\n\nNot to put too fine a point on it: All of these deals were then trash-canned. The North Korean promises in them were worthless, indeed deceitful. These agreements only seemed to hold force until, well, they no longer did, when Pyongyang unilaterally decided to ignore, violate or repudiate them.\n\nThis behavior is wholly of a piece with North Korea\u2019s nuclear discussions with the United States, and with its performance in the Six-Party Talks. In its negotiating playbook, situational ethics rule. Accepting foreign constraints on North Korean power is regarded not only as foolish, but also as positively unpatriotic.\n\nAlas, the South Korean government now seems eager to swallow another order of sucker-bait. Ahead of this week\u2019s planned summit, in return for a peace bridge to nowhere, it has already agreed to leave human rights off the table. (President Trump, for his part, gave his \u201cblessing\u201d to these misbegotten talks.)\n\nWhy, given the precedents? Because the Sunshine Policy is something of a secular religion in South Korea \u2014 at least among its adherents, who include main players in the current government \u2014 and, like all faiths, it is immune to empirical falsification. Sunshiners also seem to be convinced that only they can coax the North onto the path of common sense.\n\nAnd let\u2019s not underestimate the political psychopathology of appeasement: People grow weary of the prospect of endless conflict with an implacable enemy and want to believe in solutions even if there are none. (Western Europe suffered a similar condition regarding the Soviet Union in the 1970s and \u201980s.)\n\nThe problem is that North Korea can walk away from its peace promises at any time. And when it eventually does, it will be able to blame whomever it wishes for this tragic result \u2014 potentially polarizing politics in South Korea, igniting tensions in Seoul\u2019s alliance with Washington or fracturing the loose coalition of governments that rallied around sanctions against it. In the meantime, Pyongyang will hold the other parties hostage to the fear that if any of its new demands aren\u2019t met, it will quit the peace process.", "title": "Opinion | North Korea\u2019s Phony Peace Ploy", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-27 00:00:00", "text": "[What does Kim Jong-un want from his meeting with President Trump? Read our analysis here.]\n\nThe Trump administration has tightened sanctions on North Korea with China\u2019s help and, mindful that the North has failed to deliver on its promises in the past, insisted that Mr. Kim make substantial progress dismantling his nuclear arsenal before the \u201cmaximum pressure\u201d campaign is eased.\n\nBut by agreeing to pursue a peace deal this year, Mr. Moon held out the prospect of progress toward one of North Korea\u2019s top goals before the North has given up its nuclear weapons, and perhaps measures to withdraw troops from inside the Demilitarized Zone, the heavily armed buffer area between the two Koreas, and create a joint fishing zone around the disputed western sea border, a scene of bloody naval skirmishes between the two Koreas.\n\nMr. Moon also dangled an economic incentive, reaffirming promises made in the past by the South of huge investments to help improve the North\u2019s road and train systems. But those agreements collapsed as the North persisted in developing nuclear weapons, and Mr. Moon\u2019s aides have said that such assistance can only come after the North makes progress toward denuclearization and sanctions are lifted.\n\nPhoto\n\nIn Washington, Mr. Trump signaled his support of Mr. Moon\u2019s position, writing early Friday on Twitter: \u201cGood things are happening, but only time will tell!\u201d Fifteen minutes later, he declared in an all-caps tweet, \u201cKOREAN WAR TO END!\u201d and said that all Americans should be \u201cvery proud\u201d of what was taking place on the Korean Peninsula.\n\nDuring an appearance in the Oval Office with Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany on Friday, Mr. Trump said he believed that the North Korean leader was serious about making a deal to give up his nuclear weapons.\n\n\u201cI don\u2019t think he\u2019s playing,\u201d said Mr. Trump, who faulted his predecessors for their handling of the threat from North Korea, saying they had allowed themselves to be duped.\n\n\u201cThe United States has been played beautifully, like a fiddle, because you had a different kind of a leader,\u201d Mr. Trump said. \u201cWe\u2019re not going to be played, O.K.? We\u2019re going to hopefully make a deal; if we don\u2019t, that\u2019s fine.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nOn Twitter, Mr. Trump also thanked President Xi Jinping of China for his \u201cgreat help\u201d in the process.\n\nPhoto\n\nChina\u2019s state news media played the summit meeting prominently, even though China had been left on the sidelines with little influence over the proceedings. The Chinese Foreign Ministry praised the courage of the two Korean leaders, and said it welcomed \u201cthe new journey\u201d for peace on the Korean Peninsula.\n\nThe tone of the summit meeting \u2014 much of which was broadcast live in South Korea but not North Korea \u2014 was convivial and at times jocular, with Mr. Kim showing surprising honesty about the differences in conditions between the two nations.\n\nYoon Young-chan, Mr. Moon\u2019s spokesman, said Mr. Kim acknowledged the poor road conditions in his country, a startling admission for a member of his ruling family, which is considered godlike and faultless among North Koreans. Mr. Kim also revealed that the North Koreans who visited the South during the Winter Olympics in February all admired the bullet train there.\n\nAfter Mr. Moon spoke of wanting to visit North Korea, Mr. Kim said, \u201cIt will be very embarrassing,\u201d alluding to roads there.\n\nMr. Kim also repeated a lighthearted line he had used in his meeting with South Korean envoys who visited Pyongyang, the North Korean capital, last month, apologizing to Mr. Moon for disturbing his sleep with missile tests and forcing him to attend meetings of his National Security Council.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cI heard you had your early-morning sleep disturbed many times because you had to attend the N.S.C. meetings because of us,\u201d Mr. Kim said. \u201cGetting up early in the morning must have become a habit for you. I will make sure that your morning sleep won\u2019t be disturbed.\u201d\n\nMr. Moon joked back: \u201cNow I can sleep in peace.\u201d\n\n[The Korean leaders\u2019 meeting was a carefully choreographed dance, with a surprise step. Read more here.]\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nAn armistice brought about a cease-fire to the Korean War in 1953, but the conflict never officially ended because the parties could not agree to a formal peace treaty. They would have to overcome significant obstacles to do so now, including China\u2019s likely demand that American troops leave South Korea.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn their joint statement, the two Korean leaders said that within a year, they would push for a trilateral conference with the United States, or a four-party forum that also included China, with the aim of \u201cdeclaring an end to the Korean War\u201d and intentions to \u201creplace the armistice with a peace treaty.\u201d\n\nMr. Kim and Mr. Moon also agreed to improve inter-Korean relations by opening a liaison office in the North Korean border town of Kaesong and arranging a reunion later this year of families separated by the war. And they said Mr. Moon would visit Pyongyang in the fall.\n\nVideo\n\nMr. Moon, a progressive leader who says he likes to see South Korea \u201cin the driver\u2019s seat\u201d in pushing the peace effort forward, is trying to broker a successful summit meeting between Mr. Kim and Mr. Trump, which is expected in late May or early June.\n\nMr. Kim rattled the region last year by testing long-range missiles and trading threats of nuclear war with Mr. Trump. But then he abruptly shifted gears, saying he was willing to give up his nuclear weapons for the right incentives and proposing the meeting with Mr. Trump.\n\nLast weekend, Mr. Kim announced an end to all nuclear and long-range-missile tests, saying that his country had mastered how to mount nuclear warheads on missiles and no longer needed to conduct tests. Mr. Kim said North Korea had adopted a \u201cnew strategic line\u201d focusing on economic development.\n\nSkeptics say Mr. Kim is trying to improve ties with South Korea to steer it from the United States and escape sanctions that are increasingly hurting the North\u2019s economy. Indeed, many conservatives in the South fear that the North\u2019s goal remains to be accepted as a nuclear power in return for freezing its nuclear and intercontinental ballistic missile programs.\n\nThe declaration by Mr. Kim and Mr. Moon \u201cis breathtaking in its scope and ambition,\u201d David Albright, president of the Washington-based Institute for Science and International Security, said by email. \u201cBut how to achieve all the goals laid out in the document, given the current situation?\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nUnless \u201ca firm foundation\u201d for North Korea\u2019s verifiable nuclear disarmament were laid out, he added, most of the other commitments in the agreement were \u201cmerely wishes.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAnalysts have warned that once negotiations begin with the United States, North Korea could push them into a stalemate by trying to drag Washington into nuclear arms reduction talks.\n\nTo prevent that, South Korea and the United States are trying to persuade North Korea to agree to a specific timeline for complete denuclearization: as soon as possible and no later than the end of Mr. Trump\u2019s current term, in early 2021, according to South Korean officials and analysts.\n\nDuring their morning talks, Mr. Kim pushed for more summit meetings with Mr. Moon, saying he would like to visit the presidential Blue House in Seoul. He said North Korea would cooperate to make a \u201cbetter world.\u201d\n\nBut he also voiced caution, suggesting South Korea and the United States deserved blame for scuttling previous deals.\n\n\u201cAs the expectations are high, so is the skepticism,\u201d he said. \u201cIn the past, we had reached big agreements, but they were not implemented for more than 10 years. There are people who are skeptical that the results of today\u2019s meeting will be properly implemented.\u201d", "title": "North and South Korea Set Bold Goals: A Final Peace and No Nuclear Arms", "authors": ["Choe Sang-Hun"]} {"date": "2018-04-27 00:00:00", "text": "HONG KONG \u2014 The meeting between North Korea\u2019s leader, Kim Jong-un, and President Moon Jae-in of South Korea offered a rare opportunity to hear Mr. Kim speak spontaneously, without the filter of his nation\u2019s state news media.\n\nWhile much of the discussion between the two leaders was not revealed, South Korean officials did describe some. These are among their comments during Friday\u2019s meeting on the South Korean side of the Demilitarized Zone.\n\n\u201cNow you are here in the South, and I wonder when I can cross over to the North,\u201d Mr. Moon said when Mr. Kim crossed the border and they shook hands. \u201cWhy don\u2019t you now?\u201d Mr. Kim said.\n\nHe took Mr. Moon by the hand and they crossed over a low concrete slab that marks the border. They stood in North Korea, shaking hands for a few seconds, before returning to the South.\n\nMr. Kim found a moment to make light of his country\u2019s missile and nuclear tests, which have caused such deep concern in recent years.\n\n\u201cI heard you had your early-morning sleep disturbed many times because you had to attend the N.S.C. meetings because of us,\u201d Mr. Kim said with a smile, referring to the security council. \u201cGetting up early in the morning must have become a habit for you. I will make sure that your morning sleep won\u2019t be disturbed.\u201d \u201cNow I can sleep in peace,\u201d Mr. Moon replied.\n\nIn one conversation, Mr. Kim made reference to several delicate points in relations between the two sides.\n\n\u201cOn my way here I saw that those who had been nervous about any shelling from the North Korean Army \u2014 including the Yeonpyeong Island residents, North Korean defectors and displaced people \u2014 do have high hopes for our meeting today,\u201d he said.\n\nMr. Kim\u2019s mention of Yeonpyeong Island refers to a 2010 attack from the North that killed two South Korean marines and two civilian construction workers. The \u201cdisplaced people\u201d is a reference to Korean families who were separated during the Korean War.\n\n\u201cI look forward to making the most of this opportunity so that we have the chance to heal the wounds between the North and the South,\u201d Mr. Kim added. \u201cThe demarcation line, which is in fact not high, may disappear with many people stepping on it and passing over it.\u201d\n\nMr. Moon mentioned a recent bus crash in North Korea that killed 32 Chinese tourists and four North Korean workers.", "title": "North and South Korean Leaders\u2019 Own Words in Meeting at the DMZ", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-16 00:00:00", "text": "DeGrom has remained gangly. He proudly topped off at 190 pounds recently. His off-season strength workouts were more straightforward than the hours in the gym players like Syndergaard often spend, and they were carried out among many people older than deGrom at a rehabilitation center in his hometown, DeLand, Fla.\n\n\u201cHe\u2019s an elastic, tall and lanky person, so he doesn\u2019t need to hit the gym and get so strong,\u201d Syndergaard said.\n\nAnd in terms of a diet, well, deGrom\u2019s teammates might best explain his approach to nutrition.\n\n\u201cI\u2019d be 260 pounds if I ate what he eats,\u201d said Jay Bruce, the Mets\u2019 right fielder.\n\n\u201cHe can go to McDonald\u2019s,\u201d added Travis d\u2019Arnaud, the Mets\u2019 injured catcher, \u201cget two Big Macs and fries, and stay the same or probably even lose weight.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nAlthough most pitchers rest their arms during much of the off-season, deGrom plays catch nearly year-round with his father in his childhood backyard. Teammates joke that deGrom could roll out of bed and pitch, while others need hours to prepare their bodies. The day after starts, deGrom\u2019s arm is sprightly enough to fling a football 50 yards.\n\n\u201cIf I tried to do that, my arm would go flying with the football,\u201d pitcher Zack Wheeler said, adding with a laugh, \u201cHe recovers well and his body treats him right, even though he probably doesn\u2019t treat it right.\u201d\n\nDeGrom does care for his body; he is a professional baseball player, after all, making $7.4 million this season. He just does it a bit differently from many of his teammates. Nonetheless, it has worked.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nFrom the start of 2014, the season in which he won the National League Rookie of the Year Award, to the start of this season, deGrom\u2019s 2.98 earned run average ranked ninth \u2014 better than standouts such as Jon Lester of the Chicago Cubs, Stephen Strasburg of the Washington Nationals and Dallas Keuchel of the Houston Astros. He is lauded for his pitching smarts, too, not just throwing hard, and is 2-0 with a 3.06 E.R.A. to start this season.\n\n\u201cJake\u2019s got a routine that is probably different than 99.9 percent of the guys in here,\u201d the Mets\u2019 captain, David Wright, said. \u201cHe gets his work in and prepares, but there are just a few things about him that are offbeat.\u201d\n\nDeGrom was always thin but not tall. As a high school freshman he was 5-foot-2, but he hit a growth spurt at Stetson University, where he was a shortstop with a weak bat. He converted to pitcher before the Mets selected him in the ninth round of the 2010 draft. After struggling to add weight in the past \u2014 pitchers often seek more mass to help throw \u2014 he gave up. For the past several years, deGrom weighed 183 pounds.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nHis metabolism has apparently been impervious to all the chicken fingers, fries and fast food he loves, particularly Chick-fil-A and McDonald\u2019s, where he typically orders a Big Mac meal with large fries, a large Mountain Dew and two double cheeseburgers.\n\n\u201cI\u2019ll eat whatever,\u201d he said. \u201cI eat like a child.\u201d\n\nDeGrom said he had been \u201cvery fortunate\u201d his diet hadn\u2019t turned him into David Wells or affected his performance.\n\n\u201cIf it became a thing, I\u2019d have to cut it back,\u201d he said. \u201cI talk to people and they\u2019re like, \u2018Oh, if I eat that, I\u2019ll feel like crap.\u2019 I\u2019ve never eaten McDonald\u2019s and the next day felt terrible.\u201d\n\nThe Mets have put an emphasis on health and nutrition after a spate of high-profile injuries undermined last season, but deGrom shows little sign of changing his regimen, which does allow for more sensible choices. Asked if he ate fruits and vegetables, deGrom insisted he did. In the off-season, he said, he and his wife, Stacey, cook steaks or chicken.\n\nPhoto\n\nBut during the season, many of deGrom\u2019s meals come from the clubhouse dining room, and even then he doesn\u2019t always choose the healthiest option.\n\n\u201cI\u2019m not against eating good foods,\u201d he said, grinning. \u201cI just like to enjoy some McDonald\u2019s every once in a while.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn the off-season, deGrom worked out at CORA Physical Therapy in his hometown, which, he said, is frequented by older adults and where he underwent rehabilitation from Tommy John and ulnar nerve surgeries. Unlike Syndergaard, who has private trainers, deGrom followed whatever workouts Dustin Clarke, the Mets\u2019 strength and conditioning coach, sent him. He compared his body type to that of Chris Sale, the Boston Red Sox\u2019 hard-throwing ace whose fatty diet belies his 6-foot-6, 180-pound frame.\n\n\u201cWe\u2019re more about leverage, and being long and lanky,\u201d deGrom said, adding, \u201cIf we were in the weight room like Noah, we\u2019d probably be hurt.\u201d\n\nWhat also sets deGrom apart is how much he values running sprints and year-round throwing. He noticed that Max Scherzer and Clayton Kershaw, two multiple winners of the Cy Young Award, ran hard sprints in between starts, so he does the same.\n\nIn this era of conserving the finite life of the pitching arm, deGrom swears by constant throwing. Over the winter, he fired around 40 throws with his father from shorter distances three times a week.\n\n\u201cWhen I came into spring, my arm felt great because I kept it moving,\u201d he said. Any other approach feels illogical to him. \u201cYou work out and build this muscle, but it\u2019s not used to throwing? You throw that much throughout the year and then you want to stop for two months?\u201d\n\nDeGrom\u2019s approach has worked in the sense that he was the only Mets starter to stay healthy in 2017 and he finished with his first 200-inning campaign. Between starts during the season, he threw two abbreviated bullpen sessions, instead of one longer one, to keep his mechanics sharp. In future off-seasons, deGrom said, he might not rest his arm at all.\n\nThere is now also yet another key difference with Syndergaard.\n\nOver the winter, deGrom chopped off his trademark long locks. Fans may have thought he cared a lot about his hair, but when he decided to get rid of it, he asked Wright to trim it in the clubhouse bathroom. Just like that, it was gone. Teammates were not surprised.\n\n\u201cIt used to be legs, limbs and hair coming at you, but now it\u2019s legs and limbs,\u201d d\u2019Arnaud said.", "title": "Not Necessarily Thor: One Mets Ace Is Not Like the Other", "authors": ["James Wagner"]} {"date": "2018-04-17 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nRe \u201cHomeless in Seattle, and Wed Beneath an Overpass\u201d (Vows column, Sunday Styles, April 15):\n\nAs I flipped through my Sunday print edition, I was shocked to see the Vows column profiling a Seattle homeless couple, Michelle Vestal and Bob J Kitcheon.\n\nThis unexpected feature, far from the typical profile of vows between the elite and privileged few, humanizes our often-forgotten brothers and sisters who live under less fortunate circumstances. This is exactly what our society needs.\n\nBy showcasing a ceremony that is universal in its symbol of joy and celebration, you remind the reader that homeless folks are just like us: They\u2019re real humans with a desire not to be alone. Indeed, at the end of the day we are all on the same journey together.\n\nAARON SHEPHERD, SEATTLE", "title": "Opinion | Not Your Typical Vows", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-02 00:00:00", "text": "Rivaling a doctor who delivers babies for long and unpredictable work hours is difficult, but not for Mr. Redd. In addition to running Assai Management Consulting, a company he started in 2013 after leaving his job as director of the project management office at the Port Authority, he is a professional opera singer, currently preparing to play the lead baritone in Puccini\u2019s \u201cTurandot\u201d at New Jersey\u2019s Bergen Performing Arts Center. In his spare time, he is preparing for his second Ironman triathlon.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Of the Moment The lifestyle newsletter from the Styles, Travel and Food sections, offering the latest trends to news you can use. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe couple\u2019s joint refusal to hit the brakes on their careers or their hobbies \u2014 Dr. Cummings finds a few hours each week to dance Masala Bhangra with the Alvin Ailey Extension program, and has performed with the company \u2014 has been by design.\n\n\u201cFred is happiest when everything\u2019s going 80 miles per hour,\u201d Dr. Cummings said. \u201cAnd if I were doing just one thing instead of several, I would lose interest.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Redd said productiveness accounts at least partly for their compatibility. \u201cI think we\u2019re stretching ourselves in terms of what we do with our lives because it\u2019s who we are, and because it provides an example for our daughter,\u201d he said. \u201cThat\u2019s what life is all about, constantly growing and challenging yourself.\u201d\n\nSome challenges Dr. Cummings and Mr. Redd have confronted since their wedding have not been of their own choosing. When Autumn was born in June 2008, Dr. Cummings spent more than a month in the hospital.\n\n\u201cI had an infection related to the delivery that got me very ill,\u201d she said. \u201cIt was a tough year, and you never expect something like that early on in your marriage. We had kind of a bumpy start.\u201d Those bumps put an end to what she had long envisioned as a two-child household. \u201cAfter that, we said, \u2018Let\u2019s be thankful for what we\u2019ve got.\u2019\u201d\n\nMr. Redd\u2019s 2011 diabetes diagnosis also came as a surprise, though it prompted him to lose 55 pounds and set him on his course to becoming an Ironman competitor. Which was another adjustment for the family.\n\n\u201cAnytime anyone you love tells you, \u2018O.K., I\u2019m going to go exercise for 14 hours, you\u2019ve got to be a little wary,\u2019\u201d Dr. Cummings said. But Dr. Cummings and Autumn were there to watch Mr. Redd cross the Ironman finish line last year in Cozumel, Mexico, coming in 35th place in his age group.\n\nMr. Redd\u2019s strict diet and exercise regimen has allowed him to quit taking diabetes medications. The family\u2019s health issues haven\u2019t ended there, though.\n\nPhoto\n\nWhen Autumn was born and Dr. Cummings was still in the hospital, Mr. Redd\u2019s mother, Hilda Redd, of Friendswood, Tex., spent months in New York. \u201cBoth grandmas helped us out a lot,\u201d Dr. Cummings said. But both grandmothers have since fallen ill, and Dr. Cummings and Mr. Redd are the primary caretakers in their families (their fathers \u2014 Mr. Redd\u2019s in Texas and Dr. Cummings\u2019s in Colorado \u2014 are healthy).\n\nMr. Redd travels to Texas to help his mother as frequently as possible. And Lynne Barry Cummings has been living with the couple since Superstorm Sandy displaced her from her home in Montauk, N.Y. Ms. Cummings was at first able to help with child care, picking up Autumn from school and babysitting so the couple could plan date nights. Last year she had a health setback.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cI have to give my husband very big props for living with his mother-in-law since 2013,\u201d Dr. Cummings said.\n\nOn the other hand, both Dr. Cummings and Mr. Redd give Ms. Cummings props for indirectly bringing them together. Ms. Cummings is a former opera singer; Dr. Cummings\u2019s familiarity with the music drew her to Mr. Redd. One of their first dates, in 2005, was when Mr. Redd, a baritone, was playing the lead in Verdi\u2019s \u201cGiovanni D\u2019Arco\u201d at Carnegie Hall.\n\n\u201cI\u2019m what I call a professional music fan,\u201d Dr. Cummings said. \u201cThat was part of the connection for me.\u201d\n\nPart of the connection for Mr. Redd is his wife\u2019s scientific side. He is a trained engineer; Assai specializes in consulting transportation, technology, energy and construction businesses. \u201cI\u2019m proud of Allegra for being a doctor, but also for her varied interests, and that she\u2019s so much bigger than her job,\u201d he said.\n\nStill, both recognize the importance of their jobs, and neither begrudges the other for taking work seriously. When Dr. Cummings was called to the operating room during the recent conference call, Mr. Redd hurried her off the phone, offering to finish answering questions for both of them.\n\n\u201cI\u2019ll call you later, Fred,\u201d Dr. Cummings said, as the hospital P.A. system paged her in the background. \u201cI love you.\u201d", "title": "Not the Same Old Song and Dance: Ironman, Opera and Obstetrics", "authors": ["Tammy La Gorce"]} {"date": "2018-04-20 00:00:00", "text": "This week\u2019s issue features an essay adapted from Jesmyn Ward\u2019s introduction to a new edition of F. Scott Fitzgerald\u2019s \u201cThe Great Gatsby.\u201d In 1925, Edwin Clark reviewed the novel for the Book Review. Below is an excerpt.\n\nOf the many new writers that sprang into notice with the advent of the post-war period, Scott Fitzgerald has remained the steadiest performer and the most entertaining. Now he has said farewell to his flappers and is writing of the older sisters that have married. To use a phrase of Burton Rascoe\u2019s \u2014 his hurt romantics are still seeking that other side of paradise. And it might almost be said that \u201cThe Great Gatsby\u201d is the last stage of illusion in this absurd chase.\n\nThe story of Jay Gatsby of West Egg is told by Nick Carraway, who is one of the legion from the Middle West who have moved on to New York and finds in Long Island a fascinating but dangerous playground. Gatsby\u2019s fortune, business, even his connection with underworld figures, remain vague generalizations. Of his uncompromising love \u2014 his love for Daisy Buchanan \u2014 his effort to recapture the past romance \u2014 we are explicitly informed. This patient romantic hopefulness against existing conditions symbolizes Gatsby.\n\nNick Carraway had known Tom Buchanan at New Haven. Daisy, his wife, was a distant cousin. The post-war reactions were at their height \u2014 everyone was restless. Buchanan had acquired another woman. Daisy was bored, broken in spirit and neglected. Gatsby, his parties and his mysterious wealth were the gossip of the hour. At the Buchanans Nick met Jordan Baker; through them both Daisy again meets Gatsby, to whom she had been engaged before she married Buchanan. The inevitable consequence that follows is almost incidental, for in the overtones the decay of souls is more tragic. With keen psychological observation, Fitzgerald discloses in these people a meanness of spirit and absence of loyalties. He cannot hate them, for they are dumb in their selfishness, and only to be pitied. A curious book, a mystical, glamourous story of today.", "title": "Notes From the Book Review Archives", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-06 00:00:00", "text": "Lena Dunham reviews Meg Wolitzer\u2019s \u201cThe Female Persuasion\u201d for this week\u2019s cover. Five years ago, Liesl Schillinger reviewed \u201cThe Interestings\u201d and considered Wolitzer\u2019s place in American fiction. Below is an excerpt.\n\nH. L. Mencken once wrote that his definition of happiness included \u201ca comfortable feeling of superiority to the masses of one\u2019s fellow men.\u201d And yet his quest to be exceptional didn\u2019t appear to make him all that happy. But does the compulsion to excel make anybody happy?\n\nThat\u2019s the question that preoccupies Jules Jacobson, the ambitious protagonist of Meg Wolitzer\u2019s remarkable novel, \u201cThe Interestings,\u201d whose inclusive vision and generous sweep place it among the ranks of books like Jonathan Franzen\u2019s \u201cFreedom\u201d and Jeffrey Eugenides\u2019s \u201cMarriage Plot.\u201d \u201cThe Interestings\u201d is warm, all-American and acutely perceptive about the feelings and motivations of its characters, male and female, young and old, gay and straight; but it\u2019s also stealthily and undeniably a novel of ideas. Wolitzer has been writing excellent fiction for 30 years, and it has always been this astute. From the start, her subject has been the practical, emotional and sexual fallout of women\u2019s liberation, particularly as it affects mothers and children. But here she has written a novel that speaks as directly to men as to women.\n\nIn \u201cThe Interestings,\u201d Jules Jacobson poses a broad question, asking herself what the boys (now men) and girls (now women) she has lionized since her teens, and emulated throughout her adult life, have lost through their persistent, rarely rewarded efforts to opt in. She wonders if all of them have inaccurately defined success, believing they would only matter if they were extraordinary.", "title": "Notes From the Book Review Archives", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-27 00:00:00", "text": "Yu-Yun Hsieh reviews Robert Coover\u2019s selected short fictions, \u201cGoing for a Beer,\u201d in this week\u2019s issue. In a 1966 review of Coover\u2019s first novel, \u201cThe Origin of the Brunists,\u201d Webster Schott praised the young author\u2019s talent and forecast his success.\n\nRobert Coover writes his first novel as if he doesn\u2019t expect to make it to a second. Everything goes into it, including plots for several grim short stories and more social novels, and notes for a juicy essay on how West Condon ministers and their wives celebrate the Feast of the Resurrection. It begins as an account of the founding of a crackpot religious sect named for an Italian-American coal miner who miraculously survives a mine disaster that kills 98 others. En route to the final formalization of the Brunists \u2014 election of bishops and cutting up the territory \u2014 Mr. Coover takes apart the economy, power structure, social order and sexual codes of a small town berserk with holiness. Burning with ambition, \u201cThe Origin of the Brunists\u201d achieves much that this young teacher at Bard College hopes for. It is a novel of intensity and conviction \u2014 even though he forgets which of his many stories he most wants to tell and cries uncle in the clutch. If he can somehow control his Hollywood giganticism and focus his vision of life, he may become heir to Dreiser or Lewis.\n\nThe strength of this novel derives from the old tradition. It brings us the news about mining, petty journalism, small-town nonculture and the weird fusion of truth and wish that sometimes underpins religious belief. It\u2019s impregnated with stories. It creates characters. But it offers no new or terrifying revelations. The reason: Mr. Coover himself is unable to decide whether the Brunists are tragic or comic figures, whether West Condon is a joke or a condition.\n\nIt\u2019s a pity Mr. Coover ran out of ideas before words. He has a splendid talent. There\u2019s no joy in seeing it too lie spent.", "title": "Notes From the Book Review Archives", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-13 00:00:00", "text": "Barbara Kingsolver\u2019s review of Richard Powers\u2019s latest novel, \u201cThe Overstory,\u201d graces this week\u2019s cover. In a 1998 review of \u201cGain,\u201d Bruce Bawer marveled at Powers\u2019s prescient commentary on American life. Read an excerpt below:\n\n\u201cThree Farmers on Their Way to a Dance,\u201d which appeared when Powers had not yet turned 30, was nothing less than enthralling in its ambition and promise. Since then he has continued to explore some of the darker ironies, absurdities and tragedies of life in the American century. Dense, challenging, aphoristic and swarming with recondite allusions and puns, these novels display an authoritative grasp of a breathtaking range of subjects. But while Powers never seems out to impress or obfuscate, his conspicuous intelligence and virtuosity have also won him a reputation as difficult, even inaccessible.\n\nHis sixth novel, \u201cGain,\u201d seems designed to change all that. Like his earlier books, it is erudite, penetrating and splendidly written; alongside them, though, it seems positively straightforward. Powers cuts back and forth between two narratives. One relates the history of a small family soap-and-candle business, Jephthah Clare & Sons of Boston, which over the course of the 19th and 20th centuries grows into a giant worldwide conglomerate. The other story, set in the present day, concerns Laura Bodey, a divorced 42-year-old real estate saleswoman.\n\nNeither of the novel\u2019s parallel narratives contains so much as a single surprising plot development. Yet the book holds one\u2019s interest anyway, mainly because Powers makes a compelling tale out of the evolution of American business practices over nearly two centuries. Powers\u2019s account of how Clare\u2019s management acquires a concept of the corporate image and then consciously strives to establish the corporation as \u201ca person\u201d not only \u201cin the eyes of the law\u201d but \u201cin the minds of its customers\u201d is perceptive and valuable.\n\nPowers so powerfully communicates his sense of the corporate world\u2019s tyranny over the 20th-century American soul that one may almost forget the century\u2019s far more monstrous tyrannies \u2014 which were, of course, vanquished through the efforts and example of the capitalist democracies. Yet if one may reasonably dispute the novel\u2019s implicit politics, there is no gainsaying the remarkable artistry and authority with which Powers, in this dazzling book, continues to impart his singular vision of our life and times.", "title": "Notes From the Book Review Archives", "authors": []}
